{"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Once or twice a week, on his lunch break, Eric Dobesh walks half a city block for a nap in a single-occupancy pod. Behind a thick black curtain, Mr. Dobesh dims the twinkling \u201cstars\u201d on the pod\u2019s black ceiling and sleeps until a restaurant pager buzzes to signify the session\u2019s end.\n\nOn the walk back to work, he picks up a salad. He eats lunch at his desk.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t drink coffee, so I basically get by on willpower, food and naps,\u201d said Mr. Dobesh, 26, who lives in Sunnyside, Queens. Over the past few weeks, he has been regularly dozing off at Nap York, a month-old business in Midtown Manhattan that calls itself a \u201cwellness club.\u201d\n\nNap York and comparable venues, where people pay to rest or sleep, are expressions of a \u201cculture shift\u201d \u2014 evidence of people recognizing \u201cthat this is a much more efficient way to recharge than having a Red Bull or, you know, a double espresso in the afternoon, or three cinnamon buns to get the sugar rush,\u201d said Arianna Huffington, founder of the wellness site Thrive Global and HuffPost.\n\nAt Thrive Global\u2019s headquarters in SoHo, there is a nap room for employees. Ms. Huffington predicts that \u201crecharging rooms\u201d will be \u201cas common as board rooms\u201d within the next few years because society is recognizing the importance of getting good sleep.", "title": "Napping in a New York Minute", "authors": ["Arielle Dollinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 There\u2019s a mechanized tyrannosaur biting a hole in the roof of my mother\u2019s last house. It moves hesitantly, lifting its heavy head and widening its serrated jaws before clamping down, then nosing around a little bit, finding purchase between bites, backing up and moving forward to accommodate its long reach, its powerful orange neck swinging right and left to bump walls that stubbornly refuse to fall. I stand at the edge of the yard and watch my mother\u2019s house reduced to rubble.\n\nIt stood directly across the street from mine \u2014 I could see it from the window of my home office \u2014 but I almost missed the demolition. Between the nail guns of the framing crew five doors down and the blaring radio of the masonry crew on the other side of the street, more than half the house was gone before I even noticed. You would think the noise of a whole house falling into dust would make an instant impression, but I have lived with so much construction noise, and for so many years, I\u2019ve gotten good at tuning it out.\n\nThere\u2019s a kind of heartbreak that comes of watching whole swaths of houses scraped from a neighborhood, but this particular heartbreak is in no way tied to issues of historic preservation. The original houses were small brick rectangles, less lovely than a double-wide mobile home. Built after World War II for working-class servicemen buying on the G.I. Bill, each house followed one of two simple floor plans, with small variations \u2014 a covered stoop on some, a gable on others \u2014 to make them distinguishable from one another.\n\nWhen my husband and I moved here in 1995, we had a small son and a baby on the way. Back then, there were only a handful of young families on this block. Most of the houses were occupied by the original postwar owners aging in place or by couples buying starter homes. As families grew, they mostly moved away, and a new young couple would take their place.", "title": "Opinion | Nashville Demolition Blues", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s also a unique way for us to pay attention to the history of this city and what happened here more than 150 years ago,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Briley noted that the plans to build a park honoring slaves were started under the previous mayor, Megan Barry, who resigned on March 6 after pleading guilty to a felony theft charge related to her affair with a police officer in charge of her security detail.\n\nWhile the major redevelopment plans were derailed after the archaeological study, the mayor\u2019s announcement still stunned those who had advocated preservation of the land. Betsy Phillips, a Nashville historian who wrote articles about the Fort Negley debate for The Nashville Scene, said she was sort of in shock after the announcement.\n\n\u201cI already felt lucky that we got the development stopped,\u201d Ms. Phillips said in an interview. \u201cBut we thought we already had all the good news to be had.\u201d\n\nMs. Phillips said the proposal would allow Nashville to protect the historical site and what is buried there as well as to call attention to the city\u2019s importance in the Civil War. The site of the Battle of Nashville in 1864, which delivered a crushing blow to the Confederacy and signaled an end to the war, was not preserved and is now a residential and commercial complex.\n\n\u201cNashville and Civil War history is really important, and to not have a place where tourists or history buffs could go and see something would just have been a shame,\u201d Ms. Phillips said. \u201cWe had lost this part of Nashville\u2019s history.\u201d", "title": "Nashville Mayor Proposes City Park to Atone for Its Slave History", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Natalie Sarah Feldman and Benjamin Meyers Zagorsky were married March 1 at the Ritz Carlton in Half Moon Bay, Calif. Rabbi D\u2019ror Chankin-Gould officiated.\n\nThe bride and groom, both 27, met at Harvard, from which each graduated, the bride cum laude, and the groom cum laude with a joint bachelor-master's degree in computer science.\n\nMs. Feldman is in her final year of medical school at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine in Chicago.\n\nShe is a daughter of Robin C. Feldman and Boris Feldman, both of Palo Alto, Calif. The bride's father is a partner at the law firm Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich and Rosati in Palo Alto, Calif. Her mother is a law professor at the University of California, Hastings College of the Law in San Francisco. She is also the director of the UC Hastings Institute for Innovation Law.", "title": "Natalie Feldman, Benjamin Zagorsky", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt tells people that you\u2019re thinking about these things, you care about these things, and you want to do a better job,\u201d she said.\n\nThe magazine was far from alone in racist coverage at the time, Mr. Mason said, but it was considered a leader in photography. Its effort to directly confront its past was largely well-received. At least two web-based publications, Splinter and The Root, described the decision as a welcome \u201cfirst step.\u201d\n\nDeborah Willis, the chairwoman of the Department of Photography and Imaging at New York University, said she grew up reading National Geographic, but had long noticed the failure to capture the voices of black subjects. She never heard how they felt about being photographed or the story behind their jewelry; instead, you heard the \u201cvoice of the institution,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cI wanted to become a photographer because of National Geographic,\u201d she said. \u201cI wanted to tell a different story.\u201d\n\nModern news organizations still lag in minority representation on photography staffs, said Brent Lewis, a senior photo editor at ESPN\u2019s The Undefeated. Mr. Lewis praised National Geographic\u2019s overall effort, but said he was disappointed that the cover \u2014 the most recognizable image for an issue dedicated to race \u2014 was shot by a white man, Robin Hammond.\n\nMs. Goldberg said the main feature story featured nine photographers, five of whom were people of color. Of the eight writers, four were people of color.\n\n\u201cWe cover a diverse world,\u201d she said. \u201cIf we want to do so accurately and with authority, we need a diverse staff to cover it.\u201d\n\nThe magazine\u2019s self-reflection was among the most direct admissions of past sins from media organizations, which have occasionally wrestled with their complicity in injustices.", "title": "National Geographic Acknowledges Its Racist Past Coverage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Out of Class and Into the Streets\n\nIn some places, demonstrators chanted and held signs. At other schools, students stood in silence. In Atlanta, some students took a knee.\n\nThousands of New York City students converged on central locations \u2014 Columbus Circle, Battery Park, Brooklyn Borough Hall, Lincoln Center.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, stretched out on the sidewalk as part of a \u201cdie-in\u201d with students in Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the former home of the Occupy Wall Street protests.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHundreds sat in the middle of West 62nd Street for several minutes before rising to their feet and shouting, \u201cNo more violence.\u201d A cry of \u201cTrump Tower!\u201d sent dozens of protesters marching toward the Trump International Hotel and Tower across Broadway. Onlookers gave them fist-bumps.\n\nIn Washington, thousands left their classrooms in the city and its suburbs and marched to the Capitol steps, their high-pitched voices battling against the stiff wind: \u201cHey-hey, ho-ho, the N.R.A. has got to go!\u201d One sign said: \u201cFix This, Before I Text My Mom from Under A Desk.\u201d\n\nMembers of Congress, overwhelmingly Democratic, emerged from the Capitol to meet them. Trailed by aides and cameras, some legislators high-fived the children in the front rows, others took selfies, and nearly all soon learned that the young protesters had no idea who they were.\n\nExcept, of course, for \u201cBERNIE SANDERS!\u201d which the protesters screamed at the Vermont senator, as well at some other white-haired, bespectacled legislators.\n\nPhoto\n\nAsked by reporters about the walkouts, Raj Shah, Mr. Trump\u2019s deputy press secretary, said the president \u201cshares the students\u2019 concerns about school safety\u201d and cited his support for mental health and background check improvements.\n\nAs the hours passed, the walkouts moved west across the country.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s 10 o\u2019clock,\u201d said a man on the intercom at Perspectives Charter Schools on Chicago\u2019s South Side. With that, hundreds of students streamed out of their classrooms and into the neighborhood, marching past modest brick homes, a Walgreens and multiple churches.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeveral current and former Perspectives students have been killed in recent years, the school president said.\n\n\u201cYou see different types of violence going on,\u201d said Armaria Broyles, a junior who helped lead the walkout and whose older brother was killed in a shooting. \u201cWe all want a good community and we all want to make a change.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Santa Monica High School in Southern California, teachers guided hundreds of students to the football field. It felt like a cross between a political rally and pep rally, with dozens of students wearing orange T-shirts, the color of the gun control movement, and #neveragain scrawled onto their arms in black eyeliner.\n\n\u201cIt is our duty to win,\u201d Roger Gawne, a freshman and one of the protest organizers, yelled to the crowd.\n\nVideo\n\nStaying Silent, for the Opposite Reason\n\nAlthough the walkouts commanded attention on cable television and social media for much of Wednesday, it also was clear that many students did not participate, especially in rural and conservative areas where gun control is not popular.\n\nAt Bartlesville High School in Bartlesville, Okla., where hundreds of students walked out of class last month to protest cuts in state education funding, nothing at all happened at 10 a.m.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t heard a word about it,\u201d the principal, LaDonna Chancellor, said of the gun protest.\n\nIn Iowa, Russell Reiter, superintendent of the Oskaloosa Community School District, suggested that temperatures below 40 degrees may have encouraged students to stay indoors, but he also said that \u201cstudents here are just not interested in what is going on in bigger cities.\u201d\n\nThere was opposition even in liberal Santa Monica. Just after the organizers of the walkout there read the names of the Parkland victims, another student went on stage, grabbed the microphone and shouted \u201cSupport the Second Amendment!\u201d before he was called off by administrators.\n\n\u2018We Need More Than Just 17 Minutes\u2019\n\nSome of the day\u2019s most poignant demonstrations happened at schools whose names are now synonymous with shootings.\n\nWatched by a phalanx of reporters, camera operators and supporters, hundreds of students crowded onto the football field at Stoneman Douglas High shortly after 10 a.m.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA month after the Feb. 14 shooting, notes of condolence, fading flowers and stuffed toys, damp from recent rain, still lay on the grass outside the school and affixed to metal fences.\n\nThe walkout was allowed by the school, but several students said they were warned that they would not be permitted back onto the campus for the day if they left school grounds. Despite the warning, a couple of hundred students marched to a nearby park for another demonstration.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe need more than just 17 minutes,\u201d Nicolle Montgomerie, 17, a junior, said as she walked toward the park.\n\nAn email from the school soon went out telling students they could return.\n\nIn Newtown, Conn., where 26 people were killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, hundreds of students at Newtown High School gathered in a parking lot near the football field. Two hours later, it was Columbine\u2019s turn.", "title": "National School Walkout: Thousands Protest Against Gun Violence Across the U.S.", "authors": ["Vivian Yee", "Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "NDD stands for nature deficit disorder, a phrase coined by the writer Richard Louv in a 2005 book, \u201cLast Child in the Woods.\u201d Ms. Hovnanian first saw the term used on a psychology website called Positive Prescription, and it resonated with her own ideas about humans needing some contact with nature to be healthy, whether that means seeing mountains on the horizon or touching mud.\n\nThe artist\u2019s Immersion Room is an elaborate indoor installation that meticulously recreates a forest at night. You enter with lanterns, one or two at a time through mirrored swinging doors, to walk on leaves and a wood stump path under towering, fragrant fir trees. The sound of crickets and rushing water fills the darkness. A fake campfire flickers under an artificial sky full of stars where there\u2019s a log to sit on or a camping cot for anyone who cares to lie down. All of this is next to the West Side Highway.\n\n\u201cWhen I\u2019m anxious I always go to the park,\u201d said Leila Heller, the gallerist behind Ms. Hovnanian\u2019s multigenre and satirical installations. \u201cBut kids don\u2019t know how to do that these days because they\u2019re on their phones.\u201d That said, the show is drawing crowds.\n\nVisitors are free to sit and linger and many do. They can\u2019t, however, take pictures or text their friends.", "title": "Nature With Chirps, but No Tweets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "If a sparrow sings his heart out on an oil field, but his would-be sw eetheart can\u2019t hear him above the oil pumps, what\u2019s a bird to do?\n\nIn Alberta, Canada, researchers analyzed hundreds of hours of Savannah sparrow love songs and discovered something extraordinary: To be heard above the din, the birds are changing their tune in complex ways that scientists are only starting to understand.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re tailoring their songs depending on which part of their message is the most affected,\u201d said Miyako Warrington, a University of Manitoba biologist who led a recent study on how sparrows cope with noise from the oil and gas infrastructure that dots Canada\u2019s landscape. \u201cThis seems to show a complex level of adaptation. It\u2019s not just everybody talking louder.\u201d\n\nDr. Warrington is one of a growing number of scholars who study the noise generated by human activity \u2014 drills, turbines, roaring jet engines \u2014 and how that affects the natural world around us.", "title": "Near Noisy Oil Fields, Lovesick Birds Change Their Tunes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "It was a May night when Officers Jones and Piagentini, of the 32nd Precinct, were ambushed and shot in the back multiple times as they returned to their car after answering a call near Macombs Dam Bridge. Those killings were followed by the murders in, January 1972, of another pair of on-duty officers, Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie, who were gunned down from behind as they patrolled the Lower East Side.\n\nThe city was on edge, rife with racial tension and awash in conspiracies. Many patrol officers saw themselves as targets in a plot by black residents to kill them. Some New Yorkers who embraced the Black Panther Party\u2019s identity as a political and self-defense group saw the police as an instrument of governmental oppression.\n\nFor a long time, Mr. Bell asserted his innocence and, with his co-defendants, sought a new trial on the basis of uncovered evidence showing the first trial was unfair. Mr. Washington died in prison in April 2000. Mr. Bottom, also known as Jalil Abdul Muntaqim, is at the Sullivan Correctional Facility in Fallsburg, N.Y., officials said.\n\nIn a statement condemning the decision, Commissioner James P. O\u2019Neill recalled how Mr. Bell and his co-conspirators \u201cshot Officer Piagentini 22 times, including with his own service revolver \u2014 as the dying officer pleaded for his own life.\u201d\n\n\u201cOver the past 47 years, he has never expressed genuine remorse,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Neill said.\n\nIn a letter the parole board sent to Mr. Bell this week, however, they credited him with finally taking responsibility \u201cfor your actions\u201d and expressing \u201cregret and remorse for your crimes.\u201d Noting this maturation, the board quoted back to Mr. Bell what he told panelists during their interview of him on March 3: \u201cThere was nothing political about the act, as much as I thought at the time,\u201d Mr. Bell told them. \u201cIt was murder and horribly wrong.\u201d\n\nThe board undertook a deep review of several factors, including Mr. Bell\u2019s age, scant disciplinary history in prison and his success in compiling a \u201csturdy network of supporters,\u201d including the Prisoner Reentry Institute at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. In the end, a majority of panelists found that the state had prepared Mr. Bell well for release. Though his crime \u201crepresents one of the most supreme assaults against society,\u201d Mr. Bell is capable of living a \u201claw-abiding life,\u201d it wrote.", "title": "Nearly 5 Decades Later, Man Who Killed New York Officers Wins Parole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Egypt has previously denied being the intended recipient of the weapons, or breaching international sanctions. In response to questions about the United Nations finding, the State Information Service said this past week: \u201cThe relevant Egyptian authorities have undertaken all the necessary measures in relation to the North Korean ship in full transparency and under the supervision\u201d of United Nations officials.\n\nAfter the Trump administration slashed aid last summer, Egyptian officials said they were cutting military ties to North Korea, reducing the size of its Cairo embassy and monitoring the activities of North Korean diplomats. The relationship with North Korea is \u201climited to representation, and there is almost no existing economic or other areas of cooperation,\u201d Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry said at a news conference with Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson in Cairo last month.\n\nBut that diplomatic representation, in an embassy that doubles as a regional arms dealership, is the problem, American officials have said. In addition, Washington worries that North Korea, a longtime supplier of ballistic missile technology to Egypt, is still supplying missile parts, said Andrea Berger, a North Korea specialist at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBallistic missile customers are the most concerning of North Korea\u2019s partners and deserve the highest attention,\u201d she said. \u201cEgypt is one of those.\u201d\n\nThe Embassy\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s largest embassy in the Middle East, an elegant, three-story Victorian building with a rusty brass plate over the entrance, sits on a leafy street on an island in the Nile. The embassy walls display photos of North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, standing in a garden or strolling through a fish market. Its windows are usually shuttered, and security guards discourage passers-by from taking photos.\n\nLike those of many North Korean outposts, the duties of the Cairo embassy extend well beyond diplomacy.\n\nIn Africa especially, North Korean diplomats have engaged in a wide variety of ruses and schemes to earn hard currency, United Nations investigators say. In South Africa and Mozambique, North Korean diplomats have been implicated in rhino poaching. In Namibia, North Koreans built giant statues and a munitions factory. In Angola, they trained the presidential guard in martial arts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Egypt, their business is weapons. United Nations inspectors and North Korean defectors say the Cairo embassy has become a bustling arms bazaar for covert sales of North Korean missiles and cut-price Soviet-era military hardware across a band of North Africa and the Middle East.\n\nShielded by diplomatic cover and front companies, North Korean officials have traveled to Sudan, which was then subject to an international trade embargo, to sell satellite-guided missiles, according to records obtained by the United Nations. Others flew to Syria, where North Korea has supplied items that could be used in the production of chemical weapons.\n\nInside the embassy, arms dealing goes right to the top. In November 2016, the United States and the United Nations sanctioned the ambassador, Pak Chun-il, describing him as an agent of North Korea\u2019s largest arms company, the Korea Mining Development Trading Corporation.\n\nAt least five other North Korean officials based in Egypt, employed by state security or various arms fronts, have been sanctioned. One of them, Kim Song-chol, traveled to Khartoum in 2013 as part of a $6.8 million deal for the sale of 180 missiles and missile parts to Sudan.\n\nAccording to this year\u2019s sanctions report, Mr. Kim and another sanctioned official based in Cairo, Son Jong-hyok, continue to deal with Sudan\u2019s state-controlled Military Industrial Corporation.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAn arms dealer with a diplomatic passport is still an arms dealer,\u201d Samantha Power, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, told the Security Council in 2016.\n\nThe Ship\n\nFor weeks in the summer of 2016, American intelligence had covertly tracked the Jie Shun, the ship filled with rocket-propelled grenades that has become a focus of Cairo\u2019s ties to North Korea. As it neared the Suez Canal in August, according to a Western diplomat familiar with the case, the Americans warned the Egyptians it might be carrying contraband, effectively forcing them to intervene.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe seizure was the largest interdiction of munitions since sanctions were imposed on North Korea in 2006 \u2014 a significant victory in the international effort, including an arms embargo and export restrictions, to force Kim Jong-un to abandon his nuclear weapons program.\n\nFor the next three months, with the Jie Shun impounded at Ain Sokhna port, a diplomatic tug-of-war played out. The Americans wanted to send officials to inspect the dilapidated freighter and its illicit cargo. North Korea sent a diplomat to negotiate its release.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Egyptians refused both demands, but in November 2016 agreed to allow United Nations inspectors to board the ship. But by then, valuable information about the identity of the customer for the rockets, which had been hidden under mounds of iron ore, was missing. The North Korean crew had been sent home, which meant the inspectors could not interview them.\n\nBut one piece of evidence remained, in the form of a name stenciled on the rocket crates: \u201cAl Sakr Factory for Developed Industries (AOI),\u201d Egypt\u2019s principal missile research and development company and a subsidiary of its sprawling state weapons conglomerate, the Arab Organization for Industrialization.\n\nMohamed Abdulrahman, the chairman of Al Sakr, did not respond to emailed questions about the shipment. In its statement, Egypt\u2019s State Information Service said the measures taken by the country were \u201cpraised\u201d by the United Nations\u2019 sanctions committee, \u201cwhich reiterated that the way Egypt dealt with this case is a model to be followed in similar situations.\u201d\n\nSecret Missile Cooperation\n\nThe Jie Shun shipment was a glaring example of how cash-starved North Korea has helped finance its nuclear program by hawking stocks of cheap, Soviet-era weapons to countries that developed a reliance on those systems during the Cold War, American officials and analysts say.\n\nBut it also pointed to an established smuggling route and an entrenched military-to-military trading relationship that American officials say has long been a conduit for ballistic missile technology.\n\nPhoto\n\nStarting in the 1970s, Cairo and Pyongyang collaborated to extend the range and accuracy of Soviet Scud missiles, said Owen Sirrs, a former agent with the Defense Intelligence Agency. In the late 1990s, American officials worried that Egypt was trying to buy North Korea\u2019s Nodong missile system, which has a range of about 800 miles.\n\n\u201cWe were sending d\u00e9marches to the Egyptians to say, \u2018Knock it off \u2014 we\u2019re sending you hundreds of F-16s, and you don\u2019t need that North Korean crap,\u2019\u201d said Mr. Sirrs, who was based in Cairo at the time and now lectures at the University of Montana.\n\nIt is unclear if Egypt ever acquired the Nodong missiles. Although Cairo has spent billions on high-profile military purchases in recent years, including Russian fighter jets, French aircraft carriers and German submarines, it has been notably cagey about its offensive missile capabilities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2013, a shipment of spare parts for Scud-B missiles, which have a shorter range than the Nodong, was intercepted in transit as it was shipped by air from the North Korean Embassy in Beijing to a military-controlled company in Cairo. The missile components had been labeled parts for fish-processing machinery.\n\nEgypt denied that the military company had ordered the Scud parts.\n\nSuch missiles could strike Israel from deep inside Egyptian territory. They could also reach Ethiopia, with which Egypt has a simmering dispute over a new dam on the Nile.\n\nThe Politics of Sanctions Evasion\n\nThe Trump administration has scored some successes in its drive to isolate North Korea from its allies, notably with the Philippines and Singapore last fall. But Egypt, which receives $1.3 billion annually in American aid, has resisted Mr. Trump\u2019s entreaties.\n\nEgypt\u2019s relationship with North Korea runs deep. President Hosni Mubarak was regularly feted in Pyongyang before his ouster in 2011. An Egyptian tycoon, Naguib Sawiris, built North Korea\u2019s main cellphone network and invested in a bank there. Along with the AK-47 monument on the Suez Canal, North Korea built a large war museum in Cairo that is frequently visited by Egyptian schoolchildren.\n\nEgypt\u2019s military leaders are reluctant to cut those ties and lose access to Soviet-era weapons and ballistic missile systems, analysts say, a posture bolstered by their reflexive distaste for appearing to bow to American pressure. They may feel that, based on past experience, American criticism will eventually abate.\n\n\u201cThey think they can evade the consequences,\u201d said Andrew Miller of the Project on Middle East Democracy, who until last year worked on Egypt at the State Department. \u201cThat they are continuing to stonewall and obfuscate and pursue this course of action indicates they think they can get away with it, and whatever price will be imposed on them will be bearable.\u201d\n\nAt the North Korean Embassy in Cairo, now under a new ambassador, business continues as usual. North Korean state media has said little about the ambassador, Ma Tong-hui, other than to note that his previous post was as head of a little-known government body in Pyongyang called the Disarmament and Peace Institute.", "title": "Need a North Korean Missile? How about power addiction rehab? Harvey Weinstein and his ilk are addicted to power and express it through abusive sexuality as well as aggressive behavior toward employees and others they can dominate.\n\nIt seems clear to me that our society needs to address the abuse of power wherever we see it, and it\u2019s everywhere.\n\nMARY G. FRAN, NEW YORK", "title": "Opinion | Needed: Power Addiction Rehab", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTell the Truth About Afghanistan\u201d (Op-Ed, March 15): Susan E. Rice writes that the war in Afghanistan \u201ccan be resolved only at the negotiating table,\u201d but then states that \u201cpeace talks remain unlikely to succeed.\u201d The only options, she writes, are to provide training and equipment but not military forces, withdraw American forces, which would likely lead to the collapse of the Afghan government, or maintain a permanent military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nPresident Barack Obama said that \u201cthe only way to end this conflict and to achieve a full drawdown of foreign forces from Afghanistan is through a lasting political settlement between the Afghan government and the Taliban.\u201d\n\nIn 2013, the Taliban opened an office in Qatar to facilitate negotiations to end the war. However, the midlevel diplomats from the State Department, who led the negotiation effort, were undercut by Pakistan\u2019s Inter-Services Intelligence agency, while the C.I.A. and the Pentagon were more interested in continuing the war in the belief that the Taliban could be defeated on the battlefield.\n\nThe deal maker Donald Trump should instruct his new secretary of state, as well as the leaders of the C.I.A. and the Pentagon, to make a serious push to negotiate a peace agreement with the Taliban and finally end this 17-year war. The president is always looking to one-up the Obama administration. Here\u2019s his chance.", "title": "Opinion | Negotiate With the Taliban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "If you drive through the Mississippi Delta on a typical, achingly hot summer day, you pass former cotton plantations where thousands of black people were enslaved, and as sites where men and women struggled, and all too often died, during the civil rights movement.\n\nIt is easy to understand why the blues was born here.\n\nWhile the story of the Delta was, and in some ways still is, one of inequality and segregation between white and black people, there was another little noted community in their midst in the 20th century: a community of Chinese-Americans.\n\n\u201cThe Chinese have been in the Delta for more than a hundred years,\u201d said Frieda Quon, a retired librarian who speaks with a southern drawl. \u201cWhen we came initially, we didn\u2019t have rights. We couldn\u2019t go to the white schools, couldn\u2019t even get a haircut, could not go to the hospitals. We were second-class citizens. After the civil rights era, we gained more rights. I think the communities realized, \u2018Hey the Chinese are really making a contribution.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Neither Black Nor White in the Mississippi Delta", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "When Jimmy Kimmel took over the 11:30 p.m. time slot on ABC, she wrote a letter to Anne Sweeney, president of the ABC Television Group at the time, about the need for more women in late night, attaching a copy of her Vanity Fair piece. As she recounts in her book, two days later she received a message from Molly McNearney, the head writer for the show (and now Mr. Kimmel\u2019s wife). Ms. Scovell passed along the names of two writers (Bess Kalb, Joelle Boucai), who were hired.\n\nShe also suggested female writers to Tim Carvell, a longtime friend who was head writer at \u201cThe Daily Show\u201d and became the executive producer of \u201cLast Week Tonight,\u201d the John Oliver program where the original writing staff included two women (Jill Twiss, Juli Weiner) referred by Ms. Scovell. \u201cShe made a project of suggesting women when there was an opening for jobs, and has a great eye for talent,\u201d Mr. Carvell said, describing her as a singular figure in late night. \u201cEvery time someone is staffing up, I tell them to talk to Nell.\u201d\n\nSince her essay was published, the issue of representation has become much more widely discussed, but Ms. Scovell said of the talk of change resulting from #MeToo: \u201cI have a very pessimistic take. I think women are speaking up because we have nothing left to lose.\u201d\n\nShe added that if the David Letterman scandal broke today, she didn\u2019t think it would unfold any differently. When asked if she thought he should have been fired, she paused, considering the question as her cheerful demeanor became slightly more reserved, even wary, before saying she didn\u2019t know. \u201cI want to be very clear,\u201d she added. \u201cI\u2019m not the sex police.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, Ms. Scovell wrote jokes for Mr. Letterman when he performed at the Kennedy Center Honors, and she took the opportunity to ask him about her essay and female writers. He brushed it off, saying he never read the article. Then last month, Mr. Parajuli directed the country\u2019s press council, an independent regulatory body set up by the government, to censor stories published about him.\n\nAccording to the judicial secretariat, Mr. Parajuli\u2019s date of birth is Aug. 5, 1952. Tikaram Bhattarai, a lawyer in Kathmandu, the capital, said that Mr. Parajuli was masking his real date of birth because he was older than 65, the age when a chief justice is required to retire in Nepal.\n\nIn a brief telephone interview, however, Mr. Parajuli, who assumed his position just eight months ago, insisted that his birthday was April 28, 1953, meaning he was still 64 and could remain in office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe letter sent by the judicial council secretariat is illegal,\u201d he said. \u201cI am not going to follow it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. Trump is dealing with the special counsel\u2019s inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 election; Mr. Netanyahu faces allegations by the Israeli police that he committed bribery, fraud and breach of trust in his dealings with wealthy businessmen and newspaper publishers.\n\nMr. Trump, unlike Mr. Netanyahu, has not been personally accused of wrongdoing. But each has labeled the investigation bedeviling him a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d and attempted to discredit those involved.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Mr. Netanyahu, who faced a new round of questioning from detectives on Friday, and who is in far greater political peril than the president, the trip to the United States will provide a welcome respite, said Daniel C. Kurtzer, a career diplomat who was ambassador to Israel under President George W. Bush.\n\nBut the lift from his White House visit, and a speech on Tuesday at the annual policy conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, won\u2019t last long. \u201cHe\u2019ll be smiling in the Oval Office,\u201d Mr. Kurtzer said of Mr. Netanyahu. \u201cThey may announce this rumored invitation to Trump to come cut the ribbon on the embassy in May. He\u2019ll be cheered at Aipac \u2014 but who\u2019s it fooling?\u201d\n\nOn Iran: Seeking U.S. Assistance\n\nIsrael\u2019s determination to stop Iran from entrenching itself or its proxies in Syria has led to escalating clashes, in which Israel has made clear it will take care of matters on its own.\n\nBut Israel\u2019s desire to prevent Iran from establishing an overland supply line through Syria to Hezbollah in Lebanon would require United States forces to interdict Iran\u2019s efforts. Yet American military officials have said that, so far, countering Iran is not part of their mission in Syria.\n\nPhoto\n\nMich\u00e8le Flournoy, a former under secretary for policy at the United States Defense Department, said Mr. Netanyahu needed above all else to get the Trump administration to focus, in talks over ending the Syria war, on Iran\u2019s moves there and the risk of a broader regional conflict embroiling Israel.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. is not quite missing in action in the negotiations, but it\u2019s certainly not carrying a lot of water at this point,\u201d Ms. Flournoy said. \u201cAnd it needs to be carrying a lot of water on this, not just for our own interests but for Israel \u2014 because Israel doesn\u2019t have a seat at the table.\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu is likely to resume his critique of the Iran nuclear deal in his meeting with Mr. Trump, Ms. Flournoy said. But she warned that even Israel\u2019s national security establishment believed the agreement was worth preserving, in hopes of improving or extending it. \u201cThe worry is that Bibi pumps up Trump to walk away from the deal,\u201d she said, using Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s nickname. \u201cI would hope that he would exercise some restraint.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPeace With the Palestinians: Awaiting a Plan\n\nThe Trump administration has said it is nearing the release of its plan for an Israeli-Palestinian peace accord, and all signs point to a proposal that is far more favorable to Israel, and objectionable to the Palestinians, than United States initiatives in the past. The Palestinians, enraged by Mr. Trump\u2019s policy shifts on Jerusalem, have refused to meet with American officials and have rejected any United States role in mediating the conflict.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Netanyahu could be expected to encourage Mr. Trump to move swiftly on the plan, said Dan Shapiro, who was United States ambassador to Israel under President Obama. A plan that benefits Israel at the Palestinians\u2019 expense would only reinforce Mr. Netanyahu politically, underscoring his argument to Israeli voters that he is a peerless master of the Israeli-American relationship.\n\nMr. Netanyahu also may calculate that a one-sided deal from the Trump administration, Mr. Shapiro said, \u201cwill become a new standard American position \u2014 and a starting point for subsequent negotiations, encouraging the Palestinians to accept much a lower set of demands than they\u2019ve historically been willing to.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAmerican Jews: A Rift, And Growing Disenchantment\n\nMr. Netanyahu is likely to bask in a warm embrace at Aipac, but his standing among American Jews may be as polarizing as Mr. Trump\u2019s among American voters.\n\nTo American Jews in the political center and left, and especially Reform and Conservative Jews, Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s right-wing government has complicated their support for Israel, through policy moves like abandoning an agreement for non-Orthodox worshipers to gain access to the Western Wall in Jerusalem, and forcing thousands of African migrants to choose deportation or jail.\n\nSome observers of the two countries\u2019 close ties have even begun asking if the tight embrace between Mr. Trump and Mr. Netanyahu is truly a sign of the alliance\u2019s strength \u2014 or is masking its weakness.\n\n\u201cThe relationship may have peaked,\u201d said Charles Freilich, a former Israeli deputy national security adviser who now teaches at Harvard.\n\nMr. Netanyahu\u2019s aides insist he remains as mindful as ever of the need for a bipartisan approach to the United States, and he is likely to have warm words for Reform and Conservative Jews when he speaks to Aipac\u2019s 18,000 members on Tuesday.\n\nBut Mitchell Barak, an American-Israeli political consultant, said Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s cultivation of liberal American Jews had dwindled to little more than lip service lately \u2014 while rejecting their demands could only hearten his ultra-Orthodox supporters.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s great at telling them how much he values them,\u201d Mr. Barak said of less-religious American Jews, \u201ctill he gets home and votes for closing all stores on Shabbat, or not implementing the wall deal, or saying the ultra-Orthodox don\u2019t have to serve in the army.\u201d", "title": "Netanyahu, Under Fire at Home, Seeks a Warm Embrace in U.S.", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The third state witness, Ari Harow, Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s former chief of staff and once one of his closest confidants, signed a deal with the police seven months ago and was expected to provide incriminating evidence in two other graft cases involving illicit gifts for favors and back-room dealings with a local newspaper magnate in another bid for favorable press coverage.\n\nLast month the police recommended that Mr. Netanyahu be charged with bribery, fraud and breach of trust in both of those cases. Israel\u2019s attorney general, Avichai Mandelblit, has yet to decide whether to issue an indictment, pending a hearing with Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s lawyers, a process that can take months.\n\nMr. Netanyahu arrived in Washington on Sunday for meetings with Mr. Trump on Monday and to address the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israel lobbying group, on Tuesday. Mr. Netanyahu has a close relationship with Mr. Trump, and has benefited at home by Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.\n\nResponding to the news of Mr. Hefetz\u2019s deal with the authorities, a Netanyahu aide said in a statement: \u201cWhen there is something there, you don\u2019t need even one state witness. When you don\u2019t have anything, even a thousand state witnesses won\u2019t help. The incessant race after state witnesses is the best proof that there is nothing \u2014 and there will be nothing.\u201d\n\nIsraeli pundits have been speculating for days on whether Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s worsening legal situation would spur him to call an early election, given polls showing he still has the support of his voters. On Monday, however, they were raising the possibility that damaging testimony from Mr. Hefetz might dissuade him from the idea of rushing to the ballot box.\n\nThe new talk of early elections comes amid rising friction within Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s coalition over an unrelated matter. The looming crisis involves a clash between two parties in the coalition over a proposed law formalizing the exemption of ultra-Orthodox youths from mandatory army service.\n\nAn ultra-Orthodox party insists on its passage before a vote on next year\u2019s budget. The legislation does not appear to have the support of a majority in Knesset, since another party in the coalition opposes it.\n\nMinisters from yet another party in the coalition, the far right Jewish Home, have described the coalition squabbling as a \u201cfake\u201d crisis, indicating that Mr. Netanyahu could resolve it if he wished.", "title": "Netanyahu, Visiting U.S., Is Stalked by Legal Troubles at Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Yet there also hovered over Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s trip the vaguely valedictory sense that this outwardly triumphal visit to the United States\u2019 political and media capitals, places where he has grown accustomed to a conquering hero\u2019s reception, could turn out to be his last as prime minister.\n\nThe Israeli police have recommended bribery charges against him. Former confidants are lining up to testify against him and his wife. A criminal prosecution seems only a matter of when, not if. And the Israeli media is already treating him like an indicted man walking.\n\nThere were the little jokes: Asked if Mr. Trump had given Mr. Netanyahu his bright red tie, the Israeli leader observed, \u201cThat could be investigated too, so I won\u2019t answer.\u201d\n\nThere were the on-record demurrals, and the off-record defensiveness. After a third former aide agreed to testify against him on Monday, Mr. Netanyahu told his traveling press contingent, off the record: \u201cWhen there\u2019s something real, then there\u2019s no need for even a single state\u2019s witness. And when there isn\u2019t, even a thousand won\u2019t help.\u201d\n\nIt was a snappy comeback, and he took it public in a Facebook video two days later. But it also was a reminder that Mr. Netanyahu, once an architecture major at M.I.T. but never a lawyer, has little experience building criminal cases.\n\nPerhaps the clearest indicator of the dual audiences and agendas of this trip were the differences between Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s remarks in English and Hebrew.\n\nAddressing American audiences in English, Mr. Netanyahu beat the drum, steadily and loudly, for confrontation with Iran, over its ambitions in the Middle East and over a nuclear deal that he implored Mr. Trump to \u201cfully fix or fully nix,\u201d lest Tehran acquire weapons with which it could threaten the entire world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn English, he whittled his stance on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict down to a blunt end: \u201cThe Palestinians should have all the powers to govern themselves, except the powers that threaten us,\u201d he told reporters. \u201cDoes that constitute a state or doesn\u2019t it constitute a state? Whatever.\u201d\n\nAnd in English, Mr. Netanyahu trumpeted Israel\u2019s and, by implication, his achievements: Establishing diplomatic relations and reaching trade deals across the globe, saving the lives of other nations\u2019 innocents through peerless intelligence collection, and using drones and computers to fine-tune agricultural irrigation down to the individual plant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSpeaking to the Israeli news media in Hebrew, by contrast, Mr. Netanyahu played the victim and continued his monthslong assault on the credibility and motives of Israeli law enforcement.\n\nIt was just after his Economic Club appearance that he posted the Facebook video, in which he also suggested the police were willing to intimidate witnesses and suborn perjury if it would bring him down.\n\n\u201cThey take them into detention, terrify them and tell them: \u2018Your life is over, your family\u2019s life is over,\u2019\u201d the prime minister complained in the video. \u201c\u2018We\u2019ll take everything from you, including your freedom. You want to get out of this? There\u2019s one way \u2014 smear Netanyahu. It doesn\u2019t matter if you tell the truth \u2014 the main thing is you smear Netanyahu.\u2019\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, at the United Nations for a meeting with Ambassador Nikki Haley, Mr. Netanyahu was asked if he wanted to retract that attack. \u201cI can say one thing: We\u2019re being attacked all the time,\u201d he said in Hebrew. \u201cEvery hour, every minute. The prime minister is also allowed to insist on justice.\u201d\n\nAnd he nodded to the polls. \u201cThe citizens of Israel, in large numbers \u2014 not everyone, but in large numbers \u2014 have given their support to me and my wife,\u201d he said. \u201cThey want justice.\u201d\n\nIndeed, a brewing political dispute back home threatened to provide an excuse for him to call early elections, a turn that could well result in a public vote of confidence and perhaps enough popular wind at his back to withstand calls for him to resign if he is ultimately indicted.\n\nBy the time he wrapped up his visit and headed home, the coalition crisis seemed to be resolving itself, with members of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s government saying the only way elections would be sped up was if the prime minister insisted on it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, the opposition leader, Isaac Herzog of the left-leaning Zionist Union, was floating the idea of a unity government without Mr. Netanyahu as prime minister.\n\nThat proposal seemed far-fetched, or at least premature, but there was poignancy to Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s reception in the United States \u2014 particularly as he prepared to return home to unkind headlines and a drumbeat not his own.\n\nAsked how he thought Israelis were viewing his trip, Mr. Netanyahu expressed optimism that his statesmanship was getting across.\n\n\u201cI think they see the things that I say, they hear the things that I say, they see the reception that I receive,\u201d he said aboard his El Al jet, before leaving Washington on Wednesday. \u201cI think people have a very strong and clear impression of Israel\u2019s position in the world, in the United States \u2014 and my position in the United States, and in the world.\u201d\n\nHe said it in English.", "title": "Netanyahu\u2019s Bilingual U.S. Tour: Triumphal and Defensive", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Netflix has added a warning video that will play before its series \u201c13 Reasons Why\u201d and will promote resources to help young viewers and their parents address the show\u2019s themes, the streaming service announced Wednesday.\n\nAfter being criticized for how the series\u2019 first season depicted suicide, which had already led the network to add warning messages to the show, Netflix commissioned a study by the Northwestern University Center on Media and Human Development to gauge its impact on viewers. The show\u2019s second season will be released this year.\n\nAccording to a statement from Netflix, the study showed that \u201cnearly three-quarters of teen and young adult viewers said the show made them feel more comfortable processing tough topics.\u201d\n\nHowever, the results also showed that Netflix could do more to respond to the concerns of parents, the company said. In a statement, Brian Wright, Netflix\u2019s vice president of original series, said, \u201cResearch indicated the majority of parents felt that while the show brought up important topics, they wanted more resources from us.\u201d", "title": "Netflix Adds a Warning Video to \u201813 Reasons Why\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe ecstatically reviewed Netflix series \u201cOne Day at a Time\u201d has been renewed for a third season.\n\nThe show may seem out of place with the current television landscape in many respects: It\u2019s an earnest multicamera comedy based off Norman Lear\u2019s 1975 sitcom. But it has built a rabid following online and in particular received strong support among Latinos. The show follows three generations of a Cuban-American family, which includes a divorced veteran with PTSD (Justina Machado), her widowed immigrant mother (Rita Moreno) and her lesbian teenage daughter (Isabella Gomez).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get expert TV and movie recommendations from the Watching newsletter The best of what to watch and where to watch it, delivered to your inbox twice a week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe second season arrived on Netflix in January, without an indication of whether it would get renewed again. The silence prompted organizations like the National Hispanic Media Coalition as well as critics at Vulture and The Hollywood Reporter to call for the show\u2019s renewal.\n\nIn her New York Times review, Margaret Lyons wrote that the show \u201cradiates delight\u201d and \u201ccultivates an intimacy and sense of belonging that goes a step further, introducing a level of genuine human happiness into the experience.\u201d\n\n\u201cOne Day at a Time\u201d has also been celebrated for its diversity behind the camera. According to the showrunner Gloria Calderon Kellett, all of the show\u2019s directors were women, people of color, or both.\n\nThe third season\u2019s 13 episodes will arrive sometime in 2019.", "title": "Netflix Renews \u2018One Day at a Time\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "New this week:\n\nFIRED UP! READY TO GO! By Peggy Cooper Cafritz. (Rizzoli, $75.) Cafritz, who founded the Duke Ellington School of the Arts, amassed one of the country\u2019s most important collections of work by artists of color. Among the striking examples here are pieces by Kara Walker, Kehinde Wiley and Carrie Mae Weems. IRIS APFEL By Iris Apfel. (HarperDesign, $35.) It\u2019s hard to resist this self-proclaimed \u201cgeriatric starlet.\u201d With her owlish glasses, loud prints and necklaces upon necklaces, even in her 90s, Apfel is a fashion icon who combines a memoir with photos of the vibrant content of her closets. HOW TO SLAY By Constance C. R. White. (Rizzoli, $55.) White explores the rich history of African-American style and taste, from Josephine Baker and Diana Ross to Rihanna and Lupita Nyong\u2019o. Through text and image, she tells a long story, arguing for the centrality of African-Americans in fashion. DRESS LIKE A WOMAN. (Abrams Image, $24.99.) What do women wear when they go to work, whether firefighter, surgeon, astronaut, soldier or judge? That\u2019s the guiding question of this collection, which includes introductory essays by Roxane Gay and The Times\u2019s fashion critic, Vanessa Friedman. THIS IS M. SASEK By Olga Cerna, Pavel Ryska and Martin Salisbury. (Universe, $29.95.) The eventful life of Miroslav Sasek, the beloved children\u2019s book illustrator who created the \u201cThis Is\u201d series, is explored here through documents, book covers and his own whimsical paintings.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cAfter attending a journalism award ceremony in November named for Nellie Bly, I realized I knew little about Bly, a reporter who became an international sensation in the 1880s, when female journalists typically covered only fashion and society. So I escaped into the past, reading NELLIE BLY, an acclaimed 1994 biography by Brooke Kroeger, and then Bly\u2019s actual stories, filled with stunts and derring-do. Self-trained, Bly was not a master craftswoman: Her writing could flirt both with tedium and turgidity. Some stories seemed more truthy than truthful. But what stories! By the time she turned 26, Bly had gone undercover as a mental patient in New York, exposed corruption in the state capital and traveled the world in 72 days, a great feat at the time. She changed that world in small ways and opened the door for other women to follow. Not bad, for a girl reporter.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Kim Barker, reporter, investigations desk\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNew this week:\n\nTRUTH By Hector Macdonald. (Little, Brown, $28.) Macdonald zeros in on the slipperiness of factuality, offering an array of case studies from the worlds of history, commerce and \u2014 of course \u2014 politics to make his case about how \u201ctruth\u201d is used and misused. SEPARATE AND UNEQUAL By Steven M. Gillon. (Basic, $32.) The riots of the late 1960s, in cities like Detroit and Newark, left America reeling. In response, Lyndon B. Johnson put together the Kerner Commission, which concluded that \u201cour nation is moving toward two societies.\u201d Gillon tells the story of this commission and the debates it sparked. THE LITTLE BOOK OF FEMINIST SAINTS By Julia Pierpont. Illustrated by Manjit Thapp. (Random House, $18.) These page-long tributes, alongside paintings that look as if they belong on the side of votive candles, offer a new set of role models and heroes \u2014 \u201cmatron saints\u201d \u2014 for the feminist future. IBN KHALDUN By Robert Irwin. (Princeton, $29.95.) The 14th-century Islamic legal scholar and theologian Ibn Khaldun is not as well remembered as some of his medieval European contemporaries, but Irwin\u2019s biography makes the case for his presence in a range of fields, from literature to history. THE KREMLIN\u2019S CANDIDATE By Jason Matthews. (Scribner, $26.99.) This is the third installment in the \u201cRed Sparrow\u201d trilogy \u2014 the first of which is now a film starring Jennifer Lawrence. He continues the story here with the tale of a Manchurian candidate, activated by none other than Vladimir Putin. This is, to be clear, a work of fiction.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cI am always looking to go places I have never traveled. And when I opened Eowyn Ivey\u2019s first novel, THE SNOW CHILD, I was completely transported, both narratively and geographically. Set in Alaska in the 1920s amid the homesteaders who eked out a hard living in the short summers to survive the long winters, the story flickers between realism and the possibility of the supernatural. Mabel and Jack have arrived in Alaska on the run from their past and the loss of a stillborn child. The novel revolves around the appearance of a girl who seems to survive on her own in the woods, withstanding the winters, wild animals and loneliness. Their relationship with her, with each other and with the unbelieving neighbors pulls you into a world that for all its strangeness is rendered so realistically \u2014 the washing of dishes, the stacking of firewood, the difficulty of plowing during mud season \u2014 that you trust Ivey\u2019s voice. Much like Halldor Laxness\u2019s \u2018Independent People\u2019 the book conjures a mountainous, wintry place where geography exerts a powerful pull on anyone who dares to try to call it home.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Alissa J. Rubin, Paris bureau chief", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "New this week:\n\nALIENATION AND FREEDOM By Frantz Fanon. (Bloomsbury, $29.95.) Fanon, the influential postcolonial critic, is best known for \u201cThe Wretched of the Earth,\u201d his 1961 book on identity and race. This tome presents his previously unpublished writing \u2014 and gives a more personal portrait of the man himself. STORYNOMICS By Robert McKee and Thomas Gerace. (Twelve, $30.) McKee is the king of screenwriting workshops. Here he partners with an entrepreneur to apply his storytelling knowledge to the worlds of advertising and branding. ATOM LAND By Jon Butterworth. (The Experiment, $19.95.) Take a tour through the subatomic world with a leading physicist at the European Organization for Nuclear Research, or CERN, as he explains the electron ports, boson continents and hadron islands you see along the way. THE LIFE AND OPINIONS OF ZACHARIAS LICHTER By Matei Calinescu. (New York Review Books, paper, $14.95.) Living under Romania\u2019s Communist regime, Calinescu wrote this book for his own amusement, a fictional account of a man who spoke his mind. He never assumed it could be published. When it eventually was, it became a cult classic, now in English for the first time. ONE KISS OR TWO By Andy Scott. (Overlook, $25.95.) It\u2019s the classic traveler\u2019s quandary: How do you say hello? Scott, a former diplomat, looks at the variety of greetings throughout the world and in history \u2014 using the handshake or cheek kiss as entry point to explore subjects like evolution and neuroscience.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cAnticipating the royal wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, I have been reading a biography of Wallis Simpson, the other American divorc\u00e9e to marry into the royal family. Not until I moved to London last fall did I understand how much residual loathing exists for her. In her 2011 biography, THAT WOMAN, Anne Sebba makes a sporting attempt to vindicate Simpson in the eyes of her countrymen. Quoting from Simpson\u2019s letters, Sebba suggests that she tried to squirm out of her relationship with King Edward VIII, whom she viewed with a sort of maternal pity, but he was so infatuated that she could only watch as he hurtled toward his abdication in 1936. The trauma of the abdication did, Sebba argues, challenge Britons to accept a new principle: that members of the royal family had the right to pursue their own personal happiness, even when it meant breaking with tradition. Queen Elizabeth\u2019s family has made good use of that principle: Three of her four children, including the future king, are divorced. Her grandchildren are free to marry whomever they choose.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Ellen Barry, Chief International Correspondent", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "New this week:\n\nHOPE NATION. Edited by Rose Brock. Read by a full cast of contributors, including Angie Thomas, David Levithan and Jason Reynolds. (Listening Library.) A collection of essays and intimate recollections by some of today\u2019s most celebrated young adult authors dedicated to emboldening teenage audiences through the power of optimism. HEART TALK. By Cleo Wade. Read by the author. (Simon & Schuster Audio.) Her inspiring micro-life-lessons have become a hit on Instagram, but the artist, poet and social media phenomenon\u2019s own idiosyncratic voice makes her spiritual and practical wisdom even more forceful. HOW TO AMERICAN: An Immigrant\u2019s Guide to Disappointing Your Parents. By Jimmy O. Yang. Read by the author. (Hachette Audio.) The \u201cSilicon Valley\u201d star blends humor and pathos in his coming-of-age memoir, revealing the intricacies of life as a Chinese immigrant growing up in California, from cultural assimilation to interracial dating. THE ESCAPE ARTIST. By Brad Meltzer. Read by Scott Brick and January LaVoy. (Hachette Audio.) The veteran audiobook narrators bring to life the best-selling author\u2019s latest military thriller, about a soldier who was once presumed dead but is now discovered to be on the run. RAW. By Lamont \u201cU-God\u201d Hawkins. Read by the author. (Macmillan Audio.) A gritty and uplifting account of the author\u2019s path from a single-parent childhood on the rough streets of Brooklyn to becoming a hip-hop legend as a member of the Wu-Tang Clan.\n\n& Noteworthy\n\nIn which we ask colleagues at The Times what they\u2019re reading now.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been drawn to \u2018Game of Thrones\u2019 \u2014 too many grim characters in leather chest plates and furry capes for me. But David Benioff, a showrunner and co-creator of the series, is a masterful storyteller, and I have been absolutely mesmerized by his novel, CITY OF THIEVES. He tells the story of Lev Beniov, a self-conscious 17-year-old Jewish boy during the siege of Leningrad. He survives, even as German bombs rain down on the city, destroying Lev\u2019s apartment building, sending most of his family to the countryside and killing neighbors and friends. The city feels eerily hollowed out and menacing, and nobody has anything to eat. But the story contains moments that are surprisingly human, loving and beautiful, after Lev and an unlikely companion, an utterly charming and overconfident young Cossack named Kolya, set out on an impossible journey, during which they discuss love, poetry, hunger, sex, chickens, elephants and of course whether the Nazis will win the war. A scene in which Lev savors a baked potato \u2014 with butter! \u2014 after months near starvation is so delicately and deliciously told, I could feel my stomach start to growl.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Carolyn Ryan, assistant managing editor\n\n", "title": "New & Noteworthy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The thieves ransacked 73 safe deposit boxes and stuffed the loot into plastic garbage cans before making their getaway. Officers later found the book \u201cForensics for Dummies\u201d at one suspect\u2019s home. They continued to use their cellphones after the burglary, helping detectives to trace them.\n\nProsecutors said that the ringleaders \u2014 Daniel Jones, 61; Terrence Perkins, 67; John Collins, 75; and Brian Reader; 77 \u2014 had received an estimated \u00a313.7 million from the burglary, but only \u00a34.3 million has been recovered.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The latest titan of street art to take over the giant canvas? Banksy.\n\nThe anonymous British artist\u2019s 70-foot-long mural was unveiled on Thursday, and it protests the imprisonment of the Turkish-Kurdish artist and journalist Zehra Dogan, who was sentenced last March for painting the destruction of a predominantly Kurdish town, with Turkey\u2019s flag flying over rubble.\n\n\u201cI really feel for her. I\u2019ve painted things much more worthy of a custodial sentence,\u201d Banksy said in a statement to the New York Times.\n\nBanksy\u2019s sparse mural mostly consists of black hash marks, which visually represent jail cell bars and count the number of days that Ms. Dogan has spent in prison. (A similar array of hash marks also recently appeared in another protest art piece \u2014 \u201cParkland 17,\u201d which counts the number of Americans killed by guns daily.) A rendering of Ms. Dogan herself peers out of one of the cells, with her left hand gripping a bar that doubles as a pencil. \u201cFree Zehra Dogan\u201d is written in the bottom right corner. She still has 18 months left to serve, and remains unaware of the mural, according to a news release.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe mural was a collaboration with the graffiti artist Borf, who has spent time in jail for his work.\n\n# Nusaybin A post shared by zehra do\u011fan (@jinhazehradogan) on Jun 9, 2016 at 8:09am PDT\n\nOn Thursday evening, Ms. Dogan\u2019s grim painting was projected above the mural. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Amos Paul Kennedy Jr., a letterpress printmaker based in Detroit, collaborated with barbershops and salons near the I.C.A., social sites where the African-American population in particular gathers. \u201cHe thought that would be a great way to reach out and speak to an audience that might not otherwise be aware of the I.C.A. or think that it was a place for them,\u201d Ms. Smith said. Over the course of six months, the artist collected snippets of conversation from patrons on issues of the day.\n\nMr. Kennedy then distilled the text into hundreds of brightly colored letterpress prints that will wallpaper the entrance wall to the I.C.A. \u201cRichmond citizens will walk in and see their own voices reflected on the wall of the institution,\u201d Ms. Smith said.\n\nMr. Rucker, who is in residence at V.C.U., working with students, is interspersing historical artifacts related to the Ku Klux Klan with his refashioned Klansmen robes. The symbolism of the piece is complicated. Does it \u201creflect the ways institutionalized racism has in some cases been camouflaged within our current culture,\u201d posed Ms. Smith, or is it \u201ca Judo move neutralizing a symbol of oppression by transforming it into something that is the artist\u2019s own?\u201d\n\nSuch nuanced questions are bound to reverberate loudly in this city. \u201cThe I.C.A. sets itself in this really rich environment, equidistant from Monument Avenue, Lumpkin\u2019s jail in the center of the slave trade, the tobacco industry, the financial district and Jackson Ward, this amazing center of black entrepreneurship,\u201d said William Martin, director of the Valentine, a nearby museum dedicated to Richmond\u2019s history. \u201cThose of us downtown are surrounded by these tensions of Richmond\u2019s history. Ms. Ludwig is to take up the post on June 15.\n\nHer predecessor, Katie Hollander, a Creative Time veteran, was chosen in 2016 to fill the shoes of the organization\u2019s longtime, Anne Pasternak, who departed for the Brooklyn Museum. Facebook, Google and their ilk are facing tough questions about their inability to police the content they distribute, including Russian propaganda during the 2016 presidential campaign. The companies have also been accused by lawmakers, critics and activists of monopolistic tendencies and manipulative product design.\n\nThe critique from conservatives, in contrast, casts the big tech companies as censorious and oppressive, all too eager to stifle right-wing content in an effort to mollify liberal critics.\n\n\u201cThis could end up being the free speech issue of our time,\u201d said Alex Marlow, editor in chief of Breitbart News, which has published articles accusing Google and Facebook of, among other sins, political bias. \u201cThe Silicon Valley elites are saying: \u2018We don\u2019t care what you want to see \u2014 we know what you should see. We know better.\u2019\u201d\n\nBig Tech is easily associated with West Coast liberalism and Democratic politics, making it a fertile target for the right. And operational opacity at Facebook, Google and Twitter, which are reluctant to reveal details about their algorithms and internal policies, can leave them vulnerable, too.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the perfect foil,\u201d said Eli Pariser, a former executive director of the liberal activist group MoveOn.org and the author of \u201cThe Filter Bubble,\u201d a book about how consumers find information online. \u201cThere\u2019s not even a real basis to establish objective research about what\u2019s happening on Facebook, because it\u2019s closed.\u201d\n\nGoogle, Facebook and Twitter loomed large at last month\u2019s Conservative Political Action Conference in Oxon Hill, Md., where dozens of guests squeezed into a standing-room-only ballroom for a discussion called \u201cSuppression of Conservative Views on Social Media: A First Amendment Issue.\u201d\n\nAmong the panelists were James O\u2019Keefe, the guerrilla filmmaker who has tried to undermine news outlets like The New York Times, The Washington Post and CNN, and James Damore, an engineer fired by Google after he circulated a memo arguing that biological differences accounted for the low number of women in engineering.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Damore \u2014 a new celebrity in the right-wing world, who, in an interview, said of his first foray to CPAC, \u201cThere\u2019s definitely a lot of people that want to take selfies\u201d \u2014 described a culture of dogmatic liberalism at Google.\n\n\u201cThere are political activists in all of these companies that want to actively push a liberal agenda,\u201d he said. \u201cWhy does it matter? Because these companies are so ubiquitous and powerful that they are controlling all the means of mass communication.\u201d\n\nBefore Mr. Damore spoke, organizers distributed baseball caps to guests emblazoned with an illustration of Twitter\u2019s bird logo, upside-down and with its eyes crossed out.\n\nThe panelists accused social media platforms of delisting their videos or stripping them of advertising. Such charges have long been staples of far-right online discourse, especially among YouTubers, but Mr. Schweizer\u2019s project is poised to bring such arguments to a new \u2014 and potentially larger \u2014 audience.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Schweizer, 53, was a speechwriting consultant to President George W. Bush. His reporting has been cited by The Times and \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d although he often uses a bombastic style akin to that of Breitbart News.\n\nHe is also the president of the Government Accountability Institute, a conservative nonprofit organization. He and Mr. Bannon founded it with funding from the family of Robert Mercer, the billionaire hedge fund manager and donor to Donald J. Trump\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nMr. Schweizer declined to identify the film\u2019s financial backers. A spokeswoman for the institute said it was not involved in the project.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn some ways, the complaints from the right about Big Tech mirror the grumblings of legacy news organizations, which have expressed concern that online algorithms wield too much power over how readers gain access to their content.\n\nJeffrey A. Zucker, the president of CNN, derided Google and Facebook as \u201cmonopolies\u201d and called for regulators to step in during a speech in Spain last month, saying the tech hegemony is \u201cthe biggest issue facing the growth of journalism in the years ahead.\u201d And former President Barack Obama said at an off-the-record conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last month that he worried Americans were living in \u201centirely different realities\u201d and that large tech companies like Facebook were \u201cnot just an invisible platform, they\u2019re shaping our culture in powerful ways.\u201d The contents of the speech were published by Reason magazine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the right\u2019s more internet-savvy quarters, tech platforms have been a regular \u2014 and fruitful \u2014 subject of discussion since before the 2016 election. In May that year, Facebook was forced to respond to claims that the curators of its Trending Topics feature had suppressed conservative news sources, a controversy that called attention to Facebook\u2019s editorial power.\n\nThat charge of editorial bias was echoed last weekend by Alex Jones, the conspiracy theorist behind Infowars, who accused YouTube of planning to delete his organization\u2019s account, a claim that was widely shared among conservatives.\n\nYouTube did delete some videos that accused teenage survivors of the Parkland, Fla., school shooting of being \u201ccrisis actors,\u201d and it issued \u201cstrikes,\u201d or warnings, to the accounts of Infowars and Jerome Corsi, a conservative author and Infowars contributor. (YouTube denied that it had plans to delete the Infowars account.)\n\nFacebook has also caught flak for adjusting the algorithm for its News Feed to emphasize posts from \u201cfriends, family and groups\u201d over content from public pages. The change was part of an effort by the company to answer criticism, but also to reinvigorate its oldest and most profitable product, which recently recorded a decline in American daily users for the first time in its history.\n\nThe Facebook adjustment has affected virtually every media organization that is partly dependent on the platform for audiences, but it appears to have hit some harder than others. They include right-wing sites like Gateway Pundit and the millennial-focused Independent Journal Review, which was forced to lay off staff members last month.\n\nThe social news giant BuzzFeed recently bought ads on Facebook with the message, \u201cFacebook is taking the news out of your News Feed, but we\u2019ve got you covered,\u201d directing users to download its app. Away from the political scrum, the viral lifestyle site LittleThings, once a top publisher on the platform, announced last week that it would cease operations, blaming \u201ca full-on catastrophic update\u201d to Facebook\u2019s revised algorithms.\n\nRight-wing media has pounced. In late February, citing statistics from the social analytics firm NewsWhip, Breitbart published an article on the effects on the president\u2019s Facebook page with the headline \u201cEXCLUSIVE: Trump\u2019s Facebook Engagement Declined By 45 Percent Following Algorithm Change.\u201d The drop, the article insinuated, occurred \u201cfollowing a year of pressure from left-wing employees and the mainstream media for \u2018allowing\u2019 the president to win the 2016 general election.\u201d\n\nStill, the brewing backlash did not stop Google and Facebook from courting the very crowd that now seems ready to declare them enemies. Both companies were sponsors at this year\u2019s CPAC, leading to a few awkward moments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFacebook, which sponsored a \u201chelp desk\u201d for attendees featuring smiling representatives and cookies frosted with emoji icons, provided a demonstration of its virtual reality program, Oculus. But the company was forced to apologize for including a first-person shooter simulation, given that the conference took place a week after the Parkland massacre.\n\nGoogle, which has co-sponsored CPAC three of the past six years, held a lavish reception for attendees featuring an open bar and a roaring outdoor fireplace.\n\nMr. Marlow, the editor of Breitbart, was asked in an interview what he thought about Google\u2019s giving a party in the midst of a crowd that is gunning for it.\n\n\u201cThe least they can do,\u201d Mr. Marlow said, \u201cis buy us a drink.\u201d", "title": "New Foils for the Right: Google and Facebook", "authors": ["Michael M.
