But he noted that many Hoboken families would be away next week because the city\u2019s schools will be on spring break.", "title": "New Jersey Transit Tries Again to Buy Hoboken Waterfront Site", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "New Jersey was ranked behind only California in having the most stringent gun restrictions by the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence, named for Gabrielle Giffords, the former congresswoman who was gravely injured by gunfire in 2011 and survived. New York and Connecticut have similarly strong gun laws. Florida, which had been considered far less restrictive, responded to the shooting last month by passing some of its first gun-control measures in two decades, including raising the minimum age to buy a firearm to 21, banning bump stocks and allowing school employees to be armed.\n\nAlready in New Jersey, permits are required for the purchase of any handgun. Assault weapons and large-capacity ammunition magazines have been banned, and the state prohibits people with misdemeanor domestic violence convictions or people limited by protective orders from buying or possessing a firearm.\n\nThe proposed measures, consisting of a half-dozen separate bills, would limit magazine capacity to 10 rounds and require background checks for private gun sales. The legislation would also allow for extreme risk protective orders meant to prevent people deemed to pose a significant danger from owning or buying a firearm, and it would expand the requirements of mental health providers and other medical workers to report patients to law enforcement if they are believed to pose a threat to themselves or others.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe legislation would also codify in state law the requirement of \u201cjustifiable need,\u201d which means that an applicant would have to show that they had been subjected to attacks or threatened \u2014 \u201csomething beyond a generalized desire to have a gun in public for self-defense,\u201d according to Allison Anderman, the managing attorney at the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence.\n\nThe measures have faced considerable opposition from gun-rights organizations, who protested in Trenton on Monday as the Assembly voted on the legislation. \u201cWe think they\u2019re misguided and they won\u2019t make anybody safer,\u201d said Scott Bach, the executive director of the Association of New Jersey Rifle and Pistol Clubs.\n\nMr. Bach argued that the legislation was an incursion on the Second Amendment rights of gun owners. The limits on magazine capacity would turn people who own weapons with larger capacities \u201cinto criminals with the stroke of a pen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe said his organization and others vowed to fight the laws in court. He viewed the effort as a reflection of lawmakers\u2019 hostility over guns and said the proposed restrictions were part of \u201ca constant and never-ending call for more, regardless of the facts, regardless of the circumstances.\u201d\n\n\u201cEnough already,\u201d Mr. Bach said. \u201cEnough. Stop targeting honest citizens and instead severely punish criminals. New Jersey doesn\u2019t get that and we think it\u2019s because New Jersey doesn\u2019t want to get that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe legislation was revived after the former governor, Chris Christie, a Republican, vetoed numerous gun control measures while he was in office, including one that would have limited magazine capacity and regulations to make it more difficult to obtain a concealed carry permit. He supported loosening the state\u2019s restrictions, calling them \u201coverly burdensome.\u201d\n\nBut supporters of tougher restrictions said the measures gained new traction in recent months, bolstered by the surge in attention prompted by recent episodes of mass violence and the election of Mr. Murphy, who had campaigned on tougher gun restrictions. Mr. Murphy had also been endorsed during the campaign by Ms. Giffords.\n\nMr. Murphy has supported the measures in the Legislature, which he described as \u201ccommon sense gun measures to protect our communities and families.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe people of New Jersey have demanded we act,\u201d Mr. Murphy said in a statement on Monday, \u201cand we must.\u201d", "title": "New Jersey\u2019s Gun Laws, Already Tough, Could Soon Get Tougher", "authors": ["Rick Rojas"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The recent killing of a pedestrian by a self-driving Uber vehicle is the source of the latest negative headlines about this company. But there\u2019s a much deeper problem. While the leadership has changed \u2014 Dara Khosrowshahi replaced Uber\u2019s co-founder Travis Kalanick as chief executive last August after a series of scandals \u2014 the company itself has not evolved.\n\nThe problem with Uber was never that the chief executive had created a thuggish \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d-type culture, as Susan Fowler, an engineer, described it in a blog post. The problem was, and still is, Uber\u2019s business model: Its modus operandi is to subsidize fares and flood streets with its cars to achieve a transportation monopoly. In city after city, this has led to huge increases in traffic congestion, increased carbon emissions and the undermining of public transportation.\n\nMost customers who love Uber don\u2019t realize that the company subsidizes the cost of many rides. This is likely a major factor in Uber\u2019s annual losses surging from 2.8 billion in 2016 to $4.5 billion in 2017. This seemingly nonsensical approach is actually Uber\u2019s effort to use its deep pockets to mount a predatory price war and shut out the competition. That competition is not only taxis and other ride-sharing companies, but public transportation.\n\nStudies have found that half to 61 percent of Uber passengers in the United States say that they would have used public transportation, ridden a bicycle or walked, or not have made the trip at all, if Uber had not been available.", "title": "Opinion | New Leadership Has Not Changed Uber", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "With new practices in place, it would be hard for the Oscars to repeat last year\u2019s best picture mix-up.\n\nThe Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences confirmed several changes in January, including presenters ensuring they have the correct envelope before they go on stage, with that fact confirmed by stage managers, too. PwC accountants were forbidden from using social media during the show, in hopes of reducing distractions.\n\nBut the biggest change became quickly apparent on Sunday as Viola Davis presented the award for best supporting actor. The gold, giant bold type on the dark envelope, loudly announcing the name of the category, was so unmistakable it could be read clearly on TV. Last year\u2019s envelope was an elegant red, but the smaller gold lettering on it was not so easily readable.", "title": "New Oscar Envelopes List Category in Huge Type to Avoid \u2018Moonlight\u2019 Mix-up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018Soon Dawn appeared and touched the sky with roses.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From Emily Wilson\u2019s translation of Homer\u2019s \u201cOdyssey\u201d (W.W. Norton & Company, 2017, Page 220). The British classicist\u2019s rendering is the first published English translation of Homer\u2019s epic by a woman.\n\nThe work of Homer is, among all its wonderful qualities, also extremely repetitive. Every time a character turns around, he has to drink sweet wine and get his feet washed with oil and sacrifice a bull to a fickle god. On the level of language, too, certain phrases recur like waves: \u201cthe wine-dark sea,\u201d \u201chollow boats,\u201d \u201cbright-eyed Athena\u201d and so on. Scholars say such repetition is a signature of oral storytelling; the familiar phrases are convenient memory handles for the storyteller and the listener alike.\n\nProbably the most famous of those repetitions is the arrival, every morning, of \u201crosy-fingered dawn.\u201d I\u2019ve always found the image strangely surreal: a cosmic pink hand slowly creeping over the horizon, lightening the sky.\n\nIn her new translation of the \u201cOdyssey,\u201d Emily Wilson allows herself some creative freedom with Homer\u2019s formulaic phrases. \u201cI have used the opportunity offered by the repetitions,\u201d she writes in her introduction, \u201cto explore the multiple different connotations of each epithet.\u201d", "title": "New Sentences: From Emily Wilson\u2019s Translation of the \u2018Odyssey\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018Summertime and the living is extraordinarily difficult.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From Morgan Parker\u2019s \u201cThere Are More Beautiful Things Than Beyonc\u00e9\u201d (Tin House Books, 2017, Page 30). Parker, a poet and an editor, is also the author of \u201cOther People\u2019s Comfort Keeps Me Up at Night.\u201d\n\nEvery culture is a vast carpet of interwoven references: clich\u00e9s, fables, jingles, lullabies, warnings, jokes, memes. To be a part of that culture means that it only takes a few words, the tiniest head fake, to set your mind racing along a familiar track. You can lead a horse to. There once was a man from. When the moon hits your eye. If you liked it then you shoulda.\n\nOne trick of art is to constantly invoke \u2014 and then manipulate and complicate \u2014 these familiar mental scripts. The artist sets your mind on a well-worn road, and then, just as you settle into that automatic groove, yanks you suddenly in another direction. It\u2019s the same trick as a crossover dribble. Great art is always, if you will, breaking your mind\u2019s ankles.\n\nIn her poem \u201cThe Book of Negroes,\u201d Morgan Parker hits us with a nasty crossover in the very first sentence. She invokes one of the most famous opening lines in American music \u2014 Gershwin\u2019s \u201cSummertime, and the living is easy\u201d \u2014 a cultural script so powerful that, even without music, even as just words on a page, our internal orchestras automatically swell, and we hear the mournful crooning of Billie Holiday or Sam Cooke or Janis Joplin or Billy Stewart or Bradley Nowell of the band Sublime \u2014 whichever version you happen to know best. The familiar melody unrolls, slowly. \u201cSummertime, and the living is. ... \u201d", "title": "New Sentences: From Morgan Parker\u2019s \u2018There Are More Beautiful Things Than Beyonc\u00e9\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018There was a quiz show but who wants to feel more stupid than they already are?\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cA Long Way From Home\u201d (Alfred A. Knopf, 2018, Page 39), the 14th novel from the Australian writer Peter Carey.\n\nHow do we know how smart we are? We weigh our minds, constantly, against pieces of the world around us. We solve puzzles \u2014 knock-knock jokes, forgotten account logins, what to say next in a conversation \u2014 and we watch others solve those same puzzles, and we compare results. Our estimation of our own intelligence booms and crashes like an internal stock market. We win a chess game and feel smart; we are flummoxed by a lawn mower\u2019s engine and feel dumb again.\n\nIt is tempting to avoid feeling dumb \u2014 to build a wall between ourselves and the world, which is, after all, an infinite showroom of our ignorance. But feeling temporarily dumb is how we become smart, in the same way that feeling temporarily weak is how we become strong.\n\nOne character in Peter Carey\u2019s new novel is an Australian radio-quiz-show genius. His mind is dense with facts, from the origins of carbon paper to the many varieties of rope. But the quiz show \u2014 knowledge as public display \u2014 is, for him, a dead end.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018A Long Way From Home,\u2019 by Peter Carey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u2018While a record plant pressed \u201cAstral Weeks\u201d to vinyl, Richard Nixon was elected president of the United States.\u2019\n\n\u2014 From \u201cAstral Weeks: A Secret History of 1968\u201d (Penguin Press, 2018, Page 281), by Ryan H. Walsh, a culture journalist and the frontman of the Boston band Hallelujah the Hills.\n\nThe ancient Greeks had two words for time: \u201cchronos\u201d and \u201ckairos.\u201d Chronos was the normal, steady, workaday flow \u2014 what we would call \u201cclock time.\u201d Kairos was special: key moments that managed to transcend the ceaseless drift to become opportune, defining, holy.\n\nA few thousand years of clock time later, this remains one of human life\u2019s defining tensions: the Ping-Pong between chronos and kairos, meaning and mundanity. Our great epiphanies might feel like celestial gifts, but in reality they tend to arrive at 2:14 on gray Thursdays while plastic bags flutter in the trees and drawers we thought we had fixed suddenly scrape and stick again.\n\nPart of the job of a good historian is to return celebrated moments of kairos \u2014 the signing of the Declaration of Independence, Michael Jackson\u2019s first moonwalk \u2014 back to the chronos from which they sprang.\n\nIn a new book, Ryan H. Walsh finds a way to do this with one of the most kairos-soaked artworks of the 20th century. Van Morrison\u2019s \u201cAstral Weeks\u201d sounds less a rock album than a mystical folk cloud, formless and eternal, pulsating on the edge of the Big Bang. (\u201cIf I ventured in the slipstream,\u201d Morrison sings in the opening verse, \u201cbetween the viaducts of your dream.\u201d) But even this transcendent recording, Walsh shows, is rooted in the mundane, from the social turmoil of 1968 Boston (mystical cults, racial oppression) to the fits and whims of a diminutive alcoholic from Belfast who happened to sing with something resembling the voice of God. One of Morrison\u2019s session musicians, the jazz guitarist Jay Berliner, came to the artsy improvisations of \u201cAstral Weeks\u201d directly from working on jingles for Noxzema and Pringles. And then, in the little loop of time between Morrison\u2019s inspired recording and the album hitting stores, Richard Nixon stepped into the White House \u2014 another moment of kairos from which we are all still trying to recover.", "title": "New Sentences: From \u2018Astral Weeks: A Secret History of 1968\u2019", "authors": ["Sam Anderson", "New Sentences"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Every St. Patrick\u2019s Day for two decades, Gerry Adams or other leaders of Sinn Fein, the party once known primarily as the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, have come to the United States to lobby Washington politicians and rally Irish-American donors.\n\nThis year there has been a new item on Mr. Adams\u2019s agenda: passing the torch to the party\u2019s new president, Mary Lou McDonald, 48, whose election last month represented a generational shift at a time of great uncertainty for Northern Ireland.\n\n\u201cWe have been blessed with a generational transition,\u201d Mr. Adams, 69, said in a speech in New York on Friday, motioning to Ms. McDonald and her vice president, Michelle O\u2019Neill, 41. \u201cAnd it is a matter of pride for me that our party chose two women to lead us because women for too long have been written out of our history.\u201d\n\nMr. Adams, who won a seat in the Irish Parliament in 2011, is a towering \u2014 and divisive \u2014 figure in modern Ireland. Long accused of having a leadership role in the I.R.A., a charge he denies, he led Sinn Fein for 34 years, most notably through an American-brokered peace process that ended Ireland\u2019s sectarian conflict in 1998.", "title": "New Sinn Fein Leader Has a Familiar Task: Wooing Irish-Americans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "ABC and Disney are nothing if not in promotional sync. Mr. Van Dyke also appears in the new version in a different role, as the son of the penny-pinching banker Mr. Dawes.\n\nMeryl Streep, reuniting with Ms. Blunt from \u201cThe Devil Wears Prada\u201d and with the director Rob Marshall from \u201cInto the Woods,\u201d plays Poppins\u2019s cousin, Topsy; another acting legend, Angela Lansbury, plays the Balloon Lady, but neither appear in the teaser.\n\n\u201cMary Poppins Returns\u201d reveals a grown-up Jane and Michael Banks (Emily Mortimer and Ben Whishaw), who reunite with their magical caregiver in Depression Era London, 25 years after the first film took place. \u201cIt\u2019s wonderful to see you,\u201d Michael tells Mary, to which she agrees, \u201cIt is, isn\u2019t it?\u201d We shall see if moviegoers feel as equally supercalifragilisticexpialidocious when the new \u201cPoppins\u201d lands in theaters on Christmas Day.", "title": "New Trailer: \u2018Mary Poppins Returns\u2019", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNew Policy Lets Transgender Troops Stay in Service, but With Restrictions\u201d (news article, March 24): Our children are being shot to death in their schools. We are destroying the environment. Our infrastructure is crumbling. Millions of Americans run out of food between paychecks. Health care and higher education are out of reach of many. But the Trump administration\u2019s priority is to enact a policy that humiliates and demeans citizens who wish to serve their country. I find it revolting.\n\nSUSAN RAPPOPORT\n\nFALLBROOK, CALIF.", "title": "Opinion | New Transgender Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "At a news conference, he said Mr. Syed \u201casked me to convey his deep gratitude and thanks from the bottom of his heart to all those who have supported him and believed in him.\u201d\n\nThe accounts by the new witness, and other evidence seeming to cast doubt on the conviction, were the focus of \u201cSerial,\u201d which was a wildly successful podcast in 2014 and popularized the format for a general audience.\n\nThe 12-episode series featured Sarah Koenig, a former producer with the weekly public radio program \u201cThis American Life,\u201d telling the story of the killing, investigation and trial in a conversational narrative with interviews. It was downloaded more than 175 million times and won a Peabody Award.\n\nMr. Syed\u2019s lawyer, Mr. Brown, said he had been unable to locate the witness, Asia McClain, until the \u201cSerial\u201d team began investigating Mr. Syed\u2019s story. He said the podcast had been \u201cenormously helpful\u201d in pursuing justice for his client.\n\n\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201c\u2018Serial\u2019 kind of shook the trees and that enabled us to get in contact with Asia McClain and bring her to Baltimore for the post conviction hearing two years ago,\u201d Mr. Brown said at a news conference on Thursday. \u201c\u2018Serial\u2019 has also helped build this groundswell of support for us and for Adnan and for the case, and that has fueled these efforts and helped us to fight on as we have.\u201d\n\n\n\nMs. McClain sent Mr. Syed two letters after he was arrested in 1999 stating that she had seen him at Woodlawn Public Library at the time that Ms. Lee was killed. Mr. Syed asked his lawyer, Maria Cristina Gutierrez, to contact Ms. McClain. She said she had \u201cand nothing had come of it,\u201d the panel said.\n\nAfter Mr. Syed was convicted, it was determined that Ms. Gutierrez had not in fact contacted Ms. McClain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA friend of Mr. Syed\u2019s, a law student named Rabia Chaudry, independently reached out to Ms. McClain, who signed an affidavit saying that she had seen Mr. Syed at the Woodlawn Public Library at the time that Ms. Lee was killed.\n\nMs. Gutierrez\u2019s failure to interview or contact Ms. McClain formed a key part of Mr. Syed\u2019s argument that she had been negligent in her defense of him. Ms. Gutierrez died in 2004.\n\n\n\nAfter the podcast drew attention to the case, Mr. Syed was granted a retrial in 2016 by Judge Martin P. Welch of the Baltimore City Circuit Court.\n\n\n\nThe state appealed that ruling to the Court of Special Appeals.\n\nHe has served 16 years of a life sentence after being convicted in 2000, but has maintained his innocence for almost two decades.\n\n\n\nMs. Lee was last seen on Jan. 13, 1999, as she was leaving school. A few weeks later, a passer-by found her body partially buried in a shallow grave in a park in West Baltimore, according to The Baltimore Sun.\n\nThe Sun said Mr. Syed had told the police that he and Ms. Lee dated as high school students but kept their relationship secret because of cultural differences between their families. They broke up in 1998 and Ms. Lee later began dating another man.\n\nMs. Lee\u2019s mother, Youn Wha Kim, took the stand at Mr. Syed\u2019s sentencing hearing in 2000, telling the court that though she wanted to, she did not think she could bring herself to forgive Mr. Syed for her daughter\u2019s death, The Sun reported at the time.\n\n\u201cWhen I die, my daughter will die with me,\u201d she told the court. \u201cAs long as I live, my daughter is buried in my heart.\u201d", "title": "New Trial Upheld for Adnan Syed of \u2018Serial\u2019", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The Palestinians are less equivocal.\n\n\u201cNo Man\u2019s Land is occupied territory,\u201d said Ashraf Khatib of the Palestine Liberation Organization\u2019s Negotiations Affairs Department. \u201cAny permanent status for that territory should be part of a final status negotiation.\u201d\n\nThe dispute could turn the American ambassador, David M. Friedman, an avid supporter of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, into a new kind of diplomatic settler himself.\n\nThe plan is for the embassy to be housed in what is now the consular services section of the United States Consulate General in Jerusalem while the search is on for a permanent site. The fortresslike compound sits partly in predominantly Jewish West Jerusalem and partly in a section of No Man\u2019s Land between West Jerusalem and predominantly Arab East Jerusalem.\n\nThe American Embassy move veers from almost seven decades of American policy, and that of much of the rest of the world, which considers the status of Jerusalem subject to negotiation between Israelis and Palestinians, who each claim it as their capital. Critics say the embassy move prejudges the outcome of any future negotiations over the city.\n\nBut if the American recognition was already vague, leaving the eventual boundaries of sovereignty in Jerusalem up to the Israelis and the Palestinians, this odd quirk of political geography raises even sharper questions about which parts of the city the United States considers as Israel\u2019s capital.\n\nThat requires some historical unpacking.\n\nAfter the 1948 war surrounding Israel\u2019s creation, Israel signed an armistice agreement with Jordan, which controlled the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The sides demarcated the armistice line on a map in grease pencil. Where they did not agree they drew their own lines staking out their maximalist positions \u2014 the Israelis in green, as far as possible to the east, the Jordanians in red, to the west.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe disputed enclaves, called the \u201careas between the lines,\u201d were under neither party\u2019s control and came to be known as No Man\u2019s Land.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA senior United Nations official, who was granted anonymity to discuss a particularly sensitive diplomatic issue, said it was impossible to tell from the 1949 map exactly which parts of the Arnona consular compound sit where. The lines were drawn with the thickness of a crayon, and none of the current development in the area existed then.\n\nBut any part between the lines would be considered occupied territory, he said.\n\nAfter 1949, both Israel and Jordan claimed the territory, holding that its status would be determined in an eventual agreement. When the 1967 war broke out, the Jordanian and Israeli armies fought over it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRaphael Israeli, a professor emeritus at Hebrew University and a former Israeli delegate to the Israel-Jordan Mixed Armistice Commission, says that neither Israel nor Jordan had formal jurisdiction of it. \u201cThey simply invaded it,\u201d he said.\n\nToday, he said, after 50 years of Israeli possession and no country having had sovereignty over it beforehand, questions about its status are moot.\n\n\u201cYou can start making hairsplitting arguments,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it seems so obsolete now. Things got blended together, and I don\u2019t know any more which is what and what belongs to whom.\u201d\n\nAfter 1949, the Israelis set about fencing and farming land on their side of the territory. A Jordanian road to Bethlehem meandered through.\n\nBoth sides stationed troops in the zone. There were also instances of cooperation, such as when Jordan agreed to work with Israeli experts to eradicate a moth-borne blight infesting pine trees in the area.\n\nBut when an Israeli entrepreneur began constructing a hotel on a slope in the zone in 1963, the Jordanians lodged a complaint and the work was stopped.\n\nThe hotel, named the Diplomat, was opened after the Israeli victory in 1967. Located on the grounds of the consular compound, it is now owned by the United States and leased out as housing for elderly Russian-speaking immigrants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore moving to Arnona in 2010, the American consular section that served Arabs and Jews was in East Jerusalem. The United States Consulate General that deals with the Palestinian Authority is in West Jerusalem.\n\nEugene Kontorovich, the director of international law at the conservative Jerusalem-based Kohelet Policy Forum, contends that by moving the embassy to the Arnona site the United States is recognizing Israel\u2019s sovereignty over areas it captured in the 1967 war.\n\n\u201cMuch more important than what the State Department says, it is what their actions say,\u201d Mr. Kontorovich said. \u201cYou don\u2019t build an embassy in territory that is not sovereign to Israel.\u201d", "title": "New U.S. Embassy May Be in Jerusalem, but Not in Israel", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Magic also lies dormant in the platelets of chosen teenagers in the Nigerian-American Tomi Adeyemi\u2019s debut, CHILDREN OF BLOOD AND BONE (Holt, $18.99; ages 12 and up). But these diviners are no debutantes. Born with snow white hair and deep brown skin in the imaginary country of Or\u00efsha, young diviners morph into mighty, magic-wielding maji, or magicians, at 13. For centuries they relied on their powers (which Adeyemi based on aspects of the religion of the Yoruban people of West Africa). All that ended when the nonmagical King Saran ordered the slaughter of all adult majis. But when a mysterious scroll falls into the hands of Amari, a defiant princess, and Z\u00e9lie, a tenacious diviner warrior, the two young women set out on a thrilling, death-defying journey to restore magic and take back the throne.\n\nImage\n\nBlack Girl Magic, indeed! It\u2019s no surprise that this epic trilogy opener has already been optioned for film. Full of cinematic action sequences (the most memorable of them set almost entirely underwater and employing an army of the dead) and creatures worthy of Star Wars (horse-size \u201clionaires\u201d have saber teeth and horns), it storms the boundaries of the imagination. Yet it also confronts the conscience. Adeyemi\u2019s brutally depicted war between the noble, lighter-skinned kosidans and the enslaved, darker-skinned majis poses thought-provoking questions about race, class and authority that hold up a warning mirror to our sharply divided society.\n\nAtia Abawi mixes a fantasy element with extreme realism in her second novel, A LAND OF PERMANENT GOODBYES (Philomel, $17.99; ages 13 and up). Tareq is a Syrian refugee whose perilous journey is narrated by the voice of Destiny, characterized as a kindly, prosaic entity. After Tareq\u2019s mother, grandmother and four of his siblings are killed by a bomb, he and his father flee to Turkey with his remaining sister, Susan. They hopscotch from Turkey to Greece, Serbia, Slovenia, Austria and finally to Germany, where he finds a fragile safety. Along the way he witnesses beheadings and drownings, but also experiences the kindness of aid workers like Alexia, an American student. Abawi, a foreign news correspondent, does an admirable job of showing the grim horror of refugee life. But her efforts are occasionally undermined by cartoonish villains (\u201cYou tink you will be saved? Who will save you? Captain America is not real, just movies\u201d) and by some of Destiny\u2019s well-meaning but obvious platitudes: \u201cWhen you truly love someone, their life means more to you than your own.\u201d These interruptions may pull readers out of the story, though perhaps that distance is necessary for adolescents trying to process something as bleak and overwhelming as the Syrian refugee crisis.\n\nImage\n\nOf course, once refugees finally arrive in their adopted country, new problems arise. Until she was 13, Sara Saedi, an Iranian-American television writer and the author of the memoir AMERICANIZED: Rebel Without a Green Card (Random House, $17.99, ages 12 and up), was cheerfully oblivious of her family\u2019s immigration status. After her older sister breaks the news that they are \u201cillegal,\u201d Saedi suffers through the usual teenage rites of passage at her Silicon Valley high school (unibrow management, pimple wars, pot smoking) with the added pressure of possible deportation hanging over her head. Saedi adroitly and humorously uses these universal pubescent ordeals to contextualize Iranian culture and the immigrant experience. A memory of being teased about her eyebrow in ninth grade expands into a discussion of beauty norms: When her mother praises her for being hairless, \u201cshe meant by Persian woman standards. I was still hairy by everyone else\u2019s standards.\u201d And she has the sobering realization that pot is a privilege American teenagers can enjoy, but not undocumented kids: \u201cIf I got caught, I\u2019d have a criminal record that could be grounds for deportation.\u201d Very funny but never flippant, Saedi mixes \u201990s pop culture references, adolescent angst and Iranian history into an intimate, informative narrative that thoroughly defies current divisive views on immigration.\n\nImage\n\nMary H.K. Choi\u2019s blushingly tender and piquant debut novel, EMERGENCY CONTACT (Simon & Schuster, $17.99; ages 14 and up), about two isolated, misfit college students from Austin who fall in love via text message explores our emotional rather than geographical divides. In \u201cEmergency Contact,\u201d a Korean-American would-be writer named Penny keeps everyone at a distance, the result of living with a single, oversharing mom she calls \u201cthe equivalent of \u2026 human glitter.\u201d But when she rescues Sam, a half-German, half-Polish student filmmaker, from the sidewalk during a panic attack, she becomes his \u201cemergency contact,\u201d and he hers. Their charged, initial banter on text soon develops into increasingly personal exchanges about art, death, unstable moms and pregnant ex-girlfriends. Yet their burgeoning bond keeps stalling out. Burned by past relationships and millennial-ly tethered to their devices, they struggle to connect romantically IRL. Sam \u201ccouldn\u2019t imagine the space Penny would take up in his life if she sprang out of his phone,\u201d and Penny admits \u201cSam was her phone and her phone was Sam.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nChoi, a culture correspondent for HBO\u2019s Vice News, inserts timely issues like sexual assault, cultural appropriation and even DACA into her characters\u2019 intimate conversations, but it is her examination of digital vs. F2F communication that feels the most immediate. Has digital communication become so ubiquitous, and interpersonal contact so arduous, that we\u2019d rather type than talk? Thankfully, no. Penny and Sam put down their phones long enough to make out, proving that touch trumps text, and hormones still conquer all.", "title": "New Y.A. Books Rewrite Old Cultural Scripts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "In her first interview since accepting the post, Ms. Palitz suggested that her stint as the Nightlife Mayor would be slightly more sober and focus less on carousing than on conflict mediation. In today\u2019s New York, gentrification has pitted partygoers against the settled residents of neighborhoods like the Lower East Side of Manhattan and Williamsburg in Brooklyn. In her first official act, Ms. Palitz promised to hold a series of listening tours and entertain the gripes of those who are bothered by the vomit on their streets or the noise at 3 a.m.\n\n\u201cBoth sides feel unheard,\u201d she said. \u201cBoth sides feel that things are unfair. I think the grievances are almost the same but there haven\u2019t been any practical real-world solutions to address them.\u201d\n\nAs a fifth-generation New Yorker, Ms. Palitz, 47, claims to be of a broad enough mind to discern those solutions and to ably serve as advocate for the after-hours set while remaining responsive to community concerns. Though she was raised on 86th Street on the Upper East Side, she moved to the East Village in 1996 and has lived there ever since \u2014 on three of the four different corners at First Street and First Avenue. In her early 20s, she took her first night life job, managing the guest list at the old Club Mars. Soon she was producing the \u201cSoulution Spontaneous Groove Open Jam\u201d \u2014 a night of hip-hop, spoken word, gospel, rock and drag \u2014 at clubs like Nation, SOB\u2019s and the Tunnel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the early 2000s, a friend from grade school asked Ms. Palitz to invest in a bar near her apartment called The Flat. (It was briefly famous as a rendezvous that the actors Demi Moore and Ashton Kutcher used for their romance.) But in 2004, The Flat went under and Ms. Palitz took it over. She turned it into Sutra, which for the next 10 years until it closed, was known for Toca Tuesdays, an old-school hip-hop party overseen by the D.J. Tony Touch.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was during that period that Ms. Palitz joined Community Board 3, a fractious body that includes the East Village, Chinatown and the Lower East Side. There, she was introduced to the brass-knuckle politics of night life \u2014 chiefly through her dealings with what she has called the \u201cno-more bar contingency.\u201d\n\nIn an interview in 2012, Ms. Palitz told The Daily News that the area was \u201cripe for the picking\u201d by high-end nightclub entrepreneurs \u2014 a remark that did not endear her to local residents and bloggers. Though she later claimed she was misquoted, the comment triggered a firestorm and some in the neighborhood called for her removal from the board.\n\nNow in charge of a mayoral office with a 12-person advisory board, a $300,000 budget and a salary of $130,000 a year, Ms. Palitz seems to have realized that even a doyenne of New York night life must make a few concessions when joining city government. On her Tuesday evening drink, she was accompanied, for instance, by a minder from City Hall. While she admits that there were times in her career when she personified \u201cwhat the no-bar movement rejected,\u201d she also claimed that she has always tried \u201cto find solutions that work for everyone.\u201d\n\nAmong those who will be watching her as she begins her job is Rafael Espinal, the Brooklyn city councilman who sponsored the law that created the position. Mr. Espinal, whose district includes the night life neighborhood of Bushwick, said he was excited by Ms. Palitz\u2019s appointment, but hoped that she would not be too Manhattan-centric.\n\n\u201cI would love it if she were sensitive to the D.I.Y. underground in Brooklyn too,\u201d Mr. Espinal said. \u201cThat\u2019s the scene that has set the trend for years and has made things in the city so interesting.\u201d\n\nMs. Palitz acknowledged that the scene had changed from her day in the mix and that the once-cool clubs of the Meatpacking District had moved to Queens and Brooklyn.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t crush culture \u2014 or subculture \u2014 in New York,\u201d she said. \u201cIt just goes deeper and longer. New York culture and night life still thrive in a very real way. It\u2019s just going to find its new place.\u201d", "title": "New York City Appoints Its First Nightlife Mayor", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "That definition of homelessness includes children not just living in shelters, but also those who are doubled up in the homes of extended family members or friends, those living in cars or in hotels, or any place temporary. Mr. Stringer\u2019s audit focused on those living in shelters.\n\nTo conduct the study, the comptroller\u2019s office randomly selected 73 chronically absent students from a pool of 33,000 homeless students, most of whom lived in shelters. Though the sample is small, the comptroller\u2019s office said that size allowed them to drill down into each individual attendance record and the efforts made to try to keep those children in school. How many calls were made when a student didn\u2019t show up? What did the school do when they were late?\n\nThe audit found that the students in its sample were absent an enormous amount: an average of 41.6 days each during a 178-day school year. And while the education department is required to contact a parent the first day a student is unexpectedly absent, the audit found that it failed to do so 92 percent of the time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn response to the audit, Olivia Lapeyrolerie, a spokeswoman for Mr. de Blasio, cited a variety of efforts the city is making, including changing the way homeless people are housed and creating a data-sharing system between the education and homeless services departments.\n\n\u201cThis has been a serious challenge in our city for decades,\u201d Ms. Lapeyrolerie said. \u201cOur administration is tackling it head-on with investments in school and shelter programming, including dramatically expanded bus service, more social workers and better monitoring so we know who\u2019s missing from class.\u201d\n\nStudents who are homeless tend to perform worse than their peers in an array of academic areas. They are less likely to test on grade level or to graduate, and they are more likely to drop out. Some of this stems from the fact that they are simply not in school in enough to keep up. They also tend to move around frequently, bumping from one temporary spot to another, so it is common for them to attend at least two schools in one academic year.\n\nThe education department has rules and employees in place, both in schools and in shelters, to try to minimize student absences. But the comptroller\u2019s office found that in many cases, protocols just weren\u2019t followed, seemingly because those charged with trying to keep children in schools were overwhelmed. During the 2015-16 school year, there were 110 family-assistance workers responsible for helping the 32,243 students in city shelters \u2014 giving them an average caseload of 293 children each.\n\nThe comptroller\u2019s office said that the education department should make a number of changes, including conducting a study of caseloads and making sure that schools follow existing regulations. The second report released on Thursday went further.\n\nThat paper, released by Advocates for Children of New York and the Citizens\u2019 Committee for Children of New York, called on Mr. de Blasio to hire more trained social workers to work in shelters \u2014 family assistants need neither a college degree nor any formal training in social work or education, the paper said. It also asked that the education department create a deputy chancellor\u2019s office to focus specifically on highly mobile students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCurrently, the D.O.E.\u2019s Students in Temporary Housing Program is buried under the vast and varied portfolio of the Deputy Chancellor for Operations,\u201d the report said. \u201cThis arrangement makes it unlikely that students in temporary housing will get the attention or support they need.\u201d", "title": "New York City Is Failing Homeless Students, Reports Say", "authors": ["Elizabeth A. Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "New York City\u2019s subway struggles are not only ever-present \u2014 they appear to be getting worse, according to data that show the system\u2019s on-time performance sinking to a new low in January. Under normal circumstances, this might prompt public servants, seeing the exasperation of their constituents, to act or at least propose changes. Not in New York State government, though. Here, the lawmakers who control the subways through the Metropolitan Transportation Authority continue to twiddle their thumbs.\n\nGov. Andrew Cuomo and state legislators appear to have hit an impasse in their negotiations about a congestion-pricing plan that most experts agree represents the best hope of coming up with the billions of dollars needed to repair and upgrade the subways and regional transit services more broadly. The plan, which would levy fees on private cars, trucks, taxis and other vehicles that use the streets of Manhattan\u2019s central business district during the busiest parts of the day, would also help reduce traffic and air pollution. Cities like London, Singapore and Stockholm have already proved that such systems work. And last summer, after the subway system seemed on the verge of collapse, with derailments and extensive delays becoming increasingly common, Mr. Cuomo got on board, saying that congestion pricing was \u201can idea whose time has come.\u201d\n\nExcept that the idea seems to be stuck on a stalled subway car \u2014 under the East River, with no cellphone service.\n\nLawmakers plan to finish a state budget this week that might not include important elements of the congestion-pricing plan, which were recommended in January by Mr. Cuomo\u2019s Fix NYC panel of experts. This would be a gross dereliction. It would leave New Yorkers suffering through unnecessarily long and unpredictable commutes for years to come. All that waiting and uncertainty will sap the region\u2019s economy at a time when President Trump, a rich New Yorker who has little need or love for transit, is trying his best to hurt New York by, for example, pressuring Congress to not allocate money to important new Hudson rail tunnels.", "title": "Opinion | New York City Subways Are Still Looking for a Savior", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Buying a home in New York City isn\u2019t easy. And not surprisingly, the less money you have to spend, the more difficult it is.\n\nAccording to a study by StreetEasy, buyers searching for homes priced under $1 million face the most competition for those listings, which therefore spend the shortest time on the market, with the fewest price cuts \u2014 and are thus more likely to sell for over the asking price. Those who can afford to pay more than $1 million, on the other hand, can expect more price cuts, on listings that stay on the market longer and have a better chance of selling for below the asking price.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt is a buyer\u2019s market in Manhattan\u2019s more established, expensive neighborhoods and just over the East River in Dumbo, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens, where luxury developments have risen. But farther afield, in more reasonably priced areas, it is a seller\u2019s market.\n\nStreetEasy examined three data points for all the homes listed on its site in 2017 to identify the best buyer\u2019s and seller\u2019s neighborhoods: the share of homes sold below list price; the number of days on the market; and the sale-price-to-list-price ratio, or how much of a discount or premium homes sold for.\n\nThe chart below shows the first two criteria and the median list price for each of the top five buyer\u2019s and seller\u2019s neighborhoods in the city.", "title": "New York City\u2019s Best Buyer\u2019s and Seller\u2019s Neighborhoods", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "But Brooklyn, with a population of 2,648,771, took in more people \u2014 144,071 \u2014 to achieve the highest growth of any county in the state by absolute numbers. Its 5.75 percent jump from 2010 to 2017 was second as a percentage gain.\n\nThe population in Queens climbed 127,860, or 5.73 percent, to 2,358,582, making it second among counties in the state in terms of growth by numbers and third in percentage gains. Manhattan was fourth in the number of newcomers, with 78,854, a 4.97 percent expansion that ranked fifth in percentage terms (behind Rockland County, which grew 5.51 percent with an increase of 17,181 people).\n\nStaten Island added a more modest 10,728 people, a 2.29 percent gain to 479,458.\n\nThe city accounted for 95 percent of the state\u2019s population growth between 2010 and 2017. City demographers noted that the city\u2019s share of the state\u2019s population had edged up 1.2 percentage points, to 43.4 percent last year from 42.2 percent in 2010.\n\nThe demographers say the new figure is an indication of what the next census could find in 2020 and could have ramifications in Albany when legislative districts are redrawn after that. Many parts of upstate New York, particularly urban areas, have been in a chronic state of economic distress as the manufacturing sector has eroded.\n\nBy contrast, 45 of the state\u2019s 62 counties lost population between 2010 and 2017. Three counties upstate \u2014 Chenango, Delaware and Hamilton \u2014 lost more than 5 percent of their population from 2010 to 2017. Another five counties lost more than 4 percent.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Dr. Salvo is concerned that the Trump administration\u2019s approach to immigration could hurt the city in the 2020 census. Of the 4.4 million foreign-born residents in New York State, 3.3 million live in the city, he said. If they are undercounted, he said, \u201cNew York City will be hurt relative to the rest of the state.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe problem with the current environment is it affects more than just the undocumented,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause undocumented immigrants are often in families with legal permanent residents, they\u2019re in families with U.S. citizens and they\u2019re not distinguishing each other by their legal status. What they all have in common is fear. They\u2019re afraid for their relatives, and that might cause people not to respond to the census.\u201d\n\nA federal law protects the confidentiality of the census, stipulating that census responses can be used only for statistical computations by the Census Bureau. An accurate account is vital because, among other factors, it determines how much federal aid flows to local communities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe boom in the Bronx lifted the borough\u2019s population to 1,471,160, so the Bronx has climbed to within a few hundred people of its largest-ever total, 1,471,701 in the 1970 census.\n\nThat head count was taken seven years before \u201cladies and gentleman, the Bronx is burning\u201d became a catchphrase for the borough\u2019s slide into urban despair. Lloyd Ultan, the longtime Bronx borough historian, said \u201cthe final nail in the coffin\u201d was the 1981 film \u201cFort Apache the Bronx.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Bronx gained a reputation as a place with feral people living in rubble and ready to pounce on anybody passing by,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s easy to get a bad reputation. It\u2019s much more difficult to recover from it, but finally, people are discovering what they should have known all along: the desirability of living in the Bronx.\u201d\n\nNow people in some neighborhoods of the Bronx worry that gentrification is pushing people out, even as the de Blasio administration presses for affordable housing, especially in the Jerome Avenue corridor. But there have also been chilling reminders of violence, as on the night last summer when a man fired a .38-caliber revolver into a police command post two miles from Yankee Stadium, killing an officer inside. The gunman\u2019s aunt said he had been released from a hospital a week earlier, after a breakdown.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve always said the Bronx had the ability to bounce back, given its available land and zoning,\u201d Dr. Salvo said.\n\nBut he added: \u201cI\u2019m quite biased.\u201d He lives in the northeast Bronx.", "title": "New York City\u2019s Population Hits a Record 8.6 Million", "authors": ["James Barron"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Janet L. Yellen, the former Fed chairwoman whom Mr. Williams succeeded as president of the San Francisco Fed, called Mr. Williams a leader on the central bank\u2019s policymaking Federal Open Market Committee, known as the F.O.M.C.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a tremendous contributor to the Federal Reserve and the F.O.M.C., and has done influential research on monetary policy,\u201d Ms. Yellen said.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Williams\u2019s possible appointment \u2014 which isn\u2019t yet final and could still change \u2014 drew swift criticism from a variety of Democratic lawmakers, progressive groups and left-leaning economists. They raised concerns about his record as a banking regulator and as a policymaker, and also criticized the search process for a lack of transparency.\n\n\u201cThe New York Fed should go back and restart their search now,\u201d said Andrew Levin, a Dartmouth College economist who spent 20 years at the Fed.\n\nA New York Fed spokesman declined to comment. But in a statement this month, the leaders of the bank\u2019s search committee said they had solicited comment from a variety of groups and had interviewed a range of candidates.\n\nIn recent years, progressive groups have put increasing pressure on the Fed to diversify its leadership and to become more responsive to public concerns about inequality, slow wage growth and other issues that are outside its traditional mandate of ensuring maximum employment and stable prices. The effort has scored some notable victories, including the appointment last year of Raphael W. Bostic in Atlanta as the first African-American president of a regional Fed bank.\n\nMr. Dudley\u2019s announcement last fall that he would step down represented the movement\u2019s greatest opportunity yet. The president of the New York Fed, unique among the heads of the 12 regional banks, has a permanent vote on the F.O.M.C. and serves as the committee\u2019s vice chairman. The New York bank also plays a crucial role in carrying out the Fed\u2019s policies, and in overseeing many of the country\u2019s largest financial institutions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThose pushing for change had reason to hope their voices would be heard. In the past, the selection of Fed presidents has been heavily influenced by the financial institutions that are formally the stockholders of the Fed\u2019s regional banks. But the regulatory overhaul after the financial crisis removed the banks\u2019 representatives from the selection process. One of the two leaders of the search for Mr. Dudley\u2019s successor is Sara Horowitz, who runs the Freelancers Union, a labor organization. The other, Glenn Hutchins, is a private equity investor.\n\nIn early March, several dozen protesters marched to the New York Fed\u2019s headquarters in Lower Manhattan to demand an appointee representing workers\u2019 interests. Standing outside the Fed\u2019s imposing stone building on Maiden Lane, Shawn Sebastian, director of the Fed Up campaign, which seeks to make the central bank more responsive to labor concerns, said the board could \u201cmake history\u201d by appointing someone without Wall Street ties.\n\n\u201cThe New York Fed president is the most powerful person in the country that Donald Trump does not get to pick,\u201d Mr. Sebastian shouted to the crowd.\n\nMr. Williams would meet such demands in certain respects. He has spent nearly his entire career inside the Federal Reserve system and, unlike Mr. Dudley, the former chief economist for Goldman Sachs, he has never worked in the finance industry.\n\nBut Mr. Williams does not have extensive regulatory expertise, and the experience he does have may not help him. He was president of the San Francisco Fed while Wells Fargo, which is based in San Francisco and is partly under the local Fed\u2019s supervision, engaged in aggressive sales practices that resulted in the opening of millions of accounts without customers\u2019 knowledge.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement Monday, Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, said Mr. Williams\u2019s record in San Francisco \u201craises several questions, including about his fitness to supervise Wall Street banks.\u201d She said the Fed\u2019s Board of Governors, which must approve appointments, shouldn\u2019t do so for Mr. Williams unless he testifies before the Senate Banking Committee, which has no formal role in the selection process.\n\nFed insiders said Mr. Williams played at most a limited role in the supervision of Wells Fargo, which is primarily overseen by regulators in Washington. Bank supervision would be a much bigger part of his job if he moved to New York. But Donald Kohn, who served as vice chairman of the Fed\u2019s Board of Governors during the financial crisis, said Mr. Williams would hardly be the first president without substantial regulatory experience. Mr. Dudley\u2019s predecessor, Timothy F. Geithner, for example, served in a variety of government roles before joining the Fed, but had never supervised banks.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s been sitting in all these Open Market Committee meetings where increasingly financial stability issues are being talked about,\u201d Mr. Kohn said of Mr. Williams.\n\nBut critics said selecting Mr. Williams would be a missed opportunity to bring in a new perspective. In a commentary for Bloomberg View on Monday that never mentioned Mr. Williams, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, noted that the New York Fed has never had a woman or a person of color as its leader.\n\n\u201cIf we\u2019re serious about creating an inclusive and sustainable economy, no one should be left on the sidelines,\u201d Mr. Booker wrote.", "title": "New York Fed Weighs a Wall Street Overseer, and Left Spies an Opening", "authors": ["Ben Casselman"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "That ruling was grounded in a revolutionary string of rulings by the United States Supreme Court, all of which have found that young people are \u201cconstitutionally different\u201d from adults \u2014 their brains are still developing, their impulse control is weaker and their ability to change over time is greater. This means that they are less guilty than adults and that their punishment must be different, especially in the case of life sentences for those convicted of murder. The \u201cimposition of a state\u2019s most severe penalties on juvenile offenders cannot proceed as though they were not children,\u201d the court said in 2012. They must be given \u201ca meaningful opportunity\u201d to get out; actual life sentences should be reserved for those few who exhibit \u201cirretrievable depravity.\u201d\n\nWhile those rulings have struck down the most severe sentences for juveniles \u2014 the death penalty and mandatory life without parole \u2014 the New York appeals court rightly extended their logic to cases in which parole is technically available but is rarely or never granted. \u201cA parole board is no more entitled to subject an offender to the penalty of life in prison in contravention of this rule than is a legislature or a sentencing court,\u201d the state court said.\n\nThat\u2019s right, of course, but it should go further. Parole officials should, as a rule, expect to release juvenile offenders who have served their minimum sentences. If the board has evidence that an inmate continues to pose a threat to the public, it\u2019s reasonable to keep him or her locked up, but the inmate should still get future chances to show that he or she is ready to return to society.\n\nIn response to the state court\u2019s ruling, New York\u2019s Parole Board said last summer that it would start considering an inmates\u2019 youth when deciding whether to release that inmate, but it still regularly rejects people like Mr. Flores, whom no one would describe as \u201cirretrievably depraved.\u201d On Tuesday, Mr. Flores filed a federal class-action lawsuit against the Parole Board, claiming that its knee-jerk denials of applications by inmates like him violate the Constitution. New York holds roughly 630 prisoners on indeterminate life sentences for crimes they committed before they turned 18.\n\nNew York\u2019s Parole Board has long resisted modern understandings of crime and punishment, but the failure to treat juveniles as a unique category of offender exists nationwide. A 2016 report by the American Civil Liberties Union found that in just 12 states, more than 8,300 inmates were serving sentences of effective life \u2014 meaning 40 years or more \u2014 for crimes they had committed as juveniles. In Florida in 2015, 366 people were serving juvenile life sentences. Two were granted parole. And as in the rest of the justice system, race matters a great deal when it comes to who gets harsh juvenile sentences. A study of juvenile transfers to adult courts found that black juveniles were nearly two and a half times as likely as white juveniles to be tried as adults even when controlling for factors like prior records and seriousness of the offense.", "title": "Opinion | New York Forgets Its Juvenile Lifers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Republican consultants argue that Ms. Nixon\u2019s entry into the race will help their party\u2019s candidates in several ways, pushing Mr. Cuomo to the left \u2014 he\u2019s considered a centrist by most political observers, and dismissed as one by Ms. Nixon \u2014 as well as scuffing him up on a variety of issues, including his handling of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.\n\nMr. Cuomo will have to spend money, they argue, dipping into a formidable $30 million war chest. And Ms. Nixon has already signaled that she will use the age-old Albany issue of corruption \u2014 including the recent conviction of Joseph Percoco, formerly one of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s closest aides and friends \u2014 to batter his stewardship of state government.\n\nThere\u2019s also, they say, an even more tantalizing possibility.\n\n\u201cEither he\u2019ll come out battered,\u201d said William F. B. O\u2019Reilly, an adviser for Mr. DeFrancisco\u2019s campaign, \u201cor she\u2019ll win.\u201d\n\nThe Republicans would no doubt welcome a Nixon victory; the party currently has two declared candidates, an understated candidate who may well be the front-runner, and a renegade running as an independent who wants to legalize marijuana.\n\nMr. DeFrancisco\u2019s principal opponent at this point is Marcus J. Molinaro, the Dutchess County executive, who has been quietly amassing \u2014 and then loudly publicizing \u2014 endorsements from a variety of county chairmen and other political groups around the state. He has made no secret of his intention to run for governor, and is positioning himself as a youthful, energetic alternative to Mr. Cuomo (and Mr. DeFrancisco, for that matter).\n\n\u201cI am deeply humbled by the challenge,\u201d he said, in a March 14 email saying he would run. \u201cBut my determination is driven by the need.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe only thing he has not done is actually formally kick off his campaign, preferring to largely wage the race thus far through news releases and closed-door meetings with Republican decision makers. Nonetheless, Mr. Molinaro, 42, has assumed the posture of the prohibitive favorite, going so far as to issue another email in mid-March announcing he had secured the endorsements of 50 percent of the necessary delegates to secure the nomination when the party meets later this spring.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Molinaro is to formally begin his campaign on April 2, likely in Tivoli, N.Y., where, in 1995, he became the youngest mayor in the United States at 19, according to his old Dutchess County campaign website.\n\nBut the DeFrancisco camp notes that they have a far more substantial bankroll at this point \u2014 some $1.5 million \u2014 and a willingness to stay in the race until the convention. They also have questioned their opponent\u2019s strategy of rolling out electronic endorsements, and have said they will \u201ckeep their powder dry,\u201d and their costs down, until Mr. Molinaro starts to fight for the nomination in person.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
