View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a bizarre situation,\u201d Mr. O\u2019Reilly said. \u201cHe\u2019s not on the campaign trail.\u201d\n\nThe state Republican convention, where a nominee will be selected, is scheduled for May.\n\nKaty Delgado, a spokeswoman for Mr. Molinaro\u2019s campaign, countered that Mr. Molinaro has \u201cspent the last two years crisscrossing New York and has spent his entire professional life in the public eye.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe is already well known to many voters, which is why they support his candidacy,\u201d she added.\n\nNo matter which Republican emerges as the candidate, E. O\u2019Brien Murray, a Republican consultant, predicted that Ms. Nixon \u201cwould distract Andrew Cuomo and makes him spend resources of time and money on the race.\u201d\n\nThe governor\u2019s supporters dismiss the notion that Ms. Nixon could do damage to Mr. Cuomo, citing a raft of progressive accomplishments, including raising the minimum wage, a paid family leave program and the legalization of same-sex marriage. They also point out that Republicans had high hopes that a previous, and surprisingly strong, primary challenge \u2014 from a little-known law professor, Zephyr Teachout, in 2014 \u2014 would also weaken Mr. Cuomo. But he handily won re-election that year over Rob Astorino.\n\nThe governor\u2019s campaign seemingly is not paying Ms. Nixon, or potential Republican candidates, any mind.\n\n\u201cWhile Trump and Washington Republicans threaten to divide this country and take us backwards, Governor Cuomo\u2019s sole focus this year is on turning red districts blue to help win back the House and elect more Democrats to the State Senate,\u201d said Austin Shafran, a campaign spokesman.\n\nThe recent optimism in Republican ranks comes after several months of gloomy developments, beginning in November when Mr. Astorino, the party\u2019s 2014 nominee, lost his bid for re-election as Westchester County executive and promptly announced that he would not run against Mr. Cuomo again, disappointing party leaders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn New Year\u2019s Day, another putative candidate, the millionaire Harry Wilson, also demurred. Mr. DeFrancisco entered the race in late January, but Assemblyman Brian Kolb, an upstate Republican who serves as minority leader, dropped out.\n\nAnother candidate, Joel Giambra, the former Erie County executive, bolted the Republican primary process to run as an independent, and now wants to legalize cannabis to help pay for state programs. Joseph Holland, a former housing official under Mr. Pataki, also is vying for the bid, though he is little known.\n\nStill, nothing has seemingly excited the G.O.P. more than Ms. Nixon\u2019s entrance.\n\n\u201cThe race for governor is going Hollywood,\u201d Mr. Molinaro\u2019s campaign said on Monday, shortly after Ms. Nixon announced her plans to run. \u201cAnd our chances to win in November just got a whole lot better.\u201d", "title": "New York G.O.P.\u2019s Hopes Are Raised by Nixon. (Cynthia, That Is.)", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The city\u2019s education department comes to him for the data it uses to redraw school zones, he said, as does the health department when it needs to understand illness rates. Businesses use federal information to determine whether to open in underserved neighborhoods.\n\nThere are now 3.2 million foreign-born people in New York City, out of 8.6 million residents. Of those foreign-born, 46 percent are noncitizens, Mr. Salvo said. Mr. Salvo estimates that 500,000 are undocumented.\n\n\u201cThose immigrants are side by side with children who are citizens, with an uncle who is a legal permanent resident, with the cousin who is undocumented. All of those people are afraid,\u201d Mr. Salvo said.\n\nThe Trump administration said on Monday that the question on citizenship would be added to the census, saying it would enable the Justice Department to accurately measure the portion of the population eligible to vote.\n\nOn Wednesday, the New York Immigration Coalition, an activist group, announced its New York Counts 2020 campaign alongside congressional and local elected officials. The effort has three prongs: to fight the question; to pressure the United States Census Bureau to protect the information of all New Yorkers; and to reassure residents that they can safely respond.\n\nAt the news conference, Nydia Vel\u00e1zquez, a Democrat representing Queens, Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan, said she is co-sponsoring legislation in the House of Representatives that will require the Commerce Department to provide advance notice to Congress before changing questions on the census. Representative Grace Meng, a Democrat from Queens who sits on the committee that funds the census bureau, said she and her colleagues are considering withholding funds for 2019 unless the question is removed.\n\nIn a public hearing last week before the question was added, Ms. Meng confronted the Secretary of Commerce, Wilbur Ross, whose department oversees the U.S. Census Bureau. \u201cI told him directly that this is about accuracy; this is mandated by the Constitution to count every living person.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNew York Mayor Bill de Blasio said that he would join the multistate lawsuit brought by the state\u2019s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, against the Trump administration, to try to block the question from being included.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the last census count, in 2010, the city\u2019s response rate was 62 percent, but some heavily immigrant communities, like Washington Heights and the South Bronx, exceeded that, with more than 70 percent of residents answering the census questionnaires.\n\nAdriano Espaillat, a Democrat who in 2010 was representing Washington Heights and Harlem in the State Assembly, said that was in part because of a robust effort by volunteers to convince residents their participation counted. Mr. Espaillat, who is now in Congress, said he could not yet encourage undocumented residents to take part.\n\n\u201cI want to fight this question back, first,\u201d he said. \u201cIf not in Congress, then in the courts. If at the end of this the question remains, then we\u2019re going to have to come together to decide the messaging.\u201d\n\nNew York Democrats in Congress worry that an undercount could cause the state to lose seats. After the 2010 census, which the city challenged because it claimed that 50,000 residents were not counted, New York forfeited two seats, in part because of a loss of population upstate. That trend could hold for 2020.\n\nAndrew Reamer, a professor at George Washington University\u2019s Institute of Public Policy, who recently published a study on the 2020 census, said that the census reaches the most fundamental areas of life in the United States: government representation, democracy and the economy.\n\n\u201cThe census data is like the electrical system,\u201d Professor Reamer said. \u201cIt reaches everywhere in ways that are not readily seen.\u201d\n\nFor New York, inaccurate numbers could have effects as small as a serving at lunch. \u201cThe Asian-American community is the fastest growing senior population in the city,\u201d said Howard Shih, the director of research and policy for the Asian-American Federation in New York. Census figures, he said, could determine something as mundane, but essential, as how much food a senior center would need to order to accommodate this population.\n\nThe data compiled once a decade serves as the basis of comparison for smaller, sample surveys compiled annually.\n\n\u201cAnything that affects the propensity of people to answer the census is of concern to us,\u201d said Mr. Salvo, the demographer. \u201cThe Census Bureau\u2019s first priority should always be maximum response. Anything they do to compromise that, frankly, works against their main mission.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Census Bureau,\u201d he said, \u201ccreates reality.\u201d", "title": "New York Has 7 Billion Reasons to Worry About a Census Question", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "A New York City police officer was charged on Friday with public lewdness and exposing himself to five female officers while he was on duty.\n\nAccording to an indictment announced by the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office, the officer, Anthony Avosso, 31, exposed himself on three occasions to one of the female officers between September and last month while they were alone in an office at the 60th Precinct station house in Coney Island, where both were assigned to a plainclothes unit.\n\nOn Feb. 15, during the most recent encounter, the female officer, called Officer Avosso \u201ca pervert,\u201d prosecutors said. The next day, she filed a complaint with her union, the Patrolmen\u2019s Benevolent Association, prompting an investigation by the Police Department\u2019s Internal Affairs Bureau.\n\nProsecutors said that the inquiry revealed that Officer Avosso, a 10-year veteran of the force, had exposed himself to four other female officers at the station house, most of whom were his subordinates. Prosecutors said his conduct had created a treacherous work environment in what was already a predominantly male workplace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one incident, prosecutors said, Officer Avosso showed his genitals to a probationary female officer, who was just out of the Police Academy, while asking her about her goals in the department. In another, over the summer, he did the same to a female officer on the F train as the two were riding from the district attorney\u2019s office in Downtown Brooklyn back to the 60th Precinct station house.", "title": "New York Officer Is Accused of Exposing Himself to Female Colleagues", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Several lawmakers also lamented the lack of transparency in the negotiation process, which did not include public hearings.\n\nSenator Liz Krueger, a Democrat from Manhattan who has been vocal about the need for stricter policies, equivocated in her support, calling the bill \u201ca really good try.\u201d\n\nStill, the bill passed the Senate unanimously, and an identical version passed the Assembly. It will go to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is expected to sign it into law.\n\nThe bill will cover both the public and private sectors, requiring employers to develop anti-harassment policies and training and barring the state from awarding bids to any company that failed to comply. It would also extend protections to independent contractors who might not be defined as employees. The new policies allow for publicly-funded payouts for substantiated claims of harassment against state employees, but would require them to reimburse the government within 90 days.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe bill does not, however, address settlements in which there is no formal finding of liability. In 2015, the state paid $545,000 to settle harassment claims related to a former assemblyman from Brooklyn, Vito Lopez.\n\nThe bill also does not address longstanding criticisms of the Joint Commission on Public Ethics, a committee made up in large part by members appointed by the governor. The group is investigating several high-profile harassment claims but has often been called toothless. Mr. Cuomo had suggested creating a new arm within the commission specifically to investigate harassment complaints, but Ms. Young said on Friday that it was unclear where that proposal stood, or if there would be money available to pay for it.\n\nMs. Young conceded that the wording of the new policies would not necessarily cover other forms of gender-based harassment, such as inappropriate comments. But she defended the need for a flexible definition of harassment, citing how quickly understandings of acceptable behavior have evolved in recent months in the wake of the #MeToo movement.\n\nA stricter sexual harassment policy was one of just a few policy issues to be included in the budget talks. New York\u2019s push mirrored those in many other state legislatures: 29 states have introduced new sexual harassment bills in 2018, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, which called the number of proposals \u201cunprecedented.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in Albany, as usual, policy quickly became inextricable from politics.\n\nWhile lawmakers in both parties, as well as Mr. Cuomo, had agreed in principle on the need to formulate new policy \u2014 a rare point of consensus in the Capitol \u2014 the actual negotiations turned out to be anything but unifying.\n\nWomen\u2019s rights advocates denounced Albany\u2019s secretive model of budget negotiations, which they said would allow the new policies to be hammered out by \u201cfour men in a room\u201d: Mr. Cuomo and three legislative leaders, including Senator Jeffrey D. Klein \u2014 who was accused in January of forcibly kissing a former staffer, Erica Vladimer.\n\nSenate Democrats, who are a minority in the chamber, denounced their exclusion from the closed-door negotiations, which came after the governor\u2019s office said in February that their conference leader, Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins of Westchester, would be included in discussions.\n\nOn Wednesday, asked why Ms. Stewart-Cousins had not been privy to the leaders\u2019 meetings, Mr. Cuomo told reporters that the new policies were being formulated not by the four men but by a \u201cworking group\u201d for which Senate Democrats had been invited to provide input. But Ms. Stewart-Cousins said no such group existed.", "title": "New York Rewrites Harassment Laws, but Some Say the Changes Fall Short", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it would send information on its storm preparations later on Tuesday, but did not anticipate Tuesday evening\u2019s commute to be affected.\n\nAlternate-side parking will be suspended Wednesday and Thursday in the city. Mr. de Blasio said he instructed the city\u2019s sanitation department to move to 12-hour shifts for the storm. A \u201ccode blue\u201d is also in effect for the homeless in New York City, greatly expanding their shelter options.\n\nNew Jersey Transit announced that it would run a limited weekday rail schedule on Wednesday, and that it would be cross-honoring tickets across rail, bus, light rail and PATH services. Buses and light rail lines in New Jersey were expected to operate on regular schedules as long as conditions permit, though officials also indicated it was possible that all bus routes would be suspended for Wednesday evening\u2019s commute.\n\nThe National Weather Service said \u201cminor to moderate coastal flooding\u201d was likely for vulnerable areas of Long Island and New Jersey, and it predicted rough surf along the shore.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAirlines have started canceling flights, with the most cancellations in and out of Philadelphia International Airport. Carriers including American Airlines, Delta and United have started to waive change fees for anyone scheduled to fly Tuesday or Wednesday.\n\nThe storm comes just as many in the region have finally dug out from two punishing early March nor\u2019easters \u2014 the second one left two people dead and thousands of households in New Jersey and the suburbs north of New York City without power for days as utility companies came under scrutiny for their response.\n\nGov. Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat of New Jersey, speaking Tuesday at the train station in Madison, said he was closely monitoring the storm, and was considering declaring a state of emergency to begin around midnight should the forecasts hold fast.\n\n\u201cOur concerns have somewhat intensified,\u201d said Mr. Murphy, adding that the snow accumulation was unlikely to begin until early Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAddressing what he called the \u201cthe biggest shortfalls\u201d of the last storm, Mr. Murphy said that one of the state\u2019s much-maligned utility companies \u2014 Jersey Central Power and Light \u2014 had activated 800 workers to respond to the storm, and that all of the utility companies had activated their mutual aid agreements, meaning that they would share resources in response to outages.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been in touch with them all day,\u201d Mr. Murphy said of the utility companies. He noted that the state Board of Public Utilities was also \u201ccenter stage\u201d in planning for the storm.\n\nThe storm\u2019s potential for heavy snow, in addition to gusty winds, could lead to a repeat of the downed power lines from the last storm, Mr. Murphy warned as he urged residents to take precautions.\n\n\u201cPlease do not head out into the snow unless you absolutely have to,\u201d he said.", "title": "New York Schools Close as Region Braces for Major Snowstorm", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m not happy about it, I\u2019m not proud of it,\u201d said Andy Byford, who took over in mid-January as president of New York City Transit, which runs the subway and public buses. But he added that, based on 29 years of working on and running transit systems, \u201cYou need to look at the long-term game.\u201d\n\nMr. Byford pointed out that subway performance improved in February, though it has struggled again in March with back-to-back storms. Although on-time arrival statistics for February are not yet available, there were 56 major incidents that disrupted weekday service that month, compared with 105 incidents in January.\n\nMr. Byford also said he would review longtime safety regulations that restrict the speed of trains when they are approaching signals with timers, which some transit advocates have said may be unnecessary in some cases and slow down the system too much.\n\nEven before the latest problems, the New York City subway system had one of the worst records for on-time performance among the nation\u2019s cities, though it is by far the biggest system. For instance, in January, on-time performance was 85.7 percent for Washington\u2019s Metro system, 95 percent for Chicago\u2019s L-train system and 96.7 percent for Atlanta\u2019s Marta rail system.\n\nGov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared a state of emergency for the city\u2019s subway system last year and has helped promote an $800 million emergency rescue plan. But the continuing delays and breakdowns have exasperated many riders. On Monday, the actress Cynthia Nixon officially announced that she would challenge Mr. Cuomo to be the Democratic nominee in November\u2019s election for governor, making the subway one of her priorities.\n\nJohn Raskin, the executive director of the Riders Alliance, an advocacy group, said Mr. Cuomo had not made much progress in fixing the subways. \u201cWe\u2019ve seen what the governor can do when he prioritizes an issue, and it\u2019s time for the transit system to merit that intensity of focus,\u201d Mr. Raskin said. \u201cThe subway system is at the breaking point, and honestly, subway riders are too.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Raskin added that the governor and state lawmakers needed to pass a congestion plan for Manhattan, which would charge drivers for driving into Manhattan at peak traffic hours to help fund the subway system.\n\nIn January, there were 76,287 delayed weekday trains, up from 60,455 the year before, according to the new report. Of those, 27,249 were the result of overcrowding or insufficient capacity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition, there were 18,931 delayed weekend trains, up from 14,182 the year before.\n\nBlaming overcrowding for delays has become contentious after an investigation by The New York Times in December found that officials had been citing that to mask delays caused by breakdowns or signal problems that forced people onto fewer trains. Mr. Byford has acknowledged that overcrowding is not a meaningful measurement and that officials need to provide more specific information.\n\nM.T.A. officials said that January was particularly hard on the subway system because of a two-day snowstorm early in the month that blanketed the city, and extreme swings in temperature from cold to warm during the month that caused snow to melt faster and seep into equipment. Also, trains were stored on some express tracks instead of outside in yards to protect them from the cold, but that resulted in some delays in service while they were moved out of the way. In addition, a burst water pipe knocked out service to many trains at the subway station at Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street in Manhattan.\n\nWhile there are other indicators of subway performance besides on-time arrivals, many advocates and others say that it remains an important measure because consistent delays can mean fewer trains and more crowding.\n\nStill, Bill Henderson, executive director of a citizen\u2019s advisory committee to the M.T.A., said that he was not overly concerned based on January\u2019s performance alone. \u201cOne exceptional month would not necessarily trigger an alarm for me,\u201d he said.\n\nSeveral subway riders said they felt that train service was improving. Matt Albala, 29, a brokerage manager who takes the subway three or four times a day, said he had been delayed only once or twice in the past month. \u201cThat\u2019s pretty good, I think,\u201d he said. \u201cBefore, I would get delayed 5 or 10 minutes here and there, and that doesn\u2019t happen much anymore.\u201d\n\nBut many other subway riders said the subways were still making them late as they tried to get to work, go home or just get around the city.\n\nHorace Medley, 34, a contractor from Canarsie, Brooklyn, said that in his experience, the 4 train is delayed by 15 to 20 minutes almost every day when he takes it going home. \u201cIt makes you upset,\u201d he said. \u201cThey keep on raising the fare, and the service is not getting any better.\u201d", "title": "New York Subway\u2019s On-Time Performance Hits New Low", "authors": ["Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "There could also be thundersnow.\n\nThis is the fourth nor\u2019easter in the last three weeks, and it has the potential to drop the most snow this month in the area. Their job: track down bedbugs with their highly trained noses.\n\nWe met Nemo yesterday after he was picked up from Biscuits and Bath on the Upper East Side, where he lives, and before he and his handler of six years, David Trevino, headed out for their first inspection of the week.\n\nThe canine unit is dispatched to city apartments after a resident complains to 311 about a possible infestation.\n\nOnce Nemo arrives, and after a few belly rubs from adoring children, he gets to work with the command: \u201cFind the bugs!\u201d\n\nHe\u2019s trained to pick up the scent of bedbugs, and only bedbugs, and he scours headboards, couches and corners for the little bloodsucking critters. If he finds them, he sits down.\n\n\u201cThen I say, \u2018Show me, show me,\u2019 \u201d Mr. Trevino said, \u201cand he indicates the location of the bugs with his nose.\u201d\n\nHis reward? A Bil-Jac chicken liver treat.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s accurate about 80 percent of the time,\u201d Mr. Trevino said, a hit rate that has led some in the past to complain about using dogs to inspect for insects.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Trevino defended his co-worker. Instead of exploring an entire apartment, he said, the dogs help him narrow his search.\n\nAnd they are fast. An inspection takes about 20 minutes, or a matter of seconds if it\u2019s a full-blown infestation.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s when the dog walks in and is like, \u2018Whoa,\u2019\u201d he said, mimicking Nemo by throwing his head back and crinkling his nose. \u201cHe\u2019ll look at me like, \u2018What do you need me for?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe number of bedbug complaints dropped last year to 8,113, from 9,618 in 2016, but the dogs are still used for about 10 inspections a day. The pair recently hit a milestone, completing more than 25,000 inspections in the six years they have worked for the housing department.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve gotten better over time,\u201d Mr. Trevino said. \u201cThey\u2019ve been doing it for so long, it\u2019s in their blood.\u201d\n\nWe asked a housing department spokesman if Nemo (age 8) and Mickey (age 7), who have each worked on the force for 44 dog years, had any plans to retire.\n\nNo, the spokesman wrote in an email. \u201cThey are in the prime of their careers.\u201d\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? (Good morning everyone.)\n\nPassover begins tonight, and if you\u2019re picking up supplies for your Seder, we thought you should know: There is such a thing as matzo hierarchy.\n\n\u201cThe top is handmade shmurah matzo, then there is machine-made shmurah matzo, and after that is regular machine-made matzo,\u201d according to Rabbi Motti Seligson, a spokesman for Chabad-Lubavitch.\n\n(There\u2019s room for debate; ask tonight\u2019s Seder guests their matzo preferences or the best way to eat it, and you\u2019ll be there until Easter Sunday.)\n\nPassover commemorates Jewish liberation from slavery in Egypt, and matzo represents a sliver of that Exodus \u2014 the Jews fled so quickly, the Torah tells us, that there was no time for their bread to rise. For that reason, observers refrain from eating bread (and other leavened goods, chametz) during the holiday.", "title": "New York Today: A Lesson on the Matzo Ladder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 New Jersey Transit has told commuters to leave New York as early as possible. Service is suspended on the Gladstone and Montclair Boonton train lines in both directions; on the Morris & Essex line between Dover to Summit; and on the Atlantic City rail line between Philadelphia 30th St. and Atlantic City. Tickets are being cross-honored for rail, buses and private carriers. New Jersey Transit bus service is suspended on all routes.\n\n\u2022 Long Island Rail Road: Oyster Bay, Port Jefferson, Ronkonkoma, Hempstead, Babylon and Montauk branches are suspended. Customers are being advised to delay traveling.\n\n\u2022 Metro-North Railroad is running on a reduced schedule. Service is suspended on the New Canaan Branch line and New Haven line. After 8 p.m., service will be hourly on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines. Expect delays of up to 45 minutes on some lines.\n\n\u2022 Bridges and tunnels are open, but the Outerbridge Crossing is closed in both directions because of falling ice.\n\n\u2022 Ferries: Seastreak ferries are running on a modified schedule. NYC Ferry service is suspended on all routes.\n\n\u2022 Amtrak is operating on a modified schedule in the Northeast Corridor. Expect delays.\n\n\u2022 Airports: Check your flight at La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark before you head to the airport. Nearly 1,800 flights have been canceled at the three airports so far.\n\n\u2022 Roads: A travel advisory is in effect for all areas east of Interstate 81, essentially, the entire eastern half of New York State.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor updates on how the storm is affecting the entire Northeast, read The Times\u2019s live briefing.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow that you know how to get home, we\u2019d like to know: Did you hear the thundersnow today?\n\nAs predicted, New Yorkers were treated to the somewhat rare phenomenon, characterized by lighting and thunder during a snowstorm.\n\nIt appears, we\u2019re told, when cold air settles above warmer, moist air on the ground.\n\nThis imbalance can create a strong vertical draft of air, which can cause lightning followed by a clap of thunder, said Patrick Maloit, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service. It also produces more snow.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the same reason you get stronger rain in a thunderstorm,\u201d Mr. Maloit said. The vertical drafts move precipitation into the clouds more efficiently and \u201ceventually the cloud won\u2019t be able to support the precipitation and it will come down.\u201d\n\nHere's what it sounds like.\n\nWe\u2019ll keep you updated on the storm throughout the evening commute.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 A Yale college student was found not guilty of rape, in one of the few campus sex assault cases to be tried in court. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 After news broke that the actress Cynthia Nixon might run for governor, Andrew M. Cuomo denigrated her as a second-tier celebrity who had been egged on by Mayor Bill de Blasio. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 New York City appointed its first nightlife mayor. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 If your Uber cost an extra $50, would you still take it? [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The jury in the trial of Joseph Percoco said it couldn\u2019t reach a decision. The judge told them to try again. [New York Times]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 A man who was seriously injured in a Bronx hospital shooting last year is calling for an end to sales of AR-15 rifles. [New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Hearing testimony in the murder trial of an Upper West Side nanny was grisly enough, but now crime-scene photos have emerged. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 After two children were killed at an intersection in Brooklyn, people are asking the mayor to make changes that can better control traffic. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A federal judge in Brooklyn says if Martin Shkreli can\u2019t pay back the money he made from committing fraud, the government would confiscate his one-of-a-kind Wu-Tang Clan album. [New York Times]\n\n\u2022 This photo album presents you with an uncommon sight: an Orthodox Jewish community in vibrant color, and partying hard. [New York Times]\n\nAnd Finally...\n\nPhoto\n\nWe love a good snow day.\n\nAs the need to go out into the world melts away, so do its distractions.\n\nCooking can be the evening\u2019s entertainment.\n\nBinge-watching feels not only guilt-free, but necessary.\n\nAnd we finally get to make time for our favorite snowstorm activity: doing nothing at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut we\u2019d like to know about your snowy weather rituals. What are your favorite activities during a snowstorm, either indoors or outside?\n\nTell us at nytoday@nytimes.com. Please include your full name, age and the neighborhood or city in which you live. We may include your response in an upcoming New York Today column.\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Post a comment, email us at nytoday@nytimes.com, or reach us via Twitter using #NYToday.\n\nFollow the New York Today columnists, Alexandra Levine and Jonathan Wolfe, on Twitter.\n\nYou can find the latest New York Today at nytoday.com.", "title": "New York Today: A Snowy Evening Commute", "authors": ["Jonathan Wolfe", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The reality was quite the opposite.\n\nWe met a lively bunch of strangers, ranging from young adults to octogenarians, most of whom were not grieving at all; they had, instead, come for an intellectually stimulating, if at times uncomfortable, discussion.\n\n\u201cDeath cafes are a kind of beautiful rehearsal for coming closer to death and understanding it and grappling with it, so that when we do have a death pending in our families, as is inevitable, we might be a little more prepared for it and slightly less rattled,\u201d said the funeral director and death educator Amy Cunningham, who facilitated the get-together.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no agenda \u2014 nothing is sold or prompted \u2014 so it can go in all kinds of interesting directions in a totally natural way,\u201d she said.\n\nBetween sugar cookies and laughs, our group jumped from religion to social media to psychotropic drugs to contemporary ethics.\n\n\u201cCan you be buried with your pet?\u201d one woman, a documentary photographer, asked the group, following it up with a conversation on approaching death from a nonreligious perspective.\n\n\u201cHow do you handle the loss of an estranged family member?\u201d another wondered, prompting a third \u2014 who had lost a relative the week before \u2014 to speak about the death of her distant father.\n\nShe and her husband then debated the pros and cons of learning of a death through Facebook. Several minutes later, he told the group a separate story about the deathlike \u201cstatic peace\u201d he felt while tripping on the drug DMT.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n(My contribution to the discussion: sharing how self-conscious I feel about what to say or do at funerals.)\n\n\u201cAs frightening as it may seem,\u201d Ms. Cunningham said that night, \u201cthere are many amazing things that can occur and ways to grow and carry grief through the next chapters of your life, and this is the way we evolve \u2014 through moments that seem so painful but then have hidden miracles of ecstasy.\u201d\n\nGreen-Wood will host its next death cafe on April 10, and you can learn more through Death Caf\u00e9 New York City or the Death Lab at Columbia University.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nAnother radiant day with a high around 50 \u2014 though it may feel nippy for your morning commute.\n\nThe rest of the week is looking warmer but wetter.\n\nAnd \u2014 oh my! \u2014 April is days away. Schwarzman Building of the New York Public Library spotlights religious texts, manuscripts and archaeological photographs central to each.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe CUNY Graduate Center examines the modern practices of Jews, Christians and Muslims in their common holy places \u2014 including Bethlehem, Ephesus, Hebron and Istanbul \u2014 using contemporary art.\n\nAnd on display at the Morgan Library & Museum is the Morgan Picture Bible, a 13th-century illustrated Old Testament, which was created across civilizations, languages and cultures, revealing common threads in the Torah, the Bible and the Quran.\n\nThe exhibition opens Tuesday; on Wednesday, you can join three religious leaders \u2014 Sheikh Khaled Bentoun\u00e8s, Rabbi Rolando Matalon and the scholar and minister Cl\u00e1udio Carvalhaes \u2014 at the New York Public Library for a conversation on tolerance and traditions. A high wind warning remains in effect through Saturday.\n\nWinds that strong can blow down trees and power lines, so power failures are possible and getting around may be difficult. It\u2019s the calm before the storm.\n\n\n\nGet ready for another whack of winter.\n\nAn approaching nor\u2019easter is threatening to dump up to a foot of snow on the city and parts of New Jersey, and up to 15 inches in Westchester, even as the region is still reeling from last week\u2019s winter storm.\n\nMost of the snowfall and dangerous travel conditions will occur on Wednesday, according to the National Weather Service. A winter storm warning goes into effect at midnight tonight and will remain in place until Thursday morning.\n\nAt least eight people died and more than two million people were left without power after a \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d slammed into the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast on Friday. Here in New York, trains halted, more than 400 flights were delayed or canceled, and 132,000 customers were left without power, according to Con Edison.", "title": "New York Today: Another Nor\u2019easter Approaches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Happy Friday! It\u2019s cloudy above and slushy below. Get ready to spring forward. We lose an hour of sleep on Sunday thanks to daylight saving time.\n\nA rabble-rousing turkey. A naughty clergyman. A combative leprechaun.\n\nAs college basketball players compete this weekend for fame and glory at the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament in Brooklyn and the Big East tournament in Midtown Manhattan, a group of athletes alongside them will end the season in complete anonymity: the mascots.\n\nSure, they rile crowds, needle opponents and channel a game\u2019s emotional thrust into abstract, wordless performances for thousands of fans. But often, the people inside the suits must hide their true identities from even their closest friends.\n\nWe contacted a few of the current and former mascots at the tournaments, and after some serious journalistic negotiating, they agreed to go on the record about life behind the mask.", "title": "New York Today: Beneath the Big Foam Head", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 9:30 a.m.\n\nGood morning on this gray Wednesday.\n\nThe National Cherry Blossom Festival is again making our country\u2019s capital blush.\n\nWhich got us wondering \u2014 is there an official flower for New York City?\n\nThe state flower has long been the rose. A decade ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg named the city flower the daffodil, widely used to commemorate the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. Before that, there were official borough flowers \u2014 the tulip and rose for Queens, the pinkster azalea for Staten Island, the yellow forsythia for Brooklyn and the day lily for the Bronx. Manhattan did not have one.\n\nBut with spring flora beginning to blossom, we thought it was a perfect time to nominate a new city bloom. We asked some local flower experts to weigh in.\n\nNative witch hazel, said Scot Medbury, president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.\n\nThe city flower would have to be resilient enough to handle the roller coaster that is winter in New York, Mr. Medbury told us.", "title": "New York Today: City in Bloom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 The streets are sludgy. The Sanitation Department has dispatched nearly 1,600 plows since the start of the storm. You can see which streets were plowed, and when, with their plow tracker.\n\n\u2022 Alternate-side parking rules are suspended for snow removal. Meters remain in effect.\n\nPhoto\n\nWith 12 to 18 inches of snow in the forecast, the nor\u2019easter was expected to break the record for the largest spring snowstorm in our history. The previous record, of 10 inches, was set on April 3, 1915. A little after midnight, the ruler in Central Park read 8.2.\n\nYour snow-shoveling experience may vary. The snow fell unevenly, dropping 11.7 inches in Bedford-Stuyvesant, 12 in Queens Village, 10 in Gramercy Park, 5.5 in Riverdale and around 8.5 inches at both La Guardia and Kennedy.\n\n\u201cBut Staten Island won the lottery,\u201d said Patrick Maloit, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service. Port Richmond is waking up to 13.8 inches.\n\nEven though parts of the city saw higher snow totals \u201cthe record is still going to the April storm,\u201d Mr. Maloit said. Central Park is used for the official city total because record-keeping there is more extensive and \u201cbecause, let\u2019s face it, when you think New York City, you think Central Park, not La Guardia or Kennedy,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nWe did set one record yesterday, though. It was the most snow seen in New York on March 21.\n\nAnd you can take comfort in knowing you lived through a spring snowstorm and the fourth nor\u2019easter in one month, a super extra rare occurrence. The National Weather Service found at least one other instance of four nor\u2019easters taking place in one month \u2014 between Dec. 30, 1986, and Jan. 26, 1987 \u2014 but that was in the dead of winter.\n\nWe\u2019d advise against placing any bets on a fifth: Another big nor\u2019easter this season is unlikely, and temperatures are expected to keep climbing in the coming weeks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nToday, cloudy with a high near 42. Tomorrow, drizzly, with a high of 44.\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 The president tried to block funding for the Gateway rail-tunnel project, but a bill drafted by Congress contains as much as $540 million for it. The museum is taking proposals for \u201cPlatform,\u201d its yearly show-and-tell of creative work inspired by \u201cthe engineering, intricate choreography, and impromptu interactions of the daily commute.\u201d\n\nThey\u2019re not concerned with the vehicle for your self-expression. Submissions may include dance performances, films, academic presentations, stand-up comedy, visual art and more.\n\nLike commuting in our city, get there any way you can. They only ask that public transportation take center stage in the work.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deadline for entries is April 1. (They were, not so long ago, also banned from city schools.)\n\nAt performance halls, Dave Chappelle, Alicia Keys, Guns N\u2019 Roses and others have taken to using Yondr \u2014 a technology that locks fans\u2019 phones in pouches during shows.\n\nPhones are prohibited at Sketch Night at the Society of Illustrators, where models pose nude, and at the immersive-theater production \u201cSleep No More,\u201d once described as a \u201cmovable orgy.\u201d And the Alamo Drafthouse in Downtown Brooklyn vows to kick out those who text mid-movie.\n\nOn the menu at Sfoglia, alongside the brussels sprouts with maple butter, is a restaurant rule: \u201cNo cellphones, computers or electronics, please.\u201d\n\nBut perhaps our favorite discovery was the National Day of Unplugging, which we observed Friday at the Museum at Eldridge Street.\n\nUpon entering the Lower East Side synagogue, a National Historic Landmark built in 1887, we dropped our iPhone into a \u201csleeping bag\u201d and left it with reception. We sat wordless and motionless in the sanctuary, listening to its creaking pine floors, the inhale-exhale of another visitor and the spectacular silence in between. Staring at the stained glass windows long enough \u2014 the shiny blue ombr\u00e9 with gold stars \u2014 we began to see \u201cGoodnight Moon\u201d swirl into \u201cThe Starry Night.\u201d\n\nWe forgot where we were for an afternoon \u2014 on a street with sirens, scaffolding and soggy snow \u2014 and it was absolutely delightful.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nMore snow.\n\nFlurries (of up to three inches) and wind may affect your commute this morning \u2014 a winter weather advisory remains in effect until noon.\n\nBrave the cold: Spring is a week away.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 The lightly regulated, little-known industry that runs \u201cdoors-off\u201d helicopter flights is facing scrutiny after the deadly East River crash. Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Updated 9:35 a.m.\n\nGood Monday morning! The sun is shining today.\n\nThis past year has been a bumpy ride for our crumbling subways.\n\nSure, we could grumble about delays and overcrowding. But in the spirit of starting the week on a positive note, we thought we\u2019d take a day off from complaining.\n\nWe recently asked our readers to send their positive commuting stories, and dozens wrote in to tell us about helping hands, shared seats, spirit-lifting music and more.\n\nTurns out, it\u2019s not all bad down there.\n\n\u201cMy boyfriend and I were headed uptown on the C train. I was about to leave for vacation, so we were unusually affectionate in the train car \u2014 something I hesitate doing, as the subway isn\u2019t always the best place for queer P.D.A. We were kissing and embracing before I rushed off the train at the West Fourth Street station. One stop later, my boyfriend called and told me a man handed him a note as he was getting off the train. The note read: \u2018Thank you for being brave enough to be affectionate in public.\u2019\u201d", "title": "New York Today: Heartwarming Commutes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 More than 2,350 area flights have been canceled. La Guardia expects to cancel all flights after noon. American Airlines will suspend flight operations at Newark after 11 a.m. and at Kennedy after 1 p.m. Check your flight at La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark before you head to the airport.\n\n\u2022 The Staten Island Ferry is running on a regular schedule. NY Waterway and Seastreak ferries are running on modified schedules. The Rockaway NYC Ferry route is canceled today.\n\nA winter storm warning is in effect. For those of you who don\u2019t speak meteorologese, that means snow, sleet and ice will make traveling difficult, and at times nearly impossible, today. New York City schools are closed for the day.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe heaviest snowfall is expected this afternoon, when it could fall at a rate of one to two inches an hour. Plan on a messy trip home from work.\n\n\u201cIt may seem kind of quaint in the morning, but it\u2019s going to get a lot worse as the day goes by,\u201d said John Homenuk, a meteorologist at New York Metro Weather.\n\nThe temperature will hover around freezing, and strong wind gusts of nearly 40 miles an hour could make it feel as cold as 15 degrees.\n\nIf the forecast holds, this could be the biggest spring snowstorm in our city\u2019s history.\n\nNew York City\u2019s largest snowstorm after the vernal equinox was on April 3, 1915, when 10 inches fell.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis nor\u2019easter is forecast to drop more snow on New York City than the previous storms this month, the last of which killed two people and left hundreds of thousands in the region without power. Power failures are possible throughout the day. Broadway shows will go on as planned, but city libraries are shuttered today.\n\nLike earlier this month, we could see some thundersnow, and lots of sleet. What is sleet, exactly?\n\n\u201cSometimes what happens is that, in between a cloud that\u2019s producing snowflakes and the ground, you get a layer of warm air,\u201d Mr. Homenuk said. \u201cThe snowflake from the cloud melts into a raindrop in the warm layer, and then passes back into freezing air, and then it refreezes into like an ice pellet.\u201d\n\n(Unlike freezing rain, which freezes after it hits the ground.)\n\n\u201cWhen it\u2019s sleeting, you will know,\u201d he added. \u201cSleet stings. It pings you. It\u2019s not as gentle as a snowflake.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 Cynthia Nixon, the former \u201cSex and the City\u201d star now running for governor, wasted little time before taking jabs at Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. Even if you have a traditional 9-to-5, responding to emails or taking calls after hours are often considered a requirement of the job.\n\nWe want to know how New York Today readers handle work communications after hours. Do you pick up the phone all night, or do you have a self-imposed cutoff? Is it something you struggle with it, or have you learned to accept that the job never ends?\n\nLet us know by sending an email to nytoday@nytimes.com. After her husband (and the bridge\u2019s chief engineer) fell ill, she taught herself engineering and took over his duties.\n\nWhat is definitively known about Mary Ewing Outerbridge is that she set up the nation\u2019s first tennis courts, on Staten Island. What we think we know about Ms. Outerbridge is that she played the first game of tennis in the United States, against her sister Laura. What is still unknown is who, exactly, won that match.\n\nThe Overlooked project will continue to add overdue obituaries to The Times\u2019s pages each week. But New York has more extraordinary women in its history than could fit into a newspaper.\n\nSome of them will be featured on LinkNYC kiosks this month, including Mable Lee, a jazz tap dancer and singer; Sarah J. (Hey, shivering burns calories, right?) On the menu: buttermilk pancakes for my husband and later a super fudgy chocolate cake.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Jean Goldsmith, 65, Westchester, N.Y.\n\n\u201cWe lived in Pasadena, Calif., before moving to New York City with our small boys. Due to their lack of experience with blizzards, my 4-year-old convinced my 2-year-old to look out the window for falling lizards. Dozens of schools in all five boroughs have registered to take part in walkouts as well.\n\nMost of the students involved are too young to vote. Until he turned 18 in January, Mr. Myers was one of them \u2014 an impetus for his civic engagement. \u201cThis is our only outlet,\u201d he said. \u201cWe can\u2019t do anything other than protest.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: Students in Solidarity Over Gun Violence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Lewis said she was raped while in the Army. After that, she said, art saved her life.\n\n\u201cDoing my artwork, I was able to continue to deal with life itself,\u201d she said. \u201cI knew that I had the gift, and it helped me survive.\u201d\n\nSculpture is her specialty. \u201cSting,\u201d a work for which she was made a finalist, brings a scorpion to life through wood carvings. \u201cI kept going and going,\u201d Ms. Lewis said of the six months she spent on the sculpture, \u201cand next thing I knew, it looked like it was breathing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Cox, 60, who served in West Germany and Fort Jackson in South Carolina in the 1980s before moving to New York in 1989, said that she, too, was raped in the Army and that art had been part of her healing process.\n\n\u201cI suffer from PTSD from sexual trauma when I was in the military \u2014 when I went to the V.A., I was very depressed, I was out of it, I was suicidal,\u201d Ms. Cox said. She learned needlepoint through the facility\u2019s art therapy program.\n\n\u201cWe do art every day,\u201d she said. \u201cIt literally saved our lives. It takes your mind away from the past experiences that are not good for you.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Cox has since become a master of Egyptian needlepoint. Her piece \u201cMystic,\u201d a project 12 years in the making, earned her consideration for the national competition, which begins in October.\n\n(We\u2019re rooting for you both!)\n\nUntil then, you can see works by Ms. Lewis, Ms. Cox and other talented veterans at the Manhattan campus of the V.A.\u2019s New York Harbor Health Care System.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s what else is happening:\n\nWeather\n\nMediocre in the morning and misty in the afternoon, with a high near 56 and a rainy evening ahead.\n\nIt may be March now, but don\u2019t throw your winter coat into storage just yet \u2014 after today, we\u2019re back down to the 30s, with flurries on the horizon.\n\nIn the News\n\n\u2022 New York City\u2019s next schools chancellor will be Alberto M. Levine", "New York Today"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning on this pleasant Thursday.\n\n\u201cBeware the ides of March.\u201d\n\nThat Shakespearean warning, which foreshadowed the assassination of Julius Caesar, sounds less ominous centuries later on a sunny day in New York.\n\nIn fact, these days it seems downright positive, as it gives us a reason to remember the playwright\u2019s legacy in our city.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really important to underscore that not only America\u2019s Shakespeare \u2014 but New York\u2019s Shakespeare \u2014 is different than the Shakespeare you get in England,\u201d said James Shapiro, a professor of English at Columbia University who compiled the anthology \u201cShakespeare in America.\u201d \u201cAnd its history here, over the last 200 years, has been extraordinary.\u201d\n\nAmong the first people to bring Shakespeare to New York, in the 18th century, were touring companies from London. During the Revolutionary War \u2014 even while British forces occupied our city, Professor Shapiro told us \u2014 there was Shakespeare being performed here.", "title": "New York Today: The City\u2019s Claim to Shakespeare", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning on this brilliant Monday.\n\nIt\u2019ll be 47 degrees. Pack some sunscreen.\n\nIt doesn\u2019t quite feel like spring \u2014 with a recent snowstorm, highs in the 40s today and temperatures around freezing tonight \u2014 but we\u2019ve had a sunny start to the season, and the next couple of days will be no different.\n\nDon\u2019t let the temperature fool you: The sun can be just as strong on a chilly day as it is on a warm one.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s cold, so there\u2019s the illusion that you don\u2019t feel the sun so much, but then it reflects onto your skin and you can end up with a sunburn,\u201d said Dr. Debra Wattenberg, an associate clinical professor of dermatology at Mount Sinai Hospital and member of the American Academy of Dermatology.\n\n\u201cToday is a perfect example of a type of day where it\u2019s beautiful out and warm enough to go for a run, but not put on sunscreen or a hat, and come in with a sunburn.\u201d", "title": "New York Today: The Danger of Springtime Sunshine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "The city\u2019s first apartment buildings, like the Dakota, the Gramercy and the Chelsea, were constructed in the 1870s. Unlike the city\u2019s existing tenements \u2014 those greasy, cholera-ridden death traps described in books like Jacob Riis\u2019s \u201cHow the Other Half Lives\u201d \u2014 apartments offered amenities like telephones, electric lighting, commercial refrigerators, private dining rooms and ground-floor restaurants that could deliver food to your unit.\n\nThe gap in living conditions of the rich and the poor was lessened, to an extent, during the first half of the 20th century. In 1901, New York State banned tenements, and toilets, natural light and ventilation were added to existing buildings to make them more sanitary. During the depression, our city\u2019s luxury apartments were chopped up and sold off, while servant\u2019s quarters were converted into bedrooms. And in 1935, the nation\u2019s first public housing units went up on the Lower East Side.\n\nA trend in modern apartment living \u2014 the open floor plan \u2014 is borrowed from the way artists lived in converted warehouses in SoHo in the \u201960s and \u201970s, with \u201cthe kitchen facilities, the eating facilities and the living facilities all in one big open space,\u201d Ms. Cromley said.\n\nToday, as apartments have become the domain of even the superrich, with a penthouse in Midtown recently selling for $100 million, the ultimate amenity is the view offered by a building that soars above everything around it.\n\nBut that\u2019s not exactly new.\n\n\u201cNew York has always built taller, sooner, than other cities, and at the risk of public safety,\u201d Ms. Cromley said, offering the example of 12-story apartment buildings going up at a time when water from fire hoses could only reach the fifth floor.", "title": "New York Today: The Evolution of the Apartment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Updated, 12:38p.m.\n\nGood morning on this fabulous Friday.\n\n\u201cNo Irish need apply.\u201d\n\nThat line, printed widely in classified ads from the mid-19th century, was meant to exclude Irish immigrants from work in the United States.\n\nCenturies later, a sign with those same words hangs in O\u2019Neill\u2019s Irish Bar in Hell\u2019s Kitchen, at the behest of the bar\u2019s owner, Ciaran Staunton, himself an Irish immigrant.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve put that up because I want people to know that when we\u2019re talking about the anti-immigrant movement here, that we ourselves were on the receiving end of \u2018no immigrants need apply,\u2019\u201d said Mr. Staunton, who is from County Mayo in Ireland. \u201cAnd worse than just signs.\u201d\n\nWhen he\u2019s not tending his bar on Ninth Avenue, Mr. Staunton, a founder of the Irish Lobby for Immigration Reform, traverses the country helping the roughly 50,000 undocumented Irish immigrants in the United States \u2014 of which, he estimated, there are 15,000 in New York \u2014 forge a path to citizenship.", "title": "New York Today: The Journey of an Irish Bar Owner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI live in a multilevel private house. When I go up to my bedroom in the evening, I leave the cellphone on the charger downstairs in the kitchen. That way, I am less tempted to respond to emails or calls from my consulting clients or graduate students after the dinner hour. Of course, occasionally I take the laptop with me, which defeats the purpose.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Melba Butler, 63, Jamaica, Queens\n\n\u201cBeing a freelancer means I don\u2019t really have off-hours. As soon as a work-related email, text, or phone call comes in, the response clock stars ticking down. Unless I\u2019m asleep, teaching, or playing a gig, I respond immediately.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Jono Waldman, 36, East Harlem\n\n\u201cI \u2018Boomerang\u2019 my work email as soon as I finish for the day or week, with a message to text only if something is urgent. Any emails sent after this time return to my inbox first thing on the next business day.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Carolyn Robinson, Wooster, Ohio\n\n\u201cA few years ago I was disgusted with myself because I\u2019d become an addicted smartphone drone. I took the radical step of canceling my phone service and rejecting permanent connectivity. I got a computer phone number so I could get texts make calls when at a Wi-Fi hot spot, and told people to leave me a message and I\u2019d get back to them. Business associates envied my resolve but didn\u2019t feel it would work. It has. I am a liberated person now, free at last, free at last.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Arthur Kaye, 67, Chappaqua, N.Y.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m on the clock 24/7 \u2026 but I choose to be. I didn\u2019t move to New York to sit around and watch TV all day!\u201d\n\n\u2014 Nick El-Tawil, 27, West Village\n\nNew York Today is a morning roundup that is published weekdays at 6 a.m. If you don\u2019t get it in your inbox already, you can sign up to receive it by email here.\n\nFor updates throughout the day, like us on Facebook.\n\nWhat would you like to see here to start your day? Post a comment, email us at nytoday@nytimes.com, or reach us via Twitter using #NYToday.\n\nFollow the New York Today columnists, Alexandra Levine and Jonathan Wolfe, on Twitter.\n\nYou can find the latest New York Today at nytoday.com.", "title": "New York Today: The Right to Disconnect", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, also pressed his appointees at the Port Authority to support a higher minimum wage for airport workers. But former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, a Republican, blocked efforts by Democrats in Trenton to push through increases in their state\u2019s minimum wage.\n\n\u201cNew York proudly set an example for the nation by raising the minimum wage to $15, yet the fight for economic justice for our working families continues, and we won\u2019t stop until every New Yorker is paid the fair wages they deserve,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said in a statement.\n\nFor Mr. Cuomo, the ability to extend a generous raise to hourly workers could help him fend off attacks by the newest entrant into the governor\u2019s race, the actress Cynthia Nixon, who has sharply criticized the governor over what she has characterized as a growing economic divide in the state.\n\nAfter the November election of Gov. Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat who pledged to raise New Jersey\u2019s minimum wage to $15 an hour, the impasse at the Port Authority dissolved. Even the agency\u2019s chairman, Kevin O\u2019Toole, a former Republican state legislator appointed by Mr. Christie, supports the mandated increase.\n\nIn a statement, Mr. O\u2019Toole said, \u201cThis board has heard the voices of airport employees who\u2019ve shared their stories with us over the years. We know that higher wages won\u2019t only make a difference to them personally, but will have a significant impact in workplace morale and productivity that will directly enhance the experience of the traveling public visiting our airports.\u201d\n\nMr. Murphy praised Mr. O\u2019Toole and the other commissioners for \u201cgetting to the right place.\u201d\n\nUnder the proposal, the annual increases for the workers \u2014 most of whom are employed by private contractors as airplane cleaners, caterers and baggage handlers \u2014 would begin Sept. 1. The Port Authority estimates\n\nThe first one would raise the minimum for workers at Newark Liberty to $12.45 an hour, from the Port Authority\u2019s current minimum wage of $10.45. Workers at the New York airports already are earning at least $13 an hour, which is the state-mandated minimum wage for large employers in the city.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPort Authority officials estimate that about 20,000 airport workers are receiving wages close to the current minimums.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew Jersey\u2019s statewide minimum wage is only $8.60, which has left some workers at Newark earning $2.55 an hour less than their counterparts at La Guardia and Kennedy. By Sept. 1, 2019, that imbalance would end with the minimum wage at all three airports increasing to $15.60 an hour. After that, it would rise in three more steps, to $19 an hour on Sept. 1, 2023.\n\nPaul K. Sonn, general counsel at the National Employment Law Project, said $19 an hour would be the highest targeted minimum wage in the country. He said airports on the West Coast had set a trend of higher pay to reduce instability and improve security that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey would be catching up to.\n\n\u201cThe Port Authority has really been lagging, in part because Chris Christie was blocking action on this,\u201d Mr. Sonn said.\n\nSince fast-food workers in New York City began a campaign a few years ago for a $15 minimum wage, that number has become a rallying cry for workers around the country.\n\nBut Hector Figueroa, the president of 32BJ Service Employees International, the influential union that represents several thousand of the airport workers, has set his sights higher. Last year, frustrated by the Port Authority\u2019s slow response to demands, 32BJ; the Retail, Wholesale and Departments Store Union; and Unite Here, another union representing airport workers, lobbied for legislation in Albany and Trenton that would have set an $18-an-hour minimum at the airports.\n\nThat effort failed, but once Mr. Murphy was elected, the unions returned to the Port Authority\u2019s monthly board meetings to press their demands. This time, Mr. Figueroa said, their efforts appear to be bearing fruit.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a huge increase but it\u2019s the kind of money that you need to live in this market,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a huge increase because the workers were earning so little for so long.\u201d\n\nDozens of workers in purple knit caps bearing the 32BJ logo or red Unite Here T-shirts whooped and chanted as the agency\u2019s directors endorsed the new wage scale at a meeting in Jersey City.\n\nAndrea Bundy, who has cleaned airplanes at Kennedy Airport for five years, said she would now have the money to buy uniforms and track shoes for her 16-year-old daughter, who competes in track and field for her high school in Brownsville, Brooklyn. \u201cI feel like I got an early Christmas present, not only for me but for my daughter,\u201d Ms. Bundy said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nZakiyy Medina, 22, who has been a baggage handler at Newark Liberty for two years, said the raises would allow him to help his grandmother with the rent and other bills. \u201cI feel exhilarated, proud, happy,\u201d he said, wearing a big smile.", "title": "New York-Area He said he became ill, losing his hair and more than 65 pounds.\n\nImage Boris Karpichkov appearing on \u201cGood Morning Britain\u201d this week. Credit Good Morning Britain/ITV\n\nHis doctor initially told him he had the flu, Mr. Karpichkov said, and he did not report the episode to the police at the time.", "title": "New Zealand to Investigate Decade-Old Poisoning Claim", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Black can be practical too. In northern Europe, where tar was used as a water sealant on exteriors, the color stuck. But those black buildings are in Scandinavia or the Netherlands, far from my pallid neighborhood.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow I have more allies. In the past couple of years, black homes have cropped up on the internet, dominating decorating sites like Dwell, Gardenista and Apartment Therapy. The Black Houses Tumblr has amassed pages and pages of black homes in rural, urban and desert settings. Shou sugi ban, the ancient Japanese technique of charring exterior wood, became a thing. PPG Paints named Black Flame its 2018 color of the year. Nashville-based O\u2019More College of Design coated its 2017 show house in black. And in October, Phaidon Press published \u201cBlack: Architecture in Monochrome,\u201d with examples of 150 black exteriors.\n\nThen the impossible happened. HGTV \u2014 the model of mainstream American cheerful design \u2014 chose to color its 2018 Dream Home Sherwin-Williams\u2019s Tricorn Black.\n\nBrian Patrick Flynn, an Atlanta interior designer in charge of the Dream Home, said he often used black in his designs (Tricorn Black and Glidden\u2019s Onyx Black are his favorites) because it gives a house without architectural significance some identity.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Flynn\u2019s own home is painted black; so is his cabin about an hour outside of Atlanta.\n\nHe said he believed this interest in black was a reaction to the white paint and white kitchen trend, which started during the housing market crash a decade ago. People turned to white because if they wanted to sell their houses, they needed the color to be simple and inoffensive.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve gone from everybody doing things that are really safe with white or cream or dove gray,\u201d Mr. Flynn said. Now people are sick of the news. They\u2019re miserable about the world. They want to take charge of their homes. \u201cI think people are embracing things that may have been considered risky before and saying, \u2018Let\u2019s just go for it,\u2019\u201d he said.\n\nBlack is a color of provocation. Nineteenth-century anarchists waved their black flag. Twentieth-century fascists loved it. Beat poets, punks and Goths made it their brand. The Black Panthers wore black leather jackets and black berets. When the fashion designer Rei Kawakubo introduced everyday black clothes in the early 1980s, critics described the collection as \u201cpost-atomic.\u201d Most recently, black is what women in Hollywood and Congress chose to wear to express solidarity with victims of sexual assault.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn early 2016, Victoria Smith of SF Girl, a design blog, painted her home in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles Benjamin Moore\u2019s Onyx. She latched on to black after seeing a slew of houses painted that color in Amsterdam. For her, black houses are symbols of power. \u201cIt\u2019s like, don\u2019t mess with me,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Smith was initially worried about her neighbors\u2019 reaction. \u201cI think they thought I was some Goth person,\u201d she said. Then more people in the neighborhood began painting their homes black. Was she bothered by the imitations? No, she said. She was flattered.\n\nFor Abigail Ahern, an interior designer and retailer in London, black is warm and mysterious but also a courageous color for women to slather on walls. \u201cYou have to have a certain amount of confidence to use black, and I think we all have more confidence than ever before,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re channeling our own direction.\u201d\n\nShe first painted a small alcove black in her 1860s four-story Victorian, then became so entranced that she painted her entire interior and exterior black and filled her garden with furniture and accessories to match.\n\nThat wasn\u2019t enough. So she developed a line of dark-hued paint. Her most popular color: Hudson Black.\u201cBlack gives me a feeling of empowerment,\u201d she said. \u201cI know that\u2019s really silly because it\u2019s just a can of paint, but it actually really does.\u201d", "title": "New on the Block: The Little Black House", "authors": ["Hayley Krischer"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Outside the White House, there are few friends the president will listen to. Some of them warned him to back off his tariffs plan, telling him that he would undo what he had accomplished with the tax bill. Mr. Trump said he didn\u2019t agree, and that was that.\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s moods have always been like storm clouds passing quickly over a desert island, and aides say that has not changed. Contrary to descriptions of a constantly fuming, beleaguered president, friends and advisers say Mr. Trump is more at ease than he has been in some time. What seems like unchecked chaos to almost everyone else is Mr. Trump feeling he is in his element.\n\n\u201cHe seems more relaxed, believe it or not,\u201d said Representative Peter T. King, a New York Republican who spent several hours with the president during two St. Patrick\u2019s Day events on Thursday.\n\n\u201cI would say it\u2019s a combination of being more relaxed and also being frustrated by the fact that he feels like a lot of what he didn\u2019t succeed at, or what hasn\u2019t worked, is that he wasn\u2019t allowed to be Trump,\u201d he said.\n\nHis close allies, like Representative Mark Meadows, the North Carolina Republican who is the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, believe the president is finding his stride and learning how to navigate Washington.\n\n\u201cI see it more as a function of just, \u2018O.K., I\u2019ve taken a year to understand the different dynamics within a broad array of personalities,\u2019 and so now it\u2019s all about putting together a team to go the distance for the next three years,\u201d Mr. Meadows said.\n\nPerhaps.\n\nWarnings of dire consequences from his critics have failed to materialize. There was only a minor dip by the end of the next day.", "title": "Newly Emboldened, Trump Says What He Really Feels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "In February, it was hard to know whether the Republican surge would last.\n\nA little over a month later, Democrats have recovered. The most recent Monmouth poll, published on Wednesday, gave Democrats a nine-point lead. Over all, Democrats lead the most recent generic ballot polls by around nine points, about the same as their standing before the tax debate began.\n\nThere\u2019s nothing new about a short-term swing in the polls that fails to cause a big change in a race. So far this year, just about every big shift in the generic ballot has proved short-lived. Highly sensitive, short-term estimates have misled much more often than they\u2019ve presaged a lasting change.\n\nDemocrats have generally maintained a consistent lead of seven to nine points in a less sensitive, longer-term estimate of the generic congressional ballot. As a historical matter, the generic ballot tends to be stable over the longer term.\n\nBut the stability is perhaps more surprising in light of the events of the last six months. Since early July, the Republican health care bill has been defeated, revived and defeated again. The special counsel Robert Mueller has indicted more than 20 people. The Republicans have passed a sweeping tax cut. There was the violent far-right rally in Charlottesville, Va.; national anthem protests; the birth of the \u201cMe Too\u201d movement; as well as mass shootings in Las Vegas and Parkland, Fla. The government shut down. The stock market surged. ISIS was routed. Who knows how many times the president tweeted.", "title": "News Changes Fast, but Polls Keep Snapping Back Into Place", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNew York is very lucky to get somebody of his caliber,\u201d Mr. Benioff said in an interview on Monday. \u201cThis is probably our nation\u2019s finest school leader.\u201d\n\nMr. Carranza has described himself as coming from a working-class background: His father was a sheet metal worker and his mother a hairdresser. His grandparents immigrated from Mexico. He didn\u2019t learn English until he started elementary school. Music played a major role in his life from early on.\n\nAt Monday\u2019s news conference, Mr. Carranza said he had been a mariachi musician since he was about 6 years old. When he wanted to stay up late with his father and his uncles, they said the only people staying up late were people playing instruments \u2014 so he learned to play the guitar. He later worked his way through college at the University of Arizona \u201cgigging,\u201d as he put it on Monday.\n\nAfterward, when he became a social studies teacher at his former high school in Tucson, students knew that he played music and asked him to start a mariachi class. He did, and it eventually grew into a program serving 250 students and an award-winning student group, Mariachi Aztl\u00e1n de Pueblo High School.\n\nLater, Mr. Carranza, who eventually became principal of the school, attributed the school\u2019s improved reputation and performance to the transformative power of music in the students\u2019 lives.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s what mariachi music does \u2014 it keeps our kids connected to who they are,\u201d he said in 2016, when he was inducted into the Mariachi Hall of Fame.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the same ceremony, Mr. Carranza described himself as \u201creally a mariachi masquerading as a superintendent.\u201d (He also met his wife, Monique Garcia Carranza, through music \u2014 she works with her sister, Susie Garcia, who has an all-woman mariachi band in Los Angeles, Las Colibri.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Carranza left Tucson in 2004 for the Clark County School District in Las Vegas, where he began his ascent into administration. In 2009, his former mentor in Clark County, Carlos Garcia, by then the superintendent in San Francisco, hired Mr. Carranza as his deputy superintendent of instruction, innovation and social justice. When Mr. Garcia retired in 2012, the district skipped a national search, instead elevating Mr. Carranza as superintendent.\n\nHydra Mendoza, the president of the Board of Education of the San Francisco Unified School District and deputy chief of staff to the mayor, said that in San Francisco, Mr. Carranza presided over a period of consensus among the school board and improving academic performance. Among his focuses, she said, were reducing the district\u2019s suspension rate and pairing schools with outside organizations that would provide social services to students and families \u2014 both things that have been part of Mr. de Blasio\u2019s agenda\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
