00:00:00", "text": "The authorities also instructed ticket vendors to show concertgoers a longer list of rules: No smoking. \u201cModest outfits\u201d required. Men and women segregated.\n\n\u201cTo those going to the Tamer Hosny concert: don\u2019t dance or sway. Just pray for the Prophet,\u201d Mezan, a Twitter user from Saudi Arabia, wrote.\n\n\u201cThe attendees must perform their ablutions before coming so they can perform the evening prayers right after the concert,\u201d another Twitter user added sarcastically.\n\nThe restrictions represented another example of how foreign cultural imports like concerts have been adjusted to fit with the kingdom\u2019s ultraconservative society.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPrince Mohammed, 32, has moved rapidly and radically since he was named crown prince in 2017. He has confronted Iran, Saudi Arabia\u2019s Middle East rival; ordered the arrests of princes and members of the Saudi business elite in what he called an anticorruption crackdown; and curbed the powers of clerics.\n\nIn September 2017, the government announced that it would lift the ban on women driving this year. Since then, it has hosted several concerts, including one by the Greek composer Yanni, and promised to allow commercial movie theaters, ending a 35-year ban.\n\nHis modernizing campaign also includes a plan to reduce the petroleum-rich kingdom\u2019s near-total reliance on oil revenue, and to attract tourism.\n\nMany Saudi conservatives are deeply uncomfortable with Prince Mohammed\u2019s reforms, although they have mostly kept quiet, fearing arrest. Many of the online posts about Mr. Hosny\u2019s concert condemned the concert, not the rules governing it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI spit on Tamer Hosny and I spit on those who have given him the go-ahead,\u201d wrote Tabuk Tabuki, a Twitter user from Saudi Arabia.\n\n\u201cTo the government of Saudi Arabia, we pledged allegiance to you according to Allah\u2019s book,\u201d he said, adding that the authorities should not expect Saudis to accept their rule if they persisted in what he called violations of Muslim laws.\n\nSuch protests seem to have done little to deter Prince Mohammed so far. Later this month the kingdom\u2019s capital, Riyadh, is scheduled to host a fashion show.\n\nSaudi Arabia, an absolute monarchy, has been ruled according to a strict interpretation of Islamic law since it was founded in 1932. It is home to Mecca, the spiritual heart of Islam.", "title": "No Dancing, No Swaying: Saudi Pop Concert Comes With Warning", "authors": ["Nour Youssef"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 No one was fired at the White House on Friday.\n\nWhich was news.\n\nSeeking to tamp down the anxiety inside the West Wing and the sense of never-ending dysfunction, President Trump refrained, dawn through dusk, from any firings-by-tweet. His chief of staff delivered a buck-\u2019em-up message that no heads will roll \u2014 for now.\n\nOver at the Justice Department, Attorney General Jeff Sessions fired Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director and a frequent target of President Trump\u2019s scorn, late Friday night. That was widely expected. But at the White House, the lack of any resolution to the steady reports of coming firings has left the president\u2019s top advisers in limbo, and has undercut their authority.\n\nSome aides say they wake up each morning wondering if they will still have a job by the end of the day.\n\nTwo embattled cabinet secretaries \u2014 Ben Carson at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and David J. Shulkin at the Department of Veterans Affairs \u2014 remained in their posts despite speculation that they would soon be replaced because of the president\u2019s anger over their use of public funds.", "title": "No Heads Rolled at the White House on Friday. But Anxiety Abounds.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump confirmed on Monday that his administration would not immediately pursue a proposal to raise the age limit for buying an assault rifle, going back on earlier pledges that he made after last month\u2019s deadly mass shooting at a South Florida high school.\n\nIn a Twitter post, Mr. Trump said there was \u201cnot much political support (to put it mildly).\u201d", "title": "No Immediate Push to Raise Minimum Age for Buying Assault Rifles, Trump Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The cooperation between the I.D.C. and the Republican Party in the State Senate has been the source of intense friction between Mr. Klein\u2019s group and mainstream Democrats in the chamber, led by Andrea Stewart-Cousins of Westchester County. Mr. Klein and Ms. Stewart-Cousins have indicated a willingness to reunite if Democrats seize a numerical majority in April, when two special elections favoring Democrats are being held, but that scenario is dependent on another rogue Democrat, Senator Simcha Felder of Brooklyn, reuniting with his party\u2019s conference; he currently sits with Republicans.\n\nMr. DiNapoli\u2019s office indicated that it intends to pay out 25 percent of the stipend amounts requested \u2014 which are scheduled to be in paychecks next week \u2014 but will not pay the remaining 75 percent in April unless the Senate provides \u201cdocumentation showing that these members serve in the office or special capacity listed.\u201d It also argues that the office will attempt to claw back the money already scheduled to be paid if proper explanation is not given.\n\nThe letter from Mr. DiNapoli\u2019s office and other documents about the stipends were obtained through a Freedom of Information request. In a statement, a spokeswoman for the comptroller, Jennifer Freeman, said the office had issued the letter since \u201clegal entities have yet to clarify the legality of the Senate\u2019s practices,\u201d after they were brought to light last year.\n\nState Legislative Law 5-a allows senators who serve as chairs or ranking members of committees to receive stipends ranging from $9,000 to $34,000 a year, sometimes greatly increasing a lawmaker\u2019s $79,500 salary. But the law does not outline payments for vice chairs.\n\nIn past years, senators have received tens of thousands of dollars for jobs they did not hold. And the newest payment request, dated March 6, mirrors similar certifications made in previous years, incorrectly listing senators as committee chairmen and chairwomen. Ms. Savino, for instance, was listed as chairwoman of the Codes Committee and as such entitled to receive $4,500, a quarter of the annual $18,000 allotted to the actual chairman, Andrew Lanza. She is the committee\u2019s vice chair.\n\nThe same situation is true for Mr. Peralta, the No. 2 on the Senate\u2019s Energy and Telecommunications Committee, who is misidentified as its chairman and slated to receive $3,125, part of the $12,500 earmarked for that committee\u2019s chairman, Joseph Griffo. Lawmakers can receive only one stipend and in each case, the actual chairs of those committees \u2014 such as Mr. Lanza and Mr. Griffo \u2014 receive higher stipends for other leadership positions.\n\nState Sen. John J. Flanagan, the Republican leader, and his counsel, David L. Lewis, have strenuously argued that such misdirected lulus are legal, despite there being no explicit statutory basis for a stipend for vice chairmen. In a four-page memo released last spring, Senate officials said that the documents sent to the comptroller with the false titles were simply a way to ensure payment, not to lie about the position they held.", "title": "No Lulus for You: Comptroller Threatens to Withhold Lawmakers\u2019 Payments", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "His political nemesis, Mayor Bill de Blasio, is destined to be haunted by one Harendra Singh, a restaurant owner who, it was recently reported, secretly pleaded guilty to bribing Mr. de Blasio in return for help getting favorable lease terms. No charges were brought against the mayor or his aides. Federal prosecutors noted last year that making a case would have been difficult, presumably because the United States Supreme Court had raised the bar for proving political corruption months before Mr. Singh\u2019s plea in 2016.\n\nNonetheless, the specter of shadowy behavior isn\u2019t going away, not with Mr. Singh figuring in another federal corruption trial about to begin, that of Edward Mangano, a former Nassau County executive. He\u2019s accused of taking Singh bribes. Mr. Mangano\u2019s lawyers have left little doubt that they will make Mr. Singh\u2019s de Blasio connection \u2014 and the absence of any charges against the mayor \u2014 part of a strategy to discredit him as a prosecution witness.\n\nFor Mr. Cuomo, who\u2019s up for re-election this year, discomfiting proximity to criminal cases does not end with the Percoco trial. Another administration insider, Alain Kaloyeros, has his own federal court date in May. Dr. Kaloyeros, who headed the State University of New York Polytechnic Institute, is charged with corruption in connection with pay-to-play projects upstate.\n\nCourthouses aside, the governor has trouble keeping his deeds fully in sync with his words on ethics. He has repeatedly urged the Legislature to close the \u201cL.L.C. loophole,\u201d by which corporate interests pump vast sums into political campaigns through a series of limited liability companies. No action has been taken, a failure arguably more on lawmakers than on Mr. Cuomo. But having claimed the high ground, he could show seriousness of purpose by not slipping through that loophole himself. Instead, he has used it to plow many hundreds of thousands of dollars from corporate donors into a campaign strongbox containing more than $30 million.\n\nSimilarly, he renewed an executive order imposed by a predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, under which most people in state positions are forbidden to donate to, or solicit political donations for, the governor who appointed them. But Mr. Cuomo and his counsel interpret the order as applying solely to those who can be fired by the governor at any moment. It doesn\u2019t cover people who\u2019ve had legislative confirmation and serve fixed terms, they say. That smacks of pettifoggery. A Times investigation disclosed this week that 37 Cuomo appointees contributed a total of $2.2 million to his political campaign, directly or through relatives and companies they own or control.\n\nNo one can expect the governor to cease trawling for campaign cash in an election year, and not when he has his eye on a possible presidential race in 2020. But a serious challenger to his re-election has yet to emerge. With his bursting campaign chest, how hard would it have been to forgo a couple of million to demonstrate he\u2019s sticking to both the spirit of the rules and his own ethics agenda? In some circles, that\u2019s called walking the walk.", "title": "Opinion | No Matter the Verdict, Corruption Trial Taints Cuomo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you don\u2019t like the national anthem from the politically correct perspective of all this gender nonsense, then don\u2019t sing it,\u201d the far-right party Alternative for Germany said in a statement on Facebook.\n\nChancellor Angela Merkel\u2019s spokesman felt the need to reassure the country. \u201cThe chancellor is very happy with our nice national anthem as it is,\u201d he said.\n\nOther German politicians have agreed. \u201cAnthems are not written for the moment,\u201d Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, general secretary of Ms. Merkel\u2019s party and seen as her likely heir, said in a statement. \u201cI wouldn\u2019t want our anthem to be changed just so it fits in with the zeitgeist.\u201d\n\nThe anthem has a difficult history, she added, and has to be put in context. It was originally written in 1841 to help unite Germany\u2019s states, but its opening verse, which included the line \u201cDeutschland, Deutschland \u00fcber alles\u201d (\u201cGermany, Germany, above all else\u201d), gained sinister connotations under the Nazis and stopped being sung after World War II.\n\nThe anthem was again adopted for the united Germany after the Berlin Wall fell. \u201cOur national anthem is a piece of history itself,\u201d Ms. Kramp-Karrenbauer said.\n\nMs. Rose-M\u00f6hring\u2019s feelings about the controversy are unknown \u2014 the Family Ministry said she would not comment \u2014 but those who have succeeded in changing anthems before said it could take years, even decades, to achieve the change if she decides to push her suggestion.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not surprised by the big discussion it\u2019s caused, and I\u2019m not surprised the politicians said no \u2014 I only succeeded the second time,\u201d said Maria Rauch-Kallat, a former Austrian politician who led efforts to get her country\u2019s anthem changed, with the result that Austrians now sing about their \u201cgreat daughters\u201d as well as their \u201cgreat sons.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNancy Ruth, a former Canadian senator who spearheaded the campaign to make \u201cO Canada\u201d gender-neutral, said she felt all anthems that excluded women should be changed.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s my reaction to this?\u201d she asked, before answering her own question using an expletive and expressing frustration about the debate. \u201cOh, grow up,\u201d she added, addressing those against change. The easiest way to realize the power of a word like \u201cfatherland\u201d was to ask men if they would be happy singing about their motherland instead, she said.\n\nChanging an anthem requires a long campaign, she added: \u201cIt takes until you have a leader, with a majority, who truly wants equality among the sexes.\u201d Canadian feminists started calling for \u201cO Canada\u201d to be made gender neutral in 1980 and it took Justin Trudeau\u2019s election in 2015 for them to succeed.\n\nAngela Merkel was not in a position to offer such leadership given her recent electoral struggles, the former lawmaker said. She recommended that Ms. Rose-M\u00f6hring start singing her own words and hope others follow.\n\nNot all efforts to change Europe\u2019s anthems involve gender. Last month, the pop singer Marta S\u00e1nchez prompted debate in Spain by singing lyrics to her country\u2019s wordless anthem (\u201cI come home to my beloved homeland, where my heart was born,\u201d she began). The country\u2019s anthem has been wordless since it was first played at in an official occasion in 1770. Words were used during the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco, but not officially adopted, and any new ones could prompt concern from, say, Catalans and Basques.\n\nBosnia\u2019s anthem is also wordless, to keep a lid on potential conflicts. Some Bosnians are calling for lyrics to be added, but ethnic splits mean agreement on a set of official words looks impossible, with some Bosnian Serbs not wanting to give the country a more effective symbol.\n\nSwiss campaigners are arguably undertaking the most comprehensive effort to change a national anthem. In 2013, they held a contest to find new words to their God and weather-obsessed anthem, the \u201cSwiss Psalm.\u201d They have since been trying to cajole people into singing them. Last year, a Christian group ran a postcard campaign against the new words.\n\nLukas Niederberger, director of the Swiss Society for Public Good, the organization behind the contest, said the idea of changing Germany\u2019s anthem seemed sensible. \u201cI think for a modern society, the central text of the culture should be politically correct,\u201d he said.\n\nChange shouldn\u2019t be hard, he added. \u201cIt\u2019s not like they\u2019re saying change the whole text, just adapting a few words. It\u2019s really no big deal.\u201d", "title": "No More \u2018Fatherland\u2019? Germans Debate Gender-Neutral Anthem", "authors": ["Alex Marshall"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cThe Unmet Promise of Equality,\u201d by Fred Harris and Alan Curtis (Op-Ed, March 1), depicts the utter lack of progress our country has made over the last 50 years when it comes to reducing enormous disparities in income and wealth.\n\nHaving worked for Senator Robert F. Kennedy when the Kerner Commission report on racial unrest was issued in 1968, I vividly recall his fierce determination to forge a multifaceted public and private plan to address the systemic causes of inequality and the pain, suffering and violence that it breeds.\n\nAs he once said: \u201cAs long as there is plenty, poverty is evil. Government belongs wherever evil needs an adversary and there are people in distress.\u201d\n\nWe desperately need a new national effort to make some measurable progress in reducing poverty and inequality.", "title": "Opinion | No Progress on Inequality", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "But no matter the final outcome, Mr. Lamb\u2019s strong showing demonstrated that the Trump-inspired energy propelling Democrats across the country is not confined to liberal-leaning regions. Republicans were left with the prospect of defending a far broader range of districts this fall than they had hoped.\n\nVideo\n\nA first-time candidate and former Marine, Mr. Lamb, 33, forced Republicans to pour over $10 million into a southwestern Pennsylvania district where Democrats did not even field a candidate in the past two congressional elections.\n\nYet whoever wins here may not hold the seat for very long. The State Supreme Court ruled in January that Pennsylvania\u2019s House map was gerrymandered unlawfully and redrew congressional boundaries that may cause either candidate to run in a new district in November.\n\nEphemeral as any ultimate victory may be, this contest evolved into a test for both major parties in Trump country. Republicans scrambled to prop up Mr. Saccone, a 60-year-old state representative, mindful that a failure here would send signals well beyond Pittsburgh.\n\nThe president appeared twice with Mr. Saccone, most recently at an airport rally on Saturday night in which Mr. Trump mocked Mr. Lamb as \u201cLamb the sham\u201d and pleaded for voters to support Mr. Saccone. But Mr. Trump also delivered a rambling, 75-minute speech that careened away from the matter at hand.\n\nRepublicans concede that they will be unable to keep the 2018 battlefield limited to a few dozen districts, mainly in coastal suburbs where Mr. Trump is intensely unpopular. With a deepening mood of pessimism and fear in Washington, they may be hard-pressed to tackle additional contentious legislation this year.\n\nEven before the returns were counted, Republican officials began criticizing Mr. Saccone\u2019s candidacy in a district where the anti-abortion Republican previously holding the seat, Tim Murphy, was forced to resign after a woman with whom he was having an affair said he pressed her to have an abortion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut three months after suffering an embarrassing defeat in the special Alabama Senate election, Mr. Trump and his administration once more put their prestige on the line on friendly terrain. By continuing to aggressively compete even as Mr. Lamb was surging, Republicans tested the potency of two of their most fearsome political weapons for the midterm campaigns: their fund-raising advantage and the deep unpopularity of Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader.\n\nOutside organizations sought to derail Mr. Lamb with attacks on his record as a federal prosecutor and claims that he would, as one ad put it, merely be a sheep for Ms. Pelosi.\n\nBut the spending did not put the race away, in part because Mr. Lamb pre-emptively inoculated himself against the Pelosi offensive by stating early in the campaign that he would not support her for leader.\n\nAlong with his military service and support for gun rights, Mr. Lamb\u2019s opposition to Ms. Pelosi, which he highlighted in a TV ad, helped him win over some of the voters who were raised Democrats but have drifted to the Republican Party in this heavily unionized district.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHis approach may signal to other Democrats that they can pursue more moderate swing voters without sacrificing the support of the party\u2019s liberal base, at least in districts that will tolerate deviations from party orthodoxy.\n\nMr. Lamb confronted a furious attempt by conservatives to retain the seat. In addition to Mr. Trump\u2019s two visits, Vice President Mike Pence appeared with Mr. Saccone, and two of the president\u2019s children did as well, with Donald Trump Jr. here on Monday. Other administration officials also descended on the district, backed up by an advertising offensive by outside Republican groups that began in January.\n\nFew Republicans publicly said Mr. Trump was at fault for the race\u2019s closeness. But their difficulties here, coming mere hours after he abruptly fired Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, illustrated how much his chaotic governing style and divisive conduct has unsettled the electorate and presented Democrats the chance to portray themselves as a political safe harbor.\n\nIn his remarks early Wednesday morning, Mr. Lamb said, \u201cPeople are so tired of the shouting on TV and in our politics.\u201d\n\nMr. Lamb ran a fairly cautious campaign, calling for more cooperation in Washington and largely keeping national Democrats, other than former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., out of the district.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLess than a decade removed from law school, Mr. Lamb, a Marine prosecutor turned assistant United States attorney, said he ran because he wanted to show his party he could compete in working-class white districts and help reconnect Democrats with organized labor.\n\nMr. Saccone, a mild-mannered Air Force intelligence veteran, aggressively linked himself to Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cI was Trump before Trump was Trump,\u201d he declared at the outset of the race, and on election eve, he went about proving he could deliver his own set of incendiary remarks.\n\nStanding next to Mr. Trump\u2019s eldest son at a firehouse, Mr. Saccone said Democrats were energized by a hatred for the president, \u201ca hatred for our country\u201d and \u201ca hatred for God.\u201d\n\nMr. Saccone echoed Mr. Trump\u2019s call for steel tariffs, a popular position in what historically was a steel-and-coal anchored district. But Mr. Lamb also backed the president\u2019s proposed 25 percent tax on imported steel, seeming to blunt an issue that Republicans sought to make central late in the campaign.\n\nRepublicans hoped that stamping Mr. Trump\u2019s brand on the race would help mobilize pro-Trump voters who are otherwise mostly tuned out of politics.\n\nBut the president\u2019s presence most likely cut both ways, energizing Democrats and disaffected moderates, as well as Mr. Trump\u2019s base. In a rally with Mr. Saccone days before the election, Mr. Trump delivered a heated and unfocused speech, railing about illegal drugs, the Senate confirmation process and news coverage of his administration, and reminiscing about his own victories in 2016. He said relatively little about Mr. Saccone.", "title": "No Result Yet in Pennsylvania House Race, but Democrat Declares Victory", "authors": ["Jonathan Martin", "Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "One famous designer chair is oozing goop. Another has exploded into puffs of foam. A bookcase\u2019s shelves bubbled as gases formed within.\n\nThe culprits? Plastic. And time.\n\nPreserving and restoring furniture from bygone eras has been a skill treasured for centuries among designers, curators and collectors alike. Every day, armies of experts are fanning out to period rooms and homes, to stabilize delicate ebony and tortoiseshell inlays and flecks of gilding on furniture made before World War II. The profusions of modern plastics, however, have created repair challenges unlike any known before.\n\nSome of the problematic midcentury plastics used in furniture were formulated for military use. The domestic goods created from these polymers were marketed as versatile, affordable and easy to clean. Now, several of the more experimental objects are falling into mysterious decay.", "title": "No, Your Furniture Shouldn\u2019t Drip or Burst", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I wanted to make smothered pork chops (above) in the middle of last week, a feed for a day when things are generally falling apart in the kitchen and in our lives, everyone caught between weekends, a little frantic or bummed, with no desire to shop or follow instruction or really do anything more than receive comfort.\n\nI had the idea around 10 in the morning, a few hours into a shift and a great many ahead of me before I could scooch out to get supplies. I checked the recipe again. It called for three hours of cooking after a 12-hour soak of the pork chops in brine. My idea wasn\u2019t going to work, and I was saddened, as many are on Wednesdays, facing facts.\n\nBut I made the dish anyway. And you can, too, at least if you believe in the precepts of no-recipe recipes and especially if you\u2019ve followed the crowds and gotten yourself an electric multicooker. (You don\u2019t need one. You can always cook in one pan on the stove, letting everything bubble along under a lid until the meat collapses. But it helps to use the science machine. The stovetop version will leave you eating late.)\n\nSo here\u2019s a nice Wednesday-night meal. Buy the thickest pork chop you can for each person you\u2019re serving, on the bone and hopefully with a jaunty cap of fat. Salt and pepper the chops, herb them up as you like, rub them with flour and then brown each one hard in a pan dressed with oil or bacon grease. Set the browned chops aside and cook a whole lot of chopped onions in the remaining fat in the pan, then hit them with a few tablespoons or up to half a cup of flour, stirring and cooking until the whole lot of it goes dark and caramel and a little bit dry. Add enough chicken stock to make the onions turn into a kind of gravy, then watch it thicken and add a little more stock but not too much. You want it kind of thick.", "title": "No-Recipe Smothered Pork Chops", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Fortunately, Mr. Audley has wide-ranging tastes. Six shorts I recently sampled on the site were all striking, well made and had strong, distinct filmmaking voices.\n\n\u201cLance Lizardi\u201d (2017), which calls itself \u201ca film by Lance Lizardi\u201d but appears to be the work of Xander Robin, whose unusual feature \u201cAre We Not Cats\u201d recently opened in New York, starts off as a goofy home-baked quasi-doc about a guy who likes lizards so much he gets his name changed; it subtly morphs into an absurdist parable about taking lizard love too far.\n\n\u201cImprov Is Love\u201d (2017), another comedy, is a brutal, concise sendup of the \u201cdo what you love\u201d philosophy of life, in which an aspiring improv comedy dude (Matt Barats, who also wrote the short, which was directed by Doron Hagay) evades a family crisis to pursue his art.\n\n\u201cTaxfree,\u201d a Norwegian picture (released there in 2015) directed by Henry K. Norvalls, begins on banal notes shot straightforwardly: An attractive young woman (Selome Emnetu) picks up a bag at an airport luggage carousel, has a friendly conversation with her driver, and gets prepared, in a pleasant hotel room, for a photo shoot. The turn it makes then constitutes something of a Rorschach test. Is this a kind of horror film or a frank depiction of individuals\u2019 negotiating market forces to their advantage?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cRockaway\u201d (2012), directed by Melanie Schiele, is both a starkly evocative portrait of the New York City neighborhood it depicts and was shot in, and a frank but poignant character study. Teresa, played by Audrey Tommassini, acts out self-destructively while holed up in the house of her recently deceased grandmother. \u201cAll Shook Up\u201d (2017), directed by Eva Michon, is a surrealist nightmare in which losing a credit card in a mugging turns out to be the least of its lead character\u2019s problems.\n\nKevin Vu\u2019s \u201cSplendona\u201d (2017) envisions an \u201980s fashion firm that uses unusual models for its runway shows and fashion magazine spreads.\n\nThe site itself posts the videos with written intros (largely) by Mr. Audley; the videos themselves are hosted by Vimeo, which offers detailed instructions for watching the videos on a television screen. It can be done via Google Chromecast, or through a variety of boxes or smart TVs that support the Vimeo app.\n\nSeeing NoBudge through changes over nearly a decade has been a learning experience for its founder. \u201cAfter I began making films, I saw advances in technology that I thought would help tear down all existing distribution structures and knock down the gate for filmmakers who did not want to work within the Hollywood system or even the system that Sundance has come to represent,\u201d Mr. Audley said. His idealism didn\u2019t benefit him. \u201cI put all my features online for free, and through doing that, I learned it\u2019s something I wouldn\u2019t necessarily recommend. A number of things didn\u2019t happen the way I envisioned.\u201d (\u201cSylvio\u201d is, as per the lessons Mr. Audley learned, not available on NoBudge but rather on several video-on-demand sites including Amazon, iTunes, Vimeo on Demand and Google Play.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnce the site opened itself to submissions, Mr. Audley saw that most of them were shorts. \u201cWhich,\u201d he said, \u201cI had never been very interested in previously, but then I began to love. It occurred to me that shorts have a bad connotation for a lot of people; the only way movie audiences see them are in feature-length blocks. Ten shorts in a row is rarely going to be a good experience. So offering them as discrete experiences seemed an approach that could be rewarding.\u201d\n\nIndeed, the \u00e0 la carte exploration afforded by the site is fun and yields surprises. And it\u2019s all free. (The site does accept monetary contributions; it has a Patreon page and also takes one-off donations, but neither is required.)\n\n\u201cAs a person, I\u2019m looking for an opportunity to separate art from commerce, in a simplistic way,\u201d Mr. Audley said. \u201cThe reasons to make movies aren\u2019t always commercial. Not because there\u2019s anything wrong with working to become a career filmmaker. But I think it\u2019s an important thing for people to understand, that we don\u2019t always have to be locked into that relationship.\u201d That being the case, Mr. Audley doesn\u2019t have an urge to steer the site into any extremes. \u201cMy own taste, which has been the determining factor, does tend toward what I consider entertaining and accessible. That\u2019s another point I want to make \u2014 that the alternative mode of moviemaking doesn\u2019t have to be \u2018avant-garde.\u2019\u201d", "title": "NoBudge, a One-Man Independent Film Factory", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "With Mr. Edwards playing bass and Mr. Bogle on lead guitar, the Ventures recorded \u201cWalk \u2014 Don\u2019t Run,\u201d which rose to No. 2 on Billboard\u2019s Hot 100 chart. Inspired by a slower, jazzier recording several years earlier by the country star Chet Atkins (the original recording was by the song\u2019s composer, the guitarist Johnny Smith), the Ventures\u2019 version had a propulsive power, driven by heavily amplified guitars and the drumming of Skip Moore.\n\nAlthough Mr. Bogle\u2019s playing was a key to the single\u2019s success, Mr. Edwards soon replaced him as the band\u2019s lead guitarist; Mr. Bogle\u2019s switch to bass was an acknowledgment of Mr. Edwards\u2019s greater skill. Peter Blecha, the author of \u201cSonic Boom! The History of Northwest Rock: From \u2018Louie Louie\u2019 to \u2018Smells Like Teen Spirit\u2019 \u201d (2009), said the strength of Mr. Edwards\u2019s playing rested on the \u201cfluidity of his picking\u201d and the way he added \u201cmelodic flourishes in surprising places.\u201d\n\nThe band followed \u201cWalk \u2014 Don\u2019t Run\u201d with other hits, like \u201cPerfidia,\u201d a much-recorded song that reached No. 15 on the Billboard chart, and \u201cSlaughter on Tenth Avenue,\u201d which peaked at No. 35. \u201cWipe Out,\u201d a hit for the Surfaris in 1963, became a signature song for the Ventures.\n\nIn 1964, the band rerecorded \u201cWalk \u2014 Don\u2019t Run\u201d with Mr. Edwards on lead and a new arrangement. The song reached the Top 10 again.\n\nNearly 50 years later, Mr. Edwards said he had at least two more arrangements of the song. \u201cI may put it out and who knows, I may get another hit out of it again,\u201d he told the website Ultimate Guitar in 2011.\n\nThe Ventures\u2019 second-biggest hit was their version of the theme song from the long-running CBS television show \u201cHawaii Five-O,\u201d which went to No. 4 in 1969. It became a concert staple both for the group and for Mr. Edwards as a solo performer.\n\nNole Floyd Edwards was born on May 9, 1935, in Lahoma, Okla. His father, Elbert, and his mother, the former Nannie Mae Quinton, were migrant fruit workers. In a family of guitarists, fiddlers, pianists and banjo players, young Nokie was playing guitar by age 5.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout that time, the Edwardses \u2014 who by then had 11 children \u2014 left their land, then owned by his mother and her Cherokee family, after violent disputes with merchants who wanted them to sell it, Judy Edwards said. They fled in a horse-drawn wagon, crossed the Great Plains, stopped for a time in Idaho and settled in Puyallup, Wash., south of Seattle.\n\nMr. Edwards stayed with the Ventures until 1968, returned in 1972 and stayed until 1984.\n\n\u201cHe left the group a few times,\u201d Mr. Wilson said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe said, \u2018I\u2019m tired of playing the same songs over and over again.\u2019 \u201d\n\nAfter that, he occasionally recorded and toured with the Ventures, sometimes in Japan, where they have been popular for decades. The band, which is still active, has gone through various permutations. Mr. Wilson retired in 2015 but still occasionally records; Mr. Bogle died in 2009.\n\nMr. Edwards played with various artists in his career, including the country star Lefty Frizzell. In recent years he formed a company, HitchHiker, to make custom guitars, and toured with his own group, the HitchHiker Band. Among other honors, he was inducted into the Native American Music Awards & Association\u2019s Hall of Fame in 2011. His composition \u201cSurf Rider\u201d \u2014 which another surf-rock instrumental band, the Lively Ones, recorded in 1963 \u2014 was on the soundtrack of the 1994 movie \u201cPulp Fiction.\u201d\n\nIn addition to his wife, the former Judy Bean, Mr. Edwards\u2019s survivors include a daughter, Tina Edwards Nickerson; two stepsons, Patrick Fetters and Seth Chappell; 25 grandchildren; 10 great-grandchildren; four great-great-grandchildren; and a sister, Louise Jensen. A daughter, Kim, died in 1988. His marriages to Zelda Wade and Jean Bauers ended in divorce.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Edwards played his last show in January 2017, with the HitchHiker Band in Medford, Ore. Despite poor health, he refused to cancel the show and was brought onstage in a wheelchair before shifting to a stool to perform.\n\n\u201cHe was in a lot of distress, but he got onstage and played very well,\u201d Dan Estremado, who played guitar with Mr. Edwards that night, said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe did the best he could but kind of gave out at the end.\u201d\n\nHe went to a hospital afterward, where, his wife said, the doctor remarked that he could have \u201cfallen off the stool and died onstage from internal bleeding.\u201d\n\nIn his final days, she said, she played YouTube videos of songs for Mr. Edwards in his hospital room \u2014 including Thom Bresh and him playing \u201cI\u2019ll See You in My Dreams.\u201d", "title": "Nokie Edwards, Whose Guitar Drove the Ventures, Is Dead at 82", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The burden on prosecutors after that was high: They had to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Ms. Salman knowingly and willfully helped or tried to help Mr. Mateen commit an act that would provide material support to the Islamic State. Merely being his wife or unwittingly assisting her husband was not enough, said Joshua L. Dratel, a New York lawyer experienced in defending terrorism cases.\n\n\u201cYou have to share the intent of the actor,\u201d Mr. Dratel said. \u201cYou have to do something to make the crime succeed \u2014 not do something that makes the crime succeed without knowing that the crime is going to occur. You have to have both of those elements.\u201d\n\nProsecutors did not have to prove a motive, though Ms. Sweeney, an assistant United States attorney, said in her closing argument on Wednesday that Ms. Salman could have aided Mr. Mateen out of love, money or spite. But while Mr. Mateen\u2019s internet browsing and social media records showed intense radicalization, there was no similar history for Ms. Salman. In fact, twice on Facebook she criticized Islamic terrorists, at one point calling them bad Muslims.\n\n\u201cIn today\u2019s world, to have a case like that where you have access to all the social media, you have access to the phones, you have access to the computers \u2014 all of that, and you don\u2019t have a specific piece of evidence pointing to her intent? You don\u2019t have a case,\u201d Mr. Dratel said.\n\nIn her supposed confession, Ms. Salman told F.B.I. agents that she and Mr. Mateen had scouted Pulse as a target for the June 12, 2016, attack, yet investigators apparently knew just days later that there was no evidence to corroborate that. That false statement in her confession called into question the rest of what she told law enforcement over more than 11 hours of questioning without a lawyer present. The F.B.I. made no audio or video recordings of the interview. The jury foreman told The Sentinel that he wished a recording had been available.\n\n\u201cTwenty years ago, not everybody who you ran into had a digital recorder in their pocket, and we didn\u2019t have \u2018CSI\u2019 shows, and we didn\u2019t expect to have everything on tape for us to see,\u201d said David S. Weinstein, a former federal prosecutor in Miami who is now a defense lawyer. \u201cBut that\u2019s what we expect now. If there isn\u2019t a picture, it didn\u2019t happen. So the fact that they didn\u2019t record the confession helped to raise this reasonable doubt as to what was being said.\u201d\n\nThe final coup for the defense came during the prosecution\u2019s closing argument, when Ms. Sweeney for the first time suggested that the reason Ms. Salman told F.B.I. agents that she and Mr. Mateen had driven by Pulse was because she incorrectly thought the nightclub was at the Disney Springs shopping and entertainment complex, formerly known as Downtown Disney, which the couple did visit.", "title": "Noor Salman Acquitted in Pulse Nightclub Shooting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNordstrom\u2019s long, winding attempt to move into private ownership took another turn Monday. A special committee of the retailer\u2019s board rejected a roughly $8.4 billion offer from the Nordstrom family to buy the company, saying the price was too low.\n\nIn a statement late Monday, the committee said the cash offer of $50 a share was \u201cinadequate,\u201d and it threatened to cut off further discussions with the family group, which includes the company\u2019s co-presidents and a granddaughter of one its founders.\n\n\u201cUnless the group can promptly and substantially improve the price it is proposing to pay for the company, the special committee intends to terminate discussions,\u201d according to the statement. The committee also said it would not provide the family with any additional \u201cdue diligence\u201d information.\n\nIt has been eight months since the family, which founded Nordstrom in Seattle more than a century ago, signaled that it wanted to take the company private. Known for its stylish high-end clothing and successful discount stores, Nordstrom has been seeking a respite from the public stock market and its harsh scrutiny of brick-and-mortar retailers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a letter to the special committee on Monday, the family group said going private would \u201censure that the company has the flexibility to successfully navigate a challenging retail landscape at a critical time when the public market for retail stocks is highly volatile and increasingly focused on short-term results and risks.\u201d", "title": "Nordstrom Family\u2019s Bid to Buy the Retailer Is Rejected", "authors": ["Michael Corkery"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The historical society show, which opens at the end of May, will be divided into five sections. \u201cThe War Generation\u201d section begins with a look at the political and socioeconomic climate in which Roosevelt articulated the Four Freedoms, along with a recording of one of his fireside chats from 1938. \u201cFDR\u2019s Freedoms\u201d turns to Roosevelt\u2019s proclamation of the Four Freedoms as a reason to enter the war. \u201cThe Artistic Response to the Four Freedoms Ideals\u201d includes paintings, drawings, sculpture, prints and stamps, by the artists who heeded Roosevelt\u2019s call. \u201cRockwell\u2019s Four Freedoms\u201d tells the story of the painter\u2019s vision of the freedoms, while \u201cFreedom\u2019s Legacy\u201d explores Mr. Rockwell\u2019s continuing focus on human rights.\n\nAlong with the original Four Freedoms, Mr. Rockwell\u2019s painting \u201cThe Golden Rule,\u201d which graced the cover of The Saturday Evening Post in 1961, is on view. So is his 1963 painting, \u201cThe Problem We All Live With,\u201d which depicts an African-American girl being escorted by four United States marshals to her first day at an all-white school in New Orleans, based on the story of Ruby Bridges. \u201cThe Right to Know,\u201d about the need for government transparency, was inspired by the Vietnam War in 1968.\n\n\u201cWe think of Rockwell as small-town America and the mundaneness of everyday life,\u201d Ms. Mirrer said, \u201cbut a lot of his 1960s work is powerful and deals with really difficult issues.\u201d", "title": "Norman Rockwell\u2019s Vision of F.D.R.\u2019s Four Freedoms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "From the start, North American officials have taken pains to emphasize the ready-to-wear nature of their proposal.\n\nBut Kristick, a veteran of the losing United States bid in 2010, knows how fast new arenas can pop up, so he is keeping some options open. He cited Atlanta\u2019s Mercedes-Benz Stadium and Levi\u2019s Stadium as two venues that did not exist when he was part of the 2010 bid but that could host games today. For another example, the Rose Bowl is the listed Los Angeles site in the bid book, but the book also mentions a proposed N.F.L. stadium in Inglewood, Calif., in making the city\u2019s case.\n\n\u201cInglewood is not being bid to host the World Cup,\u201d Kristick said. \u201cIt\u2019s being built as an N.F.L. stadium, and they are making it available to be a possible stadium for the World Cup.\u201d\n\nNorth American bid officials are expected to emphasize to FIFA voters the joint nature of the effort and what Kristick labeled the \u201ccertainty\u201d of their bid\u2019s pre-existing infrastructure. The United Bid last week reorganized its leadership, installing the soccer federation presidents of the three bidding nations as co-presidents to project a spirit of unity and cooperation in what had been seen, probably correctly, as a United States-dominated effort.\n\nThe moves were widely viewed as tactical \u2014 three presidents could lobby more FIFA voters than one could \u2014 but also as political: part of an effort to de-emphasize the United States\u2019 role ahead of a vote to FIFA members still angry about a Department of Justice investigation that, since 2015, has led to the ouster of FIFA\u2019s top leadership and criminal charges for dozens of former soccer executives.\n\nMorocco is expected to submit a 2026 proposal to FIFA by Friday\u2019s deadline, but its plan is far more theoretical at this point. Morocco did not reveal even the basics of its bid until earlier this year, and the very nature of the expanded 2026 event makes it a monumental challenge for a single country.\n\nMoroccan bid officials, for example, announced in February that they wanted to use as many as 14 stadiums for the tournament. But the country currently has only six that might be up to the task, and several of those facilities would need major improvements to meet minimum standards for capacity and safety set by FIFA for the World Cup.", "title": "North American Bid for 2026 World Cup Includes 23 Cities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The committee bidding to bring soccer\u2019s 2026 World Cup to the United States, Mexico and Canada shuffled its leadership on Tuesday, announcing in a letter to FIFA\u2019s 211 member associations that the bid\u2019s chairman, Sunil Gulati, would relinquish that role to the federation presidents of the three countries in a change that they hope will stress the joint nature of the bid.\n\nGulati, the former U.S. Soccer president, will remain on the bid\u2019s board and continue to be a conduit to global soccer\u2019s top leadership through his position on FIFA\u2019s leadership council. But he will be replaced as the public face of the bid by three co-presidents \u2014 Carlos Cordeiro of the United States, Decio De Mar\u00eda of Mexico and Steven Reed of Canada \u2014 in the new structure.\n\nThe move appears to be political and tactical. Gulati\u2019s presence as chairman, and his success in claiming 75 percent of the potential 2026 World Cup matches for stadiums in the United States, had given the bid a distinctly American flavor. But three years after a Department of Justice investigation revealed widespread corruption at the highest levels of FIFA, leading to the ouster of most of its senior leadership, and as President Trump has stoked fear about immigrants and insulted entire countries, the prospect that the vote could descend into a referendum on the United States or its government\u2019s policies was not an insignificant bit of political calculus.\n\nGulati praised the move, calling it \u201cappropriate\u201d as the countries shifted to campaign mode.", "title": "North American World Cup Bid Shuffles Leaders and Tactics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "GLOUCESTER, Mass. \u2014 For the highly endangered North Atlantic right whale, the year has begun badly. One young whale that had become entangled in fishing lines was found dead in January off Virginia. Worse, not a single newborn has yet been spotted by scientists flying over the whale\u2019s calving grounds off Florida and Georgia.\n\nLast year wasn\u2019t good, either. Only five calves were known to have been born, and at least 17 whales died.\n\nOnly about 450 of these whales remain. Once decimated by commercial whaling, the right whale had been thought to be making a slow return in recent decades, with its numbers rising to about 480 in 2010 from approximately 270 in 1990. But their recovery has since faltered and their numbers are declining. If we don\u2019t act now, in a little over 20 years, the breeding females alive today may all disappear, leaving little hope for the species. How did this happen, especially since the right whale has been protected from hunting for decades?\n\nThese days, the whales are dying not from harpoons but from collisions with ships and injuries from increasingly strong fishing gear and ropes. The whales\u2019 migration route from their calving ground to their summering areas in the Gulf of Maine and Bay of Fundy cross innumerable shipping lanes and areas filled with millions of lobster and snow crab traps and thousands of miles of fishing line. Disasters are inevitable. Eighty percent of known right whale deaths are caused by humans. Our actions may be unintentional but they have been catastrophic.", "title": "Opinion | North Atlantic Right Whales Are Near Extinction. We Can Avert It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Behind the scenes, events unfolded even more haphazardly. Mr. Trump was not scheduled to meet Mr. Chung until Friday, but when he heard that the envoy was in the West Wing seeing other officials, the president summoned him to the Oval Office, according to a senior administration official.\n\nMr. Trump, the official said, then asked Mr. Chung to tell him about his meeting with Mr. Kim. When Mr. Chung said that the North Korean leader had expressed a desire to meet Mr. Trump, the president immediately said he would do it, and directed Mr. Chung to announce it to the White House press corps.\n\nMr. Chung, nonplused, said he first needed approval from Mr. Moon, who quickly granted it in a phone call. Mr. Trump later called Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, and the two discussed coordinating diplomatic efforts. Mr. Trump also plans to call President Xi Jinping of China.\n\nBy day\u2019s end, dazed White House officials were discussing whether Mr. Trump would invite Mr. Kim to come to the United States. That seemed entirely likely, the senior administration official said, though American officials doubt the North Korean leader would accept.\n\nThe announcement capped another day of swirling drama at the White House, in which the president defied his own party by announcing sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum imports and sought to ignore a mushrooming scandal over a pornographic film actress who claims to have had an affair with him.\n\nWhite House officials had expected to deliberate for several days over how to respond to North Korea\u2019s proposal for direct talks between the countries, which South Korean officials had first conveyed by telephone this week. But Mr. Kim\u2019s offer of a leader-to-leader meeting accelerated, if not upended, the administration\u2019s plans.", "title": "North Korea Asks for Direct Nuclear Talks, and Trump Agrees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHearing the intention of President Moon Jae-in for a summit from the special envoy of the south side, he exchanged views and made a satisfactory agreement,\u201d it said. \u201cHe gave the important instruction to the relevant field to rapidly take practical steps for it.\u201d\n\nMr. Kim first proposed a meeting with Mr. Moon in Pyongyang, delivering his invitation through his sister, Kim Yo-jong, who met Mr. Moon in Seoul last month. Mr. Moon has said that the two Koreas must first \u201ccreate the environment\u201d to make a meeting possible.\n\nWashington remains deeply skeptical of any attempt by the South to improve ties with the North without any progress in international efforts to end the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program. Although he advocates dialogue with North Korea, Mr. Moon acknowledges that the two initiatives must move \u201cin parallel,\u201d and has been urging the United States and North Korea to start negotiations on the nuclear program.\n\nA senior aide of Mr. Moon\u2019s told reporters in Seoul that the results of the talks would be announced after the envoys returned home later Tuesday from the two-day trip, he said.\n\nMr. Moon and Mr. Kim have both said they want to use an opening created by the North\u2019s participation in the Winter Olympics in South Korea last month to improve inter-Korean ties.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Washington and North Korea remain far apart over the terms under which they would start a dialogue, a gap that South Korea seeks to narrow. After returning home from Pyongyang, the South Korean envoys will fly to Washington for discussions with the Trump administration.\n\nThe Trump administration says it is determined not to repeat what it calls the mistakes of its predecessors, who tried both dialogue and sanctions but failed to stop the North\u2019s nuclear program. The administration now says it will enter negotiations with North Korea only after it commits to discussing denuclearization.\n\nAmerican officials fear that North Korea is more interested in weakening sanctions that have begun biting the impoverished country than engaging in serious negotiations. Even if talks begin, they say, Washington will not stop its campaign of \u201cmaximum\u201d pressure and sanctions until the North dismantles its nuclear weapons program.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorth Korea rejects any preconditions for talks, saying Washington must treat it like an \u201cequal\u201d nuclear power. It also insists that any talks with Washington would have to deal not only with its nuclear program but also with \u201chostile\u201d American policies, like the United States\u2019 annual joint military exercises with the South, which the North says forced it to seek a nuclear deterrent in the first place.\n\nMr. Moon spent most of the last year helplessly watching the Korean Peninsula edge toward a possible war, as the North test-launched intercontinental ballistic missiles and conducted its most powerful nuclear test, and Mr. Trump threatened to rain down \u201cfire and fury\u201d on North Korea.\n\nMr. Moon saw an opening when Mr. Kim agreed to send North Korean envoys, as well as athletes and cheerleaders, to the Olympics. He has since assumed the role of a matchmaker in persuading Washington and Pyongyang to soften their stances enough to make dialogue possible.\n\nThe last time South Korea sent an envoy to Pyongyang was in 2007, toward the tail end of the South\u2019s decade-long \u201cSunshine Policy\u201d of encouraging economic and other exchanges with the North. But a conservative leader took power in Seoul the following year, cutting off inter-Korean trade in retaliation against the North\u2019s nuclear weapons development and other provocations.\n\nKim Jong-un has accelerated his country\u2019s nuclear and missile tests since inheriting power after his father, Kim Jong-il, died in 2011. After launching an intercontinental ballistic missile in November, Mr. Kim claimed to have a \u201cnuclear button\u201d on his desk with which he could fire missiles capable of reaching the mainland United States. American officials say Mr. Kim is getting dangerously close to achieving the ability to strike the United States with nuclear-tipped missiles.\n\nMr. Kim, at 34, is one of the world\u2019s youngest and most reclusive dictators. He has met with envoys from China and Cuba, as well as personal guests, including the American basketball star Dennis Rodman. But until now, he has never met any envoy from South Korea. Neither has he visited any foreign country as North Korea\u2019s leader, although he studied in Switzerland as a teenager.", "title": "North Korea Hails \u2018Openhearted Talk\u2019 With South Korean Envoys", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea\u2019s apparent agreement to talk to the United States about abandoning its nuclear weapons is a relief after the world faced months of tension over Pyongyang\u2019s testing of those devices and Washington\u2019s bellicose response.\n\nFor once, President Trump\u2019s tweeted reaction made sense. \u201cPossible progress being made in talks with North Korea,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cFor the first time in many years, a serious effort is being made by all parties concerned. The World is watching and waiting! May be false hope, but the U.S. is ready to go hard in either direction!\u201d\n\nAs he indicated, optimism needs to be tempered with caution, since the hard work needed for a peaceful solution would have to overcome years of distrust and the bitterness of failed negotiations. But there finally seems to be an opening for talks, so the Trump administration needs to seize it.\n\nThe news that North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, had agreed to discuss ending his nuclear program in exchange for security guarantees and that he would suspend tests of weapons and missiles during negotiations came from senior South Korean diplomats after discussions in Pyongyang with Mr. Kim. They were the first representatives of the South to meet with Mr. Kim since he came to power six years ago. While the North has not yet made its own statement on the talks, the fact that the South Korean delegation met directly with Mr. Kim was significant.", "title": "Opinion | North Korea Has Put the Ball in Trump\u2019s Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe North expressed its willingness to hold a heartfelt dialogue with the United States on the issues of denuclearization and normalizing relations with the United States,\u201d the statement said. \u201cIt made it clear that while dialogue is continuing, it will not attempt any strategic provocations, such as nuclear and ballistic missile tests.\u201d\n\nOn Twitter, Mr. Trump, who has veered from bellicose threats against Mr. Kim to offers to sit down with him, welcomed what he called \u201cpossible progress\u201d with the North. \u201cFor the first time in many years, a serious effort is being made by all parties concerned,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cThe World is watching and waiting! May be false hope, but the U.S. is ready to go hard in either direction!\u201d\n\nMr. Trump expounded on his reaction later to reporters during an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Stefan Lofven of Sweden. \u201cWe have come certainly a long way, at least rhetorically, with North Korea,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cThe statements coming out of South Korea and North Korea have been very positive. That would be a great thing for the world.\u201d\n\nAsked if he would meet with Mr. Kim, Mr. Trump said, \u201cWe\u2019ll see what happens.\u201d\n\nThe cautious American reaction partly reflected a history of suspicion toward the motives of North Korea, which has remained an enemy of the United States since the 1950-53 Korean War.\n\nA pattern of what American officials have described as North Korean duplicity in previous talks has repeated itself, with modest variations, during the Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama administrations. In January 2009, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, who had served under both Mr. Bush and Mr. Obama, summarized the American skepticism about North Korea with an oft-repeated line: \u201cI\u2019m tired of buying the same horse twice.\u201d\n\nThe South Korean statement said the two Koreas would begin working-level discussions to prepare for the summit meeting, to be held in the Peace House, a South Korean building in Panmunjom, the so-called truce village that straddles the border. Before Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon meet, the countries will install, for the first time, a hotline by which the leaders can talk on the phone directly, the statement said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe statement gave no indication that North Korea would start dismantling nuclear or missile programs anytime soon. Nonetheless, the reported agreements represented major progress in Mr. Moon\u2019s efforts to improve relations with North Korea. Those efforts advanced considerably during the recent Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, to which Mr. Kim sent athletes, entertainers and political delegations that included his sister.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe top South Korean envoys who returned from North Korea on Tuesday \u2014 Mr. Moon\u2019s national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, and the director of the South\u2019s National Intelligence Service, Suh Hoon \u2014 are expected to be dispatched to Washington this week to brief the Trump administration on their discussions with Mr. Kim.\n\nMr. Chung told reporters in Seoul, the South Korean capital, that Mr. Kim had been unexpectedly flexible. He said the delegation had expected him to insist that the South and the United States not hold their annual joint military exercises, which were suspended for the Olympics.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un simply said he could understand why the joint exercises must resume in April on the same scale as before,\u201d Mr. Chung said. \u201cBut he said he expected them to be readjusted if the situation on the Korean Peninsula stabilizes in the future.\u201d\n\nMr. Chung said the South Koreans believed that their agreements with North Korea would be enough to start a dialogue between Washington and Pyongyang. He also said he was carrying additional messages from Mr. Kim to the Trump administration that he could not reveal.\n\n\u201cThere was no other specific demand from North Korea in returning to dialogue,\u201d he said. \u201cThey only said they wanted to be treated like a serious dialogue partner.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Trump, the overture by North Korea sets in motion a challenging phase that will call on the United States to exercise diplomatic muscles after a long stretch in which the White House relied on economic pressure, backed by threats of military force, to deal with the North.\n\nThat challenge will be compounded because the State Department\u2019s veteran North Korea negotiator, Joe Yun, recently announced his retirement from the Foreign Service. Another experienced negotiator, Victor Cha, was recently sidelined when the White House decided not to move ahead with his nomination as ambassador to South Korea.\n\nAdministration officials are deeply wary of being drawn into a negotiation in which the United States makes concessions \u2014 on issues like military exercises or shipments of medical and food aid \u2014 only to see the North Koreans renege on their commitments later.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has said that the United States could talk with North Korea, but \u201conly under the right conditions.\u201d American officials have repeatedly said they can start negotiations with the North only if it agrees to discuss denuclearizing. They have also insisted that the North first take some actions that would convince them of its sincerity.\n\nDefense Minister Itsunori Onodera of Japan, which has steadfastly supported the Trump administration\u2019s tough approach to sanctions against North Korea, struck a note of caution about Pyongyang\u2019s interest in negotiations.\n\n\u201cWhile talking about nuclear abandonment several times, it turned out that North Korea didn\u2019t halt its nuclear development in the past,\u201d Mr. Onodera said. \u201cWe need to carefully assess if this North and South dialogue will really lead to the abandonment of nuclear and missile development.\u201d\n\nChina, which has pushed for direct talks between Pyongyang and Washington for many months, welcomed the South Korean statement. Geng Shuang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said China hoped \u201cthe relevant parties can seize the current opportunity\u201d to work toward \u201cpolitically resolving the Korean Peninsula issue.\u201d\n\nOne Chinese expert on North Korea characterized Pyongyang\u2019s reported offer as \u201cconcessions that are dramatic and significant.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt will be hard for the U.S. government to resist,\u201d said the expert, Cheng Xiaohe, of Renmin University in Beijing.\n\nBut Evans J. R. Revere, a former State Department official who was involved in previous negotiations with North Korea, was less impressed. He said the formula of denuclearization for security guarantees had \u201cbeen the basis of several sets of talks\u201d between the two countries in the past.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. has actually provided security guarantees to North Korea, including in writing by President Clinton,\u201d Mr. Revere said. \u201cSuch guarantees have never been adequate or acceptable to the North Koreans, just as the U.S. provision of alternative energy sources, food and other assistance has never proved adequate.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe also noted that the moratorium on nuclear and missile tests offered by the North would not prevent Pyongyang from continuing to build its nuclear arsenal, including by producing fissile material for nuclear weapons.\n\nEven so, Mr. Revere said the Trump administration would be hard-pressed to reject the North\u2019s proposal without making it appear that Washington \u2014 not Pyongyang \u2014 was the problem.\n\n\u201cWith these developments, the door seems wide open to a U.S.-North Korea exploratory conversation if both sides want one,\u201d he said. The North went to considerable lengths to meet the American demand that dialogue had to be about denuclearization, he said.\n\nThe 10 members of the delegation Mr. Moon sent to the North were the first South Korean officials to meet Mr. Kim since he took power six years ago. They were also the first outside officials to directly hear Mr. Kim explain his intentions regarding his country\u2019s nuclear weapons programs.\n\nMr. Kim, 34, has accelerated the North\u2019s nuclear and missile tests since inheriting power after his father, Kim Jong-il, died in 2011. Mr. Moon spent most of the past year helplessly watching the Korean Peninsula edge toward possible war as the North test-launched intercontinental ballistic missiles and conducted its most powerful nuclear test yet, while Mr. Trump threatened to rain down \u201cfire and fury\u201d on North Korea.\n\nAfter launching an intercontinental ballistic missile in November, Mr. Kim claimed to have a \u201cnuclear button\u201d on his desk with which he could fire missiles capable of reaching the mainland United States. American officials say Mr. Kim is getting dangerously close to being able to strike the United States with nuclear-tipped missiles.\n\nBut Mr. Kim suddenly shifted his tone on New Year\u2019s Day, using an annual speech to propose sending a delegation to the Olympics. During the Games last month, his sister, Kim Yo-jong, hand-delivered his proposal for a summit meeting with Mr. Moon.\n\nThe South Korean leader hoped to use the thaw surrounding the Olympics to improve inter-Korean ties and to steer the United States and North Korea away from what he called a collision course. Analysts say Mr. Kim\u2019s sudden overture for dialogue is driven at least in part by his desire to weaken sanctions that have begun biting his isolated country, as well as to stave off Washington\u2019s threat to use military force.", "title": "North Korea Signals Willingness to \u2018Denuclearize,\u2019 South Says", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "She was stabbed 11 times and partly burned, and a neighbor is one of the suspects. But is it ethical?\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nOn this day in 1961, the 23rd Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was approved by the required three-fourths of the states, giving Washingtonians the right to vote for president and vice president for the first time in more than 160 years.\n\n\u201cThe United States finally gave its capital the vote today,\u201d The Times noted on its front page, with a hint of impatience.\n\nThe amendment granted representation to the District of Columbia in the Electoral College, where states are given electors based on population. Although the District\u2019s population (estimated around 700,000 in 2017) is larger than that of some states, it is given no more electors than the least populous state, which is currently Wyoming.\n\nAt the time, the push to give the vote to the district, with its large African-American population, became caught up in the civil rights movement. The amendment was opposed in the South, where Tennessee was the only state to ratify it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDemocrats have since been able to count on the district\u2019s three electoral votes, which have been cast for each of the party\u2019s presidential candidates, starting with Lyndon Johnson in 1964.\n\nAlthough the district\u2019s residents have a say at the White House, they lack a full voice in Congress, where their representative does not have full voting rights.\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nPaying billions to escape a five-star jail\n\n\u2022 As Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia prepares to travel to the U.S. this month to court American investment, Saudi officials are spotlighting his reforms.\n\nBut he is also the architect of the crackdown last year in which hundreds of influential businessmen \u2014 many of them members of the royal family \u2014 were held in the Riyadh Ritz-Carlton in what the government called an anticorruption campaign.", "title": "North Korea, East River, N.C.A.A. Tournament: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "As Mr. Putin blamed the fire on \u201ccriminal negligence,\u201d thousands of people protested nearby to demand transparency and accountability. \u201cI no longer have a family,\u201d one demonstrator said. \u201cThe ruling regime is guilty.\u201d\n\nAnd after the mass expulsion of Russian diplomats over the poisoning of a Russian ex-spy on British soil, some in the Kremlin say tensions with the West could become more volatile than during the Cold War.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 Repeal America\u2019s right to bear arms?\n\nJohn Paul Stevens, a retired U.S. Supreme Court justice, writes in a Times Op-Ed that scrapping the Second Amendment would move gun-law campaigners \u201ccloser to their objective than any other possible reform.\u201d\n\nMr. Stevens argues that, until a 2008 Supreme Court ruling, there was no absolute right to guns. He calls the amendment \u201ca relic,\u201d and says it needs to go.\n\nAnd after Citigroup limited firearm sales by its retail clients, our business columnist suggested two more steps that banks could take to influence the gun control debate.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Less than one in a trillion.\n\nThose are the odds you\u2019ll be hit by debris from Tiangong-1, when the out-of-control Chinese space station plunges to Earth as early as April 1. (For many in the Northern Hemisphere, the chances are zero.) Above, a rocket carrying the Tiangong-1 lifting off in 2011.\n\nA 2016 malfunction cost Chinese scientists the ability to plop the 19,000-pound facility into the ocean. For now, it\u2019s orbiting the planet about 130 miles up, careening a mile lower every day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cNow the fish looks better and its owner will love it even more.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s Eugene Ng, a cosmetic surgeon in Singapore who operates on Asian arowana fish, also known as dragon fish, above with a collector.\n\nThey\u2019re a prized status symbol across Asia, with price tags that can reach tens of thousands of dollars. So for owners, less than $100 for an eyelift or chin job is pocket change.\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 HNA, the Chinese conglomerate, has become a global powerhouse. A Times investigation found that a key behind-the-scenes player in that rise was Wang Wei, the younger brother of the company\u2019s co-chairman.\n\n\u2022 Facebook\u2019s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, agreed to testify before Congress over the social network\u2019s handling of customer data.\n\n\u2022 Uber was ordered to suspend testing of its autonomous vehicles on Arizona roads, eight days after one of its cars struck and killed a woman in Tempe.\n\n\u2022 \u201cGreen gold.\u201d How the avocado became the fruit of global trade.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were lower. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cLost at sea.\u201d John Fisher, a 47-year-old Briton sailing for a Hong Kong-based team in the Volvo Ocean Race, was swept overboard in strong winds 1,400 miles west of Cape Horn. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 If Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia who was seized on Sunday, is returned to Spain, a trial could backfire by galvanizing the Catalan separatist movement. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Cambridge Analytica, the political firm at the center of the Facebook data scandal, is \u201cwhat modern day colonialism looks like,\u201d said Christopher Wylie, a former employee, at a U.K. parliamentary hearing. [CNBC]\n\n\u2022 Vietnam detained the singer and activist Do Nguyen Mai Khoi in Hanoi after she arrived home from Europe, her Australian husband said. [Reuters]\n\n\u2022 Are you a U.S. citizen? The 2020 U.S. census will ask respondents that question to measure how many people are eligible to vote. Critics say it will result in a significant undercount. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Chinese archaeologists are convinced that they have solved a centuries-old mystery and found the tomb of Cao Cao, a legendary warlord from 1,800 years ago. [South China Morning Post]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\n\u2022 What we know and don\u2019t know about how to lose weight.\n\n\u2022 Determine whether your sickness is contagious.\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Tonight, bake a lemon tart with a filling that\u2019s somewhere between a custard and a pudding.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Our correspondent visited Gerald Murnane, who has become a towering literary figure while living in obscurity in Australia, pecking away at his three typewriters (he refuses computers).\n\n\u2022 In memoriam. Li Ao, 82, a Taiwanese writer and politician who became known affectionately as the \u201cmadman\u201d for his fiery anti-establishment stance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 And the secrets of cockroaches: They can live for a week without a head and run as fast as 210 miles an hour, relative to their size. All of those feats, and more, are encoded in the insect\u2019s genome, which scientists recently finished sequencing.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nEach week, The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, highlights the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: torii.\n\nTorii (pronounced TOR-ee-ee) are familiar as a symbol of Japan, but many solvers were unsure of the word when it appeared in the March 20 puzzle with the clue \u201cTraditional Japanese gate.\u201d It has appeared 63 times in Times crosswords.\n\nThese gates, which have a traditional shape and structure, are closely related to the Shinto religion. Typically located at the entrance of Shinto shrines or in spots that hold special religious significance, they signal to worshipers a transition from the profane world to the sacred. By walking through the torii, one has entered the world of the Kami, or Shinto gods.\n\nThe earliest documentation of the torii in Japan dates to 922 A.D., during the Heian period.\n\nThe structure of the torii varies, but the most important parts are the pillars (hashira), the lintel placed on the two pillars (kasagi), and a tie-beam that keeps the structure together (nuki).\n\nFor the easier puzzles at the beginning of the week, the word might also appear with the clue: \u201cShinto temple gateway\u201d or \u201cShinto gateway.\u201d\n\nLater in the week, it might be referred to as: \u201cShinto shrine entrance,\u201d \u201cTraditional Japantown feature,\u201d \u201cDecorative gateway in Japan\u201d or \u201cJapanese portal.\u201d\n\nDeb Amlen contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.
