Gov. Rick Scott of Florida signed firearm restrictions into law, breaking with the N.R.A. in a state known for gun rights.\n\nThe $400 million Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School Public Safety Act raises the minimum age to buy a gun to 21, bans \u201cbump stocks\u201d and funds school police officers and mental health services. But it also allows some staff members to carry guns in schools.\n\n\u201cYou made your voices heard,\u201d he told students from Parkland. \u201cYou helped change your state. You made a difference. You should be proud.\u201d\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Martin Shkreli, the \u201cPharma Bro\u201d who became notorious for sharply increasing drug prices \u2014 and his sneering defenses of his actions \u2014 was sentenced to seven years in prison for fraud.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe convictions stemmed from his involvement with Retrophin, a pharmaceutical company he founded in 2011, and two hedge funds he ran.\n\nA federal judge authorized the government to seize Mr. Shkreli\u2019s assets, including a one-of-a-kind Wu-Tang Clan album, if he was unable to come up with $7.36 million in restitution.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Rebel snipers are preventing civilians from fleeing an enclave near Damascus that is under brutal aerial assault by Syrian government forces.\n\nWe talked to a U.N. official who entered the area with a relief convoy this week. He said that even if civilians could leave, they might choose to stay. They fear for their safety in government-held territory, and worry they\u2019d never be allowed to return home.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. For years, many majority-white megachurches around the country had been trying to become more diverse, and finding some success. Above, Gateway Church in Southlake, Tex.\n\nThen came the 2016 election. As white churchgoers, especially evangelicals, cheered the outcome, black worshipers began to trickle away.\n\nIn this essay, our reporter explains how he came upon the story \u2014 and how it made him think back to the little Baptist church he grew up in.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. The Winter Paralympics began in Pyeongchang with a glittering performance that championed coexistence. Above, the American team.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA record 567 athletes will participate in 10 days of competition in Alpine skiing, biathlon, cross-country skiing, Para ice hockey, snowboarding and wheelchair curling.\n\nUnlike at the Olympic opening ceremony, North and South Korea entered the stadium separately, after failing to agree on conditions for a dual march.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. A new photography show at the Museum of Modern Art in New York moves away from \u201cnavel-gazing digital obsession\u201d to explore reality-based portraiture, politics and gender.\n\n\u201cBeing\u201d features 17 artists, all under 45, and proved to our writer that \u201cold-fashioned photography in the hands of an artist can feel completely up-to-date.\u201d\n\nAbove, Stephanie Syjuco\u2019s \u201cCargo Cults: Cover-Up.\u201d The staged self-portrait questions how Western manufacturers both appropriate and create \u201cprimitive\u201d designs.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Dennis Rodman is going to get the Nobel Peace Prize,\u201d Stephen Colbert joked.\n\nAnd a friendly reminder: Daylight saving time starts on Sunday. Mayor Megan Barry of Nashville agreed to resign after a turbulent five weeks in which she acknowledged having an affair with the head of her security detail.\n\nOnce a rising Democratic star, Ms. Barry had faced persistent questions about misspent taxpayer money. She pleaded guilty to theft of property, a felony, and agreed to serve three years of probation and pay restitution for unlawful expenditures.\n\nMs. Barry\u2019s words when she first admitted to the affair proved prophetic: \u201cI know that God will forgive me, but that Nashville doesn\u2019t have to.\u201d\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. They\u2019re among the lowest paid in the country, and many teach in areas wracked by poverty and the opioid epidemic.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Robot big rigs are plying Arizona\u2019s highways.\n\nUber revealed that its self-driving trucks have been carrying commercial cargo for months, though it did not say how many. A licensed truck driver is at the wheel, ready to take over in an emergency \u2014 for now.\n\nThe company\u2019s vision: using autonomous trucks for highway long hauls, and transferring cargo to human drivers for the final few miles to the loading dock.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. North Korea claimed to have a state nuclear force after conducting its sixth nuclear test and test-launching intercontinental ballistic missiles last year.", "title": "North Korea, Seeking \u2018Equal Footing,\u2019 Rejects Preconditions for U.S. Talks", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The president has insisted that he won\u2019t back down from his plan to impose the tariffs \u2014 a move clearly aimed at China, which makes roughly as much steel as the rest of the world combined.\n\nHere\u2019s an explainer on the complex and longstanding steel dispute between the U.S. and China.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Broadcom\u2019s takeover of rival chip-maker Qualcomm \u2014 a deal worth about $117 billion \u2014 appears doomed after a U.S. government panel said the Singapore firm\u2019s bid could pose a risk to national security.\n\nThe panel, the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S., or Cfius, said that the deal could weaken \u201cQualcomm\u2019s technological leadership,\u201d giving an edge to Chinese companies like Huawei.\n\nWhat is Cfius? One mergers and acquisitions expert called it the \u201cultimate regulatory bazooka.\u201d Another said it has been \u201cturbocharged\u201d by the Trump administration. Here\u2019s a look at the panel and its powerful role in major deals.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Britain\u2019s foreign secretary called Russia \u201ca malign force around the world,\u201d and vowed to retaliate if investigators find that Moscow is behind the apparent poisoning of a former Russian intelligence officer and his daughter in southern England.\n\nThe former spy, Sergei Skripal, 66, and his 33-year-old daughter were reported to be critically ill after being exposed to \u201can unknown substance.\u201d Once jailed in Russia for selling secrets, Mr. Skripal was resettled in Britain in a 2010 spy exchange.\n\nThe \u201cmajor incident\u201d has drawn comparisons to the case of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian spy who was fatally poisoned in London in 2006.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cIt\u2019s always good when you find new penguins.\u201d\n\nSatellite images and a drone discovered about 1.5 million Ad\u00e9lie penguins living in the Danger Islands off Antarctica.\n\nThe discovery of the new colony substantially increases the known populations of the knee-high creatures and has raised questions about how they\u2019re finding enough food.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Asia, delivered to your inbox. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Australia and East Timor will sign a treaty that establishes the first-ever maritime border between the countries, resolving years of bitter wrangling in a deal that divides billions of dollars\u2019 worth of oil and gas beneath the Timor Sea. (Some countries have banned e-cigarettes.)\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Cumin-roasted salmon with a vinegary herb sauce will cure the midweek blues.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cLast chance travel\u201d: Tourist operators are catering to the growing number of travelers who want to experience disappearing cultures and natural habitats before they are irrevocably altered or vanish.\n\n\u2022 \u201cI will not marry, sir. I want to study.\u201d In India, awareness about underage marriages, and stronger responses from the authorities, has caused a decrease in the practice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 And soccer, it turns out, has a power to help people with dementia. Our correspondent visited an inspiring English community health program that helps a team\u2019s fans remember its highs and lows.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThis week is the anniversary of the birth of Gabriel Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez, the Colombian novelist who was affectionately known as Gabo in Latin America.\n\nBorn on March 6, 1927, Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez defined the writing style known as magical realism, but his escapades in real life were just as noteworthy.\n\nHe started his career as a journalist, at one point enraging the Colombian dictator Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla so much that Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez fled to Europe for two years.\n\nHe became such close friends with Fidel Castro that he would show the Cuban leader drafts of his unpublished books.\n\nAt one point, he vowed never to write as long as the Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet remained in power (a promise that was broken long before Pinochet\u2019s 17-year reign ended).\n\nAnd after being denied a U.S. visa for more than three decades, Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez arrived in America for the first time in 1995, at the invitation of President Bill Clinton.\n\nBefore Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez died, in 2014, a friend said the title of Gabo\u2019s memoir summed up his life: \u201cAll his motivation is contained in that title, \u2018To Live to Tell It\u2019 \u2014 it is the pleasure of telling the story,\u201d Jaime Abello said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. The White House is busy planning for President Trump\u2019s potential meeting with Kim Jong-un of North Korea. The idea is so risky \u2014 and seemingly far-fetched \u2014 that some of Mr. Trump\u2019s aides believe it will never happen. Above, a news broadcast in Seoul.\n\nHere\u2019s what we know about Mr. Kim, the enigmatic 34-year-old dictator. And we have the back story of how two South Korean envoys brought Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to Washington. They were shocked when Mr. Trump accepted.\n\nDid you keep up with the headlines this week? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "North Korea, Xi Jinping, Trade War: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "In one sign of easing relations, this year\u2019s joint South Korean-American military exercises are expected to be shorter in duration and deploy fewer military assets. Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, reported Friday that the exercises will last only a month instead of two, and that B1-bombers and aircraft carriers would not take part, as they have in the past.\n\nPyongyang has long opposed the annual drills, viewing them as preparation for an attack.\n\nThe talks in Stockholm also touched on Sweden\u2019s role in North Korea as a diplomatic stand-in for the United States, Canada and Australia, which do not have a presence there. Sweden provides so-called protective consular services for those countries, including meeting with citizens imprisoned there.\n\nOther topics included humanitarian conditions in North Korea, sanctions, regional cooperation and security issues for South Korea, Japan, Russia, China and the United States, according to the Swedish ministry.\n\nIn addition to his talks with the foreign minister, Mr. Ri met with Prime Minister Stefan Lofven on Friday morning.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Ri arrived in Sweden on Thursday for the talks, which had been long planned but gained widespread attention after Mr. Trump accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation.\n\nMr. Lofven said this month that he was willing to host a meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim. \u201cIf we can help in any way, we will do it,\u201d he said at a news conference, noting that Sweden has had an embassy in Pyongyang since the 1970s.\n\n\u201cTheir trust in us is longstanding because we were first on the spot. We were the ones to break the ice and open an embassy,\u201d said Erik Cornell, the Swedish ambassador who opened the country\u2019s embassy in Pyongyang in 1975.\n\nNiklas Swanstrom, the director of the Institute for Security and Development Policy, a Swedish research group, said the country has \u201chad some access and influence in North Korea.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cComparative to other Western states, we have had a unique relationship with the North Korean government, due to our neutrality, due to our supervisory role and also the protective mission,\u201d said Mr. Swanstrom, referring to Sweden\u2019s supervisory role in monitoring the armistice that ended hostilities in the Korean War.\n\nIf the upcoming talks were to be held in a foreign country, then Sweden or Switzerland could be an option, Mr. Swanstrom said, but added that it was more likely they would take place in the Korean Demilitarized Zone. \u201cThe DMZ is more likely, as Mr. Kim has not traveled outside the country since he took power,\u201d Mr. Swanstrom said.\n\nOn Friday, in a short statement to journalists, Ms. Wallstrom said, \u201cWe are glad that we can have this meeting.\u201d She added: \u201cBut we are not na\u00efve in any way. We do not think that we can solve this issue. It is up to the parties to solve it. If we can use our contacts in the best way, then we will do that.\u201d", "title": "North Korea-Sweden Talks Focus on \u2018Peaceful Solution\u2019 to Nuclear Conflict", "authors": ["Christina Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 North Korea\u2019s foreign minister flew to Sweden on Thursday, amid speculation that the country could be used as a venue for hammering out details of the planned talks between President Trump and Kim Jong-un, or could be the site of the talks themselves.\n\nForeign Minister Ri Yong-ho was seen at Beijing\u2019s international airport on Thursday, South Korea\u2019s Yonhap news agency reported, following earlier reports that he might go to Sweden. Hours later, the Swedish Foreign Ministry confirmed that Mr. Ri would indeed be visiting the country for talks on Thursday and Friday.\n\nSweden has long played an intermediary role between the United States and North Korea, which do not have diplomatic relations. With the United States lacking an embassy in North Korea, Sweden is the so-called protecting power that provides consular services for Americans, including meeting with citizens who are imprisoned there.\n\nSweden has also been the site of talks between North Korean officials and experts from the United States, South Korea and elsewhere.", "title": "North Korean Envoy in Sweden Amid Planning for Trump-Kim Meeting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "It was also a remarkable shift in tone at least, if not in strategy yet, by Mr. Kim just months after he raised fears of war on the Korean Peninsula with a series of nuclear and intercontinental ballistic missile tests.\n\nConsidered by many to be a ruthless dictator with an obsession for nuclear weapons and a penchant for killing disloyal aides and relatives, Mr. Kim was now presenting a different side by hosting the South Korean envoys, who came to appeal to him to change course.\n\nFor the first time, the South Korean officials were invited into the headquarters of Mr. Kim\u2019s ruling Workers\u2019 Party. Mr. Kim beamed across the negotiating table, while the guests appeared to hang on his every word.\n\nHis wife, Ri Sol-ju, was the first North Korean first lady to be introduced to South Korean guests.\n\nWhen it was time for farewells after a night of talking and dining, Mr. Kim walked them out and sent them off with smiles and waves.\n\nMr. Chung and Suh Hoon, the director of the South\u2019s National Intelligence Service, will brief Trump administration officials in Washington later this week about their meeting with Mr. Kim.\n\n\u201cAs a leader of a rogue state, he is a tough case to deal with,\u201d said Kim Sung-han, a former vice foreign minister of South Korea who teaches at Korea University in Seoul, the South\u2019s capital. \u201cHe has the guts but also is very strong in details. He is ambitious and has a desire to win.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s portrayal of a seasoned diplomat began with a televised New Year\u2019s Day speech, exchanging his dull Mao tunic for a snazzy gray Western suit as he reached out to South Korea to improve relations. That move was so successful it laid the groundwork for the South Korean visit this week.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s news media gave zealous coverage to Mr. Kim as he presided over the roomful of reverential negotiators from the South. He also is set to travel to the border with South Korea for a summit meeting in late April with the South\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in.\n\nFormer Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a veteran diplomatic envoy in American dealings with North Korea, said the South Koreans\u2019 visit had yielded some important insights about Mr. Kim, not necessarily reassuring.\n\n\u201cI would say Kim Jong-un has been underestimated,\u201d Mr. Richardson said. \u201cHe seems to be evolving into a strategic thinker with a game plan instead of a bomb thrower. He is now setting the agenda for any possible easing of tension in the peninsula. That\u2019s what\u2019s happened.\u201d\n\nWhile the South Korean guests may have been beguiled, Mr. Richardson said, \u201cwhat we need to be worried about is this: Is he setting up a trap for all of us?\u201d\n\nRegardless what Mr. Kim may be seeking, it is clearly a change from the past six years.\n\nSoon after taking power after the death of his father, Kim Jong-il, in 2011, Mr. Kim escalated his country\u2019s standoff with the outside world by accelerating nuclear and missile tests.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe also moved swiftly to tighten his grip on the police state he had inherited, defying any hope that his studies as a teenager in Switzerland might make him more open to outside ways.\n\nHe executed scores of senior officials, including his uncle, to instill unquestioned fealty. He is believed to have ordered the assassination of Kim Jong-nam, his estranged half brother and the eldest son of his father, in Malaysia last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis spy agency, the General Bureau of Reconnaissance, is blamed for a hacking attack at Sony Pictures in 2014 as retaliation against \u201cThe Interview,\u201d its satirical film based on a fictional plot to assassinate Mr. Kim.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNorth Korea is so hermetic that foreign intelligence agencies were not sure Mr. Kim was heir apparent until a few years before the death of his secretive and dour father.\n\nUntil the North\u2019s state-run media carried photographs of Kim Jong-un, then in his 20s, attending a party meeting in September 2010, no outsider had seen him or any photos of him as an adult.\n\nToward the general public, Mr. Kim has cast himself as a \u201cpeople loving\u201d leader, one reminiscent of his grandfather and North Korea\u2019s founder, Kim Il-sung, officially revered as a godlike figure.\n\nVideo\n\nBut so far he has never met another head of state. His most high-profile guest had been Mr. Rodman, a former professional basketball player who developed something of a bromance with Mr. Kim over his fondness for basketball, during visits in 2013 and 2014.\n\nMr. Kim\u2019s agreement to denuclearization talks is no guarantee that North Korea will start dismantling its arsenal. Mr. Kim said he would give up nuclear weapons only when he felt no more military threats. Previous efforts all collapsed over the same hurdle.\n\nThe Trump administration has escalated economic pressure, backed by threats of military force, to deal with North Korea. President Trump has said he is open to talks \u201conly under the right conditions,\u201d and officials have insisted that the North first take actions to show sincerity.\n\nSome analysts speculated that Mr. Kim\u2019s charm cloaked a wily attempt to fend off sanctions and deflate talk of military action from Washington. With the United Nations banning major North Korean exports, including coal, fish and textiles, North Korea\u2019s exports have plummeted in recent months, a potentially crippling economic blow.\n\n\u201cEither Kim Jong-un\u2019s New Year\u2019s resolution to be a nice guy is real or his smiles and soft messages for Seoul are a ploy for buying time and money to perfect his own nuclear posture review,\u201d said Lee Sung-yoon, a Korea expert at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough Mr. Moon, the South\u2019s leader, has repeatedly called for dialogue with the North, relations were deadlocked until Mr. Kim used his New Year\u2019s Day speech to propose an inter-Korean dialogue and offer to send athletes and cheerleaders to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Mr. Kim also sent his younger sister, Kim Yo-jong, to meet Mr. Moon and invite him to a summit meeting.\n\nAmerican officials argued that their pressure campaign had forced Mr. Kim\u2019s hand. Nikki R. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said last month, \u201cSending cheerleaders to Pyeongchang was a sign of desperation, not national pride.\u201d\n\nBut Koh Yu-hwan, a professor of North Korean studies at Dongguk University in Seoul, said something else was at play: Kim Jong-un\u2019s credible boast that he had a nuclear deterrent, giving him far more leverage with Washington and Seoul than his father ever possessed.\n\n\u201cWe see him increasingly self-confident about what he is doing,\u201d Mr. Koh said. \u201cIf we look at what has happened in the past couple months, it was Kim Jong-un who took the initiative in each key moment.\u201d", "title": "North Korean Leader, Known for His Bluster, Reveals Diplomatic Skills", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe sleuths suspected that the satellite images showed the launching site of North Korea\u2019s most powerful missile, but they were baffled by a mysterious bustle of construction there.\n\nCloser scrutiny, astronomy and a smart hunch about North Korea propaganda confirmed it. They were witnessing the construction of a shrine to the missile, the Hwasong-15, the first built by North Korea that could hit anywhere in the United States.\n\nRoutinely, the image sleuths try to examine sites where the North launches its mobile missiles in a hunt for deployment clues and terrain suitability. North Korea, a mountainous nation, has relatively few locations flat and accessible enough for the firing of missiles from heavy mobile launchers, and analysts of late have carefully tracked the rise in launching-site diversity.\n\nThe sleuths knew the general area of the Nov. 28 missile firing because they had identified the factory where the mobile launcher had been readied. The hot spot had to be nearby.\n\nPhoto\n\nThey identified two plausible sites and then reached out to Marco Langbroek, a Dutch astronomer who helped them focus their suspicions on one particular location by studying photographs of star positions during the nighttime launching.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut last month the satellite analysts began scratching their heads. The site, carved out of farm fields and small roads, began to crawl with trucks, digging gear and construction crews. What was going on?", "title": "North Korea\u2019s Most Powerful Missile Now Has Its Own Shrine", "authors": ["William J. Broad"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSome Hope From North Korea\u201d (editorial, March 7):\n\nPresident Moon Jae-in of South Korea deserves great credit for bringing North Korea to the table. But the talks hold peril as well as promise.\n\nNorth Korea appears to see its nuclear arsenal as essential to regime survival, keeping it from becoming another Libya, and in return would likely demand full United States withdrawal from the Korean Peninsula. At that point, talks could break down, giving President Trump an excuse to unleash \u201cfire and fury\u201d in a war that could kill hundreds of thousands \u2014 or millions if it went nuclear.\n\nTo have a greater chance of success, talks should start with modest aims, such as a freeze in North Korean testing in return for a freeze in United States-South Korean military exercises.\n\nMeanwhile, we must urge Congress to pass legislation, sponsored by Senator Chris Murphy and Representative Ro Khanna, barring the president from attacking North Korea without congressional authorization. Senior negotiators from both Koreas met Thursday at Panmunjom, the so-called truce village on the countries\u2019 border, to agree on a date and discuss other aspects of the summit meeting.\n\nThe two Korean leaders will meet at Peace House, a South Korean building inside Panmunjom, according to a joint statement the negotiators issued at the end of their talks on Thursday. Peace House lies south of the demarcation line that bisects Panmunjom, which means that Mr. Kim would become the first North Korean leader to set foot in the South since the Korean War.\n\nUnification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon, the South\u2019s chief delegate to the Panmunjom talks, hinted at progress toward including denuclearization in the agenda for the Kim-Moon meeting. For instance, public schools in places like Boston and Hartford will be closed; Newark public school officials asked students and staff members to report two hours after their normal start time. New York City schools will be open.\n\n\u2022 Do you have a question about the causes of dangerous winter storms? Ask John Schwartz, a New York Times reporter who covers climate change and the environment, for an answer by emailing storms@nytimes.com. Here are some answers so far.\n\n\u2022 Sign up for the Morning Briefing for news and a daily look at what you need to know to begin your day.\n\nA woman struck by lighting in New Jersey is expected to survive.\n\nThe \u201cthundersnow\u201d on Wednesday brought quick accumulation and excited social media activity along parts of the coast. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe biggest snows in Massachusetts were expected in the western and central parts of the state. really, really, really bad for us to close \u2014 unless of course there\u2019s no power,\u201d she said.\n\nBut she predicted that even 16 inches would not leave much of a mark at this time of year.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to come and go,\u201d Ms. Brennan said, \u201cand spring will be here before you know it.\u201d\n\nBut even as the storm moved into New England, the Weather Service warned of \u201chigh uncertainty\u201d in snow totals, with thin bands separating paltry dustings from major accumulations on forecast maps.\n\nAs of about 7 p.m. Wednesday, Alan Dunham, a ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Sikura is a multiskilled playmaker, Gaudette has a lethal shot and Stevens, at 6-foot-2 and 191 pounds, does a lot of the dirty work along the boards and in front of the net.\n\n\u201cWe have a lot of chemistry together,\u201d said Gaudette, who with Sikura is among the 10 finalists for the Hobey Baker Award, given to the best player in men\u2019s college hockey.\n\nThey are especially effective on the power play, accounting for 35 goals, and Northeastern\u2019s 27.9 percent success rate with the man advantage is second in the country.\n\nStevens and Sikura have been linemates since their freshman year, but Coach Jim Madigan elevated Gaudette to the top line in late January because of their synergy on the power play. Gaudette finished the regular season with 30 goals and 29 assists.\n\nMadigan, who played at Northeastern and was an assistant coach on the previous Northeastern team to win the Beanpot, said the three players of the top line want the puck on their stick, \u201cbut they don\u2019t mind finding the best option available in the offensive end.\u201d He continued: \u201cThey\u2019re very unselfish. All three have high-end hockey intelligence.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey are the top three scorers this year in Hockey East, and have each been drafted by N.H.L. teams: Sikura by Chicago in the sixth round in 2014, Gaudette by Vancouver in the fifth round in 2015 and Stevens by St. Louis in the fifth round in 2016.\n\nThe Huskies are fifth in the country in goals per game, but also fifth in goals-against per game. Tightening play in their own zone was emphasized from the start of the season.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe knew we needed to get better there,\u201d Madigan said. \u201cThe players\u2019 commitment to defend really ratcheted up this year. That\u2019s what has allowed us to get where we are.\u201d\n\nGoalie Ryan Ruck, now a junior, anchored the Huskies\u2019 run to the Hockey East championship and the N.C.A.A. tournament in 2016, but he played only six games before an upper-body injury ended his season at the end of November.\n\nThat opened the door for the freshman Cayden Primeau, who turned 18 in August.\n\nBut he came to Northeastern with abundant experience, including leading the United States Junior Select Team to a gold medal, with two shutouts, at the World Junior A Challenge last summer in Canada.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s like the ace starter in baseball you can count on for eight strong innings,\u201d Madigan said of Primeau, the son of a former Philadelphia Flyers captain, Keith Primeau. \u201cHe wants the pressure. He wants to be \u2018the guy.\u2019 \u201d\n\nPrimeau has played every game since Dec. 1. He stopped 75 of 77 shots in Northeastern\u2019s two Beanpot victories, and ranks fifth in the country in goals-against (1.86) and save percentage (.933).\n\nGaudette, from nearby Braintree, Mass., called Primeau \u201cthe backbone for us all year.\u201d\n\n\u201cLast year, we had to score three, four, five goals to win,\u201d he added. \u201cHe takes all the weight off our shoulders. After the bill was defeated earlier this month, she lashed out online.\n\nIn a Facebook post, which she has since taken down, she said the center-left Labor Party \u201cbelieves the terrorists\u2019 rights are more important than the nation\u2019s security,\u201d and attached a photo of two veiled and gun-toting fighters from the Shabab militant group in Somalia, thousands of miles away.\n\nThat hit a nerve in a country with still-raw memories of its worst terrorist attack in modern times, in which Labor members were the targets. In 2011, a far-right, anti-Islam extremist, Anders Behring Breivik, detonated a bomb outside a building housing offices of the government, then led by Labor, killing eight people, and then went to a Labor youth camp on Utoya island, where he shot dead 69 people, most of them teenagers.", "title": "Norway\u2019s Justice Minister Resigns in Storm Over Facebook Post", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 More than two million people were without power as of 4:45 p.m. Friday, the Energy Department said on Twitter. The failures spanned 17 states and Washington, D.C. More that 500,000 customers were without power in Virginia alone. Emergencies have been declared in cities across New York, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania.\n\n\u2022 Weather officials said more than three feet of snow blanketed parts of New York State on Friday; many areas of New England got two to four inches of rain; and some coastal towns in Massachusetts felt wind gusts of more than 90 miles per hour.\n\n\u2022 New York\u2019s La Guardia Airport suspended all flights on Friday afternoon, Kennedy International Airport halted all incoming domestic flights, and around a quarter of the flights at Newark Liberty International Airport were called off.\n\n\u2022 A National Weather Service meteorologist whose office covers Southern New England said Friday night that coastal areas of Massachusetts experienced \u201cmoderate to major\u201d flooding earlier in the day; several dunes and a few sea walls were breached; many homes and roads had been flooded; and at least one car had been reported to have been floating down the street.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 New York City and Long Island can expect two to three inches of rain with some snow mixed in, but the biggest concern will be the damaging winds in the afternoon and evening. Read more in New York Today.\n\n\u2022 Some communities in Massachusetts, including Scituate and Newburyport, urged residents to evacuate ahead of the storm. The state\u2019s governor, Charlie Baker, warned that Friday\u2019s storm could be more severe than the Jan. 4 storm that brought historic flooding.\n\n\u2022 In the Massachusetts town of Wenham, the authorities said that multiple homes were evacuated for a different but related reason: An underground gas line had caught fire and sent a 30-foot fireball into the air.\n\n\n\nThe storm is the second \u2018bomb cyclone\u2019 this year.\n\nVideo\n\nMeteorologists confirmed Friday that the storm had become the second \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d in two months.\n\nThe Jan. 4 storm gained much attention in part because some meteorologists described it as a \u201cbomb cyclone.\u201d (The name essentially derives from how quickly the barometric pressure falls.)\n\nDan Kottlowski, a senior meteorologist with AccuWeather, said that the rapid pressure drop of the East Coast storm on Friday met the threshold for the bomb-cyclone classification.\n\n\u201cWhat makes this storm unique is that it\u2019s intensifying very quickly,\u201d Mr. Kottlowski said. \u201cIt will be in a position to stay strong for several days.\u201d\n\nThe pressure drop, he said, had contributed to the especially strong winds felt Friday along much of the East Coast.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese people were in a mood to celebrate, before the storm scrambled their travel plans.\n\nAnna Moyer, a graduate student at Columbia University, had planned to spend her weekend at a friend\u2019s bachelorette party in New Orleans. Instead, she was spending Friday afternoon on hold with Delta Air Lines, which canceled her flight out of New York\u2019s Kennedy Airport.\n\nAfter three hours on the phone with Delta, she said she still had not spoken with an employee.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve angry-tweeted at them, Facebook messaged them, and I\u2019ve been obsessively refreshing their site,\u201d said Ms. Moyer, 30, a bridesmaid for the friend having the party.\n\nMs. Moyer said she had been rebooked on a Saturday flight, but was still hoping to find a way to leave on Friday night. She said she had been helping to plan the party for months.\n\nWhen she finally did reach a Delta employee later Friday, Ms. Moyer said she was given no earlier flight option.", "title": "Nor\u2019easter Live Updates: At Least 5 Die as Storm Topples Trees and Strands Travelers", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Teatro particularly targeted the younger generation. It started a Rainbow Choir made up of children of immigrants, for many of whom Sicily is their first landing place in Europe.\n\n\u201cIn our community, migrants are an important part,\u201d Dr. Giambrone said. Children are also invited in for sleepovers, complete with pajama-clad treasure hunts in the byzantine corridors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSuch a place, such an amazing building,\u201d said Mario Giovanni Ingrassia, a Florence-based manager of classical musicians and a Palermo native. \u201cIt\u2019s so huge, it\u2019s just immense, but the acoustics are beautiful.\u201d\n\nIt also has a reputation for paying its bills on time, he said, unlike many Italian institutions.\n\nLike all opera houses in Italy, the Teatro has struggled with steadily declining state subsidies from a financially strapped government, but it manages to fill 80 percent of its paid seats. Non-opera fans help out, with more than 100,000 people a year paying for guided tours of the building\u2019s mammoth stage (bigger than the audience\u2019s area), its three rotundas and grand foyer.\n\nMany of the visitors are foreign tourists attracted by the opera house\u2019s appearance in the climactic bloody scenes of the movie \u201cThe Godfather: Part III.\u201d Some, like Andrew Martin, a teacher visiting from London, are drawn in by its surprising grandeur. \u201cI didn\u2019t expect to see something like this in Palermo,\u201d he said after a recent tour.\n\nWhile the opera house puts on classics \u2014 it just finished a run of the opera \u201cGuillaume Tell,\u201d in Gioachino Rossini\u2019s original French version \u2014 it also has a reputation for theatrical innovation. Currently it is staging \u201cDon Quixote,\u201d a ballet produced by the Tbilisi Opera from Georgia and choreographed by the dancer Lienz Chang, from Cuba.\n\nIn October when the Teatro stages \u201cRigoletto,\u201d Verdi\u2019s classic about a tragic hunchback, the Sicilian-American movie actor John Turturro will be making his opera debut \u2014 as the opera\u2019s director. \u201cWe are convinced that opera is not pesante, not stuffy and boring,\u201d Dr. Giambrone said. \u201cIt\u2019s something that belongs to everyone.\u201d\n\nMr. Orlando is once again the mayor of Palermo, for the third time.\n\n\u201cNowhere does the opera symbolize its city like the Teatro Massimo symbolizes Palermo,\u201d he said. \u201cCovent Garden is not the symbol of London, the Opera in Paris is not the symbol of Paris, the Met doesn\u2019t represent New York. But our opera house is not only the symbol of the rebirth of the city, it\u2019s a symbol of the end of the domination of the Mafia.\u201d", "title": "Not Just a Pretty Facade, Palermo\u2019s Opera Is an Anti-Mafia Symbol", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "No matter how beguiling and colorful my salad dreams may be, when the hectic swirl of weeknight dinner begins, I routinely ditch them for plain greens tossed with lemon juice and olive oil. Adding a grated garlic clove to the dressing is the height of my after-work ambitions.\n\nHappily, this never happens to Ilene Rosen, whose cookbook, \u201cSaladish\u201d (Artisan, 2018), came out this month. Ms. Rosen, a co-owner of R&D Foods in Brooklyn, does for salads what Brooks Headley did for veggie burgers: elevates them from the quotidian to the thrilling.\n\nMs. Rosen became obsessed with salads when she was the savory chef at City Bakery, down the block from the Union Square Greenmarket.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d see all this beautiful produce piled up, and I was never satisfied with two little bags,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019d have to buy it by the case and figure out what to do with it.\u201d", "title": "Not Strictly Salad, but Close Enough", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Tricky Clues\n\n6A: Wordplay alert! The \u201c \u2026 making the rounds\u201d part of the clue made me think of doctors in a hospital, but that\u2019s just what the constructor and editors want you to think. What other rounds do you know of? You can buy someone a round in a BAR, and the person in charge of making those rounds would be the bartender. Don\u2019t forget to tip your server.\n\n19A: I was thinking about our web and app solvers for this one. The answer is \u201cHawaii FIVE-O,\u201d and I hope you didn\u2019t type in a zero instead of the O. The show was always called \u201cHawaii FIVE-OH,\u201d not \u201cFIVE-ZERO,\u201d at least in the original television series. The 2010 reboot, an alert reader has informed me, uses the zero.\n\n45A: Tricky! Some might think that a \u201cFig. in annual reports\u201d would be a number, but today it\u2019s a person: the CEO of the company.\n\n62A: PI DAY just passed. Did you celebrate with pie?\n\n26D: LAILA Ali made her name as a professional boxer from 1999 \u2014 2007, retiring undefeated with several female super middleweight titles, and an IWBF light heavyweight title. She has been on \u201cDancing With the Stars,\u201d and she co-hosted the revival of \u201cAmerican Gladiators,\u201d among other things. But yes, she is also the daughter of Muhammad Ali, who was known as \u201cThe Greatest.\u201d\n\n30D: For those of you (and by that I mean me) who have trouble remembering whether \u201cSkating leaps\u201d are AXELS or AXLES, an AXLE is a rod that passes through the center of a wheel or wheels. An AXEL is a skating leap. Or a character in \u201cBeverly Hills Cop.\u201d\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis puzzle\u2019s theme was inspired by a text. I was chatting with a friend, and he texted, in response to something I said, \u201cBears repeating!\u201d So I sent back a row of the \u201cbear face\u201d emoji \u2014 bears, repeating. I realized I had a 14-letter phrase, and started looking around for others that began with the criteria \u201cplural animal name that is also a verb.\u201d The original grid had BEARS REPEATING (with the clue: Grizzly, panda, grizzly, panda, grizzly, panda?), along with SEALS WITH A KISS (Pinniped passion?), YAKS ON THE PHONE (Himalayan cattle call?) and the revealer ANIMAL BEHAVIOR. This was one of the very first puzzles I submitted to The New York Times, almost a year ago. Will and Joel were very encouraging in their feedback, and suggested a second draft in which each entry had a prepositional phrase (bye, BEARS!) and no revealer. I put together a new version (with much help from Erik Agard and John Lieb, both of whom have been fantastic as mentors and collaborators), which was finally accepted. This is my solo debut in The Times; much has happened since I first started constructing, and I feel very fortunate to be part of the crossword community.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Not-So-Intimidating Sort of Test", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s cover reviews look at the roles optimism and progress play in the United States. In his 1960 review of Robert L. Heilbroner\u2019s \u201cThe Future as History,\u201d Joseph Wood Krutch considered similar themes and wondered about the future\u2019s inevitability. Read an excerpt below.\n\nCan a study of the past predict the future \u2014 even when the future seems as uncertain as ours is commonly thought to be? The author of this intricately argued book, the economist Robert L. Heilbroner, says \u201cYes.\u201d Assuming that the fate of societies is largely determined economically and using the kind of extrapolating logic favored by the Rand Corporation, he emerges with the conviction that both the world in general and the United States in particular will probably go on getting richer, more powerful, more egalitarian and more thoroughly \u201cplanned.\u201d\n\nNineteenth-century optimism has given way to twentieth-century uncertainty because so much in the contemporary situation seems unprecedented. But actually, so he argues, the tendencies and forces that present new problems are only continuing developments from the very same tendencies and forces which transformed seventeenth-century society into nineteenth. Former optimism was not wholly justified; neither is our sense that the future is completely unpredictable.\n\nOur own society will be increasingly planned and regulated because only thus can the increasingly interrelated parts be assured an orderly development. Universal abundance and high incomes will (to take a particularly alarming example) abolish the pressures that now compel some citizens to undertake the less pleasant tasks which must be performed. Some sort of \u201csocial pressure\u201d will have to be substituted for the present economic pressure. \u201cWhat that source of social discipline might be is a speculative matter.\u201d Some readers may be inclined to wonder if it can be anything except slavery more or less disguised as \u201cdiscipline.\u201d\n\nIt would be unfair to suggest that what the author predicts for us seems to him a brave new world. The years ahead are indeed \u201ca time of troubles,\u201d or, as he puts it, \u201chistory will go against us for a long time.\u201d", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s cover reviews look at the role of corporations in American life. In a 1954 review of \u201cThe 20th Century Capitalist Revolution,\u201d by Adolf A. Berle Jr., Seymour E. Harris, an economic adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, reflected on the need to check the increasingly unbridled power of corporations. Read an excerpt below:\n\nThe elephantine corporation is, according to Berle, central in the twentieth-century capitalist revolution. The great corporation is necessary, inter alia, to achieve the objective of high output and low costs. But the resultant concentration of power in management may be abused, and hence the colossal corporation, if it is to survive, must serve as well as take; it must advance the good society, not merely seek to maximize profits. In fact, Berle observes a wholesome trend toward a higher moral code in corporate behavior.\n\nJust as the priest could check military power in the past, or as \u201ca higher law imposes itself in time on princes and powers and institutions of this terrestrial earth,\u201d so \u201cthere is beginning to be apparent a realization of a counter force which checks and remotely acts on, and in time may modify in certain areas, the absolute power of business discretion.\u201d\n\nThe shreds of evidence adduced by Berle are not convincing that \u201ca higher law\u201d as yet determines substantially the operations of big business. Indeed, there are corporations that will not abandon a town just to increase profits. But also relevant is the recent history of Nashua, N.H., where one corporation virtually destroyed the livelihood of the town in order to exploit cheap labor elsewhere; of Lawrence, Mass., and even of Yonkers, N.Y.\n\nHow can we contain the power of corporate management? This is the crucial question raised by Berle. We are all agreed that the corporation is a must in American life for the many reasons ably discussed by Berle. But we need in a democracy to prevent abuse of power by any group: Government, labor, capital or management. How can we mobilize the corporation to serve the nation? Shall it be through countervailing power \u2014 that is, confronting bigness with bigness?", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s issue is dedicated to women, both ordinary and trailblazing. In 1983, Paule Marshall, best known for her novel \u201cBrown Girl, Brownstones,\u201d reflected on how observing her mother\u2019s relationship to language inspired her career. An excerpt follows.\n\nI grew up among poets. Now they didn\u2019t look like poets \u2014 whatever that breed is supposed to look like. Nothing about them suggested that poetry was their calling. They were just a group of ordinary housewives and mothers, my mother included, who dressed in a way (shapeless housedresses, dowdy felt hats and long, dark, solemn coats) that made it impossible for me to imagine they had ever been young.\n\nNor did they do what poets were supposed to do \u2014 spend their days in an attic room writing verses. Several mornings a week these unknown bards would put an apron and a pair of old house shoes in a shopping bag and take the train or streetcar from our section of Brooklyn out to Flatbush. There, those who didn\u2019t have steady jobs would wait on certain designated corners for the white housewives in the neighborhood to come along and bargain with them over pay for a day\u2019s work cleaning their houses. Later, armed with the few dollars they had earned, which in their vocabulary became \u201ca few raw-mouth pennies,\u201d they made their way back to our neighborhood, where they would sometimes stop off to have a cup of tea or cocoa together before going home to cook dinner for their husbands and children.\n\nThere was no way for me to understand it at the time, but the talk that filled the kitchen those afternoons was highly functional. It served as therapy, the cheapest kind available to my mother and her friends. It restored them to a sense of themselves and reaffirmed their self-worth. Through language they were able to overcome the humiliations of the work day. Confronted by a world they could not encompass, they took refuge in language.", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "This week\u2019s cover review considers impeachment in the United States. In 1973, Philip Kurland, the legal scholar who in 1974 would advise the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Nixon tapes, reviewed \u201cImpeachment: The Constitutional Problems,\u201d by Raoul Berger. Read an excerpt below:\n\nImpeachment is the \u201cunthinkable\u201d subject about which we are thinking because of Watergate. This book is not, however, one of those instant volumes created by a publicist in response to a particular political event and rushed through production to capitalize on the daily headlines and momentary fashions. This is a serious, scholarly effort, nonetheless highly readable even by those who want to know what they want to know only because of its implications for current events.\n\nRaoul Berger\u2019s primary concern was to demonstrate that, although impeachment was a proper means for removal of derelict judges, it ought not to be the sole means for accomplishing that worthy end. Impeachment belongs in a far more important tradition: \u201cImpeachment was for the English \u2018the chief institution for the preservation of the government.\u2019\u201d And he would restore it to that lofty category.\n\nToday this volume is important for the historical exegesis of the origins and meanings of the constitutional provision. And, as Berger says, \u201cOne thing is clear: in the impeachment debate the Convention was almost exclusively concerned with the President.\u201d\n\nProbably the most important of the questions of the moment addressed by Mr. Berger concerns the proper meaning to be given the phrase \u201chigh crimes and misdemeanors.\u201d He tells us that despite the practices indulged by Congress in the past, the phrase is not an empty bottle to be filled with whatever meaning the national legislature thinks appropriate. Nor is it a term of fixed meaning whose denotations may be derived by examination of the criminal laws heretofore enacted by Congress. We must turn, rather, to the English constitutional history from which our constitutional provision took its meaning. And for these ancestors, \u201c\u2018High crimes and misdemeanors\u2019 were a category of political crimes against the state.\u201d", "title": "Notes From the Book Review Archives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Brooke Shields drew herself up to her full 6 feet, fielding reporters\u2019 questions with an agility that has become second nature.\n\nAt the Beekman Hotel in downtown Manhattan last month, Ms. Shields, the model, actress and veteran of numberless interviews, was delivering but the latest in a series of canny performances. She bantered good-naturedly, as is her habit, displaying an unflappable poise and a set of curves pneumatically packaged inside a closefitting top and skirt from the collection she was about to unveil for QVC, which will be introduced in its entirety on March 14.\n\nHer features and frame were considerably fuller than in 1980, when she scandalized television audiences with the coy claim that nothing came between her and her Calvins. The once-angular jaw is softer. Not that it matters. At 52, Ms. Shields, after transitioning through the decades from wide-eyed innocent to self-mocking glamorista in television shows like \u201cSuddenly Susan\u201d and \u201cFriends,\u201d has ripened into the kind of consummately relatable personality much coveted by QVC, the home-shopping behemoth that found success with celebrities including Iman and Catherine Zeta-Jones.\n\nMs. Shields\u2019s history is part of the draw. On screen and on the page, she has been a continual presence in the lives of her fans: a comedic talent and the author of several viscerally revealing memoirs in which she casts herself as a survivor, beating back demons that include a codependent relationship with an alcoholic mother and a severe episode of postpartum depression.", "title": "Nothing Comes Between Brooke Shields and Her New Line for QVC", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday, the Huskies seemed finished near the end of regulation, trailing by 79-74 with 21.3 seconds left before Napheesa Collier (24 points) hit a 3-pointer and Kia Nurse stole the inbounds pass and drove for a layup to tie the score, forcing five extra minutes.\n\nIn overtime, Notre Dame (34-3) drew ahead, but UConn responded. A 3-pointer by Crystal Dangerfield tied the score at 89-89 with 27 seconds left. Notre Dame called timeout with 13 seconds remaining and planned to isolate Ogunbowale (27 points) on the right wing and have her drive to the basket with about five seconds remaining, in the belief that UConn would not try to foul.\n\nBut UConn\u2019s defense made it difficult for Ogunbowale to get the ball as planned. Finally, with overtime about to expire, she shot from just inside the 3-point arc and hit nothing but net, giving Notre Dame its stirring victory. Jackie Young led the Irish with her career high of 32 points.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t know it was going in, but it felt good,\u201d Ogunbowale said.\n\nMuffet McGraw, Notre Dame\u2019s coach, acknowledged that the play, and ultimately the victory, had resulted more from improvisation than from design.\n\n\u201cI probably should thank every Catholic from coast to coast for all the prayers on Good Friday,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nImportantly for the Irish, a deep familiarity with UConn had developed over the years, creating self-assurance and stonewashing any nervousness from their annual matchup in the regular season and, with regularity, another meeting in the tournament.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just another team,\u201d guard Marina Mabrey said.\n\nAs partners in the old Big East Conference, the teams once played as many as four times a season. Their coaches \u2014 Notre Dame\u2019s McGraw and UConn\u2019s Geno Auriemma \u2014 obsessively followed each other\u2019s performances. The rivalry became the most enthralling in women\u2019s college basketball. It grew heated, sometimes to the point of bitterness.\n\nNow they are in different leagues \u2014 the Irish play in the Atlantic Coast Conference, the Huskies in the American Athletic Conference \u2014 and the rivalry is less intense, but no less predictive of deep runs in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Notre Dame prevailed over UConn in the semifinals in 2001, when the Irish won their only national title, and did it again in 2011 and 2012, as well as on Friday.\n\nFor the second consecutive year, UConn failed to reach the championship game. Last year, defeat came on a stunning jumper by Mississippi State in overtime that snapped the Huskies\u2019 111-game winning streak. Again on Friday, the Huskies were left to contemplate going home empty-handed \u2014 despite having won 147 of their last 149 games.\n\n\u201cWhen you do something and it seems like it\u2019s so effortless, you do get numb and forget it\u2019s difficult,\u201d Auriemma said of UConn\u2019s raft of national titles. \u201cIt\u2019s very difficult. There are no bad teams. There are no bad players. You can\u2019t luck into a national championship. You have to play great.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn these types of games, he continued, a necessary selfishness often prevails. One team often does not collectively beat another, he said. Instead, \u201cthere\u2019s one or two players that just make unbelievable plays and just dominate the game.\u201d\n\nWomen\u2019s college basketball is now left to deliberate whether UConn\u2019s stumble represented an anomaly or the hint of something larger \u2014 the beginning of a shift toward greater parity in the women\u2019s game, which has developed on a track parallel to the men\u2019s game.\n\nThe men\u2019s N.C.A.A. tournament began in 1939, the women\u2019s in 1982. In the first 37 years of the men\u2019s tournament Coach John Wooden and U.C.L.A. won 10 titles. In the first 37 years of the women\u2019s tournament Auriemma and UConn have won 11 titles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWill UConn\u2019s dominance begin to fade, as U.C.L.A\u2019s did? It is far too early to tell, said Coach Joanne P. McCallie of Duke, which lost to UConn in the semifinals of the Albany Region. UConn has signed the nation\u2019s top recruit for next season, Christyn Williams, a 5-foot-11 guard from Arkansas. And Auriemma, who just turned 64, has hinted that he might coach until he is 70.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUConn is still the \u201cking and queen and leader of the pack,\u201d McCallie said. \u201cLet\u2019s look at the next four years. That will be the pattern to evaluate.\u201d\n\nStill, there is undeniable equalizing occurring in women\u2019s college basketball.\n\nTennessee, an eight-time national champion, has not reached the Final Four since Coach Pat Summitt retired and died from early-onset Alzheimer\u2019s disease. This season, Tennessee lost at home for the first time in the N.C.A.A. tournament. South Carolina, the 2017 champion, and Mississippi State, in the Final Four for a second consecutive season, have supplanted Tennessee as powers in the Southeastern Conference.\n\n\u201cAnytime you can show some parity in our game on any level, it\u2019s always good,\u201d said Dawn Staley, the South Carolina coach, who won the title last year. A leveling of the playing field \u201cgives other coaches hope to keep on coaching.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOregon, U.C.L.A. and Oregon State have loosened the stranglehold that Stanford, a two-time champion and a Final Four regular, once had on the Pac-12 Conference. And two 11th seeds \u2014 Buffalo and Central Michigan \u2014 reached the round of 16 in the 2018 tournament.\n\nBuffalo provided a shrewd example of the recruiting that mid-majors have undertaken to compete with opponents in the so-called Power 5 conferences. Of Buffalo\u2019s 14 players this season, seven were international \u2014 four from Australia, two from Canada and one from Nigeria.\n\n\u201cWomen are not just saying, \u2018I\u2019m going to Connecticut\u2019; they\u2019re going everywhere now,\u201d said Buffalo Coach Felisha Legette-Jack. \u201cMy colleagues are not saying, \u2018Come play for me because I\u2019m at this school.\u2019 They\u2019re saying, \u2018Come play with me because of this relationship I\u2019m building with you.\u2019 We\u2019re not looking at buildings anymore; we\u2019re looking at people.\u201d\n\nTrue parity in women\u2019s college basketball may not arrive, McCallie said, until attendance is reliable enough during the early rounds of the N.C.A.A. tournament for all teams to play on neutral courts. For now, the top four seeds in each region are eligible to play the first and second rounds on their home courts.\n\n\u201cI think the only thing we have trouble with is where we play, the neutral court versus the home court, because we\u2019ve got to draw fans,\u201d McCallie said. \u201cI think eventually that would be the next step.\u201d\n\nBefore the tournament began, Auriemma urged a group of UConn fans to enjoy what the Huskies have accomplished, because \u201cthis isn\u2019t going to last forever.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFriday\u2019s game, he said with gallows humor, was a \u201cgreat learning tool.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut I\u2019m a pretty smart guy,\u201d he added. \u201cI don\u2019t need to learn this two years in a row.\u201d", "title": "Notre Dame, a UConn Nemesis, Topples the Huskies in a Final Four Thriller", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "MIAMI \u2014 Novak Djokovic has gone from being the most dominant tennis player in the world to sounding like an existential philosopher, and not many of those have ever won a tennis tournament.\n\nDjokovic has won 68 titles, including 12 Grand Slam championships and six Miami Opens. But those days seem a long way off. Ever since Djokovic lost in the final of the 2016 United States Open, his career has been in a tailspin, and he cannot pull himself out.\n\nAfter a 6-3, 6-4 defeat to Benoit Paire of France on Friday at the Miami Open, Djokovic had few concrete answers for why he cannot regain his once-commanding form.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m trying,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it\u2019s not working, and that\u2019s all it is.\u201d\n\nThe downturn is due in large part to an elbow injury that does not seem to have fully healed. Djokovic has also experienced off-court issues that he has not detailed publicly, and he has completely overhauled his coaching staff.", "title": "Novak Djokovic\u2019s Swoon Continues at the Miami Open", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The best-selling novelist Anita Shreve died on March 29, at her home in New Hampshire, following a battle with cancer. She was 71. Activities focus on science, creativity, play and socialization, and include lessons in squid anatomy, paper airplane building contests, scavenger hunts and talent shows. Currently on five ships, the new clubs will be rolled out to the entire fleet through 2019.\n\nCelebrity Cruises\u2019 Camp at Sea program offers activities for children 3 to 12 along four tracks, art, recreation, culinary and S.T.E.M. The line offers late-night \u201cslumber parties\u201d between 10 p.m. and 1 a.m.\n\nIn April, Norwegian Cruise Line will send the Norwegian Escape, featuring four water slides and a three-story ropes course, to New York for weekly cruises to Bermuda (from $629). The ship is the only one in Norwegian\u2019s fleet to offer child care for children from six months to three years old.\n\nEducation at Sea\n\nExpedition ships are adding educational programming that aim to make science fun.\n\nThis summer, Lindblad Expeditions plans to extend its National Geographic Global Explorers program to Alaska. Launched in the Gal\u00e1pagos last year, the program encompasses science, exploration and storytelling, including learning to drive an inflatable vessel, spot wildlife and create time-lapse videos. The program will be available on the line\u2019s three ships in Alaska and includes listening to whale vocalizations using an underwater microphone (five nights from $4,290).\n\nIn the South Pacific, Paul Gauguin Cruises is teaming up with the nonprofit Wildlife Conservation Society during the summer months to offer nature-focused educational activities for children 7 to 17. Savchenko, from entering with the weapons, it turned out, but the episode unnerved her colleagues, spurred a prosecutorial inquiry over her intentions, and led to the adoption this week of the weapons prohibition.\n\nIn the country\u2019s raucous domestic politics, brawls are common in Parliament, and apparently enough lawmakers also carry weapons that the new law immediately became contentious.\n\nOn Thursday, two members of Parliament declined to walk through a metal detector, saying the law was being enforced in a partisan fashion, with members of some parties subjected to more stringent checks.", "title": "Now Prohibited in Ukraine\u2019s Parliamentary Chamber: Weapons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Lee is the fifth former president to have been questioned by prosecutors on corruption allegations since the 1990s. She was formally removed from office and arrested last March.\n\nLast month, prosecutors asked a Seoul court to sentence Ms. Park to 30 years in prison on charges of collecting or demanding $21 million in bribes from big businesses like Samsung. Booking.com, an accommodation booking site with a database of more than 1.5 million properties, is betting on a \u201cyes.\u201d The three are part of the site\u2019s Book It List, debuting today , which is a collection of not-so-common places around the United States where guests can hang their hat for a night or more; the list has one option in each state.\n\nThe company is kicking off this new category by selling one-night stays for March 8 in three venues that have never before offered overnight accommodations: a suite on the 80th floor of the Empire State Building, in New York; a suite at the AmericanAirlines Arena, in Miami; and a tour bus in Los Angeles that the musician Nick Jonas helped design. Each stay costs $1,500.\n\nWhile these are one-time bookings, the permanent possibilities on the Book It List include a man-made cave in New Mexico, a treehouse in Ohio, a base camp in Alaska and a shrimp boat in South Carolina. The list\u2019s properties are in diverse locales ranging from major cities and the mountains to the coast and remote countryside, and prices for a night\u2019s stay range from affordable to extravagant.\n\nIt costs $65 a night, for example, to stay at the 12-room Town Hall Inn, in Lead, S.D., in the heart of the Black Hills. He was arrested and spent a month in jail.\n\nA few weeks ago the city of Oakland, now promoting itself as a hub for marijuana entrepreneurs, awarded Mr. McCullough, 33, a license to sell marijuana and the prospect of interest-free loans.\n\nFour hundred miles to the south, in the Los Angeles suburb of Compton, Virgil Grant, 50, straddles the same two worlds, but with a different outcome. He was a marijuana dealer in the 1990s whose customers are said to have included rap stars like Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg and Tupac, and he spent more than eight years in prison on marijuana convictions. But his vision of starting a marijuana dispensary in his hometown was dashed in January when the residents of Compton voted decisively to ban marijuana businesses from city limits.\n\nFrom a distance, the legalization of recreational marijuana in California can appear like a giant collective embrace of the drug by a state that is by far its largest producer and consumer. Yet the diverging paths of Oakland and Compton, two cities with histories of illicit drugs and years of aggressive law enforcement crackdowns, highlight the continued ambivalence of many Californians toward marijuana.", "title": "Oakland Embraces Marijuana Sales.
