How Is Justice Best Served?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The A\u2019s have finished in last place in each of the past three seasons, their longest such streak since the 1940s. Forever trapped in the outmoded, low-revenue Coliseum, they need to take risks to compete with the World Series champion Houston Astros and their other American League West rivals. The Fowler trade qualifies.\n\nIn moving Gray, whose rights the A\u2019s controlled through 2019, Oakland received a second injured prospect besides Fowler: pitcher James Kaprielian, a former first-round draft choice who is recovering from Tommy John surgery. Jorge Mateo, a shortstop who was not injured then but has a sprained knee ligament now, was the third \u2014 and most highly touted \u2014 prospect in the deal.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been through this cycle a lot, in my and Billy\u2019s time together,\u201d General Manager David Forst said, referring to Billy Beane, Oakland\u2019s executive vice president for baseball operations. \u201cWe\u2019ve done the up-and-down, and hopefully can recognize when there\u2019s a time to look at higher-upside guys. We\u2019ve made trades for safer guys with a lower ceiling who could impact us sooner, but we were certainly in position last July to go for the most talent regardless of how far away from the big leagues they were.\u201d\n\nIn Fowler\u2019s case, the A\u2019s had few precedents to study. The injury, Forst said, is more common in N.F.L. running backs than major league outfielders. Yet while Fowler is fast \u2014 he had 55 steals in his last two full seasons in the minors \u2014 the A\u2019s feel he has enough skills to not depend entirely on speed.\n\n\u201cHis hands are quick enough that he will drive the ball to all the fields, with gap-to-gap power,\u201d said the Oakland first base coach Al Pedrique, who managed the Yankees\u2019 Class AAA team last season, when Fowler hit .293 with 13 homers.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a very smart player, and defensively he got so much better last year with his routes and jumps. His throwing strength has improved, and his awareness of where to throw the ball has gotten so much better. He can play center field every day in the big leagues.\u201d\n\nAs a center fielder, Fowler will not have to contend with side walls. He also hopes that his example will minimize risks for other fielders. In January, Fowler sued the White Sox and the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority, the agency that owns Guaranteed Rate Field, alleging negligence and seeking compensation for possible lost future earnings. Fowler said the suit was still in progress and had not been resolved.", "title": "Oakland\u2019s Dustin Fowler Hopes to Leave an Unlucky Club of 2", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPresident and Mrs. Obama have always believed in the power of storytelling to inspire,\u201d Eric Schultz, a senior adviser to the former president, said Thursday. \u201cThroughout their lives, they have lifted up stories of people whose efforts to make a difference are quietly changing the world for the better. As they consider their future personal plans, they continue to explore new ways to help others tell and share their stories.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn one possible show idea, Mr. Obama could moderate conversations on topics that dominated his presidency \u2014 health care, voting rights, immigration, foreign policy, climate change \u2014 and that have continued to divide a polarized American electorate during President Trump\u2019s time in office.\n\nAnother program could feature Mrs. Obama on topics, like nutrition, that she championed in the White House. The former president and first lady could also lend their brand \u2014 and their endorsement \u2014 to documentaries or fictional programming on Netflix that align with their beliefs and values.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is unclear how much money the Obamas will be paid, given their lack of experience in the media business. Netflix recently signed a five-year, $300 million deal to lure Ryan Murphy away from 21st Century Fox, but Mr. Murphy is among the television industry\u2019s most sought-after producers\n\nThe deal is evidence that Mr. Obama, who left the White House when he was just 55 years old, intends to remain engaged in the nation\u2019s civic business, even as he has studiously avoided direct clashes with Mr. Trump about his concerted efforts to roll back Mr. Obama\u2019s legacy. It is also a clear indication that the former president remains interested in the intersection of politics, technology and media.\n\nSeveral people familiar with the Netflix discussions said that executives from Apple and Amazon, which have their own streaming services, have also expressed interest in talking with Mr. Obama about content deals.\n\nThe former president has maintained a low profile since leaving office. He and his wife are each writing highly anticipated memoirs, for which they were reportedly paid more than $60 million. And Mr. Obama has been paid hundreds of thousands of dollars for speeches in the United States and around the world. The Obamas are rarely seen in public in Washington, where they still live.\n\nMr. Obama has long expressed concerns about how the flow of information \u2014 and misinformation \u2014 has the power to shape public opinion. In the last several months, Mr. Obama has discussed with technology executives and wealthy investors the threats to American democracy from the manipulation of news.\n\nHe has seethed privately and publicly, about what he says is the manipulation of news by conservative outlets and the fractured delivery of information in the internet age. In several recent public appearances during the last several months, the former president hinted at his frustration with the way conservative news outlets have shaped people\u2019s perceptions about the divisive 2016 campaign and the issues he cares about.\n\n\u201cIf you watch Fox News, you are living on a different planet than you are if you are listening to NPR,\u201d Mr. Obama told David Letterman in an interview broadcast in January for the comedian\u2019s first Netflix program. Last December, at a forum in New Delhi, Mr. Obama conceded that \u201cIf I watch Fox News, I wouldn\u2019t vote for me. I would watch it and say, \u2018Who is that guy?\u2019\u201d\n\nEvidence began to emerge while Mr. Obama was president that Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube were being used to spread false information about candidates and issues. Social media\u2019s impact on society became even clearer last month, when the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, indicted 13 Russians and three companies that had used social media companies to undermine democracy in the United States and push voters to reject Hillary Clinton.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the election came to a close, Mr. Obama told The New Yorker that the new media landscape had made it possible for large swaths of the country to ignore facts. \u201cEverything is true and nothing is true,\u201d he complained. He later personally scolded Facebook\u2019s chief executive for saying it was \u201ccrazy\u201d to think the social network influenced the election.\n\nFor Netflix, securing the Obama programming is a part of the company\u2019s broader search for original content, as the streaming service competes for viewers with HBO, Apple, Amazon and the traditional broadcast networks. Netflix has said it could spend as much as $8 billion on content this year. It has been paying top dollar for original programs like its hit Stranger Things and the documentary Icarus, which won the Oscar this year for best documentary feature.\n\nIt would also be another coup for a company that began by distributing DVDs and is now doing deals with some of the most powerful names in entertainment.\n\nSeveral of the technology and media worlds\u2019 top executives have been close advisers and donors to Mr. Obama over the years, including John Doerr and Reid Hoffman, the Silicon Valley venture capitalists, and Jeffrey Katzenberg, the entertainment executive.\n\nBut Mr. Obama has particularly close ties to Ted Sarandos, Netflix\u2019s chief content officer. Mr. Sarandos is married to Nicole A. Avant, an activist who served as Mr. Obama\u2019s ambassador to the Bahamas. And Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, was close to Mr. Obama while he was president and an attendee at state dinners. A spokesman for Netflix declined to comment about any discussions with the former president and his wife.\n\nSome of the biggest media companies on the internet, like BuzzFeed and Vice, have embraced politically-themed programming, even as they have recently seen their growth flatline with shifts in the digital advertising and distribution landscapes. Political news start-ups like the website Axios and the podcast \u201cPod Save America,\u201d hosted by former Obama officials, have connected with audiences that are eager for scoops, analysis and opinion.\n\nThe deal between Netflix and Mr. Obama would be a modern media twist on an approach that former politicians have tried in the past.\n\nAl Gore, the former vice president, created a new cable network after losing the presidency to George W. Bush in 2000. Mr. Gore and Joel Hyatt, a businessman and Democratic activist, purchased a small cable company in 2004, eventually renaming it Current TV and positioning it as an \u201cindependent voice\u201d in the political debate.\n\nThe network expanded its presence on cable and satellite networks and changed formats several times during the next eight years, at one point providing a home for Keith Olbermann, an outspoken liberal and a former host at MSNBC. In 2013, Mr. Gore and Mr. Hyatt sold their company to the Al Jazeera Media Network, which shut down the Current TV channel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Obama\u2019s approach is less of a direct challenge to the existing news establishment. But he is embracing the streaming services that have become a direct threat to the cable and network television infrastructure, especially among younger viewers.", "title": "Obama in Talks to Provide Shows for Netflix", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear", "Katie Benner", "John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "In 2011, his cousin sold him 2.2 acres of agricultural land in the community of Haiku \u2014 with a verdant gulch and views to the ocean and distant West Maui Mountains \u2014 for about $240,000. And he began dreaming about how LifeEdited concepts developed in cramped city apartments could translate to such a wild, open place.\n\nA few years later, Mr. Hill, who has a bachelor of architecture degree, and his team started working in earnest to design a vacation house they hoped would be a shining example of what could be achieved by following LifeEdited\u2019s mission statement: \u201cDesign your life to include more money, health and happiness with less stuff, space and energy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt 1,000 square feet, with an additional 330-square-foot lanai and 1,330-square-foot garage, the resulting house \u2014 completed with help from the architecture and engineering firm Hawaii Off-Grid \u2014 isn\u2019t exactly small. But it packs a lot into that envelope, including four bedrooms and two and a half bathrooms.\n\nThree of the bedrooms offer more than a place to sleep. Outfitted with Clei transformable furnishings from Resource Furniture, one bedroom has a Murphy bed with an attached desk that rotates into place, when the bed is closed, to serve as an office. Another has a Murphy bed with a table that unfolds for dining or games, and the third has folding bunk beds with an integrated sofa for watching television. In this bedroom-cum-media room, a custom pegboard wall with shelves made of Richlite (a countertop material made from recycled paper) can be adjusted to respond to Mr. Hill\u2019s evolving storage and display needs.\n\nEven the lanai, open to the elements under a broad cedar-paneled ceiling, has adjustable furniture, including low coffee tables that pop up and expand to become larger dining tables, and modular sofas with weighted back cushions that can be pulled forward for support during meals or pushed back when Mr. Hill or his guests want to recline.\n\nBuilding a stand-alone house also gave Mr. Hill the opportunity to play with the sort of green technology featured on TreeHugger but almost impossible to deploy in a Manhattan apartment. The standing-seam metal roof is covered with thin-film solar panels from Sunflare that are nearly invisible. They generate enough power not only to run the house but to charge Mr. Hill\u2019s car (a 1973 Volkswagen Thing that he had Hawaii Off-Grid convert to an electric vehicle with recycled Tesla batteries) and his electric Magnum bicycles.\n\nThe roof, gutters and rain chains channel water to a 15,000-gallon tank used for irrigation. The Separett composting toilets use no water.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe house was completed in January for just under $1 million. \u201cIt\u2019s not as inexpensive as I had hoped, but it\u2019s a prototype,\u201d Mr. Hill said, explaining that trial and error drove up the cost. \u201cWe know we can make it a lot less expensive on the next one.\u201d\n\nBut the comfort of the finished house seems to have surprised even its owner. \u201cI\u2019ve been doing environmental stuff for almost 20 years, and I had no idea how cool it would feel to be living off grid,\u201d he said. \u201cDone right, green can actually be more luxurious\u201d than a conventional house.\n\nJust remember, if you\u2019re in Maui and happen to see Mr. Hill zipping past in his electric Thing with a surfboard strapped to its roll bars, he isn\u2019t on vacation \u2014 he\u2019s just doing his job.\n\n\u201cEveryone in Manhattan thinks I\u2019m being a slacker, and everyone here thinks I\u2019m being a workaholic,\u201d he said. \u201cThe truth is probably somewhere in between.\u201d", "title": "Off the Grid, on Maui", "authors": ["Tim Mckeough", "On Location"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "The North Carolina police officer seen using a Taser and punching a black man in a video recently leaked to the news media had been suspended in the past, personnel records show, and was known as a \u201csmart aleck,\u201d according to a former supervisor.\n\nThe officer, Christopher W. Hickman, 31, was charged on Thursday with assault by strangulation, a felony, and assault inflicting serious injury and communicating threats, which are misdemeanors.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what happened to him over the years,\u201d Rondell Lance, the president of the local Fraternal Order of Police and a 26-year veteran of the Asheville Police Department, said in a phone interview on Saturday. \u201cEvidently something happened. It has been eight years since the explosion and subsequent oil spill, which left 11 people dead and countless lives ruined. A culture of profits over safety led to that disaster, so a return to that thinking is inviting the next one.\n\nInstead of trying to get back to the way things were, we need to be looking toward the inevitable future when carbon is taxed and a renaissance in renewable energy jobs sweeps the country. Louisiana, and the world, will be better off for it.\n\nBRANDON SUTTON, ATLANTA\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs you reported, with the recent change in post-Deepwater Horizon drilling restrictions, we expect to see a boom in offshore oil and gas drilling, rapidly expanding opportunities for smaller oil and gas exploration and production operators. But this also brings risks.", "title": "Opinion | Offshore Drilling: Have the Lessons Been Learned?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "In another incident in mid-December, a bundle of tubing weighing hundreds of pounds fell as it was being lifted by a crane. A large pipe slipped out and dropped 120 feet, missing workers who were on a ship below, the agency said.\n\nOne worker did die in December on a drilling ship in an accident when a pipe-moving device \u2014 not a crane \u2014 crushed him when he entered an area where he was not supposed to be standing.\n\n\u201cNo one wants to face the family of a worker who dies or is severely injured because we didn\u2019t do our jobs correctly, or because we failed to recognize that the risks present on site were beyond acceptable bounds,\u201d Brian Salerno, then the head of the offshore safety agency, said in remarks to industry officials in July 2015 after the new crane safety rules were proposed.\n\n\u201cSo let\u2019s see what we can do to reverse those trends,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the problem has only worsened since then, according to Interior Department records released to The Times. The rate of lift-related offshore accidents last year increased by more than 4 percent, reaching the second-highest annual level in the past decade. On average, there was one incident for every 13.5 offshore platforms or drilling rigs, according to agency data.\n\nArena Offshore was among the companies that had multiple lift-related accidents. In one, a worker was severely injured when he was pinned against a handrail as crews were using a crane to lift a 10,000-pound construction tool house. The operator of the crane could not see the area where the offshore worker was standing, investigators found.\n\nIn another case, involving Energy XXI, a motor failed, making it impossible to control the crane. A basket carrying four workers swung out of control, injuring three of them, an incident report says.", "title": "Offshore Oil and Gas Operators Want Less Regulation, but Surprise Inspections Find Serious Safety Problems", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "The show\u2019s program includes photos of the troupe performing \u201cYeoman\u201d dating from the 1930s. The troupe has produced the Gilbert & Sullivan canon of 13 full operettas numerous times, and over the decades has raised millions of dollars for New York City charities.\n\nAbout 260 troupe members actively participate throughout the year, either in the spring or fall performances, or at other concerts and functions, Ms. Taylor said.\n\nNearly 400 more members continue to pay dues even though they are inactive or living elsewhere as a way to keep a connection to the group, Ms. Taylor said, with many traveling to New York during productions, which can resemble reunions.\n\nDozens of members have been in the group more than 50 years, and many are in their 80s and 90s, including Ed Gough, 95, who still sings with the troupe.\n\nLike many members, Sandy Dickinson, the executive producer for \u201cYeoman,\u201d has three generations of his family in the troupe. Mr. Dickinson, whose children are members, said he was \u201cborn Blue\u201d as the child of troupe members, and was then further exposed to operettas while attending the Allen-Stevenson School in Manhattan, whose theater department still offers Gilbert & Sullivan productions.\n\nFor decades, the troupe was fed by local private schools with similar theater programs. Though some patrician members remain \u2014 including Charles F. Morgan, the great-grandson of J. Pierpont Morgan \u2014 the membership has diversified.\n\n\u201cWhen I was younger, you had mostly Upper East Side blue-blooded types, but that\u2019s all changed,\u201d Mr. Dickinson said. \u201cI live in Jersey. I can\u2019t afford to live on Park Avenue.\u201d", "title": "Oh, Joy! Oh, Rapture! A Leaner Gilbert & Sullivan Troupe Turns 94.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s near-universal consensus among both economists and business leaders that Donald Trump\u2019s tariffs on steel and aluminum are a bad idea, and that the wider trade war those tariffs could trigger would be very destructive. But the chances of heading off this policy disaster are small, because this is a quintessential example of Trump being Trump.\n\nIn fact, the tariffs are arguably the Trumpiest thing Trump has done so far.\n\nAfter all, trade (like racism) is an issue on which Trump has been utterly consistent over the years. He has spent decades railing at other countries that, he claims, hurt America by taking advantage of our relatively open markets. And if his views are based on zero understanding of the issues or even of basic facts, well, Trumpism is all about belligerent ignorance, across the board.\n\nBut wait, there\u2019s more. There\u2019s a reason we have international trade agreements, and it\u2019s not to protect us from unfair practices by other countries. The real goal, instead, is to protect us from ourselves: to limit the special-interest politics and outright corruption that used to reign in trade policy.\n\nTrumpocrats, however, don\u2019t see corruption and rule by special interests as problems. You could say that the world trading system is, in large part, specifically designed to prevent people like Trump from having too much influence. Of course he wants to wreck it.", "title": "Opinion | Oh, What a Trumpy Trade War!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The junior forward Mason Jobst said Rohlik described Miller as \u201cthe Connor McDavid of assistant coaches,\u201d referring to the Edmonton Oilers star and the reigning N.H.L. most valuable player.\n\nMiller, 52, spent last season as the director of hockey operations at the Air Force Academy, which won the Atlantic Hockey championship and reached the N.C.A.A. East Regional final, one stop from its first Frozen Four.\n\nMiller arrived at Air Force from Providence College, which won its first N.C.A.A. title in 2015, his only year as an assistant there. He also was an assistant on the United States team that won gold at the 2017 world junior championships, and was George Gwozdecky\u2019s top lieutenant when the University of Denver won consecutive national championships in 2004 and 2005.\n\nMiller\u2019s coaching skills have long been recognized. The American Hockey Coaches Association in 2009 presented him the Terry Flanagan Award, which is given annually to an assistant hockey coach, for his career body of work.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen U.S.A. Hockey tabbed St. Cloud State\u2019s Bob Motzko to coach the national team at the 2017 world junior championships, Motzko said Miller was one of the first coaches he wanted for his staff.\n\n\u201cWherever he\u2019s been,\u201d Motzko said, \u201che\u2019s been the glue of the coaching staff.\u201d\n\nGwozdecky hired Miller as a graduate assistant in 1991, his second year at Miami of Ohio, then took him to Denver\u2019s program in 1994.\n\nHe called Miller \u201cthe diamond in that rough piece of coal\u201d when he hired him. Through 19 years at Denver, they forged a deep friendship. Their families have spent holidays together, and Gwozdecky is the godfather of Miller\u2019s oldest child, Alexis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s an extended part of our family,\u201d Gwozdecky said.\n\nDenver was Miller\u2019s finishing school, where he eventually graduated to Gwozdecky\u2019s No. 1 assistant. In addition to being responsible for the defense and penalty kill, Miller became a renowned recruiter. Two of his recruits, the defensemen Matt Carle, in 2006, and Will Butcher, in 2017, won the Hobey Baker Award, given to the top men\u2019s college hockey player.\n\nLast season, Air Force led the nation in killing penalties at 89.8 percent, a remarkable number. This season, Ohio State ranks first at 89.3 percent, a year after finishing 57th among 60 teams. The Buckeyes also are fifth in goals against, at 2.11 per game.\n\nDuring last year\u2019s N.C.A.A. tournament, Air Force defenseman Johnny Hrabovsky said Miller was \u201cprobably the smartest hockey mind I\u2019ve ever been around.\u201d He added, \u201cAnd he\u2019s one of the funniest guys I\u2019ve ever been around.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMotzko, an assistant with Miller on Gwozdecky\u2019s staff at Miami, said Miller treated his players like his own children and the players \u201cbleed for him.\u201d\n\n\u201cOnce you\u2019re one of his players, you\u2019re stuck with him for the rest of your life,\u201d Motzko said. \u201cHe never leaves you.\u201d\n\nAdrian Veideman, who played on two Denver title teams and was a captain his senior year, noted that even after he graduated, Miller would stop in and visit his parents on recruiting trips to British Columbia.\n\nAt Denver, after the pregame skate on Friday mornings, Miller would lead the informal pickup game for players not in that night\u2019s lineup. \u201cBut everyone wanted to play,\u201d Veideman recalled, \u201cbecause Killer was playing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAsked what kind of player he was in high school, Miller described himself as a \u201c135-pound power forward.\u201d\n\nMiller endears himself to players with his prodigious sports memory as well as a passion for music. He listens to everything from classical to country to opera, and has been known to belt out rap songs when among players. He said he still prepared for games by listening to the same songs, including \u201cSomewhere I Belong\u201d by Linkin Park and \u201cTsunami\u201d by DVBBS & Borgeous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProvidence Coach Nate Leaman called hiring Miller a no-brainer. He said he valued Miller\u2019s hockey I.Q., his ability to prepare teams for championship play and his relentlessly positive disposition.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a really, really easy person to like and enjoy,\u201d Leaman said, although he added, \u201cHe has some bite to him.\u201d\n\nVeideman, who played 14 years of professional hockey, appreciated Miller\u2019s directness.\n\n\u201cHe gets right to the point, the good and the bad,\u201d he said.\n\nOther than a short, unsatisfying stint as the general manager and coach for a Madison, Wis., franchise in the United States Hockey League, which ended before the team\u2019s first game, Miller has never been a head coach. He said there were a couple of college jobs he went after, but never with gusto.\n\n\u201cI like being a sergeant, in the fray with the guys,\u201d he said.\n\nGwozdecky said that Miller would make an outstanding head coach, but that his selfless nature might have kept him under the coaching radar.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s never, ever, ever a self-promoter,\u201d Gwozdecky said. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t force you to notice him.\u201d\n\nMiller says he is content in Columbus, Ohio. His wife and three children, who live outside Denver, are set to join him in Ohio after the season.\n\n\u201cI would love to be a head coach if the right opportunity came around, sure, but that\u2019s not what motivates me,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I\u2019m never a head coach, I\u2019m good.\u201d", "title": "Ohio State\u2019s Secret Weapon? An Assistant Coach", "authors": ["Gary Santaniello"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Even before President Trump officially opened his high-profile review last spring of federal lands protected as national monuments, the Department of Interior was focused on the potential for oil and gas exploration at a protected Utah site, internal agency documents show.\n\nThe debate started as early as March 2017, when an aide to Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, asked a senior Interior Department official to consider shrinking Bears Ears National Monument in the southeastern corner of the state. Under a longstanding program in Utah, oil and natural gas deposits within the boundaries of the monument could have been used to raise revenue for public schools had the land not been under federal protection.\n\n\u201cPlease see attached for a shapefile and pdf of a map depicting a boundary change for the southeast portion of the Bears Ears monument,\u201d said the March 15 email from Senator Hatch\u2019s office. Adopting this map would \u201cresolve all known mineral conflicts,\u201d the email said, referring to oil and gas sites on the land that the state\u2019s public schools wanted to lease out to bolster funds.", "title": "Oil Was Central in Decision to Shrink Bears Ears Monument, Emails Show", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Midazolam, a benzodiazepine, was developed in the 1970s and became one of the world\u2019s most commonly used sedatives; it is used to make a prisoner unconscious and limit pain.\n\nThe debate over lethal injection, which prompted court cases, execution delays and struggles to obtain drugs, led Oklahoma in 2015 to make nitrogen gas its backup execution method in instances when lethal injection could not be used. The last inmate to be executed in Oklahoma was Charles Frederick Warner, in January 2015.\n\nAt the news conference in Oklahoma on Wednesday, officials did not discuss the use of sedatives, but said they had not yet determined a protocol in which to carry out executions with nitrogen.\n\nDeath penalty policy experts said that if a federal court approved the method, it would take at least six months \u2014 and probably longer \u2014 for such an execution to be carried out.\n\nRobert Dunham, executive director of the Death Penalty Information Center, which opposes the death penalty, called the potential use of nitrogen in capital cases \u201can experimentation\u201d that would likely cause suffering.\n\nOklahoma officials said they had chosen nitrogen in part because it is often used in places where assisted suicide is legal. But Mr. Dunham said that a morbidly ill person voluntarily dying with the aid of sedatives and surrounded by loved ones, and an inmate being put to death against his or her will, were hardly comparable.\n\n\u201cThere is a significant difference between when someone is seeking to terminate their own life \u2014 and they are not struggling and are willfully participating \u2014 and what happens when you involuntarily seek to terminate the life of someone who wants to live, and who will be struggling and trying not to breathe,\u201d Mr. Dunham said.", "title": "Oklahoma Turns to Gas for Executions Amid Turmoil Over Lethal Injection", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "One more obstacle cropped up for Masters in the lead-up to her fourth Paralympics, in Pyeongchang, where she had been viewed as a top contender after winning four gold medals at the 2017 World Para Nordic Skiing World Championships. In late February, she slipped on a patch of ice in Bozeman, falling and dislocating her elbow. The injury was a significant setback \u2014 she may have to switch her shooting arm in the biathlon, and it\u2019s unclear how fast she can propel herself on skis without full strength in her elbow. Undaunted, she plans to compete in the biathlon on Saturday and take part in six events during the games.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not chasing medals,\u201d Masters wrote in an Instagram post. \u201cI\u2019m chasing after my dream of representing my country, any young girl who was ever told she would be too small to be an athlete, anyone who was ever told it would be impossible to comeback from an injury and still compete at an Olympic and Paralympic Games.\u201d\n\nWhen Shiffrin learned about Masters\u2019 injury, she posted an Instagram photo of the two of them and was eager to offer support. \u201cThat\u2019s a really big injury to have,\u201d Shiffrin said. \u201cBut I have absolutely no doubt that she\u2019s going to be able to blow everyone away with how she overcomes it and her mental toughness.\u201d\n\nMasters said she plans to approach these games as she does every race. As she watches the clock tick down to the start, she will take a breath. \u201cI say, \u2018I am\u2019 \u2014 I breathe out \u2014 \u2018strong. I am strong.\u2019 And then I just take off.\u201d", "title": "Oksana Masters\u2019s Road From a Ukrainian Orphanage to Paralympic Stardom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The theater, announcing his death on its website, said he had been ill for some time.\n\nMr. Tabakov was known in Russia for a wide range of film roles, racking up his first credit in 1957 and his last 60 years later. One of his most acclaimed performances was as the title character in \u201cOblomov,\u201d Nikita Mikhalkov\u2019s version of Ivan Goncharov\u2019s 1859 novel, which played at film festivals internationally to considerable acclaim. He also appeared in \u201cMoscow Does Not Believe in Tears,\u201d which won the Oscar for best foreign film in 1981. But in Russia children knew him as the voice of a cat in \u201cThree From Prostokvashino,\u201d an animated film from 1978.\n\nMr. Tabakov\u2019s biggest impact, though, was in the theater, as an actor, director and teacher. He led several important theater companies during his long career, championing not only Chekhov and the other Russian classics but also new works and directors and plays from abroad. Many actors who studied under him became well-known stars in Russia, and the theaters he ran drew healthy crowds.\n\nThe Sovremennik Theater, which he helped found in the 1950s, posted a tribute to him on its website. \u201cOn the stage, in the frame and in life,\u201d it said, \u201che was able to combine artistry with immediacy.\u201d\n\nOleg Pavlovich Tabakov was born on Aug. 17, 1935, in Saratov, in what is now southwestern Russia. His father, Pavel, and mother, Maria Andreyevna Berezovskaya, were doctors. According to his biography on the Moscow Art Theater website, his first public performance came when he was 7 in a skit for an amateur night in which he uttered the line, \u201cDaddy, give me a gun!\u201d", "title": "Oleg Tabakov, Revered Russian Actor and Teacher, Is Dead at 82", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Wilson, whose music was played by orchestras around the world, aligned himself with an African-American musical heritage that includes Frank Johnson, a 19th-century bugler, bandleader and composer; Harry Burleigh, a composer and baritone soloist; and the contemporary composer T. J. Anderson. His other influences, he said, ranged from Igor Stravinsky and Edgard Var\u00e8se to Charlie Parker and Miles Davis.\n\n\u201cMusic is experience consciously transformed, and because my experience has been an African-American experience, I think it expresses that,\u201d he told Bruce Duffie, a radio producer and interviewer in 1997, when asked if he were conveying African-American ideas in his pieces.\n\nIn the early 1990s, Mr. Wilson wrote a viola concerto for Marcus Thompson that had an improvisatory feel, with riffs associated with a jazz saxophone or trumpet and a bluesy middle section. Mr. Thompson said in a telephone interview that, compared with other viola concertos, Mr. Wilson\u2019s was special \u201cbecause he writes from a completely different medium; he\u2019s a jazz player who\u2019s written all sorts of chamber music.\u201d\n\nThe work, titled \u201cViola Concerto,\u201d had its long-delayed premiere in 2012 with the Rochester Philharmonic. Stuart Low, of The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, called the work \u201csearing and haunting.\u201d\n\nOlly Woodrow Wilson Jr. was born in St. Louis on Sept. 7, 1937. His father was a butler and a cook; his mother, the former Alma Grace Peoples, was a domestic. Theirs was the second African-American family in their neighborhood.\n\nThe elder Mr. Wilson, a tenor who sang in choirs around St. Louis, \u201cinsisted that all of his children learn to play the piano,\u201d Olly Wilson told an oral history project at Berkeley. \u201cHe thought understanding the piano was fundamental.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nYoung Olly, who also played the clarinet and string bass, was in an acoustic band as a teenager that played local bars in St. Louis when Chuck Berry arrived one day; this was early in Mr. Berry\u2019s rise to stardom, when he performed with house bands. The band \u2014 with Mr. Wilson on piano alongside a drummer, a bassist and a saxophonist \u2014 tried in vain to keep up with Mr. Berry, who brought an amplifier to augment his guitar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSo we played, but it really didn\u2019t make any difference because you couldn\u2019t hear us,\u201d Mr. Wilson said in the oral history. \u201cHe just wiped us out \u2014 bang, bang, bang \u2014 on his guitar.\u201d\n\nRecalling Mr. Berry\u2019s famous duck walk, which made women in the bar swoon, Mr. Wilson said, \u201cWe considered that silly music because we were jazz aficionados.\u201d He and his friends were more enamored of Mr. Parker and Mr. Davis.\n\nMr. Wilson graduated from Washington University in St. Louis with a bachelor\u2019s degree in music, then earned a master\u2019s in music composition from the University of Illinois and a Ph.D. in music composition from the University of Iowa, where his dissertation was a long piece called \u201cThree Movements for Orchestra.\u201d\n\nAfter teaching at Florida A&M University from 1960 to 1965, Mr. Wilson joined the faculty of Oberlin\u2019s Conservatory of Music. In addition to teaching music theory and composition, he established a course in African-American music as well as the school\u2019s electronic music studio. After his departure, the studio turned into a program known as \u201cTechnology in Music and the Related Arts.\u201d\n\n\u201cWith electronic media,\u201d he told a music department publication at Berkeley in 1997, \u201cyou can work with sound like a sculptor or painter.\u201d\n\nHe joined Berkeley in 1970 \u2014 where he would teach until 2002 \u2014 and soon after received the Guggenheim grant to study music in Ghana. His year in West Africa was the inspiration for an orchestral piece, \u201cShango Memory,\u201d a celebration of Shango, a Nigerian deity, and what he called the \u201ccultural memory of African ideas reflected in music.\u201d\n\nAt Berkeley, he was also an administrator dealing with affirmative action in the 1970s and \u201980s and helped diversify the music curriculum.\n\nMr. Wilson received numerous commissions, including two from the conductor Seiji Ozawa \u2014 one when Mr. Ozawa was music director of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, the second when he was music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother commissioned work, for the Boston Musica Viva ensemble, was \u201cA City Called Heaven,\u201d which has elements of swing music, blues, spirituals and boogie-woogie. It was first performed in 1989.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t think of that piece without being overwhelmed by its imagination,\u201d said Mr. Thompson, who is also a music professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. \u201cIt\u2019s all based on the spirituality that\u2019s common in the black community. He had the courage and skill to do it, and that\u2019s how black culture appears in the classical canon.\u201d\n\nIn addition to his daughter, Mr. Wilson is survived by his wife, the former Elouise Woods; his son, Kent; his sisters Marion Palmer and Barbara Washington; and six grandchildren.\n\nMr. Wilson described in the oral history how his work as a scholar affected his work as a composer.\n\n\u201cBecause I studied African music and the history of African-American music doesn\u2019t necessarily mean that I consciously draw upon that when I do my work as a creative artist,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I think the pleasure that that gives me and the understanding that gives me does reflect positively on what I do as a creative artist.\u201d", "title": "Olly Wilson, 80, Dies; Composer Meshed African and Western Music", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAre omega-6 fatty acids, the fats found in nuts, seeds and many vegetable oils, including those used in many processed and junk foods, helpful or harmful?\n\nIt has been believed that omega-6s generally increase inflammation, while omega-3s, the fats in fish oil, lower it, and some studies suggest that a high omega-6 intake increases the risk for heart disease. But a new long-term study suggests omega-6s can be good for the heart.\n\nFinnish researchers studied 2,480 men aged 42 to 60, following them for an average of 22 years.\n\nThe study, in The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, found that compared with men in the lowest one-fifth for blood levels of omega-6, those in the highest fifth had a 43 percent lower risk of death from any cause and a 46 percent lower risk of cardiovascular death. The study controlled for smoking, hypertension, family history of heart disease and many other factors.\n\n\u201cThis is not a license to eat junk or processed food,\u201d said the lead author, Jyrki K. Virtanen, an adjunct professor of nutritional epidemiology at the University of Eastern Finland. \u201cEven though they contain omega-6, they are full of sugar and other things that are not good for you. But there is no need to fear omega-6 in vegetables, nuts and seeds. It clearly has benefits for heart disease prevention.\u201d", "title": "Omega-6s in Nuts, Seeds and Vegetable Oils May Aid the Heart", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNo Magic Pill Will Get You to 100,\u201d by Pagan Kennedy (Sunday Review, March 11):\n\nIn my 85th year, I have some news. If you are relatively healthy, eat a balanced diet, including red meats and some sweets, even some junk food, you can make it to old age.\n\nMy father hit 97\u00bd to the day, with two pacemakers (the first wore out). Despite my mother\u2019s careful meal planning, he indulged in two hot dogs and a soda at Costco every week, because it was a bargain.\n\nAt 97, he bought a new car even though he had three cancers. His two younger sisters also lived into their 90s \u2014 one 97 and the other 93. That sister ate a rich diet of red meat and sweets most of her life. My mother lived to 87 with 30 years of various cancers, radiation and medicines.\n\nNone of their parents lived past 78.\n\nA friend of mine died last year at 107. Not one of these super-aged people smoked, or if they did, they quit after moderate or even very heavy smoking, as my father did. He worked until he was 92.", "title": "Opinion | On Aging Well: Forget the Studies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Her grandmother Lucia Armendariz, now 70 and living with Gonzalo Armendariz, 77, in Rocky Point, N.Y., remembers the first flutterings of what would become the love story of her granddaughter and Mr. Smith, now 38.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAfter Nicole moved into the place in Crown Heights she gave a party\u201d \u2014 a Thanksgiving feast for friends that would become an annual tradition \u2014 \u201cand I went to check the turkey,\u201d Ms. Armendariz said. \u201cSteve came down from his apartment, and he kept looking at her. She looked beautiful, like Gina Lollobrigida. He couldn\u2019t take his eyes off her.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Basile and Mr. Smith, who grew up in Delmar, N.Y., the romantic road forward would be marked with scholarly texts rather than stolen cha-cha sessions in Manhattan. Mr. Smith holds two bachelor\u2019s degrees, two master\u2019s degrees and a Ph.D. The master\u2019s degrees, in music performance and music history, are from the Eastman School of Music in Rochester. The Ph.D., in music history, is from New York University, which he was still working on when Ms. Basile moved to Crown Heights.\n\nMs. Basile is also a decorated academic. She graduated from New York University in 2010 with a bachelor\u2019s degree in comparative literature, then finished a master\u2019s degree in the same subject at the university in 2011. In 2020, she expects to complete her doctoral degree at Columbia, where she has already earned a master\u2019s degree in Latin American and Iberian cultures.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe couple\u2019s academic leanings connected them momentarily even before they shared the same apartment building. In December 2009, N.Y.U.\u2019s comparative literature program had a party. Mr. Smith, whose music studies overlapped with some of the department\u2019s classes, was there. So was Ms. Basile, who had a boyfriend at the time.\n\n\u201cI was getting ready to leave, and I saw this guy with cute glasses,\u201d Ms. Basile said. \u201cA mutual friend introduced us.\u201d Nothing came of that meeting.\n\nSix months later, she and her friend Emily Nonko were looking for a New York apartment with a third friend, Brigid Mitchel. \u201cWe had some misfires, like we found a place in Park Slope that we loved, but it fell through,\u201d said Ms. Nonko, a real estate writer in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. Then a cheap three-bedroom in Crown Heights popped up on Craigslist. \u201cThere were no pictures,\u201d she said, \u201cbut we went to check it out the same day.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat they found was a wreck. \u201cIt was still under construction,\u201d Ms. Nonko said. The owner of the building ferried his prospective tenants upstairs, where Mr. Smith was living with two former college buddies, to give them a sense of how the apartment would look post-renovation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Smith and Ms. Basile locked eyes in instant recognition. \u201cIt was such a funny, strange coincidence,\u201d Ms. Nonko said. Both Mr. Smith and Ms. Basile also remembered each other\u2019s names. And it was not the only coincidence that made the place seem right.\n\nThe Crown Heights building is off the southernmost corner of Grand Avenue. Decades earlier, Ms. Basile\u2019s parents, Maril\u00fa and Jorge Basile, met and fell in love in a building on the northernmost corner of Grand Avenue. Gonzalo Armendariz, the grandfather, had opened one of New York City\u2019s first tortilla factories, Mexi-Frost, there in 1975 with Ms. Armendariz\u2019s mother, Parisina Alonso.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Armendariz remembers a young Argentine stranger casting a spell over her daughter, then 21, at Mexi-Frost in 1985: \u201cMaril\u00fa was working in the factory, and Jorge came in. I was in the office. She ran in and said, \u2018I think my husband just walked into the receiving area.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Basile was newly arrived from Argentina. He was carrying 10 pounds of Argentine beef, hoping to become a wholesaler for Mexi-Frost, which was expanding into foods beyond tortillas. \u201cShe made us invite him to dinner that night,\u201d Ms. Armendariz said. \u201cThey hadn\u2019t even known each other 24 hours.\u201d\n\nLess than a year later, they were married.\n\nMarriage was not on Ms. Basile\u2019s mind when she moved to Crown Heights, though she was by then older than her mother and grandmother were when they married. She had broken up with the boyfriend from the N.Y.U. party but was in no hurry to find a new one. And Mr. Smith was too preoccupied with finishing his Ph.D. to invest a lot of time in dating. But Ms. Basile\u2019s presence proved hard to ignore.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cNicole is beautiful and brilliant,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Thanksgiving party was his introduction to Ms. Basile\u2019s culinary skills. \u201cNicole was prepping cranberry sauce for the party and she knocked on my door and said, \u2018Hey, try this,\u2019\u201d Mr. Smith recalled. \u201cI was like, \u2018This is great, where did it come from?\u2019\u201d She had made it from fresh cranberries.\n\nBut even before Mr. Smith and his roommates ventured downstairs for Thanksgiving, he had already been plotting ways to impress Ms. Basile. In one instance, he asked his N.Y.U. adviser, Jairo Moreno, who is from Colombia, what wine he should bring to a woman who was part Argentine. (Mr. Moreno recommended a rioja and a malbec that earned the thumbs up of Ms. Basile and her grandmother.) Weeks later, he secured tickets to the kind of show that perhaps only a pair of academics would appreciate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was a staged production of Kafka\u2019s \u2018Metamorphosis,\u2019\u201d Mr. Smith said. \u201cI thought it was perfect for a comp-lit gal.\u201d It was. By Christmas, Mr. Smith and Ms. Basile were a couple.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Basile didn\u2019t have to knock on the ceiling or a heating pipe to get Mr. Smith\u2019s attention the way her grandmother did to rouse Mr. Armendariz in 1961. But she was just as fully swept up in her short-distance love affair.\n\n\u201cThere are all these wonderful surprises with Steve,\u201d Ms. Basile said. \u201cLike he has this incredible sensitivity \u2014 we\u2019ll be watching a movie or something and I\u2019ll look over and see that he\u2019s crying.\u201d\n\nIn 2014, after years of romantic interludes lit by desk lamp and littered with theses, Ms. Basile\u2019s lease was coming up for renewal.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBy then it was pretty clear that they wanted to have their own space,\u201d Ms. Nonko said. She and Ms. Mitchel finished out the lease, while Ms. Basile and Mr. Smith found a place together in another Crown Heights building.\n\nOn Dec. 16, 2016, the day before their anniversary as a couple, Ms. Basile had been writing a paper all day and into the evening in their new apartment when Mr. Smith asked if she could take a break at midnight for Champagne. She was expecting a low-key anniversary toast, but Mr. Smith had a better idea.\n\n\u201cIt was midnight and he was getting the Champagne, and he said, \u2018Why don\u2019t we play the music ball?\u2019\u201d she said. Years earlier, Ms. Basile had given him a wooden sphere that, when wound with a key, plays a tune from \u201cThe Magic Flute,\u201d a favorite opera. Ms. Basile grabbed the ball off a bookshelf. As she was about to wind it up, she found, around the key, an Art Deco ring from the 1930s that Mr. Smith had bought at Erie Basin, a Brooklyn shop Ms. Basile loves.\n\n\u201cI was so surprised,\u201d she said. As \u201cThe Magic Flute\u201d played, Mr. Smith proposed. She said yes instantly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn March 10, Ms. Basile and Mr. Smith were married before 154 guests at the Brooklyn Winery, not far from where they fell in love. Ms. Basile, in a full-length fitted lace dress with a high neck from Shareen Bridal, walked down the aisle with her father. Mr. Smith\u2019s sister, Heather Hussar, who became a marriage officiant via the City of New York for the occasion, led a short ceremony punctuated by three poetry readings. (One, \u201cDos Palabras,\u201d was read in Spanish and English.)\n\nJust after the ceremony, Mr. Smith and Ms. Basile mingled with family and friends as the Respect Sextet, the band of his former roommates, played selections that included \u201cHello Mary Lou\u201d and \u201cCampi\u00f1a,\u201d an Afro-Cuban jazz number with cha-cha leanings.\n\nThe newlyweds had been planning a first dance post-dinner to the soul hit \u201cI\u2019ve Been Loving You Too Long,\u201d played by a D.J., but the lure of \u201cCampina\u201d proved too enticing. Mr. Smith cut in to his wife\u2019s dance circle and the couple showed off what looked like well-practiced moves to cheers and wolf whistles.\n\nLater, Ms. Armendariz pointed out that her granddaughter and Mr. Smith were clearly made for each other. Also that it pays to believe in serendipity, especially in New York apartment buildings. \u201cYou never know when you\u2019re going to meet somebody and your life will change,\u201d she said.", "title": "On Craigslist, 3BR Unfinished, Future Husband Upstairs", "authors": ["Tammy La Gorce"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Iungerich grew up in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., and \u201cAwkward\u201d was set in that largely white and Asian-American environment. With \u201cOn My Block,\u201d she\u2019s stayed in Southern California but shifted the demographics, setting the show in a fictional section of Los Angeles called Freeridge, whose residents are predominantly Latino and African-American.\n\nThe show has drawn praise for promoting diversity, but its most distinctive feature is Ms. Iungerich\u2019s sensibility, the same one she brought to \u201cAwkward\u201d: a kind of deadpan burlesque in which the jokes hit on the downbeat, and the young characters, no matter how bright, seem to exist in a constant state of irritable confusion.\n\n\u201cOn My Block\u201d is a coming-of-age story built around a love quadrangle \u2014 two girls (Sierra Capri and Ronni Hawk) and two boys (Diego Tinoco and Jason Genao) trying to sort out their mutual attractions and jealousies. A fifth friend played by Brett Gray, whose slightly abrasive style calls to mind Kevin Hart or (very distantly) a young Eddie Murphy, provides the pure comic relief in a subplot about an urban buried-treasure legend.\n\n\u201cOn My Block\u201d has the off-center charm and quirky comic rhythms Ms. Iungerich is known for, but it has a problem that\u2019s tied to its setting. The stumbling block Ms. Iungerich has chosen for her young characters is the gang life: One of the boys is expected to join his older brother\u2019s gang, which threatens to break up \u201cthe fam\u201d (the group of friends) as well as the central romance.\n\nThere\u2019s nothing necessarily wrong with that as a dramatic device (besides overuse), but it\u2019s uncomfortably out of proportion in a half-hour teenage comedy. The shifts from football game high jinks or a character\u2019s apple-bong-toking abuelita to the question of whether to shoot another teenager in the head are disconcerting, to say the least.\n\nIf neither cancer diagnoses nor street gangs are your idea of a children\u2019s-comedy premise, you might shift your gaze from Netflix to Amazon, where \u201cThe Dangerous Book for Boys\u201d has its premiere on Friday. In this fictionalization of the fanciful boy\u2019s-life handbooks written by Conn and Hal Iggulden, the central conflict involves a family whose three young boys are recovering from the death of their gadget-inventing father. Warmhearted and perhaps imaginary adventures ensue, facilitated by the father\u2019s identical twin (played by the always engaging Chris Diamantopoulos). If you like your nostalgia straight up, without \u201cStranger Things\u201d-style monsters, it might be for you.", "title": "On Netflix, a Growing Wave of Shows for and About Teenagers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Kim also enters any negotiation with considerable leverage. North Korea has made such strides in its nuclear and ballistic missile program in recent years that experts say it could agree to a pause in the testing of missiles, while it conducts negotiations, without really damaging its drive to be a bona fide nuclear weapons state.\n\n\u201cThey use negotiations to buy time,\u201d said Christopher R. Hill, who negotiated with North Korea for several years during the Bush administration.\n\nStill, Mr. Hill noted that it was the first time in more than eight years that North Korea had opened the door to negotiating on its nuclear program. Given that, he said the Trump administration should explore the prospect seriously, first by thoroughly debriefing South Korea\u2019s envoys.\n\n\u201cWe need to chart a course between negative churlishness and irrational exuberance,\u201d Mr. Hill said.\n\nDiplomacy between the United States and North Korea has gone through cycles of long stagnation, followed by brief bursts of hope and then disappointment, typically after North Korea reneged on any agreement. Those collapses have sometimes been accompanied by what Americans have called cheating, but what the North has called prudence.\n\nIn October 1994, Mr. Clinton concluded what was perhaps the most ambitious nuclear agreement ever reached between Washington and Pyongyang \u2014 called, appropriately, the Agreed Framework.\n\nUnder the deal, North Korea halted construction of two nuclear reactors that the United States believed would be used to produce fuel for a nuclear bomb. In return, the White House pledged to give North Korea two alternative nuclear power reactors that could not be used in a weapons program \u2014 as well as fuel to tide it over before the new reactors were ready.\n\nThe 1994 accord blocked the North from reprocessing plutonium from its reactor at Yongbyon. The North complied, but then purchased equipment to enrich uranium, another pathway to a bomb, from Abdul Qadeer Khan, one of the fathers of the Pakistani bomb.", "title": "On North Korea, Trump Finds Himself in Same Position as His Predecessors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cGood Leaders Make Good Schools\u201d (column, March 13), David Brooks rightly highlights the critical role that the leadership of principals plays in influencing school success. There are two main lessons to be drawn.\n\nFirst, the performance of any institution begins with the quality of the leadership. And second, a leader\u2019s most important task is to be a culture-setter and shaper, constantly driving toward an organizational culture that is grounded in high expectations and genuine accountability, and that puts a premium on trust, collaboration, mutual respect and inclusivity.\n\nThose are lessons that are just as applicable to business and government as they are to schools. Both our chief executives and our president would do well to take them to heart.\n\nRICHARD STOPOL\n\nLONG ISLAND CITY, QUEENS\n\nThe writer is president of NYC Outward Bound Schools.", "title": "Opinion | On School Leadership", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The Disney Magic was the first of the Disney cruise ships, launched in 1998, and renovated in 2013; this month will see another \u201creimagining,\u201d including a Rapunzel-themed restaurant. It may not be the biggest cruise boat on the seas (that became clear when we docked next to the real behemoths in the Bahamas) or even in the Disney fleet, but its dimensions are still impressive: 11 decks, 984 feet long, 171.5 feet tall.\n\nActivities were legion. I had signed up for some in advance. (Not-at-all-pro tips: Sign up early and preregister your children at the Disney Cruise website \u2014 many events book up quickly. And download the Disney Cruise app before you leave \u2014 it\u2019s how you will communicate with family members.) Other activities were noted on a daily schedule dropped off at our Deluxe Oceanview Stateroom With Verandah. At 3 p.m. on our first day, for example, we could have: caught the second half of \u201cThor: Ragnarok\u201d in a state-of-the-art movie theater that seats 278; lined up to meet Minnie Mouse on Deck 4, or Princess Sofia (of the Disney Channel\u2019s \u201cSofia the First\u201d) on Deck 5; joined \u201cGame Show: The Feud\u201d on the promenade lounge; taken part in an (adults-only) origami session; or dropped Anna off at the Oceaneer Club \u2014 one of two activity centers open to kids for the bulk of the day and evening. It was all dizzying.\n\nOr we could have gone ashore to Key West, our first stop. I couldn\u2019t convince Anna to join me, so I went solo. It turned out Anna had made the right call: It was sunny but cool and very windy; fellow passengers shivered down touristy Duval Street buying their T-shirted kids oversized sweatshirts. I headed to CVS to get some DayQuil for Nancy, who had picked up Anna\u2019s chest cold, then stopped for a mediocre Cuban lunch.\n\nI had signed Nancy and myself up for a couples massage later that afternoon \u2014 hey, we deserved a break even on day one, O.K.? \u2014 so we dropped Anna off at the Oceaneer Club and headed up to Senses Spa & Salon. The massage, given by two Serbian women (their nationalities, as with all crew members, were noted on their name tags), was a good one, if pricey ($170 per person). We passed on the products they had used during the massage, which were for sale. Almost every activity, it would turn out, ended with a gentle upsell.\n\nIt was time for dinner. There are two seatings nightly, and you are directed to one of four restaurants around the ship, the idea being that you get to try each one. Tonight was Carioca\u2019s, supposedly Brazilian-themed, though I couldn\u2019t quite figure out in what way. We were seated with a couple from Miami, whose daughter was about Anna\u2019s age. The food was fine, but the service was stellar, as it was everywhere on the ship. I can\u2019t say that I was thrilled that my daughter was constantly being called \u201cPrincess,\u201d but each crew member seemed genuinely enthusiastic and pleased to be on the boat, down to the person passing out sanitizing wipes to e very passenger entering a restaurant. (Hygiene is, understandably, a huge deal on the ship. In addition to the wipes, the kid centers have devices that might best be described as washing machines for hands.)\n\nOur servers at Carioca\u2019s at dinner were from Thailand and Scotland and introduced themselves as such, as all crew members did (there are 950 in total, of 80 nationalities, for an astounding customer-to-crew ratio of less than 3-to-1). I found all of this charming and touching.\n\nMy adult activity that night, which I had signed up for in advance, was a whiskey tasting in the loungey Cove Caf\u00e9 on Deck 9. It was not my first bar visit of the trip. The night before, I had grabbed a $20 glass of quality Scotch at Keys, one of the cluster of venues in the After Hours section of the boat (the others are Fathoms, where a D.J. was setting up, and O\u2019Gill\u2019s Pub, which offered beers on tap and free crudit\u00e9s and wings). Keys is a piano bar, complete with a high-end booze selection and a fedora\u2019d player behind the piano. (It also plays host to Friday night Shabbat services.) My bartender, Alejandro, from Peru, was friendly and knowledgeable. Noting my interest in Scotch, he offered me a flight of four Macallan single malts for $60. Another upsell, but also a pretty good deal. Still, four more ounces of booze seemed like a bad idea, so I declined, and instead caught 20 minutes of \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi\u201d in the excellent Buena Vista Theatre.", "title": "On a Disney Cruise, It\u2019s a Stressful World (After All)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Some nights on Peninsula Papagayo, on the northern Pacific side of Costa Rica, the moon shone so bright, with so little evidence of human life, that I felt like an interloper just for bearing witness, for breathing through its stillness. Then I would remember how much it cost to be able to look at that moon from this particular part of the world and the poetry was quickly shattered.\n\nIf this bio-diverse Central American country has branded itself as a playground for rich North Americans \u2014 40 percent of its tourists come from the United States \u2014 then Peninsula Papagayo, in the Guanacaste Province, is where the ultrarich go to avoid having to interact with the regular rich. The 1,400-acre luxury resort area is in a tropical dry forest, 70 percent of which is conserved as open green space. Guard stations and miles of cliffside roads separate its dwellings from any public byway. Lady Gaga rang in the New Year there. A night in a basic room at the Four Seasons, which is part of a development group that controls most properties on the peninsula, would set me back more than my monthly New York City rent (around $1,445, with taxes and resort fees). A night at its most expensive estate home goes for $34,500 in peak season.\n\nAs a traveler, I am deeply uncomfortable with frills. Our typical family vacation when I was growing up near Santa Fe, N.M., consisted of stuffing a black cargo van with camping gear and driving as far south across the Mexican border as we could before the van broke down. In this case, though, some frills couldn\u2019t be avoided. I\u2019m on assignment to visit every destination on The Times\u2019s 52 Places to Go in 2018 list, and the entirely private, entirely exclusive Peninsula Papagayo \u2014 not to be confused with the plain old Papagayo region just to the south \u2014 came in at No. 20. Beyond the Four Seasons, one can stay in private condos (more expensive), properties managed by Exclusive Resorts (more expensive), and the Andaz, the \u201cbudget\u201d option, where the cheapest room I could find for a single night came in at $735 (resort fee and tax included).", "title": "Place 6 of 52: On the Costa Rican Coast, Finding Fun by Escaping Exclusivity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEight months into his role as chief executive of Breitling, the Swiss brand best known for its masculine pilots\u2019 watches, Georges Kern is a man on the go.\n\nThe former Compagnie Financi\u00e8re Richemont executive, 53, began an action-packed roadshow to promote Breitling\u2019s new Navitimer 8 collection of pilots\u2019 watches in late January in Shanghai and concluded it a few weeks ago in Dubai, with stops in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Singapore, Zurich, Munich, New York and London in between. (At the New York stop, in late February, the brand held a celebrity-studded gala to show off 60 historic timepieces as well as the new pilots\u2019 watches.)\n\nWith the backing of the private equity group CVC Capital Partners, which acquired an 80 percent stake in Breitling last year, Mr. Kern has big plans for the 134-year-old brand, beginning with a complete overhaul of its collections and a new advertising campaign, scheduled to debut in June. \u201cBy the end of the year,\u201d he said, \u201cI think you will not recognize it.\u201d\n\nYou were at IWC Schaffhausen for 15 years and left on the brink of its 150th anniversary. Why Breitling?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s easy. First of all, I had the opportunity with CVC to co-invest in the company. Of course, there\u2019s a higher risk but potentially a higher return. And second, of the independent brands, you have Rolex, Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet and Breitling. That\u2019s it. I discovered the history, the potential, everything that is there. I\u2019ve rarely seen such a richness and depth in a historical catalog in my whole career.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s your biggest challenge as chief executive?\n\nWe are looking into everything: integrating our distribution, reducing our wholesale network. We have totally reworked our segmentation. We are launching two lines: the Navitimer 8 and the Navitimer 01. In the second half of the year, we are launching a more elegant watch. We are reviewing our boutique concept, our communication concept \u2014 a 360 review of basically everything. The brand has phenomenal awareness and is very successful but it has to become more contemporary and to enlarge its customer base.", "title": "On the Road With Georges Kern of Breitling", "authors": ["Victoria Gomelsky"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "As a result, the Turks have launched the Afrin offensive, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has vowed to wipe out the Kurdish forces throughout northern Syria all the way to the easternmost areas. \u201cStep by step, we will clean our entire border,\u201d the Turkish president said in a speech at the end of January, overlooking the inconvenient fact that American forces are active in northern Syria, as allies of the S.D.F.\n\nAs anyone who has worked in Syria knows, paperwork is an obsession here. The paper chase was a way of life when the regime of Bashir al-Assad ruled this area, and it seems just as obsessive where the S.D.F., dominated by Syrian Kurds, is in charge.\n\nWe had entered Syria by ferry across the Tigris River from Iraq, at a place called Fishkabour. The ferry was an oversized, open motorboat with a 150-horsepower Evinrude outboard motor, and it made the crossing in about 3.5 seconds.\n\nOur first stop in Syria was the Kurds\u2019 Semalka customs post, an ornate building that looked out of place in a mostly muddy lot. Inside was the affable representative in charge, Aziz Ahmad, as well as an official rubber stamp, a printer and a photocopier \u2014 all of which would prove common in official spaces here, even where electricity was scarce and heat spotty.\n\nThe above-mentioned document, issued after the customary cups of tea and Turkish coffee, declared that the Democratic Self-Administration Government of the Al Jazeera Canton of Rojava (Western Kurdistan), office of media and nongovernmental organization affairs, had granted each of us permission to enter Rojava.\n\nAlas, that did not include permission to move along Rojava\u2019s roads. For that we had to go to the city of Qamishli, which in any case had the nearest hotels, and apply to the State Security office, known here as the Asayish.\n\nUnfortunately, the Asayish could not issue such a permission until we were registered as journalists with the Self-Administration Government\u2019s High Media Council, and to do that we would have to proceed to the city of Amuda, about an hour\u2019s drive west of Qamishli. Since the office there closed at 2:30 p.m., that meant a wait until the next day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBright and early in the morning, we climbed the five flights of stairs, strewn with peeled paint, to the media council\u2019s suite of offices. The head of administration, Arsheikh Baravi, sat in front of a laptop in an office with a wood stove converted to burn oil from a scary-looking, suspended drip tank. (It\u2019s hard to explain.)\n\nThere we presented passports, our white customs entry slips, press cards and our letter of introduction from The New York Times.\n\n\u201cThis is not correctly addressed,\u201d Mr. Baravi said.\n\nWhat was the problem?\n\n\u201cIt says \u2018To Whom It May Concern.\u2019 That is not my name.\u201d But after some discussion Mr. Baravi agreeably agreed to overlook the issue, this one time.\n\nOnce back in Qamishli, inside the Asayish compound, getting our road permit required visits to two more offices and one photocopier. That allowed us to proceed west back to Ainissa, a four-hour drive. The S.D.F. media office added to our growing sheaf of paperwork a permit that allowed us to work in military areas of Rojava.\n\nJust when we thought we were done, a friendly official named Ali in the S.D.F. media office informed us that we would have to come back the next day, and every day, to renew that permission. Since the nearest hotel was an hour and a half away in the town of Kobani, that meant potentially three hours of daily paper-chase commuting lay ahead.\n\nNot so quick, though. Since we were staying in Kobani we would also need to register there and get another permission slip. That office was now closed, so we would not be able to do that until it opened at 9 a.m. the next day.\n\nAt the hotel late that night we learned that the office\u2019s employees were going into hiding, fearing Turkish airstrikes. So instead of opening at 9 a.m., the Kobani office would be closed all day, and then again the next day when a mass demonstration was called to protest the Turkish assault on Afrin and all public offices emptied out to join it.\n\nThe day after that (now four days since our initial arrival in Syria), the head of the media center in Kobani, Ghosn Rajb, finally issued the Kobani paperwork, but only after scolding us for failing to register all week.", "title": "On the Road in Syria, Where Covering the War Is a Paper Chase", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "23A: Fun story about the EDSEL: One of the things that supposedly dissuaded people from buying the car in the first place was its grille. Depending on your perspective, it was thought to resemble either a vulva or a toilet seat, and I\u2019m sure the copywriter who came up with the line \u201cThe thrill starts with the grille\u201d never quite lived it down.\n\n33A/33D: Tough crossing here if you are not up on your collective seal nouns and tailoring wordplay. A group of female seals is called a HAREM, and don\u2019t forget that when you see the word \u201cline\u201d used in clues with a question mark (like today\u2019s \u201cBottom line?\u201d), you are usually looking for a HEM or something that is shaped like a line.\n\n50A: I had to Google this to be sure, but a \u201cRail center?\u201d is a MARSH because rails are a type of bird that lives in a marsh.\n\n1D: If you are \u201cOne going against the grain?\u201d you are not necessarily blazing your own path. You could also be a REAPER, reaping your grain.\n\n2D: As mentioned above, today I learned about the AUBADE, a poem or song that focuses on the dawn or morning. An example of this form would be John Donne\u2019s \u201cThe Sun Rising,\u201d which, if nothing else, shows that Mr. Donne was clearly not a morning person.\n\n4D: Nice example of a veiled capital clue, where the first word in the clue is capitalized not just because it is the beginning of a sentence, but also because the clue is \u201chiding\u201d a trick. In the clue \u201cGiant competitor,\u201d we\u2019re not thinking of a large corporation, we\u2019re thinking of a competitor to a player on the San Francisco Giants baseball team. The answer in this puzzle is PADRE, as in a player for the San Diego team. Want more practice with those devious veiled capital clues? There\u2019s help in our solving guide under the \u201cCracking the Harder Clues\u201d tab.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nWe\u2019re both big fans of the \u201cGolden Age of Television,\u201d so we racked our brains to find some way to sneak a classic TV reference into this puzzle.\n\nShould we use \u201cSimon & Simon\u201d or \u201cRiptide\u201d in the DETECTS clue? How about the \u201cL\u201d monograms that were SEWN ON all of Laverne DeFazio\u2019s tops? We could have asked which cop show was the LEAD-IN to \u201cThe Love Boat\u201d for four seasons. (\u201cT.J. Hooker.\u201d Duh.) Or maybe a shout out to our favorite NEMESES, Jo and Blair from the \u201cFacts of Life.\u201d\n\nIn the end, we decided there was simply no elegant way to refer to a \u201970s-\u201980s sitcom that ran for nine seasons on CBS and was recently rebooted as a successful Netflix series. Maybe next puzzle!\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "On the Tip of Your Tongue", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith every new episode of \u201cSaturday Night Live,\u201d you can find us here writing about the best sketches. Looking for more stories about \u201cS.N.L.\u201d? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nIn a memorable comic turn on Saturday night, President Trump performed an impression of himself if he had been a conventional, strait-laced head of state; he hurled an obscenity at Chuck Todd, the host of \u201cMeet the Press\u201d; and he boasted that he knew what Oprah Winfrey\u2019s weakness was. But enough about the president\u2019s rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\nForced to compete with this kind of reality \u2014 and minus the services of its resident Trump impersonator, Alec Baldwin \u2014 \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d took some unusual cultural detours to arrive at its topical satire this weekend, in an episode hosted by Sterling K. Brown and featuring the musical guest James Bay.\n\nThe show\u2019s opening sketch seemed to promise a parody of the season finale of \u201cThe Bachelor,\u201d the ABC reality series, from earlier this week, in which Arie Luyendyk Jr. first chose Becca Kufrin as his bride-to-be, then broke up with her and proposed to another contestant, Lauren Burnham.
