I just want to get to the point where this is all over and life goes back to normal. I\u2019m excited to see him.\u201d\n\nEnter the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III, played by Kate McKinnon in jowly prosthetic makeup. \u201cHow do I start this conversation?\u201d she asked Strong.", "title": "On \u2018S.N.L.,\u2019 \u2018The Bachelor\u2019 With Another Kind of Breakup", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Jeff Swarey bought his AR-15 rifle five years ago after shooting guns in video games. Jessie K. Fletcher, a former Marine sniper, was given one by his platoon after he stepped on a bomb in Afghanistan that blew off his legs. Jessica Dorantes, a Texas police officer, will not go on patrol without hers.\n\nTheir shared communion is a firearm that has in recent decades become a staple of American gun culture. Its iconic silhouette is immediately recognizable \u2014 and polarizing.\n\nThe AR-15 won its place in American culture through a confluence of circumstances, described in interviews by more than 15 gun industry professionals, hobbyists, lawyers and gun owners. They pointed to 2004, when the AR-15 re-entered the gun market after the end of the federal assault weapons ban, at a time of heightened interest in the military. It was popularized by the rise of a video game culture in which shooting became an accessible form of mass entertainment, and it was marketed as accessible and easy to personalize.\n\nFor those who love the rifle, it is seen as a testament to freedom \u2014 a rite of passage shared between parents and children, a token to welcome soldiers home, a tradition shared with friends at the range. But in its relatively short life span, the AR-15 has also become inextricably linked with tragedy and has been vilified as the weapon of mass murder.", "title": "Once Banned, Now Loved and Loathed: How the AR-15 Became \u2018America\u2019s Rifle\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think Ryan\u2019s expectations had to be dramatically reduced when Trump became president,\u201d said Peter Wehner, a onetime adviser to former President George W. Bush who is close to the speaker. \u201cI think in a lot of ways he was forced into a defensive posture rather than an offensive posture.\u201d\n\nTo supporters like Mr. Wehner, Mr. Ryan\u2019s approach is pure pragmatism and smart politics. Facing a divided Republican conference and a mercurial president of his party, they say, he has little choice but to curb some of his own instincts, work behind the scenes and steer Mr. Trump gently. He also must guide House Republicans into a very difficult midterm election campaign, where his main job is to ensure that vulnerable members get re-elected. And those close to Mr. Ryan note that, with the exception of trade, he has not had serious policy disagreements with the president.\n\nBut Mr. Ryan had modeled himself as a different kind of leader, the youthful face of a new brand of conservatism that was to broaden his party\u2019s appeal and move it beyond 1980s-style Reaganism. His 2012 run for vice president lifted his national profile and fortified his standing. So to critics, the leader once described as \u201cthe intellectual center of Republicans in the House\u201d has abandoned principles to hang onto a job he ostensibly never wanted.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m tired of saying deep in his heart there is a different Paul Ryan,\u201d said Charles J. Sykes, a conservative commentator and former radio host in Mr. Ryan\u2019s home state of Wisconsin, who for years promoted Mr. Ryan as a potential presidential candidate.\n\nConservative critiques of Mr. Trump, from senators such as Jeff Flake of Arizona and Ben Sasse of Nebraska, have gone beyond policy disagreements, to temperament, defenses of democratic institutions and law enforcement, and the conduct of foreign policy. And other Republican leaders are speaking out. John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican in the Senate, is giving almost daily speeches on the Senate floor pushing for action on a modest but bipartisan bill to fortify the existing background check system for gun purchases.\n\nSenator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the chairman of the Finance Committee and a loud supporter of Mr. Trump, nonetheless scorched his tariffs as \u201ca tax hike the American people don\u2019t need and can\u2019t afford.\u201d\n\nMr. Ryan has repeatedly urged Mr. Trump to abandon the tariffs in private, according to one person familiar with their conversations. In public, he has held his tongue. He declined to be interviewed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI always imagined that there was room for an alternative conservative vision to Trumpism, and Paul Ryan was ideally suited to be that leader of a non-Trumpist conservative Republican Party, but he\u2019s chosen not to assume that role,\u201d Mr. Sykes said. \u201cIt\u2019s very disappointing to see he\u2019s become so comfortable as an ally and an enabler of Trump.\u201d\n\nFor Democrats, the speaker\u2019s deference to Mr. Trump is the stuff of ridicule \u2014 and a constitutional dereliction of duty by the man three steps from the presidency.\n\n\u201cCan you imagine Tip O\u2019Neill or Sam Rayburn or any of the portraits in this gallery saying, \u2018I don\u2019t know whether I can be for that, I\u2019ve got to go down the street and ask permission of the president\u2019?\u201d asked Representative Anna G. Eshoo, Democrat of California, referring to previous speakers whose portraits hang just outside the House chamber.\n\nTo be sure, Mr. Ryan has had some achievements, notably the rewrite of the federal tax code, which for the speaker marked the realization of a long-held dream. He pushed a repeal of the Affordable Care Act through the House, only to see it die in the Senate. And he helped negotiate a two-year budget deal that should bring some peace to Washington even as it balloons federal spending.\n\n\u201cSpeaker Ryan has taken on all the challenges of the modern speakership and deftly kept the conference united while advancing an historic conservative agenda,\u201d said Mr. Ryan\u2019s spokeswoman, AshLee Strong. She cited in particular the tax code rewrite and the budget deal\u2019s provisions for \u201cthe rebuilding of our depleted military.\u201d\n\nMr. Ryan has not always been so deferential. When Mr. Trump attacked a Mexican-American judge during the 2016 presidential campaign, Mr. Ryan called the comments the \u201ctextbook definition of a racist comment.\u201d When the infamous Access Hollywood tape came out, showing Mr. Trump boasting of sexually assaulting women, Mr. Ryan saw to it that Mr. Trump was disinvited to a rally in Wisconsin.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re from entirely different worlds,\u201d Mr. Wehner said. \u201cThat said, Ryan knows he has to deal with Trump, and Trump has probably figured out he has to rely on Ryan.\u201d\n\nNow 48, Mr. Ryan became the youngest speaker since 1869 when he was elected to the post in the fall of 2015, replacing John A. Boehner, who was effectively pushed out by conservatives in his unruly conference. Mr. Ryan told his colleagues then that he would accept the speakership only if all factions would unite behind him.\n\nTo a certain extent, he has succeeded.\n\nBut in the name of unity, he has governed with a light hand. Last month, the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee confronted Mr. Ryan after they concluded that the House Intelligence Committee had leaked a senator\u2019s private texts \u2014 a serious breach of protocol. Although the senators raised concerns about the direction of the committee under its chairman, Devin Nunes of California, Mr. Ryan apparently chose not to intervene.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe speaker heard the senators on their concerns and encouraged them to take them up directly with their counterparts,\u201d said his spokeswoman, Ms. Strong.\n\nIf Mr. Ryan is known for one quality, House Republicans say, it is his willingness to listen. Members of his conference view him as \u201cinclusive and fair,\u201d said Representative Charlie Dent, Republican of Pennsylvania.\n\nBut in a chamber where 218 votes are required to pass legislation, Mr. Ryan still faces the same fundamental problem as his predecessor: He has difficulty bringing his fractious conference together. That means he must watch his step.\n\nUnlike Representative Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader, who was speaker from 2007 to 2011, he is not a forceful presence in the House chamber. As speaker, Ms. Pelosi ruled the House with an iron fist, guiding dozens of bills large and small into law. She engineered passage of even doomed bills like a climate change bill that died in the Senate \u2014 and likely cost Democrats seats in the 2010 Republican landslide. She emerged as the undisputable face of her caucus, to some members\u2019 chagrin.\n\nThat is not Mr. Ryan\u2019s style.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard for anyone be a strong speaker in the traditional sense around here because the speaker is only as strong as his conference allows him to be,\u201d Mr. Dent said. \u201cAnd because on many issues the speaker cannot get 218 Republican votes, that weakens his position.\u201d\n\nApart from the tax overhaul, that has made for narrow legislative proposals. With Republicans under intense pressure to address gun violence after the high school massacre in Parkland, Fla., Mr. Ryan swatted away any suggestion last week that the House would take expansive action.\n\nThe chamber has already adopted a measure to make modest changes to the national instant background check database, coupled with a measure pushed by the gun lobby to expand the reach of concealed weapons permits. The speaker said Republican leaders now are waiting for the Senate to act.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to micromanage this,\u201d he said at a news conference.\n\nBut there are consequences to Mr. Ryan\u2019s low-key style. Big issues like immigration are languishing with no resolution in sight. Causes that were once Mr. Ryan\u2019s signature fights \u2014 an exploding budget deficit, soaring Medicare and Social Security spending and an entrenched welfare state \u2014 are on nobody\u2019s must-do list. Even Mr. Boehner, never viewed as a policymaking powerhouse, at least tried to negotiate a \u201cgrand bargain\u201d with the White House that was to slow entitlement spending, cut other parts of the government and raise revenue to balance the budget.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ryan\u2019s break with Mr. Trump on trade came only after several other Republicans made clear that they were not standing by the president. Republicans are running for re-election on the strength of the economy, hoping that voters credit their policies, especially the tax cuts. But a trade war marked by a spike in consumer prices could jeopardize their survival strategy.\n\nTo Representative Brian Mast, Republican of Florida and a combat veteran who lost both his legs in Afghanistan, Mr. Ryan\u2019s suggestion that the House wait for the Senate to act on guns is not good enough after the Parkland slaughter.\n\n\u201cIf we believe that tax reform is a do-or-die issue that we have to get done but we can\u2019t say that protecting our kids is that same kind of issue, then that\u2019s not leadership,\u201d said Mr. Mast, who backed an assault weapons ban after the bloodshed in Parkland.\n\nConservatives, meanwhile, have put Mr. Ryan on notice that he does not have free rein. Representative Mark Meadows of North Carolina, the chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, was instrumental in the ouster of Mr. Boehner, and he suggested last month that a misstep on immigration in particular could cost Mr. Ryan his job.\n\n\u201cI can say that it is a defining moment for this speaker,\u201d Mr. Meadows said then. \u201cIf he gets it wrong, it will have consequences for him.\u201d", "title": "Once Outspoken, Paul Ryan Wields His Speaker\u2019s Gavel Gingerly", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "It was only last year, after seeing several cases pay out, that Mr. Thomas recouped the costs of getting his practice up and running. After a client received an $8.8 million award in a New York State tax-fraud case last April, Mr. Thomas recruited three additional partners to join him, two of them alumni of the S.E.C.\n\nAside from expanding his practice, Mr. Thomas has made one concession to his improved fortunes: He traded in his 16-year old Toyota Avalon for a Tesla Model S \u2014 sticker price $68,000.\n\nMr. Thomas, 47, doesn\u2019t have the traditional pedigree of a Wall Street lawyer.\n\nHe describes his childhood as traumatic. His parents divorced when he was young, and he grew up with his mother, a teacher, and stepfather in mobile home parks in California and Yakima, Wash. He and his stepfather battled, and at 15, Mr. Thomas became an emancipated minor.\n\nLater, while studying at the University of California, Los Angeles, he was inspired by a performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and transferred to Bennington College in Vermont, known for its contemporary dance program. Seeking to create some distance from his past, he changed his name to Jordan Thomas. (He declined to give his parents\u2019 names or the name on his own birth certificate.)\n\n\u201cHe said he felt basically broken. He had a lot of wounds in his life,\u201d said Susan Sgorbati, who mentored Mr. Thomas in dance improvisation at Bennington. \u201cI remember a lot of anger, uncertainty and restlessness in him but also real ambition.\u201d His classmates included the future Hollywood star Peter Dinklage.\n\nMr. Thomas went to law school and then entered the United States Navy Judge Advocate General\u2019s Corps. In 1999, he joined the Justice Department. There, he described himself as \u201ca poor boy trying to fit in with all the Ivy League guys.\u201d\n\nMr. Thomas eventually migrated to the S.E.C., working in the enforcement division before helping to develop the whistle-blower program, which was created in response to criticism that the agency failed to heed warnings about Bernard Madoff\u2019s Ponzi scheme.", "title": "Once an S.E.C. Regulator, Now Thriving as a Lawyer for Whistle-Blowers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 When President Ashraf Ghani stood up last week to try to lure the Taliban to peace talks, promising them amnesty and political inclusion, he could point to a recent example: the deal that brought the militant group Hezb-i-Islami and its deeply divisive leader, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, in from the battlefield.\n\nThrough decades of Afghan turmoil, Mr. Hekmatyar has managed to keep himself near the action, and has broken alliances several times to do it. He has been a C.I.A.-favored fighter of the Soviets, a warlord who mauled Kabul, a prime minister, an admirer of Al Qaeda, an ally and enemy of the Taliban, and an unabashed proponent of suicide bombings against American forces.\n\nSince the deal that allowed him to return, initiated during the Obama administration and finalized last year under the Trump administration, he has become a more public player in the increasingly chaotic and hostile jumble of Afghan politics.\n\nThough his reconciliation has been held out as a hope for peace, one thing Mr. Hekmatyar has not yet become is any kind of political peacemaker.", "title": "Once-Feared Afghan Warlord Is Still Causing Trouble, but Talking Peace", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Don\u2019t tell that to the Trumps, who continue to make their case in various legal venues.\n\nIn a statement, the Trump Organization\u2019s chief legal officer, Alan Garten, noted that the management contract \u201cmandates that all disputes be resolved through binding arbitration\u201d and that \u201cTrump Hotels has filed a $50 million lawsuit against Mr. Fintiklis.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Fintiklis\u2019s actions on Thursday, Mr. Garten said, \u201cconstitute an abuse of process and represent another attempt by him to misuse the Panamanian courts in an effort to circumvent arbitration.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe look forward to litigating this matter in the forum agreed upon by the parties where we are confident we will prevail,\u201d Mr. Garten said.\n\nAmid the legal wrangling, the Trump Organization\u2019s website and social media for the property continued to exist, with no sign of the struggle.\n\nBut when a reporter tried to book a room, the Trump website \u2014 replete with information on accommodations, dining options and the health club \u2014 responded as if the hotel was filled: \u201cWe apologize. There are no available rooms for your requested stay. Please check your dates and try again.\u201d\n\nOver at thebahiagrand.com, a message greeted guests: \u201cWelcome to the Bahia Grand Panama, the only luxury hotel directly on the open waters of the majestic gulf of Panama City \u2014 with one exciting change \u2014 we\u2019re under new management.\u201d\n\nEven though the name was not unveiled until Thursday, the hotel owners seemed to have had it picked out for more than a month. The new website was registered on Jan. 30, according to records from the cyberforensics company DomainTools.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bare-bones website does not detail where guests can eat or drink on the property. But one thing is clear: The \u201cbook now\u201d tab shows availability.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn fact, the fight between the Trumps and Mr. Fintiklis has centered on the hotel\u2019s occupancy rates.\n\nMr. Fintiklis has claimed that profit has plummeted as the hotel sat \u201cvirtually empty.\u201d\n\nThe Trump Organization disputes that claim and argues that the hotel \u201ccontinues to outperform the market by a wide margin\u201d as the broader Panamanian hotel business has struggled.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe dispute exploded last month when Mr. Fintiklis appeared at the hotel with an entourage and sought to fire several Trump-employed staff members. The Trump employees stood their ground.\n\nThen, on Monday, Mr. Fintiklis arrived with a contingent of court officials and police officers \u2014 and a Panamanian court order authorizing a change of administration.\n\nHe declared victory. The Trumps pushed back.\n\nThe Panamanian court order, the Trumps argued, merely authorized \u201cthe appointment of a temporary, third party administrator to oversee the management of the property while the underlying dispute is being litigated.\u201d\n\nThat nuance did not prevent Mr. Fintiklis, a Cypriot citizen, from heading to the baby grand piano in the lobby to play and sing \u201cAccordeon,\u201d a popular Greek song about the fight against fascism.\n\nThe piano is not featured on either website.", "title": "One Hotel in Panama, but Two Competing Websites (and a Single Mention of Trump)", "authors": ["Ben Protess", "Steve Eder"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Man Who Knew Too Little\u201d (Sunday Styles, March 11):\n\nI am not writing to disparage the choices made by Erik Hagerman in \u201ctaking a break\u201d from reading the news since the election of Donald Trump. We do what we need to do to save ourselves. His choice is as valid as any other. I am writing to express disappointment that Mr. Hagerman does not even acknowledge the sacrifices of others who, as much as they would like to abdicate, don\u2019t.\n\nThey \u2014 we, if you are reading this \u2014 stay to at least think about and possibly fight for the rights of those who do not have the means or ability to move elsewhere, help themselves or execute an \u201cextreme self-care plan\u201d like Mr. Hagerman\u2019s.\n\nHe did not leave the country. He stayed and continues to benefit from what this country offers him. A fleeting acknowledgment of those who make his American ostrich life possible would have been appropriate.\n\nIn addition, I am not clear on why this is described as a \u201cliberal fantasy.\u201d He appears to be a liberal, but if I had to guess, I would say that the lion\u2019s share of liberals, recognizing that they had been reading the news for years and never \u201cdoing anything about it,\u201d would sooner start \u201cdoing something about it\u201d than institute a news blockade.", "title": "Opinion | One Man\u2019s Self-Imposed News \u2018Blockade\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIt was late, and I was lost in the East Village. I was on my way to an opening at a small art gallery. I didn\u2019t have my iPhone; even if I had, I never would have found the place.\n\nI asked a young man for help. He was probably in his mid-20s. He found the appropriate map on his phone and showed me the way.\n\nWhen he saw that I was having difficulty following his directions, he offered to escort me. I thanked him profusely, and when we arrived at the gallery I told him to tell his mother, from me, that she had raised a lovely son.\n\nHe asked if I would tell her. I said I would be delighted to.\n\nHe dialed her number, and told her that he was with someone who wanted to talk to her. He put me on the phone, and she and I had a lovely conversation.", "title": "One Mother to Another", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Given that states help pay for Medicaid, legislators are increasingly worried about the growing number of older residents, many of whom don\u2019t even have enough money saved for a comfortable retirement, let alone nursing home bills that can sometimes top $100,000 per year.\n\nA coalition of groups in Washington State saw the generational tidal wave crashing, and they got the ear of two state representatives in particular. The mother-in-law of one, Laurie Jinkins, a Democrat, is 92, has dementia and just qualified for Medicaid.\n\nThe father of the other, Norm Johnson, a Republican, used up much of his savings paying for in-home aides for Mr. Johnson\u2019s mother. The elder Mr. Johnson spent so much on care for his wife that by the time he required care of his own, he, too, wound up on Medicaid.\n\nSo Ms. Jinkins and Mr. Johnson sponsored a bill calling for a payroll tax on state residents of 0.49 percent, or $22.30 a month on average. (Washington has no state income tax but does have a statewide sales tax.) People who paid into the system over a certain number of years would ultimately become eligible to access the $100-per-day benefit if they could not complete three or more activities of daily living, like dressing or bathing.\n\nThey could then take that $100 and put it toward in-home care, adult day care, nursing home fees or similar expenses. After 365 days, they would exhaust the benefit. At that point, Medicaid would still be an option.\n\nWhy would a member of the typically tax-averse Republican Party support such a measure? After all, people are supposed to save for their old age, and they can buy long-term care insurance to protect themselves, too.\n\nMr. Johnson, a former teacher, school counselor and principal, drew on his own life to answer the question.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe had five sons in my family,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is no way we could afford long-term care insurance and raising five kids and paying for a house and school.\u201d\n\nHe knows that younger adults might resent the idea of elected officials reaching deeper into citizens\u2019 pockets to pay for benefits that are probably decades away for them. But he said that his experience had afforded him some perspective.\n\n\u201cYou never think you\u2019re going to get old,\u201d he said. \u201cBut guess what? I didn\u2019t think that either when I had kids at home, and now I will be 80 in July.\u201d\n\nThe way Ms. Jinkins and Mr. Johnson tell it, AARP was supportive until suddenly it was not. \u201cThe two people who represent AARP here, neither one had darkened my door,\u201d Mr. Johnson said. \u201cAnd then the last day, they threw a wrench into things.\u201d\n\nWhen I contacted AARP, I was told that the group had a number of concerns with the bill and had been expressing them all along. Perhaps the thorniest one involved the question of who qualified as a caregiver and how he or she would become eligible to collect to benefit.\n\nEligibility is not in dispute in licensed adult day care centers or nursing homes. But many people prefer to stay in their own homes as long as they can, and in some parts of Washington there are not enough licensed in-home caregivers. That means family members pitch in, often sacrificing their own wages to do so.\n\nEveryone in the coalition that supported the bill wanted the people who need care to be able to use the $100-a-day benefit to pay relatives. But not everyone is qualified to provide care, especially if doing so requires lifting a person or treating certain conditions.\n\nWould a spouse have to take a 75-hour class at a cost of hundreds of dollars to qualify as a caregiver? If so, was that too much to ask? How best to train a novice? Could family members train for, say, only 15 hours just to learn the specific skills they needed to help a relative? And if in-person training was required, who would care for an ailing spouse in the meantime?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe bill needed too much work, and we had too many questions and not enough answers,\u201d said Cathy MacCaul, AARP\u2019s advocacy director in Washington.\n\nWithout those answers, AARP would not support the bill as written. And without its support, and with emails arriving from AARP members encouraging \u201cno\u201d votes, lawmakers chose not to move the bill to a full vote.\n\nThe State Legislature met in a short session this year. Next year, its session will be longer, allowing more time for negotiation. All sides vow to redouble their efforts in the meantime. But the episode is a reminder of just how slowly new financial benefits creep across the country, hopping from state to state as new legislation is passed.\n\nHawaii offers some help to certain caregivers, but the Washington bill would establish the first payroll tax where the proceeds go to long-term care more broadly. It could be the difference between some families spending nearly all of their money and ending up on Medicaid or having something left after an older person\u2019s death.\n\nBut precisely because it would affect so many people, it\u2019s not going to happen very quickly. \u201cCould we all have dropped everything in our lives and answered all these questions sooner?\u201d asked Doug Shadel, AARP\u2019s state director in Washington. \u201cMaybe. But we\u2019re inventing a new social system to fix a difficult social problem.\u201d\n\nHe also offered an olive branch of sorts.\n\n\u201cThese two legislators, I know they are frustrated, but I think they showed a lot of courage putting this forward as a bipartisan effort,\u201d he said. \u201cI think they\u2019re going to be seen as pioneers going forward.\u201d", "title": "One State\u2019s Quest to Introduce Long-Term Care Benefits", "authors": ["Ron Lieber", "Your Money"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Jones and Sun contend that in many respects, Trump is reminiscent of Richard M. Nixon:\n\nNixon, like Trump, accused the media of being out to get him and predicted that the press would mischaracterize his public support or the reception he received. He believed the liberal media to be biased against him personally, maintaining that he had \u201centered the presidency with less support from the major publications and TV networks than any president in history\u201d and that \u201ctheir whole objective in life is to bring us down.\u201d\n\nUnlike Trump, however, Nixon (like the country\u2019s founders)\n\nroutinely reaffirmed to both the press and the public that he conceived of the press as central to democracy. Indeed, in his first speech to the public regarding the Watergate scandal, Nixon acknowledged that \u201cthe system that brought the facts to light and that will bring those guilty to justice\u201d was a system that included \u201ca vigorous free press.\u201d\n\nTrump stands out, according to Jones and Sun, in that his administration\n\nhas passed a threshold not approached by previous administrations in their tensions with the media. Trump is signaling \u2014 through his terminology, through his delegitimizing actions, and through his anticipatory undercutting \u2014 that the press is literally the enemy, to be distrusted, ignored, and excluded.\n\nIn response to my email, Jones replied that \u201cwar has been declared, whether they (the media) like it or not.\u201d She noted that the instincts of the press\n\nmotivate it to want to call out the changing norms that it sees around it, and to defend the role of important democratic institutions when they are attacked. But when the press is itself one of those institutions, it finds itself a part of the story in ways that it is unaccustomed to being, and it has to weigh the potential loss of credibility that might come with an aggressive self-defense.\n\nI asked Jonathan Ladd, a professor of public policy and government at Georgetown, what strategies he thought the media should adopt to counter negative portrayals by conservatives.\n\n\u201cThe best way for the press to react to Trump\u2019s undemocratic behavior is to continue trying to do their jobs the best they can,\u201d Ladd wrote. \u201cThe press is not perfect, but Trump\u2019s bad behavior doesn\u2019t change what they need to do.\u201d\n\nLadd specifically warned against \u201creacting to Trump by becoming more crusadingly anti-Trump.\u201d\n\nTrump has successfully \u201cput the mainstream media in a difficult position,\u201d according to Geoffrey Stone, a law professor at the University of Chicago:\n\nIf the media directly address the accusations of fake news, they ironically run the risk of dignifying the accusations. But if they ignore the accusations, they miss the opportunity to prove their professionalism to those who have grown skeptical.\n\nIn the long term, Stone suggested, we could begin to remedy this problem if we improved civic education and encouraged a stronger defense of the media by politicians, especially Republicans \u2014 a prospect about which he is not optimistic.\n\nOf the media itself, however, Stone wrote:\n\nI don\u2019t know that there\u2019s really much they can do to defend themselves. Those who trust them will continue to trust them. Those who distrust them are unlikely to be brought around by anything they themselves are likely to say.\n\nTrump\u2019s disdain for the First Amendment is an integral part of a much longer series of developments in which both parties have demonstrated a willingness to defy democratic norms, although the Republican Party has been in the forefront.\n\nIn \u201cAsymmetric Constitutional Hardball,\u201d Joseph Fishkin and David E. Pozen, law professors at the University of Texas and Columbia, write:\n\nFor a quarter of a century, Republican officials have been more willing than Democratic officials to play constitutional hardball \u2014 not only or primarily on judicial nominations but across a range of spheres. Democrats have also availed themselves of hardball throughout this period, but not with the same frequency or intensity.\n\nFishkin and Pozen cite the work of Mark Tushnet, a professor at Harvard Law School, to define constitutional hardball as \u201cpolitical claims and practices\u201d\n\nthat are without much question within the bounds of existing constitutional doctrine and practice but that are nonetheless in some tension with existing pre-constitutional understandings. Constitutional hardball tactics are viewed by the other side as provocative and unfair because they flout the \u2018goes without saying\u2019 assumptions that underpin working systems of constitutional government. Such tactics do not generally flout binding legal norms. But that only heightens the sense of foul play insofar as it insulates acts of hardball from judicial review.\n\nRepublicans on the far right, in particular, Fishkin and Pozen write, have been willing to engage in constitutional hardball because they are drawn to \u201cnarratives of debasement and restoration,\u201d which suggest\n\nthat something has gone fundamentally awry in the republic, on the order of an existential crisis, and that unpatriotic liberals have allowed or caused it to happen.\n\nThe severity of the liberal threat, in the eyes of these conservatives, justifies extreme steps to restore what they see as a besieged moral order.\n\nIn an email, Fishkin wrote:\n\nAs with so many things about President Trump, it strikes me that he didn\u2019t start the fire. He got into office because it was already burning and now he\u2019s pouring on gasoline.\n\nIn Fishkin\u2019s view, Trump will do all he can to make the conflict between his party and the press \u201csharper and more intense, in the same way that he depends on and aims to intensify partisan polarization.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | One Thing Donald Trump Would Like Is Freedom From the Press", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "THURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 As the person in charge of the social media for Wordplay (you can twut at Wordplay on Twitter or follow me on Facebook), I got a vicarious thrill out of today\u2019s puzzle by Ross Trudeau.\n\nPeople on social media are under a lot of pressure to rack up some of the things Mr. Trudeau mentions in his theme clues, and to see them written out as puns really helps let off a lot of steam.\n\nSo thank you for that, Mr. Trudeau. That\u2019s one fewer therapy session for me.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nIf you are as neck-deep in social media as I am, you are aware of the plethora of ways you can engage with other people online, such as \u201cliking\u201d something they\u2019ve \u201cposted,\u201d or \u201ctweeting\u201d what they\u2019ve \u201cshared.\u201d It\u2019s exhausting and it goes on forever, but it is truthfully the only way I can keep in touch with my cousins Steven (yes, that\u2019s plural \u2014 my family isn\u2019t very original when it comes to names), because we are scattered all over the country and not one of them can be bothered to pick up a phone.\n\nI\u2019m sorry, I drifted. I laughed when I got the top theme clue, \u201cOne with a lot of likes,\u201d because I remembered Moon Unit Zappa\u2019s 1982 song with her father, Frank Zappa, \u201cVALLEY GIRL.\u201d The stereotypical West Coast VALLEY GIRL was in the habit of saying \u201clike\u201d a lot, which is why the clue \u201cOne with a lot of likes\u201d is such brilliant misdirection:", "title": "One With a Lot of Tweets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "New names are Virgil Abloh of Off-White (who shows in Paris) and Gabriela Hearst.\n\nMeanwhile, for men\u2019s wear, aside from Mr. Simons, there\u2019s Mr. Abloh again, Thom Browne (who has won multiple times), Tom Ford (who won in 2015, the year after winning a Lifetime Achievement Award), and \u2014 Yay! New one! \u2014 James Jebbia of Supreme.\n\nAnyway, if the nominations reveal anything, aside from the domination of a few familiar names, it is the rise of the haute streetwear brands like Off-White and Supreme, and their induction into the establishment (you\u2019ve got to wonder how Kanye West, who has not been nominated, feels about all this).\n\nAlso that this is Donatella Versace\u2019s year: She\u2019s being celebrated with the International Award, after receiving a similar honor at December\u2019s Fashion Awards in London.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnyway, here\u2019s a full list of nominees. Talk to you soon!\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: Puffer coat season is ending. I am in need of a transitional coat. My thought is a raincoat with a zip-out liner. I do like a bit of an edge. No epaulets. And belting doesn\u2019t suit me. Knee length. I would prefer an online search, delivered to my door with an easy return policy. Budget would be in the $700 range unless it was super, super fabulous. I\u2019m really looking for something that I would like wearing for a long time. I should also mention that lack of closet space means I am unable to accommodate multiple seasonal options. \u2014 Margaret, New York\n\nA: You definitely have the right idea. My transitional coat is a Barbour from an Anya Hindmarch collaboration released in 2010. It is knee-length waxed cotton, with narrow shoulders and slightly truncated sleeves with long, ribbed cuffs. I happened upon it accidentally \u2014 I was living in London at the time \u2014 so I can\u2019t take credit for any brilliant insight, but it has turned out to be perfect for exactly the time of year you are discussing. I have been wearing it happily for eight years, and it shows no signs of looking tired, so I plan to wear it for many more.\n\nThat said, it isn\u2019t for sale any more, so it\u2019s not an option for you (sorry). But according to T\u2019s women\u2019s style director, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, heritage English outerwear brands are indeed the way to go. This makes sense, when you think about it, since the British climate is pretty much what we in North America think of when we think of a transitional climate. So to Barbour add Mackintosh, Burberry, Hunter, Belstaff and \u2014 if you want to range further afield \u2014 Max Mara. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "What does it all mean?\n\nAs for the first item, I would expect a lot of logo action to start. Then, the question will be whether the Abloh appointment really does herald the luxury streetwear age, a sector-disrupting event that may change how we think about clothes in a permanent way. (Unlike, say, when contemporary designers such as Alexander Wang hit Paris, which despite a lot of hype had very little permanent effect.) Or whether it reveals, as some have suggested, that Mr. Abloh is an emperor who talks a great game but actually has no clothes.\n\nAs for the second, there has been a lot of cheering about this being a triumph for the indie designer (an oft-seeming endangered species) versus the corporate megalith, coupled with rumors that Ms. McCartney will bring her show back to London from Paris. That isn\u2019t happening, however \u2014 at least not according to her spokesman. And while it\u2019s possible Ms. McCartney may pick up the banner of the indie designer from such champions as Dries Van Noten and Rei Kawakubo \u2014 she has never shied away from activism \u2014 my guess is that this is more a practical decision about her business, and Kering\u2019s, than a major political message about the state of the industry.\n\nBut we shall see!\n\nIn the meantime, and speaking of luxury streetwear: Apparently in Sunday night\u2019s NBC production of \u201cJesus Christ Superstar Live\u201d John Legend will play Jesus while wearing \u2026 really expensive Balmain jeans. (And no, that\u2019s not an April Fools\u2019 Day joke.) Don\u2019t know about you, but that seems kind of off-character to me.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Read more about our 48 Hours with Mr. Abloh.\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: Every year, I go to a rural location (Mendocino, Calif.) for a weeklong break, once in the summer and once during the fall/winter transition. While I\u2019m not trying to be \u201ccute,\u201d I do want to look reasonably put together. Any suggestions on some go-to pieces? \u2014 Angelin, Oakland, CA\n\nA: This is a perennial question when going to a vacation destination: You don\u2019t want to look as though you are donning a costume by going pretend-native (i.e., wearing what glossy magazines photograph as fantasy-in-the-brush clothing). That generally only makes you stand out as someone who doesn\u2019t belong. Or as the Brits like to say, \u201cmutton dressed as lamb.\u201d\n\nOn the other hand, you also can\u2019t wear the same thing you wear to, say, work in an urban environment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHowever, if you go to the same place with regularity (as I do with Wyoming and rural Ontario), the simplest answer is to start with the basics \u2014 jeans, leggings, sneakers, cargo shorts, T-shirts, a fleece \u2014 and then shop local. In fact, my general approach to vacation wardrobes is to think not fashion, but food: Source from where you are, and think small-batch. You can always add the spice later. \u2014 VANESSA FRIEDMAN", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "And with that, I think we will say goodbye to fashion month and move on to other image-making subjects. For those who haven\u2019t yet had your fill of the shows, check out reviews of the last gasps of Paris, plus our top 10 moments of the month (In related, sad, news: Jun Takahashi, the designer behind Undercover, one of the best shows all season, is apparently taking a break from the women\u2019s wear circus to focus on men\u2019s.) In the meantime, on to more global matters with this week\u2019s Q&A. Have a good weekend!\n\nYour Style Questions, Answered\n\nEvery week on Open Thread, Vanessa will answer a reader\u2019s fashion-related question, which you can send to her anytime via email or Twitter. Questions are edited and condensed.\n\nQ: I noticed in the picture of President Trump holding his crib sheet during his listening session on gun control that his shirt cuff was monogrammed with \u201c45.\u201d What are the conventions with monograms and men\u2019s shirts, and what is your opinion of this innovation? \u2014 Martha, Minneapolis\n\nA: I know I am slightly late to this issue. You weren\u2019t the only one who noticed, and it was a big Twitter moment while I was in Paris in the netherworld of fashion shows. It seems to me this is the monogram equivalent of the novelty T-shirt, though more about vanity than, say, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau\u2019s novelty socks, which are pretty obviously chosen for their strategic appeal to various constituencies.\n\nHowever, I did seize the opportunity to canvass some of my fellow show-goers about the question, to see if there was precedent for this (always an important thing in government) and to hear what they thought.\n\nRobin Givhan, the fashion critic of the Washington Post, said she couldn\u2019t remember any President wearing their number on their sleeve, though it was possible George W. Bush had done it, since he was often referred to by number (\u201c43\u201d) to distinguish him from his father. I could not find any examples of him wearing 43-monogrammed shirts, though that does not mean he doesn\u2019t have them.", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.\n\nHello, Open Thread!\n\nVanessa is off in Wyoming this week, enjoying a well-deserved break after the mania of fashion month. The first day of spring was on Tuesday, and it\u2019s been slow to come to Wyoming: Look at all that snow. Not that we have anything to brag about in New York. Another snowstorm made its belated way in on Wednesday, delaying the subways, shutting down the schools. Me? I made like Fifth Harmony and worked from home.\n\nSo maybe it\u2019s just cabin fever and a winter that seems never-ending, but I\u2019m dreaming of being anywhere but here. Someplace where I don\u2019t need snow boots for a coffee run, maybe; or, if I\u2019m thinking bigger, somewhere magical and not quite of this world.\n\nLike the reborn Dapper Dan\u2019s boutique in Harlem, where Dap \u2014 Daniel Day, the legendary tailor and bootleg couturier \u2014 has reopened his old shop; this week, my colleague Val Safronova took us on a video tour.", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.\n\nGreetings from Paris and happy March. It\u2019s Oscars minus two, but you\u2019d never know it here. There\u2019s been some talk of viewing parties and staying up, but given the nine-hour time difference, the chances are slim. I usually make it to the first half hour or so of arrivals, and then my bleary eyes just give up.\n\nMissing the red carpet makes me almost as sad as missing the Olympics.\n\nEspecially this year, given how big a role red carpets have played in the #MeToo conversation. The Oscars is not going to be a black-dress moment according to all reports, nor is it about white roses, so it will be especially interesting to see what part, if any, clothing will have this time around.\n\nThe Oscars\u2019 overlap with Paris Fashion Week also means there has been a smaller celebrity presence at the shows (they\u2019re all detoxing before Sunday). This is a good thing, in part because it makes it easier to focus on what\u2019s on the runway \u2014 even with the surprise industry news that Burberry had appointed a new designer to replace Christopher Bailey, an announcement no one had expected.", "title": "Open Thread: This Week in Style News", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "An eight-person party on New Year\u2019s Eve. Several groups of six on Saturday nights.\n\nDanny Beck, the owner of the Pearl\u2019s Southern Comfort restaurant in Chicago\u2019s Edgewater neighborhood, began noticing such no-shows, often at crucial moneymaking times, at an unusual frequency in recent months. Such failed reservations leave tables open for hours, depriving servers of tips and forcing walk-in diners to be turned away.\n\nIt turned out dozens of other restaurants using Reserve, an online reservation system, were having similar problems with no-shows. And this week, as detailed in a story at Eater, the company said it had discovered the cause: An employee at OpenTable, a rival reservation system that is considered the giant of the industry, had used Reserve to place more than 300 reservations at 45 Chicago restaurants, with the intent of leaving the tables empty.\n\nOpenTable confirmed that the employee had been fired, insisting that he or she had gone rogue and that no one else in the company knew of or directed the plan. It pledged to reimburse the restaurants for lost money and apologized, in a statement on Monday, for \u201cthis disgraceful, unsanctioned behavior.\u201d\n\nSome of the restaurant owners harmed by the scheme were livid.\n\n\u201cI just think that\u2019s one of the lowest, dirtiest tactics I\u2019ve ever heard,\u201d Mr. Beck said in an interview on Monday.", "title": "OpenTable Says Employee Used Rival Service to Book Hundreds of Fake Restaurant Reservations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "By the time spring break arrives, many species are waking up. Young humans, however, sometimes prefer hibernating. Fortunately, New York offers stimulating alternatives: Here\u2019s a roundup of programs to occupy children\u2019s minds in the coming week, when city public school classrooms are empty.\n\nPhoto\n\nMUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, QUEENS Moviegoing doesn\u2019t have to be a passive activity. Starting Friday, little visitors can enjoy daily screenings of \u201cThe Tale of the Bunny Picnic\u201d (1986), a Muppet television film with an anti-bullying theme, and nearly daily showings of \u201cThe Muppets Take Manhattan\u201d (1984), in which the title characters tackle Broadway. Children can then make their own puppets and animations in Springtime Puppet Studio, a drop-in workshop. This Saturday, there\u2019s a movie for teenagers, too: \u201cThe Breadwinner\u201d (2017), an Oscar-nominated animated tale about an Afghan girl who disguises herself as a boy to be able to earn money under Taliban rule. A discussion with two of the filmmakers follows the screening. (718-777-6888, movingimage.us).\n\nPhoto\n\nNEW YORK HALL OF SCIENCE, QUEENS This museum will exercise bodies as well as minds. Next week, its Spring Break Games will include parkour and How Many Zombies Are Too Many Zombies?, a form of tag. \u201cWhile they\u2019re playing scientists, and potentially zombies, participants learn how mathematical models work,\u201d said Liz Slagus, the museum\u2019s director of public programs and residencies. Wednesday also features the company Killer Snails\u2019 new virtual-reality marine biology game and a family game night. For third- and fourth-grade lovers of biology (and all things gross), the museum\u2019s weeklong Dissection Lab Camp also has openings. (Registration is required.) Projects include examining sheep brains and cows\u2019 eyes. (718-699-0005, nysci.org)\n\nPhoto\n\nNEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, MANHATTAN What child doesn\u2019t love a mystery? The fun starts this weekend with \u201cLiving History: Pinkerton\u2019s Historic Detectives,\u201d in which young visitors can meet a staff member portraying a 19th-century investigator. From Tuesday through April 6, they can continue as gumshoes by checking out a History Detective Briefcase. Each case \u2014 to be returned at the end of the visit \u2014 has binoculars, a notepad, activity cards and other materials; it might encourage its bearer to inspect a painting or look into a president\u2019s past. The week will also offer a history hunt, a self-guided search for artifacts like a tricorn hat or a model of Henry Hudson\u2019s ship the Half Moon. (212-873-3400, nyhistory.org)\n\nPhoto\n\n9/11 MEMORIAL & MUSEUM, MANHATTAN Not a place for children? Think again. Monday through April 6, the 9/11 Memorial & Museum Youth & Family Tour, offered twice daily for ages 7 through 14, is largely \u201cframed around how people responded to 9/11 and how this space that we\u2019re in helps us remember it,\u201d said Jennifer Lagasse, the museum\u2019s assistant director of education programs. The hourlong tour doesn\u2019t minimize the tragedy, but avoids the historical exhibition, which has news footage. Children can make rubbings of the memorial\u2019s carved names and explore the activities in the 9/11 Memorial Art Cart, which include writing and drawing in a journal. The cart even offers suggestions for preschoolers, like looking for certain shapes in the site\u2019s design. (212-266-5211, 911memorial.org)\n\nSTATEN ISLAND CHILDREN\u2019S MUSEUM Here, a grown-up\u2019s garbage is a child\u2019s inspiration. Monday through Thursday, the Junk Art Workshop will provide materials like plastic containers, cardboard tubes, bottle caps and foam packing peanuts for the creation of whimsical monsters \u2014 or any invention. On Wednesday, the museum will also offer the Imagination Playground, a pop-up space with foam building blocks, tubes and connectors, and on Thursday, it will give the fashion-minded paper plates, ribbons and other decorations to make Easter bonnets for a post-holiday parade. (718-273-2060, sichildrensmuseum.org)\n\nPhoto\n\nWAVE HILL, THE BRONX A field course called Woodland Ecology may sound like school, but how many regular classes let you lure earthworms from the dirt to count and identify? This public garden \u2014 yes, with woodlands \u2014 invites students in Grades 6 through 8 to spend next week studying soil health and decomposition\u2019s role in the ecosystem. The indoor-outdoor adventure includes gathering data on plant diversity and keeping field journals. Space is limited, and registration is required. (718-549-3200, ext. 237; wavehill.org)", "title": "Opening Young Minds With the Arts When Schools Are Closed", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "The average age at the Metropolitan Opera is about to get lower \u2014 much lower. Sitting still will not be required: Audience members will be encouraged to crawl around and interact with the singers if they like. The dress code will be so relaxed that many operagoers may opt for onesies.\n\nNo, the barbarians are not at the gate. The Met is presenting a new opera for babies.\n\nThe company will present 10 free performances of \u201cBambinO,\u201d an opera for babies between 6 months old and 18 months old, from April 30 to May 5 in the opera house\u2019s smaller auditorium, List Hall, the Met announced on Thursday. The 40-minute opera \u2014 scored for two singers and two musicians \u2014 will be performed for a small audience of babies and caregivers.\n\nDiscerning preverbal operagoers need not fear: \u201cBambinO\u201d earned good reviews when it had its premiere last summer in Britain. \u201cIt worked, contrary to expectation (mine), on so many levels it\u2019s hard to tease them apart,\u201d Fiona Maddocks wrote in The Observer.", "title": "Operagoers So Young, the Met Adds Changing Tables and Stroller Parking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "As onlookers watched, protesters brandished black banners with the phrases \u201cShame on Sackler\u201d and \u201cFund Rehab\u201d and hurled yellow pill bottles with white labels that read \u201cOxyContin\u201d and \u201cprescribed to you by the Sacklers\u201d into the wing\u2019s reflecting pool.\n\nMs. Goldin announced a series of demands in the form of short statements, including \u201charm reduction\u201d and \u201ctreatment,\u201d that were repeated loudly by the crowd.\n\n\u201cWe are artists, activists, addicts,\u201d she shouted. \u201cWe are fed up.\u201d\n\nMs. Goldin \u2014 whose intimate photographs documenting drug use, violence and deaths from AIDS are displayed in numerous museums, including the Metropolitan \u2014 started an anti-opioid group called Prescription Addiction Intervention Now, or PAIN, after being addicted to OxyContin from 2014 to 2017. She has called withdrawal from OxyContin the darkest experience of her life.\n\nA spokesman for the museum declined to comment, and a spokeswoman for the Sackler family did not respond to a request for comment. A Purdue spokesman, Robert Josephson, said the company is \u201cdeeply troubled by the prescription and illicit opioid abuse crisis\u201d and is dedicated to helping solve it by paying for prescription-drug monitoring programs and collaborating with law enforcement.\n\nOxyContin has accounted for tens of billions of dollars in sales since entering the market in 1996.\n\nIn 2007, Purdue\u2019s parent company pleaded guilty to a federal felony charge of misbranding the drug, which prosecutors said was marketed as less addictive, less subject to abuse and less likely to cause withdrawal than other painkillers. Since then, states have accused Purdue in lawsuits of misrepresenting the risks and benefits of OxyContin, allegations the company has denied.", "title": "Opioid Protest at Met Museum Targets Donors Connected to OxyContin", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nPresident Trump\u2019s inaction in handling the opioid epidemic (\u201cMr. Trump\u2019s Bluster on Opioids,\u201d editorial, March 21) is heartbreaking.\n\nThe point of \u201cdraining the swamp\u201d was to more effectively address problems that career politicians neglected, with the overprescription of opioids being a prime example. Instead, we have a president who would rather project the image of improvement than actually institute effective changes.\n\nThis is also seen in the issue of infrastructure, which Mr. Trump is happy to let fall by the wayside, knowing that his base wants him to build an impractical border wall instead.\n\nHis solutions for the opioid problem reflect his desire for brash and dramatic \u201csolutions\u201d; his proposal to arm teachers occupies the same world as his call to execute drug dealers. What\u2019s heartbreaking is that there are sensible, boring ways to fix such problems but that Mr. Trump most likely will never put them to use.", "title": "Opinion | Opioids and the President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRic Grenell not getting confirmed is an embarrassment,\u201d Mr. Hewitt told Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, on a broadcast this month.\n\n\u201cWould you go to the leader and get that scheduled?\u201d Mr. Hewitt said. \u201cI just can\u2019t get over this.\u201d\n\nMr. Grenell, who quietly helped with Mr. Trump\u2019s transition process, was the longest-serving American spokesman at the United Nations, working with four United States ambassadors there and especially closely with Mr. Bolton, a staunch foreign policy conservative. Mr. Grenell declined to comment for this article, but he has told allies that he would not take a job at the National Security Council under Mr. Bolton and that he is committed to the ambassadorship.\n\nSenate officials from both parties said a senator appeared to have placed a hold on his nomination, which means moving forward with a vote would require 30 hours of debate, burning up most of a business week. Senate rules do not require the name of the legislator requesting the hold to be made public.\n\nLast week, when the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, called for Mr. Grenell to move ahead by unanimous consent, which requires a voice vote, Senator Jeff Merkley, Democrat of Oregon, declined to advance the nomination.\n\nDemocrats cite concerns about Mr. Grenell\u2019s vocal criticism of the news media on Twitter as a concern.\n\nIn particular, he excoriated as biased journalists who did not report on the revelations in the hacked emails from the Hillary Clinton campaign chairman, John D. Podesta, when they were made public by the website WikiLeaks.\n\nSenator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, said the Senate needed to change the rules to speed up the process.", "title": "Opposing Factions Join to Push Confirmation of a Gay Trump Appointee", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. McFarland, who has been free on bail, left the courthouse after his appearance without making any further statements.\n\nFederal prosecutors began investigating soon after the festival collapsed and concluded that Mr. McFarland had defrauded investors in Fyre Media as well as a subsidiary that had promoted the music festival.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCharging documents filed by prosecutors said that Mr. McFarland, 26, had provided investors with false financial reports, including one that listed millions of dollars in talent-booking revenue for Fyre Media. In reality, the documents said, the company had earned only about $57,000 in bookings in the year leading up to the festival.\n\nMr. McFarland was also charged with showing investors bogus financial documents to claim that he owned more stock than he actually did so that it would appear he was in a position to personally guarantee an investment. And, prosecutors said, he used inflated revenue numbers to induce a ticket vendor to pay $2 million for a block of advance tickets for future festivals.\n\nTo drum up interest in the festival Mr. McFarland engaged in multifaceted, sometimes fantastical, forms of promotion. Along with his business partner, the rapper Ja Rule, he got \u201cinfluencers\u201d like Kendall Jenner and Emily Ratajkowski to post about the festival on Instagram, bestowing upon them the title \u201cFyre Starters.\u201d\n\nPackages included the $400,000 \u201cArtist\u2019s Palace,\u201d with four beds, eight V.I.P. tickets and dinner with a festival performer. The festival\u2019s website identified its location as Fyre Cay, a fictional place that was described as a private island that had once belonged to the drug lord Pablo Escobar.\n\nIn reality, a few weeks before the festival, Mr. McFarland secured some land on the island of Great Exuma and hired workers who scrambled to prepare for the event. But as ticket-holders arrived, Mr. McFarland\u2019s scheme quickly unraveled and the festival was canceled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCaterers and carpenters said that Mr. McFarland departed Great Exuma without paying more than $100,000 in bills and wages.\n\nAnd the viral communication techniques that Mr. McFarland had hoped would advance the festival\u2019s fortunes were instead turned against him as ticket-holders took to platforms like Twitter and Instagram to post images showing people milling in confusion, searching for lost luggage and dragging mattresses across darkened beaches.\n\n\u201cPeople are panicking,\u201d one young man said on a video titled \u201cFyre Festival COMPLETE Disaster. VLOG of Chaos!\u201d and posted on YouTube. \u201cLike tripping out.\u201d\n\nBoth counts that Mr. McFarland pleaded guilty to carry maximum penalties of 20 years in prison, though a sentence of that length seems unlikely. His sentencing is scheduled for June 21.", "title": "Organizer of Failed Fyre Festival Pleads Guilty to Fraud", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Jimmy Kimmel once again brought his dry, sardonic style to his role as host of the Oscars. His monologue, preceded by a black-and-white video send-up of some A-list stars, was filled with barbs against Harvey Weinstein, Mel Gibson and others. He also threw jibes at President Trump, and poked fun at last year\u2019s Oscar envelope mix-up.\n\nSome of his commentary needed to be taken with a grain of salt. At one point, Mr. Kimmel said, \u201cOf the nine best picture nominees, only two of them made more than $100 million.\u201d That may have been true domestically, but most of the films hit that total if foreign ticket sales were factored in.\n\nHere is a transcript of Mr. Kimmel\u2019s monologue:\n\nAnd greetings from Hollywood to our viewers all around the world. Thank you for watching. Thank you very having me. It is a great honor to be invited back for a second time. It is a great honor to be here among so many talented women and men. Congratulations to all of you. You made it. We\u2019re at the Oscars. Some of you will be going home tonight with an Academy Award. What could be better than that? Nothing, right?\n\nSo \u2014 oh. I do want to mention. This year, when you hear your name called, don\u2019t get up right away. Just give us a minute. We don\u2019t want another thing. What happened last year was unfortunate, and I\u2019ve not told this story in public because I wanted to save it for tonight. But here\u2019s what happened. This is true. Last year, about a week before the show, the producers asked me if I wanted to do some comedy with the accountants. And I said, \u201cNo, I don\u2019t want to do comedy with the accountants.\u201d So, then the accountants went ahead and did comedy on their own.\n\nAnd I have to hand it to them, it was hilarious. But it won\u2019t happen again. This year, the chairman of PricewaterhouseCoopers said, and I quote, \u201cOur singular focus will be on the show and delivering the correct envelopes,\u201d which is \u2014 does make sense. Just out of curiosity though, what was your focus the other 89 years? I\u2019m hopeful that things will go smoothly tonight. We can\u2019t ruin this one. This is a special year. This is a big one. These are the 90th Academy Awards. This is history happening right here.\n\nOur friend Oscar \u2014 Oscar is 90 years old tonight, which means he\u2019s probably at home right now watching Fox News. Of course \u2014 no, Oscar is here with us. After all the years, after all the awards given for achievements in show business, Oscar is still No. 1. No question about it. Oscar is the most beloved and respected man in Hollywood. And there\u2019s a very good reason why. Just look at him. Keeps his hands where you can see them. Never says a rude word and most importantly, no penis at all. He is literally a statue of limitations. And that\u2019s the kind of men we need more of in this town.\n\nHere\u2019s how clueless Hollywood is about women. We made a movie called \u201cWhat Women Want\u201d and it starred Mel Gibson. Kind of all you need to know.\n\nThe Academy, as you are no doubt aware, took action last year to expel Harvey Weinstein from their ranks. There were a lot of great nominees, but Harvey deserved it the most. And \u2014 oh, that\u2019s nice. That\u2019s very sweet. So, I\u2019m sure he\u2019ll appreciate that applause. The Academy kicked him out and after they did, I was curious, so, I looked it up. You know the only other person to be expelled from the Academy, ever, was a character actor named Carmine Caridi. In 2004, he was kicked out for sharing screeners. Carmine Caridi got the same punishment as Harvey Weinstein for giving his neighbor a copy of \u201cSeabiscuit\u201d on VHS.\n\nBut what happened with Harvey, and what\u2019s happening all over, was long overdue. We can\u2019t let bad behavior slide anymore. The world is watching us. We need to set an example and the truth is if we are successful here, if we can work together to stop sexual harassment in the workplace, if we can do that, women will only have to deal with harassment all the time at every other place they go.\n\nOver the course of this evening, I hope you will listen to many brave and outspoken supporters of movements like \u201cMe Too\u201d and \u201cTime\u2019s Up\u201d and \u201cNever Again,\u201d because what they\u2019re doing is important. Things are changing for the better. They\u2019re making sure of that. It is positive change. This is a night for positivity and our plan is to shine a light on a group of outstanding and inspiring films, each and every one of which got crushed by \u201cBlack Panther\u201d this weekend. Which, that\u2019s \u2014 that\u2019s okay. The success of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d is one of many positive stories this year. Especially for African-Americans and Bob Iger. \u201cBlack Panther\u201d and \u201cWonder Woman\u201d are \u2014 were massive hits, which is almost miraculous because I remember a time when the major studios didn\u2019t believe a woman or a minority could open a superhero movie. And the reason I remember that time was because it was March of last year.\n\nBut \u2014 this year, we have a lot to celebrate. Ceilings have been shattered. Ceilings in screenwriting. We have our first ever female nominee for cinematography, Rachel Morrison, which is historic. So many of tonight\u2019s nominees are making history, and, in fact, if you are a nominee tonight who isn\u2019t making history \u2014 shame on you.\n\nGreta Gerwig is the first woman to be nominated for director in eight years. And that\u2019s important. Only 11 percent of movies are directed by women. And that is nuts. We still have a very long way to go in that department, and a very long way to go when it comes to equal pay. Especially when you look at what happened with Mark Wahlberg and Michelle Williams. We all know the story. Mark Wahlberg was paid a million-and-a-half dollars to reshoot his scenes while Michelle Williams for her reshoots got a per diem. She was paid 80 dollars a day for the same thing. And what made it especially unfair is that Mark and Michelle are represented by the same agency. And I have to admit, this story really surprised me. This one shook me, because if we can\u2019t trust agents, who can we trust?\n\nTo his credit, Mark Wahlberg announced he would be donating all $1.5 million to the Time\u2019s Up Legal Defense Fund. That\u2019s right. So, I guess now the ball\u2019s in your court, Michelle. What are you going to do with that 80 bucks?\n\nIn the meantime, triple congratulations are in order for the kid from Comedy Central, Jordan Peele, who had a huge success with his movie, \u201cGet Out.\u201d Jordan is only the third person in 90 years to be nominated for directing, writing and best picture for his debut film. And what \u2014 what a debut it was. None other than President Trump called \u201cGet Out\u201d the best first three-quarters of a movie this year.\n\nMargot Robbie had a great year. Margot scored her first nomination for her portrayal of Tonya Harding in \u201cI, Tonya\u201d and was terrific. Whose kneecaps did Tonya Harding have to break to get this dream casting? Because, I mean, that was \u2014 if they made a movie about my life, best case scenario, I\u2019d be played by Jim Belushi. Another exceptionally gifted young actor who is nominated for the first time is Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet, who looks very dashing tonight. Wow, look at that tux.\n\nAre you having fun, Timoth\u00e9e? This is a big deal. He\u2019s missing \u201cPaw Patrol\u201d to be here tonight. Don\u2019t worry, Ryder and his team of pups saved the day, so. Timoth\u00e9e is the star of a small but powerful story called \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d which did not make a lot of money. In fact, of the nine best picture nominees, only two of them made more than $100 million. That\u2019s not the point. We don\u2019t make films like \u201cCall Me by Your Name\u201d for money. We make them to upset Mike Pence. Right?\n\nTimoth\u00e9e is the youngest best actor nominee in almost 80 years, and on the other end of the abacus, we have our oldest acting nominee ever: The magnificent Christopher Plummer is 88 years old and still going strong. Maybe this is not the place, but there\u2019s something I want to ask you. How does Lin-Manuel Miranda compare to the real Alexander Hamilton?\n\nAnd once again, right here in the front row, maybe the greatest actor of all time, Meryl Streep is here with us. She earned her 21st Oscar nomination. Meryl\u2019s film career started in 1977. The longest she ever went without being nominated was from 1992 to 1995, which \u2014 and that\u2019s only because those were the years she was in prison, and that, I think, is amazing.\n\nThe most nominated movie tonight, a film that\u2019s up for 13 Oscars, is \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d written and directed by Guillermo del Toro, a wonderful man. Congratulations, I\u2019m very happy for Guillermo. You made a beautiful movie and thanks to Guillermo, we will always remember this year as the year men screwed up so badly, women started dating fish.\n\nO.K., before we start handing out the awards, some history, because we\u2019re going to do things a little bit differently. The first Oscar ceremony lasted, and this is true, 15 minutes, from beginning to end. And people still complained. But \u2014 so, if you do win an Oscar tonight, we want you to give a speech. We want you to say whatever you feel needs to be said. Speak from the heart. We want passion. You have an opportunity and a platform to remind millions of people about important things like equal rights and equal treatment. If you want to encourage others to join the amazing students at Parkland at their march on the 24th, do that.\n\nIf you want to thank a favorite teacher, do that. Or maybe you just want to thank your parents and tell your kids to go to sleep. What you say is entirely up to you. You don\u2019t have to change the world. Do whatever you want. But with that said, this is a really long show. So here\u2019s what we\u2019re going to do. Not saying you shouldn\u2019t give a long speech, but whoever gives the shortest speech tonight will go home with \u2014 Johnny, tell them what they\u2019ll win.\n\n[ANNOUNCER\u2019S VOICE]\n\nIt\u2019s a brand new jet ski! Easy comfort on the 2018 Kawasaki ULTRA 310-LX. The No. 1 choice for watercraft enthusiasts. Retail price, $17,999. Back to you, Jimmy.\n\n[BACK TO KIMMEL]\n\nThank you, Helen. Helen Mirren not included. So \u2014 there you go. Why waste precious time thanking your mom when you could be taking her for the ride of her life on a brand new jet ski? This is not a joke. I will be timing you. I have a stop watch. The moment you are handed that Oscar, the clock will start ticking, So, get up here, grab it and go. And in the unlikely event of a tie, I need to say, the jet ski will be awarded to Christopher Plummer, so \u2014 let\u2019s get the show going.", "title": "Oscars 2018: Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s Opening Monologue, Transcribed", "authors": ["Sopan Deb"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe 90th Academy Awards rewarded a surreal love story, a Chilean drama, the portrayal of a violent cop and more.\n\n\u2022 Read what happened at the Oscars and a transcription of Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s monologue.\n\n\u2022 Our TV critic thought that the show focused on celebration and glitter despite some self-examination.\n\n\u2022 What\u2019s an inclusion rider? We explain the idea that Frances McDormand endorsed onstage.\n\n\u2022 Tiffany Haddish and Maya Rudolph, hosts for the 2019 Oscars? The Internet loved the idea.\n\n\u2022 Lupita Nyong\u2019o and Kumail Nanjiani made an appeal for Dreamers.\n\n\u2022 See photos from the red carpet and get our fashion critic\u2019s take.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Want to watch the Oscar winners at home? Here\u2019s where to stream them. And if you liked the best picture winner \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d we have recommendations for 7 other movies to check out.", "title": "Oscars 2018: The Winners", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 The doomsday ratings scenario has hit the Oscars.\n\nA record low 26.5 million people watched Sunday night\u2019s telecast, a nearly 20 percent drop versus last year.\n\nIt also represents a startling drop off: As recently as four years ago, the Academy Awards had an audience of 43.7 million viewers.\n\nThe previous record low was in 2008 when 32 million viewers watched a hastily organized ceremony that proceeded just days after the Writers Guild of America\u2019s strike had ended.\n\nMoving the ceremony up to 8 p.m. on Sunday on ABC \u2014 a half-hour earlier than its 8:30 p.m. slot \u2014 did little to aid the show\u2019s rapidly declining audience.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nABC executives were concerned enough before the ceremony that they said publicly that Oscar winners should not feel compelled to make fiery political speeches. Keeping things frothy and fun would do just fine.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd the show, for the most part, stayed away from the industry\u2019s concerns over the Trump administration (a contrast from a politics-heavy Golden Globes and Emmys), though it did emphasize the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements.", "title": "Oscars Ratings Hit Record Low", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "So sure was Mr. Gr\u00f6ning of his own position that he went public in 2005 with long interviews retelling the minutiae of his experiences as what he termed a tiny cog in the gears of the Final Solution.\n\nIn 2011, though, German attitudes were transformed when John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian, was jailed in Munich for his involvement in the killing of 28,000 Jews at the Sobibor camp in Nazi-occupied Poland.\n\nMr. Demjanjuk, who died in 2012 before an appeal could be heard, \u201cknew he was part of an organization with no other purpose but mass murder,\u201d Judge Ralph Alt said at the time. The verdict opened the way for prosecutors to charge the handful of surviving death-camp personnel with complicity in the liquidation on the grounds of their membership in a criminal organization.\n\nMr. Gr\u00f6ning had volunteered for the Waffen SS in 1941 after training in civilian life as a bank teller, credentials that the SS determined qualified him to tally the cash and personal valuables seized from Jews transported to Nazi-occupied Poland. \u201cI\u2019d never heard of Auschwitz before,\u201d he said in 2005.\n\nDuring his time at the camp, from 1942 to 1944, his ledgers recorded Polish zlotys and Greek drachmas, French francs, Dutch guilders, Czech korunas, Italian lire \u2014 a range of currencies that reflected the reach of the campaign to eradicate Europe\u2019s Jews.\n\nHis remarks to interviewers, like his testimony a decade later at his trial near his home in L\u00fcneburg, in northern Germany, offered macabre insights into the privileged life he and his comrades had enjoyed in their quarters at Auschwitz, even as freight trains arrived to disgorge Jews destined for extermination.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere were tinned sardines, and bacon, vodka and rum, he recalled in an interview with the magazine Der Spiegel in 2005 \u2014 items denied to most German civilians, and, of course, to the SS\u2019s victims.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe arrived in Auschwitz,\u201d he recalled at his trial, \u201cand there were all these things that we had not seen for a long time.\u201d\n\nOne currency confiscated from Jewish victims was the American dollar; it was used for clandestine transactions among camp personnel.
