At one point, by his own account, Mr. Gr\u00f6ning stole $30 from the sequestered funds to buy a handgun from a corrupt guard.\n\nIn interviews and in his courtroom testimony, Mr. Gr\u00f6ning acknowledged being present on two occasions when Jews were killed; in one instance, he said, a camp guard smashed an abandoned baby\u2019s head against the metal side of a truck. On the second occasion, he said, Jews who had escaped and taken refuge in a farmhouse were killed with the Zyklon B gas used for the broader extermination.\n\n\u201cThat was the only time I saw a complete gassing,\u201d he said. \u201cI did not take part.\u201d\n\nTwice, he maintained, he asked to be transferred from Auschwitz to combat duties. He equally acknowledged that his attitude toward those whose money he counted had been shaped by his upbringing.\n\nAs a child, he told Der Spiegel in 2005, he had played marbles in the street with Anne Selig, the daughter of a Jewish ironmonger whose store was next to his home. When Nazi storm troopers held up a sign outside the shop saying, \u201cGermans, do not buy from Jews,\u201d he said, he was unmoved.\n\nIndeed, so pervasive was the hatred of Jews that he recalled a song with the refrain: \u201cWhen Jewish blood begins to drip from our knives, things will be good again.\u201d\n\n\u201cBack then,\u201d he said, \u201cwe didn\u2019t even think about what we were singing.\u201d\n\nHe said that throughout his early life, as a member of ultranationalist movements including the Hitler Youth, he had been raised to believe that Jews were Germany\u2019s enemy within. His concerns about what he saw at Auschwitz related more to the modalities of killing than to its rationale or supposed principles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe had sworn an oath of loyalty, he believed the Jews were Germany\u2019s enemy,\u201d Mr. Rees, the BBC journalist, wrote in an article in 2015, \u201cand he knew that he could still manipulate his life at the camp to avoid encountering the worst of the horror.\u201d\n\nOn the first day of his trial \u2014 in a makeshift courtroom in an assembly hall chosen to accommodate the crush of survivors, lawyers, spectators and journalists \u2014 Mr. Gr\u00f6ning addressed the judge, Franz Kompisch, saying: \u201cIt is beyond question that I am morally complicit. This moral guilt I acknowledge here before the victims with regret and humility.\u201d\n\nBut \u201cas concerns guilt before the law,\u201d he added, \u201cyou must decide.\u201d\n\nMr. Gr\u00f6ning appeared at his trial as a silver-haired old man, a widower who found it difficult to walk unaided. Wartime photographs of him showed a self-confident and smiling young man in thin-rimmed spectacles, sporting the death\u2019s-head emblem of the SS on his cap.\n\nWhen the trial ended in mid-July 2015, Judge Kompisch ruled that for all his protestations, Mr. Gr\u00f6ning himself had taken the decision to accept \u201ca safe desk job\u201d at Auschwitz.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was perhaps affected by the era, but it was not because you were unfree,\u201d the judge said, adding that he \u201chad freedom to think\u201d and yet \u201casked to join the SS.\u201d\n\nOskar Gr\u00f6ning was born on June 10, 1921, at Nienburg, between Hanover and Bremen, in northern Germany. His mother died when he was 4 years old, and he was raised by his father, a stern textile worker who had emerged from World War I with a deep sense of grievance at the terms imposed on defeated Germany. Like others who shared his views, his father joined the Stahlhelm (Steel Helmet), an ultranationalist veterans\u2019 group.\n\nBy Mr. Gr\u00f6ning\u2019s account, his childhood was one of \u201cdiscipline, obedience and authority.\u201d He participated in the Stahlhelm\u2019s youth movement before joining the Hitler Youth. His formal schooling ended in 1938, when he was 17, and he began training as a bank clerk. A year later, war intervened.\n\nHis elder brother, Gerhard, died as a soldier near Stalingrad in 1942, and Mr. Gr\u00f6ning married his brother\u2019s fianc\u00e9e, Irmgard. Their first son, also called Gerhard, was born in 1944.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Gr\u00f6ning volunteered for the SS in 1941 during a recruitment drive at a hotel near his home. After his service at Auschwitz he was sent to join German forces in the Ardennes region, where he was wounded. But he returned to his unit before Germany\u2019s surrender in May 1945.\n\nHis initial instinct seemed to be to avoid mentioning his past. On a questionnaire handed to prisoners by their British captors, he said nothing about Auschwitz, he told Mr. Rees in 2005, telling them that he had worked for an SS administrative office in Berlin.\n\nIn 1946 he was shipped to England as a forced laborer, though he called his life there \u201cvery comfortable.\u201d\n\nBack in West Germany in 1947, with a job in a glass factory as his country began its postwar revival, Mr. Gr\u00f6ning told his family that the word Auschwitz and his connection to it \u201care never, ever to be mentioned again in my presence.\u201d\n\n\u201cI never really found inner peace,\u201d he told a German newspaper in 2013.\n\nIn 1977, a prosecutor in Frankfurt opened an inquiry into the activities of Mr. Gr\u00f6ning and 61 other SS members, only to determine, eight years later, that there were insufficient grounds for prosecution.\n\nMr. Gr\u00f6ning, a stamp collector, recalled later encountering a fellow philatelist, who told him that the Holocaust did not happen, according to accounts in Der Spiegel and elsewhere. He wrote a note to the man saying: \u201cI saw everything \u2014 the gas chambers, the cremations, the selection process. One and a half million Jews were murdered in Auschwitz. I was there.\u201d\n\nIn what some depict as a quest for exoneration, he wrote an 87-page memoir to his sons Gerhard and Wolfgang about his experiences. In 2005, he recorded nine hours of taped interviews for a BBC documentary.\n\nLater that same year, he told Der Spiegel, \u201cGuilt really has to do with actions, and because I believe that I was not an active perpetrator, I don\u2019t believe that I am guilty.\u201d\n\nA decade later, a court came to a different conclusion.", "title": "Oskar Gr\u00f6ning, the \u2018Bookkeeper of Auschwitz,\u2019 Is Dead at 96", "authors": ["Alan Cowell"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFrom chicken Marengo (above) to red beans and rice, here are the recipes readers loved most this week.", "title": "Our 10 Most Popular Recipes Right Now", "authors": ["Pierre Franey", "Amanda Hesser", "Mark Bittman", "Sara Bonisteel"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFrom Alison Roman\u2019s garlic braised short ribs with red wine (above) to whole-lemon tart, here are the recipes readers loved most this week.", "title": "Our 10 Most Popular Recipes Right Now", "authors": ["Tejal Rao", "Alison Roman", "Dorie Greenspan", "Mark Bittman"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Lamb meatballs, spiced with cumin, coriander, cinnamon and a touch of cayenne and showered with herbs, are then paired with a tangy yogurt sauce.\n\nCredit Karsten Moran for The New York Times", "title": "Our 10 Most Popular Recipes Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The Art of the Vacation Snap\n\nPhoto\n\nAs part of the Voyages issue in 2014, we asked some of the world\u2019s greatest photographers to share images from their own vacations. When you\u2019re photographing family, or the place you grew up in, or somewhere completely new and bewildering, how do you photograph it in a way that\u2019s beautiful and meaningful long after the trip is over?\n\nWhy Does Mt. Rushmore Exist?\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Black Hills are a geological oddity: 70-million-year-old rock jutting out from an ocean of South Dakota prairie. They\u2019re also unusual for another reason \u2014 the four faces of American presidents carved out of the mountain face. But it\u2019s possible that you\u2019ve seen the mountainscape more often in cartoons or popular culture than you have in their full, unrelenting glory in the Black Hills. These days, the gargantuan shrine to democracy has never felt so unreal. The writer Sam Anderson took his family to visit this \u201cmonument to monumentalism,\u201d photographed by the British photographer Giles Price, for our Voyages issue in spring 2017.\n\nCommuning With Some of the Biggest Trees on Earth\n\nPhoto\n\nYou already know the trees are big, because it says so right in their name: giant sequoias. But what you might not be prepared for is how you feel standing next to one. Jon Mooallem writes about his experience with the giant sequoias in Northern California: Trees so big you can walk through them. Trees so big they have their own parking lots. Trees so big you find yourself uttering the occasional, involuntary \u201cWhoa.\u201d\n\nThe Heart-Stopping Climbs of Alex Honnold\n\nPhoto\n\nAlex Honnold is a free-solo rock climber. No ropes, no safety net. His kind of climbing is the oldest kind of climbing, from before all the gear was invented. But his \u201cboulders\u201d are cliff faces and mountainsides that many other accomplished climbers wouldn\u2019t even dream of ascending without safety precautions. Hannold makes it look easy.\n\nA Glorious Muslim Festival in Guinea\n\nPhoto\n\nMamadi Doumbouya is a 21-year-old photographer based in New York. For two days in 2017, he traveled to his family\u2019s home in Guinea. He drove with his great-uncle, Mory Sanda Doumbouya, and 15 other family members in two vans, covering 400 miles between the city of Conakry to their ancestral village near Kankan to celebrate the Muslim festival of Eid al-Adha.\n\nThe Woman Who Walked 10,000 Miles (Yes, Really) in Three Years\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the taxonomy of travelers, the word \u201cexplorer\u201d suggests a morally superior pioneer; \u201cadventurer,\u201d by contrast, implies a self-indulgent adrenaline junkie who scares loved ones by courting puerile risk. In a world that has been thoroughly Google-mapped, Sarah Marquis is one of the few who can claim the former title. Her 10,000-mile journey took her three years to complete, and she cataloged it with videos and a book about the experience. Elizabeth Weil wrote about this modern-day explorer for the magazine in 2014.\n\nKarl Ove Knausgaard\u2019s Journey Across America\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Part I of Karl Ove Knausgaard\u2019s five-part epic \u201cMy Struggle\u201d was being published, the Norwegian author took a road trip with the photographer Peter van Agtmael across the northern United States. The plan had been to travel from Sweden to Canada to retrace the Viking trail from L\u2019Anse aux Meadows, the first European settlement in North America, to Alexandria, Minn., and the site of a possibly fraudulent Viking runestone. What actually happened after more than a few hang-ups is chronicled in incredible, Knausgaardian detail in our Voyages issue of March 2015.", "title": "Our 10 Most Remarkable Voyages to Far-Flung Destinations", "authors": ["Pia Peterson"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "From pasta puttanesca to fettuccine with asparagus and smoked salmon (above), our top pasta, here are the recipes readers love.", "title": "Our 20 Most Popular Pasta Recipes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "From burgers to slow-roasted citrus salmon with herb salad (above), here are the recipes readers love. (For guidance on what to buy and how to cook it, check out our salmon guide.)", "title": "Our 20 Most Popular Salmon Recipes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Actor\n\nPhoto\n\nAn actor\u2019s actor, Gary Oldman, 59, is known for his versatility and wholesale, sometimes hammy, immersion into roles that have included Dracula, Beethoven, Sid Vicious, George Smiley, the devil, Lee Harvey Oswald, Rosencrantz and Commissioner Gordon. Mr. Oldman earned his first Academy Award nomination in 2012 for \u201cTinker Tailor Soldier Spy,\u201d but it is his portrayal of Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour\u201d that will almost certainly land him the win. The crucial ingredients are there: he plays a historical figure (with the help of prosthetics and heavy makeup), he has won key precursor awards, and he is up against two whippersnappers (Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet and Daniel Kaluuya) who have careers ahead of them, and two veterans (Daniel Day-Lewis and Denzel Washington) who each have already won multiple times.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Watching Get the most out of your screen time with movie and TV recommendations, news and commentary from New York Times experts. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSupporting Actress\n\nPhoto\n\nThis category boasts a wealth of seasoned heavy hitters \u2014 Lesley Manville, Laurie Metcalf, Octavia Spencer \u2014 along with Mary J. Blige, in a breakout performance; each woman played an indomitable character. But it was Allison Janney\u2019s unflinching performance as LaVona Golden, mother of the disgraced figure skater Tonya Harding, that won prize after prize this season. Often a wise, warm, empathic onscreen presence, the 58-year-old Ms. Janney as LaVona was caustic and cruel, and almost upstaged by the pet bird that sat on her shoulder, pecking at her, for one extended, wickedly funny scene.\n\nSupporting actor\n\nPhoto\n\nAt 49, Sam Rockwell is the youngest of this year\u2019s supporting actor nominees, who include Christopher Plummer, 88, along with Willem Dafoe, Richard Jenkins and Woody Harrelson, who stars as the police chief to Mr. Rockwell\u2019s racist, dimwitted officer, Jason Dixon, in \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.\u201d Mr. Rockwell is a master at playing unpredictable, unhinged men, and, because his Dixon undergoes a transformation \u2014 which is catnip for academy voters \u2014 he was able to show his range. Having already collected a Golden Globe, a Screen Actors Guild Award and a Bafta (the British equivalent of an Oscar), Mr. Rockwell\u2019s Oscar success is pretty much guaranteed.\n\nDirector\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile fans of Guillermo del Toro do not roundly consider the merman gothic fairy tale \u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d his best picture \u2014 many rank it behind \u201cThe Devil\u2019s Backbone\u201d and \u201cPan\u2019s Labyrinth\u201d \u2014 all the momentum is there to secure him the win. \u201cShape\u201d leads the Oscars race with 13 nominations, and Martin McDonagh, the director of its biggest competitor for best picture, \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d did not manage to get a directing nomination. Mr. del Toro is widely respected and deeply liked, and buoyed by a \u201chis time is now\u201d narrative, along with wins at the Golden Globes, the Directors Guild of America Awards and the Baftas. If he nabs gold, it will be the fourth time in five years that a Mexican director has walked away with this prize.\n\nDocumentary\n\nPhoto\n\nUp until the Oscar nominations, prognosticators had their chips on the documentary \u201cJane,\u201d about the primatologist and conservationist Jane Goodall. Instead, the academy voted for less sunny films that delved into endemic racism (\u201cStrong Island\u201d), civilian rescuers and medics in the Syrian war (\u201cLast Men in Aleppo\u201d), Russian doping (\u201cIcarus\u201d) and alleged bank fraud (\u201cAbacus: Small Enough to Jail\u201d). Out of the bunch, \u201cFaces Places\u201d stands out for its quirkiness and light, teaming the 35-year-old French artist JR, who slathers outsize photos of everyday folks across favelas, water towers and buildings worldwide, with Agn\u00e8s Varda, now 89, the filmmaker nicknamed the grandmother of the French new wave. The result is an idiosyncratic, bittersweet and tender film that is the favorite to win.\n\nOriginal Screenplay\n\nPhoto\n\nOf all the films nominated for Oscars this year, \u201cGet Out\u201d almost certainly had the most impact, with its unapologetic message (white liberals are racist too), box office success ($255 million worldwide on a $4.5 million budget), and four Oscar nominations, including best picture, actor and director, a stunning haul for an edgy comedy-horror picture. The film is a long-shot for best picture, and is outmatched in the director and actor categories, but academy members wanting to make sure it wins something will probably reward its writer-director, Jordan Peele, with best screenplay. \u201cLady Bird\u201d or \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d could also prevail, but having won best screenplay at the Writers Guild of America Awards, \u201cGet Out\u201d has the edge.\n\nAdapted Screenplay\n\nPhoto\n\nEven if James Ivory had not won this year\u2019s Writers Guild Award for adapting Andr\u00e9 Aciman\u2019s gay coming-of-age novel into the Oscar-nominated \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d he would still have been the sentimental favorite here. As one half of the powerhouse filmmaking team Merchant-Ivory, Mr. Ivory brought glorious period pieces like \u201cA Room With a View,\u201d \u201cHowards End\u201d and \u201cThe Remains of the Day\u201d to the screen. This category is unusual this year; it includes the superhero film \u201cLogan.\u201d But Mr. Ivory, who is 89 and has been nominated for an Academy Award three times before, is expected to clinch it.\n\nAnimated Feature\n\nPhoto\n\nIt is really, really, really hard to beat Pixar. The powerhouse production company has won nine Oscars in the last 10 years, six of them for animated features, including \u201cWall-E,\u201d \u201cUp\u201d and \u201cInside Out.\u201d Their visuals are gasp-inducing, their story lines reduce adults to tears. \u201cCoco,\u201d about a Mexican boy on a quest tied to the Day of the Dead holiday, proves no exception, while also giving props to Mexico, a country much maligned these days in the United States. This typically wide-ranging category includes \u201cThe Breadwinner,\u201d which is from the small Irish outfit the Cartoon Saloon and which counts Angelina Jolie among its executive producers; and \u201cThe Boss Baby,\u201d starring Alec Baldwin. But \u201cCoco\u201d will probably triumph.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nForeign Language\n\nPhoto\n\nThere is a cadre of movie lovers who believe that Daniela Vega, the star of \u201cA Fantastic Woman,\u201d Chile\u2019s entry, should have landed a nomination for her performance as a trans nightclub singer and waitress, Marina, whose life is upended when her older boyfriend suddenly dies. Ms. Vega, a classically trained opera singer, played Marina with a quiet fortitude and grace that rise above the vituperation and cruel stereotyping heaped on her by her boyfriend\u2019s family and local officials. A favorite in this category, the film can already claim a win: Ms. Vega is scheduled to present an Oscar at the ceremony, which will make her the first openly transgender person to do so.", "title": "Our Expert Predicts the Oscar Winners", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "But the Bivens decision has been a popular target for conservative commentators and judges, who critique it as an unjustified exercise in \u201cjudicial lawmaking.\u201d To that end, the Supreme Court over the past three decades has slowly narrowed that decision, culminating in its ruling last June in Ziglar v. Abbasi, in which Justice Anthony Kennedy, writing for a 4-2 majority, suggested that such remedies would be \u201cdisfavored\u201d going forward, effectively limiting the application of Bivens to its particular facts. In other words, unless a victim of a constitutional violation by a federal officer can identify an identical situation in which courts have previously recognized a damages claim under the Constitution, the Abbasi decision instructs the lower federal courts to reject the claim, no matter how clear and egregious the constitutional violation may have been.\n\nThe Supreme Court\u2019s ruling in Abbasi rested on two fundamental flaws \u2014 one of them doctrinal, the other, analytical. The doctrinal flaw was that the court completely ignored the rich history of damages suits brought against federal officers before the 1971 Bivens decision. Those cases were typically brought under state law, like a tort claim for trespass, and therefore involved an exercise of judicial power similar to the Bivens case in recognizing a remedy not specifically authorized by a legislative body.\n\nBut state tort lawsuits against federal officers acting within the scope of their employment were prohibited in 1988 when Congress passed a law requiring those cases to be brought as federal claims, if they could be brought at all. Thanks to Abbasi, then, the choice in cases like these is no longer Bivens or state law, as it was in 1971; today it\u2019s Bivens or nothing. Which is why the holding in Bivens \u2014 that damages remedies for violations of constitutional rights can be inferred when they are not explicitly authorized \u2014 is so essential to enforcing federal constitutional rights.\n\nAs to the analytical flaw, Abbasi, like the Supreme Court decisions leading up to it, was based on an understanding of the separation of powers that is entirely backward \u2014 that judicial recognition of a damages remedy without express authorization from Congress would unduly commandeer the authority of the government\u2019s political branches. But when, as in the Abbasi and Hern\u00e1ndez cases, the right comes from the Constitution, it would defeat the purpose of having independent, unelected judges \u2014 to say nothing of constitutional rights in the first place \u2014 if the enforcement depended upon the government, the very institution against which the rights would be enforced. This is also why it is laughable when judges and defenders of these rulings suggest that Congress could fix the problem. Of course Congress could provide \u2014 as it has with respect to constitutional violations by state officers \u2014 for an express, statutory remedy in those cases. But Congress has no incentive to similarly provide a remedy against the federal government (which would necessarily come at the expense of taxpayers) \u2014 and it never will.\n\nAs Justice Kennedy pointed out in Abbasi, courts have not shown the same resistance to enforcing the Constitution against the federal government when the constitutional violation is continuing \u2014 as we see in cases like the pending challenges to the travel ban. But the government can always make those cases go away simply by ceasing the purported unconstitutional conduct. And in any event, there are far more cases in which the constitutional violation was a singular event or ended long before the victim can make it to court \u2014 cases that, as Hern\u00e1ndez underscores, now have increasingly little chance of success.", "title": "Opinion | Our Increasingly Unenforceable Constitution", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Brands are likely to become even more segmented into red and blue, strengthening the association between liberals and Priuses and conservatives and Cracker Barrel. Corporate brand campaigns could soon resemble political campaigns, with efforts to identify the most intensely loyal consumers for repeat purchases as opposed to attracting new ones.\n\nMainstream brands may become as common as moderate politicians \u2014 that is, a rare, perhaps extinct, species in today\u2019s political environment. Twitter and PayPal serve diverse customers today, but their recent efforts to regulate their own platforms have led to allegations of political bias and incited competitors.\n\nMost companies are not prepared for this new world of politics. Pepsi and Starbucks have already been victims of orchestrated fake news campaigns; there will be many more. As more companies take stands, those remaining will be named and shamed on social media, creating impossible choices in an environment where neutrality is not an option.\n\nLike our politicians, corporate chiefs will have to quickly figure out what stand they should take on the issue of the day by reflecting on their core convictions and estimating how their (customer) base will react. Like pollsters, they will have to assess which kind of consumers they can write off and which ones to curry favor with. The right answer will vary by a company\u2019s geographic location, who their employees are and how much they depend on favorable government regulation.\n\nThere is no going back. Lists are being kept and wins are being tallied by pressure groups aiming to get companies on their side. The issues that divide us will keep being served up in relentless succession, forcing companies to take stands on just about everything.\n\nMuch of this is a reflection of who we have become. Corporate America thrives by selling us what we want, and they do that by appealing to our identities. In 2018, for many Americans, our political identity seems to define us more than ever. It already influences whom we socialize with on Facebook, whom we marry, what news we read and where we live. It was only a matter of time before this big sort started to shape our consumer behavior, too.", "title": "Opinion | Our Newest Culture Warriors: Activist C.E.O.s", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Every April since 2010 we\u2019ve celebrated the joys of spring and of National Poetry Month with our Found Poem Contest.\n\nParticipating is easy: Just \u201cfind\u201d some poetry in a Times article \u2014 any Times article, published at any point in our 167-year history.\n\nTo help, we also have a companion lesson plan by two teachers who use this contest to \u201creinforce close reading, experimentation, peer review, self-review and revision\u201d \u2014 skills that are valuable across the curriclum. And, if that isn\u2019t enough, we\u2019ve also published an additional 22 ways to teach poetry with The New York Times.\n\nEverything you need to know about the contest is below, with links and tips galore. But if you have any questions, please post them in the comments, and we will answer you there, or write to us at LNFeedback@nytimes.com.", "title": "Our Ninth Annual Found Poem Student Contest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe concern is that the president might not want to do anything that would upset the Kushner family agreement to do business with his company,\u201d said Marilyn L. Glynn, who served as general counsel in the Office of Government Ethics during Republican and Democratic administrations, when told by The New York Times about the Trump-Kushner talks.\n\nThe White House declined to comment. Both companies on Friday confirmed their discussions about the hotel in Pier Village, while dismissing ethics concerns.\n\nThe plans under discussion in Long Branch have called for the Kushners to own the hotel and make payments to the Trump Organization to run it. The bonds issued by the city, part of a broader renewal effort, are not earmarked for the hotel, but they will support public infrastructure around Pier Village, and in turn help the hotel and nearby properties succeed.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast year, in another previously unreported endeavor involving the two family businesses, the Trump Organization began managing a Kushner-owned hotel in Livingston, N.J., people briefed on the matter said. That property, the Westminster Hotel, is believed to be the only hotel that the Trumps manage but do not brand.\n\nThe behind-the-scenes activity signals a deepening of the Trump-Kushner business relationship, which until recently appeared to be limited to a single residential project in Jersey City. It also poses potential ethical headaches for the White House, Ms. Glynn and other legal experts say.\n\nDeals between the two families, said Ms. Glynn, who also served as acting director of the ethics office for part of George W. Bush\u2019s presidency, do not inherently violate any ethics rule. But, weighing whether new financial entanglements posed more of a problem than existing family ones, she added, \u201cI think the financial concerns trump the familial ones, so to speak.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWalter M. Shaub Jr., who led the ethics office under President Barack Obama and is a frequent critic of Mr. Trump, said: \u201cIf a subordinate is your son-in-law, maybe you like them, but once you have entangled business interests, they\u2019ve got leverage over you. Blood is not thicker than money for a lot of people.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, the Kushner Companies said the Trumps \u201chave zero equity of any type in our properties or businesses.\u201d In Long Branch, the statement said, \u201cwe are contemplating a third-party operator agreement with their hotel management division at market rate.\u201d Noting that it did not specialize in the hospitality industry, the company said it had \u201ca business obligation to seek the most capable resource.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Eric Danziger, the head of Trump Hotels, disputed that teaming up with the Kushners might pose a conflict.\n\n\u201cThis is a straight-up business deal,\u201d he said. \u201cIf there were something out of the ordinary about the deal, then I think that question is fair,\u201d he said, but \u201cwe do market transactions that are reviewed and checked.\u201d\n\nMr. Danziger said that Bobby Burchfield, the Trump Organization\u2019s outside ethics adviser, had asked about the financing involved in a potential Long Branch deal with the Kushners. Mr. Burchfield, who scrutinizes how the Trump Organization\u2019s partners finance deals, among other things, often requires more information before approving a deal.\n\nWhether or not the Trumps and Kushners reach a deal, Mr. Kushner stands to gain. He is expected to eventually own 20 percent of the hotel in Pier Village, according to documents obtained through a public records request. And he was personally involved in the project early in the presidential campaign. In documents provided to Long Branch, the Kushner Companies stated that Mr. Kushner \u201cis strictly a passive investor.\u201d\n\nHe also retains a stake in a Kushner residential tower in Jersey City that bears the Trump name.\n\nIn Livingston, Mr. Kushner has divested from the Westminster Hotel, a three-story property overlooking strip malls. While it is unusual for the Trumps to manage hotels that do not carry one of their brands, Mr. Danziger said he was discussing similar deals with other companies as a way to expand the business under the \u201cright circumstances.\u201d\n\n\u201cAn owner wants to know they can depend on and rely on the operator, and we have a lot of credibility as operators,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe growing relationship between the families could be helpful to the Trumps, as the ethical restraints they voluntarily adopted after the election have proved to be a hindrance to new business. The Trump Organization, which agreed not to start any new foreign projects during the presidency, has yet to open a new hotel in the United States since Mr. Trump took office.\n\nWhile Mr. Danziger said the pipeline of potential deals was \u201cstill very active,\u201d the company has also shown some signs of scaling back: Since the election, the Trump name has been removed from properties in Manhattan, Toronto and Panama.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA pairing with the Kushners could bring other complications. If the Trumps manage a Kushner property that received foreign or domestic government funding, it could test the Constitution\u2019s emoluments clauses, which essentially prohibit the president from accepting certain gifts from foreign or domestic governments. Some legal experts argue that local bonds like the ones issued in Long Branch could brush against the domestic clause.\n\nThe Kushners, who co-own the development with Extell Development, a New York real estate firm, said they would not accept money from foreign governments.\n\nThe firm, however, has a history of seeking cash from investors with strong connections to foreign governments, including Anbang, an insurance company in China.\n\nThe Kushners also have a history of teaming up with Israeli investors, which is ethically thorny for Mr. Kushner, whose central responsibilities in the White House include handling Middle East policy. Extell\u2019s bonds have traded on the Tel Aviv stock exchange.\n\nThe Kushners also used money from Chinese investors to finance the construction of Trump Bay Street, the residential tower in Jersey City. The Chinese money came through the so-called EB-5 program, which offers visas to foreigners in exchange for $500,000 investments in real estate projects. Federal prosecutors have been investigating the Kushner businesses\u2019 use of the program, though the company has said it no longer pursues this type of funding and \u201cdid nothing improper.\u201d\n\nIn addition, investigators working for Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel looking into Russian interference in the 2016 election, have asked questions about Mr. Kushner\u2019s interactions with foreign businesspeople, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.\n\nIn Long Branch, the Kushners are moving ahead with building the hotel in Pier Village and may add more hotels in the area.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe talks with the Trumps have focused largely on the Pier Village property under construction, which might carry the Scion brand, a new line of four-star hotels the Trumps announced in 2016. The Kushner Companies, however, said on Friday that it planned only to have the Trumps manage the hotel.\n\nThe hotel construction is part of the latest phase of a decades-long effort to remake the Long Branch waterfront after a fire destroyed the boardwalk in 1987 and contributed to a downward spiral.\n\nMayor Adam Schneider and local business leaders spearheaded a redevelopment plan in the 1990s that gave rise to Pier Village. The effort increased the city\u2019s annual beachfront revenue from $200,000 in the early 1990s to more than $2 million in 2017, the mayor said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Kushners have long owned an oceanfront house in an exclusive section of town, and in 2014, they teamed up with Extell to buy Pier Village.\n\nWith the purchase, the Kushners took over the part of Pier Village that already had a row of restaurants and shops, as well as a vacant strip of land that will eventually feature luxury residential condominiums, retail stores and the hotel.\n\nMr. Kushner was involved in planning the project. He was copied on emails with city officials, and the mayor recalls meeting with him twice.\n\nMr. Kushner assumed a role in the White House, but his sister, Nicole Meyer, and his father, Charles Kushner, continued to work on the effort, including discussions with officials about the bonds.\n\nIn September, the City Council unanimously approved the bonds to help close a \u201cfunding gap.\u201d The city will borrow the money to reimburse Kushner Companies and Extell for approved costs that arise from building public improvements such as a boardwalk, public restrooms and a children\u2019s play area.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Schneider said that the arrangement would not cause a tax increase, and that the city had struck a better deal with the Kushners and Extell than with the previous owners of Pier Village.\n\nThe city expects to more than recoup its investment by collecting an annual service charge and other payments that the Kushners and Extell pay in lieu of certain taxes. And the city said it had obtained a personal guarantee from Charles Kushner.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s actually a very lucrative deal to municipalities,\u201d Mr. Schneider said.\n\nA week after the city approved the bonds, emails show, Ms. Meyer invited local officials to lunch at the Beach House restaurant at Pier Village. \u201cPlease let us know if you would like to join,\u201d the invitation said, \u201cand thank you for all your support and efforts!\u201d\n\nWhen informed by reporters that the Trump Organization might ultimately be involved in a hotel in his town, Mr. Schneider, a Democrat first elected in 1990, sighed and expressed concern.\n\nBut he added: \u201cOur success is that we have a hotel that\u2019s doing a great volume of business that\u2019s creating jobs and economic vitality. It can be achieved no matter what name is on any building.\u201d", "title": "Out of Public View, Trumps and Kushners Are Talking Business", "authors": ["Ben Protess", "Steve Eder", "Jesse Drucker"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis goes against the lore that you should have the dog sleep elsewhere,\u201d and not in the bedroom, said Dr. Lois E. Krahn, the study\u2019s senior author and a psychiatrist and sleep medicine specialist at the Center for Sleep Medicine at the Mayo Clinic. Her 6-year-old golden retriever, Phoebe, routinely sleeps on the floor in the bedroom \u2014 and in the colder months joins her and her husband on their bed. Both the dog and the people, she said, sleep fine.\n\nIn an earlier study from 2015, Dr. Krahn and her colleagues asked patients who had visited the Mayo Clinic\u2019s sleep clinic whether they owned dogs, cats or other pets. About half did, with many owning more than one. Forty-one percent said they perceived their pet as unobtrusive or beneficial to their sleep, compared to 20 percent who said their pet was disruptive. That study was self-reported, and \u201cwe can\u2019t quite trust people to have an accurate report or even be able to accurately observe their feelings for their pets,\u201d Dr. Krahn said. \u201cIt\u2019s sort of like a parent\u2019s feelings for their child. I wanted to have objective data.\u201d Hence the recent follow-up report that used activity monitors to get objective data.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhere the pet sleeps \u201cdepends on the animal\u2019s temperament,\u201d said Dr. Carlo Siracusa, a veterinarian and the director of animal behavioral science at Penn Vet in Philadelphia. \u201cThere are dogs that tend to be more reactive to stimuli. So, for example, if the dog is on the bed and the owner turns and inadvertently hits the dog with the leg, some dogs will get startled and react out of fear,\u201d growling or barking and waking the sleeper, he said. Other dogs aren\u2019t bothered at all. \u201cIf there are no problems and the owner is happy with letting the pet in the bedroom, or on the bed, it\u2019s fine with me.\u201d\n\nHe added that a dog sleeping in the same room or bed with humans won\u2019t make Sparky think he\u2019s top dog. \u201cDogs can distinguish between the relationship with its human fellows and other dogs, and the way in which they regulate their interactions with humans in the house is not trying to establish a hierarchy,\u201d he said.\n\nSome dogs may not belong in the bedroom, such as very young or old pets who may not sleep through the night, a sick pet or a reactive pet who might become aggressive when startled or woken up suddenly. Also, if a new baby is entering the family and will sleep in the same bedroom as the parents, Dr. Siracusa said, that might no longer be a good place for the pet to sleep \u2013 not because of concerns of a pet smothering a baby, he said, but because space may be an issue with that many human and furry bodies in one room.\n\nIf a pet is already sleeping in your bed or in the bedroom and interfering with your sleep, you can take steps to transition a pet out of the bedroom. Dr. Siracusa said it is best to make the transition a gradual one rather than abruptly kicking the pet out of the bed or bedroom. That may mean first moving a dog from the human bed to a comfortable spot elsewhere in the bedroom, and then moving the pet just outside the door.\n\nThe key is to create a similar sleeping experience for the pet. Dogs may be attracted to humans\u2019 beds, especially if they\u2019re elevated, \u201cbecause they are comfortable and strategically in a good position,\u201d letting dogs keep watch over their surroundings, Dr. Siracusa said. Creating an equally strategic place might mean that it\u2019s also elevated, or that it has coverings that the dog can burrow under, or that it is near a heater that can simulate the warmth of the people in the humans\u2019 bed.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome dogs will never want to sleep with their owners, especially if the owner snores or moves around a lot at night. \u201cWhen dogs sleep, they want a safe space and don\u2019t want to be bothered,\u201d just like people, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFiguring out where a new dog should sleep can take some time. When Natalie Hastings and her husband adopted Mikey, a 70-pound boxer bulldog mix, they tried letting him sleep in the bed at first, but he shifted around so much they moved him onto a couch. But as Mikey became more settled in their home and he slept more soundly through the night, that changed. He started sleeping in the bed with Mrs. Hastings when her husband traveled for work. Now he\u2019s there all the time and, Mrs. Hastings says, helps her fall asleep faster.\n\n\u201cI have trouble settling down, and he\u2019s got very rhythmic breathing,\u201d she said of Mikey. \u201cIt\u2019s almost like white noise. And he\u2019s really warm.\u201d\n\nMore Reporting on Dogs\n\nDr. Krahn said the next step in her research is to study a larger group of dogs and their owners, and also to see whether having one or two humans in the bed makes a difference.\n\nShe\u2019d also like to do a similar study on cats, though they, of course, are entirely different animals. In addition to Phoebe, she has a 4-year-old cat, Oliver, who is allowed anywhere in the house except the bedroom because \u201cthe cat wanders, scratches, meows,\u201d she said. While most dogs can be trained, \u201cI think cats do what they want. If that cat is hungry in the middle of the night, that cat does not care\u201d about waking you up, she said.\n\nOliver the cat declined to comment.", "title": "Out of the Doghouse, Into the Bed", "authors": ["Jen A. Miller"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nDespite the threat of a nor\u2019easter, I made my way to work. But by the time I had walked to 57th Street and Seventh Avenue to get a bus to Penn Station to go home, the snow had started to come down heavily.\n\nAfter I had been tangling with the snow and the wind for about a half-hour, a woman approached me and asked whether I would come in and have a cup of tea to warm up. Her name was Ellen. She explained that she and her husband, Tom, were taking a brief respite from the storm to have lunch. I agreed.\n\nWhen I got inside, a man at the bar said, \u201cI am so sorry.\u201d I couldn\u2019t see through my foggy glasses. He helped me with my coat, and then patted my behind. I quickly moved away from him.\n\nEllen and Tom moved to a table where I could sit comfortably.\n\n\u201cWould ya like an Irish coffee?\u201d the server asked in an Irish brogue. She pointed toward two couples in a booth. \u201cThese people here are buyin\u2019 it far ya.\u201d", "title": "Out of the Storm", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Clockwise from top left: Michael Vanderbyl for Janus et Cie See! O\u2019Brien returns for his third time in The New York Times Crossword with an interesting theme set. I can honestly say that I never thought about what this set has in common, but if you keep your eye on the theme entries, you should eventually spot the reasoning behind the set.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. O\u2019Brien offers us a set of four \u2014 I\u2019m not sure what you would call them as a group, because they\u2019re all different \u2014 but it\u2019s a set of four. And what they have in common is that they all have ONE EYE, which is the revealer split between 39A and 32A.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n5A: An AGORA was an open space in ancient Greece that was used for markets. You won\u2019t see the word outside crossword puzzles that much, but it\u2019s good to know for solving.\n\n18A: POLYPHEMUS, the Cyclops that met up with Odysseus in Greek mythology, has appeared only once before in The New York Times Crossword, in 1978.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n24A: \u201cTin lizzies\u201d were another name for the Ford MODEL TS that hit the road from 1908 to 1927.\n\n58A: \u201cPart of a list with bullets\u201d refers to bullet points, and each one would be an ITEM.", "title": "Outsmarted by Odysseus", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "When President Trump met on Tuesday with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, a year after he first hosted the prince at the White House, something was missing. Women.\n\nPhotos from Tuesday\u2019s meeting show that the dynamics at the table remained relatively unchanged since the last meeting, and persistently male. After years of American foreign policy that has pushed for human rights, such a stark absence of women \u2014 and minorities \u2014 could send a symbolic message to the ultraconservative country known for its oppression of women and religious minorities.\n\nSome in attendance on the American side: Vice President Mike Pence; Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser; and Lt. None Were Women.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we\u2019re adding the stories of remarkable people.\n\nWhen Alison Hargreaves reached the peak of Mount Everest on May 13, 1995, she sent a radio message to her son and daughter: \u201cTo Tom and Kate, my dear children, I am on the highest point of the world, and I love you dearly.\u201d\n\nWith that triumph, she became the first woman in history to conquer the Earth\u2019s apex \u2014 29,029 feet high \u2014 alone and without bottled oxygen. Hargreaves, one of the world\u2019s greatest alpinists then and of all time, also did without the fixed ropes set by others on that Himalayan climb. Only the Italian mountaineer Reinhold Messner had ascended Everest in a similar manner before.\n\nHer homeland, Britain \u2014 stoked by a front-page headline in The Times of London that read \u201cOne of the greatest climbs in history\u201d \u2014 rejoiced.", "title": "Overlooked No More: Alison Hargreaves, Who Conquered Everest Solo and Without Bottled Oxygen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Leer en espa\u00f1ol\n\nSince 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we\u2019re adding the stories of remarkable people.\n\nIn 1993, the Cuban printmaker Belkis Ay\u00f3n, known for her signature collage-based style and her work reflecting the Afro-Cuban religion Abuku\u00e1, was invited to show at the Venice Biennale in Italy. She was determined to make it, despite obstacles in her home country. Cuba was going through an economic depression at that time, leaving it dark and uncertain, with drastic food and fuel shortages.\n\nWith no other way to get to the airport 20 miles from their home in Havana, she and her father mounted their bikes and started riding. Ms. Ay\u00f3n raced ahead of her father, who rode with her work strapped to his bicycle. She made it in time to board, but he did not \u2014 and neither did her work (though it did eventually make the trip).\n\nFor Ms. Ay\u00f3n, who was born Jan. 23, 1967, in Havana, art was how she communicated.\n\n\u201cIt is the way, the manner, the solution that I found to say what I wanted,\u201d she said in an interview in Revoluci\u00f3n y Cultura Magazine in February 1999.", "title": "Overlooked No More: Belkis Ay\u00f3n, a Cuban Printmaker Inspired by a Secret Male Society", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "A survivor whose life had been shaped by grief, Bront\u00eb was perhaps emboldened to write as few, if any, women had before: tales of resistance and insistence on trusting one\u2019s own sense of true morality, however unconventional. In \u201cJane Eyre,\u201d she wrote from the first-person perspective of a child, an innovation that gave voice and power even to the very young; she created, too, a heroine who was, like Bront\u00eb herself, plain, pale, small, and yet frankly desirous, as well as worthy of desire.\n\nBront\u00eb once wrote to a friend that she considered the marital ambitions of women of no means or beauty \u201can imbecility which I reject with contempt,\u201d a practical response to the frank injustices of class and a kind of sexism. In her novels, however, those same plain women are entitled to not just any marriages, but to passionate, loving ones. The interior lives of Jane Eyre and Lucy Snowe are shared in such detail that the characters\u2019 unfair burdens are plainly manifest; Bront\u00eb could make great sweeping plotlines of the small moments and humiliations in an unmarried woman\u2019s life. Lucy Snowe\u2019s struggle to find a private place to read a long-awaited letter reads, over several pages, with the suspense and drama of a Spenserian quest.\n\nA miniaturist of the soul, Bront\u00eb captured shades of emotion with a psychological subtlety that still feels exquisitely modern. When Lucy Snowe, battling depression, is advised to cultivate her own happiness, her strong response will feel familiar to many a 21st-century person who has the condition: \u201cNo mockery in this world ever sounds to me so hollow as that of being told to cultivate happiness,\u201d she wrote. \u201cHappiness is not a potato to be planted in mould and tilled with manure.\u201d\n\nShe had a mordant wit, which could protect her only so much from the series of losses that left her so fragile. \u201cIt is useless to tell you how I live,\u201d she wrote to a friend in 1851. \u201cI endure life \u2014 but whether I enjoy it or not is another question.\u201d She startled readily, and wrote to friends complaining of crushing insomnia, a poor appetite, grief and flashbacks; she put off writing letters for fear of how dejected she would feel if the replies came too slowly. Her two most intense romantic passions \u2014 one, involving a married Belgian school master, was meticulously memorialized in \u201cVillette\u201d; the other, for her publisher, George Smith (also captured in the characteristics of a doctor in \u201cVillette\u201d) \u2014 were both unrequited.\n\nBut reader, she married, eventually, at the age of 38, choosing Arthur Bell Nicholls, a pastor who worked for Bront\u00eb\u2019s father. Although she acknowledged frankly that he was not her intellectual equal, he pursued her persistently, and against her father\u2019s wishes, possibly imbuing a late-in-life courtship with a jolt of romance.\n\nDid Bront\u00eb ultimately find the kind of happiness that she described as \u201ca glory shining far down upon us out of heaven\u201d? In \u201cVillette,\u201d Lucy Snowe describes her own feelings about happiness: \u201cThe negation of severe suffering was the nearest approach to happiness I expected to know. Besides, I seemed to hold two lives \u2014 the life of thought, and that of reality. And provided the former was nourished with a sufficiency of strange and necromantic joys of fancy, the privileges of the latter might remain limited to daily bread, hourly work and a roof of shelter.\u201d Once Bront\u00eb married, however, her life of thought suffered. \u201cMy own life is more occupied than it used to be,\u201d she wrote to a friend. \u201cI have not so much time for thinking.\u201d\n\nLiterature would no longer be the business of her life; whether the pleasures of marriage could offset that loss remains unclear. To one friend, she wrote, \u201cIt is a solemn and strange and perilous thing for a woman to become a wife.\u201d But several months later, she wrote, \u201cI have a good, kind attached husband, and every day makes my own attachment to him stronger.\u201d", "title": "Overlooked No More: Charlotte Bront\u00eb, Novelist Known for \u2018Jane Eyre\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we\u2019re adding the stories of remarkable people.\n\nWhen we talk about \u201cmobility\u201d for women, these days, we\u2019re often speaking metaphorically about social and economic opportunities. But in the late 1800s, the writer Lillias Campbell Davidson dedicated herself to advocating for women to become literally mobile \u2014 to travel alone in carriages and in trains; to embark on long walks and climb mountaintops; and especially, to experience the freedom and thrill of riding a bicycle.\n\nDavidson started riding in the early 1880s, when she was in her late 20s, and quickly styled herself as an advocate and expert. Women cyclists were viewed as so improper in her neighborhood in the south of England that she rode in the early morning, when the streets were empty; she once turned down a side street to avoid being spied riding by the town vicar. Soon, Davidson was publicly advocating for women to join her, in ladies\u2019 columns for the Scottish Cyclist and the Cyclists\u2019 Touring Club Gazette. In 1892, she founded the Lady Cyclists\u2019 Association, the first cycling organization for women, and served as its president for the next five years. In 1896, she published her collected wisdom in the \u201cHandbook for Lady Cyclists.\u201d\n\n\u201cA new world of enjoyment is unlocked to the woman who finds herself a-wheel,\u201d Davidson wrote. Cycling \u201cis a door that leads to many paths of pleasure.\u201d", "title": "Overlooked No More: Lillias Campbell Davidson, Who Founded the First Women\u2019s Cycling Organization", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we\u2019re adding the stories of remarkable people.\n\nAround the time Ruth Wakefield began making a chocolate chip cookie in the 1930s, naming newly invented treats after something or someone was in vogue.\n\nCase in point: the Baby Ruth chocolate-covered nutty nougat bar, purportedly named for Grover Cleveland\u2019s daughter. Wakefield\u2019s confection was known originally as the Toll House Chocolate Crunch Cookie, after the Toll House Inn, a popular restaurant that she ran with her husband in eastern Massachusetts.\n\nLegend had it that she was brainstorming about cookie dough while returning from a vacation in Egypt when she first came up with the recipe, a variation on another popular treat called Butter Drop Do pecan icebox cookies.", "title": "Overlooked No More: Ruth Wakefield, Who Invented the Chocolate Chip Cookie", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we\u2019re adding the stories of remarkable people.\n\nSEOUL, South Korea \u2014 When a call for peaceful protests in support of Korean independence came in spring 1919, a 16-year-old girl named Yu Gwan-sun became the face of a nation\u2019s collective yearning for freedom.\n\nYu was a student at Ewha Haktang in Seoul, which was established by American missionaries as the first modern educational institution for women in Korea. On March 1, 1919, Yu and four classmates joined others taking to the streets with cries of \u201cMansei!\u201d (\u201cLong live Korean independence!\u201d) in one of the earliest protests against Japanese colonial rule. Amid the demonstration, the Declaration of Independence \u2014 written by the publisher Choe Nam-seon and signed by 33 Korean cultural and religious leaders \u2014 was recited at Seoul\u2019s Pagoda Park.\n\nThe next day, protest organizers came to Ewha Haktang and encouraged Yu and her peers to join a student demonstration to be staged in three days. On March 5, she and her classmates marched at Namdaemun, a gate in central Seoul. They were detained by the Japanese authorities, but missionaries from the school negotiated their release.", "title": "Overlooked No More: Yu Gwan-sun, a Korean Independence Activist Who Defied Japanese Rule", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The opioid epidemic just keeps getting worse, presenting challenges discussed at length at a White House summit last week. But opioids are not America\u2019s only significant drug problem. Among illicit drugs, cocaine is the No. 2 killer and claims the lives of more African-Americans than heroin does.\n\nIn a recent study published in Annals of Internal Medicine, researchers from the National Cancer Institute and the National Institute on Drug Abuse found that drug-related deaths have grown across all racial groups and among both men and women. The analysis found that between 1999 and 2015, overdose deaths of any kind of drug for Americans 20 to 64 years old increased 5.5 percent per year.\n\nFor the most recent years of analysis (2012-15), the study found that deaths of men from heroin exceeded those from any other type of opioid, such as those found in pain medications. For women, deaths related to opioid medications were the most common.\n\nBut among non-Hispanic black Americans, cocaine has been a larger problem than heroin for nearly 20 years. For example, over 2012-15, cocaine overdoses claimed 7.6 per 100,000 black men. In contrast, heroin overdoses claimed 5.45 per 100,000 black men. Black women use both drugs at lower rates than men, but cocaine overdoses exceed those from heroin for them as well.", "title": "Overshadowed by the Opioid Crisis: A Comeback by Cocaine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is a certain irony that, by filing and publicizing this lawsuit, plaintiffs have brought more attention upon themselves than O\u2019Reilly\u2019s comments, which were never directed at or referred to plaintiffs, ever did,\u201d lawyers for Mr. O\u2019Reilly said. They added that Ms. Mackris and Ms. Diamond had violated their confidentiality agreements \u2014 \u201cMackris by inviting a New York Times reporter and photographer into her home, and Diamond through social media.\u201d\n\n\u201cO\u2019Reilly will, in the proper, arbitral forum, assert claims against Mackris and Diamond for breach of these agreements,\u201d his lawyers said.\n\nAccording to court documents filed Tuesday, Mr. O\u2019Reilly said that the defamation claims were \u201cfrivolous and wholly unsupported in law or fact\u201d and that none of his statements would expose the women to \u201cpublic shame or ridicule.\u201d\n\n\u201cO\u2019Reilly\u2019s statements consist of his opinions concerning the unbalanced journalism that went into stories published about him and his critique of the advocacy groups that organized a sponsor boycott against him and his top-rated show,\u201d his lawyers said. \u201cSuch statements of opinion are protected and cannot serve as a basis for a defamation claim.\u201d\n\nIn the lawsuit, the women said that Mr. Murdoch had disparaged and defamed them during an interview with Sky News in London, during which he characterized sexual harassment issues at Fox News as being isolated to Roger Ailes.\n\nThe women also took issue with the company\u2019s statement that \u201cno current or former Fox News employee ever took advantage of the 21st Century Fox hotline to raise a concern about Bill O\u2019Reilly.\u201d\n\nLawyers for Fox News said in the court filing Tuesday that the network could not be held liable for the statements made by its parent company or Mr. O\u2019Reilly. They added that statements by 21st Century Fox and Mr. Murdoch were not defamatory because they had not \u201cmentioned any of the plaintiffs, provided any details of their settlements, or cast any doubt on the merits of their claims.\u201d\n\nLawyers for Mr. O\u2019Reilly and the network said they had not breached Ms. Bernstein\u2019s settlement agreement because Mr. O\u2019Reilly was not a party to the agreement and there was \u201cno allegation that Fox News disclosed anything about Bernstein\u2019s settlement or the facts leading up to it.\u201d", "title": "O\u2019Reilly and Fox News Seek to Dismiss Defamation Suit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "But none of that should disguise quite how callow, how dismal, P.S.G.\u2019s elimination was. This is a team that has been constructed, at almost unimaginable cost, to win the Champions League. As its coach, Unai Emery, said Tuesday, losing to Real Madrid is no embarrassment. \u201cIt is a team of champions,\u201d he said.\n\nHe did not say that losing like this is, or should be. P.S.G., a team that cost half a billion dollars, did not rage against its fate. It did not hurl all it had at Real\u2019s defense, ending the game breathless and broken, fighting for pride, if nothing else. It simply accepted \u2014 as soon as Cristiano Ronaldo scored, as he always does in the Champions League \u2014 that, once again, it was going to fall short.\n\nPhoto\n\nEmery\u2019s players slowed almost to walking pace. Their passing, hardly sharp at any point in the evening, grew increasingly lazy, wayward. They were careless. They were aimless. They wandered around, as if in a daze. It is one thing not to be able to execute a plan. It is quite another not to seem to care what the plan is, or was.\n\nThey were waiting for what they had decided was inevitable, for the blissful release of Brych\u2019s whistle, for the chance to return to what they do best: beating French teams with a fraction of their budget by six- and seven-goal margins. That is where this team really comes into its own.\n\nThis defeat \u2014 just like all those defeats in the last six years \u2014 does, at least, provide some answers. We now know, for example, that Emery, whose contract would have automatically renewed if he had guided his team to the semifinals, will not be its manager next year.\n\nHe was forgiven one failure last year \u2014 \u201cwe must not allow emotion to dictate our actions,\u201d the club\u2019s chairman, Nasser al-Khelaifi, said in the aftermath of that humiliating loss to Barcelona \u2014 but he will not survive a second, and he most likely would not expect to. It is open to debate quite how satisfying he has found his work here, anyway, trying to pick his way through a forest of delicate egos, political necessities and sporting realities.\n\nMainly, though, the latest elimination brought questions, ones that are growing ever more pressing. What now? How does P.S.G. respond not just to this defeat, but to this pattern of defeats? Does Khelaifi do what he has always done and bankroll yet another market-contorting spending spree, even if it means running yet more risks with UEFA\u2019s rules on Financial Fair Play?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf money has not brought a solution thus far \u2014 P.S.G. already possesses Neymar, the world\u2019s most expensive player, and will make Kylian Mbapp\u00e9 No. 2 when he completes a permanent move from Monaco this summer \u2014 is it rational to assume that it will at some point? Has Paris Saint-Germain, the club that has blown away all of its rivals, with only two teams in Manchester as exceptions, with its checkbook, simply not spent enough?\n\nOr is it time to look at the problem from another angle, to assume that perhaps success in soccer does not simply come from accumulating as much talent as possible and seeing what happens?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat stood out on this most chastising of evenings was not some technical deficiency. Real Madrid did not win because it had better players. It won because of its character, its strength of mind, what its coach, Zinedine Zidane, described as a \u201ctrust in what we are doing.\u201d\n\nP.S.G. does not have that, and it showed. In the moments after Ronaldo\u2019s goal just after halftime, when all seemed lost, it had nothing to fall back on, and so it fell apart instead.\n\nP.S.G. can make excuses. It can hope for its luck to turn. It can spend more money; it can always spend more money. Maybe that will work, this time. But maybe it will not, and we will all be back here next year, too, asking the same questions, and getting the same empty answers.", "title": "P.S.G. The proposals include new eligibility standards and limiting the presence of shoe companies \u2014 a bold statement from a league that counts the so-called University of Nike among its members.\n\n\u201cI think the time is well past for incremental tweaks or cosmetic reactions to what we\u2019ve seen over the last year,\u201d Larry Scott, the Pac-12 commissioner, said in a phone interview on Monday.\n\nThe Pac-12 task force\u2019s recommendations could prove to be a preview of the findings of an N.C.A.A. commission, led by the former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, formed last fall to investigate potential changes for college basketball.\n\nThe Pac-12 group advocated encouraging the N.B.A. and its players\u2019 association to end its so-called one-and-done rule requiring players to be a year removed from high school before entering the league, as well as new rules like those in college baseball, in which players may sign with teams straight after high school but, if they enter college, must stay three years.
