Investigation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 A Hindu woman from a lower caste has been elected to the Senate for the first time in Pakistan, a Muslim-majority country where religious minorities have long suffered intimidation and violence. Her election to the upper house of Parliament is being hailed as a landmark moment for the country\u2019s generally oppressed religious minorities, especially Hindus.\n\nThe woman, Krishna Kumari, 39, a human rights activist and member of the Pakistan Peoples Party, was elected as a senator over the weekend. The governing party, the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz, emerged as the largest party in Saturday\u2019s Senate elections, ahead of the Pakistan Peoples Party.\n\nSenators are elected by members of provincial assemblies rather than through a direct vote by citizens. The Senate is a body of 104 lawmakers, and 52 seats were up for election.\n\nThe results, months ahead of the general elections, left the governing party in control, although its leader, Nawaz Sharif, was ousted in a controversial court decision last year and faces corruption charges.", "title": "Pakistan Elects First Lower-Caste Hindu Woman to Senate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The chief justice of Pakistan\u2019s Supreme Court, Mian Saqib Nisar, is a man on a mission. Our senior-most judge wants to rid the country of corrupt politicians, and he wants us to eat hormone-free chicken. \u201cThe aim of my struggle is clean air, clean water, pure milk,\u201d he told lawyers last week during an impromptu stop by the cafeteria of the bar association in Islamabad, the capital. He was asking for their help. Also on his to-do list: fighting against hepatitis and cancer, and for a fair price for crops.\n\nNisar has said one reason Pakistan isn\u2019t a superpower is that Pakistani gardeners take way more smoking breaks than their Chinese counterparts. He has also said the judiciary is like a village elder, and that its integrity should not be doubted.\n\nVillage elders go a bit batty occasionally, but we can\u2019t say that about the chief justice because it would amount to a serious crime called contempt of court. There is already a former senator in jail for committing this crime, and two ministers may soon join him. (All three men are from the governing Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz, or PML-N.) And so Nisar goes around exhorting fellow judges, lawyers and citizens at large to do their work not \u201cjust as a job,\u201d but with passion.\n\nIn July 2017 the Supreme Court invoked corruption charges to remove Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif from office. With passion. And last week a panel headed by Nisar passionately disqualified Sharif from heading the PML-N, also invalidating his selection of candidates to run on the party\u2019s ticket in Senate elections scheduled for March 3.", "title": "Opinion | Pakistan\u2019s Judges Are on a Mission. But What Is It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 During the debate last week over a United States-sponsored measure to throw Pakistan onto a global terrorism-financing watchlist, it appeared that Saudi Arabia and China were going to quickly shut it all down. The Pakistani foreign minister sounded a triumphant note.\n\n\u201cGrateful to friends who helped,\u201d Foreign Minister Khawaja M. Asif posted on Twitter.\n\nJust two days later, on Friday, Pakistan\u2019s relief turned to alarm at the news that those two close allies had withdrawn their support, making it inevitable that Pakistan would be added in June to the \u201cgray list\u201d of the Financial Action Task Force, a global body created to fight terrorism financing and money laundering.\n\nThe country will have a year to show that it is acting against extremist groups, shutting down their financing streams and prosecuting their leaders, or it could face having its banks cut off like those of Iran and North Korea were. Already, the gray-listing will make it harder for Pakistan to access international markets, and it has $3 billion in debts coming due this summer.\n\nPakistan has been on that gray list before, for a three-year stretch that ended in 2015, and this week Pakistani officials publicly expressed doubt that anything worse would happen.", "title": "Pakistan\u2019s Shields Suddenly Step Aside, Placing It on Terrorism Listing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cHippocratic,\u201d a documentary about the life of Dr. M.R. Rajagopal, India\u2019s leading advocate of palliative care, is now touring the United States \u2014 a country where attitudes toward pain relief have changed because of the overdose epidemic.\n\nDr. Rajagopal\u2019s chief message \u2014 and that of the film \u2014 is that the essence of care for the dying is simple compassion. His inspiration came from Mahatma Gandhi, said Dr. Rajagopal, who in 2014 won a global award from Human Rights Watch for his activism.\n\nBut for a doctor, part of compassion is relieving pain when a patient\u2019s tumors have become so large, burns so deep or wounds so grievous that they are beyond cure, Dr. Rajagopal said. And that usually can be done only with opioid-based pain relievers \u2014 like morphine and fentanyl.\n\nPeople in agony may kill themselves, and the film recalls such cases.\n\nBut opioids have been demonized in recent years because so many young Americans \u2014 often prescribed narcotic pills for dental or back pain rather than for fatal illnesses \u2014 have become addicted and gone on to use heroin, street fentanyl or other concoctions, sometimes with fatal consequences.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAmerica\u2019s crisis \u201cis an issue,\u201d even in India, Dr. Rajagopal said in an interview before \u201cHippocratic\u201d was screened in New York on Tuesday. \u201cIt stopped the boat.\u201d", "title": "Palliative Care Film Challenges Stereotypes About Opioids", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr.", "Global Health"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLittle Time to Live, and Still Stuck Behind Bars\u201d (news article, March 8):\n\nEven with optimal compassionate release policies, many older prisoners with serious illnesses will never surpass the administrative hurdles necessary to gain release from prison or indeed be eligible for such release. For these people, we must optimize prison-based palliative care.\n\nProvision of palliative care is appropriate as soon as any serious illness is diagnosed, and it can be delivered simultaneously with curative treatment. It focuses on symptom control and quality of life, is cost-efficient and, at times, may even extend life.\n\nMost important, palliative care has become community-standard medical care for patients with serious, life-limiting illness and thus should be considered a constitutional right for all prisoners.\n\nAs policy and lawmakers hone in on making compassionate release policies more effective, we must not lose sight of the pressing need to improve the quality of care delivered in prisons for all people facing serious, life-limiting illness regardless of whether or not they will ever reach freedom.", "title": "Opinion | Palliative Care for Prisoners", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "PANAMA CITY \u2014 A workman wielding a crowbar pried off the silver T-R-U-M-P name from the Trump International Hotel and Tower here in Panama City on Monday as the majority owner of the hotel declared victory in his fight to oust the American president\u2019s family business as managers of the property.\n\nThe president\u2019s company, the Trump Organization, fired back with its own statement disputing that it permanently lost control of the property, its only current hotel venture in Latin America. The developments on Monday, the company said, actually \u201cmaintain the status quo.\u201d\n\nThe dueling interpretations of the day\u2019s events reflected the chaotic nature of a dispute that has become an international spectacle and one of the biggest problems facing the president\u2019s company.\n\nThe standoff has been playing out for nearly two weeks behind the scenes in Panamanian courtrooms and ministry offices as well as in plain sight in the hotel\u2019s lobby and corridors.", "title": "Panama Hotel Owner Declares Victory and Trump\u2019s Name Is Removed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nTHE FORCE, by Don Winslow. (William Morrow/HarperCollins, $16.99.) Detective First Grade Dennis John Malone and his fellow members of an elite Manhattan police squad are hardly better than the criminals they pursue. Our critic, Janet Maslin, named the book as one of her top picks of 2017, praising Winslow\u2019s \u201crealistic tableau of police privilege, pragmatism, racial bluntness, street smarts, love of partners and loyalty to what they call the Job.\u201d\n\nAN AMERICAN SICKNESS: How Healthcare Became Big Business and How You Can Take It Back, by Elisabeth Rosenthal. (Penguin, $18.) Rosenthal, a doctor and former reporter for The Times, blames drug prices and hospital bureaucracy for health care\u2019s outsize costs. She tells of Providence Portland Medical Center, a system founded by nuns, that turned into \u201ca weird mix of Mother Teresa and Goldman Sachs.\u201d\n\nFEVER DREAM, by Samanta Schweblin. Translated by Megan McDowell. (Riverhead, $16.) As Amanda is dying in a rural hospital, a creepy young boy, not her child, is at her bedside, pressing for details of recent, unnerving events. Strains of maternal and ecological horrors underpin this story; Amanda is preoccupied by \u201crescue distance,\u201d or her ability to protect her daughter, and a poisoned environment figures into a child\u2019s monstrous transformation.\n\nWHY? Explaining the Holocaust, by Peter Hayes. (Norton, $16.95.) Hayes, an emeritus professor at Northwestern, structures his exploration around eight questions, including: Why the Germans, and why the Jews? Why didn\u2019t they fight back more? Why didn\u2019t they receive more help? In this study, which our reviewer, Nicholas Stargardt, called a culminating \u201cfinal lecture,\u201d Hayes offers \u201can intellectually searching and wide-ranging study of the Holocaust in a modest, didactic form.\u201d", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE BOOK OF JOAN, by Lidia Yuknavitch. (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) It\u2019s 2049, and a satellite colony has been taken over by a despot who has claimed victory over a child-warrior, Joan. The story\u2019s narrator, Christine, is determined to honor Joan by burning her story into her own skin. Our reviewer, Jeff VanderMeer, praised this \u201cbrilliant and incendiary\u201d novel for its \u201cmaniacal invention and page-turning momentum.\u201d\n\nDEAR FRIEND, FROM MY LIFE I WRITE TO YOU IN YOUR LIFE, by Yiyun Li. (Random House, $16.) Li, an acclaimed MacArthur-award-winning novelist, charts her transformation into a writer in this series of essays. Written over a two-year period when she was critically depressed, this collection considers her relationship to English and her literary forebears, and explores two central questions: Why write? And why live?\n\nMY CAT YUGOSLAVIA, by Pajtim Statovci. Translated by David Hackston. (Vintage, $16.95.) In 1980s Yugoslavia, Emine, a young Kosovan bride, flees with her son, Bekim, to Finland. Years later, after growing up an outcast \u2014 the boy was not only a refugee, but also gay \u2014 Bekim is prodded to confront his family\u2019s history by his roommate: a talking cat, whom our reviewer, T\u00e9a Obreht, described as \u201ca vainglorious, labile, impulsively abusive bigot.\u201d\n\nA COLONY IN A NATION, by Chris Hayes. (Norton, $15.95.) Hayes, a white journalist for MSNBC, draws on his childhood growing up in the Bronx to explore race, subjugation and power. He frames his discussion around what he sees as two \u201cdistinct regimes\u201d in the United States: \u201cIn the Nation, you have rights,\u201d he writes. \u201cIn the Colony, you have commands.\u201d His analysis draws on the country\u2019s colonial roots to expose what he sees as a founding hypocrisy: White colonists fought for independence \u2014 and the right to subjugate others.\n\nI AM FLYING INTO MYSELF: Selected Poems, 1960-2014, by Bill Knott. Edited and with an introduction by Thomas Lux. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) In poems that touch on estrangement and desire, Knott embraced experimentation and provocation. This posthumous collection is helped along by Lux\u2019s introduction and appraisal, including what he called \u201cKnott\u2019s high imagination, great skills, singular music and crazy-beautiful heart.\u201d\n\nTHE HOME THAT WAS OUR COUNTRY: A Memoir of Syria, by Alia Malek. (Nation Books, $16.99.) Malek, raised by Syrian-American parents, came to Damascus in 2011 to reclaim her grandmother\u2019s apartment, and began reporting in secret on the war. She interviewed citizens and documented their courage; as she restored her family\u2019s home, she was forced to confront her fears for Syria\u2019s future.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nEVERYTHING UNDER THE HEAVENS: How the Past Helps Shape China\u2019s Push for Global Power, by Howard W. French. (Vintage, $17.) French, a former New York Times and Washington Post journalist, envisions a China-driven world, in which the superpower will try to recover from past humiliations. His account includes maps that show how China views the world, and considers how China\u2019s rivals should respond to its bid for dominance.\n\nNIGHT OF FIRE, by Colin Thubron. (Harper Perennial, $15.99.) A house is burning in Britain, and the fire kills all its inhabitants \u2014 among them a neurosurgeon, a priest and a photographer. The tenants share overlapping details, including themes and figures that recur across their lives. Taken together, their stories offer a meditation on collective memory, universal history and the role of society\u2019s outsiders.\n\nTESTOSTERONE REX: Myths of Sex, Science, and Society, by Cordelia Fine. (Norton, $15.95.) Fine gleefully dismantles preconceived ideas about the sexes, offering a history of how such stereotypes evolved, and questions why we get so much about gender wrong. (No, women aren\u2019t more cautious than men, and men aren\u2019t more status-obsessed than women.) Put simply: Biological sex, she writes, does not create \u201ctwo kinds of people.\u201d\n\nSIX FOUR, by Hideo Yokoyama. Translated by Jonathan Lloyd-Davies. (Picador, $18.) An unresolved kidnapping is still the shame of a Japanese police department 14 years later. Yoshinobu Mikami, a former detective now working in media relations for the department, is drawn into the case amid a push to put it to rest, and is grappling with the disappearance of his own daughter when he notices aberrations in the cold investigation. The novel, the first of Yokoyama\u2019s to be translated into English, was a best seller in Japan.\n\nANOTHER DAY IN THE DEATH OF AMERICA: A Chronicle of Ten Short Lives, by Gary Younge. (Nation Books, $15.99.) Younge reports out the lives and deaths of the 10 children and teenagers who were killed Saturday, Nov. 23, 2013. As a Briton who spent over a decade in the United States, he offers a valuable perspective: \u201cI had skin in the game,\u201d he writes. \u201cBlack skin in a game where the odds were stacked against it.\u201d\n\nWOMAN NO. 17, by Edan Lepucki. (Hogarth, $16.) In her second novel, Lepucki examines motherhood, identity and art. In Hollywood Hills, Lady is searching for a babysitter to care for her children while she finishes her memoir, about raising a teenager who does not speak. When Esther arrives for an interview, Lady is charmed and hires her on the spot, but Esther\u2019s behavior is a performance, with a shocking twist.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Six new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\n\n\nTHE IMAGINEERS OF WAR: The Untold Story of Darpa, the Pentagon Agency That Changed the World, by Sharon Weinberger. (Vintage, $17.) Few know much about Darpa \u2014 populated by a \u201cprocession of nuts, opportunists and salesmen,\u201d Weinberger tells us \u2014 but the group helped shape modern life and modern warfare. Some notable inventions: stealth aircraft, armed drones, Agent Orange and even the internet.\n\nEXIT WEST, by Mohsin Hamid. (Riverhead, $16.) In this elegant meditation on refuge, exile and home, a couple flee their unnamed country riven by civil war. Hamid weaves the surreal into his tale: Magic doors separate the dangers of home from the perils of a new life. The novel, one of the Book Review\u2019s 10 Best Books of 2017, is this month\u2019s pick for the PBS NewsHour-New York Times Book Club.\n\nSTEVEN SPIELBERG: A Life in Films, by Molly Haskell. (Yale, $15.) A feminist critic\u2019s take on the filmmaker focuses on his Jewish identity. Praising the match between biographer and subject, our reviewer, Lisa Schwarzbaum, wrote, \u201cThe exploration here is lively, the critic is deeply informed and she approaches her mandate with a calmness of inquiry that is a gift often bestowed on the outsider anthropologist impervious to tribal influences.\u201d\n\nUNIVERSAL HARVESTER, by John Darnielle. (Picador, $16.) At the local Video Hut where Jeremy works as a clerk, someone begins splicing violent, vaguely malevolent scenes into the tapes, and his Iowa town is shaken. As his friends and family are consumed by the phenomenon, Jeremy pursues the mystery, culminating in a final reckoning at the remote farm where the scenes were filmed. Darnielle, the lead singer for the band the Mountain Goats, counteracts the sinister with acute sensitivity in this story, his second novel.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSix new paperbacks to check out this week.\n\nCORETTA: My Life, My Love, My Legacy, by Coretta Scott King with the Rev. Dr. Barbara Reynolds. (Picador, $17.) A posthumous account, based on conversations between King and Reynolds over 30 years, explores King\u2019s private and public selves and the drive behind her push for perfection. Her viewpoint illustrates a brutal era as seen by a very specific type of African-American woman \u2014 an unsung backbone of the civil rights movement.\n\nONE OF THE BOYS, by Daniel Magariel. (Scribner, $15.) Two brothers watch their father descend into addiction after a bitter custody battle \u2014 which he described as winning \u201cthe war.\u201d As our reviewer, Antonio Ruiz-Camacho, wrote, the novel swells \u201cwith wisdom about the self-destructive longing for paternal approval and the devastating consequences of clinging to rotten models of masculinity.\u201d\n\nTHE SPIDER NETWORK: How a Math Genius and a Gang of Scheming Bankers Pulled Off One of the Greatest Scams in History, by David Enrich. (Custom House/William Morrow, $16.99.) In his fast-paced investigation, Enrich exposes the plot to manipulate Libor, the benchmark interest rate for banks across the world, which likely caused people to pay too much interest on everything from car loans to mortgages.\n\nAMERICAN WAR, by Omar El Akkad. (Vintage, $16.95.) In this debut novel, a (highly plausible) second civil war breaks out at the turn of the 22nd century. The United States has been ravaged by climate change: All of peninsular Florida is underwater, and the government has relocated to Columbus, Ohio. A ban on fossil fuels prompts parts of the South to secede. The conflict becomes personal for 12-year-old Sarat, a refugee who is groomed for insurgency after growing up in a shipping container, then watching her parents die.\n\nTHE NATURE FIX: Why Nature Makes Us Happier, Healthier, and More Creative, by Florence Williams. (Norton, $15.95.) The Romantics probably had it right: Spending time out of doors can be an antidote to industrialization\u2019s ill effects. Williams, a contributing editor for Outside magazine, recounts how the outdoors can do everything from lift moods to help veterans cope with PTSD, with plenty of satisfying detail.\n\nMISS BURMA, by Charmaine Craig. (Grove, $16.) In mid-20th century Burma, Benny, a character based on Craig\u2019s Jewish grandfather, marries Khin, a woman of a persecuted ethnic minority. The family \u2014 including the daughter, the \u201cMiss Burma\u201d of the title \u2014 becomes entwined with the country\u2019s fate, and the story addresses questions of identity, history and trust.", "title": "Paperback Row", "authors": ["Joumana Khatib"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Papua New Guinea, which is still recovering from a deadly earthquake last week, was hit by a powerful aftershock Wednesday that left an estimated 18 people dead or injured, adding to a mounting toll from the quakes, officials said.\n\nThe exact toll from the magnitude 6.7 aftershock that struck just after midnight was not immediately known, Papua New Guinea\u2019s National Disaster Center said.\n\nMore than 100 people were killed in a magnitude 7.5 earthquake that struck on Feb. 26, said Uvenama Rova, secretary general of the Papua New Guinea Red Cross. That quake and subsequent aftershocks were centered in the country\u2019s remote Highlands Region, and a complete picture of the scope of the destruction has been slow to emerge.\n\nAt least 67 people were killed in Hela Province in central Papua New Guinea, according to an estimate by the Hela Council of Churches. An additional 38 or 39 died in Southern Highlands Province, the Papua New Guinea Red Cross said.", "title": "Papua New Guinea Hit by Powerful Aftershock as Quake\u2019s Toll Mounts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 Before racing in the men\u2019s downhill on Saturday, strapped into a contraption that resembles a fitted chair suspended atop a single ski, Arly Velasquez closed his eyes at the starting gate. He had been waiting four years for this event, ever since he skidded down the track at the Sochi Paralympics in a horrific accident that battered his back and scarred his psyche.\n\nSurgery sidelined him for about two years. In the aftermath, he lost 25 pounds. He vowed to return, training with ferocity, and now, here he was. It was time to give thanks.\n\nHe spoke with the universe and the mountain, which he called the love of his life, and he thought about deceased loved ones from his native Mexico: his father, his grandmother, a cherished friend. As always, he dedicated his race to his mother and sister.\n\nOpening his eyes, Velasquez asked who he was. This moment, he told himself.\n\nThen down he went.\n\nRegardless of how Velasquez finished, he viewed the race as a triumph. Unlike others who either retired or did not make their team, Velasquez is among the subset of skiers here who endured a ghastly crash in the treacherous conditions at the Sochi Paralympics \u2014 or in the case of the British visually-impaired skier Millie Knight, on this very course at the Jeongseon Alpine Center in a test event last season \u2014 to try again, with an altered perspective on life and their sport.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThey overcame injuries that, on the whole, were not as debilitating as the psychological anguish.\n\n\u201cMentally, I think I\u2019m still dealing with it because now I feel the speed,\u201d Velasquez said. \u201cFour years ago, I remember I was not afraid at all. Every single time, I would go for the most speed that I could. And right now I just feel the speed, I\u2019m like, \u2018whoa, whoa, whoa.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Paralympic Skiers Confront the Scars That Linger From Sochi", "authors": ["Ben Shpigel"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "As director of the Palais Galliera for the last eight years, Olivier Saillard elevated the city of Paris\u2019s fashion museum to must-visit status, thanks to programming that encompassed everything from performance pieces by Tilda Swinton to the first Azzedine Ala\u00efa retrospective in the city. So the fashion community was stunned last summer when Mr. Saillard abruptly announced he was quitting in January to become artistic director of J.M. Weston, the French luxury men\u2019s shoe company.\n\nA guessing game about who might take his place followed. In December, the answer was revealed: a relatively unknown Spaniard named Miren Arzalluz.\n\nA political historian by training and Basque by birth, the 39-year-old Ms. Arzalluz had honed her curating skills for eight years as the head of the Crist\u00f3bal Balenciaga Foundation in Getaria, Spain. She said she was hesitant to apply for the Galliera post (she had been happy in her most recent job, as director of the Etxepare Basque Institute, a cultural center in San Sebasti\u00e1n).\n\nBut she ultimately pursued it because, she said, \u201cthis job was really going back to my thing.\u201d\n\nSo what is her thing? Here is her explanation:\n\nHow did you end up in a museum, if you studied politics?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI studied history, worked at a British think tank, earned my master\u2019s in comparative politics at the London School of Economics. It was just after 9/11. The world was in such turmoil. I started going to the Victoria & Albert Museum for fashion exhibitions. Then I remember walking into the National Portrait Gallery bookshop and seeing a whole section on fashion history. It was a revelation. When you study history, it\u2019s to be a social or political historian. But fashion? That was something that I had never dreamt of. I went to the Courtauld Institute of Art in Somerset House for a master\u2019s in history of dress, and fell in love with the subject. I thought: \u201cOh, this is what I want to do.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhy do you think fashion museums and exhibitions have become such hot tickets?\n\nFashion is a creative expression with which people find themselves much more identified \u2014 maybe feel closer \u2014 than with other creative expressions, like contemporary art. Because they have an intimate relationship with clothes, they feel they can have an informed opinion. In fashion museums, we always try to find a way to transmit certain ideas about what we are exhibiting: the history, the cultural context in which these items were created, the designer and the spectacle \u2014 because spectacle is so intrinsic to fashion. You have to balance the content, the rigor and the scientific approach with the spectacle.", "title": "Paris\u2019s Fashion Museum Gets a New Director", "authors": ["Dana Thomas"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Peterson nevertheless remained outside, and he told other officers arriving on campus to do to the same. \u201cDo not approach the 12 or 1300 building,\u201d Mr. Peterson said. \u201cStay at least 500 feet away.\u201d\n\nMr. Peterson resigned eight days after the shooting once the sheriff, Scott Israel, placed him under internal investigation for failing to try to confront Mr. Cruz as quickly as possible, as outlined in office policy. Mr. Peterson\u2019s lawyer defended his client a few days after his resignation, saying Mr. Peterson thought the gunman was outside the building \u2014 something that appears at odds with Thursday\u2019s timeline.\n\nThe 911 calls came into the sheriff\u2019s office through a regional county system. The first police officers to respond to the shooting came from the city of Coral Springs, which is near the school and operates its own, separate call system.\n\nUsing the adults as intermediaries, the recordings revealed, county dispatchers tried to gather information and make recommendations about how the students could shelter inside the school.\n\n\u201cTell her to be as safe as she can,\u201d a dispatcher told a woman whose granddaughter was in the school. \u201cIf she can find somewhere secure, then do so, but use her best judgment.\u201d\n\nOnly one of the recordings was of a call from inside the school \u2014 the one from the unidentified boy, who was speaking too softly for the dispatcher to hear him clearly.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sorry, I can\u2019t hear you,\u201d the operator responded. \u201cWhat\u2019s happening?\u201d\n\n\u201cSomebody is shooting up Stoneman Douglas,\u201d he said.", "title": "Parkland 911 Calls Are Released: \u2018Someone\u2019s Shooting Up the School\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe truth is, us kids, we just want to be the voice for the people we lost, or for people who don\u2019t think they have a voice,\u201d said Ms. Fuentes, who would like to eventually become an elementary schoolteacher. \u201cI am prioritizing this over college right now, I am prioritizing people\u2019s lives over my education.\u201d\n\nUniversity admissions offices declined to discuss individual applications, but many noted that civic engagement is a plus in considering whether to admit an applicant. In fact, some colleges publicly assured high school applicants in advance of last weekend\u2019s March for Our Lives rallies that their participation in peaceful protests would not harm admission chances.\n\nHarvard, for example, issued a statement: \u201cThe mission of Harvard College is to provide a deeply transformative liberal arts and sciences education that will prepare our students for a life of citizenship and leadership. Fundamental to our mission is our belief that students have the right to protest peacefully about issues of concern to them. Students who are disciplined for engaging responsibly in exercising their rights and freedoms would not have their chances of admission compromised or their admissions revoked.\u201d\n\nWhile on spring break this week, Mr. Hogg said he was leaning toward taking a gap year to focus on the midterm elections, hoping to rally young voters and target politicians supported by the National Rifle Association.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to get these laws changed to drive down the number of people who die by gun violence,\u201d he said. \u201cI can figure out everything else later.\u201d\n\nMr. Hogg said he does not believe his outspokenness had anything to do with the college denials, but admits it has been frustrating. In a late-night, March 16 message on Twitter \u2014 liked by at least 64,000 and retweeted nearly 6,600 times \u2014 Mr. Hogg told his followers, \u201cJust got rejected from another college but that\u2019s ok we\u2019re already changing the world. Goodnight everyone.\u201d\n\nHe added that he was comforting himself by eating chocolate muffins. The response was mixed, with some mocking his rejection, some encouraging him to take a gap year and others touting him as precisely the type of student colleges should recruit.", "title": "Parkland Activist Got Some College Rejections. He\u2019ll Major in \u2018Changing the World\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Sheriff Israel later defended his \u201camazing leadership,\u201d despite Mr. Peterson\u2019s inaction and other questionable decisions by his command staff, which set up a perimeter around the school before it was clear that the shooting was over, instead of moving in on the gunman.\n\nMr. Peterson was suspended and then resigned his post. In a statement released by his lawyer, he said that he thought the gunfire originated from outside the building, and reacted accordingly by waiting for the suspect there. But a detailed timeline based on radio dispatches and surveillance footage, released last week by the sheriff\u2019s office, suggested that he came to believe the shots might be coming from inside.\n\nIn one of his first communications, he said, \u201cBe advised we have possible, could be firecrackers, I think we have shots fired, possible shots fired by the 1200 building.\u201d Later, he said, \u201cWe also heard it\u2019s by\u2014 inside the 1200 building.\u201d\n\nMr. Peterson also told other law enforcement officers who raced to the school to stay outside. Coral Springs officers, the first to arrive on the scene, pushed into the building anyway. By then, the gunman had already fled.\n\nMr. Peterson\u2019s lawyer, Joseph A. DiRuzzo III, did not respond on Thursday to requests for comment on the video.\n\nNikolas Cruz, 19, a former Stoneman Douglas High student, was later arrested about two miles from the school. He has been charged with 17 counts of murder and 17 counts of attempted murder in the shooting.\n\nThe law enforcement response to the shooting was also hampered by the failure of Broward County\u2019s police radio system. The sheriff\u2019s office was unable to connect its radio transmissions with those of the Coral Springs police, who operate on a separate system.", "title": "Parkland Shooting Surveillance Video Shows Deputy Remained Outside", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI mean, we\u2019re kind of the faces of the movement,\u201d he said. \u201cTogether we kind of form an unstoppable force that terrifies them.\u201d\n\nHe added that he and Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez were being attacked \u201cbecause they know we\u2019re strong.\u201d\n\nHere are a few of the recent attempts to discredit the students.\n\nRedState, a conservative blog, questioned whether Mr. Hogg was even at the school on the day of the shooting, then backtracked Monday.\n\nRedState, a conservative blog, ran an \u201cupdate\u201d Monday evening to a story it had published that questioned whether Mr. Hogg was present at Marjory Stoneman Douglas during the day of the shooting.\n\nSarah Rumpf, a writer for RedState, had questioned Mr. Hogg after watching an interview where he said he rode his bike to the school on the day of the shooting to interview his classmates.\n\nThe bike trip was described in a Vox article written in February. It indicated that Mr. Hogg had been at school during the shooting, as widely confirmed by many news organizations. He had left campus and then rode his bike back that evening to interview classmates.\n\nVideo has shown that Mr. Hogg was in a closet during the shooting. Ms. Rumpf eventually found the article and video, and apologized.\n\nRedState struck through the old article, but did not describe the update as a correction, seeming to blame the misinformation on confusing reports elsewhere. The false report was spread by well-known conservatives, including Erick Erickson, who has contributed to The New York Times opinion section. Mr. Erickson later deleted his original tweet.\n\nA fake image of Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez tearing up the Constitution spread quickly over the weekend.\n\nThe doctored image of Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez ripping apart the Constitution of the United States, began to spread during the march on Saturday. It was falsified from a Teen Vogue image in which she was pictured ripping apart a paper shooting target.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe image, which exists in a gray area between meme and misinformation, was promoted on Gab, the alt-right alternative to Twitter, and by the right-wing actor Adam Baldwin.\n\nSome claimed the image to be satire, and similar memes of President Trump and other political figures appear across the spectrum. But the political scientist Emily Thorson has pointed out that their spread contributes to a climate of misinformation, even if those who see the images understand them to be fake.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Gonz\u00e1lez was criticized for wearing a Cuban flag patch.\n\nSteve King, the Republican congressman from Iowa, posted on Facebook about the Cuban flag sewn to Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez\u2019s jacket.\n\n\u201cThis is how you look when you claim Cuban heritage yet don\u2019t speak Spanish,\u201d the post said, \u201cand ignore the fact that your ancestors fled the island when the dictatorship turned Cuba into a prison camp, after removing all weapons from its citizens; hence their right to self-defense.\u201d It showed an image of her with the flag patch visible on her jacket.\n\nThe post and similar ones angered other survivors of gun violence and even some of Mr. King\u2019s fellow conservatives, who pointed out that the Cuban flag has long been used by dissidents from the Castro regime.\n\nMs. Gonz\u00e1lez retweeted Mr. Hogg\u2019s response to Mr. King: \u201cShe\u2019s a beautiful woman of Cuban descent and we love her. You would too if you ever got the chance to meet her.\u201d\n\nShe also retweeted another of Mr. Hogg\u2019s tweets, which called on Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican of Florida of Cuban descent, to respond to Mr. King.\n\nThe conservative writer and commentator Dan McLaughlin suggested that reporters ask Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez \u201cwhat the flag means to her and why she wears it.\u201d She did not respond to a call Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe name-calling continues.\n\nMany attacks on the Parkland students do not even pretend to focus on issues or substance. They include the false conspiracy trope that the students are paid actors. Sometimes their appearances and intelligence are mocked, including their efforts to get accepted to colleges this spring.\n\nOn Sunday, the conservative podcaster and vocal Trump supporter Bill Mitchell referred to Mr. Hogg as a \u201cDamien, Children of the Corn, Hitler-Youth type\u201d on Twitter.\n\nThe vitriol has sometimes backfired. A Republican candidate for the Maine State House dropped out of the race after calling Ms. Gonz\u00e1lez a \u201cskinhead lesbian\u201d and Mr. Hogg a \u201cmoron\u201d and a \u201cbaldfaced liar.\u201d\n\nIn a Tuesday interview, Nicole Hockley, whose young son Dylan was killed in the 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn., advised the students to ignore the attacks as much as possible. She recalled that she had faced conspiracy theories and personal attacks after her 6-year-old son was killed along with 19 other first graders at Sandy Hook Elementary School.\n\nShe remembered how that felt: \u201cAll I\u2019m trying to do is make it so this doesn\u2019t happen to other people and you\u2019re attacking me without a lot of basis.\u201d\n\nShe said that it was also important to hear rational criticism when trying to find common ground on the issues.\n\nWhen dealing with more reasonable opponents and critics she tries to de-escalate the conversations, she said, to learn more about what they think and educate them about her views.\n\n\u201cSometimes there\u2019s a new perspective that I haven\u2019t considered,\u201d she said, though she rarely finds such views persuasive. Still, she said, those conversations \u201ccan bear a lot of fruit.\u201d", "title": "Parkland Students Find Themselves Targets of Lies and Personal Attacks", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "TUESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 When someone makes his or her New York Times Crossword debut, I try to give the puzzle maker room to learn as I consider that first creation. Not everyone will have an immediate grasp of what makes interesting fill, or whether an entry might be jarring in a grid. Hopefully, with time, these constructors will adapt their word lists and learn to put aside themes until they can give them more thought.\n\nBruce Greig makes his debut in the New York Times Crossword today, and I was of two minds about his puzzle. I enjoyed the intent behind his theme, because who doesn\u2019t love animals? However, three of the five theme entries were troublesome to me for different reasons, and Mr. Greig\u2019s fill could, in truth, have been shinier. In addition, one crossing in the northeast seemed particularly tough for a Tuesday. That\u2019s the kind of thing he will get better at as time goes on, and I look forward to watching his constructing skills grow.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Greig offers us a set of five two-word phrases that involve animals and are things people can do, as he says in his notes below. All of the entries are clued as definitions.\n\nFor example, at 50A, we have TURKEY TROT, which is an \u201cOld ragtime dance.\u201d Similarly, a BEAR CRAWL is a \u201cCore-strengthening exercise performed on all fours.\u201d", "title": "Part of Who I Am", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "In the debate over how quickly to make American cars pollute less, the nation\u2019s auto-parts makers are now in open disagreement with the automakers that buy the countless transmissions, turbochargers and other components that make up modern automobiles.\n\nCar manufacturers would like to roll back standards dating from the Obama administration that mandate a deep cut in auto emissions. The rules, which require automakers to nearly double the average fuel economy of new cars and light trucks by 2025, are the single biggest step the United States has taken to combat climate change.\n\nAutomaker groups say the Obama-era rules fail to take into account the rising demand for larger vehicles, which pollute more and make progress on overall emissions more challenging. The Trump administration is reviewing the rules for possible revision.", "title": "Parts Suppliers Call for Cleaner Cars, Splitting With Their Main Customers: Automakers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "ADELAIDE, Australia \u2014 It was foolhardy to walk into Parwana Afghan Kitchen, in the inner suburbs of Adelaide, and assume that a table would be available. At 6 on a Tuesday night, the room was already half-full. Durkhanai Ayubi, a woman with huge dark eyes, shook her head firmly. \u201cWe\u2019re about to fill up,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd we have nothing during the second seating either.\u201d\n\nMy erroneous assumption was based on my experience of neighborhood family restaurants, and on my understanding of Adelaide as a dining city. There aren\u2019t many high-demand reservations in the South Australian capital. But Parwana excels at many things, and defying expectations is one of them.\n\nZelmai and Farida Ayubi, the owners, fled the war in Afghanistan in 1987 with their five children. Parwana is a multigenerational affair, and dining there (which I eventually managed to do, by calling well in advance) mimics the boisterous energy of visiting a large family\u2019s home. The restaurant opened in 2009 as a collaboration between parents who still treasured the food and traditions of their homeland, and children who had grown up almost entirely in Australia. Farida Ayubi is the chef, while her children and husband manage the front of house.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe small storefront space has a striking aesthetic, one that is worthy of a design magazine but stays true to the history and culture of the family. The floors are tiled in bright geometric patterns; the walls are covered in old family photos and various vintage flotsam, backed by colorful paint in primary colors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are two seatings each night, one at 6 p.m. and another at 8 p.m. This style of service adds to the homey feel of the place, with all the food coming out in one great flurry. Alcohol is strictly bring-your-own, and customers can sometimes be seen sharing bottles with nearby tables. The menu is quite short \u2014 rather than offer lots of dishes on any given evening, the menu changes throughout the week. There are always dumplings, rice, stews and grilled meats, but they vary.", "title": "Review: Parwana Afghan Kitchen in Adelaide, South Australia", "authors": ["Besha Rodell", "Australia Fare"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "One of the five passengers on the doorless helicopter hovering high above Manhattan had just leaned back toward the pilot to snap a photograph of his feet dangling in midair \u2014 a coveted shot known on social media as a \u201cshoe selfie\u201d \u2014 when the trouble started.\n\nThe pilot heard and saw warnings that the single engine of the AS350 Eurocopter was losing power. He considered trying to land in Central Park but decided that there were \u201ctoo many people,\u201d he told federal investigators, according to a report issued on Monday.\n\nSo, after yelling at the passengers to return to their seats, he circled around and glided toward the East River, making a mayday call as he cleared the buildings at the island\u2019s edge. The pilot, Richard Vance, said he deployed the floats on the helicopter\u2019s skids in preparation for impact, then reached down for the emergency fuel shut-off lever.\n\nBut he found that it had already been tripped, and beneath it he spotted a possible culprit, the nylon tether that had allowed his front-seat passenger to move around the cabin and take pictures unimpeded by doors or windows \u2014 or a seatbelt. Mr. Vance said that he moved the lever back to the on position and tried to restart the engine.", "title": "Passenger\u2019s Harness May Have Tripped Switch in Deadly Helicopter Crash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "BARCELONA \u2014 This Passover I am in Spain, land of Jewish ghosts. Spain was once a place where Jewish piety and poetry flourished. Now it is full of neglected sites and abandoned synagogues. Fewer than 50,000 Jews remain.\n\nAlthough Spain\u2019s history is particular, its outlines are sadly familiar. To travel almost anywhere in the world as a Jew is a tour of loss. It\u2019s a tour I\u2019ve been taking: I have spent several months on sabbatical seeking out vestiges of Jewish life in Asia, in the Middle East and now in Europe. Each country I\u2019ve visited \u2014 whether Buddhist, Hindu, Islamic, Christian or Communist \u2014 bears marks of a once flourishing Jewish population.\n\nWith rare exceptions, there are three kinds of synagogues that survive at all. There are those that whisper their history through the faded remnant of a Jewish star on a stone above the arch of a building now serving as a mosque, a church or a department store. There is the historic synagogue, no longer in use, that is preserved by the waning Jewish community or the government as a monument to what once was. And there is the synagogue that still functions, but all too often only for the handful of older people who still care, and who pray with the ever-present consciousness that no one will come after.", "title": "Opinion | Passover in a Land of Jewish Ghosts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Credit Photograph by Inez and Vinoodh. Styled by Jay Massacret", "title": "Past Issues of T", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "KUBINKA, Russia \u2014 Often in Russia these days, what is old is new again or, to be more specific, what is Soviet is new again.\n\nThe Youth Army, open to both boys and girls, is a militarized throwback to the Young Pioneers of the Soviet era. Meant to instill a sense of Communist zeal, the Pioneers are mostly remembered for their summer camps.\n\nThe Youth Army jettisoned the Communist bits, emerging as a kind of hybrid version of the scouts and a reserve officers training program, with an emphasis on patriotism and national service.\n\nThe trademark red endured.\n\nIf the Pioneers knotted red scarves around their necks, members of the Youth Army sport red berets bearing a pin of the organization\u2019s logo \u2014 the red star of the Russian Army superimposed on an eagle\u2019s head.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFormed in May 2016, the Youth Army, or \u201cYunarmia\u201d in Russian, has grown to include 190,000 children aged 8 to 18 and spread over all 85 regions of Russia.", "title": "Patriotic Youth Army Takes Russian Kids Back to the Future", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Burgundy and multicolor-dot boutonnie\u0300re. \u201cI\u2019ve tried to wear real flowers in the past, but they\u2019re either too big or too much, like I\u2019m going to the prom.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Aurore de La Morinerie\n\nYellow paisley boutonnie\u0300re.\n\nImage Credit Aurore de La Morinerie\n\nPurple and white-dot boutonnie\u0300re. \u201cMy favorite color is purple. It\u2019s the shade of royalty but it was also the color of my bicycle when I was a kid.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Aurore de La Morinerie\n\nWhite and red-dot boutonnie\u0300re.\n\nImage Credit Aurore de La Morinerie\n\nOrange boutonnie\u0300re. \u201cLapel flowers are supposed to make you more approachable. Steve Martin, one of my heroes, came up to me at a party once and told me he had a bunch of them, too.\u201d", "title": "Paul Feig\u2019s Lapel Pins, Illustrated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "My question: How will American steel workers fare as a result of this tariff? I heard the head of a steel workers union on NPR welcome this tariff and he sounded as if their prayers have been answered! \u2014 James C., Brooklyn\n\nPK: We will gain a few jobs in steel. But we\u2019ll lose jobs in lots of other, \u201cdownstream\u201d industries like autos. Most studies of the 2002 steel tariffs say that they cost jobs on net. So yes, steel workers get a little, but at what cost to other workers?\n\nI live very near a HUGE rusted-out steel plant, Bethlehem Steel in Steelton, Pa. I came here 44 years ago and it had already started its long sad road to its present obsolescence. Trump described this phenomenon in his rollout. He then had union workers talk about the production reductions to 20 percent from the heyday of domestic steel production.\n\nWhat source of funding could possibly come in and want to turn this 3.5-mile row of rusted barned eyesore around? Billions of dollars of investment would be necessary. The ideas of \u201cMaking America Great Again\u201d seem to be based in recreating the economy of the \u201950s, \u201960s and \u201970s. This and the return of coal to the high ridges of Pennsylvania seem a distant memory. Is revitalization of these old industries even a possibility? Aren\u2019t the jobs from the Rust Belt too expensive to get back? Or would another community\u2019s landscape be blighted instead? \u2014 CC, New Cumberland, Pa.\n\nPK: There\u2019s no way to bring back all those steel plants and steel jobs, even if we stopped all imports. Partly that\u2019s because a modern economy doesn\u2019t use that much steel, partly because we can produce steel using many fewer workers, partly because old-fashioned open-hearth plants have been replaced by mini-mills that use scrap metal and aren\u2019t in the same places. So this is all a fantasy.\n\nWhat is your critique of the anti-trade argument made by the Warren-Sanders wing of the Democratic Party: that free trade has been bad for the (proverbial) American worker and has been a significant contributor to America\u2019s rising income and wealth inequality? Is the answer simply that the benefits of free trade \u2014 lower prices generally \u2014 are diffuse and therefore underappreciated, whereas the costs \u2014 worker dislocation in particular sectors \u2014 are concentrated and thus easier to highlight? How much of America\u2019s increase in income inequality over the past half-century do you attribute to free trade?\n\nThank you for addressing this. \u2014 JG in CT, Greenwich, Conn.\n\nHow should we deal with the deindustrialization and loss of community that free trade has been causing? If tariffs are not the answer, what policies would you recommend? \u2014 L Marcus, New York", "title": "Opinion | Paul Krugman Explains Trade and Tariffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "His quirkiness and cunning gave backgammon currency.\n\n\u201cHe was a big part of the reason for the backgammon boom that happened in the late \u203270s and \u203280s,\u201d Erik Seidel, a stock trader who became a professional backgammon and poker player, said in an email.\n\nMr. Magriel could be philosophical on the subject of games. \u201cGames are controlled violence,\u201d he told Gambling Times magazine in 1978. \u201cYou can take out your frustrations and hostilities over a backgammon set, where the rules are clearly defined \u2014 in contrast to life, where the rules are not so well defined. In games, you know what\u2019s right and wrong, legal versus illegal; whereas in life, you don\u2019t.\u201d\n\nPaul David Magriel Jr. was born on July 1, 1946, in Manhattan. His father, an immigrant from Latvia, was librarian at the American School of Ballet and curator of dance archives at the Museum of Modern Art. His mother, the former Christine Fairchild, was an architect.\n\nAs a child, Paul was remembered as a savant who rarely answered questions and spoke only when he had something to say. After graduating from Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire and getting a perfect score on his college boards, he earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in math from New York University. At. N.Y.U., he was a fellow of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was later a National Science Foundation fellow at Princeton University, where he specialized in probability. He taught at the Newark College of Engineering (now part of the Newark Institute of Technology) from 1969 to 1973.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Magriel was married several times and divorced. His survivors include a son, Louis, with Ms. Oules, a French-born poker player, and a brother, Dr. Nicolas Magriel, a musician and teacher.\n\nMr. Magriel made his transition from chess to backgammon in Greenwich Village, at hangouts like the Olive Tree Cafe, while he was a doctoral student at Princeton and on track to become a math professor there.\n\n\u201cPsychologically, backgammon is very different from chess,\u201d Mr. Magriel said. \u201cIt\u2019s an exercise in frustration \u2014 you can make the right moves and lose, or you can make the wrong moves and win. And chess didn\u2019t have the gambling that I like.\u201d\n\nMr. Magriel grew increasingly gifted at backgammon, and consumed by it, cataloging, in the era before computers, thousands of potential playing strategies on index cards. And he ascended to more upscale venues, like the Mayfair Club on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where wagers might be made for $1,000 a point.\n\nGambling, too, became an obsession. Coupled with that were on-again-off-again brushes with substance abuse and a preoccupation with his own celebrity in the rarefied world of backgammon, his first wife, Renee Roberts, said.\n\n\u201cHe had an incredible ability to concentrate his intellect on the things he wanted to know,\u201d she said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe had so much promise, but the gambling took him to a place where everyone was relating to him because of his fame.\u201d\n\nWith Ms. Roberts, he wrote the seminal \u201cBackgammon\u201d (1976) and \u201cIntroduction to Backgammon: A Step-By-Step Guide\u201d (1978). His Times column appeared from 1977 to 1980.\n\nMr. Magriel made a small fortune from backgammon and later low-stakes poker. Playing poker, sometimes huddled disheveled over a table, he was known for uttering a signature \u201cQuack, quack\u201d when betting (usually a bet beginning with 22, the pair of numbers known in backgammon as double ducks and in poker as ducks).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis more enduring legacy to the card game was his formulation of the M-ratio \u2014 a measure, named for him, of how many chips a player needs to sit passively and make only compulsory bets.\n\nFor all his expertise in any game that required mental acuity, Mr. Magriel found backgammon to be \u201cthe most frustrating, the cruelest.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe fascinating thing about backgammon is that it represents an interesting paradox,\u201d he told The Boston Globe in 1977, adding: \u201cPeople who want a sure thing don\u2019t make it in backgammon. There are risks, yes, but on the other hand there is an enormous amount of control needed, something most gamblers lack.\u201d\n\nIn 1977, he played a promotional match at the 21 Club in Manhattan against George Plimpton, the adventurous journalist and author who liked to slip into other careers and write about his experiences. (Mr. Magriel\u2019s original backgammon tutor, years earlier, had been Mr. Plimpton\u2019s wife, Freddy Espy, a decorator and artist.)\n\nIn this match Mr. Magriel had a serious handicap: He was playing Mr. Plimpton while blindfolded.\n\n\u201cI have nothing at stake except the honor of my psyche,\u201d Mr. Plimpton told The New Yorker. \u201cMy tactics are going to be to talk as much as possible, ply him with drinks, and do everything else I can to befuddle him. If he loses track of a single piece on the board, I win.\u201d\n\nMr. Plimpton lost.", "title": "Paul Magriel, Who Was Called the Best in Backgammon, Dies at 71", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Netanyahu, who was visiting Washington, saw his troubles grow back home. A new study found that fewer couples are trying for a son: If they already have one child, a daughter, they are less likely to keep having babies. Above, infants in Kiryas Joel, N.Y.\n\nThe reason could be that there\u2019s less bias against girls, and possibly more bias against boys. In a recent Op-Ed, the comedian and actor Michael Ian Black argued that \u201cThe Boys Are Not All Right.\u201d\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. By now it\u2019s an all-too-familiar tool in the Trump playbook, offering payment (or in this case a pardon) for silence.\n\nIf this isn\u2019t obstruction of justice, what is?\n\nNANCY LEDERMAN, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is a lawyer.", "title": "Opinion | Paying for Silence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "What story could this image tell?\n\nUse your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration and post it in the comments.\n\nThen read the related article to find out what this picture is all about.", "title": "Peek", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Officials, though, are still investigating and are \u201copen-minded to all evidence\u201d that may be gathered, Mr. Field-Lament said. The superintendent did not address the possibility that Mr. Dombroski went over the edge voluntarily and did not comment on how Mr. Dombroski was able to reach the cliff \u2014 whether by climbing a fence or otherwise.\n\nAsked whether Mr. Dombroski might have been impaired because of medication, Mr. Field-Lament said that those details would be part of the continuing investigation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. Dombroski was found with his wallet and phone.\n\nThe F.B.I. is helping with the investigation, which is normal protocol for the Bermuda Police Service, Mr. Field-Lament said. Among other things, the bureau will help extract forensic information from Mr. Dombroski\u2019s cellphone.", "title": "Pennsylvania College Athlete in Bermuda Died From Fall, Officials Say", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\n\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nMissions in Africa continued, quietly\n\n\u2022 Two months after four U.S. soldiers were killed in Niger, a group of Green Berets and local forces killed 11 Islamic State militants in a previously undisclosed battle.\n\nNo American or Nigerien forces were harmed in the fight in December. But it indicates that the deadly Oct. 4 ambush was not an isolated episode in the West African nation, where the U.S. is building a major drone base.\n\n\u2022 Wednesday\u2019s news follows the revelation last week that the U.S. carried out four airstrikes in Libya between September and January that Africa Command failed to disclose at the time.", "title": "Pennsylvania, Elizabeth Holmes, March Madness: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMs. Vincenzi writes long, elaborate, mannerly books that aren\u2019t serious literature but aren\u2019t chick-lit either,\u201d Janet Maslin wrote in 2007 in The New York Times.\n\nWith strong female characters, the stories have their share of sex and romance, although Ms. Vincenzi\u2019s own life was a solid family affair: husband and four daughters.\n\n\u201cI know I must be a disappointment to people,\u201d she told The Evening Standard of London in 1993. \u201cThe rest of my life doesn\u2019t match up with the sort of books that I write.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPenelope Hannaford was born on April 10, 1939, in Bournemouth, on England\u2019s southern coast. She was the only child of Stanley Hannaford, a banker, and the former Mary Hawkey.\n\nShe grew up in Devon and took to writing early, creating her own magazine, called Stories, at age 9 and selling it at school.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe was working as a secretary at Vogue when she met Paul Vincenzi on a blind date. They were married in 1960.\n\nMs. Vincenzi was a journalist for much of her working life, writing and editing for newspapers and magazines and in 1972 starting a fashion magazine, Looking Good, with her husband.\n\n\u201cIt was the money that made me first have a crack at writing a book,\u201d Ms. Vincenzi told an interviewer in 1999. \u201cIt was the late 1980s, and quite a few women journalists \u2014 like Jilly Cooper \u2014 had written novels. So I decided to have a go myself.\u201d\n\nShe asked Ms. Cooper, whom she was interviewing for an article, for advice.\n\n\u201cI mentioned to Jilly that I had a story in mind, and she told me about her agent, Desmond Elliott,\u201d Ms. Vincenzi told The Irish Times in 1997. \u201cWhen I got back to the office, she had got him to ring me, which is unheard-of. I mean, you don\u2019t share your agent \u2014 it\u2019s like sharing your husband.\u201d\n\nAmong her most successful novels were \u201cAn Absolute Scandal\u201d (2007), \u201cThe Best of Times\u201d (2009) and a series known as the Spoils of Time trilogy (2000-2002). She also wrote two books of short stories.\n\nMs. Vincenzi said that she never knew how her books would end before she started them. Rather, she would just let the characters take the story where it wanted to go.\n\nOnce, she was walking with her husband near their cottage on the coast of Wales when she suddenly exclaimed, \u201cOh, my God, she\u2019s died!\u201d She had just had an epiphany about the fate of a character in \u201cSheer Abandon,\u201d a 2005 novel she was writing at the time.\n\nThe businesswomen and other female characters in her books were not based on personal experience, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI like using strong women because I envy them a lot,\u201d she told The Telegraph in 2014. \u201cI could never dominate a boardroom or anything like that.\u201d\n\nMs. Vincenzi\u2019s husband died in 2009. Her survivors include her daughters Polly Harding, Sophie Cornish, Emily Gunnis and Claudia Vincenzi.\n\nMs. Vincenzi was sometimes asked if she aspired to write more highbrow material. She didn\u2019t.\n\n\u201cI have a strong aversion to people saying the kind of novels I write are \u2018escapist,\u2019 \u201d she told The Birmingham Post in 1999. \u201cBooks ought to be escapist. I don\u2019t think there\u2019s anything wrong with a good old healthy slug of glamour and glitz.\u201d", "title": "Penny Vincenzi, Best-Selling British Author, Is Dead at 78", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 There is little doubt that the Defense Department needs help from Silicon Valley\u2019s biggest companies as it pursues work on artificial intelligence. The question is whether the people who work at those companies are willing to cooperate.\n\nOn Thursday, Robert O. Work, a former deputy secretary of defense, announced that he is teaming up with the Center for a New American Security, an influential Washington think tank that specializes in national security, to create a task force of former government officials, academics and representatives from private industry. Their goal is to explore how the federal government should embrace A.I. technology and work better with big tech companies and other organizations.\n\nThere is a growing sense of urgency to the question of what the United States is doing in artificial intelligence. China has vowed to become the world\u2019s leader in A.I. by 2030, committing billions of dollars to the effort. Like many other officials from government and industry, Mr. Work believes the United States risks falling behind.\n\n\u201cThe question is, how should the United States respond to this challenge?\u201d he said. \u201cThis is a Sputnik moment.\u201d", "title": "Pentagon Wants Silicon Valley\u2019s Help on A.I.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "SAN DIEGO \u2014 President Trump\u2019s welcome committee, a few hundred strong, many dressed in the colors of the flag, gathered on Tuesday at an industrial park not far from the border, and not far from the prototypes of the president\u2019s border wall.\n\nIt was part pep rally and part celebration of what they viewed, with the president\u2019s trip, as a fulfillment of a promise, the reason they voted for him: the construction of a wall to keep undocumented immigrants away.\n\nA few miles of freeway to the west, Mr. Trump\u2019s opponents gathered in the parking lot of a hilltop church, overlooking Mexico. The distance between the groups was by design. Organizers from each side said they wanted to stay separate, and avoid clashes.\n\nIt was Mr. Trump\u2019s first visit to California since his election in 2016, a state with which he has had particularly difficult relations. After landing on Tuesday, he inspected the series of wall prototypes, accompanied by United States Border Patrol agents on horseback, and talked about the need for a stronger barrier along the border. \u201cPeople are pouring in,\u201d he said. Andrew M. Cuomo.\n\nThe jurors sent a note to Judge Valerie E. Caproni of Federal District Court in Manhattan shortly after convening Monday morning for their seventh day of deliberations. They are tasked with deciding whether the aide, Joseph Percoco, is guilty of taking more than $300,000 in bribes from three executives with business before the state. The executives are also on trial.\n\n\u201cAfter considering the facts and the evidence with open minds, and using your instructions as a road map, we remain unable to reach a unanimous verdict,\u201d the note said.\n\nJudge Caproni acknowledged the jurors\u2019 declared impasse but instructed them to continue trying to reach a consensus.", "title": "Percoco Jury Says It Is Deadlocked, Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors\u2019 records showed that there were 837 calls made from Mr. Percoco\u2019s office phone over 68 days while he was working on the campaign.\n\n\u201cTo call that \u2018transition\u2019 work is simply not credible,\u201d Mr. DeFrancisco said.\n\nQuestions about Mr. Cuomo\u2019s knowledge of the alleged crimes loomed over the trial. The government\u2019s star witness, Todd R. Howe, a disgraced Albany lobbyist, described Mr. Cuomo as a mercurial, volatile figure; several witnesses said they understood Mr. Percoco to speak with the governor\u2019s authority.\n\nMr. Cuomo told reporters on Wednesday that he had not been implicated in the trial at all, despite Republicans\u2019 efforts to link his name to Mr. Percoco\u2019s.\n\n\u201cThere was absolutely no suggestion ever made that I had anything to do with anything,\u201d he said, adding that anyone who had followed the trial would see that \u201cthe governor\u2019s involvement was never mentioned. His name was never mentioned.\u201d\n\nAlthough prosecutors did not accuse Mr. Cuomo any wrongdoing, his name surfaced often at the trial. In one striking exchange, a prosecutor asked Mr. Howe whether he had ever suggested that federal officials look into Mr. Cuomo.\n\n\u201cDid you ever tell the government representatives that Andrew Cuomo deserves attention and scrutiny and is a bully?\u201d the prosecutor, Robert Boone, asked. Mr. Howe at first said he did not recall using those words, but when Mr. Boone pointed him to a document of his conversation with government agents in 2016, he said he remembered.\n\nIn addition to training a spotlight on Mr. Cuomo in a re-election year, the trial also revived questions about ethics oversight in Albany in general, and halfhearted efforts \u2014 by both the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo \u2014 to strengthen it. In his comments on Wednesday, Mr. Cuomo said the strongest measure of ethics reform would be to bar state officials from earning outside income, a measure that state legislators have rejected.\n\nIn 2014, Mr. Cuomo earned $376,667 \u2014 more than half of his total income \u2014 from an outside source, in the form of payment for his memoir, \u201cAll Things Possible: Setbacks and Success in Politics and Life.\u201d To date, he has earned more than $750,000 from the book; it has sold about 3,200 copies, according to NPD BookScan.", "title": "Percoco\u2019s Improper Use of State Office Was for \u2018Transition Matters,\u2019 Cuomo Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. \u2014 Lexi Thompson is smiling and having fun again at the ANA Inspiration.\n\nA year after a rules violation cost her four strokes in regulation in an eventual playoff loss, Thompson shot a 4-under 68 on Thursday to finish three strokes behind the leader, Pernilla Lindberg.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if I would say it\u2019s a relief,\u201d Thompson said. \u201cI was just really looking forward to just playing this week. I love coming here.\u201d\n\nThompson also again overpowered Michelle Wie on a hot afternoon at Mission Hills, four years after routing Wie in a final-round showdown for her first major title.\n\nWie fought dizzy spells on the front nine, finishing with a 75 that left her in danger of missing the cut.", "title": "Pernilla Lindberg Leads ANA Inspiration, With Lexi Thompson Close Behind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The president said he had done nothing wrong. He said the leaked recordings had been edited in a \u201cselectively biased way that gave the impression that the government was offering public works in exchange of votes.\u201d\n\nAnalysts said that the resignation did not bode well for Latin America, where Peru\u2019s economic stability has contrasted with growing political turmoil.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week.
