Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is not a good precedent for Peru or for the region, that an opposition could essentially force out the president this way,\u201d said Michael Shifter, the president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy group in Washington. \u201cPeru has been a puzzle and a paradox \u2014 it\u2019s been such an economic performer, but you have such weak political institutions.\u201d\n\nIt is still unclear whether Congress will decide to accept Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s resignation or choose to impeach him anyway. This happened to Mr. Fujimori, who resigned in 2000 after fleeing to Japan. Congress rejected his resignation and impeached him instead. Years later he faced trial in Peru, and the country\u2019s Supreme Court sentenced him to 25 years in prison on human rights violations.\n\nLawmakers on Wednesday expressed anger that Mr. Kuczynski had not apologized.\n\n\u201cWe hoped that his resignation letter would have at least some self-criticism of the mistakes and crimes he may have committed,\u201d said Marco Arana, who leads the leftist Broad Front. \u201cInstead, he just plays the victim in his letter and doesn\u2019t admit anything.\u201d\n\nMr. Kuczynski was set to be replaced by his vice president, Mart\u00edn Vizcarra, who is also serving now as ambassador to Canada. Mr. Vizcarra himself was once forced by Congress to resign when he served in Mr. Kuczynski\u2019s cabinet, although opposition lawmakers have in recent weeks spoken highly of him. Mr. Vizcarra has not spoken publicly about the controversy, and it was not clear on Wednesday whether he was even in Peru.\n\n\u201cThis was a government that carved its tomb from Day 1,\u201d said Eduardo Dargent, a political scientist at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru. \u201cLooking forward, it\u2019s very unclear what will happen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kuczynski, a former Wall Street banker and World Bank economist who was educated at Oxford and Princeton, campaigned in 2016 on a liberal platform that promised economic growth and \u201csocial revolution.\u201d He narrowly beat Keiko Fujimori, the daughter of the former leader.\n\nLast year, Congress accused Mr. Kuczynski of \u201cpermanent moral incapacity\u201d for profiting from contracts with Odebrecht, the Brazilian corporate giant now troubled by scandal, during a period in the early 2000s when he served as a cabinet member. Mr. Kuczynski said he was merely a shareholder in a company that profited from Odebrecht deals.\n\nCongress\u2019s impeachment effort had been enthusiastically supported by the Popular Force, the party led by Ms. Fujimori.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Mr. Kuczynski avoided removal in December, thanks to Ms. Fujimori\u2019s brother Kenji Fujimori, a congressman who split with his sister and carried enough lawmakers to his side to save the president. Two days after the failed ouster, Mr. Kuczynski pardoned Alberto Fujimori on medical grounds.\n\nThe apparent deal allowed Mr. Kuczynski to save his political career in the short term, but it soon created a much larger problem, analysts say. By pardoning the elder Mr. Fujimori, after his conviction as a human rights abuser, the president alienated supporters who had remained with him.\n\n\u201cIt was his willingness to do these dirty deals to stay in power that was key\u201d to his loss of support, said Jo-Marie Burt, a political scientist who studies Latin America at George Mason University in Virginia. \u201cHe betrayed many of the promises he said he would uphold.\u201d\n\nThe sentiment was echoed widely in Peru on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cI feel sorry about this, but this is the end that Mr. Kuczynski deserves,\u201d said Pedro Cateriano, a former prime minister who counseled the president during the first impeachment attempt.\n\nThe tapes, recorded by an ally of Keiko Fujimori who pretended to be toying with the idea of switching sides, appeared to trace graft to the highest levels of government. They showed Kenji Fujimori, and some people close to him, offering favors and public works projects in exchange for political support.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one video, Bienvenido Ram\u00edrez, a congressman, bragged about all the benefits he had received because of his support of Mr. Kuczynski.\n\n\u201cIn less than a week I got the public works that I wanted,\u201d Mr. Ram\u00edrez can be heard saying. He also mentioned that a government official had been assigned to help expedite any projects that were of interest to him.\n\nAnother government official tried to explain how to earn big rewards while in Congress.\n\n\u201cImagine, brother, that in a $100 million public works that you receive only 5 percent,\u201d said Freddy Arag\u00f3n, a government official who was fired Tuesday night. \u201cBrother, you get $5 million without lifting a finger.\u201d", "title": "Peru\u2019s President Offers Resignation Over Vote-Buying Scandal", "authors": ["Marcelo Rochabr\u00fan", "Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Michelle from Rockville wonders if family views have an influence:\n\nI am a 16 year old who feels strongly about politics, but I don\u2019t think the voting age should be lowered. At 16, teens are highly impressionable and easily succumb to peer pressure. Someone might vote for a candidate just because their friends or parents like them. Even though the article says that teens have the cognitive ability to make informed decisions, I still believe that the majority of 16 year old\u2019s would not make individual decisions. I consider myself a democrat, and I feel strongly about my views, but would I still feel the same way if my parents weren\u2019t democrats as well? I can\u2019t help wondering what I would be like if I was raised in a conservative household. Would I have the same views?\n\nLaura Armedaris from Washington, D.C., said younger teens were more than capable:\n\nI\u2019m 15 years old and I know several people that are 16/17 and are far more educated than some people over 18. If the question is if we are capableI believe we are, we are not stupid and especially with social media lots of us are involved with politics sharing our opinions but it hardly means anything when we can\u2019t even vote. We are giving political speeches at our walkouts, emailing congress, writing letters and marching for justice, we are more than capable to vote\n\nSammie from California said lowering the voting age would give more teens an opportunity:\n\nTeenagers today are much more exposed to politics thanks to the internet. They can follow it and form opinions on it easily because it\u2019s at their fingertips. If they\u2019re passionate about the issue being voted upon then they should be able to take part in the decision making. Teenagers aren\u2019t oblivious to what\u2019s going on in their country anymore and want to take some kind of action. Lowering the voting age would give the younger people of America opportunities to be apart of the community political-wise.\n\nPrashamsha Rayamajhi from Danvers, Mass., said both sides have merit:\n\nI think that both sides have equally convincing evidence. On the one hand, 16 year olds are still young, and barely forming their own political opinions. Many don\u2019t know what to believe in, and many others like to live in ignorance of political issues. However, time and time again, we have seen teenagers age 16 or 17 achieve amazing feats. In regards to the Florida shooting, the \u201cchildren\u201d are the ones moving for change in a broken system, when adults refuse to do so. Teenagers this age are full of hope; they are passionate and strong-willed, and some apply these qualities to political issues as well. Even though both sides make sense, I believe that the voting age should be lowered to age 16. In these times, children are maturing much faster. There are many sixteen year olds with more rational and sophisticated opinions than adults. Also, I think that although sixteen year olds may just be forming informed political opinions, they should have a say in issues that drastically affect their lives, like gun violence. And overall, younger people are the future of the world. Change usually comes from the younger generation.\n\nShelby Johnson from Massachusetts thinks younger teenagers would vote how their parents do:\n\nAs a 16 year old myself, I do not think that the voting age should be lowered to 16. While I do accept that 16 and 17 year olds are able to make rational decisions using \u201ccold\u201d cognition in a low-pressure situation such as voting, I do not think that their scientific capability to make choices should make them eligible to vote. The primary reason that I am opposed to 16 and 17 year olds being able to vote is that they are not yet legal adults. For the majority of teens, this means that they are under the care and control of their parents. While a huge population of young people is interested in current events and politics, and stays up to date on unbiased views of various topics, there are still large numbers of 16 to 17 year olds whose only knowledge of political controversy comes from their parents. Many young people have been fed their parents\u2019 ideas since birth, and when living at home have no source of outside knowledge. If teens who are not yet legal adults and therefore not yet independents are able to vote, I think that a large portion of this age group\u2019s voters would simply vote however their parents tell them to.\n\nBryce Hilton from the United States thinks the answer is an easy one:\n\nGo to a high school and interview 3 random 16 year olds. Ask them current political questions. 2 out of the 3 will have no clue what you\u2019re talking about. Enough said.\n\nDaniel Gonzalez from St. Cloud, Fla., thinks the research in the article is incomplete:\n\nThe status quo must be maintained due to the fact that elections aren\u2019t always \u201ccold cognition\u201d scenarios. Elections have been well known to be hectic with the emphasis of political and public pressure being based on the choice of the individual, therefore the brain relies on \u201chot cognition\u201d since the would-be voter is being pressured by peers and organizations. Studies have already shown that at 16 the part of the brain that processes \u201chot cognition\u201d is not fully developed and makes them more susceptible to emotional outbursts and the bias in decisions that follows, especially when a presidential candidate tries to poke at emotions to rally people together. This part of the brain is more developed in a 21 year old and is less likely (not never) to vote based on emotions.\n\nAnaly from St. Cloud would vote if the age were lowered:\n\nIf the voting age were to be lowered to 16, I would vote. Many of the decisions that voters decide on now are what teenagers enter once they are considered \u201cadults\u201d. College students, just as high school students, have the same ability to be swayed by their peers and are quick to make impulsive decisions if they are unaware of the topic. If voters are voting on education, being a student, I wouldn\u2019t want a 60 year old high school drop out making decisions on what will occur with my education. Also, how come we can register to vote at 16, yet not be able to vote? In order to register, I believe that some sort of maturity and responsibility is needed simply to reach out and desire to vote in the future.\n\nAnthe Dalkouras from Danvers thinks most 16-year-olds are not ready to vote:\n\nI do not agree with the writer\u2019s stance that the voting age should be lowered from eighteen to sixteen. At this age I do believe that some 16-year olds are capable of making these political decisions on what to vote for, but that does not pertain to most. At this age there are many 16-year-olds who do not pay attention to current events and what is happening in politics. Also, that they truly do not have a grasp on the meaning of the events. If I was able to vote at 17, I do not believe that I would because I do not necessarily pay attention to government actions unless I am talking about it in one of my classes. Also, 16-year-olds are not a legal adult yet so they are still living at home listening to their parents opinions. This could sway them in one direction instead of making their own decision on what to vote for. I believe that the younger audience is easier to direct in one direction by feeding them false information about a certain topic. Many have not been exposed to the harsh world of politics and what occurs in order to win votes. High school students are still able to have a voice even if they are not allowed to vote. There are the high school students from the school shooting in Florida speaking out on their opinions of gun control and what should happen to control it. These students are making a difference even though they do not have the right to vote.\n\nAizik Van Horne from Tempe says teenagers need and deserve a voting voice:\n\nI believe that the voting age should be lowered. Teenagers voices should be heard and people think that our opinions are unimportant and they look over them. Teenagers are close to being adults and expect to be safe during that period of time. When a gun is easier to get that a drivers license that is unacceptable. Gun laws should be raised to be stricter and more efficient than letting people get guns with disorders and mental disabilities. We expect to be safe and not have rampaging people with guns running around and killing people. Even if we are not adults our opinions should be heard!!!!!!!!!\n\nTucker G. Oakley from Wilmington, N.C., said 16-year-olds were too young, plain and simple:\n\nShould 16-year-olds be able to vote, let me take a moment to laugh. The issue with that is, we\u2019re kids. It might sting some to be called that, but that is because it\u2019s true. We aren\u2019t as focused or passionate on politics to make specific decisions that could affect the country as a whole. Sure, this can deal a lot with gun-control and drugs, but a few hundred thousand teens still aren\u2019t loud enough to reach the government. NRA, they control what happens with guns because they have the time, money, and power to toy with whatever they want. Drugs, I don\u2019t think we need to see a bunch of stoned kids walking around campus just because \u201cit\u2019s legal\u201d. Besides, most of us will just bandwagon off of somebody else\u2019s idea of society because we don\u2019t want to understand. Our job as student is to study so we can have a greater education that the generation before us, so we have a chance to make this country better for those who come after us.\n\nSolomon from Saco, Me., answered affirmatively:\n\nI agree with the writer\u2019s proposal to lower the voting age to 16. School shootings are happening more often then they should, so there needs to be an end to them. Having kids that are of the age of 16 and are in school would be a perfect time for them to start voting because when the kids are in school they would know what to vote on.\n\n_________", "title": "Pet Instagram, Adult Dorms and Overlooked Obituaries: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "He is unaware he\u2019s being photographed. The unposed portrait has been made in bright sunshine on a busy street, and we can see other people, blurred, behind him. The man is tanned, with a head of thinning white hair and a short white goatee. His collared shirt is pale, striped and open at the neck. He has rosebud lips and somewhat worried brows that make him appear lost in thought or on the verge of making a decision. Out of the flux of the street, a unique event has been preserved: this man, this moment, this mien.\n\nNow look at another portrait. It\u2019s the same man. Placed side by side with the first portrait, it immediately raises new questions. The look is almost the same: the tanned face, the small mouth, the dark, slightly furrowed brows. With his narrowed eyes, he seems a bit more preoccupied. His white goatee is fuller and more neatly shaped, giving him the debonair look of a knight in a Renaissance painting. In this second portrait, the man is all buttoned up, and he wears an ocher bow tie. Behind him this time is a different crowd, and instead of the taxi seen in the first picture, there is an armored truck.\n\nIt\u2019s not that hard to go out into the street and take a stranger\u2019s picture. It is legal and, with the right equipment, technically simple. But how do you arrive at two pictures of the same person, with almost the same expression, on what seem to be different days? These photographs were made by the Danish artist Peter Funch, and they are part of a series of many such pairs. For nine years, from 2007 until 2016, Funch hung around Grand Central Terminal and watched commuters during the morning rush between 8:30 and 9:30 a.m. Using a long-lensed digital camera, he made countless portraits, an intriguing face here, another one there, yet another over there. He began to notice repetitions, the same people, the same faces, the same gestures, the same clothes. Each person was in the self-enclosed reverie of getting somewhere. The photos were all taken in May, June or July, in bright summer sunshine. The resulting project, published last year in a monograph titled \u201c42nd and Vanderbilt,\u201d is named for the street corner on which Funch stationed himself. It contains dozens of pairs of portraits (and a few in sequences of three), all of strangers.\n\nFunch\u2019s book contains women and men, the old and the young, people of all races and social classes. It looks like New York. One woman strides by with her chin raised and eyes closed. She wears a green blouse in one photo and a purple sweater in another. A man in a dark suit wears a peach-colored shirt in one photo and a blue one in the other, and he holds a cellphone in his right hand in both portraits. A woman crosses her arms, twice; another smokes, twice; another smiles, twice. There are two men walking side by side, and the same men walking side by side again. Do they know each other? They seem not to. There are three young women in medical scrubs, and surely they do know each other. One of them checks her phone, twice; another glances downward, twice.", "title": "Peter Funch Sees the Patterns in the People on the Street", "authors": ["Teju Cole", "On Photography"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "His father had arrived in the United States at 17, speaking no English and without any money. He took a job as a dishwasher for the Union Pacific Railroad, working, eating and sleeping in the caboose.\n\nIn 1923 the elder Mr. Peterson opened a Greek diner named the Central Caf\u00e9 in Kearney, a small city in south-central Nebraska, and operated it for 25 years. Young Peter began working the cash register at age 8. He grew up in Kearney, nearsighted and colorblind. He graduated from Longfellow High School at the top of his class and won admission to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.\n\nAt M.I.T. he found he had no aptitude for engineering and, after he was expelled for plagiarizing a term paper, he went to Northwestern University, from which he graduated summa cum laude in 1947.\n\nCorporate Chief at 34\n\nMr. Peterson began his business career at Market Facts, a Chicago research company. In 1951, he received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago Booth School of Business before returning to Market Facts as an executive vice president.\n\nFor a while, Mr. Peterson was a lecturer at the University of Chicago, where he encountered the economists Milton Friedman and George J. Stigler, both of whom would win Nobel Prizes, as well as George P. Shultz, who was dean at the time. Mr. Shultz later held three cabinet posts under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan and was instrumental in bringing Mr. Peterson to Washington.\n\nMcCann-Erickson, the large advertising agency, hired Mr. Peterson in 1953 as director of marketing services; a year later, at 27, he became a vice president. He eventually turned down the McCann-Erickson presidency to become executive vice president at Bell & Howell. There, under Charles H. Percy, later a senator from Illinois, he helped the company regain ground from its arch-competitor, Eastman Kodak.\n\nAt 34, Mr. Peterson was named president of Bell & Howell. (He recalled that when his mother witnessed the crush of photographers around him after he was named president, she asked him \u2014 calling him \u201cPetey\u201d \u2014 \u201cWhy put up with this craziness when you could go back to Kearney and own your own business?\u201d She was referring to the family diner.)", "title": "Peter G. Peterson, a Power From Wall St. to Washington, Dies at 91", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "And it made Mr. Munk immensely wealthy, though there are few good estimates of his fortune. He controlled Barrick without holding most of its shares. In 2013, it was estimated that he owned only 0.2 percent of its stock.\n\nBut Mr. Munk led the life of an international billionaire. He had three homes in Ontario and houses in Paris and Switzerland, where he remained a keen skier late in life, and took to the sea in a 140-foot-long yacht, the Golden Eagle.\n\nHis associates included Prince Charles; fellow billionaires like Bernard Arnault, the chairman and chief executive of the French luxury goods maker LVMH; and Brian Mulroney, the former Conservative prime minister of Canada.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Barrick expanded globally, Mr. Munk often dealt with governments with widely condemned human-rights records. He devoted part of Barrick\u2019s annual meeting in 1996 to praising the economic program of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former military dictator in Chile, although Mr. Munk subsequently condemned General Pinochet\u2019s human rights abuses in a letter to the newspaper The Globe and Mail.\n\nAn electrical engineer by training, Mr. Munk often attributed his success at Barrick to his lack of a mining background. That meant, he said, that he made decisions about his company almost entirely from a financial perspective, introducing measures that offset the inevitable financial risks of mining.\n\n\u201cFor 100 years it was assumed that a successful mining company had to be run by miners,\u201d he told The Economist in 2014. \u201cWhat I did know was how to run a business. The investor doesn\u2019t give a damn about what you know about mining. They want results.\u201d\n\nFor all of Barrick\u2019s later success, it was his stereo equipment company, Clairtone \u2014 Mr. Munk\u2019s first big venture and his greatest humiliation \u2014 that most shaped his approach to business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cClairtone was the single-most formative experience in my life, because it was so traumatic,\u201d he told The New York Times in 1993.\n\nHe set off to manufacture stereo equipment in 1959 with David Gilmour, a friend, and the help of 2,800 Canadian dollars from the father of Mr. Munk\u2019s first wife, the former Linda Gutterson. The audio gear became popular internationally as much for its futuristic design as for its sound. Clairtone stereos appeared in films starring Frank Sinatra and Sean Connery.\n\nThe company\u2019s success led to a move from Toronto to a large manufacturing plant in Nova Scotia, drawn in part by the province\u2019s offer of 7 million Canadian dollars in assistance. Overwhelmed by a variety of problems, however, including an unsuccessful move into television and poor management of the company\u2019s growth, the founders were ousted in 1968. Clairtone collapsed six years later.\n\nMr. Munk was born into a Jewish family in Budapest on Nov. 8, 1927. When the Nazis occupied Hungary in 1944, Mr. Munk\u2019s grandfather Gabriel, a chocolate distributor and real estate investor, used most of the family fortune to secure train passage to Switzerland for 14 family members, including Mr. Munk and his father, Lajos.\n\nThe trip was organized by the Hungarian journalist Rezso Kasztner, who was credited with saving thousands of Hungarian Jews by shepherding them to Switzerland.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy then Mr. Munk\u2019s parents had long been divorced, and his mother, the former Katharina Adler, did not join the group. She was later sent to Auschwitz but survived.\n\nBy some accounts, his mother is credited with suggesting that Mr. Munk join an uncle in Canada. At 20, he left Switzerland for Toronto on a student visa to study at the University of Toronto. The odd jobs that financed his studies included selling Christmas trees.\n\n\u201cWhen he landed in Canada, he was stunned by what he viewed as a relatively pleasant atmosphere,\u201d said Anna Porter, a friend, former publisher and author of a book about Kasztner and his wartime rescue missions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThroughout his business career, Mr. Munk publicly bemoaned the sale of Canadian corporations to foreign investors. \u201cHe chose to see himself as a nationalist,\u201d Ms. Porter said.\n\nHis first marriage ended in divorce. He is survived by his wife, the former Melanie Jane Bosanquet, whom he married in 1973; five children, Anthony, Nina, Marc-David and Natalie Munk and Cheyne Munk Beys; and 14 grandchildren.\n\nIn addition to Barrick, Mr. Munk controlled Trizec Properties, whose holdings included the Watergate complex in Washington until 2006. Mr. Munk retired from Barrick in 2014, but he continued to insist in interviews that he had never stopped working.\n\nAs a philanthropist, Mr. Munk donated about 300 million Canadian dollars (about $232 million in American money today) to a variety of medical and academic centers. He also devoted much of his time to turning a former naval base in Montenegro into a superyacht marina.\n\nWhen he sold the marina in 2016, Mr. Munk told The Globe and Mail that when he first arrived in Montenegro, appearing to many as a Canadian interloper, he was greeted with more than suspicion.\n\n\u201cI was threatened physically,\u201d he said. \u201cThey spat on my taxi.\u201d But he won the Montenegrins over, he said. \u201cToday they love what we\u2019ve done,\u201d he said.", "title": "Peter Munk, 90, Dies; Built World\u2019s Biggest Gold Mining Company", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s been a crazier two years than I would have thought,\u201d Mr. Thiel said in his new Midtown Manhattan apartment, which is so far up in the clouds that it literally looks down on Trump Tower.\n\nDespite the proximity, the mutual enthusiasm between Mr. Thiel and Mr. Trump seems to have cooled. After Mr. Thiel spoke at the Republican National Convention in 2016, there were unsourced media reports that said Mr. Trump wanted to put him on the Supreme Court. But now even photo ops are rare.\n\nThe investor said he had last spoken to the president \u201ca few months ago.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t talk that often,\u201d he said, but added, \u201cI can get access anytime I want.\u201d\n\nThe Trump whom Mr. Thiel touted at the Republican convention was a candidate who would \u201cend the era of stupid wars and rebuild our country,\u201d move us past \u201cfake culture wars\u201d and start projects the equivalent of the Apollo space program. That does not seem to be the president he got.\n\n\u201cThere are all these ways that things have fallen short,\u201d Mr. Thiel said. But he said he had no regrets about his endorsement. \u201cIt\u2019s still better than Hillary Clinton or the Republican zombies,\u201d he said, referring to the other candidates.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe White House did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nMr. Thiel is routinely labeled a libertarian. On a bookshelf in the apartment, as if in confirmation, is a hardback copy of Ayn Rand\u2019s \u201cAtlas Shrugged,\u201d the bible of the movement. A gift, he said.\n\nA lesser-known but possibly deeper influence was the French philosopher Ren\u00e9 Girard, who taught at Stanford University when Mr. Thiel was an undergraduate there. For 15 years, on and off, Mr. Thiel sat in on a study group about Mr. Girard\u2019s ideas. Mr. Girard believed human beings were deeply mimetic, which is to say they copy one another.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very anti-Ayn Rand: There are no self-contained autonomous figures,\u201d Mr. Thiel said. \u201cOur desires are not our own. They get shaped powerfully by the society around us.\u201d\n\nIt was this illumination that helped him see the potential of Facebook \u2014 where people could find out in intimate and addictive detail what their friends were up to \u2014 when it was barely a year old. He was the first outside investor, buying 10 percent of the company for $500,000.\n\nHe sold most of his holdings in 2012 as Facebook went public. A few months ago, with Facebook\u2019s market capitalization at about $500 billion, he sold most of what he had left.\n\nLast summer, there was a flap when a memo by a fellow board member, Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, appeared in The New York Times. In the memo, Mr. Hastings wrote to Mr. Thiel that he displayed \u201ccatastrophically bad judgment\u201d in supporting Mr. Trump.\n\nMark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, did not ask him to step down from the board, and reports that he wants to leave the board are incorrect, Mr. Thiel said, noting that among other things he brings \u201cideological diversity.\u201d He declined to say exactly how much or what kind of advice the Facebook board was offering Mr. Zuckerberg, but defended the company from criticism that it was slow to wake up to what the Russians did.\n\n\u201cRemember when Trump said the election was going to be rigged? People said that was crazy \u2014 \u2018How dare you question the integrity of the electoral process?\u2019 That was the view of most of the people working at Facebook, too,\u201d he said. \u201cThey did not think things were so hackable. It was a mistake, but an understandable mistake.\u201d Facebook declined to comment.\n\nThe anger now being turned on Facebook, Mr. Thiel argued, is less about Russia specifically and more about tech arrogance \u2014 its failure to do so much for so many. It is a sentiment that helped put Mr. Trump in the White House.\n\n\u201cThe Trump campaign slogan, \u2018Make America Great Again,\u2019 was perhaps the single most offensive thing you could say to Silicon Valley,\u201d he said. \u201cSilicon Valley says the future is going to be better than the past. That is the propaganda, if you will.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA friend of his in Silicon Valley had the idea of running for governor of California this year. Mr. Thiel\u2019s advice was that he had better have a good answer to this question: Why is tech good for the average person in California? The answer, he cautioned, couldn\u2019t be a banality, such as \u201cit\u2019s making us more connected,\u201d and it couldn\u2019t be utopian, such as \u201cit\u2019s going to cure all diseases.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? He declined to identify the friend, but it is well known in tech circles that Sam Altman, the president of Y Combinator, the prominent start-up accelerator, was thinking about running. Mr. Altman confirmed it was him and said he had decided not to run \u201cfor many reasons.\u201d\n\nThere is a big painting of a cresting wave in Mr. Thiel\u2019s living room, and it might as well be a visual metaphor for what is going on in big tech now.\n\n\u201cHaving some ambition that transcends just making money is a critical thing for a company,\u201d he said. \u201cBut there is some point where it gets crazy and self-delusional.\u201d He added that the companies \u201care probably in some trouble \u2014 maybe it\u2019s a little, maybe it\u2019s a lot.\u201d The prospect of government regulation looms.\n\nIn 2015 and 2016, Mr. Thiel gave $300,000 to Josh Hawley, who was campaigning to become Missouri\u2019s attorney general. Mr. Hawley won, and in November he opened an antitrust investigation of Google. A spokeswoman for Mr. Hawley, a Republican who is now challenging the state\u2019s Democratic senator, Claire McCaskill, said there was \u201cno connection\u201d between Mr. Thiel\u2019s donation and the investigation. Google declined to comment.\n\nThe news last month that Mr. Thiel is moving from San Francisco to Los Angeles reflects a shift that is as much mental as literal. Getting out of the tech bubble, he figures, will give him more clarity about his investments.\n\n\u201cNetwork effects are very positive things, but there\u2019s a tipping point where they fall over into the madness of crowds,\u201d he said.\n\nAnother of Mr. Thiel\u2019s contentious ideas was destroying Gawker, the online publisher. He secretly financed the privacy lawsuit that Hulk Hogan, the former pro wrestler, filed against the media company, which Mr. Hogan won. That led to Gawker\u2019s bankruptcy in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA news operation that specialized in deflating the arrogance of Silicon Valley should have been to Mr. Thiel\u2019s liking. But he argues that his philosophy is consistent here.\n\n\u201cGawker was trying to cut people down to size for not conforming,\u201d he said. \u201cThe ability to speak and not have every word you say get distorted, to have wrong ideas and then be able to correct them \u2014 these notions were powerfully undercut by Gawker.\u201d\n\nMr. Thiel is still pursuing the remnants of Gawker in court, which has prompted accusations that he wants to remove all of its content from the internet as a final victory.\n\nHe denied this. \u201cTerry Bollea, a.k.a. Hulk Hogan, is still owed some money from the Gawker sale, and that is what I am trying to get,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t want the archives. I don\u2019t think it makes sense to destroy them. Preserve them, study them instead.\u201d", "title": "Peter Thiel\u2019s Money Talks, in Contentious Ways. But What Does He Say?", "authors": ["David Streitfeld"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 Phan Van Khai, a Soviet-trained Vietnamese prime minister who helped his country transition away from a state-dominated economy and build a stronger relationship with the United States, died last Saturday in Ho Chi Minh City. He was 84.\n\nMr. Khai\u2019s death was widely reported this week in Vietnam\u2019s state-controlled news media. Nhan Dan, the official newspaper of the country\u2019s governing Communist Party, reported that the cause was old age.\n\nMr. Khai, who served as prime minister from 1997 to 2006, had more formal training in economics than previous prime ministers, but also \u201ca practical knowledge that was closely linked to the economic life of the people,\u201d said Le Dang Doanh, one of his former economic advisers.\n\nAmong other accomplishments, Mr. Khai helped Vietnam weather the impacts of the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998, Dr. Doanh said. He also endorsed a landmark 1999 law that made it easier for ordinary people to open businesses, Dr. Doanh added, and played a central role in negotiating Vietnam\u2019s 2007 entry into the World Trade Organization.", "title": "Phan Van Khai, First Vietnamese Prime Minister to Visit Washington, Dies at 84", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In October, Ms. Fergus delivered the first check, a $10,000 payment to St. Paul Public Schools, the district said. Combined with the $35,000 donation last week, Philando Feeds the Children has covered the debts of at least 1,788 students, the district said on Sunday night.\n\n\u201cThis fund-raiser demonstrates the kind and generous spirit our community members hold in their heart for the students of S.P.P.S.,\u201d Toya Stewart Downey, a school district spokeswoman, said in an email.\n\nMr. Castile knew firsthand the hardships many students face. In 2002, at 19, he joined the nutrition services department of St. Paul Public Schools. He became a supervisor in 2014 and had been working at J.J. Hill for several years at the time of his death. On Sunday, his mother, Valerie Castile, shared a news article about the charity\u2019s work on her Facebook page.\n\n\u201cGOD Gave US Your Spirit Of Love And Kindness,\u201d wrote Ms. Castile, who did not return a call seeking comment on Sunday. \u201cYour Legacy Will Live Forever!!\u201d\n\nIn the school district, about 70 percent of the roughly 37,000 students are enrolled in free or reduced-price lunch, a federal program that pays for a student\u2019s entire meal or a large part of it. Students whose families are part of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, commonly known as food stamps, automatically receive free lunches at school. Others are eligible based on income: A student in a family of three would qualify for free lunch if the household made less than $26,546 a year.", "title": "Philando Castile Charity Pays Off Lunch Debt for Hundreds of Students", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Philip Kerr, a Scottish-born writer whose popular novels feature a Nazi-era detective named Bernie Gunther, whose hard-boiled style made him literary kin to Philip Marlowe, Raymond Chandler\u2019s classic private eye, died on Friday in London. He was 62.\n\nThe cause was bladder cancer, according to his publisher, G. P. Putnam\u2019s Sons.\n\nThrough 13 novels, including \u201cGreeks Bearing Gifts,\u201d which will be published next week, Mr. Kerr drew Gunther as a savvy and cynical Berlin criminal police investigator who hates Hitler and quits his job when the Nazis take over. He becomes a private detective, but is then pressed into gumshoe jobs for the propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels and Reinhard Heydrich, a principal architect of the Final Solution.\n\nGunther is \u201cone of crime fiction\u2019s most satisfying and unlikely survivors: the good cop in the belly of the beast,\u201d Jane Kramer, The New Yorker\u2019s longtime European correspondent, wrote last year.\n\nSome of the novels bring Gunther into postwar intrigues in Argentina, Cuba, France, Greece and other countries.", "title": "Philip Kerr, 62, Author of \u2018Gunther\u2019 Crime Novels, Is Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "MANILA \u2014 Denouncing what he called efforts to paint him as a \u201cheartless violator of human rights,\u201d President Rodrigo Duterte said on Wednesday that the Philippines was withdrawing from the treaty that established the International Criminal Court.\n\nThe Hague-based court said last month that it was opening a preliminary inquiry into allegations that Philippine officials committed mass murder and crimes against humanity in the course of Mr. Duterte\u2019s crackdown on narcotics. Thousands of people have died at the hands of police officers or unknown gunmen since Mr. Duterte took office in 2016 promising to kill drug dealers and addicts.\n\nIn a written statement released on Wednesday, Mr. Duterte accused the court of violating \u201cdue process and the presumption of innocence.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe acts allegedly committed by me are neither genocide nor war crimes,\u201d he said. \u201cNeither is it a crime of aggression or a crime against humanity. The deaths occurring in the process of legitimate police operation lacked the intent to kill.\u201d He said the killings by police officers, which the police say now number more than 4,000, were carried out in self-defense.", "title": "Philippines Plans to Withdraw From International Criminal Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAre there times when you think using your phone while you\u2019re with other people is rude? If so, what are they and why do you think being on your phone in these situations is inappropriate? If not, why not?\n\nCan you give any examples of a time when you were with someone and they were paying more attention to their phone than to you? How did it make you feel? How did you respond?\n\nWhat guidelines for phone etiquette do you follow in your day-to-day life?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to learn more about the research on phone manners.", "title": "Phone Manners", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe acclaimed photographer Nicholas Nixon abruptly retired from the Massachusetts College of Art and Design midsemester following allegations of inappropriate behavior, the college announced this month.\n\nMr. Nixon, 70, is perhaps best known for \u201cThe Brown Sisters,\u201d a series of portraits documenting four sisters \u2014 one of whom is his wife \u2014 for 40 consecutive years. He started taking them in 1975, the same year that he began a part-time professorship at MassArt.\n\nDavid Nelson, the college\u2019s president, wrote in a letter to students and faculty that the school had received allegations against Mr. Nixon, prompting it to start investigating whether he violated Title IX, the federal law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of gender. Mr. Nixon subsequently decided to retire, and is no longer on campus.\n\nThe letter did not detail the nature of allegations against Mr. Nixon. But in a statement reported by The Boston Globe, Mr. Nixon\u2019s lawyer, Bruce A. Singal, indicated that the college is investigating reports that Mr. Nixon allegedly made inappropriate comments to students and staff members.\n\n\u201cNick has been widely known for a provocative teaching style in a creative art school environment that he believed was inspiring to his students,\u201d Mr. Singal said in the statement. \u201cThis investigation \u2014 which has not even begun yet \u2014 is to determine whether or not Nick made inappropriate comments in the classroom.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Brown Sisters\u201d is currently on display at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. Other photographs of his, which are often black and white and provide intimate looks into American life, have been collected by museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the National Gallery of Art and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.", "title": "Photographer Nicholas Nixon Leaves MassArt Following Allegations", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGenerously meaty slices of shiitake mushrooms pickled with tamari, vinegar and seaweed have been given a salty tang by Shed, a restaurant and food purveyor in Healdsburg, Calif. A bowl of them with toothpicks for stabbing can go on that antipasto platter, they add zest to grilled-cheese sandwiches or panini, and you could dice them to scatter on seared fish, just as you would capers: Pickled shiitake mushrooms, $18 for 13.5 ounces, healdsburgshed.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Pickled Shiitake Mushrooms With a Salty Tang", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner", "David Tanis"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "This is Jessica Love\u2019s debut picture book, and every choice she makes \u2014 the spare text, a color palette both muted and lively, full-bleed pages that make even subway cars and apartment rooms feel as expansive as the ocean \u2014 imbues the story with charm, tenderness and humor. In the joyous conclusion, the pair make their way to a mermaid parade (an annual event at Coney Island in Brooklyn) and join the spectacle. The final illustration shows the abuelas from the first spread, transformed into mermaids. Alongside Juli\u00e1n, readers learn that anyone can be a mermaid: All it takes is love and acceptance, a little imagination and a big swishy tail.\n\nPhoto\n\nI WALK WITH VANESSA\n\nBy Kerasco\u00ebt\n\n40 pp. Schwartz & Wade/Random House. $16.99.\n\n(Picture book; ages 4 to 8)\n\n\u201cI Walk With Vanessa,\u201d by the husband-and-wife team Kerasco\u00ebt (\u201cMalala\u2019s Magic Pencil\u201d), is not merely sparse in its text, it\u2019s wordless. On the title page, we see Vanessa and her family moving in to their new home. Then spreads set at school show her new-kid anxiety and loneliness, which take an ugly turn when she is bullied.\n\nA girl who witnesses the bullying (the \u201cI\u201d of the book\u2019s title) decides to walk Vanessa to school the next day. They are joined by a few friends, then more, and eventually a whole crowd, until it is the bully who is left out. Young readers will enjoy searching for the bully, whose red-and-white striped shirt is surely a wink at Martin Handford\u2019s Waldo.\n\nBrown-skinned Vanessa, her tan friend and the white bully are all big-headed moppets drawn with loose lines and plenty of personality. The abundance of white space and use of color keeps the focus on the characters; it also sets up a stunning nighttime spread of the girls depicted through their respective bedroom windows. I immediately thought of Maya Angelou\u2019s words that \u201cwe are all more alike \u2026 than we are unalike\u201d \u2014 a stirring example of how an image can both reflect and extend the individual reader\u2019s experience.\n\nThe book has a subtitle (\u201cA Story About a Simple Act of Kindness\u201d), as well as two sections of back matter about bullying, directed at young readers and their adults. That makes it seem as though the visuals alone weren\u2019t trusted to carry the message, but perhaps those segments of text were added for readers who prefer images to be supported by words.\n\nTHE BREAKING NEWS\n\nBy Sarah Lynne Reul\n\n48 pp. Roaring Brook. $17.99.\n\n(Picture book; ages 5 to 8)\n\nBE KIND\n\nBy Pat Zietlow Miller\n\nIllustrated by Jen Hill\n\n32 pp. Roaring Brook. $16.99.\n\n(Picture book; ages 3 to 6)\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth \u201cThe Breaking News\u201d and \u201cBe Kind\u201d lean more heavily on words. In \u201cThe Breaking News,\u201d Sarah Lynne Reul\u2019s timely text begins with a young girl\u2019s reminiscence: \u201cI remember when we heard the bad news.\u201d Next we see dark-skinned Mom and Dad staring in alarm at the words \u201cbreaking news\u201d on the television. The news is unspecified. The girl looks worriedly at her parents, capturing the story\u2019s essence with efficiency and poignancy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe girl\u2019s emotions are sensitively portrayed throughout. At first enthusiastic about trying to make those around her feel better, she grows discouraged when her attempts fail. \u201cMaybe there is nothing I can do to help in a big way. I feel small.\u201d\n\nThere are mildly jarring bumps in the text: an abrupt switch from recollection to present tense, and a confusing line that appears to be from the girl\u2019s consciousness when it should rightly be attributed to her teacher. By contrast, the heavily outlined images are steady and solid, including the closing spreads of the girl and her family planting flowers, which circle back to a scene at the beginning, affirming the resilience that can result when small acts are focused on community.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe wordiest of the four books also skirts closest to the didactic edge. \u201cBe Kind\u201d begins when curly-headed Tanisha becomes an object of derision after spilling her grape juice at school. The narrator, a dark-haired child with pale skin, flounders in an effort to comfort her, then wonders, \u201cWhat does it mean to be kind anyway?\u201d\n\nThe narrator imagines possibilities, from baking cookies for a lonely neighbor to \u201ctelling Desmond I like his blue boots,\u201d then muses: \u201cSticking up for someone when other kids aren\u2019t kind is really hard. (And really scary.)\u201d\n\nTanisha and Kerasco\u00ebt\u2019s Vanessa are both depicted as dark-complected, with lighter-skinned children befriending them. White-savior narratives? Or examples of the dominant culture taking responsibility for dismantling racism? The distinction is one ripe for discussion.\n\n\u201cBe Kind\u201d concludes with the child\u2019s hope that a small act of kindness toward Tanisha might \u201cspill out of our school\u201d and expand to encircle the world. The vignettes portraying \u201cthe world\u201d include references to familiar architecture (pyramids, the Taj Mahal, pagodas), presumably to assist in identifying location; also, alas, with the potential to reinforce stereotypes. Even so, the combination of Pat Zietlow Miller\u2019s earnest text and Jen Hill\u2019s attractive images is likely to find a receptive audience among adults wanting to spark a conversation with children. These days, it seems more important than ever for books to show young people how to act with thoughtfulness, civility and kindness \u2014 growing up as they are amid powerful adults who consistently fail to do so.", "title": "Picture Books to Help Kids Weather Our Age of Anxiety", "authors": ["Linda Sue Park", "Children S Books"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Tina Kiefer, a professor of organizational behavior at the University of Warwick in the United Kingdom, fell upon the exercise accidentally, while leading a workshop full of executives who did not speak much English. Since then it has been adopted by organizational psychologists across the world.\n\nIn terms of gender, the results are almost always the same. Both men and women almost always draw men.\n\n\u201cEven when the drawings are gender neutral,\u201d which is uncommon, Dr. Kiefer said in an email, \u201cthe majority of groups present the drawing using language that indicates male (he) rather than neutral or female.\u201d\n\nAnd yet, her clients often insisted that what they meant by \u201che\u201d is actually \u201cboth.\u201d\n\nSeveral researchers in organizational psychology who have had a similar experience with this exercise decided to investigate further. How might holding unconscious assumptions about gender affect people\u2019s abilities to recognize emerging leadership? What they found, in a study posted by the Academy of Management Journal, seems to confirm what many women have long suspected: getting noticed as a leader in the workplace is more difficult for women than for men. Even when a man and a woman were reading the same words off a script, only the man\u2019s leadership potential was recognized.", "title": "Picture a Leader. Is She a Woman?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "There is plenty of drama in Ivor Prickett\u2019s images from the ravaged streets of Mosul, Iraq, or in Meridith Kohut\u2019s continuing chronicle of Venezuela\u2019s slide into chaos, illness and hunger. The details tell the grim story, but in an era when websites, social media feeds and text messages spread millions of images daily, we face the danger not of compassion fatigue, but of turning the page \u2014 or turning away \u2014 out of sheer visual exhaustion.\n\nPicture editors know they are vying for time and attention. But they also know that in the best cases, there will be singular images and remarkable stories that stand out, that make it hard to turn away or to shut down. They make you feel, whether it is Tomas Munita\u2019s moody images of the unending wait for change in Cuba; Daniel Berehulak\u2019s documenting of the merciless, vigilante-style war on drugs in the Philippines; or Newsha Tavakolian\u2019s portraits of her fellow Iranians as they go about daily life against the backdrop of geopolitical drama.\n\nTo feel is to engage not only your eyes, but also your mind and heart. It is to experience outrage, demand action or even just understand the common humanity we share with someone whose life is cut short, upended or ignored. It is to say: We see you, we hear you.", "title": "Pictures From The Times to Make You Face \u2018Hard Truths\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Your Dog\n\n\u272e / \u272e \u272e \u272e \u272e \u272e\n\nThis is not a pillow. Please do not scream into your dog unless necessary. If you must scream into your dog, do so into the fleshy middle area, not the front or back. You may find screaming into your dog less isolating than screaming into an inanimate object, since your dog is familiar and loves you. If it does not bite you out of fear, the dog may detect your pain and lick your forehead after it resituates to move away from your screaming face. Dogs are an anomaly of goodness in an otherwise blighted universe. Getting a dog was an excellent idea \u2014 good for you.", "title": "Opinion | Pillows to Scream Into, Rated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think pineapple has grown in popularity as a cocktail ingredient due to the naturally occurring balance of acidity and sweetness in the fruit,\u201d said Ben Rojo, bar manager at the George Washington.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAlso,\u201d said Damon Boelte, \u201cit froths up.\u201d Mr. Boelte, another pineapple fan, is an owner of Grand Army, a bar in Brooklyn. \u201cIt gives this airy lightness to the drink. It\u2019s airy, but not watery.\u201d\n\nThe fruit, which is just now coming into season, is a regular presence at the Washington, D.C., bar 2 Birds 1 Stone. And while the bar director, Adam Bernbach, appreciates pineapple\u2019s soft mouth feel and versatility (he mixes it with everything from Scotch to gin), he also thinks it works a little psychological magic on customers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt takes a lot of the seriousness away, in terms of how a drink\u2019s perceived,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s a warmth to it, in terms of how people react to it. Pineapple is just fun.\u201c\n\nFor Sarah Morrissey, the bar manager at Frenchette in TriBeCa, that fun can be transporting. \u201cYou could be sitting in a dark bar in New York in the dead of winter and order a pineapple heavy cocktail, and it truly takes you somewhere else,\u201d said Ms. Morrissey, who loves the fruit so much that her nickname is Little Pi\u00f1a Girl.\n\nPineapple juice wasn\u2019t completely ignored during the early years of the cocktail revival. The innovative bartenders Audrey Saunders and Marco Dionysos, for instance, used it in signature drinks like the Tantris Sidecar and the Chartreuse Swizzle.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut two recent developments have helped push the ingredient into wider use: One is the resurrection of the tiki bar aesthetic, and its absorption into the wider cocktail culture. The other is the rising popularity of tequila and mezcal, agave spirits that get along swimmingly with pineapple.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s definitely an affinity,\u201d said Jim Kearns of the Greenwich Village bar Slowly Shirley, where pineapple lives in several drinks. \u201cYou get those tropical notes off tequila and mezcal pretty readily, and pineapple falls right into that.\u201d\n\nAll the bars said their pineapple drinks were popular. But with whom, exactly? According to Mr. Kearns, everyone. \u201cVery few people seem to be pineapple-averse,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a real crowd-pleaser.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But the bar manager, Aaron Polsky, didn\u2019t have to tell customers the combination was a good one. \u201cSaturday night, you get the tequila-and-pineapple people,\u201d he said. \u201cThey order it like a screwdriver.\u201d\n\nRecipe: Our Lady of the Harbor\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. The deal called for the group to pay off the Weinstein Company\u2019s debt, which it believed totaled around $225 million. In return, the group would receive the majority of the studio\u2019s assets, which include \u201cProject Runway\u201d and a 277-film library.\n\nBut once the buyers began looking deeper into the Weinstein Company\u2019s finances, they discovered that it had more debt than they had been led to believe, according to two people briefed on the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss confidential information. Additional liabilities totaling between $55 million and $65 million were discovered, including $27 million in unpaid residuals and profit participation; and $20 million in accounts payable.\n\nThe Weinstein Company\u2019s board said in a statement that it was \u201cdisappointed\u201d by the investors\u2019 decision to pull out of the agreement.", "title": "Planned Sale of the Weinstein Company Collapses Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "On Friday night, Mr. Trump reiterated on Twitter that \u201cthe deal with North Korea is very much in the making,\u201d and that it would be, \u201cif completed, a very good one for the World.\u201d\n\n\u201cTime and place to be determined,\u201d he said.\n\nThe White House\u2019s muddled message highlighted the confusion sowed by Mr. Trump\u2019s on-the-spot decision to meet Mr. Kim. Having built its North Korea policy on sanctions and threats of military action, the administration must now learn the language of engagement.\n\nIt also served as a reminder of how many hurdles lie ahead before Mr. Trump\u2019s spontaneous decision on Thursday afternoon leads to a meticulously staged meeting between the American president and the dictator who rules the world\u2019s most reclusive country.\n\n\u201cNorth Korean offers typically come with caveats and asterisks that need to be examined,\u201d said Daniel R. Russel, a former Asia adviser to President Barack Obama. \u201cWe all hope that the multiyear pressure campaign has had an effect, but we shouldn\u2019t prematurely celebrate.\u201d\n\nAt the State Department, where some diplomats quietly applauded Mr. Trump\u2019s gamble, there was a fear that more hawkish aides in the White House might throw up further hurdles to the meeting. The White House, they said, has invested more in sanctions and military options than in diplomacy. Officials there have in the past expressed frustration about what they viewed as the Pentagon\u2019s reluctance to provide options for a military strike on the North.\n\nWith all the potential traps and internal misgivings, some officials said they believed the chances of a meeting between the two leaders actually happening were less than 50 percent.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s decision stunned allies and his own advisers, not least Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, who was caught unaware while traveling in Africa when the president accepted Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Tillerson\u2019s lack of involvement in the announcement underscored how marginalized the State Department has become in North Korea policy. The department\u2019s chief negotiator on the North, Joseph Yun, resigned from the Foreign Service last week.\n\nOther State Department officials insisted that Mr. Tillerson had not been singled out; Mr. Trump blindsided all of his advisers. And the secretary, speaking to reporters in Djibouti, argued that Mr. Trump\u2019s decision was not the bolt from the blue that it seemed.\n\n\u201cThis is something that he\u2019s had on his mind for quite some time, so it was not a surprise in any way,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. \u201cHe\u2019s expressed it openly before about his willingness to meet with Kim Jong-un.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Sanders said the president was in a \u201cgreat mood\u201d after two momentous days in which he had announced sweeping tariffs on steel and aluminum \u2014 fulfilling a cherished campaign promise \u2014 and had scrambled the equation on his most pressing foreign policy challenge.\n\nPrivately, however, Mr. Trump sounded muted rather than buoyant, according to a person familiar with a round of calls he made Thursday evening to solicit feedback about his surprise move.\n\nWhile the president told people he liked the concept of a once-in-a-lifetime breakthrough, the person said, he struck a less boisterous note than he usually does publicly when he places a bet on himself.\n\nBut in the past 24 hours, the president has told confidants that he felt vindicated by his decision to accept the invitation for a meeting, suggesting his approach has led to a potential new path.\n\nSome advisers in the room with Mr. Trump and the South Korean envoys \u2014 including Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster \u2014 expressed concerns about a meeting, according to a senior official. But nobody vocally opposed it.\n\nMr. Trump also had to mollify a rattled ally, Japan, which got no advance notice of his decision. In a call, the president reassured Prime Minister Shinzo Abe that the United States would not ease its pressure campaign on North Korea. Mr. Abe, officials said, asked for a meeting with him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s call on Friday morning with President Xi Jinping of China was more relaxed. The Chinese have long called for direct talks between the United States and North Korea. American officials said they expected that Mr. Xi would offer Beijing as a venue for the meeting.\n\nThe location is one of a number of unresolved issues, including the size and composition of the delegations and the agenda. Some officials said Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim would set a broad framework for the talks, and leave the actual negotiating to subsequent sessions with lower-level officials. Even the logistical issues might require a couple of preliminary meetings, they said.\n\nStill, the lack of direct communication between Pyongyang and Washington was a yellow light to some experts. The two countries communicate through independent channels, one of which \u2014 the \u201cNew York Channel\u201d \u2014 goes through North Korea\u2019s mission to the United Nations.\n\nIn recent months, these channels have been used mostly for communications about Americans detained in North Korea. Mr. Yun, the former State Department negotiator, used such a channel to negotiate the return of Otto F. Warmbier, the college student from Cincinnati who suffered an irreversible brain injury while held in prison in Pyongyang.\n\nAt some point, officials said, they expected North Korea to send a message about the Trump-Kim meeting through one of the channels. The administration will parse it carefully to assess if it aligns with the message brought to Washington by the South Korean envoys.\n\nSouth Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, has tried tirelessly to broker a meeting between American and North Korean officials. He sent his envoys \u2014 Chung Eui-yong, the national security adviser, and Suh Hoon, the director of the intelligence service \u2014 to the White House almost immediately after they returned from their meeting with Mr. Kim in Pyongyang.\n\nThe message from the envoys, American officials said, was that the economic sanctions had really crippled the North. Mr. Kim, one official said, referred to North Korea as a poor country.\n\n\u201cThis was the most forward-leaning report that we\u2019ve have had in terms of Kim Jong-un\u2019s \u2014 not just willingness \u2014 but his strong desire for talks,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. \u201cWhat changed was his posture in a fairly dramatic way that, in all honesty, came as a little bit of a surprise to us.\u201d", "title": "Planning Begins for Kim Jong-un Meeting Some Trump Aides Believe Will Never Happen", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Inside her 1,800-square-foot apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Ms. Bullene, 37, cares for over a hundred plants. She has installed a green divider wall \u2014 a six-foot-by-six-foot steel shelving unit filled with a dozen wooden planter boxes and over 50 plants \u2014 that separates her living room from her in-home office, as well as a terrarium and several other large-scale plants, including an 11-foot-tall Ficus Audrey tree, to help break up the open layout of the space.\n\nBut for Ms. Bullene, the plants do more than help define the apartment; they make her home healthier, too. \u201cPlants boost serotonin levels and dissolve volatile airborne chemicals,\u201d she said. \u201cThey actually make healthier spaces for humans to inhabit.\u201d She cited a 2010 study from Washington State University that breaks down the benefits of indoor plants, including cleaner air and lowered stress levels.\n\nAlong with her floor-to-ceiling plant divider wall in the living room, she also employed a combination of plants that release oxygen at night in her bedroom \u2014 including aloe vera and sansevieria \u2014 so that she and her husband can breathe cleaner air while they sleep.\n\nMillennial-minded companies are also going to great lengths to integrate greenery into their offices.\n\nThe Etsy headquarters in Dumbo, Brooklyn, for example, could easily be mistaken for an indoor botanical garden. Spanning nine floors and over 200,000 square feet, the office is home to more than 11,000 plants, including dozens of large-scale plant displays and living walls installed and maintained by Ms. Bullene and Greenery NYC.\n\n\u201cEvery employee has a sight line to greenery,\u201d said Hilary Young, Etsy\u2019s sustainability manager, who helps the company seek ways to conserve the environment. \u201cIt\u2019s a beautiful space that inspires and boosts productivity.\u201d Greenery NYC and the architects at Gensler worked closely to create a state-of-the-art rainwater-harvesting and irrigation system at Etsy\u2019s headquarters, which is considered the largest commercial \u201cliving building\u201d in the world. It allows all the office plants to be watered with recycled storm water.", "title": "Plant-Loving Millennials at Home and at Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "After contemplating the idea of taking guns away from all Americans \u2014 \u201ceven whites\u201d\u2014 Baldwin went on to address the latest personnel losses in the Trump administration.
