I don\u2019t care. I said I was going to run this country like a business. That business is a Waffle House at 2 a.m. Crazies everywhere, staff walking out in the middle of their shift, managers taking money out of the cash register to pay off the Russian mob.\u201d\n\nIn other highlights from the episode:\n\nSurprisingly Topical Monologue of the Week\n\nThough he occasionally stumbled in his delivery, Barkley, the \u201cInside the NBA\u201d analyst, scored with a pointed comedic commentary on the role of athletes in American civic life. He began:\n\nI\u2019m an athlete, and athletes have been speaking out a lot this year. They\u2019ve been kneeling during the anthem, refusing to go to the White House, and a lot of professional athletes are worried about speaking out might hurt their career. Well, here\u2019s something that contradicts all of that: me. I\u2019ve been saying whatever the hell I want for 30 years, and I\u2019m doing great. I\u2019m hosting \u201cS.N.L.\u201d for the fourth time, for no reason. Lorne Michaels just wanted somebody to talk to about \u201cBlack Panther.\u201d But this country\u2019s had a great tradition of athletes speaking their minds. Muhammad Ali changed the way people thought about Vietnam. Jim Brown had people thinking about race. Michael Jordan even thought it was O.K. for humans to play with Looney Tunes.\n\nAlluding to the Fox News host Laura Ingraham\u2019s recent criticism of LeBron James, Barkley added:\n\nWell, some folks think we\u2019re all spoiled millionaires. But athletes work hard. \u2026 But some people don\u2019t want to hear from professional athletes. Like this lady on Fox News who told LeBron James to shut up and dribble. And dribbling\u2019s like LeBron\u2019s only fourth thing he\u2019s good at. Shooting, passing, and magically making his hairline come back. But the media does this stuff all the time. I went to President Obama\u2019s 50th birthday party. They got video of me, Jay-Z, Steve Harvey and Grant Hill at the party, and Fox News called it a \u201chip-hop barbecue.\u201d First of all, we were the only four black people there. And three of us ain\u2019t even in hip-hop. So calling it a hip-hop barbecue is like calling any tournament Tiger [Woods] plays in \u201cDef Golf Jam.\u201d\n\nAt the conclusion of his monologue, Barkley traded riffs with the \u201cWeekend Update\u201d co-anchor Michael Che. \u201cI\u2019m proud to stand for the anthem,\u201d Barkley said. \u201cUnless Fergie is singing it, and I just fall over laughing.\u201d\n\nChe responded: \u201cI stay seated for the anthem, because I\u2019m still in my Uber. Because black people are always late.\u201d", "title": "Playing Trump on \u2018S.N.L.,\u2019 Baldwin Takes On White House Turmoil", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cDemocrats Face Primary Shove From New Left\u201d (front page, March 5):\n\nIn this midterm election year, the Democratic Party is again poised \u2014 pardon the clich\u00e9 \u2014 to snatch humiliating defeat from the jaws of certain victory. The Democrats persist in their quixotic attempt to woo those who voted for President Trump and those who are on the fence. To do this, they temporize on issues with respect to which there should be no waffling or wavering.\n\nThat is the royal road to failure, and a well-deserved failure it would be. Unless the Democrats can shed their spinelessness and timidity, they will not energize that crucial youth, female, gay and ethnic horde that is yearning for uncompromising progressivism.\n\nThis is the mandate that the Democrats should embrace by stating without fear or shame that guns should be taken away, that the environment is too precious to despoil, that a woman has an inalienable right to choose, that immigrants are welcome, that the wealthy should pay more, that universal health care must be implemented and so forth.\n\nIn short, unless the Democrats use their own bully pulpit to topple the bullying pulpits that our White House and legislatures have become, they are fated to lose, and they will deserve to lose.", "title": "Opinion | Pleas to Democrats: Don\u2019t Mess Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Need another excuse to put off washing dirty dishes or doing laundry?\n\nHow about this: It\u2019s raining outside.\n\nNew York City is calling on residents in parts of Brooklyn and Queens to cut back their water use during rainstorms by postponing showers and other chores \u2014 even waiting to flush toilets. The reason is that household sewage flows into the same underground sewer pipes that also collect rainwater runoff from rooftops and streets.\n\nWhen those pipes are overloaded with rainwater, the combined overflow is then discharged directly into nearby rivers, bays and creeks instead of going to wastewater treatment plants.\n\nThe new \u201cWait \u2026\u201d campaign is the latest strategy by the city\u2019s Department of Environmental Protection to reduce so-called \u201ccombined sewer overflows\u201d that have long polluted local waterways, closed down beaches and plagued recreational sports. Today, about 20 billion gallons of combined sewer overflows are discharged annually into waterways, down from nearly 110 billion gallons in 1985, according to city officials. Typically, about 90 percent of that combined overflow is rainwater runoff.", "title": "Please Don\u2019t Flush the Toilet. It\u2019s Raining.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea appears to be making new nuclear bomb fuel, satellite imagery shows, even as its leader, Kim Jong-un, has expressed willingness to negotiate atomic disarmament with President Trump.\n\nTwo separate teams of American analysts examining satellite images from January and February have concluded that the North\u2019s reactor at Yongbyon, which had appeared to be dormant, is now making plutonium \u2014 a principal fuel of nuclear arms.\n\nIn a report this week, one of the teams, at 38 North, a research institute at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, said rising plumes of steam from the reactor complex, as well as melted river ice nearby, suggested \u201cthe reactor is operating again\u201d to make plutonium for the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program.\n\nThe 38 North analyst team includes Frank V. Pabian, formerly a satellite image analyst at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, birthplace of the bomb.", "title": "Plumes Seen at Plutonium Plant May Belie Kim\u2019s Disarmament Talk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "A podcast offers up intellectual property in a particularly appealing format \u2014 compared with a book or even a script, it\u2019s a stronger proof of concept of how a show or movie would actually play out. \u201cIt\u2019s one step closer to seeing it onscreen,\u201d Mr. Tarses said. \u201cYou already know what it sounds like.\u201d\n\nLike many of the properties bending Hollywood\u2019s ear, \u201cStartUp\u201d is a very successful podcast; it\u2019s been downloaded tens of millions of times since its debut in 2014. But podcast listeners still constitute a very different audience than viewers of network sitcoms, with different sensibilities. And the elements that make a podcast spark \u2014 internal conflict, patient world building, conversational digressions \u2014 don\u2019t translate seamlessly to TV.\n\n\u201cThere were things we loved about the podcast, but we had to turn it into an ABC show,\u201d Mr. Braff said.\n\nSo the inside story of starting a podcasting company is refocused as a broad family comedy. Mr. Blumberg\u2019s real-life business partner, the Gimlet co-founder and president Matt Lieber \u2014 who holds an M.B.A. from M.I.T. and started his career at NPR and WNYC \u2014 is recast as a scrappy salesman played by Michael Imperioli. It\u2019s a bid to differentiate the characters and inject an Everyman foil to the insular and often absurd podcaster culture on display. \u201cWe wanted to have an in for the layman who has no clue what a podcast is,\u201d Mr. Braff said. \u201cHe\u2019s a character who is comically na\u00efve to this whole world.\u201d\n\nThen there\u2019s an invented character, the female producer Deirdre, whose central personality trait is that she is hopelessly in love with Alex \u2014 a retrograde note not on display in Gimlet\u2019s offices or in its shows. Also, Alex carries a comically oversized old-time microphone with him everywhere he goes, a way to visually telegraph his job to viewers. In real life, \u201cit\u2019s not so big,\u201d Mr. Blumberg conceded. Mr. Sacca, though, is unchanged: After an acting crash-course from Mr. Braff, the investor played himself.\n\nPersonality-based podcasts offer the temptation of a more effortless adaptation. Earlier this year, HBO spun the WNYC podcast \u201c2 Dope Queens,\u201d starring the comedians Phoebe Robinson and Jessica Williams, into a four-part live special, and the network has struck a deal with the Obama staffers-turned-podcasters of \u201cPod Save America\u201d to air a live series in the lead-up to the 2018 midterms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t want to dramatically alter their formula, and that took the pressure off them to continue doing what they were already doing so well,\u201d Nina Rosenstein, executive vice president for programming at HBO, said of \u201c2 Dope Queens.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSome transitions from audio to visuals feel natural: The comedians Desus Nice and the Kid Mero\u2019s cult hit \u201cBodega Boys\u201d podcast has translated easily to the Viceland late-night talk show \u201cDesus & Mero.\u201d\n\nOthers, not so much. When the beloved podcast host Bill Simmons tried to take his interview style to HBO, on the late-night program \u201cAny Given Wednesday,\u201d he floundered onscreen. And even the most promising projects can fall through: \u201cSerial\u201d was optioned in 2015 for development by Phil Lord and Chris Miller, the filmmaking team behind \u201cThe Lego Movie\u201d and \u201c21 Jump Street,\u201d but the project languished and the option has since expired. The Serial team is now in talks to adapt its American gothic true-crime serial \u201cS-Town.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe mediums want very different things,\u201d said Mr. Blumberg, who previously worked for \u201cThis American Life,\u201d including on that radio program\u2019s TV adaptation that aired on Showtime from 2007 to 2009.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut increasingly, podcast makers are behaving more like TV and film companies, developing and packaging projects themselves. When Mr. Davis came knocking for \u201cStartUp\u201d in 2015, Gimlet ceded creative control of the adaptation to the network. At the time, Mr. Blumberg said, \u201cwe were barely putting our podcasts out the door.\u201d\n\nNow, Gimlet is developing and pitching its podcasts instead of waiting for Hollywood to call, and in January, the company started Gimlet Pictures, a new division headed by Chris Giliberti. \u201cHomecoming,\u201d the podcast network\u2019s first scripted thriller, is now headed to Amazon, and this time, \u201cour fingerprints are all over it creatively,\u201d Mr. Lieber said.\n\nMr. Giliberti has an office on the studio lot, and he flies out to Los Angeles from Gimlet\u2019s Brooklyn offices every couple of weeks. Eli Horowitz, who wrote the Gimlet show with the screenwriter Micah Bloomberg, is acting as showrunner of the Amazon series. Gimlet also recruited the show\u2019s director, Sam Esmail of \u201cMr. Robot\u201d; helped staff the writer\u2019s room; and cast the star, Julia Roberts. (Gimlet\u2019s representation with CAA, Ms. Roberts\u2019s agency, helped.)\n\nGimlet is also working to develop an episode of its tech podcast \u201cReply All\u201d \u2014 about a charismatic figure who used a new technology, radio, to manipulate the masses \u2014 into a film. The director Richard Linklater and the star Robert Downey Jr. are attached. Gimlet also recently recruited a new chief marketing officer, Jenny Wall, who\u2019s worked at Hulu and Netflix.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Gimlet recorded the first season of \u201cStartUp,\u201d the drama of the show hinged on the financial and personal risk of establishing a podcasting company. But relatively low-cost audio shows carry less financial risk than TV and film projects.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Gimlet produced \u201cHomecoming,\u201d it could land in-demand actors like Oscar Isaac and Catherine Keener because it required only a couple days of work in front of a mic. The same is true of the network\u2019s next scripted series, its first dramedy.\n\n\u201cActors are open to doing a show with us because they don\u2019t have to put on makeup, they don\u2019t have to put on their Spanx, they don\u2019t have to go on location,\u201d Mr. Lieber said. \u201cIt\u2019s fun, interesting creative work that doesn\u2019t require so much.\u201d Then, when the company pivots to casting an adaptation, it helps to already have respected actors in the audio version. As Gimlet pursued Ms. Roberts for \u201cHomecoming,\u201d it was able to send her the podcast with Ms. Keener in the role to help prove the company\u2019s bona fides.\n\nStudios and networks are not only drawn to the proven storytelling a podcast provides, but they also like the built-in fan base \u2014 one that\u2019s easier to reach and engage than, say, people who have bought a book. Tens of millions of listeners have downloaded StartUp, and \u201cnow Gimlet can go back to those people and tell them about \u2018Alex, Inc.,\u201d Mr. Davis said. \u201cIt\u2019s great synergy.\u201d\n\nFor podcasters, adaptations also offer the prospect of drawing even bigger audiences to the original audio show.\n\nAaron Mahnke of the podcast \u201cLore,\u201d who now serves as executive producer and narrator of the Amazon adaptation, has seen new listeners stream in from Amazon. These days, \u201ca story can exist in a variety of different mediums,\u201d he said. \u201cIt all feeds itself.\u201d\n\nBut only to a point. \u201cWhen we see headlines announcing a podcast gold rush, there\u2019s a shift in the people who bring content to the table,\u201d Mr. Mahnke said of \u201cLore,\u201d which hit the jackpot with its Amazon deal. \u201cI\u2019m so in love with the medium of podcasting, and I\u2019m conscious of how we can manage this growth without burning our listeners,\u201d he said. \u201cMy caveat is this: Don\u2019t get into it for the money.\u201d", "title": "Podcasts Get the Hollywood Treatment, Complete With Zach Braff", "authors": ["Amanda Hess"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Your fingers crowned with meat hooks and cleavers. You holding me and whispering, Who did this to you? sawing me into a shallow boat. You did, you did, you did, and you, and you, and you, you did this to me in my home, you did this while crying. I cannot make a sound as though my mouth is full of honey. Of a colony of bees. Honey, honey. You lift my skin. Inside it lives your dream of forests where snow grows old and you are young, cold and white and lonely without my suffering, and you want to say, Not me, Not me, I wouldn\u2019t hurt a bee, but honey. Inside my blood and bone and their network of tendon and meat we have, you and I, our histories of hunting and being the beast. Grace-panic. Warhorseman, split. Among sectile bodies, I think of you * in succorless hollow. The man you wore dwindles, wilts unhollered, daggered inches deeper into cinder block while the cellblock\u2019s every kneecap after knuckle blesses your flesh dry of betrayal, its raw use. Hours earlier, Britain\u2019s prime minister, Theresa May, said it was \u201chighly likely\u201d that Russia was to blame, and she demanded answers from the Kremlin.\n\nMr. Tillerson said that he had just spoken with his British counterpart, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, and that the State Department would issue a statement affirming the British findings.\n\n\u201cThis is a really egregious act,\u201d Mr. Tillerson said. \u201cIt appears that it clearly came from Russia. Whether it came from Russia with the Russian government\u2019s knowledge is not known to me at this point.\u201d\n\nHe added that he would be stunned if a government was behind the use of a deadly nerve agent. The former spy, Sergei V. A state actor \u2014 I cannot understand why anyone would take such an action.\u201d\n\nHe noted that the nerve agent used in the attack \u201cis only in the hands of a very, very limited number of parties.\u201d The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, a watchdog agency, is also looking into the attack.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked whether the attack would prompt a response in defense of Britain, a NATO ally that the United States is legally obligated to defend if it came under attack, Mr. Tillerson said: \u201cIt certainly will trigger a response. He had left the United States on the evening of March 6, but after just a day of meetings in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, he woke at 2:30 a.m. on Thursday with the news that President Trump had decided to accept Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation for talks.\n\nHe had another urgent phone call Friday night \u2014 he would not say about what \u2014 so that by Saturday he had managed to get just four hours of sleep over three days, he said. And then he got food poisoning.\n\n\u201cSo the combination of that, I just said, \u2018This is inhumane,\u2019\u201d he said with a chuckle.\n\nMr. Tillerson canceled his meetings set for Saturday in Nairobi, including a visit to an H.I.V./AIDS clinic, and he decided to fly home Monday night after quick visits to Chad and Nigeria.\n\nThe potential North Korean summit meeting dominated much of Mr. Tillerson\u2019s week even though he was halfway around the world from Washington. In a news conference Monday, Mr. Tillerson said that planning for the event was in \u201cvery early stages.\u201d\n\nBut he said in his later interview on his plane that, in his own experience as the chief executive of oil giant Exxon Mobil, intense preparation \u2014 what he referred to as \u201chomework\u201d \u2014 was needed to make such a meeting successful.\n\nWithout good preparation, he said, \u201cit\u2019s very difficult to map a way forward.\u201d\n\nEarly on Monday, Mr. Tillerson spent several hours in Ndjamena, Chad, where he insisted that the people of Chad were \u201cwelcome in the United States.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe said that Chad\u2019s efforts to strengthen its passport controls and increase information sharing may result in its removal from the travel ban.\n\nChad\u2019s foreign minister, Mahamat Zene Cherif, called the inclusion of Chad on the travel ban an \u201cinjustice,\u201d and said that widely reported disparaging remarks attributed to Mr. Trump about Africa \u201cshocked almost all Africans.\u201d\n\nState Department and Pentagon officials wanted to keep Chad \u2014 a partner in the fight against terrorism in the Sahel \u2014 off the travel ban list when it was formulated but were overruled by the White House. They discussed cooperation on trade and in the fight against Boko Haram and an offshoot of the Islamic State.", "title": "Poisoning of Russian Ex-Spy Is \u2018Almost Beyond Comprehension,\u2019 Tillerson Says", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 Polish and Israeli officials met on Thursday to address the diplomatic rift that erupted over a new Polish law that makes it a crime to blame Poland for the Holocaust, a measure that Israeli officials have likened to Holocaust denial.\n\nThe law, adopted last month over the furious objections of Israel and scholars from around the world, makes it a crime to blame \u201cthe Polish nation\u201d for the Holocaust and other World War II atrocities carried out by the Nazis during their occupation from 1939 to 1945.\n\nIt was the Nazis who oversaw the exterminations \u2014 by means of mass shootings, gas chambers, starvation and slave labor \u2014 that claimed the lives of some six million Jews. But the role of Polish collaborators, participants and enablers in the Nazi-run system of mechanized death remains a subject of fraught historical inquiry.\n\nPoland\u2019s right-wing government says its goal is to defend the nation from slander, but scholars say the result is to stifle inquiry and reconciliation.", "title": "Poland and Israel in Tense Talks Over Law Likened to Holocaust Denial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "I have written effusively and often about polenta, the delectable Northern Italian porridge made from cornmeal. Fan that I am, polenta for dinner is always a winner in my book.\n\nWe may know it first and foremost as a side dish: a modest spoonful placed next to a piece of braised chicken, or a crisp, grilled wedge accompanying herby lamb chops. They also did not say if they suspect it had been his idea to lie or if he been instructed to lie by superiors. At the time of the gun arrest, Officer Moloney had been a police officer for three years. As contradictions in his account were exposed, Officer Moloney cited his inexperience as the reason for the error, prosecutors said.\n\nThe charges against Officer Moloney stem from an arrest he and other officers made on May 6, 2016, in the public housing apartment building where they had been seeking to arrest a man on a warrant for low-level charges. The officers knocked on the door of an apartment and arrested the man when he answered the door, prosecutors said.\n\nBecause it was early in the morning, the man was not properly dressed. The officers followed him into a bedroom to allow him to put on clothes. Officer Moloney and a second officer left with the man to process the arrest, prosecutors said, but about 15 minutes later a sergeant who had stayed behind told the officers to come back.\n\nInside the apartment was an open black box containing a gun as well as a few bags of marijuana, prosecutors said. At that point, the sergeant told Officer Moloney to go get a search warrant. But when Officer Moloney went to the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office to apply for the warrant, he claimed that he \u2014 not the sergeant \u2014 discovered the gun.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe also insinuated that the arrested man had tried to hide the gun.\n\n\u201cAs I was assisting Mr. [redacted] to get dressed, Mr. [redacted] kicked a black plastic box under the bed where the baby was sleeping. I then opened the black plastic box and observed a silver pistol inside the box,\u201d Officer Moloney wrote in a search warrant affidavit, according to the indictment.\n\nHe repeated this account, with some variations, to a grand jury, and at court proceedings, prosecutors said.\n\nHis story came under scrutiny when photographs from the apartment showed that the bed was set on the floor. At that point, Officer Moloney said the suspect had been trying to push the box away from the bed \u2014 rather than toward it, prosecutors said.\n\n\u201cWhen we were getting him dressed we\u2019re noticing he\u2019s pushing the box away from the actual bed and we realize that it\u2019s open a little and we see that there\u2019s also a firearm in the box,\u201d Officer Moloney testified on Feb. 1. in a family court hearing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked about the discrepancy, Officer Moloney said it was an error based on a lack of experience. It was, he said in Supreme Court, a \u201cmistake on my part, being my first search warrant that I\u2019d sworn out alone, and just a rookie mistake.\u201d\n\nBut in July 2017 Officer Moloney admitted that he had not been the one to open the black box, prosecutors said. He also said that he did not observe the moment that the box was being opened, prosecutors said.\n\n\u201cI want to come clean to you,\u201d he told officials, according to the indictment. \u201cI did not open the black plastic box. I did not see the box being opened by someone else. I wasn\u2019t in the room.\u201d\n\nBased on this, prosecutors dismissed the gun charges against the man, whom prosecutors did not identify. The Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office referred the matter to the Police Department\u2019s Internal Affairs Bureau, which led to perjury charges being filed against Officer Moloney.", "title": "Police Officer Is Charged With Lying About Finding a Gun", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "KIEV \u2014 Clashes broke out near the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev on Saturday, after police began removing a camp that was set up outside the government buildings last year to protest corruption.\n\nAs heavy snow fell on the makeshift site, protesters burned tires and scuffles broke out with police, who had moved in to dismantle the camp, which has been there for months.\n\nMore than 100 protesters were detained.\n\nNearly all were later released, but Kiev police reported that about 20 people, including seven police officers, were injured in the confrontation.\n\nEarly Saturday morning, police entered the area to investigative another violent incident that had taken place in February, in which several police officers were injured, said Andrey Kryshchenko, the head of the Kiev police.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Friday, one day before the clash with the police, protesters had begun dismantling the tents by themselves after Parliament seemed to be leaning toward taking action on one of their major demands: creating a national anticorruption court. On Thursday, Parliament agreed to hear the first reading of legislation that would pave the way for the court.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the entrance of the police into the camp on Saturday escalated simmering tensions. After tires were set alight, the police rounded up dozens of the protesters and began demolishing the camp with a tractor.", "title": "Police and Protesters Clash Outside Ukraine Parliament", "authors": ["Iuliia Mendel"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Costello\u2019s flash drive would not only free his cousin, but eventually convict the detective of perjury.\n\nThis sequence of events emerged during the trial of the detective, Kevin Desormeau, in January. It was a reminder that for all the power of video to get to the truth, the criminal justice system doesn\u2019t always ensure that relevant video evidence ever makes it into court. The justice system offers few solutions to incarcerated defendants who insist that video footage will vindicate them. Yes, defense attorneys can dispatch investigators to gather video, and they often do so. But those investigators have no legal authority to force a bodega owner or a property manager to hand over surveillance footage.\n\n\u201cEspecially larger buildings, they are not going to respond to an investigator with a USB\u201d flash drive, said Cynthia Conti-Cook, a Legal Aid lawyer. If the bodega owner or property manager insist they are too busy to help, or just don\u2019t want to get involved, the defense can ask a judge for a subpoena. But that takes time, and in the intervening days there is a decent chance the footage will be deleted, Ms. Conti-Cook said.\n\nHold More Suppression Hearings\n\nPolice officers take the witness stand in open court in far fewer cases than one might expect. The reason is that the vast majority of arrests result in a plea deal or dismissal.\n\nSuppression hearings \u2014 which are held ahead of a trial and are often used to test the constitutionality of the police\u2019s conduct \u2014 are somewhat more common than trials, but are still rare. The court system doesn\u2019t track how many occur. But data provided by the Manhattan district attorney\u2019s office indicates that only about 2.4 percent of felony cases that do not end in a guilty plea at the initial arraignment wind up having suppression hearings in Manhattan.\n\nThese are the hearings at which judges scrutinize police credibility. Judges sometimes base their conclusions on the consistency or inconsistency of an officer\u2019s testimony. Or judges might point out contradictions, if serious enough, between officers\u2019 accounts. They are, defense lawyers said, often the best chance to get at the truth of how an arrest or investigation unfolded.\n\nMore suppression hearings would be a good thing, almost everyone agrees. Yet the justice system often seems reluctant to hold them.", "title": "Police \u2018Testilying\u2019 Remains a Problem. Here Is How the Criminal Justice System Could Reduce It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "WARSAW \u2014 To Magda, giving birth would have meant inflicting a slow death. Her unborn child had a rare genetic syndrome that causes severe, fatal birth defects.\n\n\u201cI would feed it, hug it, love it, get attached to it, and then, when it would be 3 or 4 months old, it would suffocate while in my arms,\u201d she recalled, explaining her decision a decade ago to have an abortion. \u201cIt would scar me for life. I don\u2019t know if I would be capable of giving birth to another child and not look at it as if it were the one that had died in my arms.\u201d\n\nShe asked that her surname not be used, fearing that the agonizing decision she made could be used to shame her. But even in Poland, an overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country with some of the strictest anti-abortion laws in Europe and a government seeking to curb reproductive rights, it is a decision she could still make legally \u2014 at least for now.\n\nLawmakers from the governing Law and Justice party, who have previously tried to ban all abortions, are making a renewed push to outlaw them, even when the fetus is sure to die in infancy.", "title": "Polish Women Protest Proposed Abortion Ban (Again)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The fall of Rex W. Tillerson from the Trump administration \u2014 on Tuesday, Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, was tapped to replace him as secretary of state \u2014 removes one the last remaining presidential advisers whose views on global warming are in line with the rest of the world.\n\nMr. Pompeo has questioned the scientific consensus that human activity is changing the climate, and he has strongly opposed the Paris Agreement, a pact among nearly 200 nations to address climate change. He told Congress last year during his Senate confirmation hearing for the C.I.A. post that the notion of climate change as a top national security threat was \u201cignorant, dangerous and absolutely unbelievable.\u201d\n\nMr. Tillerson, despite his decades-long career in the oil industry \u2014 a major contributor to planet-warming pollution \u2014 holds that rising global temperatures spurred by human activity pose significant risks.\n\nThe change in leadership at the State Department all but cements an increasingly hard-line opposition to the idea of climate change at the highest levels of the United States government. Mr. Tillerson\u2019s departure follows the resignation announcement last week of Gary Cohn, the president\u2019s top economic adviser, and the departure last month of George David Banks, a senior adviser to the president on international energy issues. All three had argued to keep the United States in the Paris agreement.", "title": "Pompeo, Trump\u2019s Pick for Secretary of State, Is a \u2018Great Climate Skeptic\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "This experiment is the most important effort of his pontificate, but in the last year he has added a second one, seeking a truce not with a culture but with a regime: the Communist government in China. Francis wants a compromise with Beijing that would reconcile China\u2019s underground Catholic Church, loyal to Rome, with the Communist-dominated \u201cpatriotic\u201d Catholic Church. Such a reconciliation, if accomplished, would require the church to explicitly cede a share of its authority to appoint bishops to the Politburo \u2014 a concession familiar from medieval church-state tangles, but something the modern church has tried to leave behind.\n\nA truce with Beijing would differ from the truce with the sexual revolution in that no specific doctrinal issue is at stake, and no one doubts that the pope has authority to conclude a concordat with a heretofore hostile and persecuting regime. Indeed, he is building on diplomatic efforts by his predecessors, though both of them declined to take the fraught step to a formal deal.\n\nBut the two truces are similar in that both would accelerate Catholicism\u2019s transformation into a confederation of national churches \u2014 liberal and semi-Protestantized in northern Europe, conservative in sub-Saharan Africa, Communist-supervised in China. They are similar in that both treat the concerns of many faithful Catholics \u2014 conservative believers in the West, underground churchgoers in China \u2014 as roadblocks to the pope\u2019s grand strategy. They are similar in that both have raised the specter of schism by pitting cardinals against cardinals and sometimes against the pope himself.\n\nAbove all, the two truces are similar in that they both risk a great deal \u2014 in one case, the consistency of Catholic doctrine and its fidelity to Jesus; in another, the clarity of Catholic witness for human dignity \u2014 for the sake of reconciling the church with earthly powers. And they take this risk at a time when neither Chinese Communism nor Western liberalism seem exactly like confident, resilient models for the human future \u2014 the former sliding back toward totalitarianism, the latter anxious and decadent and beset by populist revolts.\n\nWhich means that if these two bets go badly the Francis legacy will be judged harshly \u2014 in spite of his charisma, his effect on secular observers, and all the other elements of the \u201cFrancis effect.\u201d\n\nThe risks of the Chinese gamble are already apparent in the weirdly sycophantic language that Francis\u2019 allies have used toward the Communist regime, and their eagerness to reassure Beijing that unlike, say, American evangelicals, Rome would never take the threatening step of mixing religion and politics.\n\nIf current trends continue, China could have one of the world\u2019s largest Christian populations by this century\u2019s end, and this population is already heavily evangelical; indeed, the Vatican\u2019s desire for a deal with Beijing is influenced by the fact that a divided Chinese Catholicism is being outcompeted for converts.", "title": "Opinion | Pope Francis Is Beloved. His Papacy Might Be a Disaster.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "The pope called Padre Pio an \u201capostle of the confessional.\u201d\n\nBefore the Mass, Francis visited Santa Maria delle Grazie, the church where Padre Pio celebrated Mass for the last nine years of his life. There, he stood in silent prayer before the saint\u2019s body, moved to the church from the crypt below. He touched and kissed the crucifix that Pio was praying to when he received the stigmata in 1918.\n\n\u201cHe is the third pope to visit San Giovanni Rotondo; it\u2019s establishing a continuity,\u201d said Maurizio Placentino, the provincial minister of the Order of Friars Minor Capuchin, which oversees all things Padre Pio here. John Paul II, who canonized Pio, visited in 1987; and so did Benedict XVI in 2016.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a strong message that shows the continued attention of the church to this phenomenon: recognizing in Padre Pio a gift of God for our day,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe church did not always embrace Padre Pio. Both his superiors and the Vatican initiated more than a dozen investigations against him, and Pope John XXIII wrote of Padre Pio\u2019s \u201cimmense deception.\u201d But his successor, Paul VI, lifted the restrictions on Pio\u2019s ministry.\n\nFrancis being Francis, he went off-script in Pietrelcina, addressing the \u201cinternal migration of young people,\u201d a problem endemic to Italy\u2019s less affluent regions, where work is scarce and many are forced to emigrate north \u2014 within Italy or to other European countries.\n\nThe pope called on locals to pray that young people find work, \u201camong you, among the family and are not forced to leave to look for another way, while the country\u201d spiraled into a decline.\n\nBut his mission in coming south was to honor Padre Pio, whose global following has grown significantly since his death in 1968. The mosaics that envelop the walls on the lower part of the saint\u2019s shrine were paid for by a Philippine foundation dedicated to him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe floor of the crypt where Padre Pio\u2019s body is on view is littered with slips of papers, closed envelopes, photo-booth portraits and even money, mostly small bills. The faithful and other visitors slip similar mementos under the door of the cell where he spent the last years of his life in San Giovanni Rotondo, or into the confessional of the old church where he is said to have heard millions of confessions.\n\nPhoto\n\nThese handwritten pleas for assistance and spiritual sustenance \u201care too many to count,\u201d said Stefano Campanella, the director of the television station Tele Radio Padre Pio and the author of several books about the saint.\n\nThough St. Pio\u2019s shrine is still popular, tourists who used to flock to it are coming for shorter daytime visits, the result of the country\u2019s economic downturn.\n\n\u201cNow people come from all over Italy, but they travel overnight by bus and bring sandwiches. This helps the penitential aspect, but it depresses the economy of the city,\u201d said Antonio Belpiede, the general procurator of the Capuchin order. He added, \u201cSan Giovanni Rotondo owes everything to Padre Pio, that\u2019s for sure.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRecently, relics of Padre Pio have begun traveling outside Italy. Last year, several \u2014 including a glove, a lock of his hair and cotton gauze stained with blood \u2014 went on tour in Mexico, Canada and the United States, including New York. Two years ago, his heart was displayed in America.\n\nBut many of the faithful want to be close to his home. Brady White, an American actor who is paid to play Santa at celebrity Christmas parties (he said he has seen the Kardashian-Jenner clan grow up), began traveling to San Giovanni Rotondo 16 years ago, after being \u201ctouched by Padre Pio,\u201d he said.\n\nOn Saturday, he wore a specially made jacket commemorating Pope Francis\u2019 visit here.\n\n\u201cI was a regular guy, but when Padre Pio wants you, he gets you,\u201d he said.", "title": "Pope Francis Makes Pilgrimage to Honor a Rock-Star Saint", "authors": ["Elisabetta Povoledo"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u00d3scar Romero\n\nArchbishop \u00d3scar Romero of San Salvador, who defended the poor and the oppressed in his homilies and radio broadcasts, was shot and killed while he was saying Mass in a hospital chapel in El Salvador on March 24, 1980.\n\nMonths before, on the eve of the country\u2019s civil war, Archbishop Romero had angered many in the country\u2019s military dictatorship by writing to President Jimmy Carter to ask that the United States halt military aid to El Salvador, and by repeatedly calling for an end to the brutal killings of political opponents.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe peasants you kill are your own brothers and sisters,\u201d he had said.\n\nNo one was ever prosecuted for his death, but a 1993 United Nations commission found that his assassination had been planned by officers close to Roberto D\u2019Aubuisson, an extreme-right former army major and founder of the Nationalist Republican Alliance, which governed the country from 1989 until 2009.\n\nArchbishop Romero\u2019s beatification was stalled for years at the Vatican, as many frowned on his association with leftist political views, liberation theology and communism.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrancis, however, declared the archbishop a model of peace and forgiveness in 2015, honoring the Salvadoran as a martyr in \u201chatred of the faith.\u201d The pope beatified the archbishop in San Salvador months later.\n\nPaul VI\n\nGiovanni Battista Montini, cardinal of Milan, was elected pope in 1963. During his 15-year pontificate, he shepherded the church through a period of enormous internal change as well as social and political upheaval, trying to bring together progressive and conservative positions in the church.\n\nPaul VI was the first pope to travel to Latin America, where he presided over the assembly of local bishops in 1968. There, officials agreed that the church should give a \u201cpreferential option for the poor,\u201d a tenet of Francis\u2019 pontificate.\n\nAfter the Second Vatican Council, in the early 1960s, Pope Paul VI created the Synod of Bishops, an assembly to promote better dialogue among clerics and the Vatican. But he also reached out to other faiths, promoting ecumenism in the six continents he visited. He was the first pope to travel to Israel, in 1964, doing so even before the Vatican recognized the state.\n\nPaul VI abolished the pontifical court and simplified the Vatican administration. He is also remembered for being the first pope to dismiss the papal tiara, an emblem of intertwined temporal and spiritual power.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a highly symbolic gesture, he sold it to raise funds for the poor.", "title": "Pope Paves Way for Sainthood for Paul VI and Archbishop \u00d3scar Romero", "authors": ["Gaia Pianigiani"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Perry Bellegarde, the national chief of the Assembly of First Nations, Canada\u2019s largest Indigenous group, said he was disappointed by the church\u2019s decision and would continue to press the Vatican for an apology.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t give up,\u201d Chief Bellegarde said. \u201cIt would be a great act of healing and a great act of reconciliation if it were to happen. Let\u2019s see if we can alleviate their fears, whatever they are.\u201d\n\nDuring a visit to the Vatican last May, Mr. Trudeau asked Francis to issue an apology. On Wednesday, the prime minister also expressed disappointment, telling reporters in Ottawa that his government would keep working on reconciliation\u201cbecause we know taking responsibility for past mistakes and asking forgiveness is something that is core to our values as Canadians.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Anglican, Presbyterian and United churches in Canada, which also operated residential schools, issued apologies in the 1990s. Ten years ago, Stephen J. Harper, the Conservative prime minister at the time, apologized on behalf of the government and established the reconciliation commission.\n\nChief Bellegarde said that the pope\u2019s direct apology in 2015 during a trip to Bolivia for \u201cgrave sins\u201d committed by the church against Indigenous people in the Americas gave him confidence that a similar apology over residential schools was still possible.\n\nThe schools operated from 1883 until the last one closed in 1998. The commission found that children were severely punished for speaking Indigenous languages or following their cultural practices. It concluded that 3,201 students died while in the schools, often from mistreatment or neglect. About 80,000 former students are still alive.\n\nPope Francis has tried to decentralize authority away from the Vatican and giving more authority to local bishops. And while some in the Vatican bristle at the notion that the pope should have to answer to a request of a secular government, the more important factor could be what guidance came from the bishops in Canada.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe big question is what is the position of the Canadian bishops on this,\u201d said Thomas Reese, a veteran Vatican watcher and senior analyst at Religion News Service. \u201cIf the bishops are saying \u2018Don\u2019t do it,\u2019 he is getting mixed signals and he tends to support the local bishops.\u201d Mr. Reese added that \u201cfor him to turn down the bishops and the government, that would be noteworthy.\u201d\n\nSome in the Vatican have worried about the legal implications of apologies in cases with potentially large damages. About 50 Catholic organizations agreed to a financial settlement in the case of residential schools but were unable to raise enough money to fully cover the commitment. A 2015 court ruling released them from fulfilling the agreement.\n\nYet popes have recently made a habit of public apologies.\n\nAfter apologizing for Catholic involvement in the slave trade, the church\u2019s treatment of Jews and treating Galileo as a heretic, Pope John Paul II issued in 2000 a sweeping blanket request for forgiveness for the church\u2019s sins over the past 2,000 years. \u201cRecognizing the deviations of the past serves to reawaken our consciences to the compromises of the present,\u201d John Paul II said.\n\nIn 2010, Pope Benedict XVI apologized with \u201cshame and remorse\u201d to the victims of decades of sexual abuse by Catholic priests in Ireland.\n\nIn addition to his apology in Bolivia, Francis asked for forgiveness in 2017 for the church\u2019s role in the 1994 Rwanda genocide. As recently as January, Francis apologized to Chilean victims of abuse, though he created a larger problem for himself and his pontificate when he defended a Chilean bishop accused of covering up that abuse.\n\nThe letter to Canada\u2019s Indigenous people said the pope was considering a trip to Canada and would make meeting Indigenous people a priority in the event of a visit.", "title": "Pope Rejects Call for Apology to Canada\u2019s Indigenous People", "authors": ["Ian Austen", "Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOne of our priorities will be to equip our 189 dealerships with 800-volt DC fast chargers,\u201d said Klaus Zellmer, president and chief executive of Porsche Cars North America. \u201cWe have just installed six at our Porsche Experience centers in Atlanta and will roll them out at our experience center in Los Angeles, too.\u201d\n\nAs part of its settlement with the California Air Resources Board and the United States Environmental Protection Agency over its diesel emission test cheating, Volkswagen, Porsche\u2019s parent company, is also building a network of 2,800 DC fast chargers by June 2019.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Cross Turismo introduced on Tuesday is part of the other half of this two-pronged approach. Although it is officially a concept vehicle, it is expected to be an accurate preview of what buyers will see from Porsche after the Mission E vehicles go into production next year. While no pricing has been announced, the sedan version could run close to the existing Panamera, which begins at $85,000, compared with the $74,500 base price of a Tesla Model S 75D.\n\nThe Mission E vehicles are hardly alone in jockeying for position in the premium electric market. Last week, Jaguar unveiled the production version of its fully electric I-Pace crossover, which is scheduled to glide into showrooms in the second half of 2018. The Jaguar I-Pace, the carmaker\u2019s first electric vehicle, will start at $69,500 in the United States; a Tesla Model X starts at $79,500.\n\nAudi has announced it will ship its e-tron quattro to European showrooms this fall and to the United States in early 2019. And Volvo plans an all-electric version of its XC40 crossover in 2019.\n\nPorsche, Jaguar, Audi and other long-established carmakers have watched as Tesla has sprinted ahead, but Tesla will soon lose one crucial benefit that the later arrivals may be able to use to close the gap: tax benefits. At some point this year, Tesla will produce its 200,000th car. (General Motors, which makes the Chevrolet Bolt EV and Volt electric vehicles, will most likely reach that mark in 2018, too.) At that milestone, federal tax credits will begin to phase out.\n\nIt\u2019s not clear whether the new upscale choices will hurt Tesla or simply expand the segment. Dave Guilford, a managing editor for Crain\u2019s Automotive News, suggested that \u201cit\u2019s probably a little bit of both.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou could see when Porsche unveiled the Mission E it was aiming right at Tesla,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a beautiful car. New entries in the premium segment give it credibility.\u201d\n\nThe wagonlike all-wheel-drive Cross Turismo could be a compelling alternative to the Model X. Its 440-kilowatt system uses two permanent synchronous electric motors and a floor-mounted lithium-ion battery pack that Porsche claims will propel the Cross Turismo to 60 miles per hour in 3.5 seconds. It will also employ an air suspension that can add nearly two inches of ground clearance and rear-wheel steering that will help it in the corners. At 15 feet long, the Cross Turismo concept is about four inches shorter than the company\u2019s Macan crossover and 18 inches shorter than a Tesla Model X.\n\nThe concept\u2019s interior features a free-standing instrument cluster screen with three circular display graphics. A camera with eye-tracking ability recognizes which graphic the driver is looking at and moves it forward while reducing the size of the others. Porsche executives suggested that the technology was being considered for the production car.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the Mission E vehicles won\u2019t necessarily boast the same off-the-line performance of the Teslas \u2014 a Model S in \u201cLudicrous Mode\u201d catapults to 60 m.p.h. in about 2.3 seconds \u2014 Porsche believes that its decades of racing experience will ensure a better high-performance experience.\n\nFor example, when a Tesla is put into Ludicrous Mode, drivers are warned of the possibility of \u201caccelerated wear of the motor, gearbox and battery.\u201d And Teslas will sometimes enter a reduced-power mode under track conditions in order to protect the battery from overheating.\n\nPorsche intends to avoid such limitations, said Albrecht Reimold, a member of the Porsche executive board for production.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cEven when it is electrified, the powertrain remains a distinguishing feature for Porsche,\u201d he said.\n\nThe carmaker had plenty of ideas for offering \u201cthe typical Porsche DNA\u201d to its electric customers, Mr. Reimold said.\n\n\u201cHigh continuous output, acceleration reserves and reproducibility with power takeoff are essential features of Porsche electric motors,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTesla still boasts many advantages \u2014 the free charging for many of its customers through its 440-station charging network is a security blanket for long-distance travelers, and its customers continue to be enthusiastic brand ambassadors \u2014 but it has shown some vulnerabilities. Tesla has had trouble meeting its production goals for the Model 3, the most affordable entry in its lineup. There have also been quality issues; Consumer Reports ranked the Model X among the 10 least-reliable vehicles in its survey, and there have been well-documented fit and finish problems.\n\nThat has provided an opening not just for the luxury carmakers, but for the rest of the industry to join General Motors and Nissan, which makes the Leaf electric vehicle, in challenging Tesla\u2019s Model 3. Hyundai, for example, has confirmed plans for a fully electric Kona crossover, and Buick is rumored to be gaining a small crossover based on the Chevy Bolt platform.\n\nTesla may have created a new automotive segment and single-handedly made the electric car cool with blistering performance, high technology and svelte design, but the next few years will bring new competition from the old guard.", "title": "Porsche Positions Itself Against Tesla, on the Road and Beside It", "authors": ["Tom Voelk"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "36A: Please note that the entry WINEMAKER for \u201cPort authority?\u201d has the same number of letters as \u201csommelier,\u201d not that I am bitter.\n\n38A: Clever wordplay here. \u201cIt gets you from station to station\u201d could be \u201ctrain,\u201d but today we\u2019re talking about radios, so the answer is TUNER.\n\n55A: My word. This is the first time the word MOAN has been clued in such a sexy way (\u201cIndication of pain or pleasure\u201d).\n\n1D: Tricky one. \u201cSchool card\u201d made me think of an identification card at first, but this is a Friday puzzle and that\u2019s way too easy. A card can also be someone who cuts up, so the answer is CLASS CLOWN.\n\n3D: Today we welcome back the phrase IN ANY EVENT, which is making only its second appearance in The New York Times Crossword in 50 years.\n\n5D: I was surprised by this one. I had never heard the word EFFETE defined as \u201cWorn out,\u201d but it seems to be a dictionary definition.\n\n8D: Hi, kids! This is my own memory because I am an old, relatively speaking, but I can\u2019t think of \u201cYou rang?\u201d without thinking of Lurch from \u201cThe Addams Family\u201d:\n\n15D: Big Bird\u2019s appearance at the Muppet creator Jim HENSON\u2019s memorial made many Muppet lovers, myself included, cry:\n\n26D: Break out the quinoa bowls and avo toast, as Ms. Weintraub says below. The entry VEGETARIAN returns after a break of 25 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n30D: Did you have a tough time with this puzzle? THERE, THERE. (Sorry, I couldn\u2019t resist.)\n\n40D: \u201cMake a bed?\u201d for GARDEN reminds me that it\u2019s time to start preparing my vegetable garden beds for the spring. This is my favorite time of year, besides the harvest.\n\n47D: Were you wondering why there was a hyphen in \u201cForce-ful one?\u201d That\u2019s because we are talking about one who has the Force with them, or a JEDI. Nice use of a veiled capital clue. To learn more about these tricky clues, please scroll to the \u201cCracking the Harder Clues\u201d section of the \u201cHow to Solve The New York Times Crossword\u201d guide.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nIn my puzzles I always try to incorporate at least one exclamation, question or \u2018conversational\u2019 phrase, as I think they add a different dimension to the mix. Over the years I\u2019ve included: DO ME A FAVOR, ARE YOU DONE, IT FIGURES, DO I HAVE TO, KEEP TALKING and IMPRESS ME. In this particular puzzle there are three \u2014 and it turns out that together they comprise a little story, the gripping (yet brief) tale of one character consoling another after a distressing and suspicious incident: THERE THERE, IN ANY EVENT, I SMELL A RAT. Also, I don\u2019t usually go looking for interesting word intersections, but I find it incredibly amusing that VEGETARIAN runs through LIVING DEAD. I keep seeing images of zombies feasting on quinoa bowls and avocado toast. But maybe that\u2019s just me \u2026\n\nNew Independent Puzzle Project Raises Money for LGBTQ+ Causes\n\nFor those who are interested in supporting independent crosswords that raise money for a good cause, a $10 new donation to any of the charities listed on Queer Qrosswords will get you a PDF packet of dynamic puzzles made by constructors along the LGBTQ+ spectrum.\n\nFor more information, see the Queer Qrosswords website.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Port Authority", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The woman in the hijab turns out to be a contemporary Afghan rapper and refugee, Sonita Alizadeh, born in 1996, whose low-tech, unflinching music video about the fate of young girls sold into marriage went viral and helped her escape her own fate as a child bride. Alizadeh raps, \u201cLet me scream, I\u2019m tired of silence,\u201d while lifting a Western-style wedding veil. Beneath it her face is made up to look as if she\u2019s been beaten: swollen eyes and bruised jaw. It\u2019s a powerful image, one that Bagieu doesn\u2019t hesitate to draw into the strip.\n\nVideo\n\nAnd Bagieu\u2019s drawings are wonderful. Though sometimes spare, with minimal effort spent on backgrounds, her line manages to flow and skate through 29 stories of remarkable women. These drawings can act. They are alive with gestural attitude. They move, dance, struggle, fight back, fall in love, resist and wonder at the world. Some ham it up. Some suffer terrible abuse. To her credit, Bagieu doesn\u2019t back away from drawing the marks of violence on their faces and their bodies, which may come as a surprise to those who are expecting a rah-rah young adult girl-power sort of read.\n\nBagieu calls these comics \u201cbroad stroke portraits,\u201d and explains the sometimes too breezy storytelling this way: \u201cThis book is by no means a thorough scholarly work; rather, it\u2019s one woman\u2019s tribute \u2014 my homage to the full, daring lives they lead, often against great odds.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll of her stories follow a similar pattern. Almost every page has nine frames and each biography begins with a portrait drawn in a beribboned oval template. They cover the birth, life and death of each of her subjects in a way that can feel a bit formulaic, but this seems to have more to do with the fact that the English translation is typeset rather than in Bagieu\u2019s handwriting.\n\nIn the original version of these strips, which are luckily available in French on the Le Monde website, where they originally appeared, the difference is instantly apparent. The nature of handwriting gives the portraits a more personal \u201cvoice.\u201d It feels as if Bagieu herself is telling you these stories. They lose their Wikipedia tone and become more intimate, more like that of a cool fairy godmother recounting tales you need to hear without too much worry about sources, originality or historical accuracy. Her handwriting preserves her passion, along with clear intent to both delight and embolden the reader.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s painful to see this crucial part of her work replaced with type. It changes everything about how the stories are received. The reading speed is altered. The tone and the visual relationship between the text and the drawing just isn\u2019t there. It\u2019s her handwriting that makes these panels spring to life. Panels that seemed awkwardly composed suddenly become elegant and beautifully balanced. It\u2019s hard for people to understand the importance of a cartoonist\u2019s handwriting. In the same way melody transforms lyrics, handwriting transforms words and can have a profound impact on how the story is received and understood.\n\nSadly, nearly every scrap of Bagieu\u2019s lovely handwriting has been scrubbed and replaced in this translation, even when completely unnecessary. The only clue to this \u201cvoice\u201d is a rare lettered sign here and there, and her name, \u201cP\u00e9n\u00e9lope,\u201d sweetly signed at the end of each strip.\n\nThese \u201crebel ladies\u201d come from all over the world (though surprisingly over a third of them are American). They also come from all points in time, like Agnodice, whom Bagieu presents as a gutsy gynecologist from ancient Greece, to the astronaut Mae Jemison (the one with the tight Afro), to the \u201cAnimal Whisperer\u201d Temple Grandin and the \u201cLover of Modern Art\u201d Peggy Guggenheim (she\u2019s the one with the wild sunglasses). Bagieu includes sets of siblings, like the Wiggins sisters, who were forced by their father to form a rock band called \u201cThe Shaggs,\u201d and \u201cLas Mariposas,\u201d the Dominican Republic\u2019s Mirabel sisters, who were murdered during the Trujillo regime in 1960. And she profiles too one of my favorite women, Frances Glessner Lee, who helped crime scene investigators hone their craft by creating intensely accurate miniature replicas of rooms where murders took place.\n\nBagieu has dedicated this book to her own daughters, and I kept that in mind as I read it. When I imagine her telling these stories to them, I\u2019m reminded of something my grandmother would say when she told me these kinds of tales. \u201cOf course it is only a story my dear. But it is true!\u201d Bagieu\u2019s pen transforms these true stories into something that has the tone of a personalized fairy tale. And in the end, this turns out to be just perfect.", "title": "Portraits of \u2018Brazen\u2019 Women Who Lived as They Wanted", "authors": ["Lynda Barry", "P\u00e9n\u00e9lope Bagieu"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "And yet the nationalist banners have increased in recent years, said Mr. Myles, who claimed some credit for this. After noticing fewer banners in the parade, he exhorted marching groups several years ago to dust off their forgotten banners or have new ones made.\n\n\u201cI put the word out that we have to keep carrying the banners as a reminder that we still don\u2019t have a 32-county united Ireland,\u201d he said.\n\nTo Mr. Myles and many other participants, the banner is the most important reason for marching, a highly visible way of resisting British rule and the lack of progress on the Good Friday Agreement, not to mention the effect on Ireland of England\u2019s decision to leave the European Union.\n\n\u201cNationalism has always been part of the parade and the \u2018England Get Out of Ireland\u2019 banner still expresses that today,\u201d said Martin Galvin, a former publicity director for Northern Irish Aid, which raised money for families of I.R.A. political prisoners.\n\nMr. Galvin, a lawyer from Woodlawn in the Bronx, said the banner carries a message to Irish residents of Northern Ireland \u201cwho are still victims of British rule, and still denied freedoms, that we still support their right to freedom and don\u2019t forget them on St. Patrick\u2019s Day.\u201d\n\nThe banner is typically carried by Emerald societies, county organizations, nationalist groups and chapters of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.\n\nBut the banner has had its critics.\n\nIn 2014, a delegation from the Police Service of Northern Ireland marched in the New York parade not far from the banners. An editorial in The Belfast Telegraph afterward called the sight of the banners in the New York parade a \u201ctime warp,\u201d and a Northern Ireland political leader called the parade \u201canti-British\u201d and said parade officials should ban the banner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cParading under such a banner shows a complete lack of understanding of the political landscape in Northern Ireland in 2018,\u201d said Mark Lindsay, the chairman of the union of officers in the Police Federation for Northern Ireland. He, too, urged that the banners be prohibited.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is the 20th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement, which was wholeheartedly supported by the United States and which signaled a new beginning for Northern Ireland,\u201d Mr. Lindsay added, referring to the political arrangement between Ireland and England that governs Northern Ireland. \u201cIf Northern Ireland has moved forward so much in 20 years, is it not reasonable to ask the same of others?\u201d\n\nJohn L. Lahey, the chairman of the parade\u2019s board, said that signs and slogans \u2014 aside from each marching group\u2019s identifying banner \u2014 are banned in order to keep the parade free of politics and protest. The \u201cEngland\u201d sign has long been permitted, he said, because it simply represents the overwhelming desire among the Irish for a unified nation and is not meant to express anti-British sentiment.\n\n\u201cThere still are strong feelings that England still occupies six counties of Ireland,\u201d he said, adding that in his 25 years on the board no one has ever raised objections.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, he added, \u201cIt may be a good question for the parade board to take a look at, going forward.\u201d\n\nJohn T. Ridge, a former official historian of the parade and author of the 1988 book \u201cThe St. Patrick\u2019s Day Parade In New York,\u201d said the slogan was created by James J. Comerford, a former parade chairman and outspoken nationalist who fought the British as an I.R.A. soldier in the 1920s before emigrating to New York.\n\nOrganizers first began allowing the banners in 1948 as an outgrowth of the Anti-Partition campaign in Ireland at the time, Mr. Ridge said.\n\nIn 1972, after the Bloody Sunday massacre of Catholic demonstrators by British soldiers, the \u201cEngland Get Out of Ireland\u201d slogan was made the theme of the parade, prompting the United States Defense Department to bar military bands from participating, saying the parade had become a political event. A similar ban was ordered in 1983, when Michael Flannery, an ardent I.R.A. supporter, was named grand marshal, and called it \u201ca pro-I.R.A. parade.\u201d\n\nDuring those years, many marchers brazenly flouted parade regulations by carrying signs supporting icons of the I.R.A. movement, including Bobby Sands, who died during a hunger strike in Northern Ireland in 1981.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the years, some gay groups argued that since the \u201cEngland\u201d banner was permitted, gay groups should also be able to march under their own banner. The controversy helped pave the way for a leadership change in 2015.\n\nFor years, the parade was run by John Dunleavy, a board member whose control was loosened in 2015 when the board elected Mr. Lahey as the new chairman.\n\nMr. Dunleavy and his supporters \u2014 many of whom were members of the Parade and Celebration Committee, which he chaired \u2014 called the election illegally conducted and claimed that the board rewrote bylaws, appointed new members and eliminated elections in order to seize and expand its power, said Denis McCarthy, the committee\u2019s current chairman.\n\nMr. Dunleavy has filed a lawsuit against the board challenging the leadership and raising claims of covert finances and the spending of more than $300,000 on legal fees.\n\nMr. Lahey said those fees were necessary \u201cbecause they filed the lawsuits,\u201d and said the new leadership was critical in bringing the parade board into compliance with state laws and to change policies, including the ban against gay groups, which had attracted bad publicity and endangered sponsorships and advertising.\n\nFor the third year in a row, the Lavender & Green Alliance, an association of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, will be permitted to march under their group\u2019s banner on Saturday.\n\nAnd Mr. Myles will be carrying his banner ordering England out of Ireland.\n\n\u201cMost people watching the parade aren\u2019t up on the political situation \u2014 they\u2019re Irish for one day a year,\u201d Mr. Myles said. \u201cBut they see it and they can relate to it.\u201d", "title": "Post \u2018Troubles,\u2019 Anti-British Banner Still Flies in St. Patrick\u2019s Parade", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "As has been widely pointed out, however, the choice of color was always Britain\u2019s to make. Although European Union regulations dictate certain elements of the passports \u2014 they must be biometric, for instance \u2014 the use of some shade of red was optional, as part of an effort to promote a sense of unity across the bloc.\n\n\u201cOver the last few months, we have heard ministers happy to come on the media and talk about the new blue passport and the fact that it is an icon of British identity,\u201d the chief executive of De La Rue, Martin Sutherland, told the BBC on Thursday.\n\n\u201cBut now this icon of British identity is going to be manufactured in France,\u201d he added.\n\nMr. Sutherland said he would like to invite Mrs. May and Amber Rudd, the home secretary, to visit his factory and \u201cexplain to our dedicated work force why this is a sensible decision to offshore the manufacture of a British icon.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe decision to change manufacturer provoked outrage among politicians who backed Brexit, and many urged the Home Office to reverse the decision.\n\n\u201cThis should be a moment that we should be celebrating,\u201d said Priti Patel, a Brexit supporter and former cabinet minister.\n\n\u201cBut to be putting the job in the hands of the French is simply astonishing,\u201d she added. \u201cIt is a national humiliation.\u201d\n\nThe Home Office said it had run a \u201cfair and open\u201d competition to ensure that the new contract delivered a secure product in a way that was good value for money.\n\nThe new contract would save about $170 million over five years and create around 70 jobs at Gemalto\u2019s offices in Britain, the Home Office said.\n\n\u201cWe do not require passports to be manufactured in the U.K.,\u201d a spokesman for the Home Office said. \u201cA proportion of blank passport books are currently manufactured overseas, and there are no security or operational reasons why this would not continue,\u201d he added.", "title": "Post-Brexit U.K. Is Getting New Passports, Probably From France", "authors": ["Ceylan Yeginsu"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Of course, under a Demeny system that representation would be achieved by proxy, a novel feature for a representative democracy \u2014 but on the spectrum of powers we necessarily grant to parents, hardly that dramatic of a step. The simplest mechanism would be to assign half a vote to each custodial parent; presumably single parents with full custody could exercise the full franchise for each child, and assigning rights in custody disputes and polyamorous households would provide a mild stimulus for the legal profession.\n\nIn the U.S., higher fertility rates track with support for Republicans, but single mothers are more likely to vote for Democrats \u2014 as are recent immigrants, a relatively high-fertility group. So Demeny voting might change the balance of power within each coalition rather than benefiting either party overall: Hispanics and low-income families would have more clout within the Democratic Party, and the Hannity-obsessed elderly would cede influence within the G.O.P. to the minivan-driving middle-aged.\n\nBoth shifts would be positive. American life is increasingly polarized by age, with our politics tilted rightward by aging baby boomers voting Trump to hold off a millennial-ruled future and our cultural and commercial spheres devoted to pandering to the fashions of the adolescent. Parents, mostly Gen Xers now, are as well-positioned as any group to play a mediating role \u2014 and they will be more likely to play it effectively if they have the political power to redirect more resources to the beleaguered, ever-more-expensive cause of procreation.\n\nSuch a system, of course, would turn politically aware teenagers who differed ideologically from their parents into domestic dissidents, their citizenship hijacked, their support for an alderman who wants to build a skate park subsumed by their dad\u2019s desire to make the local dog park great again. I\u2019m personally not all that troubled by this injustice, but I\u2019m happy to offer concessions to my 16-year-old self. There\u2019s no reason Demeny voting when kids are small can\u2019t coexist with giving teenagers the vote a little earlier, if that\u2019s what\u2019s required to make their parents\u2019 empowerment during their minority more tolerable.\n\nSadly, the very thing that makes Demeny voting desirable \u2014 the political and cultural weakness of the family in an aging and individualist society \u2014 makes it hard to imagine how it could ever get off the ground politically. But it\u2019s somewhat easier to imagine experiments at the state level, where a certain kind of political self-interest could grease the wheels.\n\nJust as there\u2019s currently a push for youth voting in liberal California, where more teenage voters would top off liberal supermajorities, there\u2019s no reason that red states rich in Republican-voting families (hello, Utah) couldn\u2019t consider experiments with Demeny voting. (Certainly it would be a far better voting-reform cause for social conservatives than the present Republican fixation on hassling Democratic constituencies \u2014 sorry, preventing voter fraud \u2014 with onerous voter registration requirements.) And then blue-state feminists could respond by embracing a matriarchal Demeny alternative, like the economist Miles Corak\u2019s suggestion that a child\u2019s voting rights should be vested, not half in each parent, but wholly in the mother.", "title": "Opinion | Power to the Parents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA powerful Indian politician was sentenced on Saturday to 14 years in prison for embezzling 37 million rupees from a state government\u2019s treasury while he was the state\u2019s top elected official.\n\nThe politician, Lalu Prasad Yadav, was convicted of embezzling the equivalent of $570,000, to buy fictitious medicines and cattle fodder while he was chief minister of Bihar State from 1990 to 1997.\n\nMr. Yadav, who already had been convicted three times in related cases, was also fined $92,307.\n\nEighteen former Bihar State officials, contractors and suppliers were also sentenced in the case to jail terms ranging from three and a half to five years.\n\nMr. Yadav, 69, who served as India\u2019s railways minister from 2004 to 2009, was shifted to a hospital from a prison earlier this month, after he complained of chest pains in Ranchi, the capital of Jharkhand State.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCorruption is endemic in Indian politics, and judges are expediting trials of lawmakers accused of crimes including murder, fraud and extortion after a Supreme Court order to reach verdicts within one year in such cases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
