View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAbout 15 percent of Indian lawmakers are facing court trials on criminal charges, according to the Association for Democratic Reforms, an activist group.\n\nMr. Yadav turned his political party, Rashtriya Janata Dal, or the National People\u2019s Party, into a family enterprise, with his wife, two sons and a daughter running it.", "title": "Powerful Indian Politician Gets 14-Year Prison Sentence for Embezzlement", "authors": ["Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s a dream that has confounded generations of architects and developers,\u201d said Amanda Dameron, until recently the editor in chief of Dwell, a shelter magazine that is one of prefab\u2019s biggest proselytizers.\n\nPhoto\n\nLess than 3 percent of housing starts in the United States in 2016 were some sort of prefab. On one hand, there is a \u201cresistance to prefab as ugly boxes,\u201d she noted. But the more specialized and elaborate the look and layout, the less affordable it becomes. Designer prefab easily costs more than $300 a square foot, putting it in competition with custom-built houses.\n\nWhich is a pity, Ms. Dameron added, because, compared with traditional methods, modern prefab construction saves time, limits waste and often incorporates environmentally sensitive materials and energy-saving technologies.\n\nIf ever there was a time and place for prefab to flaunt its virtues, it is now, in Northern California. Even before the fires, stringent statewide building regulations and a shortage of contractors and construction workers made erecting a home a challenge. Now with the spike in demand for labor and materials, the wait time for completing a stick-built house in the area is estimated to be four years at a cost of anywhere from $500 to $700 per square foot.\n\nCompare that with what Stillwater Dwellings offers. The Seattle-based prefab company that Ms. Peden approached charges around $350 to $400 per square foot for a basic move-in-ready home assembled on a prepared foundation. Construction takes six to eight months once a building permit is issued.\n\nIt is to be expected that after the fires, the rebuilding process will be hampered by competition for contractors, poor site conditions and the mobbing of county building departments struggling to expedite paperwork. But prefab puts fewer demands on local construction professionals because so much of it is standardized.\n\nAn abbreviated timeline is what convinced B.J. Patnode and Glen Smith, to replace the ranch home they lost in Kenwood, Calif., just north of Glen Ellen, with a Stillwater Dwellings prefab. The men learned that if they chose an existing design rather than one they customized, the process could be substantially shortened. They picked an H-shaped model, with two bedrooms and two bathrooms in each of two wings, separated by a breezeway. They also opted for a detached garage. The estimated price is $475 per square foot.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re getting the soil boring details this week, and once they finalize the foundation and the house plans we can submit them to the county,\u201d Mr. Patnode said in late February.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf indeed the plans and expedited permits are approved as promised, manufacturing will begin this month. The materials will be delivered in June and the home should be ready by Christmas. (The men received a big advantage by jumping into the process early. According to Kaveh Khatibloo, Stillwater\u2019s co-chief executive officer, most new clients in the area are advised not to expect to begin construction until 2019 at the earliest.)\n\nBecause the men chose a panelized house \u2014 where the prefabricated parts are walls, roofing and floors, rather than three-dimensional modules with plumbing and electrical systems built into them \u2014 more work will be required to finish it on site. Expediting the project will be a general contractor and subcontractors that Stillwater Dwellings is recruiting from Reno, Nev. The crew will camp out on the property and build not just Mr. Patnode\u2019s and Mr. Smith\u2019s new home but also one for the couple next door. Both sets of neighbors will share the expense of hosting the workers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeveral North Bay fire victims said they were attracted to prefab for streamlining everything to do with home building. One Glen Ellen fire victim said he liked the idea of \u201cvery sharp designers\u201d making most decisions regarding fixtures and finishes. \u201cI\u2019m not into looking into 20 different versions of a sconce or light switch,\u201d he said.\n\nThat resident, who asked not to be named out of concern that his choice of prefab might complicate negotiations with his insurance company, had picked a one-story model from Connect Homes, a Los Angeles company that was founded with the aim of making attractive prefab housing more affordable. The style, with its open layout and expansive glass, updates the midcentury ranch house he lost and is well suited to his 1.5-acre property, he said.\n\nHe also praised Connect Homes\u2019 method of transporting modules through the intermodal system, drastically reducing shipping costs. Given a level lot, the price of a house, including design, production, installation and even appliances, ranges from $247,080 for 640 square feet to $826,160 for 3,200 square feet.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Jane Milotich, also a Glen Ellen fire victim, prefab offers a chance to have a state-of-the-art home. She went to Acre Designs, a start-up in Mountain View, Calif., for a net-zero-energy home \u201cso you practically never have to use a heating system or a cooling system,\u201d she said. Solar panels are included in all homes, and North Bay clients will receive a Tesla Powerwall battery as a standard feature, said Andrew Dickson, Acre Design\u2019s co-founder.\n\nThe homes, which cost from $250 to $320 a square foot, are engineered to be shipped flat, like Ikea furniture. This makes them easier to transport up winding roads, but they also require more attention from on-site construction teams.\n\nMs. Milotich imagined the Glen Ellen landscape dotted with new prefab homes from a variety of suppliers. \u201cIt would be like the Fountain of Youth for the community,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut as shiny contemporary buildings spring up in the North Bay, will prefab finally blossom into a viable movement? Allison Arieff, a writer and former editor of Dwell and the author of the 2002 book \u201cPrefab,\u201d doubts it.\n\n\u201cThe issue for prefab isn\u2019t aesthetic acceptance,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re way past that.\u201d Nor does speeding up construction \u2014 prefab\u2019s major benefit \u2014 ultimately matter in a process overburdened with state regulations, she said. \u201cThe permitting is the hiccup.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Arieff the cost of single-family homes built largely in factories is still too high to create an economy of scale. (She sees prefab put to its best use for multifamily construction.) Or as Ms. Dameron, lately of Dwell, put it, \u201cOnly the wealthy can afford to employ what is supposed to be a cheap alternative.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cIf you have the good fortune to be in this position, prefab is truly the smartest way to go.\u201d", "title": "Prefab Finds a Home in Fire-Ravaged Neighborhoods of California", "authors": ["Julie Lasky"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe other way was better,\u201d Amilcar Zani said as he stood in the Great Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art during his visit from Brazil. Mr. Zani, a pianist and music professor, had just learned that he was now required \u2014 as a nonresident of New York State \u2014 to pay $25 under the museum\u2019s new admission policy, which went into effect on Thursday.\n\n\u201cThis is a museum for the City of New York,\u201d he added. \u201cIt\u2019s a surprise.\u201d\n\nThe museum has gone to great lengths to prepare for Day 1 of its momentous change, from a 50-year policy of \u201cpay what you wish,\u201d announced in January. But the Met also knew that some glitches and growing pains would be inevitable.\n\n\u201cWe worked very hard for it not to be bumpy,\u201d said Daniel Weiss, the Met\u2019s president and chief executive officer. \u201cWe\u2019ll get better at it. We\u2019re going to do everything we can to welcome people and move them through.\u201d\n\n[The scene at the Met on the first day of the new fee policy.}\n\nSome out-of-state visitors on Thursday were taken aback by the new mandatory admission. \u201cHorrible,\u201d said David Walker, 34, who had come from San Francisco to take his friend Marquis Engle to the museum on the occasion of his 27th birthday. \u201cI feel caught off guard.\u201d", "title": "Prepared for Bumps, the Met Starts Charging Non-New Yorkers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Response rates to many types of surveys have declined in recent years, and Mr. Salvo said that rising dissatisfaction with government could hurt the return rate on the census. The Trump administration\u2019s approach to immigration is likely to affect the return rate in 2020 among immigrants, both those who are here legally and those who are undocumented.\n\n\u201cSome people feel the census is an instrument of the government, and they don\u2019t distinguish between ICE and the census,\u201d said Mitchell L. Moss, a professor of urban policy and planning at New York University, referring to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the federal agency that enforces immigration laws. \u201cThe undocumented, or people with uncertain immigration status, or anyone with any concern about their legal status, are not going to be responding to the census.\u201d\n\nThe census matters to the city because the count will determine how billions of federal dollars are distributed for everything from housing to bridge repairs to education. The census will also determine the state\u2019s standing in Congress. Population shifts have reduced the state\u2019s congressional delegation from 45 representatives in the early 1950s to 27 now, and New York State already expects to lose one congressional seat in reapportionment after the census. The concern among officials like Mr. Salvo is that in an undercount, New York could be forced to give up a second seat.\n\nAs in the past, census information in 2020 will be collected in two phases, first through the materials sent to every household and second by census takers who are supposed to visit the addresses that do not respond. Reflecting the digital age, the Census Bureau also has said its goal is for 55 percent of the population nationwide to be able to answer census questions online in 2020.\n\nIn New York, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced an outreach campaign to bolster participation in the census that will be called \u201cGet Counted NYC.\u201d\n\nThe 542 unreturned forms in 2010 went to addresses in the Sidney Hillman Houses on Grand Street, a complex named for a clothing workers\u2019 union leader who died in 1946. Lydia Ortiz, who has lived there for 30 years, insisted that she returned the 2010 census form, despite data showing that none had come back from the initial mailing. But she also said that mail can be a problem.\n\n\u201cIf it comes, it depends on what address they use,\u201d she said, explaining that the complex has multiple buildings with many entrances. For example, the entrances to 500 Grand Street are known as A, B and C. Collecting the original art from the refrigerator and having photographs of it in a printed book can also be protection against factors like technology\u2019s constant evolution, companies going out of business and software becoming obsolete. If you do not want to use photos from a smartphone app to create a book, custom-printing companies like Plum Print will professionally photograph children\u2019s artwork and use the high-quality images to create a hardback book for you.\n\nOther photo-sharing sites with printing services can create the art books as well. If you do not want to collect the memories in a dedicated smartphone app, and you can take a more free-form approach by snapping pictures and making videos yourself of the children explaining their art projects. Mr. Kasowitz did not respond on Tuesday to email and voice mail messages.\n\nMs. Zervos first came forward with her story in October 2016. She said Mr. Trump had kissed and groped her without her consent on two occasions in 2007, once during a job interview at his New York office and again during a later business meeting at Los Angeles hotel.\n\nThat day, Mr. Trump denied he had greeted her inappropriately. Over the following days, he released a barrage of vehement denials about the allegations from Ms. Zervos and nine other women, calling them fabrications, lies and hoaxes.\n\nMs. Zervos filed suit two months after the election, asserting she had been \u201cdebased and denigrated\u201d by Mr. Trump\u2019s comments. She is represented by Ms. Wang and Gloria Allred, who has represented several women who have accused high-profile men of sexual wrongdoing.\n\nFrom the start, Ms. Allred made it plain that the goal of the suit, beyond economic damages, was to compel Mr. Trump to admit that he lied when he said Ms. Zervos fabricated her allegation.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s lawyers, led by Mr. Kasowitz, mounted a full-court defense, arguing the suit should be dismissed as meritless, or should be halted until Mr. Trump leaves office. It was a much-needed dose of honesty undeterred by the far left\u2019s efforts to ostracize anyone with opposing opinions, and in direct defiance of the mainstream media\u2019s brutally ceaseless anti-Trump narrative.\n\nFinally, something other than the same biased opinions over and over again. But he then said law enforcement should \u201ctake the guns first, go through due process second\u201d when dealing with people who own guns and exhibit signs of mental illness.\n\nThe president also repeatedly chastised lawmakers for being \u201cafraid\u201d and \u201cpetrified\u201d of the National Rifle Association, which he then also praised as filled with \u201cgreat patriots\u201d who are \u201cwell meaning.\u201d", "title": "President Trump\u2019s Contradictory, and Sometimes False, Comments About Gun Policy to Lawmakers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump\u2019s economic report also cautioned against counting trade deficits as losses or as a metric of economic health. It argued that deficits reflect myriad factors, including the strength of the dollar.\n\n\u201cThe United States has been able to sustain a trade deficit in part because of the role of the U.S. dollar in the global economy,\u201d according to the report. \u201cForeigners are happy to hold U.S. dollars and dollar-denominated assets, which they obtain by selling more goods and services to Americans than they buy.\u201d\n\nAnd as The New York Times\u2019 economic correspondent Jim Tankersley has reported:\n\n\u201cMost economists do not see the trade gap as money \u2018lost\u2019 to other countries, nor do they worry about trade deficits to a large degree. That\u2019s because trade imbalances are affected by a host of macroeconomic factors, including the relative growth rates of countries, the value of their currencies, and their saving and investment rates. For instance, America\u2019s trade deficit narrowed dramatically during the Great Recession, when national consumption faltered.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe put tariffs on washing machines coming into the country. ...Now we have plants being built; put a 30 percent tariff on.\u201d \u2014 March 1 listening session\n\nThis confuses certain tariffs and exaggerates their impact.\n\nMr. Trump slapped steep tariffs on imported washing machines and solar panels in January. He appears to have mixed up the rates for the two products.\n\nSolar panels face a 30 percent tariff. The first 1.2 million washing machines that are imported in 2018 face a 20 percent tariff; that levy grows to 50 percent against every machine afterward that comes into the United States. Those penalties are gradually phased down in the second and third year of the three-year tariff program.\n\nComplaints by Whirlpool Inc. about its Korean competitors prompted the White House action. It has since said it added 200 jobs to a plant in Ohio in anticipation of demand resulting from the tariffs. It has not announced construction of any new plants.\n\nSamsung and LG Electronics have said they will accelerate plans to open plants in the United States following the tariff announcement. But Samsung announced its plans to build a factory in South Carolina last June and LG said it would build a new facility in Tennessee in February 2017.\n\n\u201cBut the World Trade Organization makes it almost impossible for us to do good business. We lose the cases, we don\u2019t have the judges. We have a minority of judges.\u201d \u2014 Feb. 26 speech to governors\n\nThis is misleading.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s claims of bias are contradicted by his own economic report.\n\nThe United States has won more cases than the global average. According to the White House report, \u201cthe United States has won 85.7 percent of the cases it has initiated before the W.T.O. since 1995, compared with a global average of 84.4 percent. In contrast, China\u2019s success rate is just 66.7 percent.\u201d\n\nIn cases where the United States is the respondent, \u201cit still wins 25 percent of the time, a rate that is better than the global average rate of 16.6 percent,\u201d the report noted. That rate is far better than the rates of the European Union and Japan (which have never won a case brought against them) and China (which has won only 5.3 percent of the time).", "title": "President Trump\u2019s Exaggerated and Misleading Claims on Trade", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s infinitely better that North Korea and the United States exchange words rather than missiles.\n\nYet President Trump\u2019s decision to meet Kim Jong-un strikes me as a dangerous gamble and a bad idea. I\u2019m afraid that North Korea may be playing Trump, and that in turn Trump may be playing us.\n\nI fear that Trump is being played because at the outset, apparently in exchange for nothing clear-cut, he has agreed to give North Korea what it has long craved: the respect and legitimacy that comes from the North Korean leader standing as an equal beside the American president. And I worry that we in the media and the public are being played because this is a way for Trump to change the subject from a Russia investigation and a porn actress to himself as Great Peacemaker.\n\nTo be clear, I\u2019m all for negotiations. Ever since I began covering North Korea in the 1980s, I\u2019ve favored direct talks between the United States and North Korea, and I\u2019ve called on Trump to send emissaries to meet Kim Jong-un.\n\nBut direct talks should be conducted by seasoned diplomats, offering an eventual summit meeting only as a carrot at the end of the process \u2014 and only if the summit serves some purpose higher than changing the headlines in the U.S. and legitimizing Kim\u2019s regime abroad. A face-to-face should advance the interests of two countries, not just two leaders.", "title": "Opinion | President Trump\u2019s North Korea Gamble", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Haynes could not immediately be reached for comment on Saturday.\n\nIn the suit, which was filed last month in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Lauren Bonner, an associate director at the firm, said that Mr. Haynes had belittled women employees \u2014 calling one a \u201cdumb blonde\u201d \u2014 and had a whiteboard in his office on which the word \u201cpussy\u201d was written in large letters and left there for several weeks last year.\n\nPoint72, which is based in Stamford, Conn., said in a statement after the suit was filed that it \u201cemphatically denies these allegations.\u201d In court, lawyers for Mr. Cohen and Point72 have sought to move the matter to arbitration. Also, Kathleen Finch, currently a top executive at Scripps Networks, will oversee numerous cable channels in the expanded Discovery empire, including HGTV, Food Network and ID, and will get the title of chief lifestyle brands officer.", "title": "President of TLC Is Picked to Lead the Discovery Channel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere will be lawsuits because it looks like the agency has bowed to political pressure,\u201d said Adam Winkler, a constitutional law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.\n\nThe A.T.F. and Justice Department declined to comment. A senior administration official defended the process and said that the White House had consistently coordinated with the Justice Department. In the weeks leading up to Mr. Trump\u2019s first calls to ban bump stocks, the official said, the White House knew the bureau was open to revisiting a ban.\n\nYet in tweets, public remarks and statements, Mr. Trump upended the time-consuming, often-overlooked federal rule-making process, which requires coordination among multiple agencies. The president dismissed it as \u201clong and complicated,\u201d vowing that bump stocks would be banned and that the legal review was almost finished.\n\n\u201cI expect that these critical regulations will be finalized, Jeff, very soon,\u201d Trump said in the days after the Florida shooting, directly addressing Mr. Sessions while the agency was continuing its review.\n\nAs recently as last week, the public positions of the president and the bureau were out of sync. Mr. Trump announced that the \u201clegal papers\u201d to ban bump stocks were nearly completed and said the devices would soon be \u201cgone.\u201d That same day, bureau officials said that the agency was still reviewing the issue, and that no final determination had been made.\n\nTraditionally, the bureau would study existing statutes, decide that the law permits it to regulate bump stocks and then submit a proposed rule to the Justice Department. The deputy attorney general\u2019s office would make modifications before the budget office reviewed and approved the rule change, and it would then be published in the Federal Register.\n\nThe regulation of bump stocks has strayed from that pattern. The bureau determined in 2010 that it could not regulate the devices because they could not be defined as machine guns, which are regulated under the National Firearms Act, the law that regulates firearms in the United States. To prohibit bump stocks, the agency had to contradict that earlier position, essentially saying the statute had not changed but could be read differently to include such a ban.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter the Las Vegas shooting, in which 58 concertgoers were killed by a gunman using firearms outfitted with bump stocks, public pressure grew to ban them. Justice Department and A.T.F. officials privately stuck by their earlier conclusion that they could not outlaw bump stocks, but with little appetite to tackle gun policy in Congress, Mr. Sessions asked the A.T.F. to review its determination.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAgencies periodically scrutinize earlier rulings and change interpretations. What set apart the bump stock evaluation, according to former bureau officials, was Mr. Trump\u2019s overt political pressure.\n\n\u201cNo disrespect intended, but I\u2019m sure President Trump has no idea what exactly the authority is for A.T.F. or the D.O.J. to ban these things,\u201d said Bradley A. Buckles, who was the head of the bureau from 1999 to 2004. \u201cIn all honesty, he doesn\u2019t know what his authority is in that regard.\u201d\n\nAnd in altering its 2010 interpretation made under former President Barack Obama, the bureau could be subject to lawsuits that tie up a bump stock ban in the courts.\n\n\u201cThe Justice Department and the A.T.F. are going to get sued, and Trump is going to get flak,\u201d said Josh Blackman, a professor at South Texas College of Law in Houston. \u201cObama was correct in his interpretation of the statute. If you want to ban bump stocks, it has to be done through Congress.\u201d\n\nThe apparent reversal on bump stocks appears to be more political than legal, said Rick Vasquez, a former A.T.F. official who supervised the bureau\u2019s prior determination on bump stocks.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re basically playing games with the regulations and the law right now just to make a political statement,\u201d he said.\n\nOther presidents have also influenced Justice Department rule making to help their preferred policies come into fruition, then watched as those rules became fodder for lawsuits. Under Mr. Obama, the Justice Department created the legal underpinnings to protect undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children after Congress failed to address the issue. That program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, was the subject of multiple lawsuits.\n\nIf bump stock bans are approved, as expected, questions remain on how the rule will be enforced, including whether it will apply to purchases before a ban would be instituted.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Trump continued to publicly press for a ban. \u201cBump Stocks,\u201d he tweeted, \u201cwill soon be out.\u201d", "title": "Pressured by Trump, A.T.F. Revisits Bump Stock Rules", "authors": ["Ali Watkins"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cWhite House Hails Success of Disease-Preventing Program, and Plans Deep Cuts\u201d (nytimes.com, March 13), about proposed funding cuts for the Global Health Security Agenda:\n\nAs our country increasingly embraces isolationist policies, the ever-present risk of an epidemic is a reminder that we live in an interconnected and interdependent world. Disease recognizes no borders and discriminates against no nationality.\n\nApplying an \u201cAmerica first\u201d attitude to epidemic prevention would allow for the growth and spread of disease reservoirs and would, in effect, be putting America last. Because of increased travel and mosquito migration, we are more vulnerable to the spread of disease than ever before.\n\nBecause of the success of our prevention efforts, it is easy to dismiss epidemics as an issue in the developing world. However, it takes only a few cases of Ebola to reach the United States to send the country into a fearful frenzy.\n\nWe shouldn\u2019t wait for history to repeat itself before reacting with renewed preventive efforts. We must treat threats to other countries\u2019 health as if they were threats to our own health and advocate for global health just as we would for domestic issues.", "title": "Opinion | Preventing the Next Ebola", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "When Mikael Owunna returned to his family\u2019s home in Pittsburgh after finishing a Fulbright Fellowship in Taiwan, it was unsettling. He and his family were originally from Nigeria, where gay Africans like him were scorned and mistreated. While grappling with long suppressed anxiety and depression because of that cultural tension, he saw an exhibition of the work of Zanele Muholi, the chronicler of queer experience in South Africa.\n\n\u201cThat was the first time I had ever seen an image of another queer African person,\u201d Mr. Owunna recalled. He was so moved by the experience, he began a project exploring the queer African diaspora.\n\nThere was only one problem \u2014 he didn\u2019t know any queer Africans.\n\n\u201cThat was part of the reason that I felt so isolated for so long,\u201d he said. \u201cIn the U.S., I only had ever met two other queer African people in my entire life, and I was 23. And so that was part of what really was the motivation for me \u2014 was actually just to build community and to connect with people.\u201d", "title": "Pride and Self-Love in the L.G.B.T.Q. The embassy opening is expected on May 14, to mark the 70th anniversary of the creation of the State of Israel.\n\n\u201cThis is a historic visit, the first of its kind, and he will be welcomed here with great affection,\u201d Mr. Netanyahu said of the prince\u2019s visit in a statement.\n\nOther Israelis reacted more wryly. \u201cIt only took 70 years, but finally the British royal family has gotten over the end of the Mandate,\u201d Amit Segal, the political affairs commentator for Israel\u2019s Channel 2 News, wrote on Twitter. He was referring to the quarter-century of British rule over the area, known as the British Mandate for Palestine, which ended in 1948, on the eve of Israeli independence.\n\nBut old grievances and present-day realities mean that traveling between Israel and the Palestinian territories will likely require all the royal finesse William can muster.\n\nIsrael\u2019s 70th anniversary also marks 70 years of the Nakba, or \u201ccatastrophe,\u201d when hundreds of thousands of Palestinians were expelled or fled their homes and became refugees during the hostilities leading up to, and the war surrounding, Israel\u2019s creation.\n\nHanan Ashrawi, a member of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said in a statement, \u201cPrince William, who accepted an invitation from Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, will be a welcome guest, not just of the leadership but of the Palestinian people who will provide him with the opportunity to share their stories firsthand and connect on a human level.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The visit was all the more diplomatically delicate because the grave is in East Jerusalem, which Israel annexed after the 1967 war in a move that was not internationally recognized.\n\nA report in the British newspaper The Telegraph in 2015 said British royals were unlikely to visit Israel officially before the Israeli-Palestinian conflict was resolved.\n\nAlready, there was a mini-flap over the language of the announcement. Kensington Palace said on Twitter that Prince William would visit \u201cIsrael, Jordan and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.\u201d But Israel\u2019s Haaretz newspaper noted that the Hebrew news release rendered the West Bank part of the visit as the Palestinian Authority, a term more palatable to many Israelis.\n\nAccording to Haaretz, the British Embassy in Tel Aviv clarified that the translation was consistent with their terminology. Or did occupation disappear from your terminology when talking to Israelis?\u201d\n\nMr. Abu Eid later said the translation had been updated by the embassy. In a Facebook post, the British Embassy wrote in both English and Hebrew that the prince would visit the Occupied Palestinian Territories.\n\nSome critics retorted that given its colonialist past, Britain should be the last country to preach about occupation.", "title": "Prince William Will Go to Israel, in First Official Visit by a British Royal", "authors": ["Isabel Kershner"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Probiotics and fish oil supplements during pregnancy and breast-feeding may reduce the risk for food allergies and eczema in early childhood, researchers report.\n\nIn a review of hundreds of studies, they found 19 randomized controlled trials with strong evidence showing that compared to no supplements, probiotics taken after the 36th week of pregnancy and the first months of lactation were associated with a 22 percent reduction in the risk for eczema in children.\n\nThey also analyzed six randomized trials with solid evidence that women who took omega-3 fatty acid supplements during pregnancy and lactation reduced the risk for childhood allergic reaction to eggs, the most common food allergy, by 31 percent.\n\nThe meta-analysis, in PLOS Medicine, found no evidence that avoiding certain foods or taking vitamin and mineral supplements during pregnancy had any effect on childhood eczema or food allergy.", "title": "Probiotics and Fish Oil During Pregnancy May Curb Allergies in Kids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "In her complaint, Ms. Gram-Moreno, who helped get E! off the ground in 1990 and who had worked as a part-time producer on the channel\u2019s red-carpet shows for the last 12 years, said that at the Golden Globes show, she had been instructed to flag any mention of Ms. Sadler, Time\u2019s Up or #MeToo before celebrity interviews went on the air. In the course of its red-carpet show, E! cannot broadcast all such interviews live because many take place simultaneously, so some interviews are recorded, or \u201cprerecorded,\u201d and then run a little later, with others not airing at all because of time constraints.\n\nBut after Debra Messing pointedly criticized E! during a live interview with Ms. Rancic, Ms. Gram-Moreno\u2019s legal complaint said, executives seemed concerned that more celebrities would mention Ms. Sadler. As a result, the filing said, she was directed to review more interviews before airing, in an effort to weed out mentions of Ms. Sadler.\n\n\u201cThey said, if there\u2019s any mention of Catt in the preshow, make sure you flag it,\u201d Ms. Gram-Moreno said in an interview on Thursday. \u201cYou\u2019re censoring celebrities; it\u2019s just not a good idea in my humble opinion. But it wasn\u2019t my decision.\u201d\n\nMs. Gram-Moreno said in the filing that the number of prerecorded interviews made it all but impossible to fully vet every one. She said she had listened to most but not all of the clip with Ms. Longoria, who was interviewed alongside Reese Witherspoon and Nicole Kidman, but that the decision was made to broadcast the clip before she heard Ms. Longoria say, at the end, \u201cWe stand with you, Catt.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Gram-Moreno said she was devastated about the mistake, and texted an apology to her executive producer, who replied that it probably could not have been avoided. (The New York Times reviewed the texts.) Five days later, Ms. Gram-Moreno\u2019s filing said, she received a call from an executive producer firing her from all upcoming shows she had been booked for, including the Screen Actors Guild Awards, the Grammys and the Oscars. \u201cThe executive producer said it was because you let the Catt mention get on air,\u201d Ms. Gram-Moreno said in the interview.\n\nBut Adam Stotsky, president of E! Entertainment, said in an interview on Thursday that while he and the network disputed Ms. Sadler\u2019s claims of gender inequality and pay disparity, there was no effort to censor celebrities on the carpet.\n\nIf there had been, he said, the clips of Ms. Messing and Ms. Longoria criticizing the network, and another clip of Sarah Jessica Parker alluding to the controversy, would not have been broadcast; all three interviews are also on the channel\u2019s website. And while an interview with Natalie Portman, who also voiced support for Ms. Sadler, did not make it on the air because of lack of time, he said, the network did publish the segment online too.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf we were trying to censor, which is her primary thesis here, we certainly wouldn\u2019t have done that,\u201d Mr. Stotsky said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe acknowledged that E! wanted to know ahead of time about any mentions of Ms. Sadler, and that the criticism from Ms. Messing put them on the lookout.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t agree with Debra Messing\u2019s assertion,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re not in the business of being a megaphone for an inaccurate story.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Stotsky said that there was no increase in the number of prerecorded interviews, and that the production workload did not change at the Golden Globes. Ms. Gram-Moreno\u2019s job, he said, was to \u201cscreen all of the assets completely and obviously she failed to do that.\u201d He added that she was not asked to return to work in upcoming shows (and, since she was a freelance producer, he said, she was not technically \u201cfired\u201d) because of a \u201cpattern of poor performance,\u201d with the Golden Globes slip being the final straw.\n\nAn E! spokeswoman, Sarah Goldstein, said, \u201cFor the past decade Aileen Gram-Moreno was a freelancer who worked an average of 20 days per year solely for our red-carpet coverage.\u201d\n\n\u201cAfter the Golden Globes,\u201d Ms. Goldstein added, \u201cshe was asked not to return due to job performance issues. Ms. Gram-Moreno filed her legal claim after her request for a financial settlement was turned down.\u201d\n\nMs. Gram-Moreno\u2019s lawyer, Katherine Atkinson, of Wilkenfeld, Herendeen & Atkinson, said E! never in 12 years complained about Ms. Gram-Moreno\u2019s performance; in her filing with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Ms. Gram-Moreno said she had received a performance-based raise five years ago. She also said she had been replaced with a male producer who was given a higher title.\n\nMs. Atkinson said that after her dismissal, Ms. Gram-Moreno requested that E! pay her for the shows she had been booked for, and that when the channel declined, she had to resort to legal action.", "title": "Producer Says E! Fired Her Over Red-Carpet Interview", "authors": ["Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere didn\u2019t appear to be any disciplinary consequences for cases where it seemed black and white that the officer was not telling the truth,\u201d said Richard Emery, who was the civilian board\u2019s chairman from 2014 to 2016.\n\nThe Times has examined how lying remains a persistent problem within the Police Department, which, with its 36,650 officers, is by far the nation\u2019s largest municipal force. A monthslong investigation uncovered a number of cases in recent years in which officers had clearly not told the truth about arrests they had made \u2014 a phenomenon with a storied nickname, testilying, that is still tossed around.\n\nBut the department\u2019s reluctance to investigate and discipline officers for lying \u2014 as shown by the information collected by the civilian review board \u2014 appears to be as much of a problem as the initial lies. One reason officers lie, it would seem, is that they can get away with it.\n\nLooking at the cases brought by the review board is only one way to gauge how the Police Department responds to accusations of lying within its ranks. Another way is to review criminal cases that were dismissed after a judge concluded that a police officer\u2019s testimony was not credible.\n\nIt is impossible to tally the number of such cases because they are often sealed by the court. But in several cases reviewed by The Times, it was apparent that many officers whose testimony came under suspicion experienced little negative impact to their careers; in fact, a number were subsequently promoted.\n\nOne plainclothes officer, Konrad Zakiewicz, was accused by two federal judges of testifying falsely in gun cases in 2013. His career survived. Last year, he was promoted to detective.\n\nSo was Nector Martinez, a Bronx police officer who in October 2017 testified falsely against a woman in a gun case, nearly sending her to prison on the basis of a story that appears to be made up. In November he received his gold detective shield.\n\nAnother Bronx police officer, Sean Kinane, also made detective last year, even though a federal judge the year before had said his testimony in a drug case was \u201cunreliable\u201d and \u201cnot credible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn another case, in 2016, a judge rejected the account of an arrest given by a Bronx precinct commander, Christopher McCormack, concluding that little of the commander\u2019s testimony was credible. Yet in March 2017, Inspector McCormack was promoted to deputy chief and put in charge of detectives in Manhattan North.\n\n\u2018Mistakes Based on Faulty Memory\u2019\n\nThe Police Department has pushed back against the claim that lies by officers are not punished.\n\nJ. Peter Donald, a spokesman, said the Police Department\u2019s Internal Affairs Bureau has grown more effective in recent years at catching dishonest officers. It has, for example, expanded its integrity-testing unit in which undercover investigators pretend to be crime victims, witnesses or suspects in order to see how officers respond.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re proactively rooting out people who have a problem with the truth,\u201d he said.\n\nSeparately, the Police Department convened a panel of top officials who, since 2016, have been reviewing every case in which a judge finds that an officer\u2019s testimony was not believable. The department\u2019s top legal official, Lawrence Byrne, said the cases were not, in the aggregate, indicative of a systemic problem. Often, Mr. Byrne said, the police officer\u2019s testimony was undermined by \u201cmistakes based on faulty memory, not an intentional lie.\u201d\n\nAnother police legal official, Ann P. Prunty, went further, saying that at times it is the judges, not the police officers, who are in error. \u201cSometimes you see a judge who just has a bias and thinks that an officer\u2019s account is implausible,\u201d said Ms. Prunty, an assistant deputy commissioner for legal matters and a former prosecutor in Manhattan. \u201cWhen you look at it, it is. It\u2019s quite plausible.\u201d\n\nThe Police Department noted that it brings dozens of disciplinary proceedings against police officers for making a \u201cfalse statement\u201d each year. But many of those cases appear to involve internal disciplinary matters \u2014 such as falsehoods about injuries, the circumstances of car accidents or off-duty misconduct \u2014 rather than incidents in which officers lied about arrests.\n\n\u201cIf you intentionally make a false statement as a police officer, as opposed to a mistake, you can and will be terminated for that,\u201d Mr. Byrne said. More than 70 officers have been \u201cfired or forced out of the department in the last five years\u201d for perjury or false statements, Mr. Byrne said in October at a New York City Bar Association event. About 150 more were disciplined to a lesser extent for making false statements in recent years, he said.\n\nOn paper, the Police Department\u2019s policy about lying is severe: \u201cIntentionally making a false official statement regarding a material matter will result in dismissal from the Department, absent exceptional circumstances.\u201d The policy notes that statements to the Civilian Complaint Review Board are subject to this policy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe severity of the punishment may actually discourage the department from bringing police officers up on disciplinary charges for false statements, the Commission to Combat Police Corruption noted in a recent report. With little option for lesser punishment, the Police Department may be trying to avoid ending the career of a police officer over a single lie.\n\nThe commission found that the Police Department has been \u201ccharging officers with making false official statements in far fewer instances than facts and circumstances seem to warrant.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Search of Accountability\n\nThe set of 81 cases in which the civilian review board accused officers of lying offers an opportunity to systematically examine how the Police Department handles allegations of dishonesty.\n\nThe board, with more than 80 civilian investigators and jurisdiction over a wide range of police abuses, has referred between 13 and 60 false-statement cases to the Police Department annually in each of the last five years.\n\nWhile many details remain shrouded by police secrecy laws, The Times was able to learn the names of officers cited by the board for false statements in most of the 81 cases, as well as some specifics, from a review of court documents, transcripts and internal Police Department disciplinary documents. Many of the cases involve use of force.", "title": "Promotions, Not Punishments, for Officers Accused of Lying", "authors": ["Joseph Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "This week, though, prosecutors spared the jury from reviewing autopsy photos in what may be a strategic move to avoid having the gruesome details of the case bolster the defense contention that at the time of the killings, Ms. Ortega did not understand that what she was doing was wrong.\n\nOutside experts gave several possible reasons for the prosecution approach.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re not a psychopath, why kill them?\u201d said Stephen Pokart, a Legal Aid lawyer, who represented a defendant who was found not guilty by reason of insanity in a murder trial. \u201cCrazy people do that. Human beings don\u2019t do that unless there is a reason like being seriously mentally ill. Maybe prosecutors think it will show that this woman must be insane.\u201d\n\nEvan Krutoy, a former Manhattan prosecutor who now does some criminal defense work but focuses on Title IX investigations and internal sexual harassment investigations for organizations and companies, said graphic autopsy photos did not necessarily add much to a case. He said showing autopsy photos in this case could come across to the jury as heavy-handed.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no doubt she did it,\u201d he said. \u201cMore often than not district attorneys tend not to use autopsy photos unless to advance the case in a meaningful way.\u201d\n\nMr. Krutoy said prosecutors had to strike the right balance and practice some level of restraint, particularly in a case that is emotionally charged.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t want to turn off jurors,\u201d he said. \u201cNo one wants to lose jurors in a case, particularly if they were picked for a reason.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNew York City\u2019s chief medical examiner, Susan F. Ely, described the findings in the children\u2019s autopsies, which provided insight into their final moments. Prosecutors displayed diagrams with an outline of an adult body. A diagram by the medical examiner who conducted the autopsy used lines and circles to show the location and severity of their injuries. On a diagram for Lucia Krim, there was a circle in the middle of the chest and other marks throughout.\n\n\u201cThere were many gaping wounds,\u201d Dr. Ely said. She said that her injuries indicated \u201cquite a lot of struggle and movement to get away from this knife\u201d and that some of the wounds had twisting patterns and were angular.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLeo Krim was stabbed four times in the neck and bled to death in a matter of minutes, Dr. Ely said. A diagram for Leo Krim included markings around his neck to indicate the areas where he was mortally wounded.\n\nJurors stared at the diagrams and listened intently as Ms. Ely discussed the injuries. One juror grimaced at the details. Another held her eyes closed for minutes at a time.\n\nThe autopsies could not determine which child was stabbed first.\n\nDuring cross-examination, Ms. Ortega\u2019s lawyer, Valerie Van Leer-Greenberg, tried to suggest that the multiple injuries Lucia Krim sustained reflected the actions of \u201ca person who had imploded\u201d and lost control.\n\nDr. Ely said that it was not her role to determine Ms. Ortega\u2019s mental state. \u201cI\u2019m not in the minds of people,\u201d she said. \u201cI can tell you the story of a body. Bodies don\u2019t lie.\u201d", "title": "Prosecutors Avoid Autopsy Photos of Children in Nanny Trial", "authors": ["Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Many of the cash-advance firms \u2014 some of them founded by personal-injury lawyers \u2014 rely on other lawyers to send them financially unsophisticated clients who are waiting to collect on legal settlements.\n\nIt\u2019s not uncommon for the companies to woo lawyers with gifts baskets and invitations to lavish parties. In 2013, a former part-owner of one such company pleaded guilty in federal court to engaging in a kickback scheme with a brokerage firm that recruited litigants looking for cash advances ahead of their settlements.\n\nDawn Dearden, a spokeswoman for the United States attorney\u2019s office in Manhattan, declined to comment.\n\nThe lawyers declined to name any of the parties that had received subpoenas. They said that the inquiry appeared to be in its early stages and that it was unclear whether any charges would ever be filed.\n\nHedge funds and private equity firms have poured money into the industry, lured by its fat profits. Some of the financing firms are allowing wealthy investors to get a piece of the action via online fund-raising platforms. The settlement-advance industry is an appealing area of inquiry for prosecutors in part because of its rapid growth.\n\nThe firms have moved beyond simple cash advances. Some now provide financing, at high interest rates, for surgery for plaintiffs who were injured in accidents and are suing to recover damages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe industry contends that it is providing a crucial service, allowing customers to afford basic expenses and to hold out for potentially more attractive settlements instead of automatically accepting defendants\u2019 initial offers.\n\nThe industry argues that the advances are technically not loans \u2014 the money is paid back only if the plaintiff wins a settlement or a jury award \u2014 and are therefore exempt from state usury laws. Companies say the high interest rates are necessary to cover the certainty that some funds will never be repaid.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe better-known part of the litigation finance industry \u2014 providing money to bankroll long-running, complex commercial litigation \u2014 does not appear to be under scrutiny by prosecutors.\n\nSelvyn Seidel, founder and chairman of Fulbrook Capital Management, a firm that advises commercial litigation finance firms, said an investigation into some corners of the business was overdue. He said some cash-advance firms took advantage of unsuspecting consumers.\n\n\u201cThe funders in this industry, some are very good and some are very bad,\u201d Mr. Seidel said. \u201cThey have an audience that is vulnerable. They are poor and desperate, and that is a recipe for disaster.\u201d\n\nA handful of states have imposed ceilings on the interest rates on settlement advances. State legislators in New York have introduced similar legislation.\n\nLast year, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the New York attorney general sued RD Legal, a New Jersey firm, claiming that it took advantage of former N.F.L. players who expected to receive money in the league\u2019s landmark concussion settlement. The authorities claimed that RD Legal had tricked the players \u201cinto costly advances on settlement payouts.\u201d RD Legal is contesting the matter.\n\nA representative for RD Legal said the company had not received a subpoena from the Manhattan prosecutors.\n\nRepresentatives and lawyers for several funding firms said they were unaware of the inquiry.", "title": "Prosecutors Investigate Firms That Offer Plaintiffs Early Cash", "authors": ["Matthew Goldstein", "Jessica Silver-Greenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 The Hong Kong police arrested 75 people in a raid of a local prostitution ring, the police said Thursday, a case that showed the breadth of the problem in the territory.\n\nAlthough working as a prostitute is legal in Hong Kong, the semiautonomous Chinese territory bans organized prostitution, and a conviction for knowingly taking from a prostitute\u2019s earnings could result in a 10-year prison sentence.\n\nAmong those arrested in the raid Wednesday night were eight Hong Kong residents charged with profiting from the earnings of sex workers, running a \u201cvice establishment\u201d and operating an unlicensed massage parlor.\n\nThe arrests highlighted how organized gangs, known as triads in Hong Kong, are believed to wield control over the local sex industry, which often relies on women from mainland China and other countries to fuel the trade. The women arrested in the raid came not only from mainland China but from Southeast Asia, Russia, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, The South China Morning Post reported, quoting police officials.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProstitutes in Hong Kong can work legally in so-called one-woman brothels, but prostitution syndicates often earn their money by taking a share of the income of women who ply their trade in small, subdivided flats. Wednesday\u2019s raid occurred in several such units in the Yuen Long district, not far from the border with mainland China.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. So far, 299,999 claims have been filed by homeowners and businesses but just $1.7 billion in payouts have been approved, according to the insurance department.\n\nMuch of the federal money is being dispensed as grants and loans that businesses and individuals apply for from the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Small Business Administration, among others. The typical household FEMA grant is a few thousand dollars.\n\nLawyers and community groups complain that FEMA has rejected about 60 percent of the 1.1 million household applications it has received. The agency said that figure was misleading because some rejected applicants had received loans from the Small Business Administration or aid from other agencies.\n\nOne reason for the rejections is that many Puerto Ricans cannot prove that they own a home. Only 65 percent of properties in the territory are officially registered with the government. The problem is especially acute in small cities and rural areas where there\u2019s a custom of property owners not recording titles to homes.\n\nIn Lo\u00edza, an oceanfront community of 30,000, damage to homes and businesses was extensive. Many small businesses in the town were closed for months and may never reopen. Power was restored to most residences and businesses only in the first week of February.\n\nFederal funds are only trickling into Lo\u00edza, and housing groups said one reason for the slowness was the small proportion of homes there, perhaps 20 percent, that are officially registered. In a makeshift FEMA center, agency workers allowed property owners to submit a written declaration that they owned their home. But advocates said some were still being rejected.\n\nNearby, stray horses ambled along the beach.\n\nThe halting pace of the economic recovery worries business leaders like Eli S.
