It noted that the settlement would save years of litigation, during which time workers would receive no monetary relief.\n\nMicah Wissinger, a lawyer for the Service Employees International Union and affiliated groups, which helped bring the charges against McDonald\u2019s and has been an advocate for the workers, called the proposal a sham.\n\n\u201cIn a real settlement, McDonald\u2019s would take responsibility for illegally firing and harassing workers fighting to get off food stamps and out of poverty,\u201d Mr. Wissinger said in a statement after Monday\u2019s court appearance.\n\nThe judge, Lauren Esposito, told the lawyers that she would schedule a hearing on the proposed settlement so they could air their arguments, and said the agreement would not be valid without her approval.\n\nNonetheless, some workers have already received portions of the specified payments, according to email correspondence between an official of the National Labor Relations Board and a union lawyer.\n\nThe board did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nA central question in the trial is whether McDonald\u2019s is a so-called joint employer of workers directly employed by its franchisees. A parent company is considered a joint employer if it controls their working conditions, although the legal criteria for determining control in this context has shifted in recent years.\n\nA finding that McDonald\u2019s is a joint employer would make the company liable for labor-law violations committed by its franchisees, and would require it to bargain with restaurant workers who unionized.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe workers in the case asserted that their bosses at McDonald\u2019s restaurants had disciplined them, retaliated against them and in some cases fired them for taking part in protests beginning in 2012 in which they demanded a $15 hourly wage and a union.\n\nThe general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, at the time an appointee of President Barack Obama, investigated their charges and issued complaints against McDonald\u2019s and its franchisees in 2014. A trial began in 2015 and continued into this year.\n\nBut in January, the labor board\u2019s new general counsel, appointed by Mr. Trump, was granted a 60-day stay in the case \u2014 which expired Monday \u2014 to pursue settlement talks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe general counsel, Peter B. Robb, argued that two labor board decisions in December, one of which changed the legal standard for determining joint employment, might have weakened aspects of the case against McDonald\u2019s and made a settlement more likely.\n\nIn his request for a stay, Mr. Robb said a settlement could \u201cfacilitate far more prompt and immediate remedial relief for the employees impacted by the alleged unfair labor practices.\u201d\n\nBefore the December decision by the board, a parent company like McDonald\u2019s could be considered a joint employer if it exerted indirect control over workers at a franchisee, or if it had the right to exercise control over workers that it nonetheless did not exercise.\n\nAfter the board\u2019s decision in December, a company had to have direct and immediate control over workers to be considered a joint employer.\n\nAt the time he sought a stay, labor groups argued that Mr. Robb\u2019s logic was specious because the board\u2019s case against McDonald\u2019s did not hinge on which definition of joint employment applied.\n\nLawyers for the Service Employees International Union argued that even if the general counsel preferred to seek a settlement, it made no sense to stop the trial, which was only days from concluding, in order to do so.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a court filing, they argued that stopping the trial would give McDonald\u2019s an advantage by preventing union lawyers from cross-examining a key witness, and that it fostered \u201ca game of hide-the-ball.\u201d\n\nThen, last month, one of Mr. Robb\u2019s primary arguments for a pause in the trial was upended when the labor board, on a procedural question, reversed its December decision narrowing the definition of a joint employer. At that point, the joint employer definition reverted to what it had been earlier in the trial.\n\nSeveral Democratic senators, including Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Cory Booker of New Jersey, stated in a March 7 letter that the board\u2019s reversal \u201celiminates whatever support may have existed for your efforts to settle the McDonald\u2019s case so near to the trial\u2019s close.\u201d They urged Mr. Robb to \u201cswiftly resume and finish the trial.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Robb\u2019s office pressed ahead with its efforts to reach a settlement. Last week, lawyers from the labor board\u2019s regional offices abruptly reached out to several former McDonald\u2019s workers involved in the case. In one instance, a labor board lawyer called a worker and asked if she \u201cwas ok with $50k\u201d for back pay as part of the settlement, according to an email between the board and Mr. Wissinger, one of the union lawyers. The offer was conditional on the worker\u2019s waiving her right to be reinstated in her old job.\n\nMr. Wissinger said that the calls created the impression that workers needed to accept the offers before they consulted with him or his colleagues or anyone else, and that at least two did.\n\n\u201cIt was a done deal by the time we found out,\u201d Mr. Wissinger said. \u201cThey were completely cutting us out of the process.\u201d\n\nJennifer Abruzzo, who served as deputy general counsel of the labor board until 2017, said settlement discussions that excluded lawyers who backed the workers were a break with custom.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s unusual,\u201d Ms. Abruzzo said. \u201cThe charging party is the one that the regions typically go to. And the charging party in this instance is the S.E.I.U.\u201d", "title": "Push to Settle McDonald\u2019s Case, a Threat to Franchise Model", "authors": ["Noam Scheiber"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "You need one or more big spoons in the kitchen. But a fork? Usually kitchen forks are two-pronged and fairly narrow, meant for lifting a hunk of meat or poultry or to assist with carving. This new big utility fork fills a void. It\u2019s useful not for spearing but for mixing, mashing and stirring, and for making pastry, scrambled eggs or even guacamole. The material is heat-resistant silicone. You won\u2019t let it out of your sight: Ultimate Fork, $9.95, surlatable.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Put This Fork to Work in the Kitchen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "We have demonstrated our ability to work in concert on painful sanctions after Mr. Putin\u2019s invasion of Ukraine. Now it\u2019s time to tighten those screws further, fully apply the sanctions passed by Congress last summer, and work closely with our partners to follow suit. We all need to reduce our vulnerabilities to Russia\u2019s meddling, and deny impunity to those aiding and abetting those efforts.\n\nThe project of making Russia great is part and parcel of making Mr. Putin and his crony capitalist friends rich. That is also a vulnerability. Too many countries for too long have facilitated the enrichment and corruption of Mr. Putin\u2019s inner circle. That needs to end.\n\nThe logical next step after the diplomatic expulsions is a similarly coordinated campaign to hit the wallets of the Kremlin elite. That won\u2019t be easy or pain-free for a number of economies, including our own. A strong signal that business as usual is over will unsettle Moscow and stimulate concerns about what more drastic steps might follow. Mr. Putin knows that the longer he is denied foreign direct investment, the further behind his economy will fall.\n\nThere is some risk of a more forceful response to Mr. Putin\u2019s aggression. We need to be vigilant not to prompt an unprovoked escalation in Ukraine or legitimate Mr. Putin\u2019s shrouded machinations by deploying our own impulsively \u2014 whether in cyberspace or other types of covert action. Sustaining military and diplomatic channels is not a favor or a sign of weakness. It\u2019s a way to demonstrate that while we will not give in to Mr. Putin, we will not give up on the longer-term prospect of a healthier relationship with Russia.\n\nIt may very well be that last week\u2019s countermeasures are nothing more than a passing phase. We already see cracks within the European Union and Britain is divided by the Brexit debates. The Trump administration has signaled policy shifts, like pulling out of the Iranian nuclear agreement, that will make it easier for Mr. Putin to create wedges.\n\nAmerican actions this past week offer a hopeful sign. Agile diplomacy can still land a punch. Now comes the hard part. Diplomacy won\u2019t transform the adversarial relationship with Mr. Putin\u2019s Russia, but it can manage it. Mr. Putin is right about one thing: We have the stronger cards. We\u2019ve just played them erratically.\n\nNow we should lead with diplomacy and demonstrate its enduring power and purpose. If we don\u2019t, we\u2019ll perpetuate illusions about partnerships with Mr. Putin and the irrelevance of diplomacy \u2014 and waste our bigger, better hand.", "title": "Opinion | Putin Has Overplayed His Hand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Maksim S. Lubyanoy, a sociologist, set up an independent polling organization last year called the Scientific Research Institute of Social Management Problems. Its weekly polls in Nizhny Novgorod, based on street interviews with 1,200 people, have shown in recent months a steady drop in support for Mr. Putin, a corresponding rise for Mr. Grudinin and fewer people committed to voting.\n\nThose who said they would definitely vote has dropped to 19.9 percent, from a high of 23.5 percent in mid-January. The percentage of those saying they are likely to vote has risen to 44.4 percent from 27.9 percent in the same period.\n\nSupport for Mr. Putin in those two categories combined has dropped to 38.6 percent, from a high of 52.9 percent in February. Mr. Grudinin has shown steady growth, to 26.4 percent from 14.2 percent in January.\n\nVladimir V. Zhirinovsky, an ultranationalist firebrand and perennial presidential candidate, was in third place, around 16.5 percent. The other five candidates are all polling around 3 percent or less. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.68 percent.\n\nMr. Grudinin, 57, is the director of the Lenin State Farm, a former Soviet collective on Moscow\u2019s southern outskirts that has become a successful real estate and farming enterprise famous for strawberries. Although not a member of the Communist Party, he has embraced its trademark positions, like free education, price controls and the nationalizing of strategic industries now owned by oligarchs.", "title": "Putin Is Certain to Win Re-election, but His Support May Be Slipping", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Putin\u2019s speech resonated as recognition that the international sanctions levied in response to his country\u2019s seizure of Crimea in 2014 and its continued meddling in eastern Ukraine are hurting ordinary Russians.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Putin\u2019s persistent focus on building up Russia\u2019s military arsenal has shortchanged efforts to revamp an economy that remains overly dependent on oil and woefully short of investment.\n\n\u201cThe way Russia has been avoiding the subject the last few years is to rally around the flag,\u201d said Nafez Zouk, chief emerging markets economist at Oxford Economics, a research institution in London. \u201cTwo years later, people are still earning less than they did two years before. Even if there isn\u2019t a real political opposition, Putin doesn\u2019t want his legacy to go to waste. He needs to get the economy back on track.\u201d\n\nIn certain important regards, the Russian economy has already improved \u2014 although this says more about the bleakness of recent times than how robust things are now.\n\nBetween 2014 and 2016, Russia was battered by a combination of forces. Oil prices plunged from more than $100 a barrel to less than $30, draining Russia\u2019s coffers. And international sanctions deprived Russian companies and financial institutions of access to capital markets.\n\nThe result was a brutal recession that assailed the Russian middle class, sowing joblessness and eroding savings.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose days are over, with Russia having weathered talk that its economy risked collapse. Oil prices are back above $60 a barrel, while the sanctions have forced Russian firms to wean themselves from what had been an unhealthy addiction to international debt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince the beginning of last year, Russia\u2019s economy has been growing again, albeit modestly. The World Bank forecasts expansion of 1.7 percent this year and 1.8 percent in 2019.\n\nBut even if growth accelerates, Russia remains in the same troubled patch it has occupied for years, having failed to transform an oil-dependent economy dominated by politically connected oligarchs into one in which private entrepreneurship is allowed to take root.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFundamentally restructuring the economy would entail laying off workers at uncompetitive, state-protected firms in the oil and gas sector \u2014 a course that would yield more unhappiness among the citizenry.\n\nMr. Putin, who promised to cut the poverty rate in half over the next six years, presented a long list of proposed means of spurring economic growth while relieving the middle class of its strains.\n\nSeeking to relieve a persistent housing crunch, Mr. Putin said that mortgage rates must be lowered and salaries increased to enable more people to buy homes.\n\nHe said Russia must double its spending on the construction of roads, earmarking more than 11 trillion rubles (about $193 billion) for upgrading and extending the nation\u2019s patchy transportation network. He also promised lawmakers that a bridge being erected between Russia and Crimea would soon be opened.\n\nAnd he called for increasing investment in education.\n\nMost of these talking points have been heard before \u2014 more than once. Experts were dubious that such measures could be financed absent another surge in oil prices.\n\nInternational sanctions remain, imposed in response to Russian military adventurism in seizing Crimea and intervening in eastern Ukraine. And Mr. Putin gave no signs of changing his posture, using his speech to threaten Western nations with a battery of new weapons \u2014 including an intercontinental nuclear cruise missile.\n\nStill, the speech\u2019s emphasis suggested that Mr. Putin is especially keen to shift the conversation to economic revival.\n\n\u201cHis speech is a sign that poverty is an increasing problem for Russia that cannot be ignored,\u201d said Per Hammarlund, chief emerging markets strategist at SEB Group, a global investment bank based in Stockholm.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPutin needs to acknowledge this, and the Russian electorate expects him to try to do something about it.\u201d", "title": "Putin Vows to Lift Russia\u2019s Struggling Middle Class", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "In a late-night news conference broadcast live on television, Mr. Putin said he could now begin thinking about changes in the makeup of the government. Asked if he was also planning any changes in the Constitution, particularly any that would allow him to remain in power beyond 2024, he said it was an odd night to ask such a question.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s count \u2014 what, will I be sitting here until I\u2019m 100 years old?\u201d he said. \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nAleksei V. Makarkin, a leading analyst at the Center for Political Technologies, a Moscow-based think tank, called the turnout quite high considering that there was no question about the outcome.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is a mandate to pursue any policy,\u201d he said. \u201cSociety trusts Putin and believes that he can deal with any internal and external problems.\u201d\n\nThe voting was more a referendum than a choice, but there is no question that Mr. Putin is wildly popular among Russians. His picture and his campaign slogan, \u201cStrong President, Strong Russia,\u201d blanketed the country, and many voters who supported him echoed that sentiment.\n\n\u201cHe is a strong politician, a strong president, who led Russia to rebirth,\u201d said Vitaly T. Tretyakov, the dean of the faculty of television journalism at Lomonosov Moscow State University, after casting his ballot at Polling Station No. 148, a five-story red brick schoolhouse in central Moscow.\n\nThe years under President Boris N. Yeltsin in the 1990s were a disaster, Mr. Tretyakov said, echoing a common theme. Whether the current electoral system is good or bad is a different issue, he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor many voters, choosing any of the seven opposition candidates would have been like asking one of the dwarves to assume the role of Snow White.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAleksei A. Navalny, an anti-corruption campaigner and the Kremlin\u2019s most dogged critic, was barred from the race and called for a boycott.\n\nMr. Putin\u2019s closest competitor was Pavel N. Grudinin, 57, the Communist Party candidate; preliminary results showed he got around 13 percent of the vote. Mr. Grudinin, the millionaire director of a farming enterprise, the Lenin State Farm, had vowed to restructure the economy and nationalize industries controlled by oligarchs.\n\nNikolai A. Volkov, a 26-year-old business manager, said he had voted for Mr. Grudinin because he thought his transformation of the Soviet collective into a successful agricultural and real estate business could be a model for all of Russia.\n\nPhoto\n\nKsenia A. Sobchak, 36, the only woman in the race, received less than 2 percent of the vote in preliminary results. One 26-year old theater sound engineer who voted for her \u2014 nervous enough about it that he wanted to be identified only by his first name, Andrei \u2014 said that \u201cvoting for a candidate whose program is the complete opposite of Putin\u2019s is a type of protest.\u201d\n\nGlancing around the polling station, he added, \u201cTo be honest, I feel like I have come to an old people\u2019s home.\u201d\n\nThe voters did skew older, with an exit poll conducted by the state-backed Vtsiom agency showing that just over half the voters were above age 45, while only about 9 percent of those ages 18 to 25 participated.\n\nOlga Kozlova, 20, a student at the Russian Customs Academy, was hanging out with a friend in a shopping mall on Sunday. Neither had voted.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThese are the first elections we can vote in,\u201d she said. But she skipped them, she said, because the outcome was obvious and \u201cmy vote will have no impact.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLocal governments tried various efforts to get out the vote, not least trying to turn the entire event into a carnival. There was music, discounted food for sale and games for the children. At one Moscow polling station a woman dressed as a clown shouted out historical questions and rewarded right answers with a chocolate bar.\n\nThe region of Omsk offered free iPhones for voters who turned up in the best costumes, prompting a parade of voters who came as Santa Claus or a Roman legionnaire. One family was a hockey team.\n\nState employees, pensioners and residents of rural areas, all of whom depend heavily on the government, tend to vote for Mr. Putin out of a combination of enthusiasm, habit and blackmail.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor some who supported Mr. Navalny, the outcome was a stark disillusion.\n\nIlya Amutov, a 26-year-old software engineer and longtime Navalny supporter, served as an election observer for the Sobchak campaign. He was taken aback watching elderly voters at his polling station off Leninsky Prospekt kissing Mr. Putin\u2019s pictures on the official poster listing all eight candidate and crossing themselves, he said. That is how the Russian Orthodox faithful treat religious icons.\n\n\u201cThey cherish and love Putin,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is a big cultural shock. Of course the election was like a circus, but it was not rigged by our authorities. It was rigged by our people. This is extremely depressing.\u201d\n\nMr. Navalny tried to put the best face on it, telling reporters at his headquarters that at least the boycott seemed to keep turnout below 2012 levels.\n\nThere were scattered reports of the usual election irregularities, with a few observers harassed or beaten and video cameras catching some ballot-box stuffing. There was also a discrepancy in some places between the turnout numbers tallied by Mr. Navalany\u2019s organization, which fielded more than 30,000 observers, and the official numbers.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere was no real need for extensive rigging, however, because of Mr. Putin\u2019s genuine popularity.\n\nThe result set off immediate, bitter infighting within the already divided liberal opposition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Sobchak, who just organized a new political party, came sweeping into Mr. Navalny\u2019s headquarters proclaiming that they should unite. \u201cWe have common goals,\u201d she said. \u201cThey are more important than our differences, regardless of how unjust the government has been to you.\u201d\n\nWhat came next was like a scene from \u201cHouse 2,\u201d the reality television show based on \u201cBig Brother\u201d that Ms. Sobchak hosted before she became a political journalist.\n\nMr. Navalny verbally bashed Ms. Sobchak, calling her a tool of the Kremlin and releasing the anger evidently pent up since she stepped forward to claim the liberal banner in the election.\n\n\u201cIt was a grandiose fraud and you were part of it,\u201d he shouted, accusing her of undermining the boycott. \u201cYou are part of this lie, this falsification.\u201d\n\nInstead of criticizing Mr. Putin, he said, Ms. Sobchak made advertisements for caviar and vodka during the campaign.\n\nMany suspected Ms. Sobchak, who is the daughter of Mr. Putin\u2019s political mentor, of being a Kremlin stalking horse in the campaign and agreeing to do it to raise her profile for the advertising and lucrative hosting opportunities that come with appearing on state television. She had been barred from such appearances after she took part in anti-Kremlin demonstrations in 2012.\n\nMr. Putin, a former Soviet intelligence officer, barely bothered to campaign, except to stress his constant theme that Russia was a besieged fortress and that he was the only man to keep it safe by rebuilding its arsenal and projecting power beyond its borders, especially in challenging the United States.\n\nElection Day was moved to March 18, the fourth anniversary of Russia\u2019s seizure of Crimea, to emphasize that theme.", "title": "Putin Wins Russia Election, and Broad Mandate for 4th Term", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Also on Friday, Britain\u2019s Metropolitan Police said they were treating as a murder the death of Nikolai Glushkov, a former Russian business executive who was found dead in his home in London on Monday. The police said they made the change \u201cfollowing the results of a post mortem,\u201d but did not elaborate.\n\nA Russian court tried and convicted Mr. Glushkov in absentia last year on corruption charges, and he was an associate of the former Russian business oligarch Boris Berezovsky, a Putin critic who died in London in 2013.\n\nImage Nikolai Glushkov Credit London Metropolitan Police, via Agence France-Presse \u2014 Getty Images\n\nThe Skripals were poisoned on March 4 with a nerve agent known as a Novichok, a type of powerful chemical weapon developed by the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 1980s, and both remain in critical condition, according to British officials. The case, including the use of an exotic toxin, had echoes of the 2006 assassination of Alexander Litvinenko, another former Russian agent, who was fatally poisoned in London with a radioactive isotope.\n\nAn official inquiry concluded that Mr. Putin had himself most likely ordered the death of Mr. Litvinenko, a harsh critic of the Russian government. British officials have promised to re-examine the suspicious deaths of more than a dozen people in Britain who had run afoul of the Kremlin.\n\nIn Moscow, the Russian authorities said on Friday that they had opened a criminal case into the poisoning of Ms. Skripal, which was committed by \u201ca generally dangerous method,\u201d and the death of Mr. Glushkov.\n\n\u201cThe investigation will be conducted in accordance with the Russian and international law,\u201d the Investigative Committee of Russia, the equivalent to the F.B.I., said in a statement. \u201cThe investigators plan to engage highly-qualified experts and are also ready to work with the competent agencies in Britain.\u201d\n\nThe attack on the Skripals has caused outrage in Britain and among its allies, pushing relations between London and Moscow to their lowest level since the Cold War.", "title": "Putin \u2018Likely\u2019 Ordered Russian Ex-Spy\u2019s Poisoning, Britain Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s another sign that the president may try to fire Mr. Mueller \u2014 and that he\u2019s beginning to dismiss his advisers\u2019 guidance in favor of his own instincts.\n\nMore evidence: Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer called on the Justice Department to end the investigation, and the president had Andrew G. McCabe, the former F.B.I. deputy director, fired. (Our reporter was told that Mr. McCabe kept memos about his interactions with Mr. Trump.)\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Facebook is under fire in Britain and the U.S.\n\nA collaboration between our reporters and The Observer of London showed that a firm specializing in the new field of psychological voter-profiling used private information from the Facebook profiles of more than 50 million users, taken without their permission.\n\nThe firm and its American arm were players in the campaigns for both Brexit and the presidency of Donald Trump. Above, one of our sources.\n\nFacebook banned the American arm \u2014 Cambridge Analytica, financed by the hedge-fund billionaire Robert Mercer and championed by the now-exiled Trump adviser Stephen Bannon \u2014 after we began asking questions.\n\n\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Democracy rising.\n\nVoters across Europe are gravitating toward illiberal populists. But Slovakia appears to be bucking the trend, our correspondent writes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProtests recently forced the resignation of Prime Minister Robert Fico, and they have shown little sign of abating as young demonstrators \u2014 whose parents lived under Communism \u2014 appear determined to safeguard hard-won freedoms.\n\nWatch our video on the public outcry.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cThe Devil of the Republic.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s the nickname for Jean-Marie Le Pen, above, the patriarch of France\u2019s far right. His unrepentant extremism led his own daughter, Marine, to kick him out of the country\u2019s far-right National Front party.\n\nBut his memoir, \u201cSon of the Nation,\u201d is now a best seller.\n\nOur correspondent spent time with Mr. Le Pen, who is nearly 90, at a gloomy old mansion in the Paris suburbs he inherited from a backer.\n\n_____\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. The move came two days after Xi Jinping began a new term as president.\n\n\u2022 Russian money has deep roots in British life, including in the Premier League, one of Britain\u2019s key cultural exports. That could complicate any efforts by the British government to target the London assets of Russian oligarchs.\n\n\u2022 The smuggling of U.S. technological secrets is outpacing Cold War levels, American experts and officials say \u2014 and China, Iran, North Korea and Russia are behind it.\n\n\u2022 Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the heir to Saudi Arabia\u2019s throne, begins a visit to Washington today. Her music has more than 16 million streams on Spotify.\n\n\u2022 Naomi Osaka won the BNP Paribas Open after defeating Simona Halep and other stars en route to the final.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam: Anthony Acevedo, a World War II prisoner whose diary documented Nazi atrocities, died at 93.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIn March 1957, when Elvis Presley was 22, he purchased an opulent mansion in Memphis, called Graceland, for just over $100,000.\n\nHe was already a star, and at work on his second movie, \u201cLoving You.\u201d\n\nThe land had been owned by the S. E. Toof family for generations, and it was named for one of the female relatives, Grace. Grace\u2019s niece and her husband built the mansion in 1939. Above, Mr. Presley with Yvonne Lime at Graceland around 1957.\n\nMr. Presley installed a pool with a jukebox nearby, hosted friends and relatives and created a \u201cJungle Room\u201d with green shag carpets and a Polynesian theme.\n\nAfter struggling with ill health and prescription drug abuse, he died of a heart attack at Graceland on Aug. 16, 1977, and is buried there. He was 42. Read his Times obituary here.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFive years later, Graceland opened to the public and became one of the country\u2019s most popular tourist destinations, drawing visitors from around the globe. Many visit yearly (the address is 3764 Elvis Presley Boulevard) to mark the anniversary of his death.\n\nLast year, just before the 40th anniversary, Graceland underwent a $140 million expansion, including a large hotel and entertainment complex. You can take a virtual tour here.\n\nKaren Zraick contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. (In addition to our European edition, we have Australian, Asian and U.S. editions.)\n\nSign up here to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, and here\u2019s our full range of free newsletters.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Putin, Brexit, Facebook: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Mike Ives"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 In the early spring of 2014, the world watched, astonished, as soldiers without insignia took over government buildings in Ukraine\u2019s Crimea peninsula, surrounded Ukrainian military bases and installed new leaders in the region. President Vladimir Putin of Russia claimed at the time that these were not Russian soldiers. Instead, he said, these were \u201clocal self-defense units.\u201d Less than a month later, Russia annexed Crimea. And a year after that, Mr. Putin admitted what everyone had suspected all along: Yes, Russian soldiers had been involved.\n\nThat was when the term \u201cplausible deniability\u201d became a standard part of Western discussions about Russia. The practice of carrying out dubious deeds through the hands of proxies or other hard-to-identify agents has since become something of a trademark of Mr. Putin\u2019s. Sometimes, the agents are indeed Kremlin actors in disguise, as they were in Crimea. But in the years since, Mr. Putin has pushed this tactic even further, implicitly or explicitly encouraging independent agents to act on their own, keeping the Kremlin\u2019s hands clean. On many occasions, this has left the West a helpless bystander, unable to force Russia to account for its actions.\n\nBut time may be running out on this tactic. The attempted murder of Sergei Skripal, a former Russian double agent who was found unresponsive in southwest England earlier this month, poisoned with a deadly nerve agent, may be the moment when \u201cplausible deniability\u201d has reached its limits. In fact, it now looks as if it is turning against its masters in the Kremlin. The United States\u2019 decision on Monday, alongside Canada and a number of European countries, to expel Russians in retaliation for the poisoning makes clear to Moscow that its actions have consequences, whether it denies them or not.\n\nSince the annexation of Crimea, Russia has resorted to \u201cplausible deniability\u201d again and again. The interference in the American presidential elections was a classic case: Mr. Putin has repeatedly emphasized that Russia has not intervened \u201cat the level of the government,\u201d but he admits that some \u201cpatriotic hackers\u201d or trolls with Russian citizenship might indeed have been active. The Russian president has also attempted to reap policy benefits from the denied action, steering the conversation toward his own priorities: accusing the United States of interfering in Russia and making the case for cooperating to regulate the internet and social media.", "title": "Opinion | Putin\u2019s Favorite Tactic Has Finally Backfired", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Eager to keep control of the story, Mr. Putin warned people to stick to official information. \u201cYou know it very well that social media is a murky source unfortunately,\u201d he told officials and relatives in Kemerovo. \u201cWe need to rely on the results of the actual inquiry.\u201d\n\nThat Russia is far from being a monolithic one-party state, despite Mr. Putin\u2019s lopsided re-election, was clear Tuesday evening in the two events organized to mourn the dead in Kemerovo.\n\nOne was state-sponsored, near the Kremlin; the other was held in Pushkin Square, by Muscovites who wanted no part in the official gathering. The alternative wake began as a solemn vigil with mourners burning candles and laying flowers, some of them in tears, but gradually turned into a small-scale political rally with chants of \u201cRussia without Putin!\u201d \u201cCorruption kills!\u201d \u201cShame on television!\u201d and \u201cSilence means death!\u201d\n\nInstead of fuming at the United States and its allies, Mr. Putin, during his Siberia trip, used another tool in his repertoire of responses to most problems: He set the security apparatus to work, telling relatives of the victims that the Investigative Committee, Russia\u2019s answer to the F.B.I., had deployed 100 investigators and would find those responsible for the fire and punish them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe blamed \u201ccriminal negligence\u201d and \u201cslovenliness\u201d for the blaze, which started in a children\u2019s play area and then swept through nearby cinemas crowded with young people.\n\nThe regional governor, Aman Tuleyev, a relic of the Soviet era, begged for forgiveness and accused opposition activists of trying to exploit the tragedy for political ends. \u201cIt\u2019s sacrilege when there\u2019s grief and you use it to solve your own problems,\u201d the governor said.\n\nMr. Putin avoided mention of what many, including those who lost family members, believe was the real cause of the fire: a state system, including multiple agencies responsible for limiting fire and other risks, eaten away by corruption and incompetence.\n\nRussia has strict building codes and elaborate safety regulations but, instead of being enforced, they are frequently skirted with the help of corrupt officials willing to turn a blind eye to violations in return for cash bribes and favors. Law enforcement officers, who are supposed to prevent this, are themselves often on the take or under pressure from powerful political barons not to investigate.\n\nIn a Facebook post on Tuesday, Anton Gorelkin, a member of Parliament from Kemerovo, gave a list of possible reasons the fire started \u2014 a prank by children, a short circuit, arson \u2014 but he said the real cause of the tragedy was greed.", "title": "Putin\u2019s Grim Reality: Public Fury Over Children\u2019s Deaths in Mall", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia threatened the West with a new generation of nuclear weapons Thursday, including what he described as an \u201cinvincible\u201d intercontinental cruise missile and a nuclear torpedo that could outsmart all American defenses.\n\nThe presentation by Mr. Putin, which included animation videos depicting multiple warheads aimed at Florida, where President Trump often stays at his Mar-a-Lago resort, sharply escalated the military invective in the tense relationship between the United States and Russia, which has led to predictions of a costly new nuclear arms race.\n\nWhile Mr. Putin may have been bluffing about these weapons, as some experts suggested, he cleverly focused on a vulnerability of American-designed defenses: They are based on the assumption that enemy nuclear missiles fly high and can be destroyed well before they reach their targets.\n\nThe new class of Russian weapons, he said, travel low, stealthily, far and fast \u2014 too fast for defenders to react.", "title": "Putin\u2019s \u2018Invincible\u2019 Missile Is Aimed at U.S. Vulnerabilities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "IN SHOCK\n\nMy Journey From Death to Recovery and the Redemptive Power of Hope\n\nBy Rana Awdish\n\n266 pp. St. Martin\u2019s. $25.99.\n\nImage\n\nIf Bartolo\u2019s writing breaks open the wall between the physician and the rest of the world, then Awdish\u2019s memoir of her harrowing time as a patient in the intensive care unit where she works blows it open completely. Awdish\u2019s journey from physician to helpless patient and then back to reformed physician is equal parts dramatic, engaging and instructive. Her experience of acute illness makes very clear how doctors who believe they are in control of situations establish and perpetuate barriers between themselves and those in their charge. Most devastatingly for Awdish, and for many patients, is the often unintentional use of language that alienates the patient from the physician.\n\nWhile many books about medicine and illness address this, Awdish\u2019s work is singular in its rawness and willingness to show us a person at one with her pain and isolation, able to relate completely through her writing to the intense feelings of helplessness that confront almost every patient admitted to a hospital. Awdish\u2019s book suffers only when she slips into physician mode, searching for words to relate the profundity of medicine as a profession and calling. This takes us out of a story so beautifully constructed we can feel the tip of the scalpel and the weight of the large vascular tumor that is the cause of her yearlong nightmare.\n\nAwdish\u2019s book is the one I wished we were given as assigned reading our first year of medical school, alongside our white coats and stethoscopes. It delivers the sobering message that being a physician does not confer upon you the ability to exist outside of life.\n\nTHIS NARROW SPACE\n\nA Pediatric Oncologist, His Jewish, Muslim, and Christian Patients, and a Hospital in Jerusalem\n\nBy Elisha Waldman\n\n245 pp. Schocken. $25.95.\n\nImage\n\nCan you truly be compassionate when external circumstances create walls that cannot be broken or scaled no matter how hard you try? This seems to be the central question in Waldman\u2019s fantastic book. A Jewish American pediatric oncologist and palliative care specialist who makes aliyah to Israel to work at the Hadassah hospital in West Jerusalem, Waldman exhibits a rare self-awareness, avoiding the \u201cMiddle-East-splaining\u201d that often accompanies stories from the region. Waldman believes in the Zionist project as much as he believes that as a doctor his mission is to heal whomever he comes in contact with regardless of religion or ethnic affiliation. At the same time, his left-of-center politics put him at odds with a society that, during his seven years in Israel, grows more Balkanized and violent.", "title": "Putting Down the Scalpel, Picking Up the Pen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s going on here? I don\u2019t think it\u2019s an accident that the modern G.O.P. contains so many crooks and that these crooks seem to thrive in intraparty politics. On the contrary, the success of people like Blankenship \u2014 or Trump \u2014 was an inevitable consequence of the political strategy Republicans have followed for decades. For the simple truth is that ever since Reagan, Republicans have basically played a con game on American voters.\n\nTheir sustained, invariant agenda has been upward redistribution of income: cutting taxes on the rich while weakening the social safety net. This agenda is unpopular: Only a small minority of Americans wants to see tax cuts for the wealthy, and an even smaller minority wants cuts to major social programs. Yet Republicans have won elections partly by denying the reality of their policy agenda, but mainly by posing as defenders of traditional social values \u2014 above all, that greatest of American traditions, racism.\n\nAnd this sustained reliance on the big con has, over time, exerted a strong selection effect both on the party\u2019s leadership and on its base. G.O.P. politicians tend disproportionately to be con men (and in some cases, con women), because playing the party\u2019s political game requires both a willingness to and a talent for saying one thing while doing another. And the party\u2019s base consists disproportionately of the easily conned \u2014 those who are easily fooled by claims that Those People are the problem and don\u2019t notice how much the true Republican agenda hurts them.\n\nThe point is that Trumpism was more or less fated to happen. Trump\u2019s crude racism and blatant dishonesty are only exaggerated versions of what his party has been selling for decades, while his substantive policy agenda \u2014 slashing taxes on corporations and the wealthy, taking health care away from lower-income families \u2014 is utterly orthodox.\n\nEven his protectionism is less of a departure from Republican norms than people imagine. George W. Bush put tariffs on steel, while Reagan limited imports of Japanese autos. Cutting taxes on the rich is a fundamental G.O.P. principle; free trade isn\u2019t.", "title": "Opinion | Putting the Ex-Con in Conservatism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "For the latter group, walking through the revolving doors of the Marriott Hotel in Stamford, Conn., each spring is like coming home. Angela Olsen Halsted, of Arlington, Va., is not only a dedicated solver but has also had four crossword puzzles published in The New York Times. She calls this weekend her \u201chappy place.\u201d\n\nIn the crowded lobby on Friday afternoon, warm hugs were exchanged, puns were suitably groaned at and more than a few brave souls donned crossword-themed clothing, including Karen Chu of San Francisco, who strolled nonchalantly through the lobby dressed as a pencil.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Friday evening, Mr. Shortz welcomed more than 670 contestants to the Marriott ballroom, noting that the turnout was the largest since the \u201cWordplay\u201d bump, the sudden increase in attendance attributed to the 2006 documentary. It has gotten so popular that HBO\u2019s \u201cReal Sports with Bryant Gumbel\u201d was filming an upcoming episode around the tournament.\n\nOn Saturday morning, the contestants gathered for the first puzzle, a relatively straightforward one meant to ease competitors into the speed-solving groove. Tournament officials fanned out to distribute puzzles to waiting hands. Even a mundane activity like this was exciting to competitors, because the 65 officials are the \u201cglitterati\u201d of the crossword world: the puzzle constructors and editors who deliver their obsession to them on a daily basis.\n\nPhoto\n\nA large, digital clock ticked down the minutes \u2014 as if solving next to national speed-solving champions wasn\u2019t pressure enough \u2014 and those who finished within the time limit mingled outside the ballroom to compare notes. The competitive aspect might be about speed, but the holy grail for all but a handful of the top solvers is to come away with a \u201cclean\u201d puzzle, which is one that is completed with no mistakes.\n\nPhoto\n\nSix crossword puzzles of varying sizes and difficulties were completed on Saturday. This included the notorious Puzzle 5 \u2014 created this year by digital crosswords editor Joel Fagliano \u2014 and which Mr. Shortz referred to as the most mind-bending of the weekend\u2019s challenges, using more colorful language than is allowed here.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s a mentally draining day by any standard, but there were social activities to bolster the weary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome who were flummoxed by a confusing theme in Puzzle 4 joined the survivors of Puzzle 5 in the Marriott bar to unwind over cocktails.\n\nAt 8 p.m., the ballroom filled once again. Matt Ginsberg talked about his computer program, Dr. Fill, which solved the more straightforward puzzles in a matter of seconds. A few people who resented Dr. Fill\u2019s speed enjoyed the schadenfreude when the program missed a more complex theme that the human solvers understood. Robots have yet to outdo humans when it comes to playing with words.\n\nIf the ins and outs of computer programming were not to one\u2019s taste, there was always a 10-minute play, by the playwright Donna Hoke, featuring a human crossword puzzle and his Sudoku sidekick, both of whom attempt to pick up a flirtatious pencil in a bar.\n\nSunday was all about trying to topple the reigning champion, Mr. Feyer, in the finals, but first there was the talent show. While the officials graded Puzzle 7, which was meant to shake out the top contenders, competitors and puzzle makers alike strutted their stuff with inside jokes, songs and performances about the joys and trials of crossword puzzle solving.\n\nPhoto\n\nMidway through the singing and dancing, an official quietly slipped Mr. Shortz the latest standings that told him who would be going to the final rounds. The tournament offers prizes for a variety of age and geographic divisions, but only nine people \u2014 three in each of the A, B and C divisions \u2014 solved Puzzle 8 in front of the entire audience.\n\nAll three divisions get increasingly difficult cluing for the same puzzle, but the rarefied A division is for the top money \u2014 first prize is $5,000 \u2014 and the three solvers, Mr. Feyer, Mr. Agard and David Plotkin of Gainesville, Fla., had to puzzle the very hardest clues out. This year, the puzzle for the final round was made by the assistant crosswords editor, Sam Ezersky.\n\nIt\u2019s at this point that the formerly \u201cword nerd\u201d atmosphere began to resemble a rowdy sporting event.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nColor commentary was led by a puzzle maker, Greg Pliska, as well as Ophira Eisenberg, host of NPR\u2019s \u201cAsk Me Another\u201d quiz show.\n\nAn audible gasp arose when a C division solver missed having a clean puzzle by one letter, and the entire room cheered whenever a finalist signaled that they were done. One of the B division finalists scrawled \u201cHi, Mom!\u201d on the side of her puzzle. Photos and videos were taken and immediately posted on social media to let the members of the crossword puzzle tribe who couldn\u2019t attend know what was happening.\n\nAs Jack Lechner, from Arlington, said, \u201cThis might be the only annual sporting event in which a rookie can go head-to-head with a national champion.\u201d", "title": "Puzzle Lovers Find Their Tribe at a Crossword Tournament", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 What\u2019s the first thing you think of when you think of Britain?\n\nTea? An English breakfast? The Loch Ness Monster? A new release of 10-pence coins (roughly 15 cents) has as many answers as letters in the alphabet.\n\nFrom \u201cAngel of the North\u201d to \u201cZebra Crossing,\u201d the new coins rolling out this month are a collection of memorable and mundane facts of British life. Some, like B is for \u201cBond \u2026 James Bond\u201d (L is for Loch Ness Monster), may resonate more with people outside the British Isles, while I for ice cream cone may seem more obscure.\n\n\u201cThis series really drills down into the heartland of what makes Britain British,\u201d said Dr. Kevin Clancy, director of the Royal Mint Museum, in a statement. \u201cIt\u2019s the granularity of British life celebrated on the coinage.\u201d\n\nA public survey was conducted to establish what everyday icons Britons thought represented British lore and life most faithfully. Here are some of their picks.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nN Is for the N.H.S.\n\nThe double-decker bus and zebra crossing, traditions of everyday life, were both popular with the public, the latter for being \u201cthe most British of transport symbols.\u201d (A former British member of Parliament is generally credited with coming up with the name of the road marking for pedestrian crossings.)", "title": "Q Is for Queuing: Minting British Traditions With New 10-Pence Coins", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQualcomm has slain a lion, but baited a dragon. Having the United States government essentially declare the firm a national champion allowed the chip maker to defend itself from rival Broadcom\u2019s $117 billion takeover bid. But a rise in anti-foreign sentiment may hurt Qualcomm, too \u2014 since it\u2019s still waiting for China to approve its own $44 billion acquisition of NXP Semiconductors.\n\nQualcomm\u2019s plans for growth lean heavily on acquiring the chip maker. Sealing the deal would reduce its dependence on the stagnating mobile-phone market and expand exposure to faster-growing ones such as autonomous vehicles. The problem is it needs approval from China\u2019s Ministry of Commerce, and that approval has been slow in arriving.\n\nThe United States government has derailed multiple chip deals because of fears that American technology might fall into Chinese hands. Broadcom might not appear to fall into the same camp. It is based in Singapore \u2014 and plans to relocate stateside this year \u2014 and most of its shareholders and directors are American.\n\nYet fear of the Middle Kingdom played a role: Lawmakers wondered whether Broadcom would follow its playbook on other deals and cut Qualcomm\u2019s research and development. That would risk ceding wireless-technology leadership to Chinese firms like Huawei. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States was also concerned about Broadcom\u2019s business relationships with \u201cforeign entities\u201d when it assessed the bid for Qualcomm.\n\nThe decision to rule Qualcomm off limits to foreign ownership could also grease the way for other sectors to be declared too sensitive for Chinese ownership.\n\nBeijing has already come down hard on Qualcomm, fining it $975 million in 2015 for what it called anti-competitive practices. The company could now find itself caught in the middle of escalating tensions. If there are suspicions in the Ministry of Commerce that Qualcomm stoked anti-Chinese sentiment among United States lawmakers to defend itself against Broadcom, the company may have a target painted on its back.", "title": "Qualcomm Could Find Itself in the Middle of Escalating Tensions With China", "authors": ["Robert Cyran"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Call it cheeky, sentimental or delusional, but Paul Jacobs\u2019s idea of making an offer for Qualcomm, the company he chaired until this month, is certainly daring. The chip maker only just wiggled out from under a takeover offer from rival Broadcom. What Qualcomm really needs is less a buyer and more a mediator.\n\nThere are usually two reasons to take a company private \u2014 the idea that the new owner can run it better, or a belief that the market is valuing it wrongly. Broadcom took the first path, and pointed at Qualcomm\u2019s paltry revenue growth and relatively low operating margins. Mr. Jacobs, whose father co-founded the company, is not the man to tackle those problems \u2014 if he were, he would have done it when he was executive chairman.\n\nValuation is a more compelling argument. It hinges on Qualcomm\u2019s rift with Apple. The iPhone maker is supposed to pay Qualcomm royalties on every phone sold, but has instructed its suppliers to hold back payment while it haggles with the chip maker on how those should be calculated.\n\nA simple calculation shows how important this is: At $10 per phone on 250 million devices per year, Qualcomm would make $2.5 billion in revenue a year, almost all of which would flow to the bottom line. That\u2019s equivalent to a lump-sum value of perhaps $17 billion, assuming a tax rate of 21 percent and margins of 85 percent. If investors aren\u2019t pricing in any Apple royalty at all right now, that\u2019s enough to justify a price close to the $117 billion Broadcom offered.", "title": "Qualcomm Needs a Mediator More Than a Buyer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Jacobs was chairman of Qualcomm from 2009 until March 9, when he was replaced. The change was widely seen as a move to placate shareholders who had been voicing their displeasure by voting for a slate of six candidates proposed by Broadcom for the 11-seat board as part of its bid to acquire the company.\n\nOn Tuesday, Mr. Jacobs sent the board a letter saying that he wanted to explore taking the chip maker private and that he intended to talk to potential funding sources, according to people briefed on the situation, who declined to be named because the discussions were confidential. That led to the board\u2019s decision on Friday during its regularly scheduled meeting.\n\n\u201cQualcomm is focused on executing its business plan and maximizing value for shareholders as an independent company,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cThere can be no assurance that Dr. Jacobs can or will make a proposal, but, if he does, the board will of course evaluate it consistent with its fiduciary duties to shareholders.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Jacobs, in turn, said there were \u201cclear merits to exploring a path to take the company private in order to maximize the company\u2019s long-term performance, deliver superior value to all stockholders and bolster a critical contributor to American technology.\u201d\n\nHis potential bid was earlier reported by The Financial Times.\n\nIn aiming to take Qualcomm private, Mr. Jacobs would be following a playbook used by Michael Dell. Mr. Dell, who founded Dell Computer in his university dorm room and built it into a personal computing colossus, took his company private in a $24.9 billion deal in 2013 after it had been battered by competition from Apple and the rise of mobile devices. Mr. Dell has since been working to turn Dell around, away from the prying eyes of Wall Street.\n\nYet any takeover attempt of Qualcomm by Mr. Jacobs faces extraordinarily tough obstacles. As an owner of fewer than 1 percent of Qualcomm shares, Mr. Jacobs would have to find investors to buy equity in a transaction, as well as bankers willing to fund debt. Since Qualcomm\u2019s directors had rejected Broadcom\u2019s $117 billion offer as inadequate, the total price tag would likely have to be higher.\n\nIf Mr. Jacobs reached out to foreign investors to raise funding, that would also most likely be problematic. President Trump blocked Singapore-based Broadcom\u2019s bid for Qualcomm this week partly because the White House does not want to cede American primacy in fifth-generation wireless technology, known as 5G, which Qualcomm has been developing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Jacobs is friends with Masayoshi Son, head of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, which would seem a likely candidate to help any buyout. But SoftBank has a heavy debt load already, and any move related to foreign investors could raise the same concerns that thwarted Broadcom.\n\nNot renominating Mr. Jacobs to Qualcomm\u2019s board opens a new chapter for the company, which the Jacobs family had made an institution in its hometown, San Diego.\n\nMr. Jacobs served as Qualcomm\u2019s chief executive from 2005 to 2014, a time when revenue and profits surged as its technology became a foundation for third-generation cellular networks. As a result, Qualcomm began charging patent royalties for nearly all mobile phones that used 3G technology.\n\nThe company was also able to garner a strong position in the next generation of cellphone networks \u2014 known as 4G \u2014 because it scooped rivals in delivering chips that could work with 4G networks.\n\nBut rivals such as Taiwan\u2019s Mediatek have cut into that lead recently. Qualcomm has also lately been hurt as Apple, a longtime customer, sued it over the royalty payments and stopped paying the company.\n\nApart from expanding Qualcomm, Mr. Jacobs is associated with some of the company\u2019s most famous failures, including a plan for broadcast cellular technology called MediaFlo and a technology for mobile-device displays called Mirasol. Qualcomm announced in 2013 that Mr. Jacobs would give up the chief executive position to Steve Mollenkopf after Mr. Mollenkopf was mentioned as a possible candidate to be chief executive of Microsoft.", "title": "Qualcomm\u2019s Ex-Chairman to Leave Amid Plans to Buy Company", "authors": ["Don Clark"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "MONTREAL \u2014 A former university student who killed six men at a mosque in Quebec City early last year pleaded guilty to first-degree murder on Wednesday, hastening the conclusion of a case that shocked Canadians and underscored the presence of Islamophobia in multicultural Canada.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve thought about this a long time. In my heart, this is the decision I\u2019ve made,\u201d the gunman, Alexandre Bissonnette, 28, told a Quebec City courtroom, after previously pleading not guilty.\n\nSeveral of the victims\u2019 family members sobbed openly in court after the judge read out the names of the six men killed in the attack, in which five others were seriously wounded, according to Mohamed Labidi, the president of the mosque, the Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec, who attended the proceedings.\n\nAmong those in attendance was Aymen Derbali, who was left paralyzed after being shot seven times when he tried to distract Mr. Bissonnette by staring directly at him so he would stop shooting others. The gunman\u2019s parents were also in court as their son read out his guilty plea.", "title": "Quebec City Mosque Gunman Pleads Guilty to Murder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In a move that has drawn international interest, nearly 740 doctors, residents and medical students in Quebec are demanding that the province not follow through on promises to raise their pay.\n\nLike many things related to Canada\u2019s health care debate, the reasons behind the extraordinary request from the doctors are complex and, in some cases, political. But a petition detailing their concerns appeared online in late February after several nurses in the province set off a discussion about the medical system by describing their working conditions, including an unmanageable number of patients and marathon shifts extended by mandatory overtime.\n\nThe doctors want the province to take money that would have been used to increase their incomes and give it to nurses and other health care workers who are dealing with issues like pay cuts and crushing workloads.\n\n\u201cThe system has to change \u2014 it will not survive much longer,\u201d said Isabelle Leblanc, a family physician in Montreal who is one of the petition\u2019s organizers and a professor at McGill University. \u201cFor a long time the system has revolved around physicians and hospitals.\u201d", "title": "Quebec Doctors Make a Pay Demand: Don\u2019t Raise It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Cowboys remain an American emblem to the French. They have seen enough westerns to have a clear idea of what cowboys should look like: proud, rugged, dirt-flecked \u2014 and white.\n\nAfrican-Americans, both enslaved and free, in fact, accounted for large percentages of cattlemen on horseback in the Old West. Yet images of black horsemen are rare in the American imagination \u2014 and in the Hollywood depictions that are broadcast worldwide. (The stereotype of a white cowboy is so enduring that Quentin Tarantino, in his subversive \u201cDjango Unchained,\u201d made a running joke of bystanders being scandalized by Jamie Foxx\u2019s avenging freed slave riding into town.)", "title": "Questions of Race and Inequality Among \u2018Urban Cowboys\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "By the time I got to the New School in Manhattan, I was undeniably a junkie; I studied literature, but I often skipped class to hang out with the crust punks of Union Square. They were such losers, all of them, and so was I, and there was kinship in that.\n\nMy friend Jessica lived on one of the park benches there, and we would squander days downtown, slouching across the East Village into Chelsea, where we would cop dope and shoot it in the bathroom at the Strand, where you don\u2019t need a code to get inside. After Jessica got her pit bull \u2014 whom she found one morning in the Bronx, chained to a fence and covered in scabs, like he was meant to break your heart \u2014 we went to the bathrooms in the basement at Petco instead, where an eight-millimeter syringe tip once broke off into my arm.\n\nWe were such apparent scum in those days, self-destructing in the wide-open, too sloppy and sinking to seem threatening, that it sometimes felt as if we were living below the law.\n\nJessica had hepatitis C. According to the most recent statistics from the C.D.C., there were an estimated 30,900 cases of new acute hepatitis C virus infections in the United States in 2015. Hep C is curable, but the treatment is expensive. There are programs that will cover the cost, but most will only take addicts who have been clean for a month or more. I lost track of Jessica, as I have with so many friends from those days. I can only hope she got treatment.\n\nBut, from a public health perspective, it would be far better to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases in the first place. The best way to do that is by dispensing sterile injection equipment.\n\nThe Harm Reduction Coalition, which was founded in 1993, is one of many organizations working to build a nationwide network of needle exchange programs that provide IV drug users with free clean syringes as well as training in how to administer naloxone (trade name Narcan), the antidote to opioid overdose.\n\nThe theory of \u201charm reduction\u201d is born of the palliative notion that a person can be made safer and more comfortable even while he is actively in the throes of addiction. It concedes that \u201cdrug use is part of our world and chooses to work to minimize its harmful effects rather than simply ignore or condemn them,\u201d according to the coalition\u2019s website.", "title": "Opinion | Quitting Heroin in the Sunshine State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI love volleyball, but it is just my job. JOS\u00c9 F\u00c9LIX OLETTA, a former Venezuelan health minister, on the aggressive comeback the disease is making in that country, which is reeling from an economic crisis, too.", "title": "Quotation of the Day: \u2018We\u2019re Losing the Fight\u2019: Tuberculosis Batters a Venezuela in Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Rabbi Mordechai Hager, the reserved but strong-willed leader of one of the nation\u2019s largest Hasidic sects, who settled many of his followers in a relatively bucolic upstate enclave to escape New York City\u2019s temptations and decadence, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 95.\n\nHe died of liver failure, resulting from an undetermined infection, at Mount Sinai Hospital, said Yosef Rapaport, who is a media consultant for Agudath Israel of America, an umbrella organization for Hasidic and other ultra-Orthodox groups. Rabbi Hager lived in the Hasidic village he founded, Kaser, in Rockland County, N.Y.\n\nRabbi Hager, a lushly beared figure who was known affectionately by his followers as Reb Mottele, was the leader of the American branch of the Viznitz, which is believed to number roughly 5,000 families, or 30,000 people. There is also a second branch based in Israel, though Viznitz Hasidim are scattered in many countries.\n\nRaised in Hasidic communities in Europe, Rabbi Hager was so intent on avoiding carnal and materialistic lures that he deliberately took off his glasses while walking down the street. He shunned publicity for himself; photographs of him are rare.", "title": "Rabbi Mordechai Hager, Leader of Large Hasidic Sect, Dies at 95", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRachel Antoinette Hamilton and Daniel Benedict Beyler Kuebrich were married March 24 at the Umlauf Sculpture Garden in Austin, Tex. Ronald J. Wilper, the father of the groom who was ordained through American Marriage Ministries, officiated.\n\nMs. Whitaker, 31, works in Manhattan as a television editor. Her credits include \u201cThe Late Show With Stephen Colbert\u201d and the PBS series \u201cThe Mind of a Chef.\u201d She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard.\n\nShe is the daughter of Alexis L. Gelber and Mark T. Whitaker of Manhattan. The bride\u2019s father retired as the executive vice president and managing editor of CNN Worldwide based in Atlanta and is the author of \u201cSmoketown,\u201d a book on the history of the black community in Pittsburgh in the mid-20th century. Her mother is the editor in chief of Straus News-Manhattan, a group of weekly newspapers, and an adjunct professor at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at N.Y.U.\n\nMr. Wilper, 38, is a humanities teacher at the Berkeley Carroll School, a college prep school in Brooklyn. He graduated from the University of Idaho and received a master\u2019s degree in philosophy from the University of Reading in Reading, England, and also received a master\u2019s degree in education from Columbia.\n\nHe is a son of Ronald J. Wilper of Boise, Idaho, and the late Rita M. Wilper. The groom\u2019s father is a retired district court judge in Idaho and a former president of the Idaho State Bar Association. The groom\u2019s mother was a nurse at St. Luke\u2019s Regional Medical Center in Boise.\n\nThe couple met in December 2014 on a blind date at Flatbush Farm, a restaurant in Brooklyn.", "title": "Rachel Whitaker, Michael Wilper", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "It is not the first time a social justice issue has clashed with Mr. Rice\u2019s strong stance on drugs. More than a decade ago he helped block the passage of a statewide needle-exchange program aimed at curbing the spread of H.I.V. from contaminated hypodermic needles, pitting himself against his own party.\n\nHis position on cannabis legalization not only puts him at odds with the governor and members of his party, but also with many African-Americans.\n\nIn New Jersey, African-Americans are three times more likely to be charged with marijuana possession than whites, even though both populations use the drug at similar rates. That has galvanized civil rights groups like the N.A.A.C.P. and the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey to support legalization.\n\n\u201cAll the collateral consequences that come with an arrest \u2014 jail time, losing your job, losing your housing \u2014 are disproportionately falling on communities of color,\u201d said Dianna Houenou, a lawyer with the A.C.L.U. of New Jersey. \u201cThrough legalization we can begin to address the harms that have been inflicted.\u201d\n\nA statewide coalition of black pastors, the N.A.A.C.P. and the New Jersey chapter of the Drug Policy Alliance is pushing for legalization as a social justice issue, but only if it is linked to some type of compensation for the harm they say was done to black and brown families whose sons were incarcerated. The pastors said they wanted to make sure members of their communities were able to participate in the billion-dollar cannabis industry as growers and sellers, not just workers. They are frustrated that the wealth being generated in the other states where marijuana is legal is not reaching people of color.\n\nResearchers at Marijuana Business Daily, an industry news site based in Denver, found that 81 percent of cannabis business owners were white, while less than 4 percent were black.\n\nMarijuana and racism have long been intertwined, dating back to the post-Prohibition era in the 1930s when the country\u2019s first drug czar gained traction for his war on marijuana by invoking a fear of black people. In the 1970s, President Richard Nixon\u2019s war on drugs targeted black people, as well as hippies.", "title": "Racial Justice Drives Fight for, and Against, Legal Pot in New Jersey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "North Korea, which has been saying its nuclear weapons are nonnegotiable, did not immediately provide its own version of what Mr. Kim had offered. That initial silence fed cautions that he was raising premature optimism, or perhaps strategizing to buy time.\n\nBut it seemed unlikely that the South Korean delegation would have publicized such an offer without the North\u2019s assurances, after what by all accounts was an extraordinarily cordial visit. Even President Trump, who has mocked Mr. Kim and vowed \u201cfire and fury\u201d that would obliterate North Korea if its nuclear forces ever attacked, offered a guarded but positive response.\n\n\u201cFor the first time in many years, a serious effort is being made by all parties concerned,\u201d Mr. Trump said on Twitter. \u201cThe World is watching and waiting! May be false hope, but the U.S. is ready to go hard in either direction!\u201d\n\nLater in Washington, Mr. Trump told reporters: \u201cThe statements coming out of South Korea and North Korea have been very positive. That would be a great thing for the world.\u201d\n\nWhite House officials were more cautious, with one senior official noting that the United States has negotiated with North Korea over its nuclear program off-and-on for 27 years, and that the North Koreans have broken every agreement they ever made with the Americans.\n\nThe United States, this official said, has no current plans to further delay joint military exercises with South Korea, suspended for the Winter Olympics last month in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Those exercises are scheduled to resume in April, after the Paralympic Games in Pyeongchang.\n\nWhile the Trump administration is intrigued by North Korea\u2019s offer \u2014 as relayed through the South Koreans \u2014 the senior official noted that North Korea could still manufacture missiles and bombs during a pause in testing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo top advisers to President Moon who met with Mr. Kim will visit the White House later this week to give a more detailed briefing on their talks. But the senior official said the United States had confidence in the preliminary assessment they had provided.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat assessment signals the first time Mr. Kim has indicated a willingness to discuss abandoning nuclear arms in return for security guarantees from the United States, which has technically been in a state of war with North Korea for nearly seven decades.\n\nThe South Korean delegation gave no indication that North Korea would start dismantling nuclear or missile programs anytime soon. Nonetheless, the delegation\u2019s visit represented major progress in Mr. Moon\u2019s efforts to improve relations with North Korea. Those efforts advanced considerably during the Winter Olympics, to which Mr. Kim sent athletes, entertainers and political delegations that included his sister.\n\nA senior member of the South Korean delegation that returned on Tuesday, Mr. Moon\u2019s national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, said Mr. Kim had been unexpectedly flexible.\n\nMr. Chung told reporters in Seoul, the South Korean capital, that the delegation had anticipated Mr. Kim would insist that the South and the United States not hold their military exercises. The South Koreans were wrong.\n\n\u201cKim Jong-un simply said he could understand why the joint exercises must resume in April on the same scale as before,\u201d Mr. Chung said. \u201cBut he said he expected them to be readjusted if the situation on the Korean Peninsula stabilizes in the future.\u201d\n\nMr. Chung said the South Koreans believed that their agreements with North Korea would be enough to start a dialogue between Washington and the North. He also said he was carrying additional messages from Mr. Kim to the Trump administration that he could not reveal.\n\n\u201cThere was no other specific demand from North Korea in returning to dialogue,\u201d he said. \u201cThey only said they wanted to be treated like a serious dialogue partner.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor Mr. Trump, the overture by North Korea sets in motion a challenging phase that will call on the United States to exercise diplomatic muscles after a long stretch in which the White House relied on economic pressure, backed by threats of military force.\n\nThat challenge will be compounded because the State Department\u2019s veteran North Korea negotiator, Joseph Yun, recently announced his retirement from the Foreign Service. Another experienced negotiator, Victor Cha, was recently sidelined when the White House decided not to proceed with his nomination as ambassador to South Korea.\n\nAdministration officials are wary of entanglement in a negotiation in which the United States makes concessions \u2014 on issues like military exercises or shipments of medical and food aid \u2014 only to see the North Koreans renege on their commitments later.\n\nMr. Trump has said that the United States could talk with North Korea, but \u201conly under the right conditions.\u201d American officials have repeatedly said they can start negotiations with the North only if it agrees to discuss denuclearizing. They have also insisted that the North first take some actions that would convince them of its sincerity.\n\nAnother complication is the increased tension between the United States and South Korea, both over Mr. Moon\u2019s exuberant diplomatic engagement with the North and over trade.\n\nPrivately, American officials voice frustration that Mr. Moon has responded so readily to the overtures from Mr. Kim. During Vice President Mike Pence\u2019s trip to South Korea for the Olympics, for example, Mr. Moon sought to broker a meeting between Mr. Pence and North Korean officials \u2014 seating him a few feet away from Mr. Kim\u2019s sister, Kim Yo-jong, during the opening ceremony.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s announcement of tariffs on steel could be an even greater source of friction. South Korea is the third-largest exporter of steel to the United States, accounting for nearly 10 percent of all exports.\n\nWhile the president has floated the idea of excluding Canada and Mexico from the tariffs, provided they agree to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, he has said nothing about South Korea. Other administration officials said South Korea was among the worst offenders in terms of dumping steel into the American market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump is already demanding that South Korea overhaul its free trade agreement with the United States. Some in the administration have urged Mr. Trump to delay punitive trade measures while South Korea and the United States jointly deal with the North Korea issue.\n\nDefense Minister Itsunori Onodera of Japan, which has steadfastly supported the Trump administration\u2019s tough approach to sanctions against North Korea, struck a note of caution about the North\u2019s interest in negotiations.\n\n\u201cWhile talking about nuclear abandonment several times, it turned out that North Korea didn\u2019t halt its nuclear development in the past,\u201d Mr. Onodera said. \u201cWe need to carefully assess if this North and South dialogue will really lead to the abandonment of nuclear and missile development.\u201d\n\nChina, which has pushed for direct talks between the North and Washington for many months, welcomed the South Korean statement. Geng Shuang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said China hoped \u201cthe relevant parties can seize the current opportunity\u201d to work toward \u201cpolitically resolving the Korean Peninsula issue.\u201d\n\nOne Chinese expert on North Korea characterized its reported offer as \u201cconcessions that are dramatic and significant.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt will be hard for the U.S. government to resist,\u201d said the expert, Cheng Xiaohe, of Renmin University in Beijing.\n\nBut Evans J. R. Revere, a former State Department official who was involved in previous negotiations with North Korea, was less impressed.
