He said the formula of denuclearization for security guarantees had \u201cbeen the basis of several sets of talks\u201d between the two countries in the past.\n\nEven so, Mr. Revere said the Trump administration would be hard-pressed to reject the North\u2019s proposal without making it appear that Washington \u2014 not the North \u2014 was the problem.\n\n\u201cWith these developments, the door seems wide open to a U.S.-North Korea exploratory conversation if both sides want one,\u201d he said.", "title": "Raising Hopes, North Korea Offers to Talk About Its Nuclear Arsenal", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was hard with a lot of emotions and thoughts coming into this game,\u201d Miller said. \u201cYou just want to go out and play your game. And luckily, I got one to come on my stick in front of the net.\u201d\n\nAfter an abysmal October, the Rangers rallied through November and December and seemed poised to earn a playoff spot. But their defense faltered, and the team slumped over the first two months of 2018, dropping out of contention and leading to a public proclamation that major roster changes were coming.\n\nIn the course of a week in late February, the Rangers sent McDonagh and Miller to Tampa Bay, Rick Nash and Nick Holden to Boston, and Michael Grabner to the Devils. Those moves helped complete a roster overhaul that began with the departures of Girardi and center Derek Stepan last summer.\n\nWith a new-look lineup that included the highly rated teenage forwards Lias Andersson and Filip Chytil, the Rangers were eliminated from playoff contention on Tuesday. Now, they are playing games without postseason implications for the first time since 2004, the closing days of Mark Messier\u2019s career.\n\nGirardi reflected on his lengthy tenure with the Rangers, saying he had given \u201cblood, sweat and tears for 11 years\u201d for the franchise. He also spoke of the strangeness of navigating the route to the visiting locker room after he and McDonagh stopped nearby at a coffee venue.\n\n\u201cIt took us a while to get into the building,\u201d he said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t know where to go.\u201d\n\nThis is uncharted territory for goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, who made the playoffs in 11 of his first 12 seasons, the only previous miss coming on the final day of 2009-10 season in a shootout loss at Philadelphia.\n\n\u201cIt has been a challenging time for everyone,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is our group now. It\u2019s up to us to figure out how we want to finish this.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt 36, Lundqvist has three years left on a seven-year, $59.5 million contract extension he signed in December 2013, and he has vowed to finish his career as a Ranger.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet he acknowledged that it was not easy to glance across the ice and see defensemen who protected him through countless battles now wearing opposition colors.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard to describe the feeling,\u201d Lundqvist said. \u201cIt\u2019s part of the game. It happens. You accept it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMcDonagh\u2019s departure marked the second time in four years the Rangers traded their captain to the Lightning. They exchanged Ryan Callahan for Martin St. Louis at the deadline in 2014, and the move helped the Rangers reached the Stanley Cup finals. Anton Stralman, a key defenseman on the Rangers squad that lost in those finals to the Los Angeles Kings, also plays for the Lightning now.\n\nMcDonagh, who because of an injury did not play his first game with Tampa Bay until March 10, is again paired with Girardi for the Lightning, now the best team in the Eastern Conference.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty surreal. It feels like old times,\u201d McDonagh said of the reunion. \u201cIt is great to be on the ice with him again, continuing to do the same things we did in New York.\u201d\n\nMiller, a somewhat surprising inclusion in the fire sale, has thrived with Tampa Bay, with nine goals and seven assists in 15 games.\n\nThe Rangers are playing with a spark since the roster reshuffle, which included the demotion of the high-priced defenseman Brendan Smith and season-ending knee surgery in January for defenseman Kevin Shattenkirk, last summer\u2019s major free-agent addition.\n\nTheir blueline corps now includes the newcomers Neal Pionk, John Gilmour and Rob O\u2019Gara, all of whom have impressed General Manager Jeff Gorton.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the Rangers still face many question marks heading into their early off-season. Lundqvist\u2019s understudy for next season is to be determined, though 22-year-old Alexandar Georgiev made a strong case for consideration in his 10 recent appearances. The Rangers also acquired numerous prospects in their various trades, and they currently have seven picks in the first three rounds of the June draft, including three first-round selections.\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019re just starting the process,\u201d Gorton said. \u201cWe have a lot of work to do.\u201d\n\nForward Chris Kreider, who missed 24 games because of a blood clot that required rib resection surgery, has been buoyed by the work ethic and enthusiasm displayed by the lineup since his return in late February.\n\n\u201cThose guys, the little experience they have in them, they work hard and they want to get better every day,\u201d he said. \u201cRegardless of how old you are, the team\u2019s going to lean on you at some point and you\u2019re going to have to be a leader.\u201d\n\nThe veteran Marc Staal, who has been a Ranger for 11 seasons, has become a mentor to Pionk, 22.\n\nNow second to Lundqvist in seniority, Staal, 31, has earned particular praise from Coach Alain Vigneault for his leadership. Staal exhaled slowly when asked to evaluate this uncharacteristic upheaval.\n\n\u201cI have nothing to compare this season to on a personal level,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is a first-time thing.\u201d", "title": "Rangers\u2019 Home Finale Becomes an Unexpected Reunion", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt wasn\u2019t just a poetry library,\u201d Professor Young said. \u201cIt was a library of the 20th century.\u201d\n\nMr. Danowski died on Feb. 2 at his home in Stellenbosch, South Africa, at 74. His son Henry said the cause was brain cancer.\n\nMr. Danowski always said that he had never intended to keep the collection private. He enjoyed collecting but hoped that the books he procured would become publicly available.\n\n\u201cI want to say book collecting is fun; serious fun possibly, but always an antidote to the idiocies of life and the pretensions of academia,\u201d he wrote in 2008.\n\n\u201cBook collecting is an outlet for fanaticism, passion, love, and rationality,\u201d he added, \u201cwithout their drawbacks.\u201d\n\nHis collection includes not only poetry but also periodicals, manuscripts, posters, audio and visual recordings and other artifacts about the people and global events \u2014 from the Spanish Civil War to the Black Panthers \u2014 that inspired it. (It includes at least one 19th-century artifact, a first printing of Walt Whitman\u2019s \u201cLeaves of Grass,\u201d which the poet himself published anonymously in 1855.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Danowski said he regarded the collection as \u201ca snowflake, a symmetrical structure relating to issues of the 20th century.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was lucky,\u201d he told students at Emory. \u201cI was able to find things that people were willing to get rid of.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how you save treasures,\u201d he said. \u201cHoard.\u201d\n\nRaymond Alfred Danowski was born on Sept. 10, 1943, in Manhattan and grew up in the Bronx. His mother, the former Jean Malcolm, was a Sears model. He described his father, also named Raymond, as a shellshocked World War II veteran with a violent temper who worked in a supermarket warehouse and also in tax enforcement.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe elder Raymond deliberately placed his night-school books on a high shelf, out of reach of his 4-year-old son.\n\nInstead, young Raymond borrowed Dr. Seuss\u2019 \u201cHorton Hatches the Egg\u201d (1940) from a mobile library. He listened to stories on the radio and devoured comics but didn\u2019t read another book until he discovered \u201cThe Count of Monte Cristo\u201d at his branch library on a class visit when he was 10.\n\nHe was introduced to poetry by two uncles, one an aspiring actor who flamboyantly performed Edgar Allan Poe\u2019s \u201cThe Raven\u201d at home, and another whose English bookie mailed him poems by W. H. Auden. (Mr. Danowski ultimately collected about a thousand volumes of Auden\u2019s works.)\n\nServing mornings as an altar boy at St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral in Manhattan, he mingled in museums and Greenwich Village galleries and coffee houses. As a student at Cathedral Prep, a Roman Catholic seminary, he became smitten with rare books after an aunt, who worked at Columbia University, got him an after-school job shelving books on the campus at the Burgess-Carpenter Library, now the Milstein Library.\n\n\u201cWhen I decided to create this collection, as I found the books, I was shelving them in my mind,\u201d he told The New York Times in 2004. \u201cIt was an imaginary library, based on the Burgess-Carpenter experience. It was really like being a librarian in my dreams.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter spending two years at Fordham University in the Bronx, Mr. Danowski worked as an art dealer in Woodstock, N.Y., and then in Europe. He also campaigned against apartheid in South Africa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the mid-1970s, a London book dealer he had befriended became ill and also lost his lease. Mr. Danowski bought his collection.\n\nTwo decades later, he connected with W. Ronald Schuchard, now a professor emeritus of literature at Emory, who had heard about Mr. Danowski\u2019s acquisitiveness from acquaintances at the Grolier Club for bibliophiles in New York.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Danowski chose Emory as the repository because it was expanding its poetry archive (since 1975 it had acquired the papers of Seamus Heaney and Ted Hughes) and agreed to make Mr. Danowski\u2019s \u201cbibliotheque imaginaire\u201d available not only to scholars but also to undergraduates.\n\nMost of the financing for the collection came from his third wife, Mary Moore, daughter of the sculptor Henry Moore. She later sold much of it to the Poetry Trust, which also helped subsidize his purchases.\n\nMr. Danowski\u2019s first three marriages \u2014 to Fran Kolomaznik, Susan W. Pelton and Ms. Moore \u2014 ended in divorce.\n\nHe is survived by his wife, Sandra Olivier, and a stepson, Kristo Olivier; two daughters from his first marriage, Mary Danowski Paguaga and Justine Danowski; a son, August, from his second marriage; three children from his third marriage, Guston and Henry Danowski and Jane Hoogewerf; his sisters, Elizabeth Danowski Haley, Catherine Danowski Lafex and Jean Danowski; and six grandchildren.\n\nMr. Danowski began his collecting with the Spiral Press edition of \u201cPoems by Edgar Allan Poe.\u201d Among the tens of thousands of other volumes he acquired, his favorite, he said, was \u201cFragment Thirty-Six\u201d by H. D. (born Hilda Doolittle), the early 20th-century Imagist poet.\n\nAfter three decades his quest had indeed become an obsession, he told The Poetry Foundation, but, he explained, \u201cnot in the sense of going mad; I understood it in the sense of trying to be complete.\u201d\n\nIt could never be, though, he acknowledged. The collection is still punctuated by gaps and missing links, an organic aggregation that is meant to grow.\n\n\u201cIt now has its own life,\u201d Mr. Danowski told the Emory students. \u201cYou really are its life.\u201d", "title": "Raymond Danowski, Stockpiler of Poetry, Is Dead at 74", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "It is not unusual for books to inspire movies, and this year, more than a dozen of the films nominated for the Oscars, which will air on March 4, have literary roots. Here are three books with film adaptations up for an Academy Award.\n\nPhoto\n\nCALL ME BY YOUR NAME\n\nBy Andr\u00e9 Aciman\n\n248 pp. Farrar Straus & Giroux. (2007)\n\nThis novel is about the sexual awakening of two young men: Elio, a 17-year-old who lives with his mother and father, an academic, on the Italian Riviera, and Oliver, 24, an American postdoc who stays in the family\u2019s mansion while he works on his manuscript. It is told in retrospect by an adult Elio and the novel \u201cabounds in moments of emotional and physical abandon,\u201d our reviewer wrote. Though the romance unfolds over only six weeks during one summer in the 1980s, its effects stay with the characters for a lifetime.\n\nPhoto\n\nMUDBOUND\n\nBy Hillary Jordan\n\n328 pp. Algonquin Books. (2008)\n\nSet in 1940s Mississippi, this novel takes place on the McAllan family farm, where Laura McAllan is trying to forge a new life after leaving Memphis behind. It is told from the perspectives of a number of people \u2014 black and white, male and female \u2014 to show how racism manifested in the South post-World War II. The plot is propelled forward by two veterans, Jamie McAllan, a white man, and Ronsel Jackson, whose parents are sharecroppers and live on the McAllan farm, who return from war to work the land and strike an unlikely friendship. \u201cIt is a novel of place as much as people,\u201d wrote our reviewer about the book, which also won the 2006 Bellwether Prize for Fiction for its reckoning with social justice issues.\n\nPhoto\n\nWONDER\n\nBy R. J. Palacio\n\n315 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. (2012)\n\nThis widely beloved middle grade book follows August Pullman, or Auggie, a severely disfigured 10-year-old often viewed with horror and subjected to stares and mean comments. When his parents enroll him in middle school \u2014 he had previously been home-schooled \u2014 he is scared and, it turns out, with good reason; classmates call him \u201cthe freak\u201d and the class bully starts a campaign to shun him. The book is narrated by a cast of characters including Auggie\u2019s teenage sister, Via, and other fifth graders, and Palacio captures their voices \"with equal skill,\u201d notes Maria Russo, the children\u2019s books editor at The Times Book Review. This is one case, she argues, in which you\u2019ll want to read the book first.", "title": "Read the Books Behind the Oscars", "authors": ["Concepci\u00f3n De Le\u00f3n"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our Reader Ideas are generally written by educators and describe creative methods of teaching with The New York Times. But in this edition, we feature a high school student, Matthew Tikhonovsky, who learns with The Times \u2014 on his own.\n\nMr. Tikhonovsky is the son of Ukrainian immigrants, and his Times habit has not only raised his English test scores, but has also helped him better understand American culture \u2014 which, he says, has then helped him to better appreciate his family\u2019s own history and background.\n\nIn this piece, Mr. Tikhonovsky takes us through the ways he navigates Times content , like regularly reading the Opinion section, responding to Learning Network writing prompts, conducting research for school assignments and using articles as conversation starters with his parents.\n\nHow have you learned with The Times?\n\nBrowse all our Reader Ideas or contribute one of your own.\n\n________\n\nIdea: A high school student, the son of Ukrainian immigrants, describes how he has used The Times to improve his English and learn about American culture.", "title": "Reader Idea | A Teenager Uses The Times to Improve His English and Understand American Culture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "If we have a student who is new to the \u201cWGOITP?\u201d process, we\u2019ll provide the student with a version of the photograph labeled with relevant vocabulary. It\u2019s been our experience that having the vocabulary right there decreases anxiety about not knowing what to say. We use the free app Skitch to label and draw on the image to create a low-filter environment. Before we begin the brainstorming part of this activity, we always go over the \u201cSteps to NYT VTS\u201d poster that Mrs. Montemagno created. Regardless of a student\u2019s language level, this vocabulary is reviewed every Monday.\n\nThe poster is an effective way to teach our students the vocabulary that describes what they will do with the photograph. These academic vocabulary words cannot simply be memorized. They need to be experienced and used over and over.\n\nAnalyzing and Discussing the Photograph\n\nStudents are given five to 10 minutes to analyze the photograph on their own and write any words or phrases that come to mind. They are encouraged to use Google Translate to translate words, and not complete sentences. While students are welcome to use their native language, it\u2019s our goal to have them practice their English skills. In the beginning of the school year, students work on this activity individually. As the year progresses, they work in groups and complete the brainstorming with peers.\n\nAfter the brainstorming session, students engage in a class discussion. We lead the discussion using the three questions prescribed by Visual Thinking Strategies, the organization that collaborates each week with the Learning Network on \u201cWGOITP?\u201d:\n\n\u2022 What is going on this picture?\n\n\u2022 What do you see that makes you say that?\n\n\u2022 What more can you find?\n\nAs the discussion progresses, we restate our students\u2019 ideas, paraphrase their comments and ensure that whatever it is they say is backed up with something (evidence) they see in the photograph (the second question does this job beautifully). Students are asked to use the sentence starters listed on a poster that is taped to the front of the room.\n\nWhile students are discussing the photograph, we write their ideas and questions on a large T-chart taped to our easel. We have different expectations for students with different English language levels. \u201cEntering\u201d and \u201cEmerging\u201d students copy down what we write on their own T-chart. Our rationale for this is that students at these levels still need practice copying notes from the board. \u201cTransitioning\u201d and \u201cExpanding\u201d students don\u2019t copy notes from the board in this activity because they will use their own evidence to support the claim that they create individually. They watch us as we write, and they will be allowed to refer back to the T-chart when it\u2019s time to find evidence to support the claim they created individually, or with a group.\n\nPreparing Students to Write", "title": "Reader Idea | How to Use Interesting Photos to Help Students Become Better Writers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nWhat Mr. Meyer Did and Why, in His Words\n\nAs an education journalist, it didn\u2019t take me long to recognize how important a role journalism could play in the recent movement to bring more content-based curriculums into public schools. This was part of what prompted me to launch School Life Media (SLM) in 2012, and journalism education soon became a major focus of what we were trying to do.\n\nFrom the beginning I knew we would use journalism to improve student literacy and from the beginning I knew that New York Times stories would be at the heart of the program. I have since compiled a list of dozens of Times stories that I believe not only beautifully illustrate journalism\u2019s broad content reach but also the quality of its reporting and writing in communicating that content. You can find some of them at the end of this post. In the summer of 2016, we introduced some 50 children \u2014 third through sixth grades \u2014 to the practice of journalism in various summer programs sponsored by the Hudson City School District in Hudson, N.Y.\n\nAt the invitation of our district\u2019s middle school, the M.C. Smith Intermediate School, the following winter and spring we brought the program to one third-grade class and one fourth-grade class during the school\u2019s regular school day as part of those classes\u2019 state-mandated literacy unit. This fit perfectly with our mission to deliver a journalism program to all students. There were approximately 25 students in each class, representing a demographic and academic mix, including special education students and students both below and above grade level.\n\nThe pilot was successful, and the school principal invited us to present the program to the school\u2019s entire fifth grade, some 150 students in seven different classes, including one special education classroom. We began the year with a 12-lesson program and have since expanded it to 20 lessons. Each lesson is a 35-minute period at the end of the school day, in which we provide an instructor, an aide and a complete curriculum with lesson plans. The regular classroom teacher is in the classroom and assists us. He or she remains responsible for the classroom order, as well as ensuring that we are following all education rules and regulations. One of our goals is for teachers to continue to teach the program themselves after working with us.\n\nWe introduced a two-track curriculum \u2014 a New York Times track and a Local Stories track \u2014 with detailed lesson plans and a \u201cModule at a Glance\u201d format developed by the third-grade teacher Marlene Parmentier. We emphasize three essential elements \u2014 the five senses, the five W\u2019s and the five activities; four units \u2014 what is a journalist? taking notes, what\u2019s a story? and publish; and one golden rule \u2014 finish the assignment as best you can. Our students learn by doing.\n\nReporter\u2019s Notebooks, Press Conferences and Writing News Stories\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the beginning of each course, students are given reporter\u2019s notebooks and encouraged to write in them at every opportunity. They make their own press passes, take notes on every aspect of the class, and then read from those notes in front of the class (by standing and \u201cprojecting\u201d). They learn to stand and ask questions of guests (in \u201cpress conferences\u201d) and, of course, write stories, and design and create pages that include the name of their paper, the date of publication, the price of the paper (though not yet implemented, it is one of the kids\u2019 favorite tasks!), a headline, a byline, an illustration and caption, and the story \u2013 the result, we hope, of their research and note taking.\n\nOn the New York Times track, our lesson plans include New York Times stories such as \u201cStick Insect Helps Scientist Study How Animals Move\u201d by James Gorman; \u201cShould You Let Your Dog Lick Your Face?\u201d by Christopher Mele, \u201cWhy Doesn\u2019t the United States (Finally) Get Rid of the Penny?\u201d by Binyamin Appelbaum. Given the age of the students \u2013 third-to-fifth-grade \u2013 we introduced these stories gradually.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll of the stories included a video; students were encouraged to take notes as they watched. We passed out a printed handout. A teacher then read the story out loud with students listening, circling words they didn\u2019t know as they listened. Students shared with the class the words they had circled. They filled out a Critical Reading form which asks students to identify such story characteristics as headline, byline and the five W\u2019s. We played a story game: rearranging phrases and sentences from the story and asking the students to put them together.\n\nThough I was well aware that these Times stories were above reading level for many, if not most, of the students, I had also been in enough classrooms to know that students are sponges, and they absorb. Thus, our mantra: Students will learn journalism by doing journalism and, in the process, learn a lot of content and skills. It is a clich\u00e9, but one worth remembering: Students rise to the challenge. We don\u2019t mandate mastery, only effort.\n\nWith our \u201clocal story\u201d track, we encourage students to focus on familiar subjects, including local guests brought to class to discuss the subject of the New York Times story. For instance, as part of the \u201cStick Insect\u201d story we invited the local high school\u2019s robotics teacher to visit. For the penny story, we invited a local banker. We introduce the students to the \u201cpress conference\u201d format: Students, wearing press passes that they have made, stand, identify themselves, the paper they\u2019re with, and ask questions.\n\nJournalism Activities and Routines\n\nPhoto\n\nOur five activities include:\n\n\u2022 Going to work. This means beginning each class with students writing in their reporter\u2019s notebooks their names, the date, the time, the location, the class name and the weather (basically, a who, what, when, where and why).\n\n\u2022 Quickwrites. On a subject chosen by the SLM instructor, write for two minutes in their reporter\u2019s notebooks.\n\n\u2022 Quick Review: What did we do last class (use your reporter\u2019s notebook for reference).\n\n\u2022 Press Conferences. An interview with a guest.\n\n\u2022 Assignments. Write on a subject chosen by the SLM instructor that does not have tight time constraints. A perennial favorite is, \u201cInterview with my shoe.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Oh yes, we also have a \u201cpub party\u201d at the last class, which includes passing out certificates of completion and awards (e.g., the Speed Demon Writing Award for filling the most pages in their reporter\u2019s notebooks), as well as healthy foods like fruit and vegetable platters and water.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the final step, the students\u2019 pages are then copied, \u201cbound\u201d and distributed.\n\nA note on computers: We have adopted a decidedly manual approach to our task. We use Smartboards for showing illustrations, stories and videos from the internet, but otherwise the students use paper and pencil, especially in their reporter\u2019s notebooks. We print the copies of the Times stories. (We adults use Google Docs to share information.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe also encourage the use of all the senses, most especially hearing. Thus, we discourage the adults from writing words and sentences on the \u201cboard\u201d for the kids to copy and instead encourage kids to raise their hands and ask for clarification, or ask their neighbors to help. Teachers reinforce this informational dynamic by asking various students to answer the questions, thus also reinforcing one of journalism\u2019s golden rules: two sources.\n\n_________\n\n10 Times Articles Recommended by Peter Meyer for Using With Students\n\nAn Insect That Masters Water and Air\n\nAn Obsessive Collector Who\u2019s Drawn Royalty to Brooklyn\n\nAt 100, Still Running for Her Life\n\nCapturing the Life of a Flower That Blooms for Less Than a Day\n\nHajj Prep: Search Soul, Buy Sturdy Shoes, Pay the Dentist\n\nIn More Backyards, the Chicken Comes First\n\nIt\u2019s a Bird! No, It\u2019s a Crocodile! Synchronized Swimming Themes Can Be Mystifying\n\nMarine Life Thrives in Unlikely Place: Offshore Oil Rigs\n\nNut? What Nut? The Squirrel Outwits to Survive\n\nThe Curse of a Phoenix Weatherman: Finding New Ways to Say \u2018It\u2019s Hot\u2019\n\n_________\n\nRelated Learning Network Resources\n\nReader Idea | For High School Online Newspapers, The Times Offers Inspiration\n\nImproving Your \u2018News Diet\u2019: A Three-Step Lesson Plan for Teenagers and Teachers\n\nEvaluating Sources in a \u2018Post-Truth\u2019 World: Ideas for Teaching and Learning About Fake News", "title": "Reader Idea | Promoting Literacy With Journalism Education and The New York Times", "authors": ["Peter Meyer", "The Learning Network"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Why We Chose It: With the use of just one Times article, this teacher reworks the customary Robert Burns school assignment (\u201crote-learning poems about mice and lice\u201d) and, instead, has his students revel in language new and old, making the famous \u201cBurns Stanza\u201d their own.\n\n_________\n\nWhat Mr. Gillespie Did and Why, In His Own Words\n\nPhoto\n\nEvery January pupils across Scotland are besieged with lessons and assemblies about Robert Burns, our national poet, in honor of Burns Night.\n\nIt\u2019s a legitimate and important landmark that young people should be aware of and celebrate, but I\u2019ve always been a little uncertain about how we, as teachers, go about it. I was never sure what exactly students were meant to be getting out of all these recitals and Tartan Days.\n\nWhy are they rote-learning poems about mice and lice? Are they just celebrating Burns for the sake of celebration itself? What skills are they actually learning and developing that they can relate to and build upon?\n\nWell, over 200 years since Burns\u2019s death, the rich Scots language that he used can be pretty intimidating to decipher. A lot of pupils can indeed recite whole chunks from his Greatest Hits \u2014 \u201cTo a Mouse,\u201d \u201cTam o\u2019 Shanter,\u201d \u201cAuld Lang Syne\u201d \u2014 but I doubt they could tell you what all the words actually mean. What is a syne anyway? I wanted to try and do something a little more relatable with my class, to try and teach them a few things that they might be able to put to use in future lessons or in later life.\n\nTo do this I needed a stimulus, and this fabulous piece of travel writing from 2014 was perfect: \u201cIn Scotland, Guts, Glory and Haggis.\u201d\n\nIt focuses on one of Burns\u2019s most celebrated topics \u2014 the mysterious and elusive haggis \u2014 and gives pupils a modern insight, written in an engaging style. I used this article as the launch pad and inspiration for these lessons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo simply read, memorize and recite Burns\u2019s poems felt pretty one-dimensional to me. I thought it was far more useful for students to play about with the language that he used, and the structure of his poetry, but also to write in their own register \u2014 which could be described as a pretty standard form of English with a smattering of regional colloquialisms.\n\nWhy write exclusively in the language of Burns when students have their own evolving, intricate modern Scots instead? I wanted to make use of both, and to do this I provided a glossary of 10 fabulously expressive Scots words used today (bauchle, blether, dreich, fankle, gallus, mooch, pockle, slitter, wabbit, wheescht), but also spoke to the class about how they spoke and what regional phrases they had in their armory.\n\nBelow, the lesson sequence. Notes to students are in italics, followed by my own notes on what happened in class.\n\n_________\n\nPhoto\n\nLearning Intentions:\n\n\u25cf To understand how haggis is made\n\n\u25cf To learn about the Burns Stanza\n\n\u25cf To become familiar with new Scots words\n\nStarter Activity:\n\nWorking with a partner, discuss what a haggis is. What is it made of? How is it made? Where does it come from? Write down a description that you could give to a tourist. Be prepared to share these descriptions with the class.\n\nIt became clear from this that students didn\u2019t have a great awareness of what constituted a haggis to begin with. There were lots of answers skirting around the idea of sheep, but these were a bit wooly (forgive the pun). They had loads of vague knowledge about Burns Suppers and turnips, but nothing specific. Hence, the reading task that came next.\n\nReading Task:\n\nRead the article explaining how a haggis is made.\n\nUsing highlighter pens, pick out key phrases.\n\nYou should look for:\n\n\u25cf Descriptive phrases and adjectives\n\n\u25cf Key verbs and actions\n\n\u25cf Key nouns, facts and items\n\n\u25cf Writing features such as simile, alliteration, etc.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring this phase of the lesson, it became clear that the language of the article was perfect for engaging the pupils, who had, in all honesty, not been hugely enthused by the idea of a lesson on Burns.\n\nThe writer uses fantastically gritty and descriptive language to help the reader visualize, smell and feel the preparation of the haggis: yanking veins from lungs; picking lumps of meaty gruel from her fingernails; the glorious stench of the sheep\u2019s stomach. It\u2019s wonderful, and made the whole class sit up and take notice, as they highlighted their favorite bits.\n\nWhile Burns is often lauded for his use of wit and humor, I feel that in schools we often overlook the craft and technical expertise evident in his work. I used the first verse of the immortal \u201cAddress to a Haggis\u201d to illustrate the tight rhythm and rhyme scheme which he popularized \u2014 what became known as the Burns Stanza, as closely associated with him as sonnets are with Shakespeare. This was a key piece of information and I did not move on from this until I felt confident that the whole class understood the format.\n\nNote-taking Task:\n\nThe Burns Stanza:\n\n\u25cf Six lines long\n\n\u25cf Follows an A-A-A-B-A-B rhyme scheme\n\n\u25cf Lines are always the same length: 8-8-8-4-8-4\n\nFor example:\n\nFair fa\u2019 your honest, sonsie face, A 8\n\nGreat chieftain o the puddin\u2019-race! A 8\n\nAboon them a\u2019 ye tak your place, A 8\n\nPainch, tripe, or thairm: B 4\n\nWeel are ye worthy o\u2019 a grace A 8\n\nAs lang\u2019s my airm. B 4\n\nWriting Task:\n\nIn pairs:\n\n\u25cf Write instructions for preparing and cooking haggis, according to the New York Times article about the George Cockburn & Son butchery.\n\n\u25cf This should be in the form of a Burns Stanza poem \u2013 follow the same rhyme scheme and length.\n\n\u25cf You should write at least three stanzas, and make use of at least six Scots words \u2013 use the glossary and include ones of your own.\n\n\u25cf You should include key words and phrases from the article and the glossary. Tick these off the list as you use them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI was really pleased with the response and enthusiasm shown by pupils when writing their poems. They had clearly understood the method for making haggis from the article, which they referred to frequently, and they grappled with the rigidity of the Burns Stanza until they found themselves able to tweak phrasing and expression to fit the lines and create strong rhymes.\n\nThey used some of the traditional words from the Burns glossary, but many also included modern Scots that they knew and used themselves. The paired work allowed for plenty of discussion, meaning that the lessons incorporated the four key strands of English: reading, writing, talking and listening. All that remained was for me to help with rhyming ideas and check their understanding.\n\nHow did I know that they had learned what I wanted them to? They emailed me their poems, which were finished as homework. Take a look.\n\n__________\n\nStudent Examples\n\nPoem No. 1, written by Ava and Erin\n\nI laid my hauns on the livers,\n\nCut up into tiny slivers,\n\nGiving me horrible shivers,\n\nRubbery veins,\n\nLambs blood flowing like a river,\n\nAnd greetin weans.\n\nThe Butcher wis awfy swankie,\n\nEven though his hauns were manky,\n\n\u201cGies ma pudding! Here\u2019s a hanky.\u201d\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t git donsie.\u201d\n\n\u201cAye, when am I ever cranky?\u201d\n\n\u201cAye, you\u2019re sonsie.\u201d\n\nWhat a treat, a glorious pud,\n\nThis gorgeous sight uplifts my mood,\n\nNot to praise it would just be rude,\n\nIt\u2019s in my mouth,\n\nI am gawsie, its just too good!\n\nI\u2019m really fouth.\n\nPoem No. 2, written by Ella and Abigail\n\nThis feast is a ball made of meat,\n\nIt\u2019s a gawsie good thing to eat,\n\nAnd it\u2019s anything but petite!\n\nComes from a sheep,\n\nPlease come dive into your great treat\n\nIn a fouth heap.\n\nThe wee classic Scottish puddin,\n\nSheep\u2019s insides need a good thumpin,\n\nWith a churning and a thuddin,\n\nWith much cantie\n\nWhen it comes hearts will be pumpin;\n\nMeal time, auntie!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGet a table with your neighbour,\n\nTear right in, it\u2019s full of flavour!\n\nEat your dinner, quit your haver.\n\nLies on a tray,\n\nVegetarians will waiver -\n\nWe won\u2019t delay!\n\nPoem No. 3, written by Orla and Lauren\n\nHaggis is a great meaty meal,\n\nWith a warm and rubbery feel,\n\nThis puddin can be a great deal,\n\nAnd if you try\n\nTo eat it all then you will reel,\n\nSo go and buy!\n\nHaggis is such a gawsie treat,\n\nWhen it\u2019s made it has to be neat,\n\nThe butcher is swanky, but sweet,\n\nWhen he makes it,\n\nThe oven grows tae a great heat,\n\nLet\u2019s hae a bit!\n\nPoem No. 4, written by Olivia and Heather\n\nWee rubbery bits, lamb and lung.\n\nWant some haggis but need a bung,\n\nAnd ma da wouldny gee me some.\n\nWhit a scunner!\n\nBut after he heard ma song sung.\n\nA got hunners!\n\nThen a went doon tae the main-street.\n\nWe\u2019re gonna get a smashing treat.\n\nDoon at the butchers, we\u2019ll all meet.\n\nDug stole a bone -\n\nMa nearly choked right in the street.\n\nLet\u2019s just go home!\n\n_________\n\nRelated\n\nPoetry Pairing | \u2018Winter: A Dirge\u2019\n\nIt\u2019s Tasty and Political: Britain Presses U.S. on Haggis\n\nA Night of Food and Song: Burns Supper", "title": "Reader Idea | Rhythm, Rhyme and Haggis: Celebrating the Poetry of Robert Burns", "authors": ["Alan Gillespie", "The Learning Network"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "When we published the first installment of the Overlooked project two weeks ago, we asked readers to suggest people they felt deserved, but didn\u2019t get, New York Times obituaries.\n\nBy now, we have received close to 2,500 submissions. Among these were about 30 from readers who told us of their own grandmothers or great-grandmothers who often fought strong institutional prejudice against them.\n\nWe found their stories moving, fascinating and inspiring and wanted to share them with you. A selection of these tributes, submitted by the grandchildren or great-grandchildren of the subjects, is below.", "title": "Readers Nominate Their Overlooked Grandmothers for a Times Obituary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFive women accused the architect Richard Meier of sexual harassment. Mr. Meier designed the Getty Center in Los Angeles and won the Pritzker Prize, architecture\u2019s highest honor, in 1984, making him the youngest winner of that award.\n\nIn response to the allegations, Mr. Meier announced he would take a six-month leave as the founder and managing partner of his firm, and he issued an apology. Both the duration of his leave and his apology were questioned by Times readers, who seemed to feel they were inadequate. He was accused of exposing himself to associates in his apartment and groping a woman at a holiday party.\n\nMore than 500 readers left comments at nytimes.com, and over 100 readers posted replies on social media. Here are edited excerpts from the comments.\n\n\u2018If women wanted to get anywhere, they had to have enough grit to kill a lion.\u2019\n\nReaders said the architecture and design industry was rife with similar examples of behavior.\n\nThe old guard was always an old boys club of social elite (think \u201cMad Men\u201d) having five-martini lunches, combined with the architectural norm of an oversized ego. If women wanted to get anywhere, they had to prove themselves in more ways than one, and have enough grit to kill a lion. KMSA, WASHINGTON\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStarchitects think they can do no wrong. Been there, not with this fellow, no worries. But it\u2019s \u201call about me,\u201d not for those who actually make the practice work. JANE KULIK, VIA FACEBOOK", "title": "Readers React to Misconduct Accusations Against Richard Meier", "authors": ["Lela Moore"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u2014 Dena R., Florida (This writer identified herself as a registered dietitian and nutritionist whose specialty was maternal and pediatric nutrition.)\n\nDid anyone consider that what you eat may be more important than how you eat?\n\n\u2014 Policy Researcher, Seattle\n\nSome parents said that baby-led weaning was a positive experience for their children.\n\nI nursed my son for a year and a half. When he was about 7 months old, I put some peas on his highchair tray, and he ate them. A few days later I gave him something else we were eating. As time went on, he was eating a wide variety of foods. I never made baby food, never bought baby food and never spoon fed him.\n\n\u2014 Catherine, Norway\n\nThree children and I can count on my two hands the total number of times I spoon fed. Their skill in getting food in their mouths corresponded perfectly with their increased need for that food. A beautifully elegant transition. You just have to be willing to put up with some messes for a little bit.\n\n\u2014 Donna Giersdorf-Thompson, via Facebook\n\nWe did not have to feed him while we were eating our dinner! We relaxed and ate and talked to each other and kept a close eye on him. He played with the food on his plate and tasted it, and derived some nutrition from it. He developed his fine motor skills, so that he could pick up the foods. He tried a wide variety of foods and is not a picky eater.\n\n\u2014 Ted Hefko, New Orleans\n\nBut other parents said that their babies did not self-regulate their eating.\n\nThe doctor told my wife, \u201cthe baby will tell you when he\u2019s done eating,\u201d so she took her at her word. He loved his bottle and by the age of 6 months looked like a very well-fed, miniature Henry VIII, complete with double chin.\n\n\u2014 Doug Thomson, Minneapolis\n\nWe basically tried the baby-led weaning thing and, for whatever reason, he now eats anything and everything. So much so that we now have to worry about his weight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Grumpy Gardener, the Pacific Northwest\n\nMany readers believed it was important for parents to establish good habits of their own for their children to mirror.\n\nParents\u2019 own food habits have a large impact on their children, and eating a well-balanced diet in front of your children \u2014 even as babies \u2014 has a big impact on their future.\n\n\u2014 Tom, the Midwest\n\nThe goal is not to be authoritarian any more than it is to be indulgent, but instead to authoritatively provide the structure that allows for only healthy food selection and helps children learn how to pay attention to their internal cues.\n\n\u2014 Don, Chicago\n\nBut others said that parents can\u2019t control their children\u2019s diets forever.\n\nBy all means, do whatever you can to provide a healthy diet to your kids. Just don\u2019t expect that you\u2019re necessarily going to prevent future weight problems by doing so.\n\n\u2014 Elizabeth, New York\n\nWe\u2019ve created a problem where there never was one. Some people\u2019s bodies are just going to be fat and we need to stop pathologizing them. And doing this to babies is even more messed up.\n\n\u2014 Kristen Lacombe, via Facebook\n\nIt seems to be clearer now that avoiding processed foods and refined sugars gives people of all ages a fighting chance to achieve a non-obese B.M.I., but it\u2019s a hard fight for those genetically programmed to be fat.\n\n\u2014 Ellen Tabor, New York\n\nPediatricians weighed in, with most supporting the idea that parents need to choose their children\u2019s first foods carefully, regardless of how they feed them.\n\nAs a pediatrician, I find the whole concept of baby-led feeding practices a scam. Babies don\u2019t get their food, nor control how they eat; their parents interpret their desires. All feeding, therefore, is parent determined.\n\n\u2014 Alan, Holland, Pa.\n\nAs babies turn to solids, parents must be aware that the most nutritious foods don\u2019t come from a box or bag.\n\n\u2014 Lisa Lewis, M.D., Fort Worth, Tex.\n\nDietary caution against obesity from the very beginning is appropriate. And we need to monitor not only how our children eat, but what they eat, starting with our industrial food chain.\n\n\u2014 Douglas, Portland, Ore., who identified himself as a pediatrician who recently retired after practicing for 40 years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow we\u2019d like to hear from you: Do you have experience feeding babies? Did you try baby-led weaning? If so, what was your experience? Or did you try a different approach? Tell us about it in the comments section of this article.", "title": "Readers React: What Is the Healthiest Way to Feed a Baby?", "authors": ["Lela Moore"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "When \u201cThe Americans\u201d returns to FX for its final season on March 28, the action will have leapt ahead three years to 1987, leaving us with a lot to remember from all of the spy games we\u2019ve witnessed till now. Philip and Elizabeth Jennings have come a long way without their true identities as Russian spies being discovered \u2014 so many close calls, so many wigs \u2014 but with two moody teenagers on their hands, a host of dubious sources and an F.B.I. agent living across the street, how much longer can their luck last?\n\n\u2018The Americans\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAnd how much longer can they keep it together under so much stress? \u201cThis has been hard for me, for a long time,\u201d Philip told Elizabeth last season. \u201cYou know that, right?\u201d\n\nHang in there, Philip. Only one season left. Meantime, here\u2019s some crucial intel to catch you up:\n\nState of the Union\n\nKeri Russell and Matthew Rhys in Season 1 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Craig Blankenhorn/FX\n\nWhen we first met Elizabeth (Keri Russell) and Philip (Matthew Rhys), their marriage was a complicated fiction, deep cover for their roles as K.G.B. officers. But then we saw their marriage become a little more real last season, with a traditional Russian wedding ceremony using their actual Russian names, Nadezhda and Mischa. The assumption was they would be heading back to Mother Russia soon.\n\nBut when they discovered that one of their key targets, Isaac Breland (Frank Deal), was being promoted to the head of the Soviet Division of the C.I.A., they knew they couldn\u2019t go home as planned. Together, they decided to make some changes \u2014 Elizabeth would assume most of the espionage work, and Philip would largely step aside. He would still handle Breland\u2019s daughter, Kimmy (Julia Garner); he would still help run the travel agency, which was about as neglected as their son, Henry (Keidrich Sellati); and he presumably would still keep an eye on Stan (Noah Emmerich) over Miller High Lifes. But what was that advice Elizabeth just gave their Vietnamese former prot\u00e9g\u00e9, Tuan (Ivan Mok)? \u201cYou need someone, Tuan,\u201d she said. \u201cA partner. To do this with, to get through it with.\u201d What happens when her own partner retires?\n\nProject Paige\n\nKeri Russell, left, and Holly Taylor in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Patrick Harbron/FX\n\nShe has mastered the fine arts of lying, spying and taking a punch; she has lost her Christian faith and taken a liking to Karl Marx: Paige (Holly Taylor) certainly seems interested in joining the family business. But given the K.G.B.\u2019s goal to place next-generation agents in the F.B.I. and the C.I.A, it may be in everyone\u2019s best interests to keep Paige on wig-care duty and out of harm\u2019s way. (It also gives her plausible deniability if her parents are ever captured).\n\n0\n\nRegarding Henry\n\nKeidrich Sellati in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Jeffrey Neira/FX\n\nDespite his (surprising!) smarts, Henry is probably not heading off to a fancy New Hampshire boarding school. \u201cThis family stays together,\u201d Philip insisted, back when he thought they were about to relocate back to Russia. Thanks, Dad \u2014 as if Henry needed encouragement to spend more time with the more reliable and understanding Stan. (To be fair, it\u2019s easier to be a father figure than an actual father \u2014 something Stan knows all too well). But might Philip have changed his mind now that the Russia plans are on hold?\n\nLast we saw Henry, he was already inadvertently leaking information about his family\u2019s movements and getting private tours of F.B.I. counterintelligence: Do his K.G.B. parents really want to put him in a position where he might someday have to choose between them and Stan? Could this be the season Henry finally gets a clue?\n\nQuestionable Assets\n\nFrom left, Margo Martindale, Keri Russell and Matthew Rhys in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Patrick Harbron/FX\n\nIt\u2019s so hard to get good help. Who can Elizabeth rely upon, besides their handler, Claudia (Margo Martindale); their call center operative, Joan (Polly Lee); and the surveillance queen Marilyn (Amy Tribbey)? It will be interesting to see whether Elizabeth checks in with any of the former recruits still left in the game \u2014 limited shelf lives, these players. Remember when a compulsive gambler named Sanford Prince (Tim Hopper) boldly recruited an Air Force colonel on the K.G.B.\u2019s behalf in Season 1? That colonel was a strange catch \u2014 he provided classified intel on the Strategic Defense Initiative, but he also shot Prince in the head in Season 2, claiming self-defense. Approach with caution.\n\nOver on the F.B.I. side, two sources \u2014 Sofia (Darya Ekamasova) and her beau, Gennadi (Yuri Kolokolnikov) \u2014 may become more active now that Gennadi has passed a polygraph test. (Guess the F.B.I. doesn\u2019t know about the old K.G.B. trick to beat the test by clenching).\n\nDangerous Liaisons\n\nNoah Emmerich and Laurie Holden in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Patrick Harbron/FX\n\nDating is hard in the spy world, where it\u2019s difficult to know whether someone loves you or your security clearance. Stan is in a vulnerable position with Renee (Laurie Holden) \u2014 her move into Chez Beeman and the career advice she has given him are suspect. Philip has long wondered if Renee was a K.G.B. plant, but his former handler Gabriel (Frank Langella) has denied it. (\u201cYou\u2019re losing it, Philip,\u201d were his exact words.) But Gabriel said \u2014 and failed to say \u2014 a lot of things. It would make sense for the Center to send a different agent to work Stan, given his history of romancing Rezidentura staffers and how little intel Philip has gleaned from him lately. (Another possibility: Renee works for an entirely different agency. Which one?)\n\nThreats and Liabilities\n\nCosta Ronin in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Eric Liebowitz/FX\n\nStan\u2019s extrajudicial killing of Vlad, the young K.G.B. agent from Season 1, is something that may still come back to bite the F.B.I.\u2019s counterintelligence team. Stan has already confessed the crime to the deputy attorney general (Cotter Smith), and has threatened to go public with it. (\u201cThe U.S. government killing innocent people? Splashed across the world\u2019s newspapers?\u201d) It\u2019s a card he keeps in his back pocket, but for how long?\n\nMeanwhile, Stan\u2019s K.G.B. frenemy Oleg (Costa Ronin) could be facing some unhappy music of his own. The C.I.A. has already threatened him with blackmail after he admitted on tape that a Soviet defector was a spy, as part of his (ill-fated) attempts with Stan to rescue Nina. And he\u2019s been questioned about his role in blowing the cover of their bioweapons source (Dylan Baker).\n\nThe Extended Family\n\nAlison Wright in Season 5 of \u201cThe Americans.\u201d Patrick Harbron/FX\n\nMischa Semenov, Philip\u2019s son with Irina, didn\u2019t get to meet his father in Season 5, but he did find some other relatives in the Soviet Union: Philip\u2019s older brother, Pyotr; his wife, Tamara; and their son. Philip had never mentioned having a brother, so this family reunion came out of nowhere. Now we\u2019re wondering how much more there might be to discover about this side of the family (beyond the fact that Paige and Henry have a cute little cousin).\n\nOn a less complicated happy note, Martha (Alison Wright), who was cruelly separated from her loved ones because of her exfiltration to the Soviet Union, might finally be able to start a family of her own by adopting the orphan Olya. Is a happy ending possible for these two? Poor Martha. It\u2019s nice to think so.", "title": "Ready for Season 6 of \u2018The Americans\u2019? Here\u2019s What to Remember", "authors": ["Jennifer Vineyard"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The 1918 house had no central heating, no air-conditioning, and spring water. When she moved down he had fallen behind on his utility bills, she said, and she paid them with the severance from her job.\n\n\u201cJohn was a trustafarian from a wealthy family,\u201d she said. \u201cMy father was from a modest family in upstate New York and my mother was a G.I. war bride. I had a different work ethic than John did.\u201d\n\nEven after the bills were paid, the house caused problems. In the winter, she slept in a woolen hat, gloves, pajamas, and a nightgown. During one particularly frisky cold spell the windows became so loose that there was snow in the bedroom.\n\nOne summer there was no water for two weeks; the couple fetched water from their friends and ate off paper plates. She told him she was tired of it.\n\nBut there was a positive side to her new living situation. \u201cI had a contact with nature that I had never had before,\u201d she said. \u201cI saw 14 turkeys walk across the lawn. I had a pet groundhog I called Mr. Bumbles.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Armor could be whimsical. A fan of Benjamin Franklin, he often impersonated him at public events, complete with a serpent\u2019s-head cane. At night, in bed, Ms. Mead-Armor read cookbooks, which Mr. Armor called \u201cfood porn.\u201d In the car, when the couple came to a road they had never been down, they would take it, to see what they could find.\n\nShe helped pull him out of his shell, getting him to travel to Scotland, Ireland, Greece, Croatia and Italy. Despite his well-heeled background (he had attended a boarding school and Yale), Mr. Armor had never been to Europe. Ms. Mead-Armor, a published poet, had lived in Sydney for five years and Paris for 14 and has a master\u2019s degree in translation from N.Y.U.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe ran unsuccessfully for a congressional seat in North Carolina, in the 2006 Republican primary, before they married. She said sometimes he could be insensitive and he began spending an increasing amount of time sitting in his bathrobe watching Fox News and expected her to tend to him.\n\nWhen he had proposed, she had told him, \u201cEvery man I\u2019ve ever met has treated me like the furniture,\u201d and he promised to be different. But in Highlands, she said, \u201cHe assumed I was the chief cook and bottle washer.\u201d\n\nStill, he respected her intelligence and never underestimated her. Both appreciated The Highlands Newspaper, and after a columnist died, Ms. Mead-Armor suggested that she and Mr. Armor write a column, a combination of personal and political. He was so inspired that he drove her to the editor\u2019s office so they could pitch themselves. The editor bit. The column was named \u201cHis & Hers,\u201d and they alternated from week to week. It featured a photo of her in a French beret and him a felt, wide-brimmed hat.\n\nIn April 2010, a colonoscopy revealed that he had rectal cancer. He breezed through chemotherapy and radiation, never losing his hair or weight. He and Ms. Mead-Armor were optimistic; his cancer had an 85 percent survival rate. After his surgery that August, he wrote a column called \u201cThe End of My Cancer,\u201d urging readers to get colonoscopies.\n\nBut his own recovery was not simple. Mr. Armor, who previously had suffered two heart attacks and was a pack-and-a-half-a-day smoker for 30 years, didn\u2019t bounce back. \u201cThe days we had in the hospital were some of the most special moments of our marriage,\u201d Ms. Mead-Armor said. One day he looked down at her and said, \u201c\u2018You\u2019re the strongest person I know. I could never do this without you.\u2019\u201d\n\nAfter she noticed that he was being rude to the hospital workers, beeping the call button constantly, she told him he had to stop. The next morning when she returned he had a complete change of attitude, saying \u201cplease\u201d and \u201cthank you\u201d to his nurses.\n\nOn Aug. 20, 2010, nine days after his surgery, Ms. Mead-Armor received a call from the hospital at her motel. He died of acute aspiration before she arrived. \u201cHe looked good,\u201d she said. \u201cHis hair had been washed the day before, and he didn\u2019t have that pain in his face.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe column was retitled \u201cJust Hers.\u201d The first one she wrote after his death was called \u201cWidowhood 101.\u201d She closed with the line, \u201cIn the fine tradition of Scarlett O\u2019Hara and Joan of Arc, I am maintaining.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOnce Ms. Mead-Armor returned home from Asheville, she had to figure out how to transport Mr. Armor\u2019s ashes to Highlands, a two-hour drive. She still did not have a license. She called a friend, Betty Chesna, who drove a red Corvette that Mr. Armor had nicknamed \u201cthe sex wagon.\u201d Ms. Mead-Armor put the urn box in the back seat and he was returned to Highlands in the sex wagon. \u201cJohn would have loved it,\u201d she said. \u201cMen were winking and us and blowing kisses the whole way home.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven after death, life was complicated. It took three years to probate his estate. Because of legal issues surrounding the estate, the home was eventually auctioned off, as were his possessions. Ms. Mead-Armor, after having the highest bid, retained some personal items, like his Benjamin Franklin cane.\n\nA few weeks before Mr. Armor died, his eighth book, \u201cThese Are the Times That Try Men\u2019s Souls,\u201d a collection of Thomas Paine\u2019s writings that he had edited for 10 years, was published by the American Civil Rights Union. At the launch in the Highlands public library, he announced to the crowd, \u201cThere are three women without whom this book could not have seen the day,\u201d and named his boss at the ACRU, his editor and his illustrator.\n\nMouths fell open. A man in the back of the room with a thick Carolina accent called out, \u201cBoy, if you ever intend to have sex again in your natural lifetime you\u2019d better be thanking your lady wife.\u201d\n\nMr. Armor added, \u201cAnd oh yes, of course, my wife Michelle.\u201d\n\n\u201cJohn could be extremely insensitive,\u201d Ms. Mead-Armor said as she recalled that evening, \u201cbut he was not a bad person. He could have taken better care of me, but he didn\u2019t always take care of himself.\u201d\n\nThe autumn after he died, she moved to an apartment above a bookstore in town. But it was difficult to be in Highlands without him. \u201cI had to go past the place I didn\u2019t live, the restaurants we had eaten in, and the church I used to go to,\u201d she said.\n\nShe also found less sympathy as a widow than she had expected. When Mr. Armor was alive, they would invite widowed and single friends to accompany them to dinner and the theater, rather than couples. But after his death, few extended that courtesy to her.\n\nBy 2013, she was reminiscing about her hometown, Waynesboro, Va., in the Blue Ridge Mountains. She found a townhouse on the banks of the South River, with Canada geese on the lawn, and fell in love with it on the spot.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has found her home in Waynesboro, singing in a choir, serving on the board of the local concert association, and attending the Unitarian Universalist fellowship. She has developed an interest in genealogy, discovering an ancestor who fought in the Civil War \u2014 \u201cfor the right side.\u201d Mr. Armor had always been proud of his lineage, but it turned out her ancestors arrived in America 200 years before his. In 2014, at the age of 63, she finally got her driver\u2019s license.\n\nAs far as romance goes, she has not remarried. \u201cPeople value what is rare,\u201d she said, \u201cand widows are not in short supply. I\u2019m a tall, fat, plain-spoken woman and men my age are dating women in their 30s and 40s.\u201d\n\n\u201cJohn always said, \u2018You honor a man by the way you treat his widow,\u2019\u201d Ms. Mead-Armor said. \u201cAnd, \u2018a widow honors her husband by the way she lives her life after he dies.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Real Life Can Be Raw, in Marriage and Death", "authors": ["Amy Sohn", "State Of The Unions"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Spend time with this show and you may think of Britain: the sensationalist taste of the collector Charles Saatchi (and \u201cSensation,\u201d the exhibition of his holdings); the British love of the hyper-real, of flesh and the body (think of the painters Sidney Spencer, Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud); the country\u2019s formidable literary tradition with its emphasis on subject matter, narrative and the human condition. This can snap into focus with the juxtaposition of Mr. Bentham in his vitrine, with \u201cSelf,\u201d the frozen-blood cast of the head of the artist Marc Quinn in its vitrine-like freezer. Mr. Quinn belongs to the \u201cSensation\u201d cohort led by Damien Hirst, whose famous shark in formaldehyde might be a descendant of Mr. Bentham in his box.\n\nTogether, they suggest that the \u201cBritishness\u201d of the show\u2019s two chief curators \u2014 Sheena Wagstaff, head of the Met\u2019s modern and contemporary art department, and Luke Syson, head of European sculpture and decorative arts \u2014 may be germane to its formation.\n\nPhoto\n\nUp to a point, I was willing to accept the \u201clifelike\u201d requirement as essential to the show\u2019s coherence. But on the third floor, all bets seemed off with the inclusion of a brightly enameled folk-artish sculpture of a couple by the Nigerian artist Sokari Douglas Camp. Was the show breaking ranks with realism? A trio of definitely nonrealistic works by Louise Bourgeois, Sarah Lucas and Dorothea Tanning followed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy then they tended to make you wish for more deviations from realism, which begins to feel like an easy, crowd-pleasing way out. More awkward Medieval, less Renaissance and Baroque. Why not include some of the early 20th-century carved and painted wood figures of the German Expressionist sculptors Otto M\u00fcller, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner and Hermann Scherer? They all have a gravity of feeling embedded in form itself that can be missing from more realistic work.\n\nIn the end \u201cLike Life\u201d is an outstanding theme show that could have been excellent with a less tighter adherence to theme, a little less \u201cSensation.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the Met clearly means to incubate a new at-home version of the international biennial, something with the combination of buzz, entertainment and historical seriousness that appeals to all levels of art appreciation, pro and layman. It\u2019s not a bad solution to the problems museums face in terms of attendance and audience diversity. The Met is one of the few places in the world with both the collection and clout to pull it off.", "title": "Real, or Too Real? A Dazzling Show Goes the Way of All Flesh", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Two age groups, 65 to 74 years old and 75 and older, are projected to have faster annual rates of labor force growth than that of any others, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Over the decade from 2014 to 2024, the labor force growth rate for 65- to 74-year-olds is expected to be about 4.5 percent annually, and about 6.4 percent annually for those 75 and older. One hitch: In some workplaces, negative attitudes pervade about the cost of older workers, their stamina, their technological ability and their enthusiasm for learning new ways of doing things.\n\nA rising number of role-model employers, however, are hiring, retaining and supporting workers over 50. Lee Spring was among 13 businesses and nonprofits based in New York City that recently received Age Smart Employer Awards through the program, now in its third year, that is a project of the Columbia Aging Center at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health.\n\nThose employers offer training and education opportunities and flexible scheduling; adapt physical tasks to the abilities of workers; provide advancement and leadership training for workers of all ages; retrain older workers; and allow phased retirement.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve increased our life expectancy by 50 percent in the last 100 years,\u201d said Dr. Linda Fried, dean of the Mailman School. \u201cNow we have to design society for longer lives, and these awards, I think, are a linchpin of that.\u201d\n\nOne hundred businesses and nonprofits entered the 2017 Age Smart Employer competition, double the number in 2016.\n\nHere are four other companies with pioneering programs for older workers.\n\n\u2022 Huntington Ingalls Industries, the largest military shipbuilding company in the United States, operates The Apprentice School at its Newport News, Va., division.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have an age limit,\u201d said Susan Jacobs, vice president for human resources and administration with Newport News Shipbuilding. \u201cEmployees go into The Apprentice School well past the age of what you would think a traditional student would be.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe company\u2019s overall work force of 22,000 is composed of 38 percent baby boomers, 40 percent millennials and 20 percent Generation Xers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNearly half of our employees could retire at any day,\u201d Ms. Jacobs said. \u201cThat puts us in a risky situation, and we certainly don\u2019t want those people to retire. Being a master shipbuilder is not easy, and it takes an awful lot of time to become an expert.\u201d\n\nTo keep its aging work force engaged with their work, there are intergenerational mentoring programs. Younger workers mentor older ones, too. \u201cWhat we have found is that the younger workers are helping employees who have been here longer get really comfortable with using the technology.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Accounting firm partners over age 60, who are frequently forced out by mandatory retirement practices, are just the kind of talent PKF O\u2019Connor Davies, part of a network of independent accounting and advisory firms in 440 cities and 150 countries, is happy to hire.\n\nMany of the firm\u2019s 800 employees, who range in age from 21 to 83, have the option to work shorter workweeks or flexible hours. Some employees have relocated to an office nearer to home to allow for a shorter commute, or work part time from home. Employees nearing retirement have been permitted to reduce their hours or work as consultants.\n\n\u201cHiring older workers for our team has been a home run for us as well as for workers about to go into retirement or in retirement,\u201d said Thomas F. Blaney, a partner and director of the firm\u2019s Foundation Services, based in New York. \u201cIt\u2019s not about age really. We just want talented people.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Silvercup Studios is a family-owned film and television production company in New York where shows like \u201cThe Sopranos,\u201d \u201cGirls\u201d and \u201cSex and the City\u201d have been filmed.\n\nWith studios in Long Island City and the Bronx, it employs 49, and more than half are over 50. Two workers recently celebrated their 30th anniversary with Silvercup.\n\n\u201cWe didn\u2019t sit around and say, \u2018O.K., we are going to have a plan to hire and keep older workers,\u2019\u201d said Gary Kesner, executive vice president for Silvercup. \u201cIt is not part of an overall program. It just makes sense for us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHiring people with experience presents distinct advantages. \u201cThey\u2019re more settled,\u201d Mr. Kesner said. \u201cThere\u2019s more sense of loyalty. And it costs more to bring in new staff than it costs to retain people.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The furniture maker Steelcase, headquartered in Grand Rapids, Mich., offers workers a phased retirement program with reduced and part-time hours. Facing a large number of retiring boomers, especially in the IT and manufacturing skilled trades departments, the company began a phased retirement plan in 2012.\n\nFor the past year and a half, David Rinard, 62, director of environmental special projects, has been transitioning toward retirement.\n\nHe started his career at Steelcase in 1979 as an assistant environmental engineer and moved steadily up the ranks to director of global environmental performance, a position he held for 13 years. Today, he calls himself semiretired.\n\nThe program has allowed him to spend more time with his wife, who is six years older and retired, while earning an income and not worrying about health care coverage before he is eligible for Medicare at 65, he said. He added, \u201cAnd my wife actually appreciates the days I\u2019m busy with work.\u201d", "title": "Reaping the Benefits of an Aging Work Force", "authors": ["Kerry Hannon"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "As the beloved daughter of one of America\u2019s most famous playwrights, Ms. Miller met everyone who was anyone, all from a worm\u2019s eye vantage point in their home in Roxbury, Conn.\n\n\u201cFor reasons I still haven\u2019t figured out, nobody would put me to bed when they had dinner parties, so I was expected to just go under the table,\u201d she said of her father and her mother, the esteemed Austrian photographer, Inge Morath. \u201cAnd there was a big trestle in the middle and I would lie on this five-inch trestle because I was very narrow and just listen and be in my own imagination. Our very greedy dachshund was down there, too, making laps, looking for scraps.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a life that\u2019s gone now, a life of artists who believed that if a coffee pot was broken, you welded it back together. It wasn\u2019t a fancy life and it was very much about work and about decency in a certain way. I remember the McGovern fund-raiser in the barn that my father had when I was a kid. I wore purple hot pants thinking I was just so cool. And the Styrons and the Calders and all the people who lived in those hills in those days were there. They were bohemians in a way, but they were also very straight people. It wasn\u2019t a bohemia or even Bloomsbury. They weren\u2019t sleeping around. They were just hard-working people who drank a lot of wine at night.\u201d\n\nMs. Miller, who is 55, has sky-blue eyes and long, dark wavy hair and is wearing a delicate cream blouse with origami sleeves, high-waisted black pants, and on her fingers jewelry given to her by her husband: an oval aquamarine ring and a French Claddagh ring \u2014 a heart with a fleur-de-lis. I ask if she was ever intimidated by her lineage as she made her own name, first as a fiction writer and then as a screenwriter and director.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI definitely went through periods of wishing I had been a child of unknown people,\u201d she says. \u201cBecause I felt like I could\u2019ve made my mark alone, and it pissed me off. I would have liked the chance to say things like the Monty Python guys did when they said something like, \u2018When I was a child, we used to have to scrape the muck from the bottom of a pond.\u2019\n\n\u201cBut I think my parents, especially my mother, gave me a lot of confidence. My mother was told by the poet Anna Akhmatova that because I was female, she should spoil me so that I would not be anyone\u2019s slave. I don\u2019t think my mother spoiled me in a material way. I was raised to be kind to people. But I was really raised to be an artist, sort of the way some kids are raised to be tennis players. And I kind of stuck with the program.\u201d\n\nSheila Nevins, who shepherded Ms. Miller\u2019s documentary about her dad, which will make its premiere on HBO on March 19, marvels at her friend. \u201cSweet Rebecca,\u201d she says. \u201cShe should be crazy, going to psychiatrists every five minutes. And instead she came out like a buttercup, so lovely, so guileless, so unspoiled, so nice to waiters. You expect a star and you get your college roommate.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one of her short stories, Ms. Miller writes about her protagonist, a young woman named Greta: \u201cAt first her parents and their friends thought that she was \u2018not gifted or tough enough to survive so close to the light of their parents\u2019 world.\u2019\u201d The character\u2019s father, a famous lawyer, notes: \u201cEveryone has their own personal velocity.\u201d\n\nArthur Miller got famous writing about fathers and sons. As he said in one interview: \u201cThe parent is always a mythological figure. It\u2019s the basis of all mythology, after all. What\u2019s Zeus? He\u2019s the father. He\u2019s the guy that throws thunderbolts \u2014 kills you. Or raises you up into glory.\u201d\n\nHis daughter says: \u201cI definitely feel like I lucked out being female with him. Because he was not the sort of person who wouldn\u2019t have minded being metaphorically murdered by their sons, subsumed, overtaken or whatever. I got under the radar because I was female. But had I been male, I have a feeling we would have had a much different, more difficult relationship.\u201d\n\nI tell Ms. Miller that I was so strongly affected by \u201cDeath of a Salesman\u201d when I read it in high school that I started crying when my brother told me he had gotten a job as a salesman. In her film, Ms. Miller interviews Mike Nichols, who directed a revival of \u201cDeath of a Salesman\u201d on Broadway in 2012, and Mr. Nichols wonders if Mr. Miller \u201cburned something out\u201d when he wrote that play because \u201che came so close to the target.\u201d\n\n\u201cI think there was almost a mystical property to the creation of that play,\u201d Ms. Miller agrees. \u201cThat remained a mystery to him for the rest of his life. How do you write that first act in one night? It\u2019s almost a visitation. It was a raging fire that went through him.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an interesting story because, of course, part of the play is talking about the wrong dreams and how our society has built people up to want things that maybe they can never have, so they feel like failures when really all the things that they need are right around them. But, early on, he said he was standing in the back of the theater once and he saw many people crying, and he was like, \u2018Oh my God, did I make this too sad?\u2019 That the pathos of Willy was so enormous that maybe no one was going to remember any of the social criticism.\u201d\n\nHis daughter, growing up in a time when his reputation had fallen off, felt compelled to offer a vision of her father as she saw him. She began shooting VHS tapes of him back when she was 21. \u201cI realize, you know, that this is my sixth film but it\u2019s also my first film,\u201d she says. \u201cI spent 18 months cutting it. It was quite an emotional process for me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe felt there was \u201ca huge gap\u201d between the cozy storyteller she saw at home, who enjoyed woodworking, and the cool intellectual she saw in interviews.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe had a remoteness in interviews, because he was a shy person and he was very protective of himself, understandably at that point,\u201d Ms. Miller says. \u201cIt was a feeling like, his warmth and his humor would never really come through.\u201d\n\nIt was strange, she admits, to work on the sections about his first two wives, Mary Slattery and Marilyn Monroe. \u201cHow do you express his vulnerability with these women?\u201d she says. \u201cWhich was a surprise to me. Because he had been lovely and jokey and cuddly with me, but he was hardly a romantic figure to me. That\u2019s not how I saw him.\u201d\n\nShe uses his journal entries and love letters to unfurl the relationships.\n\n\u201cOne of my biggest surprises was how tender he was with Mary,\u201d Ms. Miller says of her father\u2019s first wife, who had been his college sweetheart and with whom he had a son and a daughter. \u201cI had never had a taste of that, so it was interesting to read those letters and say, \u2018No, that really was a beautiful romance.\u2019 Her character was very reserved. But it was important because she talked to him about the plays, he asked her about them. She was a little tough on him. He needed that. He did need a woman to adore him, though, that is for sure.\u201d\n\nMr. Miller concedes in the movie: \u201cI enjoyed being a father. I also enjoyed escaping being a father. I was always in and out of my skin because I just couldn\u2019t be a father 24 hours a day and still do what I was thinking I had to do.\u201d He said he worried that he would forget to pick up his son from school. About his first wife, he writes in his journal: \u201cIn all the feeling for Mary, I rarely see her face, rarely sense her.
