At this moment I fear to go home.\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Miller gets besotted with Ms. Monroe, his first marriage quickly dissolves.\n\nMs. Miller found that portraying her father\u2019s passionate romance with Monroe was \u201cvery tricky.\u201d\n\n\u201cI felt sometimes almost that I shouldn\u2019t be in the room, I shouldn\u2019t know all this stuff,\u201d she says. \u201cThere was this one moment that we created a scene with still pictures where he seems to be looking at her and she\u2019s standing there and he says, \u2018You\u2019re the saddest girl I\u2019ve ever met.\u2019 It was weird, but that was also the moment where I sort of transformed from a daughter into a filmmaker. And I also ended up sort of seeing how she was just a person, you know? Because there\u2019s so much smoke around her. She would even tend to take up huge amounts of space in the film. I was constantly trying to cut it down again, because she has so much light coming out of her. So much charisma. I just said, \u2018O.K., how can we penetrate the mystery a little bit of this woman and this man and in the end find some clarity?\u2019\u201d\n\nShe puts one of her father\u2019s searing love letters to Marilyn up on screen, reading: \u201cSo be my love as you surely are. I think I shall be less furiously jealous when we have made a life together. It is just that I believe that I should really die if I ever lost you. It is as though we were born the same morning when no other life existed on this earth. Love, Art.\u201d\n\nI ask Ms. Miller if, as a filmmaker, she fathoms why Ms. Monroe continues to burn so bright.\n\n\u201cI think she came to represent something, like a patron saint of vulnerability or something,\u201d she says, sipping an iced cappuccino. \u201cThere was something about her orphanhood that became in itself its own kind of mythic thing.\u201d Ms. Monroe used to tell Mr. Miller how to recognize orphans in the crowd by the look in their eyes. Mr. Miller called Ms. Monroe \u201ca poet on a street corner trying to recite to a crowd pulling at her clothes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe romance that began with such passion devoured itself. \u201cHe was really, really worn down,\u201d his daughter says. \u201cHe hadn\u2019t gotten any work done for a long time, and this was a man who completely identified himself as a writer. And that had been put away, barring \u2018The Misfits,\u2019 which was itself excruciating. But I think she had had it, too. They were not matched. They tried and they just bungled it.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe was the rose and he was definitely the gardener. But he\u2019s more of a rose and he needed a gardener. People can only play the other part for so long.\u201d\n\nMs. Miller says that eventually her dad realized he could not rescue the eternal orphan.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t really save someone,\u201d Ms. Miller says. \u201cYou have to acknowledge that you\u2019re you and I\u2019m me, and your powers don\u2019t extend to being a savior. My impression is for whatever reason, I don\u2019t know exactly, but she saw death was luring her for a long, long time, and I think that had to be her end point.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe director originally put in Ms. Monroe\u2019s pregnancy during \u201cSome Like It Hot,\u201d and her subsequent miscarriage, but then cut it. \u201cWe had a version where we see her going into the hospital,\u201d she says, \u201cbut it\u2019s that line of \u2018what\u2019s gossip and what\u2019s getting to the meat of the matter?\u2019\u201d\n\nI tell Ms. Miller that I have always had a dim view of her father\u2019s treatment of Marilyn: because of his play \u201cAfter the Fall,\u201d about a Jewish intellectual in New York married to a needy show business idol who commits suicide, which he at first denied was even about Marilyn; and also because he crushed her during their marriage by leaving an open journal for her to find, with an entry about how she had disappointed him and embarrassed him in front of his brainy peers.\n\n\u201cI guess I have always been deeply terrified to really be someone\u2019s wife since I know from life one cannot love another, ever, really,\u201d Ms. Monroe wrote in her own journal in response.\n\n\u201cMaybe he did it unconsciously,\u201d Ms. Miller says about her father leaving out his journal. \u201cBut you know what? The unconscious, you never know.\u201d\n\nWhen she was still single, Inge Morath happened to be working on the set of \u201cThe Misfits\u201d for her photo agency, Magnum, and took some haunting pictures of the luminous blonde with the darkness inside.\n\n\u201cMy mother was always very sweet about Marilyn,\u201d Ms. Miller says. \u201cShe really liked her. Someone asked her how the marriage between Marilyn and my father was and my mom was like: \u2018Oh, very happy. They seemed very happy.\u2019 Because she wasn\u2019t paying attention.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout a year after his split from Ms. Monroe, Mr. Miller began dating Ms. Morath. \u201cI am discouraged with myself, my rootlessness,\u201d he wrote to her. \u201cAnd ashamed too. I can\u2019t talk to anyone but you about so many things. I feel haunted sometimes by the question of whether anything, any feeling, is eternal.\u201d\n\nIf Ms. Miller had to summon her nerve to deal with the lusty and sorrowful side of her father that bubbled up with Marilyn, she also had to summon her nerve to deal with the most disturbing part of the documentary: the institutionalization of her younger brother, Daniel, who was born in 1966 with Down syndrome.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe was asked to make the film in the mid-90s, but demurred because her parents were alive and she had not yet discussed her brother in interviews.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t really know how to approach it,\u201d she says. \u201cBecause it was a delicate subject for them and it was very personal and they were very private people. And it was a tender point for my mother, especially, and I felt very protective over that. But I also felt a filmmaker\u2019s need to be honest. And I felt, if I\u2019m doing this portrait, I\u2019m going to have to do it. And as I say in the film, my father did offer to do an interview.\u201d\n\nHe died in 2005, at 89, before that was accomplished.\n\nIt would have been revealing. The playwright known as the moralist of the century for his work and his brave refusal (backed by Marilyn) to name names during the McCarthy era, the playwright who focused on fathers and sons, ended up virtually wiping his own son out of his life; Daniel was not mentioned in Mr. Miller\u2019s memoir, \u201cTimebends,\u201d nor in his obituary in The New York Times. He was also not cited in Ms. Morath\u2019s Times obituary.\n\nIn the film, Ms. Miller shows her father\u2019s journal entry from 1968: \u201cAs the nurse was dressing Daniel in the hospital, preparing him for our journey to the institution, I turned to examine him \u2014 with some difficulty. In a few seconds I found myself, not doubting the doctor\u2019s conclusions, but feeling a welling up of love for him. I dared not touch him, lest I end by taking him home, and I wept.\u201d\n\nIf she had done the interview, Ms. Miller says, she thinks her father would have said this: \u201cThat they were advised to do it. That he believed that it was the right thing for our family. It\u2019s a subject that was just hard to broach in my family. And when you\u2019re raised like that, it\u2019s not easy to just overcome that right away.\u201d\n\nA 2007 Vanity Fair article suggested that Daniel had basically been abandoned in an \u201cunderstaffed and overcrowded\u201d facility in Connecticut, with his father rarely visiting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think the Vanity Fair article was written in a spirit of malice,\u201d Ms. Miller says. \u201cThey made it seem like he never saw him, which wasn\u2019t true. He did see him. It\u2019s just that it wasn\u2019t, perhaps wasn\u2019t, enough. But you also have to put things in a little bit of historic perspective. There were other families who put their Down syndrome children in institutions. I don\u2019t know. It\u2019s a mystery. And really, finally, in the film, I was ultimately honest with my own limitations and where my knowledge ends. I don\u2019t know exactly what transpired between those people because they never told me. All I know is what my relationship is with my brother, which is great.\u201d\n\nEncouraged by her husband, Daniel Day-Lewis, Ms. Miller incorporated her brother into her life.\n\n\u201cI started seeing him much more when I was in my 20s, actually late 20s, to be honest, and even more so once I started to have a family,\u201d she says, adding about her husband: \u201cDaniel was in my life, my children were in my life and I was sort of free to create new rules and another, different kind of life.\u201d Her husband, she says, \u201cbreathed fresh life\u201d into her relationship with her brother.\n\nShe says her brother, who is said to resemble his father, is \u201chugely happy\u201d now. He works; has participated in the Special Olympics six times, for biking; and lives with a family that has become \u201clike a second family\u201d and that \u201chas a wonderful social life,\u201d she says.\n\nIn her father\u2019s will, she says, his money \u201cwas divided by four.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one of those things where you can talk and talk and talk, but somehow you don\u2019t get any closer to the truth,\u201d she says, her eyes filling with tears.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Miller\u2019s work has been called the \u201cfeminist, non-creepy\u201d version of Woody Allen. Ethan Hawke says that being directed by Ms. Miller is \u201clike being directed by Annie Hall.\u201d\n\n\u201cLook, this is a difficult subject,\u201d she says of Mr. Allen. \u201cWhat he does inside a frame, he\u2019s moving and he\u2019s moving people around within it. He\u2019s a great artist in that sense. As for the rest of it, it\u2019s a debate. You know, my husband won\u2019t go to see any Wagner operas because he was an anti-Semite, right? If you only appreciate artists who have been good people, who\u2019s going to be left for us to appreciate? And I do think that I can\u2019t unlearn what I learned from Woody Allen.\u201d\n\nMs. Miller, who has mentored Greta Gerwig (and cast her in 2015\u2019s \u201cMaggie\u2019s Plan\u201d) and other women who want to be directors, notes about women in Hollywood: \u201cWe have to let go of that specialness, of the privilege of being the only woman. Which is a heady thing. But we do have to kind of let go and reach a hand out and pull someone up. Each time a woman makes a successful film, like Greta\u2019s, that is fantastic for all of us.\u201d\n\nShe says: \u201cWhat I worry about with the #MeToo thing is that women are getting addicted to the victim\u2019s role. And that\u2019s not going to get us anywhere in the end, right? Maybe what I worry about is, it\u2019ll kind of, in some weird way, put the screws on and make us all really afraid of sex. And that somehow, it\u2019ll end up backfiring for women. Somehow, we\u2019ll end up with the short end of the stick.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI ask if her husband\u2019s legendary intensity preparing for his roles (he made her a gray wool dress during a yearlong apprenticeship preparing for his role in \u201cPhantom Thread\u201d) has ever been hard for her. \u201cYou have to do what you have to do,\u201d she says. \u201cEveryone has a different process. The main thing is that everyone respects each other and are fundamentally kind to each other. But he\u2019s very kind, so that\u2019s not a problem.\u201d\n\nShe says she told him, when she was pregnant with their first child while he was making \u201cGangs of New York,\u201d that he could no longer bring his characters home.\n\n\u201cI was just like, \u2018That\u2019s not going to happen,\u2019\u201d she recalls, smiling. \u201cIt\u2019s good to at least maintain one personality for your child.\u201d\n\nSo, I wonder, that means he never made love to you as Abraham Lincoln?\n\n\u201cThat would have been kind of cool,\u201d she says. \u201cBut no.\u201d\n\nI tell Ms. Miller it\u2019s hard to imagine Mr. Day-Lewis lightening up.\n\nShe says she visited her husband at their home in Ireland recently. \u201cAnd we went and got hot whiskeys in a pub in Ireland,\u201d she recalls. \u201cAnd we walked up a mountain and then we got our hot whiskeys and then we got our scones with cream. That\u2019s the kind of thing of just simplicity and fun.\u201d\n\nShe declines to discuss his retirement news, saying, \u201cit\u2019s his thing,\u201d but notes that he is producing a project with her company. She says she\u2019ll be the breadwinner for now, but who knows? He could go back to cobbling. The family spent several years living in Florence while he was working as a shoemaker.\n\nAs we get ready to leave, I ask Ms. Miller to do her party trick, which is drawing with her eyes closed, or aimed up at the ceiling.\n\nShe draws a picture called \u201cA Woman Who Wants an Interview to End.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s very convincing.\n\n[More: Rebecca Miller reveals a guilty pleasure in a round of Confirm or Deny.]", "title": "Rebecca Miller on the Mother of All Subjects: Her Father", "authors": ["Maureen Dowd"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "On the second night we were finally able to go home. It was pitch black and raining. Our terrace roof was gone; a tree that had fallen on the back of the house caused some structural damage, and water had come in through the windows. But our home, built of concrete, still stood.\n\nWe were among the lucky ones.\n\nThree days after Maria hit, the streets were still largely impassable. We set out on foot to the very river that was our source of terror during the storm, checking in on neighbors along the way. There was no electricity and no running water, so the river was now our sole source of water. We bathed in it, washed our clothes and dishes on its banks and carried back home as much of it as we could manage to boil for drinking and cooking.\n\nIt would be two weeks before the town supermarket reopened, and two more months before we could use our credit cards to shop there. We ran out of cash. The local bank remained closed until the end of November. Gas was scarce. Before the hurricane, I was working toward a master\u2019s degree in management and leadership at the University of Turabo. My studies were put on hold. When the university reopened in October, I had to go to neighboring towns that had power to contact my professors and my classmates, or to work on my assignments. Everything became complicated.\n\nFor about two weeks we didn\u2019t know if my older sister, Maran \u2014 who lives in Fajardo, a city in the eastern region of the island \u2014 had survived. She finally heard that the street to Comerio was clear and made her way to us. My dad screamed when he saw her. We all gathered around her, crying and hugging.\n\nSince then, little has improved much. There\u2019s so much left to do. We\u2019re still fighting to get our lights back on. The local government hasn\u2019t come to meet with our neighborhood or give us updates. We\u2019re getting by with a generator my uncle on the mainland sent us. Other family members and friends have brought us much-needed water filters, batteries, food and tarps.", "title": "Opinion | Rebuilding Puerto Rico, One House at a Time", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Williamsburg, Brooklyn\n\nPoull Brien \u2014 the documentary director and producer behind the 2012 film \u201cCharles Bradley: Soul of America,\u201d about an aspiring soul singer in his 60s \u2014 has signed a three-year lease with a two-year option for a 1,100-square-foot second-floor loft space in this four-story building, which is on a commercial strip. A wall of south-facing windows allows a good deal of natural light into the studio, which is to be used for production, film editing and photo shoots. The tenant received a month rent-free for the build-out.\n\nTenant: Mr. Brien\n\nLandlord: Southside United H.D.F.C.\n\nBroker: Alex Robayo, Ideal Properties Group\n\nFOR SALE", "title": "Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "$13 MILLION\n\n217 Russell Street/758-770 Humboldt Street (between Meserole and Norman Avenues)\n\nGreenpoint, Brooklyn\n\nThis 21,850-square-foot 1950 warehouse, with an additional 6,500-square-foot storage yard/parking lot, is being used for prop storage by the CBS show \u201cMadam Secretary,\u201d which is filmed at Silvercup Studios in Queens, as well as storage space by a local window manufacturer. Their leases expire in 2019. The property, which is within the North Brooklyn Industrial Business Zone, is on two block-through lots and loading docks with frontage along both Russell and Humboldt Streets.\n\nSeller: Wolfsgleek\n\nBrokers: Brad Cohen and Jacob Tzfanya, Eastern Consolidated", "title": "Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "$27 MILLION\n\nThe Davos\n\n143 West 30th Street (between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue)\n\nManhattan\n\nThis 15-story, 25-foot-wide 2012 Chelsea building, with an approved condominium offering plan in place, has 26 free-market apartments \u2014 24 one-bedrooms and two duplex penthouses. Each apartment features 9-foot, 4-inch ceilings; floor-to-ceiling windows; and a gas fireplace. Most also have either a balcony or a terrace. The 19,532-square-foot building has a part-time doorman and a common roof deck that faces downtown. A 2,874-square-foot retail space is occupied by the Fur Palace, a furrier, whose lease runs until 2022. The building offers a cap rate of about 3.2 percent.\n\nSeller: Midtown Stage\n\nBrokers: Nicholas Athanail and Spencer Cutler, the Corcoran Group", "title": "Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "$125/SQ. FT.\n\n$750,000 approximate annual rent\n\nTheater House\n\n237 East 34th Street (between Second and Third Avenues)\n\nManhattan\n\nA 10-to-15-year lease is available for a 6,000-square-foot retail space, which is dividable, on the ground floor of this 23-story luxury rental apartment tower in Murray Hill. The glass structure was completed in early 2017 and sold a few months later to the Gilardian family for $110 million. The space offers 15-foot ceilings and 50 feet of glass frontage, and is next door to the Estonian House, a four-story, 1899 Beaux-Arts building that was originally an Italian civic club.\n\nOwner: Theater House Apartments\n\nBroker: Faith Hope Consolo, Douglas Elliman Real Estate", "title": "Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In the vast majority of incidents, Mr. Lander told me, drivers do not get their licenses revoked until they are charged. To get Ms. Bruns\u2019s license taken away temporarily required petitioning a judge, even though city records indicated that during the past two years, the car she was driving had been caught on camera violating speed regulations around schools four times and running red lights on several other occasions.\n\nIt is possible, of course, that Ms. Bruns was not driving the car in the moments of those infractions, but it is also possible that she should not have been driving at all. The police believe she may have had a seizure while driving; she was taken to the hospital after the crash where she remained.\n\nThe tragedy points to the limits of Vision Zero, a plan to reduce pedestrian fatalities and one of the mayor\u2019s signature initiatives. It has been largely successful: Pedestrian deaths dropped by 32 percent last year, making 2017 one of the safest on record. Speed cameras that have been shown to reduce crashes involving fatal and serious injuries are in place in some parts of the city. But automation in this sense has a real cost; it removes the presence of a police officer who could pull a speeding driver over and see if something might be off. Beyond that, Vision Zero cannot get around the broader spirit of the law, which treats cars much in the way it treats guns, sanctioning the right to operate them as nearly sacrosanct.\n\nFor five years now, this truth has been evident to Thomas Wallack, an investment manager who lives in Brooklyn Heights. On a February afternoon in 2013, Mr. Wallack was on the phone with his wife, Martha Atwater, as she was leaving a bakery in the neighborhood when the line went silent. A few seconds later he received a called from a UPS driver who had witnessed her get hit by a car. Mr. Wallack went to the hospital where she had been taken to find that she was dead. He went home to tell his children and then walked over to the scene of the crash to see what he could learn.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Where\u2019s the guy?\u2019\u201d Mr. Wallack recounted recently. He was told that the driver had been released, that the state trooper in charge had done an on-site evaluation and determined that the driver could go. No drug or alcohol test was immediately performed, Mr. Wallack said. \u201cHe was never charged; he got his car back; he didn\u2019t even get a ticket.\u2019\u2019 He had, the police said, a blackout related to diabetes.", "title": "Reckless Driving and the Limits of Vision Zero", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Is there a way to record and save Skype video calls with family members on my computer?\n\nA. For most versions of its Skype software, Microsoft recommends using a third-party program to record your audio and video calls. The company\u2019s site hosts a list of recording programs that work with Skype for Windows, Mac and Linux systems but notes, \u201cThird-party applications have not been checked, verified, certified or otherwise approved or endorsed by Skype.\u201d (Also, saving conversations with consenting members of your family is one thing, but keep in mind that laws about recording other people vary by state.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore than a dozen programs are listed, with a link to each one available. Apple\u2019s built-in QuickTime Player software for the Mac can also record screen video. When trying to decide which app to use, check out the program\u2019s list of features and reviews \u2014 and make sure the software that interests you records video as well as audio. Depending on your Windows settings, you may get a warning about installing software from outside the Windows App Store, so make sure the program you choose is from a trusted source.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou may be asked to configure the recorder program\u2019s settings when you first open it; this typically involves choosing a video format, file-storage location and other preferences. Once you have installed a recording program, start your Skype call and then click the record button on the recording app. After you complete the call, click the Stop button on the recorder and save the captured video file for later playback.\n\nMicrosoft\u2019s paid Skype for Business software within its Office 365 suite includes tools for recording and playing back audio and video meetings.", "title": "Recording Skype Video Calls", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Detectives in Los Angeles searching for an actress who disappeared last month from her Hollywood apartment found a body they believe is hers on Tuesday nearly 400 miles north, buried in a Northern California wildlife area, the police said.\n\nThe woman, Adea Shabani, 25, had been missing since the afternoon of Feb. 23, when a security camera in her apartment building captured her taking luggage onto an elevator with her boyfriend. Her friends and family never heard from her again, prompting the police to start what became an expansive investigation that spread out from Los Angeles to the foothills of the Sierra Mountains to Colorado.\n\nThe search ended on Tuesday. Along a creek in the Spenceville Wildlife Area, detectives recovered a person\u2019s remains in a shallow grave in a vast nature reserve in Nevada County, about 20 miles northeast of Sacramento. While the coroner\u2019s office has yet to identify the body, the police believe the remains belong to Ms. Shabani, Capt. William P. Hayes of the Los Angeles Police Department said at a news conference on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nShortly after her friends officially reported her missing on Feb. 25, the police focused on her boyfriend, Christopher Spotz, who was seen leaving the apartment with her. According to the police, Mr. Spotz, 33, who was engaged to another woman, told detectives that on Feb. 23, they stopped for coffee in Hollywood and then headed north for his father\u2019s home in a town outside Sacramento.", "title": "Recovered Body Is Likely That of Missing Actress, Los Angeles Police Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "There, in the Redding section, stands the abandoned Gilbert & Bennett wire factory, which operated in the 19th and 20th centuries before going bankrupt. Several redevelopment plans for the 55-acre campus have been thwarted, and the town is currently attempting to eliminate the property\u2019s debt. \u201cOur goal is for it to be sold and developed in a manner that is consistent with the needs and character of our town,\u201d said Julia Pemberton, Redding\u2019s first selectman.\n\nThe Norwalk River cuts through the site. \u201cOne day, there may be a wonderful pedestrian walkway along the water,\u201d Ms. Pemberton said. \u201cI can envision that.\u201d\n\nCONNECTICUT 2 mileS Bethel METRO-NORTH Newtown PUTNAM MEMORIAL STATE park COLLIS P. HUNTINGTON STATE park West Redding station New Pond Farm Town Hall 53 Redding TOPSTONE park Mark Twain Library 107 Easton Ridgefield Saugatuck Reservoir Branchville station CONN. FAIRFIELD COUNTY N.Y. Redding Fairfield Wilton Weston New York City\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Find\n\nHomes in Redding are predominantly single-family, most on lots two acres or larger (the town enacted two-acre zoning in 1953). Styles are an interspersed mix. \u201cYou have colonials, Capes, farmhouses, ranches and every manner of antique, from Federals to Greek revivals to saltboxes,\u201d said Roni Agress, a sales associate with William Pitt Sotheby\u2019s International Realty.\n\nJohn Ford, Redding\u2019s assessor, said there are 3,025 single-family homes, as well as 45 multifamily homes, two small condominium complexes and a luxury senior living community with 332 apartments. There are no rental or cooperative complexes.\n\nWhat You\u2019ll Pay\n\n\u201cBefore the 2008 downturn, you couldn\u2019t find a house in Redding for under $500,000,\u201d said Margi Esten, a broker with Coldwell Banker Residential Real Estate. \u201cNow you can. But the bulk of our houses sell for between $600,000 and $1,000,000, and we go up from there.\u201d\n\nAs of March 9, Ms. Esten said, there were 81 single-family homes on the market. The least expensive was a 1,020-square-foot, two-bedroom cottage, built in 1968 on 4.09 acres, listed at $349,000. The most expensive, priced at $4,850,000, was a 9,242-square-foot, six-bedroom colonial, with pool and tennis court, built in 1907 on 10.01 acres.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe median sales price for single-family homes during the 12-month period ending March 9, 2018, was $490,000, down from $537,500 during the previous 12 months.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Vibe\n\nDubbed \u201cthe Vermont of Connecticut,\u201d Redding is crisscrossed by more than 66 miles of trails frequented by hikers, cross-country skiers and horseback riders. The town is home to Collis P. Huntington and Putnam Memorial State Parks; New Pond Farm, a 102-acre environmental education center; and the town-owned Topstone Park, where residents gather in the summer to swim and kayak in a sandy-shored lake.\n\nThe community also gathers for weekly summertime Concerts on the Green, the annual daylong Rock\u2019n Roots music festival in July and various programs at the Mark Twain Library, including a huge annual book fair.\n\nWhile Redding has no downtown, shopping abounds in Ridgefield and Westport, about 20 minutes away. The closest movie theater is Bethel Cinema, six miles north in Bethel. The closest supermarket is Caraluzzi\u2019s, in Georgetown.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDining options include the popular Redding Roadhouse, the family-owned Spinning Wheel and several Georgetown establishments. One of them, Redding Beer Company, is partnering with the Land Trust in a display of commitment to open space; it will produce a special release called Spruced Up Ale, made from local spruces, with a percentage of sales donated to the Land Trust.\n\nThe Schools\n\nRedding is part of the Easton Reading and Region 9 (ER9) tri-district school system, which consists of the Redding School District and Easton School District\u2019s elementary and middle schools and the Region 9 School District, Joel Barlow High School, shared by students from Redding and neighboring Easton. Children from Redding attend Redding Elementary for prekindergarten through grade 4 and John Read Middle School for grades 5 through 8.\n\nRedding Elementary was named a 2015-2017 National PTA School of Excellence. Thomas H. McMorran, ER9\u2019s superintendent of schools, said that on the Redding district\u2019s 2017 fourth-grade state assessments, 85.7 percent met English standards and 87.8 percent met math standards; statewide equivalents were 54.1 and 50 percent. For Barlow\u2019s 2017 graduating class, mean SAT scores were 590 in evidence-based reading and writing and 580 in math; statewide means were 530 and 512.\n\nThe Commute\n\nCommuters to Manhattan, 62 miles southwest, can catch the Danbury spur of Metro-North Railroad\u2019s New Haven line at either the West Redding station or, about five miles south, the Branchville station, just across Redding\u2019s western border, in Ridgefield. Four direct rush-hour trains run to and from Grand Central Terminal; travel ranges from 93 to 111 minutes. At other times, commuters must transfer in South Norwalk or Stamford. Monthly fare from both stations is $388.\n\nThe History\n\nIn 1908, when Samuel L. Clemens, a.k.a. Mark Twain, moved from Manhattan to Redding, he found that his newly built villa couldn\u2019t accommodate all his books. So he donated the overflow \u2014 about 3,000 volumes \u2014 to the town and enlisted the townspeople to raise funds to construct a library to house them.\n\nMoney was gathered, an effort spearheaded by Clemens and his daughter Jean, who also came to Redding. She died in 1909, and Clemens in 1910, several months before the Jean L. Clemens Memorial Building \u2014 the original Mark Twain Library \u2014 was completed and stocked with Clemens\u2019s books.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, the library\u2019s space has quadrupled; its holdings now include more than 50,000 items, and its walls are inscribed with Twain quotes. The 1910 building is used as a meeting room where, in a locked cabinet, 300 of Clemens\u2019s books remain.", "title": "Redding, Conn.: More Woods and Fewer People", "authors": ["Susan Hodara", "Living In"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cDo I have the Brahms sonatas?\u201d he said. \u201cYou can put that on.\u201d\n\nAn elegant melody swelled from the speakers. He stood upright. \u201cThese are the most beautiful sonatas ever written,\u201d he said. \u201cHe\u2019s not playing the violin. The violin is playing him.\u201d Mr. Chandler closed his eyes and drank more.\n\n\u201cNobody wrote music,\u201d he said. \u201cThey heard something. Except Mozart. He wrote the same thing over and over.\u201d\n\nBach was next. A dramatic crescendo played. \u201cStop,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is amazing. Can you turn this up?\u201d He swigged his beer. \u201cCan you imagine being on this boat?\u201d he said feverishly. \u201cOut in the middle of the ocean? Millions of miles from anything? Listening to this?\u201d\n\nA few weeks later, he agreed to show me his violin, and we met at his apartment in Washington Heights, where he lives with his wife, Sula. The library was filled with books about sailing and Herman Melville novels.\n\nThe Chandlers raised their family in the neighborhood, and while music was around, his children grew up without having to practice an instrument for six hours a day. Mr. Chandler\u2019s adult son, Fred, said his father\u2019s musical past was never discussed when he was a boy. \u201cOnly thing I really remember is we had to play an instrument in grade school and I got the violin,\u201d he said. \u201cRight away, I got the sense he was uncomfortable with me playing it. He never tried to teach me. He went away while I was practicing. Except once in a blue moon, if he had been drinking, he might play a few minutes, and it was evident he was a real master.\u201d\n\nMr. Chandler went and fetched a bag of old newspaper clippings. \u201cMy mother kept these,\u201d he said. Then he retrieved a dusty case. \u201cI haven\u2019t opened this in 50 years,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m scared to see what\u2019s inside.\u201d\n\nMr. Chandler opened the case and a musky odor emerged. Inside was a dark red violin. Blue cursive ink on its interior indicated it was built by a Parisian luthier named Joseph Bassot in 1802. He dragged on a cigar as he considered the instrument in his hands. \u201cSeeing this makes me think I made the right choice with my life,\u201d he said. \u201cI lived my life. Not the life of this violin.\u201d Then he started putting it away. \u201cI hate this thing,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to see it anymore.\u201d\n\nHe opened a beer and seemed happy to talk about anything other than music. But the violin\u2019s quiet presence would not be denied. Eventually, he put down his beer and approached the case. \u201cDoubt I can even play this thing anymore,\u201d he grumbled, slowly tuning the instrument. Then he placed it to his chin and released his bow. A warm, glorious tone rose through the apartment. Then he bowed again, violently sliding his hand up the violin\u2019s neck, and a graceful, thunderous sound filled the room. Then the note faded away.", "title": "Redemption of a Lost Prodigy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The limited-series genre has been a hit with movie stars who prefer not to be tied into programs that can last for years. It is also popular with demanding audiences that may lose patience with a show at the first sign of narrative drift.\n\nMs. Witherspoon and Ms. Kidman are also taking advantage of an industry motivated by the #MeToo and #TimesUp movements to do a better job of telling stories of strong, complex women, in a space that has long been dominated by scowling male detectives, goofy sitcom dads and tortured antiheroes.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times this year, Ms. Witherspoon said it was not until September\u2019s Emmys ceremony \u2014 during which \u201cBig Little Lies\u201d won multiple awards \u2014 that her phone started ringing in earnest.\n\n\u201cI think it just clicked in people\u2019s minds that this works economically and critically and that it was very well received,\u201d Ms. Witherspoon said.\n\nAmazon, Hulu and Apple all showed serious interest in \u201cLittle Fires Everywhere,\u201d but Hulu came through with the best offer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. None of the broadcast networks or cable channels with critically acclaimed fare, like FX or AMC, were seriously involved in the bidding for \u201cLittle Fires Everywhere\u201d or \u201cThe Undoing.\u201d Show creators like sending their work out into the world without commercial interruptions.\n\nIn the new Hollywood \u2014 where Apple is handing out fat checks and Netflix has given huge deals to Shonda Rhimes and Ryan Murphy \u2014 creative producers are in very high demand.\n\nAll they have to do now is make binge-worthy shows.", "title": "Reese Witherspoon and Nicole Kidman Benefit From the Streaming Wars", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "BOSTON \u2014 The snow was blowing almost horizontally when the lights began to flicker at Steven Malatesta\u2019s home in Eastham, Mass., on Cape Cod, on Tuesday, as yet another nor\u2019easter bore down on New England.\n\nBut it was when the internet went down that Mr. Malatesta, 46, realized the power was out \u2014 for the second time in less than a week.\n\n\u201cI expect this for this area during this period of the year,\u201d said Mr. Malatesta, an advertising manager, who spent last week\u2019s storm playing board games by candlelight. On Tuesday, he headed for the local library, which was offering internet and hot coffee to residents without heat or light.\n\nA powerful storm \u2014 the third in less than two weeks \u2014 lashed New England on Tuesday, toppling trees and branches into power lines and by midday plunging more than 239,000 homes and businesses in Eastern Massachusetts into the dark.", "title": "Relentless Weather: More Snow as Another Nor\u2019easter Blasts New England", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Rem Koolhaas and Shohei Shigematsu of the Office for Metropolitan Architecture (OMA) unveiled on Friday the initial design for the Wilshire Boulevard Temple\u2019s community event space, the Audrey Irmas Pavilion.\n\nNamed after the cultural center\u2019s lead donor, whose $30 million dollar pledge in 2015 began the capital campaign, the inclined five-story building will slope away from the 1929 historic Byzantine-revival synagogue, symbolizing deference to Los Angeles\u2019s oldest Jewish congregation.\n\nThe pavilion will house a ground-level banquet hall, meeting and conference rooms and a rooftop garden, while myriad angled windows will filter light throughout the space and offer vantage points from each room.\n\nThe plan was submitted to the city on Friday and is pending approval and additional fundraising.\n\n\u201cIn a city so large and so diverse, we need community, and we need inspiring, welcoming places,\u201d Rabbi Steve Leder said in a statement. \u201cLos Angeles deserves a modern masterpiece that brings people together in the heart of the city\u2019s most diverse neighborhood.\u201d", "title": "Rem Koolhaas Firm Reveals Design for Los Angeles Temple Expansion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The sleepy seaside setting obscures the reality that Guant\u00e1namo is in a state of quiet tumult, with alarming developments occurring largely outside the spotlight. President Trump announced in his State of the Union address, which we watched in an airless tent in Camp Justice, that he had signed an executive order to keep Guant\u00e1namo open. Then last month his administration indicated that it is receptive to sending more captives there, including members of the Islamic State. They would be the first new arrivals in a decade, extending the life of an institution that has disappointed on every front.\n\nAlso last month, Secretary of Defense James Mattis fired the official in charge of overseeing the trials. The Pentagon gave no explanation, but some speculated it was because the official had been exploring a potential plea deal for the Sept. 11 suspects.\n\nAnd last week we learned, thanks to Ms. Rosenberg\u2019s reporting, why the lawyers for the man accused of masterminding the Cole bombing defied a judge\u2019s order to appear in court. Apparently they found a microphone disguised as a smoke detector in the room where they met with their clients.\n\nIt is clear that the commissions have been a failure. Since the beginning, they have been dogged by accusations of inherent unfairness. Hearsay and evidence obtained through coercion, which would never be allowed in a civilian court, are potentially admissible in these proceedings. More prosaically, the court\u2019s location on an island in the middle of the Caribbean means that all of the lawyers and judges shuttle back and forth from the United States on expensive military-chartered flights, adding logistical complexities and delays.\n\nAs a result, while roughly 780 detainees have been held at Guant\u00e1namo, the commissions have issued only eight convictions, and half of those have been either overturned or partly invalidated. Cases languish for years in pretrial proceedings. The majority of Guant\u00e1namo detainees will probably never have their day in court, which means we will never deliver the justice that the families of victims of terrorism deserve. After a decade or more behind bars, more than half of the remaining detainees have yet to be charged with any crime. The United States government simply does not know what to do with them.", "title": "Opinion | Remember Guant\u00e1namo?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump fired his secretary of state, Rex W. Tillerson, with a tweet this week.\n\nExperts, and news reports, have emphasized the unusual nature of Mr. Trump\u2019s relationship with a secretary who reportedly called him a moron \u2014 and never denied it.\n\nBut Mr. Tillerson\u2019s difficulties during his unusually short term also illustrate how the job has changed in recent years. We spoke to several experts and looked at past coverage to explore here how the role was transformed after World War II.\n\nImage Thomas Jefferson became the country\u2019s first Secretary of State in March of 1790. Credit Hulton Archive/Getty Images\n\nThe most powerful role in the cabinet?\n\nThe secretary of state, fourth in line to the presidency, was once considered the most powerful cabinet post. With four exceptions, they have always been white men, starting with Thomas Jefferson, the first to hold the position, in 1790.\n\nMany others would go on to be president including James Madison (the fifth), James Monroe (the seventh) and Martin Van Buren (the 10th). Others, like Edmund Muskie, William H. Seward and William Jennings Bryan, aspired to the top job but never won the presidency. And still others are names that might register only with a historian or a trivia buff, like Philander Chase Knox (1909-1913) or Edward Reilly Stettinus (1944-1945).", "title": "Remember Rex Tillerson? The Secretary of State\u2019s Changing Role", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "His mother died during his freshman year in high school, yet Nehemiah pressed on through that difficult time and then through an injury that sidelined him for a full year. With a skinny 5-foot-10 frame, he decided to turn aside football scholarship offers and run track at the University of Maryland.\n\nWhen modest trust funds became available to student-athletes in 1981, some of the financial pressure on him eased. The real money, though, could only be found elsewhere. He turned to football after college, as a wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers from 1982 to 1985. It wasn\u2019t until Nehemiah, nicknamed Skeets, had collected some decent salaries in the N.F.L. that he came back to his first love, hurdling.\n\nNow, of course, everything is different for elite athletes. While track and field may struggle in America, the sport is popular in other countries. Overseas, some track meets are hugely profitable. Endorsements are available. Usain Bolt was estimated by Forbes magazine to earn more than $23 million at the height of his career, in 2014. The global governing body for the sport, the I.A.A.F., awarded prize money totaling $3.2 million for its so-called Diamond League events in 2017, and handed out $60,000 to first-place finishers at its world championships.\n\nNehemiah fully understands these fresh dynamics because he is immersed in them. Since 1998, he has been an agent for track stars like Michael Johnson, Justin Gatlin and Felix, traveling 150,000 miles or so every year to keep up with events, and with his clients.\n\nHe has been on the management end for so long, this induction call came as a pleasant reminder of a past life.", "title": "Remember When Athletes Didn\u2019t Have to Specialize? These Hall of Famers Do", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Remington Outdoor, one of the oldest firearm manufacturers in the United States, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday amid mounting debt and declining sales.\n\nThe gun maker had said last month it was nearing a bankruptcy filing, which it made on Sunday in federal bankruptcy court in Delaware. In its Chapter 11 filing, Remington said it had between $100 million and $500 million in debt and would continue to operate while under bankruptcy protection. It estimated that its assets were between $100 million and $500 million.\n\nRemington did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Sunday evening.\n\nThe company, which was founded in upstate New York in 1816 but is now based in North Carolina, was acquired in 2007 by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management for $118 million. The question going forward, he said, was whether that evidence would rise to the level of a crime.", "title": "Republican Leading House\u2019s Russia Inquiry Softens a Key Finding", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "As The Times has previously reported:\n\nThe 1994 ban on assault weapons has become a particular and recent subject of intense debate. The N.R.A. has cited a 2004 analysis funded by the Justice Department to argue that the \u201cban could not be credited with any reduction in crime.\u201d On the other hand, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, has claimed in a Twitter post that \u201cthe number of gun massacres fell by 37%\u201d while the ban was in place. Christopher Koper, a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., and the lead author of the study that is cited by the N.R.A., has repeatedly said that the ban had mixed effects and final results would not be immediately evident. \u201cMy work is often cited in misleading ways that don\u2019t give the full picture,\u201d Mr. Koper said Thursday in an email. \u201cThese laws can modestly reduce shootings overall\u201d and reduce the number and severity of mass shootings.\n\n\u201cThese shooters typically are males. They\u2019re white and they\u2019re suicidal.\u201d \u2014 Senator Steve Daines, Republican of Montana\n\nTrue.\n\nA database maintained by Mother Jones, a progressive magazine, shows that 95 out of 97 mass shootings from 1982 to 2018 involved male gunmen. Fifty-five were committed by white men.\n\n\u201cThe states that have these background checks, they have a 38 percent lower domestic homicide rate \u2014 this is domestic violence.\u201d \u2014 Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota\n\nCausation is not clear.\n\nMs. Klobuchar is probably referring to a report from Everytown for Gun Safety, a gun control advocacy group, that claims \u201c38 percent fewer women\u201d are \u201cshot to death by intimate partners\u201d in states that require background checks for all handgun sales.\n\nThis analysis, however, does not account for other factors that contribute to domestic violence, leading other researchers to question the sweeping conclusion about background checks.\n\nApril Zeoli, a professor at Michigan State University who studies intimate partner violence, called the Everytown estimate a \u201cback of the napkin\u201d calculation.\n\nMs. Zeoli\u2019s research has found that state laws restricting access to firearms for people who have been convicted of domestic violence result in declines in intimate partner homicides; specifically, 11 percent from laws that mandate buyers to get a permit whether they\u2019re purchasing from licensed or private dealers, she said. (Other research also shows this.)", "title": "Republican and Democratic Lawmakers Get Facts Wrong on Gun Policy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The House passed its own measure to overhaul Dodd-Frank last year, but it was declared dead on arrival in the Senate. Mr. Hensarling, who is retiring next year, said components of that bill must be incorporated in a final package. He cited measures that would make it easier for start-ups to give presentations about their businesses without violating Securities and Exchange Commission rules and that would expand the types of investors who could participate in private corporate fund-raising.\n\nMr. Hensarling said he expected to gather Republicans and Democrats from both chambers to chart a path forward. He said Speaker Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, had promised not to hold a vote on the Senate bill in its current form.\n\nWhile the banking world welcomed the passage of the Senate bill, they hope the House will take the legislation further in the industry\u2019s direction.\n\nThe challenge is that if House Republicans insist on a much more aggressive regulatory rollback, it probably won\u2019t be acceptable to moderate Democrats in the Senate, where 60 votes are needed for passage.\n\nAnalysts at the financial services firm Keefe, Bruyette & Woods gave the banking bill an 80 percent chance of being passed eventually, although House Republicans could still scuttle it if they overreach.\n\n\u201cIt would be the greatest irony if House Republicans wind up killing the bill and doing what Senator Elizabeth Warren could not,\u201d the analysts wrote in a note to clients.\n\nMs. Warren, an opponent of loosening bank rules, has publicly criticized her Democratic colleagues who supported the Senate legislation. Liberal interest groups, such as the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, are planning to unveil online advertisements in the coming days accusing senators who supported the legislation of voting with Wall Street and against working families.", "title": "Republicans Find Undoing Bank Rules Is Easier Said Than Done", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLet\u2019s play a little game. Clear your mind. Go ahead, clear it.\n\nO.K., now, as soon as you finish reading this sentence, try not to picture a white bear.\n\nD\u2019oh!\n\nO.K., let\u2019s try again. On the count of three. One \u2026 two \u2026\n\nWhite bear! Dang it!\n\nIf you\u2019re having trouble with this, don\u2019t worry. You\u2019re not alone. The harder people try not to think of something, the more they end up thinking about it. Ironic, no?\n\nIt turns out this experience has a name. It\u2019s called the ironic process theory, and it almost guarantees that your efforts to change bad habits by resisting those habits will fail. Research shows that \u201cthought suppression has counterproductive effects on behaviors.\u201d If you\u2019ve ever desperately told yourself not to scratch that mosquito bite or buy another cactus on Amazon, I\u2019m sure this comes as no surprise.\n\nThis inconvenient little bit of neuroscience has bothered me ever since I came across a famous Carl Jung quote: \u201cWhat you resist not only persists but will grow in size.\u201d If resisting a behavior I want to change is not only ineffective but harmful, then what should I do instead?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne trick is to pull a little bait and switch on your own brain. It goes like this: When the urge comes to do the counterproductive thing, don\u2019t resist. Instead, replace.", "title": "Resistance Is Futile. To Change Habits, Try Replacement Instead.", "authors": ["Carl Richards", "Sketch Guy"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China announced Friday that it planned to impose tariffs on $3 billion worth of American-produced fruit, pork, wine, seamless steel pipes and more than 100 other goods, hitting back at the United States hours after President Trump proposed tariffs on about $60 billion worth of Chinese-made products.\n\nThe Chinese Ministry of Commerce issued the threat in an online statement that said its proposed measures retaliated against the Trump administration\u2019s earlier decision to impose tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum. The timing, though, also appeared to be a warning shot against Mr. Trump\u2019s latest action on the trade front, on Thursday, when he took specific aim at a much wider range of Chinese products.\n\nThe Chinese tariffs would \u201cbalance out the losses sustained by China through the United States\u2019 increased tariffs on steel and aluminum imports,\u201d an unnamed Commerce Ministry spokesman said in the statement. \u201cChina urges the United States to resolve China\u2019s concerns as soon as possible, resolve bilateral differences through dialogue and consultation, and avoid damage to the broader array of Chinese-U.S. cooperation.\u201d\n\nUnder the planned Chinese countermeasures, American-produced fresh fruit, nuts, wine, seamless steel pipes and other goods would be the first to get hit, by 15 percent tariffs.", "title": "Responding to Trump, China Plans New Tariffs on U.S. Goods", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve always thought of Vieques as \u2018my\u2019 island,\u201d said Stephen, who was making his second visit since the storms. He\u2019d discovered it when he was living in Boston and spotted a cheap flight to San Juan. \u201cMy copy of \u2018Let\u2019s Go\u2019 suggested Vieques as a pretty good day trip. So I left my rental car on the ferry dock in Fajardo, figuring I\u2019d be back that night. I ended up staying the whole week.\u201d\n\nOthers lured by Vieques\u2019s beauty, lack of pretension and low cost of living, have lived here for decades: In my short stay I ran into a museum director, an academic, artists, a retired nurse and a couple from Colorado, Norm and Deb, who had retired early and moved to the island sight unseen to live, as they put it, \u201con purpose.\u201d Stephen was staying at El Blok, a Brutalist-style cement hotel at one end of the Malec\u00f3n. When it opened in 2014 it was hailed as hip, chic and a little fancy, with a menu created by a famous chef \u2014 something of an anomaly on Vieques. Now the building has a plywood facade painted with the slogan \u201cVieques Se Levanta\u201d \u2014 Vieques Will Rise. Workers head to the bar after sunset, and the vibe is friendly and a little raucous.\n\nA local chef turns out delicious dishes from a mesquite grill. Prices, like those at many places, have been lowered. Burr and I ate there one night, sharing the dining room with electrical workers, visiting doctors and Mark Martin-Bras, who works with the Vieques Conservation and Historic Trust and ViequesLove, a GoFundMe organization that has been a galvanizing force for the recovery. There were also some vacationers, including a couple with a baby, first-timers on the island. Diners flowed from table to table as if they were at a party.", "title": "Returning to Vieques", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Not all the photographers in the book \u2014 which started as a 2015 exhibition at the George Eastman Museum \u2014 have green thumbs or scientific backgrounds. But all of them use photography as a way to frame nature and to explore humanity\u2019s complex relationship to it.\n\n\u201cWe see points where photographers are taking pictures of garden-related subjects \u2014 a vase of flowers, for example \u2014 but really that vase of flowers tells us more about how we see and about photography than it tells us about a vase of flowers,\u201d Ms. Allen said.\n\nPhotos of flowers in vases, in fact, appear often in the book, and each instance presents a different idea about the natural world and how we look at it. Walker Evans\u2019s photo of a vase of wilting pink roses left over from his 70th birthday celebration, for example, may be seen as a meditation on mortality. Lee Friedlander\u2019s photo of stems and leaves in a vase is a study of the power of glass and water to refract light. Jo Whaley\u2019s image of an iris awkwardly coiled into an unusual glass container, Ms. McNear writes, reflects \u201chumankind\u2019s inclination to control and categorize nature.\u201d", "title": "Revealing the Gardens\u2019 Secrets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBoy meets girl. Boy leaves girl to return to his wife. Girl falls into despair \u2014 or the nearest funeral pyre. So it goes with Dido, the famous queen of Virgil\u2019s \u201cAeneid,\u201d and Nora, her modern-day analog in Abby Rosebrock\u2019s morbidly charming \u201cDido of Idaho\u201d at Ensemble Studio Theater.\n\nThe play, co-produced with Radio Drama Network, opens with a sloppy afternoon tryst between an English professor, Michael (Curran Connor, thoroughly embodying a mansplaining academic), and an alcoholic musicologist named Nora (Layla Khosh), who bond over their mutual love of the tragic opera \u201cDido and Aeneas.\u201d\n\nTwo years into this affair, Nora imagines their life together while Michael promises he\u2019ll get a divorce. But when she meets his entitled beauty-queen wife, Crystal (performed with appropriate pep by the playwright), a series of lies leads to a violent confrontation. In an effort to regroup, Nora checks in with her estranged evangelical mother (Dalia Davi) and, we learn, her mother\u2019s roommate with benefits (Dawn McGee).\n\nPhoto\n\nUnder Mikhaela Mahony\u2019s direction, \u201cDido of Idaho\u201d is hilariously off-kilter and engrossing at the start. The characters swap witty dialogue that draws its edge from our contemporary cultural lexicon (from TED talks to wokeness), while nodding to the classic tale being referenced.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNora, its emotionally unhinged, substance-abusing protagonist, perfectly encapsulates the mix of the gut-busting and grotesque. Even when the romantic trio seem too aware of the laughs, watching them \u2014 particularly the wonderfully inelegant Ms. Khosh \u2014 is a delight.", "title": "Review: A Bad Romance with Operatic Overtones in \u2018Dido of Idaho\u2019", "authors": ["Maya Phillips"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "But as appealing and vivid as Ms. Piper has reliably been in such fare \u2014 and in West End stage productions like \u201cGreat Britain\u201d and \u201cThe Effect\u201d \u2014 nothing she did previously prepares you for this blistering portrait, which copped every acting award on offer in London. This is one of those performances that leave you bruised, breathless and grateful for an experience you wouldn\u2019t have missed for the world.\n\nFor what Ms. Piper achieves is an anatomy of an obsession that, layer by layer, peels off one woman\u2019s skin until every nerve ending is mercilessly exposed. And while Lizzie Clachan\u2019s ingenious, two-sided transparent box of a set presents this act of vivisection under glass, as if on a specimen slide, be warned that you will find it impossible to maintain a clinical distance.\n\nMs. Piper\u2019s daring, it should be noted, is matched by that of Mr. Stone, a young Australian director who has already made a name for himself as an unorthodox interpreter of classics. On the surface, \u201cYerma\u201d would seem to be an unpromising candidate for a 21st-century conversion.\n\nSet in an isolated village in Southern Spain, Lorca\u2019s tragedy tells the baleful, simple story of a farmer\u2019s wife who prays, insistently and in vain, to be a mother. (Her name, Yerma, is a play on the Spanish verb for \u201cto lay waste.\u201d) It unfolds, in darkly lyrical language, like a medieval fairy tale.\n\nMr. Stone saw something ageless in Yerma\u2019s visceral desire to conceive and her attendant, abject sense of failure. \u201cThe biological dramas will always be the same,\u201d he said in an interview with The Financial Times. \u201cWe are still just animals. It\u2019s more of a shock to discover that now.\u201d", "title": "Review: A Blistering Billie Piper Unravels Brilliantly in \u2018Yerma\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "And thus, after an unfortunate incident that leaves Mrs. Trewitt with two corpses on her hands, Jim sets out into the wide world, with nothing to his name but the savings he absconded from the whorehouse. Along the way, he will find his fate shackled \u2014 for a while, literally \u2014 to that of a slave he buys at auction, the well-spoken John Blanke (a wittily regal Chukwudi Iwuji), who has great expectations of his own.\n\nDo the trials shared by these young men forge true spiritual kinship? Nah. When they find themselves taken in by a Shaker-like religious sect, led by a blind lay preacher (Max Baker, hilarious), Jim is quick to point out the errors of his host\u2019s altruistic ways, in a lacerating, crockery-smashing dinner scene.\n\nThroughout the first act, Mr. Norris and Mr. Greif pull off the not inconsiderable feat of keeping us fully, even breathlessly engaged, without presenting a single character who entirely captures our sympathies. Granted, Mr. Iwuji\u2019s John, who escapes slavery to become an artist and activist, has conventionally heroic possibilities. But he\u2019s so pie-in-the-sky pious, too.\n\nYet after a cliff-hanging first-act finale (it involves a Hessian execution squad), the play seems to lose faith in its audience\u2019s capacity for inference. The second act begins with a 21st-century, Davos-style symposium, in which various world titans of industry \u2014 including a pompous descendant of Jim Trewitt (Richard Poe) \u2014 defend the right to be rich.\n\nDo we really need this thudding nudge? It\u2019s not as if a show titled \u201cThe Low Road\u201d was ever going to be subtle. That side-trip into the present admits a harsh, electric glare that undermines the candle-lighted artifice of the central story.\n\nAnd once we return to that story, which finds Jim and John taken up by rich New York City patrons (Ms. Harris and a period-perfect Kevin Chamberlin), \u201cThe Low Road\u201d never quite finds its sly footing again. The script sprays its venom on arts philanthropists, four-horse-coach liberals and the ancestors of Wall Street scam artists with fire-hose force.\n\nIn case we missed a point that has been sharply present from the beginning, we are treated to one other sermonizing time-travel excursion, which is so batty it\u2019s kind of fun.
