Inspired by a 2002 article in The Los Angeles Times, the story (by the director\u2019s brother Alston Ramsay, a former speechwriter who worked for the administrations of George W. Bush and Barack Obama) swerves and double-clutches with daunting speed. When the accident victim turns out to have the couple\u2019s address in his pocket and a shady connection to Lindsey\u2019s freeloading younger sister, Hannah (Perla Haney-Jardine), a scary situation turns terrifying.\n\nAs tables turn and turn again \u2014 nudged along by a wolfish impostor (Ward Horton) and some creative torturing \u2014 the movie allows scant time to ponder each new tack. Jeff and Lindsey\u2019s marriage feels long past its sell-by date, and Hannah\u2019s culpability in their predicament is only hazily defined. But if the action sometimes feels rushed, the director of photography, Alexander Alexandrov, maximizes his small budget and dimly lighted New England locations. Whether in basement, garage or on darkly wooded road, his images are clean and clear; only trust him, and he\u2019ll show you which of these characters deserves to survive.", "title": "Review: A Cover-Up Turns Terrifying in \u2018Midnighters\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "The globe-trotting, stylistically varied career of the Iranian filmmaker Amir Naderi resists easy comparison. His terrific \u201cThe Runner,\u201d an exemplar of neorealist-style storytelling first shown in the 1980s, should be more widely available. \u201cA, B, C \u2026 Manhattan,\u201d part of a trilogy inspired by his life in New York, experiments with lengthy Steadicam shots in a wandering, day-spanning narrative. You would never identify it as the work of the same filmmaker.\n\nA current retrospective of Mr. Naderi\u2019s movies at the Museum of Modern Art includes a run of his latest film, \u201cMonte\u201d \u2014 which again tries something totally different. Set in the Middle Ages, this Italian-language feature opens with a funeral. After the protagonist, Agostino (Andrea Sartoretti), a farmer, and his wife, Nina (Claudia Potenza), bury their daughter, his cousins soon depart the settlement. But Agostino wishes to remain where his ancestors lived, and Nina won\u2019t leave their daughter\u2019s grave.\n\nLike Albert Serra\u2019s \u201cQuixotic/Honor de Cavalleria,\u201d \u201cMonte\u201d demonstrates how to suggest an epic scale without the means of a Hollywood production. The natural scenery becomes a character. The howl of the wind (and in one brief moment, what sounds jarringly like air traffic) stands in place of a score. \u201cMonte\u201d weds these straightforward elements to a fittingly stark narrative: Agostino sets out to conquer the mountain that keeps his farm barren by chipping away at it bit by bit.\n\nThe film is limited by its central metaphor, but it is never less than absorbing or original.", "title": "Review: A Man Confronts a Mountain in \u2018Monte\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "A normal tragedy would end right there, but after the intermission \u201cThe Winter\u2019s Tale\u201d leaps 16 years, thousands of miles and several genres to become a pastoral comedy set in Bohemia. The famous \u201cexit pursued by a bear\u201d scene serves as the hinge between the two theatrical worlds, and we now spend an hour or so with the requisite rubes, light-fingered scalawags, misallied lovers and sheepshearing hoydens.\n\nBut before we can fully identify what happened to the plot, which involves the banished baby and her adoptive family, we are uprooted once again. Back to Sicilia we go, for a denouement that is all melodrama and magic. Hermione, apparently preserved all these years as a statue and now brought back to life by Paulina, is reunited with her lost daughter and humbled husband. Whether it counts as a happy ending may depend on how long it takes you to stop trying to make sense of it.\n\nMost productions I have seen work too hard to make these elements emulsify. (The rustic act is a chore in any case.) Ms. Arbus, who has directed six other Shakespeare plays for Theater for a New Audience, including an especially notable \u201cOthello,\u201d doesn\u2019t try; rather, she emphasizes the lumps. She begins with a severe white set (by Riccardo Hernandez) but also with the Bohemian bear, dancing in the snow and demonstrating that what follows will be both grisly and giddy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrom there until the final image, which powerfully reminds us that not every loss can be undone, the production insists on pushing the tonal contrasts rather than smudging them. The different seasons of the year and the different experiences of restraint and freedom within them are skillfully sketched in Marcus Doshi\u2019s lighting, Justin Ellington\u2019s music and Emily Rebholz\u2019s costumes, which go from tails and evening gowns to hayseed overalls.\n\nBut mostly Ms. Arbus depends on the excellent cast to squeeze the ripe Shakespearean language for all it\u2019s worth. The actors in the Sicilian roles are especially fleet and pungent, which is one of the reasons the production, at two hours and 50 minutes, is much shorter than many. (It\u2019s also lightly trimmed.) Anatol Yusef, recently a fine Laertes in the Oscar Isaac \u201cHamlet,\u201d makes an unusually convincing Leontes, whipping himself into a lather of jealousy that seems perversely sexual in itself. And you may never hear a Paulina as fierce as Mahira Kakkar, who in her defense of Hermione nearly blows down the castle.\n\nIf Ms. Kakkar inevitably brings to mind the #MeToo moment, Ms. Arbus doesn\u2019t dwell on it. She needn\u2019t; the women are already the most powerful characters, and though that power is mostly moral, they eventually find ways to weaponize it. In Hermione\u2019s resuscitation scene, regally played by Kelley Curran, Leontes\u2019s contrasting shame is palpable. We understand that what Shakespeare values is not the anarchic emotionality of men but the vigilant self-possession of women.\n\nMs. Arbus\u2019s production endorses that preference, suggesting a way to face all challenges \u2014 not just bizarre and catastrophic ones \u2014 honorably. Our lives will be both Sicilian and Bohemian, tragic and comic, constrained and free, \u201cThe Winter\u2019s Tale\u201d tells us. Some griefs will be assuaged; others will not. We must practice the patience to shoulder it all.\n\nBeyond that it may be the most we can ask that, when we exit, it won\u2019t be pursued by a bear.", "title": "Review: A Moving \u2018Winter\u2019s Tale,\u2019 With Women in Charge", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s lots of Bedlamite fun throughout. John McDermott\u2019s set couldn\u2019t be simpler \u2014 a table, a few chairs, a curtain, some carpets \u2014 and the audience is on three sides, smack in the middle of the action. As a director, Mr. Tucker is at his best and most comfortable in a middle scene, a genteel reception at which Eliza accidentally outs herself with pleasant conversation like \u201cNot bloody likely.\u201d In typical Bedlam fashion there are more characters at this party than there are actors so the scene is accomplished with lightning-strike changes of hats and accents and it\u2019s a rare treat.\n\nIf you know \u201cMy Fair Lady\u201d then there are parts you will miss, like the scenes of instruction and Eliza\u2019s success at the ball. When Eliza says she can do without Higgins or Higgins admits having grown accustomed to her face, you can\u2019t help pricking your ears for the orchestra. But this is a testament to the charm of Lerner and Loewe, not a broadside against Shaw. This \u201cPygmalion\u201d can do without music. When it slices to the core of a classic text with wit and verve and a show-off\u2019s delight, it\u2019s doing what the company does best.\n\nStill, Bedlam is doing other things, too, and they aren\u2019t as successful. There\u2019s nothing here as discouraging as its recent high-concept, low-joy \u201cPeter Pan,\u201d but some ideas don\u2019t fly. I don\u2019t question the decision to cast Ms. Sharma. She\u2019s a cracking Eliza, fierce and impish and moving. But Mr. Tucker has encouraged an Anglo-Indian accent, translated her first lines into Hindi and altered a bit of dialogue: \u201cLisson Grove prudery\u201d becomes \u201cIndian prudery,\u201d and there\u2019s a mention of Delhi. Eliza\u2019s ball gown, designed by Charlotte Palmer-Lane, borrows from a sari.\n\n\u201cPygmalion\u201d is a comedy about a woman who becomes declassed. These changes shift the play toward themes of colonialism and deracination instead. That\u2019s a play I\u2019d like to see, but it\u2019s not \u201cPygmalion,\u201d or at least it\u2019s not \u201cPygmalion\u201d with only a line or two improved. Here it\u2019s just a tease and as Higgins ought to know and doesn\u2019t, teasing isn\u2019t nice.\n\nThere\u2019s more teasing involved in having Mr. Tucker play Higgins. Because what is Higgins if not a kind of tyrannical director, rehearsing Eliza in her role until she walks and talks and smiles and laughs just the way he wants. (Let\u2019s hope Mr. Tucker is a little less domineering offstage.) When Eliza rebels, it\u2019s because they can\u2019t agree on her interpretation of the role. She thinks that a life including love and sex and the occasional kindness would be a richer one. He thinks that it would be a fatal compromise, a sacrifice of her strength and independence.\n\nThis is the tragic part, that the boy and the girl he\u2019s created, or the girl who\u2019s been allowed to create herself, can\u2019t mold themselves into some new shape that would surprise them both. I\u2019m a Henry and Eliza shipper and I have plenty of company. Audiences, actors, directors, everyone pressed Shaw to give the play a happy ending \u2014 the actress he had written Eliza for rebelled and wrote her own cutesy curtain line \u2014 but Shaw wouldn\u2019t budge. For him, an unromantic friendship was a happy ending. Maybe that\u2019s his tragedy. Maybe that\u2019s ours.", "title": "Review: A Playful \u2018Pygmalion\u2019 From Bedlam? Bloody Likely", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "SEATTLE \u2014 Stress over sequels isn\u2019t just for Hollywood moguls. Contemporary classical heavyweights can feel it, too.\n\nIn the music world, few recent works loom as large as John Luther Adams\u2019s \u201cBecome Ocean,\u201d from 2013. The follow-up to \u201cBecome River\u201d (2010), for chamber orchestra, \u201cOcean\u201d won the Pulitzer Prize, then a Grammy for the Seattle Symphony, which commissioned it.\n\nIt was a high bar to clear, then, on Thursday evening here, when the same orchestra gave the premiere of Mr. Adams\u2019s \u201cBecome Desert,\u201d completing a trilogy he never set out to write: three nature-immersed \u2014 and so inevitably, in this day and age, obliquely political \u2014 pieces. Mr. Adams has written about his concerns about our changing ecology, and has lately been pondering a line attributed to the French Romantic writer Chateaubriand: \u201cForests precede civilizations, and deserts follow.\u201d\n\nIn an essay for The New York Times, he suggested that \u201cDesert\u201d would be an experience less obviously theatrical than the cresting waves of \u201cOcean\u201d; he even imagined a listener thinking, \u201cThis music is never going to change.\u201d In a program note Ludovic Morlot, who departs as the Seattle Symphony\u2019s music director after next season, promised \u201ca very different sonic landscape.\u201d\n\nManaging expectations made some sense. But it was also unnecessary. While \u201cBecome Desert\u201d doesn\u2019t have the easily graspable transitions of its predecessor, it is packed with moments of drama in microcosm. Over a nearly 40-minute span, those slight twists combine to create a new route toward a grand impact. Precisely because the two are so distinct in method, \u201cDesert\u201d came across as a thoroughly worthy successor to \u201cOcean.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the new work Mr. Adams divides a large orchestra and a 32-member chorus into five groups. Playing at different tempos \u2014 though none of them fast \u2014 these discrete ensembles are meant to surround the audience. In Benaroya Hall here, the singers were stationed high up, toward the rear of the space. Tubular chimes were visible two levels up from the orchestra seats, along both sides. Strings, winds and percussion instruments were congregated on the stage.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis separation of sonic landscapes brought out Mr. Adams\u2019s gift for orchestration. After an opening section coasted for a bit on a meditative air, courtesy of pinging bells and hissing high strings, the soft-grained entrance of trumpets signaled a change, without overhauling the moderate, peaceable dynamics. At the same time, the disparate tempos between the mini-ensembles kept this from feeling like an easy-listening exercise. Chiming sounds were omnipresent throughout. But they rarely struck in alignment.", "title": "Review: A Pulitzer Sequel for Orchestra, Packed With Drama in Microcosm", "authors": ["Seth Colter Walls"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA show of hands, please, the audience at Gob Squad\u2019s \u201cWar and Peace\u201d was asked: How many people here have read Tolstoy\u2019s mammoth novel?\n\nOn Thursday night at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center, a smattering of hands went up, drastically reduced a moment later in response to the follow-up: How many have read the book to the end?\n\nFear not: Familiarity with the novel is no prerequisite for enjoying this antic show, a madcap mash-up of live performance, prominent video and much audience participation. But, as the members of this experimental company are happy to tell you, their 105-minute devised performance is no substitute for the 1,200-page literary experience.\n\nYou may have left Dave Malloy\u2019s wild and wonderful Broadway musical \u201cNatasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812\u201d knowing more about Tolstoy\u2019s \u201cWar and Peace\u201d than when you walked in. Gob Squad (\u201cWestern Society\u201d) has other goals in mind.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough Natasha and especially Pierre do make appearances (so does Tolstoy, in a comically awful long brown beard), here the book is more a device, a means of contemplating enmity, blood-soaked history and the possibility of civil discourse \u2014 albeit in silly costumes (by Ingken Benesch), and with occasional fog (the lighting designers are Andreas Rehfeld and Chris Umney) so thick that you can\u2019t see past it.", "title": "Review: A Salon With Strangers in a Freewheeling \u2018War and Peace\u2019", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Handsome cinematography and a highly competent supporting cast \u2014 including Michelle Monaghan, Nathan Lane and Alex Karpovsky \u2014 can\u2019t save \u201cThe Vanishing of Sidney Hall,\u201d a tortured mystery dripping with pretentiousness.\n\nHarboring enough trauma to fuel several seasons of \u201cThis Is Us,\u201d the story (by the director, Shawn Christensen, and Jason Dolan) might have packed more heat had it unfolded in linear form. Instead, it flashes repeatedly in and out of three distinct timelines in which Sidney (played throughout by Logan Lerman) is first a precociously talented teenager, then a celebrated but imploding novelist married to his high school sweetheart (Elle Fanning) and last a hirsute hobo living off the grid.\n\nBetween these periods lies a world of hurt that includes suicide, sexual abuse and probable brain damage, all of it barely teased until a walloping final reveal \u2014 a dump of distress that feels wholly unearned. Characters are sketched instead of developed, the looping structure blurring some (most egregiously, Blake Jenner\u2019s critical role as a troubled jock and Margaret Qualley\u2019s blink-and-you-miss-it turn as a melting-down mistress) and eliding others.", "title": "Review: A Young Writer Implodes in \u2018The Vanishing of Sidney Hall\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Is a double bill just a way to fill a couple of hours? Or should it somehow be balanced \u2014 in length, weight, subject matter, mood and aesthetic impact \u2014 to make a unified statement?\n\nOn the surface, New York City Opera\u2019s coupling of two Pygmalion operas at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College over the weekend seemed to make good \u2014 not to say obvious \u2014 sense, particularly with a Broadway revival of Lerner and Loewe\u2019s \u201cMy Fair Lady,\u201d based on the same story, currently in previews.\n\nBut in the event, a greater contrast would have been hard to imagine. Donizetti\u2019s spare, somber \u201cIl Pigmalione\u201d (1816) is, as program notes pointed out, a student exercise, an extended not-quite-mad scene, and basically a one-man show. Rameau\u2019s \u201cPigmalion\u201d (1748) is technically an acte de ballet: a lavish romp and hardly an opera at all.\n\nBoth works depart from the mythological tale, in Ovid\u2019s \u201cMetamorphoses,\u201d of a sculptor who falls in love with a female statue of his own making. In Ovid, Venus brings the ivory figure to sensate life.", "title": "Review: Ahead of \u2018My Fair Lady,\u2019 Two Operatic Pygmalions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "During the opening titles of \u201cWilde Salom\u00e9,\u201d it announces itself as \u201ca story about an obsession.\u201d Early on in the documentary chronicling both a film and a theater production of the Oscar Wilde play, Estelle Parsons, the great actor, asks Al Pacino, the great actor who\u2019s instigating the productions: \u201cWhy \u2018Salom\u00e9\u2019? You\u2019ve done it! You not only did it once, you\u2019ve done it twice. How many productions have you done?\u201d\n\nPerhaps one reason Mr. Pacino is so dogged in his explorations of the play is because it\u2019s one that few others would think to cast him in. The lead male role, that of Herod, a king who promises the title character anything if she will dance for him, is a meaty one, to be sure. But even more than that of the title character, a royal daughter who is determined to kiss the mouth of John the Baptist even if that requires his decapitation, Herod as a character is a figure balanced on the knife edge of Camp. And if there\u2019s one mode of art that contemporary directors do not associate with Mr. Pacino, it\u2019s Camp. (At least with intentional Camp.)", "title": "Review: Al Pacino\u2019s Journey With Wilde\u2019s \u2018Salom\u00e9\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "As the voice of a young boy sings a treble solo, Calvin Richardson begins a slow, swirling solo, often dropping to the floor, then propelling himself back up with curving, undulating momentum. He remains central throughout the piece, later coming between Ms. Lamb and Mr. Bonelli as they perform a floating, ethereal pas de deux. At another moment, he is lifted and carried by five men as the chorus sings in Hebrew, \u201cLord, Lord, My heart is not haughty.\u201d\n\nIs he a Christ figure, a seeker, in need of comfort or a giver of comfort? Ms. Lamb too seems to incarnate or represent something, as her body is arched and curved between Mr. Bonelli and Mr. Richardson, who lift and carry her in a particularly lovely passage close to the end. Is she beauty? Love? The unattainable? Mr. McGregor plays with these ideas, as his title suggests. Perhaps they remain too elusive, as do Mr. de Waal\u2019s sets, which initially suggest portals or gateways, but acquire little resonance through use or the otherwise skillful lighting by Lucy Carter.\n\nMr. McGregor remains intensely responsive to the slightly strange fusion of sacred text and tone, with jazzy undercurrents in \u201cChichester Psalms.\u201d And Mr. Wheeldon is similarly resourceful in his responses to Bernstein\u2019s \u201cSerenade after Plato: Symposium,\u201d a violin concerto in five movements that slips between poetic lyricism and driving dynamic rhythm. (Mr. Wheeldon first choreographed to this score in 1999; Alexei Ratmansky also used it in 2016.)", "title": "Review: An American in London (Bernstein, That Is)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "It took only a couple of minutes of Strauss\u2019s \u201cDer Rosenkavalier\u201d for the conductor Kirill Petrenko and the Bavarian State Orchestra to claim this score as their own on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. In the introduction to the opening act, the orchestra plays the rising, athletic motif of young Count Octavian, then the gentle, falling, noble theme of the Marschallin.\n\nThis introduction is like a compressed tone poem depicting their lovemaking. Many conductors pump the music for every bit of roiling, erotic excess.\n\nMr. Petrenko and his players conveyed the graphic passion in the music, but also its giddiness, humor and, most important, its intricacy. I\u2019ve seldom heard the passage performed with more transparency and color. Right after some raucous horn blasts suggest Octavian in his moment of, ahem, climax, Mr. Petrenko followed Strauss\u2019s instruction in the score to play \u201cin strict time,\u201d bringing exact rhythmic articulation to the series of syncopated chords. It made the ecstasy of the moment even more ecstatic.\n\nThis ensemble is the pit band of the Bavarian State Opera, where Mr. Petrenko has been music director since 2013. Right at the start of this concert performance it was clear that the audience was in experienced hands. This long opera has profoundly moving scenes, especially the great final trio for the three lead women, performed rapturously here. There are also stretches of galumphing humor that go on too long.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe triumph of this performance was that Mr. Petrenko shaped the beautiful passages with tenderness and slightly cool restraint, while also drawing out the complexities of the comedic episodes. Hearing an orchestra as excellent as this one play the music on Carnegie\u2019s stage, instead of from a pit, certainly enhanced the clarity. But the mix of lucidity and nuance, of natural flow and urgency, surely came from complete trust between conductor and players.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWould the singers rise to the same heights? Absolutely, as was clear from the first morning-after exchanges between the lovers. The mezzo-soprano Angela Brower sang Octavian with plush, full sound, yet also youthful brightness and flashes of cocky energy. And the soprano Adrianne Pieczonka was an affecting and worldly Marschallin. During romantic moments she brought melting radiance to the music, but could also summon a weightier sound with just a glint of steel.", "title": "Review: An Ecstatic \u2018Rosenkavalier\u2019 Introduces a Conductor to Carnegie", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Metropolitan Opera is struggling right now, facing longstanding challenges like declining tickets sales and a shriveling donor base, as well as looming ones like coming labor negotiations.\n\nBut Thursday\u2019s extraordinary performance of Richard Strauss\u2019s \u201cElektra\u201d pointed a way out of the company\u2019s problems: Just keep presenting opera on this level, and all should be fine. The intense, tormented one-act opera lasts just over 100 minutes. And I was swept up in every moment of the rapturous, terrifying and moving performance.\n\nPeter Gelb, the Met\u2019s general manager, has made some mistakes during his tenure. But Thursday\u2019s \u201cElektra\u201d is the result, in part, of three smart calls he made, each of which bodes well for the future.\n\nHe brought in the visionary director Patrice Ch\u00e9reau, who was responsible for two milestone productions: a grimly powerful staging of Janacek\u2019s \u201cFrom the House of the Dead,\u201d then this \u201cElektra\u201d in 2016, a collaboration with other companies that, sadly, arrived at the Met nearly three years after Mr. Ch\u00e9reau died in 2013. The production places the bloody saga of the house of Agamemnon in a vaguely updated setting: the drab, stone courtyard of the dead king\u2019s palace in Mycenae, where the tale plays out like the ultimate dysfunctional family drama.", "title": "Review: An Extraordinary \u2018Elektra\u2019 Shows a Path Forward for the Met", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Isadora Duncan wrote in her autobiography: \u201cI am an enemy to the ballet, which I consider a false and preposterous art, in fact, outside the pale of all art.\u201d\n\nWhat would she have made of Sara Mearns, a ballerina whose body seems to hold the air around her? On Sunday evening, Ms. Mearns, a principal at New York City Ballet, performed \u201cDances of Isadora,\u201d staged and directed by Lori Belilove as part of the Paul Taylor American Modern Dance program \u201cIcons.\u201d\n\nNow in its second season, \u201cIcons,\u201d presented with American Dance Festival, celebrated three of the world\u2019s most important choreographers: Duncan; Trisha Brown, with \u201cSet and Reset\u201d (1983); and Paul Taylor, represented by \u201cEsplanade\u201d (1975). It was an incandescent journey through 20th-century dance.\n\nThat a ballet dancer would be featured on a program heralding modern dance was a curious twist. (Ms. Mearns first danced Duncan\u2019s solo \u201cNarcissus\u201d to acclaim when she appeared with Ms. Belilove\u2019s group at the Joyce Theater last June.) But the twist was less bizarre than breathtaking \u2014 correct, compelling and proof that while Ms. Mearns, bold and brave, may be a ballerina of astonishing abilities, she is above all else a dancer.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuncan\u2019s choreography is deceptive: It seems like a barefoot breeze in chiffon, but is full of contrasts and intricate feats of coordination; passages of speed and stillness; and dancing that lives on the edge of floating and collapsing. In this 25-minute suite of solos \u2014 staged handsomely by Ms. Belilove and featuring the pianist Cameron Grant onstage \u2014 Ms. Mearns took on one of the biggest challenges of her career.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThroughout these works, created from 1900 to 1924, Ms. Mearns showed the edifying way she uses the rise and fall of weight to create the illusion of lightness. In the \u201cButterfly Etude,\u201d she contrasted fluttering wings with daring prances to Chopin; and in \u201cLes Fun\u00e9railles,\u201d to Liszt, she wilted with torment as her quiet poses etched themselves into space, one evaporating until another took its place.", "title": "Review: An Incandescent Journey Through 20th-Century Dance", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "And when characters are this vividly drawn, spending hours in their company is no hardship. Watching both parts of \u201cAngels\u201d \u2014 \u201cMillennium Approaches\u201d and \u201cPerestroika\u201d \u2014 on one Saturday, as I did, didn\u2019t feel much different from falling into a fat novel by Dickens or Donna Tartt, or binge-watching a quality soap on Netflix.\n\nAt the dinner break, I almost resented having to leave the theater for two hours. The play\u2019s second half still lacks the focus of its first part. Mr. Kushner takes it upon himself to elucidate mysteries he has set up earlier, and \u201cPerestroika\u201d has some of the water-treading frenzy of the last season of David Lynch\u2019s original \u201cTwin Peaks.\u201d But the characters remain so palpably there, in the writing and the performance, that attention never flags.\n\nMs. Elliott \u2014 a two-time Tony winner for her productions of \u201cWar Horse\u201d and \u201cThe Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time\u201d \u2014 has always been at home with vast canvases. But on the National\u2019s immense Lyttelton stage, her \u201cAngels\u201d could sometimes feel lost in space. And some of the British cast members were having trouble fitting into the American skins of their characters.\n\nThis \u201cAngels\u201d sits far more comfortably in its New York residence. And the method in Ian MacNeil\u2019s shadow-shrouded stage design, with lighting by Paule Constable, is now gratifyingly apparent. The mid-1980s New York conjured here is a town of endless night.\n\nIsolated spaces \u2014 apartments, offices, restaurants and hospital rooms \u2014 are defined by cool neon strips, with window-framed vistas as lonely as those of a Hopper painting. The real radiance comes from the people, and how they flicker, sputter and flame.\n\nAt their center is Prior Walter (a magnificent Mr. Garfield, last seen on Broadway in Mike Nichols\u2019s staging of \u201cDeath of a Salesman\u201d). Having just learned that he is HIV-positive when the play begins, Mr. Garfield\u2019s Prior is a mix of mortal terror, a drag queen\u2019s bravado and a profound consciousness that the world is now a different place for him. He embraces his disease by making a wild, grotesque joke of it, even when he\u2019s in pain.\n\nThis approach is not appreciated by his boyfriend, Louis Ironson (a terrific James McArdle, who wears his character\u2019s guilt like a scratchy straitjacket), a legal clerk prone to endless bloviation on morality and justice. Louis leaves Prior, drawing the first line in a pattern of abandonment that informs the entire play, and finally stretches all the way into the empyrean kingdom of an absent God.", "title": "Review: An \u2018Angels in America\u2019 That Soars on the Breath of Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The world that Anna Sperber \u2014 performer and choreographer \u2014 inhabits onstage is not yours or mine. It\u2019s private: a mystery to outsiders from first to last.\n\nYet she makes it immediately compelling. You watch in hope of understanding her better. Instead, in \u201cWealth From the Salt Seas,\u201d presented this week at the Chocolate Factory Theater in Queens, she remains opaque, an unknown species keen to remain unknowable. The audience sits on four sides of the action: Even when she comes closest to you, she feels remote.\n\nMs. Sperber ranges from being quietly withdrawn to obsessively intense. It\u2019s a pleasure to watch her face, her physique, her variety. At the start, in silence, she walks to a corner of the stage \u2014 stands, turns, looks askance. Then she places the back of her hand to her neck while she looks to one side. Is the gesture one of mild anxiety? Maybe, but her thoughts seem directed elsewhere. Her eyes continue to suggest some other preoccupation while her hands start to trace the top and bottom of her pelvis. Soon she travels across the stage: a few spins this way, a few that. Who is she? What\u2019s driving her?\n\nBut \u201cWealth From the Salt Seas\u201d tells no story. And, although this hourlong piece changes Ms. Sperber\u2019s character, it does not deepen it. After this beginning in silence, the piece becomes a collaboration with the singer-musician Gelsey Bell \u2014 who shares the stage, is similarly dressed (barefoot, leggings and chemise in matching brown) and is evidently a kindred spirit. Some of Ms. Bell\u2019s music is taped, but some consists of remarkable vocalism. She emits a number of trills (long lines of rolling Rs with full voice, now inwardly delivered, at high pressure) and single notes sustained with the steadiness of electronic signals.\n\n\u201cWealth\u201d proceeds in sections, as if the two women were switching from one task to another, all equally mysterious, but some failing to sustain interest. Among the highlights was Ms. Sperber\u2019s way of standing on the spot, hands clasped high above her head, while sending rapid vibrations from her knees and heels. And in a quietly thrashing solo \u2014 helplessly driven \u2014 she paced to and fro within a limited space, bending low from the waist in a fixed rhythm during a sequence in which she also shookher head rapidly from side to side.\n\nIn another moment, the two women, at opposite ends of the room, shook large metal rectangles between their hands, so that the quivering material both gave off sound and reflected it, gradually reaching a climax, then ebbing from it. It recalled an earlier passage in which they had picked up small, tintinnabulating obelisks. All this was wonderfully strange \u2014 until it started to become schematically strange. The spell of the early sections didn\u2019t grow; I became aware of having to work to pay attention.", "title": "Review: Anna Sperber\u2019s Mysteries Remain Intact", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Met has hired a 12-member ensemble that includes sword swallowers, a strongman, a fire eater, a contortionist and a bearded lady to help make this setting seem a place where disbelief can be suspended. When these boyfriends appear in disguise, they look like classic greasers, with slicked-down hair, mustaches, leather jackets and jeans. You believe that their fianc\u00e9es, in time, could see these strangers as the kind of guys one could let yourself go with.\n\nI don\u2019t think even Mozart realized how deeply he had managed to probe below the comic surface of Lorenzo Da Ponte\u2019s libretto. The work\u2019s ambiguities quickly grow darker. The girlfriends don\u2019t recognize their disguised boyfriends? Well, perhaps on some level they do! \u201cCos\u00ec\u201d explores the baffling truth that romance may be more arbitrary than we like to admit. After all, Mozart fell in love with one woman and then, when it didn\u2019t work out, wound up marrying her younger sister. So this sister or that one, this boyfriend or the other? Perhaps it\u2019s not that crucial.\n\nPhoto\n\nI have never seen a production that completely cracks the code of \u201cCos\u00ec,\u201d and for all its charms and insights, this production also comes up short. Mr. McDermott\u2019s concept doesn\u2019t explore the unsettling elements as much as some productions I\u2019ve seen. But one thing it gets right is the role of sexual desire as a motivator for these lovers. To that end, moving the story to the 1950s, when proper young people refrained from premarital sex, and setting it in an amusement park, where the couples are on vacation, work well.\n\nThings start off with a playful pantomime during the overture. We see Don Alfonso (the hearty, excellent baritone Christopher Maltman) acting as a sort of master of ceremonies. His assistant is Despina, the maid who works for the two sisters, and here the wonderful Kelli O\u2019Hara, a Broadway star who brings savvy dramatic instincts, a lovely soprano voice and quite good Italian diction to the role.\n\nAlfonso rolls out a box, out of which pop the sideshow performers, who show us their tricks and hold up signs to signal what\u2019s to come: Lust, Love, Big Aria, Lies, Intrigue and more. The audience applauded each trick, understandably; if this meant that the spirited playing of the orchestra under the conductor David Robertson became background music, I don\u2019t think Mozart would have minded. Mr. Robertson\u2019s performance of the long score was fleet, clean and vibrant.\n\nWhen we meet the young officers, they are having a drink at a garish nightclub near the park with Alfonso. The tenor Ben Bliss is wonderful as Ferrando, with an ideally sweet voice and boyish earnestness. The bass-baritone Adam Plachetka, as Guglielmo, comes across as more blustery and impulsive, with a robust voice and swagger.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe sisters, it\u2019s strongly suggested here, are sexual innocents, and they\u2019re an adorable pair. The soprano Amanda Majeski, as Fiordiligi, and the mezzo-soprano Serena Malfi, as Dorabella, wear \u201950s-style skirts, sweaters and pumps. Ms. Majeski\u2019s lustrous, focused voice and Ms. Malfi\u2019s mellower tones blend beautifully in the scene, set on the boardwalk with a Ferris wheel and roller coaster in the distance, when the sisters pine for their boyfriends and say that they are sure weddings are not far off. You sense what they are really longing for.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s mostly effective to see visitors to the park strolling in the background and sideshow performers doing their thing as the main characters interact. But sometimes it distracts from the richness of Mozart\u2019s harmonically intense and complex music during the many intricate ensembles in which the lovers go through moments of genuine confusion and torment.\n\nMr. McDermott knew, thank goodness, when to clear the stage and focus our attention on the music. When Mr. Bliss sang the melting aria \u201cUn\u2019aura amorosa,\u201d as Ferrando thinks about the breath of true love that comes from his fianc\u00e9e, he faced the audience, lost in reverie. Guglielmo \u2014 and even, for a moment, Alfonso \u2014 seemed touched by his sincerity.\n\nAnd in Act II, when Fiordiligi realizes that her resolve to stay faithful is weakening, and she sings the heartbreaking \u201cPer piet\u00e0,\u201d asking her absent boyfriend to pity her inability to contain her desire, Mr. McDermott created stage magic. Ms. Majeski sang from within a teacup-like compartment of a ride that lifted her into the air against an empty stage.\n\nI\u2019ve still never seen an ideal \u201cCos\u00ec\u201d production. But the Met certainly has a winning show here, albeit one now shadowed by the company\u2019s ongoing battle with the Mozart-loving conductor who has defined its modern history.", "title": "Review: As James Levine Sues, the Met Opera Opens a New \u2018Cos\u00ec\u2019", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Her \u201cMyriad\u201d is for six women and one man. Although set to a selection of Purcell music (played on tape), it strongly evokes the female-centered Romantic/classical world of George Balanchine\u2019s \u201cSerenade\u201d (1934), to Tchaikovsky, in which a group of women are affected by the presence of a man and the love he brings to one of their number before departing. As in \u201cSerenade,\u201d the women here wear calf-length blue dresses, which Ms. Bond has designed with beautifully individuated shades for each dancer.\n\nHer choreography, however, is busy and overwrought, especially beside its chosen music. She crams each phrase with too many movements, each romantic encounter with too many lifts. And so her dancers don\u2019t leave an impression of complete sincerity: They all seem to be concerned with making effects \u2014 not emotion but emotionalism.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Brown and Mr. Gomes both create stage worlds that contain same-sex partnering as well as conventionally heterosexual duets; both allow for those same-sex relationships to be interpreted in sexual terms. Although Mr. Brown is much the least experienced dance-maker of this program\u2019s three, he\u2019s the one with the strongest sense of structural suspense. One group of four (one woman, three men) is juxtaposed with another of six (three male-female couples); and what he does with each group keeps you wondering what will happen next. A sustained duet for two men looks natural: a study of intimate cooperation.\n\nHis worst flaw here, one from which Mr. Gomes\u2019s work also suffers, is cuteness. Dancers flirt with the audience and jokily vie for attention in ways that shatter the stage reality they\u2019ve been building together. The music is Rossini\u2019s unusually scored but appealing Duet for Cello and Double Bass in D major. If Mr. Brown can pare away his immaturities, he may yet become a choreographer.\n\nMr. Gomes uses Dvorak\u2019s \u201cAmerican\u201d String Quartet (No. 12 in F major, Op. 96) to tell a tale of social relations in small-town America. One man wants to leave (with suitcase) despite his powerful affection for the woman we may assume is his wife. Two pairs of male-female lovers spend time together, with one couple reaching the marriage ceremony as the ballet ends (veil, bouquet, trousseau, confetti); but one of these two men is keener on the other man than on his own girlfriend, and so sulks when his devotion is rejected.\n\nThat\u2019s quite a soap opera to pile onto poor Dvorak\u2019s wonderful and large-spirited quartet. Mr. Gomes is not short of ideas; but almost none of them feel organic. There are forcefully folksy handclaps where the music doesn\u2019t call for them; later, when the music develops a folk atmosphere, Mr. Gomes ignores it. Though I believe that there are many such small-town stories to tell, I don\u2019t believe the way Mr. Gomes tells this one. He keeps nudging us to notice the same points about the same relationships. The long pas de deux between the husband and wife creates its own clich\u00e9s.\n\nLarger than each work is the engaging impression created by Ms. Kent\u2019s dancers. They carry the evening. They aren\u2019t, however enriched or extended by it.", "title": "Review: At Washington Ballet, 3 Affable, Immature Premieres", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Where the previous season dragged \u2014 it was more like the first half of a season, all prelude \u2014 this one opens with a sense of things closing in. The first few hours suggest any number of ways things can end in heartbreak: for Oleg (Costa Ronin), a principled former K.G.B. agent who supports the reforms; for the Jenningses\u2019 F.B.I. agent friend Stan Beeman (Noah Emmerich), who\u2019s unwittingly been on their trail for years; for their son, Henry (Keidrich Sellati), happily oblivious to his family\u2019s origins.\n\nThat\u2019s true above all for their idealistic daughter, Paige (Holly Taylor), now in college, whom Elizabeth has been easing into the spy life. As nerve-racking as it is to watch, \u201cThe Americans\u201d makes Elizabeth\u2019s decision understandable from her perspective: If you believe this is a battle for the future of every child, how can you exempt your own?\n\nEspionage, it turns out, is a great bonding experience. Paige and Elizabeth spend hours with Claudia (Margo Martindale), Elizabeth\u2019s handler, watching the Soviet movie melodrama \u201cMoscow Does Not Believe in Tears\u201d and cooking up a batch of zharkoye, a Russian peasant stew. Elizabeth reminisces to Paige about her own mother making giant pots of it to fend off starvation.\n\nElizabeth is committed to Marxism as an idea, yes, but she\u2019s fighting for more than an abstraction. Her nation is not just an ideology. It\u2019s meat scraps and potatoes. It\u2019s memory, taste, a history of shared privation and loss \u2014 an ancestral call that survives the rise and fall of regimes. All of this rings especially strong in 2018, when we know well that the end of the U.S.S.R. was not the end of history or of nationalism.\n\nIt\u2019s that melancholy intimacy that makes \u201cThe Americans\u201d more than the sum of its wigs, stabbings and spot- on period-music choices. (No plot point in \u201cThe Americans\u201d is as big a spoiler as its soundtrack selections, so I\u2019ll keep them to myself.)\n\nThe history itself is no spoiler; we know how the Cold War played out. But \u201cThe Americans\u201d understands history as more than the record of which nations rise and fall. It\u2019s also the story of individual people for whom life goes on, or doesn\u2019t.", "title": "Review: Both \u2018The Americans\u2019 and the U.S.S.R. Will End. Can This Marriage Be Saved?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "It does at least feature live music, a worthy use of extra money, with the incisive pianist David Friend playing a commissioned score by Jerome Begin. The strongest drive in the largely minimalist music comes, strangely, before the curtain rises. Throughout, the composer Mr. Begin processes the sound electronically, so that we sometimes seem to be hearing snatches from an old sci-fi flick, a ray-gun battle in the distance.\n\nLater, low rumbles arrive and cacophony increases, yet that kind of drama has little effect on Mr. Brooks\u2019s even-tempered choreography. Over and over, the dancers grapple lightly, manipulating one another\u2019s limbs with careful grips at the wrist or elbow. The delicacy of this could be dreamy, but it\u2019s too dry for that. And despite the resemblance to martial arts, it has no urgency or kick. It\u2019s a fight without fight.\n\nIt also doesn\u2019t feel like much of an advance from \u201cDivision,\u201d the 2015 work also on the program. In that slight piece, the dancers sweep the stage with squares of wood, framing choreography that has little shape of its own. In \u201cPrelude,\u201d too, there\u2019s a flat object \u2014 a metal table brought onstage in the second half. It\u2019s heavier than in \u201cDivision,\u201d yet the sliding off its surface is similarly amorphous and idea-thin.\n\nWhich isn\u2019t to say that \u201cPrelude\u201d lacks promising moments \u2014 solos near the end, in which the reversal idea shows some life. To what sounds like a record played backward, the dancers (especially Matthew Albert, who resembles a young Mr. Brooks) bounce up from a fall, and the oddness of the momentum is novel, a discovery.\n\nIn the final solo, the music sounds a bit like a Chopin prelude, and the wraparound choreography for the unaffected Stephanie Terasaki even acquires some melancholy, some emotion. If only \u201cPrelude\u201d had started there. But Mr. Brooks\u2019s residency isn\u2019t over. This ending could be a beginning.", "title": "Review: Brian Brooks and the Endless Spiral", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Last Movie Star\u201d centers on Vic Edwards (Burt Reynolds), an alcoholic, washed-up actor who travels to a Nashville film festival to receive an honor without realizing that the event is a small-time, back-of-the-bar affair. (The organizer is played by Clark Duke, from \u201cHot Tub Time Machine,\u201d while Ellar Coltrane of \u201cBoyhood\u201d plays a colleague who peppers Vic with trivia.)\n\nEmphasizing how pathetic and lonely Vic has become and how cluelessly the festival treats him \u2014 putting him up in seedy lodging, shoving a video camera in his face \u2014 the first part of the film is almost as mortifying to watch as it probably is for Vic to experience. We\u2019re meant to regard the festivalgoers as harmless, overly avid fans, but the potshots are too broad and cheap.", "title": "Review: Burt Reynolds Confronts His Past in \u2018The Last Movie Star\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Shut up. Keep talking.\n\nThose clashing orders whisper side-by-side in your mind as you watch the meticulously acted revival of Kenneth Lonergan\u2019s \u201cLobby Hero,\u201d which opened on Monday night at the renovated Helen Hayes Theater, the new Broadway home for Second Stage Theater.\n\nThat\u2019s because you will probably come to \u2014 if not like \u2014 then feel personally invested in the four self-sabotaging New Yorkers so completely embodied here by Michael Cera, Chris Evans, Brian Tyree Henry and Bel Powley. And none of them can participate in the simplest exchanges of words without doing serious damage.\n\nSure, the talk at first seems merely casual as these four characters pair off to shoot the breeze in and around an apartment building lobby where it always feels like 3 a.m. But lives as well as livelihoods are possibly at stake in what\u2019s being said, and everyday conversation becomes a minefield. Whenever someone starts talking again after a long silence, you feel an \u201cOuch!\u201d coming on.\n\nAt the same time, you can\u2019t wait to hear what\u2019s about to emerge from the mouths of Jeff (Mr. Cera), a newbie security guard (don\u2019t call him \u201cdoorman\u201d) and his exacting boss, William (Mr. Henry); and the Mutt-and-Jeff police partners who drop by. They are the swaggering Bill (Mr. Evans, in a terrific Broadway debut) and his rookie partner, Dawn (Ms. Powley).", "title": "Review: Chris Evans and Michael Cera Tell Lies to Live by in \u2018Lobby Hero\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The imaginations in question belong to the director Eli Roth and the writer Joe Carnahan, who move the action from New York City to Chicago, where Paul Kersey (Bruce Willis, in the role originated by Charles Bronson) is a trauma surgeon. The narrative remains roughly the same: When violent attackers murder Paul\u2019s wife and leave his daughter comatose, he buys a gun \u2014 and a contraption for the home hilariously termed \u201ctactical furniture\u201d \u2014 dons a hoodie and starts hunting down the perpetrators.\n\nReveling in urban paranoia, the filmmakers present Paul as a locked-and-loaded hero in a city where weary detectives point to a wall plastered with unsolved cases and a radio jock \u2014 in a tone typically reserved for describing home runs \u2014 announces 48 murders in a single weekend. Yet where the original film (based on Brian Garfield\u2019s 1972 anti-vigilantism novel) was a brutal psychological study of a bereaved man using random violence almost as a form of therapy, the tone here veers from rah-rah to jokey. Mr. Roth, whose 2005 shocker, \u201cHostel,\u201d took a shrewdly offensive swipe at First World arrogance, may lack Mr. Winner\u2019s viselike grip on action scenes, but he can do better than give us dopey dialogue and vending-machine villains.\n\nMorally unconflicted about its self-taught shooter, \u201cDeath Wish\u201d promotes a vision of a city whose streets run red and whose residents run scared. It\u2019s ready-made for an N.R.A. ad campaign.", "title": "Review: Cleaning Up Chicago in \u2018Death Wish\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Daniil Trifonov, the 26-year-old Russian pianist, composer and budding superstar, has made intriguing choices for his Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall this season.\n\nLast month he proved a sympathetic yet strong collaborator with the baritone Matthias Goerne in Schumann\u2019s \u201cDichterliebe\u201d and Brahms\u2019s \u201cFour Serious Songs\u201d: The demeaning term \u201caccompanist\u201d never came to mind. But perhaps the most touching evening in the series came on Thursday at Zankel Hall, in a two-piano recital Mr. Trifonov shared with his teacher, Sergei Babayan.\n\nMr. Trifonov gave the lead to the Armenian-born Mr. Babayan, now an American citizen living in New York who maintains an active international performing career. It is certainly true that not every teacher could hope to hold his own technically in combination with a student as precious as Mr. Trifonov. But the firepower they achieved together is rare among piano duos.\n\nThey opened with Schumann\u2019s Andante and Variations in B flat \u2014 a lovely work that is not often heard, though Schumann gave it a chance at continued life by eliminating the original two cellos and French horn. Mr. Babayan would state an entire musical sentence as if setting up a challenge for Mr. Trifonov, who would respond with a repeat embellished with a slight, exquisite shift in accentuation or rhythmic twist.", "title": "Review: Daniil Trifonov and His Teacher Dazzle With Dual Virtuosity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m so nervous. Why?\u201d Tommy Tune, a tower of sartorial splendor in pinstripes and denim, asked at City Center on Wednesday night. \u201cGuess it\u2019s because my baby\u2019s walking without me.\u201d\n\nMr. Tune, the fabled Texas-born showman, was speaking as a member of the opening-night audience for the six-performance Encores! revival of \u201cGrand Hotel, the Musical.\u201d And while this singing, sighing adaptation of Vicki Baum\u2019s 1929 novel about desperate characters in Weimar Berlin has the usual official roster (credited and uncredited) of book and song writers, it has indeed always been regarded as Mr. Tune\u2019s baby.\n\nWhen it opened on Broadway in 1989, after a long and laborious gestation, \u201cGrand Hotel\u201d was acclaimed as a triumph of stagecraft over substance. Few critics seemed thrilled by the songs, the story or even the performances.\n\nWhat sent them into swoons was the look of the show (Tony Walton did the set) and the fluid, endlessly inventive mise-en-sc\u00e8ne provided by Mr. Tune, its director and choreographer. \u201cGrand Hotel\u201d went on to run for more than 1,000 performances, a testament to the selling power of creative camouflage.", "title": "Review: Divine Decadence Revisited in \u2018Grand Hotel\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Pill, in the least developed role, nevertheless suggests a youthful vanity as powerful as A\u2019s. In her own hard shell of a navy pinstripe suit, she is tart, verging on pitiless; you feel her need to distance herself from the prospect of becoming exactly the same kind of woman.\n\nAnd then, in the second act, here performed continuously with the first, her nightmare comes true.\n\nHaving slyly acclimatized the audience to a naturalistic comedy about the frailty of memory, Albee gleefully reshuffles the cards. After a boffo stage trick straight out of vaudeville, he lands you in a newly arranged world, in which A, B and C are no longer different women but the same one, refracted, at different ages.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the new configuration, with the whole cast dressed in coordinated purples \u2014 the superb costumes are by Ann Roth \u2014 the tone darkens even as the play remains raucously funny. You may never have heard a dirty story about a man\u2019s anatomy told as Ms. Jackson does in the second act, but A, B and C, now a living time-lapse photograph, have more at stake in one another\u2019s success, and more at risk in failure.\n\nPerhaps that\u2019s because they are all, in essence, Albee\u2019s mother, who (he always said) bought him from an adoption agency for $133.30 and forever after hoped to return him. \u201cThree Tall Women\u201d is based, in part, on conversations she had with him about her life, marriage and unhappy parenthood. In more ways than one, Albee hovers about the action.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut unlike in much of his early work, he does not insist on dominating it. \u201cThree Tall Women\u201d is rigorous but also generous, even loving, to its characters \u2014 and audience. It honors the women\u2019s flintiness and fear as C swears not to become B and B hopes not to become A. In doing so, it slips Beckettian existentialism through the commercial barricades by disguising it as comfortable mainstream entertainment.\n\nWell, not always comfortable. By the end, when Ms. Jackson gives voice to A\u2019s terror as her faculties wane, and considers the idea that death will be a relief, you may be struck, as I was most recently in the Signature Theater\u2019s revival of \u201cAt Home at the Zoo,\u201d by Albee\u2019s willingness to go anywhere. Or rather, his unwillingness not to.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean this is a perfect play. Given the Cubist structure, it\u2019s not surprising that the themes eventually start to recycle with more panache than novelty. And C, as written, does not always stand for compelling.\n\nStill, time has been good to \u201cThree Tall Women,\u201d and Mr. Mantello\u2019s production further burnishes its insights and confirms its originality. The staging tricks enhance the ones that Albee built in, with Miriam Buether\u2019s astonishing set design, at first so pretty and cozy, holding unexpected dimensions of alienation in store. The lighting (by Paul Gallo) and subtle sound design (by Fitz Patton) beautifully support the idea of a play slipping identities in the same way its characters do.\n\nFinally, though, it comes back to the actors. Ms. Jackson\u2019s history with us, and her aura of indomitability, mean that she is not merely a casting coup for A but a natural advocate for the play\u2019s central themes. She is, politically and personally, the embodiment of not going gentle into that good night; death and Thatcherism are all the same to her.\n\nAnd though Ms. Metcalf and Ms. Pill look nothing like Ms. Jackson, or each other, they bring more important skills and associations to their roles. Ms. Metcalf, once known for tragedy but now transformed into a peerless comedian (thanks to \u201cRoseanne,\u201d \u201cA Doll\u2019s House, Part 2\u201d and \u201cLady Bird\u201d), is thus a very Albee creature. And it is not irrelevant, seeing Ms. Pill\u2019s just-holding-it-together C, to think of the devastated young woman she played, under Mr. Mantello\u2019s direction, in the Off Broadway premiere of \u201cBlackbird.\u201d\n\nWatching these three women in \u201cThree Tall Women\u201d means seeing the ghosts and echoes of many other women as well. They complete Albee\u2019s imaginative leap into difficult souls, which of course means all of us. And they honor a play that despite its frailties and wrinkles has aged beautifully, into a burning, raving classic.", "title": "Review: Glenda Jackson Gets Her Queen Lear Moment in \u2018Three Tall Women\u2019", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt\u2019s no secret that classical music institutions are struggling to attract new audiences. This challenge is often on my mind, but I had something of an epiphany about it on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.\n\nThe place was packed for a concert performance of Handel\u2019s opera \u201cRinaldo.\u201d It was the latest in a series of nearly annual Handel performances at Carnegie by Harry Bicket and his English Concert ensemble; since 2013, this has become a beloved ritual for many.\n\nThe exceptional cast of singers included the superb countertenor Iestyn Davies in the title role. (He had a busy Sunday: After \u201cRinaldo\u201d he had to dash to the Belasco Theater for his closing night as the voice of a legendary castrato in \u201cFarinelli and the King\u201d on Broadway.) The Handel performance could not have been better.\n\nIf I were recommending a program to someone fairly new to classical music, I wouldn\u2019t immediately think of \u201cRinaldo\u201d in concert. It\u2019s long (nearly three hours of music) and, hewing to the conventions of Italian opera seria, it\u2019s structured as a seemingly endless series of so-called da capo arias. Taken at face value, the story \u2014 a love tangle set during the Crusades \u2014 is full of improbable plot twists designed to let the characters milk some emotion and display their voices.\n\nPhoto\n\nYet perhaps because Americans are enduring a period of fractious partisanship, disinformation and social media hysteria, performances that offer honesty and insight are like salves. The authenticity of this \u201cRinaldo\u201d was like a clarifying gift. I kept thinking that even newcomers to classical music would \u201cget\u201d what\u2019s profoundly true about Handel\u2019s work and these fine artists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf the libretto contorts itself again and again, Handel seizes each opportunity to explore complex emotions through wondrous music. This comes through in the first aria for Rinaldo, a Christian hero, who loves Almirena (the radiant soprano Jo\u00e9lle Harvey), the winsome daughter of Goffredo (the dark-voiced mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke), the captain of the Christian armies intent on seizing Jerusalem from the Saracen king Argante (the robust bass-baritone Luca Pisaroni).", "title": "Review: Handel\u2019s \u2018Rinaldo,\u2019 in Concert and Profoundly Authentic", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Most of those are undercooked, but the movie, drawing the bulk of its vitality from an electric lead performance, suffers less than you might imagine. As the hollow-eyed, foulmouthed Danny, Jack Roth (a dead ringer for his father, Tim Roth) is alive with unpredictable menace. Equal parts grit and grandiosity, he views himself as a fed-up political rebel, railing in monologue against one-percenters. Social warrior or just plain sociopath, he has frustrations that are real; and as he and his balaclava-wearing accomplices (Andrew Tiernan and Daniel Kendrick) terrorize their hostages, the film\u2019s jazzy tone and nervy editing \u2014 Guy Ritchie\u2019s stylistic fingerprints are all over it \u2014 hustle us along.\n\nTapping into a vein of blue-collar resentment that\u2019s both thematically rich and uncomfortably current, the writer and director, Joseph Martin, is not above using tricks to bolster an occasionally sagging narrative. Split screens, a fractured timeline and a soundtrack that skids from The Damned to Vivaldi help us push past an unfortunate episode of torture, and Stefan Mitchell\u2019s stellar camerawork highlights the plot\u2019s unexpected emotional shifts.\n\nA switchback of mixed motives and ping-ponging sympathies, \u201cUs and Them\u201d declines to go all in for its working stiffs. For My Dear Brooklyn,\u201d Modesto Jimenez, a.k.a. Flako, had to place a call. He was a bit tipsy and no, it could not wait. He FaceTimed his mother, who lives in the Dominican Republic. They chatted a bit. Eventually, Mr. Jimenez hung up and resumed the show.\n\nExcept, of course, this interlude was very much a part of \u201c\u00a1Oye!,\u201d a loosely structured mix of autobiographical morsels and ruminations on identity, immigration, gentrification and art that\u2019s playing at the Abrons Arts Center.\n\nMr. Jimenez, a writer-performer who moved to Brooklyn when he was 9, segues seamlessly between reminiscences and digressions, English and Spanish. There are no supertitles, so monolingual theatergoers will be at a bit of a disadvantage, but Mr. Jimenez usually hopscotches deftly between the two languages so you can pick up some of what you may have missed.\n\nBut the bilingual element is not the most distinctive aspect of the show. That would be the bicultural fluidity so central to many immigrant New Yorkers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter settling in Bushwick, where he was raised by his grandmother, Mr. Jimenez discovered theater and gang life. \u201cLatino guys should have Sweet Sixteens,\u201d he says. \u201cMaybe I would never have joined the black-and-gold brigade.\u201d He is referring to the Latin Kings, whose activities helped him pay for extras when he attended Bennington College.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a scene whose pedagogical matter-of-factness is both chilling and funny, Mr. Jimenez stuffs cocaine (we\u2019ll assume legal constraints and an Off Off Broadway budget mean it\u2019s actually flour) into a condom, which he then lubricates so it can be inserted into \u2014 let\u2019s just leave the rest to your imagination.", "title": "Review: Hopscotching Between Worlds in \u2018My Dear Brooklyn\u2019", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "It takes a lot to sustain human life. You need the right temperature, atmosphere and gravity; some water, enough nutrients, not too many volcanoes. And in Don Nguyen\u2019s \u201cHello, From the Children of Planet Earth,\u201d you also need a willing sperm donor.\n\nAmbitious and labored, Mr. Nguyen\u2019s play, produced by the Playwrights Realm at the Duke on 42nd Street, is set in the misty long ago of 2012. Directed by Jade King Carroll, it twins Voyager 1\u2019s journey toward interstellar space with a lesbian couple\u2019s attempt to fertilize an egg. Betsy (Kaaron Briscoe), an Amnesty International advocacy director, and Shoshana (Dana Berger), a farm-to-table chef, have maxed out their accounts on I.V.F., so now they\u2019re trying a budget option, D.I.Y. insemination. The woman with frizzy blond hair was taken to her first pornographic movie by a date. He turned out to be the star. The man in the blue shirt likes gay porn even though he\u2019s straight, mostly. The woman in the red shirt likes it, too. \u201cI\u2019m horrified by some of the stuff I watch,\u201d she says.\n\nThese people were speaking on Monday night at \u201cPrurience,\u201d a self-help program for people addicted to pornography that is also a tricky, mutable, overstuffed performance piece by the British conceptualist Christopher Green, co-directed by Holly Race Roughan.\n\nPart immersion, part indictment and part encounter group, it guides the crowd through a set program of conflict and disclosure, mixing unscripted audience comments and more carefully composed revelations from actors. (That woman in the red shirt was one of them.) Speak Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cHell hath no fury,\u201d reads a tagline on a poster for \u201cAcrimony,\u201d and at first glance, the latest sermonizing melodrama from Tyler Perry appears to be the story of how a scorned woman worked up the courage to leave her exploitative, untrustworthy husband.\n\nThe upshot is a good deal plottier, though, and the message less universal. The moral of \u201cAcrimony\u201d seems to be: Leave a bad man, especially one who cheated on you before marriage and leeches off your financial resources \u2014 unless he has poured his life into the dream of inventing a self-recharging battery, in which case the bonds of matrimony are sacrosanct and no sacrifice is too great.\n\nIn those circumstances, who could disagree? The movie opens with a judge ordering Melinda (Taraji P. Henson), who has skirted a restraining order, to undergo counseling. As the camera slowly moves in on Ms. Henson on the couch, Melinda tells us about the man who ruined her life.\n\nVideo\n\nWe learn how in college (when she\u2019s played by Ajiona Alexus), Melinda met Robert (Antonio Madison, and later Lyriq Bent), a handsome chemical-engineering student who seduced her to the strains of Nina Simone. But Robert is no Prince Charming. After catching him with another woman, Melinda rams her car into his mobile home, knocking it over \u2014 an accident that also injures her and results in a hysterectomy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe film is just getting started. Melinda marries Robert anyway, and he continues to drain the money she inherited from her mother. Mr. Perry tracks the major expenses in onscreen text, and puts synonyms for the movie\u2019s principal themes (\u201cacrimony,\u201d of course, as well as \u201cderanged\u201d and \u201cinexorable\u201d) in title cards.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Acrimony,\u2019 Taraji P. Henson Endures Marriage and Script Woes", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg", "Tyler Perry"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs recovery culture has seeped into the mainstream, the axiom \u201churt people hurt people\u201d is morphing from truism to clich\u00e9. \u201cAllure,\u201d a new film from Canada written and directed by the brothers Carlos and Jason Sanchez, introduces its lead character, Laura, as a damaged person, and then sometimes teases the viewer about how she got that way.\n\nVideo\n\nThe movie is pretty direct, though, about the damage she can do in turn. Laura, played by Evan Rachel Wood with her usual commendable concentration and attention to detail, works for a home-cleaning company run by her father (Denis O\u2019Hare). In one of the houses she looks after there\u2019s a delicate 16-year-old girl, Eva (Julia Sarah Stone), who\u2019s locked in a battle with her mother. The two form a tentative friendship over music and weed, and soon Laura has Eva at her home, and very much wants her to stay \u2014 to the extent that she forces the issue, to say the least, first through wheedling, then through locked doors.\n\nAfter Laura convinces the police that she had nothing to do with Eva\u2019s disappearance, the film becomes a character study of one lost soul trying to engulf another. Laura\u2019s behavior once Eva settles in is discomfiting. She acts as both a gentle lover and an egocentric, vengeful parent figure. In a number of scenes, the characters are framed in doorways and hallways, the camera maintaining a distance that I suppose it wishes the viewer to take as discreet. I saw the strategy as more to do with withholding, and I think it backfires.\n\nThe filmmakers seem less concerned with telling a story than in convincing the audience (and maybe themselves) that they can handle this provocative and potentially exploitive material they\u2019ve contrived with what\u2019s conventionally considered \u201cappropriate\u201d sensitivity. That consideration, which might be a bad-faith one to begin with, becomes moot well before this grim cinematic exercise ends.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Allure,\u2019 Evan Rachel Wood Is a Friend With a Sinister Side", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Carlos Sanchez", "Jason Sanchez"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The series, created by Mr. Hader and Alec Berg (\u201cSilicon Valley\u201d), ingeniously mixes wetwork and dry irony. (The relationship between Barry and Fuches, as it develops, is very much that of a frustrated actor and a money-minded agent.)\n\nBut it would be a cold satire without the transformation of Mr. Hader, best known for playing outlandish characters like Stefon on \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d His Barry is wound so tight he hums \u2014 he\u2019s like a slightly zanier Michael Shannon character \u2014 but Mr. Hader also shows you the light flicking on inside him for the first time.\n\nThe criminal going straight, or pretending to, is a mini genre unto itself (\u201cBanshee,\u201d \u201cLilyhammer\u201d). There are a couple ways you might expect a hit-man-in-Hollywood story to go: The killer teaches a few lessons to the showbiz phonies, or he discovers that crime has given him unique insights into human nature.\n\nNot so in \u201cBarry.\u201d Murder is a soul-numbing day job for Barry that\u2019s done no good for him except pay the bills. It\u2019s a messier, better remunerated version of slinging coffee.\n\nThere\u2019s a recurring theme in cable dramas that criminality is, if not admirable, at least more authentic and exhilarating than the overcivilized straight life. Walter White in \u201cBreaking Bad\u201d says that crime made him feel \u201calive.\u201d Tony Soprano, monster though he may be, is continually contrasted with pathetic and envious civilian schnooks like Artie Bucco.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHere, Barry\u2019s the schnook. He\u2019s not animated by his work but drained by it. For someone who kills for a living, he\u2019s awfully passive, having let his hit-man career happen to him more than having pursued it.\n\nWhen Barry tries to win Sally over by buying her an outlandishly expensive gift, she\u2019s put off by the \u201cweird-ass Tony Soprano move.\u201d When she calls him out on his \u201ctoxic masculinity\u201d \u2014 having no idea how toxic it really is \u2014 Barry actually takes it to heart, even if he has a hard time applying the lesson.\n\nBecause of Sally\u2019s role as a foil in what is indeed a very male show, I wish her character were better fleshed out. \u201cBarry\u201d is well-cast top to bottom, though, from Henry Winkler as Gene, the acting class\u2019s passionate but fatuous instructor, to a scene-stealing Anthony Carrigan as NoHo Hank, an incongruously polite Chechen lieutenant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe spatter comedy is not for the squeamish, but \u201cBarry\u201d plays cleverly with the contrast between Barry\u2019s two worlds. His mob clients have their own Hollywood-inspired sense of theatrics, as when Hank needlessly complicates a hit by insisting on express-mailing the target a bullet, because it will be cooler.\n\nThis all might come across glib if \u201cBarry\u201d weren\u2019t also willing to go dark when necessary, and if Mr. Hader were less effective at finding the drama in his comic character. The season\u2019s last half finds another gear, as the guilt-racked Barry has a harder and harder time compartmentalizing his vocation from his avocation.\n\nBy pushing its story to an extreme, \u201cBarry\u201d hits on a universal conflict. Like many of us who are not trained assassins, Barry wants to believe he can make moral compromises while telling himself, \u201cThis is not who I am.\u201d (He sees himself in the character of Macbeth, but in his reading, Shakespeare\u2019s murderous Scot was \u201cjust following orders.\u201d)\n\nBut there comes a point \u2014 Barry crosses that point, and then some \u2014 where that\u2019s a crock. What you do is who you are. Barry\u2019s targets, were they still alive, would testify that the guy who killed them was plenty real.\n\nIt\u2019s a tricky game \u201cBarry\u201d is playing, cultivating our empathy for its protagonist, then confronting us with this recognition. And the season finale does raise the question of how long the series can string out its double-life premise.\n\nBut mostly, \u201cBarry\u201d pulls off the feat, developing into something more profound than its high-concept premise suggests. You don\u2019t expect this comedy to find its target in the way it does. And as Barry could tell you, that element of surprise is the mark of a professional.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Barry,\u2019 This Actor Slays Them, Offstage", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Adding a sci-fi kink to the home-invasion thriller, Jamie Patterson\u2019s \u201cCaught\u201d is small, strange and surprisingly inventive. The unexpectedness lies in a screenplay (by Dave Allsop and Alex Francis) that cares little for audience expectations, and a mood that shifts from tense to terrifying in the space of a single, unearthly sound.\n\nSet in 1972, in an English village on the edge of a moor, the movie follows Julie and Andrew (Mickey Sumner and Ruben Crow), married small-time journalists who notice suspicious military activity in the area and take photographs.
