For a movie that revolves around a notoriously violent sport, Michelle Walshe and Justin Pemberton\u2019s profile takes a soft, superficial approach. It makes a rote installment of ESPN\u2019s \u201c30 for 30\u201d look like Pulitzer-worthy muckraking.\n\nVideo\n\nAny player who has reached the top of the rugby world has clearly faced adversity, but \u201cChasing Great\u201d mostly hops from one triumph to another, reminding us that Mr. McCaw remained an ordinary guy despite his success. Judging from the film, the main setbacks he encountered were his team\u2019s crushing loss to France in the 2007 Rugby World Cup (the subject of national hand-wringing in New Zealand, but not an incident whose emotional impact travels) and playing with a broken foot during the World Cup in 2011. \u201cChasing Great\u201d makes that look easy.\n\nToo little time is spent on strategy, Mr. McCaw\u2019s style of captaining or his apparent skill for tiptoeing up to the edge of the rules. We do learn about his habit of writing notes to himself before a game (be \u201ccalm, clear and decisive,\u201d \u201cenjoy,\u201d \u201cjust play\u201d) and the pressure he felt to go out with a win. But even fans, the only conceivable audience here, already know how that turned out.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Chasing Great,\u2019 the Softer Side of Rugby", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg", "Justin Pemberton", "Michelle Walshe"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSince early in his career, the South Korean director Hong Sang-soo has told stories about the frustrated and frustrating love lives of movie people. They\u2019re mostly male, mostly screenwriters or directors, and they\u2019re mostly very heavy drinkers. Although they\u2019re more confused than is considered healthy even when they\u2019re sober. One thing about these characters is that you\u2019d never know they worked in movies if they didn\u2019t mention it in the dialogue. Mr. Hong\u2019s camera almost never depicts movie sets.\n\nVideo\n\nSo it stands to reason, then, that although \u201cClaire\u2019s Camera,\u201d the latest of Mr. Hong\u2019s films to open in New York, was shot in Cannes, a little beach town on the French Riviera known for hosting perhaps the most famous film festival in the world, there\u2019s nary a glimpse of ritz and glamour to be seen. Yes, the movie opens in a makeshift Korean film sales office, and on one of its doors hangs a poster for Mr. Hong\u2019s 2016 movie, \u201cYourself and Yours.\u201d But there\u2019s no red carpet, no paparazzi, and the beach the characters visit seems far from the cinema palaces of Cannes.\n\nThe relatively plain settings allow the filmmaker to do what he does best: focus on his characters, whose befuddlement is sometimes funny and sometimes troubling. In a maddeningly elliptical conversation at a caf\u00e9 table outside, a young assistant, Man-hee (Kim Min-hee, of the 2016 film \u201cThe Handmaiden\u201d), is fired by her boss, Yang-hye (Chang Mi-hee). As it happens, Man-hee had a one-night stand with the director So Wan-soo (Jung Jin-young), who is officially dating Yang-hye, albeit perhaps on the sly. \u201cNinety-five percent of the mistakes\u201d in his life, he muses, have been because of drinking.\n\nInto this awkward triangle walks Claire, a French schoolteacher with a blue Polaroid camera. The cinephile joke is that Claire, played by French cinema royalty Isabelle Huppert, has never been to the festival before. \u201cIf I take a photo of you, you are not the same person anymore,\u201d she tells So, as he gets increasingly drunk at lunch. It\u2019s possible that Claire\u2019s camera also alters the stream of time itself, as the story line introduces some elements of temporal dislocation while never shifting into an obvious sci-fi mode. In the meantime, the movie offers up pertinent and dispiriting observations on gender relations, particularly in one scene in which the loathsomely hypocritical So tries to dress down Man-hee for wearing what he considers too-revealing attire at a cocktail party. Ms. Huppert\u2019s presence \u2014 steady, warm, thoughtful but with a casual air \u2014 keeps the entire enterprise classically comedic.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Claire\u2019s Camera,\u2019 Isabelle Huppert Plays a Cannes Newbie", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Sang-Soo Hong"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nToo leaden for farce and too bland for satire, Lisa Addario and Joe Syracuse\u2019s \u201cDear Dictator\u201d wastes a potential gold mine of culture-clashing silliness on worn, high school movie clich\u00e9s.\n\nParalleling two revolutions \u2014 one social, the other political \u2014 the story makes unlikely allies of Tatiana (Odeya Rush), a misfit American teenager, and Gen. Anton Vincent (Michael Caine), a newly ousted Caribbean despot. Initially pen pals as a result of an innocent social-studies assignment, the two become unexpected roommates when a coup sends Anton fleeing to the suburban home where Tatiana lives with her vacuous single mother, Darlene (Katie Holmes). I wish I could say that wackiness ensues.\n\nVideo\n\nSettling in the garage, Anton busies himself making propaganda videos and tidying the garden. Between lectures on the evils of capitalism, he advises Tatiana on how best to overthrow her school\u2019s slutty queen bees. Darlene, for her part, is too impressed by their guest\u2019s plumbing skills and perfect mole to wonder if he\u2019s dangerous. Anyway, having your toes sucked daily by your married boss (a greasy Seth Green) leaves little time to fear for your life.\n\nSimultaneously preposterous and dull, \u201cDear Dictator\u201d is the kind of movie where music and wardrobe choices \u2014 like the mean girls\u2019 stridently visible underwear \u2014 substitute for character. Ms. Rush is believably disaffected but struggles to anchor a plot lousy with loose ends and lazily drawn relationships. As for Mr. Caine, never one to be fazed by the ludicrous, he plays Anton as less murderous tyrant than grandfatherly codger. If, that is, your grandfather just happens to be a whiz at waterboarding.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Dear Dictator,\u2019 a Despot Does Housework", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Lisa Addario", "Joe Syracuse"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn Wednesday, thousands of students walked out of their schools in a forceful protest calling for gun control. And on the stage at 59E59 Theaters, one high school kid, Mick, tried to burn a dollar-store American flag.\n\nIt\u2019s an art project, Mick (Wesley T. Jones) tells his principal. It protests censorship in schools and also, maybe, defends a woman\u2019s right to choose and supports Black Lives Matter and opposes mass incarceration and critiques big pharma and mourns the breakdown of the Democratic Party and rebukes the failing separation of church and state and shames the overuse of mayonnaise \u201con everything, including batter-dipped fried cheese.\u201d\n\nIf you haven\u2019t already guessed it, Brian Dykstra\u2019s \u201cEducation\u201d is not an especially focused work of theater. When you create a character who walks around with lighter fluid in his pocket, everything starts to look like tinder. What seems like a play about free speech becomes a play about family dynamics and repressive religion and budding artists and young love and probably some other stuff, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nMick is supported by his uncle Gordon (Matthew Boston), a liberally minded law professor, and Bekka (Jane West), Mick\u2019s sort of girlfriend, a performance poet with an explicit vocabulary. (Neither Mr. Jones nor Ms. West is particularly plausible as a high school student.) The principal, Mr. Kirks (Bruce Faulk), might be on his side, too. \u201cI miss that part of me. The part that believes in things,\u201d he says. So it can be hard to locate any actual conflicts. Bekka\u2019s Jesus-loving mom, Sandy (Elizabeth Meadows Rouse), is an overly broad target.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMostly these characters talk over and around each other, quibbling over semantics instead of articulating ideas. A lot of the dialogue is forgettable, placeholders enabling the next poem or rant. Honestly, the speech could be less free and less discursive. Several of the actors, directed by Margarett Perry, struggled with the lines. Only the delightful Mr. Boston, whose views seem close to the playwright\u2019s own, appeared to enjoy the language.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Education,\u2019 a Fictional Protest That Pales Next to Real Ones", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "To play the most vile (if not the most clich\u00e9d) residents of this heat-hammered hellhole, the writer and director, Ivan Sen, smartly hired two virtual legends. Over at the local pleasure palace, Cheng Pei Pei is squeezed into the much smaller role of town madam.\n\n\u201cThe world was not made for you,\u201d she admonishes one of her unhappy Chinese charges. \u201cYou were made for it.\u201d It\u2019s a sentiment that Jay Swan (Aaron Pedersen), a perpetually sozzled Aboriginal detective, can appreciate. Distrusted by whites and blacks alike, he exhibits all the tics and trappings of the alienated loner, including a ratty trailer and a mistrust of personal hygiene. His uneasy alliance with Josh (Alex Russell), a morally conflicted white police officer, is the movie\u2019s thematic heart. Yet its sociopolitical concerns \u2014 primarily around indigenous land rights \u2014 are muted and muddled by a script that favors manly grunting and moody looks over clarifying dialogue.\n\nRiven with racism and sharp bursts of violence, \u201cGoldstone\u201d nevertheless has a rough, desolate beauty. A 12-year-old with \u201cbig storms inside\u201d that she can only control by cutting herself. A mother who gets excruciating headaches whenever she thinks of her son. A pathological pack rat. A man haunted by his mother, a suicide. Another whose best friend is a hamster.\n\nOne of these is the therapist.\n\nThe others \u2014 and a few more besides \u2014 are the troubled patients seeking help at Northwood Mental Health Center, the fictional small-town facility \u201cnear the Berkshire Mountains\u201d in which David Rabe\u2019s \u201cGood for Otto\u201d is set. They and the staff are exhibits in the play\u2019s attempted argument about a system that has itself gone mad.\n\nNot that Dr. Robert Michaels \u2014 the one haunted by his mother \u2014 is to blame. As played by Ed Harris in the tedious New Group production that opened on Thursday at the Pershing Square Signature Center, he is a good guy out of a \u201950s melodrama, quixotically fighting the bean counters in hopes of helping his patients. If he errs, it is on the side of over-involvement; he suffers, too smugly, from a savior complex.\n\nHis colleague Evangeline Ryder (Amy Madigan) has better boundaries but might as well wear a sign proclaiming her a profound empath and active listener. Her patients include F. Murray Abraham, as a man who refuses to get out of bed, and Maulik Pancholy, as a man fresh out of the closet but no less lonely for it. Using insight-based therapeutic techniques that would not be unfamiliar to anyone who has ever taken an Intro Psych course, she cures one, if not the other.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Good for Otto,\u2019 a Case of Psychiatrist, Shrink Thyself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThis documentary about the photojournalist Chris Hondros is also a tribute, directed by his longtime friend, Greg Campbell, himself a journalist. After some harrowing video footage in which Mr. Hondros finishes a phone call while crouching for cover around the corner from a fire fight, the movie cuts to an archival interview with Mr. Hondros, who died in Libya in 2011. Likable and articulate, the photographer responds to a question about war photographers being \u201cthe craziest\u201d of journalists: \u201cThe problem with war photography is there\u2019s absolutely no way to do it from a distance. You have to be close.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nIn Iraq, Liberia, Libya and elsewhere, Mr. Hondros got very close, during conflicts in which old rules of engagement were eroding. The movie is at its best telling discrete stories of Mr. Hondros\u2019s excursions. In Tal Afar, Iraq, in 2005, American soldiers opened fire on a car approaching a checkpoint and wound up orphaning two Iraqi children whose continued stories the film tells. Mr. Hondros\u2019s pictures of the traumatized children are some of the most famed images from that war zone.\n\nThe filmmakers visit Samar Hassan, the little girl featured in the Hondros photograph from Tal Afar, now a teenager. She is eloquent in her rage at those responsible for her parents\u2019 death. The interview scene is impressive for that reason. But the movie has already claimed that Samar\u2019s brother Rakan was targeted and killed because of the exposure he received in Western media. It made this viewer a little queasy, then, to see the filmmakers bring Samar into their lens. If the movie doesn\u2019t go more than skin deep in interrogating questions about interventions both military and journalistic into the Middle East, it does succeed in opening up Mr. Hondros\u2019s contradiction-filled world.\n\nHondros Director Greg Campbell\n\nWriters Jenny Golden, Greg Campbell\n\nRunning Time 1h 26m\n\nGenres Documentary, Biography, War\n\nMovie data powered by IMDb.com\n\nLast updated: Mar 9, 2018", "title": "Review: In \u2018Hondros,\u2019 a Tribute to a Bold and Compassionate War Photographer", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Jenny Golden", "Greg Campbell"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThis is a landmark motion picture \u2014 a movie about people living with autism in which all of the characters who have autism are portrayed by nonprofessional performers who also have it. The problem with thirtysomething David (Brandon Polansky) is that he doesn\u2019t think he has a condition of any kind. His occasional anxious fits of wheezing he puts down to allergies, and he\u2019s not at all self-conscious about the staggeringly offensive jokes he tells at the wrong time to the wrong people. A pig joke told to a cop has gotten him arrested and sentenced to spend time with a support group of other people with autism. He\u2019s at first completely contemptuous.\n\nVideo\n\nHe\u2019s particularly annoyed by Sarah (Samantha Elisofon), with whom he is given a homework assignment that obliges them to visit the Brooklyn Bridge together. Sarah has a winning and nearly constant smile and a startling openness. The film, written and directed by Rachel Israel, respects these characters by portraying their whole, unfiltered selves.\n\nIn many respects the romance that develops between David and Sarah is like a conventional one. There\u2019s even an \u201cit\u2019s not you, it\u2019s me\u201d conversation. The movie grows more moving as David gets real with himself about his own loneliness, and his rich parents\u2019 bigotry and denial. (The parents are played by the veteran actors Jessica Walter and Tibor Feldman, and they work well with Mr. Polansky and Ms. Elisofon.) \u201cKeep the Change\u201d is not a seamlessly crafted movie, but it\u2019s awfully tenderhearted and thoroughly disarming. It deserves to be widely seen.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Keep the Change,\u2019 Two People With Autism Find Love", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Rachel Israel"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn the basis of \u201cLeaning Into the Wind,\u201d when it rains, the British artist Andy Goldsworthy immediately drops to the ground and lets the water outline his body. He describes two ways of approaching the world: \u201cYou can walk on the path, or you can walk through the hedge.\u201d It\u2019s almost a given that this documentary about his ephemeral, nature-based art will eventually show him trudging through a hedge, oblivious to or uninterested in the perfectly functional sidewalk next to it.\n\n\u201cLeaning Into the Wind\u201d is a de facto sequel to \u201cRivers and Tides\u201d (2003), by the same director, Thomas Riedelsheimer. Because time erases or alters Mr. Goldsworthy\u2019s sculptures, movies are the ideal medium to capture them (although with the sequel, the switch from 35-millimeter film to digital cinematography has removed some of the artisanal quality).\n\nVideo\n\nThe surprise of \u201cLeaning Into the Wind\u201d is that it\u2019s just as concerned with how time has changed Mr. Goldsworthy. His grown daughter Holly now assists him with projects, including one in which they capture the hoof prints of sheep. Mr. Goldsworthy explains the evolution of his views on cities, and his desire to locate the nature beneath them. (Cut to San Francisco, with its wildly uneven sidewalks.)\n\nThe title comes from a kind of performance piece in which the artist leans into extremely high cliff winds and doesn\u2019t fall. There\u2019s no warning not to try this at home \u2014 which is regrettable, given how many viewers the movie seems poised to captivate with Mr. Goldsworthy\u2019s worldview.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Leaning Into the Wind \u2014 Andy Goldsworthy,\u2019 an Artist Grapples (Again) With Time", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor anyone who has recently lost a spouse or parent, \u201cLove After Love\u201d may be almost impossible to watch. Others, though, are unlikely to fare much better, given that this unflinching debut feature from Russ Harbaugh delivers something rarely seen in American movies: a warts-and-all examination of extended grief.\n\nArranged in discrete, scrapbook-like scenes, the narrative (loosely based on Mr. Harbaugh\u2019s own family experiences) comes at mourning only obliquely. At the center is Suzanne (a remarkable Andie MacDowell), who watches her husband die, painfully and exhaustingly, at home, attended by their two sons, Nicholas (Chris O\u2019Dowd) and Chris (James Adomian).\n\nVideo\n\nThose early scenes are harrowing enough, depicting the draining physical labor of caring for someone who\u2019s terminally ill. What comes after, though, is more subtly distressing as pain manifests, not in weepy conversations, but in behavior that \u2014 at least as far as the sons are concerned \u2014 seems an exaggeration of tendencies already in place. So while Suzanne drifts uneasily into new relationships, Nicholas swaps partners and Chris dives into a bottle.\n\nOn paper, this doesn\u2019t sound like much. But Mr. Harbaugh and his cast (all of whom shine, but Mr. O\u2019Dowd is revelatory) have created a wary, chilly drama that refuses to shy away from ugliness \u2014 or from Nicholas and Suzanne\u2019s sometimes uncomfortably jagged intimacy. Elegantly shot on film by Chris Teague, the movie feels unforced and at times shockingly authentic, allowing its emotions to percolate and rise of their own volition. In one dreamy, wordless scene, Suzanne wanders alone into a crowded dance party, her bewilderment that of a woman who\u2019s no longer sure of her place \u2014 either in that room, or in the world.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Love After Love,\u2019 an Unflinching Look at Extended Grief", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor the most part, \u201cLove, Simon\u201d is an amiable, slick, silver-tongued teen romantic comedy. Set in a particularly idyllic Atlanta suburb, replete with lifestyle wish-fulfillment production design, it\u2019s the kind of movie in which the filmmakers signal their exquisite taste by proxy. (Said filmmakers are the director Greg Berlanti and the screenwriters Elizabeth Berger and Isaac Aptaker, adapting a novel by Becky Albertalli.) For instance, when Simon, the lead character, needs to choose an email address from which to send a series of love letters to an anonymous subject, he adapts a lyric from the Kinks\u2019 classic album \u201cSomething Else by the Kinks.\u201d Which Simon enjoys on vinyl, of course.\n\nVideo\n\nThe reason for the anonymity is that the high schooler Simon is, like his correspondent, gay. He hasn\u2019t come out largely because he\u2019s not sure how to go about doing so, and his continuing reluctance gets him enmeshed with a thoroughly obnoxious weasel of a blackmailer. The blackmailer\u2019s aim is simple: He wants to gain a romantic advantage with one of Simon\u2019s female friends, and while Simon is in a sense too smart for this nonsense, he reluctantly complies.\n\nIn the movie\u2019s last third it gains a lot of guts. Simon has to contend with the fallout from what he considered a necessary hypocrisy and the personal betrayals it entailed. The emotional resonance may be surprising given the movie\u2019s relentless gloss, but it\u2019s real. The spectacularly charming cast, led by the young Nick Robinson in the title role (who brings a knowing touch of 1980s Matthew Broderick to some of his line readings), puts it all across, including a genuinely crowd-pleasing ending.\n\nLove, Simon Director Greg Berlanti\n\nWriters Elizabeth Berger, Isaac Aptaker\n\nStars Nick Robinson, Jennifer Garner, Josh Duhamel, Katherine Langford, Alexandra Shipp\n\nRating PG-13\n\nRunning Time 1h 49m\n\nGenres Comedy, Drama, Romance\n\nMovie data powered by IMDb.com\n\nLast updated: Apr 15, 2018", "title": "Review: In \u2018Love, Simon,\u2019 a Glossy Teen Romance, the Hero Has a Secret", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Elizabeth Berger", "Isaac Aptaker"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Because of her condition, Katie is isolated from her peers, spending most of her time with her adoring father (Rob Riggle), who tries to keep his daughter\u2019s confinement cozy. Though neither Katie nor \u201cMidnight Sun\u201d seems disturbed by the paternalism of her circumstances, most fairy tales revolve around a prince, not a parent, and, accordingly, both Katie and the film idealize romance.\n\nSo, from the safety of her ultraviolet-light-resistant bedroom window, Katie daydreams about puppy love as if she were a princess in a tower. Every day, she waits for the same boy, Charlie (Patrick Schwarzenegger, son of Arnold), to roll by on his skateboard. When this saint of the Seattle suburbs stumbles upon Katie busking near the local train station one evening, he falls in love at first sight. They begin to see each other only at night, and Katie conceals her illness, despite her father\u2019s warnings. Like the sun, the potential for disaster inevitably rises.\n\nUnder the limp direction of Scott Speer, \u201cMidnight Sun\u201d suffocates its sentimental script, portraying passion without wonder, sacrifice without ecstasy. Charlie professes his devotion with a plastered smile and dead eyes. Katie writes love songs that are forgotten the moment she stops singing. Lacking both the romantic chemistry and the directorial panache that might justify its life-or-death stakes, \u201cMidnight Sun\u201d is a medical melodrama in need of resuscitation.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Midnight Sun,\u2019 the Dawn of Romance Can Be Fatal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The name PS122 has been the subject of discussion lately in the world of contemporary performance. In January, the organization known since 1980 as Performance Space 122, housed in a former public school building in the East Village, announced that it would now be called Performance Space New York. The change, timed to the building\u2019s reopening after a renovation, caused an outcry among those who saw it as a generic rebranding, an erasure of the institution\u2019s colorful history as a home for experimental live art.\n\nLess discussion has surrounded the other, less public-facing PS122: Painting Space 122, a center for visual artists that has been a tenant in the building since 1978. It\u2019s Painting Space that turns out to be the subject \u2014 at least the most visible one \u2014 of \u201cP.S. 122,\u201d a work by the artist Yve Laris Cohen that had its premiere on Thursday in the larger of Performance Space\u2019s two new theaters.\n\nMr. Laris Cohen\u2019s work often deals with the infrastructure \u2014 architectural and institutional \u2014 behind the production of dance, theater and visual art. In 2015 at Danspace Project, he installed and uninstalled a portable dance floor used by New York City Ballet on tour. In 2014, he shuttled a slab of white wall from the old Whitney Museum into the new, unfinished one, bringing an audience with him. It may not be dance in any conventional sense, but Mr. Laris Cohen, who has a background in ballet, arranges materials and events with an exacting choreographic eye.\n\nIn \u201cP.S. 122,\u201d part of Performance Space\u2019s East Village Series, he has covered the floor of the 3,600-square-foot theater in blank canvas, setting the stage for a conversation between painting and performance: a medium that yields tangible, purchasable objects and one defined by fleetingness. As the audience entered on Thursday, several artists were stationed at canvases around the room, and for an hour, to the roar of heavy metal played by the band Dither, we watched them work, engaged in activities much more placid than the music.", "title": "Review: In \u2018P.S. 122,\u2019 Watching the Painters Paint and Scrape", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "As sequels to sci-fi action thrillers showcasing giant metallic fighters go, \u201cPacific Rim Uprising\u201d is adroit and enjoyable. John Boyega, who\u2019s also a regular in the new \u201cStar Wars\u201d pictures, stars as Jake Pentecost, the decidedly more roguish son of Idris Elba\u2019s character from 2013\u2019s \u201cPacific Rim.\u201d He steals parts from scrapped Jaegers \u2014 the gigantic human-piloted machines that battled hordes of Kaiju (giant monsters, that is) in the first film. Early in the movie he meets a whiz-kid Jaeger bootlegger named Amara (Cailee Spaeny) and they both end up back in pilot school.\n\nWith the world supposedly free from Kaiju threat, the movie spends its first hour toggling between \u201cTop Gun\u201d-style cadet rivalries and a corporate espionage plot that\u2019s not unfamiliar, except that you almost never see it done well in this kind of movie. But you know that the scaly, slimy creatures are going to turn up eventually, and when they do, they spend a good amount of time in Tokyo.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Pacific Rim Uprising,\u2019 Scary Monsters and Super Robots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRamen Heads\u201d has all the thrills of a corporate training video, with about as much humor, too. Over-narrated and self-serious, this documentary allows its good intentions to pave the way to a tepid tale.\n\nCentering on Osamu Tomita, who runs one of Japan\u2019s most-praised ramen restaurants, the film follows him and a few other chefs as they mix broth, cook noodles and greet customers. We\u2019re told that making and eating ramen can be a quasi-religious experience. Slow-motion footage, instrumental music and loving close-ups of ingredients do all they can to drive that point home.\n\nWhat the film lacks, though, is a strong reason to watch. Unlike the obsession witnessed in \u201cJiro Dreams of Sushi\u201d or the drollness of \u201cThe Search for General Tso,\u201d \u201cRamen Heads\u201d usually forgoes a driving theme or story line. Other than late scenes charting Mr. Tomita\u2019s plans for his shop\u2019s 10th anniversary celebration, food preparation is the overwhelming motif, leading to myriad shots of boiling pots and steaming meals.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Ramen Heads,\u2019 a Noodle Chef Gets Tangled Up in His Job", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "In the film, set in 2045, Wade Watts (a young man played by the agreeably bland, blandly agreeable Tye Sheridan) lives in \u201cthe stacks,\u201d a vertical pile of trailers where the poorer residents of Columbus, Ohio (Oklahoma City in the book), cling to hope, dignity and their VR gloves. Humanity has been ravaged by the usual political and ecological disasters (among them \u201cbandwidth riots\u201d referred to in Wade\u2019s introductory voice-over), and most people seek refuge in a digital paradise called the Oasis.\n\nThat world \u2014 less a game than a Jorge Luis Borges cosmos populated by wizards, robots and racecar drivers \u2014 is the creation of James Halliday (Mark Rylance). After Halliday\u2019s death, his avatar revealed the existence of a series of Easter eggs, or secret digital treasures, the discovery of which would win a lucky player control of the Oasis. Wade is a \u201cgunter\u201d \u2014 short for \u201cegg hunter\u201d \u2014 determined to pursue this quest even after most of the other gamers have tired of it. Among his rivals are a few fellow believers and Nolan Sorrento (Ben Mendelsohn), the head of a company called IOI that wants to bring Halliday\u2019s paradise under corporate control.\n\nIn the real world, IOI encourages Oasis fans to run up debts that it collects by forcing them into indentured servitude. Sorrento\u2019s villainy sets up a battle on two fronts \u2014 clashes in the Oasis mirroring chases through the streets of Columbus \u2014 that inspires Mr. Spielberg to feats of crosscutting virtuosity. The action is so swift and engaging that some possibly literal-minded questions may be brushed aside. I, for one, didn\u2019t quite understand why, given the global reach of the Oasis, all the relevant players were so conveniently clustered in Ohio. (If anyone wants to explain, please find me on Twitter so I can mute you.)\n\nBut, of course, Columbus and the Oasis do not represent actual or virtual realities, but rather two different modalities of fantasy. Wade\u2019s avatar, Parzival, collects a posse of fighters: Sho, Daito, Aech and Art3mis, who is also his love interest. When the people attached to these identities meet up in Columbus, they are not exactly as they are in the game. Aech, large and male in the Oasis, is played by Lena Waithe. But the fluidity of online identity remains an underexploited possibility. In and out of the Oasis, Art3mis (also known as Samantha, and portrayed by Olivia Cooke) is a male fantasy of female badassery. Sho (Philip Zhao) and Daito (Win Morisaki) are relegated to sidekick duty. The multiplayer, self-inventing ethos of gaming might have offered a chance for a less conventional division of heroic labor, but the writers and filmmakers lacked the imagination to take advantage of it.\n\nThe most fun part of \u201cReady Player One\u201d is its exuberant and generous handing out of pop-cultural goodies. Tribute is paid to Mr. Spielberg\u2019s departed colleagues John Hughes and Stanley Kubrick. The visual and musical allusions are eclectic enough that nobody is likely to feel left out, and everybody is likely to feel a little lost from time to time.\n\nNostalgia? Sure, but what really animates the movie is a sense of history. The Easter egg hunt takes Parzival and his crew back into Halliday\u2019s biography \u2014 his ill-starred partnership with Ogden Morrow (Simon Pegg), his thwarted attempts at romance \u2014 and also through the evolution of video games and related pursuits. The history is instructive and also sentimental in familiar ways, positing a struggle for control between idealistic, artistic entrepreneurs (and their legions of fans) and soulless corporate greedheads.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHalliday is a sweet, shaggy nerd with a guileless Northern California drawl and a deeply awkward manner, especially around women. Sorrento is an autocratic bean counter, a would-be master of the universe who doesn\u2019t even like video games. These characters are clich\u00e9s, but they are also allegorical figures.\n\nIn the movie, they represent opposing principles, but in our world, they are pretty much the same guy. A lot of the starry-eyed do-it-yourselfers tinkering in their garages and giving life to their boyish dreams back in the \u201970s and \u201980s turned out to be harboring superman fantasies of global domination all along. They shared their wondrous creations and played the rest of us for suckers, collecting our admiration, our attention and our data as profit and feudal tribute.\n\nMr. Spielberg incarnates this duality as perfectly as any man alive. He is the peer of Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, and a Gandalf for the elves and hobbits who made Google, Facebook and the other components of our present-day Oasis. He has been man-child and mogul, wide-eyed artist and cold-eyed businessman, praised for making so many wonderful things and blamed for ruining everything. His career has been a splendid enactment of the cultural contradictions of capitalism, and at the same time a series of deeply personal meditations on love, loss and imagination. All of that is also true of Halliday\u2019s Oasis. \u201cReady Player One\u201d is far from a masterpiece, but as the fanboys say, it\u2019s canon.", "title": "Review: Spielberg\u2019s \u2018Ready Player One\u2019 Plays the Nostalgia Game", "authors": ["A. O. Scott", "Zak Penn", "Ernest Cline"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYour love is going away like water in the fingers,\u201d complains Renato (Ricardo Herrera) to his lover, Ivan (Pablo Sotomayor Prat), near the beginning of \u201cShining Moon\u201d (\u201cEl Destello de la Luna\u201d), the new film from the Chilean director Gustavo Letelier. Though both are underemployed actors, Renato is clearly the more theatrical of the two: Fond of declamatory monologues and carefully calibrated gestures, he\u2019s a man who seeks the light as instinctively as any newly liberated soul.\n\nWith passions dwindling and careers stalled, the men gratefully accept lead roles in a film about Lola and Ana, a pair of aging cross-dressers and former drag artists. Renato, however, finds the characters grotesque; and as he works to overcome his prejudices \u2014 mainly through speechifying and pensive stares \u2014 Mr. Letelier (who wrote the story with Victoria Wharfe McIntyre) takes direct aim at his country\u2019s repressive and homophobic history. In the film-within-the-film, effigies of fascist, religious and Communist leaders hang on Lola and Ana\u2019s wall, silent reminders of violence and fear.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Shining Moon,\u2019 Two Gay Chilean Actors Confront the Past", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe director Roland Joff\u00e9 (who made \u201cThe Killing Fields,\u201d about Pol Pot\u2019s slaughter in Cambodia, and \u201cThe Mission,\u201d a tale of 18th-century colonialism with pronounced allegorical accents) is not known for a light touch. Here, adapting a play by Michael Ashton, he makes South Africa\u2019s Truth and Reconciliation Commission of the 1990s his subject, and \u201cThe Forgiven\u201d is heavy-handed from its early texts explaining apartheid through its end credits.\n\nMr. Ashton\u2019s scenario, on which Mr. Joff\u00e9 collaborated for the screenplay, pits the real-life figure Archbishop Desmond Tutu (Forest Whitaker) against a fictional composite, Piet Blomfeld (Eric Bana), an unrepentant one-time death squad member and now a prison lifer. Blomfeld taunts Tutu, quoting Milton at him (the \u201cBetter to reign in hell\u201d line, what else), while the archbishop holds that \u201cno one is beyond redemption.\u201d As it happens, Blomfeld holds the key to an atrocity mystery that the commission is investigating.\n\nVideo\n\nThe character notes here are beyond obvious \u2014 it\u2019s not long into the picture before the archbishop\u2019s wife affectionately refers to her spouse as an \u201cold goat.\u201d But Mr. Whitaker does an extraordinary job not just of impersonation (he has the clergyman\u2019s infectious laugh down pat), but also of showing the way the character thinks. The talented Mr. Bana returns to the brutish-but-bright mode of his 2001 breakthrough film \u201cChopper.\u201d When the movie can stay out of its own way, it delivers some powerful scenes, including one in which Blomfeld faces down a would-be assassin (Nandiphile Mbeshu, superb) in a prison shower room. But beyond that, the movie offers conventional gratifications and no surprises.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Forgiven,\u2019 Forest Whitaker as Archbishop Desmond Tutu", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Michael Ashton", "Roland Joff\u00e9"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn camera, talking about the time her husband tried to kill her, first with a hibachi knife and then with a Glock, Dee Crosby is the picture of professional composure. A boxing champ, she knows her way around an interview.\n\n\u201cSo what did you do to fight back?\u201d the reporter asks, and this is the question that finally flusters Dee. \u201cI know you didn\u2019t go down without a fight.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Theater Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest news, interviews and reviews from Broadway and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t go down,\u201d Dee says. \u201cI\u2019m here.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Wholehearted,\u201d a multimedia, almost-solo play by Stein/Holum Projects, unfolds in the grubby back room of a gym where Dee is hiding for the night. Charlie, her husband and trainer, is getting out of prison and heading home. With a gun of her own, Dee is preparing to seek revenge. Then, if all goes well, she\u2019ll drive cross-country to California and restart the life she left behind more than 20 years earlier.\n\nWritten by Deborah Stein, performed by Suli Holum and directed by both of them, \u201cThe Wholehearted\u201d is a fast-jabbing fantasy where sweaty physicality rubs up against shape-shifting surreality, with a little country music thrown in. (The composers are James Sugg and Heather Christian.) In the playhouse at Abrons Arts Center, the audience sits onstage, surrounding Amy Rubin\u2019s set on all four sides, like spectators at a boxing match \u2014 close enough to spy, on Dee\u2019s body, the scars Charlie left there.\n\nDee smashes away at the punching bag in the corner, or fights the air as she relives a match in her head, and we see video (designed by Katherine Freer and Dave Tennent) on big overhead screens: some footage prerecorded, some shot live (by Stivo Arnoczy) and some brilliantly intercutting the two, blending past glory with present determination. Other times, Dee records herself on video, speaking to Carmen, her long-lost sweetheart \u2014 the girl she jilted for Charlie all those years ago. Ms. Holum also plays Carmen, and when we meet Charlie, Ms. Holum slicks back her hair and becomes him, too.\n\nShe gives a clear and lithe performance, and the production design is excellent. But the show as a whole feels skimpy and incomplete, touching too briefly on too many charged elements and allowing too little space for Ms. Holum\u2019s winsome humor to break through. For all the kinetic energy of the staging, the story seems stalled \u2014 like Dee with her revenge, on the verge of action but not taking it just yet.", "title": "Review: In \u2018The Wholehearted,\u2019 Old Wounds Feel Angry and New", "authors": ["Laura Collins-Hughes"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "An opening quotation from H.P. Lovecraft signals that explanations won\u2019t be forthcoming. Keith (William Jackson Harper) and Jessica (Rebecca Henderson) have been sent by their company to a remote pocket of woodland on some sort of biological study, but the animals are acting strangely. The location was also the site of a massacre by a cult that sounds like a cross between the Peoples Temple and the Manson family.\n\nInevitably, the surveillance cameras will malfunction, stories of troubled past teams will be shared and strange voices and hallucinations will enter the picture. (There are too many only-a-dream fakeouts.) \u201cThey Remain\u201d is less interesting for its familiar ideas than its lo-fi craft. Mr. Gelatt uses negative space to emphasize Jessica and Keith\u2019s isolation from each other and plays games with perspective, inviting speculation about Jessica\u2019s offscreen actions.\n\nProductive ambiguity can tip into unrealized potential, and \u201cThey Remain\u201d ultimately leans too heavily on vagueness as a crutch. But an unsatisfying ending isn\u2019t the end of the world.", "title": "Review: In \u2018They Remain,\u2019 Scientists Investigate the Site of a Cult Massacre", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOver the last 40 years, the writer-performer John Kelly has explored the life and work of several wondrous real-life artists, both in raucous East Village clubs and in such temples of high art as Lincoln Center or the Brooklyn Academy of Music. There were the cross-dressing trapezist Barbette (\u201cLight Shall Lift Them\u201d) and the painter Egon Schiele (\u201cPass the Blutwurst, Bitte\u201d). Mr. Kelly has channeled Joni Mitchell on a regular basis, and she was the subject of his evening-length piece \u201cPaved Paradise.\u201d As for the grand diva Dagmar Onassis, this renegade daughter of Maria Callas and Aristotle Onassis was fictional but deserved to be real.\n\nIf the protean Mr. Kelly has had one recurring theme through the years, it is the shaping of the self through art. In his new show at La MaMa, \u201cTime No Line,\u201d the subject is himself \u2014 but then, hasn\u2019t it always been, even when refracted through the creations of others?\n\n\u201cTime No Line,\u201d which Mr. Kelly describes as a \u201clive memoir,\u201d draws from the diary he has been keeping since 1976. The narrative alternates between first and third person, with Mr. Kelly occasionally referring to himself as \u201cthe artist,\u201d as if he were looking at his own past from a cool, outside standpoint. But as quiet as it is, this visually elegant show is anything but dispassionate.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe story begins in 1971, when Mr. Kelly, then \u201ca young man from New Jersey,\u201d saw the gender-bending troupe the Cockettes in New York. \u201cThis encounter shifted his perspective and sense of possibility,\u201d a slide informs us. \u201cHis creative life had begun.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Kelly trained in dance but eventually realized he had taken it up too late to be good enough, so he switched gears and attended art school in his early 20s. Both trainings are evident in the poise of his movement and in the projected diary excerpts, adorned with sketches and illustrations. The performer also gradually covers the stage in chalk drawings, which he executes with a dancer\u2019s fluid grace.", "title": "Review: In \u2018Time No Line,\u2019 John Kelly Revisits Decades of Diary Entries", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSteven Soderbergh\u2019s new movie, \u201cUnsane,\u201d is an effectively nasty, sometimes funny, sometimes grindingly unpleasant thriller about a woman who is involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital. From one angle, it plays like an old-school exploitation flick, one of those damsel-in-distress freakouts in which an intrepid heroine faces down danger in a skin-baring top. This being Mr. Soderbergh, peril isn\u2019t sloppily served up with flat line readings, jiggling breasts and lousy cinematography but delivered with slyness and jolts.\n\nSawyer \u2014 an excellent, febrile Claire Foy, best known for playing Queen Elizabeth II on the Netflix series \u201cThe Crown\u201d \u2014 is a new arrival in a generic city. She doesn\u2019t say much about herself, but Mr. Soderbergh, a fast, efficient worker, fills in Sawyer\u2019s life with quick, grim strokes \u2014 a dire cubicle, nosy co-workers, a predatory boss \u2014 and then he lets her out to play. This proves bleaker still. She hooks up with a stranger but when they end up in her apartment she flees to her bathroom. The prescription pills in her cabinet suggest there\u2019s a reason she has fled, and a dark back story emerges piecemeal.\n\nSawyer goes to a hospital to speak with a counselor, revealing that she was a victim of stalking before relocating. This earnest confession leads to her being locked up \u2014 ostensibly because she\u2019s a suicide risk \u2014 at first for 24 hours. Bad choices and violent encounters extend her stay, which grows progressively more frightening. The chick in the next bed, Violet (Juno Temple, persuasively feral), keeps harassing Sawyer, though Sawyer is given a friendly welcome by another inmate, Nate (a sympathetic, egregiously badly lighted Jay Pharoah). Then one day while lining up for her meds, Sawyer meets David (a terrific, utterly creepy Joshua Leonard), whom she claims is her stalker.\n\nVideo\n\nWritten by James Greer and Jonathan Bernstein, the movie plays out as an extended game of cat-and-mouse. Despite some teasing it\u2019s obvious who\u2019s who and what\u2019s what; but if the story holds next to no surprises, it does unload some brutally ugly shocks. Mostly, Sawyer insists that she doesn\u2019t belong in the hospital but doesn\u2019t help her case \u2014 she makes one mistake and then another, and consistently refuses to play the good girl \u2014 which prolongs her incarceration and torment. It\u2019s easy to get how rotten she feels, especially given that Mr. Soderbergh keeps pushing his camera into Ms. Foy\u2019s face.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Soderbergh shot \u201cUnsane\u201d primarily on iPhones using additional lenses, including a fish-eye. (He shot it using the name Peter Andrews, which are his father\u2019s first two names; he also edited it, borrowing his mother\u2019s maiden name, Mary Ann Bernard.) Big budget or on the cheap, like here, he is a great shooter and he plays with perspective inventively, distorting the edges of the image so they bulge out, a warping that dovetails with Sawyer\u2019s disturbed, disturbing world. At times, the distortion skews bluntly comic as when, after she\u2019s committed, Sawyer sits at a table partly obscured by an absurdly large coffee mug that looms in the frame like a threat (or a wee monolith).", "title": "Review: In \u2018Unsane,\u2019 It\u2019s Not Paranoia if Someone\u2019s After You", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Jonathan Bernstein", "James Greer"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The \u201cwe\u201d in \u201cWhat We Started\u201d are the demigods of electronic dance music \u2014 the people who liked EDM before EDM was cool. In this documentary, directed by Bert Marcus and Cyrus Saidi, they gush about the genre\u2019s milestones and metaphorically high-five one another while trying not to bore the uninitiated into a drugless stupor.\n\nThat\u2019s a tricky balancing act. \u201cWhat We Started\u201d appears to have been conceived with contradictory audiences in mind. On one hand, it tries to present an accessible history of electronic music, starting with its outgrowth from disco, house and techno and continuing through its commercialization and fusion with pop. On the other hand, a subcultural cliquishness creeps into the movie. If you already know all these names and have bought your tickets to Ultra Music Festival, for which \u201cWhat We Started\u201d could double as a promotion, dig in.", "title": "Review: In \u2018What We Started,\u2019 the Back Story Behind the Backbeat", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The women are hilariously wary of the United States, of one another and especially of Renia, who won\u2019t share her story. Still, the movement of the first act is from mistrust and recrimination to solidarity. When the roommates change into clubbing clothes to toast Isabela with whatever sad staples they can scrounge, the lamest farewell party ever becomes, briefly, one of the most joyous.\n\nPlaying both ends of the scale like that is a distinctive trick Ms. Majok uses to release emotion without sentimentality. These women are tough, and not in a glamorous way: Their expectation of mistreatment is no pose and no metaphor. They are angry at the world yet nurture that anger, recognizing that in it may be the beginning of progress. Certainly there is no progress without it.\n\nThis makes for thrilling writing. But as the play further complicates its story in the second and third acts, it loses control of its effects. We are offered too much information for the frame to contain, even if it\u2019s vital: How Inna got from Ukraine to Queens after a six-month stop as a potential internet bride in Florida; what brought Renia to the basement and how she becomes its landlady. New characters come and go as well, their identities and stories blurred because they are played by the same actors who played the previous ones. After seeing \u201cqueens\u201d and reading the script carefully I was still confused by many plot points.\n\nConfusion can be salient, of course, in plays about confusion, whether moral or existential. But \u201cqueens\u201d isn\u2019t squishy that way, so its confusion is subtractive. It may in fact be the result of cutting to keep the production under three hours. (The timing of the acts is lopsided.)\n\nIf so, I think Ms. Majok would have done better to expand her scope rather than contract it. The material is so important, so ripe and so multi-stranded that it might have been better off as a marathon or a mini-series. Squeezed into its current shape it can do little more than check the boxes on its trenchant to-do list.\n\nThis puts excess pressure on the production to provide coherence, but Danya Taymor\u2019s direction opts for suggestiveness rather than clarity. The powerful set design by Laura Jellinek \u2014 dominated by a vast ceiling that lowers and lifts over the stage to create feelings of containment and freedom \u2014 is more successful in sculpting moods than in defining space or telling the story. (You are never sure where the doors to this basement are.) Action specified in the script is not always clear onstage: a problem of focus. And the fine performances, especially by Ms. Reeder and Ms. Tolan-Mee, dissipate under the excessive dramatic pressure.\n\nFor all that, \u201cqueens\u201d is still a notable work, or maybe several. It strikes at the heart of the immigrant experience, which is often unfair, one way or another. \u201cYou? Are lucky,\u201d Renia tells one of the women. \u201cWhich means that maybe other people: not so much.\u201d\n\nWelcome to America.", "title": "Review: In \u2018queens,\u2019 11 Immigrant Women and What They Left Behind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Near the outset, the harpsichordist Steven Beck gave a vivid account of Ligeti\u2019s compact, crazily dense \u201cContinuum.\u201d But it took about half an hour for the full ensemble to play a long-form piece by the composer: the five-movement 1988 Piano Concerto.\n\nThis performance was a marvel. In the first movement, Mr. Pierson made sure players articulated each madcap twist of rhythm not just with precision, but with a sense of glee. The way the bass and trombone savored droning tones in the second movement served as a reminder of what this group has learned from engaging with the Minimalist aesthetic. The soloist, John Orfe, sounded magnificent throughout, whether pummeling or delicately shaping Ligeti\u2019s emotionally varied piano motifs.\n\nPhoto\n\nAll told, this made for approximately 25 minutes of the best live music I\u2019ve heard so far this year. Which raises the question: Did it really need so much setup?\n\nMost of the preplanned banter between Ms. Sirota and Mr. Pierson came off smoothly enough. And the sound effects that rolled underneath the narrative material were all tasteful \u2014 an important hurdle to clear, given that the topics included concentration camps, where some of Ligeti\u2019s family members were killed. (He narrowly eluded the same fate.)\n\nYet when Mr. Pierson led the group in a brief excerpt of music, referred to during some radio-play aside, I often found that I wanted to hear more of each piece. Why not play all of Karlheinz Stockhausen\u2019s \u201cKontra-Punkte\u201d? Or more of Charlie Chaplin\u2019s score to \u201cModern Times\u201d (in the arrangement by Courtney Orlando)? The answer, presumably, is that then you\u2019d only have time for a regular concert.\n\nClassical performers and venues are well advised to be rethinking inherited strictures of the recital hall. Monastic seriousness isn\u2019t the only way to take in a show. Lowering anxieties about what to wear and when to clap is all to the good. (There was some scattered, justly earned applause before Alarm Will Sound presented the final movement of Ligeti\u2019s Chamber Concerto for 13 Instruments, which closed the concert. No one went mad.)\n\nBut neither is innovation where all the excitement is. The most persuasive advocacy on Friday night occurred when these players channeled their evident desire to connect into performances of notes on the page.", "title": "Review: Ligeti Sounded Thrilling, When Alarm Will Sound Was Let Loose", "authors": ["Seth Colter Walls"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The film\u2019s writer and director, Amber Sealey, hews close to Lexi, but the camera rarely takes up Lexi\u2019s perspective, preferring to observe her behavior rather than trying to see through her eyes. A result of this visual flatness is that some sequences drag with clich\u00e9s, as the camera dithers on hackneyed images like Lexi flushing her wedding ring down the motel sink.\n\nBut in the scenes that break with banality, there is a zing not only of originality, but of daring. The film\u2019s most memorable sequence is a sex scene in which Lexi acts out a prostitution fantasy, inviting a man to her room only to be shocked when her conquest brings a friend without asking for her permission. As Lexi maneuvers the two men, seeking ways to regain the control that was taken from her, Ms. Sealey navigates power through nudity, physically and psychologically exposing her male subjects while allowing her female protagonist to remain an enigma. In a film of mostly mixed merits, such mysterious highs sustain the mundane lows.", "title": "Review: Los Angeles Through a Stranger\u2019s Eyes in \u2018No Light and No Land Anywhere\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThoroughbreds\u201d opens on an ominous, murkily lit scene \u2014 a girl, a horse and a worryingly sharp knife \u2014 that telegraphs just how ugly things are going to get in this movie. You learn in short order that the horse is a goner, and it isn\u2019t long into this slick, shallow movie that you wish the girl, Amanda (Olivia Cooke), was, too. This is no fault of Ms. Cooke, an appealing performer (she was the girl in \u201cMe and Earl and the Dying Girl\u201d). She and her equally likable co-star, Anya Taylor-Joy (\u201cThe Witch\u201d), have been burdened with giving their matching ciphers flesh and a reason for us to watch.\n\nVideo\n\nMs. Taylor-Joy plays Lily, a wealthy teenager who is tutoring Amanda when the story begins. Amanda, who\u2019s more middle-class comfortable, knows that Lily is getting paid for her attention, which doesn\u2019t stop the girls from curiously circling each other. They were once friends and soon ease into a new, unpersuasive intimacy (they watch Shirley Temple on TV), largely so the writer-director Cory Finley can make them combust. What happens next is pretty much what you would expect from peewee nihilists (\u201cHeathers\u201d) adrift in a bourgeois hellscape of quiet dinners and symmetrical visuals (\u201cAmerican Beauty\u201d).\n\nMaking his feature directing debut, Mr. Finley gives the movie a professional sheen and gets fine performances from his actors, including Anton Yelchin as a sad sack with a bull\u2019s-eye where his brains should be, and Paul Sparks as Lily\u2019s chilled-to-the-bone stepfather. Nothing these two characters do or say is surprising. Yet both actors give their roles a spark of life \u2014 Mr. Yelchin lends the movie heart in one of his final performances, Mr. Sparks gives it a touch of realistic cunning \u2014 that let you see where this movie might have gone if Mr. Finley hadn\u2019t relied on formula.\n\nFor all the chatter and intrigue, Mr. Finley never settles on a point or theme. At times, he seems invested in performing a cultural autopsy on Lily and Amanda, opening them up so we can see the pathologies crawling inside. At other times, he seems to want us to see them as symptoms of a larger malady, which doubtless accounts for the scene in which a wealthy woman idles in a tanning bed that looks like a coffin. The ostensibly comic images of the workers laboring at Lily\u2019s palatial digs are presumably meant to say something, too, though their marginality here says less about their employers than it does about the filmmaker.", "title": "Review: Meet the Peewee Nihilists of \u2018Thoroughbreds\u2019", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Cory Finley"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Meredith Monk has spent over 50 years steadily churning out gracefully challenging works. It has come to feel like part of the rhythm of living in New York \u2014 one of the better parts \u2014 for Ms. Monk to announce a new stage show.\n\nSections of \u201cCellular Songs\u201d \u2014 her latest evening-length piece, written for an entirely female version of her vocal ensemble and running through Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music \u2014 have appeared as works in progress since 2015. In those presentations, several of Ms. Monk\u2019s stylistic hallmarks were in evidence: unpredictable yet ensorcelling rhythmic grooves; trebly, chattering murmurs arising from groupings of singers; solo passages requiring the deep, plaintive power of the composer\u2019s shockingly serene voice.\n\nA listener might have heard an excerpt or two \u2014 say, at the annual boisterous free festival hosted by the Bang On A Can organization \u2014 and come to the conclusion that Ms. Monk was focusing on tidy new miniatures. She was not.\n\nThe premiere of the entire \u201cCellular Songs\u201d on Wednesday evening had the cumulative force of some of her best writing. Joined with Ms. Monk\u2019s installation-art scenarios (realized by the video artist Katherine Freer) and choreography, this linked series of pieces was a coherent meditation on themes of individual flourishing and collective belonging. The microscopic unit of measurement suggested by the title hardly represents the work\u2019s ambitions.\n\nPhoto\n\nConcepts that engage individuality tend to be a bandleader\u2019s dream, since they allow performers to show off singular talents \u2014 as here, with Allison Sniffin\u2019s gifts on multiple instruments, or the lithely expressive dancing and finely controlled vibrato of Jo Stewart, the latest addition to the ensemble. Like Duke Ellington, Ms. Monk knows well how to weave solo lines tailored to specific performers (herself included), but her dramatic gifts are often clearest during passages involving multiple players.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn \u201cHey-nyo,\u201d a lengthy ensemble number that was the evening\u2019s centerpiece, Ms. Monk charted numerous routes between clashing semitones, unsettling microtonal swoops and gentler harmonies. No sonic experience was given short shrift; by the end, a sense of calm felt honestly won.\n\nThe formidable complexity of material like that helped the poetry of seemingly simpler numbers \u2014 like \u201cHappy Woman,\u201d in which Ms. Monk gradually offers up contradictory self-identifications (\u201cI am an honest woman,\u201d \u201cI\u2019m a lying woman\u201d) \u2014 sneak up on a listener. That song\u2019s unsheathing of new personalities \u2014 each different, yet connected to the ones before \u2014 seemed in tune with Yoshio Yabara\u2019s subtly varied layers of costuming.", "title": "Review: Meredith Monk, Still Peerless at Shocking Serenity", "authors": ["Seth Colter Walls"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "As my New York Times colleague Zachary Woolfe has suggested, Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, the successor to James Levine as music director of the Metropolitan Opera, may have cause to feel anointed: To judge from recent audience reactions, he is seen as the new grand maestro on the block, and quite possibly a savior for the troubled company.\n\nBut Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin\u2019s response to audience acclaim for his concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening was distinctly unregal; indeed, un-maestro-like. It was hugs all around as Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin, who has been the orchestra\u2019s music director since 2012 and was clearly energized by an hourlong immersion in Rachmaninoff\u2019s Second Symphony, made his way through the ranks, congratulating individual players.\n\nAnd congratulations were in order. The Philadelphia Orchestra became a sort of spiritual home for Rachmaninoff after he left Russia in 1917, and the ensemble maintained a close relationship with his work during its many years under Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy. If Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin and the current players can no longer claim primary ownership of Rachmaninoff\u2019s music, evidently no one has told them.\n\nThe lush string playing, in particular, summoned memories of the Fabulous Philadelphians of yore. And individual contributions from others \u2014 particularly Ricardo Morales, the principal clarinetist, in the big tune of the third movement \u2014 enhanced that impression.", "title": "Review: Met Opera\u2019s Next Maestro Energizes His Philadelphians", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMindy Kaling\u2019s first TV show after \u201cThe Mindy Project\u201d is \u201cChampions,\u201d a single-camera comedy she created with Charlie Grandy, a writer and producer for \u201cMindy.\u201d Beginning on Thursday on NBC, \u201cChampions\u201d has the same constant ticker of references and perky zingers, as well as similar personnel: Anders Holm and Fortune Feimster are both playing versions of their \u201cMindy\u201d characters.\n\nThe main difference is that rather than centering on a pop-culture-obsessed, melodramatic 30-something doctor (Mindy), it\u2019s centered on a pop-culture-obsessed, melodramatic 15-year-old gay kid (Michael). And it works.\n\nMs. Kaling appears in the first two episodes of the show (three were made available to critics) as Priya, a single mom from Ohio. She has raised this theater-crazed teenager (J. J. Totah), who wants to go to a performing arts high school in New York. Luckily, that\u2019s where his father, Vince (Mr. Holm), lives and runs a Brooklyn gym. Unluckily, they\u2019ve never met, nor does Michael know anything about his dad. This doesn\u2019t stop Priya from dropping off her son, though, and this being a sitcom, Vince and his roommate and brother, Matthew (Andy Favreau), turn out to be decent, mostly upstanding and generally O.K. with this arrangement.\n\nAs in many \u201cthe day everything changed\u201d comedies, the first episode of \u201cChampions\u201d exhibits symptoms of pilot-itis: It\u2019s heavy on exposition and feels a bit forced, with a too-pat ending. But that\u2019s a treatable disease, and it clears up completely by Episode 2, when the supporting characters who work at the gym settle into natural rhythms, and the show establishes what level of corniness it\u2019s aiming for in the father-son plotlines. The answer is only the slightest bit, and in a sweet and compelling way.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat tiny sweet streak is essential. Vince has to be a loving dude because Michael is, as he would probably describe himself, quite \u201cextra.\u201d When Vince balks at one aspect of Priya\u2019s parenting, Michael snaps: \u201cMy mother is an angel! You robbed her of her youth and left her for dead, like Fantine in \u2018Les Miz,\u2019 so I had to be raised by the ghoul she had become!\u201d In the second episode, Michael sizes up a basketball arcade game: \u201cWhat is that? It looks homophobic.\u201d In the third, Dana (Ginger Gonzaga), one of the gym employees, insists that her romantic relationship is going fine. Michael scoffs: \u201cAre you a freshman at Berkeley? Because you protest too much.\u201d", "title": "Review: Mindy Kaling\u2019s \u2018Champions\u2019 Is Off to a Winning Start", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "But it is a great story, even if you just turn on the camera and let it roll. One incidental revelation, or reminder, is how breathlessly and exhaustively the events were reported. They were the reality TV of their time, with guns, sex, a mass poisoning and murder schemes. The events may have been playing out in the proverbial middle of nowhere, but that was the point: A movement, or cult, of thousands of post-\u201960s seekers in orange and purple mufti had descended upon a thin population of ranchers and retirees, who took on the mantle of frontier yeomen protecting American values against foreign invasion.\n\nThe battle between the Rajneeshees and the citizens of Antelope prefigures, in a funhouse-mirror way, our current cultural and political landscape \u2014 notions of American liberty and morality were being defended against perceived (and actual) outside threats.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re invading,\u201d an Oregonian said at the time. \u201cMaybe not with bullets, but with money and, um, immoral sex.\u201d In the long and successful fight to get rid of Rajneeshpuram \u2014 which led to the deportation of the Bhagwan and the jailing of some of his followers \u2014 the government used immigration law, accusations of church-and-state violations and the denial of voter registration as tactics.\n\nParanoia and anger reigned on both sides, though, and the emotional crux of the story lies in the arrogant, tone-deaf and eventually criminal behavior of the Rajneeshees. The Ways supply ample testimony to this, along with lots of shots of the members toting semiautomatic rifles and conducting Al Qaeda-style combat drills. There is also a recurring motif of the newcomers in their monochromatic attire walking around Antelope, where they co-opted the government and much of the real estate. (Some of this footage has been slowed slightly, for an \u201cInvasion of the Body Snatchers\u201d effect \u2014 like the heavy-handed music, another unfortunate choice.)", "title": "Review: On Netflix, a Wild Story of Guns, Sex and a Guru", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The sentiment is admirable; the execution decidedly is not. (Some other Alzheimer\u2019s films, like \u201cAway From Her,\u201d have done a better job of avoiding this trap.) When it\u2019s time for a twist, John\u2019s mind happens to be in the right year and place to share a secret.\n\nNeither ailment interferes with a host of cloying incidents, as when John drives off without Ella, forcing her to take a ride on a motorcycle to catch up. Or when the two experience a flat tire and are held up by a pair of young men. (Ella retrieves the shotgun she\u2019s brought along, scaring them off, and John, who has already scolded one for ending a sentence with a preposition, tells them it\u2019s not too late to take evening classes and turn their lives around.) In a mortifying sprinkling of topicality, the movie \u2014 set in summer 2016 \u2014 shows John, a lifelong Democratic voter, unwittingly joining in the chants at a rally for Donald Trump.", "title": "Review: On the Road for a Last Taste of Freedom in \u2018The Leisure Seeker\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCW has 15 scripted shows for the 2017-18 season. Eight are based on comic books; two more are based on existing properties; one is the long-running stalwart \u201cSupernatural\u201d and another is a likely-to-be-canceled military drama. Then there are the two quirky, critical beloved genre-benders: \u201cCrazy Ex-Girlfriend,\u201d a dark-comedy musical, and \u201cJane the Virgin,\u201d a sudsy but deeply sincere telenovela. Which brings us to \u201cLife Sentence,\u201d starting Wednesday, neither superhero nor supernatural nor super bold. Instead, it feels like the straightforward family drama of CW\u2019s \u2014 and WB\u2019s \u2014 past: light, young, heartfelt. It\u2019s also unmoored, though, without a clear anchor or companion, putting the show in the unenviable position of having to stand on its own right from the start. It\u2019s enough to crush a mightier, meatier show. But then, \u201cLife Sentence\u201d is all about surprise survival.\n\nLucy Hale, who starred as Aria on the teen thriller \u201cPretty Little Liars,\u201d plays Stella, a manic pixie cancer girl who was miraculously cured, thanks to a trial medication. So the good news is that she\u2019s cancer-free. The bad news is that her family has been lying to her constantly, in the hopes of not adding to her suffering.\n\nNo one is as stable as she thought: Her parents (Gillian Vigman and Dylan Walsh) instantly separate, her lovable older brother (Jayson Blair) reveals himself to be a lowlife and her type-A older sister (Brooke Lyons) admits to feeling trapped by their family\u2019s put-on-a-happy-face dysfunction. Stella herself had impulsively married a hunky Brit (Elliot Knight) she met in Paris because, well, if you\u2019re only going to live a few more months you might as well marry hunky Brits you meet in Paris. But now she\u2019s married-married and perhaps shouldn\u2019t be.\n\nIf you\u2019ve ever seen a bohemian-aspirational character before, it\u2019ll come as no surprise that Stella rides a cute little motor scooter and gets a job at a coffee shop, or that \u201cLife Sentence\u201d is set in Oregon. Stella\u2019s largely unnecessary voice-over drives home the show\u2019s coming-of-age vibe and its naked earnestness. \u201cLife\u201d might be a little too light for its cancer story, but it certainly isn\u2019t glib or ironic. Maybe everyone really did learn a valuable lesson that day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn many fronts, Stella\u2019s recovery mirrors a healthy person\u2019s march to adulthood. Oh! Mom and Dad are people, too, who have their own stories. Oh! People are suffering, everywhere, all the time, and I can either blithely contribute to it or try to alleviate it in some way. Oh! I am very special, but also very unspecial, and reconciling this conflict is in some ways the definition of maturity.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
