View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhere the show struggles, though, is that Stella\u2019s path is not conventional \u2014 the miseries and indignities of a devastating disease are not whimsical study-abroad programs. \u201cLife Sentence\u201d never meaningfully conveys Stella\u2019s illness as anything more severe than an occasion to wear a silk head scarf, and darn if she doesn\u2019t look a little bit glamorous. (Would that we could all have such strong eyebrows on our sickbeds.) In flashbacks, we see her parents weep and worry, but it never lands with the gravity of what it really is.", "title": "Review: On \u2018Life Sentence,\u2019 Life Is a Little Too Beautiful", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "In any case, the story line is confined to one episode of the three screened for critics. The original series rarely talked politics openly; it just lived the country\u2019s realities in all the little ways that matter. As Ms. Barr told The Los Angeles Times in 1992: \u201cWe do it. We don\u2019t talk it.\u201d\n\nThe other plots are more about personal struggles \u2014 work and school, bills and pills. The Conners\u2019 son D.J. (Michael Fishman) is back from the Army, raising his young daughter while his wife serves in Syria. (The youngest Conner son, Jerry, is off somewhere working on a fishing boat.)\n\nBecky, meanwhile, is applying to be a surrogate mother for a well-to-do woman \u2014 played by Sarah Chalke, who took over for Ms. Goranson as Becky in the show\u2019s original run. It\u2019s another meta joke, yes, but with a kick: Becky is trying to better her prospects by having a baby for another, more fortunate version of herself.\n\nIn one of the stronger new stories, Darlene\u2019s son, Mark (Ames McNamara), a spirited nine-year-old who likes to wear skirts, discovers that Lanford, Ill., is not as tolerant of daring fashion choices as his old home in Chicago. It\u2019s a nuanced episode, pitting his grandparents\u2019 worry for him against the Conners\u2019 constitutional mandate to be defiantly different.\n\nIt also echoes the third-season episode \u201cTrick or Treat,\u201d in which Dan fretted that D.J. would get bullied for dressing as a witch for Halloween, while Roseanne went to the bar in a convincing beard and passed herself off as one of the guys. (In the end, Dan broke up a bar fight she was about to get into: \u201cHe\u2019s my husband!\u201d)\n\nThere\u2019s a lot more here that recalls earlier \u201cRoseanne,\u201d which I mean as a compliment, but also points up a limitation of today\u2019s many revivals. In the best-case scenario, they can approximate the original. (Ms. Metcalf and Mr. Goodman fall back into their characters seamlessly.) But they\u2019re too wed to expectations to improve on it.\n\nThis \u201cRoseanne\u201d at least has reasons to exist beyond, \u201cWhy not?\u201d One of them is the same reason it was refreshing 30 years ago: There are scant few sitcoms now about working-class families, like \u201cThe Middle,\u201d about to end its run on ABC, and \u201cOne Day at a Time,\u201d just renewed at Netflix.\n\n\u201cRoseanne\u201d is a revival that\u2019s willing to grapple with the time that\u2019s passed rather than deny it. It\u2019s feisty and funny and a little sad. And like that old couch you can\u2019t throw out, it may just have a good year or two left in it.", "title": "Review: On \u2018Roseanne,\u2019 Times Have Changed, but They\u2019re Still Tough", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "But for the past few years, Mr. Taylor has changed the game. Performances of the renamed Paul Taylor American Modern Dance shuffle not only new Taylor with old, but both with classics by other choreographers and commissions by younger artists. The last element, in particular, deflects attention from the unequal contest between the 87-year-old Mr. Taylor and his younger self to the unequal contest between Mr. Taylor\u2019s best work and the latest effort by whomever. The house holds the advantage.\n\nThis was the case during the first week of this year\u2019s encampment at the David H. Koch Theater, with premieres by the choreographers Bryan Arias and Doug Varone mixed in with the debut of Mr. Taylor\u2019s \u201cConcertiana\u201d and several of his greatest hits. Unsurprisingly, Paul Taylor won.", "title": "Review: Paul Taylor Classics Outshine New Dances (His and Others\u2019)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "About two hours in, the touring concert \u201cRocktopia,\u201d which is making a six-week pit stop on Broadway, had settled into a benign, dull groove. Then the slide show, which until then had been mostly sunsets and rolling clouds, jolted me awake.\n\nCould it be? Yes, that was Anne Frank looming over the stage, followed by images of Eleanor Roosevelt, Mother Teresa, Diana, Princess of Wales and a Van Gogh self-portrait. All of them visual aids for Queen\u2019s \u201cWe Are the Champions.\u201d\n\nIf anything, \u201cRocktopia\u201d will go down as featuring one of the most misguided PowerPoint presentations ever to grace a Broadway stage.\n\nHatched by the singer Rob Evan and the conductor Randall Craig Fleischer, \u201cRocktopia\u201d brings together the worlds of classical music and rock under the theory that they are more simpatico than a casual listener might assume. The idea is that, say, Mozart was the Mick Jagger of his time, while many beloved singalongs and air-guitar staples draw from centuries-old masterpieces.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo illustrate, the six \u201cRocktopia\u201d singers, led by Mr. Evan, are backed by a five-person band, a 20-strong orchestra and a chorus of 30 under Mr. Fleischer\u2019s direction. (Before the Broadway opening, Actors Equity slapped the production with a \u201cDo Not Work\u201d warning because, among other problems, the choir members were paid below scale; the parties have since reached an agreement. It is not just rock and classical that can get along.)\n\nPhoto\n\nLike a tasting menu with wine pairings, the set list is organized around not-so-odd couples: Strauss\u2019s \u201cAlso sprach Zarathustra\u201d segues into the Who\u2019s \u201cBaba O\u2019Riley,\u201d for instance \u2014 a song originally intended as part of a rock opera and whose title partly refers to the composer Terry Riley. Sometimes the classical composition is used mostly as a glorified intro to the song, as if we were in a stadium waiting for the entrance of a band with delusions of grandeur and a Carl Orff fetish.", "title": "Review: Roll Over, Beethoven? At \u2018Rocktopia,\u2019 It\u2019s Time to Roll Back", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "A crescendo of humiliation, anxiety and abuse, \u201cBeauty and the Dogs\u201d plays like a horror movie where every choice is a Catch-22 and every door a trap.\n\nUnfolding over one endless night and nine chapters \u2014 each confidently filmed in a single, liquid take \u2014 the story (by the film\u2019s Tunisian director, Kaouther Ben Hania) follows Mariam (Mariam Al Ferjani), a young student. Raped by the police after a university party, Mariam, accompanied by a young man she has just met (Ghanem Zrelli), desperately seeks help, first from an indifferent private clinic and then a chaotic public hospital.", "title": "Review: Seeking Justice After a Rape in \u2018Beauty and the Dogs\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn her latest starring role, Sharon Stone plays Senna, a woman who has found herself spiritually comfortable, but romantically, financially, and professionally at sea. Senna\u2019s career as a fashion buyer is at a standstill, and her dreams of becoming a designer seem out of reach. Marriage, she thinks, doesn\u2019t suit her. But thanks to the meddling of her friend Darla (Liza Lapira), she meets cute with Adam (Tony Goldwyn), a lawyer with a heart of gold. Susan Walter\u2019s \u201cAll I Wish\u201d checks in with Senna over the course of several birthdays thereafter, and we watch as this free spirit changes her ways, locking down a bridegroom to go with her business.\n\nSenna might be flighty, but she is always grounded by Ms. Stone, who understands that this is a character that ought to be sold through presence, not performance. Her portrayal here is all ease and glowing smiles \u2014 she is a femme fatale reborn as a family-friendly comedian.\n\nVideo\n\nUnfortunately, Ms. Stone is fighting an uphill battle against a generic screenplay. Senna and Adam speak to each other as if they were reading from greeting cards, and the turning points in their relationship are served like reheated romantic comedy leftovers. Even when the script doesn\u2019t trip over gumball wedding rings and tone-deaf karaoke scenes, the direction drains the story of specificity and feeling. The costume design is especially egregious, as Senna\u2019s style as a designer seems culled straight from fast fashion stores at outlet malls. Both sartorially and cinematically, the seasoned star at the heart of \u201cAll I Wish\u201d deserves a movie with more to offer than knockoff style.", "title": "Review: Sharon Stone Stars in \u2018All I Wish,\u2019 a Lukewarm Romantic Comedy", "authors": ["Teo Bugbee", "Susan Walter"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Is it relevant to add that Perry is black?\n\nActually, Perry\u2019s mother, Ginnie (Sally Murphy), is white, and his father, Don, an English instructor at Hillcrest, is biracial. (We do not meet Perry or Don.) But who gets to \u201ccount\u201d as diverse is one of the play\u2019s horrible-hilarious wrangles. In an argument with Roberta, a member of Hillcrest\u2019s development staff, Sherri insists that the school\u2019s admissions catalog must depict a student body that is visually diverse \u2014 so Perry, who is light-skinned, doesn\u2019t count. To comply, Roberta (Ann McDonough) has to stage photos that feature recognizably dark-skinned students, reading \u201cThe Bluest Eye\u201d no less.\n\nPerry may not be black enough for the catalog, but Charlie certainly thinks he was black enough for Yale, and accepted for that reason. In an astonishing 17-minute howl of disappointment, he undoes a lifetime of indoctrination as he dissects the logical fallacies on which, he feels, his parents\u2019 values \u2014 and Yale\u2019s, and Hillcrest\u2019s \u2014 are based.\n\nPhoto\n\nIs Pen\u00e9lope Cruz a person of color? Is Kim Kardashian? If so, why isn\u2019t, say, Marion Cotillard? And why does Perry\u2019s mother act as if \u201cit\u2019s this huge achievement that a not totally white baby popped out of her vagina\u201d? Should white people hate white people?\n\nThe evening I saw it, this line of thought had the audience roaring and clapping and then seeming to want to retract both responses as Charlie veered into ever more uncomfortable ideas.\n\nThat\u2019s good satire at work, causing us to think critically about people we don\u2019t at first recognize as images of ourselves. And the discomfort only deepens when Charlie, stung by his parents\u2019 reaction to his tirade \u2014 his father calls him a spoiled brat \u2014 reconsiders his position and makes a startling decision.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf there are going to be new voices at the table,\u201d he says later in the play, \u201csomeone has to stand up and offer someone else his seat.\u201d By a method I will not spoil, Charlie proposes to do for diversity what his parents only give the appearance of doing, and in the process reinvent himself as a Great White Martyr.\n\nBut martyrs are not always as determined as mothers, and Sherri\u2019s tolerance turns out to be finite. Her assumptions of privilege, however unexamined, will not be denied. The crux of Mr. Harmon\u2019s argument, which is as tightly constructed as a finger-trap toy \u2014 almost every piece of information supplied at the start pays off by the end \u2014 is that hypocrisy may look a lot like love.\n\nSatires don\u2019t usually go there. Recent racial comedies, like Branden Jacobs-Jenkins\u2019s \u201cAn Octoroon\u201d and Bruce Norris\u2019s \u201cClybourne Park,\u201d have been built on ludicrously bad behavior, and let the results speak for themselves. \u201cAdmissions\u201d is less extreme but also, as a result, harder to put across. The characters are caught somewhere between well-observed types and absurd caricatures. Sherri\u2019s mama bear ferocity is necessary to turn the plot, just as Charlie\u2019s hysteria about Yale is, but in real life both would be subtler. Of course, in real life this plot wouldn\u2019t happen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean it shouldn\u2019t happen onstage. As in his previous plays \u201cBad Jews\u201d and \u201cSignificant Other,\u201d Mr. Harmon is admirably unafraid of portraying incorrectness in the guise of sour comedy. In a way, Charlie is a combination of Daphna, the relentless scold of \u201cBad Jews,\u201d and Jordan, the whiny wallflower of \u201cSignificant Other.\u201d But \u201cAdmissions\u201d is even better for being about something substantially larger than one character\u2019s unhappiness.\n\nStill, I\u2019m not sure that Daniel Aukin\u2019s warm and intermittently rollicking production finds the right tone. Though there are moments in which the mere placement of bodies on the Newhouse\u2019s thrust stage is enough to make you anxious, there are too many others that seem to pull back from the blinding clarity that\u2019s needed. (Mark Barton\u2019s lighting is way too gentle.) When the actors, generally working in a naturalistic vein, tear into their characters\u2019 most unhinged moments they seem to be grinding gears. You find yourself questioning the likelihood of their behavior when, ideally, you would be too breathless to study it.\n\nNo matter. One of the things the theater should be doing today, and rarely does, is lancing the boil of our own self-deception. \u201cAdmissions,\u201d as that pun of a title suggests, is a kind of confessional, except that no forgiveness is offered, or deserved.", "title": "Review: Skewering White Pieties About Diversity in \u2018Admissions\u2019", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMagical, subtle, sensitive and touching, \u201cI Kill Giants\u201d is everything the bombastic \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d is not. Written by Joe Kelly (based on his graphic novel with J.M. Ken Niimura), this intimate story about a troubled 12-year-old who\u2019s on a mission to save her town is virtually tone perfect.\n\nThat\u2019s not easy in a feature (the first from the Danish director Anders Walter, returning to ideas he explored in his 2013 Oscar-winning short film, \u201cHelium\u201d) that treads a fragile path between adult themes and childlike wonder. Their point of intersection is Barbara (Madison Wolfe), a driven loner who wears bunny ears \u2014 a nod to her spirit animal \u2014 and believes that giants are threatening her small coastal community. When we meet her, she\u2019s setting ingeniously intricate traps with a jam-like bait containing glitter and gummy bears. Later, she checks the protective amulets she\u2019s scattered around her school, brushing off a bully with sharp-witted confidence. She\u2019s not afraid: she\u2019s the dragon slayer.\n\nVideo\n\nThinly plotted but beautifully executed, \u201cI Kill Giants\u201d clings fiercely to Barbara\u2019s fantastical quest, only tentatively allowing those closest to her \u2014 a worried school counselor (Zoe Saldana), a curious new girl (Sydney Wade) and Barbara\u2019s exhausted older sister (a fine Imogen Poots) \u2014 to shed light on its source. Capturing beach and woodland in wide, scenic sweeps, the director of photography, Rasmus Heise, balances the film\u2019s thick and volatile emotions with a welcome airiness. Outside, stalking monsters, is where Barbara lives and breathes.\n\nPondering grief and denial, lost dreams and irrevocably altered futures, Mr. Walter proves you don\u2019t need a giant-sized special-effects budget to conjure enchantment and danger.\n\n\u201cPeople close to me get hurt,\u201d Barbara tells her sole friend. She\u2019s not wrong.", "title": "Review: Slaying Monsters (and Avoiding Grief) in \u2018I Kill Giants\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Joe Kelly"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Right as the show begins, an awful squeaking assaults your ear. Is it the sound, sure to subside, of seats creaking? No, it\u2019s part of the sound score, and it\u2019s going to sustain and swell like a screeching subway car. If you want to watch the dance, you\u2019re going to have to deal with it.\n\nFor decades, that kind of noise in a dance program was a signal: You were probably experiencing the radical theater of Merce Cunningham. He died in 2009, and his company disbanded two years later, yet at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, the squeaking returned and was almost heartwarming \u2014 one sign among many of how robustly Cunningham\u2019s work is surviving.", "title": "Review: Taking a Chance on Merce Cunningham", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cRags, Strides & Habaneras,\u201d a Jazz at Lincoln Center concert, might have seemed miscellaneous. What do ragtime and stride piano, two early forms of jazz, have to do with the Cuban rhythm also known as the tango? And the lineup of performers only increased the sense of incongruity: four virtuoso pianists from different parts of the world, joined by three dancers \u2014 one tap, one salsa, one flamenco.\n\nNo wonder one of those pianists, the 90-year-old master Dick Hyman, confessed to being bewildered at the start of the early show on Friday. By the early show on Saturday, though, he was able to announce that he and his fellow artists had figured out what the title meant: What had been an enjoyable mess on Friday had by Saturday cohered into something more.\n\nThe programming was far from random. The habanera is a hybrid seed of great potency. An adaptation of the European contradanza by slaves from West Africa, it is not only an early version of a New World rhythm that took over the globe, but also a direct ancestor for much of jazz and rock \u2018n\u2019 roll. Ragtime and stride are part of the same African-diaspora tree, though on a different branch. And these dance rhythms call for dancers.\n\nThe concert touched on all this. You could sense history in the various dances of the pianists\u2019 left hands: the slinky syncopations of habanera; the manic but metronomic bounce, in swing, as if between two trampolines. But the show wasn\u2019t nearly selective enough for the history to be clear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe format was a relay, with two pianos onstage. After one pianist played a few songs, another came on for a duet before embarking on his own set. Mr. Hyman, along with his high-finesse renditions of Scott Joplin ragtime and Fats Waller stride, dutifully inserted a tango bass line into \u201cAll the Things You Are.\u201d Sullivan Fortner, from New Orleans, and Chano Dom\u00ednguez, from Spain, both played habaneras beautifully. But why did Joey Alexander, the adorable and astonishingly skilled 15-year-old pianist from Indonesia, play original compositions with almost none of the three title elements?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong the dancers, who joined in periodically, the outlier wasn\u2019t the Spanish flamenco dancer, Jes\u00fas Carmona (in town for the Flamenco Festival at City Center), so much as the New York salsero, Eddie Torres Jr. In his ruffled shirts and sequined spangles, the friendly Mr. Torres, snapping his fingers and shimmying, simply didn\u2019t have enough vocabulary", "title": "Review: Tapping Out Some New World Rhythms", "authors": ["Brian Seibert"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cFlower,\u201d like its pushy 17-year-old heroine, Erica (Zoey Deutch), has a dirty mouth and a strutting confidence. Our introduction to both takes place in the front seat of a police car, where Erica is enthusiastically pleasuring the uniformed driver before extorting cash for her silence. Then it\u2019s off to the Dairy Queen with her two sidekicks to crow over a caper she\u2019s enacted several times before.\n\nVideo\n\nCruelly amoral and only marginally credible, \u201cFlower\u201d is nevertheless wildly entertaining and at times even touching. Antic and impulsive, Erica is a smart, damaged bully whose father is in prison and whose mother, Laurie (the great Kathryn Hahn), would rather befriend than parent. The teenager also has a strange fixation on penises, which she gratifies by having close encounters with as many as possible and sketching them in a notebook. It\u2019s all very cute, until Laurie\u2019s boyfriend and his deeply troubled son (Tim Heidecker and Joey Morgan) move in and the narrative dives off a cliff.\n\nEven so, the fall is propelled by such zippy dialogue and unexpectedly sweet moments (Erica and Laurie\u2019s relationship, especially, is warmly believable) that you may not care. The supporting players \u2014 including Adam Scott as a possibly skeevy high school teacher \u2014 are all strong, and the director, Max Winkler (son of Henry), never breaks stride. Making liberal use of dizzying close-ups, he swerves from dark coming-of-age comedy to outright horror, refusing to punish Erica for behavior that grows ever more appalling.\n\nYet Ms. Deutch is so engaging, and so adept at selling her wounded character, that damned if we don\u2019t want to give Erica a pass, too.", "title": "Review: Teenage Kicks Go Too Far in \u2018Flower\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Alex Mcaulay", "Matt Spicer", "Max Winkler"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHarold Soyinka, a midlevel executive at a Chicago pharmaceutical company, is originally from Nigeria. This puts someone in mind of those princely email swindles. It\u2019s a pretty weak joke (made worse by the fact that Harold says an uncle of his made a fortune that way) and also an example of what passes for irony in \u201cGringo,\u201d a new movie directed by Nash Edgerton from a screenplay by Anthony Tambakis and Matthew Stone. Harold, you see, is a perfect sucker, an innocent whose trusting good nature makes him an easy target for grifters, scammers and liars.\n\nThere are a lot of those in his life, including his wife, Bonnie (Thandie Newton), and his boss, Richard (Joel Edgerton, the director\u2019s brother), a type-A blowhard who insists that Harold is his friend. Richard and Elaine (Charlize Theron), his predatory colleague-with-benefits, are planning a merger and are also involved in some off-the-books deals in Mexico having to do with medical and nonmedical marijuana. A business trip down there goes south in fairly predictable ways, at least in the context of the kind of hectic, strenuous, nasty caper-comedy \u201cGringo\u201d aspires to be.\n\nVideo\n\nHarold, as he wises up to the fact that he\u2019s been played, takes matters into his own hands, faking a kidnapping and setting off a flurry of chasing, shouting, coitus interruptus and gunplay. A few familiar characters are summoned from the clich\u00e9 repository and outfitted with a random quirk or two. The ruthless drug kingpin (Carlos Corona) is obsessed with the Beatles. The international mercenary (Sharlto Copley) is running a nonprofit in Haiti. The small-time hood (Harry Treadaway) dragging his clueless girlfriend (Amanda Seyfried) into potential danger has a British accent. Harold, as we\u2019ve established, is from Nigeria.\n\nHe is also played by David Oyelowo, which turns out to be a mixed blessing. Mr. Oyelowo is without a doubt the best thing in \u201cGringo,\u201d supplying the only grace notes in a cacophony of secondhand attitude and facetious overacting. But the deck is stacked against him, much as it is against Harold, who as the designated nice guy is assumed to be the least interesting person in the movie.\n\nThe attention is lavished on his foils and tormentors, who are cut from gaudy, worn-out cardboard and set in motion like furious windup toys. Ms. Theron vamps and sneers, Joel Edgerton struts and blusters, and everyone works hard to sustain a mood of jokey, wised-up menace. It is possible to sit through it all without feeling completely miserable, and to remember a time when these comic-grotesque shenanigans might have seemed fresh. The mid-90s, roughly, when this kind of knockoff of early Tarantino, middle-period Coen brothers and jaunty Elmore Leonardism enjoyed something of a vogue. If you\u2019re tempted by \u201cGringo,\u201d you might be better off streaming something from that era.\n\nBy the time the violence escalates from the amputation of a toe \u2014 happy birthday, \u201cThe Big Lebowski\u201d \u2014 to gunshots to the head, \u201cGringo\u201d has long since blown out its own meager brains. You keep rooting for Harold, of course, because he\u2019s a decent fellow who has done nothing whatsoever to deserve any of this.", "title": "Review: The Caper-Comedy \u2018Gringo\u2019 Is Staler Than Yesterday\u2019s Tortillas", "authors": ["A.O. Scott", "Anthony Tambakis", "Matthew Stone"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOn Feb. 13, when the New York Philharmonic revealed its plans for next season \u2014 its first led by Jaap van Zweden as music director \u2014 it also announced a new partnership with the record label Decca Gold. The inaugural release, a Beethoven recording with Mr. van Zweden, came out last week. Our critics consider it alongside this week\u2019s concerts of Brahms and Prokofiev.\n\nWe Heard Them at Lincoln Center ...\n\nDoes Mr. van Zweden always require time to warm up? A couple of weeks ago, it seemed to take some days for him and the orchestra to find a groove. I heard that program \u2014 dominated by the first act of Wagner\u2019s \u201cDie Walk\u00fcre\u201d \u2014 on both Wednesday and Saturday, and the latter performance was significantly tenser and sharper than the former\u2019s vague dreariness.\n\nThis week, on Wednesday evening at David Geffen Hall, it took only 20 minutes or so to slough off the stolidity. Mr. van Zweden began Brahms\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 1 with a deliberation drained of energy. By comparison, the pianist Yuja Wang\u2019s offhand dreaminess \u2014 she always somehow seems at once modest and virtuosic \u2014 crackled with vitality. There was more grandeur in her solo restatement of the opening theme than the whole Philharmonic had mustered at the start.\n\nMr. van Zweden found more focus in the second movement\u2019s otherworldly tenderness, and polished to a glisten effects like that Adagio\u2019s hushed strings. In the finale, he gave particular prominence in the blend to the brasses; similarly, the strong profile of the cellos near the end suggested Mr. van Zweden was at pains to make the orchestra\u2019s layers visible, to create textures simultaneously dense and transparent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Prokofiev\u2019s Fifth Symphony was a far better fit for both conductor and orchestra. While the Philharmonic\u2019s sound had smooth warmth, it maintained an edge of hysteria throughout \u2014 undercurrents ominous, high-string rustles prickling, attacks in the finale admirably harsh. The second and third movements were a pair of danses macabres: the first alternately ferocious and suave, the second brooding and ghostly.", "title": "Review: The Philharmonic and a New Conductor, on Disc and in Person", "authors": ["Zachary Woolfe", "David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The action shifts to Moscow and assorted gruesome and grandiose interiors in which Khrushchev and the rest take turns organizing the funeral and their own uncertain futures. Karl Marx increasingly gives way to the Marx Brothers as Stalin\u2019s son and daughter (the contrapuntal Rupert Friend and Andrea Riseborough) rush in to wail and thunder, adding absurdity and self-dramatizing melodrama to the mix. There are secret meetings, crowds of mourners, visiting dignitaries and more secret meetings. Mr. Iannucci is particularly good at the theater of sycophancy and at all the ways in which supplicating faces, hands and bodies can quiver in fear and with a terrible love.\n\n\u201cThe Death of Stalin\u201d is by turns entertaining and unsettling, with laughs that morph into gasps and uneasy gasps that erupt into queasy, choking laughs. Mr. Iannucci\u2019s decision to have the performers speak in an array of accented English \u2014 from Brooklyn to Cockney \u2014 carries some political resonance, suggesting that totalitarianism knows no borders. But it also makes the familiar strange, creating a Brechtian alienation that few movies succeed in pulling off. Mr. Buscemi plays Khrushchev with persuasive realism, and he certainly looks the part, with his bald head and boxy clothing. But the character\u2019s Brooklyn accent also underscores Mr. Buscemi\u2019s identity, making him present, too.\n\nThis doubling in which both the actor and the character wave at the audience is also a familiar comic strategy, one used by the likes of Bugs Bunny and Jim Carrey. It fits for a movie in which almost all the characters have been playing variations on the same role of slavishly adoring, lethally submissive servant. Stalin hasn\u2019t taken his final breath before Beria and Khrushchev stop playing those roles; others, like Molotov and Malenkov (Jeffrey Tambor), the deputy prime minister and Stalin\u2019s heir apparent, scarcely seem to have anything left except their long-enacted performances.", "title": "Review: The Slapstick Horror of \u2018The Death of Stalin\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "His version of the character is upright, forthright and transparent almost to the point of invisibility. Similarly, the revival in which he appears, directed by Jonathan Silverstein, is most notable for its lucidity. It\u2019s a gentle production that lets Gurney speak for himself, without flashy interpretive obstructions.\n\nWhile this approach may not make for thrilling theater, it does allow you to see Gurney plain. And I came away from this production with new respect for \u201cLater Life,\u201d which now seems to me one of his most eloquent statements on an archetype that hears the chimes at midnight almost from the moment of birth.\n\nThe plot of this 90-minute work functions as a sort of lab experiment for our dubious hero. Austin goes to a party at a friend\u2019s house and is introduced to a woman named Ruth (a down-to-earth Barbara Garrick), who tells him they have met before, when he was stationed with the Navy in Italy several decades earlier.\n\nPhoto\n\nGuided to the quiet of the terrace by their host (the al fresco set is by Steven Kemp, with autumnal lighting by David Lander), Austin and Ruth become increasingly attracted to each other. Our almost-lovers\u2019 conversation is periodically interrupted by an assortment of other guests (all appealingly embodied by Jodie Markell and Liam Craig, in quick-change mode). These intruders are, like Austin and Ruth, in their late middle age. And they wonder, via subjects that range from quitting smoking to moving house, how much they are still capable of change.\n\nGurney lets us know he is putting Austin\u2019s adaptability to the test from the very beginning. \u201cI\u2019m setting the stage here,\u201d says Sally (Ms. Markell), the party\u2019s host, in the play\u2019s opening lines, as she arranges a terrace table for two. \u201cThat\u2019s all I can do. Just set the stage.\u201d\n\nEnter Ruth, attractive and newly separated, and a reminder of the many roads Austin has never taken. She hasn\u2019t been able to stop thinking about him since their brief first encounter, she tells him, mostly because of his assertion as a young man that his life, even then, was a process of \u201cwaiting for something terrible to happen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn prefatory notes for \u201cLater Life,\u201d Gurney thanks the great American novelist Henry James. And this play seems to be a variation of sorts on James\u2019s novella \u201cThe Beast in the Jungle\u201d (which, by the way, has been newly adapted in a play with music that opens in May at the Vineyard Theater).\n\nIf you know the plot of James\u2019s \u201cBeast,\u201d you know how things will turn out. That \u201cLater Life\u201d still engages us has to do with how carefully the script allows its hero the chance to break his stasis. But Austin just can\u2019t rise to the opportunity. Gurney has created this paradoxical loser of a born winner \u2014 a man whom life has blessed with creature comforts and stability \u2014 with equal compassion and exasperation.\n\nThis production doesn\u2019t ultimately provide the emotional payoff we were hoping for, but it reminds us of what a craftsman Gurney was, and how many rueful shades of warmth he could find in frozen lives. Mr. Lau\u2019s performance provides just enough hopeful signals of melting for us to feel the bona fide tragedy of a man \u2014 and a class \u2014 doomed to extinction.", "title": "Review: They Meet Again in \u2018Later Life.\u2019 Will Fireworks Follow?", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Certainly, Ms. Brewer\u2019s presence lends a compelling center of gravity to \u201cAmy and the Orphans,\u201d a Roundabout Theater Company production directed without much zest by Scott Ellis. She dominates the stage without effort. (Her credits include roles in \u201cAmerican Horror Story\u201d on the FX channel.) And neither she nor the script patronizes her character, who turns out to be far more self-aware and purposeful than her siblings realize.\n\nThe problem is much of what surrounds her. The squabbling Maggie and Jacob have been accoutered with those bright, jumbo-size neuroses and eccentricities that are often found in dysfunctional-family sitcoms. Despite eager performances from Mr. Blum and Ms. Monk, those most reliable of pros, their characters feel cut from shiny, synthetic cloth.\n\nThe same might be said of Vanessa Aspillaga\u2019s lovably overbearing Kathy, the loudmouthed but big-hearted Italian nurse, who is tending to Amy in the Queens, N.Y., institution where Maggie and Jacob come to visit. They arrive bearing grim news. Dad is dead, and though it\u2019s already been several months since Mom\u2019s demise, they have yet to tell Amy about either one.\n\nAnd thus begins what might be called a road trip \u2014 in the tradition of that prototypical unhappy, car-bound family movie, \u201cLittle Miss Sunshine\u201d \u2014 as the three siblings (and the pushy Kathy, who insists that she drive) travel across Long Island to lay Dad to rest and to clear out his house, a place that was never home to Amy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMaggie becomes carsick, Jacob kvetches, Kathy delivers monologues with subtexts of disapproval about Amy\u2019s relatives, and Amy takes inventory of the passing nail salons along the highway. (Rachel Hauck did the functional sets, which are as depressing as they are surely meant to be.)\n\nRevelations about the sister they never really knew await Maggie and Jacob at the end of the road. These are of such a grimness that when a certain notorious place is uttered by Kathy, my audience gasped collectively.\n\nAnd it is here that I suppose I should tell you that \u201cAmy and the Orphans\u201d has two hitherto unmentioned characters. They are convincingly played by Diane Davis and Josh McDermitt, who appear in self-contained scenes that punctuate the story of the siblings. I guess it\u2019s kind of a spoiler (stop reading if you must) to say that what\u2019s happening in these scenes is the conversation that will determine the infant Amy\u2019s future.\n\nAnd if you\u2019re still reading, yes, these are Amy\u2019s parents here, several decades earlier, trying to determine if it\u2019s possible for them to care for an infant daughter with Down syndrome without destroying the rest of their family. What\u2019s most remarkable about these scenes is the degree to which we accept the potency of this couple\u2019s love for each other. And as in other families \u2014 though I would wager not the majority \u2014 their love is the first priority.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe exclusiveness of that affection may explain in part why Jacob and Maggie are so ill-equipped to deal with adult life. \u201cIsn\u2019t there a grown-up who can take care of this for us?\u201d Maggie wails, referring to planning the funeral, when she meets Jacob at the airport. She also keeps crying out, \u201cWe\u2019re orphans now!\u201d\n\nThere are orphans and then there are orphans, though. And the more we learn about Amy, the less we feel able to sympathize with Jacob and Maggie. I think Ms. Ferrentino over-eggs their obnoxiousness in this regard, to make the contrast more apparent.\n\nShe doesn\u2019t need to. Amy is more than capable of making her own, implicit case. Wisely, Ms. Ferrentino allows Amy to have the last word \u2014 or words \u2014 in a curtain-closing monologue made up entirely of her beloved film quotations. And while you\u2019ve probably heard most of these words before, it\u2019s unlikely they\u2019ve ever had the defiant, heartbroken resonance they acquire here.", "title": "Review: Three Degrees of Loneliness in \u2018Amy and the Orphans\u2019", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nComfort food for the young at heart, Richard Loncraine\u2019s \u201cFinding Your Feet\u201d is as cozy as old slippers and as familiar as the British character actors who populate its London locations.\n\nLed by a charming pairing of Imelda Staunton and Celia Imrie as the long-estranged sisters Sandra and Bif, this creaky romantic comedy (with a side order of death and dementia) is by turns warm, silly and thoroughly mortifying. When Sandra, a suburban toff, surprises her husband mid-clinch with his mistress, she grabs her fancy luggage and lands at the door of Bif\u2019s cluttered council flat. Within days, Sandra is joining Bif\u2019s dance class, smoking her weed and making eyes at a two-stepping retiree named Charlie (the wonderful Timothy Spall).\n\nVideo\n\nAssembled by the numbers and filmed (by John Pardue) as if it matters, \u201cFinding Your Feet\u201d boasts an embarrassingly on-the-nose soundtrack and plot twists you can see coming without your bifocals. Meg Leonard and Nick Moorcroft\u2019s screenplay virtually defines \u201cformulaic\u201d \u2014 and the less said about the dance routines, the better \u2014 but with performers this seasoned, predictability will be for some viewers less a liability than a bonus.\n\nMarrying age-appropriate humor \u2014 like a date-night striptease that does the opposite of resuscitate \u2014 with moments of gentle pathos, the movie delivers exactly what its poster promises. Watching it demands little effort. Evict your inner cynic and enjoying it should demand even less.", "title": "Review: Two-Stepping to Happiness in \u2018Finding Your Feet\u2019", "authors": ["Jeannette Catsoulis", "Meg Leonard", "Nick Moorcroft"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn most performances of Donizetti\u2019s \u201cLucia di Lammermoor,\u201d it\u2019s hard not to feel a little sorry for the lead tenor during the final scene. This tormented moment for the character Edgardo is one of the composer\u2019s most inspired creations, but it immediately follows Lucia\u2019s famous mad scene \u2014 usually the showstopper.\n\nBut thanks to a fearless performance by the tenor Vittorio Grigolo, Edgardo\u2019s scene was the high point of the evening on Thursday when Mary Zimmerman\u2019s 2007 production of \u201cLucia\u201d returned to the Metropolitan Opera. Other cast members had their moments, especially the luminous soprano Olga Peretyatko-Mariotti, singing her first Lucia at the Met, who was at her best when it mattered most during the long, demanding mad scene. Still, all night Mr. Grigolo was in the zone with a fervor that no one else matched.\n\nMr. Grigolo put everything on the line for that final scene, at the graveyard of the Ravenswoods, a landed Scottish family in decline. Edgardo, the laird of that estate, has fallen in love with Lucia, the sister of a rival clan, the Lammermoors, now headed by her imperious brother, Enrico, who is Edgardo\u2019s sworn enemy. But to save the Lammermoors from financial ruin, Lucia, who adores Edgardo, has been forced into a marriage of convenience with a wealthy lord.\n\nEdgardo comes to the graveyard at the very moment he believes Lucia is entering her bridal chamber with her new husband. Mr. Grigolo mingled raw despair and feral intensity when he sang Edgargo\u2019s wrenching aria of farewell to life, as he anticipates being killed in a duel at dawn with Enrico and welcomes it. In the second part of the scene, when Edgardo learns that Lucia is dying (having gone mad and stabbed her husband to death), Mr. Grigolo\u2019s vocally burnished and wild-eyed singing made the young man seem unhinged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWas his performance over the top? Perhaps. But the field of opera could use a little more of Mr. Grigolo\u2019s animalistic intensity. This otherwise curiously tame \u201cLucia\u201d certainly benefited from it.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere were admirable qualities to Ms. Peretyatko-Mariotti\u2019s Lucia. During her first aria, when she tells her handmaid Alisa (Deborah Nansteel) that she keeps seeing the ghost of a young woman slain by a jealous lover in the waters of a fountain at the castle, Ms. Peretyatko-Mariotti conveyed the emotional shakiness of her fragile character by injecting the ornate vocal lines with a touch of skittishness.\n\nThough the technical aspects of her singing were mostly secure, now and then, even during the otherwise compelling mad scene, Ms. Peretyatko-Mariotti seemed cautious and distracted \u2014 for example, taking a moment to prepare for sustained high notes, then singing them shakily. During the heated romantic exchanges in Act I, Mr. Grigolo, with his unbridled passion, inspired Ms. Peretyatko-Mariotti to risk more. Her scene in Act II with Lucia\u2019s brother fell flat though, mostly because of the stolid singing of the baritone Massimo Cavalletti as Enrico. Ms. Peretyatko-Mariotti seemed disengaged.", "title": "Review: Vittorio Grigolo Is the Reason to See the Met\u2019s \u2018Lucia\u2019", "authors": ["Anthony Tommasini"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The story of the abused animals of Trash Island evokes tales of pain and suffering like \u201cBlack Beauty\u201d and \u201cBeautiful Joe.\u201d Mr. Anderson, who also wrote the screenplay, handles this theme unpersuasively, nodding at genocide only to skitter away and return to his embroidered visuals. \u201cIsle of Dogs\u201d is filled with exquisite illustrations, whimsical flourishes and nostalgic details \u2014 old-fashioned labels, computer punch cards \u2014 that thicken the texture of its imaginary world. But too often the movie feels overworked, fussy. And when an explosion darkens Trash Island, evoking the horrors of Japan\u2019s past, Mr. Anderson feels like he\u2019s circling a profundity he doesn\u2019t know how to handle.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike many of Mr. Anderson\u2019s movies, \u201cIsle of Dogs\u201d is very much about storytelling \u2014 it\u2019s narrated by Courtney B. Vance \u2014 which means that it\u2019s about the past as much as the present or future. It opens with a fable about a boy samurai, a precursor to Atari and one of Mr. Anderson\u2019s wise youngsters. We spend a lot of time with Atari, so it\u2019s too bad that much of what he says is not translated into English. There are some cute interpretive moves (a translator voiced by Frances McDormand), but Mr. Anderson clearly didn\u2019t want subtitles competing with his visuals. So when the Japanese characters speak, their words are usually reduced to the decorative, at least for non-Japanese speakers.\n\nIt\u2019s a strange, discomfiting choice not least because it means that few of the Japanese characters, including Atari, have the depth or dignity given the dogs. Back in Megasaki City, when the mayor plots and scientists (Akira Ito and the one and only Yoko Ono) work on a cure for what ails the dogs, only some of what they say is conveyed. At the same time, high school journalists, led by a foreign-exchange student, Tracy (Greta Gerwig), investigate the mayor. Tracy speaks Japanese but mostly yammers on in English. A bossy boots with a blond puffball of hair, she is a tedious variation on Tracy Flick (of \u201cElection\u201d) and Mr. Anderson\u2019s own young strivers (\u201cRushmore\u201d and elsewhere).\n\nMr. Anderson has always drawn liberally from film history, folding allusions to favorites into his work. In \u201cIsle of Dogs,\u201d he gives an apparent shout-out to the director Seijun Suzuki. The mayor was amusingly (and convincingly) modeled on the actor Toshiro Mifune, known for his work with Akira Kurosawa, whom Mr. Anderson has referenced, with Hayao Miyazaki, as an influence on \u201cIsle of Dogs.\u201d The allusions are loving, but at times also ritualistic, distracting and uninvolving; mostly Mr. Anderson is replaying his own greatest hits, going back to familiar ideas \u2014 the fallen adult world included \u2014 that would work better if they weren\u2019t smothered in filigree and self-consciousness.\n\nAnd yet, time and again, Mr. Anderson pulls you hard into \u201cIsle of Dogs.\u201d His use of film space, which he playfully flattens and deepens, is one of his stylistic signatures; he likes symmetry and, in contrast to most directors these days, does a lot inside the frame. He\u2019s especially inventive in this movie, and I could watch hours of its noble dogs hanging out, sniffing the air. Their relationships are expressed in asides and periodic growls but more poignantly when they are separated in the frame and when they\u2019re gloriously united. (By protecting others, you save yourself.) Here, when a dog looks into the camera, the wind caressing him where a human hand once did, the movie finds its soul.", "title": "Review: Wes Anderson\u2019s Bleakly Beautiful \u2018Isle of Dogs\u2019", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Wes Anderson"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The cinematic cosmos of the French director Arnaud Desplechin teems with literary allusions. He frequently makes films about a character named Paul Dedalus \u2014 a nod to the young hero of Joyce\u2019s \u201cUlysses.\u201d And Mr. Desplechin\u2019s characters sometimes soliloquize with words adapted from Philip Roth\u2019s novels. This latest film, \u201cIsmael\u2019s Ghosts,\u201d adds Henri Bloom, an aging filmmaker, to Mr. Desplechin\u2019s oeuvre, and his name, of course, evokes the older protagonist in Joyce\u2019s novel.\n\nFor all that, Mr. Desplechin\u2019s films cannot, or ought not, be considered literary. Cinema is the only medium that can accommodate the narrative sprawl that has distinguished this director\u2019s work since even before \u201cMy Sex Life \u2026 or How I Got Into an Argument\u201d (1996), a film in which he originated several characters who incarnate in his later works.\n\n\u201cIsmael\u2019s Ghosts\u201d opens with a film-within-a-film, an espionage thriller about one Ivan Dedalus, a globe-trotting diplomat turned spy. (He\u2019s probably related to Paul, but you don\u2019t have to understand this convoluted situation to enjoy the movie.) Ivan springs from the mind of Ismael Vuillard (Mathieu Amalric), whose reverie is interrupted by a 3 a.m. phone call from his former father-in-law, Henri Bloom (Laszlo Szabo). Both men are still mourning the loss of Carlotta (hello, \u201cVertigo\u201d people), Bloom\u2019s daughter and Ismael\u2019s wife, who disappeared 20 years ago. Ismael is now involved with Sylvia (Charlotte Gainsbourg), an astrophysicist, who, shortly after her introduction becomes the movie\u2019s temporary narrator, and takes the story back a couple of years. On return to the present, Ismael and Sylvia hole up in a beach house, and one afternoon while sunbathing, Sylvia is approached by a woman (Marion Cotillard) who introduces herself as Carlotta.", "title": "Review: Wife Returns in \u2018Ismael\u2019s Ghosts.\u2019 Confusion Ensues.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "An uneasy calm suffuses \u201c12 Days,\u201d a documentary set at the juncture of personal liberty and the law. An opening title card offers some context: Since 2013, patients in France who have been involuntarily committed to psychiatric hospitals must be \u201cpresented to a freedom and detention judge\u201d within 12 days and then, if needed, every six months. That\u2019s pretty much all the background that the director Raymond Depardon provides in this movie, which suggests that the line between mental illness and health is sometimes determined by who tells your story and how. For those who have long been silenced \u2014 and often remain so \u2014 being able to tell those stories is clearly monumental.\n\nThe documentary largely consists of patient-judge interviews, which take place in small, nearly identical-looking institutional rooms. The spaces are sterile and anonymous, and the exchanges insistently informal; no one wears a suit and tie or announces the judges. The patients are accompanied by an advocate or two who speak on their behalf, at times sharing medical reports. Occasionally, other men and women quietly sit behind the patients; perhaps, you intuit, these are nurses or orderlies. The judges \u2014 polite, direct yet reserved \u2014 ask and at times answer questions.", "title": "Review: \u201812 Days\u2019 and the Rights of the Mentally Ill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The story proceeds, day by day, from right before the hijacking to the aftermath of the rescue. Parallel stories unfold, each showing the tensions and divisions within one of the sides. On the plane and in the terminal \u2014 and in a few flashbacks \u2014 some of the militants air their doubts and debate tactics and ideology. The focus is not on the Palestinians but on Wilfried B\u00f6se (Daniel Br\u00fchl) and Brigitte Kuhlmann (Rosamund Pike), German leftists associated with the Baader-Meinhof group and drawn to the Palestinian cause. Wilfried experiences some qualms about the implications of being a German holding Jews at gunpoint, while Brigitte gobbles pills and maintains an air of steely ruthlessness.\n\nMeanwhile, Peres (Eddie Marsan) and Rabin (Lior Ashkenazi) are engaged in a complicated battle of wills. Peres, portrayed as an unsentimental hard-liner \u2014 an interesting contrast to his later dovish reputation \u2014 pushes the prime minister, a more emotional and indecisive man, to approve a risky military response. Rabin, worried about the safety of the hostages and his own political future, broaches the previously taboo idea of negotiating with terrorists.\n\nAs the decisive moment draws near, Mr. Padilha uses a dance performance \u2014 by a company that includes the girlfriend of an Israeli soldier \u2014 to amplify the suspense and vary the film\u2019s visual texture. It\u2019s a halfway-effective conceit, showcasing his skill at pacing and crosscutting and relieving some of the claustrophobia of the tense indoor scenes in Entebbe and Tel Aviv. But the choreography also emphasizes the shallowness of the film, which gestures toward relevance without finding a coherent historical or political point of view.\n\nWhat should unfold like an unsettling chapter in a long, tragic story \u2014 or a tale of cruelty and heroism \u2014 feels more like an old TV show. Everybody is going through the motions.", "title": "Review: \u20187 Days in Entebbe\u2019 Revisits a Notorious Hijacking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe story of \u201cA Bag of Marbles\u201d follows two young Jewish brothers, Joseph (Dorian Le Clech) and Maurice (Batyste Fleurial), who flee Nazi-occupied Paris in 1942, as Hitler moves the policies of his so-called final solution into the city.\n\nIn Vichy France, the boys find a town by the sea that is almost idyllic; the Italians stationed there are not pursuing Hitler\u2019s goals. But when Italy surrenders to the Allies and Germany takes full control of Vichy, the rounding up of Jews begins there.\n\nThe boys go on the run once more. The movie takes a terrifying turn when the brothers are taken into Nazi custody, and an obsessive commandant, who wields a cigarette holder as if it\u2019s a mustache he\u2019d like to twirl, is hellbent on getting them to admit they\u2019re Jewish.\n\nVideo\n\nThis film, directed by Christian Duguay, is the second time the French author Joseph Joffo\u2019s 1973 autobiographical novel, \u201cUn Sac de Billes,\u201d has been adapted into a movie. (The first version, directed by Jacques Doillon in 1975, never found a U.S. release.) Mr. Duguay chooses to frame this story in a period mode highly influenced by Hollywood pictures. Despite the hardships endured by the characters, nearly every shot seems dappled with nostalgia. The music score is sentimental, with shimmering pianos and trembling strings.\n\nBut the writing and its attendant characterizations have an undeniable integrity, the particular historical detail offered by the story is not common in films about this era, and the lead performers are moving.", "title": "Review: \u2018A Bag of Marbles,\u2019 a Tale of Brothers Fleeing From Nazis", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Christian Duguay", "Beno\u00eet Guichard", "Joseph Joffo", "Novel"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "What I remember most about \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d is my second-grade teacher crying over the final pages during read-aloud time, along with nearly everyone else. I suspect some variant of this experience is common among readers who grew up any time since 1962, when Madeleine L\u2019Engle\u2019s beloved science-fiction coming-of-age novel was first published.\n\nThe movie adaptation, directed by Ava DuVernay from a screenplay by Jennifer Lee and Jeff Stockwell, has been a long time coming, and it arrives in theaters buoyed by and burdened with expectations. It is the first $100 million movie directed by an African-American woman, and the diversity of its cast is both a welcome innovation and the declaration of a new norm. This is how movies should look from now on, which is to say how they should have looked all along. Fans of the book and admirers of Ms. DuVernay\u2019s work \u2014 I include myself in both groups \u2014 can breathe a sigh of relief, and some may also find that their breath has been taken away.\n\nMine was, once or twice, though I would describe the overall experience as satisfaction rather than awe. \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d faithful to the affirmative, democratic intelligence of the book, is also committed to serving its most loyal and susceptible audience. This is, unapologetically, a children\u2019s movie, by turns gentle, thrilling and didactic, but missing the extra dimension of terror and wonder that would have transcended the genre. Thankfully, though, Ms. DuVernay has dispensed with the winking and cutesiness that are Hollywood\u2019s preferred ways of pandering and condescending to grown-ups. The best way to appreciate what she has done is in the company of a curious and eager 10-year-old (as I was fortunate enough to do). Or, if you\u2019re really lucky, to locate that innocent, skeptical, openhearted version of yourself.", "title": "Review: \u2018A Wrinkle in Time\u2019 Gives a Child of the Universe Powerful Friends", "authors": ["A. Scott", "Jennifer Lee", "Jeff Stockwell"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhen I was your age, younger, all my friends were dying,\u201d Sam, a gay man in his 50s, tells his 20-something lover. \u201cI went to funerals twice a week.\u201d\n\nSam had been an AIDS activist decades ago who watched his partner die of the disease, and nearly every scene in \u201cAfter Louie\u201d finds him haunted by the past. Like a former soldier, this middle-aged man grapples with survivor\u2019s guilt, and with the sort of emptiness of a battlefield after the war ends.\n\nSuch a character could, in some hands, come off as inert as he chain-smokes and dwells on his memories. Yet he\u2019s vividly played here by Alan Cumming, who uses a minimalist palette to paint a complex personality. It\u2019s a masterly, controlled performance, in which a glance or a change in voice tone colors an entire scene.", "title": "Review: \u2018After Louie\u2019 Looks at an Activist Once the Fighting Ends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Preparing food onstage is not new, from the eggs and bacon in David Cromer\u2019s staging of \u201cOur Town\u201d to Hugh Jackman filleting a trout in \u201cThe River.\u201d But duplicating the multicourse banquet in \u201cBabette\u2019s Feast\u201d would be impossible \u2014 if you think that trout was bad, imagine stuffing the many quails this new show would require.\n\nSo Karin Coonrod, who directed this new adaptation, did not represent the meal literally. Those familiar with the Oscar-winning Danish film from 1987 \u2014 which builds up to the banquet and essentially ushered in the era of the modern food flick \u2014 will be able to conjure up visions of blini with caviar and rum spongecake. Others will be at a disadvantage, because none of these things materialize in the show.\n\nThere is a certain elegance to Ms. Coonrod\u2019s decision to let audience members flex their imaginations, and the purity of intention matches the story\u2019s setting in an austere Nordic hamlet. Plastic props, in that instance, may well have been distracting. But as it is, the revelatory repast feels undercooked.\n\nConceived and developed by Abigail Killeen and written by Rose Courtney, this \u201cBabette\u2019s Feast\u201d draws not from the film but from its source, a short story Isak Dinesen published in Ladies\u2019 Home Journal in 1950. We are in the late 19th century, in the isolated Norwegian village of Berlevag. As the daughters of the religious leader, now deceased, the aging sisters Martine (Ms. Killeen) and Philippa (Juliana Francis Kelly) represent Berlevag\u2019s puritanical soul: They are uncommonly sweet and kind but, you know, not a barrel of laughs. (Adding an immersive frisson, the Theater at St. Clement\u2019s, which hosts the production, is part of an Episcopal church.)", "title": "Review: \u2018Babette\u2019s Feast\u2019 Is Served, This Time Onstage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn \u201cBack to Burgundy,\u201d Jean (Pio Marma\u00ef), the prodigal son of a winemaking family, returns to France from his current home in Australia after learning that his father is ill. The sensations of youth work on him like Proustian madeleines, though reuniting with his alliteratively named siblings isn\u2019t easy.\n\nJuliette (Ana Girardot) is delighted at his return, but J\u00e9r\u00e9mie (Fran\u00e7ois Civil) wonders why his brother \u2014 away 10 years \u2014 never acknowledged their mother\u2019s death. While Jean\u2019s spoiler-ish reason for not returning then is surprisingly plausible, his estrangement in the intervening time is less so. As \u201cBack to Burgundy\u201d unfolds, it often seems that phone calls or the timely removal of a letter from a jacket pocket might have spared this clan wells of resentment.\n\nVideo\n\nBut so it goes with C\u00e9dric Klapisch\u2019s comfort-food feature, which is primarily a scenic and knowing ode to traditional winemaking. Mr. Klapisch lingers his camera lovingly over shots of grapes being harvested and stomped, all the while employing story mechanics and flashbacks indelicate enough to suggest the churn of a factory juicer.\n\nIn a premise that owes something to Olivier Assayas\u2019s acclaimed \u201cSummer Hours,\u201d the semi-globalized siblings must find a way to reconcile their goals and geographies to divide the estate. Jean and his difficulties with his faraway partner (Maria Valverde) get most of the attention, but there are clich\u00e9s to go around. For a land often perched on the edge of ruin, she says, mere survival is something to celebrate.\n\nDirected by Mark Jonathan Harris and Oles Sanin, the film starts with a rundown of a history that has repeated itself for centuries \u2014 invaders have long prized Ukraine for its resources and geography, and modern times are no exception.", "title": "Review: \u2018Breaking Point\u2019 Finds Fake News and Real Violence in Ukraine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWebster Breitwisch\u2019s old childhood pal is running for office, and Web is unimpressed.\n\n\u201cJimmy Feucht for State Assembly,\u201d he says. \u201cYou\u2019re the guy who almost burned down Scott Pritchard\u2019s house by lighting farts in the basement.\u201d\n\n\u201cPeople grow up and people change,\u201d Feucht (pronounced Foyt) replies, but on the other hand maybe he hasn\u2019t changed all that much. Rumblings beneath the surface figure heavily in Jeremy J. Kamps\u2019s political tragicomedy \u201cBreitwisch Farm,\u201d a smart, complex but overloaded riff on Chekhov\u2019s \u201cThe Cherry Orchard.\u201d It takes place on an organic family farm facing foreclosure in contemporary Wisconsin \u2014 and as Feucht points out, approvingly, frackers drilling nearby would pay loads of money for that property.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d rather give my kidney to Dick Cheney,\u201d Web (Joe Tapper) says.\n\nNot that the place belongs to him and his sister, Leena (Katie Hartke), yet. As their mother, Connie, lies ailing offstage, Breitwisch Farm keeps running. That\u2019s largely thanks to Dolores (an excellent Maria Peyramaure), a Mexican immigrant whose teenage son has grown up on the farm, and Zai (Danaya Esperanza), a doctor\u2019s daughter from Connecticut who loves the romance of working the land.\n\nDirected by Ryan Quinn for Esperance Theater Company, the play lays out dueling visions of the American dream, circa 2010 \u2014 most significantly between Dolores\u2019s son, Oscar (Alejandro Rodriguez), a high school football hero and academic star whose future is held hostage by his undocumented status, and the fervently Republican Feucht (Charlie Murphy), Oscar\u2019s principal and an avid suitor of his mom.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut there are also the regular people \u2014 like Leena, who\u2019s been piling up credit-card debt; her ex-husband, Randy (Will Manning), a good guy but also a serious drunk; and their teenage daughter, Bree (a standout Katie Wieland) \u2014 who just want to be left in peace to watch a Packer game. They\u2019re not particularly paying attention to changes in the landscape.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
