Mr. Platt\u2019s expressionistic performance made Evan\u2019s descent into a hell of misrepresentation seem inevitable; someone so desperate would of course make those mistakes. He was thus, in a way, blameless and sacrificial. But because Mr. Trensch\u2019s Evan is less tortured, he is also more culpable. You can see him choosing, however ruefully, the wrong path.\n\nThat deliberateness may inflame the portion of the audience that already objected to the show because Evan does bad things and isn\u2019t horribly punished for it. Go tell it to Pal Joey. Or pick your politician.\n\nFor me, the shift helps clarify the logic of the story \u2014 and the ingenuity of Mr. Levenson\u2019s book. This seems a fair trade for the slight dimming of Evan\u2019s vocal and emotional fireworks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnother fair trade: With Mr. Trensch\u2019s Evan less dominating, the weight of the story is more evenly distributed among its eight characters. The excellent work of Michael Park as Connor\u2019s stony father and Laura Dreyfuss as his ambivalent sister reveals itself more than ever. (The entire cast has dug deeper into its roles.) I also noticed more clearly how the director Michael Greif\u2019s relentless staging figures in the storytelling, as if it were a ninth character. This is high-def theater: full of color and information wherever you look.\n\nBut not everything that feels different about \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d is a result of the cast change. A story that turns on a high school tragedy naturally plays differently so soon after the shootings in Parkland, Fla. The audience on Tuesday gasped when a character described Connor\u2019s look as \u201cvery school-shooter chic.\u201d And when social media turns his classmates into famous survivors \u2014 then turns on them with suspicion and vitriol \u2014 I felt almost nostalgic for a time, just a year ago, when that plot point seemed like a stretch. Turns out, it was prescient.\n\nEven so, and despite the intensity of interest in the title role, \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d remains \u2014 for this father, anyway \u2014 most moving as the story of two mothers. Connor\u2019s (Jennifer Laura Thompson) is naturally crushed by the death of her son. Evan\u2019s (Rachel Bay Jones) tirelessly enacts the role of cheerleader-in-chief for her lonely, awkward boy. But both are also dealing with something I suspect every parent in the audience understands: their terrifying responsibility for the happiness of their children, coupled with their marginal ability to do anything about it. When Ms. Jones sang the song \u201cSo Big/So Small\u201d near the end of the show on Tuesday, there wasn\u2019t a dry eye in my face.\n\nSo in fundamental ways, \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d has not changed after all. It has survived the big cast change that many predicted it couldn\u2019t, and, the succession assured, seems likely to thrive on Broadway for the foreseeable future.\n\nCritics shouldn\u2019t care about that, of course; box office is not our concern. But if there are going to be long-running Broadway musicals, we can at least mind which ones. A run of three or five or even more years multiplies the impact of a show\u2019s story enormously; such spans are generations in the lives of young theater geeks.\n\nMany of those theater geeks see themselves as invisible Evans already, which is why even those who may never see the show in person have it in their earbuds and argue about it online. But eventually a lot of them will also be parents. When they are, they could do worse than recall what \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d says (and sings) about the compromises and heartbreaks of the job.", "title": "Review: \u2018Dear Evan Hansen\u2019 Has a New Evan, and a New Balance", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "In the middle of the forest, in the middle of the play, quite a distance down a narrative path littered with hairpin turns, one unnamed character asks another a clarifying question: \u201cAren\u2019t you the murderer?\u201d\n\n\u201cI was never the murderer,\u201d the possible murderer (Samuel Im) replies, though he understands any confusion on that point. \u201cThey call me that,\u201d he explains. \u201cSort of a nickname.\u201d\n\nSort of. I, for one, had been thinking of him as the murderer ever since the darkly comic opening scene of \u201cDistant Observer: Tokyo/New York Correspondence,\u201d where he blurts out a confession of his homicidal past and his 10 years\u2019 time served. I kept thinking of him as the murderer even when it emerged that his supposed victim had actually killed herself, and he lied to protect her from shame. Or then again maybe she was murdered after all, just not by him, and by the way, what is he doing with that very long and bloody knife?\n\nIn the mesmeric, deadpan fever dream of a play that is \u201cDistant Observer,\u201d at La MaMa, you grasp onto what you can in trying to keep track of who\u2019s who, and what\u2019s occurring. Like Surrealists playing an extended game of Exquisite Corpse, the play\u2019s authors \u2014 Takeshi Kawamura, in Japan, and John Jesurun, in the United States \u2014 tossed the script back and forth for three years, translation facilitating their exchange. With Mr. Kawamura working in Japanese, Mr. Jesurun in English, each new section one of them wrote was in response to the previous section by the other. Inside the world they built, reality and identity are mutable things, place and memory ephemeral, truth elusive. Plot, too.", "title": "Review: \u2018Distant Observer\u2019 Shifts Shape as Authors Take Turns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA time capsule that somehow reveals a neglected masterpiece every decade, the back catalog of the prolific German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder (1945-82) keeps on giving.\n\nIn 2010, the rediscovery of his science fiction mini-series \u201cWorld on a Wire\u201d showed that he had gotten the jump on \u201cInception\u201d by almost 40 years. Now \u201cEight Hours Don\u2019t Make a Day,\u201d a five-episode series shown on West German television in 1972 and 1973, arrives at Film Forum, where it\u2019s screening in three chunks. Once again, here is a work that \u2014 in the generosity of its scope and the sophistication of its staging \u2014 makes Mr. Fassbinder look more inventive than just about any filmmaker working today.\n\nScreened earlier this year at MoMA\u2019s \u201cTo Save and Project\u201d festival, \u201cEight Hours\u201d has played in the United States before. The New York Times reported its presence in a program at the Museum of Broadcasting in 1983, at least. But the new restoration, from the original 16-millimeter film, probably represents the best it\u2019s ever looked, given its original airing on tube television. (Movies-versus-TV debates inevitably hit a wall with Mr. Fassbinder, whose broadcast dramas had a habit of turning up theatrically outside his home country.)\n\nYet this so-called \u201cfamily series,\u201d an ensemble portrait of an extended clan in a West German city, is also a complete surprise \u2014 funnier, more humane and more optimistic than anything in the Fassbinder canon. The plot pivots on the relationship between Jochen (Gottfried John) and Marion (the ever-luminous Hanna Schygulla), a working-class couple who meet cute when he helps her to extract a stuck pickle jar from a vending machine. Soon, to the delight of Jochen\u2019s family and the tut-tutting of Marion\u2019s busybody colleague (Irm Hermann), Marion has dumped her white-collar boyfriend for Jochen, and they set about building a life.\n\nVideo\n\nAnyone familiar with the doomed fruit seller of Mr. Fassbinder\u2019s \u201cThe Merchant of Four Seasons,\u201d the luckless lottery winner of his \u201cFox and His Friends,\u201d or the Weimar-era ne\u2019er-do-well hero of his \u201cBerlin Alexanderplatz\u201d (with Mr. John as a villain as treacherous as Jochen is good-hearted) is forgiven for expecting the worst. While few characters in \u201cEight Hours\u201d wind up dead or humiliated, it\u2019s not as if Mr. Fassbinder\u2019s bleak worldview has entirely gone away.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat \u201cEight Hours\u201d is a comedy \u2014 or perhaps a tragedy stopped short \u2014 owes something to both design and chance. According to the film scholar Brad Prager, Mr. Fassbinder told a contemporaneous interviewer that he wanted to leave a broad TV audience with a sense that the world was full of possibilities. On the other hand, West German television, which commissioned the project, pulled the plug before the director was able to film the last three episodes, in which he had planned to lower the hammer.", "title": "Review: \u2018Eight Hours Don\u2019t Make a Day,\u2019 Another Fassbinder Masterpiece", "authors": ["Ben Kenigsberg", "Rainer Werner Fassbinder"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "If ever there were a time to be drunk in the theater, this is it.\n\nAnd the good news is that \u201cEscape to Margaritaville,\u201d the Jimmy Buffett jukebox musical that opened on Thursday, makes getting sloshed on Broadway easier than ever. The lobby at the Marquis Theater has been kitted out as an island-style thatched-hut alcohol fueling station, complete with margaritas for $12 (on the rocks) or $16 (frozen), as well as bottle openers, koozies and other drink-oriented paraphernalia.\n\nThe bad news is that you still have to see the show.\n\nOr at least that was bad news for me, stone cold sober and with enough functioning brain cells to recall the past glory of musicals. If my twentysomething nephew liked \u201cEscape to Margaritaville\u201d better than I did, perhaps that\u2019s because he had two drinks and no historical horror.\n\nBut if you\u2019re not drunk or a Parrothead, as Mr. Buffett\u2019s fans are called, you\u2019re in trouble. Mr. Buffett\u2019s denatured country-calypso ditties and horndog smarm seem awfully lowbrow, even in a Broadway environment debased for decades by singing cats and candlesticks. It\u2019s quite a comedown in the sing-to-me-of-romance department from \u201cShall We Dance?\u201d to \u201cWhy Don\u2019t We Get Drunk (and Screw).\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018Escape to Margaritaville,\u2019 Where Work Is a Dirty Word", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "From the moment we hear the French cafe-style accordion music, we suspect that \u201cFinal Portrait\u201d won\u2019t be painting too far outside the lines. Chronicling roughly two weeks in Paris in 1964 when the Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti (Geoffrey Rush) asked a friend, the American writer James Lord (Armie Hammer), to sit for what would be his last portrait, this flimsy feature from Stanley Tucci is essentially a 90-minute conversation that feels like three hours.\n\nImage Cl\u00e9mence Po\u00e9sy as Caroline, a prostitute and a model for Giacometti, in \u201cFinal Portrait.\u201d Credit Parisa Taghizadeh/Sony Pictures Classics\n\nConfined for much of the time to an uncomfortable chair in Giacometti\u2019s dilapidated studio, hair slicked back, attired in an immaculate coat and tie, Lord seems the stoic opposite of his unkempt, mercurial host.\n\n\u201cYou have the head of a brute,\u201d Giacometti tells his subject, who has of course nothing of the kind. As the camera peers into Lord\u2019s invisible pores, his friend futzes with art supplies and confesses faintly shocking non sequiturs, like his youthful habit of falling asleep by fantasizing about raping and killing women. (\u201cOh,\u201d responds Lord, barely changing expression.) Musing on the worthlessness of his gift in an age of photography, Giacometti emerges as a testy celebrity who cares as little for the wads of cash delivered by his unflappable brother, Diego (Tony Shalhoub), as he does for the happiness of his long-suffering wife, Annette (an underemployed Sylvie Testud).", "title": "Review: \u2018Final Portrait\u2019 Watches Giacometti\u2019s Paint Dry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Rosealia Fabrisio is a young muckraking journalist in the making, and you get the sense that she didn\u2019t pick her outfit \u2014 the white eyelet dress, the big matching bow in her hair.\n\n\u201cI am 13 and smarter than you,\u201d she says firmly by way of introduction in Jaclyn Backhaus and Andrew Neisler\u2019s new musical \u201cFolk Wandering.\u201d And because Rosealia is both arrogant and charming, we tumble instantly into her world: 1911, the poor immigrant tenements of Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side, whose genuine horrors she is more than willing to embellish for the sake of a good story. Maybe her article needs a touch of leprosy, or a dead kid on the lawn?\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t even have a lawn, Rosie,\u201d her sweet, awkward neighbor Harlan objects.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m lifting our families out of the gutter with my journalism,\u201d Rosealia (Lena Hudson) thunders.", "title": "Review: \u2018Folk Wandering,\u2019 a Wistful Musical Full of Story and Searching", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "That they almost never sing together as they head out on separate adventures is a structural problem no one has solved. Nor are the numbers for the subsidiary characters compelling. Still, Prince Hans (John Riddle) is Disney dashing; his rival, the ice seller Kristoff (Jelani Alladin), is beamish; and the creatures (Greg Hildreth as Olaf the snowman and Andrew Pirozzi as Sven the reindeer) are aptly \u201caw\u201d-worthy and ready for purchase in the lobby.\n\nBut these two elements of \u201cFrozen\u201d \u2014 the somber and the silly \u2014 are not blending, visually, musically or emotionally. Onscreen, the U-turns from Norwegian chanting (\u201cVuelie\u201d) to musical comedy charm (\u201cDo You Want to Build a Snowman?\u201d) to Carnaby Street pop (\u201cLove Is an Open Door\u201d) can be made to fit with the anything-goes animation aesthetic.\n\nOnstage, the dozen or so new songs that Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez have written to supplement the seven they wrote for the movie feel over-tailored to their moments and, as a result, though in one or two cases lovely, mismatched.\n\nThat problem echoes throughout the production. If there are dozens of words for \u201csnow\u201d in circumpolar languages, there are as many looks for ice in \u201cFrozen.\u201d I\u2019m sorry to say that none of these special effects are especially effective, except in reminding you that there are things that cannot be done well onstage. The best attempt is the simplest: a stunning curtain of Swarovski crystals, arranged in patterns that blend traditional Norwegian rosemaling imagery with \u201cWonderful World of Disney\u201d sparkles and swirls.", "title": "Review: \u2018Frozen\u2019 Hits Broadway With a Little Magic and Some Icy Patches", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn movies like \u201cPitch Perfect\u201d and \u201cMike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,\u201d the actor Adam Devine plays a particular kind of hapless vulgar goofball, an amalgam of a couple of innocuous characters in the 1978 comedy \u201cNational Lampoon\u2019s Animal House.\u201d In the new movie \u201cGame Over, Man!\u201d (in which Mr. Devine stars with Anders Holm and Blake Anderson, his cast mates on the TV series \u201cWorkaholics\u201d) the actor adds some of John Belushi\u2019s anarchic slobbery from the 40-year-old landmark comedy. It doesn\u2019t help the movie overall.\n\nAlexxx, Mr. Devine\u2019s character, is the idea man in a troika of service-industry losers who dream of video game entrepreneurship while enduring their work as housekeepers/waiters at a deluxe hotel. In an early scene, Alexxx and his pals negotiate a bedroom littered with used condoms. Upon learning that a blinged-out Bey (Utkarsh Ambudkar) is giving a party at the hotel, the crew is determined to pitch him their business idea. But there is villainy afoot. As one character in a group of black-clad folks disembarking from an S.U.V. says to their ringleader, \u201cYou didn\u2019t bring me along because I look like the black nerd from \u2018Die Hard,\u2019 cause I don\u2019t.\u201d So there\u2019s your premise, but instead of John McClane fighting the evildoers invading the building, you\u2019ve got the bro variant of the Three Stooges.\n\nThis almost laugh-free comedy, a Netflix Original directed by Kyle Newacheck, is distinguished by a relentless level of outrageous yet strangely listless vulgarity. There are several penis jokes, including one requiring a high level of exposure on Mr. Devine\u2019s part. Several characters die gorily, prompting other characters to make observations like \u201cHe is full-on spaghetti and meat sauce.\u201d There is a \u201cwhy am I watching this\u201d analingus sight \u201cgag.\u201d The genuinely amusing comedian Joel McHale makes a cameo appearance in this mess. I hope that\u2019s because he lost a bet.", "title": "Review: \u2018Game Over, Man!\u2019 Is Far From Pitch Perfect", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "There are millions of stories in the naked city, and a lot of them have been filmed in Los Angeles. A city partly made by the movies and defined by them, too, Los Angeles rarely comes off like a lived reality onscreen. It\u2019s a hazy dream, a gaudy fantasy, a noirish nightmare, an Instagramble clich\u00e9. It\u2019s no wonder moviegoers and other virtual tourists can map it in their heads without visiting it, even if the Los Angeles they probably know is little more than an aerial view of the Hollywood sign, a cutaway to a clogged freeway and a slavering look at a bountiful blonde.\n\nEvery so often, a filmmaker plays with these banalities, which I imagine is why Aaron Katz opens \u201cGemini,\u201d a pleasurably drifty, low-wattage mystery set in Los Angeles, with an upside-down shot of a palm tree. Perfectly framed and photographed, its feathery fronds spreading in silhouette against a dark-indigo night sky, the tree hangs in the shot like a chandelier. Mr. Katz gives \u201cGemini\u201d the expected smoggy freeways and a blonde on a billboard, as well as the kind of mystery that certain Hollywood dreams are made of, complete with a femme fatale, a detective and a lonely horn on the soundtrack. But as that upside-down palm tree suggests, he is coming at Los Angeles from his own angle.\n\nLike a lot of intrigues, this one opens at night. Jill (an appealing Lola Kirke), a personal assistant, is sitting behind the wheel of a parked car, her face lighted by a cellphone. It\u2019s a decidedly ordinary scene, even if cinephiles might flash on a different woman staring into a glowing box in the explosive 1955 noir \u201cKiss Me Deadly.\u201d As she often is, Jill is waiting for Heather (Zo\u00eb Kravitz), a young star going through some kind of undefined rough patch. Heather has a meeting with a filmmaker, Greg (an amusingly acid Nelson Franklin), one of those jaundiced, permanently disappointed industry types who doubtless read Nathanael West\u2019s \u201cThe Day of the Locust\u201d at too tender an age.", "title": "Review: \u2018Gemini\u2019 Finds Murder in a Movie-Soaked Los Angeles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 It\u2019s never good news when the curtain draws back before the second act, and the artistic director steps out to speak. And so it went on Thursday night at the Royal Opera House here, where the American star David Hallberg and the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova were finally reunited on stage in \u201cGiselle,\u201d the ballet that ignited their celebrated partnership when they first performed it together in 2009 at American Ballet Theater.\n\nMr. Hallberg, announced Kevin O\u2019Hare, the director of the Royal Ballet, had injured himself at the start of Act 1, and would not perform Act 2. Matthew Ball, a first soloist who recently made his debut in the role, would take his place.\n\nJudging by the loud groan, it was a huge disappointment for the audience, many of whom had probably never seen Mr. Hallberg perform with Ms. Osipova, a principal with the Royal Ballet since 2013. And how must he have felt? Mr. Hallberg returned to the stage just 14 months ago, after a two-and-a-half-year injury-filled break and a painful, painstaking fight back to physical prowess. (Dancing with Ms. Osipova again, he has said, was one of his strongest motivations.)\n\nUntil the announcement, there was little indication of a problem. Albrecht, the nobleman who disguises himself as a peasant to court the lovely village girl Giselle, doesn\u2019t have a great deal of dancing in Act 1. If Mr. Hallberg seemed slightly muted in those passages, with legs and jumps kept low, it was in keeping with the effortless air of nobility that he brought to the role from the moment he arrived on stage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis Albrecht is genuinely infatuated with Giselle, rather than a cad with a seduction plan. By the end of the act, Mr. Hallberg seemed aware of the depth of his feelings, appalled by the vast error and consequences of his actions. That he could convey all this while negotiating a just-sustained injury is a tribute to his artistry and to that of Ms. Osipova, who offered a rivetingly original account of the role.\n\nPhoto\n\nMost ballerinas play Giselle as a shy, charming, innocent village girl who readily falls for the mysterious (and perhaps calculating) stranger she has just met. Ms. Osipova\u2019s Giselle may be na\u00efve, but she rushes at life with gusto and sensuality. The moment when Ms. Osipova and Mr. Hallberg first lock eyes has a Romeo and Juliet electricity: You can almost see the shock of physical sensation and recognition, and feel the inexperienced Giselle\u2019s confusion and momentary fear at these unfamiliar emotions.", "title": "Review: \u2018Giselle\u2019 Reunited Hallberg and Osipova, but Only for an Act", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "The face is everything. From the very first shot, tight and merciless, Charlotte Rampling\u2019s pale, stricken countenance sets the tone of \u201cHannah\u201d and dominates virtually every moment thereafter. By the end, we feel so wrung out it takes a second or two to realize that very little has happened.\n\nThis is partly because the movie, with implacable sterility, gradually nudges its title character toward a threatened tipping point. Details are sparse and dialogue scant as Hannah, an older resident of an unidentified Belgian city, sees her husband off to prison for an unspecified (but, eventually, horribly clear) crime. Later, she will feed her dog, water her plant and attend an acting class as, one by one, social and familial connections are cruelly severed. Her husband\u2019s actions have built a wall around them both.", "title": "Review: \u2018Hannah\u2019 Presents a Woman Undone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlison Chernick\u2019s documentary is a fond portrait of the violinist Itzhak Perlman. He makes \u201cgarbage-pail soup\u201d for Alan Alda; plays the national anthem for a Mets game; collaborates, jovially and seemingly scrubbed of ego, with other musicians. Most important, he plays, filling the film with the yearning strains of his instrument.\n\nAmple archival material shows a child sensation playing on the \u201cEd Sullivan Show\u201d in 1958 and a young man performing in Israel in 1974 \u2014 and more impassioned music.\n\nMs. Chernick devotes time to Mr. Perlman\u2019s discussions of the violin \u2014 its presence at Auschwitz, for example \u2014 with luthiers and students. To elicit a sound from a piano is automatic, Mr. Perlman says in Hebrew. From a violin, he says, \u201cwhen you finally get the sound, you are really getting something out of yourself.\u201d To coax emotional shadings from a violin, \u201cthe more you have in your heart, the more you have to give,\u201d he explains.\n\nVideo\n\nThe film crew follows him unobtrusively through New York moments: observing the Sabbath with family, rehearsing a trio or maneuvering his scooter through snow. His wife, Toby Perlman \u2014 a sunny, empathetic presence \u2014 is with him, and there\u2019s a shovel for clearing impassable intersections.\n\nAside from frank views of his crutches and leg braces (childhood polio left him disabled), and a mention of early rejections because of his handicap, the film glides lightly and uncritically along the surface of a life. Verongos"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe plan to have every episode of the second season of Marvel and Netflix\u2019s \u201cJessica Jones\u201d directed by women was conceived a year before the Harvey Weinstein revelations. But now that season arrives like a presciently timed herald of the #MeToo-Time\u2019s Up revolution, with 13 female directors and 9 of 13 episodes written or co-written by women. For added emphasis, it begins streaming on Thursday, which is International Women\u2019s Day.\n\nThis concentration of female creators is unusual, of course, particularly for a high-profile, comic-book-based drama. But \u201cJessica Jones\u201d was already one of the more women-centric dramas around when its first season appeared more than two years ago.\n\nIts creator and showrunner, Melissa Rosenberg of the \u201cTwilight\u201d movies, focused tightly on Jones (Krysten Ritter), a moody private eye who had super strength forced on her as a child, and a few other female characters: Trish Walker (Rachael Taylor), a talk-radio host who is Jones\u2019s only friend, and Jeri Hogarth (Carrie-Anne Moss), a ruthless lawyer who helps Jones when it aligns with her own agenda.\n\nIn the first five episodes of Season 2 (an atypically small number for Netflix to provide for review), that triumvirate is even more central to the plot. And their portrayals have taken on new shades. Already isolated \u2014 none has children or a spouse \u2014 they are defined even more than before by their pain and rage and their desperate efforts to assert control over their lives. Jones is an emotional cripple unable to confront her past; Hogarth\u2019s monomaniacal focus on her career leaves her unprepared to face mortality. The relatively well-adjusted Walker is an abuse victim and recovering addict who can\u2019t commit to a relationship.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd in spelling out these issues, the show inverts some familiar situations and characterizations. We\u2019ve seen a powerful person\u2019s downward spiral play out in a room with multiple hookers, cocaine and embarrassing dancing, but that person usually isn\u2019t a woman. We\u2019ve seen protagonists whose bottled-up anger turns them sullen, violent and heedless of others, but they\u2019re usually men. We\u2019ve seen the heroes of mystery-thrillers worry about their investigations putting loved ones in danger, but heroines not so much. (Conversely, traditional roles are preserved in a plot element involving Walker\u2019s past as a child star that explicitly invokes #MeToo.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThese depictions are interesting to parse and refreshing to see. But a clich\u00e9 is still a clich\u00e9, whether it\u2019s presented from a female or male point of view. And the early episodes of the season make a lot of room for fairly static character development, with proportionally less attention paid to the traditional genre pleasures, like atmosphere and action, which were central to the first season\u2019s invigorating noir-superhero synthesis. (The noir part of the equation is still present, but dimly, in Jones\u2019s occasional voice-overs and in a preponderance of detective work that\u2019s pretty basic and arbitrary, a step or two above Googling when it isn\u2019t simply Googling.)", "title": "Review: \u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 Returns, Well Timed for the Time\u2019s Up Moment", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The World War I drama \u201cJourney\u2019s End\u201d is an old-fashioned movie from a well-worn source, the play by R.C. Sherriff, who fought in the war himself. The first movie version, directed by James Whale with Colin Clive, opened in 1930, a year before their immortal work in \u201cFrankenstein.\u201d The new film\u2019s air of stodgy nobility resembles that of \u201cThe Four Feathers\u201d (1939), one of many movies for which Mr. Sherriff wrote the screenplay.\n\nThe scene is 1918 in the north of France. British units take turns rotating into the front lines, where a German attack is imminent. A newcomer, Raleigh (Asa Butterfield), has pushed to serve under Captain Stanhope (Sam Claflin), his sister\u2019s sweetheart, danger notwithstanding. Osborne (Paul Bettany), a father figure in the company who insists that the men call him \u201cuncle,\u201d warns Raleigh that he\u2019ll find the shell-shocked Stanhope changed.", "title": "Review: \u2018Journey\u2019s End\u2019 Returns a Play About World War I to the Screen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "MONTCLAIR, N.J. \u2014 The Chilean-born artist and director Alejandro Jodorowsky is most famous nowadays for \u201cEl Topo\u201d and \u201cThe Holy Mountain,\u201d a pair of mind-melding, mystico-absurdist westerns that lit up midnight screenings worldwide in the early 1970s. Mr. Jodorowsky is a singular character, to say the least, but a few years before making those films, in the mid-1960s, he more than met his match in Leonora Carrington, a painter, sculptor and writer who had hobnobbed with the likes of Max Ernst.\n\nTheir first encounter kicks off the Double Edge company\u2019s trippy show \u201cLeonora and Alejandro: La Maga y el Maestro,\u201d part of Montclair State University\u2019s Peak Performances series. Jodorowsky (Carlos Uriona) is here depicted as an apprentice on a quest, looking like a hybrid of psychedelic magician and glam-rock shaman in platform boots and a long black robe \u2014 an outfit not unlike the one he wore in \u201cThe Holy Mountain.\u201d He is nervous entering Carrington\u2019s home in Mexico City, where they both lived at the time. \u201cThat morning I washed my hands three times more than you normally do,\u201d he says. \u201cI could not decide which was more courageous: to stay here or to leave without saying anything.\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018Leonora and Alejandro\u2019 and One Rather Trippy Encounter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHere\u2019s a question no New Yorker wants to hear, especially not late at night, hissed by a stranger: \u201cAre you a bitch or a pussy?\u201d\n\nBe careful how you answer. But not that careful. Once she hears your response, that stranger is going to reach into her basket and hand you an appropriate pair of felt dog or cat ears. And then, like it or not, you are going to put them on.\n\nThis all happens at the Flea Theater, which after hours transforms into Bitchfield Animal Shelter, the home of Catya McMullen\u2019s \u201cLocked Up Bitches,\u201d a 90-minute musical adapted from a series of playlets. (Yes, Catya is her real name.) Bitchfield is an all-female, no-kill, no-spaying, treat-giving, onsite-grooming-available kind of place, but as several musical numbers tell us, this is one bad animal control center. And it\u2019s getting worse. The dogs are starving out the cats, and a couple of sphynx supremacists are pushing for total war. How will Pipsy, a purebred spaniel lured here by her duplicitous feline girlfriend, survive?\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you have ever insisted that 2018 is definitely not too late for an oddly slavish interspecies parody of the first season of \u201cOrange Is the New Black\u201d; if you have ever fantasized about a soft-core \u201cPaw Patrol\u201d; if you have ever hoped for many more jokes about canine vaginas, then sit. Stay.\n\nOtherwise, this is not exactly a walk in the park. \u201cLocked Up Bitches\u201d originated at Serials @ the Flea, so while it wears its vulgarity like a rhinestone-studded collar, too many of the same crass jokes repeat, and the episodic plot pulls in too many directions. Ms. McMullen and Scott Allen Klopfenstein have supplied some original music, but most of the songs are set to familiar tunes like \u201cDream On\u201d and \u201cThriller.\u201d The playwright has not strained herself over the lyrics, pretty much all unpublishable. There\u2019s certainly nothing here to rival Peggy Lee\u2019s \u201cHe\u2019s a Tramp,\u201d still the apogee of shelter-set ballads.\n\nBut the actors are enjoying themselves. Because, while the material could be funnier and a lot less derivative, under Michael Raine\u2019s loosey-goosey direction, it\u2019s brash, bratty and unabashed in its embrace of queer sexuality. (\u201cPrison Heat\u201d? Try a whole prison in heat.) Have you lived this long without witnessing a dog orgy? Woof. There it is.", "title": "Review: \u2018Locked Up\u2019 and in for a Ruff Night", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe title of \u201cMaineland,\u201d Miao Wang\u2019s new documentary, is a pun whose awkwardness seems deliberate. It combines a reference to the world\u2019s most populous country, the People\u2019s Republic of China, with the name of a sparsely peopled American state. The visual contrast between the two places is striking, and symbolic of the cultural differences that are the film\u2019s subject.\n\nThe China that Ms. Wang depicts is a megalopolis of gleaming skyscrapers and breakneck economic growth. Maine moves at a slower pace. It\u2019s a landscape of woods and quiet lakes, with a few buildings nestled among the hills, notably the dormitories and classrooms of Fryeburg Academy, a private school founded in 1792.\n\nVideo\n\nAs the school\u2019s admissions director explains during a trip to China to interview applicants, Fryeburg, which has both boarding and day students, depends on the tuition paid by the parents of foreign students. In the past, those pupils (and that money) came mostly from Japan and South Korea, but since the end of the 2008 economic crisis, China has emerged as a leading exporter of ambitious teenagers from affluent families.\n\nTwo of them \u2014 Harry and Stella \u2014 are the focus of Ms. Wang\u2019s astute and absorbing film. Their time at Fryeburg changes them in subtle ways. They adjust to some degree to life in America and to the individualistic ethos of American education, but the experience also affirms their sense of Chinese identity. They arrive carrying the baggage of parental expectations, and assert their own contrary desires and ambitions in a spirit of negotiation and compromise rather than rebellion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Wang, whose previous feature is the sensitive and elliptical \u201cBeijing Taxi\u201d (2010), is less interested in explaining than in listening and observing. \u201cMaineland\u201d takes up a large and complicated set of topics \u2014 the global economy, the shifting relations between East and West, the commodification of American education \u2014 and addresses them with understated delicacy. Harry and Stella and their friends may be part of an important social and demographic trend, but they\u2019re also kids: shy, smart, silly, thoughtful and self-absorbed.\n\nPhoto\n\nTheir interactions with the Mainers at Fryeburg are sometimes uncomfortable and sometimes comical, as efforts at cross-cultural communications tend to be. It\u2019s sometimes hard to judge how successfully the Chinese students have been integrated into the daily life of the school. They tend to stick together, and to be regarded with a curiosity that sometimes verges on suspicion. A sign in a common area of one building declares it an English-only zone, which could be interpreted both as an encouragement to develop social and language skills and as an alienating, hostile gesture.\n\nBut good will and hard work are the prevailing values of \u201cMaineland.\u201d The portmanteau title maps out a patch of common ground defined by the understanding that education is a path to worldly success. It can be more than that, of course, and the movie hints at complications that are all the more intriguing for remaining largely unstated. One of the dogmas of American schooling is the importance of critical thinking, a slogan dutifully cited by Chinese applicants to Fryeburg in their interviews.", "title": "Review: \u2018Maineland\u2019 Considers America With Help From Chinese Students", "authors": ["A. O. Scott"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "This is not the kind of piece that waits for an invitation to enter. It\u2019s cavorting to spry klezmer as soon as the house lights dim and it rarely loses its sense of madcap urgency. The setting is ostensibly a century ago, but the title is borrowed from a 2015 comment by Stephen Harper, then the Canadian prime minister, who drew a distinction between refugees and \u201cold stock Canadians.\u201d\n\nSo while Ms. Moscovitch is writing about the past, she is also addressing mass migrations today and the people and countries who would oppose those migrants. A few of the play\u2019s grimmer stories recall today\u2019s emergencies.\n\n\u201cOld Stock\u201d is overwritten, the book and lyrics both. It\u2019s alternately sentimental and lewd (those greased weasels) and strains too hard for universality, spelling out its metaphors in marquee lights. \u201cWe all, sometimes, pound on the door, hoping to be let in, even if it\u2019s the door to \u2026 the human heart,\u201d Mr. Caplan says.\n\nStill, it succeeds. A near catastrophe teaches Chaim and Chaya to care for each other, and it teaches us to care for them, too. The play is a reminder \u2014 salutary, obvious \u2014 that there\u2019s a face behind each immigration form, a history attached to each petition for asylum.\n\nMs. Moscovitch is Chaim and Chaya\u2019s direct descendant. That she exists at all means it\u2019s not spoiling much to tell you that \u201cOld Stock\u201d ends in a cavalcade of numbers \u2014 Chaim and Chaya have so many children, so many grandchildren, so many great-grandchildren. Ms. Moscovitch\u2019s own son is one of the great-greats. That\u2019s a lot of babies. A lot of tangos. So many lives made possible because a young man and a young woman, hounded from their first homes, found a country humane enough to take them in and let them build another.", "title": "Review: \u2018Old Stock,\u2019 an Immigrant Love Story Set to Klezmer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cPersonal Problems\u201d contains not a single shot that can be called beautiful, but there\u2019s also not a genuinely wrong-footed view in the whole work. It\u2019s as if the camera is negotiating with reality, trying to find a place at the characters\u2019 tables. The viewer gets a wide window into African-American life in New York at this time; it\u2019s intimate to the point of awkwardness. The title derives from what Ms. Brown, who works as a nurse (and is brought to spectacular, unaffected life by Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor, the groundbreaking culinary anthropologist and writer) says in an onscreen interview at the opening of the work. Reflecting on her place in the city relative to South Carolina, from where she came, and how she related to a patient who came in with a bullet wound who was also from that state, she goes on: \u201cOf course everybody\u2019s got their own personal problems so you go home, you got the problems of home \u2026 I\u2019m tense, a lot of the time.\u201d The tensions are such that anyone can understand them, but this work is also about how the added dimension of being black in America increases stress.\n\nThis is hardly a humorless examination though. At a lunch, a group of women gossip snarkily; one recounts of a friend, \u201cShe said \u2018I\u2019m doing office work now,\u2019 guess what, she means she was cleaning offices.\u201d There\u2019s a boisterous, querulous argument in the back room of a bar between characters played by Mr. Reed and Kip Hanrahan, the recording artist and musical impresario; Mr. Hanrahan\u2019s white radical posture generates no small amusement. The movie shows the personal as political while never overtly insisting on the point.", "title": "Review: \u2018Personal Problems,\u2019 a Look at African-American Life in 1980 New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "The C.I.A. digs the novel and posted a review on its website, which suggests it would also approve of the movie\u2019s politics (United States good, Russia bad); humorously, the agency did warn that the sex was explicit and \u201cthe Russian characters are not as nuanced as their U.S. counterparts.\u201d (The violence onscreen is, as with most mainstream movies, blunter and more attentively staged and filmed than the sex, which is ho-hum decorous.) The Russians are about as movie-real as the American characters, which mostly just means that they\u2019re types fleshed out with recognizably human detailing and all the polished professionalism \u2014 and the slight, detached irony \u2014 that comes when you hire smooth veterans like Charlotte Rampling, Jeremy Irons and Ciaran Hinds.\n\nThey\u2019re welcome company, as is the rest of a cast that includes Joel Edgerton as Nate, a C.I.A. operative in Russia whose cover is blown soon after the movie opens. He\u2019s working with a Russian intelligence insider called Marble, a meaty bone that the Americans are gnawing on. (Nate\u2019s colleagues include a roundup of yammering, evidently spineless bosses in the States and a few colleagues in the field played by Sakina Jaffrey and Bill Camp with stern faces and wit.) While Nate takes care of American business, Dominika is forced deeper into the Russian intelligence apparatus, a two-track narrative that finds him fighting for credibility while she trains to become a Motherland prostitute.\n\nDominika\u2019s part of a cohort that is decorously called sparrows, though she speaks angry truth to power when she accuses her uncle of sending her to \u201cwhore school.\u201d Filled with pretty young things \u2014 all equally exploitable women and men \u2014 this is a suitably grim academy supervised by a severe matron who could be the daughter of Rosa Klebb, one of James Bond\u2019s most memorable adversaries. A diminutive operative with a knife in her shoe, Klebb (an indelibly ferocious Lotte Lenya) appears in the Cold War-era film \u201cFrom Russia With Love.\u201d Part of what\u2019s both queasily provocative and instructive about \u201cRed Sparrow\u201d is that while Dominika might have been a Bond Girl in an earlier time (or, really, just in the next flick), here she\u2019s allowed to go full-on Klebb.", "title": "Review: \u2018Red Sparrow\u2019 Has Spies, Lies and Dirty Dancing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "I think \u201cRise\u201d wants to be that kind of show. But its first 10-episode season, starting Tuesday, is proof that wanting alone does not make a thing so.\n\nIts first problem is stage center. Lou Mazzuchelli (Josh Radnor), a dispirited English teacher, talks his way into taking over the school drama department. He has no experience \u2014 unlike the colleague, Tracey Wolfe (Rosie Perez), he blithely steps over \u2014 but he has a big ambition: putting on \u201cSpring Awakening,\u201d the rock musical about teenagers in sexually repressed 19th-century Germany.\n\nLou\u2019s character was controversial even before the show was screened. The series is based (like \u201cF.N.L.\u201d was) on a nonfiction book, \u201cDrama High,\u201d by Michael Sokolove, about Lou Volpe, a high school drama teacher in Levittown, Pa., who came out as gay late in life. Mr. Katims renamed Lou and reimagined him as a married straight man with kids.\n\nI can\u2019t know if Lou would work better if Mr. Katims hadn\u2019t taken that liberty. I do know that Mr. Radnor is not convincing \u2014 or he is, but in the wrong ways.\n\nLou has supposedly taught in Stanton for 17 years, yet he interacts with everyone as if he\u2019s just stepped off the bus. He seems blindsided, for instance, that the conservative small town he\u2019s taught in for a generation might resist a school play that involves incest, abortion and a kiss between boys.\n\nThe character has a priggish self-seriousness that worked for Mr. Radnor when he starred in \u201cHow I Met Your Mother\u201d as Ted, whose emo intensity the show tweaked lovingly.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn \u201cRise,\u201d it\u2019s confusing. Lou comes across as well-meaning but full of himself, like Mr. Schue in \u201cGlee.\u201d (Like that show, \u201cRise\u201d also involves the ruse of recruiting a football player \u2014 Robbie, played by Damon J. Gillespie \u2014 as a singer). The performance cues you to see Lou as blinded, maybe a little ridiculous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the show, especially early on, treats him as a heroic inspiration. This dissonance with his character makes \u201cRise\u201d feel at times like someone remade \u201cWaiting for Guffman\u201d in the manner of \u201cDead Poets Society.\u201d\n\nThe young cast is good to terrific, and \u201cRise\u201d is better the closer it gets to the kids\u2019 stories. Lilette (Auli\u2019i Cravalho) waitresses alongside her mother to pay the household bills. Simon (Ted Sutherland) is wrestling with his sexual identity, which becomes doubly fraught when Lou casts him as a character with a male love interest, outraging Simon\u2019s conservative Catholic family. Ellie Desautels is remarkable as Michael, a transgender boy with a knockout voice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are a lot of stories to interweave here. (I found myself confusing two characters until one helpfully got a nose ring.) The shaky pilot takes the group from reluctant performers to a cohesive unit implausibly fast. But the cast sells the offstage drama, and the musical snippets are transporting.\n\nThe other global issue is how \u201cRise\u201d stacks the deck dramatically. Lou\u2019s opponents are almost all portrayed as craven, repressed or philistine for preferring that the school produce \u201cThe Pirates of Penzance.\u201d The major exception is Tracey, whom Ms. Perez plays as a passionate pragmatist.\n\n(It\u2019s also a little rich for NBC to air a show about a town being too provincial for \u201cSpring Awakening,\u201d a show that it\u2019s hard to imagine the network mounting uncensored for its December musical.)\n\nBut more often, \u201cRise\u201d sees Stanton through Lou\u2019s perspective, which ranges from bleak to condescending. \u201cI wanted to send a message to the people of Stanton,\u201d Lou says when the production is in jeopardy. \u201cWe see you. You\u2019re not forgotten.\u201d The town is shot in drained color, as if it\u2019s cloudy even on sunny days.\n\nI wouldn\u2019t expect \u201cRise\u201d to be neutral about free expression or closed-mindedness: Works of fiction naturally tend to be pro-art. But without seeing its antagonists as full people \u2014 the expansive empathy that defined \u201cF.N.L.\u201d \u2014 it has little to add to a familiar story of artists vs. censors.\n\nIn the second half of the season, \u201cRise\u201d becomes more vibrant, less dour. It starts to challenge and leaven Lou\u2019s self-absorption, and both character and story make more sense. It even shows a sense of humor when Lou has to rewrite a profane lyric to meet community standards. (\u201cTotally hosed\u201d is one variant he tries.)\n\nThis version of \u201cRise\u201d works better, and the finale gave me the right kind of chills. I could imagine the series coming into its own in future seasons (presumably involving other productions and challenges).\n\nBut a stage production can go through weeks of rough rehearsals, and none of it will matter if it works out the kinks by the premiere. With \u201cRise,\u201d you have to sit through the growing pains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou might do that if, like me, you find that this is the sort of show essentially engineered in a lab for you to want it to succeed. But the best version of this high school musical will have to come, if it does, in its second act.", "title": "Review: \u2018Rise\u2019 Is No \u2018Friday Night Footlights\u2019", "authors": ["James Poniewozik"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The music is a backdrop for a gripping, often brutal story of the struggles of a girl growing up poor in Queens. Ms. Adams delivers a compassionate performance as a girl whose swagger and practicality hides a melancholy edge. Stardom changes her life, but less than you\u2019d think. Early scenes show Lolita resorting to petty crime to support her family and butting heads with her strict mother (Nia Long), a compelling character who could use more screen time.\n\nAnd then there\u2019s a small galaxy of men that disappoint or abuse both mother and daughter. As her older love interest, Mahershala Ali gives a silky performance with ominous undertones that never turns into caricature. The scenes between him and Ms. Adams are charged, filmed with a patient if herky-jerky pacing. Some shots linger longer than necessary. At other times, Mr. Larnell cuts quickly, shifting from a shot of sex to pregnancy in a blink.\n\nYou get a sense of the film\u2019s dramatic priorities from the first scene. Roxanne paces the streets preparing for a rap battle as a crowd of friends trail her. From the look on her face, you can tell she\u2019s formidable, and when she faces off against a guy who scoffs at her, you wait for the virtuoso performance. But then the film cuts away.\n\nDon\u2019t worry: There will be rap battles and concert scenes and they do not disappoint. But they are the bass line beat.
