(Like the movie, this review needs better wordplay.)", "title": "Review: \u2018Sherlock Gnomes\u2019 and the Search for Better Wordplay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSummer in the Forest\u201d is an extraordinarily tender documentary that asks what it means to be human. Here, even the most gentle scenes raise mighty questions.\n\nIn the 1960s, Jean Vanier founded L\u2019Arche, a community near Paris that has become home to many men and women with developmental disabilities. The filmmakers follow Mr. Vanier, now in his 80s, as he lives and works with those who have Down syndrome and other conditions.\n\nThough Mr. Vanier provides some background in his comforting voice-over, we mostly survey L\u2019Arche residents as they go about their lives. Decades ago, it was a radical experiment to remove those with disabilities from institutions. But by doing so, Mr. Vanier says, they have greater freedom and can prompt those without disabilities to redefine what is considered \u201cnormal\u201d and \u201chappy.\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018Summer in the Forest\u2019 Captivates With Questions of Humanity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "A number of executives have built wildly successful careers optimizing the creative and financial potential of a single brand. Some of them, like Dan Lin, whose Lin Pictures is responsible for exploring the creative possibilities of Legos, are a new breed of executive who combine creative and financial chops. Others, like the Academy Award-winning screenwriter Akiva Goldsman, who has been charged with turning Hasbro\u2019s toys into a film franchise, are established industry figures who have reinvented themselves to align with the times.\n\nThe portrait of Hollywood that emerges is one in which the power of stars and directors has been usurped by writers/producers whose expertise is brand exploitation. A single producer will manage a cinematic universe across properties, but directors and actors are swapped in and out as economics and professional idiosyncrasies dictate. When Terrence Howard demanded more money for Iron Man\u2019s first sequel, he was quickly replaced by Don Cheadle. The six Spiderman movies since 2002 have grossed almost $5 billion with three different starring actors and directors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStudios, for their part, increasingly focus on a relatively small number of established franchises. The rest of their slate is filled with mid-budget films financed by others from whom the studios extract a fee for marketing and distribution. Although Mr. Fritz seems to suggest that something profound has been lost culturally in these shifts, I was left feeling this new industry configuration is preferable for both shareholders and viewers. Everyone is worse off in a world where the \u201chot\u201d star or director of the moment can force a studio to fund their latest vanity project.\n\nThe strength of the narrative and reporting in \u201cThe Big Picture\u201d is not matched by equally trenchant judgments and predictions. Mr. Fritz\u2019s observations, both aesthetic and financial, are often unconvincing and unnecessarily hyperbolic \u2014 particularly in contrasting the contemporary film and television businesses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI have not attempted to watch all of the new original scripted TV series \u2014 it would be more than a full-time job \u2014 but what I have seen makes me skeptical of Mr. Fritz\u2019s assertion that \u201cmost\u201d of them are \u201cinteresting, sophisticated and made for intelligent adults.\u201d He repeats the canard that Netflix has magical powers to pick hits. As evidence, he points to Netflix\u2019s awareness of how previous Kevin Spacey and David Fincher films had performed on its platform to justify the $100 million bet on \u201cHouse of Cards.\u201d Mr. Fritz does not share the talismanic algorithm that led Netflix to spend almost as much on the disastrous \u201cMarco Polo\u201d series. In television, as in film, if you count only the hits, everyone is a genius.\n\nMr. Fritz claims that \u201ca new economics of film\u201d has emerged in which dependable funding will come from \u201csubscriptions to video services, wireless packages, and free product shipping.\u201d He expresses confidence that this model \u201cwill flourish\u201d indefinitely producing \u201cas many and perhaps more\u201d movies than ever alongside the apparently limitless flow of new series.\n\nHistory has shown, however, that even the deepest pockets eventually tire of being emptied. As long as there are no structural barriers to creating new entertainment content \u2014 or investing to establish the next great branded franchise \u2014 the quest for sustainable superior returns will remain elusive. As a result, the future of entertainment \u2014 with a rotating cast of hapless investors embracing a shifting set of new and improved strategic imperatives \u2014 is likely to look a lot like the past.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Big Picture\u2019 Chronicles a Changing Entertainment Industry", "authors": ["Jonathan A. Knee", "Book Entry"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "From \u201cRoger & Me\u201d to \u201cAn Inconvenient Truth,\u201d documentaries have shown that they can be great tools for spreading awareness, even on complicated topics that don\u2019t lend themselves to visual storytelling. But in the case of \u201cThe China Hustle,\u201d a documentary may simply be the wrong delivery mechanism for a byzantine expos\u00e9 that cries out for detailed news reporting.\n\nWith a rapidly paced barrage of talking heads and TV clips, the director Jed Rothstein makes his case: After the financial crisis, investors turned to Chinese companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. But skeptics say those assets show signs of being overvalued.\n\nIn one of the best sequences, Dan David, a founder of GeoInvesting, which investigates U.S.-listed Chinese companies, explains how \u2014 using calculations and surveillance that the film describes as illegal in China \u2014 he determined that a fertilizer company could not be producing as much as it claimed. If or when these stocks crash en masse, the movie argues, the result, like the burst of the housing bubble, will hit Americans\u2019 pension funds.", "title": "Review: \u2018The China Hustle\u2019 Warns of Dicey Investments", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "A mixture of song, dance and journalistic narratives, \u201cThe Fall\u201d reminds us that even the most cohesive movements are made up of disparate parts that will never entirely mesh. People being people, no two are entirely similar or even entirely compatible. In union, inevitably, there are fissures as well as strength.\n\nThat each cast member is such a compellingly specific presence is a blessing and a necessity. (They are Ameera Conrad, Cleo Raatus, Oarabile Ditsele, Sihle Mnqwazana, Sizwesandile Mnisi, Tankiso Mamabolo and Zandile Madliwa.) For many of their characters\u2019 shared scenes \u2014 particularly those portraying the increasingly contentious meetings among the protest\u2019s organizers \u2014 they come across as little more than the sums of their political points of view and social backgrounds.\n\nThe variety of sexuality-based perspectives alone is dizzying and embraces several stripes of feminism, beleaguered African manhood, and nonbinary and transgender \u201ccadres.\u201d The resulting clashes of opinion will be familiar to anyone who has been following the gender conflicts on campus in the United States.\n\nFurther divisions arise from the characters\u2019 geographic and financial origins, and even from the differences in their skin tones. The debaters\u2019 doctrinaire arguments, as uncomfortable and tedious as such conflicts tend to be, are contrasted by the portrayal of those moments when they all unite in acts of physical protest.\n\nThese include not only the removal of Rhodes\u2019s statue but also marches against Afrophobia \u2014 and the killings of African nationals (mostly non-South Africans) \u2014 and a university boycott over student tuition fees and debts. A gathering before the Parliament building in Cape Town ends with police forces using tear gas and stun grenades on the protesters.\n\n\u201cThat day,\u201d one of the students remembers, \u201cfor the first time I witnessed how little our lives matter as black people.\u201d American audience members will no doubt hear echoes of similar sentiments spoken with damning frequency in their own country.\n\nVideo footage of the real-life events described here is projected intermittently. But the rushing momentum of what happened, both scary and exhilarating, is most evocatively conjured by the details of first-person reminiscence. When Rhodes\u2019s statue is at last hoisted, it is momentarily suspended above the plinth, \u201clike he wasn\u2019t sure if he should get off or not; it looked like his ghost was fighting back.\u201d", "title": "Review: \u2018The Fall\u2019 Delivers Stirring Protest in South Africa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith its leggy white tulips, literal primrose paths and stalks of violet delphiniums stretching to the sky, Les Quatre Vents, the Canadian estate of Frank and Anne Perkins Cabot is a tribute to the glory of horticulture in all its forms \u2014 at least all the forms the Quebec climate will permit.\n\n\u201cThe Gardener,\u201d directed by S\u00e9bastien Chabot, relies on previously recorded narration by Mr. Cabot, who died in 2011. Mr. Cabot refers to himself as a \u201cmaster plagiarist\u201d for purloining ideas from gardens he visited on his travels to Nepal, European cities and India, and employing them at home. The result is a dazzling series of separate outdoor scenes that open onto one another, with each framing a view of the next, or the St. Lawrence River beyond. The sights are enchanting, especially when the camera lingers on the Japanese garden, which was years in the making, or the charming pigeonnier, or the Chinese moon bridge set on a reflecting pond.\n\nVideo\n\nExperts discuss Mr. Cabot\u2019s achievements in conserving other gardens and his philosophy in building his own, but the insights of Raynald Bergeron, the head gardener at the estate, who speaks only briefly, seem most authentic because he is closest to the earth.\n\nSome original music and a few well-worn classical choices accompany the natural beauty. Although Mr. Cabot says he planned his plantings with the \u201cjoy of discovery\u201d and the emotional impact in mind, overall \u201cThe Gardener\u201d is flat and lacking in soul, a word that comes up many times in the movie. And the revelation of how rarely the average human gets to share the pleasures of this sprawling paradise \u2014 just a few days each summer \u2014 deepens this disappointment.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Gardener\u2019 Cultivates the Wealth of Nature", "authors": ["Helen T. Verongos", "S\u00e9bastien Chabot"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI\u2019m not generally one for nostalgia, but I do regret the loss of a certain kind of craziness that used to flourish in movies \u2014 the kind that is on rich and ripe display in \u201cThe Great Silence,\u201d a 1968 Italian western by Sergio Corbucci that is only now receiving a proper theatrical release in this country.\n\nThere is something about the film\u2019s brazen mixing of incompatible elements that defies categorization, imitation or even sober critical assessment. It\u2019s anarchic and rigorous, sophisticated and goofy, heartfelt and cynical. The score, by Ennio Morricone, is as mellow as wine. The action is raw, nasty and blood-soaked. The story is preposterous, the politics sincere.\n\nIn 2018, it\u2019s possible \u2014 and perhaps inevitable \u2014 to view \u201cThe Great Silence\u201d as a footnote to the oeuvre of Quentin Tarantino, whose admiration for Corbucci is well documented. Corbucci\u2019s 1966 western \u201cDjango\u201d was an inspiration for Mr. Tarantino\u2019s \u201cDjango Unchained,\u201d and \u201cThe Hateful Eight\u201d shares a snowbound aesthetic and a gleeful commitment to cruelty with \u201cThe Great Silence.\u201d The scholarly minded viewer can trace other connections and divergences as well \u2014 to classic American westerns and to the contemporaneous and better-known work of the spaghetti maestro Sergio Leone.\n\nVideo\n\nBut this plate of pasta \u2014 bitter and pungent, nourishing and perhaps a bit nauseating \u2014 should be savored on its own. It takes place at the end of the 19th century in \u201cSnow Hill, Utah,\u201d a place name that sounds infinitely more exotic in Italian. There, farmers have been driven off their land and forced into banditry, leaving them at the mercy of bounty killers, the most fearsome and sadistic of whom is played by Klaus Kinski.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis character \u2014 referred to as Tigrero aloud and Loco in the subtitles \u2014 is a whispering sociopath and a symbol of the Darwinian brutality that governs Snow Hill. The actual governor wants to bring the area under the rule of law, and dispatches a bumbling, decent sheriff (Frank Wolff) to bring Tigrero and the rest of the bounty killers into line. The lawman\u2019s earnest efforts are a sideshow to the main drama, though, which pits Tigrero and his minions against a solitary avenger known as Silenzio.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Great Silence,\u2019 a 1968 Spaghetti Western Unchained", "authors": ["A. O. Scott", "Vittoriano Petrilli", "Mario Amendola", "Bruno Corbucci", "Sergio Corbucci"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt\u2019s never a good sign when a movie racks up its first ironic music cue before there is anything to be ironic about. \u201cThe Strangers: Prey at Night\u201d opens with the \u201980s rock classic \u201cKids in America\u201d by Kim Wilde, I guess because some of the masked rampaging killers in this movie are youngish, and are in America.\n\nThis is a follow-up to \u201cThe Strangers,\u201d an exercise in sadism from 2008 that got some respect from folks who, I believe, were yearning a little too hard for a subtext feast along the lines of \u201cThe Texas Chainsaw Massacre.\u201d\n\n\u201cPrey at Night\u201d follows an unhappy family \u2014 Christina Hendricks as mom, Martin Henderson as dad, Bailee Madison and Lewis Pullman as their discontented teens \u2014 to a trailer park for an overnight stay that turns into slaughter. There\u2019s a lot of low-lying fog before the masked killers come a-calling, and a lot of arterial stab wounds after they show up.\n\nThe film, directed by Johannes Roberts, shamelessly lifts from several better horror movies. To give you an idea of how low I\u2019m setting the bar in terms of \u201cbetter,\u201d one scene simultaneously cribs from the no-budget Southern cult film \u201cThe Mutilator\u201d (1984) and the ultra-gory and occasionally goofy Italian shocker \u201cZombie\u201d (1979).\n\nVideo\n\nIf you recognize those films, you might find yourself mildly diverted by this tawdry, occasionally effective shock-delivery device. Watching it with a demonstrative crowd in a Times Square theater proved to this former grindhouse devotee that sometimes you can go home again, at least momentarily. That said, the movie\u2019s ludicrously drawn-out finale sapped the good will out of some of my fellow audience members. \u201cThat movie should be rated \u2018D\u2019 for \u201cDumb,\u201d one of them groused on the way out of the theater.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Strangers: Prey at Night\u2019 Delivers on Its Title", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny", "Ben Ketai"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe biggest name attached to \u201cThe Terror,\u201d a new series on AMC, is that of the executive producer Ridley Scott. And the show has some Scott trademarks. It\u2019s about a dangerous expedition to what might as well be a distant planet (unless you\u2019re an Inuit) \u2014 the Canadian Arctic in the 1840s. And along the way there\u2019s a monster that hides in the shadows and picks off the crew in a notably violent and bloody manner.\n\nCreated by David Kajganich, a screenwriter (\u201cA Bigger Splash\u201d) and former wilderness guide, the show does not, unfortunately, display Mr. Scott\u2019s ruthless talent for putting the viewer\u2019s guts in a knot. \u201cThe Terror,\u201d which begins its 10-episode run on Monday, is like many polar expeditions: long, educational, full of interesting things to look at and not completely successful.\n\n\u201cThe Terror\u201d is based on a best-selling 2007 novel by Dan Simmons, which was in turn based on the fate of the Franklin expedition of 1845. In one of the great mysteries of the Victorian age, John Franklin\u2019s two ships, the Erebus and the Terror, were sent to find the Northwest Passage and vanished along with their 129 men.\n\nOver the next half-century, search parties found skeletal remains, interviewed Inuit witnesses and pieced together the story: Caught by pack ice and stranded for two straight winters, the survivors set out to walk hundreds of miles to the nearest outpost, but all died far short of the goal. The wilderness of sea, ice and barren land where they spent their last few years was so remote that the wreckage of the ships was not found until 2014 and 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Terror\u201d doesn\u2019t just make do with this already fascinating, though admittedly downbeat, story. It adds that monster, a spirit animal that\u2019s part polar bear, part Mack truck, known as the Tuunbaq. The beast is there both for supernatural-thriller jolts and for mystical-philosophical weight \u2014 it\u2019s the manifestation of the unknown and savage, a point the show\u2019s later episodes drive home pretty heavily.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Terror,\u2019 or \u2018Alien\u2019 in the Arctic", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFeelings run deep and menacing in \u201cThe Workshop,\u201d an intimate and timely film from the French director Laurent Cantet, about a group of young adults enrolled in a summer writing class in the South of France. Only this isn\u2019t the lavender-scented idyll of Provence or the gleaming luxury of the Riviera; the setting is La Ciotat, a port town that has gone from its midcentury glory days of building ships to its current slot in the global economy, servicing yachts. The students are a diverse bunch of working-class locals; the teacher, Olivia, is a famous novelist, brought in from elsewhere to help them write a book together that has to take place in the town.\n\nThe class differences between teacher and students are so pronounced that they threaten to plunge the film into a schoolhouse drama \u2014 that well-worn genre in which a charismatic authority figure, inevitably likable yet inevitably tough, gains her students\u2019 grudging respect and eventual trust. (Mr. Cantet also directed \u201cThe Class,\u201d a moving yet unsentimental film about a teacher and his young charges in one of Paris\u2019s poorer arrondissements.)\n\nBut Marina Fo\u00efs\u2019s performance as Olivia pulls off a delicate balancing act. Even as Olivia emerges as a complicated character \u2014 an accomplished novelist with sympathy for her students as well as a surprisingly perverse imagination \u2014 she never quite sheds her remote cosmopolitan sheen.\n\nVideo\n\nOlivia\u2019s good intentions keep running aground with Antoine, the workshop\u2019s gadfly and troll, played with taut intensity by Matthieu Lucci, in a bracing debut. While the other students propose a thriller based on La Ciotat\u2019s proud shipbuilding past, Antoine repeatedly goads them with his casual racism and violent fantasies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe see a lot of Antoine \u2014 in class, at home, goofing around with his friends, swimming in the cove \u2014 but the smart, canny screenplay by Mr. Cantet and Robin Campillo takes care not to make him more explicable to us than he is to himself. In the workshop, Antoine gives a resolute performance as a disaffected young man; in the rest of his life, he seems to be drifting. More than caustic anger, he emanates uncertainty and confusion.", "title": "Review: \u2018The Workshop\u2019 Plunges Into a Class Divided", "authors": ["Jennifer Szalai", "Robin Campillo", "Laurent Cantet"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen characters with names like Dancing Dan and Good Time Charley are out looking for scratch or ladling rock candy and rye, odds are good that you are reading Damon Runyon. A journalist with the soul of a mythmaker, Runyon wrote about the exotic fauna of Broadway around the area he called \u201cthe Roaring Forties,\u201d with its two-bit bootleggers and natty bookies, its fast-talking gangsters and softhearted broads.\n\nRunyon, who died in 1946, made up quite a bit of his flowery vernacular, and his prose can now be as opaque as the language of a lost tribe. Take a line like \u201cDancing Dan is a guy with no Barnaby whatever in him, and in fact he has about as much gizzard as anybody around,\u201d which is cryptic to most modern readers \u2014 and may even have been back then. It can be found in \u201cDancing Dan\u2019s Christmas,\u201d a Runyon short story from 1932 that, together with 1933\u2019s \u201cThe Three Wise Guys,\u201d inspired the new comedy, \u201cThree Wise Guys.\u201d\n\nBut what this production from The Actors Company Theater mostly demonstrates is how difficult it is to bring Runyon to life nowadays. (The troupe has announced it is closing shop, after 25 seasons, with this show.)\n\nThe company\u2019s artistic director, Scott Alan Evans, teamed up with Jeffrey Couchman to combine characters and plotlines from the two stories, and they liberally added flourishes of their own. The titular guys are the charming crook Dancing Dan (Jeffrey C. Hawkins), the bootlegger Blondy Swanson (Karl Kenzler) and the Dutchman (Joel Jones), an aging operator with a taste for gambling.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Christmas Eve 1932, they leave their watering hole in the West 40s to embark on a picaresque journey to Pennsylvania \u2014 these three are always on the run from something or someone. The trip includes a detour to Great Neck, Long Island, where Dancing Dan has been roped in as a guest Santa Claus. Shenanigans ensue.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Runyon was not so much about plot as he was about character and color, something the creators of the 1950 musical \u201cGuys and Dolls,\u201d inspired by his stories, perfectly understood. \u201cThree Wise Guys,\u201d on the other hand, lacks the relish Runyon brought to his larger-than-life creations.\n\nUnder Mr. Evans\u2019s direction, the pace lags and the actors never find that sweet spot between arch formalism and comic abandon. Mr. Hawkins, for instance, needs more of the carefree swagger of a lovable rogue like Dancing Dan, while Dan\u2019s companions recede into the background as failed toughs. At least Victoria Mack efficiently sketches the dancing girl Muriel O\u2019Neill, then the wide-eyed ing\u00e9nue Miss Clarabelle Cobb; John Plumpis also brings just the right amount of urbane menace to the well-heeled racketeer Heine Schmitz.", "title": "Review: \u2018Three Wise Guys,\u2019 Spreading Good Cheer and Stumbling Into Trouble", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The ghost of Angelina Jolie past \u2014 that mesmerizing dark star, to the screen born \u2014 hangs over the new, suitably titled \u201cTomb Raider.\u201d A dreary, inept reboot of the franchise that helped propel Ms. Jolie into global domination (and pop-culture divinity), it stars the talented, badly misused Swedish actress Alicia Vikander as the British adventurer Lara Croft. Sexed down and pumped up, Ms. Vikander certainly looks the role, with flowing hair and a washboard stomach you could play the blues on. She runs, jumps and leaps into this yawning void with grim determination.\n\nThere are many ways for a movie to go wrong, and \u201cTomb Raider\u201d goes wrong in many of the most obvious: It has a generic story, bad writing, a miscast lead, the wrong director and no fun. When you first meet Lara Croft, she\u2019s doing the poor little rich girl thing in London, working as a bike messenger and kick boxing in her off hours. Her globe-traveling zillionaire father (Dominic West) disappeared years ago while chasing down a Japanese goddess of death or some such. Refusing to accept either his death or her inheritance, she ends up taking her daddy issues to Asia.\n\nFirst, Lara runs around Hong Kong, where she hires a cute boozer captain (an underused Daniel Wu) who instantly sobers up and takes her to a mysterious isle. There, she runs and runs some more, dodging danger and villains who are also searching for her father\u2019s mystery goddess. The lead baddie is a cookie-cutter scoundrel, but at least he\u2019s played by Walton Goggins, a skilled mustache twirler (as he regularly proved on the TV show \u201cJustified.\u201d) Looking rather like a midcareer Bruce Dern here, Mr. Goggins oils up his rust-bucket role enough to give it a hint of personality.\n\nVideo\n\nMs. Vikander barely manages to do the same with Lara, a center who can\u2019t hold. An appealing performer who popped off the screen as the enigmatic android in \u201cEx Machina,\u201d Ms. Vikander never settles comfortably into Lara, whether she\u2019s delivering the empty, often risible dialogue or running the movie\u2019s endless obstacle course. She has a trained ballet dancer\u2019s familiar amalgam of silk and steel \u2014 the fluid gestures, the ramrod posture \u2014 and she can move beautifully, as she showed in \u201cEx Machina.\u201d Here, though, she often seems to be trying too hard; at times you can almost see her thinking about the marks she needs to hit. You see the strain, not the play.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd without play, there\u2019s nothing left but franchise fumes. The first \u201cTomb Raider\u201d movies are ridiculous, but they have their minor satisfactions, not least being Ms. Jolie\u2019s badass superbabe. A video game heroine turned media franchise, Lara Croft, with her pneumatic breasts and heavy guns, always came off as an onanistic cartoon for 12-year-old boys. With her amused smile and self-possession, Ms. Jolie seemed happy to strut around in Lara\u2019s shorts and big boots, but she also seemed to be there for her own pleasure, which she made easy for girls (and women) to share. Ms. Vikander doesn\u2019t yet have that kind of self-possession, but one day might.\n\nNo one person deserves all the credit or blame for an industrial product like \u201cTomb Raider\u201d; one place to start griping, though, is with those who signed off on its script. (The writers are Geneva Robertson-Dworet and Alastair Siddons.) The director Roar Uthaug knows how to work on a sizable scale as he proved in \u201cThe Wave,\u201d an amusing nail-biter about a tsunami that sweeps away a Norwegian paradise. But he can\u2019t make \u201cTomb Raider\u201d work on any level or in any location. At times, he seems to be playing with genre, particularly when Lara hits the island and begins pinballing from peril to peril, but the action is leaden, dispirited and finally dispiriting.", "title": "Review: \u2018Tomb Raider\u2019 and the Perils of Blockbustering", "authors": ["Manohla Dargis", "Geneva Robertson-Dworet", "Alastair Siddons"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Kirstein\u2019s taste, often controversial \u2014 he was strongly opposed to both Manet and Matisse \u2014 is a common factor in much of this show. He championed Tchelitchew as well as Nadelman; he had caught the final seasons of the Diaghilev company in Europe and, four years later, brought Balanchine (Diaghilev\u2019s last choreographer) to America. High among the realist artists he praised was his brother-in-law, the painter Paul Cadmus. Paintings by Cadmus and by PaJaMa (a collective name for Cadmus, Cadmus\u2019s lover Jared French and French\u2019s wife, Margaret French) hang on the \u201cTransmissions\u201d walls. One of the people shown is the dancer Jos\u00e9 Martinez, Kirstein\u2019s lover.\n\nAlthough Kirstein made ballet the central part of his vast operation, Nadelman and the photographer Walker Evans (also represented here) were two of the many artists he admired who had no connection to ballet. \u201cTransmissions,\u201d like Kirstein, does not stay in one box. Other photographers here, often depicting dance as Evans did not, are Carl Van Vechten and George Platt Lynes.\n\nThe display of Lynes (1907-55) pictures is where the exhibition most evidently connects ballet to overtly gay art. (The images shown here come from the Kinsey Institute in Indiana, which houses his originals.) Lynes made many intensely poetic studio images of dancers and choreography. They impressed Balanchine in particular with their sense of light, darkness and drama. No less poetically, he was also a pioneer of homosexual photography. His work certainly anticipated that of Robert Mapplethorpe; its imagery and contrasts are often more touching.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you want to see how gay photography can be admirable art and memorable pornography at the same time, start here. One photo shows a nude man whose anus is the focal point; another, not shocking but striking, is a full frontal nude view of the dancer Nicholas Magallanes. Two 1934 Lynes pictures show three male dancers from the all-black cast of the Virgil Thomson-Gertrude Stein opera \u201cFour Saints in Three Acts\u201d recumbent on the floor, calmly nude, intimately juxtaposed. In one picture, they\u2019re grouped with their choreographer, Frederick Ashton, kneeling, elegantly attired in suit and tie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVan Vechten, a complex figure who touched several arts and aspects of society, had been intelligently passionate about ballet since before World War I. His photographs, most dating from the 1940s and \u201950s, are full of information \u2014 but some tip matters decidedly over into the tastelessly tasteful, ego-flaunting, offbeat area known as camp. Although he took pictures in color, they\u2019ve been almost invariably published in his inferior black-and-white reproductions. In \u201cTransmissions,\u201d however, a series of some 800 of his originals are projected on a large screen.\n\nIn several cases, the color makes them far more peculiar. Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin \u2014 British ballet stars central to this era of dance in America \u2014 are shown in a wide range of roles. Seen in close-up, they often look precious, combining lurid hues and aesthetic flamboyance. Dolin is also seen in a number of nude poses, far from full frontal, but startlingly self-dramatizing. This man was famous as one of ballet\u2019s princes? You\u2019d never guess from the poses he strikes when naked here. Van Vechten\u2019s photos are fascinating but quaint: They often accentuate ballet\u2019s glamorous triviality rather than its more profound capacity for drama.", "title": "Review: \u2018Transmissions\u2019 Evokes a Climate (Poetic, With a Chance of Ballet)", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Two takes on the kidnapping of John Paul Getty III (a story that\u2019s more than four decades old), both involving major directors and both starring exceptional actors, are arriving within a few months of each other. Coincidence? Schadenfreude? An insatiable appetite for true-crime dramas?\n\nWhatever the reason, \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d \u2014 the Ridley Scott film starring Christopher Plummer, released in late December \u2014 and \u201cTrust,\u201d the new FX series (beginning Sunday) partly directed by Danny Boyle and starring Donald Sutherland, are different enough that watching both doesn\u2019t feel excessively repetitive.\n\nIf you see \u201cAll the Money\u201d first, though, \u201cTrust\u201d will feel a little anticlimactic. The film was terrific and Mr. Plummer (who replaced Kevin Spacey) was magnificent as J. Paul Getty, the filthy-rich industrialist grandfather of the victim. Based on three of 10 episodes, the series is flashy, intermittently entertaining and ephemeral \u2014 a ghastly event turned into a jazzy satire.\n\nAnd Mr. Sutherland, in the early going, doesn\u2019t make the impression you\u2019d hope for, mainly because the script \u2014 by Simon Beaufoy, Mr. Boyle\u2019s collaborator on \u201cSlumdog Millionaire\u201d \u2014 doesn\u2019t seem to have much of a handle on the senior Getty. The character seesaws from cruel to avuncular to pervy, but we don\u2019t see the connections. He appears to have been conceived as a comic monster (as opposed to the tragic monster Mr. Plummer played), and scene by scene Mr. Sutherland gets all the mileage he can out of that. But it\u2019s more about technique than feeling.", "title": "Review: \u2018Trust\u2019 Is Flashy but Ephemeral", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cU.S. Holocaust Museum Revokes Award Over Rohingya Crisis\u201d (news article, March 8):\n\nThe Holocaust Museum is to be applauded for revoking its human rights award given to Myanmar\u2019s civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who has failed to condemn and possibly stop the mass killings and harsh persecution of the Rohingya minority.\n\nThe Rohingya people are fleeing for their lives by the thousands and live in the most horrendous conditions, just because of who they are. For a leader who herself endured 15 years of house arrest because of her deep convictions of fairness and justice to keep her silence in face of this tragedy is unseemly. The revocation of the award, given to her justifiably at the time, was the right move, since it is no longer deserved.\n\nRACHEL KAPEN\n\nWEST BLOOMFIELD, MICH.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cI Saw Genocide in Slow Motion,\u201d by Nicholas Kristof (column, March 4):\n\nWhen one is lauded for his or her performance, it is incumbent upon that person to continue to earn that recognition so as not to sully the honor. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is greatly disgracing the Nobel Prize that she was awarded for her struggle for human rights in Myanmar.\n\nOther countries are reluctant to directly intervene in the utterly inhumane treatment that Myanmar is perpetrating against the Rohingya, but we could perhaps bring worldwide shame upon her and her government by petitioning the Nobel Committee to revoke her prize. It has never been done, but perhaps it is now time.", "title": "Opinion | Revoking Awards to Aung San Suu Kyi", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "MUNICH \u2014 \u201cWe all want to change the world,\u201d the Beatles sang on \u201cThe White Album,\u201d released in 1968. Half a century later, the legacy of \u201968, its hopes, its dreams and whether it achieved its goals, are still up for debate, here in Germany as in America.\n\nJ\u00f6rg Meuthen, one of the leaders of the far-right Alternative for Germany party, recently insisted that the country must change its \u201cfilthy\u201d and \u201cmorally rotten\u201d course, forged by the generation of left-wingers who came of age in that year of upheavals. The conservative denunciation of the student movement, the peace movement, civil rights and the sexual revolution provides the impetus for an ambitious new theatrical production that explores the contemporary meaning of \u201968.\n\nBilled as \u201can occupation\u201d of the M\u00fcnchner Kammerspiele theater, \u201c1968\u201d is a wild, uneven but often thought-provoking series of eight 15-minute vignettes, conceived and performed by different artists and theater collectives. The Berlin-based architecture group Raumlabor has transformed the Kammerspiele\u2019s main theater into something resembling a university lecture theater, with the audience invited to sit pretty much anywhere it pleases.\n\nThe stage is set, so to speak, for an immersive evening. Two hippies preach \u201clove instead of rockets\u201d in the opening segment, by the director Leonie B\u00f6hm. Three magnetic performers in the German-Ivorian group Gintersdorfer/Klassen proclaim the theories of the post-colonial thinker Frantz Fanon. The director Henrike Iglesias uses a flashy game show format to encourage participation in a discussion about feminism. As the evening wears on, ushers hand out beer in plastic cups.", "title": "Revolution\u2019s the Rage in German Theaters. But Don\u2019t Expect Utopia.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 In looking for a solution, the president has turned his attention to an Obama-era effort to reduce the suspensions and expulsions of minority students. Conservative commentators have argued that relaxing disciplinary rules could let a killer slip through the cracks.\n\nInterference? Yes. Collusion? No.\n\n\u2022 Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee said on Monday that they agreed with U.S. intelligence agencies that Russia had interfered with the 2016 presidential election.\n\nThey differed on the intent: \u201cWe disagree with the narrative that they were trying to help Trump,\u201d said Representative Michael Conaway, the Texas Republican who led the investigation.\n\nThe end of the House investigation comes as the special counsel, Robert Mueller, expands his own inquiry. He is pursuing criminal charges against at least four Trump associates.\n\n\u2022 Separately, a special election in Pennsylvania today has become the latest test of whether Democrats can make inroads in a district that Donald Trump carried handily. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Today\u2019s number: One-fifth\n\nAn estimated one in five adults in the U.S. has at least one tattoo, and tens of thousands of laser removals are performed each year.\n\nA study of the cells in tattooed mice might help improve removal procedures for people.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nStephen Colbert was eager to discuss Stormy Daniels and her \u201c60 Minutes\u201d of fame.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like allowing someone to walk on the wing of an airplane, and in my judgment poses too much of a risk.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Gary Robb, an aviation lawyer, referring to open-sided helicopter tours, like the flight that crashed in New York on Sunday, killing five passengers.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nThailand officially declared today, March 13, National Elephant Day \u2014 or Chang Thai Day \u2014 in 1998.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe country\u2019s national animal, the elephant has always played an important role in Thai society, where it was seen as a symbol of royalty.\n\nPhoto\n\nPractically, the elephant also helped in warfare, harvest and transportation. In Buddhism, Thailand\u2019s predominant religion, the elephant is a symbol of mental strength and frequently appears in allegories and art.\n\nThere\u2019s even a Thai Elephant Orchestra (!), which has been trained to play percussion instruments.\n\nIt\u2019s not completely clear how many elephants live in the country, but in 2006 the number of wild elephants was estimated at 3,000 to 3,700, while elephants in captivity numbered around 4,000. At the beginning of the 20th century, Thailand was said to have had more than 300,000 wild elephants and about 100,000 domesticated ones.\n\nToday, Asian elephants are endangered, with a population of fewer than 50,000 worldwide.\n\nClaire Moses contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 With South Korea taking the lead on brokering a possible U.S.-North Korean summit meeting, Japan is scrambling to be more than a diplomatic third wheel. [BBC]\n\n\u2022 Recordings of the conversation between air traffic control and the pilot of the Bangladeshi passenger plane that crashed in Nepal indicate possible confusion over the runway. (Our correspondent reached the airport shortly after the crash.) [NDTV]\n\n\u2022 Our Southeast Asia correspondent visited Phnom Penh, where around 600 U.S. residents of Cambodian descent have been deported, many directly from prison. The adjustment is jarring, to say the least. Hundreds more may be sent back to Cambodia this year. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The Taliban briefly captured a district in western Afghanistan, and officials warned that the country\u2019s security could further deteriorate in the coming year. [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Is a late-career change worth it?\n\n\u2022 Check-in time hours away? In some cities, you can ditch those annoying bags.\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Do some throwback cooking with a recipe for spaghetti primavera.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cThis is how they lived,\u201d a German high school student visiting a concentration camp whispered. A recent proposal to make visits to Nazi camps mandatory for everyone comes at a time when Germany is grappling with a rise of anti-Semitism.\n\n\u2022 A controversial work by the artist Xu Bing that was pulled from the Guggenheim exhibition \u201cArt and China After 1989: Theater of the World\u201d will return as part of the museum\u2019s permanent collection. The work, \u201cA Case Study of Transference,\u201d is a video documentation of a 1994 performance in which two pigs copulated before a live audience.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Our science team looked at a species of ancient assassins that hunt their own kind. Once thought extinct, pelican spiders are actually thriving in Madagascar, South Africa and Australia.\n\n\u2022 The Olympics may be over, but that doesn\u2019t mean you have to give up your curling obsession.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe reaction to our collaboration last week with The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, was overwhelmingly positive, so we\u2019re doing it again.\n\nEach week, Wordplay\u2019s editor, Deb Amlen, will highlight the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: aubade.\n\nIt was the answer to a clue in last Friday\u2019s crossword: \u201cPoem greeting the dawn.\u201d (It might also be clued as \u201cmorning music,\u201d \u201cMorning song\u201d or \u201cSunrise song.\u201d)\n\nAn aubade (pronounced o-BAHD) can also be a musical composition about the morning. Its counterpart, a poem or song about the evening, is a nocturne.\n\nAccording to the Oxford English Dictionary, the word was first used in 1678 and was adopted by the French from the Spanish word \u201calba,\u201d meaning sunrise.\n\nBen Zimmer, the language columnist for The Wall Street Journal, noted that \u201cA skim of Google Books shows that aubade appeared chiefly in French sources, or French-English dictionaries, until the early 19th century.\u201d\n\nAn example of an aubade would be John Donne\u2019s \u201cThe Sun Rising,\u201d which, if nothing else, shows that the English poet was clearly not a morning person.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith that, we wish you a wonderful start to your day.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles Police Department said, \u201cWe are prepared for anything that arises.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. How young is too young to protest?\n\nThat\u2019s what educators are asking \u2014 and deciding \u2014 across the U.S. as they prepare for what organizers call the National School Walkout in protest of gun violence. Above, a fifth-grade student in Akron, Ohio, holds the name of a victim of the school shooting in Parkland, Florida.\n\nMany districts and schools are tolerating, if not encouraging, participation, but they\u2019re also enforcing age limits.\n\nIn New York City, middle and high school students may walk out of class with parental approval, but elementary school students may not unless a parent or guardian is with them.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Conor Lamb, a moderate Democrat, led by 579 votes over Rick Saccone, a Republican lawmaker and Trump ally, with a few thousand absentee ballots still to count.\n\nThe race became an acid test for the allegiance of working-class voters, attracting millions of dollars from Republican \u201csuper PACs\u201d and from small-donor Democrats across the country. Above, Saccone supporters in Elizabeth, Pa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. \u201cIt\u2019s like allowing someone to walk on the wing of an airplane.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s how an aviation lawyer spoke of rides on doorless helicopters, like the one above before it crashed into the East River on Sunday night, killing five, the deadliest such accident in New York City since 2009.\n\nAviation experts point to startling safety gaps in the fast-growing industry of doors-off photo flights, once reserved for professional photographers but increasingly booked by tourists looking to share stomach-churning pictures on Instagram.\n\nInvestigators are trying to determine the cause of the crash, why pontoons did not keep the helicopter from flipping over and sinking and whether the pilot could have done anything for the passengers afterward.\n\n_____\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\n6. \u201cNonsense.\u201d That\u2019s what Russia\u2019s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, above, called Britain\u2019s allegation that Moscow was to blame for the poisoning by nerve agent of a former Russian spy-turned-double agent.\n\nThe dismissal came after Prime Minister Theresa May said it was \u201chighly likely\u201d that Russia was behind the poisoning of the former spy, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter.\n\nRussia now has more intelligence agents deployed in London than at the height of the Cold War. Our correspondent spoke to some of the powerful expatriate Russians they watch.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Chilean grapes. Mexican berries. Vietnamese dragon fruit.\n\nAs it stands, more than half of the fresh fruit and almost one-third of the fresh vegetables Americans buy now come from other countries.\n\nIs that a bad thing? Our food team tracks how it happened and examines the pros and cons for farmers and consumers.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Trade wars can resemble a game of chicken. (Sometimes, our columnist writes, they even involve chickens.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs pundits fret about how countries might retaliate against President Trump\u2019s tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum, our reporters in China note that it has already moved away from exporting sheets of steel or chunks of aluminum.\n\nIn fact, Beijing is forcing many Chinese companies to close wasteful, polluting factories to fix its economy and clean up its skies. Above, an aluminum-sided F-150 rolls off the assembly line in Dearborn, Mich.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Rex Tillerson, Russia, California: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Charles Mcdermid", "David Scull"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "When Mr. Bignone was handed the reins on July 1, 1982, the military junta that had engulfed Argentina in repression and economic chaos was on its last legs.\n\nMr. Bignone, who had retired from the military in 1981, was asked by the military leadership to succeed Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, who in 1982 led Argentina to embarrassing defeat when British forces repulsed an invasion of the British-held Falkland Islands.\n\nMr. Bignone took over with the stated goal of transitioning to a democratically elected civilian government. On Dec. 10, 1983, he handed power to Ra\u00fal Ricardo Alfons\u00edn, who had been elected in late October.\n\nBefore the transition, however, Mr. Bignone led a methodical process not only to destroy evidence about the dictatorship\u2019s crimes but also to justify its repression. He approved an amnesty that was effectively an effort to shield military officers from prosecution.\n\nMr. Bignone\u2019s convictions in 10 war-crimes trials led to three life sentences and seven sentences of 15 to 25 years. He was also acquitted in one case and indicted in nine others that never went to trial, according to data from the Argentine attorney general\u2019s office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cDeath was left without its last boss: The genocide perpetrator Bignone died,\u201d Hijos, a human rights group that advocates for descendants of the disappeared, wrote on Twitter. \u201cHis family knows the time, the reasons and the location. It can also decide where to bid him farewell. The thousands of families who are Bignone\u2019s victims can\u2019t.\u201d\n\nMr. Bignone\u2019s convictions and sentences marked a stark shift in how Argentine society regarded him. He had once been seen as the most benevolent member of the military junta because he had led the transition to democracy, but he came to be reviled when his key role in the darkest chapters of the dictatorship became clear.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bignone was sentenced to prison for the first time in April 2010 after being found guilty of torture and killings as the head of the Campo de Mayo military base, where illegal detention centers had held thousands.\n\nHe had also led the military takeover of the Posadas Hospital in Buenos Aires Province, where another illegal detention center was set up.\n\nIn 2016, Mr. Bignone was sentenced for his role in Operation Condor, a joint effort by right-wing dictatorships in the region to track down dissidents.\n\nHe never expressed regret for his crimes. In a memoir, \u201cThe Last De Facto\u201d (1992), he sought to justify the actions of the juntas.\n\nHe did so again before being sentenced in 2010, saying that there had been an \u201cirregular war\u201d underway in Argentina at the time and that the armed forces \u201chad to get involved in the fight to defeat terrorism.\u201d\n\nReynaldo Benito Bignone was born on Jan. 21, 1928, in Mor\u00f3n, Buenos Aires Province, and entered the Military Academy at 19. He went on to become general secretary of the Army and was named head of the Military College months before the 1976 coup that ousted President Mar\u00eda Estela Mart\u00ednez de Per\u00f3n.\n\nArgentina\u2019s Defense Ministry stripped Mr. Bignone of his military rank in October 2014.\n\nHe is survived by two of the three children he had with his wife, Nilda Raquel Bel\u00e9n Etcheverry, who died in 2013.", "title": "Reynaldo Bignone, Argentina\u2019s Last Military Dictator, Dies at 90", "authors": ["Daniel Politi"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "It was a sign that Rita Prats had recently eyed with intrigue while walking down Second Avenue in Manhattan: \u201cPlaza Prayers for Lent.\u201d\n\nOn the morning of Good Friday, she decided to follow its instructions, grabbing a pen and purple ribbon from the available box. \u201cThis one is for my older brother, Alfredo, who died yesterday,\u201d she said, as she wrote. \u201cI just want to thank him for the wonderful things he did during his life, and just how much he enjoyed his life.\u201d\n\nMs. Prats, 52, of East Harlem, then tied her purple ribbon to one of the many handrails and short birch trees outside of the Church of the Epiphany, an age-old Roman Catholic church in Gramercy Park, joining thousands of others before her who, for the last four weeks, have turned the church\u2019s outside plaza into a public display of deeply felt love and loss.\n\n\u201cMany cities, like Paris and London, have something like this, but New York City doesn\u2019t. You\u2019d get a summons if you did this anywhere,\u201d Ms. Prats said, nodding to the ribbons behind her. \u201cIt\u2019s a public expression that\u2019s missing in this city, where we can say our hopes and feelings. People really need that.\u201d", "title": "Ribbons of Hope and Prayer Fill a Manhattan Sidewalk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "I have a theory about why even experienced cooks are intimidated by plain rice. Cooking rice is mysterious in the same way as baking a cake. There are proportions you need to stick to religiously, a cooking process that you can\u2019t see, and a rest period during which you can only cross your fingers and hope for the best. It\u2019s all an act of faith where you trust heat, time and a particular ratio of liquid to rice and have no control over the outcome.\n\nBut once you nail down a basic rice formula \u2014 and you can \u2014 you regain control. For me, every new rice dish is a controlled experiment in which I play with variables like flavor and method, and adjust the formula accordingly.\n\nIn recent years, for example, my rice has often been migrating to the oven, and cooking in a baking dish rather than a pot. I do this when I want a large surface area, either underneath or on top of the rice, in which I can embed flavors in all sorts of interesting ways. On one occasion, I braised two heads of garlic and a dozen shallots in lots of olive oil before adding the rice and slowly baking it with curry leaves. Another time, I covered the large surface of the baked rice with thin \u201ctiles\u201d of feta, placed it under the grill and then finished off with a sweet and salty garnish of pomegranates, walnuts, olives and herbs.", "title": "Rice, Coming Off the Sidelines, Becomes a Centerpiece", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "(There were some naysayers, however. One, Murray Gell-Mann, an American physicist and future Nobel laureate, postulated in 1964 that such a thing as a quark might indeed exist. Perhaps fittingly, he was the one who gave the particle its name, taking it from a line in James Joyce\u2019s \u201cFinnegans Wake\u201d: \u201cThree quarks for Muster Mark!\u201d)\n\nDr. Taylor shared the 1990 Nobel with two physicists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Jerome I. Friedman and Henry W. Kendall, who had also worked on the experiments at SLAC alongside Dr. Taylor.\n\nDr. Taylor believed that many others deserved to share in the prize as well, among them Wolfgang K. H. Panofsky, the director of SLAC from its founding until 1984. He had been the driving force in getting the accelerator built and oversaw it at a time when four different experiments performed there would lead to Nobel Prizes.\n\n\u201cThere were 20 of us named on that experiment,\u201d Dr. Taylor said in a 2008 interview with the Nobel Institute, referring to their work on deep inelastic scattering. \u201cThere were, like, 40 of us who built that apparatus, backed up by another 40 engineers and technicians, using an accelerator that is built by a thousand people.\u201d\n\nA science prize given to even more recipients, he said, would \u201cacknowledge that it is not the work of an individual person, but a huge group of people.\u201d\n\nRichard Edward Taylor was born on Nov. 2, 1929, in Medicine Hat, Alberta, the son of a Canadian father (whose own parents had immigrated from Northern Ireland and Scotland) and an American mother (a daughter of Norwegian immigrants).\n\nWhen he was young, Richard wanted to be a surgeon, but while in high school he lost the forefinger and parts of the middle finger and thumb on his left hand after accidentally blowing up a chemistry lab in his basement at home. He recalled that a surgeon said to him at the time, \u201c \u2018People aren\u2019t going to come to a surgeon without fingers.\u2019 So I had to give that up.\u201d He switched to science.", "title": "Richard E. Taylor, Nobel Winner Who Plumbed Matter, Is Dead at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAfter the storm we decided to increase our involvement with the event and double our budget for it because other organizations had backed out,\u201d Mr. Mille said. \u201cSt. Barth is undoubtedly one of the most financially strong of the Caribbean islands but it still needs help to get back on track. Increasing our sponsorship of the regatta is one way of showing that we are there, whether times are good or bad.\u201d\n\nLoyalty to its partners is a recognized aspect of the Mille philosophy. It has longstanding agreements with, for example, Rafael Nadal, the tennis star; Felipe Massa, the Formula One driver; Pablo Mac Donough, the polo legend and Bubba Watson, the golfer.\n\nMr. Mille doesn\u2019t deny there is an important commercial side to the brand\u2019s involvement with St. Barth, where it opened a boutique two years ago.\n\n\u201cI think any high-end watch brand must operate in different universes,\u201d he said, \u201cand sailing perfectly combines the sporting universe with the idea of a luxury lifestyle, so our support of it gives a very good signal in terms of positioning.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt also gives Peter Harrison, chief executive of the brand\u2019s Europe, Middle East and Africa operation, the opportunity to have some serious fun. A passionate sailor, he has succeeded in combining business with pleasure as the helmsman of the brand\u2019s own racing yachts, the latest of which will compete in St. Barth next month.\n\nInitially, he and his handpicked crew competed in Jolt2, a good-looking, quick but not especially competitive Baltic 45 class yacht built by the Finnish yard Reichel. Mr. Harrison then upgraded to Sorcha, $750,000 worth of TP52 class yacht, a thoroughbred racer requiring only the lightest of winds that was made in Spain by Longitud Cero.\n\nNow Team Richard Mille has gone one step further.\n\nThe final touches are being completed on the brand\u2019s latest boat, a Mini Maxi 72 class yacht by Green Marine in Britain. In the hands of previous owners, the boat, using the name Ran, won the inaugural world championship for its class in 2010.\n\nRenamed Sorcha, she is to appear at St. Barth with a crew of 22 and will be instantly recognizable by her sails, which display a giant image of a Richard Mille RM60-01 Regatta watch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe hand-drawn graphic added $30,000 to the boat\u2019s purchase price, the total which Mr. Harrison wouldn\u2019t reveal, saying only that the boat would have been around $4 million when new and requires an annual budget of $1 million to race and maintain.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no doubt that it is an expensive sport to participate in, but it gives us a great deal back,\u201d Mr. Harrison said. \u201cUnlike going to a Formula One race where spectators can\u2019t get behind the wheel or meet the drivers, people can get aboard the race boats, meet the crew and learn how everything works \u2014 and it\u2019s hard to beat for visual entertainment.\n\n\u201cAs to whether or not it translates directly into sales of our regatta watches, that I don\u2019t know \u2014 but we feel we get very good value out of the association,\u201d he added.\n\nOne person you won\u2019t find aboard Sorcha as she skims the waves in St. Barth is Mr. Mille himself. He prefers classic motor racing \u2014 and suffers severe sea sickness.", "title": "Richard Mille, St. Barth, Watches and Racing Yachts", "authors": ["Simon De Burton"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "He also played major roles in the preservation of the United States Custom House in Lower Manhattan and what became the South Street Seaport.\n\nIn the 1970s, he helped negotiate the development of Battery Park City on landfill from the construction site of the World Trade Center. He also conceived a plan for selling air rights over the Museum of Modern Art in Midtown Manhattan to a private developer to subsidize the museum\u2019s expansion. The developer built a residential high-rise next door.\n\nMr. Weinstein moved to California in 1985 and became dean of the Graduate School of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of California, Los Angeles. He held that post until 1995 and was a professor emeritus until 2008.\n\nAs dean, he incorporated computer technology and robotics into the curriculum. He also helped select designs for the Walt Disney Concert Hall \u2014 Frank Gehry\u2019s was chosen \u2014 and the new Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels, designed by Jos\u00e9 Rafael Moneo.\n\n\u201cHe was certainly a champion of creating humanity and urbanity,\u201d Mr. Gehry said in a telephone interview on Thursday.\n\nSamuel Richard Weinstein (he was named after his grandfather, an immigrant from Belarus, but apparently switched his first and middle names) was born on Nov. 30, 1932, in Manhattan to Herman and Lillian Weinstein. His father was in the garment business.\n\nAfter graduating from the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, he earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in experimental psychology from Brown University and a master\u2019s in clinical psychology from Columbia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile administering psychological exams at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, Mr. Weinstein was captivated by several houses in the capital area designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. He began taking correspondence courses in architecture.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe later enrolled in an architecture program at Harvard but found it stifling and transferred to the University of Pennsylvania, where he received a master\u2019s degree in architecture in 1960.\n\nIn 1961, he won the Prix de Rome for architecture, and he later worked for the architectural firms of I. M. Pei and Edward Larabee Barnes.\n\nMr. Weinstein joined the city government after campaigning for Mr. Lindsay in his successful run for mayor in 1965. His new colleagues included visionaries like Donald H. Elliott, who became the chairman of the City Planning Commission, and Jaquelin T. Robertson, Jonathan Barnett and Myles Weintraub, who, along with Mr. Weinstein, became founding members of the Urban Design Group.\n\nAs director of the Office of Planning and Development for Lower Manhattan from 1968 to 1974, Mr. Weinstein persuaded David Rockefeller and other downtown bankers to buy air rights that preserved the buildings that later formed the South Street Seaport, now a popular tourist attraction.\n\nHis work in creating special zoning for the Lincoln Square neighborhood around Lincoln Center and the theater district helped preserve and promote their unique cultural characteristics and encouraged the construction of more theaters.\n\n\u201cIn New York, while everyone watches politicians playing politics as usual, the planners and lawmakers are making a new kind of city possible through a new kind of zoning,\u201d Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic for The Times, wrote in 1971.\n\nIn a 1994 interview with the Museum of Modern Art, Mr. Weinstein explained what that new kind of zoning demanded when a developer wanted to build beyond what regulations allowed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe completely stopped the practice of granting variances to developers in exchange for increased taxes to the city,\u201d he said, \u201cand took the position that public benefits had to be identified as flowing from the variance.\u201d\n\nFor example, he said, in the theater district, \u201cif a developer wanted to build a building, he had to build a theater in it if he wanted the variance.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a result of that policy,\u201d he added, \u201cfour theaters were built: the Minskoff, the Uris, the Circle in the Square and the American Place Theater \u2014 two experimental theaters and two Broadway theaters.\u201d\n\nWhen Cass Gilbert\u2019s Beaux-Arts custom house (later renamed the Alexander Hamilton Custom House) was about to be carved into courtrooms for federal judges, Mr. Weinstein collaborated with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and others to preserve much of the building\u2019s historic character, including its 1930s murals by Reginald Marsh. He later helped relocate the Museum of the American Indian there from Upper Manhattan.\n\nHe was also a consultant to the National Park Service\u2019s Gateway National Recreation Area in New York Harbor.\n\nMr. Weinstein is survived by his wife, the former Edina Mommaerts; his sons, Nikolas and Alexandr, from his first marriage, to Sandra Cohen; and two granddaughters.\n\nIf his influence was enduring, it was also eclectic.\n\nWhen Mr. Weinstein learned that the city\u2019s Department of Transportation was about to apply a new coat of olive green paint to the Brooklyn Bridge in the early 1970s, he checked with the Smithsonian Institution to determine the bridge\u2019s original color, from 1883.\n\nIt was tan and silver.\n\nThe city has applied that two-tone pattern to the bridge ever since.", "title": "Richard Weinstein, Public-Minded Urban Planner, Dies at 85", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "When right-to-work laws are in place, Democrats up and down the ballot do worse. In presidential elections, we estimate that these laws cost Democratic candidates two to five percentage points in right-to-work counties. Voter turnout also dropped by approximately two points. That is not trivial, especially considering that Hillary Clinton lost Michigan and Wisconsin in 2016 \u2014 two relatively recent right-to-work states \u2014 by less than one percentage point each. We find similar effects at other levels of government. Democrats, for instance, are less likely to win state legislative seats after the passage of right-to-work laws.\n\nWith a weaker labor movement, it\u2019s not just Democratic electoral prospects that suffer. The working class loses, too. We find that the number of state legislators who had previously worked in blue-collar jobs drops sharply after right-to-work goes into effect. These politicians tend to strongly support economic policies preferred by working-class Americans, like a higher minimum wage and a stronger safety net. Right-to-work laws thus undercut political representation for working-class people, a group that is disproportionately nonwhite, and reduce the legislative voice for progressive economic policies.\n\nWhy do unions matter so much to Democrats\u2019 electoral chances and to working people\u2019s political voice? Most people know that unions are big campaign spenders and help turn out voters during elections. But in between elections, unions also help develop political interest and skills among workers who might not otherwise devote much time to thinking about politics. And, on a deeper level, unions shape how working-class Americans perceive their political and economic interests. For all of these reasons, unions have been vital to Democratic electoral success and in ensuring that Democrats, once in office, take the concerns of working people seriously.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, unions and Democrats are attempting to recreate the old winning formula. The A.F.L.-C.I.O.-endorsed Democrat in the 18th District, Conor Lamb, is running on union rights, infrastructure investment and the protection of Social Security, Medicare and the Affordable Care Act. His Republican opponent, Rick Saccone, supports anti-union policies like right-to-work laws. The election next week affords unions an opportunity to show their strength.\n\nBut whatever happens in this one race, revitalizing the labor movement ought to be at the center of the Democratic agenda. Democrats would do well to ban right-to-work laws, as Senator Elizabeth Warren and Representative Brad Sherman have recently proposed. Democrats might consider making it easier for workers to organize and bargain collectively with their employers. Our work suggests that, for Democrats, the old labor anthem had it right: \u201cThe union makes us strong.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Right-to-Work Laws Have Devastated Unions \u2014 and Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSnapchat users noticed an ad that asked whether they would rather \u201cslap Rihanna\u201d or \u201cpunch Chris Brown.\u201d On Thursday, the pop star took to Instagram, a direct competitor for Snapchat, to criticize the ad for making light of domestic violence. Stock prices for Snap Inc., the parent company of Snapchat, sank by 4 percent.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d love to call it ignorance but I know you ain\u2019t that dumb!\u201d Rihanna wrote in a statement, posted to her Instagram Stories. \u201cYou spent money to animate something that would intentionally bring shame to DV victims and made a joke of it!!! This isn\u2019t about my personal feelings, cause I don\u2019t have much of them\u2026but all the women, children and men that have been victims of DV in the past and especially the ones who haven\u2019t made it out yet \u2026.you let us down! Shame on you.\u201d\n\nIn 2009, Mr. Brown was charged in a brutal beating after he hit, choked and bit Rihanna, and tried to push her out of the car. He eventually pleaded guilty to felony assault and received five years of probation.\n\n\u201cThis advertisement is disgusting and never should have appeared on our service,\u201d a spokesperson for Snapchat said. \u201cWe are so sorry we made the terrible mistake of allowing it through our review process. We are investigating how that happened so that we can make sure it never happens again.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. The actress Rita Moreno walked the Oscars red carpet on Sunday in the same black and gold gown she wore to the Oscars in 1962, when she won the statue for best actress in a supporting role for \u201cWest Side Story.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI would think it would tarnish,\u201d Ms. Moreno, 86, told Ryan Seacrest, who was hosting the red carpet broadcast for E!\n\nMs. Moreno \u2014 a Puerto Rican who is one of just 12 people to hold an EGOT (Emmy, Grammy, Oscar and Tony) \u2014 said the skirt was made from a single piece of obi fabric, which is traditionally used to construct kimonos.\n\nSlide Show\n\nThe dress, which was created in Manila, was made strapless for Sunday\u2019s event. And unlike the first time around, she accessorized it heavily, wearing a black headband, a black and gold collar necklace, a chunky bracelet and earrings, as well as elbow length gloves, which she also wore in 1962.\n\n\u201cWait till you see what I\u2019m wearing!!!\u201d Ms. Moreno tweeted late last month.\n\nWhen she accepted her Academy Award more than 55 years ago, she gave only a 15-second speech. Why? She had no clue that she would win, she told Mr. Seacrest on Sunday night. \u201cI was sure it was going to be Judy Garland,\u201d she said. Ms. Garland had been nominated for \u201cJudgment at Nuremberg.\u201d\n\nMs. Moreno now stars in the television show \u201cOne Day at a Time,\u201d a reboot of the 1970s-\u201980s Norman Lear sitcom of the same name.
