Even for Ryan Seacrest, who has been accused of sexual harassment, it was more or less business as usual.\n\nThe red carpet was still a showcase of glamorous fashion and bold attire. Adam Rippon, the Olympic figure skater, showed up in a Moschino harness and Tiffany Haddish wore a pattern gown that referenced her Eritrean roots. Whoopi Goldberg wore heavy boots hidden under a floral Christian Siriano gown, and Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet sported an all-white tuxedo. The actress Rita Moreno, 86, was one of the most talked-about stars of the red carpet, showing up in the exact same dress she wore to accept an Oscar for best actress in a supporting role for \u201cWest Side Story\u201d in 1962.\n\nCheck out the other beautiful and surprising looks of the evening here.", "title": "Rita Moreno, Jennifer Lawrence, Tiffany Haddish and More on the Oscars Red Carpet", "authors": ["Maya Salam"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Utilizing Barnabas Health Hockey House, the Devils\u2019 practice facility, gives Riveters players amenities, like their own locker room and access to ice time, that weren\u2019t always available when they were based out of Aviator Sports and Events Center at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn during the 2015-16 season.\n\nJohnston, who commutes from the Albany area for Riveters practices and games, joked that driving toward the Rockaways took 10 years off her life (it did, actually eat away at the life span of her car \u2014 Johnston\u2019s engine died before this season, forcing her to replace it).\n\nKetchum was pleased to see conditions in the league pointing upward, particularly after the N.W.H.L. cut salaries in the middle of last season. The improvements have included a more active role by the league\u2019s players\u2019 association and better communication with the league\u2019s commissioner, Dani Rylan.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot more transparency between Dani and her staff and her players,\u201d Ketchum said. \u201cAfter that pay cut last year, we really wanted to see that. That was the most important thing.\u201d\n\nAt one point during the off-season, three of the four original veterans had decided they were going to retire. But as Ketchum, Dosdall and Packer began discussing their competitive void, the band got back together.\n\n\u201cWe all talked at different points and kind of came to the same conclusion at the same time that we were going to do it and come back,\u201d Johnston said. \u201cLike a domino effect.\u201d\n\nIn addition to the original four players, the Riveters are the only team to have employed the same head coach and athletic trainer \u2014 Ashley Robbins \u2014 since their first game. All of the Riveters\u2019 core four credited Wiseman with creating a rigid culture that brought them to the apex of the league, even when they may not always have had the most talented roster.", "title": "Riveters\u2019 Core Four Leads Way to First N.W.H.L. Championship", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "2000\n\nNorth and South Korea Hold Talks\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Il-sung\u2019s son and successor, Kim Jong-il, and the then president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, met in Pyongyang in 2000, the first such summit meeting between the leaders of the two Koreas since a war divided the peninsula 50 years earlier.\n\nThe talks ushered in an unprecedented rapprochement and various joint projects including a factory park in the North Korean town of Kaesong. But the credibility of Kim Dae-jung\u2019s so-called Sunshine Policy was damaged after an investigation revealed that the South Korean government had funneled $450 million to the North shortly before the talks.\n\nMadeleine Albright Visits the North\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Jong-il invited President Clinton to North Korea in 2000. Madeleine K. Albright, the secretary of state, went instead. She traveled to Pyongyang in an effort to expand the Agreed Framework to include ballistic missiles, which North Korea was developing and selling abroad.\n\nClinton administration officials said a deal was close, but nothing was concluded by the time President George W. Bush took office in 2001.\n\n2002 - 2006\n\nA Nuclear Bomb Test\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Agreed Framework collapsed in 2002 after the United States confronted North Korea over its secret program to enrich uranium using equipment from Pakistan. The United States stopped oil shipments to North Korea and Pyongyang restarted its nuclear weapons program.\n\nThe so-called Six-Party Talks continued fitfully between representatives of North and South Korea, China, Russia, Japan and the United States. The North said in 2005 that it would give up nuclear weapons and its existing nuclear programs in return for security guarantees. North Korea carried out its first nuclear test in 2006.\n\n2007 - 2011\n\nSix-Party Talks Collapse\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2007, Kim Jong-il and South Korea\u2019s president at the time, Roh Moo-hyun, held the second summit meeting between the two sides. The meeting produced an agreement aimed at expanding inter-Korean ties and easing military tensions along the disputed maritime border on the west coast of the Korean Peninsula. But the deal came at the end of Mr. Roh\u2019s five-year administration and his conservative successor quickly scrapped it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Six-Party Talks eventually collapsed in 2009, largely over the question of allowing international inspectors into North Korean sites.\n\nThat same year, Mr. Clinton traveled to North Korea and met with Kim Jong-il to secure the release of two American journalists, Euna Lee and Laura Ling.\n\nKim Jong-il died in 2011 and his youngest son, Kim Jong-un took over control of North Korea.\n\n2012\n\nPresident Obama Pursues \u2018Strategic Patience\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Obama administration pursued a strategy of escalating sanctions it described as strategic patience, although meetings between diplomats from the two sides continued.\n\nVideo\n\nAn agreement appeared to be reached on Feb. 29, 2012, under which the North would allow the return of weapons inspectors, and halt its long-range missile and nuclear weapons programs in return for American food aid.\n\nHowever, the deal died soon after when North Korea launched a rocket to put a satellite in orbit, which the United States considered part of its efforts to develop long-range ballistic missiles.\n\n2016 - 2017\n\nTrump Signals Willingness to Talk\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the 2016 presidential campaign, Mr. Trump said he would be willing to hold direct negotiations with Mr. Kim as part of efforts to halt North Korea\u2019s nuclear program.\n\nHe later pushed back against criticism over his willingness to speak with the North Korean leader.\n\n\u201cWho the hell cares? I\u2019ll speak to anybody. Who knows?\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cThere\u2019s a 10 percent or a 20 percent chance that I can talk him out of those damn nukes because who the hell wants him to have nukes? And there\u2019s a chance \u2014 I\u2019m only gonna make a good deal for us.\u201d\n\nAfter the death of Otto F. Warmbier, a University of Virginia honors student who spent 17 months in North Korean captivity, Mr. Trump condemned the \u201cbrutal regime\u201d in North Korea.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStronger Missiles and More Powerful Nukes\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the first year of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency, North Korea tested ballistic missiles with increasingly longer ranges that put the United States within reach. The North also carried out its sixth and most powerful nuclear detonation, which the regime claimed was a hydrogen device.\n\nMr. Trump threatened to assail North Korea with \u201cfire and fury\u201d if the country endangered the United States. Undeterred, North Korea announced it was considering a strike against Guam, where the United States maintains a critical air base, that would create \u201can enveloping fire\u201d around the Pacific island.\n\nTrump and Kim\u2019s War of Words\n\nPhoto\n\nIn his inaugural speech to the United Nations General Assembly, Mr. Trump vowed to \u201ctotally destroy\u201d North Korea if it threatened the United States or its allies. \u201cIf the righteous many don\u2019t confront the wicked few, then evil will triumph,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cRocket man is on a suicide mission for himself,\u201d he said of Mr. Kim in September, having debuted the nickname on Twitter earlier that month. Mr. Kim later called Mr. Trump \u201ca dotard.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s United Nations speech came just days after North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan.\n\n2018\n\nAn Olympic Overture\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo days into 2018, Mr. Trump said American and international sanctions on North Korea prompted talks between North and South Korea \u2014 a prospect raised during a speech made by Mr. Kim on New Year\u2019s Day.\n\nMr. Kim boasted of having a button on his desk from which he could order a strike against the mainland United States. Mr. Trump responded on Twitter that he possessed a \u201cmuch bigger & more powerful\u201d nuclear button.\n\nLater that month, during his inaugural State of the Union speech, Mr. Trump vowed he would not repeat \u201cthe mistakes of past administrations that got us into this dangerous position.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNorth Korea agreed to send a delegation to South Korea for the Winter Olympics last month. The move helped ease tensions between the two sides. Kim Yo-jong, Mr. Kim\u2019s sister, went to Pyeongchang, South Korea, for the opening ceremony.\n\nIvanka Trump, the president\u2019s daughter and a senior White House adviser, traveled to South Korea to attend the closing ceremony. Her appearance came after a failed attempt by South Korean officials to coordinate a meeting between Kim Yo-jong and Vice President Mike Pence at the outset of the Games.\n\nTwo top South Korean officials, Chung Eui-yong, national security adviser, and Suh Hoon, the director of National Intelligence Service, traveled to North Korea this week to meet with Mr. Kim and set the groundwork for the overture to Mr. Trump.", "title": "Road to Talks Between the U.S. and North Korea Has Been Bumpy", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy", "Emily Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "A 1972 gatefold cover for National Lampoon depicted Nixon with a very long nose, one that seemed to run off the page; when the foldout was opened, the rest of the nose appeared, and on the end of it was perched a tiny Henry Kissinger, depicted as Jiminy Cricket.\n\nFor a 2006 Rolling Stone cover, he put the second President Bush on a stool in a corner wearing a dunce cap; the headline beside him read, \u201cThe Worst President in History?\u201d\n\nMr. Grossman also drew President Ronald Reagan in Mickey Mouse ears and Bill and Hillary Clinton in a Stone Age serial called \u201cThe Klintstones.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a 2008 interview with The New York Times, he was asked about the complaint that caricatures of presidents and presidential candidates were undignified.\n\n\u201cUndignified?\u201d he said. \u201cVirtually anything has more dignity than lying and blundering before the whole stupefied world, which seems to be the politician\u2019s eternal role.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRobert Samuel Grossman was born on March 1, 1940, in Brooklyn. His father, Joseph, owned a silk-screen printing shop, Masta Displays, and his mother, the former Ethel Stern, was a homemaker and the shop\u2019s bookkeeper.\n\nAs a child, Robert sometimes attended art classes at the Museum of Modern Art. He graduated from Midwood High School in Brooklyn and received a bachelor of arts degree at Yale in 1961.\n\nWhile at Yale he edited the humor magazine The Yale Record, creating a parody issue of The New Yorker and drawing its spot-on cover, which had the magazine\u2019s name as The Yew Norker. Apparently the real New Yorker did not take offense, because his first job out of college was as an assistant to the magazine\u2019s art editor.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Grossman, though, spent virtually all of his career as a freelance illustrator for hire, and he was hired a lot. He drew more than 500 magazine covers. One of his regular customers was The Times, particularly its Sunday book review section.\n\nSteven Heller, a former art director at The Times and now the co-chairman of the M.F.A. design department at the School of Visual Arts in New York, said Mr. Grossman was one of four artists \u2014 along with David Levine, Edward Sorel and Jules Feiffer \u2014 who found the 1960s and beyond to be fertile ground. Mr. Grossman, he said, gave his work a distinctive look.\n\n\u201cGrossman kind of redefined the genre of caricature by introducing the airbrush as a tool,\u201d Mr. Heller said. \u201cHe gave it a kind of sculptural but at the same time comic form. He gave it shades and gradients that the others didn\u2019t do. And at the same time he also captured likenesses with brilliant precision and great wit.\u201d\n\nMr. Grossman, whose mentors included Harvey Kurtzman of Mad magazine, found a nice niche in the early 1970s when New York magazine gave him a regular space to fill under its weekly politics column.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt was Watergate time and there was much talk about bugs and bugging,\u201d he recalled in an interview with The Atlantic in 2012. \u201cI drew some insects named Haldebug and Ehrlichbug serving their master, the terrifying Richard M. Nightcrawler.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDecades later, during the early days of the 2008 presidential campaign, he would reach back to the very beginning of his career for an inspiration. In the early 1960s he had drawn a black superhero named Captain Melanin.\n\n\u201cIt was the civil rights era,\u201d he said. \u201cSuddenly in early 2007 there was Barack Obama, whose extraordinary poise and charisma seemed to be inspiring messianic hopes in a portion of the population. So it wasn\u2019t hard to imagine for him a secret identity with the ability to fly and to lead stranded whales to safety by walking on water.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe created O-Man, who lived in O-Manland and went up against characters like Milt Rhomboid and Rich Gingnewt. O-Man\u2019s adventures appeared in The New York Observer, then in The Nation, then on a website Mr. Grossman created to continue them.\n\nMr. Grossman was not about to leave the current goings-on in government unremarked upon. He had of late been posting on his website episodes of a strip called \u201cTwump and Pooty,\u201d whose title characters look suspiciously like President Trump and President Vladimir Putin of Russia.\n\nBut for all of his politically oriented drawings, his best-known work might well have been the poster he created for \u201cAirplane!,\u201d a 1980 disaster-movie parody that became a box-office hit. It shows an airplane whose bizarrely flexible front end is tied in a knot.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe also drew the occasional book and album cover and made animated commercials.\n\nMr. Grossman\u2019s first marriage, to Donna Lundvall in 1964, ended in divorce in 1980. His second marriage, to Vicki Anne Morgan, ended in divorce in 1987. In addition to his son Alex, his survivors include his partner of 24 years, Elaine Louie; another son, Michael Jonathan Grossman Rimbaud; two daughters, Leila Suzanna Grossman and Anna Jane Grossman Pedicone; two brothers, James and David; and five grandchildren.\n\nIn a 2008 interview with The Tennessean, Mr. Grossman explained why, of the various jobs that fit under the big tent of journalism, he preferred illustrator.\n\n\u201cReporters labor under the terrible requirement that what they report must be true,\u201d he said. \u201cOpinion writers need to endure the less stringent demand that what they opine be at least plausible. Nobody ever expects what cartoonists do to be either true or even plausible. That\u2019s why we\u2019re all as happy as larks.\u201d", "title": "Robert Grossman, Illustrator With a Brash Touch, Dies at 78", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNASA has been without a permanent leader for more than a year. Now the agency\u2019s temporary leader is leaving, too.\n\nIn an email to the space agency\u2019s employees on Monday, Robert M. Lightfoot Jr., the acting administrator, announced that he would retire on April 30.\n\nMr. Lightfoot said he was leaving \u201cwith bittersweet feelings,\u201d but did not say why he was retiring.\n\n\u201cI cannot express enough my gratitude to the entire NASA team for the support during my career and especially the last 14 months as your acting administrator,\u201d Mr. Lightfoot wrote.\n\nMr. Lightfoot\u2019s impending departure could leave a vacuum at the top of NASA just as a revived National Space Council, which last existed more than 20 years ago, looks to revamp American space policy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe council, with Vice President Mike Pence as chairman, is to coordinate what various agencies, military and civilian, are doing in space. Two priorities are streamlining regulatory processes for space companies and returning astronauts to the moon.", "title": "Robert Lightfoot, NASA\u2019s Acting Administrator, to Retire as Trump\u2019s Nominee Is Stalled", "authors": ["Kenneth Chang"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "That requires a constitutional judgment. Answering strictly legal questions in a potential trial does not resolve the issue of the president\u2019s accountability under the Constitution. Congress\u2019s inquiry can and should be informed by an unfettered special counsel investigation, but it cannot depend on it.\n\nFurthermore, narrowing impeachable offenses to include only violations of law may lead to a constitutional dead end. In opinions issued in 1973 and 2000, the Department of Justice\u2019s Office of Legal Counsel has taken the position that a sitting president cannot be indicted while in office. If Mr. Mueller concludes that the president engaged in criminal conduct but follows O.L.C. opinions in declining to indict him, the president\u2019s legal responsibility will not be adjudicated as long as he occupies the White House. On what basis would Congress then proceed to oust him from office under the legalistic conception of the impeachment power?\n\nMany people assume that the special counsel will report to Congress on the evidence against the president. But the special counsel regulations, unlike the now defunct independent counsel statute, do not clearly mandate or authorize any such report from either the counsel or the deputy attorney general. Congress may be more likely to learn about Mr. Mueller\u2019s work from publicly filed indictments and plea agreements.\n\nAnd Congress cannot rely on the Mueller record alone. Even if Congress made impeachment a legal rather than political process, a president will be quick to argue that he is entitled to a fair adjudication of any criminal charge.\n\nMoreover, the timetables for the two processes are not the same. Congress cannot responsibly defer its task for as long as it may take for lawyers to clash and courts to rule.\n\nA Congress that was serious about meeting its responsibility would neither shirk nor rush a judgment about a president\u2019s impeachable offenses. The House would structure an investigative and deliberative process that it would explain in clear terms to the public. As in 1974 in the Nixon impeachment process, the House Judiciary Committee would review and publish the best constitutional learning on what presidential misconduct rises to the level of \u201chigh crimes and misdemeanors.\u201d It would proceed in the same spirit as its predecessor did when the 1974 committee said that \u201cwhat is said here does not reflect any prejudgment\u201d of the allegations but is \u201cintended to be a review of the precedents and available interpretive materials, seeking general principles to guide the committee.\u201d The Committee would then move to the investigative phase.\n\nAs in the Watergate case, the congressional inquiry would run parallel to the legal process, each benefiting from the other even as Congress took steps as necessary to avoid compromising the criminal investigation. It\u2019s not difficult to imagine a new Mueller indictment spurring the Congress to action. While the special counsel may conclude that he cannot indict the president, the nature of charges against close aides and relatives could support the initiation of an impeachment inquiry. Even in this case, Congress\u2019s task is to carry on its own investigation and to arrive at an independent judgment about whether the president should remain in office.", "title": "Opinion | Robert Mueller Is Not a Superhero", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "In 1967, Robert P. Langlands set out a road map to prove a \u201cgrand unified theory\u201d that would tie together disparate areas of mathematics.\n\nThe conjectures of Dr. Langlands, now 81 and an emeritus professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., have proven fertile ground for mathematical advances in the past half-century. And although his suppositions remain far from fully proven, the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters announced on Tuesday that Dr. Langlands was this year\u2019s winner of the Abel Prize, which many view as a Nobel Prize of mathematics.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a visionary,\u201d said Sun-Yung Alice Chang, a mathematician at Princeton University who served on the five-member prize committee. The panel reviewed more than 100 candidates before selecting Dr. Langlands, Dr. Chang said.\n\nThere is no Nobel Prize in mathematics. (Contrary to myth, that is not because of an affair between a mathematician and Alfred Nobel\u2019s wife. For one, Nobel never married.)", "title": "Robert P. Langlands Is Awarded the Abel Prize, a Top Math Honor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Robert S. Rubin, an investment banker and philanthropist who as the chairman of the Brooklyn Museum deflected Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani\u2019s threat to censure an exhibit he considered sacrilegious, died on Saturday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 86.\n\nThe cause was complications of pneumonia, his son Nathaniel said.\n\nThe show was titled \u201cSensation: Young British Artists From the Saatchi Collection,\u201d and even before it opened in 1999 the mayor denounced it as pornographic and anti-Catholic.\n\nHe was so scandalized by one work, Chris Ofili\u2019s portrait of the Virgin Mary stained with elephant dung, that he sued in state court to remove the museum\u2019s directors and evict the institution from its city-owned Beaux-Arts home. He also sought to slash the annual subsidies that made up about a third of the museum\u2019s budget.\n\nMr. Rubin offered compromises, but the city rejected them, and the museum countersued in federal court, arguing that the mayor was defying the First Amendment.", "title": "Robert S. Rubin, Banker Who Defended Brooklyn Museum, Dies at 86", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019re a fish in the ocean.\n\nIt\u2019s 2023 and humans have begun deploying swarms of sentinel robot fish along the reef where you live that will monitor your environment, track pollution and collect intelligence on your behavior. Welcome to the future, my finned fishy friends.\n\nO.K., so you\u2019re not a fish. And this sci-fi fishland doesn\u2019t exist. But it could \u2014 not long from now.\n\nAllow me to introduce SoFi \u2014 like \u201cSophie,\u201d but short for \u201cSoft Robotic Fish,\u201d revealed on Wednesday in Science Robotics, by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab.", "title": "Robotic Fish to Keep a Fishy Eye on the Health of the Oceans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "His 1955 memoir \u2014 called \u201cThe Four-Minute Mile,\u201d and reissued 50 years later as \u201cThe First Four Minutes\u201d \u2014 amounted to a portrait of the athlete as a young artist. In a typically analytic and introspective passage, he described the moment at which a runner decides to break from the pack and take the lead:\n\n\u201cThe decision to \u2018break away\u2019 results from a mixture of confidence and lack of it. The \u2018breaker\u2019 is confident to the extent that he suddenly decides the speed has become slower than he can himself sustain to the finish. Hence he can accelerate suddenly and maintain his new speed to the tape. But he also lacks confidence, feeling that unless he makes a move now, everyone else will do so and he will be left standing.\n\n\u201cThe spurt is extremely wasteful because it is achieved at the cost of relaxation,\u201d he went on, \u201cwhich should be maintained throughout the race. The athlete\u2019s style and mood change completely when he accelerates. His mind suddenly starts driving an unwilling body which only obeys under the stimulus of the excitement. The earlier in the race this extra energy is thrown in, the greater the lead captured, but the less chance of holding it.\u201d\n\nThe idea at the heart of this passage \u2014 that you must seize the right moment or risk its passing forever \u2014 was very much a factor in Bannister\u2019s record-setting run. Milers had been flirting with four minutes for at least a decade. The Swedish runner Arne Andersson ran a 4:01.6 in 1944; the next year, his countryman Gunder H\u00e4gg sliced two-tenths of a second from the world record.\n\nIt had gone no lower before Bannister toed the starting line at Iffley Road, but it was widely believed that the four-minute barrier was on the verge of falling, and that one of three men \u2014 Bannister, the Australian John Landy and the American Wes Santee \u2014 would bring it down. (Landy became the second to do so; Santee never did.)", "title": "Roger Bannister, First Athlete to Break the 4-Minute Mile, Dies at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Here is his speech:\n\nHey, thank you, thank you. I guess I better say something or else they\u2019ll give me a jet ski and I don\u2019t see myself on a jet ski somehow. I want to share this with my wife of 27 years, James, whatever. I want to share it with Andrew and Broderick and Denis Villeneuve. You know, I \u2014 I really love my job. I\u2019ve been doing it a long time, as you can see. But you know, one of the reasons I really love it is the people I work with, both in front of the camera and behind the camera. Some of my crew on \u201cBlade Runner\u201d I\u2019ve been working with for over 30 years. And others \u2014 others I met for the first time in Budapest and this is for every one of them. Every one of them. In fact, I\u2019ve got to say it\u2019s for us because it was a team. It was really a team effort. Thank you. Thank you very much.", "title": "Roger Deakins Finally Gets His Oscar After 14 Nominations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "INDIAN WELLS, Calif. \u2014 Roger Federer was on the ropes, down two breaks in the second set and another one in the third. Borna Coric thought he was close to toppling the world\u2019s top-ranked player.\n\nNot so fast.\n\nFederer rallied for a 5-7, 6-4, 6-4 victory in the BNP Paribas Open semifinals on Saturday, extending his career-best start to 17-0 and giving him a chance to win his record sixth title at the tournament.\n\n\u201cI went for my shots,\u201d Coric said. \u201cI was not waiting. I made the right choices all the time. He was just a better player in those specific moments. At the end, he just got through.\u201d\n\nBarely.\n\n\u201cI should have lost a match,\u201d Federer said.\n\nHe will meet No. 6 Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro in Sunday\u2019s final. Del Potro breezed past No. 32 Milos Raonic, 6-2, 6-3, in 66 minutes for his 10th consecutive match victory and the 400th of his injury-plagued career. Federer is 18-6 against del Potro, with two of the losses coming at the United States Open, in the 2009 final and last year\u2019s quarterfinals.", "title": "Roger Federer Rallies to Reach the Final in Indian Wells", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSure, it\u2019s a great one,\u201d Federer said of his season so far. \u201cBut you know how it is. You can\u2019t plan for these runs to happen. Either they happen or they don\u2019t. Sometimes you just need a bit of luck to keep the runs going, and this year it\u2019s just been really good, you know, solid matches.\u201c\n\nHe added: \u201cWe\u2019ll see how long it lasts, really. This might be the last day. So we\u2019ll see. It\u2019s just how it goes. Don\u2019t jinx it.\u201d\n\nThe bespectacled Chung had to deal with misfortune of his own making in Australia, developing severe blisters after neglecting to shave down the soles of his feet. He ended up with open sores that required repeated painkilling injections, although those did not prevent him from retiring during the semifinal in Melbourne with Federer leading 6-1, 5-2.\n\n\u201cSeeing the blister after, that wasn\u2019t very nice,\u201d Federer said, looking the slightest bit squeamish. \u201cI can just imagine how much pain there is to it. You kind of want to go out and give it a shot, but then you\u2019re like, I probably shouldn\u2019t. You\u2019re just stuck in a situation which is hard, so I felt for him.\u201d\n\nChung, a 21-year-old South Korean who is up to 26 in the ATP rankings, returned to action in Delray Beach, Fla., three weeks after the Australian Open, and reached the quarterfinals, just as he did at the Mexican Open in Acapulco this month.\n\n\u201cI was honestly quite surprised how quickly he came back, because that thing looked nasty and it takes some time to heal,\u201d Federer said, referring to the blister. \u201cSo I hope he\u2019s O.K. now and didn\u2019t come back too early.\u201d\n\nHardcourt tennis is particularly tough on players\u2019 feet, and Chung\u2019s brand is tougher than most, as he slides in an open stance into the corners like his stylistic role model, Novak Djokovic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s got great range on the court,\u201d said Bob Brett, the veteran Australian coach. \u201cI would assume Roger will do things to break up what Chung is normally used to doing, but that doesn\u2019t mean Chung isn\u2019t going to be ready.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDjokovic was Chung\u2019s boyhood role model, and Chung would play the part of Djokovic when he and his older brother were pretending to play Grand Slam matches in a parking lot near their home.\n\nAt this stage, Federer thinks the parallels with Djokovic are real but limited to aggressive footwork, even if both men changed their service actions in the off-season.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the only similarity I see,\u201d Federer said of their movement. \u201cIt\u2019s not a bad one to have, to be honest, because Novak has maybe the best footwork on hard courts we have ever seen. So it\u2019s just a question for Chung to see that he can maintain that level, with the blister and with injuries over the course of the 10 to 15 years to make sure he stays injury-free and doesn\u2019t get injured three months of the year.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cBut it\u2019s highly explosive; it\u2019s highly impressive what he does, and I think he\u2019s going to be a great player,\u201d he continued. \u201cHow good will still remain to be seen.\u201d\n\nThe elastic Djokovic is still working his way back from a chronic right elbow problem but has managed to avoid major leg injuries, in part by his daily commitment to stretching: a habit that started nearly as soon as he began playing the game in the Serbian mountain resort of Kopaonik.\n\n\u201cPhysicality is obviously a massive part of Hyeon\u2019s game,\u201d said Chung\u2019s coach, Neville Godwin. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely something we have to make sure we maintain and keep working on and staying on top of. Twenty-one is still pretty young in the tennis world, and he wants to play 10 or 15 years, so we have make sure physical blocks are put in place. The younger you can put the right protocols in place, the better you\u2019ll be going forward.\u201d\n\nAfter retiring in Australia, Chung spent 10 days resting at home in Seoul, South Korea, without playing tennis or even doing gym work. He has hired an experienced full-time physical therapist, Alessio Ceccarelli, an Italian who has worked with Francesca Schiavone, Flavia Pennetta, Alexandr Dolgopolov and Elina Svitolina.\n\n\u201cAlessio\u2019s obviously working on the whole body, including the feet, which need to be shaved down every other day with the calluses,\u201d said Stuart Duguid, Chung\u2019s agent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChung has also been using a new shoe orthotic, one that was supposed to hold out for several months but which lasted little more than a week under his punishing style.\n\nBut he has been running and sliding with abandon in Indian Wells. After beating Tomas Berdych, 6-4, 6-4, in the third round here, Chung needed 10 match points before defeating Pablo Cuevas, 6-1, 6-3, on Wednesday.\n\nHe is now in his first quarterfinal in a Masters 1000 event. Federer has won 27 of them and won 97 tour singles titles in total, including his 20th Grand Slam title in Australia. He also reclaimed the top ranking last month, becoming the oldest singles No. 1 in ATP history.\n\nWhen another enduring 36-year-old, Feliciano Lopez, was asked on Wednesday if another man would ever reach No. 1 at that age, he did not hesitate.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d said Lopez, after losing in the fourth round to Sam Querrey. \u201cThere are many things that Roger achieved that won\u2019t happen again.\u201d\n\nFor now, Federer\u2019s priority is defeating Chung, one of the game\u2019s rising stars, for the second time in a row.", "title": "Roger Federer, Riding High, Isn\u2019t Underestimating Hyeon Chung", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Like presidents who are re-elected, Goodell is reshaping his staff for what will likely be his stretch run, according to several people familiar with the shake-up at the N.F.L.\n\n\u201cRoger looked at his executive team and is thinking, I\u2019ve just been awarded a new contract, so who do I want on my team over the next five, seven years?\u201d said one person with knowledge of the promotion.\n\nLeiweke was brought in three years ago to help handle some of the day-to-day work that Goodell was doing. Leiweke, who was once the chief executive of the Seattle Seahawks, was close with Goodell. But he was less visible to the owners, and he did not control any of the major divisions that generate income for the league, most notably the media group, where Turcke worked.\n\nPhoto\n\nLeiweke is just the latest in what is turning into a string of departures. Natalie Ravitz, who was hired as a media specialist, has already left. Joe Lockhart, the league spokesman, is also leaving. Last year, the league offered buyouts to employees at its headquarters, and roughly a dozen people took the offer. Other executives may be eased out of their jobs as well.\n\nThe question for Goodell is how their replacements will help him accomplish his most important mandate from his bosses: increasing the league\u2019s profits. The commissioner\u2019s two biggest challenges are clear: Renew and enhance the bevy of major media contracts that expire around 2020 and 2021, and renegotiate a new collective bargaining agreement with the players\u2019 union before it expires in 2021.\n\nOn that front, promoting Turcke makes sense. She worked for the past year in Los Angeles at NFL Network, which has grown in prominence, even as it copes with a series of sexual harassment accusations. Before joining the N.F.L., she was the president of Canada\u2019s Bell Media, which included television and radio broadcasting and digital media.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLike other leagues, the N.F.L. is trying to figure out how to make more money streaming games and other content over the internet. The N.F.L.\u2019s television ratings have fallen the past two seasons, in large part because younger viewers are more likely to consume sports on their phones or tablets and less likely to subscribe to pricey pay-television services.\n\nDespite the decline in ratings, though, the league continues to get a premium for its product.\n\nIn December, Verizon agreed to pay more than $2 billion over the next five years for the rights to stream games. The league also sold its Thursday Night Football package to Fox for $660 million annually, up from the $450 million it received from CBS and NBC.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs a relative newcomer to the league, Turcke may also have an easier time reshaping some of the league\u2019s departments. As C.O.O., she will run the marketing, communications, human resources, international and events, and technology departments.\n\nOne of the tougher issues she will face may be pushing out longtime employees and hiring replacements \u2014 or not. Some owners have complained that the league office has become too unwieldy, with new departments devoted to investigating players and other employees, another department focused on social initiatives, and a larger public relations profile. Others want to overhaul the league\u2019s constitution to dilute the power of the commissioner.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nobody that doesn\u2019t see the need for changes in the N.F.L. in several areas,\u201d the Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones said. \u201cWe\u2019re doing a lot of things good, but there are some areas we need to change. One of them is an antiquated constitution, an antiquated situation as to the power of the commissioner.\u201d\n\nThe power of the commissioner, of course, includes his subordinates, which is why the departure of the league\u2019s chief operating officer is one of the changes on the way at the league\u2019s headquarters.", "title": "Roger Goodell Begins to Shape a Team for His Stretch Run", "authors": ["Ken Belson", "On Pro Football"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell has won the latest tug-of-war with Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys.\n\nDespite appealing to Goodell for leniency, Jones will have to pay a significant portion of the league\u2019s legal fees, which paid for lawyers to defend six owners that Jones had threatened to sue.\n\nJones will also have to cover the league\u2019s legal costs associated with Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliott, whose appeal of a six-game suspension forced the N.F.L. to argue its case in federal court.\n\n\u201cAfter a hearing with the Commissioner and the Finance Committee, the matter of the reimbursement of legal fees has been resolved to the satisfaction of all parties,\u201d the league said in a statement on Wednesday, without citing any specifics.", "title": "Roger Goodell Forces Jerry Jones to Pay Millions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Besides being the longtime chairman of Penske Corp., which he turned into a transportation empire, Roger Penske has formidable teams in Nascar and in the IndyCar Series. He will have four cars competing in the Indianapolis 500 in May. He has put together a top-level sports car racing program. Oh, and he just celebrated his 81st birthday.\n\nWhen will this guy ever slow down?\n\n\u201cMy wife asks me that every weekend,\u201d Penske said recently in an interview at the New York Stock Exchange.\n\nInstead, he considers his racing enterprises \u201cmy fishing trip and golf game on the weekends.\u201d\n\nThen he laughed and added: \u201cNo, it\u2019s a brand-building exercise. It\u2019s an asset we have among our 56,000 people. We create winners. We have a positive impact on our customers and our brand. As long as I\u2019m able, I want to be connected with motor sports because it\u2019s something we know. We\u2019re in the transportation business.\u201d\n\nAnd racing delivers an immediate bottom line.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like having your quarterly earnings every weekend,\u201d Penske said. \u201cWhen you have your quarterly earnings every weekend, you got to be on top of it.\u201d", "title": "Roger Penske, IndyCar\u2019s Grand Old Man, Shows No Signs of Slowing Down", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "It also dovetailed with the era\u2019s sensibilities. \u201cMovies don\u2019t invent behavior,\u201d said the film historian and Wesleyan University professor Jeanine Basinger, whose many books include \u201cA Woman\u2019s View: How Hollywood Spoke to Women, 1930 to 1960.\u201d \u201cThey reflect behavior. But in reflecting behavior with good clothes and beautiful stars, they begin to define it as cool.\u201d\n\n\u201cI always go back to Valentino,\u201d she told me, referring to the actor Rudolph Valentino and the movies \u201cThe Sheik\u201d (1921) and \u201cThe Son of the Sheik\u201d (1926). \u201cHe carries her off \u2014 it is actually a rape thing \u2014 but it\u2019s couched so romantically. He\u2019s so beautiful and exotic and he sweeps her up on the horse.\u201d Basinger wasn\u2019t endorsing this scenario. She was just describing its presentation.\n\nIn books, there\u2019s a genre called \u201cthe bodice ripper,\u201d and, she noted, \u201cThe woman doesn\u2019t rip her own bodice.\u201d That\u2019s a man\u2019s work. And that idea informs countless movies in which, she said, \u201cThe man is supposed to desire and pursue and the woman is supposed to resist and make demands.\u201d\n\nThat theme persisted beyond \u201cRocky\u201d and the 1970s. For your consideration: \u201cCoal Miner\u2019s Daughter,\u201d 1980. On her wedding night, Loretta Lynn, just a teenager, cries \u201cno, no, no, no\u201d as her older husband wrestles her into submission. The next morning, when he tells her to get used to it and she says that she won\u2019t, he slaps her. It\u2019s not pretty, but it\u2019s a necessary rite of passage \u2014 or so the movie seems to maintain.\n\n\u201cRevenge of the Nerds,\u201d 1984. Fixated on sorority women typically beyond his reach, a college nerd costumes himself so that one of them mistakes him for her boyfriend and has sex with him. When he removes his mask, she\u2019s not appalled at his subterfuge. She\u2019s impressed by his prowess.\n\n\u201cOverboard,\u201d 1987. Dean and Joanna luxuriate in a post-coital embrace. \u201cWas it always like this?\u201d she asks him. He answers, \u201cEvery time with you is like the first time.\u201d It\u2019s a line meant for laughs, because this was the first time: She\u2019s a spoiled heiress suffering amnesia, and he\u2019s a working-class hunk who has duped her into cleaning his house, caring for his kids and sharing his bed by telling her that they\u2019ve long been a couple. From this elaborate ruse comes her ecstatic rebirth. The movie is a romantic comedy.\n\nEach of those episodes has a particular context and justification. None are intended as instructive. But all, I think, would be changed if being filmed today. Time passes, consciousness expands and movies look different in retrospect.", "title": "Opinion | Romance, Rough Sex or Rape?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "BUCHAREST, Romania \u2014 A Romanian court has rejected a man\u2019s claim that he is alive after his wife officially registered him as dead, saying that the decision cannot be reversed.\n\nA spokeswoman for the court told local news outlets on Friday that the man, Constantin Reliu, 63, lost his case in the northeast city of Vasului because he had appealed too late.\n\nThe ruling is final.\n\nLocal news reports on the case said that Mr. Reliu had lost contact with his wife and family when he traveled to Turkey in 1992 for work.\n\nHearing no news from her husband for years, his wife got a death certificate for him in 2016.\n\nThe authorities in Turkey found Mr. Reliu this year with expired papers and deported him. But when he arrived in Romania, he discovered he had been declared dead.", "title": "Romanian Court Rejects Man\u2019s Claim That He\u2019s Alive", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "After the buzzing, marble-strewn congestion of the Forum, the Palatine is like a country stroll. The huge squares of weedy grass and clumps of umbrella pines outlined in brick stubs could almost be farm fields \u2014 but, in fact, most of the stubs are remains of a colossal royal residence, the Domus Flavia, inaugurated by Vespasian and completed by his wicked, wildly ambitious second son, Domitian. Josephus, whose life spanned all three Flavian emperors, would have come to the Domus Flavia to pay homage to his patrons and perhaps murmur a prayer before the sacred scroll they had cached here.\n\nI lingered on the Palatine for half an hour, trying to conjure the nerve center of an empire from its ruins. Somewhere buried under the dandelions and broken shards stood an inlaid niche or marble alcove where the stolen Torah was caged like a captive king.\n\nImage Flavius Josephus Credit Culture Club/Getty Images\n\nJosephus\u2019 footsteps lie closer to the surface in the Templum Pacis. I\u2019d never heard of this monument, though I must have passed its ruins a score of times on the wide glaring Via dei Fori Imperiali (Street of the Imperial Fora) that Mussolini carved out as his own triumphal route between the Colosseum and Piazza Venezia. On my second morning in Rome, Josephus\u2019s text in hand, I stood by the railing near the Forum ticket booth and peered down at the ongoing excavations of the temple\u2019s sanctuary, arcades, fountains and gardens. Josephus notes that the Templum Pacis, built \u201cvery speedily in a style surpassing all human conception,\u201d housed not only the spoils of Jerusalem, but \u201cancient masterpieces of painting and sculpture \u2026 objects for the sight of which men had once wandered over the whole world.\u201d\n\nThese masterpieces have long since vanished, but a wall of the temple still stands at the entrance of the sixth-century Basilica of Saints Cosmas and Damiano, now a Franciscan convent. One of the resident brothers, who humbly insisted on anonymity, showed me around. \u201cThe Templum Pacis was not only a shrine but a kind of cultural center,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re standing on the site of the temple\u2019s library where the Forma Urbis \u2014 an immense marble map of the city \u2014 was displayed.\u201d He pointed out a rusty bent spike that once fixed marble veneer to the rough-hewed stone. \u201cGo ahead and touch \u2014 it\u2019s been here since the first century A.D.\u201d", "title": "Rome, Through the Eyes of Flavius Josephus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 For archaeologists, the excavation of Rome\u2019s newest subway line has been the gift that keeps on giving.\n\nTwo years after a second-century military barracks was found during the excavation of the Amba Aradam station, archaeologists last week presented the remains of a richly decorated domus, or house, that they believe belonged to the commander of the military post.\n\nEven after the discovery of the military complex, \u201cwe didn\u2019t imagine that we\u2019d find a house with a central courtyard,\u201d a fountain and at least 14 rooms, said Simona Morretta, the state archaeologist responsible for the site. One of the rooms appears to have been heated.", "title": "Rome\u2019s Subway Project Keeps Digging Up Archaeological Marvels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In The New York Times Book Review, Kenneth M. Pollack reviews Ronen Bergman\u2019s \u201cRise and Kill First: The Secret History of Israel\u2019s Targeted Assassinations.\u201d Pollack writes:\n\nImage\n\nAmerica\u2019s difficult relationship with targeted killing and the dilemmas we may face in the future are beautifully illuminated by the longer story of Israel\u2019s experiences with assassination in its own endless war against terrorism. Israel has always been just a bit farther down this slippery slope than the United States. If we\u2019re willing, we can learn where the bumps are along the way by watching the Israelis careening ahead of us. Americans now have a terrific new introduction to that story with the publication of Ronen Bergman\u2019s \u201cRise and Kill First: The Secret History of Israel\u2019s Targeted Assassinations.\u201d It\u2019s easy to understand why Bergman\u2019s book is already a best seller. It moves at a torrid pace and tells stories that would make Jason Bourne sit up and say \u201cWow!\u201d It is smart, thoughtful and balanced, and the English translation is superb. It deserves all of the plaudits it has already received.\n\nOn this week\u2019s podcast, Bergman talks about \u201cRise and Kill First\u201d; Felix Salmon discuss Chris Hughes\u2019s \u201cFair Shot\u201d; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; and Gregory Cowles, Tina Jordan and John Williams on what people are reading. Pamela Paul is the host.\n\nHere are the books mentioned in this week\u2019s \u201cWhat We\u2019re Reading\u201d:\n\n\u201cUlysses\u201d by James Joyce\n\n\u201cFrankenstein\u201d by Mary Shelley\n\n\u201cMy Family and Other Animals\u201d by Gerald Durrell\n\n\u201cNot My Father\u2019s Son\u201d by Alan Cumming\n\nWe would love to hear your thoughts about this episode, and about the Book Review\u2019s podcast in general. You can send them to books@nytimes.com.\n\nHow do I listen? Two ways\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.", "title": "Ronen Bergman on Israel\u2019s Targeted Assassinations", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRonnie Franklin, who rode Spectacular Bid to victory in the 1979 Kentucky Derby and Preakness before their Triple Crown try was derailed in the Belmont, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 58.\n\nThe cause was lung cancer, said his nephew, Walter Cullum, who was also a jockey.\n\nFranklin was 19 when he guided Spectacular Bid to victory as a 3-5 favorite in the Kentucky Derby. After winning the Preakness by five and a half lengths, Franklin\u2019s bid to capture the Triple Crown ended in the Belmont Stakes, when Spectacular Bid finished third.\n\nIn the mile-and-a-half race, Spectacular Bid chased a speedy long shot early in the race and tired in the stretch. Franklin was blamed for the loss by the horse\u2019s trainer, who also said the colt had stepped on a safety pin in his stall before the race. But the track\u2019s chief veterinarian, Dr. Manuel Gilman, asserted: \u201cAll I can tell you is what I saw. The horse went out for the race all right and he came back all right.\u201d\n\n\u201cI lacked experience,\u201d Franklin said years later. \u201cI shipped him out of the gate, I should not have done that. Consequently, we were too close to the pace and then I took it up too early. I got him beat.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA week after the race, Franklin was charged with possession of cocaine after an arrest in the parking lot of Disneyland. He struggled with substance abuse in the ensuing years, and was repeatedly denied licenses from state commissions because of his problems.", "title": "Ronnie Franklin, Who Won the Kentucky Derby at 19, Dies at 58", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Jackson, a career Naval officer, appeared in the spotlight this year when he announced the results of Mr. Trump\u2019s first physical while in office. In this first-person account, Anthony Ray Hinton, who was sentenced to death in Alabama for two murders he didn\u2019t commit, describes the book club he created for inmates on death row, and seeing \u2018men be transported in their minds for a small chunk of time.\u2019 \u201d [Longreads]\n\n\u2014 Anne-Sophie Bolon, London-based editor\n\n\u201cThe Chicago Tribune is preparing to move out of the landmark Tribune Tower, which has nearly 150 stones from famous sites embedded in its facade. This visual catalog will take you on a grand tour around the United States, across oceans and through history.\u201d [Chicago Architecture]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Gina Lamb, senior staff editor, Special Sections\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Our Austin bombings coverage, explained\n\nLast week, some readers criticized The Times\u2019s coverage of the suspect in the attacks in Texas, saying we treated him too lightly or humanized him too much.\n\nOur journalists answered some of the most common questions, including how we define terrorism.\n\n\u2022 Bunny best sellers\n\nEaster\u2019s nearly here, and the competition between rabbits is hopping on our children\u2019s picture book best-seller list. He was back on Wednesday with a new impression, of John Bolton.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cTo accept to die so the innocent can live, that is the essence of what it means to be a soldier. Others, even many who are brave, would have hesitated.\u201d\n\n\u2014 President Emmanuel Macron of France, at a memorial for Col. Arnaud Beltrame, who was killed after he took the place of a hostage during a terrorist attack at a supermarket.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBack Story\n\nOn this day in 1961, the ratification of the 23rd Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was completed, giving residents of Washington, D.C., the right to vote for president and vice president for the first time in more than 160 years.\n\n\u201cThe United States finally gave its capital the vote today,\u201d The Times noted on its front page.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe amendment granted representation to the District of Columbia in the Electoral College, where states are given electors based on population. Although the District\u2019s population (estimated around 700,000 in 2017) is larger than that of some states, it is given no more electors than the least populous state, which is currently Wyoming.\n\nAt the time, the push to give the vote to the district, with its large African-American population, became caught up in the civil rights movement. The amendment was opposed by almost every state in the South.\n\nDemocrats have since been able to count on the district\u2019s three electoral votes, which have been cast for every one of the party\u2019s presidential candidates, starting with Lyndon Johnson in 1964.\n\nAlthough the district\u2019s residents have a say at the White House, they lack a full voice in Congress, where their representative does not have full voting rights.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here.\n\nCheck out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Ronny Jackson, North Korea, \u2018Roseanne\u2019: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "All of this matters because, if Dr. Jackson cannot be trusted to act independently when it comes to the president\u2019s mental and physical health, we cannot be confident that he will do so when it comes to the fitness of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The department has the sacred charge of repaying our soldiers for their service by providing them with health care and other support. If Dr. Jackson tells the president \u2014 and the country \u2014 what Mr. Trump wants to hear about his own health, how can we trust him to honestly and rigorously diagnose the ailments of the V.A., and to treat them appropriately?\n\nHaving a candid V.A. secretary is all the more important because the department faces profound challenges. Since 2014, it has dealt with a pattern of negligent treatment at hospitals operated by one of its agencies, the Veterans Health Administration. Outgoing Secretary David Shulkin revealed yesterday that he had fought Trump administration proposals to privatize services provided by the V.A. \u2014 a move that could undermine the quality of health care provided to our veterans. Dr. Jackson\u2019s treatment of the president does not inspire confidence that he will take on the V.A.\u2019s problems with the brutal honesty that the job demands.\n\nDr. Jackson\u2019s nomination is also undermined by the fact that although he is a medical professional, he lacks the management experience that the job demands. The V.A. secretary is responsible for a department that provides health care services to over nine million individuals. While Dr. Jackson has served his country with distinction, both in Iraq and as the White House physician, managing a relatively small medical team is not preparation for leading a vast and sprawling bureaucracy. The V.A. is one of the most complex health care management jobs in the world, and ideally would be run by someone with experience operating hospital systems or health businesses or enterprises, and large ones.\n\nThe nomination fits a pattern of cronyism, with the president appointing those of dubious qualifications to patronage jobs across the administration. The president\u2019s former golf caddy is now the White House social media director. A contractor married to one of the Trump\u2019s former household staff members now has a job at the Environmental Protection Agency. And a longtime friend of the Trump family who has been involved in planning golf tournaments and Eric Trump\u2019s wedding is the head of the New York and New Jersey office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. And now he has appointed his White House doctor to oversee the health care of millions of veterans.\n\nFinally, in addition to concerns about independence and qualifications, it appears that Dr. Jackson had not undergone the normal vetting process for White House presidential personnel. Reportedly, the tweet-from-the-hip nomination of Dr. Jackson by the president surprised even his own advisers. That suggests that Dr. Jackson has not in fact received the careful review that is normally completed before such an announcement.\n\nOne of us worked (just down the hall from Dr. Jackson, actually) on vetting hundreds of senior administration officials. Very presentable and capable individuals \u2014 sometimes even those with existing security clearances \u2014 are sometimes disqualified by the rigorous personnel investigations that are normally undertaken for cabinet positions. Such cabinet-level vets complement but are more thorough than a typical pre-existing security clearance, and can uncover conflicts, misdeeds or other disqualifying information.\n\nWe are not suggesting that vetting will uncover anything improper, but caution is warranted, since many of Mr. Trump\u2019s nominees have had unprecedented conflicts and other issues.", "title": "Opinion | Ronny Jackson\u2019s Disturbing Lack of Independence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "A bomb threat in Austin, Tex., led to an arrest and the cancellation of a Roots concert at the South by Southwest festival.\n\nOn Saturday afternoon, a representative of the event promotion company Live Nation Music called the police to report that a bomb threat had been sent via email. The police scoured the area around the Fair Market venue, where a \u201cBud Light x The Roots & Friends Jam\u201d showcase was scheduled for that evening, and found no threat. But Bud Light opted to cancel the event.\n\n\u201cYour safety and the safety of all fans at SXSW is our most important priority,\u201d the company wrote on Twitter on Saturday.", "title": "Roots Show at SXSW in Austin Is Canceled After Bomb Threat", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "How are you different than during the last run of \u201cRoseanne\u201d?\n\nWell, I\u2019m older, and I\u2019ve been through menopause, so that was great. I\u2019m a grandma now. I\u2019m older and wiser. I appreciate things better, and appreciate having an opportunity at age 65 to come back and do what I love to do.\n\nWhat kind of stories did you want to tell on the new \u201cRoseanne\u201d?\n\nHow families are still struggling and what they do about it. There\u2019s an arc in this season, and it\u2019s the closest I\u2019ve been to doing what I want to do. It\u2019s about everything in our country. It\u2019s about opioids and health care. How we deal with whole new issues that we didn\u2019t even have before, like gender-fluid kids. How working class people \u2014 how and why they elected Trump.\n\nRoseanne Conner has become a Trump supporter. How did that happen?\n\nI just wanted to have that dialogue about families torn apart by the election and their political differences of opinion and how we handle it. I thought that this was an important thing to say at this time.\n\nWas it your idea for Roseanne to back Trump?\n\nYes. Because it\u2019s an accurate portrayal of these people and people like them. In terms of what they think, and how they feel when they are the ones who send their kids over to fight. We\u2019ve been in wars for a long, long time, which everybody seems to forget \u2014 but working class people don\u2019t forget it because their kids are in it.\n\nTrump has had tough words for ABC. Did you get any pushback from ABC about making Roseanne a Trump supporter?\n\nNot from ABC, no.\n\nFrom who?\n\nEveryone else in the world.\n\nWhy do you think?\n\nYou know, people only want to see \u2014 they want to stick to their narrative and they don\u2019t want it shaken up. As it turns out, the women had been looking for her: They wanted to produce a movie based on Ms. Shante\u2019s life as a little-known hip-hop pioneer. \u201cI was like, O.K. these must be some really strong drinks,\u201d Ms. Shante said.\n\nYou can\u2019t blame Ms. Shante for her skepticism. As dramatized in \u201cRoxanne, Roxanne\u201d \u2014 a biopic having its premiere in theaters and on Netflix on Friday \u2014 she endured crushing betrayals after that first blast of success.\n\nIn 1984, prompted by UTFO\u2019s \u201cRoxanne, Roxanne,\u201d about a woman who had spurned that rap trio\u2019s romantic entreaties, Ms. Shante, then 14 and living in the Queensbridge projects in Long Island City, changed her first name from Lolita to Roxanne and released an answer record with lyrics like \u201cIf he worked for me, you know he would be fired\u201d and \u201cHe ain\u2019t really cute, and he ain\u2019t great/He don\u2019t even know how to operate.\u201d The record, \u201cRoxanne\u2019s Revenge,\u201d became a huge hit for Ms. Shante and led to dozens of singles by other artists supposedly telling the real story of Roxanne.\n\n\u201cIn the pre-internet days, that was a meme,\u201d said Alan Light, former editor in chief of Vibe and a contributor to The New York Times. \u201cIt took on a crazy momentum.\u201d", "title": "Roxanne Finally Gets Her Revenge, 3 Decades After Her Hit Single", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe was elite in the game when he was pitching here so from a manager\u2019s standpoint the biggest decision was when do you take him out,\u201d Gibbons said. \u201cThat was always a battle. It was never a good feeling walking on the mound in case he looked at you like: \u2018What are you doing?\u2019\u201d\n\nThe towering right-hander quickly became a fan favorite in Toronto, where he spent 12 of his 16 major league seasons. Halladay won the American League Cy Young Award with the Blue Jays in 2003 and took the National League award with the Phillies in 2010, his first season in Philadelphia.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe signed a one-day, free-agent deal with Toronto in December 2013 to retire as a Blue Jay.\n\nThe club returned the favor Thursday, enshrining him on the Rogers Centre\u2019s Level of Excellence and unfurling a No. 32 banner from the center field rafters to thunderous applause.\n\nA large, round, black-and-white 32 decal was laid flat on the mound for the pregame tribute while four black-and-white photos of Halladay, taken at different points in his Blue Jays career, stood on the infield.
