The penalty will begin on opening day.\n\nBonifacio, 24, made his major league debut last season, hitting .255 with 17 home runs and 40 runs batted in in 113 games.\n\nKansas City was reshuffling its outfield this spring after Lorenzo Cain left as a free agent, and Bonifacio was competing for playing time in the field and at designated hitter.\n\nThe Royals recently signed the free-agent outfielder Jon Jay. Paulo Orlando and several others are also trying to earn spots in the outfield.\n\nBonifacio is the fourth player suspended this year under the major league drug program. Houston pitcher Dean Deetz, Washington catcher Raudy Read and Pittsburgh pitcher Nik Turley were previously penalized.", "title": "Royals\u2019 Jorge Bonifacio Barred 80 Games After Positive Drug Test", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere had to be some credible evidence to convince them that there might have been gold there,\u201d he said, referring to the F.B.I. \u201cThe fact that they got a court order to go in there and do a dig \u2014 that might have been based on some evidence that they had.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat is just creating a mystery in itself,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThe locals are just \u2014 \u2018Did you see that? Wow,\u2019\u201d he added.\n\nIn 1863, according to historical accounts, just before the outbreak of the Battle of Gettysburg in July, the Union army wanted to move dozens of gold bars from Wheeling, W.Va., northeast through Pennsylvania, to pay soldiers. The wagon train caravan went to Ridgway and then on to St. Mary\u2019s, where the idea was to pick up a local guide and then swing over the mountains and onward to Philadelphia, Mr. Burke said.\n\nThe story of the gold bars was pieced together from old documents, a map and even a mysterious note found decades ago in a hiding place on the back of a bed post in Caledonia, Pa., he said.\n\n\u201cThe gold got lost,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was pretty much a wilderness area, and they got wrapped around in the mountains over in Dents Runs or Hicks Run.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSome reports say there were 52 bars, but Mr. Burke said he thought there were 26, with each 14-carat bar weighing 50 pounds, making the trove potentially worth millions of dollars.\n\n\u201cWe have very, very little credible or documented evidence of the gold,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of it is hearsay.\u201d\n\nOver the years, the speculation has turned into action, inspiring treasure hunters. Finders Keepers USA, a Pennsylvania group that describes itself as a treasury-recovery service, has documented its efforts to locate the gold. The owners of Finders Keepers, Dennis and Kem Parada, were at the site when the F.B.I. visited last week, according to a report by WJAC, a television station in Johnstown.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn their website, the Finders Keepers founders, who did not reply to an email on Tuesday, said that they believed they had found the location of the gold but that federal law had prevented them from excavating it. The group, which describes itself as a \u201clocate and recovery service for under ground metal artifacts,\u201d also posted a copy of a 2005 letter from the Bureau of Forestry to the district overseeing Elk State Forest.\n\nIt said Dennis Parada had excavated materials from Dents Run that he believed were related to the Civil War, but on examination they were found to be camp debris, from the 1880s at the earliest, and of no cultural or historical significance. Mr. Parada was banned from further excavations there, but he was permitted to use metal detectors, the letter said.\n\n\u201cI told D.C.N.R. I\u2019m not going to quit until it\u2019s dug up,\u201d Mr. Parada told The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette in 2008, referring to the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources. \u201cAnd if I die, my kid\u2019s going to be around and make sure it\u2019s dug up. There\u2019s something in there and I\u2019m not giving up.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, Terrence Brady, a spokesman for the conservation department, which also sent representatives to the site when the F.B.I. was there, said he had been told not to say anything about the F.B.I.\u2019s excavation.\n\nThe story of the lost gold \u201chas always been on the back burner,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWhat prompted this resurgence of interest with a federal agency?\u201d he added. \u201cIt is a rumor, a story if you will, that refuses to die.\u201d", "title": "Rumors of Lost Civil War Gold Stir Hope in Pennsylvania", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Springsteen, Bette Midler, Lou Reed and Michael Jackson were regular patrons. So was David Chiu, a Brooklyn journalist.\n\n\u201cWhen you walked into the Tower Records store in New York City\u2019s Greenwich Village neighborhood back in the day, you just didn\u2019t go in there to buy an album and then rush off to leave,\u201d he wrote in Cuepoint, an online publication, in 2016. \u201cTo me, going into Tower was like visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art or attending a baseball game \u2014 it required a certain investment of time.\u201d\n\nMr. Solomon told Billboard magazine in 2015: \u201cOur favorite regular was Elton John. He probably was the best customer we ever had. He was in one of our stores every week, literally, wherever he was \u2014 in L.A., in Atlanta when he lived in Atlanta, and in New York.\u201d\n\nIn an interview for this obituary last September, Mr. Solomon recalled that he opened the first Tower Records store in what had been his father\u2019s drugstore with $5,000 in borrowed capital. He called it \u201ca neighborhood business,\u201d which he named after the Tower Theater, a local landmark that was built in 1938 and topped by a neon-bathed, 100-foot Art Deco pillar.\n\nHe soon opened a second Sacramento outlet, but the business did not take off until 1968, when he opened Tower Records in San Francisco. It was an instant sensation in the heart of the hippie and music scene, capitalizing on the 1967 Summer of Love. At 5,000 square feet, the store was small by later company standards, but it set a formula for the future: wide selections and discounted prices.\n\n\u201cI stole ideas from supermarket merchandising,\u201d Mr. Solomon recalled. The store, he said, stacked hot-selling items on the floor, to encourage impulse buying and to suggest plentiful supplies, reinforcing the impression that Tower would be well stocked when competitors\u2019 supplies had run out. The store also set late-night closing hours.\n\nBut the most important innovation, he said, was hiring a staff so well versed in the local music scene that the store could order its own inventory. It was a task that music chains typically assigned to a central office to achieve economies of scale for their outlets. But Mr. Solomon found that local judgments were more profitable, and decentralized ordering became a pattern for all his stores.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe wanted people in the store to run the store \u2014 they\u2019re your strength,\u201d Mr. Solomon said. \u201cCentral buying is just a bad idea. You can\u2019t make decisions on what to do in Phoenix if you\u2019re sitting in New York or London.\u201d\n\nWhile staff wages were relatively low, the workers were given unusual fringe benefits, including parties with live bands and opportunities to mingle with musicians, promoters, record company executives and radio and television personalities, Mr. Solomon said. And in the 1960s and \u203270s, he said, employees were given time off to attend protests against the Vietnam War.\n\n\u201cIt was the right thing to do,\u201d he said. \u201cWe had to be with the scene. It was important to us and to them.\u201d\n\nAs business boomed in the \u203270s and \u203280s, he established Tower Records outlets in major cities across the United States, many with 20,000 to 40,000 square feet of space. The New York flagship, in Greenwich Village, opened in 1983.\n\nTower began opening stores abroad in the 1980s, starting in Japan and spreading in Asia, Europe and Latin America. In the 1990s, it became the nation\u2019s largest privately held music retailer, with nearly 200 stores in the United States and 14 other countries.\n\nBut it never went public. \u201cThat was the dumbest thing I ever did,\u201d Mr. Solomon conceded. Selling stock might have paid for further expansion. Instead, he borrowed to finance more stores, and his debt swelled to $300 million. In 1999, Tower sales topped $1 billion, but its financial tailspin had already begun. The company lost $10 million in 2000 and $90 million in 2001.\n\nMr. Solomon sold and closed stores and converted others to franchises. At the same time, the music business went into a slump. Tower declared bankruptcy in 2004, and in 2006 it was forced to liquidate and close.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Solomon acknowledged that he had underestimated the internet\u2019s threat to store retailing. Pirates downloaded music without paying for it, and paying customers turned to online vendors and price-cutters like Wal-Mart and Best Buy. The owner blamed himself.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was overextended,\u201d Mr. Solomon said. \u201cI was swamped by the debt.\u201d\n\nRussell Malcolm Solomon was born on Sept. 22, 1925, in San Francisco to Clayton Solomon and the former Annette Sockolov. The boy and his sister, Shirley, grew up mostly in Sacramento, the state capital, where their father established his business, Tower Cut Rate Drugs, in the late 1930s.\n\nRussell, an indifferent student, was expelled for repeated truancy from C. K. McClatchy High School at 16 and went to work for his father. He served stateside in the Army Air Forces from 1944 to 1946.\n\nIn 1946, he married Doris Epstein, from whom he was divorced. In 2010, he married Patricia Drosins, who survives him. Besides his son Michael, he is also survived by another son, David; four grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. Michael Solomon said his father died, apparently of a heart attack, while watching the Academy Awards ceremony on television.\n\nMr. Solomon attempted a comeback in 2007, opening a store called R5 Records at the location of his first Sacramento store. He no longer had the rights to the Tower Records name, but used its red and yellow color scheme for his logo. After three relatively unsuccessful years, R5 Records was sold to a local music chain.\n\nA nostalgic documentary, \u201cAll Things Must Pass: The Rise and Fall of Tower Records,\u201d directed by the actor Colin Hanks, was released in 2015. It featured Mr. Solomon and many of his former employees and patrons, including Elton John, who called the shuttering of Tower Records \u201cone of the great tragedies of my life.\u201d", "title": "Russ Solomon, Founder of Tower Records, Dies at 92", "authors": ["Robert D. Mcfadden"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOpening the first page of his biography of Eleanor Roosevelt is be transported into her child-life,\u201d Lisa Von Drasek, curator of the children\u2019s literature research collections at the University of Minnesota Libraries, said by email. \u201cWhen I\u2019ve read it aloud to fifth graders, they vocally identified with her feelings of being unloved and isolated in the shadow of a family of extroverts.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd,\u201d added Ms. Von Drasek, whose university archive is a repository of Mr. Freedman\u2019s papers, \u201che was the original \u2018crossover\u2019 writer, publishing for children and young adults but perfect for an adult just entering into the subject matter.\u201d\n\nThat was by design, Mr. Freedman indicated.\n\n\u201cIf my grown-up friends cannot read one of my books with interest and respect,\u201d he said in an interview when he won a National Humanities Medal in 2007, \u201cthen it\u2019s not a good book for kids.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRussell Bruce Freedman was born on Oct. 11, 1929, in San Francisco. His father, Louis, was West Coast manager for Macmillan publishing; his mother, the former Irene Gordon, was a homemaker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter graduating from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1951 with an English degree and doing counterintelligence work in the Army during the Korean War, Mr. Freedman worked as a journalist and publicist. But then a chance bit of browsing changed his direction.\n\n\u201cOne day I read an article about a 16-year-old blind boy who invented a Braille typewriter,\u201d he recounted in a 1988 interview with The Chicago Tribune. \u201cI thought that was remarkable. Then, as I kept reading, I learned that the Braille system itself, as used around the world, was invented by another 16-year-old blind boy, Louis Braille.\u201d\n\nHe decided to write a book, \u201cTeenagers Who Made History.\u201d\n\n\u201cBy the time the book was completed, he realized it had to be a book for young readers,\u201d said the critic and filmmaker Evans Chan, Mr. Freedman\u2019s partner of many years, whom he married in 2013. The book was published in 1961, with a little help from Mr. Freedman\u2019s father.\n\nThe many works that followed included a string of nature books like \u201cAnimal Architects\u201d (1971). But a trip to a photographic exhibition changed his focus and approach.\n\n\u201cHis interest in biographical and history writings was rekindled by a visit to a New-York Historical Society exhibition of \u2018Street Kids: 1864-1977\u2019 in 1978,\u201d Mr. Chan said. \u201cThe show inspired Russ to begin combining text with vintage photos (and eventually archival illustrations) in his own books.\u201d\n\nHe quickly put the approach to the test in \u201cImmigrant Kids\u201d (1980), using photographs and text to tell the stories of young immigrants in the early 1900s. A particularly effective example was \u201cLincoln: A Photobiography,\u201d which won the Newbery Medal in 1988. It was one of only a handful of nonfiction books to win that prestigious children\u2019s-literature award at that point, something Mr. Freedman attributed partly to poor writing practices.\n\n\u201cCondescension used to be the rule in children\u2019s nonfiction,\u201d he said at the time, \u201cthe belief that we needed to dramatize history to make it palatable and keep kids reading. So we lied. We created unbelievable characters \u2014 bland stereotypes \u2014 and fictionalized their lives. Biographies, almost without exception, were adulatory and reverential.\u201d\n\nIn the Lincoln book, he said, he strove to convey the human qualities of Lincoln, including the shortcomings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen he started out, he was weak, indecisive, insecure, a crybaby,\u201d he said. \u201cYet in my book, I can show the process of growth taking place. If kids see that our greatest president had the same fears, doubts and failings they have, they realize that Lincoln, whose picture hangs on every schoolhouse wall, was not all that different from them.\u201d\n\nLincoln may be one of American history\u2019s marquee names, but Mr. Freedman did not confine himself to obvious subjects.\n\n\u201cRussell\u2019s writing was beautiful in its clarity and precision,\u201d Mary Cash, his editor at Holiday House, said by email. \u201cYet his approach was usually broad. He included the perspectives of people whom others overlooked, such as Native Americans and enslaved people.\u201d\n\nDinah Stevenson, his longtime editor at Clarion Books, recalled that someone once referred to Mr. Freedman as \u201cthe Zen master of children\u2019s nonfiction.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe mastery is evident,\u201d she said. \u201cPerhaps the Zen was in the discipline and dedication that went into crafting his clear, compelling books. He made it look easy.\u201d\n\nOne of the books she edited was \u201cThe War to End All Wars,\u201d a work augmented by more than 100 photographs and illustrations. Mr. Chan said that the book so impressed the directors of the 2011 Broadway production of \u201cWar Horse,\u201d a story set during World War I, that they assigned it as reading for the cast. Mr. Freedman adapted an essay from the book for the Lincoln Center Theater Review\u2019s \u201cWar Horse\u201d issue.\n\nIn addition to Mr. Chan, Mr. Freedman is survived by a sister, Carol Hutchinson.\n\nOne thing that teachers, librarians and inquisitive students love about Mr. Freedman\u2019s books is that most are thoroughly annotated, so that the curious can follow his research path and delve deeper into the subject. In his book about one of the greatest American female athletes, \u201cBabe Didrikson Zaharias: The Making of a Champion,\u201d he included a cautionary tale for historians young and old.\n\n\u201cShe tended to glamorize the story of her life, adding choice tidbits and details, putting a shine on past events,\u201d he wrote. \u201cAs impressive as her achievements were, she could not resist the temptation to embellish them.\u201d\n\nIn researching that book, he discovered that he had erroneously included her in his very first book, \u201cTeenagers Who Made History.\u201d One of the things she stretched the truth about, it turned out, was her birth year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe first thing I was surprised to learn,\u201d he wrote, \u201cwas that Babe wasn\u2019t a teenager at all during the 1932 Olympics, as she claimed and the world believed.\u201d Despite using, variously, a birth year of 1913, 1914, 1915 and 1919, she was born in 1911.", "title": "Russell Freedman, 88, Writer of History for Young Readers, Dies", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Russell Simmons has once again been accused of rape. A woman identified as Jane Doe filed a $10 million lawsuit against him in Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday. Mr. Simmons, the music mogul who co-founded Def Jam Recordings, denied the claim.\n\nIn the suit, the woman alleges that she and her son met Mr. Simmons at a concert. Following the performances, Mr. Simmons invited them backstage and, after dropping her son off at home, took the woman out for drinks. At the end of the night, Mr. Simmons asked her to accompany him to his hotel room: \u201cShe was reluctant, but Simmons insisted it was not an invitation to have sexual relations since he was dating a well-known model,\u201d the complaint reads. The suit then alleges that he raped her in the room.\n\nThe complaint seeks $10 million in damages for forcible rape, intentional infliction of emotional distress and negligent infliction of emotional distress. The lawsuit does not specify when the woman says she met Mr. Simmons.\n\nIn a statement to Billboard, Mr. Simmons said he \u201cvehemently\u201d denied all of the allegations. \u201cThey have shocked me to my core as I have never been abusive or violent in any way in my relations with women,\u201d the statement said. \u201cI have submitted myself to multiple lie detector tests.\u201d", "title": "Russell Simmons Accused of Rape in New Lawsuit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Russian minister of culture has banned my new movie, \u201cThe Death of Stalin.\u201d He said its satire was part of a Western plot to destabilize the country. Now the Russian presidential election is looming, and we all know how vehemently Vladimir Putin despises the idea of anyone interfering in the elections of a foreign power; so onto the blacklist my movie went, and no one in Russia is officially allowed to see it.\n\nThe last thing I expected was hearty congratulations, but that\u2019s what I got from many film industry insiders. Bouquets of tweets and emails arrived telling me what smart publicity this was and how great this would look on our posters; the Russians had given us a marketing campaign no money could buy.\n\nI had to tell these same insiders that publicity is effective only if it leads more people to buy the product you\u2019re selling, and since my product was banned, then it could not, by definition, be bought. It\u2019s roughly how the marketing director of napalm must feel: He or she can dream up the most imaginative posters, but it won\u2019t make the product more readily available in the shops.\n\nMore important, though, this act of censorship gave me no joy; the overwhelming emotion has been one of sad disappointment that in the world of instant communication, and the anarchic dissemination of information, people still think it\u2019s O.K. to ban stuff they don\u2019t like. That they should ban a film making fun of repression is wonderfully ironic, I know, but I still don\u2019t get any kick out of it.", "title": "Opinion | Russia Banned My Movie. Hold Your Applause.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe election results should be compared not with democracies, but with the Soviet Union,\u201d wrote Ivan Kurilla, a historian, on Facebook. \u201cBack then it was 99.9%, and now it\u2019s 75%. It\u2019s precisely by that 24% that today\u2019s elections are freer than Soviet ones.\u201d\n\nObservers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe also found the entire process wanting, if well organized. \u201cOverall, the campaign was marked by a lack of genuine competition among contestants,\u201d the group\u2019s election observation mission concluded in a statement.\n\nThere were also some complaints about irregularities. A few videos of ballot stuffing appeared, although the results from a couple such polling stations were quickly nullified. But critics worried about more sophisticated techniques.\n\nOne of those was the new \u201cabsentee voting\u201d system that allowed people to vote where they were physically rather than where they were registered. One opposition organizer who said he managed to vote twice using the system was immediately charged with a misdemeanor. But that left open the question of how many people might have been able to abuse the system.\n\nThe \u201celectoral sultanates\u201d that previously produced whopping numbers for Mr. Putin also seemed to have curbed their enthusiasm. In previous years the Republic of Chechnya, for example, habitually awarded Mr. Putin more than 99 percent of the vote with more than 99 percent turnout. This year it was a slightly more temperate 91.5 percent on both scales.\n\nOver all, Mr. Putin received some 56.4 million votes out of more than 110 million eligible voters, the most ever cast for a Russian president. Turnout was 67.5 percent. The closest candidate to him was Pavel N. Grudinin from the Communist Party with 11.78 percent, followed by Vladimir V. Sobchak, the only woman, attracted just 1.68 percent.", "title": "Russia Credits the West for Putin\u2019s Big Victory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Russia on Saturday ordered 23 British diplomats to leave the country within a week, escalating a diplomatic crisis after a former Russian spy and his daughter were poisoned with a military grade nerve agent on British soil.\n\nThe order came days after Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain expelled the same number of Russian diplomats and called off high-level contacts between the two governments.\n\nThe Russians also ordered the closing of the British Council, a cultural and educational organization, in Russia, and revoked permission for the British consulate general in St. Petersburg.\n\nThe announcement came after the British ambassador, Laurie Bristow, was summoned to the Foreign Ministry in Moscow on Saturday morning.", "title": "Russia Expels 23 British Diplomats, Escalating Row Over Ex-Spy\u2019s Poisoning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBIRMINGHAM, England \u2014 Track and field\u2019s world governing body said Tuesday that Russia\u2019s athletics federation is risking permanent expulsion if it does not begin complying with a series of two-year-old antidoping requirements the country has shown little inclination to fulfill.\n\nFed up with what he described as foot-dragging by Russia\u2019s sports officials in the wake of revelations about its state-sponsored doping program, Sebastian Coe, the president of the International Association of Athletics Federations, said the organization will meet in July to consider a new set of punishments. Those sanctions could include ending the practice of allowing Russian athletes to compete as neutrals if they can prove they have not used performance enhancing drugs, or expelling Russia\u2019s track and field federation from the I.A.A.F.\n\nAs part of a pathway to reintegration, Russia had agreed to a series of conditions with the I.A.A.F. Sports officials were supposed to acknowledge that the doping scheme that lasted at least from 2008-2015 was part of a systemic effort to corrupt sports. They have not done so. Russia has also failed to identify athletes in a database of individuals suspected of using performance enhancing drugs.\n\n\u201cThere is no ambiguity about the criteria, and the criteria was agreed,\u201d Coe, a former two-time Olympic gold medal-winning runner, told reporters in Birmingham, England, where the world indoor championships are currently taking place. \u201cWe want the country and their athletes back, but we want the world to be in a position to trust.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussia\u2019s athletics officials were not immediately available for comment.\n\nTuesday\u2019s announcement followed a meeting of the I.A.A.F. executive board. The police arrested many of them for parading without a permit and sent them to jail. Officers also turned fire hoses on the protesting children. It didn\u2019t deter them. The marches, known as the Birmingham Children\u2019s Crusade, continued for days.\n\nThe children-led protests in 1963 were part of the Birmingham Campaign, a series of civil rights protests led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The children\u2019s protest helped turn the nation\u2019s attention to Jim Crow laws and segregation in the South and served as a turning point of the movement.\n\nA month later, President John F. Kennedy called for a bill that would later become the 1964 Civil Rights Act.\n\n\u201cCan you imagine?\u201d one of the protesters from 1963 told NPR last week, \u201chere we are in 2018, and we\u2019re still reliving some of this stuff.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClaire Moses contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 \u201cI know I\u2019ll regret this for the rest of my life.\u201d Steve Smith, the disgraced former captain of the Australia cricket team, broke down in tears as he apologized on live television for a cheating scandal that has shocked the sport. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Venezuela, at least 68 people died after a fire broke out during a riot at a jail in the northern city of Valencia. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 \u201cI\u2019m really happy now.\u201d Eiko Kadono, 83, the Japanese children\u2019s author known for \u201cMajo no Takkyubin\u201d (\u201cKiki\u2019s Delivery Service\u201d), won the 2018 Hans Christian Andersen Award, considered the Nobel Prize of children\u2019s literature. Here\u2019s our full coverage.\n\nThe N.C.A.A. tournament, also known as the Big Dance, is among the most cherished rites of American sports. About 350 colleges and universities field a team in the top division, compared with 65 in football. At the end of the regular season, 68 teams move on to a knockout tournament.\n\nThe first men\u2019s tournament was held in 1939, and for more than a decade only eight teams were invited. The women\u2019s tourney started in 1982. The moniker \u201cMarch Madness\u201d became part of pop vernacular in the mid-1980s, stemming from the David-versus-Goliath upsets that always shock players, coaches, fans and bookmakers.\n\nThe odds of picking a perfect bracket are 1 in 9.2 quintillion. Even so, it\u2019s almost a duty of U.S. citizenship to fill out a tournament bracket. (Last year, ESPN.com reported that some 70 million brackets were filled out and a total of $10.4 billion was wagered.)\n\nThe men\u2019s Final Four consists of Kansas, Michigan Villanova and Loyola-Chicago, a team that entered as a 300-to-1 underdog and wasn\u2019t supposed to win its first game.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the women\u2019s tournament, Connecticut, Louisville, Mississippi State and Notre Dame are the last teams standing.\n\nMatt Futterman contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. He was selected after numerous other directors turned down the job, and in part for his Italian heritage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe saga of the Corleones, an organized crime family in New York in the 1940s and \u201950s, \u201cThe Godfather\u201d became an almost instant classic. It was the top-earning film of 1972 and remains one of the highest-grossing (and most critically acclaimed) movies of all time.\n\nNominated for 10 Academy Awards in 1973, \u201cThe Godfather\u201d won three, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Marlon Brando, who played Vito Corleone, the family\u2019s aging patriarch. Brando famously declined to accept the award as a protest against Hollywood\u2019s portrayal of Native Americans.\n\n\u201cThe Godfather\u201d was \u201ca superb Hollywood movie,\u201d Canby wrote in 1972, \u201cscaring the delighted hell out of us while cautioning that crime doesn\u2019t (or, at least, shouldn\u2019t) pay.\u201d\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. The turnout size will be interpreted as the strength of Mr. Putin\u2019s mandate.\n\nBritain said that Russia has been stockpiling novichok, the military-grade nerve agent that was used to poison a former Russian spy on British soil this month. Russian officials have either denied that the former spy was attacked, or have accused Britain of being the culprit.\n\nHere\u2019s a look at other assassination weapons: spiked toothpaste, ice axes, killer clowns.", "title": "Russia, North Korea, Xi Jinping: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Russia has denied the charge.\n\nIf proven true, it will cast doubt on the work of the monitoring body, which was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2013 for making chemical weapons \u201ctaboo under international law.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is a real shock to the system,\u201d as members question Russia\u2019s reporting of its own stocks, said Paul F. Walker, director of environmental sustainability at Green Cross International, a disarmament advocacy group.\n\n\u201cNobody that I know of has questioned their veracity about declaring everything,\u201d Mr. Walker said. \u201cNow, with the Novichok situation, it is a new day at the O.P.C.W. People will ask, is this inspection system intrusive enough? In the executive council in particular, people are raising questions about secret stockpiles.\u201d\n\nMr. Walker said that he was surprised by Britain's claim it had proof Russia has been producing and stockpiling the nerve agent, and that he had not yet seen evidence to back it up.\n\n\u201cThey must have something we haven\u2019t seen,\u201d he said. \u201cThat has to come out.\u201d\n\nRussia has pushed back hard against the accusation, comparing it to the American case, later discredited, that Saddam Hussein was stockpiling chemical weapons. Moscow has suggested that the nerve agent used on the Skripals could have been produced in Britain, Sweden, Slovakia, the Czech Republic or the United States.\n\nForeign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova and Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov have each said that no Novichok program existed in either Russia or the Soviet Union.\n\nBut scientists have come forward to describe it. Leonid Rink, who worked at a Soviet chemical weapons laboratory, told the Ria Novosti news service that \u201ca big group of specialists\u201d had worked on the strains and that it would be \u201czero problem\u201d for laboratories outside Russia to produce the nerve agent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVladimir Uglev, who worked in the same laboratory as Mr. Rink, told The Bell news website that he helped produce four agents under the code name Foliant, from 1972 until 1988. He said he believed that, by analyzing the remains of chemical agents in the blood, it would be possible to determine \u201cwhere the specific dose was produced and by whom.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe added that, based on what he witnessed at that time, the victims were not likely to survive.\n\n\u201cI can say with nearly 100 percent certainty that if Skripal and his daughter are taken off life support, they will die,\u201d Mr. Uglev said. \u201cThey are now only technically alive.\u201d\n\nThe British authorities have been tight-lipped about the inquiry, but in recent days intensified their focus on vehicles the Skripals traveled in, where the agent, in powder form, could have been planted on a door handle or in a ventilation system. In an interview with RIA Novosti, Mr. Rink, the Russian scientist, scoffed at the theory that Novichok could have been planted in Ms. Skripal\u2019s suitcase, saying that it was so lethal that, as he put it, \u201cshe would not have reached London.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt present, inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons have a limited task: to take samples of the agent used in the attack and send them to independent laboratories to determine whether it is Novichok.\n\nIf the dispute escalates, however, Britain could request a so-called challenge inspection of Russian laboratories to look for signs of Novichok production \u2014 a measure that has never been invoked in the monitoring group\u2019s 21-year history. Russia, in turn, could request its own challenge inspections.\n\nChallenge inspections are designed to be intensive and carried out at short notice; inspectors are to be allowed access to a laboratory within 36 hours of arrival.\n\nThe Chemical Weapons Convention was designed to eliminate large stocks of chemical weapons that could be used on the battlefield. Russia committed to destroying 40,000 metric tons, and the United States to 31,500 metric tons. Russia announced last year that it had completed this task. The United States has eliminated seven of nine stockpiles, holding about 90 percent of its agents.\n\nNovichok, then an early-stage project, was not included on a list of banned chemicals compiled in 1987, so Russia was under no obligation to regularly report on its stockpiles and their destruction. But producing Novichok would be a serious violation, because the treaty broadly prohibits the development and use of chemical weapons, said Richard Guthrie, an independent chemical weapons expert and editor of CBW Events.\n\nMr. Johnson said on Sunday that Britain had evidence that Russia had stockpiled Novichok during the past decade and had investigated ways to deliver nerve agents for assassination. A Foreign Office spokesman declined to describe the evidence, saying only that \u201cclearly, the information the foreign secretary was referring to is very sensitive.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExperts said that Britain could have learned of a secret program in various ways: communications intercepts, moles within laboratories, publications by Russian chemists reporting their synthesis of rare compounds, or a computer virus lurking within Western equipment sold for use in Russian laboratories.\n\nMr. Guthrie said that concerns about a Novichok program had surfaced occasionally, but that Britain probably chose not to raise the issue publicly with the weapons-monitoring organization for fear of derailing trade deals or other agreements with Russia.\n\n\u201cIf your information isn\u2019t perfect, you might think, \u2018We\u2019ll leave this allegation, maybe these aren\u2019t so serious,\u2019\u201d Mr. Guthrie said. \u201cThey didn\u2019t feel it was important enough, and I think Novichoks would have stayed on the back burner if they hadn\u2019t been used in Salisbury.\u201d\n\nThis would not be the first time the chemical weapons watchdog was shaken by great-power politics. In 2002, its director general, Jos\u00e9 Bustani, was ousted amid divisions over whether Iraq maintained stockpiles of chemical weapons. Mr. Bustani, in an interview, said the United States pushed for his removal because he had persuaded Mr. Hussein to accede to the convention, which he said would have undermined the American case for invading Iraq.\n\nMore recently, Russia has used its veto power in the United Nations Security Council repeatedly to block action against Syria, its ally, based on the monitoring group\u2019s reporting on chemical weapons use there. Andrew C. Weber, a former assistant secretary of defense for nuclear, chemical and biological defense programs, said this had tarnished Russia\u2019s \u201cextraordinary achievement\u201d in destroying 40,000 metric tons of stockpiled weapons.\n\n\u201cIt does take away from their achievement \u2014 frankly, it\u2019s disgraceful \u2014 and now the Russian Federation has apparently been caught in a flagrant violation of the Chemical Weapons Convention,\u201d said Mr. Weber, who emerged on Tuesday from a routine meeting with Russian chemical weapons experts on disarmament projects. They were \u201cembarrassed,\u201d he said, when Novichok came up in conversation.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t want to believe that their government actually did this,\u201d he said.", "title": "Russia, Praised for Scrapping Chemical Weapons, Now Under Watchdog\u2019s Gaze", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The real Patrick, who became a patron saint of Ireland, wasn\u2019t even Irish: He is believed to have been a Roman born in England who was enslaved by Irish marauders. He escaped after six years and returned to Ireland to spread Christianity.\n\nCorned beef, a mainstay of St. Patrick\u2019s Day in the U.S., was introduced to Irish immigrants by Jewish neighbors in New York City. Then there\u2019s the color: It was once St. Patrick\u2019s blue. (Green dates to 18th-century Irish independence movements.)\n\nAnd for a celebration of Irish culture, St. Patrick\u2019s Day is remarkably global. In Sydney, where the Opera House is tinted green each year, the celebrations date to 1810. In Singapore, as The Irish Post writes, \u201cthe Singapore River transforms into a sea of green as part of its own two-day street festival.\u201d\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Browse past briefings here.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. To receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, sign up here.\n\nCheck out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Russia, Robert Mueller, Miami: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "St. Patrick\u2019s Day, which is Saturday, is all the more enjoyable for a number of intriguing myths and misconceptions \u2014 and not just about leprechauns.\n\nScientists say there were never any snakes in Ireland, for one thing, which contradicts the tale of St. Patrick driving them into the sea. It\u2019s not even airtight to maintain, as scholars do, that the snake story is an allegory for St.Patrick\u2019s eradication of pagan religions. (Christianity may have already arrived.)\n\nThe real Patrick, who became a patron saint of Ireland, wasn\u2019t even Irish: He was believed to have been a Roman born in England who was enslaved by Irish marauders. He escaped after six years and returned to Ireland to spread Christianity.\n\nCorned beef, a mainstay of St. Patrick\u2019s Day in the U.S., was introduced by Irish immigrants who bought it from Jewish neighbors in New York City. And there\u2019s the color: It was once St. Patrick\u2019s blue. (Green dates to 18th Century Irish independence movements.)\n\nAnd for a celebration of Irish culture, St. Patrick\u2019s Day is remarkably global. In Sydney, where the Opera House is tinted green each year, the celebrations date to 1810. In Singapore, as the Irish Times writes, \u201cthe Singapore River transforms into a sea of green as part of its own two-day street festival.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. Forget the story.\u201d\n\nThe actress said the threat influenced her decision to accept $130,000 for her silence about the alleged affair. She is now suing to get out of that agreement.\n\n(The \u201c60 Minutes\u201d interview drew 22 million viewers, the highest ratings for the program in almost a decade.)\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 \u201cAn absolute win-win.\u201d\n\nTreasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin hailed President Trump\u2019s first major trade deal: South Korea won an exemption from U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs by agreeing to import more American cars and reducing its steel exports.\n\nThe deal soothed fears, at least for the moment, about a global trade war. A bigger battle looms over Made in China 2025, Beijing\u2019s plan to dominate advanced industries.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Is Kim Jong-un in Beijing?\n\nThe question emerged after a video showed an old-style green train \u2014 similar to one used by used by North Korea\u2019s leaders \u2014 arriving in the Chinese capital amid high security.\n\nThere was no official pronouncement from China or North Korea. But the Japanese broadcaster NTV showed footage of what it said was the train, raising the possibility that a powerful envoy or even Mr. Kim himself may be visiting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJournalists also spotted a military honor guard welcoming a convoy that entered the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse, above, where top North Korean leaders have been known to stay.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Hong Kong\u2019s housing market is so tight that \u201cnano flats,\u201d smaller than 200 square feet, are all the rage. (A parking spot just sold for $664,000.)\n\nThe city is considering some other unusual proposals to ease the squeeze: turning drain pipes into tiny apartments, above, and warehousing people on cruise ships before they get permanent shelter on artificial islands.\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 Uber is out of Southeast Asia. The U.S. company agreed to sell its ride-hailing and food-delivery business in the region to Grab, a rival in Singapore. Uber sold its China operations to Didi in 2016 and retreated from Russia in 2017.\n\n\u2022 Facebook stock fell as much as 6.5 percent after the Federal Trade Commission confirmed it was investigating the company\u2019s privacy practices.\n\n\u2022 Remington, the U.S. firearm company founded in 1816, filed for bankruptcy amid mounting debt and slow sales.\n\n\u2022 Alibaba and Ford unveiled an unstaffed car vending machine \u2014 five-stories tall and containing 42 cars of various models \u2014 in Guangzhou, China.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks rose sharply on news of the U.S.-South Korea trade deal. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Russia, emergency exits were blocked and a security guard had switched off the fire alarm in a shopping mall in Siberia that burned on Sunday, killing at least 64 people, including many children. [The New York Times]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Malaysia is considering an anti-fake news bill, with those convicted of disseminating false content facing up to 10 years in prison. [BBC]\n\n\u2022 A U.S. water slide that decapitated a 10-year-old boy violated basic engineering standards, and park officials knew it posed serious dangers, an indictment said. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Japan, home to the world\u2019s oldest population, prisons have become a haven for lonely older women in search of community and stability. [Bloomberg]\n\n\u2022 A pothole epidemic has turned the streets of Rome, the city that built an empire on its roads, into an embarrassing mess. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 An 2,500-year-old Egyptian coffin that had been stored at Sydney University for 150 years was found to be filled with human remains, shocking archaeologists who thought it was empty. [ABC]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Is it time to give up on fish oil? Not all supplements carry the same health benefits.\n\n\u2022 Whether or not you have kids, creating a will is about your legacy.\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Try a different kind of pizza topped with caramelized onions, figs, bacon and blue cheese.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cI feel I\u2019m in Japan,\u201d Vincent van Gogh wrote to his brother, although he\u2019d never been there. The Dutch painter, in fact, became obsessed by Japanese art. An exhibition in Amsterdam explores how that fascination shaped his work, like \u201cAlmond Blossom,\u201d above.\n\n\u2022 Is it love if it\u2019s not on Instagram? In an Op-Ed, a writer questions \u2014 and laments \u2014 the blurring of people\u2019s personal and online lives.\n\n\u2022 Add your voice: We\u2019re preparing our coverage of the 50th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who connected his fight for civil rights in the U.S. to the global reality of racism and poverty. We\u2019d like to hear what he means to you.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nOn this day in 1915, Mary Mallon, nicknamed \u201cTyphoid Mary,\u201d was placed in quarantine for the second time in New York City. Though she never displayed any symptoms of the disease, she would be confined for the rest of her life.\n\nIn 1906, health officials tied Ms. Mallon to outbreaks of typhoid fever in seven wealthy families for whom she had worked as a cook.\n\nShe was confirmed to be a carrier of the disease and quarantined. Doctors released her in 1910 under the condition that she no longer work as a cook. Shortly after, she disappeared.\n\nMs. Mallon was rediscovered in 1915 by officials investigating a typhoid outbreak in a Manhattan hospital. She had been working there as a cook under an assumed name.\n\nShe was then quarantined for 23 years, until her death in 1938 from the effects of a stroke.\n\nDuring her life, the public was fascinated by Ms. Mallon, above. She often appeared in news stories and cartoons, with one depicting her frying skulls in a pan. She was frustrated by the attention, and by her captivity, once describing herself as \u201ca peep show for everybody.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer case is often referenced during public health crises, such as the Ebola epidemic, in debates over the power of officials to quarantine people they believe are disease carriers.\n\nJillian Rayfield contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. I know you think he is bad, and we\u2019ll take care of it.\u2019 Problem is, you can\u2019t find that lawyer, because no one will be able to do that.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Roger Cossack, a longtime legal analyst, on President Trump\u2019s struggles to find and keep lawyers.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\nLast week, the Library of Congress in Washington announced its annual additions to the National Recording Registry, which honors significant pieces of American history and culture. (Here\u2019s the list.)\n\nWe\u2019d like to look at one: the original 1930 recording of \u201cLamento Borincano,\u201d by Canario y Su Grupo.\n\nPhoto\n\nKnown as an unofficial anthem of Puerto Rico, \u201cLamento Borincano\u201d was composed by Rafael Hern\u00e1ndez, one of the island\u2019s most renowned and prolific songwriters (although he wrote it while living in New York City).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe title refers to Borinquen, a derivation of Puerto Rico\u2019s indigenous name.\n\nThe song reflects the plight of Puerto Rican farmers during the Great Depression. They faced not only the threat of hurricanes but also the economic changes brought after 1917, when Puerto Ricans were granted U.S. citizenship, leading to a wave of emigration.\n\nThe lyrics tell of a farmer who is \u201cloco de contento\u201d (crazy with happiness) at the prospect of selling his produce in town. But he arrives to find the town empty. With no one to buy anything, he returns to his farm demoralized. The song ends:\n\nBorinquen, the land of Eden The one that when singing, the great Gautier He called the pearl of the seas. Now that you die With your regrets Let me sing to you too.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Russia, Stormy Daniels, N.C.A.A. Basketball: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Practically, the elephant also helped the Thais in warfare, harvest and transportation. In Buddhism, Thailand\u2019s predominant religion, the elephant is a symbol of mental strength and frequently appears in allegories and art.\n\nThere\u2019s even a Thai Elephant Orchestra (!), which has been trained to play percussion instruments.\n\nThe number of both wild and domesticated elephants has dropped significantly in Thailand over the past century.\n\nIt\u2019s not completely clear how many elephants live in the country, but in 2006 the number of wild elephants was estimated at 3,000 to 3,700, while elephants in captivity numbered around 4,000. At the beginning of the 20th century, Thailand was said to have had more than 300,000 wild elephants and about 100,000 domesticated ones.\n\nToday, Asian elephants are endangered, with a population of fewer than 50,000 worldwide.\n\nClaire Moses contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Nikulin, appeared in Federal District Court in San Francisco after arriving in the city around 6 a.m. He pleaded not guilty to the charges against him. Magistrate Judge Jacqueline Scott Corley scheduled his next court appearance for next week.\n\n\u201cThis is deeply troubling behavior once again emanating from Russia,\u201d Attorney General Jeff Sessions said in a statement. \u201cWe will not tolerate criminal cyberattacks and will make it a priority to investigate and prosecute these crimes, regardless of the country where they originate.\u201d\n\nMr. Nikulin had been held in the Czech Republic since the authorities there arrested him in 2016. His case quickly turned into a battle between Washington and Moscow over whether he should be tried in the United States.", "title": "Russian Accused of Hacking U.S. Technology Firms Is Extradited", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The British authorities said on Wednesday that Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, the poison victims at the epicenter of a diplomatic crisis between Russia and the West, had been sickened with a nerve agent on the front door of Mr. Skripal\u2019s house.\n\nThe announcement narrows the many possibilities of how the Skripals came into contact with the poison.\n\nDetectives will focus their efforts now on Mr. Skripal\u2019s house in the cathedral town of Salisbury, England, said Dean Haydon, senior national coordinator for counterterrorism policing, in a news release.\n\nThey will also, presumably, search for a person who could have delivered the poison.\n\nMr. Skripal, a former Russian double agent, and his daughter, who had been visiting him from Russia, were found unresponsive on a bench in a Salisbury park on March 4.", "title": "Russian Ex-Spy Sergei Skripal Was Poisoned via Front Door, U.K. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 A Russian military transport plane carrying 33 passengers and six crew members crashed on landing at an air base in Syria on Tuesday, killing all on board, the Russian Defense Ministry said.\n\nInitial reports ruled out a terrorist attack against the aircraft, an Antonov An-26 transport plane, with technical failure being the likely cause, the Interfax news agency reported. All those on board were Russian military personnel, the ministry said.\n\n\u201cAccording to a report from the scene, the airplane was not fired upon,\u201d the Russian Defense Ministry said in a statement, adding that an investigation into the crash had begun. The plane hit the ground more than 1,600 feet short of the runway at the Russian-operated Hmeimim Air Base, the statement said.\n\nRussia has stepped up security at the air base and at a naval facility at Tartus on the Mediterranean coast after both came under a drone attack in early January. The drones were shot down before they caused any damage and there were no casualties, according to a statement on the military\u2019s Facebook page.", "title": "Russian Military Transport Plane Crashes in Syria, Killing 39", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "The first accusations against Mr. Slutsky emerged last month in an article on the website of TV Rain, a small, independent broadcaster, which quoted two unidentified female journalists. In one instance cited in the article, the lawmaker reportedly placed the inner part of his palm against a reporter\u2019s crotch. Later in February, RTVI\u2019s deputy chief editor, Ekaterina Kotrikadze, went public with accusations against Mr. Slutsky, as did two other female journalists.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Slutsky denied all the accusations and turned to Facebook to mock his accusers. He and some of his fellow lawmakers, including the speaker of the Duma, Vyacheslav V. Volodin, suggested that the accusations were part of an anti-Russian campaign on the eve of the Russian presidential election.\n\n\u201cAttempts to make a Russian Harvey Weinstein of Slutsky look very much like a cheap, shoddy provocation,\u201d Mr. Slutsky wrote on Facebook, suggesting that the complaints would go nowhere.\n\nHowever, at least one member of Parliament, Oksana V. Pushkina, sided with the journalists. She pledged to submit an amendment to Russian law to provide a legal framework for prosecution of sexual harassment, which it currently lacks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Parliament\u2019s ethics commission took up the case, sifting through evidence that included the transcript of a conversation in which Mr. Slutsky suggested to a reporter from the Russian-language service of the BBC that she could become his mistress.\n\nThe ethics panel ruled the same day as the hearing that it had not observed \u201cany breaches in the standards of conduct\u201d by Mr. Slutsky. The chairman of the commission, Otari I. Arshba, hinted that the journalists seemed to have plotted together, and that some waited too long after the incident \u2014 several years \u2014 before coming forward.\n\nSome reporters took to Twitter to mock the report, suggesting that the very problem was that the Duma did not consider Mr. Slutsky\u2019s actions to be out of the ordinary.\n\nOn Thursday, after the various news organizations announced that they would not interact with Mr. Slutsky, some of their reporters were not allowed into the building at all.\n\nDmitri S. Peskov, the spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin, declined to comment on the issue.", "title": "Russian News Outlets Boycott Parliament After Harassment Decision", "authors": ["Oleg Matsnev"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRussia is very good at creating tension and getting attention \u2014 it is like a dog running after a car,\u201d said Aleksandar Trifunovic, the editor of Buka, a popular online news site in Banja Luka. The tubby bikers, he added, were \u201ca joke\u201d but had nonetheless sent a message that \u201cRussia stands behind\u201d the Republika Srpska and its leader, Milorad Dodik, whom the United States last year labeled a \u201csignificant threat\u201d to Bosnia and placed on a Treasury Department sanctions list.\n\nSending bikers without bikes, Mr. Trifunovic noted, was much cheaper than sending hard cash, with which Moscow has been extremely sparing.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Dodik, the Republika Srpska\u2019s president, complained in an interview that, despite his frequent meetings with Russia\u2019s president, Vladimir V. Putin, he was still waiting for Moscow to follow through on what he said was a 2014 promise to provide his government with loans of at least $625 million.\n\n\u201cWe have received nothing from Russia,\u201d said Mr. Dodik, a former American prot\u00e9g\u00e9 who has morphed into a hard-line Serb nationalist. \u201cWe had a promise but got nothing. We are a bit disappointed.\u201d\n\nInstead, Mr. Dodik got the Night Wolves, such a motley crew that one local newspaper asked whether it would not have been better for Moscow to send some ballet dancers.\n\n\u201cThey looked pathetic; even I am taller than they are,\u201d said Srdjan Puhalo, a bookish, ethnic Serb psychologist who posed with the bikers for photos outside Christ the Savior Cathedral in Banja Luka, perhaps the most enthusiastically pro-Russian city outside Russia.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Dodik, whose security forces have been stocking up on weapons and recently purchased 2,500 automatic rifles for the police forces, insisted that he did not want violence and wanted the Republika Srpska to secede peacefully from Bosnia and join the European Union. The chances of that happening, however, are near zero, not least because his would-be country claims territory, like the border town of Brcko, that does not belong to it and has a habit of belittling Bosnian Muslims as fanatics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe described the Night Wolves, a mix of Russians and Serbs, as harmless \u201ctourists\u201d who were far more welcome than \u201cmen in short trousers with beards but no mustaches,\u201d a reference to the dress code and shaving habits of Muslims who follow a rigid form of the faith promoted by Saudi Arabia and who many Serb nationalists believe, against all evidence, are numerous in Bosnia.\n\nWhile claiming not to know much about the Night Wolves, Mr. Dodik in January gave a medal to their leader, Alexander Zaldostanov, a burly bruiser and friend of Mr. Putin\u2019s, to honor what he described as the biker\u2019s contribution to human rights, the rule of law and relations between Republika Srpska and Russia.\n\nThat the Night Wolves are not just another group of motorcycle enthusiasts, never mind human rights activists, however, has been evident since March 2014, when its members traveled, this time with their bikes, to Crimea to set up road blocks and provide other support for a Moscow-orchestrated takeover of the Ukrainian peninsula on the Black Sea.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome of them went on to fight alongside pro-Russian rebels who seized power in eastern Ukraine.\n\nThey then reappeared in 2016 in Montenegro, joining events celebrating pan-Slavic solidarity and hostility to the West ahead of what the authorities there have since claimed was an unsuccessful, Russian-sponsored coup attempt aimed at blocking the country\u2019s entry to NATO.\n\nWashington takes such a dim view of the Night Wolves that the Treasury Department placed the gang on a sanctions list in December 2014, accusing the bikers of kidnapping, assault and close ties to Russia\u2019s security services. It has since added various affiliates, like a bike shop in Moscow, to the list.\n\n\u201cThese guys are not good-will ambassadors \u2014 we can all be sure about that,\u201d said Emir Suljagic, a former deputy defense minister in Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital.\n\nThe Night Wolves gang, which has local branches around the region, he added, is part of an \u201cextremist ecosystem\u201d nurtured by Russia through its ties to the Serbian Orthodox Church and radical Serb nationalists who still dream of a \u201cGreater Serbia.\u201d It was that idea that led to murderous ethnic cleansing in the early 1990s and also the creation of the Republika Srpska, whose founding president, Radovan Karadzic, was convicted in The Hague of war crimes in 2016.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Security Ministry in Sarajevo declared the bikers a security threat and barred Mr. Zaldostanov and the leader of the Night Wolves\u2019 Serbian chapter from its territory. The Bosnian news media covered the progress of the Night Wolves as if they were an invading army, something that Mr. Dodik dismissed as anti-Russian hysteria.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs the bikers started out on their meandering journey from Belgrade, the Serbian capital, to Banja Luka and then back, the United States put down markers of its own by sending the assistant secretary of state for European and Eurasian affairs, Wess Mitchell, on a diplomatic tour of the region.\n\nThe parallel tours, one by a button-down American diplomat, the other by a group of unkempt Russian and Serbian bikers, are all part of a long struggle for influence in an unstable region with an unhappy history of inciting wars and an insatiable appetite for great power conspiracy theories.\n\n\u201cSpying is a very popular game in the Balkans,\u201d said Milos Solaja, a professor of international relations at the University of Banja Luka. \u201cPeople here greatly enjoy intrigue and conspiracies.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRussia \u201cis not going to start World War III over the Republika Srpska,\u201d he said, and only \u201cwants to be represented here \u2014 there is no big conspiracy.\u201d Bosnia, he added, has been \u201cpermanently failing\u201d for more than a decade and did not need any prodding by Russia to become a failed state.\n\nAfter a night of heavy drinking, the Night Wolves started their Russian Balkan Tour with a visit to Velika Remeta, an Orthodox monastery founded in the 14th century near the Serbian town of Novi Sad.\n\nTheir host was the monastery\u2019s abbot, Father Stefan, whose office displays a big map of Serbia showing the country\u2019s borders at the time of the monastery\u2019s founding: They reach down into what are now Greece and Albania. \u201cWe had access to three seas then,\u201d the abbot lamented. \u201cNow we have none.\u201d\n\nHe denied having any interest in politics and said he was not sure what the bikers were up to. But, with a clock decorated with a portrait of Mr. Putin on his office wall and a Russian flag on his desk, Father Stefan said he was happy to receive anyone who cherished the long spiritual bonds between Russia and Serbia.\n\nHe served the bikers \u2014 who he acknowledged \u201cdid not seem very religious\u201d \u2014 homemade red wine and cherry liquor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nApparently eager to avoid parallels with the Night Wolves\u2019 antics in Crimea, the group\u2019s leader, Mr. Zaldostanov, did not join his comrades on their Balkan tour.\n\n\u201cThe purpose of our pilgrimage is to expand the spiritual bond between people and friends in Serbia and the Republic of Srpska,\u201d Yevgeny Strogov, the stand-in leader, told journalists at the border crossing between Serbia and Bosnia.\n\nThe trip, he said, was all about \u201cconnecting cultures,\u201d adding that Russia and Serbs \u201chave the same culture and the same religion. That means a lot to us.\u201d", "title": "Russia\u2019s Feared \u2018Night Wolves\u2019 Bike Gang Came to Bosnia. Bosnia Giggled.", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Despite their demands, however, neither Russia nor Iran can afford rebuilding costs that Syria has estimated at more than $200 billion. Instead, both seem to want to act as agents for private firms or other countries.\n\nMost Arab and Western players have hinged any investment on political reconciliation. China, too, is holding back.\n\nRussia insists that a political dialogue is alive, experts said, partly because it needs one to sway the European Union and other rich donors. \u201cThe Americans, the Gulf and the E.U. have all conditioned the reconstruction on a meaningful political process, which the Russians cannot deliver from Bashar,\u201d said Vladimir Frolov, a foreign-policy analyst. \u201cSo the Russians are trying to use a P.R. campaign to make it look like a real, Syrian-led, indigenous constitutional process while it is basically fake. Bashar is not going to negotiate himself out of power.\u201d\n\nThe ghost of Afghanistan \u2014 which became a military quagmire for the Soviet Union in the 1980s and helped speed its collapse \u2014 hangs over Syria. Yet the level of Russian commitment is far lower, in money and loss of life, less visible at home and so far not an issue with average Russians.\n\nUltimately, analysts say, the Kremlin will have to deal with Washington, whose coalition forces control about one-third of the country, including most of the oil wealth. Many experts believe that some form of Russian-American dialogue that ropes in the rest of the outside players is the only hope to end the conflict.\n\nBy sticking around, Russia expects to eventually hammer out some peace agreement with Washington that will cement the Kremlin\u2019s enhanced role in the Middle East.\n\nHowever, the wait carries the risk that Russia could be dragged deeper into the conflict by an unexpected spark along any one of several tense battlefronts: in the north, between Turkey and its longtime Kurdish foes; in eastern Syria, between Syrian government troops backed by Russian mercenaries and American-allied forces; and along Israel\u2019s border with Lebanon and Syria near the Golan Heights, the site of a recent confrontation between Iran and Israel.\n\n\u201cMaybe the Russian government thought that when it destroyed Daesh the war would be over, that it would end the violence and provide the means to a political solution,\u201d said Boris V. Dolgov, a Middle East expert at the Russian Academy of Sciences, using the Arabic acronym for the Islamic State. \u201cThe reality is not like this.\u201d", "title": "Russia\u2019s Greatest Problem in Syria: Its Ally, President Assad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "He flowered as a hitter with the Astros of the mid-1960s; became the Expos\u2019 first star player; and played nine seasons with the Mets in two stints: in the 1970s, when they won their second National League pennant, and then in the \u201980s, when he became one of baseball\u2019s most accomplished pinch-hitters.\n\nHe was later a Mets broadcaster, from 1986 to 1995, working mostly with Ralph Kiner and Tim McCarver. And though a native of New Orleans, he was much the New Yorker. At one time he owned two restaurants in Manhattan, Rusty\u2019s and Rusty Staub\u2019s on Fifth.\n\nStaub was especially respected, during his baseball career and afterward, for his community involvement and his charitable work.\n\nHe particularly endeared himself in Canada, where he played for the expansion team the Expos; he was an All-Star in all three of his full seasons in Montreal, from 1969 to 1971. Staub learned French and became a traveling ambassador for the team, hailing the advent of Major League Baseball in Canada.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe did so out of respect for the fans, he said.\n\n\u201cI was in Quebec \u2014 I couldn\u2019t talk to a child,\u201d he told The Montreal Gazette in 2012. \u201cI couldn\u2019t say something encouraging. I felt like I was not doing my job \u2014 not being able to respond to the media at least in some basic form.\n\n\u201cI took about 25 French classes after the first season, and the next year I took longer classes,\u201d he continued. \u201cThere\u2019s not a question that my making that effort is part of the reason that whatever Le Grand Orange represented to Montreal and all those fans, they knew I cared and I tried.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for the sobriquet that stayed with him, he wrote in The New York Times, teammates had been calling him the Big Orange even before he arrived in Montreal in a trade with Houston.\n\n\u201cThe name wasn\u2019t formalized for the public until one day when we were playing in Los Angeles,\u201d he recalled. \u201cI hit a home run and made a pretty good catch when Willie Crawford hit a pea against the fence. The next day in the newspapers, I was \u2018Le Grand Orange.\u2019 And in both English and French papers, it stayed that way.\u201d\n\nThe Expos traded him to the Mets in April 1972. A year later, he helped propel them to a National League pennant, hitting three home runs \u2014 accounting for all his hits \u2014 in their five-game victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the National League Championship Series.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe also injured his shoulder in that series while making an outstanding catch. But he went on to bat .423 in the World Series, with two doubles and a homer, though the Mets were defeated by the Oakland A\u2019s in seven games.\n\nStaub drove in 105 runs in 1975, setting a Mets record that stood for 15 years. But he was traded that December to the Detroit Tigers, with the Mets receiving the pitcher Mickey Lolich, and served mostly as a designated hitter.\n\nStaub returned to the Expos in a trade in July 1979. In his first at-bat back at Olympic Stadium, Expos fans gave him a standing ovation.\n\nIt was a short second stint in Montreal. He spent the 1980 season with the Texas Rangers and then signed with the Mets as a free agent, playing his final five seasons with the team. As a pinch-hitter in 1983, he had eight consecutive hits in June and drove in 25 runs that season.\n\nStaub was also seen displaying his cooking techniques on television, but his love of food made it challenging to keep his weight down.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s hard,\u201d he told The Times in 1985. \u201cI\u2019ll go into my favorite Italian restaurant, and there\u2019s this risotto dish that I just love. It\u2019s got gravy and porcini mushrooms, and I say, \u2018Not this time.\u2019 But every time I go there I have to get it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDaniel Joseph Staub was born in New Orleans on April 1, 1944. He signed with the Houston Colt .45s organization in September 1961 out of Jesuit High School of New Orleans. The franchise, which later became the Astros, was preparing along with the Mets to enter the National League the next season as an expansion team.\n\nAfter playing in the minors, Staub made his debut with Houston in 1963. His breakout season came in 1967, when he batted .333 with a league-leading 44 doubles and was an All-Star for the first time.\n\nHe retired after the Mets\u2019 1985 season with 1,466 runs batted in and a career batting average of .279 to go with his 292 homers and 2,716 hits.\n\nPhoto\n\nBesides his brother, he is survived by his sisters, Sally Johnston and Susan Tully.\n\nAfter leaving baseball Staub became president of the Rusty Staub Foundation, which has supported emergency food pantries throughout New York in collaboration with Catholic Charities. He also created the New York Police and Fire Widows\u2019 and Children\u2019s Benefit Fund, which has raised millions of dollars for the families of uniformed personnel killed in the line of duty. (An uncle of Staub\u2019s died while working as a New Orleans police officer.)\n\nWhen Major League Baseball returned to New York for the first time after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, with the Mets playing the Atlanta Braves, the Mets donated proceeds from the game, about $450,000, to the fund for widows and children.\n\nThat night, Staub said the organization had distributed $8.3 million in the 15 years before the attacks.\n\n\u201cSince then, we\u2019ve already raised $8 million,\u201d he told The Times. \u201cYou want to get money to the widows and children, we\u2019re the ones.\u201d", "title": "Rusty Staub, Durable Batter Who Won Pennant With Mets, Dies at 73", "authors": ["Richard Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump has shown no sign that he plans to retreat from the trade action. But his administration continues to sow confusion over the breadth, scope and legality of the tariffs on steel and aluminum that Mr. Trump announced last Thursday. The White House has said those tariffs would apply to imports from all countries with no exemptions.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s tweet came as the United States, Mexico and Canada are wrapping up the seventh round of talks over the North American Free Trade Agreement in Mexico City. But no such confrontation was broadcast, and his interviews with celebrities stuck to the typical fare of fashion and film. There were no immediate indications that celebrities were bypassing him for interviews. Mary J. Blige, Christopher Plummer, Allison Janney and other Oscar nominees talked to him. But as Us Weekly reported, none of the five women up for best actress stopped by.\n\nWhile the Harvey Weinstein accusations made the red carpets at other award shows this year a primary platform for actors to voice support for sexual harassment victims and the fight against gender imbalances, Sunday\u2019s preshow event could have fit in any prior year. The federal government isn\u2019t immune to hackers, either. The systems of the Office of Personnel Management and even the S.E.C. have been breached.\n\nThe response from companies usually seems to be about keeping a lid on the hack. That\u2019s something the S.E.C. would like to end, but its guidance may not go very far in changing how companies deal with cybersecurity issues.\n\nThe S.E.C.\u2019s guidance is full of good advice. The regulator tells companies that they need to have in place \u201cdisclosure controls and procedures that provide an appropriate method of discerning the impact that such matters may have on the company and its business, financial condition and results of operations.\u201d Just as important, companies are expected \u201cto disclose cybersecurity risks and incidents that are material to investors, including the concomitant financial, legal or reputational consequences.\u201d", "title": "S.E.C.\u2019s New Cybersecurity Guidance Won\u2019t Spur More Disclosures", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "AUSTIN, Tex. \u2014 This year the South by Southwest Film Festival is celebrating its 25th edition, and my, how it has grown. She was 57.\n\nThe cause was pancreatic cancer, her husband, Charles Hirschkind, said.\n\nIn her studies, Professor Mahmood, a scholar of modern Egypt who specialized in sociocultural anthropology at the University of California at Berkeley, also challenged entrenched notions about secularism and religion, particularly in Muslim societies. She had been brought up as a Muslim.\n\nIn her book \u201cPolitics of Piety: The Islamic Revival and the Feminist Subject\u201d (2004), Professor Mahmood explored a grass-roots women\u2019s movement focused on moral reform in Cairo in the 1990s.\n\nThe movement \u2014 one face of a broader Mideast effort to revive Muslim ethical practices \u2014 was unique in that these women \u201ccame to understand that the rebuilding of a pious Islamic community could not be left to men alone,\u201d said Professor Hirschkind, a fellow scholar of sociocultural anthropology at Berkeley who had sometimes collaborated with his wife.", "title": "Saba Mahmood, 57, Dies; Traced Intersection of Feminism and Islam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "The department said the officers \u2014 one white, the other black \u2014 -\u201cbelieved the suspect was pointing a firearm at them,\u201d and each fired 10 shots. Crump, the Florida civil rights lawyer who represented the family of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager who was killed in 2012, is representing Mr. Clark\u2019s family.\n\n\u201cIt is yet another troubling example of a young, unarmed black man being shot by police under highly questionable circumstances,\u201d Mr. Crump said. \u201cFrom what we have seen so far, Sacramento law enforcement\u2019s actions \u2014 both before and after the shooting \u2014 have raised more questions than provided answers.\u201d\n\nDeMarcus Cousins of the New Orleans Pelicans, who spent seven seasons in Sacramento, has reached out to Mr. Clark\u2019s family and offered to pay for his funeral, a Pelicans spokesman and Mr. Cousins\u2019s manager said on Friday.\n\nMr. Cousins, who won the N.B.A.\u2019s community service award last year, also offered to pay for funeral expenses in 2015 for a Sacramento high school football player. Two officers fired 10 rounds each, the police told reporters, according to a report by KCRA.\n\nIt did not say whether they had previously been disciplined.\n\nMr. Clark, who the local news media said had two children, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. Investigators found a cellphone near his body but no firearms, they said.\n\nThe officers who fired their weapons have been with the department for two and four years and also had several years of experience in other departments.
