Hope Hicks has left the building.\n\nThursday was the last day for Ms. Hicks, the White House communications director known for her close ties to President Trump. There is now a palpable worry in the West Wing about whom the president will confide in \u2014 and how many other people might be able to occasionally pull him back \u2014 now that Ms. Hicks is gone.\n\nHaving trouble keeping track of all the turnover in the Trump administration? You\u2019re not alone. Here\u2019s our running tally.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. David J. Pecker, the tabloid media mogul whose company owns The National Enquirer, has always showcased his ties to President Trump. (And has long worked to protect Mr. Trump\u2019s image.)\n\nThe friendship started in the 1990s, when Mr. Trump was on a real estate comeback after his casino bankruptcies and was deeply enmeshed in New York gossip.\n\nIn a previously untold chapter in this relationship, a Times report looks at how Mr. Pecker used his powerful friend as he tried to expand his publishing business into Saudi Arabia. So far, the outcome of his efforts remains unclear.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. Jurors in Orlando, Fla., acquitted Noor Salman, the widow of the man who gunned down dozens of people at the Pulse nightclub two years ago. She had been charged with aiding and abetting a terrorist act and obstructing justice. Here\u2019s a video of how that attack unfolded.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe verdict marked a rare setback for federal prosecutors, who have a strong record of convictions in terrorism trials. Ms. Salman, 31, would have faced a sentence of up to life in prison had she been convicted.\n\nAcross the courtroom, Pulse victims and their families sat in silence. \u201cWe respect their verdict,\u201d one of the prosecutors said.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. At least 15 Palestinians were reported killed by Israeli soldiers along the border fence with Gaza.\n\nThe bloodshed came at what was meant to be a series of peaceful protests. Soon after the rally began, the Israeli military reported that protesters were rioting, rolling burning tires and hurling stones. Later, the military said that Palestinians threw Molotov cocktails at soldiers and that it had thwarted a shooting attack in northern Gaza and an attempt to infiltrate the border.\n\nThe Palestinian Health Ministry in Gaza said that more than 1,000 had been injured.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. \u201cMy only remorse is not being able to do more than dedicating my life to my country.\u201d\n\nOur Overlooked series remembers the life of Yu Gwan-sun, a Korean independence activist who organized peaceful protests against Japan\u2019s colonial rule.\n\nMs. Yu was tortured to death at 17, but is remembered as the face of Korea\u2019s 35-year fight for independence.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Say it ain\u2019t so, Joe.\n\nBig Coffee is bracing to fight a California judge\u2019s ruling that would require the beverage to be branded with cancer warning labels. (Yes, you read that right.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ruling stems from a 2010 lawsuit that charged that Starbucks and other companies did not warn consumers that ingesting coffee would expose them to acrylamide, a chemical formed when coffee beans are roasted.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. From the long ball to \u201cMoneyball.\u201d\n\nAs a new Major League Baseball season dawns, our columnist looks at how the national pastime is evolving. It\u2019s not a question of if things will change, many baseball people say, only when and how.\n\nFor the time being, here are our previews for the American and National Leagues. (And we bid farewell to Rusty Staub, a tough redheaded hitter who made six All-Star teams in a 23-year career. He died Thursday at 73.)\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. First, the Final Four times two.\n\nThe semifinals of the N.C.A.A. Women\u2019s Tournament tip off at 7 p.m. with Mississippi State playing Louisville. After that, undefeated UConn faces Notre Dame.\n\nAs UConn chases its 12th national title, our columnist ponders whether such dominance is good for the sport.\n\nOn Saturday, in the men\u2019s tourney, Loyola Chicago, a No. 11 seed, will play third-seeded Michigan, before Villanova, the 2016 champion, faces a fellow top seed, Kansas.\n\nAnd with two representatives in this Final Four, Loyola and Villanova, we examined why Catholic colleges excel at basketball.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n11. Finally, here\u2019s a flyaround look at Easter celebrations across the globe.\n\nOne highlight came on Holy Thursday, when Pope Francis washed the feet of prisoners in Rome \u2014 including two Muslims, an Orthodox Christian and a Buddhist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEveryone always has the opportunity to change life,\u201d Francis said, \u201cand one cannot judge.\u201d\n\nHave a great night.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. Oliver"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLet Cities Open Safe Injection Sites\u201d (editorial, Feb. 25):\n\nYes, Seattle plans on opening a safe injection site, recommended as a pilot project by King County\u2019s Heroin and Prescription Opioid Addiction Task Force and approved unanimously by the Board of Health in October 2016.\n\nI was pleased to vote for it, especially as my husband\u2019s young nephew died of an overdose the month before in Minneapolis. Someone dies of an overdose every 36 hours on average in King County, which has more than two million residents.\n\nPeople, including children, are finding dangerous, dirty needles in parks and public bathrooms. Unlawful fentanyl is overwhelming Vancouver, Canada, and will probably come to our beautiful city and region soon.\n\nI wish my young nephew had had access to a safe injection site. I wish that my mother hadn\u2019t become addicted to fentanyl and OxyContin prescribed by her doctor.", "title": "Opinion | Safe Injection Sites in Cities", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cStocking an Antidote at the Reference Desk\u201d (news article, March 1): Safer consumption spaces will provide people struggling with substance use disorder a safe, medically supervised environment to use drugs.\n\nIn the absence of these spaces, bathrooms in libraries, fast-food restaurants and other public spaces have become the location of last resort for those looking for a seemingly safe and private environment.\n\nWithout these safer consumption spaces, librarians and many others have been forced to become crisis caregivers who know how to identify overdose signs and administer lifesaving reversal drugs.\n\nWe will continue to see overdose deaths in public spaces, and ordinary people will be forced to do the extraordinary until we establish these spaces in New York, which my Assembly bill A.8534 would do.", "title": "Opinion | Safer Spaces for Drug Use", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Some, holding Samoan flags, made a beeline for the waka Gaualofa. At the head of the vessel was Fealofani Bruun, a 32-year-old female captain whom many \u2014 particularly \u201cMoana\u201d fans \u2014 had come to see.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Bruun said that in addition to using celestial navigation, her crew had followed traditional protocols for every part of their journey, including their interactions with one another, meal preparation and, where possible, the food they ate, including coconut cream, taro and fresh fish.\n\nHoturoa Barclay-Kerr, a master navigator who has spent decades sailing waka throughout the Pacific, was one of the creative producers of the festival opening. He lamented that the stories of Maori ancestors arriving in New Zealand had long been taught in schools as myths or fairy tales rather than recognized as history.\n\nHis own waka, the Haunui, circumnavigates New Zealand spreading a message of environmental conservation. Mr. Barclay-Kerr said the sight of a waka sailing into the bay often awakened memories among older Maori people of oral histories they had learned as children.\n\n\u201cOften they\u2019re not confident enough to talk about it until the waka arrive, because people tell them, \u2018Ah, it\u2019s just a story,\u2019 \u201d he said.\n\nStanding knee-deep in the sea on Petone Beach, a 35-year-old Haunui crew member, Dale Dice, said taking to the sea had strengthened his connection with his culture. Mr. Dice, who works as a furniture removalist, said he had tried everything he could think of \u201cto get a chance to sail around the world \u2014 but nothing worked out.\u201d\n\nTurned down for the navy, Mr. Dice joined a yacht squadron and then the Coast Guard in the hope that he would learn to sail, but it was the waka that provided the opportunity he sought. He was now preparing for a voyage to Hawaii on the double-hulled canoe in 2020.\n\n\u201cI never really knew the history of these waka,\u201d he said. \u201cBeing on board, it adds a whole new dimension to my knowledge of being Maori. I feel more Maori now.\u201d", "title": "Sailing Maori Journey, New Zealanders Rekindle Indigenous Pride", "authors": ["Charlotte Graham-Mclay"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Volvo Ocean Race is one of the most demanding sailing challenges in the world. A race around the globe held every three years in 65-foot yachts, it tests sailors in sometimes brutal weather conditions over eight grueling months.\n\nOn Tuesday, the fears of every yachtsman came true, as race organizers announced that a crew member of one of the boats was presumed lost at sea.\n\nAs the racers crossed the Pacific on leg seven, between Auckland, New Zealand, and Itajai, Brazil, John Fisher, a 47-year-old Briton sailing for a Hong Kong-based team, Sun Hung Kai/Scallywag, was swept overboard in strong winds 1,400 miles west of Cape Horn. The incident was reported on Monday, and on Tuesday morning Eastern Time, organizers said Fisher was presumed lost.\n\n\u201cThe Sun Hung Kai/Scallywag team conducted an exhaustive search for several hours in extremely challenging weather conditions, but they were unable to recover their teammate,\u201d said Richard Brisius, the race president, in a statement. Fisher was serving on watch and wearing survival equipment at the time he went overboard, organizers said.", "title": "Sailor in Round-the-World Race Is \u2018Lost at Sea\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Worried that she might die during cardiac surgery without passing on a secret she had concealed for 50 years, Sala Kirschner in 1991 handed her daughter, Ann, a battered red cardboard box from an outdated children\u2019s game.\n\n\u201cThese are my letters from the war,\u201d she said.\n\nInside was an extraordinary cache of 350 letters, postcards and photographs from family and friends that she had squirreled away from the eyes of Nazi guards as an inmate in seven forced-labor camps over five years, starting when she was just 16.\n\nThe yellowed, tattered letters \u2014 in Yiddish, Polish and German, some with Hitler stamps and inky Z\u2019s indicating that they had been censored \u2014 offered intimate if doleful glimpses of the disintegration of Jewish life before and during World War II in Mrs. Kirschner\u2019s hometown, Sosnowiec, in southwestern Poland, whose Jewish population was confined to a ghetto before 35,000 of them were deported to Auschwitz.\n\nAlthough Mrs. Kirschner may not have been aware of the letters\u2019 value, scholars like David S. Ferriero, the archivist of the United States, described them as exceptional in their sheer numbers and in what they reveal about life in the labor camps themselves.", "title": "Sala Kirschner, 94, Whose Trove of Letters Told of the Holocaust, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. Our Melissa Clark has a fascinating new article up on The Times about the chef Ilene Rosen and her new sorta-salad cookbook \u201cSaladish,\u201d recently published by Artisan. The book and the interview inspired Melissa to make a bunch of Rosen\u2019s recipes for dips for crudit\u00e9s.\n\nThere\u2019s one for sweet lime salt, which Melissa calls an intriguing combination of sugar, salt and grated lime zest. Another is for a luscious avocado-mint cream (above). And a third results in a tangy cilantro-and-cumin dip that Melissa reckons might be a great sauce for her Seder-dinner gefilte fish this week.\n\nMe, I might make one or more of them for dinner tonight, alongside a pile of carrots and radishes, cucumbers and celery. That and some rosemary spiced nuts? I\u2019m good.\n\nAlison Roman has a new recipe, for garlicky braised short ribs with red wine: classic and straightforward and powerfully delicious. And David Tanis has been busy as well. He takes us into a modernized wayback machine this week, with a new recipe for seared rare tuna served with cannellini beans, lemon and shaved fennel. That would make a nice dinner as well, some day soon, in my imaginary restaurant where Los Lobos are always on the playlist. There, 108 images \u2014 47 of them never before exhibited \u2014 and an excellent catalog provide a provocative tour through the photographer\u2019s accomplishments. It is also a record of exploration \u2014 into the past, into the country\u2019s history and photography\u2019s, stamped with a powerful vision.\n\nThe exhibition focuses first on Ms. Mann\u2019s preoccupation with family relations when her children were young and she adroitly registered the endemic conflicts and convolutions in the process of growing up. From there she set out to discover the Virginia land she lived on and nearby Southern states.", "title": "Sally Mann\u2019s Haunted South", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSally Rose Zemmol and Keith Dovie Hoffman are to be married March 4 at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan. She graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology.\n\nShe is the daughter of Luna Zemmol and Jonathan I. Zemmol of Brooklyn. He graduated from Yeshiva University.\n\nHe is a son of Cathy Hoffman and Stan Hoffman of Los Angeles. She is also the founder of an online company, Mazeltops.com, that provides customized Judaica and artwork. Putin, the Russian president. And at a National Rifle Association event that April, Mr. Trump met Alexander Torshin, the deputy governor of the Russian central bank who has been linked to both Russia\u2019s security services and organized crime, according to Mr. Torshin.\n\nMr. Torshin would later try to broker a \u201cbackdoor\u201d meeting with the campaign. Mr. Mueller and congressional investigators have obtained emails relating to the campaign\u2019s contacts with Mr. Torshin.\n\nMr. Nunberg has been asked to provide information from Nov. 1, 2015, through the present about Mr. Trump and several of his aides, including his communications director, Hope Hicks; Corey Lewandowski, his former campaign manager; Stephen K. Bannon, the president\u2019s former chief strategist; Mr. Trump\u2019s longtime bodyguard, Keith Schiller; and Michael D. Cohen, the former Trump Organization lawyer.\n\nIn a somewhat Trumpian fashion, Mr. Nunberg, in an interview, seemed more interested in the spectacle he created this week than the legal ramifications of vowing to tear up a subpoena from Mr. Mueller\u2019s team on live television.\n\n\u201cI do believe that Donald Trump and Roger Stone are right: No publicity is bad publicity,\u201d Mr. Nunberg said. \u201cTo me, it made for good TV, and everybody\u2019s talking about me.\u201d\n\n(He added that Gary D. Cohn\u2019s departure from the White House had probably bumped him from the news.)\n\nMr. Nunberg described his TV appearances on Monday as \u201cjust me letting loose.\u201d He was red-faced, defiant and nonchalant about being asked to provide documents and appear before the special counsel. Erin Burnett, the CNN anchor, asked him if he had been drinking, because she smelled alcohol on his breath. He denied it.\n\nSeveral people close to Mr. Nunberg said that he had struggled with sobriety on and off, and that contact from Mr. Mueller\u2019s team had distressed him. According to two friends of Mr. Nunberg, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they did not want to discuss his personal life, Mr. Nunberg had appeared out of sorts in TV appearances for weeks. But What Does He Know?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\n\u2018Blood in the Water\u2019\n\nSamantha Bee reveled in the Democratic candidate Conor Lamb\u2019s upset victory in a special House election in Pennsylvania. Bee said that she hopes the Democratic leadership will take the win to heart and run candidates in other red districts next year.\n\n\u201cJust two years ago, Trump won this district by 20 points. Two years before that, Democrats didn\u2019t even bother running an opponent against the Republican incumbent. You know, I\u2019m really enjoying this radical new Democratic strategy called \u2018trying.\u2019\u201d \u2014 SAMANTHA BEE \u201cHey Democrats, you know that delectable, unfamiliar aroma you\u2019re smelling today? It\u2019s blood in the water. And yes, I know you\u2019re vegans, it\u2019s fine \u2014 it\u2019s hummus in the water. Just get to work.\u201d \u2014 SAMANTHA BEE\n\nBee went on to address the student marches in support of gun control that took place across the country on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cWe cover hard topics all the time, but gun violence is the worst because honestly, I never thought anything would change,\u201d Bee said. \u201cBut I should have known better. I should have known that a generation would come that wouldn\u2019t repeat our mistakes.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrevor Noah Says Protests Were Even Louder Than Bernie Sanders\n\nTrevor Noah was stunned by how boisterous a crowd of protesters was in Washington. Senator Bernie Sanders was caught on camera delivering a speech, but his voice was all but inaudible over the crowd.", "title": "Samantha Bee Celebrates Conor Lamb\u2019s Win in Pennsylvania", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Two days after the 2016 presidential election, I held a town hall at the United States Mission to the United Nations. American diplomats were in shock; the president-elect had pledged to undo much of what we had helped achieve internationally.\n\nOne of the first people who got up to speak, a Foreign Service officer, said: \u201cI don\u2019t agree with a lot of the things Trump has said. But he doesn\u2019t seem to have a lot of people experienced in foreign policy in his inner circle. He and his team will need us. And we will have the same duty to our country \u2014 and the same privilege of serving our country \u2014 on Jan. 20, as we had when we served George W. Bush and Barack Obama.\u201d This sentiment was echoed by speaker after speaker.\n\nMany of them, along with some of our most capable diplomats, have since left government. Ridiculed as \u201cObama holdovers\u201d and unable to defend policies that depart so markedly from American interests, our diplomatic corps has been hollowed out. If Mike Pompeo, the director of the C.I.A., wins confirmation as Rex Tillerson\u2019s replacement as secretary of state, fixing this would become his responsibility. He can\u2019t change the president, but he can make it his mission to revitalize America\u2019s diplomatic corps and get back to trying to solve problems in the real world.\n\nMr. Pompeo should start by putting forward nominations for dozens of open foreign ambassadorships (including key posts like Egypt, Jordan, South Korea, Turkey and South Africa). This would give us the means of engaging officials in those countries \u2014 to promote investment, protect Americans abroad and combat terrorism. It would also send a signal that diplomats matter.", "title": "Opinion | Samantha Power: How Mike Pompeo Could Save the State Department", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "He had broken the record for consecutive strikeouts by a rookie in his debut, which had been held by Pete Richert and Karl Spooner. (In 2010, Stephen Strasburg of the Washington Nationals tied the record in his debut.) He was removed from the game after he surrendered two runs in the sixth but got the win in the Orioles\u2019 9-3 victory.\n\n\u201cThis is the one you wait for for a long time,\u201d Stewart said afterward, adding that Ray Miller, the Orioles\u2019 pitching coach, had told him, \u201cJust go hard for five or six innings.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd that\u2019s what I tried to do,\u201d he said. \u201cDidn\u2019t expect anything like this to happen, though.\u201d\n\nBy the time Stewart reached the Orioles\u2019 clubhouse, his teammates had switched the nameplate above his locker in the clubhouse with that of Jim Palmer, the Orioles\u2019 ace and a future Hall of Famer.\n\nStewart did not start often in his career. The Orioles were stocked with top-flight starters \u2014 along with Palmer, the staff included Mike Flanagan, Scott McGregor and Dennis Martinez \u2014 and Stewart became an effective, hard-working long reliever who threw more than 100 innings six times in his career. In 1981, his 2.32 earned run average ranked second in the American League.\n\n\u201cHe could really throw,\u201d Ken Singleton, his Orioles teammate, said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe had starter\u2019s stuff with an explosive fastball.\u201d\n\nThere would be other high points, like his 12 scoreless innings over two postseasons: the 1979 World Series, which Baltimore lost to the Pittsburgh Pirates, and the 1983 American League Championship Series and World Series, which the Orioles won.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a humbling sport,\u201d Stewart said before an Orioles broadcast in 2016. \u201cI never did get down.\u201d He said his wife had asked him why he listened to the blues after a loss, and he told her, \u201cThat means someone\u2019s doing worse than me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was traded to the Boston Red Sox before the 1986 season. He later reacted unhappily to Manager John McNamara\u2019s refusal to use him during that year\u2019s World Series, in which they lost to the Mets in seven games.\n\n\u201cIf they let me pitch, we would\u2019ve won that Series,\u201d he told The Globe.\n\nAfter being granted free agency by the Red Sox, Stewart did not play with another team until June 1987, when he signed with the Cleveland Indians. He proceeded to have his worst season.\n\nHe retired after that disappointing year and by 1988 had started smoking crack. He was charged in 1990 with kidnapping and assaulting his wife, the former Peggy Jean Logan, and pleaded guilty to misdemeanor assault.\n\nIn 1991 their son, Colin, who had cystic fibrosis, died in his arms. Their daughter, Alicia Stewart Allen, who also had cystic fibrosis, died in 2016.\n\nStewart\u2019s arrests multiplied \u2014 for drug and weapons possession, larceny, driving while intoxicated, passing bad checks, resisting arrest. He was imprisoned at least six times. To the North Carolina Department of Public Safety, he was a habitual felon.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve slept under bridges, on park benches out in the woods,\u201d he told The Baltimore Sun in 2006. \u201cI\u2019ve been homeless, friendless, shot at. I\u2019ve been hit with hammers. I\u2019ve been stabbed in the back over $55. I\u2019ve run over people with a car.\u201d\n\nHe pawned his 1983 World Series ring and sold his father\u2019s gun collection for drug money. His daughter told The Sun in 2006 that he had used her illness to persuade people to give him money to buy drugs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe even told someone I was dead,\u201d she said.\n\nSamuel Lee Stewart Jr. was born on Oct. 28, 1954, in Asheville, N.C., to Samuel Lee Stewart and the former Mary Faye Wardrup. Both his parents were factory workers. Growing up in Swannanoa, a small town near Asheville, Sammy acquired the nickname the Throwin\u2019 Swannanoan.\n\nHe graduated from high school in Black Mountain, N.C., and after attending Montreat Anderson Junior College, was drafted by the Kansas City Royals in 1974. He chose not to make a deal with Kansas City and signed a year later with the Orioles as an amateur free agent.\n\nHe rose through the Orioles\u2019 farm system and was 13-10, with an E.R.A. of 3.80, for Rochester when the Orioles called him up in 1978. Despite Stewart\u2019s strong, record-setting opening game, he did not find his way back into Weaver\u2019s starting rotation until four weeks later, when he gave up two earned runs over six innings in a loss to the Detroit Tigers.\n\nBy the next season, it was evident that while he would start only on occasion, he was becoming one of baseball\u2019s top long relievers, who would pitch several innings in most appearances.\n\n\u201cHe was a lovable guy and a terrific pitcher, but he was a lost soul,\u201d Palmer said in a telephone interview. \u201cThose of us who knew Sammy knew what he\u2019d gone through in his life. He was a little bit of a con man. You never knew if he was telling you the truth, but that\u2019s the same thing with anyone who has an addiction.\u201d\n\nHe is survived by his wife, the former Cherie Nechvatal; two sons, Ryan and Christian; and two sisters, Linda Banks and Judy Terra. His first marriage ended in divorce.\n\nUntil recently Stewart had been an instructor at a baseball and softball training facility in Asheville.\n\nLeslie Burrell, whose son received instruction from Stewart, told a local ABC station after his death, \u201cHe was one of those people that got kicked so many times in life and just got back up.\u201d", "title": "Sammy Stewart, Pitcher Whose Life Took a Downturn, Dies at 63", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "As he was leaving to tour out-of-town with fellow drag performers in the troupe, he explains, his parents arrived early at the stage door to say goodbye. He was mortified, as he confided to the director:\n\n\u201cAnd there they were standing in the middle of all these . . . And all they said to me was, \u2018Please write, make sure you eat and take care of yourself.\u2019 And just before my parents left, my father turned to the producer and he said, \u2018Take care of my son . . .\u2019 That was the first time he ever called me that.\u201d\n\nBen Brantley, the New York Times\u2019 chief drama critic, later wrote that the monologue \u201cbrought shattered audiences to tears when Sammy Williams delivered it.\u201d\n\nHarris Green agreed in The Times that \u201cthe longest \u2014 and most excruciatingly sentimental \u2014 of all these narratives would have been unbearable if Sammy Williams hadn\u2019t been so affectingly understated as the homosexual doomed to a career in drag shows.\u201d\n\nMr. Williams won the Tony Award for best performance by a featured actor in a musical in 1976 as well as an Obie Award.\n\n\u201cA Chorus Line,\u201d produced by Joseph Papp for the Public Theater, opened at the Shubert Theater on July 25, 1975. It played 6,137 performances, becoming Broadway\u2019s longest-running production until 1997, when it was overtaken by \u201cCats.\u201d\n\nThe script was a case of art imitating life. It was heavily drawn from taped interviews with actual dancers, leavened by a hefty dose of artistic license.\n\nPaul\u2019s story was drawn from that of Nicholas Dante, who wrote the book for the show with James Kirkwood Jr. It also mirrored Mr. Williams\u2019s own journey from personal humiliation to self-awareness and acceptance and to professional recognition.\n\nPhoto\n\nSamuel Joseph Williams was born on Nov. 13, 1948, in Trenton to Joseph Williams, a factory worker, and the former Nona Dibella, who worked in a hospital.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to his brother Carmen, he is survived by his father; another brother, Joseph; and his stepmother, Julie Williams.\n\nAs a boy, Mr. Williams would tag along to his sister\u2019s dance classes. One day, as the story goes, when she didn\u2019t feel like dancing, he announced, \u201cI can do that!\u201d \u2014 four words that were immortalized in a song by the same name in \u201cA Chorus Line.\u201d\n\n\u201cAlthough I ended up doing \u2018I Can Do That\u2019 in the show,\u201d said Wayne Cilento, who played the role of the singer and tap-dancer Mike Costa in the original production, \u201cit was actually the story of Sammy Williams.\u201d\n\nAfter graduating from Steinert High School in Hamilton Township, N.J., where he performed in school plays, Mr. Williams, at 19, went to New York to try his luck. Within a year he had landed in the ensemble of David Merrick\u2019s \u201cThe Happy Time\u201d on Broadway (where he also understudied for 20 parts). He later danced opposite Lauren Bacall in \u201cApplause,\u201d which opened in 1970.\n\nAfter winning the Tony, Mr. Williams\u2019s life imitated art.\n\nIn the play, Paul injures his knee during an audition, and, in a painful reminder of fleeting fame, he is dropped as one of the remaining candidates for the chorus.\n\nMr. Williams, who was gay, played Paul on Broadway until April 24, 1976. In mid-1978, he reprised the role in Los Angeles, hoping for film offers there. But his agent told him mercilessly, \u201cYou can put your Tony away; it doesn\u2019t mean anything in this town.\u201d\n\nMr. Williams grew a beard and managed to get cast as a drug dealer in an episode of \u201cKojak\u201d on television, but he lamented, \u201cNobody recognized me, not even my agent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 1983, he returned to the Broadway cast of \u201cA Chorus Line\u201d for two years, but by then, he said, the depictions on stage seemed less authentic.\n\n\u201cOriginally, we were those characters we played,\u201d he said at the time. \u201cThe people now are acting what we were.\u201d\n\nThe show was transformed into a film, directed by Richard Attenborough, in 1985, but Mr. Williams wasn\u2019t cast in it. (Cameron English got the part of Paul.) He later moved to California permanently and worked full-time as a florist. He also performed episodically in touring and regional productions and in a one-man autobiographical show, \u201cAnd the Winner Is.\u201d\n\nBy evoking the decades when Mr. Williams was, indeed, a winner, the show\u2019s title was an implicit reminder \u2014 if Mr. Williams or Paul San Marco needed one \u2014 of fame\u2019s ephemerality.\n\n\u201cWhen \u2018A Chorus Line\u2019 opened, we were really it,\u201d Mr. Williams said. \u201cBut when it\u2019s over, so are you.\u201d", "title": "Sammy Williams, Tony Winner in \u2018A Chorus Line,\u2019 Dies at 69", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Samuel Belzberg, a feared corporate raider of the 1980s who perfected the contentious practice known as greenmail to build one of Canada\u2019s foremost family dynasties, then reinvented himself as a successful private-equity investor, died on Friday night in a hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 89.\n\nHe had suffered a stroke, his daughter Wendy Belzberg said in confirming the death.\n\nApart from his business career, Mr. Belzberg, who lived in Vancouver, was widely known for his philanthropy devoted to Jewish causes, among them the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, one of the world\u2019s leading organizations dedicated to Holocaust research and education. He was its founding chairman.\n\n\u201cSam was both a visionary and proud Jew,\u201d said Rabbi Marvin Hier, who founded the center.\n\nMr. Belzberg will be remembered primarily as a self-made businessman \u2014 a get-out-of-my-way entrepreneur who rose from the Canadian prairie to the pinnacle of the corporate world.\n\nStarting out by selling used cars in Alberta in the 1940s, he went on to join his brothers, Hyman and William, in 1963 in founding what became First City Financial, a financial services giant and holding company, originally based in Vancouver, that would be used by the family for its high-profile corporate takeovers.", "title": "Samuel Belzberg, Corporate Raider in a Family Dynasty, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Some on the inside with the Spurs will counter that before this Leonard flap, there actually were a few flare-ups of tension behind the scenes in the intervening years. The public simply never heard much about them, according to the disclaimer, perhaps because no sports organization is better at concealing its soap operas than the Spurs.\n\nBut the veteran Spurs swingman Danny Green conceded in a recent interview that dealing with the stream of headlines about the club\u2019s tenuous relationship with Leonard \u2014 which Green called \u201cmostly just talk and rumors\u201d \u2014 is among the many adjustments that the Spurs have been coping with in their second season post-Duncan.\n\n\u201cUsually you don\u2019t hear any of that stuff around this organization,\u201d Green acknowledged.\n\nAs a longtime observer of the San Antonio machine from relatively close range, I\u2019d say what has changed is that the Spurs\u2019 centerpieces \u2014 Leonard and the All-Star forward LaMarcus Aldridge \u2014 are true modern-day stars who want to do things on their terms. This, of course, is the norm pretty much everywhere else in the basketball universe in these days of Player Power, with Cleveland\u2019s LeBron James as the league\u2019s foremost flexer. But it\u2019s a serious departure for the Spurs, who enjoyed 19 seasons of Duncan willingly doing things San Antonio\u2019s way \u2014 and everyone else in silver and black falling in line.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter its failed pursuit of Jason Kidd in the summer of 2003, San Antonio largely avoided big-name free agency for the next decade, until the summer of 2015, when the Spurs won the Aldridge sweepstakes thanks largely to some surprisingly dogged recruiting by their famously gruff coach. Popovich then surprised us all to an even greater degree in January, when he revealed that Aldridge last summer became the first Spur he had ever coached to request a trade. Popovich took the blame and vowed to use Aldridge offensively in the manner he preferred after a substandard 2016-17 campaign, which had the Spurs weighing whether to trade him.\n\nBut Leonard, after finishing third and second in Most Valuable Player Award voting the past two seasons, is San Antonio\u2019s most important player. So the resultant frenzy to try to pinpoint the true source of the media-shy Leonard\u2019s supposed discontent has been nonstop, whether it is dismay with how his injury was initially diagnosed, fears that he won\u2019t be offered the most free-agent money San Antonio can give or the fact that the Spurs have done so much to mollify Aldridge.\n\nPopovich appeared to give us a window into the Spurs\u2019 frustrations on Feb. 22 when he announced that he would be \u201csurprised\u201d if Leonard returned at all before season\u2019s end. Longtime Pop watchers quickly concluded that Leonard was the sole intended audience for that announcement, which was predictably soon followed by Leonard\u2019s first interview in nearly two months. He vowed to be back as soon as possible and said (albeit not in the firmest fashion) that he wanted to stay in San Antonio for the long term.\n\nReminders of how tranquil life used to be in the Alamo City are never far away because Duncan is a frequent visitor to the team\u2019s practice facility. It\u2019s completely normal for him to drop in while his children are at school to get in a workout or to occasionally tutor the little-known Matt Costello, who is in his first season as a Spur on a two-way contract. Yet it\u2019s unreasonable to expect anyone else to operate quite the way Duncan does.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs often as those pesky pundits (yours truly included) painted the spotlight-averse Leonard as the perfect next-generation franchise player for the Spurs, let\u2019s face it: There\u2019s only one Timothy Theodore Duncan. Shame on us for expecting Leonard to be an exact copy.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s also wise here not to underestimate Popovich, who is far more adaptable than his reputation would suggest. It\u2019s really not hard to imagine Popovich and Leonard staging their own lunch summit after the season, as Popovich and Aldridge did, to sort this all out.\n\nPoint guard Tony Parker, for one, takes comfort in the knowledge that Popovich remains the man steering the Spurs through the storm. Popovich, 69, promised Aldridge that he would stay on the bench beyond Duncan\u2019s exit as part of his free-agent pitch nearly three years ago.\n\nAnd Pop, true to his word, is still there, trying to drag a team plagued by a defensive slump, constant lineup turnover because of injuries, spotty 3-point shooting and a slew of blown fourth-quarter leads through this most un-Spurs-like season.\n\n\u201cJust one of those years so far where some things haven\u2019t gone as they have in the past,\u201d Popovich said, trying to find the most benign terms possible.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s earning his salary now,\u201d Parker said with a laugh.", "title": "San Antonio Spurs Face an Unfamiliar Opponent Down the Stretch: Discontent", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSan Francisco will take down a controversial statue depicting a submissive Native American man after an outcry sparked by a deadly rally last summer in Charlottesville, Va., led the city\u2019s arts commission to vote unanimously this week to remove it.\n\nThe statue, known as \u201cEarly Days,\u201d shows a Native American man at the feet of a Catholic missionary, who towers over him and gestures toward the ground, and a Spanish cowboy gazing off in the distance. It was built in the late 19th century as part of the Pioneer Monument, a memorial recounting California\u2019s early history that currently sits across a park from San Francisco\u2019s City Hall.\n\nCritics have called the statue racist and disrespectful, saying it promotes genocide, portrays Native Americans as inferior and relies on inaccurate stereotypes. (Among the specific critiques: that the person depicted in the statue is styled like a Plains Indian rather than a member of any California tribe.)\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s more than just racist,\u201d said Mariposa Villaluna, who helped organize a grass-roots campaign to remove the statue. \u201cIt celebrates human subjugation.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe statue has been the focus of heated debate in the past. In the early 1990s, when the city announced a plan to move the Pioneer Monument to its current location, Native American activists urged the city to leave \u201cEarly Days\u201d behind. After years of debate, the city kept the statue but installed a plaque meant to add historical context.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the decades-long effort to move \u201cEarly Days\u201d to storage was reinvigorated in August, after a deadly white nationalist rally in Charlottesville over the potential removal of a statue of the Confederate general Robert E. Lee. The episode brought more attention to a national conversation over Confederate monuments that, for some in California, resonated.", "title": "San Francisco Will Remove Controversial Statue of Native American Man", "authors": ["Michael Gold"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Hoh Rain Forest is one of the largest temperate rain forests in the United States. Situated within the Olympic National Park in western Washington State, the Hoh is protected from commercial logging and is a haven for old-growth Sitka spruce, western hemlock, coast Douglas fir, big-leaf maples and black cottonwoods. The isolated region is far from main roads and development, making the Hoh one of the quietest places in North America.\n\nThis virtual reality Op-Doc provides an immersive experience into the Hoh Rain Forest, told from the perspective of the acoustic ecologist Gordon Hempton. For the past 35 years, Mr. Hempton has been documenting the sounds of the Hoh and its many species, including Pacific tree frogs, Roosevelt elk, northern spotted owls, the red-breasted nuthatch and Pacific wrens. He believes silence is on the verge of extinction. Planes often fly over the Hoh en route to Seattle, emitting a dull roar that punctures the silence of the landscape. The Hoh is but one of many remote corners of the world being affected by noise pollution.", "title": "Opinion | Sanctuaries of Silence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSara Marie Brandsema and John David Handal were married March 2 at St. Aedan\u2019s Church on the campus of St. Peter\u2019s University in Jersey City. He has already been ordered to stand trial in another case, involving the financing of his 2012 campaign.\n\nMr. Sarkozy, one of his lawyers and a former magistrate have all been ordered to stand trial on charges of active corruption and influence-peddling, the judicial official said.\n\nThe national financial prosecutor\u2019s office had requested in October that they stand trial, but the magistrates investigating the case made their decision on the request only this week. In France, complex criminal cases are handled by special magistrates with broad investigative powers.", "title": "Sarkozy to Face Trial in Influence-Peddling Case in France", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Saudi officials have gone to great lengths of late to spotlight promises by the crown prince to let women drive and play a greater role in the country\u2019s work force; to expand entertainment opportunities; and to encourage foreign investment. Change, they say, is in the air.\n\nArab Fashion Week Riyadh, at which shows will be held in the evening for women-only audiences, will come at a time when women have more access than ever to public arts and entertainment: In January, female fans were welcomed into soccer stadiums for the first time, and a decades-long ban on cinemas was lifted in December.\n\nNow the Arab Fashion Council, which opened its regional office in Riyadh in December, plans to position Saudi Arabia as a hub for an emerging regional fashion industry, appointing Princess Noura Bint Faisal al-Saud as its honorary president. Recently it also forged an alliance with the British Fashion Council to provide support in establishing a sustainable infrastructure for the fashion industry in the Middle East and the 22 countries of the Arab League.\n\n\u201cThe first Arab Fashion Week in Riyadh will be more than a world-class event,\u201d Ms. Issa Abuzaid said when the project was announced. \u201cIt is a catalyst through which we believe the fashion sector will lead other economic sectors such as tourism, hospitality, travel and trade. Our retail sector is among the fastest growing in the world.\u201d\n\nWith two weeks to go before the start of the rescheduled fashion week, the postponement, and lack of information about it, continues to shroud the event in an aura of mystery. That said, the fashion shows in Riyadh will come at a time when Saudi Arabia\u2019s religiously conservative rules constraining the attire of women outside their homes are showing signs of relaxing. In an interview with \u201c60 Minutes\u201d on CBS this month, the crown prince said that women should be able to choose what they wear.\n\n\u201cThe laws are very clear and stipulated in the laws of Shariah (Islamic law): that women wear decent, respectful clothing, like men,\u201d Prince Mohammed said.", "title": "Saudi Arabia Almost Had a Fashion Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "RIYADH, Saudi Arabia \u2014 The lights dimmed, the conductor emerged and the nearly full house applauded as he stood before the orchestra. Then the lights went up and the cast appeared on stage in historical Arab garb.\n\n\u201cMy love, speak to me in a poem,\u201d sang the female lead, opening an opera about racism, war and love. It was remarkable not for the show itself, but for the fact that it was happening at all, on a public stage, in the conservative capital of Saudi Arabia. The recent production of \u201cAntar and Abla\u201d was part of a new, large-scale push by the Saudi government to create \u2014 virtually from scratch \u2014 a vibrant entertainment sector for its 29 million people.\n\nSaudi Arabia has long been known as one of the world\u2019s most conservative places, where bearded religious police enforced strict social codes and women cloaked their bodies and often covered their faces in public. Concerts and theater were largely banned, and even the notion of fun was often frowned upon as un-Islamic.\n\nNow the kingdom is lightening up with comic book festivals, dance performances, concerts and monster truck rallies. The New Age music guru Yanni performed there in December, as did the American rapper Nelly (for an all-male audience). The Egyptian pop star Tamer Hosny is set to perform this month, although his fans will be barred from dancing and swaying. Cirque du Soleil will make its Saudi debut this year (with less racy outfits than it uses elsewhere). And international companies are signing deals to operate movie theaters across the country.\n\n", "title": "Saudi Arabia Lightens Up, Building Entertainment Industry From Scratch", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia declared that women \u201cabsolutely\u201d are equal to men during his visit this month to the United States. But women there must still abide by so-called guardianship laws, which give male relatives the power to make many decisions integral to their daily lives. Come June, women have been promised the freedom to apply for a driver\u2019s license.", "title": "Opinion | Saudi Arabia\u2019s Remote-Controlled Reform", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Investors hoping for the chance to buy a piece of Aramco, Saudi Arabia\u2019s state-owned oil behemoth, will probably have to wait.\n\nAramco had indicated that it expected to begin trading on a public stock market later this year, but, according to three people briefed on the company\u2019s planning, that is now likely to happen in 2019. The delay reflects the difficulties in arranging what would easily be the world\u2019s biggest-ever initial public offering.\n\nThe company\u2019s potential market debut, a centerpiece of an ambitious economic overhaul of Saudi Arabia by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has drawn the interest of investors around the world \u2014 and political leaders hoping to win the listing.\n\nIn November, President Trump publicly courted Saudi officials to list Aramco on the New York Stock Exchange on Twitter. His statements were in an excerpt, released on Thursday, of a prerecorded interview with \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d the CBS News program.\n\nIran\u2019s Foreign Ministry responded by calling the prince a delusional and devious novice who \u201chas no idea of politics.\u201d\n\nSaudi Arabia, a Sunni monarchy, blames Iran for funding militias to undermine Arab states, while Shiite Iran accuses Saudi Arabia of backing Sunni extremist groups. Their struggle for regional dominance has put the two nations on opposite sides of conflicts in Yemen, Syria and Iraq that have killed hundreds of thousands of people and displaced millions.", "title": "Saudi Crown Prince Likens Iran\u2019s Supreme Leader to Hitler", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 The powerful crown prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman, 32, arrives in the United States on Monday for an extended visit during which he is scheduled to meet President Trump and tour a number of American cities.\n\nAmong his trip\u2019s goals: selling Americans on his sweeping plans to reform the economic and social life of the kingdom \u2014 and to get American investors to put money into them.\n\nOn Sunday, \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d the CBS News program, aired an episode about the prince and where he hopes to take Saudi Arabia. The quotations below were taken from a transcript provided to The New York Times.\n\nOn Islam\n\nPrince Mohammed acknowledged that Saudi Arabia has been dominated by an ultraconservative interpretation of Islam that was wary of non-Muslims, deprived women of basic rights and constricted social life by banning movie theaters and music.", "title": "Saudi Crown Prince, in His Own Words: Women Are \u2018Absolutely\u2019 Equal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCrown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia has renewed his attack on the Iran nuclear deal during a visit to the United States, saying the agreement would delay but not prevent Tehran from acquiring nuclear weapons.\n\n\u201cDelaying it and watching them getting that bomb, that means you are waiting for the bullet to reach your head,\u201d Prince Mohammed, 32, the heir to the Saudi throne, said Monday during his first meeting with editors and reporters from The New York Times. \u201cSo you have to move from today.\u201d\n\nPrince Mohammed, on a cross-country charm offensive in the United States, is visiting Washington, New York, Silicon Valley, Houston and other areas. His trip is aimed at reinforcing ties between Saudi Arabia and the United States and drumming up American investment in the kingdom. He discussed his plans for economic and social changes in Saudi Arabia, his views on the kingdom\u2019s conflicts with Iran and Qatar and the war in Yemen.\n\nThe meeting was off the record, but Saudi officials allowed some of Prince Mohammed\u2019s comments to be published.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe reserved his most forceful comments for Iran, Saudi Arabia\u2019s political and religious nemesis. The two countries follow different sects of Islam and are locked in a regional struggle for power and influence that plays out across conflicts in Yemen and Syria, among others.", "title": "Saudi Crown Prince, on U.S. Visit, Urges Tough Line on Iran", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump, the official said, urged Prince Mohammed to settle the festering battle that pits Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates against Qatar. Mr. Trump had initially sided with the Saudis and Emiratis, echoing their claims that the Qataris finance extremism and terrorism around the region.\n\nBut as the feud has dragged on, the administration has become worried about the long-term effect on unity in the Persian Gulf, especially in the face of an emboldened Iran. Anthony C. Zinni, a retired Marine Corps general and the former head of the Central Command, recently toured the gulf to try to find ways to resolve the grievances.\n\nMr. Trump repeated his description of the Iran nuclear deal, negotiated by President Barack Obama, as the \u201cworst deal ever,\u201d the official said. But he did not preview what he plans to do about it, when he faces the next deadline in May.\n\n\u201cThe Iran deal is coming up soon and you will see what will happen,\u201d Mr. Trump told reporters. \u201cIran hasn\u2019t been treating that part of the world, or the world appropriately.\u201d\n\nPrince Mohammed has cut his own wide swath in the Middle East over the last year, pushing through radical overhauls of Saudi society but also imprisoning more than 380 princes, businessmen and former government ministers in the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Riyadh, as part of an anticorruption campaign.\n\nVideo\n\nMr. Trump, who made his first overseas trip as president to Riyadh in May, has lavished praise on Prince Mohammed for his calls for tolerance and moderation, while largely ignoring his purge of the Saudi establishment.\n\nAdministration officials said Mr. Trump was focused on regional issues, like Iran\u2019s aggression and tensions in the Persian Gulf, rather than on the internal crackdown, which has led to charges \u2014 denied by the Saudi government \u2014 that it used physical abuse to get people to surrender their assets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump did raise humanitarian concerns in Yemen, an official said, though the White House has tried to head off a drive in Congress to reduce military aid for the bombing campaign. Since 2015, the United States has provided the Saudis in Yemen with air-to-air refueling, intelligence assessments and other military advice. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis has warned that cutting back that aid would harm the broader relationship.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
