View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe United States, a senior official said, has urged the Saudis, through diplomatic channels, to allow access to ports in Yemen for shipments of food and fuel. Refugee groups are calling on the president to take stronger action to ease the suffering of some three million people displaced by the fighting between the Yemeni government and Houthi rebels, who are backed by Iran.\n\nAmong those at the White House lunch were Vice President Mike Pence; the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, recently nominated by Mr. Trump to succeed Rex W. Tillerson as secretary of state; and the national security adviser, Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster. After the lunch, Prince Mohammed met with congressional leaders from both parties on Capitol Hill.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, Prince Mohammed had dinner with Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser; Jason D. Greenblatt, Mr. Trump\u2019s special envoy for Middle East peace; and Michael Bell, the senior director for the Middle East at the National Security Council.\n\nThe three Americans briefed the prince on the status of their peace plan for the Israelis and Palestinians, which is nearly finished but has run into headwinds after Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.\n\nSaudi Arabia condemned the move, which drove the Palestinians away from the bargaining table, and analysts said it was unlikely that Prince Mohammed would be able or willing to pressure the Palestinians to go back.\n\nMr. Kushner, 37, has cultivated a personal relationship with Prince Mohammed, 32, meeting him over dinner in Riyadh. But Mr. Kushner\u2019s recent loss of his top-secret security clearance has raised questions about how deeply involved he will be in delicate national security issues.\n\nFor his part, Prince Mohammed will be soliciting $35 billion in American investment to accelerate his plan to overhaul Saudi Arabia\u2019s infrastructure \u2014 part of his ambitious Vision 2030 plan, which seeks to modernize the kingdom and wean its reliance on oil.\n\nMuch of the itinerary on his two-week trip is outside Washington. He plans to travel to New York, Boston, Silicon Valley, Los Angeles and Houston, visiting companies that include Apple, Google and Lockheed Martin.", "title": "Saudi Prince\u2019s White House Visit Reinforces Trump\u2019s Commitment to Heir Apparent", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "AL MUKALLA, Yemen \u2014 Saudi Arabia said its air defenses destroyed seven ballistic missiles late Sunday, fired from neighboring Yemen and targeting at least four Saudi cities including the capital, Riyadh.\n\nThe reported barrage was said to have been launched by Houthi insurgents in Yemen, the Arab world\u2019s poorest country. If confirmed, it would be one of the rebels\u2019 most audacious assaults on Saudi Arabia since the kingdom began bombing Houthi targets in Yemen exactly three years ago.\n\nThe Saudi-owned Al Arabiya news website quoted Col. Turki al-Maliki, a military spokesman, as saying three of the missiles were directed at Riyadh and the others were fired toward the southwestern cities of Khamis Mushait, Najran and Jazan, near the Yemen border.\n\nAl Arabiya said that they were \u201claunched indiscriminately to target civilian areas and population\u201d and that fragments of the destroyed missiles landed on residential neighborhoods. The extent of any damage was not immediately clear.", "title": "Saudis Claim to Intercept 7 Missiles Fired at Cities From Yemen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "To leave the Ritz, many of the detainees not only surrendered huge sums of money, but also signed over to the government control of precious real estate and shares of their companies \u2014 all outside any clear legal process.\n\nThe government has yet to actually seize many of the assets, leaving the former detainees and their families in limbo.\n\nOne former detainee, forced to wear a tracking device, has sunk into depression as his business collapses. \u201cWe signed away everything,\u201d a relative of his said. \u201cEven the house I am in, I am not sure if it is still mine.\u201d\n\nAs the architect of the crackdown, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, prepares to travel to the United States this month to court American investment, Saudi officials are spotlighting his reforms: his promise to let women drive, his plans to expand entertainment opportunities and his moves to encourage foreign investment. They have denied any allegations of abuse and have portrayed the Ritz episode as an orderly legal process that has wound down.\n\nBut extensive interviews with Saudi officials, members of the royal family, and relatives, advisers and associates of the detainees revealed a murkier, coercive operation, marked by cases of physical abuse, which transferred billions of dollars in private wealth to the crown prince\u2019s control.\n\nCorruption has long been endemic in Saudi Arabia, and many of the detainees were widely assumed to have stolen from state coffers. But the government, citing privacy laws, has refused to specify the charges against individuals and, even after they were released, to clarify who was found guilty or innocent, making it impossible to know how much the process was driven by personal score settling.\n\nPart of the campaign appears to be driven by a family feud, as Crown Prince Mohammed presses the children of King Abdullah, the monarch who died in 2015, to give back billions of dollars that they consider their inheritance, according to three associates of the Abdullah family.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd although the government said the campaign would increase transparency, it has been conducted in secret, with transactions carried out in ways that avoid public disclosure, and with travel bans and fear of reprisals preventing detainees from speaking freely.\n\nMost people interviewed for this article spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid the risk of appearing to criticize Crown Prince Mohammed.\n\nThe government said in its email that \u201cthe investigations, led by the Attorney General, were conducted in full accordance to Saudi laws. All those under investigation had full access to legal counsel in addition to medical care to address pre-existing, chronic conditions.\u201d\n\nThe government, and several Saudi officials contacted separately, declined to answer further questions about the crackdown.\n\nThey have argued, however, that it was a necessarily harsh means of returning ill-gotten gains to the treasury while sending a clear message that the old, corrupt ways of doing business are over. And they have defended the process as a kind of Saudi-style plea bargain in which settlements were reached to avoid the time and economic disruption of a drawn-out legal process.\n\nIn a separate statement on Sunday announcing new anti-corruption departments in the Attorney General\u2019s office, the government said that King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed \u201care keen to eradicate corruption with utmost force and transparency.\u201d\n\nBut the opaque and extralegal nature of the campaign has rattled the very foreign investors the prince is now trying to woo.\n\n\u201cAt the start of the crackdown they promised transparency, but they did not deliver it,\u201d said Robert Jordan, who served as American ambassador to Saudi Arabia under President George W. Bush. \u201cWithout any kind of transparency or rule of law, it makes investors nervous that their investments might be taken and that their Saudi partners might be detained without any rationale to the charges.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA Five-Star Jail\n\nBefore dawn on Nov. 4, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, the kingdom\u2019s most famous investor and one of the world\u2019s richest men, was asleep at a desert camp where he repairs to relish the simple life when he was summoned by the royal court to see King Salman, according to two associates of his family. It was a strange request for that hour, but one does not ignore the king\u2019s wishes, so he returned to Riyadh, where his guards were dismissed, his phones taken from him and he was locked in the Ritz.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOver the next 24 hours, similar calls lured in more than 200 people, including some of the kingdom\u2019s wealthiest and most powerful men. They included Prince Mutaib bin Abdullah, a son of King Abdullah and head of one of the country\u2019s three main security services; Fawaz Alhokair, who owned the kingdom\u2019s franchises of Zara, the Gap and dozens of other stores; Salah Kamel, an elderly businessman from the Red Sea port city of Jidda; and many other princes, businessmen and former government officials.\n\nMost ended up in the Ritz, in rooms whose glass shower doors and curtain rods had been removed to prevent suicide attempts. They could watch television and order room service, but had no internet or phones.\n\nOutside, their relatives panicked, and managers of their far-flung businesses drew up contingency plans to keep operations running, unsure of how long their bosses would be gone.\n\nEventually, the detainees were allowed to reassure their families through short, monitored calls.\n\nMany were prevented from contacting their lawyers, but Prince Alwaleed spoke weekly with some of his managers, his associates said. He remained out of public sight until January, when the royal court allowed a journalist from Reuters to interview him in the Ritz to counter a BBC report that he was being kept in a cell-like room.\n\n\u201cRest assured that this is a clean operation that we have,\u201d the prince told Reuters, having visibly lost weight and grown a beard. \u201cThere is a misunderstanding and it is being cleared.\u201d\n\nThe video struck many who knew the prince as strange.\n\n\u201cIt looked artificial in many ways,\u201d said Mr. Jordan, the former ambassador, who has met the prince many times, most recently last April.\n\nWithin a few hours, he was released, but even close associates say they do not know what agreement he made with the government.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTurki Shabanah, the chief executive of a television network owned by Prince Alwaleed, said that he had spoken with the prince by phone several times while he was detained and had seen him frequently since.\n\nHe said he had \u201cno idea\u201d if the prince had reached any kind of settlement with the government, but he endorsed the crackdown on corruption as long overdue.\n\n\u201cThe way it was was not normal, not for Saudi investors nor for foreign investors,\u201d he said. \u201cThe system needed that shock to clear the past and start a new future.\u201d\n\nRepresentatives of Prince Alwaleed\u2019s company, Kingdom Holding, declined to make him available for an interview, but two associates of his family said he is under armed guard. He has told very few people, if anyone, what happened to him in the Ritz.\n\n\u201cIt is something he wants to forget,\u201d one associate said.\n\nPhoto\n\nReports of Abuse\n\nIn the early days of the Ritz detentions, as many as 17 detainees required medical treatment for abuse by their captors, according to a doctor and an American official.\n\nRelatives of some of the detainees said they were deprived of sleep, roughed up and interrogated with their heads covered while the government pressured them to sign over large assets.\n\nEvidence of such abuse has been slow to emerge, but officials from two Western governments said they deemed the reports credible.\n\nOne case involved a Saudi military officer who died in custody. One person who saw the corpse of the officer, Maj. Gen. Ali al-Qahtani, said that his neck was twisted unnaturally as though it had been broken, and that his body was badly bruised and distended. His skin showed other signs of physical abuse, the person said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA doctor and two other people briefed on the condition of the body said that it had burn marks that appeared to be from electric shocks.\n\nIn the emailed response to questions about General Qahtani, an official of the Saudi Embassy in Washington said, \u201cAll allegations of abuse and torture of those investigated during the anti-corruption proceedings are absolutely untrue.\u201d\n\nThe official added that the detainees had \u201cfull access\u201d to legal counsel and medical care.\n\nGeneral Qahtani, an officer in the Saudi National Guard who was believed to be about 60, was not wealthy himself, so his value as a major anti-corruption target is questionable. But he was a top aide to Prince Turki bin Abdullah, a son of the late King Abdullah and a former governor of Riyadh, and the interrogators may have been pressing the general for information about his boss, Prince Turki. The members of King Abdullah\u2019s family are seen as rivals of Crown Prince Mohammed and his father, King Salman.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn November, General Qahtani was taken to an elite hospital near the hotel for radiological scans and other treatment, where he showed signs of having been beaten, according to a doctor briefed on his condition.\n\nHe was returned to the hotel for further interrogation, and later pronounced dead at a military hospital.\n\nThe kingdom has never publicly provided an explanation of the general\u2019s death.\n\nMembers of the Qahtani and Abdullah families have been afraid to discuss the general\u2019s death publicly for fear of further retribution, several people who have spoken to them said.\n\nAnother of the late king\u2019s sons, Prince Mishaal bin Abdullah, complained about General Qahtani\u2019s treatment to a circle of friends, and immediately afterward Prince Mishaal, too, was arrested and locked in the Ritz.\n\nPhoto\n\nForeign Aid\n\nWhatever pressure was applied in the Ritz, the goal was to get detainees to sign over assets. In some cases, the government brought in prominent international firms to help.\n\nCrown Prince Mohammed first expressed interest in buying the Arab world\u2019s largest private media company, MBC, in 2015, according to three associates of the company\u2019s leadership. Although not considered highly profitable, MBC owns a range of satellite television stations beaming shows like \u201cThe Voice\u201d and \u201cArabs Got Talent\u201d into millions of homes, and the company has tremendous power to sway Arab public opinion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNegotiations over the sale had bogged down when a team from the international accounting firm PWC arrived to vet the company\u2019s books in October.\n\nThe company\u2019s owners and most of its board were arrested and detained on Nov. 4. Four days later, PWC\u2019s accountants visited the company\u2019s headquarters in Dubai to finish their report, according to two professionals with knowledge of the meeting.\n\nThen a second foreign firm, the British law firm Clifford Chance, drew up the paperwork to transfer the company\u2019s ownership, according to three professionals with knowledge of the deal.\n\nNeither firm publicly raised any concerns that the sellers had been detained by the buyer.\n\nA spokesman for Clifford Chance declined to comment, but one Clifford Chance lawyer involved in the work sought to distance the firm from the crackdown, saying its lawyers were retained after the detentions began and learned about them only from the news media.\n\nOne PWC accountant involved in the MBC valuation declined to comment. But another executive, speaking on the condition of anonymity because of client confidentiality rules, said PWC had played no role in helping the kingdom track the assets of those accused of corruption.\n\nNo set code of ethics governs the conduct of accounting and consulting firms in international cases but Western firms like PWC typically preach the virtues of predictable rules, transparent procedures and open markets, not state seizures of private assets.\n\nBritish law firms like Clifford Chance are subject to Britain\u2019s legal ethics code, which requires solicitors to uphold \u201cthe rule of law and the common administration of justice.\u201d\n\nStephen Gillers, an expert on legal ethics at New York University, said lawyers would not be penalized as long as they adhered to local laws \u2014 in this case, those set by the Saudi monarch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLawyers take the position that so long as they comply with the law in the nation in which they are representing their clients, they\u2019re acting ethically, even if the same conduct would be illegal or unethical in their home country,\u201d he wrote in an email.\n\nStill, he said, \u201clawyers can decline to assist conduct that they find morally objectionable even if it is entirely legal.\u201d\n\nWaleed al-Ibrahim, MBC\u2019s chairman, was released from the Ritz in late January, but has yet to return to Dubai, despite promises to his staff. In recent weeks, MBC representatives have met with Clifford Chance lawyers to finalize an agreement that will leave Mr. Ibrahim with 40 percent of the company, likely paving the way for his ouster as director, according to two professionals with knowledge of the deal.\n\nBut the company\u2019s programing has already changed. This month, it canceled six popular Turkish drama series, costing the company about $25 million, according to professionals familiar with the company\u2019s finances.\n\nThe Saudi government is at odds with Turkey over its ties with Qatar, which Saudi Arabia and its allies are boycotting. The professionals said the order came from a senior Saudi official close to Crown Prince Mohammed.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Haul\n\nThe kingdom\u2019s public prosecutor said in January that the government had reached settlements worth $106 billion, and other officials have said they expect the process to yield $13 billion in cash by the end of 2018.\n\nBut separating those two figures is the fact that relatively little cash was seized, either because the detainees did not keep large sums in Saudi banks or because they hid their cash abroad, where the government could not take it without a substantive legal process. There have been no clear indications that the government seized any foreign investments in the kingdom, nor succeeded in taking Saudi assets held abroad.\n\nMost of the seized assets, according to financial advisers and associates of the detainees, were domestic real estate and shares of companies, which the government is expected to liquidate over time, a process that could take years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCiting privacy laws, the government has given no information on what was taken from whom, but interviews with associates of the former detainees have filled in some details.\n\nThe government has taken management control of Saudi Binladen Group, the construction giant founded by Osama bin Laden\u2019s father that for decades has served as the royal family\u2019s go-to contractor. Its chairman, Bakr Binladen, remains detained, and his relatives have lost much of their private wealth.\n\nLarge sums and pieces of land have been taken from Mohammed al-Tobaishi, the former head of protocol of the royal court; Fawaz Alhokair, a retail tycoon; Khalid al-Tuwaijery, a former chief of the royal court; Adel Fakieh, a former government minister who helped Prince Mohammed develop his reform plans; and Amr Dabbagh, the former head of the government body that oversees foreign investment.\n\nPhoto\n\nRoyal Rivalry\n\nOne target is the wealth of the offspring of King Abdullah, the previous monarch. They were seen as potential rivals for the Saudi throne and since Salman became king in 2015, he and the crown prince have moved to sideline them.\n\nOne of Abdullah\u2019s sons, Prince Turki, was removed from his post as the governor of Riyadh in 2015, while another, Prince Mutaib, was dismissed as the head of the National Guard in November. Both men, and a number of their brothers, were detained in the Ritz.\n\nKing Abdullah left tens of billions of dollars in the Abdullah Foundation, which was meant to finance projects in the king\u2019s name while also serving as a piggy bank for his heirs, according to three associates of his family. After he died in 2015, the foundation paid out billions of dollars to his more than 30 children, about $340 million to each son and $200 million to each daughter.\n\nThe crown prince is seeking to recover that money, which he believes was taken illegally from a charity, according to people familiar with the negotiations. King Abdullah\u2019s children, however, consider it their inheritance.\n\nThe foundation\u2019s administrator is Prince Turki, whose aide, General Qahtani, died in custody. Prince Turki is still detained and most of his siblings and their families are banned from traveling outside the kingdom. Others are abroad in London and elsewhere, afraid to return to the kingdom that their father recently ruled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to one relative and two associates of the Abdullah family, his children are allowed to withdraw $26,000 per week each from their accounts to cover their expenses.\n\nThe government said in January that 56 people are still being held because of \u201cpending criminal cases\u201d and will be put on trial. Anyone who preferred to challenge the corruption accusations in court had the right to do so, the government says.\n\nThose who have been released say they are not really free. They have kept low profiles, unsure when the government will take the assets they signed away in the Ritz.\n\nMost are barred from travel and cannot obtain access to their financial accounts. Some detainees believe the ankle bracelets they are wearing that track their movements also transmit their conversations. Some cover the trackers with pillows or play loud music to deter potential eavesdroppers, people who have visited them say.\n\n\u201cThey want to pressure you and your kids so that you will sell your assets to be allowed to travel again,\u201d one relative of a released detainee said. \u201cIt is the same inside and outside of the Ritz.\u201d\n\nBut they have little recourse because what remains of their lives and fortunes, as well as the well being of their families, depends on their standing in Saudi Arabia.\n\n\u201cNo one can talk about what happened in the Ritz,\u201d said one associate of a former detainee. \u201cIn the end, they all have to live in Saudi Arabia.\u201d", "title": "Saudis Said to Use Coercion and Abuse to Seize Billions", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard", "David D. Kirkpatrick", "Kate Kelly", "Mark Mazzetti"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "The Iberian lynx is smaller than other species of lynx living in northern Europe, but it has the same pointy, tufted ears, large paws and glowing eyes. \u201cWe like to say beauty isn\u2019t everything, but it does count and \u2014 let\u2019s be frank \u2014 the lynx sells extremely well,\u201d Mr. Salsi said.\n\nAs a counterexample, he cited another European project to protect a freshwater mussel from pollution. \u201cPeople don\u2019t really care about what\u2019s at the bottom of the river,\u201d he said.\n\nBecause rabbits are often considered pests, the lynx has also been welcomed back by farmers, in contrast to the tensions incited by the return of brown bears and wolves in many parts of Europe, where they can also threaten the livestock.\n\nIberian farmers have allowed environmentalists to build artificial rabbit burrows on their land to help feed the lynxes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn southern Spain, landowners and tourism operators are also combining to take visitors on day-trips, in search of this elusive feline. Agust\u00edn Navarro, a rancher, said he has a couple of lynxes living near a pond on his farmland, but \u201cit\u2019s been more about feeling their presence than ever seeing them properly,\u201d he said.\n\nEven if the Iberian lynx is no longer facing extinction, its future continues to depend upon that of the rabbit, whose population first decreased significantly because of myxomatosis, a highly infectious disease, which was introduced as a control agent worldwide in the 1950s. More recently, rabbits have been killed by a viral hemorrhagic virus.\n\nWithout enough rabbits in a territory, the famished lynx will be driven to cross more dangerous roads in search of its staple diet, while females will have smaller litters.\n\nTo address the prey question, the Spanish program released 50,000 rabbits into lynx-populated areas over the past five years.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s paradoxical that each rabbit is costing us \u20ac10, where there\u2019s a plague of them in some other places,\u201d said Montserrat Fern\u00e1ndez San Miguel, an official from the state agency that runs Spain\u2019s national parks. \u201cIt\u2019s actually a fight involving two very complicated species, in which nature can raise new and unexpected obstacles every day.\u201d", "title": "Saving a Fussy Predator in Europe, With Help From 50,000 Rabbits", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "In a 1982 recipe for The New York Times, Pierre Franey called for ground sirloin mixed with Gorgonzola cheese, flattened into patties and griddled in cast iron before a flaming in cognac \u2014 you can almost hear the opening bars of \u201cLe Marseillaise\u201d through the blue flames. Perhaps my favorite chopped steak (which is what steak hach\u00e9 means) is another by Pierre Franey, in The Chicago Tribune, called \u201csteak hache (hamburger) with an egg rider.\u201d You grill sirloin patties, fry one egg per and top the burgers with them, then lay anchovy fillets around the yolks of the freshly cooked eggs. Then you sizzle a handful of capers and chopped parsley in hot butter and pour it over each beef-egg-and-anchovy stack. (In a flash of heathen inspiration, I have devised an artless inversion of Franey\u2019s method, cooking a small, fatty sirloin patty quickly until well browned outside and still almost bloody within. I then pour all the fatty juices from the pan over a halved, lightly boiled egg. The hot juices cook the egg a bit further, and marinate and warm it. I eat the egg and sirloin together over a mix of young lettuces, thinking: Now this is a fine way to eat steak and eggs!)\n\nMy contribution to the category is actually by my husband, Peter. He was forced more than inspired to its creation. I was trying different combinations of herbs and herb butter and herb sauces and dried mushrooms and other savories in an attempt to come up with a Salisbury-esque chopped steak. I asked Peter how he thought it should all be combined, and he used a little bit of everything. This means keeping the midcentury habit of mushrooms \u2014 a good idea. It also means some finicky deftness because of all the chopping and the number of sauces: two! Though I wouldn\u2019t have devised his rules, I obey them here, and it probably makes this version closer to really old than others I trim of all their steps but about one.\n\nIt goes without saying \u2014 or perhaps more correctly with what I have already said \u2014 that these buttered, herby chopped steaks do not need buns. Nor do they need the mechanical partnership of potatoes. They look and taste as good accompanied by buttery rice or a chicory salad as by spuds. If you do want your meat and potatoes to be meat and potatoes, then little ones, wedged and put in a hot oven in a cast-iron pan with a good deal of olive oil or duck fat are particularly fine.", "title": "Saving the Salisbury Steak From TV-Dinner Obscurity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Yet, the Kaddish is an odd prayer to have become the centerpiece of mourning. Despite its association with death and dying, it does not mention the word death. Instead, it is an endlessly repetitive celebration of the glory of God.\n\nThe Kaddish\u2019s origin, and its adoption by Jews as the signal act of mourning, is not entirely clear. The first words of the prayer are adapted from a verse in the Book of Ezekiel. And there are opaque references to the dominant refrain of the Kaddish \u2014 \u201cLet His Great Name be forever blessed for all eternity\u201d \u2014 in a commentary on the Bible written in Talmudic times.\n\nBut it appears that the custom of reciting the Kaddish for a deceased parent did not develop until the Middle Ages. Many scholars believe it to have been a Jewish response to the massacres of Jews of the Rhineland during the Crusades. Others have posited, based on a story about Rabbi Akiva, a leading second-century scholar, that the Kaddish was a response to the Christian concept of purgatory, and is intended as a plea to God to mitigate the eternal punishment of the deceased.\n\nWhatever its origins, the text of the prayer leaves me cold. Each day as I say the Kaddish, I struggle with the fact that I am praising a God who, according to Jewish tradition, created the world \u201caccording to His Will.\u201d Does God really will that the world endure the cruelty and suffering we see so often? And, on a more personal level, did God will that my father, an intellectual who suffered from dementia, would lose the ability to communicate and have the mental faculties of a 5-year-old during his last 18 months on earth?\n\nThe Kaddish is hardly the only prayer that troubles me. Take the 145th Psalm, which I say every day as an observant Jew. It proclaims that \u201cGod protects all those who love God, but will destroy all the wicked?\u201d Really? Do I honestly believe that\u2019s a true reflection of God or our universe?", "title": "Opinion | Saying a Prayer I Don\u2019t Believe In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "All of this has contributed to the understanding of the biological basis of A.D.H.D., and the complexity of it. \u201cThere are structural differences in brain volumes, there are connections between brain regions reflected in white matter changes in people with A.D.H.D., there are chemical changes in some of the major transmitter systems in the brain,\u201d Dr. Mahone said. \u201cWhen the brain is asked to do something, the brains of children with A.D.H.D. do the same task but the brain is less efficient.\u201d\n\nNone of the children in the study had ever taken any kind of medication for A.D.H.D., which is important, Dr. Mahone said, because questions have been raised in the past about whether having taken stimulant medications might have contributed to some of the brain differences seen in older children with A.D.H.D.\n\nBut what matters most is not so much what the brain looks like at any particular moment, Dr. Mahone said, but how the brain grows and changes; it\u2019s the trajectory that needs to be understood, and which will help project future function and target help and interventions. By starting early and following these children, there will be a lot to learn about typical and atypical development.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re betting some of them are going to grow out of it,\u201d he said, and will not eventually have the diagnosis. The matched controls will also be followed. \u201cAnd some who don\u2019t have symptoms at 4, may later on.\u201d\n\nThis is a descriptive study, Dr. Griffin said, which looks at patterns in brain development, but cannot establish cause and effect. But with longitudinal studies, looking at these children\u2019s brains as they change over time will be very important. Eventually, he said, we may be able to look at questions like, \u201cif we had started a behavioral intervention at age 2, would we still see these changes?\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is very much a biological disorder,\u201d Dr. Mahone said, and it\u2019s clearly possible to distinguish A.D.H.D. from normal 4-year-old behavior. \u201cVery clear evidence of things happening differently in the brain helps us reinforce that this is a very real condition with onset very early in life.\u201d Trying to identify it earlier and start behavioral interventions as early as possible, he said, may improve outcomes.\n\n\u201cThese children and their families are providing invaluable data that allow us to learn more about children with A.D.H.D. symptomology and atypical development as well as typical development,\u201d Dr. Griffin said. \u201cYou have children with A.D.H.D. symptomology who have to be still in a scanner; this is not an insignificant undertaking and commitment on their part.\u201d", "title": "Scans Show Differences in Brains of Preschoolers With A.D.H.D.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "AT 1 MINUTE 43 SECONDS\n\nInfectious Swagger\n\nIt\u2019s become almost expected for the charismatic tenor Vittorio Grigolo to dominate any opera he appears in. It happened again on Thursday when the Metropolitan Opera brought back Donizetti\u2019s \u201cLucia di Lammermoor.\u201d The lovely soprano Olga Peretyatko-Mariotti had admirable qualities as Lucia, but Mr. Grigolo\u2019s hotheaded, vocally burnished Edgardo is the reason to see this production. He usually manages to make an impact even in bizarre productions, as in this 2017 video from a strange, modern-dress staging of Verdi\u2019s \u201cRigoletto\u201d at the Paris National Opera. Here, as the duke, he sings \u201cLa donna \u00e8 mobile.\u201d Mr. Grigolo seems rattled at first: He and the orchestra take a phrase or two to get in sync. But once he takes off, Mr. Grigolo brings infectious swagger to the aria. When a roster of birdlike chorus girls enters the scene, he actually sings with more elegance. Catch the moment when he holds on to a melting high note as his silly companions shake their posteriors. Mr. de Blasio emphasized social justice themes in his first campaign for mayor, including what he described as overly harsh discipline practices in schools, and during the first school year of his tenure, suspensions fell 17 percent.\n\nThe trend has now swung in the other direction.\n\nIn a mandatory report to the City Council, the education department said that in September, the number of suspensions had actually decreased from the same month the year before, with 1,317 students getting suspended Then, in the next month, suspensions jumped to 4,396 and stayed at about that number for the remaining months of the calendar year, which was significantly higher than they had been the previous year. It was not clear what caused the jump.\n\nAt the end of September, a student at the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation in the Bronx stabbed two of his schoolmates, killing one of them. The principal was removed, and the school will be closed at the end of the school year. But Miranda Barbot, an education department spokeswoman, said that there were no changes made to the city\u2019s discipline policies after that episode.", "title": "School Suspensions in New York Rose 21 Percent During Last Months of 2017", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Students from the Perspectives Charter Schools in Chicago gathered as part of a nationwide protest against gun violence on Wednesday.\n\nCredit Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times", "title": "School Walkout: Photos From Across the Nation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Military invasions and outbreaks of malaria kept Emslie moving from one field hospital to another \u2014 even serving as a commanding officer \u2014 all the way until the end of the war. Even then she stayed on in the region for two more years to treat civilian surgical patients in Serbia and children in Sebastopol.\n\nDespite Emslie\u2019s distinguished war record, her marriage in 1921 disqualified her from future employment as a surgeon in Britain. Resuming a prior interest, she served three decades as honorary consultant psychiatrist at the British Hospital for Mental and Nervous Disorders in Camden, \u201cplaying a key role in the introduction of psychoanalysis to Britain.\u201d At the same time she campaigned for equal pay for women doctors and helped women achieve international pilot\u2019s licenses by demonstrating that they were not \u201cincapable of flying during periods and pregnancies.\u201d When her husband was posted to India she gave up her own career to follow him. \u201cTrapped there during the Second World War,\u201d Isabel Emslie Hutton became director of the Indian Red Cross.\n\n\u201cA Lab of One\u2019s Own,\u201d with its title salute to Virginia Woolf, is primarily an English war story. \u201cBroad Band,\u201d in contrast, mostly takes place in the United States of the 1940s through the 1990s, and is peopled predominantly with all-American girls wanting, as Time magazine once quipped, \u201ca ROM of their own.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nThe author, Claire L. Evans, has met and managed to interview most of the principals in this recent history of technology. Her familiarity puts the reader on a first-name basis with all of them, as well as with two important predecessors \u2014 Ada (Countess of Lovelace, generally considered the world\u2019s first programmer) and Grace (Admiral Hopper, the Navy\u2019s much decorated queen of software).\n\nEvans proves a companionable guide for a tour through cyberspace. An insightful, intelligent observer, she speaks fluent tech lingo, has written about science and sci-fi for the likes of Vice and Wired, and also sings in a pop group.\n\n\u201cWhen we say the words \u2018internet\u2019 and \u2018web,\u2019\u201d Evans writes, \u201cwe often mean the same thing: the force, larger than nature, that emanates from our screens.\u201d But the internet predates the web by decades. It harks back to the time when folks \u201cdialed directly into each other\u2019s machines and into host computers to exchange files and post messages\u201d in text-only format. \u201cMany of these ad hoc networks interacted with, and eventually coalesced with, the infrastructure of the internet,\u201d a map of which today \u201cis a tensile, crazy, fractal thing\u201d akin to \u201ca beating heart, a web of synapses, a supernova.\u201d The World Wide Web sits atop the internet, functioning as \u201ca network of interconnected visual pages built in a shared language called HTML \u2026 structured pages of text, images and video dotted with clickable links connecting individual points to one another. Those connections don\u2019t just influence how we navigate the web \u2026 but how we communicate with one another, and ultimately how we understand the world.\u201d\n\nThe women pioneers who penetrated the mostly male domain of early computing did not always fit the geek mold. When Radia Perlman, for example, enrolled in her first programming course as a high school student in the 1960s (and many more courses later as an odd-woman-out at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology), she discovered that her classmates had been dismantling radios and other electronics from a tender age. \u201cI never took anything apart,\u201d she told Evans. \u201cI would have assumed I would break it or get electrocuted.\u201d Nevertheless, Evans reports, Perlman invented a protocol for moving information that is now fundamental to the way computers are networked. \u201cHer work might be invisible to the everyday user, but it\u2019s invisible in the way that laws are invisible or the rules of traffic in a busy city are invisible: It directs the flow of information at a layer beyond our conscious awareness.\u201d", "title": "Science\u2019s Invisible Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump ordered the expulsion of 60 Russian officials on Monday, joining a coordinated campaign by two dozen countries to retaliate for the poisoning of a former Russian spy in Britain in a Cold War-style escalation that again highlighted the disparity between the president\u2019s words and actions.\n\nThe mass expulsion of Russian personnel stationed in the United States was the largest ever, eclipsing even the darkest days of the global showdown with the Soviet Union. But Mr. Trump avoided any public condemnation of Russia\u2019s role in the attack just days after phoning President Vladimir V. Putin to congratulate him on a re-election widely considered a sham.\n\nIn approving the expulsions and ordering the closure of the Russian Consulate in Seattle, Mr. Trump followed the lead of Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain, who rallied a multinational coalition to respond to the poisoning. With London pressing for action, Mr. Trump called foreign counterparts to see if they would join, too. Aides said he encouraged them to take part, but he also knew that failure to go along would have left the United States isolated.\n\nIn addition to the United States, at least 22 other nations backed Britain by expelling about 57 more Russian diplomats and intelligence officers as of Monday evening, including France, Germany, Italy, Australia, Poland and Canada. Shaub Jr., who until last July was the director of the Office of Government Ethics, pointed out that federal ethics guidelines say that \u201cemployees should consider declining gifts when they believe that their integrity or impartiality would be questioned if they were to accept the gift.\u201d\n\nAccording to the E.P.A., the landlord of the building was Vicki Hart, the president and founder of a health care lobbying firm that does not have business before the agency.\n\nHer husband, J. Steven Hart, is the chairman of a Washington lobbying firm, Williams & Jensen, with several energy clients including OGE Energy Corporation, Cheniere Energy and Colonial Pipeline.\n\nAccording to lobbying disclosure records, Mr. Hart\u2019s firm reported lobbying the E.P.A. on behalf of OGE Energy, an energy company based in Oklahoma, on greenhouse gas regulations and other rules affecting electric utilities. The forms were previously reported by E&E News.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Hart did not respond to a request for comment.\n\nE&E News reported that Mr. Hart said that he had not personally lobbied the E.P.A. in the past two years and was unaware that his firm had done so, and that a federal disclosure form listing him as having lobbied the E.P.A. on behalf of a glass-container manufacturer was an error that he would ask to have corrected.\n\nDemocrats in Congress were quick to criticize the agency chief. \u201cFrom the very beginning, Scott Pruitt has acted as if the E.P.A. is his own personal fiefdom,\u201d Representative John Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, who sits on the House committee that oversees the agency, said in a statement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Also last year, the E.P.A. asked a federal court to delay the haze rule requirements for Texas. A federal court later denied the request.\n\nBrian Alford, a spokesman for OGE Energy, said the company was previously unaware of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s rental agreement.\n\nMr. Hart\u2019s firm through the end of 2017 also represented Cheniere Energy, lobbying on issues \u201crelated to the export of liquefied natural gas (LNG), approval of LNG exports and export facilities,\u201d according to a disclosure report.\n\nMr. Pruitt traveled to Morocco last year to promote the export of natural gas. That trip is the subject of an investigation by the E.P.A.\u2019s inspector general, based on requests from Senate Democrats.\n\nIn a statement, Rachel Carmichael, a spokeswoman for Cheniere Energy, noted that the company had not been aware of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s rental arrangement and had not used Mr. Hart\u2019s company to lobby the E.P.A.\n\nJeffrey Lagda, a spokesman for the Office of Inspector General, said his office had been made aware of Mr. Pruitt\u2019s living arrangement and declined to say whether the office was considering an investigation.\n\nOn Friday, ABC News reported that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s daughter had also lived in the apartment, while she held an internship at the White House last summer. Chief, Rented Residence From Wife of Energy Lobbyist", "authors": ["Brad Plumer", "Eric Lipton"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Pruitt has flipped the script. As Oklahoma\u2019s attorney general, he sued the E.P.A. 14 times, and he has spent the past year working to undo regulations that would have required farmers to restrict their fertilizer use; oil and gas firms to control global warming pollution from their wells; and Midwestern power plants to burn less coal.\n\n\u201cHe has made a big splash,\u201d Mr. Reilly said. \u201cThe mission he is on is not one that his predecessors at E.P.A. have recognized. And it could be a good strategy to win the constituency that elected the president.\u201d\n\nMr. Pruitt\u2019s precise political path forward is not certain. He is viewed as a likely candidate to run for a Senate seat in Oklahoma in 2020 if the incumbent, James Inhofe, retires. But it remains unclear if Mr. Inhofe, 83, will do so, and his office declined to comment. There is also speculation that Mr. Pruitt might jump in as a last-minute candidate in this year\u2019s governor\u2019s race.\n\nWhen asked about its boss\u2019s ambitions, Mr. Pruitt\u2019s staff emphasizes that he is focused only on the job at hand. It also notes that the E.P.A. chief has made a significant effort to promote his work. \u201cAdministrator Pruitt has utilized a wide array of news outlets to advance President Trump\u2019s agenda on regulatory certainty and environmental stewardship,\u201d his spokesman, Jahan Wilcox, wrote in an email. Through Mr. Wilcox, Mr. Pruitt declined an interview request.\n\nSome former E.P.A. chiefs noted that Mr. Pruitt\u2019s unusual speed at attempting to dismantle regulations could mean that those efforts might not stand up to later legal challenges. \u201cThe policies he\u2019s pushing play very well in his home state and with the base \u2014 but you can\u2019t do them overnight,\u201d said Christine Todd Whitman, who headed the E.P.A. in the George W. Bush administration and before that was the governor of New Jersey. \u201cThey\u2019re getting rushed out. I don\u2019t think the homework is being done. It makes for good sound bites, but they might not stand up legally.\u201d\n\nThat might not affect Mr. Pruitt\u2019s longer-term political aspirations, though. \u201cPruitt could be gone from E.P.A. by the time that happens,\u201d Ms. Whitman said.\n\nAmong the largest regulations Mr. Pruitt aims to roll back, at Mr. Trump\u2019s direction, is an Obama-era clean water rule, known as Waters of the United States, which would have restricted the chemical fertilizers used by farmers. The rule has been particularly unpopular with the rural voters who make up the core of Mr. Trump\u2019s base. This year, Mr. Pruitt announced he would freeze implementation of the rule and issue a more farmer-friendly version by the spring.", "title": "Scott Pruitt, Trump\u2019s Rule-Cutting E.P.A. Chief, Plots His Political Future", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "We don\u2019t have the details of the new policy. But don\u2019t be fooled by this talk of transparency. He and some conservative members of Congress are setting up a nonexistent problem in order to prevent the E.P.A. from using the best available science. These studies adhere to all professional standards and meet every expectation of the scientific community in terms of peer review and scientific integrity. In the case of the air pollution studies, a rigorous follow-up examination was done by the Health Effects Institute, a nonprofit research group that studies air pollution. The institute corroborated the findings.\n\nIn taking this action, Mr. Pruitt appears to be adopting the policies of the Honest and Open New E.P.A. Science Treatment Act, a bill aimed at the agency. Conservative lawmakers have tried to pass versions of this bill before to shackle the agency\u2019s rule making. That law would prohibit the E.P.A. from taking any action \u201cunless all scientific and technical information relied on to support\u201d it is \u201cspecifically identified, and publicly available in a manner sufficient for independent analysis and substantial reproduction of research results.\u201d\n\nAn analysis of a similar bill introduced in 2015 by the Congressional Budget Office estimated it would cost $250 million a year over the first few years to carry out because it would require new \u201cdata collection, correspondence and coordination with study authors, construction of a database to house necessary information, and public dissemination\u201d of the information.\n\nThe analysis, which did not appear to take into account the cost of redacting details like trade secrets or personally identifiable medical information, also predicted the agency would reduce by half the number of studies it relies on in developing policies and regulations because of the cost of complying with the law.\n\n\u201cThe quality of the agency\u2019s work would be compromised if that work relies on a significantly smaller collection of scientific studies,\u201d the analysis found.\n\nThis approach would undermine the nation\u2019s scientific credibility. And should Mr. Pruitt reconsider regulations now in place, this new policy could be a catalyst for the unraveling of existing public health protections if the studies used to justify them could no longer be used by E.P.A.\n\nSo why would he want to prohibit his own agency from using these studies? It\u2019s not a mystery. Time and again the Trump administration has put the profits of regulated industries over the health of the American people. Fundamental research on the effects of air pollution on public health has long been a target of those who oppose the E.P.A.\u2019s air quality regulations, like the rule that requires power plants to reduce their mercury emissions.", "title": "Opinion | Scott Pruitt\u2019s Attack on Science Would Paralyze the E.P.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Prosecutors said Dr. Strampel failed to take steps to protect patients from Dr. Nassar when allegations of abuse emerged. He neglected, the prosecutors said, to follow a set of protocols that would, for instance, have required Dr. Nassar to conduct exams only with other staff members present. \u201cDespite his representation of his (and the college\u2019s) intended response to the allegations against Nassar, Strampel did not actually enforce or monitor these protocols, nor did he alert other employees in the Sports Medicine Clinic about the existence of the protocols,\u201d the charging documents said.\n\nThe police detective\u2019s affidavit outlining the charges also described a series of disturbing interactions between Dr. Strampel and four female medical students, none of whom were named publicly. In several of the cases, the women said they had gone to meet with Dr. Strampel to discuss their academic work but that he had turned the conversation to other topics.\n\nOne woman who said she had been summoned to Dr. Strampel\u2019s office after falling asleep in class said that he told her to \u201cturn around in a circle twice so that he could observe her body,\u201d and that he said that she was \u201cnever going to make it in the profession if she did not dress sexier.\u201d When she was later called to a dinner honoring scholarship recipients at a club on Michigan State\u2019s golf course, she said Dr. Strampel reached around and gripped her buttock as they posed for photos, according to the affidavit.\n\nAnother student who had failed a medical school test said she was required to meet with Dr. Strampel, who asked her what her \u201cPlan B\u201d was since \u201cshe could not cut it in medical school.\u201d The student said Dr. Strampel told her he would do her a favor by letting her take the exam again, but that she would then be required to do anything for him. \u201cGiven the context,\u201d the affidavit said, the woman \u201cunderstood that she was being asked to the case, said that Dr. Strampel made inappropriate sexual remarks, beginning soon after she started school in 2006.", "title": "Scrutiny of Michigan State\u2019s Role in Nassar Case Brings New Sex Charges", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 A reconstruction of an ancient statue of a winged bull destroyed by ISIS is the latest public art installation to sit on a sculpture platform here known as the Fourth Plinth, on Trafalgar Square.\n\nThe sculpture, by the American artist Michael Rakowitz, titled \u201cThe Invisible Enemy Should Not Exist,\u201d was unveiled on Tuesday. It depicts a re-creation of Lamassu, an Assyrian statue that stood in Iraq in the ancient city of Nineveh, on the outskirts of modern-day Mosul, until 2015 when the militant group destroyed it along with other irreplaceable works of ancient art.\n\nLamassu is a mythological creature known for its protective qualities. It has the head of a man and the body of a winged bull. Mr. Rakowitz\u2019s re-creation is made of 10,500 recycled cans of date syrup; dates were a key export in Iraq before war shrank the industry.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times when he was shortlisted for the commission, Mr. Rakowitz described his work as \u201ca placeholder for the thousands of human lives that have gone missing and can\u2019t be reconstructed.\u201d", "title": "Sculpture of Winged Bull Destroyed by ISIS Is Recreated for London\u2019s Fourth Plinth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was a performance filled with clarity and projection, dramatic inflection and intelligence,\u201d Anna Kisselgoff wrote in The Times the first time he danced the title role of George Balanchine\u2019s \u201cApollo\u201d in New York, in November 1985. \u201cHow incredible that a dancer could assume a new role so burdened with baggage about its historic importance and make it so naturally his own.\u201d\n\nAlmost exactly one year later, Mr. Lavery was dancing Balanchine\u2019s \u201cWho Cares?\u201d on opening night of City Ballet\u2019s season when he knew something wasn\u2019t right.\n\n\u201cI started to walk and, just walking, kind of stumbled,\u201d he recalled later. \u201cI finished the performance, but I was scared. My left leg was stupid, lazy. I really had to concentrate to use it.\u201d\n\nIt was an early inkling of the tumor and the end of his dancing career. He was 30.\n\nOwen Sean Lavery was born on Aug. 16, 1956, in Harrisburg, Pa. His father, Eugene, was a supervisor at Bell Telephone, and his mother, the former Rose A. Flood, was a homemaker.\n\nHe began his ballet training at 10. He studied at the Pennsylvania Ballet School and, in 1973, joined the San Francisco Ballet. In 1975, he joined the Frankfurt Opera Ballet in Germany. The next year, he began taking classes at City Ballet\u2019s School of American Ballet. He was invited to join the company in 1977 and quickly became a reliable presence with his suave, solid partnering.\n\n\u201cMr. Lavery continues to impress with his forthright virtuosity,\u201d the dance writer Don McDonagh wrote in The Times in June of that year, and two days later, reviewing another performance for the paper, Clive Barnes said of him, \u201cA newcomer this season, he seems a very sound cavalier.\u201d\n\nMr. Lavery was promoted to soloist in early 1978 and later that year made a principal dancer. Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and Mr. Martins all created roles for him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHis size, his proportions, are quite wonderful,\u201d Robbins once said of him, adding that \u201che has a very elegant line, but it is a very human line \u2014 never so aesthetic that the ability, strength and the vigor of the man are ever lost.\u201d\n\nThe company put his abilities to good use; sometimes he was featured in all eight performances a week. The spinal tumor, though, cut his career short. In January 1987 he underwent an eight-hour surgery to remove it.\n\nMany fans had not known why he suddenly disappeared from City Ballet\u2019s programs, but in November 1987 The New York Times Magazine chronicled his operation and slow rehabilitation. \u201cA Dancer\u2019s Nightmare,\u201d the article was titled.\n\nAfter the surgery, Mr. Lavery said, he could not feel his leg at first. \u201cI didn\u2019t know where it was unless I looked at it,\u201d he said.\n\nHe began intensive therapy and, barely a month after his surgery, insisted on attending a matinee at City Ballet, using a walker and accompanied by Marika Molnar, the company\u2019s physical therapist.\n\n\u201cMarika and I forgot that I hadn\u2019t learned how to do stairs on the walker yet,\u201d he recalled. \u201cWe took a car to the theater, went in backstage, got to the stairs, looked at each other and burst out laughing. But she just told me what to do, step by step, and I did it.\u201d\n\nHe eventually recovered enough that he could teach dance, which he did at City Ballet and at Barnard College.\n\nIn addition to Ms. Alsedek, Mr. Lavery is survived by another sister, Patrice Lavery, and a brother, Michael.\n\nMr. Lavery retired from City Ballet several years ago. As Mr. Martins\u2019s right-hand man, his duties had included scheduling the company\u2019s seasons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is very difficult,\u201d he told The Times in 1996, describing the challenges of balancing ballet types, dancers\u2019 availability, audience expectations and more. \u201cMaddening! When I started doing this eight years ago, I\u2019d think, \u2018Great program!\u2019 Then, \u2018Oh, my God, three ballets with black and white costumes, a gala performance for the colorblind!\u201d", "title": "Sean Lavery, Ballet Star in a Shortened Career, Dies at 61", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBOB HONEY WHO JUST DO STUFF\n\nBy Sean Penn\n\n176 pp. Atria Books. $24.\n\nWhat have you done this time, Sean Penn? What is this book-shaped thing that lies before us? Is it just a lark \u2014 a nutty novel you wrote because you\u2019re famous and they let you? Or is it more than that \u2014 a furious, despairing takedown of America as the country battles its own worst instincts? If it\u2019s the latter, why did you bury your truest feelings and loveliest writing so deep in muck? \u201cBob Honey Who Just Do Stuff\u201d might have had the power of a manifesto. Instead, it\u2019s a riddle wrapped in an enigma and cloaked in crazy.\n\nPenn originally created \u201cBob Honey\u201d for a short audiobook in 2016, which he narrated but playfully denied writing, insisting it was the work of a guy he\u2019d met in Florida named Pappy Pariah. Bob is a 56-year-old Californian with \u201can ultraviolent skepticism toward the messaging and mediocrity of modern times.\u201d Profession-wise, he is one of the following or some combination thereof: a globe-trotting entrepreneur, a contract killer who murders elderly people with a mallet or just a delusional homebody whose neighbors think he\u2019s weird.\n\nUnwaveringly true to its title, \u201cBob Honey Who Just Do Stuff\u201d has no formal plot. Our antihero sits on his sofa recalling possibly imaginary exploits and lamenting the state of the nation, which he regards as \u201ca shopping mall with a flag.\u201d He loathes his ex-wife, who\u2019s now happily coupled with her divorce lawyer and driving an ice-cream truck, the twinkly music of which punishes him from a distance. He pines for a sex-positive young woman named Annie, who may or may not exist and who inspires such purple rain as this: \u201cEffervescence lived in her every cellular expression, and she had spizzerinctum to spare.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOccasionally, Bob will attempt to be more social by throwing a misbegotten barbecue \u2014 or he\u2019ll go out and dispatch a senior citizen with a blow to the head. (The folks who issue the kill orders believe the elderly stand in the way of marketing and globalization.) What narrative tension \u201cBob Honey\u201d does have comes courtesy of a man claiming to be an investigative journalist who shows up at Bob\u2019s door and, as Penn might put it, punctures his peace and piques his paranoia. If that sounds like an unfair swipe at the prose, take a look: \u201cThere is pride to be had where the prejudicial is practiced with precision in the trenchant triage of tactile terminations.\u201d That\u2019s a sentence about hunting, by the way.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo be fair, \u201cBob Honey\u201d is perplexing and unquantifiable by design. Penn has clearly ingested the Beats, as well as Hunter S. Thompson and Chuck Palahniuk, and he evokes their trippiness to advance a sincere argument: that right now, America is enough to drive any rational, empathetic person nuts. Some of Bob\u2019s adventures \u2014 helping victims of Hurricane Katrina, nosing around Baghdad at the outset of the Iraq War \u2014 overlap with the author\u2019s own habit of following his conscience and not waiting for invitations. That seems like a nice, self-effacing wink to the reader, suggesting that Penn the Untamable Activist is also just figuring out stuff as he goes.", "title": "Sean Penn, Satirist, Swings at America in a Wild Debut Novel", "authors": ["Jeff Giles", "Sean Penn"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Sebastian Coe, the Olympic champion who now runs track and field\u2019s global governing body, has been accused of misleading a parliamentary investigation into sports doping and corruption.\n\nCoe, beloved as an athlete in Britain and the leader of the 2012 Summer Games in London, ascended to the presidency of the International Association of Athletics Federations in 2015. In a report published Monday, he faced blistering criticism over answers he gave to the group of British lawmakers about an extortion scheme run by officials, including his predecessor, which sought to blackmail Russian athletes who had failed drug tests.\n\nIn a hearing and in written submissions to the digital, culture, media and sports committee, Coe said he had not been aware of specific allegations of corruption in Russian athletics before the scandal was first publicly exposed by a German television documentary in December 2014. At that time he was vice president under the I.A.A.F. president Lamine Diack.\n\nHowever, the report details telephone and email contact between Coe and Dave Bedford, also a former middle-distance runner and the longtime director of the London Marathon. Bedford called Coe in August 2014 to tell him that the Russian athlete Liliya Shobukhova had been forced to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars to cover up a failed drug test that would have ruled her out of the 2012 London Olympics. Coe had also been the head of the organizing committee for the London Games.", "title": "Sebastian Coe Misled British Lawmakers, Parliamentary Committee Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSANTIAGO, CHILE \u2014 Sebasti\u00e1n Pi\u00f1era, a political conservative, returned to Chile\u2019s presidency on Sunday, vowing to revive an economy that slumped under the departing center-left leader Michelle Bachelet.\n\nMs. Bachelet handed the presidential sash to the president of Congress, who then swore in Mr. Pi\u00f1era \u2014 who himself turned over the office to Ms. Bachelet in a similar ceremony four years ago.\n\nMr. Pi\u00f1era, a billionaire entrepreneur, oversaw growth that averaged 5.3 percent a year during his first term from 2010 to 2014, aided by pro-business policies, rising prices for Chile\u2019s chief export, copper, and a giant rebuilding effort following a magnitude 8.8 earthquake that hit just before he took office.\n\nA slump in copper prices helped sour Ms. Bachelet\u2019s second round as president, with the economy \u2014 and the president\u2019s popularity \u2014 slipping badly in 2014 and 2015. Ms. Bachelet, the first women to lead the country, had been wildly popular when she ended her initial term and handed power to Mr. Pi\u00f1era.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFrom Day 1, Pi\u00f1era is going to want to show that under him, the wheels of the economy will start to spin again,\u201d said Crist\u00f3bal Bellolio, a professor of government at the Adolfo Ib\u00e1\u00f1ez University.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But its accompanying lightning injured a middle-school teacher in Manchester Township, N.J., who was holding an umbrella while outside on bus duty. The teacher, a 33-year-old woman, was hospitalized and expected to survive.\n\nIn New York, by 8 p.m., Con Edison was reporting over 30,000 customers were without power, with Westchester County among the hardest hit. Long Island reported that nearly 30,000 customers were affected by outages there.\n\nAcross the region, in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, electric companies said that thousands of workers have been deployed to work on restoring electricity. Thousands of people across the Northeast have not had electricity since a winter storm blew across the region last week. They have waited, bundling up in their cold houses, staying in hotels or squeezing in with relatives and friends, as the time they were told their power would be restored has been pushed back repeatedly. He will serve as an adviser to Mr. Parker until then.", "title": "Second Top Nike Executive Departs Amid Complaints of Workplace Behavior", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "In the age of \u201c1,000 Things to Do Before You Die,\u201d what are the benefits of under-scheduling?\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for meaningful experiences, chances are you\u2019re not going to get them by hustling around checking things off your list. You need time to discover, to reflect, to have a conversation with a stranger. In my experience, that\u2019s when something really special can happen. Also, under-scheduling gives our minds a break from the regular grind. Slowing down can be really restorative and that\u2019s one of the many reasons that we travel.\n\nImage Sara Clemence. Credit Britney Young\n\nWhat are your tips for meeting people while traveling?\n\nStarting a conversation with a total stranger is challenging whether you\u2019re traveling or not. It really helps to ask a question. One of my favorite ways to start an actual conversation with somebody is to ask about food because so many people really like to give their opinions about food. So, ask them where they like to eat. There\u2019s a fine distinction between asking, where should I eat \u2014 I being the tourist \u2014 and where do you like to eat. Sometimes people will give a tourist-friendly place. But if you ask where they like to eat, it\u2019s more likely to yield a local, interesting restaurant or food stall or market.\n\nYou advise leaving the camera at home to focus on the experience. Is there some way to shoot and be mindful?\n\nIt can really help to be more thoughtful about how you use your camera. Say you\u2019re only going to take three photos a day or only photograph certain kinds of things. Photographers say everybody needs to be taking fewer better photographs. It has a dual effect. One, it makes you more thoughtful about what photographs you\u2019re taking and it also removes the temptation to photograph everything.\n\nHow can families practice mindfulness while traveling?\n\nLetting your kids help plan your travels is a big one, because then it becomes a team effort. They\u2019re invested in what you\u2019re doing. It\u2019s important to set limits on devices just as you set limits on yourself. When your kids start getting bored, it can be really hard not to rush to fill their time with some sort of activity. It\u2019s perfectly healthy for children to be bored. When we were traveling for six months last year, my 5-year-old son started making toys out of whatever materials we had at hand. He would make a house out of tissue box, or he\u2019d make a bottle into an airplane. It made me feel we were accidentally enhancing his resourcefulness.", "title": "Secret to a Great Trip: Ditch the Devices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "THE CRUEL PRINCE\n\nBy Holly Black\n\n384 pp. Little, Brown Books for Young Readers. $18.99.\n\n(Ages 15 and up)\n\nImage\n\nJude is a human girl who lives in Faerieland. But hold on: This is a book by Black, so it\u2019s not the pretty fairy story you might imagine. Jude, her twin sister, Taryn, and their half-faerie sister, Vivi, were \u201cstolen from the mortal world\u201d by their mom\u2019s former husband, Madoc, a faerie general who murdered their parents. The sisters have been living under the protection of Madoc, the closest thing they have to a father. \u201cIt\u2019s just not a comfortable kind of love,\u201d Jude explains. They know tricks for surviving as humans there, like salt for their food and dried berry necklaces to resist enchantments. Even so, they\u2019re bullied, especially by Prince Cardan and his friends, who call them \u201cThe Court of Worms.\u201d\n\nWhile Jude embraces toughness, seeking knighthood in the High King\u2019s Court \u2014 \u201cI do not yearn to be their equal,\u201d she says, \u201cI yearn to best them\u201d \u2014 Taryn hopes to fall in love, marry a faerie, and fit into her adopted society. The twins\u2019 plans grow more disparate after the High King decides to step down and crown an heir the ruler of Elfhame. Of course, it\u2019s not as easy as all that, with conspiracies, intrigue and evil at every turn.\n\nBlack is a master at world-building, conveying integral details without that information ever seeming tedious or encyclopedic, whether you\u2019re well versed in faerie or a newcomer to the genre. It\u2019s an especially neat trick because the experience of reading a novel like this is something like being surrounded by magic. Jude, who possesses just enough badness that you really root for her \u2014 faeries don\u2019t lie, but she can, and she uses that \u2014 will have fans eager to follow her. Good thing the book kicks off a trilogy.\n\nTHE PRINCE AND THE DRESSMAKER\n\nBy Jen Wang\n\n288 pp. First Second. $16.99.\n\n(Ages 14 and up)\n\nImage Credit\n\nIn this graphic novel, Prince Sebastian of Belgium has a secret life: He likes to wear dresses, the more dramatic the better, as a way to escape \u201cother people deciding what\u2019s acceptable.\u201d Meanwhile in Paris, a young seamstress named Frances dreams of becoming a famous designer. She\u2019s fulfilled the request of one customer to (hilariously) \u201cmake her look like the devil\u2019s wench\u201d at a ball. While the gown horrified the ladies of the court, it caught the eye of Sebastian, who, keeping his own identity hidden, hires Frances to make dresses for him.\n\nThe two realize they are kindred spirits, and soon enough, Frances figures out she\u2019s working for the prince, not a princess. \u201cYou\u2019re not weirded out?\u201d he asks her. \u201cWhat difference does it make?\u201d she responds. \u201cThis is my dream job.\u201d But as Sebastian and Frances introduce their fantastical new looks to the public (he appears as the ever-fashionable, increasingly popular Lady Crystallia), secrets get harder to keep. And then there\u2019s the issue of Sebastian needing to find a bride.", "title": "Secrets, Lies and a Murder (or Three) in the Latest Y.A. Crossover Novels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "BURNLEY, England \u2014 Jack Cork wears his status lightly. The Burnley midfielder has been aware of it since his brother pointed it out a few weeks ago, and he is proud of it, too. He is much too bashful to draw attention to it, though, and much too circumspect to read too much into it.\n\nBurnley has played 30 games in the Premier League this season: 2,700 minutes (plus injury time) of soccer in what is marketed as the most intense league in the world. And Cork has been there for every second of it.\n\nThis status does not make Cork unique. There are 11 other players who have yet to miss a minute of the current Premier League season. The majority \u2014 as should be expected \u2014 are goalkeepers, the one position where conventional wisdom still decrees that permanence is paramount. The other four are central defenders.\n\nBut since early March, Cork has been the only midfielder in the group.
