But at a seaside resort known for its raunchy entertainment scene, she gets arrested for helping to conduct a sex workshop.\n\nHoping to avoid deportation, she offers information about President Trump and Russia. But her appeal is for naught. No one has stepped forward to grant her asylum.\n\nSuch has been the saga this week of Anastasia Vashukevich, who also goes by the name Nastya Rybka.\n\nThe 21-year-old model and blogger was arrested Sunday in the Thai holiday town of Pattaya along with nine others involved in the sex training course, which was aimed at male Russian tourists.\n\n\u201cShe will be deported,\u201d said the chief of Thailand\u2019s Immigration Bureau, Suttipong Wongpin, in an interview Thursday. \u201cHer immigration offense is working without a work permit.\u201d", "title": "Seeking Asylum, an Escort Has a Tale of Trump and Russia to Offer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Under the new state rules, insurers in Idaho would still have to offer policies that comply with the Affordable Care Act on the state\u2019s health insurance exchange, a web-based marketplace for individual and business plans. But in policies sold outside that exchange, Idaho insurers could omit some of the benefits required by the Affordable Care Act. Under the guidelines that emerged from Idaho\u2019s executive order, those policies would not have to comply with federal limits on out-of-pocket costs and they could impose caps on the dollar amount of benefits available to consumers.\n\nSome people with pre-existing conditions could be denied coverage for up to 12 months if they had not maintained \u201ccontinuous prior coverage.\u201d And insurers could in some cases charge different rates based on a person\u2019s health status. Insurers would be able to ask consumers if they have had any of numerous medical conditions, including cancer, heart disease, diabetes, AIDS and asthma.\n\nSome groups representing patients, including the American Heart Association, the American Diabetes Association and the lobbying arm of the American Cancer Society, have denounced Idaho\u2019s plans, saying they fear that some people will actually end up paying more. The new, cheaper plans would appeal to the healthiest people, they said, leaving less healthy people in a shrinking pool of people seeking coverage that meets the Affordable Care Act standards.\n\n\u201cA.C.A. premiums would increase, and options for individuals with pre-existing conditions would narrow,\u201d the American Academy of Actuaries, a nonpartisan professional group in Washington warned in a letter to the Idaho Department of Insurance.\n\nGary Ottman, a farmer in south-central Idaho who sells malt barley to the brewers of Coors beer, said he just wanted something that works.\n\n\u201cWith being self-employed, you can\u2019t go on a group plan, and you\u2019re pretty much like a lone wolf out there \u2014 they pick you apart,\u201d said Mr. Ottman, 60. He said that he was satisfied for a while under an Affordable Care Act policy that he bought for himself and his wife, Teresa. But then their premiums soared to more than $900 a month, he said, with a $7,500 deductible before a first claim would be paid. Politicians who promise to fix the system and don\u2019t follow through, including Congress with its failed efforts to repeal the health care law, are part of the problem, Mr. Ottman said.\n\n\u201cIt disgusts me to no end that these politicians go in there and keep telling you what they think is best for you and they don\u2019t know nothing about you,\u201d he said.", "title": "Seeking Cheaper Health Insurance, Idaho Bucks Affordable Care Act", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "All three, at Homer\u2019s gentle insistence, cycled through their memories of their playing days, telling stories, cracking jokes, amiably mocking one another. When Lovett lost the thread on one anecdote, Williams suggested with a smile that perhaps he should be in the audience, not on the stage.\n\nSkillfully, Homer seizes on every little story to spark something in the group. He asks where the players used to drink, and asks those listening if they remember the pub, if they know where it is. He mentions cafes and ice cream parlors, some long since closed, and cars that have not been on the road for decades.\n\nAt one point, he breaks into an impromptu chorus of \u201cWonderful Copenhagen,\u201d from the 1952 musical film \u201cHans Christian Andersen.\u201d A few of the guests take up the tune. They remember the lyrics perfectly.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe key is to go into their world, not drag them into yours,\u201d Homer said. He brings along old newspaper clippings and weathered programs as prompts, each one passed around, and pored over, by the group.\n\nSome visitors join in more readily than others, but whenever Homer \u2014 or any of his guests \u2014 brings up a player, even a name long forgotten, the reaction is universal. As Lovett tells a story about playing against Johnny Haynes, a revered 1950s star for Fulham, there is a ripple of recognition, a murmur of approval.\n\nThese sessions do not cure dementia. They cannot. Nonetheless, their effect can be profound. Some of that comes from the simple act of socializing, organizers said, since many of those living with dementia find themselves increasingly isolated.\n\n\u201cThe clinical impact of loneliness is massive,\u201d said Tony Jameson Allen, co-founder of the Sporting Memories Foundation, an organization that uses similar reminiscence therapies to run more than 100 such programs in Britain. \u201cPeople with dementia often see their social circles reduce significantly. Groups like these can be really powerful.\u201d\n\nIncreasingly, soccer is being used as their focal point. A number of teams \u2014 including Everton and Wolverhampton Wanderers, West Brom\u2019s fierce local rival \u2014 run similar programs, and the National Football Museum in Manchester opens its doors for patients suffering with dementia, too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLiddell said that she has seen how effective it can be firsthand. \u201cWhen they come here, they all talk and interact, and they see that they are not alone,\u201d she said. \u201cThere is a definite benefit for their well-being.\u201d\n\nMost of all, though, the pleasure and the purpose are in the acts of remembering, of being able to remember, of feeling like themselves again.\n\n\u201cThis disease strikes at the heart of identity,\u201d said Jason Karlawish, a co-director of the Penn Memory Center at the University of Pennsylvania. \u201cIt can lead to a fractured sense of who you are. The logic of an activity like this is to kindle emotionally salient memories that tap back into that identity.\u201d\n\nHe noted that while there was no data proving such therapies had a curative effect, much the same could be said of medication. \u201cThese are substantive programs,\u201d he said.\n\nOver the years, Glover has seen hundreds of people like Griffiths attend the sessions, but the experiences of one or two have stayed with him.\n\n\u201cWe had one woman who came to the group with her father,\u201d he said. Under Homer\u2019s guidance, the man started to talk about the games he had seen, the players he had watched, the highs and lows. He was no longer someone with dementia. He was what he always had been, what he still was: a West Brom fan. The visit was just as powerful for his daughter.\n\n\u201cShe said that when he was here, she did not see him as she knew him,\u201d Glover said, but as something, someone else. \u201cShe said she saw him as his younger self.\u201d", "title": "Seeking Solace, and Finding Strength, in Shared Soccer Memories", "authors": ["Rory Smith", "On Soccer"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDid you apply for college this year and write an undergraduate application essay about money, work, social class or related topics? If so, I\u2019d like to see it.\n\nI write the personal finance column for The New York Times, and since 2013 I\u2019ve been collecting as many essays like this as I can find each spring and publishing a handful of great ones in early May. You can read a selection of essays from 2017 here.\n\nWhat qualifies? A description of your job at McDonald\u2019s is welcome, as are musings on what it\u2019s like to have no earthly idea what you want to be when you grow up. We\u2019ve published stories about the struggles of families who are poor and disquisitions on towns where parents can cover for their children\u2019s recklessness with their cash and connections. Reckoning with wealth (yours or that of others) is welcome, as are all attempts to wrestle with its absence and the impact of that.\n\nPlease submit your essays to us by Wednesday, April 25, using the form on this page. We\u2019ll publish a few of them during the first weekend in May and pay the writers our normal freelance rate.\n\nAlso, anyone who wants to send in a bit of multimedia to go with the essay is welcome to do so below. Videos, Instagram Stories or Snapchat stories are all fine. If you are submitting a story from either Instagram or Snapchat, please download it and send it as a video file.\n\nNot including multimedia will not hurt your chances, but we\u2019re open to the possibility that anything else you might want to include besides your words could bring your relationship with money to life.", "title": "Seeking Your College Application Essays About Money", "authors": ["Ron Lieber", "Your Money"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Secretary of State Rex W. He did not mention, however, that the Trump administration has proposed slashing funding for both programs, along with other aid efforts seen as vital in Africa. Mr. Tillerson is scheduled to visit Ethiopia, Djibouti, Kenya, Chad and Nigeria.\n\nThough it will be his first trip to the continent as secretary of state, Mr. Tillerson noted that \u201cin my previous life, I spent quite a bit of time in Africa.\u201d\n\nAs chief executive of Exxon Mobil, Mr. Tillerson was known as a take-no-prisoners negotiator who pushed deals in African countries such as Nigeria, Equatorial Guinea, Chad and Angola that have been widely accused of corruption and poor human rights. I\u2019d like to thank President Trump, the vice president and his wonderful national security team, including my close friend General McMaster. I explained to President Trump that his leadership and his maximum pressure policy, together with international solidarity, brought us to this juncture. I expressed President Moon Jae-in\u2019s personal gratitude for President Trump\u2019s leadership.\n\nI told President Trump that, in our meeting, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said he is committed to denuclearization. Kim pledged that North Korea will refrain from any further nuclear or missile tests. He understands that the routine joint military exercises between the Republic of Korea and the United States must continue. And he expressed his eagerness to meet President Trump as soon as possible.\n\nPresident Trump appreciated the briefing and said he would meet Kim Jong-un by May to achieve permanent denuclearization.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Republic of Korea, along with the United States, Japan, and our many partners around the world remain fully and resolutely committed to the complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlong with President Trump, we are optimistic about continuing a diplomatic process to test the possibility of a peaceful resolution.\n\nThe Republic of Korea, the United States and our partners stand together in insisting that we not repeat the mistakes of the past, and that the pressure will continue until North Korea matches its words with concrete actions.", "title": "Seeking \u2018Peaceful Resolution\u2019: Transcript of South Korean Adviser\u2019s Remarks", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis tragic incident makes clear that autonomous vehicle technology has a long way to go before it is truly safe for the passengers, pedestrians, and drivers who share America\u2019s roads,\u201d said Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut.\n\nThe Uber car, a Volvo XC90 sport utility vehicle outfitted with the company\u2019s sensing system, was in autonomous mode with a human safety driver at the wheel but carrying no passengers when it struck Elaine Herzberg, a 49-year-old woman, on Sunday around 10 p.m.\n\nSgt. Ronald Elcock, a Tempe police spokesman, said during a news conference that a preliminary investigation showed that the vehicle was moving around 40 miles per hour when it struck Ms. Herzberg, who was walking with her bicycle on the street. He said it did not appear as though the car had slowed down before impact and that the Uber safety driver had shown no signs of impairment. The weather was clear and dry.\n\nUber said it would work with the police.\n\n\u201cOur hearts go out to the victim\u2019s family,\u201d an Uber spokeswoman, Sarah Abboud, said in a statement. \u201cWe are fully cooperating with local authorities in their investigation of this incident.\u201d\n\nTempe, with its dry weather and wide roads, was considered an ideal place to test autonomous vehicles. In 2015, Arizona officials declared the state a regulation-free zone in order to attract testing operations from companies like Uber, Waymo and Lyft.\n\n\u201cWe needed our message to Uber, Lyft and other entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley to be that Arizona was open to new ideas,\u201d Doug Ducey, Arizona\u2019s governor, said in an interview in June 2017.\n\nUsing an executive order, Mr. Ducey opened the state to testing of autonomous vehicles that had safety drivers at the wheel, ready to take over in an emergency. He updated that mandate earlier this month to allow testing of unmanned self-driving cars, noting that a \u201cbusiness-friendly and low regulatory environment\u201d had helped the state\u2019s economy.\n\nEven when an Uber self-driving car and another vehicle collided in Tempe in March 2017, city police and Mr. Ducey said that extra safety regulations weren\u2019t necessary; the other driver was at fault, not the self-driving vehicle.", "title": "Self-Driving Uber Car Kills Pedestrian in Arizona, Where Robots Roam", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "But these days, ad agencies are using classical music as more than a jokey device or a signifier of wealth and sophistication. A snippet of Arvo P\u00e4rt\u2019s \u201cSpiegel im Spiegel\u201d threads through an ad for the rugged but hardly luxe Jeep Cherokee. And Coke, while a classic, is the most democratic of beverages.\n\nIt may have something to do with pop fatigue.\n\n\u201cThe name of the game is to stand out,\u201d said Jon Pearce, the chief creative officer at Hudson Rouge, a boutique ad agency in the WPP network. \u201cIf you\u2019re going up against a lot of commercials with contemporary music and energy, the way to get attention is to land on people\u2019s ears in a different way.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSome products split the difference. A Delta faucet ad that began airing in 2016 uses \u201cHabanera\u201d from Bizet\u2019s \u201cCarmen\u201d to underscore the elegance of the fixtures in question, and an electronic dance beat shows how hard those fixtures work. A 2017 Mountain Dew ad, set in an underground garage, led off with a hip-hop rhythm, then segued into Chopin\u2019s Fantaisie-Impromptu in C-sharp minor.\n\nAnd there is this: Classical music can be cost effective. \u201cThere are so many production catalogs that have lush orchestral versions of all these songs that don\u2019t require purchasing rights because they\u2019re in the public domain,\u201d said Chris Clark, the director of music at Leo Burnett U.S.A. \u201cIt\u2019s wonderful to be able to open the classical music treasure chest.\u201d\n\nAgencies also benefit from what the composer and arranger Robert Miller calls the recognition factor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe thing about \u2018Hall of the Mountain King\u2019 is that there was something profoundly familiar and legitimate about it that was going to allow the animation to come to life in a way that brand new music may not have allowed,\u201d said Mr. Miller, who scored the current Coke commercial as well as several other Coke ads that used classical music.\n\nAs Karl Westman, the director of music at Ogilvy, put it: \u201cThis music immediately pulls the switch for us. Even if we\u2019re not mavens we understand it because it\u2019s so deeply seated in our daily lives.\u201d\n\nA half-dozen years ago, Mr. Westman deployed the \u201cWilliam Tell\u201d Overture in a commercial for the deodorant Dove Men +Care and, more recently, the \u201cAnvil Chorus\u201d from Verdi\u2019s opera \u201cIl Trovatore\u201d in an ad for a technology client.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother plus: Bach and friends aren\u2019t around to object. \u201cIt\u2019s fantastic working with a dead composer,\u201d said Hal Curtis, the creative director of the ad agency Wieden & Kennedy. \u201cThey like all your comments, they listen to all your ideas, and they do exactly what you want.\u201d\n\nThe risk for advertisers is turning off the audience. \u201cPeople could be intimidated by classical music or feel they\u2019re out of their depth,\u201d Mr. Muhlenfeld of the Martin Agency said. There\u2019s also a hazard of being just a bit too obvious: reflexively trotting out Delibes or Debussy to provide the soundtrack for a scene that shouts \u201ctuxedo territory.\u201d\n\n\u201cClassical music will always do the job,\u201d Mr. Clark of Leo Burnett said. \u201cBut as a creative professional, you don\u2019t want to just say, \u2018Let\u2019s use \u201cPeer Gynt,\u201d\u2019 and then press play on it. You want to alter the instrumentation or juxtapose it with something contemporary. You want to show people how indelible these compositions are and how enjoyable in different contexts.\u201d", "title": "Selling Products With a Swelling Score", "authors": ["Joanne Kaufman"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Senate took a key step on Tuesday toward loosening rules imposed after the 2008 financial crisis as some Democrats joined with Republicans to vote to begin debate on legislation that would roll back restrictions on large parts of the banking industry.\n\nIn a rare demonstration of bipartisanship, the Senate voted 67 to 32 to allow the bill to proceed, setting the stage for a vote this week that rewrites parts of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act.\n\nWhile the bill is intended to provide relief to thousands of small and midsize banks, the prospect of deregulating the financial industry has laid bare a fissure in the Democratic Party, pitting moderate Democrats who support easing bank rules against progressives who view the bill as a gift to Wall Street.\n\n\u201cThis deregulatory bill puts the entire economy at risk,\u201d Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, said on Tuesday. \u201cWe\u2019re not here to do the bidding of Wall Street banks. We\u2019re here to do the bidding of the American people.\u201d", "title": "Senate Advances Bill to Loosen Banking Rules, Revealing Democratic Split", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Fox News published the texts, which were sent via a secure messaging application, in early February. President Trump and other Republicans loyal to him quickly jumped on the report to try to discredit Mr. Warner, suggesting that the senator was acting surreptitiously to try to talk to Mr. Steele.\n\n\u201cWow! -Senator Mark Warner got caught having extensive contact with a lobbyist for a Russian oligarch,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote at the time. \u201cWarner did not want a \u2018paper trail\u2019 on a \u2018private\u2019 meeting (in London) he requested with Steele of fraudulent Dossier fame.\u201d\n\n\u201cAll tied into Crooked Hillary,\u201d Mr. Trump added.\n\nThe Fox News article made prominent mention of work by Mr. Waldman\u2019s Washington lobbying firm on behalf of Oleg V. Deripaska, a Russian aluminum magnate who was once close to Paul Manafort, Mr. Trump\u2019s indicted former campaign chairman.\n\nCopies of the messages were originally submitted by Mr. Waldman to the Senate committee. In January, one of Mr. Nunes\u2019s staff members requested that copies be shared with the House committee as well, according to a person familiar with the request who was not authorized to talk about it publicly. Days later, the messages were published by Fox News, the person said. Fox\u2019s report said that it had obtained the documents from a Republican source it did not name.\n\nThe documents published by Fox News appear to back up the senators\u2019 accusation. Though they were marked \u201cCONFIDENTIAL: Produced to USSSCI on a Confidential Basis,\u201d suggesting that they had come from the Senate panel, known as the United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, the person familiar with the congressional requests said that the stamp was misleading and that other markings gave away their actual origin.\n\nSpecifically, the copy of the messages shared with the Senate had page numbers, and the one submitted to the House \u2014 while preserving the reference to the Senate committee \u2014 did not.\n\nA lawyer for Mr. Waldman independently concluded that the House committee had probably shared the document and sent a letter to Mr. Nunes complaining about the leak, according to a person familiar with the letter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Burr appeared to make a veiled reference to the texts during a public hearing with the heads of the government\u2019s intelligence agencies last month.\n\n\u201cThere have been times where information has found its way out, some of it recent, where it didn\u2019t come from us, but certainly people have portrayed it did,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd that\u2019s O.K., because you know and we know the security measures we\u2019ve got in place to protect the sensitivity of that material.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Democrats have repeatedly accused Mr. Nunes of using his position to protect Mr. Trump from the investigation.\n\nThe House committee spent much of the last month locked in a bitter dispute over the secret Republican memorandum, which accused top F.B.I. and Justice Department officials of abusing their powers to spy on one of Mr. Trump\u2019s former campaign advisers. Republicans released the document over the objections of the Justice Department and the F.B.I., which warned in a rare public statement that it was dangerously misleading.\n\nDemocrats called the document reckless and said it was merely a political tool to tarnish the agencies investigating Mr. Trump\u2019s potential ties to Russia. They eventually released their own memo, drawn from the same underlying material, rebutting it.\n\nThe Senate committee has conducted its investigation primarily in private, and Mr. Burr and Mr. Warner remained in lock step both publicly and privately. When Fox News published Mr. Warner\u2019s texts, for example, an aide to Mr. Burr told the network that he had been aware of Mr. Warner\u2019s contacts with Mr. Waldman, and the two senators issued a joint statement condemning the leak.\n\nSenator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and another member of the Intelligence Committee, also defended Mr. Warner.\n\nAnd while Mr. Nunes\u2019s memo consumed Republicans in the House, as well as officials in the White House, Mr. Burr largely steered clear of it. He told CNN it ought not to have been released, and in private he discounted it.\n\nIn the hearing with the intelligence chiefs last month, he sought to draw a distinction between his committee\u2019s approach and that of the House.\n\n\u201cI promised you when we started a year ago that the sensitive nature of that material would, in fact, be protected,\u201d he said. \u201cThe vice chairman and I have done everything in our power to do that.\u201d", "title": "Senate Intelligence Leaders Say House G.O.P. Leaked a Senator\u2019s Texts", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "A decade after the federal government rescued the first of many faltering financial firms, the Senate voted on Wednesday to pass legislation that would relax restrictions on large parts of the banking industry, representing the most significant changes to the rules that were put in place after the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nIn a rare showing of bipartisanship, the Senate voted 67 to 31 to pass the bill, which is intended to help small- and medium-size banks but which critics say is a dangerous rollback of financial regulations intended to prevent another meltdown.\n\nThe legislation faces an uncertain fate going forward, as House Republicans are expected to push for a much more expansive rollback of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act. Senate Democrats who voted for the bill that passed on Wednesday have insisted that major changes along the lines of what the House passed last year will sink the effort but expressed hope that the legislation could herald a return to the kind of cooperation that has recently eluded Congress.\n\n\u201cThis legislative package is an example of what we can achieve by working together and shows Democrats and Republicans can break the gridlock,\u201d said Senator Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana.", "title": "Senate Passes Bill Loosening Banking Rules, but Hurdles Remain in the House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Multiple Republican officials said Mr. Bryant was likely to pick somebody who would run for the seat in November, avoiding a caretaker. The question now is whether Mr. McDaniel will drop his challenge to Mr. Wicker and try to claim Mr. Cochran\u2019s seat.\n\nMr. McDaniel, a hard-line conservative with a history of making inflammatory statements, had remained silent about his 2018 intentions for months, waiting to see whether Mr. Cochran would resign. By waiting until Monday to reveal his intention to step down, Mr. Cochran effectively forced Mr. McDaniel to enter the race against Mr. Wicker.\n\nYet even as he formally declared his bid last week, Mr. McDaniel did not rule out changing races.\n\n\u201cWhile it is certain that Mississippi will have two U.S. Senate races this year, I am currently focused on my campaign against Roger Wicker,\u201d he said in a statement Monday, \u201cbut all options remain on the table as we determine the best way to ensure that Mississippi elects conservatives to the United States Senate.\u201d\n\nMr. Wicker, for his part, was asked by reporters at the Capitol if he was relieved to see Mr. Cochran step aside. \u201cNo,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s sad news.\u201d\n\nMr. Bryant has not offered any hints about whom he would appoint to replace Mr. Cochran, but Republicans close to the governor said he would not choose Mr. McDaniel.\n\nImmediately after Mr. Cochran put out word on Monday that he would leave the Senate after nearly four decades, the senator\u2019s top aide and close adviser, Brad White, said, \u201cI hope he appoints somebody who can win a general election.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Last week, David Baria, the State House Democratic leader, announced his intention to run for Mr. Wicker\u2019s seat. Democrats have also wooed Brandon Presley, a cousin to Elvis Presley and the chairman of the state\u2019s Public Service Commission, to run for the Senate.\n\nMike Espy, a former Democratic congressman and agriculture secretary in the Clinton administration, said late Monday that he would consider running for Mr. Cochran\u2019s seat.\n\nMr. Espy, who is African-American and from a prominent Delta family, could be a formidable candidate in a state where black voters make up much of the Democratic Party.\n\nDemocrats are watching which race Mr. McDaniel chooses, hoping to put their most formidable candidate against the state senator.\n\nMr. Cochran has been a genteel presence in the Senate for decades, but in recent years his physical decline has become apparent. On Monday, as the Senate voted on two judicial nominations, he was guided into the chamber by aides and was silent as reporters peppered him with questions.\n\nHis decision to leave opens up the coveted chairman\u2019s spot on the Senate Appropriations Committee, where leadership is determined by seniority. The senator next in line is Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama. Asked if he wants the job, Mr. Shelby said, \u201cIt would be a great honor, but I\u2019m not there yet,\u201d and added, \u201cI would be interested at the proper time.\u201d\n\nLongtime members of the Senate said they were sorry to see Mr. Cochran go. \u201cI\u2019m devastated,\u201d said Senator Patrick J. Seat", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg", "Jonathan Martin"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Senate rejected a bipartisan effort to halt American military support for the deadly Saudi-led bombing campaign in Yemen, as lawmakers from both parties declined on Tuesday to support a rare attempt to limit the president\u2019s war powers.\n\nThe resolution, which brought together a handful of Republicans and liberal Democrats, provided a venue for a highly unusual debate on the Senate floor, on the 15th anniversary of American forces entering Iraq, over the extent of the use of force abroad and Congress\u2019s role in doing so. But by a vote of 55 to 44, the measure was ultimately referred back to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for further debate without a final vote.\n\nIn a show of opposition, the Trump administration sent Pentagon and State Department officials to Capitol Hill last week to make the case in a classified briefing that the measure was misguided and could do lasting damage to the United States\u2019 relationship with a key Arab ally, Saudi Arabia. Tuesday\u2019s debate played out as President Trump met with the influential young Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, at the White House.\n\nTrump administration officials insist that American involvement in Yemen has been limited to noncombat support like intelligence sharing, logistics and military advice \u2014 and therefore is technically out of the senators\u2019 reach. The officials have also raised concerns that an affirmative vote could have set a precedent that would have hemmed in American forces and diplomatic efforts in the Middle East.", "title": "Senators Reject Limits on U.S. Support for Saudi-led Fight in Yemen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Federal officials have also concluded that Russian hackers targeted election systems in 21 states and breached that of at least one, Illinois, during the last election cycle. No votes were changed, though.\n\nDan Coats, the director of national intelligence, told the Senate committee at a hearing last month that the intelligence agencies were still grappling with these twin challenges: neutralizing Moscow\u2019s disinformation campaign and securing the integrity of vulnerable election systems around the country. The senators shared that assessment.\n\n\u201cThe Russians were relentless in attempting to meddle in the 2016 elections, and they will continue their efforts to undermine public confidence in Western democracies and in the legitimacy of our elections,\u201d Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, told reporters on Tuesday after the recommendations were released.\n\nThe senators called on Congress to \u201curgently\u201d make available funds and other resources for states to update voting software and systems, institute vote audits and hire additional staff and contractors focused on cybersecurity.\n\nThe senators said 14 states had used at least some machines in 2016 without a paper trail that could be audited. Five states used only those machines.\n\nAt the same time, they took pains to make clear that while it was the states\u2019 responsibility to run their own elections, the federal government should play a significant role in monitoring threats and providing resources. Both were to blame for missteps in 2016, they said.\n\n\u201cWe were all disappointed that states, the federal government, the Department of Homeland Security were not more on their game in advance of the 2016 elections,\u201d Mr. Warner said. While the department had made important improvements since then, he added, it was still a work in progress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe senators pointed to top state election officials, who have complained in recent weeks that the federal government has left them in the dark on specifics of the threat to voter databases, machines and other systems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Intelligence Committee is likely to try to illustrate those breakdowns and possible solutions on Wednesday during a hearing with Homeland Security and state election officials on attempted attacks by the Russians on state election systems in 2016 and the federal response.\n\nThe committee has also assembled a classified written report on election security. But the document has to be submitted to the intelligence agencies for review and declassification before it can be released publicly, which could take weeks or months.\n\nMore than a year into its investigation into Russia\u2019s meddling, the Intelligence Committee has thus far offered little visibility into its work. Witnesses have come and gone in relative secret. Staff members and lawmakers have pored over thousands of pages of documents related to the Trump campaign, as well as sensitive government secrets.\n\nAnd while the House Intelligence Committee shut down its investigation last week amid rancorous partisan disputes, the Senate panel is said to be nowhere near completion, with months of work left to go. Whether the increased scrutiny that comes with being the only remaining investigation on Capitol Hill will change that remains unclear.\n\nIn a show of bipartisan resolve, nearly every member of the committee took part in Tuesday\u2019s announcement and those who spoke endorsed the committee\u2019s findings.\n\nThe committee\u2019s leaders had last updated the public on the investigation in October, when they said that a review had broadly confirmed the conclusions of American spy agencies that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia directed a campaign of hacking and propaganda to disrupt the 2016 presidential election. They said then that their investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian effort was still open.\n\nMr. Burr said that Tuesday\u2019s recommendations and the accompanying report would be the first in a series of findings that the committee would release in the coming months, as it closed out portions of the investigation. He said to expect the next update from the committee in about a month.\n\nThe panel does not plan to draft specific legislation related to its election security findings given its lack of jurisdiction, but Mr. Burr said its members would work with the relevant committees to implement the recommendations. Lawmakers in both chambers have introduced competing bills to address security at the ballot box and cyberdefenses, but Republican leaders who control the House and Senate have shown little interest in advancing them.\n\nThe House panel, for its part, is scheduled to vote on Thursday to release a final report drafted by Republicans that includes more than 20 election-related recommendations.", "title": "Senators Warn About Russian Election Meddling and Call for Paper Ballots", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Matthew Rosenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "I was determined to prove they could. That meant fighting many decades of opposition to having women in front-line combat roles. This was especially true in the Marine Corps, where we say, \u201cEvery Marine a rifleman.\u201d Those riflemen are the infantry troops who put themselves in the paths of bullets and bombs while carrying heavy rucksacks, who jump out of planes and otherwise subject their bodies to extreme wear and tear.\n\nUntil recently, women had been officially excluded from the infantry, even as they unofficially served in combat jobs \u2014 going on patrols as military police or medics, or getting caught in ambushes while driving in convoys. This all changed when the Defense Department required that by 2016 all military occupations, including the infantry, be opened to women.\n\nThe Marines were the only service to request a waiver to not integrate women into some combat positions. The Pentagon rejected that request, but statistics suggest the corps has dragged its feet. About 500 Army women serve in combat jobs, 10 have graduated from the elite Ranger school, and 74 have graduated from the infantry or armor basic leader\u2019s course. They have met the same exacting standards \u2014 for push-ups, speed and the weight they carry in their packs \u2014 as the men. But only 11 female Marines have made it into the infantry. And only one woman has made it through the punishing Marine infantry officer course.\n\nThe Marine Corps has taken some steps. It recently introduced women to Marine Combat Training at Camp Pendleton, Calif., which had been all male, and brought in male drill instructors to train female recruits at Parris Island. The Marine Corps says that where schedules permit, men and women sometimes train side by side in boot camp. But that is a far cry from full integration, where men and women compete against each other, work through problems together and learn to respect each other as teammates \u2014 all the things that happen in combat.\n\nIn the Marine Corps, the perception that women can\u2019t do some things as well as men quickly becomes reality, because of how we conduct entry-level training. For officers, it starts with little comments at the Basic School for new officers (which is gender integrated). At my own training, I heard comments like \u201cStay with your teams \u2014 make sure the females make it over the walls in the obstacle course.\u201d And \u201cWe\u2019re running fast this morning, so the women will be falling out.\u201d\n\nI went to Parris Island feeling like we could change the dynamic for women. That\u2019s the funny thing about recruits: They don\u2019t know any better. If you teach them \u2014 that shooting is all about breathing, that running fast is all about training, that ruck marches are all about mind-set \u2014 that\u2019s what they\u2019ll do.\n\nAt Fourth Battalion, I heard the shooting coaches tell women that their arms were too short to shoot well. The slowest woman in the platoon set the pace for runs. I mapped out the hikes and discovered that they had been improperly measured, which meant that women hiked fewer miles than they were supposed to. They weren\u2019t being taught to stretch properly or were trained to build up their strength to avoid injuries. Those were fixable problems.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore I arrived, between 67 percent and 78 percent of Fourth Battalion had qualified in marksmanship during their initial tests on the rifle range. The male units qualified at between 85 percent and 93 percent. The following year, we raised the women\u2019s weapons qualification rate to 92 percent. Our injury rate for women went down to a rate comparable with the men\u2019s when we instituted better strength training. And women ran faster when we placed them in groups based on ability.\n\nBut the Marine Corps didn\u2019t seem interested in building on what I had learned. I wrote an article for Marine Corps Gazette in 2015 outlining our changes and our success. It was killed after I was pushed out for my \u201ctoxic\u201d leadership. I felt that my immediate boss thought I was changing the status quo and, frankly, simply didn\u2019t like me. There was no mentoring. I was never written up for not following an order.\n\nThe things I saw in the Marine Corps raised questions that the #MeToo movement would later bring center stage. If a female Marine is seen as a weak link, based on stereotypes first bred at boot camp, why would anyone believe her if she reported an assault? With so few women in the Marine Corps \u2014 about 8 percent \u2014 what are the chances that someone in power will stop women from being pushed into clerical positions when they were trained to be medics, electricians or mechanics? If women start at a disadvantage because of segregated and unequal training, how can they catch up? And how will they escape the false double-binds of \u201cI only got this job because I\u2019m a woman\u201d or \u201cI have to act like a man to be respected\u201d?\n\nI want Congress to understand that there is still no such thing as separate but equal. And I desperately want female Marines to understand just how capable and competitive they can be. What might the possibilities be for the military if women were allowed to compete and lead?\n\nIf blatant sexism continues, we may never find out. Why would parents encourage a smart, talented daughter to join the Marine Corps if the first thing she would encounter is the message that she\u2019s simply not good enough?\n\nThis must change, not only because our military services are struggling to fill slots since so few Americans are willing or fit enough to serve, but also because future generations will not stand for it. The definition of female strength continues to change, redefined by CrossFit gyms and extraordinary female endurance athletes. Yet the Marine Corps continues to insist that women can\u2019t train with men.\n\nIt\u2019s silly. It\u2019s insulting. It\u2019s time to lead.", "title": "Separate Is Not Equal in the Marine Corps", "authors": ["Kate Germano"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "After more than a year away from the tour, Williams has no official ranking. If she defeats the 53rd-ranked Diyas, she would face No. 29 seed Kiki Bertens in the second round, with her sister Venus a possible third-round opponent.\n\nIn an interview with WTATennis.com, Williams\u2019s coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, said: \u201cThe plan is to get back to her best level. She has been practicing hard for that, and competition is part of the process. She needs more than anything to compete and that is why she will plan to play Indian Wells and Miami.\n\n\u201cWe do not know how much time she will need to get her best level back, and I think that we should give her the necessary time for that without having too much expectations at the start.\u201d\n\nHe added that her target was to win Grand Slam titles and that he expected Williams to be back to her best by the French Open in May.\n\nThe Indian Wells tournament also marks the return of Victoria Azarenka. She has not played a tour event since Wimbledon last July. She has decided not to play outside of California, where she lives, until a custody dispute over her son, Leo, is resolved. Azarenka, now ranked 204th, will face Heather Watson in the first round, and with a win, would play 13th-seeded Sloane Stephens in the second round.", "title": "Serena Williams Will Face Zarina Diyas in Comeback Match at Indian Wells", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Thursday night, in the main stadium at the Indian Wells Tennis Garden, Williams and Azarenka took turns resuming their remarkable tennis tales. And both emerged victorious in first-round, straight-set matches that were not quite that straightforward.\n\nWilliams went first, defeating Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, 7-5, 6-3. Azarenka then beat Heather Watson of Britain, 6-4, 6-2, in a match that finished close to midnight.\n\n\u201cIt was a little bit nerve-racking because I felt there was quite a bit of expectation,\u201d said Azarenka, 28. \u201c Watching Serena, I thought she played really well, and seeing her fight out there, that\u2019s all I wanted to do. My focus was just to be out there and enjoy myself and not put too much pressure.\u201d\n\nThat is easier said than managed, of course, and there were plenty of gesticulations, two-toned grunts and withering glances as Azarenka struggled to close out the quick and erratic Watson in both sets.\n\nStill, for someone who had not played a tour match since Wimbledon in July, there was much to feel sanguine about.\n\n\u201cA week ago, I wasn\u2019t sure if I was going to be here today, and I won my first match in however long, so I\u2019ll take it,\u201d Azarenka said.\n\nWilliams was also doing her best to think of the big picture, as she did when she returned to competitive tennis last month as part of the United States Fed Cup team. But she played only doubles, and lost an essentially meaningless match after the American team had already clinched the first-round victory over the Netherlands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not where I want to be, but I\u2019m getting there and that\u2019s one thing I realize: I\u2019m not going to be there today or next week or tomorrow,\u201d Williams said. \u201cBut I will eventually get there, and I do have my goals.\u201d\n\n\u201cEvery day is going to be a challenge for me,\u201d she added, \u201cbut I know I\u2019ll overcome it, and I\u2019m ready to overcome it.\u201d\n\nNext up in the second round on Saturday: No. 29 seed Kiki Bertens for Williams; No. 13 seed Sloane Stephens for Azarenka.\n\nThough far from her best on Thursday, Williams gave big hints that the traditional pillars of her game remain intact.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe can still crush groundstrokes, punish soft second-serves, strike aces to all four corners of the service box, and bare her teeth and find the lines under duress.\n\nIt will now be a matter of doing so consistently and against more daunting competition than Diyas, a crafty counterpuncher ranked No. 53 who lost to Williams 6-2, 6-0, when they played in the third round of Indian Wells in 2015.\n\nAt the time, Williams was in the midst of an 186-week run at No. 1. She returned to No. 1 after winning the Australian Open and her 23rd major singles title in January 2017, when she was two months pregnant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter giving birth to a daughter, Alexis Olympia, in September, she experienced what she said were life-threatening postnatal complications that kept her bedridden for several weeks.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m playing with nothing to lose; I only can gain,\u201d Williams said. \u201cI could have been playing like that for years, but I really have nothing to lose right now, and it\u2019s a real joy to be out there. Sometimes I think about those moments I was in the hospital and not even realizing how serious it was until later. Being able to come through that just makes me feel like no matter what happens, I\u2019m capable of being strong. Whether I win or lose, there\u2019s so much more to my life.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWilliams\u2019s husband, Alexis Ohanian, was in the stands Thursday night, but her daughter, who was a courtside regular at the Fed Cup matches, was not.\n\n\u201cI almost cried before the match,\u201d Williams said. \u201cBut playing at night really helped, because I know she goes to bed and goes to sleep and if she\u2019s asleep I can\u2019t play with her right now.\u201d\n\nAzarenka\u2019s 14-month-old son, Leo, was not there, either. The custody fight in California with Leo\u2019s father, Billy McKeague, has been Azarenka\u2019s primary focus of late, restricting her travel with Leo outside the state. She withdrew from several events, including last year\u2019s United States Open, the 2017 Fed Cup final in her native Belarus and the Australian Open in January.\n\nShe said she intended to play in the Miami Open this month, but she would not discuss the details of the dispute with McKeague.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t wish that on anybody to go through what I\u2019ve been going through, but it\u2019s part of life and there are blessings in these situations as well for me,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cYou know, I\u2019m free,\u201d she continued, seeming to refer to her relationship with McKeague. \u201cBut it\u2019s definitely been and still is a really difficult situation to be in, and it\u2019s hard to only focus on playing tennis \u2014 and I probably will never just focus on playing tennis being a mom.\u201d\n\nDuring her forced layoff, Azarenka dropped a significant amount of weight, altered her service motion and split with her coach, Michael Joyce. She has since hired Slava Konikov, a former men\u2019s tennis coach at Sacramento State University who was one of her childhood coaches in Belarus.\n\nShe said that she did not see the missed tournaments as \u201clost time.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m still 28 years old,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd recently there are No. 1s over 30, so I\u2019m O.K. with that. I\u2019m still young.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWilliams, who was No. 1 at 35, and Roger Federer, who is back at No. 1 on the men\u2019s tour at 36, have indeed shifted the thinking on career timelines.\n\nWilliams and Azarenka played each other in some of the best women\u2019s matches of the 2010s. That rivalry has changed somewhat, as they have become friends with much in common.\n\n\u201cWe have another connection which is a lot bigger than tennis I think right now,\u201d Azarenka said. \u201cBut I think we both can easily say we can\u2019t wait to play against each other on some big stages.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, they had to settle for sharing a stage in the California desert. But after all they have been through, it was a promising place to start.", "title": "Serena Williams and Victoria Azarenka Set the Stage for a Comeback", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "So much has changed in 17 years. When Serena, now 36, took the court on Monday night, she did so as a new mother, while Venus, 37, walked out as a new aunt \u2014 and as the favorite, which has not been her customary role as this increasingly lopsided rivalry has evolved.\n\nSerena is the one with 23 Grand Slam singles titles, one short of the record held by Margaret Court. Venus has had to make do with a very respectable seven, although she twice came close to an eighth during her resurgent 2017 season, when she reached the finals of the Australian Open and Wimbledon.\n\nSerena, as so often, played the spoiler on one of those occasions, defeating her in Australia when, unbeknown to the general public, she was already two months pregnant.\n\nShe did not play again for the rest of 2017, giving birth to a daughter, Olympia, in September, recovering from traumatic postnatal medical issues and then marrying Alexis Ohanian in November, before resuming training in earnest.\n\nThis was the first singles tournament of her comeback, and though it showed, she was hardly far off the pace, winning two matches and then giving Venus cause for concern as she tried to close her out.\n\n\u201cI just feel it\u2019s never over until it\u2019s over, and she just came right back,\u201d said Venus, who faltered in her first attempt to serve out her victory at 5-2 in the second set. \u201cYou know, I\u2019m just lucky I played more matches than her right now.\u201d\n\nSerena still leads their sibling rivalry, 17-12, and has won eight of their last 10 matches. But Venus now has her first victory over Serena since 2014 and a place in the fourth round, where she will face Anastasija Sevastova, a Latvian with a game brimming with spin and guile, on Tuesday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI definitely know her well,\u201d said Serena of Venus. \u201cBut she definitely played a little better than she normally does today.\u201d\n\nVenus was certainly the more reliable power player: making 19 unforced errors to Serena\u2019s 41, and not because she was taking fewer risks from the baseline.\n\nAlthough Venus has sometimes struggled to find her service rhythm early in her matches against Serena, she was at close-to-full strength from the start, hitting a first serve of 121 miles per hour at her sister\u2019s body during the tense opening game.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere would be much more of that, as she won 68 percent of her first-serve points to Serena\u2019s 53 percent during the match. And in a much clearer indicator of Serena\u2019s rust, Venus also won 52 percent of her second-serve points, despite struggling to generate depth and pace on many of those second serves.\n\nIn peak form, Serena would have pounced on them repeatedly. And though she did her best to capitalize, taking some returns very early, she could not find her range consistently.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t really replicate the situation no matter how much I do in practice, or if I make those shots 10 times out of 10 in practice,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s just the nerves, the anticipation you feel naturally. It\u2019s a little bit of everything that comes in a match that just doesn\u2019t normally happen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSerena arrived in Indian Wells with no official ranking and no seeding, which explains how she and the eighth-seeded Venus could face each other so early in the draw.\n\nDarren Cahill, the ESPN commentator who also coaches women\u2019s No. 1 Simona Halep, tweeted earlier on Monday that he believed the WTA Tour should allow players returning from maternity leave to have a protected seeding, not just a protected ranking that guarantees them entry into tournaments. But for now, the current rule stands, and Serena, who will have an official ranking close to 500 when she plays the Miami Open later this month, will continue to be the most dangerous outsider in women\u2019s tennis.\n\n\u201cI think she\u2019s going to be speeding back to the seedings and to winning tournaments sooner than later,\u201d Venus said. \u201cThat\u2019s all I see. I think that\u2019s what everybody sees.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSerena is understandably still searching for consistency and timing and was often off balance on Monday. But it is tempting to believe that when she gets her fitness and footwork right, the rest of the tennis world should resume watching out.\n\n\u201cI have a lot to improve on,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s good that I don\u2019t have to say that this is the best tennis I have ever played and I lost. My room for improvement is incredible. So I have just got to keep saying each tournament my goal is just to be better than the last. I definitely don\u2019t want to go backwards. I just want to continue to go forwards.\u201d\n\nIn 2001, the sisters were set to play here in the semifinals, but Venus withdrew minutes before the match, citing an injury. The Indian Wells crowd later booed Venus and her father, Richard Williams, when they arrived to watch Serena play the final against Kim Clijsters, and Serena heard plenty of jeers herself that afternoon.\n\nRichard Williams claimed to have heard racist taunts, and no member of the family returned to this increasingly prestigious tournament for more than a decade, with Serena ending her boycott in 2015 and Venus ending hers in 2016.\n\nNeither sister said that she gave much thought to 2001 this year, but others did. And there were certainly no heckles on this cool Monday night in the desert, just the usual cheers of \u201cGo Venus\u201d or \u201cGo Serena\u201d or, for those feeling ambivalent, \u201cGo Venus and Serena.\u201d\n\nIt has been quite a journey, and earlier on Monday, Roger Federer, a 36-year-old who has had a tennis odyssey of his own, took the time to mark the moment.\n\n\u201cLongevity and dominance; they showed that,\u201d Federer said of the sisters. \u201cThey had a massive arrival on the scene, a lot of buzz around them, and they lived up to the hype. Came out and crushed it. From the very beginning, they were very interesting to follow.\u201d\n\nThey remain just as interesting now as they, like Federer, play deep into their 30s and, unlike any other tennis stars, continue their sibling rivalry into those years.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s great for the sport, and they have done so much already,\u201d Federer said. \u201cThis is like, you know, the extra lap they are doing, and the fans can enjoy it. So I\u2019m very happy for them.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOnly one Williams left the court feeling satisfied on Monday, however. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely not less disappointing,\u201d Serena said of her defeat. \u201cI wish it were. But it\u2019s not. But then again, I wish it wasn\u2019t. Then I wouldn\u2019t be who I am. So I just have a long way to go, and I\u2019m looking forward to the journey.\u201d", "title": "Serena Williams\u2019s Return to Tour Is Ended by Her Sister Venus", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Specifically, it said that the board had erred in not looking more deeply into Mr. Worboys\u2019s offenses, and \u201cin particular, the extent to which the limited way in which he has described his offending may undermine his overall credibility and reliability.\u201d\n\nThe High Court also suggested that the parole board could have considered Mr. Worboys\u2019s statements about the dozens of assaults for which he was not prosecuted, but that the police said he had committed. He was convicted of 19 offenses against 12 women, but the police, and a previous High Court ruling, have put the total number of his victims at \u201cwell in excess of 100.\u201d\n\nThe chairman of the Parole Board of England and Wales, Nick Hardwick, had said that the board had always understood that it could not take into account anything beyond the counts on which he was convicted.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
