Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe court also said that a much-criticized rule prohibiting parole boards from revealing publicly anything about their decision-making must be changed. \u201cIt seems to us that there are clear and obvious reasons why\u201d the principle of transparent justice should apply to the parole process, the judges said.\n\nDavid Gauke, the British justice secretary, said the government would replace the secrecy rule \u201cas soon as possible.\u201d\n\nMr. Worboys\u2019s case has drawn an uproar before, leading to changes in the criminal justice system. After his arrest a decade ago, it emerged that the police had not taken seriously some women\u2019s accusations against him, allowing the assaults to continue. That prompted changes in police training and the treatment of sexual assault complainants.\n\nAfter the court\u2019s order on Wednesday, Mr. Hardwick stepped down as chairman of the parole board. He had advocated greater openness, but wrote in an open letter that in light of the Worboys case, Mr. Gauke had told him that his position was untenable.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe board has more than 200 members. Three are ordinarily assigned to each case, and their names are not revealed. The High Court told the board to have the Worboys case heard again by a different set of three people, and to consider whether \u201ca serving or retired judge should chair the panel.\u201d", "title": "Serial Rapist\u2019s Release Is Blocked, for Now, by U.K. Court", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPortrait of a Turkish Novelist as Prisoner\u201d by Ahmet Altan (Opinion, Feb. 28). This is no doubt a correct and overwhelming account of the trials he and his co-defendants have been going through and the life sentence they now face in prison. Yet Mr. Altan has omitted the precursor to these trials.\n\nA few years ago, many people spent years in prison in Turkey, and a few died while going through similar trials referred to as \u201cergenekon\u201d and \u201csledgehammer.\u201d Although the absurdity of the trials had been exposed, several life sentences were decreed. Later, all of the defendants were found not guilty. As with Mr. Altan\u2019s trial, evidence has been called false or fabricated. Once the trials became a farce and were no longer useful to the government, they were dropped and forgotten.\n\nThe newspaper where Mr. Altan was editor provided so-called \u201cevidences\u201d for these earlier trials, placing him at the forefront of accusers. It could be said that Mr. Altan had no concern for the injustices so many people suffered. So when he received a life sentence without parole, some called it \u201ceternal justice.\u201d Others called it \u201ckarma.\u201d I call it and the previous trials a sad moment for humanity.\n\nAHMET OZGIUNES\n\nISTANBUL", "title": "Opinion | Serving Time in Turkey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Attorney General Jeff Sessions rejected on Thursday a request from Republican lawmakers to appoint a special counsel to investigate allegations by conservatives that Justice Department officials abused their authority in surveilling a former Trump campaign official.\n\nIn a letter to three congressional committee chairmen, Mr. Sessions said an existing Justice Department inquiry into issues raised earlier by the lawmakers included an examination of the surveillance matter, obviating the need for a special counsel. He identified John W. Huber, the United States attorney in Utah, as the prosecutor leading that investigation and stressed that he welcomed lawmakers\u2019 scrutiny.\n\n\u201cI take the concerns you raise seriously,\u201d Mr. Sessions wrote, adding, \u201cNo institution is perfect.\u201d\n\nNonetheless, his decision not to appoint a special counsel, at least for now, is almost certain to disappoint Republicans. Even after the announcement a day earlier that the Justice Department inspector general is also examining the allegations, lawmakers reiterated their calls for a special counsel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPresident Trump had demanded last month that Mr. Sessions turn to Justice Department lawyers, not the inspector general, to investigate accusations of surveillance abuse.\n\nThe department had told lawmakers in November that senior prosecutors were examining a variety of issues, including allegations related to the Clinton family foundation. Included in that inquiry, Mr. Sessions wrote on Thursday, was the surveillance of the campaign official, Carter Page, who served as a foreign policy adviser during Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential run.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe wiretap of Mr. Page has been at the heart of attacks on the Russia investigation by Mr. Trump, Republican lawmakers and conservative commentators, who have assailed the inquiry as an effort by federal law enforcement officials to undercut Mr. Trump. They have said the application to spy on him, submitted to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, relied on information from Democrat-funded research without being fully forthcoming about its source.", "title": "Sessions Rejects Republican Calls for Second Special Counsel", "authors": ["Katie Benner"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe tables are turned,\u201d said Peter J. Spiro, a law professor at Temple University.\n\nThe California case seems likely to reach the Supreme Court, where it could give rise to a landmark reckoning on the role of states in setting immigration policy. In the process, state and federal officials, along with judges and justices, will face a test of their commitment to consistency.\n\nThey will face stark choices. One is to apply legal principles established in a case that mostly protected immigrants to one that seeks to imperil them. Another is to revise those principles in light of the very different circumstances.\n\nStephen Vladeck, a law professor at the University of Texas, said history was repeating itself, but backward.\n\n\u201cThe suit is modeled on the Obama administration\u2019s successful suit against Arizona,\u201d he said. But he added that \u201csome of the key considerations are flipped.\u201d\n\nIn the Arizona case, conservatives insisted that respect for state sovereignty required letting states play a leading role in controlling immigration within their borders. But Mr. Sessions, a longtime conservative himself, disavowed that position in his speech on Wednesday. \u201cImmigration law is the province of the federal government,\u201d he said.\n\nJustice Antonin Scalia, the conservative jurist who died in 2016, took a different view of the Arizona case. In an impassioned partial dissent, he wrote that \u201cit is easy to lose sight of the states\u2019 traditional role in regulating immigration \u2014 and to overlook their sovereign prerogative to do so.\u201d\n\nThere is no doubt that the California lawsuit is at odds with some of the Trump administration\u2019s usual positions. \u201cIt\u2019s a fascinating suit on a number of levels,\u201d Professor Vladeck said, \u201cnot the least of which is the aggressive assertion of federal enforcement power directly against states by those, like Attorney General Sessions, who have historically been ardent defenders of states\u2019 rights in the deeply analogous contexts.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCristina Rodriguez, a law professor at Yale, said she detected political parallels between the two suits.\n\n\u201cBoth administrations claim that the state laws they challenge impermissibly interfere with the executive branch\u2019s ability to enforce the immigration laws,\u201d she said. \u201cBut both lawsuits are also clearly designed to take on visible and politically powerful local officials whose vision of immigration policy conflicts with the president\u2019s and his supporters\u2019.\u201d\n\nIn a news conference on Wednesday, Xavier Becerra, the California attorney general, said he was ready for the fight. The state\u2019s laws, he said, were \u201cfully constitutional and provide for the safety and welfare of all our people.\u201d\n\n\u201cCalifornia is in the business of public safety,\u201d he said. \u201cWe are not in the business of deportations.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Justice Department challenged parts of three of California\u2019s so-called sanctuary laws. One restricts employers from cooperating with immigration officials. A second generally prohibits state officials from telling federal ones when undocumented immigrants are to be released from state custody. A third requires state officials to inspect some facilities that house people detained on behalf of the federal government.\n\nJennifer Chacon, a law professor at the University of California, Irvine, said the state laws had been carefully written to avoid direct conflicts with federal immigration laws. \u201cI think it is clear that California deliberately tried to draft laws that involved core exercises of state police power in a way that did not run afoul of federal law,\u201d she said.\n\nEach state law presents different issues, and courts may give varying answers depending on how directly the state laws conflict with federal ones. More generally, though, courts will take account of the Supreme Court\u2019s decision in the Arizona case, which called for collaboration rather than conflict.\n\n\u201cConsultation between federal and state officials is an important feature of the immigration system,\u201d Justice Kennedy wrote in the court\u2019s decision in the Arizona case.\n\nGov. Jerry Brown, a Democrat, has said that consultation is fine but that federal officials should not use California\u2019s resources to pursue undocumented Californians. The federal government, he added, may do so on its own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey are free to use their own considerable resources to enforce federal immigration law in California,\u201d he said in October in signing one of the challenged laws.\n\nThe Supreme Court has said that the federal government may not commandeer state resources to achieve federal objectives. In his speech on Wednesday, Mr. Sessions denied that anything like that was afoot.\n\n\n\n\u201cContrary to what you might hear from the lawless open borders radicals,\u201d he said, \u201cwe are not asking California, Oakland or anyone else to enforce immigration laws.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are simply asking California and other sanctuary jurisdictions to stop actively obstructing federal law enforcement,\u201d he added.\n\nBut Professor Rodriguez said the commandeering issue was a substantial one. \u201cTo the extent the Trump administration\u2019s claims against California would produce an outcome that would effectively force states and localities to participate in immigration enforcement,\u201d she said, \u201cthere could be an unconstitutional commandeering.\u201d\n\nProfessor Spiro said that California may have the upper hand in the suit\u2019s early stages, as the issues in it are novel, leaving judges with substantial discretion.\n\nThe Trump administration has not fared well in federal courts in California in other cases concerning immigration, including ones challenging President Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict travel from predominantly Muslim countries and to rescind a program protecting some 700,000 young unauthorized immigrants from deportation.\n\nBut the ultimate fate of the suit will probably rest with the Supreme Court. In 2012, with what may have been unwarranted optimism, Justice Kennedy said he hoped that conflicts over immigration policy would be worked out through reasoned discussion.\n\n\u201cThe national government has significant power to regulate immigration,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThe sound exercise of national power over immigration depends on the nation\u2019s meeting its responsibility to base its laws on a political will informed by searching, thoughtful, rational civic discourse.\u201d", "title": "Sessions Targets California Immigrants Using a Ruling That Protected Them", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In the final months of the Obama administration, the Justice Department announced a new approach to preparing prisoners for life beyond their cells. Officials created a prison school system, pledged money for technology training and promised to help prevent former inmates from returning to prison.\n\nAlmost immediately after taking office, Trump administration officials began undoing their work. Budgets were slashed, the school system was scrapped and studies were shelved as Attorney General Jeff Sessions brought to bear his tough-on-crime philosophy and deep skepticism of Obama-era crime-fighting policies.\n\nNow, nearly a year and a half later, the White House has declared that reducing recidivism and improving prisoner education is a top priority \u2014 echoing some of the very policies it helped dismantle.\n\nThis whiplash approach to federal prison policy reflects the tension between Jared Kushner, the president\u2019s reform-minded son-in-law and senior adviser, and Mr. Sessions, a hard-liner whose views on criminal justice were forged at the height of the drug war. It has left both Democratic and Republican lawmakers confused and has contributed to skepticism that the Trump administration is serious about its own proposals.", "title": "Sessions and Kushner Square Off, and Prisoners Hang in the Balance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\nClash of the Titans\n\nPresident Trump took to Twitter on Thursday to taunt former Vice President Joe Biden. Earlier this week, Biden had suggested in a speech that he would like to fight Trump one-on-one. Trump pushed back on Twitter, saying that Biden would \u201cgo down fast and hard\u201d in a fight with him.\n\nBoth Trevor Noah and Seth Meyers were amused.", "title": "Seth Meyers on Trump vs. Biden: \u2018Can You Imagine That Fight?\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "As a new generation is introduced to the determined young heroine of \u201cA Wrinkle in Time,\u201d a recent crop of empowering, diverse TV shows for girls is popping up on streaming sites everywhere. Some feature brainy female characters who study science and worship Marie Curie. Others feature girls with magical powers, or who lead soccer teams and fight for gender equality. These are girls who save princes, rather than waiting for the prince to save them \u2014 a refreshing rewrite of traditional gender dynamics for young viewers, whatever their gender.\n\nThis new class of feminist TV encourages tween girls to experiment, fail and then try all over again. Here are seven examples that should both entertain and inspire, especially good for girls aged 8 to 14.\n\nGenneya Walton, left, and Victoria Vida in \u201cProject MC2.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Project MC2\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn this upbeat Netflix original, four brilliant high school girls team up to fight crimes for a government organization. The four heroes \u2014 who include a chemist, a web guru, an inventor and a spy \u2014 are frequently confronted with sexist stereotypes, and the girls take a lot of satisfaction in proving wrong those who underestimate them. Under the guidance of creator Jordana Arkin, who also worked on the animated Disney XD show \u201cStar vs. the Forces of Evil,\u201d the writers room for \u201cMC2\u201d was mostly female, and the show does a good job of letting its characters be both fun and brainy. The girls\u2019 boss at the spy agency is played by Danica McKellar (she played Winnie Cooper in \u201cThe Wonder Years\u201d), who has written several books aimed at getting middle-school girls more interested in math. The message here is clear: Smart is the new cool.\n\n\u2014\n\nClockwise: Aubrey Miller, Olivia Sanabia and Abby Donnelly in \u201cJust Add Magic.\u201d Amazon Prime Video\n\n\u2018Just Add Magic\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cJust Add Magic\u201d has been described as \u201cBuffy for tweens\u201d and is essentially a witch story, with three 14-year-old girls huddling around an updated version of the caldron: the oven. Based on the novel by Cindy Callaghan, this Amazon series centers on Kelly, Darbie and Hannah, who conjure powerful recipes from a magic recipe book belonging to Kelly\u2019s mysteriously ailing grandmother. (Dishes include Shut \u2018Em Up Shortcake, Walk through Wall-fles and If These Walls Could Tacos.) \u201cI need you to trust your instincts,\u201d urges Kelly\u2019s grandmother, herself under a magic spell that renders her mostly mute \u2014 because when Kelly does that and follows the Golden Rule, troublesome magic spells like the one gripping Kelly\u2019s grandmother can be undone. Powerful young girls working to liberate their silenced grandmothers? That\u2019s magical.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nSixx Orange in \u201cThe Kicks.\u201d Amazon Prime Video\n\n\u2018The Kicks\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDevin Burke is the 12-year-old star of her Connecticut soccer team, so when she and her family move to California, it isn\u2019t just a change \u2014 it\u2019s a total upheaval. Challenges abound in Devin\u2019s fight to improve her new school\u2019s hapless team, from encouraging reluctant teammates to finding a new coach. Through the ups and downs, the shows underscores the notion that teamwork and hard work are the best means of building success. Adapted from a series of books written by the Olympic gold medalist Alex Morgan, \u201cThe Kicks\u201d also explores how girls are condemned early on for being \u201cbossy\u201d and features plot lines that explore the real-world resource disparities between middle-school girls\u2019 and boys\u2019 sports teams.\n\n\u2014\n\nLucky and Spirit in \u201cSpirit Riding Free.\u201d DreamWorks Animation Television\n\n\u2018Spirit Riding Free\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe heroine of \u201cSpirit Riding Free\u201d is also adjusting to a cross-country move. Set in the 19th century, this animated series from Dreamworks follows the 12-year-old city girl Lucky, as she moves with her father to a small Wild West town so he can work on the railroad. There, she befriends an unbroken horse named Spirit and follows in the footsteps of her own mother, an adventurous Mexican woman who worked as a trick horse rider with a circus. Set in a time when girls were expected to be seen and not heard, \u201cSpirit Riding Free\u201d tracks Lucky and her friends as they gallop freely to uncover hidden treasure and rescue an abused horse. Lucky\u2019s courage may be fierce, but life with her strict family presents a challenge as she tries to honor her mother\u2019s legacy. The series is based on the Oscar-nominated Dreamworks movie \u201cSpirit: Stallion of the Cimarron,\u201d also on Netflix, and both are appropriate for younger girls, too.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cEarth to Luna!\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Earth to Luna!\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAimed at curious kids ages 4 and up, this lively animated series follows the 12-year-old Luna; her little brother, Jupiter; and their ferret, Clyde, as they embark on scientific adventures. \u201cLuna\u201d keeps the younger crowd stimulated with colorful singing and dancing, but its complexity keeps things interesting for the 10-to-12-year-old set, as Luna and her team of scientists get up close and personal with the scientific method \u2014 investigating natural phenomena like the way bees communicate by dancing, or how bananas grow without seeds. Created, directed and written by women, this adaptation of a Brazilian series encourages girls to be hungry for knowledge, about everything from the tiniest ants underfoot to the movements of the cosmos overhead.\n\n\u2014\n\nAddison Holley, left, and Millie Davis as Pal in \u201cAnnedroids.\u201d Amazon Prime Video\n\n\u2018Annedroids\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWe\u2019ve all heard that artificial intelligence is the future, and \u201cAnnedroids\u201d imagines the fun kids could have with that technology. Anne is an 11-year-old robotics inventor who needs more voltage to power up Pal, the sophisticated speech-enabled android she\u2019s working on (who is also genderless \u2014 \u201cWhat makes you think it\u2019s a he?\u201d Anne asks). When her gaming-obsessed neighbor stumbles across Anne\u2019s tech junkyard, they team up to help get Pal running. In their adventures together, they teach Pal to play hide-and-seek; encourage Hand (a flexible grabber android) to experience love; help Eyes (a rolling telescope, microscope and binocular set) experience the joy of flying; build Fangs (a robotic guard dog) to defend the junkyard against prying eyes; and much more. Across four seasons and 53 half-hour episodes, \u201cAnnedroids\u201d blends sensitive live-action acting with skilled animation, introducing the possibilities of A.I. technology to a new generation of future scientists.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cSciGirls.\u201d PBS\n\n\u2018SciGirls\u2019\n\nWhere to stream: Amazon Prime and YouTube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn another blend of animation and live action meant to appeal to a digitally-native generation, this series, funded in part by the National Science Foundation, is narrated by Izzy, the animated 12-year-old founder of an after-school club called the Gigabyte Techbots. Each episode follows real-life girls as they investigate a given scientific challenge, from gauging humans\u2019 emotional reactions to improving the responsiveness of a rescue robot to creating a smartphone app that teaches users about the geology of the 1989 San Francisco earthquake, with Izzy popping in to ask hypothetical questions and encouraging viewers to dive deeper into the science. Throughout the series, the junior scientists learn to tackle challenges and persist. The show is built around the SciGirls Seven, a research-driven, seven-pronged approach to getting girls interested in STEM subjects (science, technology, engineering and math), and it is complemented by an extensive presence on social media and learning resources on the SciGirls website.\n\n\u2014", "title": "Seven Streaming Shows for Adventurous Girls", "authors": ["Dakota Kim"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Rescue workers, joined by construction workers, desperately dug through the rubble looking and listening for signs of life, using listening devices, fiber optics and dogs. Officials said that they expected the search to continue through the night, and that they had to work carefully because part of the structure was still unsafe.\n\nJuan Perez, director of the Miami-Dade Police Department, said the police homicide bureau would begin investigating as soon as rescue operations ended.\n\nThe National Transportation Safety Board also rushed investigators to the scene on Thursday, for an inquiry that was likely to focus on the design and construction of the bridge, as well as the methods used to put it in place.\n\nThe walkway spanned about 174 feet over Southwest Eighth Street, a major thoroughfare that crosses the county and separates the F.I.U. campus in western Miami-Dade County with the city of Sweetwater. The walkway was built adjacent to the street using a method called accelerated bridge construction. It was then driven into its perpendicular position across the road by a rig in about six hours on Saturday, while students from the university\u2019s engineering and architecture programs watched.\n\nOn the F.I.U. website, a time-lapse video shows the intricate raising of the bridge before dawn on Saturday to the accompaniment of triumphant music.\n\nAt the time, Mark B. Rosenberg, president of the university, hailed it as a symbol of the bond between the university and the surrounding community.\n\nAccelerated construction is a well-regarded method of erecting bridges that avoids the long months of street closings when a structure is built over a road or river. Instead, parts of the bridge are prefabricated away from the site. For some bridges, including the one at F.I.U., the entire length is built before being lowered into place on its supports. A national database of accelerated bridge construction projects, which is maintained by F.I.U., lists more than 100 such projects across the United States.", "title": "Several Dead After Walkway Collapse in Miami", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s a wake-up call,\u201d said Senator John Thune of South Dakota, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, which convened hearings on sex trafficking. \u201cThis is clearly illegal activity. It was happening online. But I think in the future, tech companies have to understand that it\u2019s not the wild West, and they have to exercise responsibility.\u201d\n\nPaul Gallant, an analyst at Cowen, said the sex trafficking bill would not directly hurt big internet companies. But he said it was \u201ccracking the door open to broader platform liability for other types of content.\u201d\n\n\u201cToday, it\u2019s sex trafficking,\u201d he added. \u201cAnd down the road, it\u2019s content from foreign governments.\u201d\n\nInternet companies have feared the bill would weaken a crucial legal shield that since 1996 has guarded them from liability for illegal content on their sites. They point to the safe harbor provision as the foundation for the growth of internet commerce. Civil liberties groups have decried the bill as a threat to free speech and a limit to the free flow of content on the web.\n\nBut that protection for websites, lawmakers argued, has been abused and needed revision so law enforcement could pursue the worst perpetrators, such as Backpage.com, a popular classified advertising site that freely advertises sex for sale, while hiding behind the safe harbor clause.\n\nThe new bill will allow state police and attorneys general to go after sites that knowingly host sex trafficking content. It will also allow victims of sex trafficking to sue such sites for damages.\n\n\u201cThis is legislation that is overdue in my view, and it\u2019s required,\u201d said Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, who was a co-author of the bill with Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut. \u201cThe courts have told us that. The district attorneys have told us that. The attorneys general told us that.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen it was introduced in August 2017, the bill attracted immediate support from law enforcement and advocates for victims of sex trafficking. It also drew intense opposition from tech companies and free-speech advocates, who say any weakening of liability protections would lead to abuse by law enforcement, hurt start-ups that cannot afford to fight lawsuits and stifle free speech.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe law \u201cwould almost certainly cause irreparable harm to free speech and the internet economy,\u201d said Robyn Greene, policy counsel and government affairs chief for Open Technology Institute at New America, a research and advocacy group.\n\nBut with prominent fights flaring over Russian election interference, data breaches and other scandals, the biggest tech companies \u2014 no longer wishing to publicly oppose a bill fighting sex trafficking \u2014 retreated from their lobbying effort in recent weeks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Internet Association, a trade group whose members include Facebook, Google, Netflix and Apple, has backed off from the strong stance they had against the bill when it was introduced.\n\n\u201cThe internet industry shares the goals of lawmakers who want to put an end to trafficking online, and Internet Association will continue to be a key partner with policymakers on this important issue,\u201d said Michael Beckerman, president of the group, who added that it would work to preserve other aspects of the liability shield.\n\nThe legislation stemmed from a two-year Senate investigation led by Mr. Portman into Backpage.com, the classifieds page rampant with ads for prostitution and sex trafficking. During the investigation, Mr. Portman and Mr. Blumenthal heard from state law enforcement officials who said that they were not able to press charges against websites like Backpage.com, which evoked safe harbor under the liability portion of the 1996 Communications Decency Act.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re opening the courthouse doors,\u201d Mr. Blumenthal said after Wednesday\u2019s vote.\n\nAccording to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, nearly 90 percent of the trafficking of children occurs online. Seven out of 10 child trafficking reports involve Backpage.com, the group said.\n\nBut over the past seven years, 20 cases involving the website were rejected by courts that \u201cacknowledged the horror of the allegations made regarding the child victims\u2019 trafficking\u201d but were \u201cpowerless to act,\u201d Yiota G. Souras, general counsel for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, told Congress last November.\n\nThe liability provision, created by Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, was intended to help foster the growth of the nascent internet. It was adopted before smartphones and companies like Google and Facebook existed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Wyden argued on the Senate floor that the bill as written would harm the internet economy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019ll pull up the ladder, leaving the established giants at the top,\u201d Mr. Wyden said. Start-ups need the legal shield most, not tech giants, he added: \u201cThe big guys can take care of themselves.\u201d\n\nMr. Wyden was one of two senators to oppose the bill; the other was Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky.\n\nDozens of victims\u2019 advocates hailed the bill as landmark action to fight trafficking.\n\n\u201cThis is a huge day for victims because we are finally saying enough is enough,\u201d said Lauren Hersh, the national director for World Without Exploitation, a group for victims\u2019 rights. \u201cThey will no longer allow companies to profit from ads that make millions off the backs of exploited people.\u201d", "title": "Sex Trafficking Bill Heads to Trump, Over Silicon Valley Concerns", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The title of Joyce Carol Oates\u2019s new collection of stories, \u201cBeautiful Days,\u201d is drawn from \u201cLes Beaux Jours,\u201d a painting by Balthus of a girl reclining in a chair and examining herself in a hand mirror, while a faceless man tends the fireplace behind her. But it might equally refer to \u201cFleuve Blue\u201d or \u201cBig Burnt,\u201d the first two stories in the book \u2014 which are about (among other things) the strange disconnection that separates our romantic lives from the rest of life. \u201cFleuve Blue\u201d describes an affair between a prominent small-town lawyer and a younger woman, whom he first sees walking across a bridge. He thinks, \u201cI will marry her. That one.\u201d Except, of course, he\u2019s already married. Later, he offers her a ride when she gets caught wearing high heels in a downpour and they start meeting in the afternoon in a rented room. \u201cShe told him it would be the inside-out of the rest of her life, her relationship with him. \u2026 She meant, what they had together was a counter-world. \u2026 \u2018Because I\u2019m always lying. In that other life. In my \u201creal\u201d life. I tell people \u2014 I tell myself \u2014 \u201cI live for my children. I adore my children.\u201d\u2019 \u201d Unsurprisingly, their affair turns out to be susceptible to the same sort of forces that she wants to escape in her real life \u2014 boredom and the passage of time.\n\nBut it\u2019s the lying, or deception, or really just the uncertainty about other people that dominates the rest of this collection. A woman desperate for marriage spends a weekend with a guy she used to date who hasn\u2019t always been particularly nice to her. She doesn\u2019t know that he\u2019s tying up loose ends before killing himself, and afterward she has to deal with the puzzle of his intentions. Even years of shared life fail to produce real intimacy. Parents are just as untrustworthy as lovers. In \u201cOwl Eyes,\u201d a geeky kid at a math camp runs into a professor who tells him a story about how he used to be involved with the boy\u2019s mother \u2014 that he used to be a father to the boy himself. Vague memories come back to the boy, but it\u2019s hard to tell if they offer doubt or hope.\n\nImage\n\nIn general, Oates is dealing here with the academic world \u2014 professors and their kids, editors, writers, adjuncts \u2014 people who live in the provinces, on the outskirts of real success. Characters are often referred to by titles rather than names: mother, daddy, wife, husband, professor. \u201cExcept You Bless Me,\u201d one of the standouts in a very strong collection, recounts an early incident in a woman\u2019s teaching career. She has become convinced that a black student in her class \u2014 one she\u2019s been trying to help \u2014 has been sending her racist hate messages. Is the professor unusually patient and conscientious or completely delusional and possibly racist herself?\n\nSlowly the realism of the collection gives way to stories that are more experimental. Oates is a master of many different kinds of story, including the gothic and something like science fiction \u2014 \u201cFractal,\u201d for example, and the extraordinary \u201cUndocumented Alien,\u201d which follows a Nigerian man tricked into applying for a bogus degree at a New Jersey engineering college. Eventually, to stop himself from being deported, he agrees to take part in a secret government experiment designed to test the extent to which people can be denatured. The power of the conceit, of course, comes from the fact that this is happening anyway.", "title": "Sex, Lies and Subterfuge Roil Joyce Carol Oates\u2019s New Story Collection", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Starting an independent bookstore in a borough with few book-buying options might seem like a giant leap of faith, but for Ms. Santos of The Lit Bar, it\u2019s the culmination of a dream begun three years ago when she learned that the local Barnes & Noble would close. \u201cBeing an avid reader, that spoke to me on personal level,\u201d she said. \u201cWhile I appreciated Barnes & Noble when it was there, you would never know that you were in the Bronx. It didn\u2019t offer a lot of opportunities for the community. If you were a local author, good luck in getting your book on the shelf. But with an independent store, you can feel the energy of the neighborhood reflected in the choices. I couldn\u2019t think of a better way for people to engage and become real neighbors.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s a difference between surviving and thriving for some indies. \u201cThriving is a tough word,\u201d said Christine Onorati of Word in Greenpoint, Brooklyn (with a branch in Jersey City). \u201cWe have people who are unbelievably loyal to us, and we\u2019re digging in, trying to make our mark, but it\u2019s a tough business.\u201d Rent is a challenge for many. Miles Bellamy opened Spoonbill and Sugartown in Brooklyn\u2019s Williamsburg neighborhood almost 19 years ago, long before there was a Whole Foods and an Apple store, but he recently saw his rent almost double, to $14,500 a month from $8,000 a month.\n\n\u201cJust as I go to both the local drugstore and Duane Reade, book lovers can support my store and buy books online,\u201d Mr. Bellamy said. \u201cI feel like a better person when I go into the small store. But the pressure is constant. It\u2019s a full-time hustle.\u201d\n\nThere is an opportunity for certain industries to reinvent themselves after a large shock in their business model or in technology, according to Ryan L. Raffaelli, assistant professor at Harvard Business School, who has been studying independent bookstores for about five years. (He even took a course in how to open one.) \u201cWhat I\u2019ve found is that the indies are able to compete on several dimensions,\u201d he said. \u201cOne is community. They championed the notion of \u2018shop local\u2019 and \u2018Small Business Saturday.\u2019 Another is curation: They\u2019re not just offering best-sellers but diamonds in the rough. They\u2019ve taken back a sense of pride in what they can provide: a deeper and ongoing relationship with their customers. In high-rent districts, because profit margins are relatively thin, success must come from multiple repeat customers, so that the customer can\u2019t imagine not visiting as part of his or her monthly routine. They\u2019re also flirting with adapting newer forms of technology.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s what Mr. Neller is banking on. Each of the planned new Shakespeare and Company stores will have an Espresso Book Machine (Mr. Neller is also head of the manufacturer, On Demand Books) that has the potential to print and bind any book not on the shelves while you\u2019re having a cappuccino at the store\u2019s cafe. (Since Mr. Neller is the former chief executive of Dean & DeLuca, the new stores will definitely have baristas and snacks.)\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really a renaissance,\u201d he said, \u201ca new permutation that will have elements of the mom-and-pop blended with technology, allowing a store to have a practically infinite selection in a small setting. We\u2019ll take a digital file and convert it into an analog product, putting the warehouse inside a small footprint. That\u2019s transformative.\u201d It\u2019s almost like a new happy ending to \u201cYou\u2019ve Got Mail.\u201d\n\nSomewhere, Nora is smiling.", "title": "Shakespeare and Company Is Coming Back to the West Side and the Village", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 Shammi, an actress who appeared in some 200 Bollywood films and was beloved for her comedic roles as doting sisters, mothers and grandmothers, died on Tuesday at her home in Mumbai. She was 89.\n\nPandhari Nath Chavhan, an employee at the crematory where she was taken, confirmed her death, which he said came after a long illness.\n\nShammi, whose real name was Nargis Rabadi, began her career in 1949, when a family friend working in the movie industry arranged a meeting between her and the actor and producer Sheikh Mukhtar to discuss a role in a film he was working on called \u201cUstad Pedro.\u201d\n\nMr. Mukhtar was worried at first about casting a young woman who had never acted before, and he pressed her about whether her Hindi was good enough to pull off the role. \u201cHe asked me, \u2018What about your Hindi? You are Parsi,\u2019 \u201d Ms. Rabadi recalled in an interview. \u201cI immediately replied, \u2018But I am talking to you just now in Hindi, so you can find out whether I am talking properly or not.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Shammi, Bollywood Actress Known for Comedic Roles, Dies at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith his typical bluster, Shane Smith announced on Tuesday that he had surrendered his chief executive job at Vice Media to Nancy Dubuc, the chief executive of A&E Networks, saying the two of them were a \u201cmodern day Bonnie and Clyde\u201d who would \u201ctake all your money.\u201d\n\nMr. Smith said he would remain at the company as executive chairman of its board, working closely with Ms. Dubuc and focusing on content and deal-making. He positioned the executive shake-up as a move to \u201cstrategically position the company for its next phase of growth\u201d by bringing in a \u201cbest-in-class management team.\u201d\n\nMr. Smith, 48, is one of the founders of Vice, which started as a free punk magazine in Montreal in 1994 and has transformed into a global company with about 3,000 employees. Backed by media giants like the Walt Disney Company and 21st Century Fox, Vice now spans a TV network, a digital presence, a film-production company and programs on HBO.\n\nMs. Dubuc, 49, is taking on the chief executive role at a company that has faced a reckoning over sexual harassment in the past several months. In December, a New York Times investigation detailed the mistreatment of women at the company and found four settlements involving allegations of sexual harassment or defamation against Vice employees. In addition, more than two dozen women said they had experienced or witnessed sexual misconduct at the company, including unwanted kisses, groping, lewd remarks and propositions for sex.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn response to the Times report, Mr. Smith and Suroosh Alvi, co-founders of the company, said in a statement that \u201cfrom the top down, we have failed as a company to create a safe and inclusive workplace where everyone, especially women, can feel respected and thrive.\u201d In the months that followed, Vice\u2019s chief digital officer left the company after it looked into harassment allegations against him. The company\u2019s president, Andrew Creighton, has been on leave. Meanwhile, the company faces a lawsuit from a former employee who said that the company marginalized women and discriminated against them by paying them less.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a memo to employees signed \u201cLove S,\u201d Mr. Smith made no specific mention of issues related to sexual harassment but referred to the company\u2019s earlier promise of 50-50 female-male representation at every level by 2020.", "title": "Shane Smith Says Vice Leaders Are \u2018Modern Day Bonnie and Clyde\u2019", "authors": ["Emily Steel"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Shannon Marie Demers and Harwood Brooks Comstock II were married March 3 at the Union Club of the City of New York. Suanne Bonan, a Universal Life minister, officiated.\n\nMrs. Comstock, 26, is an account manager at Project MM, a public relations agency in Brooklyn specializing in luxury beauty brands. She graduated from the University of Michigan.\n\nThe bride is a daughter of Diane L. Demers and Gregory T. Demers of Bay City, Mich. The bride\u2019s father is a partner in Warner Norcross & Judd, a law firm in Midland, Mich. Her mother retired as a coordinator for Heartland Hospice Center in Bay City.\n\nMr. Comstock, 35, is the vice president for advertising and demand in Manhattan at Sotheby\u2019s. He graduated from Trinity College in Hartford.", "title": "Shannon Demers, Brooks Comstock", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA major part of this is education,\u201d said Victor P. Lopez, the city\u2019s mayor, a diabetic who beat back dialysis by walking three miles a day and changing his preferred diet of fried pork rinds, pulled pork carnitas and at least 10 flour tortillas a day, he said. \u201cThe men love soccer big time,\u201d he added. \u201cWe needed something for the ladies.\u201d\n\nShared use agreements have been proliferating over the past decade, spurred by obesity and other chronic diseases, diminishing green space, and new research that links health to the man-made environment, said Jeff Vincent, deputy director for the Center for Cities and Schools at the University of California, Berkeley. The C.D.C.\u2019s recommended 60 minutes a day of physical activity for children and adolescents has also inspired schools to think beyond physical education.\n\nAlthough nobody tracks exact numbers, a 2012 survey by the C.D.C. found that out of 630 school districts that responded, 61 percent reported some form of shared use, with large Western urban school districts the most enthusiastic adopters. Promoting community health and other programs through shared use \u201cmay be an untapped resource\u201d for schools, the survey suggested.\n\nNevertheless, making it happen isn\u2019t always easy. The story of the Burroughs Elementary School in Fresno, where a group of parents rallied to the shared use cause only to see their efforts shelved after a yearlong pilot program, is a cautionary tale, albeit one with a happy ending.\n\nSusana Cruz, a 36-year-old mother of three, started a campaign to unlock the gates after school and on weekends because the closest park for children in southeastern Fresno, an area of concentrated poverty, was more than two miles away. Neighborhood children would routinely jump the school fence to play basketball or climb on the monkey bars. \u201cSome parks were not well maintained and unsafe for our children to go to,\u201d Cruz recalled. \u201cHaving the school gates unlocked was an immediate solution to our needs and one that we felt safe using.\u201d\n\nThe parents, all volunteers, made an informal arrangement with the school in which each adult took responsibility for a specific time slot to monitor the playground, passing the key back and forth. But reports of vandalism and the difficulty of handing off the key caused the school district to pull the plug. \u201cThat was frustrating,\u201d said Carlos Castillo, Burroughs\u2019s principal at the time. \u201cWe wanted this to be a good thing.\u201d\n\nThe pilot ended, but the idea stuck. Six years later, shared use has been embraced big time by Fresno, which was eager to escape its ranking as one of the nation\u2019s most park-poor cities. While the Burroughs pilot was based on an informal agreement with parents, the city initiative involved an investment of $1.2 million to open up playgrounds and other green spaces at 16 school sites on weekends; those spaces now offer organized fitness, sports, yoga and nutrition classes led by student-mentors from Fresno State University alongside grassy fields for picnicking and other activities. The partnership has been so successful that last summer, seven high school pools were opened up to public use and \u2014 no shock here \u2014 they were packed all season long.\n\nHistorically, the biggest hurdle to shared use, especially for schools, is concern over liability, which frequently becomes \u201ca nine-letter word for \u2018no,\u2019\u201d Winig said. Yet schools, he noted, are already under a legal obligation to safely maintain playground equipment and other facilities. \u201cA school doesn\u2019t suddenly become unsafe when the school bell rings,\u201d he pointed out. All states have laws that either fully or partly protect school districts from liability based on a negligence claims, he added.", "title": "Opinion | Sharing Public Spaces to Improve Public Health", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I keep getting Instagram alerts on my phone that say someone has updated a \u201cstory.\u201d What exactly is an Instagram story?\n\nA. Instagram, primarily known as a social network for sharing smartphone camera photos in a square format, added a feature called Stories in 2016. Stories are basically temporary compilations of photos and videos on a theme, like a visit to a theme park. You add to the collection over the course of the day and can annotate the material with text, virtual stickers and digital doodles. Instead of posting multiple pictures and clips separately, where your friends might miss some of them, you can start a Story that lets all the content be viewed in one place.\n\nTo see a Story in the Instagram mobile app, tap the house icon in the lower-left corner of the screen to go to the Feed page. Stories shared by accounts you follow appear at the top of the screen, so tap a profile icon to see the content. The app automatically moves to the next Story in your feed unless you tap the X in the corner to stop.", "title": "Sharing Your Story in Instagram", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSharisse Edwards Kimbro and Clemont Robert Austin IV were married March 17 at Merry-Go-Round rock, an outdoor wedding venue in Sedona, Ariz. The Rev. Dr. Brenda Salter McNeil, who was ordained by the Evangelical Covenant Church, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 49, is an ethics adviser of the Boeing Company in Chicago. She also wrote \u201cBeyond The Broken\u201d (Open Book Edition, 2013). She graduated from Stanford and received a law degree from the University of Michigan.\n\nShe is the daughter of Mattie E. Kimbro of Dayton, Ohio, and Larry H. Kimbro of Yellow Springs, Ohio. The bride\u2019s father is a retired budget analyst for the Air Force; he worked as a civilian at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton. Her mother is a retired physical therapist and former chairwoman of the Physical Therapist Assistant Program at Sinclair Community College, also in Dayton.\n\nThe groom, also 49, is a director in the health care practice of Navigant Consulting, a consulting firm in Chicago. He also graduated from Stanford and received an M.B.A. from Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland.\n\nHe is a son of Penny S. Austin and Mr. Austin III of Erie, Pa. The groom\u2019s father is the chief executive of EE Austin & Sons, a family construction business in Erie. His mother is a retired guidance counselor for the Erie Day School.\n\nThe bride\u2019s first marriage ended in divorce, as did the groom\u2019s.\n\nThe couple met during their freshman year at Western Reserve Academy, a boarding school in Hudson, Ohio, when she was 13 and he was 14.", "title": "Sharisse Kimbro, Clemont Austin IV", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSONG OF A CAPTIVE BIRD\n\nBy Jasmin Darznik\n\n405 pp. Ballantine Books. $27.\n\n\u201cI take the first true measure of my body and decide that it\u2019s shame, not sin, that\u2019s unholy.\u201d It\u2019s 1955 Iran and Forugh Farrokhzad, a soon-to-be divorced mother, awakens to sex and art in Jasmin Darznik\u2019s novel, \u201cSong of a Captive Bird.\u201d A few pages later, having begun an affair with a progressive Tehrani editor, Farrokhzad writes the poem that will make her both a symbol of female strength and a notorious \u201cwoman without shame,\u201d as Persian mothers like to say. In it she confesses, \u201cI\u2019ve sinned a sin of pleasure / beside a body trembling and spent.\u201d She doesn\u2019t hide behind metaphor, and she isn\u2019t the meek beloved of the old poems. She acts on her own desires. When she pines, it isn\u2019t for a romantic savior but for a body. Tehran is scandalized.\n\nFarrokhzad was Iran\u2019s most celebrated \u2014 and controversial \u2014 female poet, and Darznik, the Iranian-born author of the memoir \u201cThe Good Daughter,\u201d recreates her sexual and creative liberation while exploring the threat she posed to social order in prerevolutionary Iran. By the year of Farrokhzad\u2019s debut, the \u201cNew Poetry\u201d of Nima Yooshij and Ahmad Shamlou \u2014 both men \u2014 had made Iranian verse more accessible, freer in form and subject matter. But critics instantly denounced Farrokhzad as a silly girl, dismissing her work as an outgrowth of the national fascination with the hedonistic West, a trend Tehrani intellectuals called \u201cWestoxification.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFarrokhzad was defiant, in life and in Darznik\u2019s fiction: \u201cBy writing in a woman\u2019s voice I wanted to say that a woman, too, is a human being. To say that we, too, have the right to breathe, to cry out and to sing.\u201d By the 1960s, she had come to represent Iran\u2019s New Woman. At once loved and hated, she was a literary sensation and an acclaimed filmmaker, who demanded that female desires, expressed in plain language, be given the weight of serious literature. Male poets had been writing breathlessly about women for centuries \u2014 why should the reverse be any less palatable?\n\nPhoto\n\nDarznik follows Farrokhzad\u2019s turbulent life from her abusive childhood \u2014 including a virginity check that turns violent \u2014 through her oppressive teenage marriage, motherhood, literary career and early death in a car crash in 1967. Her version is superbly dramatized and, with its cast of spineless lovers and hymen-breaking villainesses, a very Iranian tale, every scene designed to stir up fury or longing. Yet Darznik has composed her novel for Western ears, in elegantly simple language. She resists Persian flourishes in both her prose and her translations of Farrokhzad\u2019s work; I question whether the poet would recognize herself in Darznik\u2019s voice, compelling as it is. And here is a larger problem of poetic translation: How do you capture a language as floral and breathy as Farsi without access to its unique sounds? In Farrokhzad\u2019s poetry, each sigh carries meaning.\n\nPerhaps to replace these lost sounds, and to remind us that these events are happening far away, Darznik peppers her novel with everyday Farsi words. A hammam or a ta\u2019arof here and there is to be expected. But ordinary words like \u201cforeigner,\u201d \u201cfilthy,\u201d \u201cbride,\u201d \u201cbroken\u201d and even \u201cyes\u201d appear in Farsi every few pages, only to be translated in the next phrase or sentence; these are markers of casual exoticism, the American cousin of Westoxification. They don\u2019t capture the true sound of Farsi, its soft, easy rhythms, its heavy-hearted notes, often so grating to Western readers.\n\nNear the end of the novel, Farrokhzad evokes the charged political atmosphere on the eve of the revolution: \u201cWe bought plastic roses and decorated our lawns and courtyards with plaster swans. We saw the future in neon lights \u2026. Still our country wasn\u2019t our own.\u201d Today few Iranian women would say that their country is their own. They still argue about Farrokhzad. \u201cShe opened the tongues of women,\u201d they say, and it\u2019s not clear whether this is intended as a compliment. \u201cEvery poem I\u2019d ever written was entangled with my country\u2019s story,\u201d the Farrokhzad of Darznik\u2019s imagination says. \u201cI loved its downtrodden, small-minded, generous people. I loved them; I belonged to them.\u201d \u201cSong of a Captive Bird\u201d is a complex and beautiful rendering of that vanished country and its scattered people; a reminder of the power and purpose of art; and an ode to female creativity under a patriarchy that repeatedly tries to snuff it out.", "title": "She Dared to Write Poetry About Sex. Iranians Loved and Hated Her for It.", "authors": ["Dina Nayeri", "Jasmin Darznik"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEDUCATED\n\nA Memoir\n\nBy Tara Westover\n\n335 pp. Random House. $28.\n\nAmerica has struggled with the urban-rural divide for centuries, stretching all the way back to when Manhattan\u2019s own Alexander Hamilton fixed his sights on backwoods whiskey distilleries as a revenue source for the new Republic, prompting rebellion. But one could make the case that the divide has never consumed us as much as it does today. The political parties are aligned more than ever around blue metropolises and red spaces in between. Economic growth is now so glaringly concentrated in certain urban areas that it has reignited the age-old debate over staying vs. going. Should the young and ambitious from struggling small towns and cities be encouraged to seek their fortune in the hotbeds of dynamism and overpriced Sunday brunch, or does this only sunder family ties and hasten the collapse of the interior?\n\nIt was this dilemma that helped make J. D. Vance\u2019s \u201cHillbilly Elegy\u201d a runaway best seller in 2016 \u2014 the tale of a young man who\u2019d overcome the dysfunctions of his transplanted Appalachian family to ascend to the Ivy League and Silicon Valley, with plenty of culture shocks along the way. Yet Tara Westover\u2019s new tale of escape, \u201cEducated,\u201d makes Vance\u2019s seem tame by comparison. Where Vance wrote affectingly of showing up at Ohio State and Yale Law with the limited preparation provided by his middling schools in Middletown, Ohio, Westover describes showing up in college with no schooling at all. Where Vance describes a family contending with the all-too-common burdens of substance abuse, Westover lays bare a family cursed by ideological mania and outlandish physical trauma. If Vance\u2019s memoir offered street-heroin-grade drama, Westover\u2019s is carfentanil, the stuff that tranquilizes elephants.\n\nThe extremity of Westover\u2019s upbringing emerges gradually through her telling, which only makes the telling more alluring and harrowing. The basics are these: Now in her early 30s, she was the youngest of seven in a survivalist family in the shadow of a mountain in a Mormon pocket of southeastern Idaho. Her father, Gene (a pseudonym), grew up on a farm at the base of the mountain, the son of a hot-tempered father, and moved up the slope with his wife, the product of a more genteel upbringing in the nearby small town. Gene sustained his growing family by building barns and hay sheds and by scrapping metal in his junkyard; his wife, Faye (also a pseudonym), chipped in with her income from mixing up herbal remedies and from her reluctant work as an unlicensed midwife\u2019s assistant and then midwife.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring his 20s, Gene\u2019s edgy and not uncharismatic intensity morphed into politically charged paranoia, fueled by what the reader is led to presume is a severe case of bipolar disorder. Around the age of 30, he pulled his eldest children from school to protect them from the Illuminati, though they, at least, had the benefit of a birth certificate, an indulgence the youngest four would be denied. In theory, the children were being home-schooled; in reality, there was virtually no academic instruction to speak of. They learned to read from the Bible, the Book of Mormon and the speeches of Joseph Smith and Brigham Young. The only science book in the house was for young children, full of glossy illustrations. The bulk of their time was spent helping their parents at work. Barely into her teens, Westover graduated from helping her mom mix remedies and birth babies to sorting scrap with her dad, who had the unnerving habit of inadvertently hitting her with pieces he\u2019d tossed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGetting hit with a steel cylinder square in the gut was the least of the risks in the Westover household. The book is, among other things, a catalog of job-site horrors: fingers lost, legs gashed, bodies horribly burned. No pointy-headed bureaucrat could make a stronger case for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration than do the unregulated Westovers with their many calamities. Making matters worse is Gene\u2019s refusal to allow any of the injured and wounded (himself included) to seek medical attention beyond his wife\u2019s tinctures \u2014 \u201cGod\u2019s pharmacy\u201d \u2014 a refusal that also greatly exacerbates the effects of two terrible car accidents. \u201cGod and his angels are here, working right alongside us,\u201d he tells Westover. \u201cThey won\u2019t let you get hurt.\u201d When she gets tonsillitis, he tells her to stand outside with her mouth open so that the sun can work its magic. She does, for a month.", "title": "She Didn\u2019t Own a Birth Certificate or Go to School. Yet She Went On to Earn a Ph.D.", "authors": ["Alec Macgillis", "Tara Westover"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Shifa Fahim Mahmood and Ramy Mohsen Fakhr were married March 23 at the Islamic Cultural Center of New York in Manhattan. Then she moved the brothers into the mobile home park where she was living in South Florida.\n\nOne of them, Nikolas Cruz, would be out of the home in less than a month. Ms. Deschamps said on Tuesday that she had called 911 on him three times \u2014 once after finding a receipt for a gun and bullets in Mr. Cruz\u2019s room, again after finding an empty gun box, and the third time after he punched holes in the wall and got into a fight with her son.\n\nFinally, she gave Mr. Cruz an ultimatum: lose the guns, or leave the home. He chose the latter.\n\n\u201cI did everything I could to warn law enforcement about what could happen,\u201d Ms. Deschamps, 42, said on Tuesday, the first public account she has given since the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., in which Mr. Cruz is accused of killing 17 people in one of the worst school shootings in American history.\n\n\u201cI wanted to protect not only my own children, but also anyone else who might be at risk of being harmed,\u201d she said. \u201cI also wanted to protect Nikolas from himself.\u201d", "title": "She Gave Nikolas Cruz an Ultimatum: The Gun Goes, or You Do. But she said she would not yield to calls that she step down.\n\n\u201cI have not resigned, and I will not resign,\u201d she said in the interview.\n\nThe House, which is controlled by Duterte allies, is widely expected to vote for impeachment next week. The case would then go to the Senate, whose 23 members would rule on the merits of the complaint. Most of the senators are supporters of Mr. Duterte, but it is not clear whether the necessary two-thirds would vote for an ouster.\n\nChief Justice Sereno, 57, was appointed in 2012 by Mr. Duterte\u2019s predecessor, Benigno S. Aquino III. She began to clash with Mr. Duterte soon after he took office in 2016, having campaigned on a promise to carry out a bloody crackdown on drug dealers and addicts.\n\nIn August of that year, Mr. Duterte on live television accused a series of politicians and other public figures of being involved in drugs, urging them to turn themselves in. Chief Justice Sereno, whose duties include overseeing more than 2,000 lower courts, said that judges on the list should not surrender to the authorities unless they were shown a warrant duly issued by a local court.\n\nMr. Duterte responded by saying the chief justice \u201cmust be joking.\u201d He added: \u201cIf this continues, you\u2019re trying to stop me, I might lose my cool,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
