But Chief Justice Sereno has voted against at least two of the president\u2019s other high-profile initiatives: his declaration of martial law in the southern Philippines last year, after Islamist militants took over the city of Marawi, and his move to give the dictator Ferdinand Marcos a hero\u2019s burial decades after his death.\n\nShe said that Mr. Duterte, an admirer of Mr. Marcos, had \u201cacted with grave abuse of discretion\u201d when he ordered the dictator\u2019s remains transferred to the Heroes Cemetery in Manila in 2016. She said the president was shirking \u201cobligations to do justice for human rights victims\u201d under the Marcos regime, which a popular uprising overthrew in 1986.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe court sided with Mr. Duterte in that case, and on the martial law issue. But Chief Justice Sereno\u2019s supporters say she is an impediment to authoritarian policies, with one calling the impeachment drive a \u201cwell-orchestrated but pathetic telenovela.\u201d\n\nThe chief justice said that nothing had emerged from the hearings to justify her removal.\n\nBut Mr. Duterte\u2019s spokesman, Harry Roque, has called on her to resign \u201cto protect the institution.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe president has said he was not involved with the impeachment drive, and Chief Justice Sereno said she took him at his word.\n\n\u201cIf he has said that he has nothing to do with the impeachment, let\u2019s leave it at that,\u201d she said. \u201cIn the meantime, I will continue to discharge my duties. I have a duty to respect this president, or any president, for that matter.\u201d She called the impeachment process a \u201cdistraction\u201d that the understaffed judiciary did not need.\n\nShe refused to appear in person before the House. But on Friday, in a speech to lawyers in the northern city of Baguio, she said she would defend herself at the Senate.\n\nThe National Union of Peoples\u2019 Lawyers, an association of legal experts on human rights, has criticized the 13 justices who asked Chief Justice Sereno to go on leave, saying they had \u201cprejudged the impeachment proceedings.\u201d\n\nChief Justice Sereno, who has two children and says she is a devout Christian, said in the interview that she found it difficult at times to separate her personal life from her public profile. She has begun to travel with armed guards.\n\n\u201cThere are many who are expecting to see someone crumble under the situation,\u201d she said.", "title": "She Stood Up to Duterte. Now She Faces Impeachment.", "authors": ["Felipe Villamor"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 An 85-year-old woman who as a child narrowly escaped France\u2019s most notorious wartime roundup of Jews has been murdered in Paris, and the authorities are calling it a hate crime.\n\nThe body of the woman, Mireille Knoll, was found on Friday in her apartment in the city\u2019s working-class 11th Arrondissement. She had been stabbed to death, and her body was partly burned after her attackers apparently tried to set fire to the apartment.\n\nThe Paris prosecutor\u2019s office said on Monday that Ms. Knoll had been killed because of the \u201cmembership, real or supposed, of the victim of a particular religion\u201d \u2014 a roundabout way of saying she was killed because she was Jewish.\n\nMs. Knoll was a child in Paris when, in the summer of 1942, the French police, cooperating with the Germans, rounded up thousands of the city\u2019s Jews, stuffing them into a cycling stadium, the V\u00e9lodrome d\u2019Hiver. Virtually all were subsequently murdered at Auschwitz.", "title": "She Survived the Holocaust, to Die in a 2018 Hate Crime", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "That seemed unlikely given the mess Muzerall inherited.\n\nNate Handrahan, the coach from 2011 to \u201915, resigned under pressure when a university investigation confirmed allegations that he had sexually harassed players. Handrahan\u2019s replacement, the 1998 Olympic goal medalist Jenny Potter, was fired after one season for multiple N.C.A.A. violations. Ohio State Athletic Director Gene Smith reassigned the women\u2019s hockey administrator, Shaun Richard. He put Diana Sabau, the executive associate athletic director, in charge and instructed her to find the next coach.\n\nSabau, who also oversees football, had no hockey contacts. So she searched the internet and called dozens of hockey people while assembling a list of candidates. Muzerall, a Canadian known as Muzz or Muzzy in the Minnesota hockey community, stood out as a winner who had paid her dues.\n\nHer 139 goals as a Gopher remain the school record. Muzerall coached and taught at Northfield Mount Hermon School in Massachusetts from 2002 to \u201909, then played briefly in Switzerland before returning to Minnesota in 2011 to join Frost\u2019s staff.\n\nFormer Minnesota Coach Laura Halldorson described Muzerall as a \u201cspitfire\u201d who thrived under pressure. The day before the 2000 national semifinals at Matthews Arena in Boston, Muzerall tripped at practice, banged her head on the ice and was taken off immobilized on a stretcher as a precaution. Cleared to play the next day, Muzerall scored twice as Minnesota ousted Minnesota Duluth, 3-2, in the semifinals. Then she added a goal and an assist in the 4-2 championship victory over Brown.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe elevated the program, no question,\u201d Halldorson said. \u201cI say she\u2019s a character, and I mean that in an endearing way. She\u2019s got a big personality. She\u2019s not afraid to speak her mind and tell it like it is. There was never an uninteresting day with Nadine Muzerall.\u201d\n\nTwo Ohio State teammates, Spring and Jincy Dunne, were part of the coaching search committee that interviewed the finalists. Muzerall was struck by how weary they appeared.\n\n\u201cThey looked sad, and they looked broken,\u201d she said. \u201cI was like, this is ridiculous. If you\u2019re not having fun in college, when are you going to have fun? You have the rest of your life to be stressed out. You\u2019re supposed to enjoy college and enjoy your hockey. I\u2019m going to come in and try to make you a better hockey player, but I also want to make you a better person.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOnce hired, Muzerall asked for additional resources \u2014 a full-time operations director, which the program had never had, and occasional charter flights to get students back from games quickly. Practices were harder, with more structure and greater accountability. Muzerall also instituted biweekly individual meetings with players to discuss hockey and life issues. She wanted her players to know she cared about them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf I coached them four years ago, I probably would have been a different coach,\u201d said Muzerall, who has two children. \u201cBut now being that I\u2019m a mom, you have that tough love where I\u2019m going to love you and take care of you and be loyal, but maybe I have to whip your butt a little bit from time to time.\u201d\n\nWhen the University of North Dakota dropped its women\u2019s hockey program last year, Muzerall hired its associate head coach, Peter Elander, a skills specialist. Under his tutelage at North Dakota, Jocelyne Lamoureux-Davidson perfected the shootout move that won an Olympic gold medal for the United States last month.\n\nThe Buckeyes\u2019 roster features seven Minnesotans and seven Canadians, a terrific goaltender in Kennedy Sauve (10 shutouts), and a strong freshman class led by Emma Maltais (16 goals, 40 points), the Western Collegiate Hockey Association Rookie of the Year.\n\nSweeping Wisconsin, then top-ranked, in a two-game series at home in early February helped the Buckeyes land an at-large N.C.A.A. Tournament bid. In the quarterfinals, Sauve made 23 of her 38 saves in the third period as the Buckeyes handed Boston College its only shutout of the season.\n\nThe gloom over the Buckeyes program has lifted, and Spring credits Muzerall.\n\n\u201cWhen you have three different coaches in a span of three years, each coach comes with different beliefs and philosophies,\u201d Spring said. \u201cFor Coach to step in on that third time around and provide us with guidance and leadership, and the commitment to create a culture we can all thrive in and be successful, was extremely important for her. She\u2019s been dedicated from Day 1, and I think it shows through us and what we\u2019ve been able to do this year on the ice.\u201d\n\nOhio State has the worst record among the Frozen Four participants, but Muzerall is as undaunted as she was when she took the Buckeyes job.\n\n\u201cAs excited as we are to be here, and honored, we\u2019re not going to be the ones that are sitting back as the fourth-ranked team out of four, bedazzled by all the lights and the press,\u201d Muzerall said. \u201cWe\u2019re here to win a tournament. We\u2019re going to come in competitive, and come in ready to rock and roll.\u201d", "title": "She Took Over Ohio State\u2019s Scarred Hockey Program. A Title Is 2 Wins Away.", "authors": ["Pat Borzi"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "We eventually bonded over hamburgers at a campus cafeteria. A week later I organized a group paintball outing, mostly to invite her. She came, though she hid in terror behind a barricade for much of the afternoon. Next we got together for a bike ride followed by Brie-stuffed French toast at a local breakfast spot \u2014 not quite as romantic as paintball.\n\nSix years later, our refrigerator is decorated with souvenir magnets from our trips across America. She\u2019s my girlfriend and partner in life, even in my sickness. I massage her knotted shoulder when it freezes up, and we laugh riotously alone together in the dark after turning off the lights.\n\nWe find pleasure in hashing out legal issues from the news or Dunia\u2019s job as a corporate lawyer. When I\u2019m well enough, I accompany Dunia to the dozens of weddings she is invited to every year. Apparently she still relishes having me as her tuxedoed guest, and that makes me happy.\n\n\u201cThese watches keep time perfectly,\u201d the salesman said.\n\nComing off a month of almost constant bed rest, I was antsy and overcome by a compulsion to do something \u2014 stomp my feet, scream, buy a wristwatch, anything.\n\nI had managed to hold on to the hefty bonus I had earned three years earlier, before taking medical leave from my Wall Street law firm. Maybe a watch would be an important investment, a commitment to my future during this difficult time.\n\nJust do it, I told myself. Do something.\n\nStaring at the stainless-steel timekeeper on my wrist, I sensed an impending front coming on, a dueling mix of unease and elation that accompanies an extravagant purchase worth more than three months of rent. I stared into the salesman\u2019s hopeful eyes and announced my intentions without quivering.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ll buy it.\u201d\n\nThe salesman, suddenly quite spirited, set into motion a string of fanfare. His assistant produced a miniature bottle of champagne from a back room (the mere sight of which increased my nausea). A young man in a slim suit peeled the protective wrapping from the sapphire crystal of my chronometer and began to polish feverishly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe held the timepiece up to the light for examination after every few strokes of his cloth. A barrel-chested technician emerged from behind an elevator door and measured my wrist, saying, \u201cSir, we should remove one link.\u201d\n\nWhile the watch was being adjusted, I handed over my debit card and gulped. There was no turning back. Part of me felt as if I had purchased a distant star and named it after myself.\n\nChronic illness is a grind. Renowned neurologists have told me I have disorders I never knew existed \u2014 dysautonomia, autonomic failure, persistent visual snow. They have assured me these conditions aren\u2019t terminal, but I am less concerned with death. Rather, I am consumed with how to live, how to maintain health care coverage, how to sustain disability insurance.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs my roommate and sometimes caregiver, Dunia has witnessed my struggles, replete with ambulance rides and crying fits. I imagine she would rather be elsewhere during these distressing episodes, but she stands by me nonetheless.\n\nPerhaps it\u2019s no coincidence that Dunia means \u201cthe world\u201d in Arabic, because having her with me is everything. We would be married but for my condition, which has placed a question mark at the end of nearly everything. Will experimental treatments eventually fix me? Can I contribute to a family? Is it fair to ask that Dunia sustain a lifetime of my poor health?\n\nI left the vast Tourneau showroom that day lighter in the wallet but heavier on the wrist. The watch felt dense, luxurious. It delighted me. And yet, as I loitered in front of the store, I was struck by how unchanged the city appeared, how unchanged I felt. The cabbies honked; the clip of the pedestrian stream was as swift as ever; the summer humidity was thick and filthy; and I still felt dizzy and disoriented.\n\nI shuffled at my sluggish pace toward the subway and wondered what Dunia would make of the small fortune dangling from my arm.\n\nOur shared bedroom is a cloud of freshly painted white walls, soft sheets and warm bedside lighting. Above the bed hang sunny oversize photographs shot from inside the canopy of a California date palm tree. This is our hide-out, a treehouse floating above the implausible pandemonium of New York.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re still the smartest and most handsome man I know,\u201d Dunia says to me in our hide-out. \u201cI\u2019m proud of you, proud of how you\u2019re handling this.\u201d\n\nThen, at other times, she is lost to me, constructing an invisible wall of uncertainty and fear as we talk about the future.\n\nAfter we voice these fears, I fall asleep awash with shame, fantasizing that I\u2019ll awake cured, competent to practice law, capable of helping Dunia with her plans and aspirations. But for now these are just dreams. A load of laundry overtires me. I can\u2019t imagine the marathon of work, parenthood and homeownership.\n\nLately I have concluded that the best thing for Dunia would be for me to leave her, free her from the burdens of a disabled partner, provide her the opportunity to find someone new and healthy with whom to build her vision.\n\nI said nothing of the shimmering fixture on my wrist when she arrived home from work.\n\n\u201cWait,\u201d she said, having caught it in the light. \u201cWhat\u2019s that on your wrist?\u201d\n\nI held it up.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so beautiful,\u201d she said. \u201cI fully support this. You deserve it.\u201d She asked to try it on and became fixated with it.\n\nI observed Dunia as she studied the Roman numerals on the dial, harking back to a distant, ancient time. As I watched her, my uncertainty about the future gave way to the certainty of the present, and I was overcome by the notion that she and I were moving through time together, like musicians playing from the same sheet music. A duet not yet completed, partially composed but largely improvised.\n\nOur future may be unsure, but such is the case for everyone and everything. As the second hand on the Datejust skated forward on Dunia\u2019s wrist, I saw that it portended nothing other than the now, the togetherness of Dunia and me alive and undeniable, good and right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this sense, my timekeeper is a shield, an armor of steel defending against the gnawing fear of the unknown. I peered into the sapphire crystal of my wristwatch and saw that the future is merely an accumulation of present moments \u2014 moments I can choose to savor. A watch to keep time perfectly.\n\nI thought about the grandfather clock from my law school days, ticking by my nook in the reading room. Another hungry law student sits there now, reading doggedly about fairness and rightness, Lady Justice keeping vigil.\n\nI can no longer say whether time is kind or just, if I ever could. Dunia and I may adapt fully to this life, maybe not. It may be true that time heals all wounds; I can\u2019t say. Who am I to judge time?", "title": "She Was My World, but We Couldn\u2019t Marry", "authors": ["Ari Diaconis", "Modern Love"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "You turn to social media.\n\n\u201cHey Twitter,\u201d Ms. Andersen wrote in a post on March 9. \u201cI\u2019m on a mission.\u201d\n\nAfter she posted the photo, hundreds of people replied with comments and suggestions.\n\nThe thread caught the attention of Margot Lee Shetterly, the author of the book \u201cHidden Figures: The American Dream and the Untold Story of the Black Women Mathematicians Who Helped Win the Space Race.\u201d\n\n\u201cHere\u2019s a working scientist, contributing alongside her colleagues, and she\u2019s not even given the professional courtesy of having her name recorded at a scientific conference,\u201d Ms. Shetterly said on Sunday. \u201cThe photo, with her brown face half obscured by the people around her, is a perfect metaphor for the larger issue of history\u2019s failure to record the work of women scientists, particularly women scientists of color.\u201d\n\nInspired by Ms. Andersen\u2019s post, amateur researchers began combing through historical records and unearthing the names of women who worked in the sciences during the 1970s.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMaybe, some suggested, the photo was of the oceanographer, professor and lawyer Matilene Spencer Berryman, who died in 2003? Or perhaps it was Suzanne Contos, who helped organize the conference in 1971? (It was neither. Ms. Berryman\u2019s age did not seem to match the photo, and Ms. Contos said it was not her.)\n\nThen Dee Allen, the research program officer at the Marine Mammal Commission, saw the photograph on Twitter and contacted some of her mentors.\n\n\u201cI figured it was probably something I could track down pretty easily, and I have an appreciation for the history of the field,\u201d Ms. Allen said. She contacted Don Wilson, the emeritus curator of mammals at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Wilson remembered. He told Ms. Allen that the woman had worked as a museum technician, and her name was Sheila.\n\n\u201cSheila was working at the museum in the Division of Mammals when I first started there in September 1971,\u201d Dr. Wilson said, adding that she was \u201can excellent technician.\u201d\n\nMs. Allen gave the information to Ms. Andersen, who began to look for Sheila on social media.\n\nBy March 12, she had found her. Ms. Andersen revealed that Sheila\u2019s original surname was Minor and posted snippets of their conversation, in which she said she had worked in several federal agencies for 35 years and \u201cloved every moment of my career.\u201d\n\nThe discovery was cheered by Ms. Andersen\u2019s Twitter followers, and by Ms. Shetterly, who said it was \u201ccritically important\u201d to tell the stories of people like Sheila who have historically been underrepresented, \u201cas the leaky pipeline exists in the history of science and technology as well as in its present.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Sunday, Sheila said her full name is Sheila Minor Huff. She is a retired, 71-year-old grandmother of five who belly dances, volunteers at her church and lives in Virginia.\n\nMs. Huff said she began working as an animal technician shortly after graduating with a bachelor\u2019s degree in biology. When she applied for her first job at the Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife, she was asked to work as a typist. \u201cI said, \u2018No, I went to school too long to be your secretary!\u2019\u201d she recalled.\n\nMs. Huff said she went on to complete a master\u2019s degree while working full time. She went to the Soviet Union to attend a conference for mammalogists. She worked with top government officials on a range of wildlife and environmental projects. By the time she retired, at 58, she had become a GS-14 federal employee \u2014 one of the highest designations possible \u2014 at the Department of the Interior.\n\nShe said she was not too bothered about going unnamed in the 1971 snapshot.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of like, no big deal,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen I try to do good, when I try and add back to this wonderful earth that we have, when I try to protect it, does it matter that anybody knows my name?\u201d", "title": "She Was the Only Woman in a Photo of 38 Scientists, and Now She\u2019s Been Identified", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Conservative figures in the government, including Islamic preachers or mullahs serving in Parliament, have bristled over the shelters for years and see them as foreign meddling and an imperialist imposition on Afghan culture.\n\nThose operating the shelters say officials are also angered that connections and bribes that grease other government affairs have mostly proved useless for fathers or husbands seeking to retrieve women from the independent shelters. Entrusting the shelters to a ministry would rob women of their only defense against so-called honor killings, they say.\n\nWestern embassies, for whom modest advances in women\u2019s rights are a tangible success of the war even amid battlefield setbacks, have blocked previous government efforts to roll back protections.\n\nThe Parliament came close in 2011 to passing harsh limitations on the shelters, and in 2013 it tried to gut a law barring violence against women. Lawmakers backed down under pressure from the European Union and United States.\n\nThe Ministry of Women\u2019s Affairs has sought financial control over the shelters before, also in 2013. Then, the private donors from the United States, and also European and American government agencies, strongly objected.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut as the Western presence winds down, the Afghan government has a freer hand, and it is unclear how Western governments will respond today. A spokesman for the American Embassy declined to comment.\n\nEfaf Benafsha, a province manager for Women for Afghan Women, a group that runs 26 shelters and other aid sites that serve about 5,000 women a year, the country\u2019s largest network, said donors opposed the plan. \u201cThey don\u2019t have enough trust\u201d in the ministry, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPeople are calling them centers of prostitution,\u201d she said. \u201cWe are hearing this from the government.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNabila Musleh, a deputy minister of women\u2019s affairs, said that her ministry was obliged to defend the shelters from their opponents in Parliament and other ministries and that having control over their finances would ensure that the nongovernmental organizations running the shelters were in turn responsive to the ministry.\n\n\u201cIf the donor community is interested in providing financial support for women protection centers, they can do it through the government,\u201d she said in an interview.\n\nThe ministry, she said, has struggled to arbitrate between foreign donors to the shelters and conservative members of the government, who are deeply critical of the sites, where women live unsupervised by men, and have spoken darkly of them as brothels.\n\n\u201cThe nature of the complaints is that women are being misused at the women protection centers, in different ways,\u201d she said. Those objections include that the women are \u201csometimes sexually misused.\u201d\n\nMs. Musleh conceded, however, that no evidence had ever emerged that the shelters were prostituting abused women. The allegation is continually raised, endlessly infuriating women\u2019s rights advocates. Still, she said, the government needed more direct control as a means to refute the brothel rumors.\n\nGovernment control would also ease access for women at the shelters to state-run mental hospitals, she said, and allow the government to open shelters in unstable regions where nongovernmental groups do not venture.\n\nThe Women\u2019s Ministry drafted the proposal to take over financing of the shelters, which would change a decade-old decree legalizing the facilities. The cabinet has considered but not yet adopted it.\n\nAfghan culture, said Ms. Benafsha, of Women for Afghan Women, still lags behind the laws protecting women that Western nations pressed the government to pass. In large parts of Afghanistan, daughters are still considered chattel property, to be traded to settle debts or blood feuds, a practice known as baad, or married off to strengthen familial alliances.\n\n\u201cWe talk to the husbands,\u201d Ms. Benafsha said. \u201cWhen we ask, \u2018Why do you beat your wife?\u2019 They say, \u2018This is my right.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Shelters Have Saved Countless Afghan Women. Kramer"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 Shen Zhihua, bon vivant, former businessman, now China\u2019s foremost Cold War historian, has set himself a near-impossible task. He wants China to peel back its secrets, throw open its archives and tell its citizens what went on between China and the United States, between China and North Korea, and much more.\n\nEven before the hard-line era of President Xi Jinping, the Communist Party has acted like a supersensitive corporation, blocking highly regarded historians like Mr. Shen from peering too deeply. Precious documents have been destroyed, stolen or kept under seal by librarians skilled at deflecting the inquiries of even the most tenacious researchers.\n\n\u201cChinese leaders have historical baggage,\u201d Mr. Shen, who will turn 68 next month, said over a glass of white wine at a handsome villa hidden behind a high wall in the heart of Beijing. His tousled graying hair, casual jacket and open-necked shirt depart sharply from the buttoned-down party look.\n\n\u201cThe party was popular, but after 1949 the party made a lot of mistakes: land reform, the Cultural Revolution, the Great Leap Forward. No such evidence ever surfaced, allowing him to ride out the scandal and hang on to power.\n\nBut a government report released on Monday suggests that some crucial evidence may have been deleted \u2014 and that has put Mr. Abe back in the hot seat. An internal investigation by the Finance Ministry concluded that unidentified officials tampered with official documents related to the land deal by deleting references to Mr. Abe\u2019s wife and senior members of his party.\n\nThe findings caused an uproar in Japan, where critics called for the finance minister, Taro Aso, to resign. At a news conference on Monday, Mr. Aso, a former prime minister, said he would stay in his post. But analysts said the latest revelations would be politically damaging for Mr. Abe as he prepares to seek a third term.\n\n\u201cThis materially changes the outlook for Abe\u2019s future,\u201d said Tobias Harris, a Japan analyst at Teneo Intelligence, a political risk consultancy based in New York. \u201cThe basis for him seeking a third term is evaporating.\u201d", "title": "Shinzo Abe of Japan Back in Spotlight Over Tampered Documents", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "What do you think this image is saying? The complaint describes an elaborate edifice of false statements through which the two \u201cdeceived investors\u201d into believing Theranos\u2019s unique technology could perform comprehensive tests on a single drop of blood.\n\nAmong the more brazen falsehoods peddled to potential investors: that Theranos technology was used by the Defense Department in Afghanistan and on medevac helicopters, and that the company\u2019s revenue in 2014 was $108 million and was \u201con track\u201d to generate $1 billion in 2015.\n\nIn fact, Theranos technology was \u201cnever deployed\u201d on the battlefield in Afghanistan, \u201cor on medevac helicopters,\u201d the S.E.C. said. Theranos\u2019s revenue in 2014 was barely $100,000, \u201cnowhere near\u201d $100 million, the agency said, and the $1 billion projection was a fantasy that \u201chad no basis\u201d in reality.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Holmes settled the S.E.C.\u2019s charges without admitting or denying them. She is barred from being an officer or director of any public company for 10 years and agreed to pay a fine of $500,000. Though she lost voting control of Theranos, a private company, she remains chairman and chief executive.\n\nShe could still face criminal charges. It\u2019s unusual, though not unprecedented, for the S.E.C. to settle a case while a criminal investigation is underway. (The United States attorney\u2019s office in San Francisco has declined to comment on whether it is investigating potential criminal charges; in a note to outside partners in 2016, the company said that the Justice Department had requested documents and that an investigation was active.)\n\nStill, the relatively lenient treatment she\u2019s gotten so far, compared with Mr. Shkreli\u2019s seven-year prison term, provokes the question: Is this fair?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have any connection to the case, but from reading the S.E.C.\u2019s complaint, the allegations are of a nature that prosecutors would typically pursue to determine if criminal charges can be brought,\u201d said Antonia M. Apps, a former federal prosecutor and partner at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy who teaches a course on white-collar crime at Harvard Law School. \u201cIt\u2019s outright fraud.\u201d\n\nJohn C. Coffee Jr., a professor at Columbia Law School who teaches classes on white-collar crime, agreed that \u201cit appears a lot of people were defrauded.\u201d But he said he would not be surprised to see a plea bargain or even a deferred prosecution agreement, in which Ms. Holmes could avoid a prison term, especially if she cooperates with prosecutors.\n\n\u201cTypically you get more sympathy from the criminal justice system if you\u2019re an attractive young woman than a brash, arrogant young male,\u201d he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Coffee and other lawyers I spoke to cautioned that, because she settled the S.E.C.\u2019s charges, the public hasn\u2019t heard her defense. When more facts emerge, her case may be more complex than it now appears. But on the face of the S.E.C.\u2019s complaint, Mr. Shkreli\u2019s crimes pale in comparison.\n\nAt the heart of both cases are lies: At Mr. Shkreli\u2019s sentencing, federal Judge Kiyo A. Matsumoto referred to Mr. Shkreli\u2019s \u201cegregious multitude of lies,\u201d and the same might be said of Ms. Holmes. But the financial consequences of her deceptions were in another league.\n\nJudge Matsumoto said it didn\u2019t matter that Mr. Shkreli later repaid the investors he defrauded, or that some of his investors made millions. Still, the magnitude of the fraud was just over $10 million.\n\nPhoto\n\nTheranos\u2019s was far greater. According to the S.E.C. complaint, from 2013 to 2015 Theranos used false claims to raise more than $700 million from investors. By late last year, Theranos was \u201con the verge of bankruptcy,\u201d the S.E.C. said.\n\nMr. Shkreli\u2019s victims were mostly wealthy individuals, presumably sophisticated investors. Many of Ms. Holmes\u2019 victims were, too; they included the media magnate Rupert Murdoch and Larry Ellison, the billionaire co-founder of Oracle. But she also attracted venture capital funds whose investors included pension funds and endowments, affecting thousands of ordinary Americans.\n\nIn comparison to Mr. Shkreli\u2019s fraud, the Holmes allegations \u201care really a different order of magnitude,\u201d Ms. Apps said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the reactions of Ms. Holmes and Mr. Shkreli to the charges are also wildly divergent \u2014 a factor that may ultimately determine whether Ms. Holmes is charged, and, if convicted, whether she ends up in prison.\n\nBoth Ms. Holmes and Mr. Shkreli courted celebrity and seemed to revel in media attention. But in Mr. Shkreli\u2019s case, that impulse seemed only to intensify once he was charged.\n\nMr. Shkreli repeatedly defied Mr. Brafman\u2019s admonitions to keep quiet and avoid the limelight. He smirked through his trial, taunted prosecutors as the \u201cjunior varsity,\u201d called the case a \u201cwitch hunt\u201d and was suspended by Twitter after he threatened to have sex with a freelance journalist who covered him. His bail was revoked and he was imprisoned after he offered a $5,000 bounty in a Facebook post for a strand of Hillary Clinton\u2019s hair \u2014 a \u201csolicitation to assault,\u201d Judge Matsumoto ruled.\n\nIn theory, Mr. Shkreli\u2019s well-publicized bizarre antics, both in and out of court, should have had no bearing on his guilt or sentence. As Mr. Brafman put it in his opening statement, Mr. Shkreli shouldn\u2019t be found guilty for being \u201codd,\u201d \u201cweird,\u201d or having a \u201cdysfunctional personality.\u201d But prosecutors cited his behavior to assert in closing arguments that he \u201chad no respect for the law.\u201d At his sentencing, Judge Matsumoto suggested his actions called into question whether his purported remorse was genuine.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never had a client who did more to hurt his own standing with the court than Martin Shkreli,\u201d Mr. Brafman said. His behavior and comments \u201cprobably added several years to his sentence.\u201d\n\nSo far, Ms. Holmes has followed the traditional route of the contrite potential defendant: She has maintained a low profile and said nothing to provoke the government or prosecutors.\n\nAfter the S.E.C. settlement, Ms. Holmes made no comment. In keeping with that strategy, John Dwyer, the Palo Alto, Calif., lawyer representing her, declined to comment for this column. Theranos issued a statement stressing that she had \u201ccooperated with the S.E.C. throughout its investigation\u201d and said its independent directors were \u201cpleased to be bringing this matter to a close.\u201d", "title": "Shkreli vs. Holmes: 2 Frauds, 2 Divergent Outcomes. Stewart", "Common Sense"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Ohtani, 23, will be part of the Angels\u2019 six-man rotation and make occasional starts as their designated hitter. So far in his first American spring training, he is 1 for 4 with two walks in six trips to the plate. On the mound, he has struck out 10 in four innings while allowing six hits, one walk and three runs.\n\nOn Friday, Ohtani pitched at the Milwaukee Brewers\u2019 ballpark in a B game that started at 10 a.m. The press box was packed with dozens of reporters from Japan and a few from the United States, and scouts watched from behind the plate. The stands were almost empty, though \u2014 although the Brewers opened the gates early for fans holding tickets to an afternoon game, few showed up.\n\nThe Brewers estimated the crowd at 60, nearly one for every pitch Ohtani threw in a tantalizing performance against minor leaguers. He recorded eight outs against 12 batters, all by strikeout, and two of the Brewers\u2019 four hits deflected off a fielder\u2019s glove. Working only from the stretch, Ohtani yanked some sliders into the dirt and struggled with his landing spot on the mound. But he felt comfortable by his third inning, when he struck out the side in order.\n\n\u201cI am satisfied with this outing,\u201d he said through an interpreter. \u201cI felt like I was in the zone with all my pitches compared to last time. I still need to work on the break of my breaking balls, and my timing. But I did take a step forward.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOhtani threw to the veteran catcher Rene Rivera and used fastballs, sliders, curveballs and splitters among his 52 pitches.\n\n\u201cHe looked nasty today,\u201d Rivera said. \u201cThat slider, you see the hitters jumping back, thinking they\u2019re going to hit it, and the ball is right on the corner.\u201d\n\nRivera, a defensive stalwart for the Mets and the Chicago Cubs last season, was one of several winter additions for the Angels, who have finished 21 games out of first place in each of the last two seasons. They traded for second baseman Ian Kinsler and signed Zack Cozart, an All-Star shortstop for Cincinnati who will play third base. They also re-signed Justin Upton, the slugging outfielder who arrived in a trade last Aug. 31.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe coup, of course, was Ohtani, who was so eager to play in the majors that he left Japan before he could seek his true value as a free agent, a decision that cost him a chance at a nine-figure contract. While Ohtani had his choice of teams, his age restricted his maximum signing bonus. The Angels paid $20 million to the Fighters for his rights, but had less than $2.5 million to spend on Ohtani, who will make the major league minimum salary of $545,000 this season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is his dream,\u201d said Charles Nagy, the Angels\u2019 pitching coach. \u201cHe\u2019s a great kid, very respectful, great poise and confidence. He\u2019s done everything we\u2019ve asked of him. He just wants to mesh in and be one of the guys.\u201d\n\nRivera called Ohtani \u201ca funny dude, always joking and happy,\u201d adding that he was trying to learn English quickly. Ohtani said that he was enjoying camp and his teammates and that the lack of days off had been his biggest adjustment; in Japan, players get to rest every fourth day or so.\n\nOhtani could not guess which would be his bigger challenge \u2014 hitting or pitching \u2014 because the competition in the majors is stronger for both.\n\n\u201cBoth are going to be pretty much the same,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s going to be hard.\u201d\n\nMaybe, but maybe not. Parker Bridwell, a starter who was 10-3 as a rookie last season, said Ohtani\u2019s pitches seemed to jump from his hand, and he marveled at Ohtani\u2019s variance in speed: a fastball near 100 miles an hour, a curveball under 70. Just as impressive, Bridwell said, was Ohtani\u2019s diligent approach.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019ll go through a bullpen, and if he doesn\u2019t like everything he\u2019s feeling, or what the ball\u2019s doing, he\u2019ll finish his bullpen, go hit batting practice, and then go throw more balls against the wall,\u201d Bridwell said. \u201cYou can tell he\u2019s paying attention to every detail.\u201d\n\nSo is the whole baseball world.", "title": "Shohei Ohtani Inspires Awe, and a Bit of Envy, Among His Teammates", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "When you learn that the name Hesperios means \u201cevening star\u201d in Greek, the notebooks seem less like a branding exercise and more like taking a moment to stop and ponder starlight. Broad tables with marble tops invite you to sit, and it almost feels as if Ms. Hruby would rather her customers write than shop.\n\nPerhaps the logic is that the longer you\u2019re there, the more a $450 Greek wine vessel or an $85 porcelain splatter-paint beaker with grooves like a peach pit seems necessary. It\u2019s like Vegas for sober, aesthetically obsessed minimalists, lured and kept until they make choices outside their means.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. Sent weekly. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOnce you get in there, you never get out,\u201d a saleswoman said when my friend sat down in a spare metal-framed rocking chair in the corner next to a marble block lamp made-to-order by the architect Andrew Trotter. On Mr. Trotter\u2019s website, it says the marble is hand-carved by a stone worker named Jean Briac.\n\nMy friend asked, \u201cIs that a sweater or a blanket?\u201d when we saw one of many meticulously arranged piles of beautiful knits (it was a sweater, for $325), the colors of which look sourced from a sun-faded page of paint samples propped in a window of an old hardware store in the Swedish countryside. The only clothes in the shop besides the knitwear are ornate dresses by Mark Fast, made-to-order from London. One dress looks like chandelier prisms hooked on a silk fishing net ($3,000).\n\nBefore it was Hesperios, the Cleveland Street space was a vape shop. I like imagining disappointed vapers peering inside, shaking their heads and exhaling orange-scented nicotine smoke against the windowpanes before skulking away.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere\u2019s a clementine tree potted at the front of the store. I asked if the saleswomen eat clementines from the tree throughout the workday. \u201cI think I would be smacked on my hand if I did,\u201d one said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInspired by a tiny leaf stalk placed in a glass jar on the shelf (not for sale), I decided to try on two green knit sets, one with a ribbed turtleneck ($283), the other a crew neck with a more textural weave ($283), each with a pencil skirt. A lot of Ms. Hruby\u2019s designs are monochrome full knit looks. There are even sets of high-waist underwear ($122) and bralettes that remind me a little of Yeezy Season 1 knit separates. What is it about an allover sweater that feels so luxurious?\n\nHesperios contains all the trappings of perfect taste: The store is a banquet set to let you know about a life well read, well traveled, well indulged.\n\nIn my green set (ribbed pencil skirt, $331), which I was impressed to see had delicate side pockets in the skirt, I looked like I, too, could be a leaf in a glass on someone\u2019s windowsill. What would I see from there? Would the person who placed me actually be reading a print magazine on their bed, consulting \u201cThe Physiology of Taste\u201d with a piece of toast on a ceramic plate beside them, or composing a handwritten note at their desk? I just don\u2019t believe it. But I\u2019ll take a cheese plate.", "title": "Shop, Eat, Envy", "authors": ["Katherine Bernard", "Critical Shopper"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "In nearly three decades of visiting Paris, a highlight of my sojourns is shopping for the sort of Franco-distinct fashions impossible to find at home. Over the years, the proliferation of chain stores in Paris (and easy access to French luxury brands at home) has made finding unique pieces a challenge.\n\nSo, on a recent trip, when I noticed a secondhand shop filled with high-end designer jackets, bags, boots and jewelry \u2014 many from defunct Parisian ready-to-wear brands, I was thrilled. While paying for my haul (a cashmere blazer by Angelo Tarlazzi and vintage fur stole), I learned that there were dozens of others, a network of resale shops catering to Frenchwomen\u2019s exacting taste and passion for a deal.\n\nAs a longtime designer resale and thrift store aficionado, I find few things more satisfying than tracking down accouterments that whisper \u201cFabriqu\u00e9 \u00e0 Paris\u201d \u2014 without paying retail. Thus began my deep dive into the City of Light\u2019s lively d\u00e9p\u00f4t-vente scene: upscale thrift shops that traffic specifically in luxury goods.", "title": "Shopping High-Fashion Paris on the Cheap", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBookends have one key functional requirement: staying put.\n\n\u201cYou can distill a bookend to what it really is,\u201d said Billy Cotton, an interior and furniture designer in Brooklyn. \u201cA heavy object.\u201d\n\nYet bookends can be so much more.\n\nBecause of that relatively low bar for functional success, they offer an opportunity for experimentation. And product designers have lavished no shortage of creativity on thinking up new shapes, sizes and materials \u2014 producing a range of statement-making accessories.\n\nIronically, the bookend\u2019s aesthetic possibilities have grown as book collections continue to shrink. \u201cNowadays, people have fewer and fewer books, so it becomes more about this play between books and objects,\u201d Mr. Cotton said.\n\n\u201cYou have to look at a bookend as you would a small object or sculpture,\u201d he added. \u201cIts form is almost ahead of its function.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Are purpose-built bookends the only option? No, said Mr. Cotton, who has employed all manner of objects to hold books upright: \u201cI\u2019ve used rocks and crystals, cast-metal blocks, old magnifying lenses.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. But when you walk into a room and need immediate illumination, there is no better multipurpose performer.\n\n\n\n\u201cYou have the opportunity to flood the room\u201d with light, said the New York interior designer James Huniford. \u201cIf you don\u2019t have something there, it can feel like a black hole. And if you have a bunch of recessed lights, it starts to look like Swiss cheese.\u201d\n\nSometimes Mr. Huniford uses simple ceiling lights that could almost go unnoticed, like basic porcelain sockets paired with mirrored bulbs, which he put in his house in Bridgehampton, N.Y. But other times, he aims for high drama with pieces like a custom snaking plaster fixture that he recently installed in a home on the Upper West Side. \u201cIt\u2019s like a sculpture,\u201d he said, \u201chugging the ceiling.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Should a ceiling fixture be installed in the middle of a room? Sparingly.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis is going to get expensive,\u201d he said.\n\nAfter admiring the preening shop cat, he pulled out his phone, its screen cracked just that morning, and pulled up a list from his wife: Marmite, Colman\u2019s English Mustard, oatcakes, Lee & Perrins Worcestershire sauce, Twinings Earl Grey Tea, Twinings English Breakfast Tea. A small basket ran to more than $100. But one item on the list, a box of smoky Lapsang souchong tea, eluded him, so he set off through the warren of West Village streets, getting turned around only a few times. \u201cI\u2019m going to start following the sun,\u201d he said jokingly.\n\nHe arrived at the Tea & Sympathy annex, a small shop on Greenwich Avenue stocked with teapots, chocolate boxes and kitsch accessories. He found the Lapsang souchong there and went next door to treat himself to a cup of tea.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m right underneath the queen,\u201d he said, settling into the cozy tea shop. In a panic he phoned his one friend in New York who is a similar size.
