(\u201cI paid her,\u201d he later deadpanned.)\n\nWith one jammy scone eaten, he hurried to bring his bounty to his wife and daughters. Would Higgins have headed home with a similar haul? \u201cMaybe Marmite,\u201d Mr. Hadden-Paton said. \u201cHe\u2019s a Marmite lover.\u201d", "title": "Shopping for Marmite With Harry Hadden-Paton", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Not only has the ideological composition of the Democratic electorate shifted leftward, but with Trump in the White House, the liberal wing of the Democratic Party has become energized in a way that has driven a national grass-roots mobilization.\n\nLarry Bartels, a political scientist at Vanderbilt, provided insight into the Democratic strategic dilemma in a recent paper, \u201cPartisanship in the Trump Era.\u201d\n\nBartels determined that Democrats are close to united in their support of an activist government that reduces the gap between rich and poor, regulates the environment and insures access to health care.\n\nStill, according to Bartels, cultural issues sow discord among Democrats. While more than a quarter of Democratic voters, 26.3 percent, are \u201ccloser to the Republicans than to their fellow Democrats\u201d on cultural attitudes, nearly three quarters of Democrats, 73.9 percent, are more liberal on cultural issues.\n\nIn an email, Bartels described these culturally liberal Democrats as:\n\nrelatively more enthusiastic about atheists, gays and lesbians, and Muslims; more negative about Fox News, Walmart, and Christians; more willing to rely on \u201cexperts\u201d; less likely to say that \u201canyone who is willing to work hard can still achieve the American dream\u201d; more likely to deny that \u201cthe interests of ethnic and racial minority groups often conflict with those of the white majority\u201d; less \u201cauthoritarian\u201d (as measured by questions about child-rearing), further to the left in their ideological self-placements, and more pro-choice on abortion.\n\nAccording to Bartels, Democrats who are most firmly culturally liberal are overwhelmingly white.\n\nI exchanged emails with a Democratic consultant who has played a prominent role in presidential, Senate and House elections. He asked to remain anonymous in order to be more candid.\n\nThe first question I posed was: Could Lamb \u2014 who did not face a primary \u2014 have won the seat if the contest had been held in 2016, during a general election? The answer was no:\n\nWe know that PA-18 was not winnable in a year with Hillary at the top of the ticket. Democrats did not win any seat with the demographic profile of this one anywhere in the country in 2016 \u2014 save for handful of longtime incumbents.\n\nHow about 2020? Could a centrist like Bill Clinton get the nomination?\n\nI\u2019d say the answer is \u201cno.\u201d I think the politics of the Democratic Party have changed significantly since that time and while it may not be the MOST liberal candidate who wins the nomination, all viable candidates will have to pass a certain threshold of liberal-ness.\n\nOne of the best case studies of center-left intraparty schism can be seen in the upcoming May 22 runoff election for the Democratic nomination in the 7th Congressional District in Texas \u2014 upscale suburban Houston.\n\nThe two candidates are Lizzie Pannill Fletcher, a local lawyer who led the primary with 29.3 percent and is generally viewed as the moderate, establishment candidate (referred to as Republican-lite by her opponents), and Laura Moser, a liberal political activist, author and former journalist, who came in second with 24.3 percent, and was described by the Houston Chronicle as the candidate of \u201cthose who want a full-fledged push to the left to provide the starkest possible contrast with Trump.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Should Democrats Embrace the Center or Abandon It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn your opinion, what is \u2014 or should be \u2014 the purpose of prison? In other words, how does incarcerating people serve society? What should prisons do for convicted criminals?\n\nIn \u201cTurn Prisons Into Colleges,\u201d Elizabeth Hinton writes:\n\nImagine if prisons looked like the grounds of universities. Instead of languishing in cells, incarcerated people sat in classrooms and learned about climate science or poetry \u2014 just like college students. Or even with them. This would be a boon to prisoners across the country, a vast majority of whom do not have a high school diploma. And it could help shrink our prison population. While racial disparities in arrests and convictions are alarming, education level is a far stronger predictor of future incarceration than race. The idea is rooted in history. In the 1920s, Howard Belding Gill, a criminologist and a Harvard alumnus, developed a college-like community at the Norfolk State Prison Colony in Massachusetts, where he was the superintendent. Prisoners wore normal clothing, participated in cooperative self-government with staff, and took academic courses with instructors from Emerson, Boston University and Harvard. They ran a newspaper, radio show and jazz orchestra, and they had access to an extensive library. Norfolk had such a good reputation, Malcolm X asked to be transferred there from Charlestown State Prison in Boston so, as he wrote in his petition, he could use \u201cthe educational facilities that aren\u2019t in these other institutions.\u201d At Norfolk, \u201cthere are many things that I would like to learn that would be of use to me when I regain my freedom.\u201d After Malcolm X\u2019s request was granted, he joined the famous Norfolk Debate Society, through which inmates connected to students at Harvard and other universities.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Based on Ms. Hinton\u2019s article, what do you think she believes is the purpose of prison? What does she think prison should do for society? For incarcerated people?\n\n\u2014 Do you think prisons should provide incarcerated people with access to education programs? Why or why not? How would this serve individuals and society?\n\n\u2014 If you do think prisons should give education opportunities, how extensive do you think these should be? Should they offer college and high school courses? Degree programs? Books for inmates to educate themselves? Or, as Ms. Hinton suggests, should prisons actually look like college campuses \u2014 with classes taught by university professors, a student government, extracurricular activities and a library?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Some lawmakers have opposed offering education programs in prisons, arguing that they waste taxpayer money on educating criminals, give convicts a competitive edge over law-abiding citizens in the job market, threaten prison security by encouraging protests and escape, defeat the purpose of serving a sentence and even make \u201csmarter criminals.\u201d What do you think of this reasoning? Does it change your mind or reinforce your opinion on educating incarcerated people? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Ms. Hinton writes that \u201ceducation is a civil right that improves society and increases civic engagement.\u201d To what extent do you agree with this statement and why?", "title": "Should Prisons Offer Incarcerated People Education Opportunities?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Before I joined Crampton and Michelle Clark, a biologist from the Pacific Islands Fish and Wildlife Office, at the Lihue heliport for the 15-minute flight into the interior, Crampton warned me that journalists tend to underestimate the Alakai. She recalled how one photographer, who had planned to spend a full week with the team, made it just a few hundred yards before giving up; she spent the remainder of the day at the field camp. Another visitor, who regularly hiked the Sierra Nevada, was flown out after less than 24 hours. \u201cI guess she was used to pine trees or something,\u201d Crampton told me. \u201cAnd trails.\u201d\n\nBy the time I arrived in late May, the team had spent the past three months rotating in and out of a muddy field camp consisting of a single large tent with four cots, a Coleman stove, a laminated map and several musty plastic ration tubs. With the season winding down, the team that week consisted of just two people: Mandy Peterson and Marcus Collado, a wildlife biologist from Maine who was easygoing but prone to turning morose. Crampton called his bleaker comments \u201cMarcus musings.\u201d\n\nBefore coming to Kauai, Collado worked banding golden-eagle chicks, a task that required him to stand on the skid of a helicopter as it flew, then jump from the skid to the cliff-face ledge where an eagle had nested. By comparison, harvesting eggs in the Alakai qualified as a relaxing vacation, though Collado noted that \u201cit can get a little sad\u201d because akikiki are so scarce. \u201cIn the job interview, they warn you: \u2018You may not see any birds or find any nests,\u2019 \u201d Collado told me. \u201cAnd I thought, Man, this could be tough.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen the akikiki\u2019s steep decline was discovered in 2012, the Fish and Wildlife Service convened a panel of experts to determine what, if anything, should be done to stave off extinction. After three days of debate, the group agreed to a set of interventions, including the construction of an eight-foot-tall, five-mile-long, pig-proof fence, and the installation of what would eventually be 300 reusable rat traps, each of which to be hand-placed in key areas and stocked with bait, to keep nonnative rats from eating the birds\u2019 eggs, their chicks and sometimes even the birds themselves, usually when a bird refused to abandon its nest.\n\nPeople tend to go into conservation biology to save species, but in practice, the job can be more about killing things. The camp keeps two binders for logging information. One is devoted to akikiki sightings and nests. Another tracks rat kills and is labeled \u201cCharlie work,\u201d a reference to the TV show \u201cIt\u2019s Always Sunny in Philadelphia,\u201d in which a character named Charlie is regularly dispatched to kill rats. When I pointed out that the rat binder was almost four times thicker than the bird binder, Peterson shrugged. \u201cWe do a lot of rat killing. We probably kill more rats than we find birds.\u201d\n\nEither way, the work can be wearing. Earlier this season, the camp started keeping a dream journal, which ended up doubling as a kind of anxiety log. A few weeks back, Collado said, he had a dream in which he saw the last surviving akikiki drowning in a canal. He raced to save it but arrived too late. Not long after that, Peterson dreamed that she saw an akikiki made of Legos and knew, in that moment, that all the real akikiki had died.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI joined Collado and Clark one morning when they went to check on an akikiki nest in a valley known as Far Quarter, about two hours from camp. At a previous job on Mono Lake, the associate director of the Kauai Forest Bird Recovery Project, Justin Hite, worked with a biologist who gave colorful names to the lake\u2019s islets \u2014 Little Norway, Little Tahiti \u2014 and in the Alakai, Hite carried on the tradition. A sharp-edged stretch became Titanic Ridge (\u201cI\u2019m on top of the world!\u201d). An area that shone with a rare forest rainbow was called Unicorn Paradise. One particularly inaccessible stretch became the Chasm of Doom, but when this nickname led field teams to avoid the area, it was rechristened Kasmadu.\n\nThat day, the forest had a sleepy feel. Clark stopped to admire a tiny, lacy fern known as lady of the mountain; later, she pointed out another, larger fern covered in soft brown hairs, which were once collected to make mattresses. Surprisingly, there was almost no bird song and not even much in the way of insects, just the occasional drone of a helicopter. (Though tourist helicopters aren\u2019t supposed to fly that low over the Alakai, Clark told me, some still do.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the time we got to the site, it was almost midday and hot. Because the team had already harvested eggs from this pair of birds, Collado\u2019s task was to see whether the new clutch had hatched and, if so, to find out how many of the chicks survived. Sitting on the stream bank, Collado used athletic tape to lash a GoPro video camera to the top of a collapsible 30-foot aluminum pole. Fully extended, the pole had an alarming sway; maneuvering it close enough to see inside a nest, without hitting the nest itself, was a heart-stopping project.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat morning, though, the main problem was getting the camera high enough; even held directly overhead, the pole was almost 10 feet too short. Peering around, Collado considered the landscape. \u201cJustin wasn\u2019t kidding when he said it was nearly impossible to check this nest,\u201d he said. Spotting some scuff marks on a dead ohia tree, he began to shinny up. \u201cI know Justin managed it somehow,\u201d he added. \u201cBut I\u2019ve also seen him fall a lot. He does sketchy stuff that the rest of us won\u2019t.\u201d\n\nOnce he managed to climb about 10 feet, Collado asked Clark to hand him the pole, which he carefully levered into the canopy, only to find that the view was blocked by leaves. For the next 20 minutes, Collado patiently worked the camera closer, while Clark watched the video feed on her phone. Finally, a blurry image of a small gray bird came into view. \u201cThere she is!\u201d Clark said excitedly. Peering at the screen, I saw a small, disgruntled-looking bird with a slim tail and a tiny patch of white over its eye.\n\nOver dinner the night before, Crampton described akikiki as \u201cthe little guys that at first you think are really boring, but then you spend a little time with them and discover that they have all these talents that are totally endearing. They do flips around the branches.\u201d That morning, though, the only talent the akikiki exhibited was an unbudging perseverance.\n\nHoping to get a look inside the nest, Collado climbed down, assuming that the akikiki would eventually fly off to feed. It didn\u2019t. My notes from the time say: \u201cBeen here an hour. No change. Nothing to do but sit and watch.\u201d\n\nThe history of the planet is rife with extinctions, often sweeping ones. Roughly 250 million years ago, a cataclysmic eruption destroyed more than 95 percent of the life in the oceans and 70 percent of the animals on land, effectively erasing about 10 million years of evolution. In the past five centuries, extinctions have become less dramatic but arguably more constant: a slow drip of change as humans have spread across the globe, clearing forests, planting crops, building cities and roads.\n\nWhen the Endangered Species Act was passed in 1973, it was in response to a slowly dawning awareness of how the planet was changing under human dominion. Centuries of aggressive hunting and development had shrunk the once-spectacular abundance of American wildlife to a degree that prompted widespread bipartisan alarm. The new law, which was unanimously approved by the Senate, made it a federal crime to kill an endangered animal and, more radical, established the rigorous protection measures still in place today: that once a species reaches the point of endangerment, government agencies are required to take steps to save it. At the time, this inflexibility was considered a crucial bulwark against the pressure that would be brought by politically powerful industries, like logging and drilling. \u201cNothing is more priceless and more worthy of preservation than the rich array of animal life with which our country has been blessed,\u201d President Nixon said while signing the act.\n\nThough it can be hard to imagine today, the Endangered Species Act was intended to be a starting point rather than an endgame; a last-ditch way to save species that were vanishing until more comprehensive and farsighted conservation plans could be put in place. As Chris D. Thomas, an ecologist and evolutionary biologist at the University of York, puts it, \u201cThe fact that we reach this point, with all the heroic measures, shows that we\u2019re not great at planning ahead.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBut it\u2019s also true that extinctions just seem to get to us. We make a modest effort as a species dwindles and then, when it\u2019s really on the ropes, we suddenly panic. \u201cThere\u2019s just something gutting about a thing being lost to us forever,\u201d Thomas says.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore debatable is the degree to which extinctions are genuinely catastrophic. Do these disappearances represent the loss of rare, beloved plants and birds? Or are they simply the next evolutionary step in an ever-changing, increasingly global ecosystem? When I spoke with Thomas, he supported the idea that truly invasive species \u2014 the kind that transform the landscape \u2014 may need to be contained. But it\u2019s also true that the early isolation of the Pacific islands was itself an artifact. \u201cIf you look at it cruelly and unemotionally, Hawaii has native birds and introduced birds,\u201d he told me. \u201cThe native birds are dying out, and the introduced birds are malaria resistant. Are the introduced birds worse? Not necessarily. You could argue that this is simply a case where island species have lost out and continental species have won.\u201d\n\nIn this view, the loss of Hawaii\u2019s native birds and plants and their replacement by species that are more resistant to disease and predators, is just another case of the fittest surviving. If humans have accelerated this process by planting Argentine pampas grass in their gardens or by dumping tropical aquarium fish in their local lake, it\u2019s still just a faster, looser version of what has been happening on the planet anyway: Starbucks in Paris and McDonald\u2019s in Soweto; Australian brown tree snakes in Guam and Asian carp in the Great Lakes.\n\nIn short, it\u2019s fair to ask why, exactly, biodiversity matters. As Thomas says: \u201cEven if we were to lose 10 percent of all species in the next hundred years, would biology stop? Would ecology stop? No. In fact, most people wouldn\u2019t even be aware of the loss.\u201d Given how radically we\u2019ve already altered the landscape, how bad would it be if we just kept doing what we\u2019re doing: paving the land, overfishing the oceans and letting the chips fall where they may?\n\nFaced with this dilemma, some conservationists have tried to shift the focus to an economic argument known as \u201cecosystem services\u201d: the idea that we benefit from preserving biodiversity either because it saves us money (mangroves prevent coastal erosion that we would otherwise have to handle with an expensive engineering project) or because it contains something of value to us, either now or in the future. For instance, a biodiverse planet may provide a first defense against global warming. Or it may act as a repository of potential discoveries: new materials that mimic the strength of spider silk; drones modeled after insects; an anticancer drug derived from Amazonian moss.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile all this may be true \u2014 mangroves do prevent coastal erosion; research into new cancer drugs derived from plants is underway \u2014 it can also sound wishful, like a hoarder arguing that his pile of junk might someday contain collectors\u2019 items. The difference, Thomas says, is that unlike a hoarder\u2019s pile, ecosystems perform vital planetary functions, like keeping soil fertile, preventing desertification and absorbing carbon dioxide. The reason some conservationists want to prioritize genetic or functional diversity isn\u2019t that either of those things are inherently valuable to people, though they can be, but because they\u2019re essential to the health and resiliency of ecosystems themselves. The true problem, then, is not whether we would notice those vanished species and ecosystems; it\u2019s that there\u2019s no good way to quantify the opportunity cost of our loss, which in turn can lead us to underestimate it. \u201cThe species we have now are the ancestors of all future species,\u201d Thomas says. \u201cAnd I don\u2019t think we know enough about ecology or evolution, or how humans are going to affect the planet over the next thousand years, to bet on which animal or plant to keep.\u201d\n\nAll of which makes it hard to know where to draw the line. We can\u2019t put every ecosystem in the world under glass. (We can\u2019t even manage to do that on Kauai, a 500-square-mile island in the middle of the Pacific.) Even if we could, conservation isn\u2019t always an ethically straightforward choice; in countries like Brazil and Kenya, do we prioritize protecting wild animals and their habitats or the farmers facing hunger who hunt those animals and who log forests to plant crops?\n\nPresumably, though, we also don\u2019t want a planet that\u2019s nothing but pavement, cattle farms and monoculture farmland. The biologist E.O. Wilson eloquently argued against living in a world of crows and rats, and against the loss of beautiful, fragile species like snow leopards, white rhinos and tiny mouse lemurs; even if you never see a lemur or an arctic fox in person, the world can be a richer place by having such creatures in it. Others simply see conservation as a moral duty: because we\u2019re the ones creating these problems, isn\u2019t it up to us to fix them?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhether we regard conservation as an ethical or an economic issue, we\u2019re still faced with the question of how we decide what to save. In an ideal world, Michael Scott told me, conservation science would have the resources to study this question, rather than being stuck reacting to the latest crisis. \u201cFiguring out which species and ecosystems are the most important to protect is a complicated project,\u201d Scott says. \u201cAt this point, just coming up with a list of qualities we want to investigate would be a good start.\u201d\n\nBut for such an approach to take hold, the conservation movement would have to undergo a profound shift \u2014 away from triage mode and toward a more coherent and deliberate plan for global conservation. And such a shift would most likely require more resources and more political support than currently exist. The question is whether it will happen in time to shelter us from some of the more significant changes that climate change and development are likely to bring.", "title": "Should Some Species Be Allowed to Die Out?", "authors": ["Jennifer Kahn"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The connection between partner abuse and mass shootings has become almost commonplace. Among the many examples: Devin Patrick Kelley, who murdered 26 congregants at First Baptist Church in Sutherland Springs, Tex., in November, had been court-martialed by the Air Force for domestic violence; James Hodgkinson, who fired on members of Congress as they played baseball last June, had a court record of abuse against his foster daughter; Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, who killed 84 people with a truck in Nice, France, in July 2016, was known to the authorities because he had assaulted his wife.\n\nHow can we make sense of the connection between domestic abuse and large-scale violence? The men (and they typically are men) who perpetrate private abuse often use violence to create a climate of fear for the women who live with them. The gunman in a mass shooting does the same thing, sowing terror among his targets and the public.\n\nThis is not to say that all those who commit domestic violence are at risk of becoming mass murderers. Only a small subset of people who abuse family members also commit large-scale murder. The link, however, is a crucial one. In fact, experts refer to particularly dangerous domestic relationships as \u201cintimate terrorism.\u201d\n\nWhen domestic violence follows the pattern of intimate terrorism, the perpetrator typically tries to control every aspect of the victim\u2019s life: her finances, clothes, contact with friends and family, even what position she sleeps in. Once an abuser has appropriated the power to restrict his partner\u2019s daily life, he no longer needs to resort to regular physical harm; it is only when she tries to resist his \u201crules\u201d that he\u2019s likely to follow through with violence. Physical violence is his punctuation mark, the tactic he uses when others have failed to yield the control he requires.\n\nProsecutors say Ms. Salman made financial arrangements with Mr. Mateen in advance of the attack and helped him devise a cover story. The F.B.I. has said that Ms. Salman confessed to joining Mr. Mateen on a trip to scout out the nightclub. Ms. Salman denies prior knowledge of the attack. Again, the trial has not yet begun, and nothing has been proven.", "title": "Opinion | Should an Abused Wife Be Charged in Her Husband\u2019s Crime?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Is the minimum legal voting age of 18 years old fair and appropriate, in your opinion, or should it be lowered?\n\nIn your view, at what age should people be able to vote in the United States? Why?\n\nIn \u201cWhy We Should Lower the Voting Age to 16,\u201d Laurence Steinberg writes:\n\nThe young people who have come forward to call for gun control in the wake of the mass shooting at their high school in Parkland, Fla., are challenging the tiresome stereotype of American kids as indolent narcissists whose brains have been addled by smartphones. They offer an inspiring example of thoughtful, eloquent protest. Unfortunately, when it comes to electing lawmakers whose decisions about gun control and other issues affect their lives, these high schoolers lack any real power. This needs to change: The federal voting age in the United States should be lowered from 18 to 16. Skeptics will no doubt raise questions about the competence of 16-year-olds to make informed choices in the voting booth. Aren\u2019t young people notoriously impulsive and hotheaded, their brains not fully developed enough to make good judgments? Yes and no. When considering the intellectual capacity of teenagers, it is important to distinguish between what psychologists call \u201ccold\u201d and \u201chot\u201d cognition. Cold cognitive abilities are those we use when we are in a calm situation, when we are by ourselves and have time to deliberate and when the most important skill is the ability to reason logically with facts. Voting is a good example of this sort of situation. Studies of cold cognition have shown that the skills necessary to make informed decisions are firmly in place by 16. By that age, adolescents can gather and process information, weigh pros and cons, reason logically with facts and take time before making a decision. Teenagers may sometimes make bad choices, but statistically speaking, they do not make them any more often than adults do.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 At the end of the article, Professor Steinberg writes:\n\nThe last time the United States lowered the federal voting age was in 1971, when it went from 21 to 18. In that instance, the main motivating force was outrage over the fact that 18-year-olds could be sent to fight in Vietnam but could not vote.\n\nDo you agree with the writer\u2019s proposal to lower the voting age to 16 so that those most vulnerable to school shootings have a say in how those shootings are best prevented? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Do you agree that the brain science discussed in the article supports the argument for lowering the legal voting age in the United States? If so, how and why?\n\n\u2014 What other reasons might you have for lowering the voting age, or for keeping the status quo, and why?", "title": "Should the Voting Age Be Lowered to 16?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "The last team to win back-to-back titles was the Detroit Red Wings in 1997 and \u201998. When the Red Wings were going for three in a row, they lost in the second round of the playoffs.\n\nThe Penguins have thrived in a salary-cap era that seeks leaguewide parity. They have played 213 regular-season and playoff games in their past two championship seasons, the most by an N.H.L. team in a two-year span.\n\nEntering Saturday\u2019s game against Montreal, the Penguins are on a roll in this calendar year, going 25-10-3 since Jan. 1. With one week left in the regular season, Pittsburgh sits in second place in the Metropolitan Division.\n\nCrosby, who has 28 goals and 57 assists, sees a benefit in peaking in the weeks leading up to the postseason.\n\n\u201cWe weren\u2019t even in the playoff picture earlier this season; it was more about that than any thoughts of a three-peat,\u201d said Crosby, who missed the playoffs in only his rookie year. \u201cIt\u2019s good that we\u2019ve been fighting to get in, not just coasting.\u201d\n\nCrosby continues to excel, along with his fellow forwards Evgeni Malkin, Phil Kessel and Patric Hornqvist, all of whom are over 30. Malkin is 7 points short of his fourth 100-point season, but his first since 2011-12. Kessel and Hornqvist have reached the 25-goal mark. And the veteran defenseman Kris Letang is having a fine comeback season after missing last year\u2019s Cup run because of a herniated disk that required neck surgery.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Penguins continue to incorporate young talent. In the past two Cup-winning seasons, they benefited from the emergence of the versatile forwards Conor Sheary, Bryan Rust and Jake Guentzel; defenseman Brian Dumoulin; and goalie Matt Murray, 23, a two-time champion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut they did not settle for the roster they started the season with. Pittsburgh traded for center Riley Sheahan from Detroit in October and acquired Derick Brassard at the deadline in February to be the third-line center, a luxury few teams are able to accomplish.\n\n\u201cThey achieved that and never messed with the integrity of their roster,\u201d the NBC Sports analyst Pierre McGuire said. \u201cThat was smart. Plus they have young players who have improved, and that speaks to coaching and development and work habits. He is driven by the endless quest for perfection.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a hard league and it\u2019s hard to win,\u201d he said. \u201cYou never really arrive. Everything you go through is an experience, a learning opportunity. Whether it\u2019s a success or a failure, there\u2019s always something you can take away that will help you be a better person or a better player or a better teammate. That\u2019s the mind-set we have to have.\u201d\n\nSullivan promoted the former Penguins Sergei Gonchar and forward Mark Recchi to assistant coaches this season, and continues to rely on Jacques Martin, previously head coach of four N.H.L. teams, to be a calm and sage presence.\n\n\u201cJacques is invaluable; I could go forever and tell you what he means to me,\u201d Sullivan said. \u201cHe\u2019s a guy I can lean on in a lot of circumstances. We\u2019re just trying to hang on.\u201d", "title": "Sidney Crosby and Penguins Try to Peak at the Right Time", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOh my god, this is so cute!\u201d\n\nRobin Li, an investor with the San Francisco venture capital firm GGV Capital, was standing in the lobby of the Madison building in downtown Detroit. Built in 1917 as a theater and refurbished several years ago as a tech co-working space, the Madison checks all of the aesthetic boxes of hipsterdom: reclaimed wood, exposed brick walls, pour-over coffee served by tattooed baristas.\n\n\u201cThis is nicer than San Francisco,\u201d Ms. Li concluded.\n\nLast month, I accompanied Ms. Li and roughly a dozen other venture capitalists on a three-day bus trip through the Midwest, with stops in Youngstown and Akron, Ohio; Detroit and Flint, Mich.; and South Bend, Ind. The trip, which took place on a luxury bus outfitted with a supply of vegan doughnuts and coal-infused kombucha, was known as the \u201cComeback Cities Tour.\u201d\n\nIt was pitched as a kind of Rust Belt safari \u2014 a chance for Silicon Valley investors to meet local officials and look for promising start-ups in overlooked areas of the country.", "title": "Silicon Valley Is Over, Says Silicon Valley", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Two days after Donald J. Trump won the 2016 election, executives at Google consoled their employees in an all-staff meeting broadcast around the world.\n\n\u201cThere is a lot of fear within Google,\u201d said Sundar Pichai, the company\u2019s chief executive, according to a video of the meeting viewed by The New York Times. When asked by an employee if there was any silver lining to Mr. Trump\u2019s election, the Google co-founder Sergey Brin said, \u201cBoy, that\u2019s a really tough one right now.\u201d Ruth Porat, the finance chief, said Mr. Trump\u2019s victory felt \u201clike a ton of bricks dropped on my chest.\u201d Then she instructed members of the audience to hug the person next to them.\n\nSixteen months later, Google\u2019s parent company, Alphabet, has most likely saved billions of dollars in taxes on its overseas cash under a new tax law signed by Mr. Trump. Alphabet also stands to benefit from the Trump administration\u2019s looser regulations for self-driving cars and delivery drones, as well as from proposed changes to the trade pact with Mexico and Canada that would limit Google\u2019s liability for user content on its sites.\n\nOnce one of Mr. Trump\u2019s most vocal opponents, Silicon Valley\u2019s technology industry has increasingly found common ground with the White House. When Mr. Trump was elected, tech executives were largely up in arms over a leader who espoused policies on immigration and other issues that were antithetical to their companies\u2019 values. Now, many of the industry\u2019s executives are growing more comfortable with the president and how his economic agenda furthers their business interests, even as many of their employees continue to disagree with Mr. Trump on social issues.", "title": "Silicon Valley Warms to Trump After a Chilly Start", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSimran Rebecca Winkelstern and Moses Jonathan Kagan were married March 16 at the Beverly Hills Courthouse in Beverly Hills, Calif. Bruce Weinberg, a deputy commissioner of civil marriage for Los Angeles County, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 35, is an interior designer in private practice in Los Angeles. She graduated magna cum laude from Princeton. She received an associate degree in baking and pastry arts at the Culinary Institute of America in St. Helena, Calif. She also received a certificate in interior architecture at the University of California, Los Angeles. She is the daughter of Linda K. Winkelstern and Subagh S. Winkelstern of Chautauqua, N.Y. The bride\u2019s father, who is retired, was a dentist in private practice in Rochester, N.Y. Her mother, also retired, was a school psychologist and administrator for the Rochester City School District. The bride\u2019s parents are now the co-directors of the Chautauqua Institution\u2019s Mystic Heart Meditation Program.\n\nThe groom, 38, is a partner in Adaptive Realty, the Los Angeles-based real estate development company. He graduated magna cum laude from Princeton, and received a Master of Arts degree from the London School of Economics and Social Sciences. He is a son of Lisa M. Kagan and Larry Kagan of Troy, N.Y. The groom\u2019s mother, who worked in Albany, retired as an associate commissioner of the New York State Office for People With Developmental Disabilities. She also retired from another job, as the chief compliance officer of AHRC, a company that provides services to people with developmental disabilities, in New York. His father, a sculptor whose work is on display at the Jewish Museum in New York, is emeritus professor of art at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.\n\nThe groom\u2019s first marriage ended in divorce.\n\nThe couple met on OkCupid in January 2016. The bride\u2019s friend had seen the groom first on the site, and made the introduction.", "title": "Simran Winkelstern, Moses Kagan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "With a brother on the West Coast and no nieces or nephews to step in, Ms. Peveler has, through her church and several civic activities, developed a surrogate family of friends and neighbors, many of them several decades younger, who keep tabs on her. For added protection, she signed up for a service, EyeOn App, that signals three friends if she does not reply within a half-hour to scheduled alerts on her cellphone.\n\n\u201cOnce, I didn\u2019t respond, and everyone called me,\u201d she said. \u201cMy next-door neighbor sent her daughter over.\u201d\n\nAlthough no plan is foolproof, Ms. Peveler said she was as confident as she could be. \u201cI know people would have my back,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Peveler is among a growing number of older Americans who are unmarried and childless. By 2030, about 16 percent of women 80 to 84 will be childless, compared with about 12 percent in 2010, according to a 2013 report by AARP.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile Ms. Peveler is trying to control the risks of aging alone, many so-called elder orphans may not fare as well. Older single and childless people are at higher risk than those with children for facing medical problems, cognitive decline and premature death, according to a 2016 study led by Dr. Maria Torroella Carney, chief of geriatric and palliative medicine at the Northwell Health system on Long Island. The study noted that about 22 percent of people 65 and older either are childless or have children who are not in contact.\n\nAdult children typically help elderly parents negotiate housing, social-service and health care options. Without such a fallback, elder orphans can reduce their risks by building their own support structures, Dr. Carney said.\n\n\u201cPeople who are aging alone need to make plans when they are independent and functional,\u201d she said. \u201cThey need to learn about the resources in the community and the appropriate time to start using them.\u201d Those services could include senior-friendly housing and the growing number of home-delivered products and services aimed at the aging-solo market, such as healthy meals and doctors who make house calls, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the first steps childless people should take is to hire an elder law lawyer, who can draw up documents that will protect them if they become incapacitated. Childless people typically turn to a friend, a lawyer, clergy, or a niece or nephew to make medical decisions, according to experts. A bank\u2019s trust unit can take on financial tasks, with a friend, a relative or a lawyer monitoring the bank\u2019s decisions.\n\nChristina Lesher, an elder law lawyer in Houston, suggests appointing a \u201cmicro board,\u201d which includes the lawyer, the health care and financial agents, an accountant and a geriatric care manager. \u201cThe board can step in if a client cannot make decisions,\u201d Ms. Lesher said. The client could assign a network of friends and neighbors to call the lawyer in an emergency or if they notice any cognitive decline.\n\nAs for housing, Dr. Carney recommends that people aging alone consider a senior-friendly \u201ccongregate living\u201d arrangement. Besides offering a variety of services, such housing can lessen isolation, which her research shows can lead to physical and cognitive decline. If that is not possible, she said, elder orphans should move closer to shopping, medical care, recreation and senior support services.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne housing option with a built-in support system is a continuing care retirement community. Residents usually start in an independent living unit and, depending on the care needed, move to an on-site assisted-living unit or a skilled-nursing facility. Entrance and monthly fees tend to be hefty, however. Typical entry fees range from just over $100,000 to more than $400,000 while monthly services fees can range from $2,000 to $4,000, according to MyLifeSite, which tracks the pricing and financial information of more than 800 C.C.R.C.s.\n\nWith no one to oversee their care, elder orphans who want to remain in their own homes for as long as possible could enlist a geriatric care manager, who monitors elderly clients and coordinates care.\n\nIn Washington, D.C., clients of Iona Senior Services, for example, can arrange for a care manager to be on call as their health deteriorates, said Deborah Rubenstein, director of consultation, care management and counseling programs. If a client is discharged from a hospital, for example, the care manager, in consultation with the designated health care agent, would arrange for rehabilitation or home care, she said.\n\n\u201cMore and more people were coming to us and saying, \u2018I\u2019m O.K. now, but I\u2019m realistic enough to know my health status could change,\u2019\u201d Ms. Rubenstein said. Iona charges $150 an hour.\n\nPhoto\n\nMeanwhile, a growing number of volunteer neighborhood groups are providing both social connections and practical help to older people who are at home alone. More than 200 organizations in the Village to Village Network, including \u201cvillages\u201d in the New York area, provide rides to medical appointments, snow removal, home repairs and computer support. Villages in 150 additional neighborhoods are in development. Tax-deductible membership fees can range from $100 to $400.\n\nEntrepreneurs and companies, many nationwide, are moving into the so-called longevity market. On-demand services, accessible by a phone app or a computer, can connect people to personal assistants and food delivery.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe on-demand marketplace will be the best friend of elder orphans,\u201d said Mary Furlong, a Silicon Valley consultant to companies that cater to seniors.\n\nFor example, the ride-hailing service Lyft is working with health care systems and retirement communities to provide rides to nonemergency medical appointments and other destinations. And because financial acuity often declines with age, childless singles can enroll in a service such as EverSafe, which monitors accounts for unusual spending and alerts the client or a trusted advocate of possible fraud.\n\nIn-home technology, like medication reminders, also can help people live alone safely longer, experts say. Besides her EyeOn home-monitoring system, Ms. Peveler uses an Amazon Alexa device.\n\n\u201cIf I am reading a recipe, I can tell her what to put on a shopping list,\u201d said Ms. Peveler, who has a harder time remembering some details since her mini-strokes. And just for fun, she may tell Alexa \u201cto make cat noises, and one of my cats goes nuts.\u201d\n\nFor those aging solo, expanding a social network is essential, according to experts on aging. Two years ago, Carol Marak, who is in her mid-60s and lives alone in Dallas, started the Elder Orphan Facebook Group.\n\n\u201cI wanted a place to feel less lonely and to connect with others in the same situation,\u201d said Ms. Marak, who is also the spokeswoman for SeniorCare.com, a site that provides information on local care options. About 6,500 childless singles, mostly women, are members, she said.\n\nMs. Marak said she was struck by the number of members who worried about being \u201cisolated and disconnected from the community.\u201d She said she was trying hard to create her own social connections. She moved from a suburban house to a downtown condominium building, where she is making new friends. And she has organized brunches for Dallas members of the Facebook page.\n\nDetermined to stay healthy for as long as possible, Ms. Marak said she walks six miles a day and eats mostly vegan meals. \u201cI need to keep stronger because I am totally responsible for myself,\u201d she said.", "title": "Single? No Kids? Don\u2019t Fret: How to Plan Care in Your Later Years", "authors": ["Susan B. Garland"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "For personal assistance on an even tighter budget, there are companies like Fiverr, which hires freelancers around the world, resulting in lower prices, though perhaps a slightly more alienated feeling.\n\nI tried a few of these services. Here\u2019s what I found.\n\nFin\n\nOn Day 1 of signing up with Fin, my hopes are high. After reading through the website\u2019s live feed of customer requests, I\u2019m convinced that the app can take whatever I throw at it, no matter how obscure the request.\n\nThe first task is my insurance coverage, which is set to expire in a few weeks. It\u2019s a prime example of my most dreaded task, the kind I\u2019d normally put off.\n\nFirst on the website chat box, then with voice-to-text on my phone, I ask Fin to look into it and find me the cheapest plan it can. Later in the day, I also ask it for help with shipping my car out of state. I have found one service, but ask if Fin can find something better. Then I sit back, remembering my own days as a personal assistant, thinking how the tide has turned.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy the end of the day, Fin has given me estimated health insurance quotes and a link to an online insurance website. But when I try to open the link, I have to re-enter all of my information again myself to see anything. Didn\u2019t I pay Fin to do this? Later that night and the next morning, Fin sends me car shipping services, but they aren\u2019t faster or cheaper than what I\u2019d found myself in a few minutes of quick research.\n\nI get frustrated and decided to do the job myself on my commute. About 45 minutes later, I have found a faster shipping service and booked it. All of Fin\u2019s calls and emails on my behalf start to feel like halfhearted busywork.\n\nLater that second morning, I consider giving Fin one last task but decide to check my balance first. The problem is, I can\u2019t find it anywhere. One long search later, I do find it and my jaw drops. Fin says it spent 215 minutes on the requests, and with an initial free 60 minutes deducted, is going to charge me $181.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI call customer service, which eventually reviews my case and says Fin should have kept me more informed about the time it was spending. They give me a 100-minute credit.\n\nCost: $81\n\nBillable time spent: 3.6 hours\n\nMagic\n\nI begin trying Magic around the same time as Fin. I\u2019m feeling sick, so I ask Magic to schedule me a last-minute doctor\u2019s appointment for the same day. It\u2019s both a challenging request and something I really don\u2019t want to do myself. Magic promises encryption for personal data, so I feel comfortable giving it my health insurance and personal information. It tells me it\u2019ll check back with me in 35 minutes.\n\nMy doctor isn\u2019t available for at least two weeks, so Magic ends up finding me an appointment at an urgent care center. In the end, Magic hands the task back to me \u2014 the doctor\u2019s office won\u2019t let it schedule the appointment for me because of privacy concerns. But Magic does tell me who to call, and that I can see a doctor that day. Since I\u2019m already stressed and feeling sick, I find that Magic\u2019s help does actually feel helpful. At least it got the process started.\n\nCost: $31.86\n\nBillable time spent: 54 minutes\n\nFiverr\n\nAfter my experiences with Fin and Magic, I\u2019m ready to try something low risk. I search around on Fiverr and find a virtual personal assistant named Rex, based in Nigeria, who charges $10 an hour and has five-star reviews.\n\nWith Rex, I decide to start with a non-research task: listing some items I want to sell on eBay. But right away, we run into problems. It\u2019s raining hard in Lagos, where Rex is based, and his internet keeps going out. Once the rain eases up, I give him my eBay login information, but before long, eBay has noticed the unusual activity on my account and shuts it down.\n\nAfter we solve that issue, Rex needs my PayPal information, and I remember a conversation with Mr. Chen about protecting personal information. Magic and Fin guarantee security with data encryption, but Rex is working on his home computer. He keeps reassuring me it\u2019s fine, but I decide to switch up the task. Instead, I ask him to research the amount of time I have to find new health insurance. He sends me snapshots of the Covered California website that I don\u2019t find very helpful, but we part on good terms.\n\nCost: $22\n\nBillable time spent: two hours\n\nUpwork\n\nAfter searching the online freelancer marketplace, I selected a Florida-based \u201cpersonal virtual assistant\u201d named Corin because of her 100 percent job success rating, and her low hourly rate ($20). In only a few hours, she accepts my invitation to do the job. With my budget running low, I decide to offer Corin as much as I think she could possibly do in one short hour: check on a medical insurance rule for me, call my bank about my car loan, list the items I still want to sell on eBay.\n\nBefore half the hour had passed, Corin has already sent me a Google doc answering my first two questions, and following up about my eBay products. By the end of the hour, she hasn\u2019t listed everything but tells me she\u2019ll finish the task for no extra charge. For the first time in the experiment, I actually do trust my virtual personal assistant to get things done without draining my wallet.\n\nCost: $20\n\nBillable time spent: one hour\n\nAs the experiment drew to a close, I realized that my initial mistakes had come from the fact that I wanted a personal assistant to do my work, but I didn\u2019t necessarily anticipate the work of managing a personal assistant. Would I use some of them again? Probably. But as Mr. Lessin said: \u201cWe always talk about what we\u2019re competing with, and what we\u2019re competing with is people doing tasks themselves.\u201d", "title": "Siri, Alexa and That Google Gal Will Get You Only So Far", "authors": ["Breena Kerr"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "DUBUQUE, Iowa \u2014 A former mayor of this town lives here on a bluff overlooking the Mississippi River, with about 180 other retired members of the Sisters of Charity of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Several other residents were college presidents, including one who was appointed by President Nixon to a White House task force on women\u2019s rights and responsibilities.\n\nNow these nuns, the B.V.M.s, as they like to be called, have a college basketball celebrity in their midst, too, if only in spirit and bobblehead form: Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt, the 98-year-old chaplain for the Loyola-Chicago men\u2019s team, an 11th seed that pulled off two upsets last week to advance to the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament.\n\nMany of the retired nuns living here at the order\u2019s headquarters planned to drop everything to watch Loyola play against seventh-seeded Nevada on Thursday night in Atlanta. In doing so, he made a number of false or misleading claims, including some The New York Times has previously checked.\n\n\u201cWe spent $7 trillion in the Middle East over a 17-year period, $7 trillion as of three months ago.\u201d\n\nFalse.\n\nMr. Trump has cited the $7 trillion figure several times before, and it appears to refer to an estimate of war spending that is regularly updated by the Watson Institute for International and Public Affairs at Brown University.\n\nThe $7 trillion figure closely resembles a Watson Institute estimate of future debt from war spending by 2053: $7.9 trillion. This would be in addition to increased veterans\u2019 care, terrorism-prevention spending and other \u201cmacroeconomic costs to the U.S. economy.\u201d", "title": "Six Claims Trump Made at His Weekend Rally That Were False or Lacked Context", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Hazm was soon overpowered by Jabhat al-Nusra, yielding its American-supplied weapons to the Qaeda affiliate \u2014 a process resembling what has played out repeatedly since 2001 in Afghanistan and Iraq, where many American partners have been bedeviled by desertion and battlefield defeat. A Hazm operative shares a scalding critique, telling Abouzeid that \u201cRussia is more honorable and trustworthy than the United States, because at least it is really standing alongside its ally.\u201d\n\nAbouzeid was briefly in New York this month. She sat down to discuss her reporting, and that word in her book\u2019s subtitle \u2014 \u201chope.\u201d\n\nYou covered Syria from the beginning, before protest seemed likely and when uprising seemed impossible. How did you select characters from the many people you met?\n\nI ended up with these characters because I felt that although they are individuals, each of their stories illuminated larger truths. I wanted to use characters and their experiences as vehicles, for example, to explain what happened to a Free Syrian Army battalion or the Islamization of the uprising. So I chose characters who would help a reader understand certain elements of the Syrian conflict.\n\n\u201cNo Turning Back\u201d illuminates experiences and points of view of female characters, including girls who came of age during war. Such voices are not prominent in news reports. Was it a mission to include them?\n\nI wanted to include as many voices as I could to present as full a picture as I could. I spent more time with the men, because it\u2019s the men who wage the wars. But the women are certainly there, and they\u2019re there in many different capacities. I focused on Ruha, who was 9 years old in 2011, to tell the story of her family of very strong women, because I wanted to make sure that even in stories of war, the voices of others, who are not necessarily waging it, are also heard.\n\nThe book mostly covers Sunnis, but there are sections that cover Alawites and sections that cover the government point of view. It was very hard in Syria to toggle between sides, but you managed, in spite of all of your time with Free Syrian Army and Islamist battalions, to be a guest of Air Force Intelligence in one of their main detention centers in Damascus \u2014", "title": "Sketching Cruelty and Finding Humanity Beside Syria\u2019s \u2018Waterfall of Blood\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "What is this bump on my leg? It\u2019s been here for six years, but I think it\u2019s growing bigger. I know the doctor said a few years ago it was some kind of fatty tumor and they are hardly ever malignant, but hardly ever is not never, and it\u2019s not like he has a certificate with \u201cBoard Certified, Fatty Tumors, Duke University\u201d on his wall. I wonder if these fatty tumors get so big they cut off the blood flow to the muscles in your leg. Then you\u2019d get gangrene.\n\n***\n\nWhy do I have this stupid landline on my bedside table when my cell is right next to it and nobody calls me on my landline anyway? Why do I even still have a landline? It\u2019s so uncool. Not as uncool as still using AOL, but pretty close. I should get rid of this landline. But if I did that and I lost my cell, how would people contact me? Sure, they could email me, but say New York City has a blackout. That\u2019s one good thing about landlines, you have power in a blackout. And if I give up my landline, I have to change my contact information with every company I\u2019ve ever done business with, which would take hours, maybe days.\n\n***\n\nI wish I could find something on Kindle as good as \u201cAsymmetry.\u201d It was like having an affair with Philip Roth without having to shave your legs.\n\n***\n\nI could always Google \u201cfatty tumor.\u201d No, bad idea.\n\n***\n\nMaybe some self-love. Let\u2019s flip through the greatest hits playbook and see if I can get inspired. Jim, when we were in our 20s, and spent that fantastic weekend in Newport? No, that\u2019s inappropriate, he just died. Ivan, that day in San Miguel when we didn\u2019t leave the hotel till 8 at night? What a sensual guy, he had skin like silk, maybe because he\u2019d put on so much weight. And that zipper scar on his chest from open-heart surgery. Every serious boyfriend I\u2019ve had, dating back to high school, has gained 70 pounds and had heart surgery. There\u2019s a bad pattern here. I have been choosing guys who would take terrible care of themselves since I was 16. I should just give up on men.", "title": "Sleepless in Manhattan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "What books on life in New York City would you recommend?\n\nAnything by Joseph Mitchell and Dawn Powell. \u201cGone to New York,\u201d by Ian Frazier, and \u201cThe Colossus of New York,\u201d by Colson Whitehead, are delightfully nostalgic. Also: Edith Wharton (\u201cThe House of Mirth\u201d over \u201cThe Age of Innocence\u201d); John O\u2019Hara\u2019s stories; \u201cGo Tell It on the Mountain,\u201d by James Baldwin; \u201cThe Flamethrowers,\u201d by Rachel Kushner; \u201cLast Exit to Brooklyn,\u201d by Hubert Selby Jr.; and \u201cJust Kids,\u201d by Patti Smith. For dessert, read Joan Didion\u2019s essay \u201cGoodbye to All That\u201d while eating a peach.\n\nWhat are your literary guilty pleasures? Do you have a favorite genre?\n\nI never feel guilty about reading something. I was at a motel for a writers\u2019 conference recently and, ironically, found myself with nothing to read. So I borrowed one of the \u201cTwilight\u201d books from a communal shelf. It\u2019s not the worst thing that ever happened once you accept the parameters and decide it won\u2019t mar your brain to read it. What made me put it down was the frequency of the word \u201cglance.\u201d Everyone is always glancing at everyone else. Once you notice it, you can\u2019t not notice it. It\u2019s like snoring but with verbs.\n\nWhich books might we be surprised to find on your bookshelves?\n\n\u201cGrowing Your Own Way: An Informal Guide for Teenagers,\u201d by Ruth Bockner, my maternal grandmother. This woman had no business giving advice to teenagers. In one section, she suggests pointing out the deformities of peers recovering from polio because this will prepare them for the real world. It\u2019s very funny if you read it as satire and not as a snapshot of my mother\u2019s childhood. Next to it (but on the opposite end of the lovability spectrum) is \u201cZero Dances,\u201d by Arthur Sainer. My paternal grandmother dated Zero Mostel for a long time and they remained close. Her chapters in this thing are priceless. She yells at him for smoking cigars and he carries her Kotex back from the store and everybody\u2019s always eating chicken soup to combat HUAC stress.\n\nWhat was the last book to make you laugh?\n\nI like dry humor with a stick of dynamite strapped to it. The forthcoming collection \u201cSome Trick,\u201d by Helen DeWitt, is probably the most recent example. The third story in that book, \u201cOn the Town,\u201d is her most accessible (and therefore not an ideal DeWitt calling card) but God, it\u2019s funny. \u201cThe Sellout,\u201d by Paul Beatty, and \u201cDear Committee Members,\u201d by Julie Schumacher, both made me burst out laughing. The latter is like a companion piece to \u201cStraight Man,\u201d by Richard Russo. \u201cOur Mutual Friend,\u201d by Charles Dickens, is always good for a laugh, as are \u201cDo the Windows Open?,\u201d by Julie Hecht; \u201cHome Land,\u201d by Sam Lipsyte; \u201cAt Freddie\u2019s,\u201d by Penelope Fitzgerald; and \u201cPnin,\u201d by Nabokov. I\u2019m a humorist, or at least I\u2019m shelved that way, so this question is too big for me. If you\u2019ve never read the actual play of \u201cPeter Pan,\u201d by J. M. Barrie, do that.\n\nThe last book that made you cry?\n\nOh, everything makes me cry. Nonfiction about refugees or mass shootings will do it. Any story line where an animal or a child dies. Genre-wise, short stories are the worst. Something about the emotional space they have to cover in a shorter amount of time, it\u2019s like there\u2019s no time for the anesthesia to kick in. If, for some reason, you felt compelled to make me recite the last lines of \u201cWhite Angel,\u201d by Michael Cunningham, or \u201cIn The Gloaming,\u201d by Alice Elliott Dark, I\u2019d cry on the spot. I plan on using this gift during my second career as an Oscar-winning actress.", "title": "Sloane Crosley: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKEY BISCAYNE, Fla. \u2014 Half an hour after Sloane Stephens won her hometown tournament, she lingered on the confetti-covered court, posing for photos and signing autographs as if reluctant to leave Key Biscayne.\n\nThe Miami Open is moving, and Stephens became the picturesque island\u2019s final women\u2019s champion on Saturday by beating Jelena Ostapenko, 7-6 (5), 6-1.\n\nStephens was born in South Florida, practiced on Key Biscayne as a junior and lives in nearby Fort Lauderdale. She was eager to win the tournament before its switch next year to the Miami Dolphins\u2019 stadium in Miami Gardens.\n\nFans jeered during the trophy ceremony when the tournament director, James Blake, mentioned the relocation.\n\nPhoto\n\nSeeded 13th, Stephens won with defense, repeatedly extending rallies until Ostapenko would make a mistake. And those words kept popping into her head Thursday, when she shook off a very slow start to beat Victoria Azarenka, 3-6, 6-2, 6-1, in the semifinals at the Miami Open.\n\nStephens\u2019s opponent in Saturday\u2019s final will be either sixth-seeded Jelena Ostapenko or the American qualifier Danielle Collins, who faced off later Thursday in the other semifinal.\n\n\u201cIn the first set, I was down but came back and I battled really well,\u201d said Stephens, who is looking to improve to 6-0 in finals. \u201cSo I knew if I did that in the second I\u2019d be right in there. Many of the demonstrators who have taken to the streets in the largest numbers since the Velvet Revolution of 1989 have demanded the fall of the government and a new round of elections.\n\nLeaders of the protests released a statement saying that leaders of the parties in the governing coalition had \u201chumiliated and misled the whole public with their decision.\u201d They plan to hold protests in more than 30 cities on Friday.", "title": "Slovak Prime Minister Quits in the Wake of a Reporter\u2019s Murder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "BRATISLAVA, Slovakia \u2014 After an investigative journalist and his fianc\u00e9e were gunned down last month, thousands of Slovakians took to the streets, week after week, demanding change and condemning the ruling party.\n\nThe protests, the largest in the country since the Velvet Revolution in 1989, forced Prime Minister Robert Fico, Interior Minister Robert Kalinak and several other officials to resign.\n\nBut when President Andrej Kiska named a new government on Thursday, many of those who had railed against the corruption of top officials feared that the new boss was not much different from the old boss.\n\nThe government refused to call new elections, as demonstrators had demanded, and the same three-party coalition that governed under Mr. Fico will remain in power. They\u2019re Not Much Different From the Old Bosses.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The infrastructure project would add 16 miles of rail track to link the Slovenian port of Koper with the transport hub of Divaca, near the border with Italy. It is intended to bolster Koper\u2019s ability to compete with other ports on the Adriatic Sea, such as Trieste in Italy and Rijeka in Croatia.\n\nVoters approved the project in a referendum in September, but the Supreme Court found that the government\u2019s fierce backing of the plan had breached campaign rules in ways that might have influenced the result of the election. It ordered a new referendum.\n\nMr. Cerar\u2019s resignation comes three months before scheduled elections, set for early June. \u201cIt\u2019s important to know what is right and what is wrong,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cI have made a decision any trustworthy politician should make in such a situation.\u201d\n\nIn line with the country\u2019s Constitution, he is expected to lead the government as a caretaker, until the voting, which could now take place a few weeks earlier than had been planned. But his resignation allows Modern Center Party to choose another standard-bearer for the campaign; the party has not indicated how it will proceed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPraising his government\u2019s achievements, Mr. Cerar said \u201cthe economic crisis ended\u201d during his term, and he cited the lowest unemployment figures since 2009. Slovenia\u2019s economy grew by 5 percent in 2017, one of the fastest rates in Europe, according to the European Union.\n\nHowever, Mr. Cerar has been under pressure as his approval rating has been dragged down by a crippling public sector strike and deadlocked negotiations with the unions representing teachers and doctors over austerity measures.\n\nTanja Staric, a veteran political reporter and news editor of Slovenia\u2019s public broadcasting network, said that Mr. Cerar and his party were already struggling for support.\n\n\u201cLife has become a bit easier since he took over, and the economy has recovered, but the continuous strikes by the public sector were a clear indicator that Cerar and his party are headed for a crushing defeat at the elections,\u201d Ms. Staric said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cerar\u2019s handling of a border dispute with Croatia was another source of criticism, Ms. Staric said, prompting censure from his coalition partners as well as from the right-wing nationalist opposition.\n\nSo far, populist and far-right parties have not gained much traction in Slovenia, as they have in neighboring Austria and Italy. In contrast to popular views in those two countries, approval of European Union membership remains high in Slovenia, which adopted the euro more than a decade ago, and has been able to tap E.U. funds for regional development.\n\nVoters could again opt for an outsider over a political veteran; the front-runner in opinion polls is the center-left party led by Marjan Sarec, a former actor who came close to unseating the incumbent president, Borut Pahor, last year.\n\nTrailing behind Mr. Sarec\u2019s party is the Slovenian Democratic Party, a right-wing nationalist group led by a former prime minister, Janez Jansa.
