If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\n\u2018The Least Surprising Story I Have Ever Heard\u2019\n\nStephen Colbert on Monday was eager to dig into Anderson Cooper\u2019s \u201c60 Minutes\u201d interview with Stephanie Clifford, the former pornographic film actress known as Stormy Daniels. Colbert was thrilled to hear Clifford\u2019s account of her alleged affair with President Trump \u2014 but even the juiciest details didn\u2019t shock him.\n\n\u201cThe interview covered everything: The president had sex with a porn star, she spanked him with a magazine with his face on it, he didn\u2019t wear a condom, later they watched \u2018Shark Week,\u2019 then his lawyer paid her to keep her mouth shut, and now Trump\u2019s suing this porn star for $20 million. It\u2019s an insane, salacious tale about a sitting president \u2014 and the least surprising story I have ever heard.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT \u201cIt all felt real, it all felt true. That felt truer than him getting elected.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nAt one point in the interview, Clifford described turning the tables on Trump. Early in their first romantic encounter, she said, she suggested the president should stop talking about himself as much, and spanked him with a magazine featuring his photograph. After that, she said, Trump opened up to her, and started acting \u201cmore appropriate.\u201d\n\n\u201cHmm, a couple of spanks and Donald Trump started acting more appropriate. John Kelly, you know what to do.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nTrevor Noah had his own thought about who might have been watching.\n\n\u201cYou know Bob Mueller is watching this interview, right? You know that. Now he\u2019s going to walk into the interrogation room with a rolled-up magazine, like, \u2018O.K., Donald, time to talk about Russia.\u2019\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nHere\u2019s Colbert on the moment when, according to Clifford, Trump told her that she reminded him of his daughter Ivanka.", "title": "Stephen Colbert on the Stormy Daniels Interview: \u2018It All Felt True\u2019", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "The N.B.A. playoffs start in three weeks. Whether Boston\u2019s Kyrie Irving and Golden State\u2019s Stephen Curry will be ready when the postseason starts seems doubtful.\n\nThe Celtics said that Irving would need three to six weeks to recover from a procedure performed on Saturday to relieve irritation on his left knee, that news coming almost simultaneously with word that Curry has a sprain of the medial collateral ligament in his left knee. The Warriors said Curry, who was hurt when his teammate JaVale McGee fell awkwardly into him during a victory on Friday night, would be evaluated again in three weeks.\n\nBased on those timetables, it would appear that both the Celtics and the Warriors will not only be without their All-Star point guards for the rest of the regular season, but very easily could still be without them for when their first-round playoff matchups begin on April 14 or 15.\n\nIn the short term, it would seem that being without Irving or Curry for the final games of the regular season will not have a pronounced effect on either club. Boston is fairly well locked into the No. 2 spot in the Eastern Conference playoffs, trailing East-leading Toronto by 4\u00bd games but leading Cleveland by six. Golden State, four games behind first-place Houston in the Western Conference and 10 ahead of third-place Portland, will almost certainly finish No. 2 in the West.", "title": "Stephen Curry and Kyrie Irving Are Sidelined by Knee Problems", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "It also meant that black holes had a temperature and had entropy. In thermodynamics, entropy is a measure of wasted heat. But it is also a measure of the amount of information \u2014 the number of bits \u2014 needed to describe what is in a black hole. Curiously, the number of bits is proportional to the black hole\u2019s surface area, not its volume, meaning that the amount of information you could stuff into a black hole is limited by its area, not, as one might think, its volume.\n\nThat result has become a litmus test for string theory and other pretenders to a theory of quantum gravity. It has also led to speculations that we live in a holographic universe, in which three-dimensional space is some kind of illusion.\n\nAndrew Strominger, a Harvard string theorist, said of the holographic theory, \u201cIf it\u2019s really true, it\u2019s a deep and beautiful property of our universe \u2014 but not an obvious one.\u201d\n\nTo \u2018Know the Mind of God\u2019\n\nThe discovery of black hole radiation also led to a 30-year controversy over the fate of things that had fallen into a black hole.\n\nDr. Hawking initially said that detailed information about whatever had fallen in would be lost forever because the particles coming out would be completely random, erasing whatever patterns had been present when they first fell in. Paraphrasing Einstein\u2019s complaint about the randomness inherent in quantum mechanics, Dr. Hawking said, \u201cGod not only plays dice with the universe, but sometimes throws them where they can\u2019t be seen.\u201d\n\nMany particle physicists protested that this violated a tenet of quantum physics, which says that knowledge is always preserved and can be retrieved. Leonard Susskind, a Stanford physicist who carried on the argument for decades, said, \u201cStephen correctly understood that if this was true, it would lead to the downfall of much of 20th-century physics.\u201d\n\nOn another occasion, he characterized Dr. Hawking to his face as \u201cone of the most obstinate people in the world; no, he is the most infuriating person in the universe.\u201d Dr. Hawking grinned.", "title": "Stephen Hawking Dies at 76; His Mind Roamed the Cosmos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen Hawking, the English cosmologist and black hole maven, liked to say he was born 300 years to the day after Galileo died, and he died on Wednesday, 139 years after Albert Einstein was born.\n\nThat was a fitting bookend.\n\nIn the popular press, he was often referred to as the greatest physicist since Einstein. That, he always said, was media hype, driven by the public\u2019s thirst for heroes.\n\nAs someone who might have contributed in some small way over the years to this impression, I have to say I agree. History will pass judgment on that dubious and problematic distinction.\n\nBut Dr. Hawking\u2019s life was Einsteinian and he was a hero, not just for what he taught about the universe, but for what he taught us about how to live.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhether or not he overturned the universe, he did overturn our imaginations. To the public, however, he was, in Homer Simpson\u2019s words, \u201cthe wheelchair guy,\u201d who despite being slowly paralyzed by Lou Gehrig\u2019s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, to the point where he could move only an eyeball, roamed the world and figuratively the universe, married twice, fathered three children, wrote best-sellers and nurtured generations of graduate students.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was the kind of guy who showed up at his own 60th birthday party with a broken leg after flipping his wheelchair trying to take a street corner too fast, a guy whose eyes lit up with a mischievous grin at good and bad jokes. He mingled with kings and presidents and the Dallas Cowboy cheerleaders. He had hoped someday to take a trip to the edge of space on Richard Branson\u2019s Virgin Galactic spaceship.", "title": "Stephen Hawking Taught Us a Lot About How to Live", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThey played poker together on Star Trek: The Next Generation.\n\nNow Stephen Hawking, the English cosmologist and black hole maven who died last week, and Sir Isaac Newton, the Englishman who founded modern physics, will rest together for eternity, or at least for its practical equivalent: the lifetime of the stones that make up Westminster Abbey in London.\n\nThe Abbey announced Wednesday that Dr. Hawking would be given the ultimate tribute. His ashes will be interred in the Abbey in a ceremony \u201cof thanksgiving\u201d to be held later this year.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe will be in good company. Sir Isaac Newton was buried in the Abbey in 1727. Charles Darwin was buried beside him in 1882. More recently, the physicists Ernest Rutherford in 1937 and Joseph John Thomson in 1940 have been interred there.\n\n\u201cWe believe it to be vital that science and religion work together to seek to answer the great questions of the mystery of life and of the universe,\u201d the dean of Westminster, the Very Rev. Dr. John Hall, said in a statement.\n\nPhoto\n\nArmed only with a wheelchair and a voice synthesizer in the face of lifelong paralysis from Lou Gehrig\u2019s disease, or Amytrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Dr. Hawking steered physics and our understanding of the universe into strange new territory and became an avatar of curiosity and determination. He discovered that black holes, the fearsome hungry pits of bottomless gravity, were not final death but would leak and radiate, eventually exploding, recycling matter and energy in ways that still challenge physicists\u2019 understanding.\n\nDr. Hawking often said that he wanted a formula describing what is called Hawking radiation \u2014 a fizz of particles and energy appearing to come from the surface of a black hole \u2014 engraved on his tombstone. One hopes that the Abbey will follow through.", "title": "Stephen Hawking to Be Interred at Westminster Abbey", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen could compose his sentences at a rate of only about six words a minute. At first I would sit impatiently, daydreaming on and off as I waited for him to finish his composition. But then one day I was looking over his shoulder at his computer screen, where the sentence he was constructing was visible, and I started thinking about his evolving reply. By the time he had completed it, I had had several minutes to ponder the ideas he was expressing.\n\nThis was a great help. It allowed me to more profoundly consider his remarks, and it enabled my own ideas, and my reactions to his, to percolate as they never could have in an ordinary conversation.\n\nWhen I argued a point of physics with Stephen, I always lost. I would scribble equations on a pad or a whiteboard, trying to sway him, but when I was done, I would find that the answer was the one he had already worked out in his head.\n\nHe was no less certain in his ideas about how to write our books, though when we disagreed on those matters, there was no right or wrong answer, only preference. And so we might argue at length \u2014 on one occasion we did so for two hours \u2014 over a single sentence.\n\nThere was an important difference between us here. Making my arguments took little effort. To oppose my ideas, Stephen had to struggle to type every letter of every word. Yet it was I, not he, who ceded points out of exhaustion. Once, during a particularly heated discussion, I waited several minutes for him to respond, and then, when his response finally came, it was a joke. Even when contemplating the cosmic, he had a keen sense of the comic.\n\nStephen\u2019s expertise was gravitation, the weakest of the four fundamental forces of the universe. Yet Stephen himself was a strong force. When, as a student, he started his work on black holes, most scientists thought it was a dead-end field. His doctors made a similar assessment regarding his prospects in life.\n\nProving people wrong turned out to be his strength \u2014 and his gift to all of us.", "title": "Opinion | Stephen Hawking, Force of Nature", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, Mr. Trump ventured to California, the blue bastion of liberal resistance, with a combative message on immigration.\n\nA by-election in Pennsylvania has become an unexpectedly narrow test of whether Democrats can make inroads with voters who supported Mr. Trump in 2016.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Mr. Tillerson\u2019s firing was announced only hours after he tied Russia to the March 4 poisoning of a former Russian spy in England with the deadly nerve agent Novichok.\n\nRussia\u2019s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, dismissed accusations that Moscow was to blame for the poisoning as \u201cnonsense.\u201d\n\nPoliticians and policy experts have suggested a number of punitive actions Prime Minister Theresa May could take against Russia. It remains unclear how willing she is to wield them.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Germany\u2019s economy could hardly be in better shape as Angela Merkel begins her fourth term as chancellor today.\n\nBut the political compromise with the Social Democrats that allowed her to remain in power risks bringing that boom to an end, our correspondent reports from Frankfurt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd some even forecast France to take over as the eurozone\u2019s driving force.\n\n(Above, the Social Democrats\u2019 headquarters in Berlin.)\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 China unveiled new superagencies to tackle three potential threats to the Communist Party\u2019s rule: financial recklessness, corruption and environmental pollution.\n\nOn a lighter note, the carefully scripted pageantry of an annual gathering of lawmakers in Beijing was punctured by a journalist\u2019s unscripted expression of disgust over a colleague\u2019s fawning.\n\nCensors struggled to contain an outpouring of satire.\n\nBusiness\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 More than half of the fresh fruit Americans buy is imported. A new study suggests that, instead, our ancestors thrived in its aftermath.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe reaction to our collaboration last week with The Times\u2019s crossword column, Wordplay, was overwhelmingly positive, so we\u2019re doing it again.\n\nEach week, Wordplay\u2019s editor, Deb Amlen, will highlight the answer to one of the most difficult clues from the previous week\u2019s puzzles.\n\nThis week\u2019s word: aubade.\n\nIt was the answer to a clue in last Friday\u2019s crossword: \u201cPoem greeting the dawn.\u201d (It might also be clued as \u201cmorning music,\u201d \u201cMorning song\u201d or \u201cSunrise song.\u201d)\n\nAn aubade (pronounced o-BAHD) can also be a musical composition about the morning. Its counterpart, a poem or song about the evening, is a nocturne.\n\nAccording to the Oxford English Dictionary, the word was first used in 1678 and was adopted by the French from the Spanish word \u201calba,\u201d meaning sunrise.\n\nBen Zimmer, the language columnist for The Wall Street Journal, noted that \u201cA skim of Google Books shows that aubade appeared chiefly in French sources, or French-English dictionaries, until the early 19th century.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn example of an aubade would be John Donne\u2019s \u201cThe Sun Rising,\u201d which, if nothing else, shows that the English poet was clearly not a morning person.\n\nWith that, we wish you a wonderful start to your day.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. He was 76.\n\n\u201cNot since Albert Einstein has a scientist so captured the public imagination and endeared himself to tens of millions of people around the world,\u201d said a physics professor at the City University of New York.\n\nIn 1963, Dr. Hawking learned that he had Lou Gehrig\u2019s disease and was given a few years to live, but he went on to become a world expert in gravity and the properties of black holes. Instead, a new study suggests, our ancestors thrived in its aftermath.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was an offer that the Times film critic Vincent Canby couldn\u2019t refuse.\n\n\u201cThe Godfather,\u201d which opened in New York on this day in 1972, was \u201cone of the most brutal and moving chronicles of American life ever designed within the limits of popular entertainment,\u201d he wrote in his review.\n\nThe adaptation of Mario Puzo\u2019s best-selling 1969 novel was directed by a young Francis Ford Coppola. He was selected after numerous other directors turned down the job, and in part for his Italian heritage.\n\nThe saga of the Corleones, an organized crime family in New York in the 1940s and \u201950s, \u201cThe Godfather\u201d became an almost instant classic. It was the top-earning film of 1972 and remains one of the highest-grossing (and most critically acclaimed) movies of all time.\n\nNominated for 10 Academy Awards in 1973, \u201cThe Godfather\u201d won three, including Best Picture and Best Actor for Marlon Brando, who played Vito Corleone, the family\u2019s aging patriarch. Brando famously declined to accept the award as a protest against Hollywood\u2019s portrayal of Native Americans.\n\n\u201cThe Godfather\u201d was \u201ca superb Hollywood movie,\u201d Canby wrote in 1972, \u201cscaring the delighted hell out of us while cautioning that crime doesn\u2019t (or, at least, shouldn\u2019t) pay.\u201d\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning. You can also receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nAnd our Australia bureau chief offers a weekly letter adding analysis and conversations with readers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at asiabriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Stephen Hawking, Theresa May, School Walkout: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Charles Mcdermid"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Stephen Hawking, the brilliant physicist who died at 76 in Cambridge, England, on Wednesday (Einstein\u2019s birthday), never won a Nobel Prize. But his book \u201cA Brief History of Time\u201d made him a star beyond his field, and his penchant for dropping bons mots on subjects large and small made him an enduring pop culture figure.\n\nHere is a selection of his quotes.\n\n\u201cI have lived with the prospect of an early death for the last 49 years. I\u2019m not afraid of death, but I\u2019m in no hurry to die. I have so much I want to do first.\u201d\n\nThe Possibility of an Afterlife\n\n\u201cI regard the brain as a computer which will stop working when its components fail. There is no heaven or afterlife for broken-down computers; that is a fairy story for people afraid of the dark.\u201d\n\nHis Mission in Life\n\n\u201cMy goal is simple. It is a complete understanding of the universe, why it is as it is and why it exists at all.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere is no god. I am an atheist.\u201d\n\nFame\n\n\u201cThe downside of my celebrity is that I cannot go anywhere in the world without being recognized. It is not enough for me to wear dark sunglasses and a wig. The wheelchair gives me away.\u201d", "title": "Stephen Hawking, in His Own Words", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "A brief history of Stephen Hawking\n\nStephen Hawking spent his scientific life exploring some of the deepest questions a human caught in the Einsteinian opera of space and time could ask.\n\nAlthough Einstein himself never really accepted it, his general theory of relativity predicted that if enough mass or energy were concentrated at one point, space would sag like mattress and eventually close itself off, creating a black hole from which nothing, not even light, could ever escape.\n\nIt would be Dr. Hawking\u2019s fate to explore these imagined monsters and ask what their presence portends for the universe, and for those of us who live inside it.\n\nThe universe had a beginning", "title": "Stephen Hawking\u2019s Beautiful Mind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "So here\u2019s the thought experiment: Throw a book into the black hole. The book carries information. Perhaps that information is about physics, perhaps that information is the plot of a romance novel \u2014 it could be any kind of information. But as far as anyone knows, the outgoing Hawking radiation is the same no matter what went into the black hole. The information is apparently lost \u2014 where did it go?\n\nThus we have the \u201cblack hole information loss puzzle,\u201d perhaps Dr. Hawking\u2019s most profound gift to physics. At issue is the fate of the principle of the conservation of information. Without general relativity, quantum mechanics predicts that information is conserved; likewise, without quantum mechanics, general relativity predicts that information is conserved, even if some of it is hidden inside a black hole. It is therefore bothersome that putting the two theories together seems to lead to information just disappearing.\n\nFor a long time Dr. Hawking argued, against the intuition of most other leading physicists, that information was simply erased from the universe, and we would have to learn to deal with it. But eventually he changed his mind (something he always was admirably willing to do), conceding in 2004 that information was probably somehow retained in the outgoing radiation. The matter, however, is very far from settled.\n\nDr. Hawking\u2019s information-loss thought experiment is the single biggest clue we have to how quantum gravity might operate. Even if we don\u2019t have the full theory yet, we know a lot about quantum mechanics and a lot about gravity. Together those are enough to convince us that Hawking radiation is real, even if it has never been directly observed. This means that any eventual theory of quantum gravity will have to explain either how information somehow escapes from black holes or how it is destroyed.\n\nBlack-hole radiation and the information-loss puzzle were certainly not Dr. Hawking\u2019s only contributions to modern physics. Back on the firmer ground of classical relativity, he proved a number of fundamental theorems about the behavior of black holes and the expansion of the universe. On the more speculative side, Dr. Hawking and the physicist James Hartle proposed a candidate for the \u201cwave function of the universe,\u201d the quantum state describing all of reality. In between, Dr. Hawking found time to make contributions to deep questions like the origin of structure in the universe and whether it is possible to build a time machine. (It\u2019s not, he argued.)\n\nHe did all of this, of course, in addition to reaching a broad popular audience and sharing with it his passion for physics and the mysteries of the universe. Dr. Hawking was an extraordinarily influential scientist, as well as a courageous and determined human being. He has left us a lot to think about.", "title": "Opinion | Stephen Hawking\u2019s Most Profound Gift to Physics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cStephen W. Hawking, 1942-2018: Seated, He Explored Universe and Awed World\u201d (front page, March 15): Stephen Hawking, the author of \u201cA Brief History of Time,\u201d had a remarkable gift for timing. He was born on the 300th anniversary of the death of Galileo. It was also a time when the Nazis were killing handicapped people. Yet during his lifetime, people with physical limitations were increasingly accepted and accommodated.\n\nAs his amyotrophic lateral sclerosis progressed, computer technology did, too, allowing him to continue to contribute to our understanding of the universe. The development of general relativity and quantum mechanics opened the door to the study of black holes.\n\nHis most renowned discovery, \u201cHawking radiation,\u201d resulted serendipitously from a dispute he lost with another young theoretical physicist, Jacob Bekenstein, over whether black holes had entropy.\n\nEven his entry into celebrity owed a nod to timing: The Nobel laureate Steven Weinberg\u2019s book \u201cThe First Three Minutes: A Modern View of the Origin of the Universe\u201d (1977) and Carl Sagan\u2019s book and PBS series \u201cCosmos\u201d (1980) set a precedent for theoretical physicists and astrophysicists writing about cosmology for a general audience. This paved the way for Dr. Hawking\u2019s 1988 book, which became an unexpected best-seller.", "title": "Opinion | Stephen Hawking\u2019s \u2018Gift for Timing\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Stephon Clark, the unarmed black man who was fatally shot last week by Sacramento police officers, was struck eight times, mostly in his back, according to an independent autopsy released Friday, raising significant questions about the police account that he was a threat to officers when he was hit.\n\nThe autopsy \u2014 commissioned by the family of Mr. Clark, 22, and conducted by Dr. Bennet Omalu, a private medical examiner \u2014 showed that he was shot three times in his lower back, twice near his right shoulder, once in his neck and once under an armpit. He was also shot in the leg. The neck wound was from the side, the doctor found, and he said that while the shot to the leg hit Mr. Clark in the front, it appeared to have been fired after he was already falling.\n\n\u201cHe was shot from the back,\u201d Dr. Omalu said Friday at a news conference. Standing next to diagrams of the findings, he said that seven of the shots could have had a \u201cfatal capacity.\u201d He described severe damage to Mr. Clark\u2019s body, including a shattered vertebrae, a collapsed lung and an arm broken into \u201ctiny bits.\u201d\n\n\u201cHe bled massively,\u201d said Dr. Omalu, who became nationally known for his fight with the National Football League over head injuries to its players.", "title": "Stephon Clark Was Shot 8 Times Primarily in His Back, Family-Ordered Autopsy Finds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJohn Sterling is in a quandary.\n\nSterling, the oft-imitated but truly inimitable radio voice of the Yankees, thinks he has come up with a great home run call for Giancarlo Stanton, and if Stanton hits as many home runs in his first year as a Yankee as he did in 2017 for the Miami Marlins, Sterling will repeat it, with his unique vocal inflections, some 59 times in 2018.\n\nBut there is trepidation because one of the great joys in Sterling\u2019s life is when fans approach him and repeat back to him one of his trademark calls \u2014 \u201cThat\u2019s when you know you\u2019ve got something\u201d \u2014 and he\u2019s not sure Stanton\u2019s will clear that bar.\n\n\u201cThis one is so different,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s an Italian phrase that rhymes. I don\u2019t know if anyone will get it. I\u2019m really worried. Well, not really worried. In fact, I\u2019m not worried. Let\u2019s say I\u2019m mildly concerned.\n\n\u201cBoy, I hope it works. It may not.\u201d\n\nStanton is not of Italian ancestry \u2014 he is of African-American, Irish and Puerto Rican descent \u2014 but the sound of his first name was enough to inspire Sterling to summon his amateur Italian to create what he believes will be a worthy addition to a catalog of personalized home run calls that already includes Thrillas by Godzilla (for Hideki Matsui) and A-Bombs for A-Rod (for you know who).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSterling is not showing his cards. He declined a chance to give it a trial run in an interview, and when Stanton hit a spring training home run a couple of weeks ago, Sterling proclaimed it \u201ca Stantonian blast!\u201d But that was just a placeholder; the real thing will not be unveiled until Stanton homers in a regular-season game.", "title": "Sterling Readies His Windup for the Yankees\u2019 Newest Star", "authors": ["Wallace Matthews"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "In Zurich, Mr. Bannon says, he had a \u201cfascinating\u201d meeting on Tuesday with leaders of Germany\u2019s far-right Alternative for Germany party.\n\nThey included Alice Weidel and Beatrix von Storch, who recently reacted to a New Year\u2019s Eve public service announcement by the German police that went out in various languages, including Arabic, by tweeting, \u201cAre they seeking to appease the barbaric, Muslim, rapist hordes of men?\u201d\n\nBut it is Italy, where populist forces smashed the country\u2019s establishment by combining to win more than half the vote on Sunday, that Mr. Bannon has turned into his de facto headquarters.\n\nIn a sprawling interview here, he declined to name whom he had met, other than to describe them as a broad array of politicians, operatives and investors.\n\n(A spokesman for Matteo Salvini, the leader of the anti-immigrant League, said the two would have liked to have met, but did not. A spokesman for the anti-establishment Five Star Movement, which won a third of Italian votes, did not return a request for comment.)\n\nAside from the occasional coffee at Campo de\u2019 Fiori or photo-op at Piazza Navona, Mr. Bannon has been holed up in hotel rooms, taking meeting after meeting.\n\nIn Rome, he stayed at the luxurious Raphael hotel, where Bettino Craxi, the face of Italy\u2019s corrupt establishment and mentor to Silvio Berlusconi, was pelted with coins in 1993 by an angry mob as he departed the political scene.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Milan, he sat in a room at the grand Principe di Savoia, opposite a copy of Titian\u2019s portrait of the Duke of Mantua, a master of intrigue in Renaissance Italy and a longtime sufferer of syphilis, surrounded by red damask wallpaper. Jams were on a room service cart, and a copy of a book titled \u201cHeadlines All My Life\u201d was on the desk.\n\nIn both cities, he wore a blue and white striped button down over a polo shirt. In Rome the polo was orange. In Milan it was blue.\n\nHe sipped sparkling water and described a grand vision for a global populist future.\n\nIn the United States, Mr. Bannon said, he is working on a project to create a think tank to \u201cweaponize\u201d populist economic and social ideas.\n\nHe sees that work spreading to Europe, where a proliferation of populist websites in the image of Breitbart News, either owned by him or others, will spread those ideas, under his guidance.\n\nAs a final component, he wants to train an army of populist foot soldiers in the language and tools of social media.\n\nMr. Bannon said that a common message he had received from populists throughout Europe was a desire to establish a media outlet for their views.\n\n\u201cThey see what Breitbart did and they want it in their own language,\u201d said Mr. Bannon, who slipped into the present tense when talking about the website from which he recently separated. \u201cThat\u2019s the key. Right now my sites are in English, they want one in their own language,\u201d he said, calling that \u201cphase two.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe could be forgiven the slip, as the site still seems to be in his thrall. (\u201cStephen K. Bannon took Zurich by storm Tuesday, addressing a sell-out crowd,\u201d began Breitbart\u2019s article on the speech.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Bannon, who said he was paying for the trip, said he was weighing whether to buy a name-brand outlet, like Newsweek or United Press International, or to start a new one, or to connect entrepreneurs with capital or invest himself.\n\nHe imagined a scoop-driven and high-metabolism outlet \u201clike Axios,\u201d he said, referring to the buzzy Washington newsletter, but with a populist bent that would devour Europe\u2019s sleepy legacy papers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhether I do it or a local entrepreneur does it,\u201d he said, \u201cthere are going to be these populist nationalist news sites that pop up in the next year on line. That will only take these things to the next level.\u201d\n\nWith Europe more aggressively tackling the migration issue, Mr. Bannon was aiming to move the future battle of populism to other terrains.\n\nHe said that the reason it was so important to get populist nationalist governments in place was to prepare for a coming great-powers clash with an axis of ancient Turkish, Persian and Chinese civilizations. \u201cElites can\u2019t fight that fight,\u201d he said. \u201cBecause people have to buy into it.\u201d\n\nHe is also increasingly interested in motivating people to fight media conglomerates like Facebook that monetize their data. And he has become fascinated with crypto currencies and how they can help populist movements, the subject of a speech he gave in Zurich this week.\n\nIn preparation for the speech, organized by Die Weltwoche, a conservative Swiss magazine, Mr. Bannon said he visited the town of Zug, known as Crypto Valley for its bustling cryptocurrency industry. He was impressed.\n\n\u201cIf Brussels and the European Central Bank is worried about Italy going to the lira, their concerns should be that all these communities and states are going to crypto,\u201d he said in Milan.\n\nIn the meantime, he said, he admires Italy\u2019s populist parties for already being on the technological cutting edge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Five Star Movement, a web-based party that preaches direct, online democracy, and the League, the hard-right, formerly northern-based secessionist party, both dominated social media during the campaign.\n\nOften, their critics say, they did it with spurious and inflammatory fake news about migrants and crime. Many of those messages seemed propelled by automated bots rather than real supporters.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t just have just all humans, I\u2019m sure they have some bots,\u201d Mr. Bannon said, unbothered. \u201cThe thing is that they are generating enthusiasm on shoestrings.\u201d\n\nHe said he hoped the two parties would eventually join forces \u2014 something not out of the question as the Italians try to form a government after an inconclusive election.\n\nBut he spoke also almost sympathetically about Matteo Renzi, the now vanquished Italian leader who only years ago seemed to be the future of Italy and the European center-left.\n\nMr. Renzi, he said, was \u201can object lesson to every rising politician in Europe,\u201d and not a good one.\n\nThe former prime minister, he said, had tried to play by Brussels\u2019s rules when it came to the migration crisis, and instead the European Union allowed other countries to close their borders, leaving Italy to take the brunt of the burden.\n\n\u201cThey hung him out to dry,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Bannon said Italian voters on Sunday also spurned Pope Francis, who has urged tolerance for migrants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis vote was a rejection of the pope,\u201d said Mr. Bannon, a Catholic who has nonetheless been a longtime critic of the pope\u2019s politics. \u201cThe pope likes to see himself as a radical and an anti-establishment revolutionary for the little guy; the little guy put the pope in his place on Sunday.\u201d\n\nHe said he had intended to return to Rome to visit his allies in the Vatican, including the American cardinal Raymond Burke, but then France\u2019s National Front extended its invitation.\n\n\u201cThey said, \u2018Hey would you stay for the weekend?\u2019 \u201d Mr. Bannon said. \u201c \u2018All our people would love to hear you speak.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Steve Bannon Is Done Wrecking the American Establishment. Now He Wants to Destroy Europe\u2019s.", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "GANGNEUNG, South Korea \u2014 A goaltending coach for nearly 20 years, Jason Wolfe has tutored neophytes and European professionals, college stars and minor leaguers, netminders as young as 4 and as old as 74. But until last fall he had yet to encounter a pupil like Steve Cash, nor had he been charged with a mission quite so weighty: how to make the best sled hockey goalie in the world even better.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a little bit of a tricky position,\u201d Wolfe said. \u201cI\u2019m there to try to coach and help, and you\u2019re talking about a guy who\u2019s done things no one else has. I\u2019ve never worked with a goalie who\u2019s pitched four or five straight shutouts at a world-class level.\u201d\n\nIn leading the United States to gold at the last two Paralympics, Cash held opponents scoreless for a record 313 minutes 17 seconds. No one, in the Olympics or Paralympics, had recorded five consecutive shutouts until Cash sparkled in Vancouver in 2010, saving all 33 shots he faced in the tournament. Four years later in Sochi, after the Russians scored twice against him in pool play, the only goals he has allowed at the Paralympics, Cash exacted revenge by shutting them out in the gold medal game.\n\nThose performances across the last decade offered convincing evidence that Cash, 28, did not need a dedicated coach to dominate the sport. He had not received such individualized instruction, he said, since 2006, when at age 16 he served as the American team\u2019s backup at the Turin Paralympics.", "title": "Steve Cash Was Already the World\u2019s Best Sled Hockey Goalie. Then He Got a Coach.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSteve Wynn, the former chief executive of Wynn Resorts, has agreed to sell all of his remaining eight million shares in the firm, in a swift exit of the casino and hotel company he founded more than 16 years ago.\n\nSeparately, the Macau casino operator Galaxy Entertainment agreed to buy 5.3 million shares of Wynn Resorts at $175 a share, giving it a stake of around 5 percent in the operator, which has resorts in Las Vegas and Macau.\n\nGalaxy is one of six licensed operators in the world\u2019s largest gambling hub of Macau, and competes with Wynn, Sands China, MGM China and Melco Resorts.\n\nMr. Wynn\u2019s share sale comes a week after Wynn Resorts said he and his former wife, Elaine Wynn, who has a 9.26 percent stake, had scrapped a shareholder agreement that prevented them from selling their stakes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Wynn resigned last month as chief executive of the company, based in Las Vegas, following claims that he had subjected women who worked for him to unwanted sexual advances. It has always appeared farther south, beyond the bounds of normal aurora sightings.\n\nAmateur aurora watchers have taken hundreds of photographs of this adjacent phenomenon, often drawing out its fluorescent colors with long exposures or photo editing. They called it Steve, as a sort of place-holder until a more formal name could be found.", "title": "Steve, a Famous Northern Light, Stays Mysterious (and Keeps His Name)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Much of the book is taken up with evidence-based philosophizing, with charts showing a worldwide increase in life expectancy, a decline in life-shattering diseases, ever better education and access to information, greater recognition of female equality and L.G.B.T. rights, and so on \u2014 even down to data showing that Americans today are 37 times less likely to be killed by lightning than in 1900, thanks to better weather forecasting, electrical engineering and safety awareness. Improvements in health have bettered the human condition enormously, and Pinker tells us that his favorite sentence in the whole English language comes from Wikipedia: \u201cSmallpox was an infectious disease caused by either of two virus variants, Variola major and Variola minor.\u201d The word \u201cwas\u201d is what he likes.\n\nImage Credit Alessandra Montalto/The New York Times\n\nHe later adds that he could have ended every chapter by saying, \u201cBut all this progress is threatened if Donald Trump gets his way.\u201d Trumpism risks knocking the world backward in almost every department of life, especially by trying to undo the international structures that have made progress possible: peace and trade agreements, health care, climate change accords and the general understanding that nuclear weapons should never be used. All this is now in question. Pinker is particularly sharp on the dangers of ignoring or overriding the systems that make nuclear war unlikely.\n\nHaving said this, he argues that catastrophism is itself a risk \u2014 that is, the pessimistic tendency to fix on the worst imaginable outcome, and to panic. Authoritarian populism itself has fed on the feeling that everything is going wrong: that crime and terrorism have run amok, that immigration is disastrous and that the world has lost its ethical direction in some terrible way. Meanwhile, fear and despair play havoc with the opposition too. In general, people are more likely to work constructively if they think problems are solvable, or that progress has already been made and can be extended. As Pinker says, considering the fact that we have not yet blown the world up in a nuclear war, our best approach is \u201cto figure out what has gone right, so we can do more of whatever it is.\u201d Optimism does not mean lying back and relaxing. He cites the economist Paul Romer, who distinguishes the \u201ccomplacent optimism\u201d of a child waiting for presents with the \u201cconditional optimism\u201d of a child who wants a treehouse, and gets hold of the wood and nails to make one. Someone who thinks a treehouse is impossible, or assumes someone will instantly come and knock it down, is unlikely ever to start hammering.\n\nThis book will attract some hammering itself: It contains something to upset almost everyone. When not attacking the populist right, Pinker lays into leftist intellectuals. He is especially scathing about newspaper editorialists who, in 2016, fell over themselves in their haste to proclaim the death of Enlightenment values and the advent of \u201cpost-truth.\u201d His (rather too broadly painted) targets include humanities professors, postmodernists, the politically correct and anyone who has something nice to say about Friedrich Nietzsche. \u201cProgressive\u201d thinkers seem to consider progress a bad thing, he claims; they reject as crass or na\u00efve \u201cthe notion that we should apply our collective reason to enhance flourishing and reduce suffering.\u201d\n\nIn fact, there may already be signs of a change in mood, with chirps of optimism being heard from varied directions. The musician David Byrne has just launched a web project entitled \u201cReasons to Be Cheerful,\u201d celebrating positive initiatives in the realms of culture, science, transportation, civic engagement and so on. Quartz, a business journalism site, ended 2017 with a list of 99 cheerful links to the year\u2019s good news: snow leopards being taken off the endangered species list; a province in Pakistan planting a billion trees over the last two years as a response to the 2015 floods; a dramatic fall in sufferers from the hideous Guinea worm (from 3.5 million in 1986 to just 30 in 2017); and a slow but steady increase in women holding parliamentary seats worldwide, from 12 percent in 1997 to 23 percent now.", "title": "Steven Pinker Continues to See the Glass Half Full", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThis week, we take the Oscar-nominated film \u201cThree Billboards Outside of Ebbing, Missouri\u201d as a starting point for a discussion about a new sense of placelessness in film and on TV. Over the last year, we\u2019ve been seeing stories set in ambiguous spaces \u2014 the limbo between heaven and hell, distorted models of our world, towns that look like no place we recognize as American. We talk about \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d \u201cWestworld,\u201d \u201cDownsizing\u201d and the Sunken Place from \u201cGet Out\u201d to try to figure out how we lost a sense of where we are. Then we look to shows like \u201cAtlanta\u201d and \u201cThe Chi\u201d to think about how we might find our way back.\n\nHow do I listen? Audio\n\nFrom a desktop or laptop, you can listen by pressing play on the button above.\n\nOr if you\u2019re on a mobile device, the instructions below will help you find and subscribe to the series.\n\nOn your iPhone or iPad:\n\n1. You may want to adjust your notifications to be alerted when a new episode arrives.", "title": "Still Processing: We Want To Know What Love Is", "authors": ["Wesley Morris", "Jenna Wortham", "Still Processing"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Grimly dystopian yet bursting with cinematic brio, Alfonso Cuar\u00f3n\u2019s \u201cChildren of Men\u201d (2006) is a film that, set in 2027, feels like the present day \u2014 only more so. It could almost have taken the title of Anthony Trollope\u2019s 1875 novel, \u201cThe Way We Live Now.\u201d\n\nThe movie \u2014 showing Friday and Saturday at midnight at the IFC Center in a good 35-millimeter print \u2014 opens in a dank, despoiled Britain ruled in the name of Homeland Security. Murderous gangs plague the countryside. Refugees are kept in cages. A bomb explodes on a busy London street even before the movie announces its title. \u201cThe world has collapsed,\u201d the TV reports, but \u201cBritain soldiers on.\u201d\n\nThis collapsed future world, as imagined in P.D. James\u2019s 1992 speculative fiction, is also a world that has no future. Human fertility has vanished. The species is dying even faster than the earth. It\u2019s been 18 years since the last baby was born. Indeed, the movie opens with mass mourning for the world\u2019s youngest person, who has been killed.\n\nThe protagonist, Theo, played by Clive Owen, is a low-level bureaucrat and depressed former activist drawn back into the struggle after agreeing to help a resistance group led by his ex-partner, played by Julianne Moore. (Chiwetel Ejiofor is another member.) Theo\u2019s mission is to get transit documents for a young woman (Clare-Hope Ashitey) who, miraculously pregnant, needs to be smuggled out of the country.", "title": "Still Stoking Terror: The Hopeless World of \u2018Children of Men\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "After a year in which a 1-percent move, up or down, in the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 stock index was a rarity, 2018 has featured stomach-churning market swings on a regular basis. Monday was a good example. Stocks plunged initially on news that Gary Cohn, President Trump\u2019s top economic adviser, had resigned, only to recover those losses by the end of the day.\n\n\u201cWe are seeing extreme volatility here \u2014 it is the Goldman Sachs business model,\u201d said Adam Sender, the founder of Sender Company & Partners, a hedge fund the specializes in making quick bets in up-and-down markets. \u201cThings are moving around like crazy \u2014 the opportunities are tremendous.\u201d\n\nMr. Sender was so frustrated by the long period of markets grinding higher, absent any sharp moves, that he simply stopped trading last November and took a three-week tour of Sweden, Iceland and Japan.\n\n\u201cIt made me sick looking at my screen all day,\u201d he said. \u201cI felt I was wasting time.\u201d\n\nNo longer. On a day last week when stocks plunged, Mr. Sender was in and out of the market all day \u2014 buying a stock here, betting it would fall there.\n\nOf course, a choppy, fun-to-trade market could easily turn ugly if the economy suddenly slows or a trade war erupts with China, to name just two risks. And these days of roiled markets might not last, or the volatility could grow so severe that traders seeking to profit from the turbulence are instead capsized by it.\n\nAfter the stock market plunged in early February, Charlie McElligott, a derivatives strategist at Nomura, said that his clients were eager to put on trades that would capitalize on increased volatility.\n\nBut by last week, when markets plunged again, many of those same investors had had enough. They sold their shares in a panic, trying to cut their losses. \u201cIt is the second sell-off that scares you \u2014 there has been a change in psyche,\u201d Mr. McElligott said. \u201cPeople were burned when they bought the dip.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInvestors who make bets on stocks, currencies and bonds based on where they think the overall economy is headed argue that the recent market spasms are healthy, if nerve-rattling, for the financial system.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat is because a stock market that goes up for 15 consecutive months, as the S. & P. 500 did before its streak was broken in February, lulls investors into a false sense of security. When that happens, investors largely remove the prospect of losing money on an investment from their calculations.\n\nTraders say that much of the selling in recent weeks has come from funds that gambled that markets would remain calm. When they instead became volatile, the funds \u2014 many of them programmed to automatically buy or sell based on computer-driven strategies \u2014 started selling en masse. The clearest manifestation of the heightened volatility is an index known as the VIX, whose levels have doubled in recent months.\n\n\u201cThe machines had taken control \u2014 now they are selling everything,\u201d said Philippe Jabre, founder and chief investment officer of Jabre Capital in Geneva, which manages $1.5 billion in assets.\n\nMr. Jabre made his name as a hedge fund investor in the 1990s, a time when markets were turbulent and unpredictable. He pointed out that higher volatility does not necessarily mean lower markets; they are just more challenging to navigate. That was why he got into the business in the first place. \u201cWe have made our name in these up-and-down cycles,\u201d he said. \u201cThings are more interesting today because we are more nimble and we can find great picks.\u201d\n\nOver the past several years, there has been a vast migration of investor money \u2014 more than $1 trillion, analysts estimate \u2014 from funds run by stock pickers to those, such as exchange-traded funds, or E.T.F.s, that are designed to track major market indexes.\n\nSuddenly, funds that have human beings in charge of investment decisions are looking more attractive to anxious investors.\n\n\u201cLast year, people were saying, \u2018Why am I paying all this money to a hedge fund? I can just buy an E.T.F.,\u2019\u201d said Said Haidar of Haidar Capital, a hedge fund in New York with $440 million under management. \u201cBut with all this volatility, you might want someone who can trade around these markets.\u201d\n\nIn other words, investors are now looking for hedge funds \u2014 investment vehicles that engage in a wide range of trading, including making bets that markets will fall \u2014 to actually live up to their names and offer protection, or hedges, against falling stock markets. That could mean, for example, buying stocks that didn\u2019t benefit from the bull market and thus are less likely to fall as sharply as the broader index.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is the strategy being followed by Thomas H. Forester, chief investment officer for Forester Capital Management in Chicago.\n\nHis fund used to manage $250 million. It\u2019s now down to $40 million. When markets seem to go up forever, the very idea of protecting your downside, thus missing out on returns, seems foolish to many \u2014 and that was what Mr. Forester was doing.\n\nIn the past month, though, Mr. Forester\u2019s phone has started ringing. Wary investors want to give him their money, and he is finally seeing stocks that might be cheap enough to buy.\n\n\u201cWe are no longer watching reruns,\u201d Mr. Forester said, referring to the stock market\u2019s regular rise each year. \u201cYour stomach starts churning, it\u2019s more dicey \u2014 but it is a lot more fun.\u201d", "title": "Stock Markets Are Scary. Suddenly, It\u2019s a Good Time to be a Trader.", "authors": ["Landon Thomas Jr."]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "It wasn\u2019t too hot. It wasn\u2019t too cold.\n\nInvestors welcomed Friday\u2019s unemployment and jobs data from the government, which showed a near-perfect combination of surprisingly strong job growth and little indication of rising wages that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates faster.\n\nThe Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index all closed more than 1.7 percent higher, driven by gains across a range of sectors.", "title": "Stock Markets Jump in Response to Jobs Report", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump\u2019s vow to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum next week rattled financial markets Thursday.\n\nStocks, which had already been down for the day, slipped further after the White House announced the planned tariffs. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index fell 1.2 percent to 2,682 Thursday afternoon, after falling roughly 2 percent earlier in the day.\n\nShares of automakers such as Ford and General Motors, large consumers of steel and aluminum, fell sharply, as the tariffs would raise the cost of raw materials.\n\n\u201cHistorically, the automakers have to absorb these costs,\u201d said Colin Langan, an analyst at UBS who covers automakers. \u201cConsumers don\u2019t adjust their price expectations based on higher steel prices.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShares of industrial companies also dropped, led by exporters such as Boeing and United Technologies.", "title": "Stocks Drop as Trump\u2019s Tariffs Rattle Markets", "authors": ["Matt Phillips"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "A framed eighth-grade diploma, dated June 19, 1913, hangs on the wall opposite my computer. It belonged to my grandmother, Minnie Rothenhoefer, one of eight children in a German immigrant family, who was forced to quit school at age 14 after her alcoholic father abandoned his family. Her first job was picking onions and her greatest regret \u2014 she lived to age 99 \u2014 was that she never attended high school. \u201cBut there\u2019s no excuse for ignorance when you can go right down to the public library,\u201d she often said.\n\nGran has been in my thoughts even more than usual this year, because I know that she would have scoffed at one of the unanticipated consequences of the Trump presidency. I am referring to the endless self-flagellation among well-educated liberals \u2014 \u201cthe elites,\u201d in pejorative parlance \u2014 about their failure to \u201cget\u201d the concerns of white working-class voters. Gran never expected anyone to \u201cget\u201d her. She was determined to educate herself for what she considered the privilege of citizenship.\n\nOur current political discourse is corrupted by two equally flawed narratives about the relationship between social class and politics. The first is a fable accepted by many intellectuals, who have found themselves guilty because just enough white working-class voters in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin handed Mr. Trump his Electoral College win in 2016. Many fear that this year\u2019s midterm elections will once again result in a rejection of \u201celitism\u201d by the same voters.\n\nIn a second, equally flawed narrative \u2014 adopted by a segment of both blue-collar workers and intellectuals \u2014 the American working class is so victimized that almost none of its members are capable of accepting the responsibility of civic self-education.", "title": "Opinion | Stop Apologizing for Being Elite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "MONTCLAIR, N.J. \u2014 The first time I drive with my daughter, she makes a left turn without putting on her blinker. She says: \u201cWant to know a funny thing about me? I never signal.\u201d\n\nI say: \u201cThat\u2019s not a funny thing. You have to signal.\u201d\n\nMy daughter shrugs \u2014 an adolescent Morse code meaning: Whatever/You don\u2019t get it /Julia\u2019s mom lets her do it. She\u2019s relaxed as we tool around town, picking up a carton of milk here, a sibling there.\n\nFrom then on, for the rest of the summer, she drives us everywhere. According to suburban legend, teenagers are supposed to spill their secrets when you\u2019re in the car together. This doesn\u2019t happen with mine \u2014 it\u2019s just a lot of questions about what we\u2019re having for dinner. But one day, cruising down a quiet street, my daughter says, \u201cI love driving.\u201d\n\nThis is better than a secret. I can still feel my first license in my hand \u2014 the heat of it, the freedom. I can\u2019t wait for her to feel that, too.", "title": "Opinion | Stop Asking About My Kid\u2019s College Plans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "The survivors of the Parkland shooting have led a national call to action, and the nation has responded. Students have walked out of their schools in protest, businesses have cut ties with the N.R.A., and our collective frustration culminated in the March for Our Lives this weekend.\n\nSenator Charles Schumer has proposed three measures to reduce gun violence: expanded background checks, protective orders to disarm individuals at risk of violence or self-harm, and an assault weapons ban. These proposals are critically important. But there is another effective response that has been largely ignored: repeal of a law that prevents suits against the gun industry.\n\nA bedrock principle of the American legal system is accountability for wrongdoing. Businesses that cause harm may be held legally responsible in a court of law. Through the imposition of financial liability, our legal system encourages businesses to reduce harm to consumers by making their products safer and disclosing the risks associated with their use.\n\nThanks in part to the accountability imposed by lawsuits, society knows more about the dangers of smoking, and tobacco companies market their products more responsibly. Automakers continually develop and install new safety features, and these innovations deliver results: From 1975 to 2016, the rate of motor vehicle deaths decreased by nearly half. While motor vehicle deaths have declined over the last two decades, firearm deaths have not: According to the most recent statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more people now die from firearms than motor vehicle accidents.", "title": "Opinion | Stop Shielding Gun Makers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Bret Stephens: Gail, last week\u2019s big items of news were, first, Gary Cohn\u2019s departure as President Trump\u2019s top economic adviser; second, the steel and aluminum tariffs that reportedly prompted his departure; and third, Trump\u2019s decision to meet face-to-face with North Korea\u2019s Kim Jong-un to try to resolve the nuclear standoff.\n\nOrdinarily, liberals would be thrilled to see the architect of last year\u2019s tax bill leave the White House, even while the president chooses diplomacy over belligerence with Pyongyang. And they probably might not entirely mind the tariffs, either. Yet I\u2019m going to guess that you\u2019re not jumping for joy. Am I wrong?\n\nGail Collins: The North Korean thing is good news followed by the realization that this is never going to work out well. Sort of like your realtor calling to say there\u2019s finally a buyer for your house, and then the second part is that it\u2019s a commune of 1,000 people, each of whom has personally pledged to raise $500 begging on street corners.\n\nBret: Agree, though in this case I\u2019d say it\u2019s like someone has agreed to buy your house, and you\u2019d better sell it because the buyer will kill your realtor if you don\u2019t, so you\u2019d better shave 50 percent off your asking price. Trump in 2006 and had been offered money to keep it quiet, took up more than half the episode.
