It proceeded despite an arbitrator\u2019s ruling reaffirming an agreement that she reached with Mr. Trump in October 2016 to remain silent about their alleged relationship in exchange for $130,000.\n\nShe has said she had a consensual relationship with Mr. Trump that started in 2006 and lasted several months.\n\nIn recent weeks, Ms. Clifford\u2019s lawyer, Michael Avenatti, has led a publicity blitz, appearing frequently on cable news shows, since she filed a lawsuit on March 6 seeking to break her 2016 agreement. She asserts that the nondisclosure agreement was void because Mr. Trump did not personally sign it.\n\nThat lawsuit came after Michael D. Cohen, the president\u2019s longtime personal lawyer who said he paid her $130,000 legally pressured her to stay silent. Days before Ms. Clifford sued, Mr. Cohen secretly obtained a temporary restraining through an arbitrator in California to prevent her from speaking about her alleged affair.\n\nMr. Avenatti wrote in a letter to Mr. Cohen on Monday that Ms. Clifford would be willing to pay back the $130,000 to end the deal to stay quiet. The offer had a deadline of noon Tuesday for Mr. Cohen to answer, which came and went.\n\nHer interview with Mr. Cooper raised the prospect that Mr. Cohen might seek an injunction to stop CBS News from showing it. Over the weekend, CBS said it had not received any legal threats.", "title": "Stormy Daniels Interview to Air on \u201860 Minutes\u2019 This Month", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA lawsuit opens the door, and judges almost always allow for a plaintiff to have a fishing expedition,\u201d said Robert S. Bennett, the Washington lawyer who represented Mr. Clinton in the Paula Jones case. The questions could include, \u201cHave you paid other people money?\u201d he said.\n\nDavid A. Super, a law professor at Georgetown University, said the lawsuit Ms. Clifford filed on Tuesday centered on a limited contract law matter, but he noted that it also specifically stated that Ms. Clifford would amend her complaint in the future to add the names of people who she said participated in wrongdoing with Mr. Trump and Mr. Cohen.\n\nHe suggested that Ms. Clifford and her lawyer might be starting with a narrow argument aimed at getting the contract declared invalid, perhaps intending to broaden it later to include claims that Mr. Trump and Mr. Cohen coerced her into silence. \u201cIf that happened,\u201d he said, \u201cthey certainly could seek to depose Trump.\u201d\n\nAnd in that case, he said, \u201cI can certainly imagine how it might get broader. And if it did, the wide array of Trump\u2019s sexual interactions could be addressed, just as the wide array of Clinton\u2019s sexual interactions was addressed in the Paula Jones case deposition.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nGetting into a public court setting, however, is a big hurdle.\n\n\u201cIf the parties agreed to binding arbitration, they have waived their right to file a lawsuit,\u201d said H. Christopher Bartolomucci, a law partner at Kirkland & Ellis in Washington who previously worked in the White House as associate counsel to President George W. Bush. Ms. Clifford\u2019s signature on the contract, and acceptance of the money, could count as a clear sign of agreement.\n\nBut other legal experts were struck by the sweeping nature of the nondisclosure agreement Ms. Clifford signed, and expressed skepticism that it would hold up in court. Beyond the circumstances of the alleged sexual relationship, the agreement barred her from doing anything, even indirectly, to \u201cpublicly disparage\u201d Mr. Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt actually presents a relatively clean issue for the court,\u201d said Lawrence M. Noble, a former top lawyer at the Federal Election Commission who is now the general counsel for the Campaign Legal Center, a watchdog group. \u201cWhat she signed amounts to a gag order, and she has rights if this agreement is not found to be valid.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Avenatti is building his case on what he calls \u201csloppy\u201d lawyering by Mr. Cohen, dating to October 2016 when Mr. Cohen negotiated the agreement for Ms. Clifford\u2019s silence. Ms. Clifford has claimed that she met Mr. Trump at a celebrity golf tournament in 2006 and began a relationship that included sex and promises from Mr. Trump to get her on his NBC show \u201cThe Apprentice\u201d and to give her a condominium. A close friend of hers, Keith Munyan, confirmed several of those details in an interview this week, saying he heard Mr. Trump offer her the apartment when Ms. Clifford invited him to eavesdrop on the conversation. Mr. Trump has denied the affair.\n\nMr. Avenatti\u2019s argument hinges on a blank signature line by the alias used for Mr. Trump, David Dennison, on the contract. Ms. Clifford, identified as \u201cPeggy Peterson,\u201d and Mr. Cohen, representing the shell company he used to facilitate the payment, both signed the document. Mr. Avenatti argues that because Mr. Trump did not sign it himself, the agreement is invalid \u2014 a point Mr. Super, the Georgetown professor, basically agreed with and Mr. Noble said might have merit.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe initial contract is not confined to the commitments Ms. Clifford makes to Mr. Trump \u2014 to never speak of their affair and to relinquish any material she might have relating to him, like emails, photos and video. It also includes commitments Mr. Trump makes to her, such as a promise not to take any legal action against her for her claims.\n\nSo, Mr. Avenatti argues, Mr. Cohen is improperly acting as a stand-in for Mr. Trump as he seeks to enforce the deal, including the provision he cited in bringing the temporary restraining order.\n\nThe extent to which Mr. Cohen was acting on his own in striking the agreement with Ms. Clifford and paying her is crucial not only to Ms. Clifford\u2019s case but also to the complaint against the Trump campaign and the Trump Organization filed with the Federal Election Commission. That complaint, brought by Common Cause, alleges that Ms. Clifford was bought off because she posed a threat to Mr. Trump\u2019s presidential prospects, and argues that the $130,000 payment was effectively a contribution to Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign that should have been reported to the commission. Common Cause has also filed a complaint with the Justice Department demanding an investigation.\n\nImportant factors in the case would include just how closely Mr. Cohen coordinated the payment to Ms. Clifford with Mr. Trump and whether it was intended to help the campaign avoid negative publicity.\n\nMr. Cohen has said that he \u201cfacilitated\u201d the payment with his own money and was not reimbursed by Mr. Trump\u2019s company or campaign, and that the payment was \u201cnot a campaign contribution or a campaign expenditure by anyone.\u201d But in her suit, Ms. Clifford tries to implicate Mr. Trump in the transaction, saying the offer of money was intended to buy her silence to help \u201censure he won the presidential election.\u201d\n\nPaul S. Ryan, the vice president for litigation and policy at Common Cause, said that assertion makes clear that the payment was connected to the campaign. \u201cThat\u2019s a threshold legal issue, establishing that the purpose of the payment was to influence the election,\u201d he said.\n\nJan Baran, a former general counsel to the Republican National Committee, said the facts so far do not support the notion that the payment to Ms. Clifford was \u201cindisputably directly for the campaign itself.\u201d It could have simply been a personal matter, he said, of Mr. Trump wishing to keep a secret from his wife.", "title": "Stormy Daniels Lawsuit Opens Door to Further Trouble for Trump", "authors": ["Jim Rutenberg", "Mike Mcintire"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "The pornographic film actress who says she had an affair with President Trump offered on Monday to return $130,000 she received from Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer in 2016 for agreeing not to discuss the alleged relationship.\n\nIn exchange, the actress, Stephanie Clifford, seeks an end to her deal to keep quiet about what she says was an affair with Mr. Trump that started in 2006 and lasted for several months.\n\nIn the letter, which was sent to Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, early Monday, Ms. Clifford\u2019s lawyer, Michael Avenatti, wrote that Ms. Clifford would wire the money into an account of Mr. Trump\u2019s choosing by Friday.", "title": "Stormy Daniels Offers to Return Payment to End Deal for Her Silence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Daniels\u2019s most shocking disclosure was her account of being threatened, apparently on Trump\u2019s behalf, in 2011, a few weeks after agreeing to tell her story to a gossip magazine for $15,000. She said she was in a parking lot with her infant daughter when a man approached and said: \u201cLeave Trump alone. Forget the story.\u201d Then, she said, he looked at the baby and warned, \u201cA beautiful little girl \u2014 it would be a shame if something happened to her mom.\u201d\n\nThere was another, less direct threat earlier this year, Daniels said, after The Wall Street Journal reported that Cohen had arranged a $130,000 hush money payment to her before the 2016 election. Both her former attorney and her former business manager, she told \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d pressured her to sign statements denying the tryst and the payoff, saying of the Trump camp, \u201cThey can make your life hell in many different ways.\u201d\n\nIn a statement from his lawyer on Monday, Cohen denied threatening Daniels, and said he didn\u2019t believe the parking lot encounter ever happened. But Michael Avenatti, the aggressive, mediagenic lawyer who took on Daniels\u2019s case this year, is convinced the attempted intimidation originated with the Trump camp, and he told me he \u201cabsolutely\u201d has evidence about the threat that has not yet become public.\n\nAvenatti has been strategically \u2014 if maddeningly \u2014 coy about just what he\u2019s holding back. Last Thursday, he tweeted, \u201cIf \u2018a picture is worth a thousand words,\u2019 how many words is this worth?,\u201d accompanied by a photo of a CD or DVD. Whatever was on that disc, we didn\u2019t see it on Sunday. \u201cIn no way would we play our entire hand on \u201860 Minutes,\u2019\u201d he told me.\n\nOf course, he could be bluffing. But if he\u2019s not, this case could provide a crucial window into Trump\u2019s thuggish way of doing business.", "title": "Opinion | Stormy Daniels Spanks Trump Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Donald J. Trump never signed the nondisclosure agreement lawyers had presented in 2016 to a pornographic-film actress, rendering it null and void, according to a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by a lawyer for the actress.\n\nThe filing, in Los Angeles Superior Court, represents the latest development in a legal battle involving Mr. Trump, his longtime personal lawyer and the actress, Stephanie Clifford, whose stage name is Stormy Daniels.\n\nThe lawsuit came days after Michael D. Cohen, Mr. Trump\u2019s personal lawyer, had legally pressured Ms. Clifford, initiating arbitration proceedings against her in Los Angeles in efforts to prevent her from speaking out about an affair she said she had with Mr. Trump, according to the complaint.\n\nThe suit, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, alleges that Mr. Trump \u201cpurposely did not sign the agreement so he could later, if need be, publicly disavow any knowledge of the Hush Agreement and Ms. Clifford.\u201d", "title": "Stormy Daniels Sues, Saying Trump Never Signed \u2018Hush Agreement\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Clifford\u2019s interview \u2014 which made for the most anticipated episode of \u201c60 Minutes\u201d in recent memory \u2014 was something of a national event, one marked by viewing parties and \u201cDark and Stormy\u201d cocktail specials at bars, a nod to her professional name, Stormy Daniels.\n\nAnd it was a quintessential moment of the Trump presidency \u2014 a tabloid-ready scandal and must-see television \u2014 that carried potential legal implications for Mr. Trump and his longtime lawyer and personal fixer, Michael Cohen. Until Sunday\u2019s broadcast, Ms. Clifford had kept her public appearances to the strip club circuit \u2014 what she called her \u201cMake America Horny Again\u201d tour. But, in speaking with Mr. Cooper, she chose businesslike attire that was in keeping with the seriousness of the legal case she is making, that she had been silenced in a cover-up effort to protect the presidential prospects of Mr. Trump.\n\nMs. Clifford is one of two women who have recently filed suit seeking to get out of agreements they said they entered during the last stretch of the 2016 campaign to give up the rights to their stories about what they have said were affairs with Mr. Trump. The other woman, a former Playmate named Karen McDougal, sold her rights to the company that owns The National Enquirer \u2014 which never published it \u2014 and spoke to Mr. Cooper on CNN on Thursday. Representatives for Mr. Trump have denied that he had an affair with either woman.\n\nBoth cases present potentially consequential legal challenges for Mr. Trump, forming the basis of complaints that have been filed with the Federal Election Commission and the Justice Department saying that the payments constituted illegal campaign contributions.\n\nMs. Clifford\u2019s appearance on \u201c60 Minutes\u201d showed that the effort to keep her story from public view had failed spectacularly \u2014 just as statements from Mr. Cohen that he would seek millions of dollars in damages from her for violating a hush agreement had not kept her from appearing on what is often the highest-rated program in television news.\n\nShortly after \u201c60 Minutes\u201d aired, a lawyer for Mr. Cohen, Brent H. Blakely, sent a cease-and-desist letter to Ms. Clifford\u2019s new lawyer, Michael Avenatti. It accused him and Ms. Clifford of defaming Mr. Cohen in relation to the threat she says she received and demanding a public apology.\n\n\u201cMr. Cohen had absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with any such person or incident, and does not even believe that any such person exists, or that such incident ever occurred,\u201d Mr. Blakely wrote. \u201cYou and your client\u2019s false statements about Mr. Cohen accuse him of criminal conduct and constitute, among other things, libel per se and intentional infliction of emotional distress.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDuring the interview Mr. Cooper asked Ms. Clifford why she was taking the legally risky route of sitting for a nationally televised interview. \u201cI was perfectly fine saying nothing at all, but I\u2019m not O.K. with being made out to be a liar,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Clifford had first threatened to speak out in February, after, she said, Mr. Cohen broke his part of the previously secret 2016 agreement by telling The New York Times that he had paid the $130,000 from his own pocket. He has denied Mr. Trump had an affair with Ms. Clifford.\n\nVideo\n\nThe White House was quiet ahead of the airing of Ms. Clifford\u2019s interview, though an ally of Mr. Trump\u2019s, the Newsmax founder and editor in chief, Christopher Ruddy, told ABC News earlier on Sunday that Mr. Trump considered her story \u201ca political hoax.\u201d Mr. Trump spent the evening before the interview dining at his club in Palm Beach, Mar-a-Lago, with Mr. Cohen.\n\nMs. Clifford said during the interview that while she had seen Mr. Trump more than once, she had had sex with him a single time, unprotected. That happened shortly after they met at a celebrity golf tournament in Lake Tahoe in 2006. (Ms. McDougal has also said that she, too, was intimate with Mr. Trump during that event.) Mr. Trump was 60 at the time; Ms. Clifford was 27.\n\nMs. Clifford said that Mr. Trump had invited her to his hotel suite for dinner, and that their banter began with him showing her a magazine cover featuring his photograph. \u201cI was like, \u2018Someone should take that magazine and spank you with it,\u201d\u2019 she said. \u201cSo he turned around and pulled his pants down a little \u2014 you know, had underwear on and stuff, and I just gave him a couple swats.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was done in a joking manner, she said, and the flirtation \u2014 which included Mr. Trump comparing Ms. Clifford to his daughter \u2014 led to intercourse, though, she said, she had not been particularly attracted to Mr. Trump and had not wanted to have sex with him. (She said she nonetheless went along of her own accord.)\n\n\u201cHe said that it was great,\u201d she said, and told her he had had \u201ca great evening, and it was nothing like he expected, that I really surprised him, that a lot of people must underestimate me \u2014 that he hoped that I would be willing to see him again, and that we would discuss the things we had talked about earlier in the evening.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump, she said, had raised the possibility that he get her onto his reality show, \u201cCelebrity Apprentice,\u201d but it would not come to be.\n\nShe said that he had invited her to his Beverly Hills Hotel bungalow in 2007 to fill her in on that promise. The entertainment for the night, she said, was a \u201cShark Week\u201d documentary. Mr. Trump, she said, wanted to have sex but this time she did not go along with it, and when he did not have an answer for her about being on the show, she left. She said he told her over the phone a month later that he would not be able to get her onto the program and that was effectively the end of it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut when her story threatened to surface again in 2016, Ms. Clifford said, her lawyer, Keith Davidson, called her. \u201cI think I have the best deal for you,\u201d she said Mr. Davidson told her, presenting Mr. Cohen\u2019s offer. (Mr. Davidson had also represented Ms. McDougal.)\n\nWhen Mr. Cooper said some viewers would be skeptical that Ms. Clifford had made her decision because of a threat made years earlier, she said she \u201cdidn\u2019t even negotiate\u201d and \u201cjust quickly said \u2018yes,\u2019 to this very, you know, strict contract, and what most people will agree with me, extremely low number.\u201d Ms. Clifford also said that she had \u201cturned down a large payday multiple times.\u201d\n\nMs. Clifford said that she can remember the man\u2019s face to this day and would recognize him immediately. Mr. Avenatti said earlier this month that she had been threatened, although he did not provide any details. At the time, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said, \u201cObviously we take the safety and security of any person seriously, certainly would condemn anyone threatening any individual.\u201d\n\nWhen the story about the payoff first broke earlier this year, Ms. Clifford had signed a statement emphatically denying that an affair had taken place. She told Mr. Cooper that she had been told that if she failed to sign it, \u201cthey can make your life hell in many different ways.\u201d That sentiment, she indicated, was based on the terms of the agreement, not on any new threat of physical violence, though, she said, she felt both \u201cintimidated\u201d and \u201cbullied.\u201d\n\nLawyers for Mr. Cohen have said that Ms. Clifford faces $20 million in penalties for violating an agreement to remain quiet and that the agreement was still binding.\n\nMs. Clifford\u2019s suit hinges on Mr. Avenatti\u2019s argument that the agreement is invalid because Mr. Trump had not signed it. Mr. Cohen signed the agreement, representing the Delaware shell company Essential Consultants, through which he paid Ms. Clifford.\n\nMr. Cohen has denied any involvement by the Trump Organization or the Trump campaign. But Mr. Avenatti, through his various media appearances, has been trying to build a case that Mr. Cohen was acting in his capacity as a lawyer at the Trump Organization when he worked on the agreement. He presented new evidence on \u201c60 Minutes\u201d: a FedEx envelope showing that Mr. Davidson had sent the contract to Mr. Cohen at his office at the Trump Organization, and addressed a cover letter to him in his official Trump Organization capacity.\n\nMr. Cooper pressed Ms. Clifford on whether she was not coming forward to cash in on her affair now that Mr. Trump had become president. She did not apologize for the extra money she says she is already making as a dancer because of the surrounding publicity, but noted that she was also opening herself up to real financial risk.\n\nAsked what she would tell the president if he was watching, she said, \u201cHe knows I\u2019m telling the truth.\u201d", "title": "Stormy Daniels Tells \u201860 Minutes\u2019 That Fear of Trump Kept Her Silent", "authors": ["Jim Rutenberg"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "But not everyone was upset. A former French left-wing parliamentary candidate was arrested for celebrating the officer\u2019s death on Twitter and saying it meant one less voter for President Emmanuel Macron.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 President Trump returned from his Florida resort to a White House he left in turmoil last week. In an Op-Ed, a writer questions \u2014 and laments \u2014 the blurring of peoples\u2019 personal and online lives.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nLast week, the Library of Congress in Washington announced its annual additions to the National Recording Registry, which honors significant pieces of American history and culture. (Here\u2019s the list.)\n\nWe\u2019d like to look at one: the original 1930 recording of \u201cLamento Borincano,\u201d by Canario y Su Grupo.\n\nKnown as an unofficial anthem of Puerto Rico, \u201cLamento Borincano\u201d was composed by Rafael Hern\u00e1ndez, one of the island\u2019s most renowned and prolific songwriters (although he wrote it while living in New York City).\n\nThe song\u2019s title refers to Borinquen, a derivation of Puerto Rico\u2019s indigenous name.\n\nThe song reflects the plight of Puerto Rican farmers during the Great Depression. They faced not only the threat of hurricanes but also the economic changes brought after 1917, when Puerto Ricans were granted U.S. citizenship, leading to a wave of immigration north.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lyrics tell of a farmer who is \u201cloco de contento\u201d (crazy with happiness) at the prospect of selling his produce in town. But he arrives to find the town empty. With no one to buy anything, he returns to his farm demoralized. The song ends:\n\n\u201cBorinquen, the land of Eden\n\nThe one that when singing, the great Gautier\n\nHe called the pearl of the seas.\n\nNow that you die\n\nWith your regrets\n\nLet me sing to you too.\u201d\n\nChris Stanford contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nCheck out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. Stephanie Clifford needed no reintroduction. \u201cEverybody already knew,\u201d she said of her career in an interview. She worked the room of suits and gowns with a smile.\n\nBy now, the public knows both too much about Ms. Clifford, who goes by Stormy Daniels, and almost nothing at all.\n\nShe is the actress in pornographic films who is suing a sitting president, with whom she said she had a consensual affair, in order to be released from a nondisclosure agreement she reached with his lawyer just before the 2016 election. Over the past two months, she has guided the story of her alleged relationship with President Trump \u2014 and the $130,000 she was paid to keep silent \u2014 into a full-fledged scandal. If Ms. Clifford\u2019s court case proceeds, Mr. Trump may have to testify in depositions, and her suit could provide evidence of campaign spending violations. She is scheduled to appear on \u201c60 Minutes\u201d on Sunday.", "title": "Stormy Daniels, Porn Star Suing Trump, Is Known for Her Ambition: \u2018She\u2019s the Boss\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "1. President Trump ordered the expulsion of 60 Russian diplomats from the U.S., and European nations quickly followed suit. Together, the moves constituted a broad swipe at Russia\u2019s diplomatic capabilities, and possibly its ability to conduct spying operations.\n\nThe president\u2019s decision was the latest action in a long history of espionage feuds between Washington and Moscow.", "title": "Stormy Daniels, Russia, Cricket Scandal: Your Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Could this loneliness, this outsiderness, be a permanent fixture of my identity now? When Andrew made the radical decision to join the Army just before we married, I hadn\u2019t guessed I\u2019d one day be considering this question. I hadn\u2019t anticipated an Army life at all when we fell in love, and yet, when he made the impassioned argument for joining, I wasn\u2019t exactly surprised. My husband is not an easily categorizable man: He\u2019d be equally at home at a gun range and a poetry reading. He found a way to fit in at Fort Benning because he is skilled at negotiating different worlds. He gets lonely too, but he has the architecture of the Army to hold him up, and I\u2019m the home he always returns to.\n\nArmy wives, on the other hand, are left to erect their own scaffoldings. Andrew is in a rapidly deployable combat unit with backbreaking daily hours. As the saying goes among wives in his unit: \u201cEven when they\u2019re here, they\u2019re not really here.\u201d It is the kind of life that one later apologizes to a spouse for: \u201cI\u2019ll make it up to you,\u201d I watched a soldier say to his wife at his retirement ceremony, his voice breaking.\n\nThose wives are the toughest people I\u2019ve ever known. Before we moved, I\u2019d snobbishly envisioned my stint at Fort Benning as a kind of anthropological study, a view into another world.\n\nBut from almost the moment we arrived, I sensed just how much I\u2019d need these women, so I made every effort to inch my way into their lives. In the beginning, I couldn\u2019t even navigate a conversation with most of them. We had nothing in common; we were separated by the chasms of life experience, education, politics, cultural vocabulary.\n\nStill, we forged relationships in the iron of showing up. We flew to emergency rooms, school pickups, maternity wards, kitchen counters. During my high-risk pregnancy with Fiona, Andrew was deployed; I spent so many nights at a friend\u2019s house in those months that my Maps app registered her address as \u201cHome.\u201d\n\nMy life with the other wives was like life with family: intense, necessary for survival, claustrophobic and never enough. By the time we left Georgia I was hungry for freedom from the Army, so I made sure we lived a freeway ride away from base, in a city full of progressive Seattle transplants. But now, surveying this circle of hip Tacoma strangers, I feel unmoored.\n\nThe librarian announces the start of \u201cfree play,\u201d which means parents can mingle. The guy in the \u201cKindness Is Everything\u201d shirt approaches. He tells us he is a massage therapist who owns a Pilates studio.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cMy wife and I split the child care,\u201d he says.\n\n\u201cMy husband watches the baby on weekends while I Skype with clients,\u201d the R.I.E. mom offers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m alone with Fiona for weeks until my eyes bleed, I want to say, but I don\u2019t think it will play very well in this crowd.\n\nThe Georgia moms would have related in an instant. Even though I was a mystery to them, arriving childless at 28, they brought me into their fray. I became the de facto babysitter, the honorary aunt at Mother\u2019s Day lunches.\n\nThey taught me everything I know about parenthood: You get through the days by force of will, by relying not on family or husbands but on friends \u2014 and often, brutally, on just yourself. You welcome people\u2019s help with open arms, but recoil from anyone\u2019s pity. And on the overwhelming days, you let your kids cry, walk into the summer heat of the backyard, and chug a beer.\n\nYou also snuggle them past dawn and nurse them through every sickness and let them sleep in your bed when they cry. You need those kids as much as they need you. They are your anchors. Without them, you might drown or drift away.\n\nAfter free play, my blind date and I walk home, our babies cuddled in carriers. In the past week, spring has come to coastal Washington, the winter rains finally gone. Snowy white blossoms shower the ground and bursts of rhododendron fill front yards. Fiona and I spend our afternoons wandering these cracked sidewalks, peeking in the windows of old Tacoma craftsmen.\n\nThe mom asks if I\u2019d like to come to Easter brunch at her house.\n\n\u201cThere will be gluten free options,\u201d she adds nervously.\n\nI hesitate.\n\n\u201cThere will be some really good people,\u201d she says.\n\nIn Georgia, I went to barbecues with \u201creally good people,\u201d young parents who had climbed out of hard backgrounds and carved out lives for themselves and their children. At first, I\u2019d dreaded these barbecues, until, one day, I stopped dreading them. The wives and I never came to understand each other, really, but we allowed life to happen to us together, appearing on each other\u2019s doorsteps with children in pajamas after blowout fights with husbands, after pipes bursting and miscarriages and late night phone calls alerting us of casualties overseas.\n\nMaybe that is all there is to know or understand in any human exchange: the asking to be let in. The vulnerable welcoming of another across our thresholds.\n\nIt occurs to me that here, now, is an opening. So I might as well walk in.\n\n\u201cWhat should I bring?\u201d I ask, and she smiles.", "title": "Story Hour, Off the Army Base", "authors": ["Simone Gorrindo"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 How you watch \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d and CNN is about to have its day in court.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s bid to block AT&T\u2019s $85 billion merger with Time Warner is set to head to trial next week, in one of the most anticipated antitrust battles in years.\n\nThe deal, if approved, would create a media giant that combines AT&T\u2019s nationwide mobile and satellite distribution networks with Time Warner\u2019s huge collection of popular movies and television offerings, including \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d on HBO, news on CNN and college and professional basketball on TNT. The central question of the trial: Would that combination hurt consumers or help them?\n\nHow the judge rules in the case has the potential to shape the fast-changing business of video, as consumers increasing turn to streaming services instead of traditional cable TV. AT&T, a nationwide satellite TV and wireless provider, argues that pairing up with a major content company is necessary to compete against the reach and resources of tech giants like Netflix and Amazon. But the Justice Department says the deal would hurt upstart streaming services and lead to higher prices for consumers.\n\nThe decision will frame the competition among Silicon Valley, Hollywood and Madison Avenue, while also establishing what kinds of corporate mergers \u2014 in the media industry and beyond \u2014 will be permitted in the years to come.", "title": "Streaming Soon: A Fight Over AT&T, Time Warner, and the Future of TV", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe are obviously keeping a listening attitude, but also a very big determination to pursue the transformation,\u201d said Benjamin Griveaux, a government spokesman, after a cabinet meeting on Wednesday.\n\nOne poll this week painted a conflicted picture of public opinion, with most people supporting the demonstrations but also favoring the government\u2019s reform projects. Another found that nearly three of every four people in France believed that the Macron government\u2019s policy overhauls were unjust, but that almost half saw the overhaul of the railway system as warranted.\n\nPhoto\n\nOfficial estimates on Thursday said the strikes affected 40 percent of intercity trains and 30 percent of flights.\n\nThe protests on Thursday were initially scheduled by civil servants angered by salary freezes and by Mr. Macron\u2019s pledge to cut 120,000 jobs, as well as by government plans to introduce merit-based pay and use more private contractors. However, after elements of the proposed railway overhaul became clear, the unions decided to join.\n\nWhile the largest protests were in Paris, there were also large turnouts in Marseille, Nantes, Lyon and other cities.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Paris, public workers converged with railway workers at the Place de la Bastille, the traditional gathering site for political protests. There were minor skirmishes mostly involving masked protesters, who often represent anarchist groups and who on Thursday threw projectiles at the police.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe rail workers\u2019 mood seemed at once boisterous and bleak. They played loud music, sang protest songs and set off so many smoke bombs that it was hard to see at times. Still, several said they had little hope that the government would pay attention, and many said Mr. Macron did not care about them.\n\n\u201cThis is a message for Monsieur Macron: Keep the public services,\u201d said Christian Boumard, 57, who came to the protest from Nantes, a union stronghold on the Atlantic coast.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe railroads are a public service. When you attack the rail workers, you are attacking a public service,\u201d said Mr. Boumard, who has worked for the rail company, known as the SNCF, for 37 years.\n\n\u201cThe rich do not give to the poor, but public services give something back to them,\u201d Mr. Boumard said. \u201cThis is a political battle: It is not to gain some small benefit, it is public services he is attacking.\u201d\n\nLaurence Michel, 48, joined the SNCF in 2008 through a program she said could well disappear with the government overhaul. When her husband, a rail worker, died, the company hired her as part of a support policy for its families.\n\n\u201cOur job isn\u2019t attractive to young people anymore,\u201d said Ms. Michel, from Rennes. \u201cWe have night shifts and work during weekends. We keep hearing that we are privileged, but I\u2019d like Mr. Macron to come and see if he finds privileges in our everyday job.\u201d\n\n\u201cPass the reform, and the SNCF will slowly die,\u201d she said.", "title": "Strikes Disrupt France as Thousands Protest Macron Overhauls", "authors": ["Alissa J. Rubin", "Elian Peltier"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "A campaign to unseat eight state Democratic senators \u2014 members of a renegade group that has helped empower Republicans to rule the Senate in Albany \u2014 will receive a significant boost from the city comptroller, Scott M. Stringer.\n\nMr. Stringer on Thursday will endorse two Democratic challengers trying to topple members of the group, the Independent Democratic Conference, in the September primary.\n\n\u201cWhen you run for office as a Democrat and caucus with the Republicans, you are not acting like a Democrat.\u201d Mr. Stringer, a Democrat, said in an interview. \u201cThis has gone on for too long. I want to break the dam.\u201d\n\nThe cooperation of the eight-member body has helped allow Senate Republicans to control the chamber even though they are outnumbered by Democrats.", "title": "Stringer to Back 2 Candidates Challenging Breakaway Democrats in Albany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "And while Mr. Saccone carried the most Trump-supporting counties along the West Virginia border, Mr. Lamb made just enough inroads in those rural areas to give the voters in suburban Allegheny County the chance to deliver the Democrat the slimmest of leads.\n\nRarely shy about weighing in on other news of the day, Mr. Trump made no mention of the race on Wednesday on Twitter or at any public appearance. But during a closed-door fund-raiser outside St. Louis late in the day for Josh Hawley, a Republican running for Senate, Mr. Trump argued that he had helped Mr. Saccone come back from a seven-point deficit to a virtual tie. Moreover, Mr. Trump asserted that Mr. Lamb\u2019s strong showing was really a validation of the popularity of the president\u2019s own policies.\n\n\u201cThe young man last night that ran, he said, \u2018Oh, I\u2019m like Trump. Second Amendment, everything. I love the tax cuts, everything.\u2019 He ran on that basis,\u201d Mr. Trump said, according to The Atlantic, which obtained an audio recording of the event. \u201cHe ran on a campaign that said very nice things about me. I said, \u2018Is he a Republican? He sounds like a Republican to me.\u2019\u201d\n\nWhile he searched for the best possible interpretation, the stinging message could hardly have been more pointed for a Republican president mired in low approval ratings, burdened by investigations and facing the growing likelihood that Democrats may seize power in the House this year.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Lamb, 33, defied political geography and appeared on the verge of capturing the state\u2019s 18th District despite a torrent of Republican money and Mr. Trump\u2019s personal intervention. At a rally Saturday, Mr. Trump mocked Mr. Lamb as \u201cLamb the Sham,\u201d promised that Mr. Saccone would \u201cvote for us all the time,\u201d and rambled about his own achievements as he sought to transfer his own political success to the Republican candidate.\n\nIn the end, none of it seemed to be enough. Democratic enthusiasm appeared to overwhelm a part of the state that has long been a Republican stronghold. For the president, the vote is an ominous echo of Democratic victories in Virginia and Alabama, where his political efforts were shrugged off or counterproductive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe tally was also a blunt rejection of the president\u2019s political calculation that tax cuts and steel tariffs would persuade voters in a region once dominated by the steel industry to embrace the Trump agenda on behalf of Mr. Saccone. \u201cSteel is back,\u201d he repeatedly said at the rally, apparently to little effect.\n\nA Republican victory in Pennsylvania might have helped deflect attention from the continuing collapse of the president\u2019s inner circle, which Tuesday included Mr. Trump\u2019s abrupt firing of Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and the forced resignation of John McEntee, one of Mr. Trump\u2019s closest personal aides, who is under investigation for financial crimes and was marched out of the White House.\n\nInstead, Mr. Saccone\u2019s lackluster performance was a grim bookend for a day in which the president\u2019s trip to the Mexico-California border to view wall prototypes was completely overshadowed by the churning turnovers in his national security team.\n\nMr. Trump and Republican Party leaders had desperately sought to head off an outcome that was once thought of as politically impossible. Conservative groups spent more than $10 million in the hopes of defeating Mr. Lamb, who received similar help from Democratic politicians like former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.\n\nA barrage of Republican advertisements condemned Mr. Lamb as a \u201cRubber Stamp for Nancy Pelosi,\u201d the Democratic leader in the House. One flier sent to voters showed Mr. Lamb firing an assault weapon, an attempt to weaken the Democrat\u2019s support among liberal voters. A deceptive video purported to show Mr. Lamb in a fight with labor unions.\n\nBut in recent weeks, polls in Pennsylvania consistently showed Mr. Saccone\u2019s popularity slipping, and Mr. Lamb gaining traction. Visits by Vice President Mike Pence and other White House officials did little to buck up the party\u2019s candidate.\n\nBy the time Mr. Trump arrived in Moon Township, Pa., for the rally, the race had tightened significantly, and many White House and Republican Party officials were already worried that he was lending his support to a lost cause.\n\nAs it turned out, they may have been right. During the rally, Mr. Trump called Mr. Saccone \u201can extraordinary person\u201d and dismissed Mr. Lamb as someone who should not be trusted by voters in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\u201cThe people of Pittsburgh cannot be conned by this guy Lamb because he\u2019s not going to vote for us,\u201d Mr. Trump said. Only after the election did the president pivot to argue that, in fact, Mr. Lamb was something of a quasi supporter.", "title": "Strong Performance by Democrat Conor Lamb in Pennsylvania Shakes Trump and G.O.P.", "authors": ["Peter Baker", "Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "The White House, engaged in a trade dispute with China, has announced exemptions to steel and aluminum tariffs for several allies, including the European Union, and is marginalizing the World Trade Organization. Below is a selection of notable reactions to the protectionist moves.\n\n\u201cIf attacked, we will respond without weakness. Everyone needs to understand this, and I think I can say that the American strategy is a bad strategy. ... We talk about everything, in principle, with a friendly country that respects the rules of the W.T.O. We talk about nothing, in principle, when it is with a gun to our head.\u201d\n\nEmmanuel Macron, France\u2019s president.\n\n\u201cMaybe it\u2019s a way to exert strong pressure on the European Union, to start some sort of a negotiation with a revolver to our head. That\u2019s a strange way of negotiating with an ally.\u201d\n\nCharles Michel, Belgium\u2019s prime minister, explaining why he still had \u201cdoubts\u201d after the European Union was among several American allies granted an exemption to steel and aluminum tariffs.\n\n\u201cChina does not want to fight a trade war but is absolutely not afraid of a trade war. We are confident and capable of meeting any challenge and hope that the United States will pause on the brink of a precipice, make careful decisions, and avoid dragging bilateral trade relations to a dangerous place.\u201d\n\nA Chinese Commerce Ministry representative.\n\n\u201cThis European Council will send a strong message on where the European Union stands in relation to trade: No protectionism.\u201d\n\nFederica Mogherini, the European Union\u2019s foreign policy chief.\n\n\u201cOf course the president has announced a temporary exemption for the European Union. We were discussing this morning the need that we want to ensure that does become a permanent exemption for the European Union and I stayed on to be part of that discussion because the steel industry is important to the United Kingdom and I want to ensure that the U.K. steel industry and its workers are safeguarded.\u201d\n\nTheresa May, Britain\u2019s prime minister.\n\n\u201cThe long-term costs of weakening the W.T.O. cancel out the short-term advantages of temporarily preventing a trade war between the E.U. and the U.S.A. ... The E.U. should not let itself be drawn into this game.\u201d\n\nGabriel Felbermayr, director of the Ifo Center for International Economics in Munich.\n\n\u201cThe global trade conflict is still threatening to escalate. And U.S. President Donald Trump will demand a price from the E.U. for exemption from punitive tariffs.\u201d\n\nThilo Brodtmann, executive director of the German Engineering Federation, an industry group.", "title": "Strong Reactions to U.S. Trade Moves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The protest and sit-in in the university\u2019s administration building began Thursday morning and quickly grew. At one point a large group of protesters belted out the Rihanna song \u201cBitch Better Have My Money.\u201d\n\nMaya McCollum, a 18-year-old freshman who helped organize the sit-in, said on Friday that the news of the misappropriated financial aid money was \u201cthe straw that broke the camel\u2019s back.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, Dr. Frederick issued a statement addressing HU Resist\u2019s demands. \u201cHoward University has birthed generations of student activists and we will always continue in that spirit,\u201d Dr. Frederick said.\n\nThe statement included a list of HU Resist\u2019s demands and information on efforts he said the university had made or has planned for each item \u2014 though he did not address the call for his resignation.\n\nHe ended by saying: \u201cYour concerns are valid. We are listening. We are committed to jointly making changes to move Howard forward.\u201d\n\nProtesters did not appear moved by his response. At the administration building on Friday afternoon, where a list of the demands were scrawled on large pieces of paper and hung above a main entrance, dozens of students were gathered in the foyer, chanting, \u201cWhose school? Our school!\u201d They had been there since Thursday afternoon, Ms. McCollum said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nInside, empty Dunkin\u2019 Donuts boxes and Red Bull cans were scattered across the floor.\n\nRows of chairs blocked the entrance, and the glass doors were marked with handwritten signs: \u201cSTUDENTS ONLY. (ID REQUIRED.)\u201d\n\n\u201cThe staff work for us, not the other way around,\u201d said Zephaniah Galloway, 19, a freshman from Cleveland and a member of HU Resist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOutside the building, members of the board of trustees lingered, waiting for an afternoon meeting scheduled with protesters. Eugene Newman, a board member known as Rock, declined to comment on the financial aid scandal but gave a full-bodied high-five to a student protester who came out to welcome him.\n\nThe meeting did not appease HU Resist. The group said on Friday evening that the board had not taken its demands seriously \u2014 or even fully read them \u2014 and that it would continue to occupy the building, where it was controlling all entrances and exits.\n\nThe statement released on Wednesday by the university\u2019s president did not disclose how much money was potentially embezzled by members of the financial aid office. But it said six employees had been fired \u201cfor gross misconduct and neglect of duties.\u201d Dr. Frederick added, \u201cWe will refer this matter for criminal prosecution, as appropriate.\u201d\n\nIn a statement on Friday afternoon, the board of trustees said it stood with Dr. Frederick on the handling of the financial aid matter and on his response to HU Resist\u2019s demands.\n\nIn December 2016, Dr. Frederick and the board of trustees became aware that financial aid funds may have been mishandled, quickly prompting an internal investigation, Dr. Frederick said. The university hired an outside auditor to investigate. Those results, which were reported to the president in May 2017, confirmed that misappropriation of funds had occurred from 2007 to 2016.\n\nDr. Frederick said he reported the matter to the United States Department of Education in July 2017. Howard\u2019s investigation concluded in September, and the employees were fired.\n\nIn a letter to students on Wednesday, Dr. Frederick said: \u201cI feel strongly that any dollar that is taken away from a deserving student due to malfeasance or fraud is unacceptable. We will continue to take swift action against any individuals involved in this wrongdoing.\u201d", "title": "Student Protesters Take Over Howard University Administration Building", "authors": ["Maya Salam", "Emily Baumgaertner"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nOn Wednesday, students will walk out of their classes for 17 minutes and stand together to let the rest of the country and world know that they have had enough of the gun violence that is becoming so commonplace. Enough killing of innocent people, of sons and daughters, of grandkids, of friends.\n\nStudents and parents have asked the nation\u2019s leaders for help; instead they have encountered political resistance. Public servants have failed to do anything to protect them against the next gun attack. Instead they cower at the threat of retaliation from gun owners and the National Rifle Association. Do they not care about our kids? Why don\u2019t they take these school shootings seriously?\n\nOn Wednesday, my son and daughter will walk out of their classes, forgoing classroom learning to teach their elders a much more important lesson. They matter, and guns are the problem!\n\nCHUCK MUIR\n\nMOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIF.", "title": "Opinion | Student Walkout: A Plea for Action", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "In light of recent events, it was no surprise to us that \u201cDo You Think It Is Important for Teenagers to Participate in Political Activism?\u201d was the most popular writing prompt this week. We received excellent comments from students all over the country who organized and participated in the national student walkouts on March 14, as well as those who chose to opt out. Here are their thoughts on the protest and teenagers\u2019 roles in politics:\n\nKate Silver from Wilmington, N.C., shared her experience:\n\nOn Wednesday March 14th, thousands participated in Nationwide walkouts to protest gun violence and honor the 17 lives lost in the Parkland shooting. Among the participating schools was mine, Hoggard High School. At 10 am when the protests began, hundreds of students marched to the forum with their voices ready to be heard. I came prepared with my \u201cArms are for Hugging\u201d t-shirt and \u201cNo more silence, end gun violence\u201d written on my poster. 17 students were standing on a wooden bench and came forward one by one, passionately representing each of the 17 victims. The experience was amazing. I felt as though anything was possible and that we could make a difference. Seeing so many students vying for change made me proud of my generation. I felt like my father, who years earlier, marched on Washington to protest the Vietnam War. As a teenager, adults look down on us. They see us as hormonal children that only care about themselves. But during the walkout, we showed them that we will not stay silent and afterwards, they were looking up to us.\n\nSydney Durner from Wilmington, N.C., also participated in the walkout, though for a different reason:\n\nTeenagers are usually looked down upon in politics, like our opinion doesn\u2019t matter, we don\u2019t know enough about politics to have a say. It\u2019s important for teenagers to be able to speak out for what they believe in. This enforce good political habits, speaking your mind, standing up for what you believe in, participating in voting, etc. I participated in the walkout on Wednesday, March 14th. I don\u2019t necessarily agree with what my school was preaching about. I went to honor the victims. The walkout turned into a ban guns rally. Guns aren\u2019t the problem, it\u2019s the ones behind the trigger that are the problem. In the article \u201cNational School Walkout: Thousands Protest Against Gun Violence Across the U.S.,\u201d they mention a 16 year-old who stayed in class during the protest, saying that banning guns isn\u2019t the issue and that the real issue is the people doing it.\u201d That was his way of participating in political activism. He stayed because it\u2019s what he believed in. Teenagers should participate in political activism. It feels good to be a part of something bigger than you could imagine and trying to make a change in the world. In the article \u201cWhy Demonstrating is Good for Kids,\u201d it mentions a study in the journal Child Development, teens and young adults who voted, volunteered, or engaged in activism went farther in school and had higher incomes than those who didn\u2019t advocate for change. It is so important that we develop our voices at a young age. It only helps us in the long run.\n\nLeah Schwagerl from Wilmington, N.C., was proud of her classmates:\n\nPersonally, I am proud of all of the adolescents that participated in the walkouts for gun violence or for memorializing the 17 victims of the Parkland shooting. Even if our efforts to promote change are denied by legislation, at least we were able to experience the unity that comes with standing up for what we believe in. I hope that the nation wide walkout sparked adults to see teenagers in a more respectable way. After all, just a week before the walkout I saw an upsetting post on social media that stated something along the lines of \u201cHow am I supposed to listen to teenagers talk about gun laws when earlier this year they were eating tide pods?\u201d To conclude, I can say with pride that after my positive experience from the national school walkout, I plan on being a lot more politically active in the years to come. Political activism allows teenagers, adults, and people in general to align their beliefs and engage in the world.\n\nCollin from Lawrence was less impressed with his school\u2019s demonstration:\n\nI feel like at my school, Walkout was the wrong term. At my school there was a rally. Disappointed. That was my reaction. Disappointed because instead of being a respectful memorial. It was a political charged anti gun rally. Now, there is nothing wrong with expressing your own political beliefs but school is not the place to hold a political protest. I was under the impression there was going to be 17 minutes of silence but what I got was quite the opposite. People with megaphones, yelling and screaming, chanting. It was far from a memorial. Do I think young people should protest? Yes go right ahead but school is not the place. A large portion of people who went to the \u201crally\u201d didn\u2019t even know why they were there. Conflicted Ideas about guns swarmed around the place. \u201cBan all guns!\u201d \u201cBan Assault Rifles\u201d Some people didn\u2019t even know what they stood for. The worse thing about it is, The school can practicality host an anti gun rally, but if a student walks into class wearing a shirt or a hat that portrays their conservative beliefs or lifestyle, they are asked to take it off. It reminds me of a court case we learned about in Civics. Tinker vs Des Moines. This court case ruled that students have the right to protest as long as they don\u2019t disrupt the learning environment. Although the verdict stands true to this day, I don\u2019t see the law being enforced in America\u2019s High Schools.\n\nKalpana from New York, N.Y., was also confused about the message protesters were sending, but remained hopeful:\n\nI\u2019m not sure about the message my school was trying to send. I know that the students and teachers believe gun violence is bad, and I do too, but it confuses me why we were not doing 17 minutes of silence. I wish we had. I thought the walkout was supposed to be for students in Parkland, Florida, and we would be supporting them by walking out and doing 17 minutes of silence and reading their names. Instead, we did 20 minutes of shouting and rallying for gun control. The message we were sending out was not \u201cParkland we sympathize with you\u201d but \u201cNRA, we\u2019re going to take you down!\u201d I do hope, still, that our rallies help convince Trump to make some gun control laws so there will be fewer incidents involving guns.\n\nThough some students doubted the effectiveness of the walkouts, Sydney G. from New York thought they had the potential to make a difference:\n\nI think that it was very important that us children, the future of our world went out and stood up for something that we believe in. It is very significant that as individuals at this age that we use our voices, because our opinions are very powerful and influential. I believe that we did make a difference just by going out among millions of others to support the people who have suffered and are still suffering and stand up for what we believe in. When I see photos of the other young adults going out and protesting, I feel proud that there is a group of people who are not afraid to share their true feelings to the nation and that there are people who are willing to protect and support each other no matter how frightening it is.\n\nAs did Cam from Maine, who hoped young people\u2019s voices wouldn\u2019t be silenced by adults:\n\nI think that it is more important than ever for teens to participate in political debates and issues. Sadly, we are the generation that has grown up with mass shootings being a norm, and it needs to stop. I think that students taking a stand will make a difference because we are also the next generation of voters. My school had a snow day on the day of the national walkout so we weren\u2019t able to participate, but from what I saw it got plenty of news coverage and attention, which will help with raising awareness even more. Personally, I also believe that teachers and administrators should allow students to have open, honest conversations about what they believe in without punishment. I also think that is wrong to not allow students to walkout and threaten them for standing up for what they believe in.\n\nBut Derek Han from San Jose, Calif., thought there were better ways for students to voice their concerns:\n\nMany problems are being noticed around the country nowadays such as school shootings, and students may want to protest. Recently, there was a peaceful protest on March 14, where students across the nation walked outside of their classrooms in order to spread awareness about the issue of gun violence in schools. As a student, I didn\u2019t take part in the protest as I believed that walking outside of my classroom for 17 minutes was not the best way to spread awareness about the issue and was not the most efficient way to address nationwide problems. I believe that the idea of teenagers trying to spread their opinions on problems is great, but I just think that there are better ways of accomplishing their goal. Spending class time in order to give respect to the murdered students may not have been the best idea. Letting others know about issues through social media and the internet is a great way to spread awareness and still save class time for learning. While the intentions of protesting students or teenagers may be good, I think that some teenagers may be more prone to act on their emotions, and I feel that teenagers may cause something similar to a riot if their opinions are not agreed upon, or if their actions are not recognized.\n\nMany students were passionate about teenagers\u2019 involvement in politics, like Hugo Veliz from Providence, R.I., who wrote:\n\nPersonally, if the teenagers are being active in political issues, we see different aspects and different views on problems being discussed today. Also, what would happen if the issues being discussed today are about the teenagers and the youth? How could they not be apart of that discussion if they are the discussion. For example, the tragic shootout that recently happened in Florida. Would those in danger be silent and not say what is on their mind? It would be unjust. The teenagers of today will be those making those influential decisions of tomorrow. Being quiet will not only danger today, it will also danger the future.\n\nNelly3D from YC CLIP agreed:\n\nThese days is very important to raise our voices to get changes. I think is important to teach the teenager to participate in political activism because some teenagers do not how good or bad is to fight to get some positive change. Nowadays, some of our teenagers do not know how to choose good decisions, because some parents do not allow that their children grow independently, this makes us create children unable to make their own decisions. Some of them are influence negatively of bad persons. However, some teenager are more mature than an adult. I think that we have to allow the teenagers participate in different way like political activism in this way in this way they get involved in positive things so that they grow up to be wise people with a lot of knowledge and they can take advantage of it in the future. If we want to see in the future good resolve for this country, we as parents have to educate our children. They are our future.\n\nRobert Yates from Wilmington, N.C., argued that civic participation is one of the most important things citizens \u2014 young and old \u2014 can do for their country:\n\nI believe that the willingness of teenagers to take a stand against the government is the most important factor in regards to the reversal of the socioeconomic damage previous generations have dealt to our country and planet. I participated in the walkout last week at my high school along with hundreds of others. Many people, though, opted out of the protest to sit in class and do nothing for seventeen minutes. These people have their reasons, the vast majority of which I disagree with, however the one excuse I heard from a few people that frustrated me the most was that they didn\u2019t \u201cwaste their time\u201d because \u201cone person won\u2019t make a difference\u201d. This mindset is the antithesis of meaningful change, which is also shared by people such as those that abstain from exercising their right as an American citizen to vote. As the study referenced in the first article stated, both voting and participating in political activism have a high correlation with going far in school and higher incomes, most likely because proactivity lends itself to success more so than complacency. As far as school staff are concerned, I believe they should remain neutral on the topic and allow students to make their own decisions. I felt pressured to not participate last week because my teacher was clearly biased against the protesters. When school staff share their opinion, it can scare students into doing the opposite of what they believe in, which isn\u2019t a good way to acclimate students to taking a stand.\n\n_________", "title": "Student Walkouts, March Madness and Risk-Enhanced Playgrounds: Our Favorite Student Comments of the Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Standing before vast crowds from Washington to Los Angeles to Parkland, Fla., the speakers \u2014 nearly all of them students, some still in elementary school \u2014 delivered an anguished and defiant message: They are \u201cdone hiding\u201d from gun violence, and will \u201cstop at nothing\u201d to get politicians to finally prevent it.\n\nThe students, as they seized the nation\u2019s attention on Saturday with raised fists and tear-streaked faces, vowed that their grief about school shootings and their frustration with adults\u2019 inaction would power a new generation of political activism.\n\n\u201cIf they continue to ignore us, to only pretend to listen, then we will take action where it counts,\u201d Delaney Tarr, a student at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, where a gunman killed 17 people last month, told tens of thousands rallying in Washington. \u201cWe will take action every day in every way until they simply cannot ignore us any more.\u201d\n\nFor many of the young people, the Washington rally, called March for Our Lives, was their first act of protest and the beginning of a political awakening. But that awakening may be a rude one \u2014 lawmakers in Congress have largely disregarded their pleas for action on television and social media in the five weeks since the Parkland shooting.", "title": "Students Lead Huge Rallies for Gun Control Across the U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. Kim Severson\u2019s byline is on the front page of the Food section we sent to the printer last night and delivered to the homes of our subscribers in the inky pre-dawn chill of this morning, above a yarn about one of the more regionally specific dishes in America: the stuffed ham of southern Maryland. It is a marvelous read. It may even prompt you to make the recipe (above) for Easter this year, or just because.\n\nYotam Ottolenghi, meanwhile, gave us his latest it\u2019s-a-project-it\u2019s-not-a-project column this week, along with two great new recipes to illustrate it: one for a fairly involved spiced tomato maqluba with tahini sauce; the other for a much simpler, but no less delicious dish of turmeric rice with tomatoes, garlic and cardamom. I think one or both of those could be great to plan for this coming weekend, maybe to go with Yotam\u2019s recipe for lamb shawarma.\n\nAnd in advance of Passover, our pal Joan Nathan wrote from Carpentras, in the northern part of the south of France, about Jewish food life and the 14th-century synagogue there. Naturally she brought back some Passover recipes along with her tale: one for a stuffed veal breast with Swiss chard and the other for an ancient haroseth. Save for later!\n\nTonight, though, maybe you can join in on our weekly exercise of cooking without a recipe, off a narrative prompt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor instance, I say: fish with ginger, scallions and soy. What I mean is, buy a few fillets of the fish you like (I like fluke), then put a sheet pan in the oven and get it ripping hot. Make a sauce in a small bowl: a few tablespoons of soy sauce to each one of rice wine or sherry, and a heap of minced or grated ginger, and plenty of thinly sliced scallions. You could put some garlic in there, if you like, and a dash of hot chili oil, or sesame. Salt and pepper the fish, then pull the hot sheet pan out of the oven and get some neutral oil on it. Add the fish, cook it for a minute or so, then a minute or so more under the sauce, until it has just cooked through. Serve with rice and greens, or on rice with greens. And I bet it\u2019d make a good sandwich?", "title": "Stuffed Ham!", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "What To Cook", "Yotam Ottolenghi", "Kim Severson", "Joan Nathan"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt makes no sense to highlight that Canadian steel or aluminum might be a security threat to the United States,\u201d he continued, referring to the argument that the imports threaten the United States\u2019 national security.\n\nHe echoed the sentiment of his foreign minister, Chrystia Freeland, that any tariffs on steel or aluminum were \u201cabsolutely unacceptable\u201d \u2014 but he did not echo her foreboding statement that they might set off \u201cresponsive measures.\u201d\n\nExperts had some optimism that Mr. Trump might not go through with his plan of imposing tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s still some hope that cooler heads will prevail and America\u2019s closest allies and most reliable trade partners will be excluded from these types of protectionist measures,\u201d said Roland Paris, a professor of international affairs at the University of Ottawa and a former foreign policy adviser to Mr. Trudeau.\n\nHugh Segal, a former chief of staff to the prime minister in the 1990s, said the move would hurt American consumers among others. \u201cIf this is about unfair trade practices of other countries, we are not the violators on that front,\u201d he said. \u201cAny rational analysis will indicate that.\u201d\n\nAlthough the United States and Canada have long had a mutually beneficial trade relationship, tensions have grown since Mr. Trump came into office. Last year, the Trump administration announced the imposition of new tariffs on Canadian lumber imports, the latest round in a longstanding battle over those products. It also threatened to impose crippling tariffs on a new airliner from the Canadian company Bombardier, although it ultimately backed off.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow, the Trump administration appears ready to apply tariffs on Canadian newsprint. In response, Canada has gone to the World Trade Organization with a sweeping challenge over how the United States handles trade complaints from its industries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile other American administrations had quarreled with Canada over trade issues in the past, Mr. Trump has distinguished himself with harsh comments about what he calls Canada\u2019s unfair trade practices.\n\nThen there is the matter of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Mr. Trump has threatened to tear up if the United States cannot obtain substantial changes through negotiations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGordon Ritchie, a former Canadian trade negotiator, said he worried the American move on tariffs would further fray good will between the countries during the seventh round of negotiations over Nafta. But if the Americans want to \u201cshoot themselves in various parts of their anatomy, then there\u2019s not a lot we can do about it,\u201d he said.\n\nCanada has declared many of the main American demands on Nafta to be unacceptable, and Mr. Trudeau has recently said it will walk away from the deal rather than accept a bad one \u2014 despite the fact that a full 70 percent of the country\u2019s exports go to the much larger American market.\n\nSince Mr. Trump was elected, Mr. Trudeau has sent a series of envoys \u2014 cabinet ministers, premiers and a former prime minister, Brian Mulroney \u2014 on regular trips to the United States to meet with American officials, lawmakers, chambers of commerce and businesses, to convince them of the mutual benefit of free trade with their northern neighbor.\n\nThe hope is that they, in turn, might deflect and contain Mr. Trump\u2019s impulses. Most Canadian observers consider the approach \u2014 called the \u201cdoughnut strategy\u201d \u2014 successful to date.\n\nBut this seems the biggest test of that strategy, especially as Mr. Trump has taken the unusual step of invoking United States security as the reason to impose the tariffs. And on Friday, Mr. Trump also said that a trade war was \u201cgood\u201d and \u201ceasy to win.\u201d\n\nLaura Dawson, the director of the Canada Institute at the Wilson Center, a research organization in Washington, called the American move \u201crisky,\u201d and said it could prompt other countries to cite national security grounds to slap tariffs on things like American corn and grain.\n\nShe also asked: \u201cIs Canada no longer a trusted partner in defense?\u201d\n\nOthers offered a similar blend of criticism, based on economics and friendship.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrank McKenna, a former ambassador to the United States, said the country would be \u201ctraumatized\u201d by the tariffs should they be implemented next week. Although much smaller in size, Canada does have some ammunition to hurt the United States as the \u201cbiggest provider of energy to the U.S. \u2014 in terms of oil, gas, uranium and hydro.\u201d\n\nBut he also called the American plan \u201ca repudiation of our friendship.\u201d\n\nJean Simard, the president of the Aluminum Association of Canada, whose industry\u2019s nine smelters export about $5.6 billion across the border every year, said it was \u201cvery difficult to accept being treated this way.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cIt\u2019s not how to deal with a country that has been the most strategic ally of the U.S.A. since the Second World War.\u201d", "title": "Stung by U.S. Tariff Plan, Canada Takes a Deep Breath", "authors": ["Catherine Porter", "Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Audran was born Colette Suzanne Dacheville in Versailles, France, on Nov. 8, 1932. Her father, a doctor, died when she was young, and she was raised by her mother.\n\nIn the early 1950s she took acting classes and was cast in several plays but did not have much success onstage. Her first film role was in 1957 in \u201cLe Jeu de la Nuit\u201d (\u201cThe Game of the Night\u201d), but her career accelerated when Mr. Chabrol began casting her. In their almost two-dozen films, she often played a bourgeois woman.\n\nBefore her marriage to Mr. Chabrol, who died in 2010, Ms. Audran was married to Jean-Louis Trintignant; after their divorce she acted with him in several films, including \u201cLes Biches\u201d (\u201cThe Does\u201d), with her new husband, Mr. Chabrol, directing. It was one of Ms. Audran\u2019s most challenging roles. She played a bisexual woman named Fr\u00e9d\u00e9rique.\n\n\u201cI like challenges,\u201d she told The Los Angeles Times in 1988, \u201cand I like jumping into the unknown.\u201d\n\nShe demonstrated that to a greater extent with the work she did with other directors. She played the mistress of Laurence Olivier\u2019s character in the TV mini-series \u201cBrideshead Revisited\u201d in 1981. In the 1996 action film \u201cMaximum Risk,\u201d she played the mother of Jean-Claude Van Damme\u2019s character, who investigates his twin brother\u2019s death.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a career in which she covered the whole range of roles \u2014 drama, comedy, romance \u2014 she was best known for her turn in \u201cBabette\u2019s Feast,\u201d based on a story by Isak Dinesen. Ms. Audran played the enigmatic title character, a sophisticated Frenchwoman who arrives unexpectedly in a remote Danish fishing village in the 1800s and shakes things up when she prepares a sumptuous, cosmopolitan meal for a group of its dour, upright inhabitants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe movie was by the Danish director Gabriel Axel, who said casting the quintessentially French Ms. Audran, rather than a Danish star, was crucial.\n\n\u201cShe opens a door differently from a Danish woman,\u201d he said in a 1988 interview. \u201cShe even moves differently. Now this is very important. It wouldn\u2019t have been the same with a Danish actress.\u201d\n\nVincent Canby, reviewing the movie in The New York Times, wrote: \u201cMiss Audran dominates the movie in the same way that Babette takes charge of the sisters\u2019 household and the village. The actress is still one of the great natural resources of European films.\u201d\n\nMs. Audran is survived by her son.\n\nIn a 1994 interview with The Chicago Tribune, Ms. Audran had an unusual description of how she begins to find a character.\n\n\u201cIt starts with the clothes,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is the first thing you have to think of. It\u2019s helpful because, if you notice, the way you wear your clothes is the way you are.\u201d", "title": "St\u00e9phane Audran, Star in Oscar-Winning \u2018Babette\u2019s Feast,\u2019 Dies at 85", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Coin offerings are a way for start-ups or online projects to raise money without selling stock or going to venture capitalists. The money is raised by creating and selling a virtual currency, generally with rules similar to well-known virtual currencies like Bitcoin.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe demands for information are the most concrete sign of the S.E.C.\u2019s intention to crack down on the sudden emergence of coin offerings. Companies raised over $5 billion through coin offerings in 2017, according to the news and data site Coindesk.\n\nJay Clayton, the chairman of the S.E.C., has said on several occasions that most of the virtual currencies that have been sold should have been categorized as securities and registered with regulators, which few companies have done.\n\nCompanies have been able to get around regulatory checks because they have collected the money in Bitcoin and other virtual currencies, which can be sent without going through any banks or other middlemen that might look into the legality of the transactions.\n\nThe New York Times Explains...\n\nIn January, Mr. Clayton said he had asked his agency to go after both the companies that sold virtual currencies and the \u201cgatekeepers\u201d that helped them.\n\n\u201cMarket professionals, especially gatekeepers, need to act responsibly and hold themselves to high standards,\u201d he said in the speech at the Securities Regulation Institute. \u201cTo be blunt, from what I have seen recently, particularly in the initial coin offering space, they can do better.\u201d\n\nThe S.E.C. has already brought cases against a few small companies that have sold virtual currencies. But the subpoenas are the first concrete sign of a broader regulatory push.\n\nIn a sign of the breadth of the agency\u2019s effort, the subpoenas have been sent out by S.E.C. offices in multiple cities, including Boston, San Francisco and New York, according to the four people who have seen the subpoenas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe subpoenas have asked companies for a wide array of information about the virtual currencies they have sold, including the information used to market the digital tokens and the identity of the investors who bought them, the people who saw the subpoenas said.", "title": "Subpoenas Signal S.E.C.
