Crackdown on Initial Coin Offerings", "authors": ["Nathaniel Popper"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "While banked northern white rhino sperm is available from several males not related to Najin and Fatu, neither female is able to carry a pregnancy to term. Conservationists hope to extract Najin and Fatu\u2019s eggs; fertilize the eggs in vitro with banked sperm; and then implant the embryos in surrogate southern white rhino females.\n\n[READ: We Might Soon Resurrect Extinct Species. Is It Worth the Cost?]\n\nIn vitro fertilization is commonly performed in humans and livestock, but the procedure has never succeeded with a rhino. So far, the researchers have perfected egg-extracting techniques on southern white rhinos, and soon they plan to attempt the first extraction on Najin and Fatu.\n\nEven if their eggs do lead to a number of healthy northern white calves, however, a population originating solely from a mother and a daughter will be dangerously lacking in genetic diversity.\n\nSo scientists also plan to use frozen cell cultures from 12 northern white rhinos, including Sudan, stored at the San Diego Zoo to create stem cells, which in theory might be coaxed into becoming egg and sperm and united to create an embryo.\n\nRecently advances have made the plan less far-fetched than it might seem. The potential to make stem cells from cell cultures earned Kyoto University medical researcher Dr. Shinya Yamanaka a Nobel Prize in 2012. The technique has since been used to create healthy, fertile mice.\n\nEncouraged by those findings, rhino researchers have so far succeeded in reprogramming stored skin cells from five northern white rhinos into specialized stem cells.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be a long process, but it\u2019s an incredible story in scientific study and analysis,\u201d said Oliver Ryder, director of conservation genetics at the San Diego Zoo Institute for Conservation Research. \u201cAnd the backdrop, of course, is the imminent extinction of this form of rhinoceros.\u201d", "title": "Sudan, the Last Male Northern White Rhino, Dies in Kenya", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Some people might consider that to be just another constructor\u2019s trick, but if you notice it when you first start solving, it\u2019s almost like an amuse-bouche for the puzzle. We\u2019ve seen \u201cstunts\u201d like this before, but they usually make the clues sound stilted; in Mr. Gordon\u2019s puzzle, the clues are so well written that the trick is barely noticeable, and it\u2019s delicious when you discover it.\n\nNot to worry if you almost missed it, however. The revealer is tucked away at the very end at 59D, where Mr. Gordon or perhaps the editors had to stretch to make the clue end the way it was supposed to: \u201cEnd of each word in 17-, 27-, 43- and 54-Across \u2014 as well as every clue (and that\u2019s a fact!)\u201d is the word TEE.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nMost of the clues are straightforward because of the constraint of having to end in a T, but there are a few that play with words today:\n\n64A: We\u2019re not supposed to be thinking about reading a magazine both backward and forward, but there is a magazine title that is a palindrome. That would be ELLE magazine.\n\n1D: I was surprised to find that the entry NOTORIOUS R.B.G. for the Supreme Court justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg had not been in The New York Times Crossword yet, but I welcome her initial debut clued to the titular best seller, \u201cNotorious R.B.G.\u201d\n\n44D: \u201cGets the lead out?\u201d is a great clue for ERASES. More than 670 people did just that this weekend at the 2018 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.", "title": "Suddenly Showed Interest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "This major policy divide goes to a disconnect between the president and congressional Republican leaders that has been papered over by fights with Democrats over the past year as well as the party unity behind the tax bill.\n\nMost of the Republican leaders on Capitol Hill remain firmly aligned with big business and want to retain the strong support of advocacy groups such as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and organizations affiliated with David H. and Charles G. Koch. Those business factions, always important to Republicans in a campaign year, do not like new tariffs.\n\nMr. Trump, on the other hand, has for years preached about the dangers and disadvantages of free trade and the harm it has done to once-leading American industries. Republicans now hoping to talk the president down from his tariff stance may find that his campaign promises about protectionism are ones he truly wants to keep.\n\nIt is a similar situation with gun safety. Mr. Trump has in the past backed the idea of an assault weapons ban. But congressional Republicans figured that his strong campaign embrace of the National Rifle Association would keep him securely in the anti-gun-control corner.\n\nThen, in last week\u2019s extraordinary public White House meeting after the Parkland, Fla., school massacre, Mr. Trump embraced multiple aspects of the gun control agenda. He even uttered the words \u201ctake the guns first\u201d \u2014 a phrase previously unthinkable for a top Republican politician given the party\u2019s history on gun rights.\n\nRepublicans were aghast. They also figured that, under pressure from his allies at the N.R.A., Mr. Trump would quickly return to the fold and let his enthusiasm for gun control wane. More important, congressional Republicans also knew that gun control legislation was really in their hands, not the administration\u2019s, and that they could easily bottle up any proposal.\n\nBut tariffs are a completely different matter, with the president given wide latitude to act on international trade policy. Republicans, who say they have little legislative recourse, are now engaged in a furious effort to pull the president back from making too sweeping a decision.", "title": "Suddenly, the G.O.P. Remembers All Its Doubts on Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 A suicide attacker drove a car full of explosives into a crowd leaving an evening wrestling match on Friday in southern Afghanistan, killing at least 14 and wounding 42, according to Afghan government officials.\n\nOmar Zwak, the spokesman for the governor of Helmand Province, said the bomber struck about 7 p.m. at a field in the provincial capital, Lashkar Gah, where a traditional wrestling match drawing hundreds of spectators had just ended. He said the dead and wounded included many children, and some of the wounded were in critical condition.\n\nMost of the victims were civilians, but some were security officials, said the Helmand governor, Hayatullah Hayat. Mr. Hayat blamed the Taliban for the attack. \u201cThe enemy has been beaten up badly by our brave security forces across Helmand Province, and now they are trying to take revenge on civilians,\u201d he said.\n\nHelmand is heavily dominated by the Taliban, and there are no known Islamic State operations in the area. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the latest bombing, but similar attacks in Lashkar Gah have been attributed to the Taliban.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bombing came two days after an attack in Kabul claimed by the Islamic State, and aimed at a Shiite shrine; 33 died there in the latest count, according to police in Kabul.\n\nAccording to Abdul Razaq, one of the spectators, the matches had ended and spectators joined in the evening prayer before filtering out of the area. Then the car bomb exploded at the gates, where security officials were stationed.", "title": "Suicide Attack in Afghanistan Kills at Least 14 at Wrestling Match", "authors": ["Rod Nordland"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Curry Morgan, a 2015 Madison graduate, had returned from college to visit. He wanted to thank his former coach. Morgan is a junior biology and neuroscience major at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, on an academic scholarship, with plans for medical school.\n\nHis father was out of his life by the time he was in kindergarten. His brother was addicted to pills and sold drugs. His mother died of liver disease two days before his senior year. The day of the funeral, Morrison ended practice early and dispatched buses of teammates so they could support Morgan.\n\nAfterward, when Morgan didn\u2019t have a place to live, teammates offered couches. At graduation, Morrison collected money to pay for Morgan\u2019s cap and gown and class ring.\n\n\u201cI was scared people would treat me differently because of my family circumstances, but Coach Morrison, he wouldn\u2019t let that happen,\u201d Morgan said. \u201cSports is the reason I\u2019m resilient. It\u2019s the reason I\u2019m where I am and not selling drugs right now.\u201d\n\nEyes wet, he buried his face in his hands. It has been an especially rough year for him, he told me. His college roommate, also a 2015 Madison graduate, killed himself in March. Morgan was in an apartment next door, just before dawn, when he got the news. Morgan\u2019s brother, who had been visiting, showed up bloodied and crying hysterically. \u201cHe\u2019s gone,\u201d he said. His roommate had shot himself on the living room couch.\n\n\u201cNo one knows why, but he did,\u201d Morgan said.\n\nThose young adults and teenagers, even middle schoolers, from Madison who killed themselves in the past few years have left behind unanswerable questions. At least three students in the class of 2015 and one from 2014 have committed suicide.\n\nOne, a former soccer star, hanged herself from the basketball hoop in her family\u2019s driveway. Another hanged himself in his garage. Another, David Lee Wheeler, shot himself as he hanged himself from a 100-year-old maple tree in his yard.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis mother, Dee Wheeler, was the waitress at Horst\u2019s bakery who had asked me for help. She and I met for lunch after her shift had ended.\n\n\u201cThis really came out of nowhere,\u201d Wheeler said of her son\u2019s suicide. \u201cHe was fine when I last saw him that night. Before going to bed, I said to him, \u2018There\u2019s crab salad in the refrigerator.\u2019 It was his favorite.\u201d\n\nA Team Becomes an Oasis\n\nMadison is a swing-shift town where it\u2019s not uncommon for parents to work two or more jobs. So if a child is looking for an available adult role model, a football coach \u2014 a Patric Morrison \u2014 can be a last, best hope.", "title": "Suicides, Drug Addiction and High School Football", "authors": ["Juliet Macur", "Sports Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The boards were created after World War II, when Congress recognized that disciplinary decisions made quickly under wartime pressure by military commanders often contained mistakes, and that in the aftermath, veterans deserved an avenue for due process to correct them, according to Jonathan Petkun, one of the Yale students who filed the lawsuit.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t see that happening now,\u201d said Mr. Petkun, a former Marine captain who served in Iraq and Afghanistan. \u201cThe board seems to just be rubber stamping things.\u201d\n\n\u201cAs a former officer, I think commanders in the field need broad discretion,\u201d he said. \u201cBut when I was an officer, I thought, if I made a mistake, veterans would have recourse. Now I see that is rarely the case.\u201d\n\nYale students working with veterans groups have gradually forced the Pentagon to be more open to correcting what veterans groups largely view as unfair discharges. In 2014, in response to a lawsuit by Yale and the group Vietnam Veterans of America, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel issued new guidelines for upgrading discharges. The guidelines instructed the review boards to give \u201cliberal consideration\u201d to the possibility that PTSD contributed to a veteran\u2019s other-than-honorable discharge.\n\nThe Army board quickly changed course, and its denial rate for applications involving PTSD fell from 96 percent to about 45 percent, according to Department of Defense data. The Air Force made similar changes. But the Navy board, which oversees both sailors and Marines, has scarcely budged.\n\nBrad Carson, who oversaw the Army board as an undersecretary in the Obama administration, said the boards were overworked, and had only a few minutes to review each case. But even with more time, he said, it is far from simple to reach a fair outcome in cases where a veteran clearly committed misconduct and also has a stress-disorder diagnosis.\n\n\u201cHow do you determine how PTSD affected an action, which might also be due just to, well, being a bad soldier?\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cThe Navy has a strong cultural belief, going back centuries, that you do not second-guess commanders. I suspect because of that, when they have a difficult case, they fall back on tradition and defer to commanders.\u201d", "title": "Suit Calls Navy Board Biased Against Veterans With PTSD", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "For example, at 20A, the answer to \u201cLight deli offering\u201d is LEAN CORNED BEEF. Inside that entry, we have the word ACORN (not necessarily a nut that is typically consumed by humans, but whatever), but it is split by the letter N.\n\nWhat could that mean, I wondered? Are we splitting nuts? Is there such a thing as a broken nut? No, what we are looking at is the entire nut, including the shell. The kernel is the letter that is circled. And if you look at all three of those kernels, they spell out N-U-T.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nIf you\u2019re looking for easy fill-in-the-blank clues to get you started, you might have trouble today. There are a few of them, but their answers do not immediately jump to mind. I found my foothold randomly, with SPF, BAGEL and RCA.\n\n5A: You need to be sharp to get \u201cThe answer to this clue is located on one.\u201d The answer is EDGE, but I didn\u2019t guess this until I had ED _ _ in the grid.\n\n16A: Nice misdirection here. I still have nightmares about failing at lanyard-making in summer camp, but that\u2019s not the kind of craft we\u2019re looking for today. We\u2019re looking for a craft that floats on the water, like that CANOE you paddled at camp.\n\n24A: \u201cDash letters\u201d is not referring to the Morse Code dash, but to a dashboard, and the answer is MPH for miles per hour.\n\n30A: I had trouble with this one, mainly because I am woefully uneducated when it comes to my starchy tubers. The word \u201cpowdered\u201d in \u201cPowdered ingredient in sweet teas and smoothies\u201d confused me, because I wasn\u2019t expecting TARO as an answer. I thought that TARO root was used to make the \u201cbubbles\u201d or pearls in bubble tea, but that\u2019s tapioca, which is made from yucca. The powdered TARO root is used to thicken and give color to sweet teas and smoothies. You can make your own at home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n31A: I did not see this one coming. I know enough to expect a suffix when I see a clue like \u201cEnd to terrorism?\u201d but today\u2019s answer was the second word of the name of an actual terrorist group, AL QAEDA.\n\n37A: I am still of the school that believes that plaits are not the same as twists when it comes to hairstyles.\n\n2D: Conquering the NEMEAN lion was one of Hercules\u2019 Labors. You can learn more about this mythical beast in our \u201cWhat the Heck Is That?\u201d series, which includes ways you might see the entry clued.\n\n12D: The minute you see that question mark in a clue like \u201cDriving instructor?,\u201d you should be thinking about other kinds of driving you know of besides automotive, because there is definitely wordplay happening here. Golfers also drive their shots, so an instructor in that game would be a GOLF PRO.\n\n45D: Once again, watch those question marks. \u201cLike good spellers?\u201d could refer to spelling words, but not with that wordplay indicator. What other kinds of spells do you know? How about the kind that WICCANs might cast?\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nClaire Muscat: The first iteration of this puzzle was actually for a Midi pack that David (who I am lucky enough to have as my constructing mentor and friend) and I constructed this summer. For the themed Midis, we kept the themes pretty simple, so I decided to try a NUTTY-themed puzzle for fun. I was a pretty green constructor at the time, so I accidentally split the grid in half in my attempt to keep the fill clean, not realizing it would be an issue. David got a good kick out of both the silly theme and poorly laid out grid, and so the NUTTY puzzle became a running joke between the two of us. When he sent me an idea for an updated, more sophisticated version of my initial idea, I couldn\u2019t help but laugh about how the infamous NUTTY puzzle had come back to haunt me. However, I couldn\u2019t turn the opportunity down. I loved David\u2019s ingenious idea to have the word NUT enclosed in the \u201cshell\u201d of the themers, and we spent a good amount of Skype hours working on the grid together to reach our final product. The end result is something I think we\u2019re both quite happy with, especially some of the fun fill (PIZZA FACE, GIANT SQUID) that we were able to squeeze in. Most of all, I\u2019m thrilled to be making my New York Times print debut, and am happy to finally be redeemed from my initial attempt. Also, if you haven\u2019t already, please check out Queer Qrosswords, a puzzle pack I am so proud to say I contributed to and whose profits go completely to LGBTQ+ charities. Happy solving! David Steinberg: Always a pleasure to work with Claire! We \u201cmet\u201d through the Cruciverb-l mailing list, when I noticed she answered someone\u2019s question about an iffy entry from a millennial\u2019s perspective. Since there are so few young female constructors, I decided to reach out and see if she wanted to collaborate. It turned out that she\u2019d been constructing for a few months but didn\u2019t feel confident enough to submit her work. Claire did send me her earliest constructions to test-solve, though, and I could already see she had talent. Fast forward a year. Claire\u2019s crosswords have appeared in The Los Angeles Times, the A.V. Club, The Orange County Register, The New York Times app, Queer Qrosswords (an LGBTQ crossword pack I highly recommend), and now The New York Times itself. She also has several themelesses in the queue for the new daily 15x15 Puzzle Society Crossword I edit, which appears in The Philadelphia Inquirer, The San Francisco Examiner, and other papers. The creativity and modern vibe that Claire brings to our community is very exciting, and I look forward to watching her continue to blossom! One more quick plug for Erik Agard\u2019s and Will Nediger\u2019s Puzzle Collaboration Society group on Facebook. If you\u2019re a new constructor, there are many wonderful experienced constructors who are eager to connect with you and give you tips! Don\u2019t be a stranger.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Summer Camp Craft", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI never met a man like this,\u201d Kennedy told Hugh Sidey of Time magazine. Kennedy said he \u201ctalked about how a nuclear exchange would kill 70 million people in 10 minutes, and he just looked at me as if to say, \u2018So what?\u2019\u201d\n\nKhrushchev told Kennedy it would be up to the United States to decide if there would be war or peace between the two nations.\n\n\u201cThen, Mr. Chairman,\u201d Kennedy responded, \u201cthere will be war. It will be a cold winter.\u201d\n\nRelations quickly grew more hostile. The Berlin Wall was erected a few months later, dividing the city between communist East and capitalist West. James Reston of The New York Times wrote in his memoir, \u201cDeadline,\u201d that the president came out of the meeting determined to show toughness.\n\n\u201cAnd the place to do it, he remarked to my astonishment, was Vietnam!\u201d Mr. Reston recalled.\n\nNixon-Mao, Beijing, February 1972\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Richard M. Nixon\u2019s weeklong visit to China was the pivotal event that ended the Cold War hostility between China and the United States. It looked like a contradiction at the time: the American politician who had risen to fame as a virulent anti-communist was venturing into the world\u2019s most populous communist country. But as Nixon himself had conceded years earlier, \u201cWe simply cannot afford to leave China outside the family of nations.\u201d\n\nAs he departed Washington for Beijing, Nixon was not even sure he would meet the Chinese leader, Mao Zedong.\n\nBut it was not a spur-of-the-moment trip. On the contrary, it had taken months of secret discussions, which began in April 1971 when the United States table-tennis team arrived in China.\n\nIn what became known as Ping-Pong diplomacy, the team\u2019s groundbreaking visit led to a clandestine trip to China by Henry A. Kissinger, Nixon\u2019s national security adviser, that laid the groundwork for Nixon\u2019s arrival. Premier Zhou Enlai of China said, \u201cNever before in history has a sport been used so effectively as a tool of international diplomacy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nReagan-Gorbachev, Geneva, November 1985\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Cold War-era meeting between President Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then secretary general of the Soviet Communist Party, was the first time in six years that leaders of the two nuclear superpowers had come face to face.\n\n\u201cWe met, as we had to meet,\u201d Mr. Reagan said upon his return to Washington. \u201cI had called for a fresh start and we made that start. I can\u2019t claim we had a meeting of the minds on such fundamentals as ideology or national purpose \u2014 but we understand each other better. That\u2019s the key to peace.\u201d\n\nLittle substantive decision-making came from the summit meeting, but both said they would use it to jump-start greater cooperation.\n\nThe next time the pair met, in Reykjavik, Iceland, in October 1986, the outcome was less positive. They failed to come to an agreement on arms control after Gorbachev insisted the talks include regulating America\u2019s Strategic Defense Initiative \u2014 the so-called Star Wars antimissile defense system \u2014 a project Mr. Reagan had embraced. Talks between the two countries would not resume for more than a year.\n\nBush-Putin, Ljubljana, Slovenia, June 2001\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident George W. Bush, meeting Vladimir V. Putin for the first time during a June 2001 summit meeting in Slovenia, offered a surprising public display of warmth toward the Russian leader, just six months into Mr. Bush\u2019s first term.\n\nConfounding aides who warned that Russia respected only toughness, Mr. Bush told reporters at a news conference with Mr. Putin: \u201cI looked the man in the eye. I found him to be very straightforward and trustworthy. We had a very good dialogue. I was able to get a sense of his soul.\u201d\n\nThe effusive praise would later be interpreted as a sign of na\u00efvet\u00e9 about Mr. Putin, the former K.G.B. spy who has come to be seen as a vexing adversary of the United States.\n\nObama-Castro, Panama, April 2015\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Barack Obama and Cuba\u2019s Ra\u00fal Castro met in Panama in 2015, ending a half-century in which leaders of the two countries had not come face to face.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe meeting on the sidelines of the Summit of the Americas was part of a push by Mr. Obama to normalize diplomatic relations with Cuba after generations of hostility.\n\n\u201cOur governments will continue to have differences,\u201d Mr. Obama said at a news conference. \u201cAt the same time, we agreed that we can continue to take steps forward that advance our mutual interests.\u201d\n\nMr. Castro praised Mr. Obama\u2019s \u201chumble\u201d background and said he had read his books.\n\nMr. Castro\u2019s older brother Fidel, the iconic revolutionary who took power in 1959, never met with any sitting American president while he was Cuba\u2019s leader. When Castro visited the United States shortly after the revolution, President Dwight D. Eisenhower made a point of going to the golf course. Castro wound up meeting instead with Nixon, who was then the vice president.", "title": "Summits of Adversaries: They Haven\u2019t Always Worked Out So Well", "authors": ["Megan Specia", "Rick Gladstone"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI was super-focused at the U.S. Open, and felt just as focused today,\u201d the 24-year-old South Korean player said. \u201cI just felt really good about my driver. In Maine, polling support for the measure declined between introduction and the final vote, before failing, 52-48.\n\n\u201cWe know for a fact we lost the argument at the kitchen table and the bar and the bowling alley,\u201d he said. \u201cThe gun enthusiasts were talking to their friends and relatives and neighbors. They felt about it in a way that was so passionate that they won those one-on-one encounters, and they were very successful in bringing in people to their side.\u201d\n\nThe enthusiasm of gun rights activists doesn\u2019t show up just in personal conversations. Over the last few decades, they have been more likely to speak to their legislators or give money to gun-related political groups, according to research from the Pew Research Center. Those actions have sent a signal to legislators that there is robust opposition even to laws that show strong public support in polls.\n\nJohn Feinblatt, the president of Everytown for Gun Safety, a group that favors stricter gun laws, thinks the energy imbalance is shifting. He said the group\u2019s donations, membership and Instagram follows have all risen since the Parkland shootings, a suggestion, he said, that members of the public who back Everytown\u2019s agenda are increasing the intensity of their support.\n\nHe also noted a string of recent state legislative successes on gun restrictions for domestic abusers, including some in Republican-led states, and the recent passage of a law in Florida that allows judges to temporarily confiscate guns from people who are judged a threat. (On Friday, an N.R.A. spokesman declined to offer the organization\u2019s views of public opinion on gun measures.)\n\nMr. Farmer said he is also optimistic that his side can do a better job of persuading voters in the future. He said he\u2019s particularly heartened by the recent groundswell of activism by young Americans. He said he sees parallels between their energy and that of the opposition.\n\nSeveral polls since the Parkland shootings show a rise in support for gun restrictions, including some that go beyond universal background checks . President Trump\u2019s proposal to arm schoolteachers has received more lukewarm support \u2014 with fewer than 45 percent of the public supporting it in two recent surveys. It will take some time to see whether the trends hold.", "title": "Support for Gun Control Seems Strong. But It May Be Softer Than It Looks.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Some justices expressed frustration with the thin court record in the case, which arrived at the Supreme Court at an early stage in the proceedings. That left open the possibility that the justices could return the case to the lower courts for a full trial.\n\nIn 1992, the Supreme Court upheld a Pennsylvania law that required doctors who performed abortions to provide some kinds of information to their patients. Several members of the court\u2019s liberal wing said that the California law served similar interests.\n\n\u201cIn law,\u201d Justice Stephen G. Breyer said, \u201cwhat is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.\u201d Justice Kagan called the California law \u201cthe exact flip side\u201d of the one sustained in the 1992 decision, Planned Parenthood v. Casey.\n\nMichael P. Farris, a lawyer for the centers, said the law upheld in the Casey decision differed from the one in California because it concerned medical professionals.\n\n\u201cPennsylvania imposed that requirement in the context of an informed consent discussion,\u201d he said. \u201cInformed consent is triggered by a doctor proposing to perform a particular medical intervention.\u201d\n\nJustice Kennedy, who joined the controlling opinion in Casey and probably holds the crucial vote in the new case, seemed hostile to the California law.\n\n\u201cDo you agree,\u201d he asked a lawyer for the state, \u201cthat mandating speech that the speaker would not otherwise give \u2014 indeed, does not agree with \u2014 alters the content of the message?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lawyer, Joshua A. Klein, said yes. The required disclosures, he said, provided information where and when they were most valuable.\n\nJustice Neil M. Gorsuch responded that the state had other ways to convey its message. \u201cIf you\u2019re trying to educate a class of persons about their rights,\u201d he said, \u201cit\u2019s pretty unusual to force a private speaker to do that for you under the First Amendment.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe California Legislature found that the roughly 200 centers in the state used \u201cintentionally deceptive advertising and counseling practices that often confuse, misinform and even intimidate women from making fully informed, time-sensitive decisions about critical health care.\u201d\n\nJustice Sotomayor said she had examined one center\u2019s website and found it misleading. She said it showed what appeared to be a nurse in front of an ultrasound device, mentioned abortion and indicated that the center complied with medical privacy laws.\n\n\u201cIf a reasonable person could look at this website and think that you\u2019re giving medical advice,\u201d she asked, \u201cwould the unlicensed notice be wrong?\u201d\n\nMr. Farris said unlicensed centers do not provide medical services but only advice about pregnancy.\n\nJustice Kennedy was critical of Justice Sotomayor\u2019s outside research. \u201cIn this case,\u201d he said, \u201cI didn\u2019t go beyond the record to look on the internet because I don\u2019t think we should do that.\u201d\n\nJustice Gorsuch said the state could address misleading speech more directly, through lawsuits and prosecutions. That \u201cputs the burden on the government to prove that someone has abused their free-speech rights,\u201d he said. The California law, by contrast, he said, \u201crequires you to compel speech from someone else that implicates First Amendment concerns.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd this court,\u201d he added, \u201cis normally pretty jealously protective of speech.\u201d\n\nA unanimous three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, upheld both parts of the law.\n\n\u201cCalifornia has a substantial interest in the health of its citizens, including ensuring that its citizens have access to and adequate information about constitutionally protected medical services like abortion,\u201d Judge Dorothy W. Nelson wrote in an opinion upholding the requirement that licensed clinics post a notice about obtaining abortions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe notice informs the reader only of the existence of publicly funded family-planning services,\u201d Judge Nelson wrote. \u201cIt does not contain any more speech than necessary, nor does it encourage, suggest or imply that women should use those state-funded services.\u201d\n\nOther federal appeals courts have struck down similar laws, saying that the government could find other ways to inform women about their options.\n\nJeffrey B. Wall, a lawyer for the federal government, took a middle ground. He said requiring centers not licensed by the state to say so was acceptable. But he objected to requiring licensed centers to provide information about abortion.\n\n\u201cWhat the First Amendment does not allow and what California has done is to require pregnancy centers to make disclosures about services they do not provide and that would violate their most deeply held beliefs without any showing by the state that it truly needs to compel speech rather than speak its own message,\u201d he said.\n\nThe case, National Institute of Family and Life Advocates v. Becerra, No. 16-1140, is in some ways similar to one argued last year concerning a Colorado baker who refused to make a custom wedding cake for a same-sex couple.\n\nBoth cases arose from religious objections but were pursued as free-speech challenges to state laws.", "title": "Supreme Court Warily Eyes California Law Involving Abortion and Free Speech", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court rejected on Monday a second emergency application from Republican lawmakers in Pennsylvania seeking to overturn decisions from that state\u2019s highest court, which had ruled that Pennsylvania\u2019s congressional map had been warped by partisan gerrymandering and then imposed one of its own.\n\nThe ruling means a new map drawn by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court will very likely be in effect in this year\u2019s elections, setting the stage for possible gains by Democrats. Under the current map, Republicans hold 12 seats while Democrats hold five and are expected to pick up another when the result of a special election last week is certified.\n\nThe latest application was denied by the full Supreme Court without comment or noted dissents.\n\nIn a terse ruling in January, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court struck down the state\u2019s congressional map, saying that it \u201cclearly, plainly and palpably\u201d violated the state\u2019s Constitution. The court told state lawmakers to redraw the state\u2019s 18 House districts, which favored Republicans.\n\nPennsylvania Republicans asked the Supreme Court to block that ruling, but their request was rejected last month by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr.", "title": "Supreme Court Won\u2019t Block New Pennsylvania Voting Maps", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Supreme Court on Monday turned down a request that it take a fresh look at whether the death penalty is constitutional anywhere in the nation.\n\nThe court also refused to consider a narrower question in the same case: Whether Arizona\u2019s capital sentencing system, which appears to make virtually all murderers eligible for the death penalty, violates the Constitution.\n\nIn a 2015 dissent, Justice Stephen G. Breyer had urged his colleagues to revisit the death penalty, saying that \u201cit is highly likely\u201d that it violates the Eighth Amendment, which bars cruel and unusual punishments. He said that there was evidence that innocent people have been executed, that death row exonerations were frequent, that death sentences were imposed arbitrarily and that the capital justice system was warped by racial discrimination and politics.\n\nOnly Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined the 2015 dissent, and the issue does not seem to have gained traction in the intervening years.", "title": "Supreme Court Won\u2019t Hear Challenges to Arizona\u2019s Death Penalty Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "The justices largely agreed that the oddly shaped Maryland congressional district at issue, drawn by Democrats in the Legislature, was an extreme example of distasteful political gamesmanship.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t seem to have any internal logic,\u201d Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said of the district, which stretches from northwestern Maryland to the Washington suburbs. He added that the district had been redrawn in a way \u201cthat prefers one party over another.\u201d\n\nJustice Elena Kagan said it sometimes might be hard to tell when politics played too large a role, but she said that was not a problem here. \u201cHowever much you think is too much,\u201d she said, \u201cthis case is too much.\u201d\n\nBut it was not at all clear that the court was prepared to say the Constitution may place limits on extreme partisan gerrymandering, where the party in power draws voting districts to give itself an outsize advantage in future elections.\n\nThe Supreme Court has never struck down a voting district as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander. A ruling allowing such challenges could revolutionize American politics.\n\nWednesday\u2019s arguments provided little information about whether the justices are prepared to take that step. Indeed, if arguments in October in the earlier case, a Democratic challenge of a Republican map from Wisconsin, had heartened opponents of extreme partisan gerrymandering, Wednesday\u2019s arguments in the Maryland case only served to confuse them.\n\n\n\nJustice Anthony M. Kennedy, who probably holds the crucial vote in both cases, returned to a theme he had pursued in the arguments in the Wisconsin case, asking whether a law that required partisan gerrymandering in so many words would violate the Constitution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSteven M. Sullivan, Maryland\u2019s solicitor general, said it would.\n\nJustice Kennedy asked, \u201cHow is this case different?\u201d Mr. Sullivan said the redistricting law did not expressly call for a partisan advantage.\n\nJustice Kennedy was not satisfied. \u201cSo if you hide the evidence of what you\u2019re doing, then you\u2019re going to prevail?\u201d he asked.\n\nThe court\u2019s surprise announcement in December that it would hear the second partisan gerrymandering case, Benisek v. Lamone, No. 17-333, led to much speculation about what the move meant for the challengers in the Wisconsin case, Gill v. Whitford, No. 16-1161. But Wednesday\u2019s argument did almost nothing to clear up the mystery of why the justices decided to hear a second case.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf there was a hint about where the court was headed in the Wisconsin case, it came from Justice Breyer, who suggested that the court schedule a new round of arguments in both cases, along with one from North Carolina, in the term that will start in October. His question suggested that at least some of the challengers could not demonstrate that they had suffered the sort of direct injury that gave them standing to sue.\n\n\u201cWhat would you think,\u201d Justice Breyer asked, \u201cof taking the three cases and setting them for re-argument on the question of standing and there we\u2019d have all three variations in front of us?\u201d he asked a lawyer for the challengers, Michael B. Kimberly. But Justice Breyer\u2019s real audience seemed to be his colleagues, none of whom spoke up in support of the proposal.\n\nJustice Breyer, who seems ready to allow constitutional challenges based on partisan gerrymandering, probably would not have made the suggestion had his views prevailed when the justices took their preliminary vote in the Wisconsin case in October.\n\nSeveral justices said the Maryland case was plagued by procedural and practical problems.\n\nJustices Ruth Bader Ginsburg said there was little reason for the court to rule now because its decision would come too late to affect the 2018 elections.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s much too late, even if you were successful, for there to be any change for the 2018 election,\u201d Justice Ginsburg told Mr. Kimberly. Justice Kennedy seemed to agree. Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Sonia Sotomayor said the challengers had waited too long to file suit.\n\nMr. Kimberly, representing the plaintiffs, argued that Democratic state lawmakers there had redrawn a district in northwestern Maryland to retaliate against citizens who supported its longtime incumbent, Representative Roscoe G. Bartlett, a Republican. That retaliation, he said, violated the First Amendment by diluting their voting power in a district that had been controlled by Republicans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bartlett had won his 2010 race by a margin of 28 percentage points. In 2012, he lost to Representative John Delaney, a Democrat, by a 21-point margin.\n\nSeveral justices said the evidence of extreme partisan gerrymandering was strong.\n\n\u201cPeople were very upfront about what they were trying to do here, which was to create another Democratic district,\u201d Justice Kagan said. \u201cAnd they did that.\u201d\n\nIn the past, some justices have said the court should stay out of such political disputes. Others have said partisan gerrymanders may violate the Constitution.\n\nJustice Kennedy has taken a middle position, leaving the door to such challenges open a crack, though he has never voted to sustain one.\n\nIn 2004, he wrote in a concurring opinion on a gerrymandering case that he might consider a challenge if there were \u201ca workable standard\u201d to decide when such tactics crossed a constitutional line. But he said he had not seen such a standard.\n\nIn the Maryland case, a divided three-judge panel of the United States District Court in Maryland in August denied the challengers\u2019 request for a preliminary injunction. In dissent, Judge Paul V. Niemeyer, who ordinarily sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., wrote that partisan gerrymandering was a cancer on democracy.\n\n\u201cThe widespread nature of gerrymandering in modern politics is matched by the almost universal absence of those who will defend its negative effect on our democracy,\u201d Judge Niemeyer said. \u201cIndeed, both Democrats and Republicans have decried it when wielded by their opponents but nonetheless continue to gerrymander in their own self-interest when given the opportunity.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe problem is cancerous,\u201d he wrote, \u201cundermining the fundamental tenets of our form of democracy.\u201d", "title": "Supreme Court, Again Weighing Map Warped by Politics, Shows No Consensus", "authors": ["Adam Liptak"]} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 The Mets may be without starter Jason Vargas, to begin the season. Vargas, whom the Mets signed to a two-year, $16-million contract last month, will undergo surgery on Tuesday in New York to remove a fractured hamate bone in his right hand, the team said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nVargas, who throws with his left hand, was hit with a line drive on the base of his right hand when pitching in a minor league spring training game on Friday. Doctors recommended the removal of the broken bone instead of pitching with it.\n\nThe Mets said Vargas was expected to resume throwing five days after surgery. Vargas may not miss much time, but he will almost certainly begin the season on the disabled list. Rahul Gandhi, an opposition leader, wrote on Twitter at the time that anybody who \u201cspeaks against\u201d the Bharatiya Janata Party and Hindu nationalist groups affiliated with it are \u201cattacked & even killed.\u201d\n\nThat theory was back into the spotlight on Friday when the authorities detained Naveen Kumar, the founder of the far-right group Hindu Yuva Sena, according to Bijay Kumar Singh, the leader of a special team formed to investigate Ms. Lankesh\u2019s death.\n\n\u201cHe is in our custody for interrogation,\u201d Mr. Singh said by telephone on Saturday.\n\nDuring her career, Ms. Lankesh, 55, had occasionally been sued after being accused of defamation by leaders of the Bharatiya Janata Party. Why should it? The place stayed open late and was my refuge from the elements and sketchy characters while I waited for my train to Long Island.\n\nTariq worked nights. He was friendly, good-natured and chatty. He often asked how my day had been. Some nights he talked about his wife and their young daughter and how hard it was for an immigrant family to survive in New York.\n\nAt some point he started giving me muffins, discreetly passing a brown bag over the counter.\n\nI bought something. I tipped. I got a free muffin. Sometimes I got apple turnovers, cheese Danish or doughnuts instead. He expected cash. I didn\u2019t say \u201cno\u201d to free pastry.\n\nI was inadvertently rolled into a cinnamon bun of casual bribery.", "title": "Sweet Corruption", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Facebook page for Waymore Post-Conviction LLC \u2014 a legal firm that purported to assist the wrongfully convicted \u2014 is topped with the slogan: \u201cTake the correct road home \u2026 Your family is waiting.\u201d\n\nThe page shows a photograph of two young children kissing a man who seems to be their father.\n\n\u201cWaymore P.C. will review the entire case file and transcripts for a criminal case,\u201d it says. \u201cAt the conclusion, a detailed report outlining the issues are provided to the defendant.\u201d\n\nBut according to prosecutors in Brooklyn, Waymore Post-Conviction was run by a man who had no training as a lawyer and stole as much as $15,000 from hopeful convicts and their families from 2012 to 2016. On Tuesday, the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office unsealed an indictment against the man, Kenneth Moore, charging him with crimes that included larceny, fraud, forgery and the unauthorized practice of a profession.\n\nWorking from an office in Bushwick, prosecutors said, Mr. Moore, 53, of Queens, targeted inmates serving long sentences, sending them certified letters in which he offered to file post-conviction motions on their behalf. His victims included prisoners in New York, North Carolina, Kansas and Virginia and his pitch was simple, according to the indictment: Mr. Moore would ask the inmates\u2019 relatives to sign contracts with him and pay him 80 percent of his standard fee of $5,000 to $10,000 in advance of any work. But in 16 instances, prosecutors said, he never filed a motion. In two others, they added, Mr. Moore submitted fraudulent briefs, using the forged signature of a real attorney who had no idea the papers had been filed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a \u201cparticularly egregious case,\u201d prosecutors said, Mr. Moore persuaded a defendant to hire him instead of using the Innocence Project, the well-regarded New York organization that was founded in 1992 to reverse wrongful convictions. Eric Gonzalez, the Brooklyn district attorney, said he took the conduct personally because his office has a special team devoted to wrongful convictions, the Conviction Review Unit, that has become a national model.", "title": "Swindler Exploits the \u2018Hope of Inmates,\u2019 Prosecutor Says", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "AINISSA, Syria \u2014 At the headquarters of the Syrian Democratic Forces in Ainissa, the normally bustling offices were thinly populated on a recent day as the Kurdish-dominated coalition shifted its fighters to battle against the Turkish invasion in northwestern Syria.\n\nHaqi Kobani, the deputy commander of the S.D.F., was holding down the fort in his capacious office, where a portrait of Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned leader of the Kurdistan Workers\u2019 Party, or P.K.K., had pride of place. While Kurds hold most of the leadership positions, the S.D.F. is a majority Arab force now, engaged with the Americans in the fight against the Islamic State, mostly in Arab rather than Kurdish areas of Syria.\n\n\u201cArabs love Abdullah Ocalan too,\u201d Mr. Kobani said, casting a glance at the portrait. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing hidden from our side. Everything we do is obvious and clear to the world.\u201d\n\nMany Arabs would probably differ about their love of Mr. Ocalan, whose socialist, radically egalitarian philosophy of governance holds sway throughout the autonomous region, known as Rojava, that the Kurds have carved out in Syria, with the help of the American-led international coalition. Their uneasy alliance, held together by the fight against the Islamic State, could be severely tested as the Kurds expand their control.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKurdish aspirations will also come up against an implacable Turkey, which regards a self-governing Kurdish region across its southern border, and controlled by the P.K.K., as nothing short of an existential threat. Those fighters were detained last year by the Army of Islam, the group that controls Douma, the main city in Eastern Ghouta.\n\nThe evacuation was the first such concession by the rebels in Eastern Ghouta, a collection of towns and agricultural areas adjacent to the capital, Damascus. The agreement, struck with a delegation that accompanied a United Nations aid convoy into Douma on Friday, came as the rebels were under intense pressure.\n\nGovernment forces continued to advance in a ground campaign aiming to split Douma and the town of Harasta from the rest of the enclave. Many had taken refuge in Turkey in recent years because of their opposition to the Y.P.G., and 15 people had also traveled from Afrin for the meeting, organizers said.\n\nTURKEY Gaziantep Manbij Afrin Raqqa Aleppo SYRIA LEBANON Damascus/ Ghouta 100 miles\n\nTurkish officials will post Turkish troops and Free Syrian Army fighters to secure the wider region but intend to leave the internal security of the city to the local police, according to Abdolaziz Tammo, the Kurdish politician who organized the meeting. TAG Heuer, however, has an authentic connection to motorsport because it became the first watch brand to be associated with a Formula One team when Heuer became the sponsor and official timekeeper of Scuderia Ferrari in 1971.\n\nThat legacy is on display this week at the Geneva International Motor Show, where the brand has erected a 3,300-square-foot stand presenting historic and contemporary timepieces as well as several racecars. Here, Jean-Claude Biver, president of the LVMH Watch Division and chief executive of TAG Heuer, explains the brand\u2019s new automotive partnership.\n\nThis is your fourth consecutive year exhibiting at the Geneva motor show. Why is it important for TAG Heuer to have a presence here?\n\nIt\u2019s one of the major automobile shows in the world, and, as such, it is already important. No. 2: It\u2019s important because it\u2019s next door \u2014 we couldn\u2019t be closer. And No. 3, it\u2019s important because since the end of the 1950s, TAG Heuer has constantly partnered with automobiles, mainly racing cars. Part of our DNA is motorsport.", "title": "TAG Heuer Displays Its Motorsport Legacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The focus is still on multiple strands of elaborately, sometimes confusingly plotted detection (with more red herrings than necessary). But the body count has come down, and an improbable, oddly moving love story between the emotionally damaged Swedish detective Saga (Sofia Helin) and her new Danish partner (Thure Lindhardt) has become central to the show. The true constant is Ms. Helin\u2019s tightly controlled performance \u2014 without any showboating, she continues to find both heartbreak and humor in a difficult character.\n\n\u2018Jordskott\u2019\n\nThis Swedish series uses the house style of Nordic noir \u2014 subdued but highly charged, like a dream always on the verge of a nightmare \u2014 but it crosses a typical conspiracy-minded crime story with a spooky eco-horror fable. The resulting hybrid, a police procedural with elements of contagion thriller and vampire tale, is handled so adroitly that it requires surprisingly little suspension of disbelief.\n\nThat credibility flows from the trio of characters at the show\u2019s center: Eva (Moa Gammel), the detective who in Season 1 becomes infected with the parasite that slowly turns humans into forest creatures; Wass (Goran Ragnerstam), the federal cop who secretly works for the alternately benign and threatening forces of nature; and Tom (Richard Forsgren), the stouthearted and hopelessly square local cop who pines for Eva. All three return, and are again excellent, in Season 2, now available on the horror streaming site Shudder.\n\n\u2018OCTB\u2019\n\nThis Web series, named after the real-life Organized Crime and Triad Bureau of the Hong Kong police, was such a faithful evocation of 1990s-vintage Hong Kong police dramas that its 30 episodes reportedly drew 1.3 billion views on the Chinese video service Youku \u2014 and that was before Netflix picked it up for streaming in the rest of the world.\n\nThe story \u2014 about an undercover cop who gets pulled back into the game one last time, posing as a rising gang boss \u2014 is set in the years before the British handover of Hong Kong in 1997. The sprawling series\u2019s time-capsule quality is accentuated by an enormous cast full of performers familiar to Hong Kong action aficionados, including Carrie Ng, Frankie Ng Chi-Hung Ng, Philip Chan and Ng Man-Tat. Jordan Chan, who played Chicken Chiu in Andrew Lau\u2019s \u201cYoung and Dangerous\u201d movies in the \u201990s, stars here as another bird \u2014 the detective\u2019s mob-boss name is Phoenix.", "title": "TV Shows to Watch From Hong Kong, Brazil, Sweden and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Albany has a checkered record when it comes to sexual harassment, on both sides of the aisle, perhaps most notably of the disgraced Democratic power broker, Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez. Mr. Lopez was accused in 2012 of sexually harassing several female staff members, graphic incidents, including groping, which later led to his resignation.\n\nIn 2014, a Buffalo-area assemblyman, Dennis H. Gabryszak, a Democrat, stepped down amid accusations that he sexually harassed several female staff members. In 2016, Angela M. Wozniak, a first-term Republican from western New York, was censured after an affair with a male staffer; she did not seek re-election.\n\nAnd as recently as last fall, the former Assemblyman Steven T. McLaughlin, an outspoken Republican, was disciplined for asking a female staff member to send him naked pictures of herself.\n\nDuring the Lopez scandal, Sheldon Silver, then the speaker of the Assembly, was also harshly criticized for authorizing secret financial settlements to harassment victims. Such payments are now the subject of proposals from both Mr. Cuomo and Senate Republicans, who introduced a bill last week that would outlaw such confidential settlements, echoing a similar push by Senate Democrats in January.\n\nThe Assembly has already passed internal rules banning confidential settlements, and has made other reforms, including the mandatory reporting of any sexual harassment complaint. It, too, is expected to introduce legislation confronting sexual harassment on Monday, after establishing a work group of members last month to study the issue.\n\nThe seeming commonality of purpose greatly increases the likelihood of a deal on the issue, even if the question of who will be doing the negotiating remains unsettled.\n\nThe traditional \u201cthree men in a room\u201d \u2014 Mr. Cuomo; the Senate majority leader, John J. The program for \u201cDancing Platform, Praying Grounds,\u201d he added, \u201cis about cracking that open.\u201d\n\nSt. Mark\u2019s, as dancegoers know, is not the only church in which downtown dance has thrived. The other prime example: Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village, where the trailblazing Judson Dance Theater sprang up in 1962, giving rise to postmodern dance, and where Movement Research has hosted free weekly showings for over 25 years. A new partnership in a similar vein has been developing at Cadman Congregational Church in Clinton Hill, home to Brooklyn Studios for Dance since 2015.\n\nMr. Wilson said he was intrigued not just by churches but also by other spiritual sites hospitable to not-necessarily-spiritual arts, such as the Jewish-affiliated 92nd Street Y and the former Sufi mosque in SoHo that once housed Dia Center for the Arts. For Ms. Hussie-Taylor, the complex subject always leads back to St. Mark\u2019s: \u201cWhere are we actually standing?\u201d she said. \u201cWhat is this place? You could go in a million directions, but that\u2019s a question we\u2019ve returned to again and again.\u201d\n\nMr. Wilson, 50, who grew up in Milwaukee and founded the company Fist & Heel Performance Group in 1989, has long explored spiritual traditions in his own work, particularly within African and African-American cultures. He said his dances are guided by two lines of inquiry: \u201cWhat is the relationship between postmodern dance and African diasporic culture? And what is the relationship between Protestant Christianity and African diasporic religions? Even if the piece seems like it has nothing to do with either of those, they creep back in there.\u201d", "title": "Take Me to Church and Let Me Dance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "Health tech companies are making a big push to digitize medicine, introducing novel tools like digital pills that track when patients take their drugs and smart spoons that can automatically adjust to hand tremors.\n\nNow they want some patients to get prescription treatments from the app store as well.\n\nLater this year, doctors treating patients addicted to substances like cocaine and amphetamines will be able to prescribe Reset, an app that gives patients lessons to help them modify their behavior. The Food and Drug Administration cleared it in September as the first mobile medical app to help treat substance-use disorders.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s all the things you would traditionally associate with a pill or any other medication,\u201d said Dr. Corey McCann, the chief executive of Pear Therapeutics, the start-up behind Reset. \u201cBut it just so happens to be a piece of software.\u201d", "title": "Take This App and Call Me in the Morning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "In Ava DuVernay\u2019s much-anticipated Disney movie adaptation of the book, which comes out Friday, Meg is being played by an African-American actress. That\u2019s huge: It\u2019s thrilling, and important, for all children to see a story where a young black girl saves the day.\n\nWhat\u2019s less inspiring is the Hollywood makeover that Meg\u2019s three mentors received. In the book, their appearances range from frumpy to \u201clittle more than a shimmer.\u201d In the movie, they\u2019re played by Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling and Oprah Winfrey, who was cast, Ms. DuVernay has said, not in spite of her celebrity but because of it.\n\nIn an interview, the director said that the character of Mrs. Which embodies what Ms. Winfrey has taught over the years \u201cabout owning your light and conquering darkness and how we have to power ourselves through this life in a certain way and look out for each other.\u201d\n\nBut are young filmgoers going to know Ms. Winfrey as the SuperSoul Sunday light-bringer, the warrior for women who told an exultant Golden Globes audience that \u201cwhat I know for sure is that speaking your truth is the most powerful tool we all have\u201d? Or will they recognize her as the woman handing out tacos in Weight Watchers ads, above text listing how many pounds each fiesta-goer has lost?\n\nMs. Sherer, of Weight Watchers, gave a firm \u201cabsolutely not\u201d when I asked if the timing of the Weight Watchers announcement had anything to do with the release of the film. But when the board member/part owner/celebrity endorser of a commercial weight-loss program stars in a movie aimed squarely at young women \u2014 the same demographic that her program is trying to tempt with free memberships \u2014 what\u2019s the message? Is it love yourself, faults and all, or is it that maybe there should be a little less of you to love?\n\nI\u2019ll take my daughters to see \u201cA Wrinkle in Time\u201d and cross my fingers that they\u2019ve somehow escaped those Weight Watchers commercials, along with the idea that celebrations, and tacos, are reserved for women who fit themselves into society\u2019s narrow constraints of pretty. I\u2019ll hope that one version of \u201cIT\u201d \u2014 the pervasive, pernicious notion that thin equals happy \u2014 doesn\u2019t hook them in, the way it hooked me, that they won\u2019t spend their 20s on a diet.\n\nBecause what I know for sure is this: I wish I had treated my body with love and respect, rather than blowing money I didn\u2019t have on a futile effort to fix it. I wish that I\u2019d respected my body\u2019s strength and health, and insisted that the world needed to expand its views of what was acceptable much more than I needed to shrink.", "title": "Opinion | Take Your Daughter to the Movies, Not to Weight Watchers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "The company is also well capitalized with positive free cash flow and no debt.\n\nRoom to Grow? The number of smartphone users to continues to grow but Spotify said it only reaches a small portion within the countries it operates. The company is also working with auto makers to integrate its platform with cars, where more than 30 percent of music listening happens.\n\nApple and Amazon are a big risk to Spotify\u2019s business? Tech giants like Apple, Amazon and Google each have their own streaming music services. Spotify\u2019s service is delivered over Apple\u2019s iPhone and Amazon\u2019s Echo. Those companies could prioritize their own services on their devices.\n\nWhat is the next date to watch? March 26. That\u2019s the date when Spotify will release first-quarter results and 2018 guidance.\n\nWhat is \u201calgotorial?\u201d It\u2019s the term that Spotify\u2019s head of research and development used to describe the mix of algorithms and humans that Spotify uses to curate its music.\n\nPhoto\n\nWells Fargo\u2019s C.E.O. gets a pay raise.\n\nRegulators recently penalized Wells Fargo for years of misconduct, but on Wednesday, the bank gave its C.E.O. a hearty pay rise. How did that happen?\n\nThe numbers: Timothy J. Sloan\u2019s compensation for 2017 totaled $17.6 million, a 35 percent increase from the $13 million he earned in 2016. His stock award for 2017 was $15 million, a big jump from $10.5 million in 2016.\n\nIs the increase justified, given the bank\u2019s issues? Wells Fargo would no doubt point to the fact that Mr. Sloan decided to forgo a cash bonus in 2017. John G. Stumpf, a former C.E.O., got a $4 million cash bonus in 2015, for instance. Also, Mr. Sloan\u2019s stock award was set in February last year and reflects his promotion in 2016 to C.E.O. And if Wells Fargo slips up badly over the next three years, Mr. Sloan may not get the entire $15 million stock award.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow does Mr. Sloan\u2019s pay stack up against others? He is making less than the C.E.O. of Bank of America, Brian T. Moynihan, who made $21.8 million last year. But Mr. Sloan is making quite a bit more than the chief executives of large regional banks. US Bank\u2019s chief executive, Andrew Cecere, had 2017 compensation of $12 million.\n\nBut Mr. Sloan looks overpaid on a new metric that public companies must provide. This yardstick compares a C.E.O.\u2019s pay with that of the median employee\u2019s pay. Mr. Sloan\u2019s 2017 pay was 291 times that of Wells Fargo\u2019s median earner. That is above the 250 times for Mr. Moynihan. And Mr. Sloan\u2019s ratio is far in excess of Mr. Cecere\u2019s 205 times.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nThiel on Trade\n\nOne of President Trump\u2019s most prominent supporters in the business world on Thursday said the United States would have the upper hand against China in a trade skirmish.\n\nPeter Thiel, a technology entrepreneur with libertarian leanings, told the Economic Club of New York that the United States doesn\u2019t export enough to China to make it vulnerable to Chinese retaliation. If Mr. Trump imposed trade restrictions on Chinese goods, as he may in the coming weeks, China could do the same to United States exports. Mr. Thiel seemed unfazed by that. \u201cIt\u2019s quite unclear where China can reciprocate because we are exporting so little,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Thiel\u2019s views echo those of Mr. Trump.\n\nThe American exports to China are not small. They totaled $184 billion in the 12 months through the end of September 2017. That makes China the United States\u2019 fourth-largest export market after the European Union, Canada and Mexico. The United States, however, imports far more from China than it exports, which means the deficit with China is far larger than it is with Mexico and the European Union.\n\n- Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nTheranos and its C.E.O. are accused of fraud by the S.E.C.\n\nThe blood-testing start-up was once one of Silicon Valley\u2019s most lauded unicorns. But, the S.E.C. says, it deceived investors about what its tech could do and how much business it did. And its founder Elizabeth Holmes \u2014 a Stanford dropout who was compared favorably to Steve Jobs \u2014 has been stripped of her C.E.O. title and her shares.\n\nMore from John Carreyrou of the WSJ, who first reported on issues at Theranos:\n\nMany Theranos investors have lost the entire value of their investment. The losses for [Rupert] Murdoch, once the company\u2019s largest investor, total more than $100 million, people familiar with the matter said. The S.E.C. said in its civil lawsuit Wednesday that Theranos was \u201con the verge of bankruptcy\u201d in late 2017. The company has been kept afloat by a loan from a private-equity firm that is secured by Theranos\u2019s patents.\n\nMatt Levine of Bloomberg View reminds us about the company\u2019s other victims: patients.\n\nPeter Henning\u2019s take: The S.E.C.\u2019s case shows that it considers privately held companies as capable of defrauding investors as publicly traded ones.\n\nElsewhere in S.E.C. violations: The agency charged a former Equifax executive with insider trading, saying he sold shares after learning of the company\u2019s data breach before it was publicly reported.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat will be on Larry Kudlow\u2019s agenda?\n\nIt\u2019s official: The CNBC commentator will become President Trump\u2019s chief economic adviser, replacing Gary Cohn. But what will Mr. Kudlow \u2014 who on TV is an ardent supporter of free trade \u2014 push for?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe supports a strong dollar and tariffs that make exceptions for allies like Canada and Mexico. And he\u2019s in favor of permanently extending the Republican tax cuts for individuals.\n\nAs for his stance on China, here\u2019s what he told CNBC:\n\n\u201cA thought that I have is the United States could lead a coalition of large trading partners and allies against China, or to let China know that they\u2019re breaking the rules left and right.\u201d\n\nOne thing to watch for: whether his past admission of substance abuse would affect his work. \u201cWe\u2019ll see how that plays out,\u201d Mr. Kudlow said.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner: Mark Hamrick, Bankrate.com\u2019s senior economic analyst, writes, \u201cIt remains to be seen whether Kudlow can step into the role of a virtual moderating influence in this administration.\u201d And Noah Smith of Bloomberg View asserts, \u201cIt also seems like there are just so few credible economic thinkers willing to stand up and sign their name to the Trump economic agenda.\u201d\n\nElsewhere in economic policy: U.S. companies have few ways around the proposed metals tariffs. And U.S. allies might emphasize their toughness against China to win tariff exemptions.\n\nSome of Mr. Kudlow\u2019s economic predictions that did not bear out.\n\nMr. Kudlow has prognosticated on many economic and political issues, often in a way that mirrors his future boss. His predictions, which will soon carry new weight as the president\u2019s top economic adviser, have not always been on the mark.\n\nOur colleagues Deborah Solomon and Kitty Bennett take a look at some of Mr. Kudlow\u2019s not-so-on-the-money calls. Here are a few of the ones they found:\n\nIn 2005\n\n\u201cAll the bond bears have been dead wrong in predicting sky-high mortgage rates. So have all the bubbleheads who expect housing-price crashes in Las Vegas or Naples, Fla., to bring down the consumer, the rest of the economy and the entire stock market.\u201d\n\n(Well, we all know what happened. By 2008, home prices were in a free-fall, threatening to plunge the financial system and the economy into the abyss.)\n\nIn 1993\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no question that President Clinton\u2019s across-the-board tax increases on labor, capital and energy will throw a wet blanket over the recovery and depress the economy\u2019s long-run potential to grow.\u201d\n\n(The period between 1990 and 1999 was the longest bull market in history. The S&P 500 more than tripled during that time.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2015\n\n\u201cGiven the recent rise of presidential candidate Donald Trump, we should all be thankful that stocks haven\u2019t plunged. Trump\u2019s agenda of trade protectionism, dollar devaluation, and immigrant deportation is completely anti-growth. It\u2019s like Fortress America in an economy that is completely globalized and where the U.S. must compete in the worldwide race for capital and labor. Trump\u2019s policies don\u2019t fit.\u201d\n\n(President Trump was elected and the stock market has only climbed. )\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 How Steve Schwarzman of Blackstone became a close adviser to President Trump on China \u2014 but lost the tariff battle. (WaPo)\n\n\u2022 After Rex Tillerson\u2019s firing, Washington is wondering if H.R. McMaster, John Kelly or Jeff Sessions might go next. And allies are hoping that the cabinet reshuffle will clarify American foreign policy.\n\n\u2022 Moving from the C suite to Washington is tougher than it looks. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 The Democrat Conor Lamb narrowly won a special House election in southwestern Pennsylvania, an area that Mr. Trump carried handily in 2016. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The administration is considering Randy Quarles, the Fed\u2019s vice chairman for supervision, as the next head of the Financial Stability Board, unnamed sources say. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump has discussed including protections for Dreamers in a spending bill. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 A Trump Organization lawyer was involved in an arbitration proceeding involving Stormy Daniels, according to documents. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Jeff Sessions is considering whether to fire the former F.B.I. deputy director Andrew G. McCabe days before he would retire, unnamed sources say. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy did John Skipper leave ESPN abruptly?\n\nAn extortion plot related to his cocaine addiction.\n\nMr. Skipper told The Hollywood Reporter:\n\n\u201cIn December, someone from whom I bought cocaine attempted to extort me.\u201d \u201cThey threatened me, and I understood immediately that threat put me and my family at risk, and this exposure would put my professional life at risk as well. I foreclosed that possibility by disclosing the details to my family, and then when I discussed it with Bob, he and I agreed that I had placed the company in an untenable position and as a result, I should resign.\u201d\n\nAlibaba is exploring a China listing.\n\nThe WSJ reports that the Chinese online shopping giant is working on a plan to list shares in its home market. Such a listing would come nearly four years after Alibaba went public on the New York Stock Exchange, in what is the still the world\u2019s largest initial public offering.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Alibaba is incorporated in the Cayman Islands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 China also doesn\u2019t allow companies with dual-class share structure to list in the country.\n\nContext\n\nAlibaba\u2019s plans come as \u201cChinese authorities are trying to lure some of the country\u2019s technology stalwarts back to its capital markets,\u201d The WSJ reports. Alibaba\u2019s stock has jumped nearly 200 percent since it went public in 2014, gains that most Chinese investors have missed out on.\n\nShares of Alibaba are up 3.1 percent Thursday.\n\nFormer Deutsche Bank trader pleads guilty to Euribor rigging\n\nChristian Bittar, a former senior trader at Deutsche Bank, pleaded guilty earlier this month to conspiracy to defraud in the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate known as Euribor, the Serious Fraud Office said on Thursday.\n\nA court in Britain lifted an order on Thursday that prevented the media from reporting his plea.\n\n\u201cIt would not be right to make comment prior to the trial of the remaining defendants and prior to Mr. Bittar\u2019s sentencing,\u201d David Savell, a lawyer for Mr. Bittar, said.\n\nDeutsche Bank agreed to pay $2.5 billion in penalties in 2015 related to the benchmark interest rate rigging scandal.\n\nA trial of five other traders is set for next month.\n\n- Chad Bray\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Dodd-Frank rollback takes an onward step\n\nThe Senate, in a rare show of bipartisanship, voted 67-31 to relax regulations on small to medium-sized banks. What the bill includes:\n\n\u2022 Raising the threshold for \u201csystemically important\u201d banks to $250 billion in assets, up from $50 billion\n\n\u2022 Exempting firms with less than $10 billion in assets from the Volcker rule\n\nBut the House may want a more aggressive version that would curtail the power of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. That could endanger the proposed overhaul, with the analyst Brian Gardner telling the NYT, \u201cIf the House overreaches in its effort to amend the Crapo bill, it could slow down the bill\u2019s progress.\u201d\n\nElsewhere in banking: Why another Bear Stearns-like collapse isn\u2019t likely, but another crisis is.\n\nPhoto\n\nToys \u201cR\u201d Us is one of Amazon\u2019s biggest casualties\n\nThe 70-year-old company\u2019s plans to close or sell its stores in the U.S. and Britain show how hard life has become for bricks-and-mortar retailers. The collapse could put over 30,000 U.S. jobs at risk.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore on what happened from Michael Corkery of the NYT:\n\nWeighed down by the debt that its owners heaped on the company when they bought it, Toys \u201cR\u201d Us has not adequately invested in its fading stores and e-commerce operations. Unable to compete with other retailers, it has lost market share to better capitalized toy sellers.\n\nSpeaking of Amazon: The company has become shorthand for \u201cdisruption\u201d across industries.\n\nPhoto\n\nTech companies are growing up (slowly)\n\nThe current generation of Silicon Valley giants started out with an ethos of revolution first, fixes afterward. (Remember Facebook\u2019s \u201cmove fast and break things\u201d motto?) But Facebook, Google and others are becoming more bureaucratic, according to our columnist Kevin Roose \u2014 and that\u2019s a good thing.\n\nAmong the latest signs of change in their attitudes:\n\n\u2022 Facebook\u2019s taking down accounts related to Britain First, a far-right group accused of inciting anti-Muslim hatred, and talking about the limits on its commitment to being an open platform.\n\n\u2022 YouTube plans to put info from Wikipedia alongside conspiracy videos (even if it didn\u2019t tell the Wikimedia Foundation).\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Siri made its debut before it was ready, former Apple executives assert, and internal struggles at the iPhone maker have left its voice assistant behind Amazon\u2019s Alexa and the Google Assistant.
