The top menu bar of my Mac has become cluttered with these little icons that I rarely use and are more distracting than anything. Is there a way to turn them off?\n\nA. Most of the icons clustered on the right side of the Mac\u2019s menu bar \u2014 \u201cstatus icons,\u201d as Apple calls them \u2014 can be removed, rearranged or restored according to your personal preferences. The icons are meant to provide quick access to controls like the Mac\u2019s network, Bluetooth and AirPlay settings, and third-part apps may also add their own mini-menus up there. Spotlight search, Siri and the Mac\u2019s Notifications Center are typically on the far right side of the menu bar.\n\nYou can remove unwanted menu-bar icons in a couple of ways. When you click on a status icon and open the preferences for the app, you may get a check box to turn off the menu-bar display. (You should be able to restore the icon in the program\u2019s preferences if you later change your mind.)", "title": "Taking Items Off the Mac\u2019s Menu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Yayo was poring over a pair of hands, one of the three to five she tends to any given day at Vanity Projects in Manhattan. With a small pair of scissors she cut and placed a thin foil on each nail , creating boundaries for the polish. Then, with the pad of her index finger and thumb, she held the tiniest of brushes and painted white polish within the lines. The final touch was a fine gold powder that she sprinkled over a clear base and buffed to a shine.\n\nThe artist herself wears elaborate eight-inch-long nails covered in crystals and handmade 3-D appliqu\u00e9s. Yayo calls them her \u201csuperlong bling-bling nails.\u201d Think Edward Scissorhands, but with diamond-encrusted talons instead of shears. While she works, the clicking of her nails is often the only sound that can be heard.", "title": "Taking New York by the Hand", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Are there any easy database programs I can use to make a visual catalog of my possessions for insurance purposes?\n\nA. Check with your insurance company to see if it has any specific tips or tools you should use to make a comprehensive list of your possessions. Some companies, including Nationwide and State Farm, suggest taking a narrated digital video as you walk from room to room in your house, and include the contents of closets, drawers and storage rooms.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough recent reviews have been mixed, Allstate offers a free Digital Locker app for Android and iOS devices that you can use to snap pictures of your belongings and make notes, The list is backed up online and can be exported as a PDF file or a spreadsheet if needed to make a claim.\n\nSimilar apps with a range of features can also be found for Android, iOS, Mac and Windows systems. Search your preferred app store for \u201chome inventory\u201d to see what is available on your platform. Some inexpensive, feature-rich apps (like Memento Database for Android, Nest Egg for iOS or Sortly for Android, iOS and web) include barcode-scanning to automatically identify books and other items. Some apps also allow you to store images of purchase receipts to record the original value of the item.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo make sure the inventory is around when you need it, back up the data securely in a separate location. Many inventory apps include an online backup tool to sites like Dropbox or their own servers. Airtable, an online spreadsheet/database app that allows you to add notes and pictures to entries, is another option. You can also log images of your possessions in web-based spreadsheets like Apple Numbers, Google Sheets or Microsoft Excel.", "title": "Taking Stock of Your Belongings for the Future", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Raymon has contributed cryptic puzzles to The Times, and his theme entries are very charming. I took the theme a little too far at the beginning, as the title plus a couple of entries made me think of a particular actor (in a particular role), but by the last few I was trying to figure out answers with no letters to help, as well as trying to come up with some of my own.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nUnderstandably, there were an inordinate number of Q\u2019s in this puzzle, which helped me greatly in solving. But there were also several clues in this puzzle that could go more than one way; even though I filled the grid out pretty quickly, it got sloppy because of a few wrong choices. Mr. Raymon availed himself of some oddball variations like AEON, STRIVEN, and EAMONN, and some just plain old oddball words like APERY, HISN and TWINY.\n\nIn addition, there were some cute hints for the fill, so hopefully you were pleasantly struck by a clue or two. I liked those for SPIN, SANG, ASL and AAA, among others.\n\n21A: I filled in \u201cShoshone\u201d for this clue, \u201cMembers of an Oklahoma tribe,\u201d instead of SHAWNEES. The Shoshones were further east, but there were tons of different groups in Oklahoma.\n\n29A: Similarly, I had \u201cOsteo\u201d for OSSEO, which is clued far less frequently than the prefix I chose, for \u201cbone\u201d or \u201cbony.\u201d\n\n66A: Because of some crosses, I incorrectly entered \u201cloathe\u201d for \u201cInterest\u2019s opposite.\u201d Much as the opposite of love is indifference, the opposite of interest is APATHY.\n\n17D: \u201cBishop\u2019s group, once\u201d had me searching for religious terms, or maybe chess. The Bishop in question is Joey, though, one of the members of the RAT PACK. (I guess those rats SANG, eh?)\n\n54D: Aw, this one made me feel old, and I can\u2019t imagine how a certain little dwarf planet takes it. I learned, as a mnemonic for the PLANETS, \u201cMy Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Nine Pizzas.\u201d C\u2019est la vie, Pluto!\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n93D: Here\u2019s a Q word down the southwest corner that doesn\u2019t come up that often in the puzzle. QUAHOGS include a variety of delicious hard-shelled clams; I use littlenecks in this delicious linguine alle vongole recipe.\n\n100D: I have read about the AEOLIAN Islands, which sound wonderful. But I didn\u2019t know what an Aeolian harp was, and it\u2019s quite fascinating, sort of a string version of a windchime, named for the Greek god of the wind. The sounds produced are appropriately atmospheric.\n\nAeolian harp music Audio\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nI\u2019m super excited for everyone to see my first ever Sunday puzzle! It\u2019s been over 10 years since I got my first crossword published, but the first time I tried to make a Sunday was last year. I wasn\u2019t sure I wanted to put in all the extra time and effort without even knowing how the puzzle would be received, but I finally figured I might as well try. And this is the result. Lesson learned! I think this theme (changing the K sound at the starts of words to the Q sound) is great because the idea is very simple and the resulting phrases are \u2026 quite quirky! As Will noted regarding a previous puzzle of mine, puns with Q\u2019s are a lot of fun. I\u2019m actually very surprised that this theme hadn\u2019t been done before. I\u2019m pleased that most of my clues were kept, and as always I appreciate the vast majority of the changes from Will and crew. A few clues I liked that didn\u2019t make it: 46-Down: Are BEINGS by definition \u201cSentient ones\u201d? Would that make the expression \u201csentient beings\u201d redundant? Anyway, I thought my clue was cute: \u201cLivers?\u201d 91-Down: I guess \u201cGraphic opening?\u201d doesn\u2019t pass the breakfast test, so it was replaced by \u201cPrefix with -graphic.\u201d Oh well. 96-Down: I think my clue was more colorful than \u201cBagel variety\u201d: \u201cSource of the headline \u2018Area Man\u2019s Life Comes to Tragic Middle,\u2019 with \u2018The.\u2019\u201d Have a fun solve!\n\nThe Sunday Sherpa\n\nReady to make like a little fox and kit? You can take a peek at the answer key here. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Taking Your Q", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Coats said Afghan forces \u201cprobably will maintain control of most major population centers with coalition force support, but the intensity and geographic scope of Taliban activities will put those centers under continued strain.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump, under his new strategy for the region, has expanded the presence of American military advisers in Afghanistan by a few thousand troops, making more available to work with the Afghan forces at a smaller unit level.\n\nCapt. Tom Gresback, a spokesman for the United States military in Afghanistan, said new specialized units were arriving to assist Afghan forces at the battalion level across the country. Already, about 800 such service members \u2014 many of whom have done previous tours in Afghanistan and have received specific training for this kind of mobile advisory mission where they will be sent from one part of the country to the next \u2014 have arrived.\n\n\u201cWe are in the process of deploying them throughout the country,\u201d Captain Gresback said.\n\nOfficials in northern Afghanistan said that already more American advisers were arriving to help in the battle.\n\nSaid Sarwar Hussain, a spokesman for the Afghan police in the north of the country, said a unit of about 300 American special forces would be based in the restive province of Faryab.\n\n\u201cThey will advise in our operations and assist with air power,\u201d Mr. Hussaini said, adding that \u201c120 of them have arrived by air, and the rest are waiting for the main highway to be cleared before they go to Faryab.\u201d\n\nViolence also continued in the east of the country. In the Bati Kot district of Nangarhar Province, Afghan officials said Taliban fighters had opened fire on a civilian vehicle, killing seven members of the same family, three men and four women. But the Taliban denied they were behind the attack.", "title": "Taliban Briefly Take Afghan District as Security Worsens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "The offer on the table, made by President Ashraf Ghani, included recognition of the Taliban as a legitimate political party, passports for their officials, an office in Kabul or somewhere else they preferred, the release of Taliban prisoners and efforts to remove their leaders from international sanctions lists.\n\nJust because the Taliban may be discussing the offer does not mean they\u2019re going to take it, of course. Most of the Taliban figures reached for comment by The New York Times preferred to remain quiet, referring the queries to representatives in Qatar. Members at the office in Qatar, in return, did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nSome Taliban figures who did speak made sure to express their old mistrust of any peace offer by the Western-backed Afghan government.\n\nMullah Hamidee, a Taliban military commander in the south, said: \u201cOur stance on peace talk is totally dependent on foreign troops\u2019 abandoning our country. Anytime they set the date for leaving, we will be willing to talk on peace.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne senior Taliban commander, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he was talking to the news media without the leadership\u2019s permission, insisted that the insurgents were not ready to negotiate directly with the Afghan government. The discussions underway, he said, are over what kind of negotiations might be acceptable, \u201cbut the mood of leadership is likely to not initiate peace talks with the Afghan government.\u201d\n\nWhile that is far from a rousing endorsement, it is a long way from the Taliban\u2019s outright and fulsome dismissal of past peace initiatives, always insisting that they would talk only to the \u201coccupiers,\u201d meaning the American military, as long as they remained on Afghan soil.\n\nRecently, several former officials involved in previous efforts to negotiate with the Taliban said the United States would need to play larger role as facilitator if the insurgents were to take any prospects of negotiations seriously.\n\nOne senior diplomat in Kabul, Afghanistan\u2019s capital, said the government\u2019s offer had been a game changer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Taliban feel a bit confused, they feel pressured,\u201d he said. \u201cAt the Kabul conference, everybody said they should talk to the Afghan government; they are the only ones insisting they should talk to the occupiers.\u201d\n\nAs the government of Uzbekistan convened the conference here, pressure on the Taliban came from another, unexpected quarter: the group\u2019s own heartland.\n\nIn Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, a major Taliban stronghold, a suicide bombing at a wrestling match Friday killed 14 people. This week hundreds of Helmand residents held a sit-in, vowing to carry out a \u201clong march\u201d to the Taliban-held town of Musa Qala to demand peace talks. The protesters included women, rarely seen outside their homes in that conservative corner of Afghanistan.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe only aim of the sit-in is to stop fighting from both sides,\u201d said one of the organizers, Iqbal Khaibar. \u201cThe Taliban should not send bombers and the government should not drop bombs on them.\u201d\n\nHe said their march would take place without security: \u201cThis is our country and we can go anywhere in it.\u201d\n\nAkram Khpalwak, the head of the Afghan government\u2019s High Peace Council secretariat, was among the optimists. \u201cThe narrative needed to change,\u201d he said. \u201cThere was a perception that, over the years, the Taliban wanted peace but the government side did not have a clear plan for it, and was not offering a comprehensive plan. We wanted to change that perception, and make an offer that leaves few questions.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Ghani\u2019s offer to the Taliban came after consultations among all elements of Afghan society, Mr. Khpalwak said, including the most ardent anti-Taliban factions and the most sympathetic.\n\nSo optimistic is Mr. Ghani\u2019s government that when the American secretary of defense, James N. Mattis, visited Kabul recently, the two men spent most of their time discussing the technical measures that would be needed to implement the government\u2019s offers and get peace talks underway, according to Afghan officials briefed on Mr. Mattis\u2019s visit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Taliban are no longer the united force they were under their former leader, Mullah Omar, but they are also reeling from heavy battlefield losses \u2014 as is the government side. While the insurgents have continued to gain territory, no clear victory is in sight for either side.\n\nIn addition, the Pakistanis have come under heavy pressure from the United States over the issue of Taliban sanctuaries in Pakistan.\n\nThe Afghan government hoped that the Tashkent conference would help bring the Russians on board, as well, particularly with the involvement of their Central Asian allies, Uzbekistan and its neighbors. The Uzbek president, Shavkat Myrziyoyev, offered to host eventual peace talks.\n\nBut the conference convened in the midst of widespread expulsions of Russian diplomats by Western countries, and Russians were reported to be unhappy with what they see as sidelining Moscow from the peace process.\n\nThe American military has accused Russia of working behind the scenes with the Taliban. In a recent interview with the BBC, the American commander, Gen. John W. Nicholson, said the Russian \u201cactivity really picked up in the last 18 to 24 months.\u201d He said, \u201cPrior to that we had not seen this kind of destabilizing activity by Russia here.\u201d\n\nThat led to a furious response from the Russian Embassy in Kabul. \u201cThose who are really responsible for the deteriorating situation in Afghanistan are trying to put the burden of guilt for their failures on Russia and damage the Russian-Afghan relations,\u201d the embassy said in a statement.\n\nDespite such setbacks, Mr. Ghani\u2019s recent offer was the most concrete sign of progress in at least the past three years.\n\nThe high point came in 2015, when the two sides actually met in person near Islamabad, Pakistan, for exploratory talks. But the next session was scuttled when it turned out that the Afghans were, in effect, negotiating with a dead man: The Taliban\u2019s founder, Mullah Muhammad Omar, had died more than two years earlier, and the talks fell apart amid those revelations.\n\nBut even if the Taliban are willing to join the peace process, said the senior diplomat, a long process of confidence building and pre-talks lies ahead before any actual, face-to-face peace negotiations. More terrorist bombings in Kabul and other Afghan cities would put the Afghan government in a difficult position, he said.", "title": "Taliban\u2019s Rare Silence on Talks Charges Up a New Peace Conference", "authors": ["Rod Nordland", "Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "MONTREAL \u2014 Since arriving back in Montreal after nearly three decades abroad, one of the most striking changes I\u2019ve noticed has been the seeming retreat of the separatist movement here. The younger generation seems far more focused on becoming the Quebecois Steve Jobs than in fomenting revolution.\n\nSo as I began my Quebec road trip this week in my hometown, I sought out Gabriel Nadeau-Dubois, a charismatic young proponent of Quebec\u2019s independence from Canada. My aim was to try and understand how the movement has evolved since the culture wars of the 1980s, when the province was buffeted by the aftermath of a referendum on independence.\n\nMr. Nadeau-Dubois is a proud left-winger, who compares his politics to that of Bernie Sanders, Jeremy Corbyn or Jean-Luc M\u00e9lenchon. He was one of the leaders of the 2012 \u201cMaple Spring,\u201d huge student protests against an increase in university tuition fees that galvanized a generation of young Quebecois. He is also unrepentant about Quebec pursuing its national sovereignty.\n\n\u201cQuebec needs to change the rules of the game, and that is not possible when Canada is based on a system in which Queen Elizabeth is the head of state and the constitutional system is centuries old,\u201d he told me on Monday over a coffee in Rosemont-La Petite-Patrie, a gentrifying working-class neighborhood. It is part of the district he represents in the province\u2019s National Assembly as one of three members from his left-wing party, Quebec Solidaire.", "title": "Talking Politics With the Self-Styled Bernie Sanders of Quebec", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "A few months ago, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published a report about a young boy from Connecticut who developed lead poisoning as a direct result of his parents giving him a magnetic healing bracelet for teething. It seems every few months a story will cover a tragic case of a parent choosing an unconventional medical treatment that causes harm.\n\nMore often, the alternative treatments parents choose pose little risk to their kids \u2014 anything from massage therapy to mind-body therapies like mindfulness meditation and guided imagery. Research indicates that overall, there are few serious adverse events related to using alternative therapies. But when they do occur, they can be catastrophic, in some cases because caregivers or alternative care providers are poorly informed on how to recognize the signs of serious illness.\n\nThe National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health, part of the National Institutes of Health, now refers to these alternative treatments as complementary health approaches, or C.H.A. They are defined as \u201ca group of diverse medical and health care systems, practices and products not presently considered to be part of conventional Western medicine.\u201d In some cases they complement traditional care. In others they are used in place of standard medical practices.\n\nIt\u2019s a polarizing subject that unfortunately gets muddled with conversations about anti-vaccination. But while some anti-vaxxers use complementary health approaches, people who use C.H.A. don\u2019t necessarily doubt vaccine effectiveness.", "title": "Talking to Your Child\u2019s Doctor About Alternative Medicine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 When China hosted the last serious talks on North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons program, in the mid-2000s, the setting was a huge, hexagonal table covered in green felt, in a government guesthouse in Beijing.\n\nAt each side of the table, made specially by the Chinese, were diplomats from one of the six countries involved: North and South Korea, the United States, Japan, Russia and China itself. Months passed between sessions, sometimes a year. Occasionally, China rearranged the seating, hoping for better chemistry among the delegates as they endured the complex, eye-glazing proceedings.\n\nIn 2009, North Korea walked out \u2014 ending, to China\u2019s dismay, the so-called six-party talks that Beijing had nurtured and prodded along for six years.\n\nNearly a decade later, China is a bystander as President Trump says he\u2019s open to the North\u2019s new offer to talk. Even so, analysts say, Beijing is sure to be pleased by the prospect of a drawn-out diplomatic process that delays the possibility of war on its border \u2014 even if the talks ultimately come to nothing.", "title": "Talks With North Korea? China Approves (No Matter the Outcome)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Tanzina Vega has been named the new host of the public radio program \u201cThe Takeaway,\u201d succeeding John Hockenberry, who retired in August and was subsequently accused of engaging in sexual harassment and bullying behavior during his decade with the show.\n\nMs. Vega, who will begin working on the nationally syndicated news program on May 7, was most recently at CNN, where she reported on race, inequality and the criminal justice system. She was previously a reporter for The New York Times.\n\n\u201cSince its inception, \u2018The Takeaway\u2019 has sought out voices from across the country to provide context for and perspective on the day\u2019s news,\u201d Alisa Miller, president and chief executive of Public Radio International, which produces the show with WNYC Radio, said in a statement. \u201cTanzina\u2019s deep curiosity about the intersection of people\u2019s lives and events will extend this tradition in new ways, deepening understanding across different points of view.\u201d\n\nMr. Hockenberry, a founder of \u201cThe Takeaway\u201d in 2008, had expressed a desire for the show to engage with, and appeal to, minority listeners. After the allegations against him became public, he released a statement that read, in part, \u201cIt horrifies me that I made the talented and driven people I worked with feel uncomfortable, and that the stress around putting together a great show was made worse by my behavior.\u201d", "title": "Tanzina Vega Is New Host of WNYC\u2019s \u2018The Takeaway\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat story could this image tell?\n\nUse your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration and post it in the comments.\n\nThen read the related article to find out what this picture is all about.", "title": "Tape", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI was in the neighborhood supermarket clutching the list my wife had given me and buying my groceries for the weekend.\n\nI was in the fruit section vetting the Gala apples carefully with a special technique I learned from a neighbor. It entails tapping each apple you pick up. If you hear a dull thud, the apple is dry and not good. If the sound is sharp, the apple will be crunchy and juicy on the inside.\n\nI had selected about 10 apples this way when I noticed that two workers tending to the fruit were watching me with questioning looks on their faces.\n\nI smiled and told them how the apple-picking technique worked. They were delighted by my explanation. They said it was new and interesting to them and that we all learned something new everyday. We exchanged smiles and pleasantries, and I proceeded on with my shopping.", "title": "Tapping Apples", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBut under today\u2019s rules, those profits are not taxed,\u201d Mr. Moscovici said. \u201cThe current legal vacuum is creating a substantial shortfall in the budgetary revenues of our member states.\u201d It also creates an uneven playing field between digital and traditional businesses, he argued.\n\nThe European Commission, the European Union\u2019s executive arm, says tech companies use the profit-shifting method to reduce their tax burdens. In documents obtained by The New York Times before Wednesday\u2019s announcement, officials estimated that digital businesses in the bloc pay an average effective tax rate of just 9.5 percent, compared with 23.3 percent for traditional businesses.\n\nUnder the new proposals, a 3 percent tax would be levied on the sale of user data, targeted advertising and \u201cinterfaces that put together buyers and sellers.\u201d Officials estimate the tax would generate at least 5 billion euros, or $6.15 billion, annually for European Union member states.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMinimum thresholds, however, will mean that only large tech businesses will be subject to the tax, and companies will be able to deduct the payments from their corporate tax contributions to avoid double taxation.\n\nThe plans announced on Wednesday are not certain to be carried out, as they require the approval of the European Union\u2019s member states, and there is considerable disagreement over how much change is needed.\n\nNotably, while big countries like France and Germany have pushed for changes, at least two smaller members have objected, saying the system allows them to attract employers by offering tax advantages.\n\nIreland \u2014 which is in a dispute with the European Commission over its tax treatment for Apple \u2014 quickly voiced opposition to the new plans on Wednesday. Leo Varadkar, the country\u2019s prime minister, said the measures were \u201cill judged.\u201d\n\nStill, policymakers both within and outside the European Union largely agree that changes are necessary to make global companies \u2014 whether digital or not \u2014 pay their fair share of tax.\n\nThe role that tech companies play in society has gotten particular attention in recent days, amid revelations that a political data firm with ties to President Trump\u2019s 2016 campaign gained access to private information on tens of millions of Facebook users. Facebook is one of several companies that have been in the cross hairs of regulators in Europe over the mishandling of personal data, tax avoidance and antitrust violations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, the European Commission fined Google \u20ac2.4 billion for abusing its dominant market position, while companies like Apple, Amazon and Qualcomm have also been investigated or penalized. The dominance of Silicon Valley in the industry has, however, spurred criticism that European regulators are too harsh on American businesses, an allegation officials in Brussels strongly reject.", "title": "Targeting Tech Giants, Europe Unveils Digital Tax Proposal", "authors": ["Milan Schreuer"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "President Trump pushed forward with a two-pronged trade offensive this week, enacting tariffs on imported aluminum and steel on Friday, a day after announcing levies on up to $60 billion in Chinese goods. The target of both actions is China, a country that Mr. Trump has called \u201can economic enemy\u201d of the United States.\n\nFor now, the administration has given exemptions from the first set of tariffs to multiple nations, making it clear that the main point is to curb the influx of cheap Chinese metals.\n\nBeijing\u2019s initial response has been muted, setting the stage for what could be a methodical escalation of retaliatory measures. The Chinese government announced Friday that it planned to impose tariffs on just $3 billion in American products, including fruit, pork, wine, seamless steel pipes and more than 100 other goods. Missing were vulnerable prey like aircraft and soybeans, which experts say may come next if tensions continue to build.\n\nThere\u2019s clearly uncertainty about how the tariffs will play out. Here\u2019s what we do know.\n\nWhat\u2019s directly at stake?\n\nMarkets around the world tumbled on the news of the new tariff package, but for now, the panic seems premature. Sixty billion sounds like a big number, but the reality is that the measures would barely dent the $11 trillion Chinese economy. And the Chinese retaliation for the aluminum and steel tariffs, at least initially, is even milder.", "title": "Tariff Battle: Where the U.S. and Chinese Moves May Lead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "Looking from behind the wheel of the SQ5, the road has far more twists than the administration may anticipate. The president seems to think that tariffs will strong-arm manufacturers and suppliers into basing more production in America, or somehow get Europeans to buy Chevys. But supply chains have become so sophisticated as to be borderless, and Audi and other foreign companies have already invested billions of dollars in the United States.\n\nForeign-badged cars aren\u2019t the only ones that have foreign parts. The Chevrolet Bolt EV \u2014 an important vehicle for General Motors \u2014 is composed of 26 percent American/Canadian parts. The sales sheet isn\u2019t more specific because the parts don\u2019t care whether they\u2019re made in Ontario or Michigan. The motor and transmission \u2014 more than half the total parts \u2014 are from South Korea, which has already been frosted by President Trump\u2019s refrigerator tariff. The Bolt is then bolted together at G.M.\u2019s Lake Orion, Mich., plant. In terms of origin, the Chevy Bolt is as American as a karaoke bar \u2014 a venue that has become increasingly popular in the United States. Maybe Mr. Trump should slap a tariff on bad singing.\n\nUnlike the president, automakers have realized that free trade isn\u2019t a policy; it\u2019s essential to manufacturing efficiency. They source globally and manufacture locally when it makes economic sense \u2014 one reason Audi\u2019s owner, Volkswagen, is investing in more production capacity in Tennessee. American automakers haven\u2019t been able to make small cars very profitably in the United States, so some of that production, such as that for Ford\u2019s Focus, goes to Mexico. Or China. President Trump is now revving up duties on up to $60 billion in unspecified Chinese imports to punish that country for stealing American technology. He might want to avoid autos. Buick\u2019s Envision crossover S.U.V., a potential Audi competitor, is manufactured in Yantai, China, from 88 percent Chinese-made parts. Buick is a best-seller in China; indeed, G.M. sells more Buicks there than here. Cadillac sales increased 50 percent in China last year.\n\nOne company that is helping the administration close the automotive trade gap with Germany is Mercedes-Benz. It builds and exports S.U.V.s in Tuscaloosa County, Ala. Mercedes says there are about 200 suppliers tied to the plant, the majority of them international firms that have followed the Germans to the United States and built plants here. They\u2019ve added thousands of jobs and pay millions in taxes. Many of these suppliers also export components to other Mercedes-Benz plants worldwide, the company says.\n\nThis is how trade works in a rational world \u2014 a world the president apparently doesn\u2019t visit. Ford uses fewer than a dozen global platforms, meaning that any car built here can be built the same way (with some local modifications) in China or Brazil. Fiat Chrysler\u2019s all-American Jeep Renegade is assembled in Melfi, Italy. You can order a Renegade with a Tigershark engine built in Dundee, Mich., or with Fiat\u2019s highly efficient 1.4 liter MultiAir version. Both power plants combine expertise and technology from Chrysler and Fiat. Small world. That\u2019s how Jeep can compete with Range Rover and Toyota outside the United States.\n\nBefore he became president and had to give up the wheel, Mr. Trump had a taste for foreign models like Lamborghini and Ferrari. (And for foreign models in general.) Mr. Trump liked bespoke Rolls-Royce motorcars as well. For rich boys and their auto toys, a 10 percent or 20 percent tariff added to the price of exotic metal is meaningless. For the people who make or buy automobiles, a tariff is a road tax, one that won\u2019t help the economy, or the auto industry.", "title": "Opinion | Tariffs on Imports? Above, a scene in Glasgow.\n\nResearchers say the extreme weather is most likely linked to climate change. A growing body of research suggests that the warming Arctic is weakening the polar vortex, allowing cold air to escape, much like when you leave your refrigerator door open.\n\nIn the U.S., a nor\u2019easter walloped the East Coast, stranding travelers, knocking out power lines and creating dangerous flooding conditions. R. McMaster, will be replaced by John R. Bolton, a hard-line former U.S. ambassador who supported Britain\u2019s withdrawal from the E.U.", "title": "Tariffs, Strikes, Facebook: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "A crusty loaf of whole-grain bread to start a meal and some elaborate French pastry classics to end one are new options on the Upper East Side. Vaucluse, the French restaurant owned by Michael White\u2019s Altamarea Group, is selling more than a dozen of its breads, baked by Jacqueline Eng, retail. Several are sourdough, including an unusual one, with a golden crumb, seasoned with turmeric, onion, pepper and ginger. Baguettes; whole grain and olive breads; even a dark chocolate flax Pullman are also on the menu. At Caf\u00e9 Bilboquet, which opened a few doors east of Le Bilboquet last summer and becomes a wine bar in the evening, Bea Boumendil is fashioning an array of individual pastries, most notably an exquisite g\u00e2teau St.-Honor\u00e9. Both restaurants are also selling viennoiseries like croissants and pains au chocolat: Boulangerie V, Vaucluse, 100 East 63rd Street, breads to order two days in advance from shop.altamareagroup.com, for pickup at the restaurant from noon to 9 p.m. daily. Caf\u00e9 Bilboquet, 26 East 60th Street, 646-869-4660, lebilboquetny.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Tasty Carbs on the Upper East Side", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "Oops, they did it again. After Republicans rammed through their big tax cut, there were a rash of stories about corporations using the tax break to give their workers bonuses. Have the media learned nothing from the Carrier debacle? After all, companies have every incentive to curry favor with a sitting administration by attributing nice things they would have done in any case to Dear Leader\u2019s glorious policies. Amid tightening labor markets lots of firms would have been trying to attract or hold workers by offering a bit of money; why not use the occasion to hype something that raises your after-tax profits?\n\nAnyway, now we have enough information to start assessing the real impact of the tax cut. No, it isn\u2019t going into wages; you should never have expected that in the short run anyway. What\u2019s more, we aren\u2019t even seeing the kind of response that would raise wages in the long run. And it\u2019s even possible, as I\u2019ll explain, that the tax cut could reduce wages.\n\n1. The optimists\u2019 theory of the case\n\nWhat was the theory of the case for those who believed, or at least claimed to believe, that a cut in corporate taxes would be passed through into wages? The story, as told by people like Kevin Hassett or the Tax Foundation, was that (a) markets for goods and labor are close to perfectly competitive, and (b) America is part of a global capital market that more or less equalizes after-tax rates of return. The idea, then, was that by reducing the rate of taxes on corporate profits, America would attract inflows of capital from the rest of the world. A rising capital stock would drive pre-tax returns on capital down and, by increasing competition for labor, drive wages up. In the long run, they claimed, all the benefits would go to workers.\n\nThere were multiple reasons not to believe in this story. One reason is that the U.S., if only because of its sheer size, doesn\u2019t face a perfectly elastic supply of capital from the rest of the world; even in the long run, we would expect a tax cut to raise after-tax profits. Another is that we\u2019re nowhere close to perfect competition: a lot of corporate profits represent some kind of monopoly rent, and there\u2019s no reason to expect capital inflows to compete those rents away.", "title": "Opinion | Tax Cuts and Wages Redux (Slightly Wonkish)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "So you go out for dinner with a wealthy acquaintance. \u201cI\u2019ll take care of everything,\u201d he says, and orders you a hamburger. Then he orders himself an expensive steak and a bottle of wine, which he doesn\u2019t share. And when the waiter comes with the check, he points at you and says, \u201cCharge it to his credit card.\u201d\n\nNow you understand the essence of the Trump tax cut, signed into law a little over two months ago.\n\nThe key thing you need to know is that right now the U.S. government has no business cutting taxes. We need more revenue, not less.\n\nWhy? The federal government, as an old line says, is a giant insurance company with an army. Most of its costs come from Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid \u2014 and all three programs are becoming more expensive as ever more baby boomers reach retirement age. This means that unless we cut back sharply on benefits that middle-class Americans count on, we will need to raise more revenue than in the past.\n\nYet even before the tax cut, federal tax receipts were looking weak for an economy with low unemployment and a rising stock market \u2014 for example, far lower as a percentage of G.D.P. than the tax take during the Clinton boom of the 1990s, and even a bit lower than they were at the end of the Bush-era expansion. The tax cut will push them lower still. Something will have to give.", "title": "Opinion | Taxpayers, You\u2019ve Been Scammed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Frailich realized his colleagues needed the ability to invest directly in mutual funds in their retirement plan, the way most people with for-profit employers can. That would give them a chance at higher returns. To do that, however, those colleagues needed entirely new accounts \u2014 on top of the annuities in their original accounts, which came with penalties if you sold them before several years had gone by.\n\n\u201cIn the process of making things better, I also had to make them more complex,\u201d Mr. Frailich said. After he left the school, another administrator made further adjustments, leaving some veteran teachers there with five or six separate 403(b) accounts.\n\nNow, years later, some of his former colleagues (some of whom have become clients) are having a hard time getting out of the old 403(b)\u2019s and into one consolidated account that would be simpler and cheaper. Some of the problem appears to be sloppiness on the part of Voya Financial, the company that controls the old accounts.\n\nOne teacher, Katie Harvey, recently discovered that Voya had her first name wrong, her birthday wrong and her email wrong. Changing all of that required printing out a form and sending Voya a copy of her identification by mail.\n\nAnother teacher, Sara Wilson, had been trying for four months to extract her accounts from Voya, but still hadn\u2019t managed to finish when I spoke to her this week, even with the help of other local financial advisers. \u201cIt\u2019s been very entertaining to listen in on the calls,\u201d she said. \u201cThe girl is saying words to me that I don\u2019t understand. And my adviser keeps saying \u2018Do you expect my client to understand this?\u2019\u201d\n\nKristin Foght, who also teaches in the area, tried to move her accounts away from Voya without any expert help. She began in August. There were name-change forms, since she got married along the way. Then spousal consent forms. Then demands for notarization. Then requests for a letter of acceptance from the company that would be receiving the funds. Then a requirement to fax the forms. \u201cThey kept telling me that they were not getting the fax,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I kept saying \u2018Nobody faxes anymore besides you guys!\u2019\u201d", "title": "Teachers and Annuities: A Questionable Match and Hard Products to Shed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe\u2019s shaken up, but he\u2019s going to be O.K.,\u201d the boy\u2019s father, Fermin Gonzales, told KSBW. \u201cI\u2019m just pretty upset that no one told us anything and we had to call the police ourselves to report it.\u201d\n\nWhen asked why the parents had not been informed about the accident, Ms. McFadden said she could not comment because the matter was under investigation.\n\nMr. Alexander\u2019s class, which includes 32 juniors and seniors, has been offered for a couple of years as one of the school\u2019s career technical education offerings, Ms. McFadden said. She said she did not know whether students are normally shown guns during the class.\n\nMr. Alexander was placed on administrative leave at both Seaside High School and the Sand City Police Department, where he works about four hours a week as a reserve police officer whenever the department is short-handed, Sand City Police Chief Brian Ferrante said in a phone interview on Wednesday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Alexander, who has been employed by the school district since 1994, did not immediately respond to messages on Wednesday.\n\nAcross the country, another school was also investigating a weapon that discharged accidentally this week. The Alexandria Police Department in Virginia said that a school resource officer accidentally fired his gun inside his office at George Washington Middle School on Tuesday morning. Nobody was hurt, the police said.\n\nThe officer, whose name was not released, is a five-year veteran of the Police Department and has been placed on administrative leave during its investigation of the episode, the police said.\n\nBoth accidents occurred just days after President Trump vowed to push ahead on his proposal to arm school employees with guns, a controversial idea that would entail partnering with local law enforcement to provide teachers and other school officials with firearms training after a gunman killed 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., on Feb. 14.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCowards will only go where there is no deterrent!\u201d Mr. Trump said in a tweet on Monday.\n\nThe latest mass shooting prompted thousands of students at hundreds of schools to walk out of class on Wednesday to protest gun violence, the culmination of weeks of public outrage at the glacial pace of gun reform, a topic that has remained prominent in the news largely through the efforts of a group of social media-savvy students from Stoneman Douglas.\n\nIn Washington, where the gun debate has remained static, Mr. Trump has not indicated a willingness to disrupt the way things stand. On Monday, he discarded a proposal to raise the age limit to purchase rifles. \u201cNot much political support (to put it mildly),\u201d Mr. Trump said in a tweet.\n\nInstead, Mr. Trump has advocated improving reporting to the national background check system \u2014 a step that is backed by the National Rifle Association.", "title": "Teacher\u2019s Gun Is Accidentally Fired During Public Safety Class, Injuring 3", "authors": ["Christina Caron"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Before reading the article:\n\nWatch the first part of the Retro Report video below, \u201cHow ISIS Resembles the Doomsday Cults of the 1970s,\u201d until 3:40. It is a snapshot of America that determines how congressional seats are apportioned, how state and federal dollars are distributed, where businesses choose to ship products and where they build new stores. The suspect is dead, and we may never know for sure. Whatever the investigation yields, the bombings will forever feel like terror to the city\u2019s longstanding African-American and Latino residents.\n\nHe continues:\n\nAnthony Stephan House, a 39-year-old African-American, was the first to be killed by a package bomb on March 2. Ten days later, Draylen Mason, a 17-year-old African-American, was killed by a similar device left at his doorstep. Draylen\u2019s mother, Shamika Wilson, was injured in that explosion. Later that afternoon, Esperanza Herrera found a third package bomb and was severely wounded. All three bombings took place east of Interstate-35, Austin\u2019s main artery. East Austin is home to the majority of the city\u2019s African-American and Mexican-American residents, and it is synonymous with minorities and the city\u2019s history of segregation.\n\nThese first three bombings led some to wonder whether the attacks were racially motivated. These can be based on the dictionary definition, a quick search you do on the web or your own background knowledge.\n\nWhat are some of the common characteristics among people, places or things that colonize? What are some examples of colonization from history, science or other areas? What are some non-examples?\n\nNow, given your understanding of the term \u201ccolonize,\u201d what do you think the word \u201cdecolonize\u201d means? What do you think it means in the context of the article\u2019s headline \u201c\u2018Decolonizing\u2019 Roller Derby? Team Indigenous Takes Up the Challenge\u201d?\n\nAnd, if you\u2019ve never seen roller derby before, watch this short video to learn more about the sport and see it in action.", "title": "Teaching Activities for: \u2018\u2018Decolonizing\u2019 Roller Derby? Team Indigenous Takes Up the Challenge\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Before reading the article:\n\nWhat do you know about the state-wide strike by teachers that is happening in West Virginia? Have your teachers or teachers at other school districts in your area ever gone on strike? If so, what did they hope would be the result?\n\n\n\n\n\nNow, read the article, \u201c\u2018All-In or Nothing\u2019: West Virginia\u2019s Teacher Strike Was Months in the Making,\u201d and answer the following questions:\n\n1. When did public school teachers in West Virginia go on strike?\n\n2. Why did they decide to strike?\n\n3. What did a bill passed by the West Virginia Senate on Saturday night grant teachers in that state?\n\n4. How did the three unions representing school employees in West Virginia respond?\n\n5. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)\n\n5. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\n6. To learn more, read \u201cArctic Boyhood.\u201d Mr. Collardey writes:\n\nI started making documentaries by shooting fragments of my family\u2019s life on their farm, in the snow-covered mountains of Jura, in eastern France. My fascination with documenting rural, snow-covered and remote worlds on film is what led me to Greenland.\n\nI first visited Greenland in 2015. That was when I met Julius, a villager who guided me through the five villages around Tasiilaq, which with around 2,000 inhabitants is the largest town on Greenland\u2019s east coast. It quickly became obvious I would focus my film on Julius\u2019s own village, Tiniteqilaaq. The village has only around 60 inhabitants and is isolated from the rest of the world by ice for about nine months every year. Over the course of the next year, I spent several months there and learned to share the lifestyle of its inhabitants: I went hunting and fishing with the men, shared family dinners of seal and narwhal, and attended baptisms and funerals. Little by little, I was accepted by Julius\u2019s friends and family. After all, we shared more in common than it might have seemed: Since I come from a village of 250 in Jura, there is nothing less exotic to me than a village half that size.\n\nUltimately, I wound up using my time in Julius\u2019s town to make my fourth feature film, \u201cA Polar Year,\u201d from which this short documentary is adapted. Just as my feature film traces the village\u2019s life over one year, through the changing seasons and rhythms of life and death, for this short I followed one of its young residents during the routine of a single day.\n\nThe result is a portrait of Asser Boassen, an 8-year-old Tunumiit boy who wants to become a hunter. Like many children of his village, Asser has not been raised by his biological parents. Instead, he lives with his grandparents, Thomasine and Gert Jonathansen. In many ways, Asser\u2019s daily life as a young boy, fed by the hunting tradition passed on by his grandfather and by the mythical stories told by his grandmother, represents challenges many in modern Greenland are navigating. When Asser turns 12, he will have to leave his village to attend middle school in the city, far away. When he returns to his village, he will be 16, effectively an adult, and uprooted from the traditions and knowledge he spent his childhood absorbing from his grandparents. Across the country, Inuit children are torn between two conceptions of education, one rooted in their native identity and the other imposed by a globalized world \u2014 knowledge that is essential for navigating that very world. The outcomes are often problematic. But for now Asser is just a child dreaming to become a great hunter. As great as Qajaarngaa, the mythical hunter who triumphs in Asser\u2019s grandmother\u2019s tale.", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018Arctic Boyhood\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Film Club"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "Note: This film deals with sensitive medical ethics issues involving the death penalty, capital punishment and executions. Teachers may want to preview the film.\n\n\"Death Row Doctor,\" an eight-minute film that touches on themes of justice and injustice, life and death, profiles Carlo Musso. He is a doctor who contemplates his moral compass as he participates in executions, even though he personally opposes capital punishment.\n\nStudents\n\n1. Watch the eight-minute film above. While you watch, you might take notes using our Film Club Double-Entry Journal (PDF) to help you remember specific moments.\n\n2. Anything that challenged what you know \u2014 or thought you knew?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 What messages, emotions or ideas will you take away from this film? Why?\n\n\u2022 What questions do you still have?", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018Death Row Doctor\u2019", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Film Club"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "\"My Grandfather's Memory Book\u201d is a four-minute film that touches on themes of artistic expression, creative inspiration and generational connectivity. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)\n\n4. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, and then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\n5. To learn more, read \"True Believers in Justice.\u201d It reads:\n\nI\u2019d always wanted to be a lawyer, but unlike Travis Williams \u2014 the subject of this Op-Doc video \u2014 I never wanted to be a public defender. I didn\u2019t understand how anyone could represent people who did terrible things. \u201cCriminals\u201d were not people I wanted to help.\n\nThen, in 2009, while working in the legal department at A&E Television, I met Jonathan Rapping, the founder of what\u2019s now Gideon\u2019s Promise. He invited me to his client-centered legal training program in Alabama. At the start of training, Mr. Rapping asked each lawyer to articulate why he or she chose to become a public defender. One young man said he had a brother with Down syndrome, so he wanted to help people who could not navigate the legal system for themselves. Another said he had been arrested as a teenager, so he wanted to help kids like him who didn\u2019t know their rights. Their stories moved me. I learned more about the true state of the criminal justice system during that week than I knew from all my years practicing law. I wanted other people to learn about what they were doing and so I decided to make this film.\n\nI was horrified by what I learned about the criminal justice system. Innocent people, in prison for months or years, sometimes plead guilty to get out of jail; onerous sentences are too often given for minor crimes; people can lose civil rights, like the right to vote, as a result of criminal convictions. In America, a felony conviction can be a lifelong sentence because of this multitude of collateral consequences.\n\nI also saw what a difference it made to have lawyers like Travis fighting hard for poor people\u2019s rights. I saw him tell clients and their families that they were facing long sentences, outrageous bail terms or prison. But I saw him deliver even the worst news with compassion, and I saw him fight for every client. He\u2019s inspired me to judge less and listen more, to try to put myself in the position of people who face a terribly structured system that often provides justice to neither the victim nor the accused. Thanks to Travis and the other young lawyers I met on this journey, I can proudly say I\u2019m a \u201ctrue believer\u201d in their cause.", "title": "Teaching With: \u2018True Believers in Justice\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWho Speaks Wukchumni?\u201d, a nine-minute film that touches on themes of identity and tradition, profiles Marie Wilcox, the last fluent speaker of Wukchumni, a Native American language. Ms. Wilcox spent seven years creating a comprehensive dictionary of Wukchumni words, and worked on it with her daughter and grandson.\n\nStudents\n\n1. Watch the short film above. While you watch, you might take notes using our Film Club Double-Entry Journal (PDF) to help you remember specific moments.\n\n2. What do those changes say about us as a society? How can a newspaper and its archives help answer those questions?\n\nIn this collection of five of our best related teaching resources, we suggest ways for students to shape their own inquiries into any aspect of women\u2019s history that interests them, from women\u2019s suffrage to \u201cemoji feminism.\u201d\n\nIn the last 14 months, we have seen both the Jan. 21, 2017, Women\u2019s March on Washington \u2014 which some say is most likely the largest single-day demonstration in recorded United States history \u2014 and the #MeToo movement, a watershed event that, as The Times\u2019s new gender editor writes, is unique because \u201cfor perhaps the first time in history, powerful men are falling, like dominos, and women are being believed.\u201d\n\nWhat do these recent events say about the future for women and girls in the United States and around the world? Why?", "title": "Teaching and Learning About Women\u2019s History With The New York Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTech Eyes the Ultimate Start-Up: An Entire City\u201d (The Upshot, Sunday Review, Feb. 25):\n\nSo Silicon Valley whiz kids are going to build new cities with none of the problems of places like San Francisco.\n\nI once lived in the San Francisco area and learned that most of the architects there did not live in their sleek modern creations. Many lived in Sausalito, which has to be one of the most unplanned cities in the Bay Area. Will those who want to build efficient cities deign to leave San Francisco to live in their sterile creations?\n\nMy suggestion to these novice city builders is to find out what has worked elsewhere. The Swiss-French architect Le Corbusier, a strong believer in social advancement through technology, designed and inspired a lot of failed housing development that did not serve human needs. His was top-down planning that did not work.\n\nIn Finland, the low-tech planned community of Tapiola near Helsinki is home to some 9,000 residents. Surveys in Tapiola have found that the vast majority are happy with their living environment.", "title": "Opinion | Tech-Designed Housing?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "Technology stocks helped propel the nine-year bull market. Optimistic investors piled into the shares, hoping to grab a piece of the profits from industries such as social media, autonomous driving, video streaming and artificial intelligence.\n\nNow, that confidence is evaporating.\n\nInvestors pummeled technology company stocks again on Tuesday, knocking the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index down 1.7 percent. The Nasdaq composite, laden with technology stocks, sank 2.9 percent after a flurry of bad news about specific companies metastasized into a broad retreat from technology stocks.\n\nThe sell-off was ignited when the chip maker Nvidia said it was suspending tests of its self-driving car technology after an autonomous Uber vehicle struck and killed a pedestrian in Tempe, Ariz., last week. Nvidia has made supplying chips to self-driving vehicles a major part of its growth strategy, and Uber had selected Nvidia to outfit its fleet.\n\nThe news sent Nvidia shares plunging 7.8 percent, the sharpest decline of any company in the S.&P.\n\nShares of Tesla, a maker of electric-powered vehicles, also were in free fall, plunging 8 percent plunge after the National Transportation Safety Board said it was investigating a fatal crash last week involving a Tesla vehicle in California. The explosion triggered a stampede that injured tens of passengers.\n\nThe judge in the case said that Mr. Hassan had constructed a bucket bomb filled with screwdrivers, knives, nuts, bolts and explosives and detonated it on a train carriage with 93 passengers, hoping \u201cto kill as many members of the British public as possible.\u201d\n\nSpeaking at England\u2019s Old Bailey central criminal court in London, Judge Charles Haddon-Cave called Mr. Hassan a \u201cdangerous and devious individual\u201d who had let down the country that gave him shelter, the foster charity that cared for him and the college he attended.", "title": "Teenager Sentenced to Life in Britain Over London Tube Bombing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Megan Moreno, a pediatrician who is vice chair of digital health at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, said: \u201cMy main message would be for parents to step back for a minute from the alarmist nature of the word \u2018sexting\u2019 and think about developmentally appropriate foolish romantic things teenagers do.\u201d Parents might, for example, think about the risky things they did themselves when they were younger, and when they discuss it with their teenagers, \u201ctry to view sexting through that lens: here is something that might feel like a normal thing to do and a normal thing to ask, and other people are doing it, but it\u2019s a risky thing for you to do and if you find yourself in that situation we can talk about it.\u201d\n\nAs kids get older, the parenting guide by Dr. Moreno in the journal suggests, conversations can \u2014 and should \u2014 become more direct. Let kids tell you what they know, what they think, what they\u2019re seeing, what they\u2019re feeling. It\u2019s part of talking about safety, online and offline, and part of talking about social behavior, friendships and romantic relationships and how people treat others and want to be treated. For teenagers themselves, there is a thorough handbook available from Common Sense Media, which will walk a kid through the scarier scenarios.\n\n\u201cParents are very invested in the idea that sexting is a terrible thing,\u201d Dr. Englander said. \u201cThey want to be able to turn to their kids and say, this could be the end of your life as we know it, it could ruin your chances for college, it could ruin your chances for jobs.\u201d\n\nBy focusing on those possible but worst case scenarios, parents are not necessarily addressing the much more common problems: About 13 percent of sexters report bad experiences, and another 7 to 8 percent mixed experiences; the negatives are for the most part emotional.\n\nSo those conversations should include the \u201cwhat if\u201d scenarios: What if you feel pressured to send a sext and you don\u2019t want to, what are the right strategies? Who would you turn to, how could you get help and advice?\n\nThe most upsetting statistic to come out of these studies is that one in nine teenagers report forwarding sexts without consent. Those are the scenarios parents worry about most; images end up in someone else\u2019s hands, or made public. The sender\u2019s trust has been violated, and there can be legal implications.\n\nBut Dr. Ellen Selkie, an adolescent medicine specialist in the University of Michigan department of pediatrics, said, \u201cIt\u2019s far more common for kids to be doing it as part of a relationship with a boyfriend or girlfriend.\u201d When she is counseling parents about sexting, she said, \u201cI do try to present it as a manifestation of typical adolescent development \u2014 sexual experimenting is something kids have always done, and now we have digital media.\u201d", "title": "Teenagers Are Sexting \u2014 Now What?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Florida Students Began With Optimism.
