The Tefaf foundation or the dealers?\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cTefaf is a foundation that was formed by dealers, paid for by dealers, and it should be for the dealers. It\u2019s not a business for the people behind it. The focus, I think, should be the success of the dealers who participate. Everything else is not relevant.\u201d\n\nJames Roundell, a director of the Dickinson Gallery, who will step down as the modern chairman section after this year\u2019s fair, said he thought it was time for Tefaf to think bigger.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re living in a world where brand is all-important, so to be just a little art fair is no longer enough if you want a profile which is worldwide,\u201d he said. \u201cWe live in a world of brands; what is Nike if not a brand, what is Apple, what are Christie\u2019s and Sotheby\u2019s? There\u2019s no reason why Tefaf cannot be up there with them in terms of worldwide profile, with a little work.\u201d\n\nA longtime Tefaf participant, the old masters dealer Bob Haboldt, who has galleries in New York, Paris and Amsterdam, is optimistic about the changes. \u201cThe people who are now in charge, together with a younger board, have looked at Frieze and they\u2019ve looked at the weaknesses of other fairs, and they\u2019re trying to establish a fair that has its own trademark that they can export,\u201d he said in a telephone interview. \u201cIt\u2019s so far moderately successful at the Armory, but I don\u2019t think we\u2019re there yet.\u201d\n\nMr. Dekking also guessed that this was only the beginning of a process that would unfold over several years. As to what other kinds of services the brand might encompass, Mr. Dekking and Mr. van Maris said that they were working on a partnership called Tefaf Education with nearby Maastricht University to develop courses in art connoisseurship, for example. They said it was too soon to discuss any other specific plans.\n\n\u201cWe can dream about what you can do as a brand, but let\u2019s first establish the brand as much as we can,\u201d Mr. Dekking said. \u201cWe want to focus on the vetting committee, and I think we need a few years to establish the New York fair. The brand is only a brand when you can explain to people what you stand for.\u201d", "title": "Tefaf Widens Its Focus From Maastricht to a World of Art Collectors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is what hard-liners see, versus what other people see,\u201d one user wrote.\n\nHard-liners took a different view. \u201cA vulgar display, and the mayor is cheering it on,\u201d one wrote.\n\nMr. Najafi, who as an official in the Islamic republic has extremely little space to maneuver on the issue of limiting personal freedoms, replied that he had not clapped for the girls but for the musicians who were also on stage.\n\n\u201cThe organizers of the event,\u201d the Entekhab news website quoted him as saying, \u201csaid the girls were all under 8 years old, 9 years old, so the dancing was not against the Shariah law. However, I admit it would have been better had that part of the program not been performed.\u201d\n\nIt was too late.\n\nThe Tehran prosecutor\u2019s office summoned Mr. Najafi, and the City Council, which is dominated by reformist politicians like Mr. Najafi, held an emergency meeting to discuss the episode.\n\nDuring his short term as mayor of Tehran, a city of 12 million including the outskirts, Mr. Najafi was notably absent from the hard-liner-dominated state media. Some of his predecessors, among them Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Mohammad Bagher Qalibaf, used their years as mayor of the capital as steppingstones to national political roles. Mr. Ahmadinejad became president and Mr. Qalibaf the commander of the Revolutionary Guards.\n\nMr. Najafi, the first reformist to take on the post since 2005, seemed reined in. His administration did manage to hang billboards across the city honoring famous Iranian women, something unthinkable under the other administrations.\n\nBut as often happens in Iranian politics, victory goes to those who most rigidly interpret Islam.\n\nOn Wednesday Mr. Najafi handed in his resignation, a City Council member told the Fars news agency. Another council member said Mr. Najafi had resigned because of medical reasons.", "title": "Tehran\u2019s Mayor Watched a Dance Recital. Now He\u2019s the Ex-Mayor.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "What\u2019s the most surprising thing you learned while writing it?\n\nIt has taken me 15 years to finish this book, which allows for many opportunities to be surprised. The first was discovering, in a box of musty newsletters that my father dragged out of the barn, that he had also given me his journals. For the first time, I saw Haiti through his eyes. It was a perspective shift that changed how I remembered those hard years. We fought so much when I was a teenager that I didn\u2019t understand how much he loved Haiti.\n\nImage Apricot Irving Credit Tyler Merkel\n\nLater, when I returned for the first time with my parents and my husband in 2003, 12 years after we\u2019d left the missionary compound, I was surprised by how much beauty and strength and dignity was still flourishing in Haiti, despite the odds stacked against it. The story we\u2019d told in our missionary newsletters was consistent with the usual caricature of Haiti: desperately poor and in need of our help. That was not what I saw when I returned. In trying so hard to forget the pain and fear of those politically volatile adolescent years, I had also unwittingly forgotten the beauty and strength of Haiti.\n\nIn what way is the book you wrote different from the book you set out to write?\n\nI\u2019m a reluctant memoirist, and in one early draft I wrote, quite confidently: \u201cThis is not my story.\u201d I felt so safe behind those words. I was far more interested in interviewing the missionary dynasty that ran the hospital compound, and in telling the story of the rise and decline of the missionaries. I was at best an ancillary character. Over time, at the insistence of wise editors, I began to understand that the story needed to be grounded in my own subjectivity. I had to include my utter delight in Haiti as a six-year-old girl, swept away by its beauty and energy. And I had to include my years as a resentful teenage missionary\u2019s daughter. I had to lay bare my grief and fears and longings alongside the research and the interviews. To make it sing, I had to let my voice be heard.\n\nWho is a creative person (not a writer) who has influenced you and your work?\n\nThe Scottish land artist Andy Goldsworthy, whose work is featured in the documentary \u201cRivers and Tides,\u201d is an inspiration. His book \u201cEphemeral Works\u201d is folded open in our living room, and my husband and I take walks in the woods with our 10- and 12-year-old boys, creating art out of moss and icicles and river rocks and leaves. Goldsworthy describes how he listens to the materials \u2014 the ice, the stones, the branches \u2014 as he creates, which is how I would describe the process of weaving together the interviews, transcribed cassette tapes, journal entries, historical research and memories that compose this memoir.\n\nIn another life, I would so much prefer to be a land artist. Sentences are so permanent and exacting. I admire the freedom of creating art that disintegrates, or grows, or shifts into another form; there is such wisdom in the act of letting go.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Missionary\u2019s Daughter in Haiti", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "text": "There was a pretty intense reaction to the issue of taking the monuments down. My mother would say, \u201cI\u2019m not sure that\u2019s a smart thing to do.\u201d And I\u2019d walk through with her what the history is. And she said, \u201cWe didn\u2019t know any of that stuff. We didn\u2019t know whether Robert E. Lee ever stepped foot in New Orleans.\u201d A gentleman named James Loewen wrote a book called \u201cLies Across America\u201d that does an exhaustive job of going back and talking about miseducation.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn what way is the book you wrote different from the book you set out to write?\n\nI always conceptualized writing a book after finishing 30 years of government service, which I\u2019m getting ready to do in May. I assumed the book would be about how my team and the people of New Orleans rebuilt a great American city, what we actually did to turn the city around. Part of taking the monuments down, as much as it was about how the past informs the future, was also an aesthetic choice about how you rebuild a city and where you put physical structures. Steve Jobs always talked about the symbiotic relationship between function and design. Every mayor is in some ways an architect.\n\nBut then when I gave the speech, it reignited an issue that I had dealt with my entire life and was the culmination of not only my work but my father\u2019s work and a lot of people in the civil rights movement and probably the biggest issue in the country, which is race. I also thought about writing a memoir, so I decided to write about my life and how race has informed every step of it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho is a creative person (not a writer) who has influenced you and your work?\n\nI really wanted to be a professional actor when I was young. I got a degree in theater, and as a consequence I\u2019ve always had a keen ear for poets and playwrights. I always thought that\u2019s where the truth was, not just about human nature but also about history. And I was always drawn to the history of musical theater, Rodgers & Hammerstein and Leonard Bernstein. \u201cWest Side Story\u201d was one of my favorite shows. And in \u201cSouth Pacific,\u201d there\u2019s a song called \u201cYou\u2019ve Got to Be Carefully Taught,\u201d which is about where racism comes from. I can quote the lyrics: \u201cYou\u2019ve got to be taught before it\u2019s too late / Before you are six or seven or eight / To hate all the people your relatives hate / You\u2019ve got to be carefully taught.\u201d When I was doing these shows as a kid, the lyrics informed the way I was thinking about life.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe ultimate writer of the American songbook is Stephen Sondheim. He\u2019s been one of the more incredible inspirations in my creative thinking about how you form thoughts and communicate to people.\n\nPersuade someone to read \u201cIn the Shadow of Statues\u201d in 50 words or less.\n\nIt\u2019s essential if we really want to move forward that we do so together. We cannot do that unless we deal forthrightly with the issue of race. And unless and until we do that, we\u2019re never going to reach that aspirational moment where out of many we are one.\n\nThis interview has been condensed and edited.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: The Mayor of New Orleans on Rethinking Southern History", "authors": ["John Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cI felt proud that I\u2019d fought, or something like proud, but also glad it was over.\u201d That\u2019s the narrator of one story in Will Mackin\u2019s debut collection, \u201cBring Out the Dog.\u201d During his time in the United States Navy, Mr. Mackin was deployed with SEAL teams on assignments in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere. When he came home, he relied on notes he kept during his time in combat to write these stories, three of which have appeared in The New Yorker. Below, Mr. Mackin talks about the experiences that inspired the book, why he chose to write fiction, a Pink Floyd lyric that has influenced his life and more.\n\nWhen did you first get the idea to write this book?\n\nI\u2019ve always wanted to write, as long as I can remember. The idea for this particular book came out of the sensory details of the wars. When I was deploying with a SEAL team in Iraq and Afghanistan, our mission was night raids, and we wore night vision. There was a disconnect between the actual image and the image I was seeing in the goggles, and in some of the transmission \u2014 I could hear the guy next to me speaking on the radio, and a few seconds later I\u2019d hear his voice in my head on delay. The voice would sound different but all the words were the same.\n\nNothing directly appears as what it is. Especially at night, when you\u2019re seeing things basically in three different forms: the heat-and-light image in night vision; the silhouette in darkness I\u2019d see in my peripheral or if I looked under the goggles; and the image I knew \u2014 like, if I was looking at a teammate, the guy I was familiar with, my memory of what he looked like in daylight. That sort of sensory confusion really stuck with me.\n\nWhat\u2019s the most surprising thing you learned while writing it?\n\nProbably how much of writing isn\u2019t writing. My work ethic prior to this, in terms of writing, was: More is better. I tried to sit at the desk and generate more. If I was stuck, I thought, \u201cAll I have to do is just sit here and think about it more.\u201d But I learned that I had to take a break when it just wasn\u2019t working. I did stuff around the house \u2014 things that were repetitive and didn\u2019t require a lot of thought. We live out near Albuquerque, and we have grass, which is rare. Our sprinkler system was broken. I dug up a line to fix, and then another, and I ended up digging up the whole network of lines in the backyard. It was hard work. It was knotted with roots and all kinds of craziness. My mind was occupied with other things, and ideas came.", "title": "Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Turning SEAL Assignments Into Stories", "authors": ["John Williams"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The nearly 17-year-old Afghanistan conflict, the longest war in United States history, will not end on the battlefield. It can be resolved only at the negotiating table. So, the bold offer last month from President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan to negotiate with the Taliban \u201cwithout preconditions\u201d is a welcome initiative. But it faces daunting obstacles.\n\nMr. Ghani\u2019s proposal envisions an outcome in which the Taliban would be recognized as a legitimate political party, prisoners would be released and United Nations sanctions against the group would be lifted. In exchange, the Taliban would have to recognize the Afghan government and respect the rule of law, including women\u2019s rights.\n\nSecretary of Defense Jim Mattis, during a surprise visit to Afghanistan this week, said there was evidence that some Taliban factions are interested in talks. The Taliban have not responded formally to Mr. Ghani\u2019s proposal, but in the past they have refused to negotiate directly with the Afghan government, which they deem an American puppet. Instead, the Taliban have insisted on direct talks with the United States that exclude the Kabul government, as a way to discredit it. The United States has long supported an Afghan-led peace process, in which Washington might play a role but would not stand in for the Afghan government.\n\nAssuming the Taliban refuse Mr. Ghani\u2019s offer, it\u2019s timely to ask: Is there an alternative to an indefinite United States military presence in Afghanistan?", "title": "Opinion | Tell the Truth About Our Longest War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "From early on, Mr. Balter said, he was attracted to Pan\u2019s complicated story: The demigod makes beautiful music, but on a flute fashioned in anger when the nymph Syrinx is turned into water reeds to protect her from Pan\u2019s advances. His arrogance leads to misdeeds that, when revealed \u2014 his \u201cHarvey Weinstein moment,\u201d Mr. Fitch said \u2014 bring about his downfall and death.\n\n\u201cThere are so many issues here about how one deals with power, and even love and consent,\u201d Mr. Balter said of the piece, which he added was conceived years before the #MeToo movement but now has even more relevance.\n\nStill, the production eludes attachment to a specific time or place. It has the feeling of a primitive ritual, or a \u201cvery long s\u00e9ance,\u201d as Mr. Balter put it. By using Lingua Ignota \u2014 a secret language invented by Hildegard of Bingen, the polymathic medieval abbess and composer \u2014 for the libretto, he also aimed to strip the storytelling of connections to any particular culture.\n\nPhoto\n\nPerforming in an invented language is just one more challenge for the part of Pan, played by Ms. Chase on an array of flutes as small as the piccolo and as large as the mammoth contrabass flute. The music is dizzying in its rhythms and endlessly shifting dynamics. At times, Ms. Chase vocalizes while inhaling, then sounds the flute on the exhale. She does all of this while also acting, which under Mr. Fitch\u2019s direction requires dancelike movement.\n\nFor the opening scene, the death of Pan, Mr. Balter wanted to create \u201csomething that would look exhausting,\u201d he said. Ms. Chase said that she feels like she\u2019s \u201cgoing to die\u201d most of the time, but added that her relationship with Mr. Balter has always involved pushing each other\u2019s limits.\n\n\u201cPart of \u2018Density\u2019 has always been a line of inquiry,\u201d she said. \u201cOnce we\u2019ve reached a threshold and the body\u2019s been extended, it\u2019s time to ask how you extend even further.\u201d\n\nPreparing the rest of the cast is not unlike passing on oral history. Rehearsals have been almost as ritualistic as \u201cPan\u201d itself, with Mr. Fitch and Mr. Balter explaining scenes and acting them, then asking the performers to follow their lead. Kingmelvin Brown \u2014 a 65-year-old from the Roundtable Center with his face shaved clean down the middle, including one eyebrow \u2014 said he appreciated the rehearsal style because it was \u201cout of the box, just like me.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the children, learning the piece with Mr. Balter, Mr. Fitch and Ms. Chase was like school, \u201conly fun,\u201d said Sean Little, an 11-year-old student at All City Leadership Academy in Brooklyn. His friend Raymond Hughes Bullard, also an 11-year-old student at the school, said that learning \u201cPan\u201d was like playing a video game in which opening night is the same as facing a final adversary.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThey haven\u2019t just accepted \u2018Pan,\u2019\u201d Ms. Chase said of the boys, who have been with \u201cPan\u201d since its early stages of development. \u201cThey\u2019re constantly interrogating it.\u201d\n\nAll the creators are, in fact. \u201cI\u2019m not saying we don\u2019t fight like cats and disagree,\u201d Ms. Chase added, \u201cbut my definition of a great rehearsal is one in which I\u2019m transformed, leaving with different ideas and new worlds opened up. I get that with Doug and Marcos.\u201d\n\nEven as she is immersed in preparations, Ms. Chase is plotting future installments of \u201cDensity,\u201d which will feature collaborations with female composers including Pamela Z, Olga Neuwirth, Liza Lim and Phyllis Chen. But \u201cPan\u201d will have an ongoing life: After it ends its run at the Kitchen, it will head to Chicago, and Ms. Saks said Project& is in talks to take it abroad to places in Mexico, Brazil and the Middle East.\n\nWhile there will be new community participants at each location, the boys of \u201cPan\u201d are hoping they can stay involved with Ms. Chase. After winning the lunch-break game of basketball against her \u2014 their first win after a long streak of losses \u2014 they were sure this wouldn\u2019t be their last collaboration.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to let her go,\u201d Mr. Little said. \u201cI say we do another god next. How about Apollo?\u201d", "title": "Telling a Demigod\u2019s Story Through \u2018Collective Virtuosity\u2019", "authors": ["Joshua Barone"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf I could, I would tile the world,\u201d Gerry Eisenberg said. \u201cBecause I think it is the most wonderful medium.\u201d\n\nMs. Eisenberg has not yet paved the streets in one-by-one-inch squares. But last summer, she did install a large mosaic in her master bathroom. Spidery tree branches rendered in stone tile are accented with 24-karat gold glass pieces incorporated in the form of delicate leaves. The mosaic design, executed by the company New Ravenna, takes up the entire shower wall, with a unifying ribbon of leaves encircling the room.\n\nAfter renovating her historic 1920 house in Aiken, S.C., Ms. Eisenberg saved the bath project to do in a special way. \u201cWhat is more wonderful than mosaic? What is more traditional?\u201d she said. \u201cBut mosaic with gold glass to give it that modern zip.\u201d\n\nTile mosaics, often associated with churches and the Roman Empire, are hardly modern. But with the current maximalist insurgency in the design world, with the entirely welcome return of color and pattern and idiosyncratic interiors, elaborate tile installations may soon follow wallpaper as an old-fashioned adornment updated and rediscovered.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn these handcrafted mosaics, you get pattern on pattern on pattern,\u201d said Cean Irminger, creative director for the Virginia-based New Ravenna, which recently unveiled a new collection of designs, including \u201cMod Palm,\u201d a tropical motif that blends glossy and matte glass. \u201cIt can be super intricate and detailed.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKim Wozniak, who runs WitsEnd Mosaic, an online tile store that sells to both artists and homeowners, said glass tile is surprisingly adaptable. \u201cEverybody thinks of this old Byzantine style,\u201d she said. \u201cBut it can really be anything you want it to be\u201d \u2014 or go anywhere, not just in bathrooms and kitchens. \u201cFoyers, for example. You can do it like a rug, but it\u2019s inlaid in the floor.\u201d", "title": "Telling a Story Through Tiles", "authors": ["Steven Kurutz"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "In tennis, few things arouse the crowd more than confrontations, especially those involving players, umpires and line judges.\n\nWho can forget Ilie Nastase pulling down his pants and mooning the chair umpire Charles Hare in Palm Springs in 1976? Or John McEnroe at Wimbledon in 1981 screaming, \u201cYou cannot be serious, man!\u201d after what he perceived to be an incorrect call, and referring to the umpire Edward James as the \u201cabsolute pits of the world\u201d?\n\nOr that night at the 2009 United States Open when Serena Williams cursed at and threatened to stuff a tennis ball down the throat of the line judge Shino Tsurubuchi for calling a foot fault, an incident that cost Williams her semifinal match against Kim Clijsters?\n\nBut tennis tantrums could soon go by the wayside. The ATP World Tour, the governing body of men\u2019s professional tennis, is testing Hawk-Eye Live, an electronic line-calling device that would eliminate the need for line judges. The system will be discussed by ATP leadership and then debated by players and officials during ATP Council meetings at Wimbledon this summer.", "title": "Tennis Moves Toward Taking the Human Element Out of Line Calls", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe G.O.P. Locks In a Judicial Legacy\u201d (editorial, Feb. 27):\n\nThe \u201ccynical ploy\u201d by Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, to refuse to consider any Supreme Court nominee from President Barack Obama, so as to let Americans \u201chave a voice in the selection\u201d through their votes in the 2016 presidential election, may give rise to the same fate of future attempted appointments.\n\nJudicial appointments have become far too political, something they were never intended to be. As you said, Justice Neil Gorsuch could easily be issuing opinions four decades from now.\n\nI believe that the time has come to limit the term of a Supreme Court justice to 8 to 10 years. At the very least this change would prevent radical political appointees from handing down ultraconservative opinions for possibly 40-plus years.\n\nIf we can\u2019t remove politics from political appointments, then we should at the very least place a term limit upon them. But this will require a constitutional amendment.", "title": "Opinion | Term Limits for Justices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "Tesla\u2019s reversal of fortune is a jolt for both the company and its chief executive, who had built a reputation not only as a visionary but also as an achiever, masterminding an automotive brand, breaking ground on a battery plant that would be the world\u2019s biggest building, and launching rockets through his SpaceX venture.\n\nFor years, Tesla has ridden a wave of enthusiastic support from its customers and a certain set of investors, even though it generated barely any profit in the 15 years since its founding. Company events to present new models tend to have the feel of a religious revival, with hundreds or thousands of owners cheering wildly at each new pronouncement from Mr. Musk. Anticipation for the Model 3 prompted nearly 400,000 prospective customers to put down deposits of $1,000 each.\n\nIn November, before a screaming audience of several hundred guests, Mr. Musk unveiled a battery-powered semi truck and a two-seat roadster. He vowed to begin producing the truck by the end of 2019, even though the company does not have a factory to build it, and is still trying to work the kinks out of the Model 3 assembly process at its manufacturing plant in Fremont, Calif.\n\n\u201cThere is a huge part of Tesla that is simply presentation and not substance, and Elon is a master at messaging,\u201d said Karl Brauer, a senior analyst at Kelley Blue Book. \u201cThe problem is the reality is starting to stack up, and that\u2019s a reality of accidents the cars have had, quality issues, and massive misses on Model 3 production numbers. You add all that up and there\u2019s a real question about whether this company can deliver what it promises.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s no doubt Tesla has achieved some breakthroughs that have left the established automakers scrambling to catch up. It has proved that there is a viable market for electric cars, and that they can command premium prices. It has pioneered methods of upgrading cars through software updates beamed over the air, the way iPhones can download new operating systems.\n\nAnd it was Autopilot that set off a race to develop advanced driver-assistance systems that can guide cars under certain circumstances and actively prevent collisions \u2014 though Tesla\u2019s technology appears to have been surpassed by the self-driving systems from other companies, including G.M. and the Google spinoff Waymo.\n\nAlong the way, Mr. Musk has also courted controversy, including his move in 2016 for Tesla to take over SolarCity, a maker of home solar panels run by his cousin. A group of investors has filed a lawsuit contending that Mr. Musk had a conflict of interest because he was SolarCity\u2019s chairman, and this week a judge cleared the way for the case to go forward.", "title": "Tesla Looked Like the Future. Now Some Ask if It Has One.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Tesla said on Friday that its semiautonomous Autopilot feature had been turned on before a fiery crash of a Model X sport-utility vehicle that killed the driver last week in California, raising more questions about the safety of the company\u2019s self-driving technology.\n\nThis is the second fatal crash in which the Autopilot system had been engaged, including a 2016 crash in Florida that killed a Tesla driver. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration concluded that the Florida crash did not result from a flaw in the system, but the agency found that the system lacked safeguards to prevent its misuse.\n\nFederal investigators are looking into the crash in California, which occurred March 23.\n\nThe company said in a statement posted on its website that the driver in the crash last week had \u201cabout five seconds and 150 meters of unobstructed view\u201d before he crashed into a median barrier, adding that \u201cthe vehicle logs show that no action was taken.\u201d The driver, Wei Huang, had been given \u201cseveral visual and one audible hands-on warning earlier in the drive,\u201d Tesla said.\n\nStill, Tesla defended its Autopilot hardware. In its statement, the company said there was one automotive fatality for every 86 million miles across all vehicles in the United States, compared with one fatality for every 320 million miles in vehicles equipped with Autopilot.", "title": "Tesla Says Crashed Vehicle Had Been on Autopilot Before Fatal Accident", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-18 00:00:00", "text": "When Carolina\u2019s wing players went inside after that early block, one could almost feel their caution. In the second half, the mere threat of Williams lurking down low caused Joel Berry II to turn a routine drive into a circus layup that failed to drop.\n\nWilliams\u2019s block was one of eight for the Aggies. With the inside closed off, the Tar Heels shifted to 3-pointers. They entered Sunday averaging 22.7 attempts per game; on Sunday, they tried 31. They shot 36.7 percent from deep during the season; they shot 19.4 percent on Sunday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The highest No. 2 on the men\u2019s basketball committee\u2019s seed line, the Tar Heels were pegged by many for a third consecutive trip to the Final Four.\n\nThe atmosphere here was predictably heavy in their favor. Except for one loud section set aside for Texas A&M fans, Charlotte\u2019s Spectrum Center may as well have been Chapel Hill\u2019s Dean Dome. Because of that and Carolina\u2019s reputation, what was numerically a blowout felt a little more tenuous. When Berry hit a 3-pointer with just under 10 minutes left, the crowd came alive as though he had cut the Aggies\u2019 lead to 5, not 19.\n\nThe Tar Heels were able to make up a little ground late with an aggressive, trapping defense and a dash of Aggies conservatism on offense. But the game had been effectively blown open by then.\n\nAt one point late, the Aggies\u2019 lead comfortably in double-digits, the Tar Heels\u2019 press forced a turnover and a fast break led by the senior Theo Pinson. He put it home with a windmill dunk.", "title": "Texas A&M Swats Second-Seeded North Carolina From Tournament", "authors": ["Marc Tracy"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe have a code for it so we can track it,\u201d said Chief Acevedo, who requires his officers to document all immigration-status interactions. \u201cWhen we reviewed the data two weeks ago, out of tens of thousands of contacts this department has had, we\u2019ve had two inquiries.\u201d\n\nSenate Bill 4, or S.B. 4, does not require all officers to ask about a person\u2019s immigration status, but instead allows them to ask those questions at the officers\u2019 discretion.\n\nThe low number of reported inquiries illustrates the conflict between the state Republican leaders behind the law and local elected officials and law enforcement in largely Democratic major cities like Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio.\n\nOfficials in those cities, several of which have sued Texas seeking to overturn the law, are trying to walk a fine line between complying with the measure and minimizing its impact on their operations. They have followed requests from immigration authorities to hold detainees suspected of being in the country illegally \u2014 another provision in S.B. 4 \u2014 while reassuring anxious and outraged immigrants in their communities.\n\nAfter the ruling on Tuesday, the mayor of Houston, Sylvester Turner, made an unscheduled appearance at a rally by opponents of the law outside City Hall. \u201cIt remains my position that the Houston Police Department is not U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and H.P.D. should not function as an arm of ICE,\u201d Mr. Turner said later in a statement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nState leaders were unwavering. \u201cHopefully this ruling will make the law crystal clear for those liberal public officials in some Texas cities who have flaunted their opposition to S.B. 4 and misrepresented its intent,\u201d Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, a Republican, said in a statement.\n\nSupporters of the law viewed the ruling as a victory, including conservative leaders in other states seeking to pass similar bans on sanctuary cities, jurisdictions that limit cooperation between local law enforcement and federal immigration authorities.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepublican lawmakers in Florida tried but failed to pass a bill banning sanctuary cities this legislative session. But the Republican speaker of the Florida House, Richard Corcoran, who has pushed for a crackdown, said the ruling on Tuesday in the Texas case would help their cause.\n\n\u201cThe linchpin of the sanctuary defenders\u2019 argument was that courts would find such legislation unconstitutional,\u201d Mr. Corcoran said in a statement. \u201cWe knew they were wrong, and today the court agreed. Any elected official who thinks they can choose which laws they will and will not follow is sadly mistaken and this ruling reinforces that fundamental American truth.\u201d\n\nIn addition to prohibiting sanctuary policies, S.B. 4 threatens officials who violate the law with fines, jail time and removal from office. The measure was backed by the state\u2019s Republican governor and lieutenant governor, and passed by the Republican-controlled Legislature.\n\nAustin, Dallas, Houston and other cities and counties sued Texas to block the law, saying it was unconstitutional, opened the door to racial profiling and would make documented and undocumented immigrants fearful of reporting crimes and cooperating with the police.\n\nThe ruling on Tuesday by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit only complicates the situation. Parts of the law went into effect after a court ruling in September. The Fifth Circuit opinion allows nearly all of the law\u2019s provisions to kick in, although lawyers for the localities and groups suing the state said they were considering appealing the decision to either the full Fifth Circuit or the Supreme Court.\n\nDespite upholding most of the law\u2019s provisions, the Fifth Circuit\u2019s decision could narrow the effect of the law. The ruling suggested that local officials who limit their cooperation with federal immigration enforcement because of limited resources were not necessarily violating the law.\n\n\u201cIt is not 100 percent obvious what is allowed and not allowed as far as policymaking,\u201d said Thomas A. Saenz, the president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, which represents San Antonio and other jurisdictions and groups in the lawsuit. \u201cYou don\u2019t know how it\u2019s going to be put into effect in the field.\u201d\n\nThe Fifth Circuit judges struck down one provision of the law \u2014 a clause that had barred officials even from endorsing policies that limit immigration enforcement, which the judges said violated the First Amendment. But some local leaders are concerned that the free speech rights of city employees remain restricted by the law, because the judges lifted the endorsement prohibition only for elected officials and not for nonelected government personnel.\n\nOn Wednesday in San Antonio, some of those dynamics seemed to be at play. Shortly before the start of a news conference held by groups opposed to the law, Councilman Rey Salda\u00f1a wondered whether the city\u2019s police chief, William McManus, would speak at the event. Mr. Salda\u00f1a invited Chief McManus \u2014 who is an appointed official, not an elected one \u2014 but the chief did not attend.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m protected according to the Fifth Circuit, because I\u2019m an elected official, but the police chief is not,\u201d Mr. Salda\u00f1a said. \u201cHe works for the city. It gets us to the point where we might just have to wear a muzzle around our face with respect to whether we can truly represent the interests of community members that come to us.\u201d", "title": "Texas Banned \u2018Sanctuary Cities.\u2019 Some Police Departments Didn\u2019t Get the Memo.", "authors": ["Manny Fernandez"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "HOUSTON \u2014 Texas Democrats surged to the polls on Tuesday in the first primary of 2018, demonstrating a wave of Trump-inspired energy, but also showcasing party divisions that have emerged at the outset of an otherwise promising midterm campaign.\n\nNearly 886,000 Texans cast ballots early in the state\u2019s 15 most populous counties, the highest early-vote turnout in a nonpresidential election year in state history. And more Democrats statewide voted early this year than even in 2016, the year that Donald J. While wearing a standard brace, he tried to return for No. 2 seed Purdue\u2019s win over Butler, but the rule would not allow it.\n\nSo before Friday\u2019s matchup with No. 3 seed Texas Tech, he was outfitted with a new brace. The N.C.A.A. said it would amend its rules to allow Haas to play, and he warmed up gingerly. But ultimately he remained rooted to the bench, a critical absence for Purdue in a 78-65 loss to the Red Raiders at TD Garden.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout its 7-foot-2 center, the Boilermakers were outrebounded by the Red Raiders, nearly outscored in the paint, and overwhelmed by one of the nation\u2019s best defensive teams.", "title": "Texas Tech Advances Past Purdue\u2019s Diminished Frontcourt", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "The Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, and Gov. Greg Abbott praised the decision in statements on Tuesday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cSenate Bill 4 is lawful, constitutional and protects the safety of law enforcement officers and all Texans,\u201d Mr. Paxton said. \u201cEnforcing immigration law prevents the release of individuals from custody who have been charged with serious crimes. Dangerous criminals shouldn\u2019t be allowed back into our communities to possibly commit more crimes.\u201d\n\nThe Texas case is one segment of a national debate over sanctuary cities and immigration. Several of the nation\u2019s largest cities \u2014 including Chicago, New York, Philadelphia and San Francisco \u2014 have adopted sanctuary policies, and three months into Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency, the Justice Department threatened to cut funding to such cities. This month, the administration sued California, accusing it of trying to \u201cobstruct the United States\u2019 enforcement of federal immigration law.\u201d\n\nAmong those challenging the Texas law were several of the state\u2019s largest cities and counties \u2014 including Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio, as well as El Paso County \u2014 and a number of advocacy groups. Reacting to Tuesday\u2019s ruling, many of them expressed disappointment but also resolve.\n\n\u201cImmigration is a federal responsibility, and forcing local law enforcement to take on immigration enforcement is bad for community safety, as we heard numerous times in testimony from police chiefs and sheriffs,\u201d State Senator Jos\u00e9 Rodr\u00edguez, whose district includes El Paso County, said in a statement. \u201cI am looking forward to an appeal regarding the constitutionality of this misguided, anti-immigrant law.\u201d\n\nIn his own statement, Mayor Ron Nirenberg of San Antonio said his city would \u201ccontinue to honor the law, including individual civil rights.\u201d\n\nLee Gelernt, a lawyer for several of the plaintiffs, said they were considering whether to appeal and would probably make a decision this week. The first step in an appeal would most likely be to request a review by the full Fifth Circuit court.\n\nMr. Gelernt, deputy director of the American Civil Liberties Union\u2019s Immigrants\u2019 Rights Project, said his organization would also be monitoring how the law was carried out. He said that certain activities, like immigration arrests, were the exclusive responsibility of the federal government, and that the A.C.L.U. could file challenges in specific cases if Immigration and Customs Enforcement demanded that local officials take such actions \u2014 or if evidence of racial discrimination came to light.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added that local officials had been given little guidance as to what requests they were and were not allowed to refuse, and that with huge penalties on the line \u2014 violations of S.B. 4 can be punished with jail time or fines ranging from $1,000 to $25,500 \u2014 some officials might cooperate with illegal requests out of fear. (The Fifth Circuit judges noted that officials uncertain about the legality of a request from ICE could contact Mr. Paxton\u2019s office for guidance, and Mr. Gelernt said the A.C.L.U. would monitor whether the office actually provided such guidance.)", "title": "Texas\u2019 Ban on \u2018Sanctuary Cities\u2019 Can Begin, Appeals Court Rules", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 Twenty migrant workers from Myanmar were killed when their bus caught fire in northwestern Thailand early Friday, the police said.\n\nThe workers were traveling to a factory district near Bangkok when their chartered bus was engulfed in flames around 1:30 a.m. in Tak Province.\n\nThe cause of the fire was not yet known, said Col. Krissana Pattanacharoen, a Royal Thai Police spokesman. The authorities were planning to interview the driver, who survived the fire.\n\nThe bus was carrying 47 people, and 27 escaped, Colonel Krissana said. But 20 others were killed in the fire, which incinerated the double-decker bus and left it a charred shell on the roadside.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe are trying to identify the bodies and also trying to contact the Myanmar Consulate in order to identify the bodies,\u201d Colonel Krissana said. \u201cThey are Buddhists, so we\u2019ve got to send them back to their hometown for religious ceremonies there.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKittasak Boonchan, an administrator of a rescue group in Tak Province, said he arrived at the scene around 2:30 a.m., about 20 minutes after the first rescue team.", "title": "Thailand Bus Fire Kills 20 Migrant Workers From Myanmar", "authors": ["Austin Ramzy"]} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nAlmost everyone who lives or works in a big city knows the feeling: You\u2019re sitting inside a quiet subway car when the doors open and a throng of children \u2014 often on a class trip \u2014 boards the train. Your quiet car is suddenly loud and packed with people jostling for space. Sometimes, it\u2019s worth moving to another car.\n\nOn my morning commute yesterday, one of these throngs entered my subway car, but this time I didn\u2019t mind at all. The teenagers \u2014 a mix of black, white, Latino and Asian \u2014 were in a buoyant mood. Many were carrying signs. They were headed to a gun protest outside the White House.\n\nAt times yesterday, the protesting students seemed to be everywhere \u2014 on social media, on television, in communities. And they offered a needed jolt of inspiration in a dark political time. David Axelrod, the political strategist, has said that today\u2019s central political battle is cynicism versus idealism, and it\u2019s clear which side the students are on.", "title": "Opinion | Thank a Teenager", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRE: RUSSIA\n\nKarl Ove Knausgaard wrote about his journey into the heart of Russia.\n\nWhen I think of Russia, I try to bypass my present political impressions. This has been a country that has seen its share of suffering and suppression, but through its turmoil, it has gifted us with some of the best literature and music of the world: Tolstoy and Pasternak, Rachmaninoff, Tchaikovsky and Borodin\u2019s ethereal \u201cPolovtsian Dances.\u201d I see a people who are poets and who are still searching.\n\nMy mother-in-law, long passed, grew up in that part of the world, eastern Poland, then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. During World War I, she was inadvertently shot during a battle and subsequently hospitalized. One day she was seen crying by a recuperating Russian soldier. He reached out and kindly said to her: \u201cPlease stop your tears. You will be happy and healthy and have five wonderful sons.\u201d She never forgot him. After becoming an American citizen, she would retell that story to each of her four sons. Kathy Lollock, Santa Rosa, Calif.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen I was growing up in India, the \u201cgood vs. evil\u201d narrative wasn\u2019t as omnipresent given that our now discarded system of state-controlled socialism was modeled after the U.S.S.R. The following line from Knausgaard so aptly sums up my feelings: \u201cWhen I got older and started to read, the situation became more complicated, because it was from Russia that the best and most intense literature came.\u201d I must have been 12 when I read my first Chekhov short story. To me, he remains the most eloquent and honest storyteller of the human condition. For so long now, I have wanted to travel to Russia to see Chekhov\u2019s towns and villages and meet and get to know the people, but somehow I never got around to it. I have been to other parts of the former U.S.S.R., which has only heightened the fascination. I know I, too, am guilty of \u201cmyths and romantic imagery.\u201d This lovely read made my Russia travel lust even greater. Will be sure to reread it when I finally make my trip to Russia. Sharadiya, New York\n\nRE: BLACK PANTHER\n\nCarvell Wallace wrote about the significance of the \u201cBlack Panther\u201d film to black audiences.\n\nPhoto\n\nFantastic article. Years ago, I remember Michelle Obama was chastised by white Americans for saying something like: For the first time in my life, I am proud of my country. I remember my rage at the reaction. Did white Americans know nothing of the history of oppression? It is easy for me to understand the disillusionment of African-Americans with a country that has systematically abused and rejected them. Even today, Waco, Tex., has no memorial to Jesse Washington, a man whose horrific murder in that city in 1916 led to a national outcry against lynching.", "title": "The 2.18.18 Issue", "authors": ["The New York Times Magazine"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "As a fellow academic who has studied the topic of interpersonal forgiveness from a psychological perspective for almost 30 years, I have to respectfully disagree when Prof. Charles L. Griswold makes a distinction between forgiveness and mercy but does not explain the difference. He is correct that someone can only forgive for the way he or she was deeply hurt. However, forgiveness falls under the category of mercy because when someone forgives, that person is showing mercy, a sort of kindness, to the offender, who does not necessarily deserve this mercy because of his or her hurtful actions.\n\nGriswold accurately points out how forgiveness is not condoning or accepting further injury, but the working through and letting go of anger and other negative feelings. It is courageous and difficult to forgive, and it is not something often done overnight. It took the incest survivors I worked with, on average, 14.3 months to forgive their abusers. Suzanne Freedman, Ph.D., University of Northern Iowa\n\nThe word \u201cforgiveness\u201d has never felt as if it were the right word to use when I\u2019ve had to move on from a hurtful or malicious action by another. My first reaction generally is to give no reaction to the wrongful deed. That way the person can either reach out to me with an apology or sit and contemplate what just happened. If they do nothing, then it\u2019s easy. I just move on and take it as an indication that we no longer need to deal with each other. I owe it to myself to not allow toxic people into my life. Although, I will admit that I have asked myself this as well: \u201cHow much time do I want to spend on this?\u201d If my answer is \u201cnone,\u201d then it\u2019s easy to move on. There are times when I\u2019ve wanted to resolve issues with people and it has generally been worth the effort. Pick your battles. Deanna Haddow Voelker, Cambria, Calif.", "title": "The 2.25.18 Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "For Democrats, the Pew and CAP calculations suggest that because the noncollege white vote remains highly significant, the party and its candidates need to prevent any further erosion in this constituency that went so strongly for Trump.\n\nThe corollary for Republicans is that the party, already behind in the popular vote, cannot afford to suffer continued losses among college-educated white voters, especially college-educated women. Pew found by 2017, a year into the Trump presidency:\n\nVoters who have completed college make up a third of all registered voters. And a majority \u2014 58 percent \u2014 of all voters with at least a four-year college degree now identifies as Democrats or leans Democratic, the highest share dating back to 1992. Just 36 percent affiliate with the Republican Party or lean toward the G.O.P.\n\nThis danger has become more acute, according to the Pew study:\n\nThe share of women identifying as Democrats or leaning Democratic is up 4 percentage points since 2015 and is at one of its highest points since 1992.\n\nAt the same time, though, Trump appears to be strengthening Republican support among noncollege whites:\n\nVoters with no college experience have been moving toward the GOP: 47 percent identify with or lean toward the Republican Party, up from 42 percent in 2014.\n\nThe Pew and CAP studies received relatively little publicity compared to the massive coverage of the exit polls, raising the question of how much the political community will adjust to the conflicting data.\n\nMichael McDonald, a political scientist at the University of Florida who studies the intricacies of polling, is not optimistic:\n\nIn real time on election night, the exit polls set a narrative, and for a long time there is no other data that changes that narrative, and that narrative solidifies into place and it\u2019s really hard to get past it.\n\nPolling that provides an inaccurate picture of the electorate does more than undermine partisan strategy and media analysis. Trevor Tompson, vice president of NORC (formerly the National Opinion Research Center) at the University of Chicago, emailed me:\n\nThe overrepresentation of college-educated voters, and especially those with postgraduate degrees, has long been a known issue with the in-person exit poll.\n\nHe then added:\n\nThe bottom line is we need to have much better data for the health of our democracy.\n\nFor Democrats, these questions are a matter of competitive survival.\n\nTeixeira of the Center for American Politics and William Galston of The Brookings Institution, two longtime Democratic strategists, suggest different but complementary directions in which to take the Democratic Party going forward.\n\nGalston, writing in the March 16 Wall Street Journal, argues that Democrats need to moderate their stand on immigration in order to win over white noncollege voters.\n\n\u201cNo issue has done more than immigration to feed populism, and finding a sustainable compromise would drain much of the bile from today\u2019s politics,\u201d Galston writes. He continues:\n\nDefenders of liberal democracy should acknowledge that controlling borders is a legitimate exercise of sovereignty, and that the appropriate number and type of immigrants is a legitimate subject for debate. Denouncing citizens concerned about immigration as bigots ameliorates neither the substance nor the politics of the problem. There\u2019s nothing illiberal about the view that too many immigrants stress a country\u2019s capacity to absorb them, so that a reduction or even a pause may be in order.\n\nTeixeira points out that if Clinton had done as well with white working-class voters as Obama\n\nshe would have carried, with robust margins, the states of Michigan, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, and Iowa, as well as Florida and Ohio. In fact, if Clinton could simply have reduced the shift toward Donald Trump among these voters by one-quarter, she would have won.\n\nIn Alabama\u2019s special Senate election, Doug Jones, the winning Democrat, would have lost if he had not made substantial inroads with the white working class, Teixeira argued:\n\nWithout the hefty swing among the white non-college population, particularly women, there is no way Jones would have won the state, or even come close.\n\nTeixeira concluded:\n\nThere is no way around it \u2014 if Democrats hope to be competitive in Ohio and similar states in 2020, they must do the hard thing: find a way to reach hearts and minds among white non-college voters.\n\nLet\u2019s go back to Galston, writing on the Brookings website, presciently, in June 2016. I will quote him at some length, because in my opinion no one captures the situation better than he does:\n\nMost working-class whites have incomes below $50,000; most whites with BAs or more have incomes above $50,000. Most working-class whites rate their financial circumstances as only fair or poor; most college educated whites rate their financial circumstances as good or excellent. Fifty-four percent of working-class whites think of themselves as working class or lower class, compared to only 18 percent of better-educated whites \u2026.\n\n\n\nIn many respects, these two groups of white voters see the world very differently. For example, 54 percent of college-educated whites think that America\u2019s culture and way of life have improved since the 1950s; 62 percent of white working-class Americans think that it has changed for the worse. Sixty-eight percent of working-class whites, but only 47 percent of college-educated whites, believe that the American way of life needs to be protected against foreign influences. Sixty-six percent of working-class whites, but only 43 percent of college-educated whites, say that discrimination against whites has become as big a problem as discrimination against blacks and other minorities. In a similar vein, 62 percent of working-class whites believe that discrimination against Christians has become as big a problem as discrimination against other groups, a proposition only 38 percent of college educated whites endorse.\n\nThis brings us to the issue of immigration. By a margin of 52 to 35 percent, college-educated whites affirm that today\u2019s immigrants strengthen our country through their talent and hard work. Conversely, 61 percent of white working-class voters say that immigrants weaken us by taking jobs, housing, and health care. Seventy-one percent of working-class whites think that immigrants mostly hurt the economy by driving down wages, a belief endorsed by only 44 percent of college-educated whites. Fifty-nine percent of working-class whites believe that we should make a serious effort to deport all illegal immigrants back to their home countries; only 33 percent of college-educated whites agree. Fifty-five percent of working-class whites think we should build a wall along our border with Mexico, while 61 percent of whites with BAs or more think we should not. Majorities of working-class whites believe that we should make the entry of Syrian refugees into the United States illegal and temporarily ban the entrance of non-American Muslims into our country; about two-thirds of college-educated whites oppose each of these proposals.\n\nOpinions on trade follow a similar pattern. By a narrow margin of 48 to 46 percent, college-educated whites endorse the view that trade agreements are mostly helpful to the United States because they open up overseas markets while 62 percent of working-class whites believe that they are harmful because they send jobs overseas and drive down wages.\n\nIt is understandable that working-class whites are more worried that they or their families will become victims of violent crime than are whites with more education. After all, they are more likely to live in neighborhoods with higher levels of social disorder and criminal behavior. It is harder to explain why they are also much more likely to believe that their families will fall victim to terrorism. To be sure, homegrown terrorist massacres of recent years have driven home the message that it can happen to anyone, anywhere. We still need to explain why working-class whites have interpreted this message in more personal terms.\n\nThe most plausible interpretation is that working-class whites are experiencing a pervasive sense of vulnerability. On every front \u2014 economic, cultural, personal security \u2014 they feel threatened and beleaguered. They seek protection against all the forces they perceive as hostile to their cherished way of life \u2014 foreign people, foreign goods, foreign ideas, aided and abetted by a government they no longer believe cares about them. Perhaps this is why fully 60 percent of them are willing to endorse a proposition that in previous periods would be viewed as extreme: the country has gotten so far off track that we need a leader who is prepared to break some rules if that is what it takes to set things right.\n\nThe bottom line, as the 2016 election amply demonstrated, is that if the Democratic Party does not take the bull by the horns, someone else will.", "title": "Opinion | The 2016 Exit Polls Led Us to Misinterpret the 2016 Election", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "The result of the vote will be announced Sunday. If the 463,000 members reject the coalition, Germany faces the prospect of an unstable minority government or new elections or both. In any case, it would likely spell the end of the Merkel era. That would be fine with Mr. K\u00fchnert.\n\n\u201cGoing into another coalition with Merkel is bad for social democracy and bad for democracy,\u201d Mr. K\u00fchnert said, summing up his pitch as he rushed to another campaign stop in an eastern district of Berlin.\n\nMany in his party agree. One recent afternoon Mr. K\u00fchnert arrived at its headquarters in Berlin wrapped in a thick scarf and nursing a cup of peppermint tea. He was not feeling well. Back-to-back speaking events in 23 cities with multiple television interviews every day, not to speak of Facebook Lives and podcasts, were taking their toll.\n\nWhile a volunteer dabbed makeup on his blotched cheeks in preparation for a camera interview, Mr. K\u00fchnert recounted how energized he had been when his party had campaigned against Ms. Merkel last year on the premise that they would either win or go into opposition.\n\nThe leadership had reiterated that pledge on election night, after they had just got the worst election result since World War II. But the mood was combative, upbeat even. They would rebuild in opposition, they would come back.\n\n\u201cIt felt like a new beginning,\u201d Mr. K\u00fchnert recalled.\n\nThat feeling did not last. Within weeks, the party leadership spectacularly reversed course and entered coalition talks with the chancellor. \u201cHow can voters trust us if we can\u2019t even trust our own leaders?\u201d Mr. K\u00fchnert said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe makeup was done. Mr. K\u00fchnert checked his watch and popped an aspirin. He was, he said, \u201cready for the next round.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is a battle between hope and fear. It pits those, like Mr. K\u00fchnert, urging the party to regroup in opposition with the hope of growing back into the formidable political force it once was, against those who fear that new elections now might just kill it.\n\n\u201cSuicide for fear of death,\u201d has become a common refrain for those urging comrades to work with Ms. Merkel one more time.\n\nMr. K\u00fchnert sees it differently. \u201cBeing a dwarf today so we can be giants in the future,\u201d is one thing he likes to say. And, \u201cIf we do politics because we\u2019re scared, we\u2019re lost.\u201d\n\nThe Social Democrats are Germany\u2019s oldest party. In its proud 155-year-history it has fought for workers\u2019 rights, battled fascism and helped shape Germany\u2019s postwar welfare state. But like many of its sister parties elsewhere in Europe, it has been self-destructing at an alarming pace.\n\nIts vote share has halved over the past two decades. Many blame the cozy working relationship with Ms. Merkel, which critics say has stripped the party of its identity and its place as the leading voice of opposition.\n\nThe Social Democrats were still winning 34 percent of votes when they entered their first coalition with Ms. Merkel in 2005; in September that had shrunk to 20 percent.\n\nIn one poll last week, the far-right Alternative for Germany, pulled ahead of them for the first time.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. K\u00fchnert was born in 1989, the year the Berlin Wall fell. Capitalism had beaten communism. Trickle-down economics, already the default ideology on the right, was embraced by the left, too. Some say that is when the problems of social democracy began.\n\nMr. K\u00fchnert joined his party when he was 15, the same year Ms. Merkel became chancellor and formed her first coalition with the Social Democrats.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike a whole generation of young Germans, he came of age in a period when the traditionally opposing camps on left and right governed jointly, blunting political debate and pushing voters in search of an opposition to the extremes.\n\n\u201cAnyone who is in their mid-20s today has pretty much only known Merkel and these grand coalitions,\u201d Mr. K\u00fchnert said in an interview. \u201cShe embodies this style of politics.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs for the Social Democrats, he said, \u201cWe have become the party that governs with the conservatives, the party that makes things get worse a little more slowly.\u201d\n\nIn Mr. K\u00fchnert\u2019s view, the Social Democrats have failed to offer distinctive answers to the most pressing issue of the day: The future of the welfare state.\n\nThe tension over migration, he argues, is in large part a proxy conflict at a time when large parts of the population feel neglected by the state and see migrants as competing for scarce public goods.\n\nLater, addressing an attentive crowd in Berlin, he boiled down his argument to a question. \u201cWhy should we exist as a party in the 21st century?\u201d he asked. \u201cWhat do voters get from us that they don\u2019t get anywhere else? Right now: Nothing.\u201d\n\nPolitics has been a keen interest for him since childhood. According to his grandmother, Mr. K\u00fchnert watched parliamentary debates on television when he was in primary school. (He is a little embarrassed about that.)\n\nThe only child of two civil servants, he was named after Kevin Keegan, an English soccer player his mother adored, and soccer has shaped his politics. His team, a plucky little 5th league club called Tennis Borussia Berlin, has a proud Jewish history and several Turkish players, and regularly encounters anti-Semitism and racist slurs from hostile fans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe club\u2019s purple colors sometimes draw homophobic jeers, too. Mr. K\u00fchnert is himself gay, but he never talks about it. \u201cI don\u2019t want to do identity politics,\u201d he said.\n\nBreathless commentators already compare him to Gerhard Schr\u00f6der, the former chancellor, who had also been a leader of the party\u2019s youth wing. The tabloid Bild recently printed extracts of Mr. K\u00fchnert\u2019s high school yearbook, where friends bet he would be chancellor one day.\n\nHe dismisses such predictions as \u201cmedia hysteria\u201d but rules nothing out.\n\nIf Mr. K\u00fchnert prevails on Sunday, it would not be the first time he beat the odds and his elders. As a freshman in high school, he was elected student representative on the back of a rousing speech, beating his contenders, who were all seniors.\n\nLater, aged 20, when his local soccer club faced financial problems, he convened an extraordinary members\u2019 meeting and persuaded them to fire the entire board. He then founded a charity to raise money for the club, printing T-shirts and selling them for $25 a piece.\n\nWhat worries Mr. K\u00fchnert most is that once again too many party members might opt for short-term stability over long-term democratic revival.\n\nOne party member recently challenged him during a rally. \u201cI don\u2019t understand you,\u201d the young man said, noting that the coalition deal gives the Social Democrats three powerful ministries and a governing program which by some estimates contains a majority of their proposals.\n\nWhy reject this?\n\n\u201cWe should not just worry about the next four years but about the next 40,\u201d Mr. K\u00fchnert replied. \u201cI don\u2019t want to be the last generation that had an SPD.\u201d", "title": "The 28-Year-Old Socialist Who Could End the Merkel Era", "authors": ["Katrin Bennhold", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "RE: THE MUSIC ISSUE\n\nTwenty-five writers told us where pop is headed.\n\nDespite the talents of the artists in your list, there are many more with equal or better things to share musically. To make such a bold statement related to the direction of music, one needs to understand how drastically different things are today in the music industry. The cultivation of new acts no longer applies to any development of new songs, no less new bands.\n\nThe Billboard charts do not share a mixed collection of talent from all facets of the music pool. A single sound does not constitute a future. It stagnates the ability of original acts to break the mold. It is embarrassing to imagine that such sounds, considered songs, have now been a part of the industry\u2019s go-to algorithm for longer than any other style of music since the advent of the Top 40 format in the 1950s.\n\nThe music companies today market crossover acts who can sell merchandise to fans who are more fashion-minded than musically interested. The acts themselves are more inclined to be fashion-first as well. Meanwhile, real musicians and real singers desperately try to win contests on TV shows. In closing, there are karaoke bars with better talent than the predictions of the future your issue supplied. Jonathan Kiddrane, Glendale, N.Y.", "title": "The 3.11.18 Issue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "RE: RANSOM\n\nRobert F. Worth wrote about the extreme lengths to which Qatar went in order to secure the release of a captured hunting party.\n\nRobert F. Worth\u2019s chronicling of the 2015 abduction of Qataris in Iraq attempts to connect regional events beyond Qatar\u2019s control with efforts to secure the safe return of citizens and residents who were held for over a year.\n\nWhile the reporting makes for good spy fiction, events like the dramatic incident at the Baghdad airport did not take place as outlined by Mr. Worth. Just as Qatar did not pay a ransom, Qatar never went behind the back of the Iraqi government. Rather, we worked with them from the beginning to resolve the abduction by unknown groups.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring the Arab Interior Ministers Council meeting in March 2017, Iraq\u2019s minister of interior and Qatar\u2019s prime minister and minister of interior held a meeting and discussed ways in which both countries could strengthen bilateral relations and ensure the safe release of the abductees. We are thankful for the safe return of our citizens, and Qatar is proud of the work that Iraq has undertaken to combat terrorism and rebuild their nation. We will continue to support their efforts going forward.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Worth\u2019s story shifts the blame for violent acts against innocents in the region from extremist groups onto Qatar\u2019s efforts to secure the release of the abductees. The idea that Qatar would undertake activities that support terrorism is false. We would never support any individual who seeks to harm civilians, nor would we provide resources to organizations carrying out terrorist acts. Sheikh Meshal Bin Hamad Al Thani, Qatari ambassador to the United States\n\nPhoto\n\nRE: ENDANGERED\n\nJennifer Kahn wrote about whether some species should be allowed to die out.\n\nJennifer Kahn and her sources say that the biota has changed drastically before; but never before, since humans appeared 200,000 years ago, have so many species disappeared. Hawaii is not the best example of what is happening. All island ecosystems are highly sensitive to new species. Birds that nest on the ground there do so because no land mammal ever made it across the ocean of its own accord in tens of thousands of years, except one kind of bat.\n\nThe species we should be worried about are those that decline because of logging, polluted rivers, suburban development or the warming atmosphere. Extinctions indicate that we are making the earth less habitable. At what point will the forces driving extinction swarm up and engulf us? I do agree that we cannot save some species. But why do we endure a social system that values the accumulation of wealth over human welfare and environmental continuity? Steven Stoll, professor of history, Fordham University", "title": "The 3.18.18 Issue", "authors": ["The New York Times Magazine"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "ST.
