Tournament", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf there\u2019s one thing our Australian readers love, it\u2019s Modern Love, our column on the joys and tribulations of coupling.\n\nHaving just returned from two weeks away for my own wedding and honeymoon along the Great Ocean Road, I thought we would all enjoy a countdown of our favorite essays on love.\n\nHere are Australia\u2019s five most popular Modern Love columns ... read into their popularity what you will.\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nA youthful affair told in snatches of joyful irresponsibility: missed brunches, clothed swims, waking to afternoon light. It is all fun and games until she rings \u2013 with her husband on the line.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nAndrew Rannells, an actor from \u201cGirls\u201d, looks back on a drunken one-night stand and waking up to six missed calls.", "title": "The 5 Most-Read \u2018Modern Love\u2019 Columns in Australia", "authors": ["Tacey Rychter"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "The history of conservation is a story of many victories in a losing war. Having served on the boards of global conservation organizations for more than 30 years, I know very well the sweat, tears and even blood shed by those who dedicate their lives to saving species. Their efforts have led to major achievements, but they have been only partly successful.\n\nThe extinction of species by human activity continues to accelerate, fast enough to eliminate more than half of all species by the end of this century. Unless humanity is suicidal (which, granted, is a possibility), we will solve the problem of climate change. Yes, the problem is enormous, but we have both the knowledge and the resources to do this and require only the will.\n\nThe worldwide extinction of species and natural ecosystems, however, is not reversible. Once species are gone, they\u2019re gone forever. Even if the climate is stabilized, the extinction of species will remove Earth\u2019s foundational, billion-year-old environmental support system. A growing number of researchers, myself included, believe that the only way to reverse the extinction crisis is through a conservation moonshot: We have to enlarge the area of Earth devoted to the natural world enough to save the variety of life within it.\n\nThe formula widely agreed upon by conservation scientists is to keep half the land and half the sea of the planet as wild and protected from human intervention or activity as possible. This conservation goal did not come out of the blue. Its conception, called the Half-Earth Project, is an initiative led by a group of biodiversity and conservation experts (I serve as one of the project\u2019s lead scientists). It builds on the theory of island biogeography, which I developed with the mathematician Robert MacArthur in the 1960s.", "title": "Opinion | The 8 Million Species We Don\u2019t Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "But that link shouldn\u2019t be inevitable. We filed a brief in this case supporting the First Amendment rights of crisis pregnancy centers, even though we also personally support abortion rights (our firm shares our view of the First Amendment, though it takes no position on abortion).\n\nWe filed our brief because focusing on the abortion debate means missing out on the fact that a decision siding with the State of California could upend decades of First Amendment doctrine and threaten everything from the right to have conversations in a doctor\u2019s office to the right to use math to criticize government officials. (Really.) That\u2019s because the Becerra case raises one of the most important unanswered questions in First Amendment law: Do speakers check their First Amendment rights at the office door?\n\nThe question of how the First Amendment interacts with the government\u2019s power to regulate the practice of an occupation has bedeviled courts for decades. But a growing number of courts \u2014 including the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which upheld California\u2019s law \u2014 have held that many restrictions on occupational speech are governed by what they call the professional speech doctrine, a rule that says professionals like doctors are entitled to less First Amendment protection than ordinary citizens because of the reliance clients place on their expertise. Applying that rule to the California case could give government officials broad authority to compel or prohibit speech by crisis-pregnancy centers.\n\nThat idea may seem appealing to readers whose sympathies lie with California in this case, but it is nonetheless a recipe for widespread, ideologically motivated censorship. And that is not speculation; it is how this rule has played out. When government officials are given the power to regulate speech they deem professional, they abuse it \u2014 immediately and with unseemly zeal.\n\nSometimes, government officials use their newfound powers to silence speech they find politically uncongenial. For example, after the American Medical Association adopted a policy urging doctors to discuss gun ownership with their patients \u2014 either to talk to them about gun safety or, perhaps, to dissuade them from owning guns at all \u2014 the Florida Legislature, spurred by gun-rights advocates, rushed to prohibit doctors from doing so. In court, Florida defended the law as a regulation of unprotected \u201cprofessional speech.\u201d It took five years of litigation, in the face of repeated court rulings upholding the ban, before the law was finally struck down in 2017 by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit.", "title": "Opinion | The Abortion Case That\u2019s Really About the First Amendment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "Though the tax rate has dropped by 3 percent and the standard deduction has doubled, people who work in creative industries can no longer deduct the big expenses that contribute to their success. According to the new tax law, expenses like buying scripts for auditions, taking acting classes and hiring a voice coach are no longer deductible. \u201cActors are spending 20 to 30 percent of their income just to generate jobs,\u201d said Mr. Manzino. \u201cIf you\u2019re a gym trainer or a lawyer or work for the Yankees, you don\u2019t have to worry about expenses like that.\u201d\n\nAdam Donshik, an actor who appeared in shows like \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d decided to form his own entity in December. For him, deducting head shots, haircuts, clothing, and travel expenses used to be the norm. \u201cThose are things that might seem mundane,\u201d said Mr. Donshik, who lives in Montclair, N.J., and whose career spans everything from Mountain Dew commercials to Shakespeare. \u201cBut for an actor making a living wage, it was the only way you could survive.\u201d\n\nBy incorporating, those lost expenses can be offset, though incorporating carries some costs of its own. The initial filing fees may cost around $1,000. But then there are costs that the newly incorporated actor must pay: Medicare, social security, corporate taxes. Add in the bookkeeping and accounting costs, and in the end it could cost as much as $20,000.\n\nAlso, if you\u2019re incorporated, you can no longer receive unemployment if you\u2019re out of work.\n\n\u201cWe run the calculus, and ask if we can save you enough money,\u201d said Mr. Manzino. Each case is different, depending on whether you\u2019re married or single, rent or own and, most important, how much money you make. Looking at three different clients working on the same show and earning the same salaries, Mr. Manzino recommended that only one of them incorporate. It wasn\u2019t worth it for the other two.\n\nHis general rule of thumb is that performers making over $200,000 \u2014 already a rare accomplishment, as the median annual salary among union film and television actors is around $38,000 \u2014 should seriously think about incorporating. This easily knocks most actors with support jobs out of the equation, as income can\u2019t include money earned working at Starbucks or as a temp at a law firm \u2014 corporations themselves through which that money flows.", "title": "The Actor Incorporates", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m your king!\u201d he said in a menacing accent, as he tensed for a dead lift. Had Mr. Casta\u00f1o beaten the comedy out of it? \u201cNah,\u201d Mr. Casta\u00f1o said. \u201cHe\u2019ll come back to it.\u201d And Mr. Pharoah did, slipping into the Scottish accent during his chest presses.\n\n\u201cYoung Spartan, I can lift way more than this,\u201d he said.\n\nWhen Mr. Pharoah wasn\u2019t doing impressions, he joked around as himself. \u201cCurls for girls,\u201d he said during his biceps curls, admiring his veined arms in the mirror.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going on vacation,\u201d he said. He hopes other vacationers will see him as a sex object. \u201cI can\u2019t wait. Thirst trap, thirst trap, walking thirst trap, gonna be crazy.\u201d\n\nMr. Pharoah wouldn\u2019t say where was he was going, since it was surprise for \u201csomebody special.\u201d (Sorry, ladies, the thirst trap is taken.)", "title": "The Actor and Comedian Jay Pharoah Channels \u2018Sparta\u2019 at the Gym", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "We survived our son\u2019s autism, we survived the N.F.L., the distance of being away, and the depression of athlete retirement. When autism hit I thought that would break us, but it didn\u2019t.\n\nWhen we argue in front of kids, it makes us feel bad. It makes them feel bad, so we\u2019ve learned to get on the same page. That\u2019s when we are the happiest. We try to turn down the volume of the radio. That\u2019s supposed to take us to a place of calm and introspection. We try. It doesn\u2019t always work. You have to put everything on the shelf and come down from it. That\u2019s how we can get back to the same page.\n\nI\u2019m controlling, impatient and blunt. As a special needs mom you don\u2019t take no for an answer, and that can make you a ball-buster. Rodney lets me know I have to soften my edges, listen, be patient and not be judgmental. I hear that from my kids, too. I need to slow down and relinquish control.\n\nI\u2019m a millennial mom; he\u2019s an old school dad. He cares so much about our family. He wants to over-dad and I need to let him do that, and that\u2019s hard for me. I\u2019ve learned it\u2019s not just my way or the highway, I need to share the road.\n\nHe still has the desire to be romantic and make me happy. And that\u2019s really nice. We have not evolved parentally, we\u2019re still working on that. But he\u2019s evolved with me on what matters. And that\u2019s what\u2019s really important.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Peete You need the right partner to reach and achieve the goals you have. You need to be on the same path going forward. Meeting Holly and getting to know her allowed me to get more in touch with my own feelings. I learned what a relationship was about. She was extremely strong, independent and confident. She had her own identity. She wanted a partner and companion. I hadn\u2019t had that before.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUsually I was the one willing to walk away. Holly had her own life and she was willing to walk away if we weren\u2019t on the same page. That was an attractive trait. She could take it or leave it. That made me realize how much I loved her.\n\nWe learned together. I\u2019ve learned no one\u2019s right. I\u2019ve learned to be more sensitive, more emotional. I was a guarded guy. And very wary of relationships getting in the way. I didn\u2019t always let people in. I had to grow up. She did, too. Marriage is an agreement. There\u2019s a time when you\u2019re single and a time to know you have a significant other.\n\nFrom the beginning, we were very open about wanting a big family, that was very important to both of us. Marriage has reaffirmed that fact. And we respected each other and each other\u2019s careers, which let us thrive on our own separately.\n\nI\u2019ve learned Holly is stronger than I thought. She\u2019s the rock in our family. She is family first and keeping the family strong and right. I have to fight for her to take time for herself. She doesn\u2019t always do that.\n\nWe are so busy with kids to raise, and with work, you can lose sight of yourself and what brought you together. Three or four years ago I came up with the 20-second hug. No matter how mad you are, if one asks for the hug, it\u2019s mandatory. It\u2019s embracing and emotional. That runs through you while you\u2019re not saying anything. You slow down. You become less angry. It reminds you of why you\u2019re together.", "title": "The Actress and Quarterback Still Work at Winning", "authors": ["Alix Strauss"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "As a feminist, too, his stagecraft has been successful. On Monday, as Ms Nixon said that she would run, Mr. Cuomo directed the state attorney general to review the ways in which the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., had handled \u2014 or mishandled \u2014 a 2015 allegation of sexual assault against Harvey Weinstein.\n\nIn her speech on Tuesday Ms. Nixon called for a greater investment in the city\u2019s ever-deteriorating public housing system. Only a few days earlier, during an appearance at the Jackson Houses in the Bronx, the governor, who served as the federal housing secretary under President Bill Clinton, said he was prepared to declare a state of emergency in the buildings of the New York City Housing Authority \u2014 which would allow him to replace its failing management team, appointed by the city. He also promised to release $200 million of state funds to the agency once an independent monitor had been appointed to oversee all that has gone wrong.\n\nIn the continuing war between the governor and Mayor Bill de Blasio, it has been Mr. Cuomo who has been continually advancing, amounting to another hindrance for Ms. Nixon. A longtime public education activist, she has been a strong supporter of the mayor\u2019s, but Mr. de Blasio, who is so intensely disliked by so many of his own Democratic constituents, could provide her with little advantage in her own race. Within two hours of Ms. Nixon\u2019s speech on Tuesday, the former City Council speaker Christine Quinn, openly gay and an ally of the governor\u2019s, declared via The New York Post that Ms. Nixon was an \u201cunqualified lesbian\u2019\u2019 who should not have opposed her own more viable bid to become the mayor of New York several years ago when Mr. de Blasio won his first term.\n\nMs. Quinn lost, in part, because she was unable to come up with a pitch that voters found as resonant as Mr. de Blasio\u2019s \u201ctale of two cities\u201d rhetoric, his focus on the vast gaps between the rich and the disadvantaged. Ms. Nixon wants to stand in the same philosophical space, railing against the unaffordable city, the tyranny of urban plutocrats. But she earned her celebrity and fortune through a pop cultural product, \u201cSex and the City,\u201d that promoted a vision of New York that stands entirely in opposition to her professed values. It was the HBO series, beyond any other entertainment, that helped solidify the image of the city as a luxury brand \u2014 an elite, fantastical consumer paradise where it was never too early or late in the day to buy an $800 pair of shoes.\n\nIs Cynthia Nixon, ultimately, the best vessel for her own invaluable message?", "title": "The Actress, the Governor and Performance Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "So when I get home from the theater with my notebook bristling with scribbles like \u201cwhat is happening?\u201d and \u201ckill me now,\u201d I ask myself a few questions. Was there anything at all I admired? Can I imagine why someone else might like it? Are there people I would send to the show despite my own distaste for it?\n\nWith \u201cEscape to Margaritaville\u201d (which I kept typing as \u201cEscape From Margaritaville\u201d while drafting my review), there was indeed one element I admired: the cast. Though it bothered me that such top-notch performers were made to do such inane things, I had to admit they did them well.\n\nAnd, yes, I could imagine why others might like the show. Perhaps those who already felt connected to Mr. Buffett\u2019s country-calypso ditties would relish the chance to hear them in a new context. Or perhaps those who aspire to the laid-back lifestyle his alcohol-fueled empire promotes would enjoy another taste of it.\n\nThat insight allowed me to recommend \u201cEscape to Margaritaville\u201d heartily to two groups: Parrotheads and people sloshed enough not to care about its theatrical merits.\n\nI am not, by profession or temperament, either of those things. I did bring my twentysomething nephew with me as a control subject, but although he had two margaritas, he liked the show only marginally better than I did.\n\nWhat I couldn\u2019t control for is taste. Arts criticism is in some ways a paradox, like Marianne Moore\u2019s \u201cimaginary gardens with real toads in them.\u201d Critics try to make objective judgments based on responses they know to be subjective.\n\nSo when readers are stung (or just annoyed) by my pans, I remind them that fighting about theater is often the best part of the show.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd when they insist, \u201cYou\u2019re wrong: I had a great time,\u201d I respond that I\u2019m glad. I don\u2019t need them to agree with me.\n\nBut I have to agree with myself, which is why I said that it was my \u201cresponsibility\u201d to pan \u201cEscape to Margaritaville.\u201d Not just because the theater needs to set a higher bar for musicals. And not just because \u2014 let\u2019s be honest \u2014 writing pans is invigorating. Every critic savors Oscar Wilde\u2019s observation, in \u201cThe Importance of Being Earnest,\u201d that on certain occasions \u201cit becomes more than a moral duty to speak one\u2019s mind. It becomes a pleasure.\u201d\n\nWhat really makes a pan a responsibility is that criticism is a form of journalism, which is, in theory, a form of truth. A critic reports honestly on his own thoughts and feelings, as if they were a war or a trial. They often are both.\n\nSo when I see something as objectionable and cynical as \u201cEscape to Margaritaville,\u201d I believe I have no choice but to say so, in terms that match the size of the feeling. That other critics may feel otherwise (though in this case few did) doesn\u2019t matter, because the point is to let readers navigate by a steady aesthetic star.\n\nIdeally that means more than just denunciation, even in a pan. It means providing theatrical or social context, arguing a position clearly and, yes, getting in a few zingers.\n\nIn that sense, \u201ctheater snob\u201d isn\u2019t really an insult. It\u2019s my job description.", "title": "The Agony and Ecstasy of Writing Negative Reviews", "authors": ["Jesse Green"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "It was, in the end, about only one thing: the necessity of loving one another.\n\nWell, Jesus, I thought. I could get behind that.\n\nLater, on the way out of church, I saw that same old painting of Christ in the garden, hanging in a small chapel. And I suddenly realized what I had been looking at, even while I was a child in the Lutheran church.\n\nIt was a portrait of a man thinking, \u201cPlease God, don\u2019t make me do it.\u201d And yet he did it anyway, in spite of his doubt.\n\nWe have had hard lives, my old friends and I, in some ways. Since we first met in 1970, there have been all kinds of misfortunes. There have been car accidents and job losses, divorces and heartbreaks, newborn babies whose lives were endangered. One of us is in a wheelchair now.\n\nBut here we all are, on the threshold of 60, and still deeply connected to one another. That day in New Jersey, as I sat there with these precious souls at the shore \u2014 can I call them anything but old men now? \u2014 it occurred to me that I have seen things a lot more improbable than talking donkeys turn out to be true. What greater miracle could there be than friendships that last a lifetime?\n\nThe next morning, my friend Kenny and I were up early enough to see the sun rise over the Atlantic, standing on the same beach where we had stood, nearly half a century before, as teenage boys. Thirty years ago, before I came out as trans, he\u2019d been my best man.\n\nHe is still my best man.\n\nListen: I do not know if an actual person named Jesus rose from the dead. I hope that this is true, but I don\u2019t know. I wasn\u2019t there.\n\nI know this though: On Sunday morning I stood on a beach with the friend of my youth, our arms around each other\u2019s shoulders. The rising sun burst over the ocean, and the light shone on our faces.", "title": "Opinion | The Agony of Faith", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Their budget was $2,500 to $3,500 a month for a dog-friendly one-bedroom with its own washer-dryer and parking spot, all of which turned out to be easy to find in Jersey City.\n\nBut moving from a house to an apartment raised concerns for Ms. Zhang, who had grown up in apartments and had bad memories of basement laundry rooms with broken machines.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI have lived in apartments my whole life,\u201d she said, and \u201cI worked so hard to achieve that house.\u201d\n\nIf she was going to return to apartment living, she had several requirements in addition to her own laundry facilities. Having a gym in the building would be nice \u2014 and maybe a small theater, too.\n\n\u201cI came in with a long list of nice-to-haves,\u201d she said. \u201cSome of it was not realistic.\u201d\n\nThe couple also wanted to be in a building handled by a management company, as they feared an individual landlord might be nosy or slow at repairs.\n\nDuring a weekend trip to Jersey City \u2014 which they found accessible and lively in person \u2014 they kept copious records of all the places they saw in a Moleskine notebook: monthly rents, incentives, fees, parking costs, amenities.\n\nPhoto\n\nTheir notes even included details on things like when the swimming pools were open. One, Mr. Beckett noted, closed at 7 p.m., which was far too early: \u201cThat\u2019s like a children-only pool.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTaking everything into account, \u201cprices were all over the place,\u201d he said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t really care about the base rent, but we cared about how much we paid per month,\u201d once all the extras were added in.\n\nSome agents never returned their calls, and the buildings they represented were automatically eliminated. \u201cIf their management company is that bad at selling an apartment, they are probably going to be that bad at managing an apartment,\u201d Mr. Beckett said.\n\nIn total, they toured seven buildings. Some were easy to cross off the list. At one building, residents had to stand in line to use the elevator. At another, there were no shades or drapes on large windows that would be expensive to cover.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd in other buildings, the apartments were large, but so awkwardly configured \u2014 with irregular corners and intrusive columns \u2014 that arranging furniture would have been nearly impossible.\n\nThey liked 70 Columbus, which was close to the PATH train. But it was surrounded by construction sites. And Columbus Towers, the complex it was part of, was so large they worried the common amenities would be too crowded to use.\n\nThe building did, however, have one thing they hadn\u2019t seen before: a dog run.\n\nAnd Butters, they knew, would like that a lot better than walking along slushy city sidewalks. Now the lack of a dog run became a quick way to eliminate buildings.\n\nAt The One, on First Street, there was a dog run, but it was outside. The building\u2019s golf simulator did little to make up for that deficiency. \u201cI\u2019ve never played golf,\u201d Ms. Zhang said. \u201cI would never use it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMost amenities, they realized, were expendable; all they needed were the practical ones.\n\n\u201cBeing honest with ourselves, we weren\u2019t going to go to the gym that regularly or invite people to use a movie theater,\u201d Ms. Zhang said. \u201cBut we have to take our dog out at least twice a day. What I thought was important didn\u2019t end up being that important.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt 18 Park, they saw a one-bedroom on a low floor that didn\u2019t have much natural light. And the water pressure, they noticed after testing the shower, was weak. But they liked the layout, the closet space and the window coverings. And they especially liked the building\u2019s dog run.\n\nThe next day, when they checked back, a unit on a higher floor had become available. This one was sunnier, and it had great water pressure. \u201cIt was better in the ways we wanted it to be better,\u201d Mr. Beckett said.\n\nThe couple signed on, rented their Durham house and arrived in Jersey City in the fall. Their rent is $2,550; with pet, amenity and parking fees, their monthly payment comes to just under $2,900.\n\nMr. Beckett, who has since taken a new job in Newark, now rides the PATH train in the opposite direction. And they have used their car so infrequently that the battery has died.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been surprisingly happy here,\u201d Mr. Beckett said. \u201cIt is small compared to where we came from, so we had to be creative.\u201d\n\nStill, he added, \u201cI don\u2019t have to do yard work anymore. It\u2019s nice to have weekends entirely open \u2014 not, like, I have to clean the gutters and mow the lawn.\u201d", "title": "The All-Important Dog Run", "authors": ["Joyce Cohen", "The Hunt"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cYour Kid\u2019s Phone Is Not Like a Cigarette\u201d (Sunday Review, March 4): Anya Kamenetz writes, \u201cThe real \u2018truth about tech\u2019 is that there just isn\u2019t enough research about this yet.\u201d\n\nOur cultural reliance on scientific research is blinding us to common-sense truths directly in front of us. Do your own study: At the next traffic light, try to find somebody not staring into his device. Try again during your next restaurant experience: Observe the children especially. They are completely absorbed by their phones.\n\nHow many confused, malcontent, depressed, angry, lonely children and teenagers do you know or know of? How much science does it take to come to your senses?\n\nJAMES B. GRAVES JR.\n\nLEXINGTON, KY.", "title": "Opinion | The Almighty Phone", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "A. I learned to become a bit of the hummingbird whisperer. I figured out how to introduce them to the mask and teach them that sticking their head inside this little plastic tube with air rushing past their ears wasn\u2019t something to be scared of, and that if they did that, they would get their sugar meal at the top of the mask from a feeder. And they said, \u201cVery well. O.K. I\u2019ll do this in order to get my food. And you can watch me while I do it.\u201d\n\nQ. And what are you watching for?\n\nA. We\u2019re measuring oxygen consumption rates. If I were to stick an elite Olympic athlete, a cross-country skier, onto a cycle ergometer and ask them to wear a mask and say, \u2018O.K., go as hard as you can go, and I want to measure your peak metabolic rate,\u2019 one of the ways we can quantify that is in oxygen consumption. So I can say, \u2018This human athlete is consuming four milliliters of oxygen per gram of body weight per hour.\u2019\n\nA hummingbird can easily hit 40 milliliters of oxygen per gram per hour. And if I ask the hummingbird to do extra, if I give it a little bit of extra weight to wear, that can go up to well above 60. So, their tissues are using oxygen at rates that are many, many times what we can possibly achieve.\n\nQ. And they need the oxygen to help them metabolize the relatively enormous amounts of sugar they are taking in to get the energy to power their muscles?\n\nA. I did a calculation back in graduate school. It turns out that when they\u2019re hovering around and foraging during the day, they\u2019re pretty much exclusively burning the sugar that they\u2019ve been eating in the last 30 minutes to an hour. And so, they have this incredible ability to move sugar through their system. And I did the calculation and said, \u2018O.K., if I scale one of my hummingbirds up to adult male human size, my size, how much sugar would I need to drink per minute if I were theoretically a hovering hummingbird as big as I am?\u2019 It turned out to be right around the amount of sugar that\u2019s in a can of Coca-Cola per minute. I haven\u2019t actually tried to do this. My doctor advised against it.", "title": "The Amazing Metabolism of Hummingbirds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Racially speaking, the United States is zero percent Hispanic. This is confusing \u2014 especially for America\u2019s nearly 58 million Hispanics.\n\nThe United States census breaks our country into six general racial categories: White; Black; Asian; Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander; American Indian or Alaska Native; and Some Other Race. \u201cHispanic, Latino or Spanish origin\u201d is treated not as a race but as an ethnicity \u2014 a question asked separately. So someone may be White (Hispanic) or Black (Hispanic) but not simply Hispanic. As a result, many Hispanics check \u201cWhite\u201d or, increasingly, \u201cSome Other Race.\u201d This ill-defined category is what mixed-race Americans, like me \u2014 half Burmese, half Luxembourgian-Irish \u2014 often check. It might just as well be called \u201cGenerally Brown.\u201d Today, the third-largest racial group in America is \u201cSome Other Race\u201d \u2014 and it is made up overwhelmingly of Hispanics.\n\nEqually obscured are America\u2019s estimated 3.7 million residents of Arab descent. With neither a racial nor an ethnic category to call their own, they most often opt for a racial designation of \u201cWhite.\u201d But to count Yemenis and Syrians as generically white is a complicated proposition these days, when whiteness confers power, and men and women from the Arab world are instead the subjects of travel bans and national security debates.\n\nNearly four years ago, the Census Bureau began researching how to more accurately represent these populations and decided to combine the race and ethnicity questions into one, and to add two new categories: one for residents of Middle Eastern/North African origin and one for those of Hispanic origin. Many advocates within those groups celebrated the reforms, and the broad expectation was that the next census, in 2020, would incorporate these changes. After all, the bureau itself concluded that they were necessary to \u201cproduce the highest quality statistics about our nation\u2019s diverse population.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Americans Our Government Won\u2019t Count", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "#SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at@nytimes.", "title": "The Animal Underneath", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "Dream of Better Days\n\nFor Raf Simons at Calvin Klein, the future looks a lot like the past, but with a few ominous twists. At his latest outing, models strode the runway in filmy dresses seemingly lifted from \u201cLittle House on the Prairie,\u201d but styled with balaclavas and chunky white patent leather or silver boots. It makes sense: Once we\u2019ve settled into our underground shelters, we\u2019ll likely dream of simpler times. Work a similar juxtaposition by pairing a Victorian lace frock with slick accessories and a protective underlayer.\n\nMadewell cotton kerchief, $12.50 at Madewell, madewell.com; Kendall & Kylie mesh catsuit, $160 at Topshop, topshop.com; Monki patent leather over-the-knee boots, $95 at us.asos.com; Cecilie Bahnsen tiered silk-blend dress, $1,209 at matchesfashion.com.", "title": "The Apocalypse Is Coming. Here\u2019s How to Dress for It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe artist Francesca DiMattio is zigzagging across her vast, warehouselike studio in the rural town of Hillsdale, N.Y., simultaneously firing porcelain, hand-painting ceramic flowers and touching up pottery glazes for three different sculptures. Wearing a paint-splattered brown mechanic\u2019s suit, crowned with her signature Frida Kahlo-esque braids and vibrant coral lips, she is a portrait of elegant incongruity. \u201cI\u2019m really interested in contrast,\u201d she says, \u201cand it\u2019s something I always want in my life.\u201d\n\nOn this morning, there is just over a week until DiMattio\u2019s latest show opens at Salon 94 Bowery in New York City, and her new paintings and sculptures are not yet finished. This is largely the result, she says, of her hectic reality in the two-plus years since her last solo show; she has been hopscotching between city and country living, juggling work and her two-year-old son, Bruno, with her husband, the artist Garth Weiser. \u201cI left months to make this show, which should have taken a year and a half,\u201d she says.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo, on this wintry day, with a sleet storm looming over the Berkshire Mountains outside her expansive windows, she\u2019s working briskly amid an indoor blizzard of paint pots, ladders and chicken wire. Dotting the space are classical torsos, animal figurines and cartoonishly large children\u2019s shoes made of porcelain and stoneware \u2014 elements she will later combine in her complex, hybrid pieces. One of her new ceramic sculptures for the show, tentatively titled \u201cShe-Wolf,\u201d still lies in parts around an armature of steel pipes. When it is finished, its form will resemble a kind of buffalo-llama chimera, with a bisonlike sculpted head, a Turkish Iznik-patterned leg, and breasts on its underside referencing the maternal wolf from the myth of Romulus and Remus.\n\nThe theme of contrast has been a lifelong \u2014 and career-defining \u2014 preoccupation for DiMattio, who grew up in Manhattan in the 1980s and 1990s and spent summers at her parents\u2019 country home in Saugerties, N.Y. (her mother is also a ceramist). Since earning her M.F.A. from Columbia in 2005, she\u2019s steadily garnered acclaim for her large-scale paintings and sculptures, which interweave a dizzying array of art historical references, craft techniques and decorative styles. In her sculptures, DiMattio has spliced together elements as diverse as Delft pottery, S\u00e8vres porcelain, Wedgwood china and spikes reminiscent of nail-studded Nkondi religious idols. Her paintings have toyed with unlikely intersections of architectural space, abstract patterns and textile prints.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDiMattio\u2019s new show, \u201cBoucherouite,\u201d which opens on March 6, takes its name from the colorful, tufted rag rugs woven from torn and recycled clothing by Berber women in Morocco. The works \u2014 two paintings and three sculptures \u2014 continue her fascination with cultural and aesthetic sampling, using the pieced-together patterns and textures of boucherouite as a leitmotif.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs DiMattio walks me around her studio, the sculptures tower over us in twisting configurations. At the far end of the studio stands \u201cVenus I,\u201d a bright-pink female figure in classical Greek style with a Louise Bourgeois-esque cluster of breasts on her backside. Her hand clasps a phallus adorned with Ming dynasty porcelain motifs. An aberrant arm juts out from one side, sporting a Mickey Mouse glove glazed with Viennese florals. All around the figure encroaches the colorful pile of sculpted boucherouite (made by extruding clay through a garlic press, DiMattio notes). On the other side of the studio, \u201cVenus II,\u201d anchored by a ceramic giant panda with a Venus of Willendorf on its posterior, sprouts a structure that calls to mind an otherworldly tree or magnified piece of coral. \u201cIt\u2019s all about the way the different elements interact with one another,\u201d DiMattio explains. \u201cEvery piece is interrupted or affected by something next to it. It has a kind of grafted surface.\u201d", "title": "The Artist Testing the Limits of Ceramics", "authors": ["Mimi Vu"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBridge of Clay,\u201d he explained, was difficult to write for several reasons. It is a bigger novel than \u201cThe Book Thief,\u201d it includes many more characters, and it uses a completely different sort of narrative voice, he said.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t until Mr. Zusak\u2019s wife intervened in June 2016 that the writing process began to improve markedly. \u201cShe basically said to me \u2018I think you and Clay need a break. If you can\u2019t get this together in the next week, get it back on track, you\u2019ve got to quit the book.\u2019\u201d He took a monthlong holiday and when he returned to the book the writing began to flow. \u201cIt suddenly started to come to life and I started to have a lot more fun with it. And I became quite joyful again in the challenges I was meeting,\u201d he said.\n\nImage Markus Zusak said that writing \u201cBridge of Clay\u201d was more difficult for him than \u201cThe Book Thief.\u201d Credit Michael Lionstar\n\nThe difficulties of artistic creation are central to \u201cBridge of Clay.\u201d Clay and his father are inspired by the work of the Italian sculptor and painter Michelangelo, but they identify less with him than with the unfinished sculptures known as \u201cThe Slaves,\u201d and certainly not his masterpiece, \u201cDavid.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen Clay and his dad are building the bridge they say, \u2018it would be great to create something like the \u2018David\u2019 one day but we live the life of the slaves.\u2019 And far from being negative, I actually think that\u2019s the real beauty. And I think that\u2019s the way we live. We want to create these beautiful things and we want to do beautiful things but we\u2019re forever trapped in the marble and in the making of it.\u201d\n\nWhile he expressed excitement for the novel\u2019s publication, Mr. Zusak made it clear he\u2019s still challenged by \u201cBridge of Clay.\u201d \u201cI could write this book until I die and it still won\u2019t be the way I want it. But I think now it\u2019s got the right heart and I think once you\u2019ve got that then you\u2019ve got an obligation to yourself to see it through and you hope people will find that in it.\u201d", "title": "The Author of \u2018The Book Thief\u2019 Has a New Y.A. Novel Coming This Fall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Could the voters do a better job sifting through the reboot-remake mediocrity to find high-grossing jewels? Perhaps: A list of nominees for this year\u2019s Oscars that included \u201cLogan\u201d and \u201cBlade Runner: 2049\u201d might have boosted the nominees\u2019 popular appeal without sacrificing quality.\n\nBut there\u2019s already been a respectable attempt to nominate the better genre efforts, from \u201cMad Max: Fury Road\u201d and \u201cArrival\u201d (probably the best movies of their respective years) to this year\u2019s garlands for the low-budget racial horror of \u201cGet Out.\u201d And there\u2019s little to be gained from having the academy go down the same path as certain fanboy (or bullied-by-fanboys) critics and ask us all to pretend that \u201cWonder Woman\u201d was more than just a fun vehicle for the charismatic Gal Gadot, or that \u201cThe Last Jedi\u201d really deserves its absurd 90 percent \u201cfresh\u201d rating on Rotten Tomatoes, or that Marvel\u2019s assembly-line showcases are actually good movies the way \u201cSense and Sensibility\u201d or \u201cApollo 13\u201d or \u201cBraveheart\u201d were.\n\nBut the alternative to such a lowering of standards, as the sharp Hollywood observer Richard Rushfield notes, is an Oscars that increasingly resembles the Independent Spirit Awards \u2014 which in turn tends to politicize the awards beyond the movie business\u2019s usual broadly liberal bent.\n\nOne of the virtues (both civic and artistic) of the old mass-audience, high-middlebrow model was that it forced Hollywood to temper its own partisan inclinations because of the size of its intended audiences, to produce tacitly conservative Big Movies as well as liberal ones and reward them both at Oscar season. (That reliable right-wing favorite \u201cBraveheart\u201d won in the year I cited earlier, and the prior year\u2019s undeserving but entertaining winner, \u201cForrest Gump,\u201d wore a Reaganite conservatism on its simpleton hero\u2019s sleeve.)\n\nThis tempering still happens in the superhero factory (despite being marketed as event movies for the woke, films like \u201cWonder Woman\u201d and \u201cBlack Panther\u201d play it safe with their political messages), even if there the goal is sometimes appeasing Red China rather than Red America, and of course a certain kind of pulp entertainment will always tend to skew right-wing. But the more the only plausible Oscar nominees in terms of cinematic quality are passion projects and message movies \u2014 the kind of movies, to quote Kimmel, that are made \u201cto annoy Mike Pence\u201d \u2014 the more the film industry\u2019s inevitable liberalism seems less one reliable theme of Oscar season than the symphony entire.\n\nFor some people in the movie business and the press that covers it, this may seem like a happy evolution, a shift toward more of a vanguard role in pursuing social change, with fewer political compromises and greater moral clarity in what messages the academy offers to the world.\n\nBut even if, as is fervently hoped, we are entering an age of stronger minority and female representation in cinema, without the mass audience that high-middlebrow cinema once enjoyed that representation\u2019s influence on the American imagination will be limited. \u201cLady Bird\u201d is a lovely mother-daughter movie and may God send many more female-centric movies like it \u2014 but 35 years ago a little mother-daughter movie called \u201cTerms of Endearment\u201d won Best Picture and made the equivalent of $300 million, numbers that only superhero movies tend to hit today. Michael B. Jordan and Chadwick Boseman of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d are talented and charismatic, but they ultimately serve the superhero brand, and they are unlikely to gain the kind of black stardom-in-its-own right enjoyed by Eddie Murphy and Denzel Washington. No matter how much more enlightened the movie industry becomes, what was 20th-century America\u2019s most influential and unifying mass art form is increasingly a business of niche markets and lowest-narrative-denominator blockbusters \u2026 and it is not only conservatives who might reasonably regret that shift.\n\nLike many cultural rituals the Oscars are peculiar and arbitrary and frequently absurd, but like many they have supplied a thread of unity and memory and shared experience for the millions who watch them every year. For the show to become a boutique affair for American liberals that\u2019s sponsored by a globalized superhero content provider is not, I think, a happy change \u2014 and for all that it seems overdetermined and inevitable, it\u2019s a transformation that filmmakers and moviegoers and academy members, in all their various ways, should still make an effort to resist.", "title": "Opinion | The Autumn of the Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "If you\u2019ve ever been a professional baseball player, you know that every year for spring training you arrive at camp with a host of teammates you\u2019ve never played with before. You may know them as opponents, or maybe you know nothing at all.\n\nIn such situations it\u2019s easy to default to the simplicity and comfort of one\u2019s assumptions. And to be consistent with the preferred evaluative framework of baseball is to judge by the numbers: You can determine someone\u2019s level of discipline by his on-base percentage, say, or his precision by his strikeout-to-walk ratio.\n\nBut metrics won\u2019t tell us what kind of teammate he will be.\n\nThe new season is here and 30 major league teams have finalized their rosters. Each will contain 25 players from a variety of backgrounds. In my first spring training with the Chicago Cubs, my locker in the clubhouse physically placed me between the quiet strength of the Hall of Famer Ryne Sandberg, who advised through action and a whisper, and the exploding intensity of Randy Myers, an avid fan of military equipment (including the Hummer he drove before it turned \u201cluxury\u201d), whose locker was full of Tasers and camouflage gear. Both were All-Stars; you wanted both on your team.\n\nWe also had the vociferous Shawon Dunston, an African-American Brooklyn native who spoke plainly and directly on issues, which often caught the attention of the Caucasian So-Cal dude Mark Grace. Their epic debates were conducted with a mutual respect and genuine brotherhood, even though one could be seen as the photographic negative of the other. They were teammates who respected the game and each other, and I learned from both. (Shawon taught me about hustling on every at-bat, no matter how many hits you got that day, and Mark taught me about finding advantages, right down to using the shadows in a day game to see where the catcher was setting up, which helped anticipate the location of the coming pitch.)", "title": "Opinion | The Baseball Season Begins. So You Think You Know Your Teammates?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWith every wave of immigration in the past, American freedom and openness have triumphed. Will we, telling ourselves \u2018These immigrants are different,\u2019 be the weak link, the first generation to fail? Will we forget who we are?\u201d That\u2019s inspiring, and even more so are the citations of Martin Luther King Jr., Lin-Manuel Miranda and Langston Hughes that finish the book.\n\nInspiring \u2014 but not wholly reassuring. A lot of the interest of \u201cPolitical Tribes\u201d comes from the strong sense it emanates of an author arguing with herself. Chua both condemns tribalism and respects its power. She insists that the United States alone of nations among the earth has often transcended it \u2014 and then presents impressive contrary evidence from the past and the present. Chua reckons with the many tribalisms of the American past: ethnic, religious and racial. She hopes for a future in which tribalism fades \u2014 even as she mercilessly details its accumulating strength.\n\nAs Chua notes, tribes can coalesce out of previously unrelated pieces. Immigrants to Europe from North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia \u2014 of different languages, ethnicities, folkways and religious practices \u2014 raised children who created for themselves a new identity as post-ethnic Muslims. ISIS, as Chua mordantly observes, is in its own way a melting pot, bringing together young men and women from across Europe, Asia and the Americas to fight for a new ideology. She quotes a New York Times article about young British girls lured to ISIS. For them, \u201cIslam is punk rock.\u201d\n\nTribes can be created by fission as well as by fusion. Chua suggests that in the United States, divisions that would once have been understood as class divides have been reinterpreted in our time as cultural, even when they are not ethnic. \u201cWhite Americans often hold their biggest disdain for other white Americans \u2014 the ones on the opposite side of the cultural divide.\u201d\n\nThese fast-evolving and ever-changing identities may look contingent from the outside. They feel overwhelmingly powerful to those inside. Chua repeatedly scolds American policymakers for underestimating the importance of ethnocultural identity in Vietnam in the 1960s, Venezuela in the 1990s and Afghanistan in the 2000s. Through her book pulses an evident worry that tribal claims are now overpowering national ones within the United States. If she cannot quite bring herself to make her own anxieties explicit \u2014 or figure out what if anything to do to address them \u2014 she is hardly alone. As the rise of Donald Trump over more conventional politicians has so emphatically proved: Worsening social divisions are much easier to exploit than to explain or redress.", "title": "The Battle Over What It Means to Be American", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBUILT\n\nThe Hidden Stories Behind Our Structures\n\nBy Roma Agrawal\n\nIllustrated. 300 pp. Bloomsbury. $28.\n\nOnce, in a younger America, architects and engineers alike were simply called \u201cbuilders\u201d: people, mostly men, who had both design and construction skills. But after the American Institute of Architects was founded in 1857, the professions split. Architects began to garner all the glory while engineers toiled in their shadows. At the 1964 dedication of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, then the world\u2019s longest suspension bridge, Robert Moses actually seemed to forget the name of Othmar Ammann, its designer and arguably the greatest engineer of the last century, referring to him only as \u201ca Swiss.\u201d\n\nSuch oversights have become rarer these days in the face of societal and environmental changes that demand we use and waste less. Engineers are responding with astonishing solutions culled from multiple disciplines. Supertall buildings like One World Trade Center, Shanghai Tower and the Shard are touching new ceilings of safety, sustainability and efficiency. Mimicking nature, infrastructure can now self-diagnose and self-heal when problems arise. Uses for graphene, one atom thick and the strongest material yet, are still a twinkle in the structural imagination, but not for long. Engineers are saving the world.\n\nIf that sounds like a grand claim, it\u2019s because engineering is so seamlessly integrated into every facet of our lives that it is all but invisible. Drawing on varied examples across centuries and continents, Roma Agrawal\u2019s \u201cBuilt\u201d seeks to tell this untold history \u2014 for, as the author claims, the \u201cengineered universe is a narrative full of stories and secrets.\u201d\n\nAgrawal is a rarity: a female structural engineer in an adamantly male profession. A self-proclaimed \u201cgeek,\u201d she shares her discoveries far above and below ground with an enthusiasm worthy of Dora the Explorer. She will inspire young women who are considering a career in engineering.\n\nIn early chapters, Agrawal slowly builds a foundation on familiar concepts, but your patience will soon be rewarded with more esoteric investigations into \u201chidden engineering.\u201d Two of the most interesting chapters \u2014 \u201cPure\u201d and \u201cClean\u201d \u2014 examine water and the technologies that have been developed to collect and process it.\n\nPhoto\n\nNo one cares \u201cabout poo,\u201d a drainage engineer complains in \u201cClean.\u201d Agrawal disagrees. In fact, she shines when explaining the sorts of things people might be too shy to admit they find inherently fascinating. In Japan, for instance, Agrawal tries out an amped-up toilet, itself an engineering marvel of heat, water and music. She then leaps back to the 18th century, when Japan traded in solid human waste, a valuable agricultural commodity for an island with little land and a growing population. As the \u201cturd trade\u201d boomed, laws were enacted that entitled landlords to their tenants\u2019 feces (but not their urine).\n\nAgrawal hopscotches to London and its once sewage-filled Thames, commemorated as \u201cMonster Soup\u201d in an 1828 etching, one of the book\u2019s many black-and-white illustrations. The river\u2019s stench was so rank that at last, in 1859, city officials approved Joseph Bazalgette\u2019s proposal for a new sewage system. Nearly 20 years in the making and 1,300 miles long, that network also created space for the London Tube, the first underground railway. The sewers moved untreated effluent from central London and out to sea. Agrawal notes that \u201cit may come as a surprise to learn that we use exactly the same system today.\u201d\n\nEnter the engineers. Work has begun on the Thames Tideway Tunnel. When completed in 2023, this massive infrastructure project will expand the existing system and divert waste to treatment plants before releasing it to the sea. Most of this super-sewer will run beneath the riverbed, eliminating the need to dig up city streets and the strata of foundations and utilities beneath them. Equally ingenious is their plan to use the river to transport 90 percent of construction material. The amount of wastewater into the Thames will be reduced from 62 million to 2.4 million tons annually. Economy, for engineers as well as poets, is the sum definition of beauty.", "title": "The Beauty and Mystery of How a Building Is \u2018Built\u2019", "authors": ["Judith Dupr\u00e9", "Roma Agrawal"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "A construction team is busy retrofitting the venue into Jeppe\u2019s dream brewery. The courtyard, enclosed by a pastel pink wall, will become a year-round greenhouse and seating area. A side area is being turned into a barrel room where beer will be aged in wine and bourbon vessels. There, the original sign from \u201cTwin Peaks,\u201d the noir television series, will be on display. \u201cWhen people are in here drinking, it will be good for them to have something to look at,\u201d said Jeppe.\n\nJeppe visits the brewery, which is still under construction, every day. \u201cI live two miles away and am involved in all the recipes,\u201d he said. Like Mikkeller, Evil Twin will also make beers specific to New York City.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBecause the twins claim they don\u2019t communicate with each other, it\u2019s impossible to know whether their brewery openings are coincidental, acts of one-upmanship or clever public-relations stunts.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s nothing more than the fact that there are a lot of breweries coming up in New York,\u201d said Jim Raras Jr., the executive vice president of Mikkeller NYC. \u201cWe happen to be one of them, and they happen to be another one.\u201d (Mikkel does not comment publicly about his brother.)\n\nJeppe, however, called the turn of events \u201cweird,\u201d and questioned his brother\u2019s motivations. \u201cHe doesn\u2019t even live here,\u201d Jeppe said. \u201cHe\u2019s only been here five times.\u201d Mikkel disagrees with Jeppe\u2019s latter statement, saying that he has visited New York at least 50 times.\n\nRegardless of the timing, there are legitimate business reasons both brothers are interested in Queens.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn New York, especially in Queens, the beer industry is still underdeveloped, compared with the rest of the country. Even fashionable Brooklyn companies like Other Half and Threes Brewing only opened in 2014. \u201cToday we have now 25 brewers in New York, it\u2019s nothing,\u201d Jeppe said. \u201cSan Diego has 150.\u201d\n\nMikkel\u2019s view is similar. \u201cFor such a big international city, it\u2019s kind of strange that there has been a lack of breweries until recently,\u201d he said. \u201cSo it\u2019s an interesting time to do something young.\u201d He promises his Citi Field brewery will be something new. \u201cWe\u2019ll do everything, we\u2019ll do crazy stuff,\u201d he said. \u201cIt won\u2019t be boring. We\u2019ll give them the full range of what we are capable of.\u201d\n\nJeppe chalks up the lack of brewery growth in the city to how expensive it is to operate a business here. \u201cBut if you have success here?\u201d he said. \u201cThey say if you can make it here, there is much more attention to what is happening here. The world pays attention.\u201d\n\nFor Evil Twin, ready to give up the life of the gypsy brewer, building a headquarters in New York makes sense. \u201cWe moved here six years ago to become New Yorkers,\u201d said Jeppe. \u201cWe have become a New York brand, and this is the last step to that. We get emails every day from all over the world from people coming here on vacation and asking if they can visit something.\u201d People even knock on his home door asking for a tour because they think it\u2019s a brewery.", "title": "The Beer Twins (One Evil) Take Their Feud to Queens", "authors": ["Alyson Krueger"]} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "But opioids aren\u2019t only a problem. They can also be highly effective medications that make the difference between a functional and dysfunctional life. In a new article in Reason magazine, Jacob Sullum makes this case. The federal crackdown on opioids has failed to solve the overdose problem \u2014 indeed, it has made it worse \u2014 while also saddling many people with chronic pain, Sullum writes. Among his points:\n\n\u2022 \u201cContrary to the impression left by most press coverage of the issue, opioid-related deaths do not usually involve drug-naive patients who accidentally get hooked while being treated for pain,\u201d he writes. \u201cInstead, they usually involve people with histories of substance abuse and psychological problems who use multiple drugs, not just opioids.\u201d\n\n\u2022 So making it harder for people with chronic pain to get opioid prescriptions is a mistake, Sullum argues. \u201cThe truth is,\u201d he writes, \u201cthat patients who take opioids for pain rarely become addicted.\u201d A large majority of opioid deaths don\u2019t come from prescribed medicine; they come from illegally produced substances like heroin.\n\n\u2022 Illegal use of pain medications has declined in recent years, even as deaths have surged \u2014 another sign that the main problem isn\u2019t prescribed medicine.\n\n\u2022 You often hear that patients in pain can simply switch to other, nonopioid drugs. Some can, but some can\u2019t. Many get far less relief from nonopioids than opioids, and the piece quotes several of them.\n\nI encourage you to read Sullum\u2019s piece, especially if all you\u2019ve read about opioids are the horror stories. I still believe the government should be aggressively responding to the situation, given the death toll \u2014 and the abhorrent behavior of many drug companies. (In articles elsewhere, Paige Winfield Cunningham, Josh Katz and Megan McLemore offer some policy ideas.) Perhaps above all, regulators should cut down on the number of unused pills in circulation.", "title": "Opinion | The Benefits of Opioids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo Focus is a creamy, medium-coverage foundation that applies beautifully, blends out smoothly and dries with a matte finish that stays shine-free throughout wear. I have combination skin and usually have to blot excess oil off my face at least once, even when I wear matte foundations, but I don\u2019t have to blot when I wear this. It controls oil and shine without making my skin look dry or flaky, or bringing out any uneven texture.\n\nWet n Wild tested this foundation under seven photo lighting conditions to ensure it keeps your face looking gorgeous and natural in photos and selfies. Available in 20 shades, this is a beautiful option for anyone looking for a luxury foundation for barely over $5.\n\nConcealer\n\nI reach for the same concealer whether I\u2019m wearing a full face of high-coverage makeup or on the days when I\u2019m \u201cnot wearing any makeup.\u201d The right concealer can be incorporated into any makeup routine, and a real standout can be found in the drugstore. That standout is NYX HD Photogenic Concealer.\n\nNYX Photogenic Concealer gives you workable high coverage without being too dense or too thick. It blends beautifully, is creamy and hydrating enough to be worn under the eyes and has a luminous matte coverage with a skinlike finish that won\u2019t throw you under the bus when you\u2019re trying to spot conceal. Available in a diverse range of 20 shades for most skin tones (and an additional three for color correcting) for just $5, this is one of those products that should be in everyone\u2019s makeup bag.\n\nBronzer\n\nSearch no further than Physicians Formula Butter Bronzer.\n\nIt\u2019s the best drugstore bronzer, full stop. There is really just no competition. Honestly, it would be a challenge to find a high-end bronzer that beats this.\n\nThe reason this one stands out from the rest is that, while being a pressed powder, it applies with the color payoff and blendability of a cream product, but doesn\u2019t build up too quickly, look chalky or gray as some bronzers tend to do, or get too orange. It\u2019s just ... good.\n\nThe downside, and possible deterrent from buying this product, is that, as drugstore products go, it\u2019s a bit on the pricey side: $15 is at the high end of the drugstore spectrum, but this bronzer is worth the splurge, I promise you. There is a reason this is an essential product for so many.", "title": "The Best Makeup You Can Buy at the Drugstore", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "What I\u2019ve found with cooking at the start of the week, it\u2019s good to have insurance on top of the id\u00e9e fixe. So if something goes wrong this afternoon, and I get home a few hours after I\u2019d intended: thin slices of the Olympia Provisions salamis my sister-in-law sends me every month, shingled into corn quesadillas or diced into scrambled eggs. I\u2019ll serve that with fridge-cold red wine, then watch this video recipe for cheesecake afterward, browse this guide to the best gas grill and dream of a better tomorrow.\n\nThere are many, many more recipes to consider cooking tonight and all week \u2014 all month, all year \u2014 at NYT Cooking. Go take a look and see what you find. (I bet I could make this mustard and chile-rubbed beef tenderloin on my new grill, serve it with maple-candied sweet potatoes, then eat the cheesecake and go into a food coma.)\n\nSave the recipes that interest you to your recipe box. Then send yourself a shopping list for those you want to make and cook them real soon. If you make an ingredient substitution or come up with a shortcut, leave a note on the recipe to tell us about it, or tag us on Instagram or Facebook, to show your work plain.\n\nAnd please get in touch if anything goes wackadoodle with a recipe or the technology we use on our site and apps. We want to make things better, every day. Just write: cookingcare@nytimes.com. We\u2019ll write back.\n\nNow, a long way from debating Marengo or stir-fry (and only if you\u2019re not triggered by moms, diapers and crying), you might want to check out the trailer for \u201cTully,\u201d the Charlize Theron vehicle that\u2019s coming to theaters next month.", "title": "The Best Monday Meals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Watching, The New York Times\u2019s TV and movie recommendation site. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter, here.\n\nEvery month, Netflix Australia adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for March, broken down by release date. Netflix occasionally changes its schedule without giving notice. (Unfortunately, the streaming information provided in our Watchlist listings only applies to viewers in the United States.)\n\nTV Series New to Netflix\n\n\u2018The Defiant Ones\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe intricate story of the unlikely business partnership between Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine fills up four fascinating hours in this documentary series, which doubles as a history of pop, rock, hip-hop and R&B from the 1970s to now. Beginning with Dre\u2019s origins as a music-obsessed boy in Los Angeles \u2014 and Iovine\u2019s early career as an engineer and producer for the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Tom Petty \u2014 \u201cThe Defiant Ones\u201d continues through the dawn of gangsta rap and the rise and decline of the CD era, examining the way new technologies and social movements continue to change music.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cHomeland\u201d Season 6 (March 1), \u201cQueen of the South\u201d Season 1 (March 1), \u201cGhost Wars\u201d Season 1 (March 2) and \u201cThe Hollywood Masters\u201d Season 2 (March 15).\n\nNew Netflix Original TV Series\n\n\u2018Flint Town\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFlint, Mich., is infamous for the recent crisis involving lead-contaminated water, as well as for the General Motors downsizing covered in Michael Moore\u2019s documentary expos\u00e9 \u201cRoger & Me.\u201d The docu-series \u201cFlint Town\u201d describes a different problem, noting how the city\u2019s poverty has led to an underfunded police department, an escalating crime rate and citizens who live in fear. The show tracks the efforts to rectify the problem, which involves a lot of missteps, but also some genuine will to squeeze hope out of a hopeless situation.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarts streaming: March 8\n\nMarch 8 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix\u2019s Marvel shows vary wildly in quality, but \u201cJessica Jones\u201d is one that even a lot of the franchise\u2019s skeptics like. Give a lot of credit to the star, Krysten Ritter, who\u2019s both cool and heartbreaking as a crusty, superstrong detective, clobbering creeps while indulging in multiple vices to numb her pain. Three years after the show\u2019s first season became a critics\u2019 darling, it finally returns, with the heroine determined to crack a case that could lead her back to how she got her powers in the first place.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Collateral\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nCarey Mulligan stars as a dogged, London-based Detective Inspector in this BBC Two mini-series, about a seemingly random murder that leads the police to a larger criminal conspiracy, potentially involving the government and the church. Not just another gritty British crime drama, \u201cCollateral\u201d has been given a sophisticated polish by David Hare, a writer best-known for the Tony-nominated plays \u201cPlenty\u201d and \u201cSkylight,\u201d and for the Oscar-nominated screenplays for \u201cThe Hours\u201d and \u201cThe Reader.\u201d Expect more subtle character building than surprising twists.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018On My Block\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 16\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFans of the darkly comic, painfully real MTV series \u201cAwkward\u201d should be thrilled to hear that the show\u2019s creator, Lauren Iungerich, is back to making television, once again taking on high school but from a different perspective. Shifting her focus from the ritzy Palos Verdes region of Los Angeles to the more hardscrabble South Central, Iungerich should bring her usual snappy dialogue \u2014 and her sensitivity to adolescent emotions \u2014 to a part of the city where life is often more complicated than just finding a date for prom or mastering Snapchat.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Wild Wild Country\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 16\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nReaders who lived through the 1980s may recall the name of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a guru whose small Oregon cult briefly made national news because of his followers\u2019 alleged involvement with bioterror and an attempted political assassination. The docu-series \u201cWild Wild Country\u201d uses rare archival footage and recent interviews to help explain where Rajneesh\u2019s movement came from, how it took hold in America and how it all came to a violent end.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Alexa & Katie\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe former \u201cHannah Montana\u201d writer Heather Wordham and the former \u201cWonder Years\u201d and \u201cMalcolm in the Middle\u201d writer Matthew Carlson bring their knack for family-friendly tales of teen angst to this, another of Netflix\u2019s growing stable of old-fashioned multicamera sitcoms. Paris Berelc and Isabel May star as high-school freshmen who struggle with this latest phase of their lives while discovering that making a good impression isn\u2019t entirely within their control.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018The Mechanism\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFrom the mind of a \u201cNarcos\u201d producer, Jos\u00e9 Padilha, comes another true crime story, based on the still-unfolding \u201cOperation Car Wash\u201d money-laundering scandal in Brazil. \u201cThe Mechanism\u201d (or \u201cO Mecanismo\u201d in the original Portuguese) follows a team of investigators who start looking into kickbacks and bribes in a state-run petrochemical company. Things get hairy as they realize they could be exposing corruption on a scale that could destabilize the social order, not only in Brazil but also around the world.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cB: The Beginning\u201d Season 1 (March 2), \u201cLove\u201d Season 3 (March 9), \u201cEdha\u201d Season 1 (March 16), \u201cSanta Clarita Diet\u201d Season 2 (March 23), \u201cA Series of Unfortunate Events\u201d Season 2 (March 30) and \u201cTrump: An American Dream\u201d Season 1 (March 30).\n\nMovies New to Netflix\n\n\u2018What We Do in the Shadows\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBefore \u201cThor: Ragnarok,\u201d director Taika Waititi collaborated with his old friend and comedy partner Jemaine Clement on this horror mockumentary, in which the two men play ancient vampires leading sad lives in a shabby Wellington, New Zealand, neighborhood. It\u2019s funny enough just to watch these classic movie monsters engaging in mundane roommate squabbles, but eventually \u201cWhat We Do in the Shadows\u201d does develop a surprisingly engaging story, concerning the arrival of younger creatures with different values and habits. Waititi and Clement root their jokes in the anxieties of very old men, struggling to keep up with the times.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Anomalisa\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 8\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe screenwriter Charlie Kaufman (\u201cBeing John Malkovich,\u201d \u201cEternal Sunshine of Spotless Mind\u201d) turns to stop-motion animation for this wonderfully weird movie, which follows a depressed self-help guru on a business trip to Cincinnati. Michael Stone (voiced by David Thewlis) imagines that every person he meets has the same face and same voice, until he meets an \u201canomaly\u201d named Lisa (Jennifer Jason Leigh), who bewitches him even though she\u2019s otherwise completely ordinary. Both a character sketch about an arrogant man and a hilariously accurate depiction of what it\u2019s like to stay in a Middle American luxury hotel, \u201cAnomalisa\u201d is stunning to look at and rewarding to argue about after the credits roll.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\n\u2018Dope\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 17\n\nMarch 17 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAn electrifying combination of caper picture and high-school comedy imagines what would happen if three teenage nerds from Inglewood, Calif., stumbled on the cache of drugs that their neighborhood\u2019s local dealers are literally killing one another to retrieve. As the three friends come up with clever, cutting-edge ways to sell their unexpected stash, the writer-director Rick Famuyiwa revels in the specific slang, codes and status symbols that mean the most to poor kids today. That\u2019s how \u201cDope\u201d stays both energetic and up-to-date for the 2010s.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Spotlight\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 17\n\nMarch 17 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe winner of the 2015 Academy Award for best picture is based on the true story of a Pulitzer-winning Boston Globe investigative reporting team, which uncovered a disturbing pattern: Higher-ups in the Roman Catholic church were paying off parishioners who complained of having been sexually abused by priests. Tom McCarthy, who directed and helped write \u201cSpotlight,\u201d is primarily interested in examining the recent and sudden decay of venerable American institutions, from the church to the government to the media. He does this by focusing on minute details, as a talented cast (including Michael Keaton, Mark Ruffalo and Rachel McAdams) buries itself in the roles of diligent professionals doing work that matters.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Wonder Woman\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 20\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBoth a blockbuster and a cultural phenomenon, \u201cWonder Woman\u201d is the rare superhero movie that stands strong on its own, telling a story that\u2019s complete and entertaining story if viewers never watched anything else from \u201cthe DC Extended Universe.\u201d Anchored by charismatic performances from Gal Gadot (as Diana, the titular heroine) and Chris Pine (as the American pilot and spy Chris Trevor, working to win World War I), \u201cWonder Woman\u201d is a stirring throwback adventure, which has resonated with the many, many people who have been eager to see a big-budget action picture with a female lead.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cI, Robot,\u201d (March 1), \u201cThe Purge: Election Year\u201d (March 1), \u201cRicki and the Flash\u201d (March 3), \u201cBushwick\u201d (March 15), \u201cCars 3\u201d (March 18) and \u201cAustralia\u201d (March 31).\n\nNew Netflix Original Movies\n\n\u2018Les Affam\u00e9s\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA hit at the Toronto International Film Festival last fall, this arty French Canadian zombie thriller \u2014 with a title that translates as \u201cThe Ravenous\u201d \u2014 crosses \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d with muted neorealism and a touch of \u201cThe Twilight Zone.\u201d When a rural Quebecois community begins to succumb to a ghoulish plague, the survivors regroup in the surrounding forests and fight to reclaim their home. But will they become as horrible as the monsters they\u2019re aiming to expel? The writer-director Robin Aubert asks that question subtly, in a horror movie that is as thoughtful as it is creepy.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Annihilation\u2019\n\nStart streaming: March 12\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA surefire candidate for \u201cBest of 2018\u201d lists, this Alex Garland adaptation of the Jeff VanderMeer\u2019s novel opened in theaters in the United States and China just a few weeks ago, but it is already arriving on Netflix in other international territories. The reasons are an endorsement, not a red flag. A story about five troubled women who investigate a mysterious energy-bubble that\u2019s been obscuring a vast stretch of the American wilderness (the women are played by Natalie Portman, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Gina Rodriguez, Tessa Thompson and Tuva Novotny), \u201cAnnihilation\u201d has been called too smart and surreal for mainstream audiences. Fans of brainy, ambitious science-fiction should probably jump on it right away.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2018Game Over, Man!\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nProducers Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg join forces with the team behind the Comedy Central series \u201cWorkaholics\u201d to put a stoner-comedy twist on \u201cDie Hard.\u201d Anders Holm, Adam Devine and Blake Anderson play Los Angeles waiters who work in a building that gets seized by terrorists. Determined to be rough-and-tumble, blockbuster-style heroes \u2014 with guns and cool catchphrases \u2014 the three waiters bumble their way into even more trouble, and end up fighting with one another as much as with the bad guys.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cThe Outsider\u201d (March 9), \u201cLayla M.\u201d (March 23), \u201cHappy Anniversary\u201d (March 30) and \u201cThe Titan\u201d (March 30).", "title": "The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in March", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "Clockwise from left: \u201cGhostbusters,\u201d \u201cAtomic Blonde,\u201d \u201cMarch of the Penguins 2,\u201d \u201cUp in the Air\u201d and \u201cThe Secret of N.I.M.H.\u201d\n\nClockwise from left: \u201cGhostbusters,\u201d \u201cAtomic Blonde,\u201d \u201cMarch of the Penguins 2,\u201d \u201cUp in the Air\u201d and \u201cThe Secret of N.I.M.H.\u201d Columbia Pictures; Focus Features; Hulu; Paramount Pictures; MGM\n\nWatching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nEvery month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for March, broken down by service and release date. Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice.\n\nMovies New to Netflix\n\nJesse Eisenberg and Kristen Stewart in \u201cAdventureland.\u201d Abbot Genser/Miramax Films\n\n\u2018Adventureland\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt\u2019s 1987, and James and Em (Jesse Eisenberg and Kristen Stewart) are workers at a rundown amusement park where the games are rigged. He makes her a \u201cbummer\u201d mixtape, saying of its contents: \u201cThey\u2019re truly miserable, pit of despair-type songs.
