I think you\u2019ll love it.\u201d The music serves as shorthand: We know that the mechanic, Connell (Ryan Reynolds), is a poseur because he claims he once jammed with Lou Reed; that the preening Lisa P. (Margarita Levieva) is superficial because she dances to Falco; and that the fumbling James and the guarded Em could be a good match because they both love H\u00fcsker D\u00fc. It\u2019s all wonderfully cynical, and yet sweetly earnest.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Harold Ramis, Dan Aykroyd, Bill Murray and Ernie Hudson in \u201cGhostbusters.\u201d Sony Pictures\n\n\u2018Ghostbusters\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 1984 smash isn\u2019t really about ghosts. It\u2019s about the effortless chemistry among the three leads: Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis and Bill Murray. Or, to be honest, it\u2019s about Murray. The story, now firmly imprinted in our national comedy DNA, is a woozy swirl of proton packs, shape-shifting Sumerian gods and, of course, the Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man. Sigourney Weaver is on hand, too \u2014 also in top form. But Murray is the deadpan master who fuels the movie.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cMoon.\u201d Sony Pictures Classics\n\n\u2018Moon\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cMoon\u201d is an underrated debut and a must-see before viewing director Duncan Jones\u2019s most recent film, \u201cMute,\u201d which feels like something of a successor. Sam Rockwell is absorbing as Sam Bell, an off-world corporate caretaker who, after being alone on the moon for three years, is starting to unravel. Aided by Clint Mansell\u2019s eerie score, the film examines the toll taken by living in total isolation, what it\u2019s like to confront ourselves and the lengths to which corporations might go to protect its interests. It\u2019s a haunting movie.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nLeonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet in \u201cRevolutionary Road.\u201d Francois Duhamel/Paramount Vantage\n\n\u2018Revolutionary Road\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cMarried, two kids \u2014 it should be enough,\u201d Kate Winslet\u2019s character despairs. But what if it\u2019s not? In this 2008 film from director Sam Mendes, an ill-suited couple (Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio) tries to escape what the husband calls the \u201chopeless emptiness\u201d of settled-down conformity in the 1950s suburbs, but they can\u2019t agree on how. Winslet is devastating in her rage and disillusionment as she cycles through limited options. Then, a sizzling Michael Shannon steps in, who, because his character is certifiably insane, has no fear of telling it like it is.\n\n\u2014\n\nGeorge Clooney in \u201cUp in the Air.\u201d Dale Robinette/Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018Up in the Air\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAs the traveling corporate hatchet man Ryan Bingham, the ever-charming George Clooney flies around the country firing workers he has never met before, often with a smile. He\u2019s a man with no personal life to speak of, whose main interest is racking up frequent-flier miles. (To him, loyalty means rewards programs.) But as he trains a chipper subordinate (Anna Kendrick) and connects with a fellow road warrior (Vera Farmiga), he\u2019s forced to confront the emptiness of his transient life. Some of the movie\u2019s most affecting moments are provided by real people who describe on-camera the trauma of losing their jobs.\n\n\u2014\n\nThe title character in \u201cBenji.\u201d Disney, via Photofest\n\n\u2018Benji\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 6\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWith a new \u201cBenji\u201d coming to Netflix on the March 16, Netflix is making the \u2026 er \u2026 \u201cclassic\u201d titles available, including this 1974 original, the first of five written around the scrappy little stray. In a twist on the typical family-dog scenario, the pup begins the franchise as a homeless freelancer who works his way into the hearts of the townspeople, especially a pair of siblings who feed and play with him behind their parents\u2019 backs. When the children are kidnapped, it\u2019s up to Benji to do the sleuthing necessary to find them.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix Original TV Series\n\nA scene from \u201cFlint Town.\u201d Zackary Canepari/Netflix\n\n\u2018Flint Town\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFlint, Mich., is infamous for the recent crisis involving lead-contaminated water, as well as for the General Motors downsizing covered in Michael Moore\u2019s documentary expos\u00e9 \u201cRoger & Me.\u201d The docu-series \u201cFlint Town\u201d describes a different problem, noting how the city\u2019s poverty has led to an underfunded police department, an escalating crime rate and citizens who live in fear. The show tracks the efforts to rectify the problem, which involves a lot of missteps, but also some genuine will to squeeze hope out of a hopeless situation.\n\n\u2014\n\nKrysten Ritter in \u201cJessica Jones.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarts streaming: March 8\n\nMarch 8 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nNetflix\u2019s Marvel shows vary wildly in quality, but \u201cJessica Jones\u201d is one that even a lot of the franchise\u2019s skeptics like. Give a lot of credit to the star, Krysten Ritter, who\u2019s both cool and heartbreaking as a crusty, superstrong detective, clobbering creeps while indulging in multiple vices to numb her pain. Three years after the show\u2019s first season became a critics\u2019 darling, it finally returns, with the heroine determined to crack a case that could lead her back to how she got her powers in the first place.\n\n\u2014\n\nCarey Mulligan in \u201cCollateral.\u201d Fabio Affuso/Netflix\n\n\u2018Collateral\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe veteran playwright and screenwriter David Hare, a two-time Oscar nominee for \u201cThe Hours\u201d and \u201cThe Reader,\u201d scripted this original four-episode BBC Two series about the investigation of a London murder with sensitive sociopolitical ramifications. Carey Mulligan stars as one of the officers investigating the case of a Syrian refugee who was shot and killed as he was working a food delivery job. As the case unfolds, the motives behind his assassination tip toward a disturbing commentary on England itself and its growing anti-immigrant sentiment.\n\n\u2014\n\nSierra Capri, left, and Jessica Marie Garcia in \u201cOn My Block.\u201d John O. Flexor/Netflix\n\n\u2018On My Block\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 16\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFans of the darkly comic, painfully real MTV series \u201cAwkward\u201d should be thrilled to hear that the show\u2019s creator, Lauren Iungerich, is back to making television, once again taking on high school but from a different perspective. Shifting her focus from the ritzy Palos Verdes region of Los Angeles to the more hardscrabble South Central, Iungerich should bring her usual snappy dialogue \u2014 and her sensitivity to adolescent emotions \u2014 to a part of the city where life is often more complicated than just finding a date for prom or mastering Snapchat.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cWild Wild Country.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Wild Wild Country\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 16\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nReaders who lived through the 1980s may recall the name of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a guru whose small Oregon cult briefly made national news because of his followers\u2019 alleged involvement with bioterror and an attempted political assassination. The docu-series \u201cWild Wild Country\u201d uses rare archival footage and recent interviews to help explain where Rajneesh\u2019s movement came from, how it took hold in America and how it all came to a violent end.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nParis Berelc, left, and Isabel May in \u201cAlexa & Katie.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Alexa & Katie\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe former \u201cHannah Montana\u201d writer Heather Wordham and the former \u201cWonder Years\u201d and \u201cMalcolm in the Middle\u201d writer Matthew Carlson bring their knack for family-friendly tales of teen angst to this, another of Netflix\u2019s growing stable of old-fashioned multicamera sitcoms. Paris Berelc and Isabel May star as high-school freshmen who struggle with this latest phase of their lives while discovering that making a good impression isn\u2019t entirely within their control.\n\n\u2014\n\nSelton Mello in \u201cThe Mechanism.\u201d Pedro Saad/Netflix\n\n\u2018The Mechanism\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFrom the mind of a \u201cNarcos\u201d executive producer, Jos\u00e9 Padilha, comes another true crime story, based on the still-unfolding \u201cOperation Car Wash\u201d money-laundering scandal in Brazil. \u201cThe Mechanism\u201d (or \u201cO Mecanismo\u201d in the original Portuguese) follows a team of investigators who start looking into kickbacks and bribes in a state-run petrochemical company. Things get hairy as they realize they could be exposing corruption on a scale that could destabilize the social order, not only in Brazil but also around the world.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix Original Movies\n\nA scene from \u201cLes Affam\u00e9s.\u201d Netflix\n\n\u2018Les Affam\u00e9s\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA hit at the Toronto International Film Festival last fall, this arty French-Canadian zombie thriller \u2014 with a title that translates as \u201cThe Ravenous\u201d \u2014 crosses \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d with muted neorealism and a touch of \u201cThe Twilight Zone.\u201d When a rural Quebecois community begins to succumb to a ghoulish plague, the survivors regroup in the surrounding forests and fight to reclaim their home. But will they become as horrible as the monsters they\u2019re trying to expel? The writer-director Robin Aubert asks that question subtly, in a horror movie that is as thoughtful as it is creepy.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Blake Anderson, Anders Holm and Adam DeVine in \u201cGame Over, Man!\u201d Cate Cameron/Netflix\n\n\u2018Game Over, Man!\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nProducers Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg join forces with the team behind the Comedy Central series \u201cWorkaholics\u201d to put a stoner-comedy twist on \u201cDie Hard.\u201d Anders Holm, Adam Devine and Blake Anderson play Los Angeles waiters who work in a building that gets seized by terrorists. Determined to be rough-and-tumble, blockbuster-style heroes \u2014 with guns and cool catchphrases \u2014 the three waiters bumble their way into even more trouble, and end up fighting with one another as much as with the bad guys.\n\n\u2014\n\nNora El Koussour in \u201cLayla M.\u201d Cinemien\n\n\u2018Layla M.\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nHow might radicalization actually work? The Dutch director Mijke de Jong offers a persuasive case study with this fictional account of a young Muslim woman in Amsterdam (Nora El Koussour) whose anger over Islamophobic policies leads her to get married, drop out of school and follow her husband to an austere religious community in Amman, Jordan. \u201cLayla M\u201d is about a headstrong woman whose convictions are met with different forms of oppression in Amsterdam and Jordan, tying her to a grim destiny like ropes to a railroad track.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest (TV and movies): \u201c300\u201d (March 1), \u201cCasino\u201d (March 1), \u201cCruel Intentions\u201d (March 1), \u201cThe Descent\u201d (March 1), \u201cForgetting Sarah Marshall\u201d (March 1), \u201cLaw & Order: Special Victims Unit\u201d Season 18 (March 1), \u201cWet Hot American Summer\u201d (March 1), \u201cLove\u201d Season 3 (March 9), \u201cTerrace House: Opening New Doors\u201d Season 1 (March 13), \u201cBenji\u201d [new Netflix Original version] (March 16), \u201c50 First Dates\u201d (March 28) and \u201cLittle Women\u201d (March 28).\n\nNew to Amazon Prime\n\nJodie Foster in \u201cThe Accused.\u201d Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018The Accused\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nReleased in 1988, \u201cThe Accused\u201d was one of the first Hollywood films to address the moral culpability of unprotesting witnesses to rape. Jodie Foster won her first Oscar for playing the abrasive, working class Sarah Tobias, who is treated as an \u201casking for it\u201d poster girl after she is gang raped in a bar. It\u2019s not only the rape itself that\u2019s on trial here, however: It\u2019s also the frat boy privilege, the whooping enablers and the pernicious victim blaming. A harrowing but necessary watch.\n\n\u2014\n\nJason Segel in \u201cJeff, Who Lives at Home.\u201d Hilary Bronwyn Gayle/Paramount Vantage\n\n\u2018Jeff, Who Lives at Home\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe sibling directors Jay and Mark Duplass might seem to be typecasting Jason Segel as a pot-smoking man-child, but this is one of the actor\u2019s best films. In it, he plays a 30-year-old slacker who continually interprets random events as \u201csigns\u201d about what he should do with his life \u2014 and perhaps he\u2019s right. The movie is sweet and discursive, with something serious on its mind.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Secret of N.I.M.H.\u201d MGM\n\n\u2018The Secret of N.I.M.H.\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMy sixth-grade teacher kept a cage of white rats in the classroom, and I would pretend that these were the rats from N.I.M.H. \u2014 lab rat escapees from the National Institute of Mental Health, who had gained superior intelligence from chemical brain enhancement experiments there. In this acclaimed animated film (based on a trilogy of books), the rats are the heroes, capable of reading, orchestrating their own escape, devising their own independent society and other brilliant plans. It\u2019s a kid pleaser.\n\n\u2014\n\nCharlize Theron in \u201cYoung Adult.\u201d Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018Young Adult\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe \u201cJuno\u201d team \u2014 director Jason Reitman and writer Diablo Cody \u2014 do something really risky in this movie: They give us a female antihero who\u2019s incredibly unlikable but still funny and fascinating. Charlize Theron\u2019s Mavis Gary is someone who grew older without growing up, hence her desperate scheme to win back a happily married ex (Patrick Wilson). The story deconstructs Hollywood\u2019s usual rom-com view of women: Mavis is not on any road to redemption, and we aren\u2019t rooting for her anyway. Patton Oswalt gives the film its bittersweet heart as an old schoolmate who once worshiped Mavis from afar.\n\n\u2014\n\nBen Stiller and Jenna Fischer in \u201cBrad\u2019s Status.\u201d Jonathan Wenk/Amazon Studios\n\n\u2018Brad\u2019s Status\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 2\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nMaybe we all resent it a bit when our friends become successful, but Brad (Ben Stiller in fine form) is obsessed with it. Even though he has a prestigious job, a loving marriage and a son on his way to college, he can\u2019t stop comparing his life \u2014 unfavorably \u2014 with those of his old college friends (Michael Sheen, Jemaine Clement, Luke Wilson and the film\u2019s writer and director, Mike White), all navigating a sea of first-world problems. Produced by Amazon, the film is sharply observed, and all too real.\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Remix.\u201d via Amazon Prime\n\n\u2018The Remix\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 9\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIndia often produces nearly 2,000 films a year, absolutely dwarfing Hollywood in volume and earnings. And yet most Americans are rarely exposed to the films and music of Bollywood, the Indian film industry\u2019s Hindi-language component, known around the world for its heroic tales, its brilliant costumes and its elaborate song-and-dance numbers. This new series from Amazon Prime offers an original twist on both Bollywood and the reality-competition series, pitting singers, dancers and DJs against one another to create remixed performances of popular Bollywood tunes.\n\n\u2014\n\nDave Franco and Aubrey Plaza in \u201cThe Little Hours.\u201d Gunpowder & Sky\n\n\u2018The Little Hours\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 27\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nFrustrated nuns go wild at a 14th Century Italian convent in this assertively foul-mouthed tale (loosely based on Giovanni Boccaccio\u2019s \u201cThe Decameron\u201d). The death-stare master Aubrey Plaza is one such sister who can\u2019t stay repressed for much longer, not when Dave Franco is the new groundskeeper and an irrepressible Jemima Kirke heads up the local witches\u2019 coven. Who knew confession could be so hilarious?\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of Interest: \u201c1984\u201d (March 1), \u201cChaplin\u201d (March 1), \u201cDirty Rotten Scoundrels\u201d (March 1), \u201cThe Doors\u201d (March 1), \u201cI\u2019m Gonna Git You Sucka\u201d (March 1), several \u201cJames Bond\u201d titles (March 1), \u201cSneaky Pete\u201d Season 2 (March 9), and \u201cThe Dangerous Book for Boys\u201d Season 1 (March 30).\n\nNew to Hulu\n\nA scene from \u201cThe Square.\u201d Magnolia Pictures\n\n\u2018The Square\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe art world gets a good going-over in this Oscar-nominated satire about a Stockholm museum from the Swedish director Ruben Ostlund. The targets are admittedly easy: ridiculous exhibitions put together by pretentious and hypocritical progressives. But two happenings in particular \u2014 a performance-art stunt in which a man pretends to be a monkey, and an explosive social-media campaign for an installation meant to represent \u201csanctuary\u201d \u2014 provoke compelling questions about confrontational art. What happens when you confront it right back?\n\n\u2014\n\nAgyness Deyn and Jim Sturgess in \u201cHard Sun.\u201d Hulu\n\n\u2018Hard Sun\u2019 Season 1\n\nStarts streaming: March 7\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIn this loopy new original action series from Hulu, two detectives (Jim Sturgess and Agyness Deyn) live in a world that is about to face an extinction-level event in five years\u2019 time. All sorts of what Detective Charlie Hicks (Sturgess) calls \u201cfreaks, nutters, religious weirdos and psychos\u201d are using that as an excuse to get away with murder before the apocalypse, which might mean the world is coming to an end ahead of schedule.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nA scene from \u201cForce Majeure.\u201d Magnolia Pictures\n\n\u2018Force Majeure\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 12\n\nMarch 12 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAs an avalanche comes crashing down an alpine ski resort, vacationers naturally panic. A mother lunges for her children, but her husband flees \u2014 taking his iPhone. Everyone is safe, but is the marriage? Ruben Ostlund offers here a wickedly funny exploration of marital dissatisfaction, along with one of the best (worst?) man-cries ever committed to film.\n\n\u2014\n\nMelanie Lynskey and Christopher Abbott in \u201cHello I Must be Going.\u201d Justina Mintz/Oscilloscope Laboratories\n\n\u2018Hello I Must Be Going\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 15\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLovers of the New Zealand actress Melanie Lynskey, this one\u2019s for you. Finally, after years of playing soft supporting roles, Lynskey took center stage, in this bittersweet 2012 comedy about a 35-year-old divorced woman who finds her way out of a life slump by way of an affair with a 19-year-old guy (Christopher Abbott). Lynskey is luminous, even when she literally hits rock bottom. (It\u2019s a sight gag. Don\u2019t miss it.)\n\n\u2014\n\nA scene from \u201cMarch of the Penguins 2: The Next Step.\u201d Daisy Gilardini/Hulu\n\n\u2018March of the Penguins 2: The Next Step\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 23\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWhat could be cuter than penguins? Baby penguins! The French documentarian Luc Jacquet returns to Antarctica for this sequel in order to track a waddling father and son on the younger bird\u2019s first journey across and under the ice. Morgan Freeman\u2019s dulcet tones and an underwater camera accompany their plunge. Under the sea, the birds seem to fly.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cChaplin\u201d (March 1), \u201cChicago\u201d (March 1), \u201cDirty Dancing\u201d (March 1), \u201cStuart Little\u201d (March 1), \u201cVeni Vidi Vici\u201d Season 1 (March 1), \u201cThe Bridge\u201d Season 4 (March 15), \u201cThe Englishman Who Went Up a Hill but Came Down a Mountain\u201d (March 15), \u201cThe Son\u201d Season 1 (March 15), \u201cJohn Q\u201d (March 16) and \u201cWho Framed Roger Rabbit\u201d (March 24).\n\nNew to HBO\n\nBruce Willis in \u201cDie Hard.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\n\u2018Die Hard\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAlan Rickman made his big-screen debut in this film as the icy Hans Gruber, a disaffected German terrorist intent on stealing a huge cache of bearer bonds for unstated nefarious purposes. Gruber almost seems bored by the whole affair \u2014 that is, until the arrival of Bruce Willis\u2019s pesky \u201ccowboy,\u201d John McClane. The ensuing showdown makes for the greatest Christmas action movie ever made. Yippee-ki-yay!\n\n\u2014\n\nGene Hackman in \u201cThe French Connection.\u201d 20th Century Fox\n\n\u2018The French Connection\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nPopeye Doyle is a racist creep; but he\u2019s also a relentlessly effective cop, and Gene Hackman brilliantly captures both sides of this prickly character. (He won an Oscar for his performance.) Popeye is on the trail of a silky international drug lord (Fernando Rey), and in the process of hunting him down takes part in one of the greatest slam-bang car chases of the 1970s. Which is saying something.\n\n\u2014\n\nAnthony Hopkins in \u201cThe Silence of the Lambs.\u201d Orion Pictures\n\n\u2018The Silence of the Lambs\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cQuid pro quo\u201d: It\u2019s only one of the terrifying demands made on the F.B.I. trainee Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster) by the caged Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins). She seeks his help in creating a profile of a serial killer, but he wants something in return, elevating this brooding horror-thriller into something brilliant. It won five Oscars, and it still haunts.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlly Sheedy and Matthew Broderick in \u201cWarGames.\u201d MGM\n\n\u2018WarGames\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 1\n\nMarch 1 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nHoping to keep up with the references in Steven Spielberg\u2019s coming movie \u201cReady Player One\u201d? Then it\u2019s time to get reacquainted with this 1983 hacker thriller, which occupies a significant place in that movie\u2019s plot. Matthew Broderick \u2014 looking ridiculously youthful \u2014 is a high-school kid named David Lightman, who is determined to play what he thinks is an unreleased computer game, Global Thermonuclear War. (Yikes!) Key word being \u201cthinks.\u201d Get to know David really, really well, and it will help you crack some of the \u201cReady\u201d codes.\n\n\u2014\n\nCharlize Theron in \u201cAtomic Blonde.\u201d Jonathan Prime/Focus Features\n\n\u2018Atomic Blonde\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 24\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAnyone who\u2019s contemplated the possibility of a female James Bond should take a look at \u201cAtomic Blonde.\u201d The movie is set in Cold War Berlin, with Charlize Theron as a top spy for Britain\u2019s MI6, who\u2019s capable of dispatching multiple K.G.B. thugs at once with punches, flying kicks and found-item weapons (garden hoses, corkscrews). Theron was once a serious ballet student, and she did most of her own fight-scene stunts here (and looks suitably banged up after they\u2019re over). Bond would certainly approve.\n\n\u2014\n\nFrom left, Tiffany Haddish, Jada Pinkett Smith, Regina Hall and Queen Latifah in \u201cGirls Trip.\u201d Universal Pictures\n\n\u2018Girls Trip\u2019\n\nStarts streaming: March 31\n\nMarch 31 Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nDoes absinthe makes the heart grow fonder? It definitely does the trick for the four college pals in this film (Queen Latifah, Jada Pinkett Smith, Regina Hall, and Tiffany Haddish), who get together for a wild reunion in New Orleans. Gleefully outrageous, Haddish steals the show (you\u2019ll want to see her grapefruit-banana trick), and it\u2019s a pleasure to watch her break through.\n\n\u2014\n\nAlso of interest: \u201cThe Beguiled\u201d (March 1), \u201cIce Age\u201d (March 1),\u201cWhere the Wild Things Are\u201d (March 1), \u201cAlien: Covenant\u201d (March 3), \u201cMy Cousin Rachel\u201d (March 10) and \u201cThe Zen Diaries of Garry Shandling\u201d Parts 1 and 2 (March 26 and 27).\n\n\u2014\n\nNoel Murray and Scott Tobias contributed reporting", "title": "The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in March", "authors": ["Jennifer Vineyard"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The most effective way to monitor blood pressure may be to do it yourself.\n\nBritish researchers randomly assigned 1,003 patients with hypertension to one of three groups. The first took their own readings daily for one week every month over the course of a year and mailed them to a doctor. A second used a phone app, sending their readings to the doctor through a web-based system. A control group was assigned to \u201cusual care,\u201d in which patients had their blood pressure checked at their doctor\u2019s office. The data gathered was used to adjust medication.\n\nThe average systolic reading (the top number) for all patients was about 153 at the start. By the end of 12 months, members of the control group had lowered their average to 140. But the telemonitoring group and the self-monitoring group had lowered theirs to 136 and 137, respectively. The authors estimate these lower numbers would lower stroke risk by 20 percent and coronary artery disease risk by 10 percent. The study was published in Lancet.\n\n\u201cPeople who monitor their own blood pressure and share the readings with their physician get better control,\u201d said the lead author, Dr. Richard J. McManus, a professor of primary care at the University of Oxford. \u201cSeventy-five million Americans have hypertension. If a good proportion of those self-monitored, it would lead to a big reduction in stroke.\u201d\n\nThe monitors were provided free by their manufacturer.", "title": "The Best Way to Monitor Your Blood Pressure? Do It Yourself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "The comedian Tiffany Haddish, perhaps the brightest light of this awards season, showed up on the red carpet wearing a traditional Eritrean gown, a homage to her late father, and hopped a velvet rope to jump in front of Meryl Streep, whom she curtsied to. But it was Ms. Haddish\u2019s decision to wear her white Alexander McQueen dress onstage as a presenter that really popped.\n\nMs. Haddish wore the same frock on the red carpet for \u201cGirls Trip\u201d and onstage as host of \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d During that gig, she noted that the gown had cost more than her mortgage and that she would wear it again and again. \u201cI don\u2019t give a dang about no taboo,\u201d she said. Seeing her wear it again to the Oscars only underscored her persona as the down-to-earth funny woman people can\u2019t seem to get enough of. \u2014 Cara Buckley\n\nThe Envelope Least Susceptible to Mix-Ups\n\nPhoto\n\nWith new practices in place, it would be hard for the Oscars to repeat last year\u2019s best picture mix-up.\n\nThe Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences confirmed several changes in January, including that presenters make sure they have the correct envelope before they go onstage, with that fact confirmed by stage managers, too. PwC accountants were forbidden from using social media during the show, in hopes of reducing distractions.\n\nBut the biggest change became quickly apparent as Viola Davis presented the award for best supporting actor. The gold, bold type on the envelope, loudly announcing the name of the category, was so unmistakable it could be read clearly on TV. Last year\u2019s envelope was an elegant red, but the lettering on it was rendered in a light, not-easily-readable gold. \u2014 Daniel Victor\n\nThe Most Political Statement\n\nPhoto\n\nBefore introducing the award for production design, Lupita Nyong\u2019o and Kumail Nanjiani made one of the night\u2019s most pointed political statements. The two introduced themselves as immigrants \u2014 Ms. Nyong\u2019o was born in Mexico and raised in Kenya; Mr. Nanjiani is from Pakistan \u2014 and then made a not-so-subtle appeal on behalf of the so-called Dreamers, who are in the United States under the policy of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA. Their future remains in limbo after President Trump moved to end the program.\n\nMs. Nyong\u2019o and Mr. Nanjiani, without mentioning the politics of immigration directly, briefly spoke about dreams being the \u201cfoundation of Hollywood\u201d and the United States. Mr. Nanjiani, who was nominated for best original screenplay for \u201cThe Big Sick,\u201d closed by saying, \u201cTo all the dreamers out there, we stand with you.\u201d \u2014 Sopan Deb\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Best Acceptance-Speech Opener\n\nPhoto\n\nAllison Janney brought the house down when her first line upon accepting her supporting actress Oscar for \u201cI, Tonya\u201d was a brash \u201cI did it all by myself.\u201d If she had left it there, it would have been a speech for the ages, and probably would have earned her a Jet Ski, referring to the host Jimmy Kimmel\u2019s prize for the shortest speech of the night. \u2014 Margaret Lyons\n\nThe Sweetest Victory After 13 Losses\n\nPhoto\n\nThe 14th time was the charm.\n\nAfter repeatedly being nominated for Oscars for cinematography on films like Martin Scorsese\u2019s \u201cKundun\u201d and Frank Darabont\u2019s \u201cThe Shawshank Redemption,\u201d Roger Deakins finally won his first statue. His work on the sequel \u201cBlade Runner 2049\u201d did the trick for an expansive career dating to the 1970s.\n\nMr. Deakins was lighthearted and reserved in his acceptance speech, joking that he had \u201cbetter say something or else they\u2019ll give me a Jet Ski.\u201d \u2014 Sopan Deb\n\nThe Worst Use of an Editing Trick\n\nMontage overload. We don\u2019t need montages about how the existence of movies is good; these are the Oscars, so we in the audience have at least a marginal appreciation of the form. High-within-the-low: All the montages were superb! There were just way too many of them. \u2014 Margaret Lyons\n\nThe Most Electrifying Number", "title": "The Best and Worst of Oscars 2018", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "College-Basketball-Reference rates Bearcats forward Gary Clark as the best defensive player in the country and has three other Cincinnati players in the top 20.\n\nWORST Texas Southern, the only team in the tournament with a losing record (15-19), allows 109.1 points per 100 possessions.\n\n3-Point Shooting\n\nBEST Purdue shot 42 percent from the 3-point line, although Villanova made the most total 3s. Guard Dakota Mathias made 46 percent of his attempts, the best figure of any player in the tournament, with three other starters hitting at 39 percent or more.\n\nWORST Texas is not filled with sharpshooters this year, hitting only 32 percent of its 3-point attempts.\n\nDefending the 3\n\nBEST Penn\u2019s opponents shot only 29 percent from outside the 3-point line. Top-seeded Kansas (40 percent on the season) will test that in the first round.\n\nWORST Surprisingly, North Carolina struggled to defend the 3, allowing 38-percent shooting to opponents. Virginia shot 53 percent (9 for 17) against the Tar Heels in the A.C.C. title game.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSpeed\n\nFASTEST Bring your oxygen tanks when playing Lipscomb, a No. 15 seed that likes to run. The team averaged 77 possessions per game this season. Oklahoma and Marshall are close behind.\n\nSLOWEST For the third year in a row, Virginia was the most methodical team in the nation, averaging 60.5 possessions. It worked, as the Cavaliers\u2019 31-2 record attests. The team never gave up more than 68 points in a game. If it meets the defensive wizards from Cincinnati in the regional final, consider betting the under.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPassing, Rebounding, Shot Blocking\n\nBEST Michigan State, a No. 3 seed, looks good from a lot of analytic angles. The Spartans lead the nation in assist percentage (Cassius Winston averages 7 per game), rebound percentage (Nick Ward and Miles Bridges, 7 per game), and shot-blocking percentage (Jaren Jackson Jr., 3 per game). Those numbers have prompted a lot of prognosticators to see the third-seeded Spartans as a top contender to win the tough Midwest bracket.\n\nWORST Passing, College of Charleston; rebounding, Marshall; shot-blocking, South Dakota State.\n\nFrom the Line\n\nBEST Davidson makes 80 percent of its free throws. But its most famous graduate is unimpressed. Stephen Curry made 88 percent in college and is at 90 percent for the N.B.A.\u2019s Golden State Warriors.\n\nWORST Trailing New Mexico State late? Consider fouling. The Aggies shoot only 64 percent from the line as a team.\n\nGetting to the Line\n\nBEST Drawing fouls is a skill, and often an underrated one. Cal State Fullerton managed 0.44 free throw attempts for every field goal attempt, with guard Kyle Allman getting to the line an average of eight times a game.\n\nWORST Though Davidson usually makes its free throws, it does not draw that many, just 0.25 for every field goal attempt.\n\nProtecting the Ball\n\nBEST Of all the teams in the N.C.A.A. field, it was 12th-seeded South Dakota State that took care of the ball better than any other, surrendering it just 12.2 times per 100 possessions.\n\nWORST Missouri, by contrast, was a little sloppy, averaging 18.2. Seven of its players had 1.5 turnovers per game or more.", "title": "The Best and Worst of the N.C.A.A. Tournament", "authors": ["Victor Mather"]} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Before the Rohingya started crossing into Bangladesh from Myanmar in large numbers in the summer, fleeing attacks on their villages by the army and allied mobs, the hills were dotted with forest.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut then, in a matter of weeks, as refugees poured in by the tens of thousands, trees were hacked away. Canals were dug. Bamboo-and-tarp shacks went up. More trees were cut as refugees scrambled to find firewood.\n\nThe hills, where elephants recently roamed, are now bare. Even the roots have been pulled out, leaving nothing to hold the parched soil together as rainwater washes downhill, potentially taking tents and people with it and quickly inundating low-lying settlements. The United Nations says 100,000 refugees are at acute risk from landslides and floods.\n\nThe early rains \u2014 known in Bengali as kalboishakhi, which translates loosely as the storms of an \u201cevil summer\u201d \u2014 are a precursor to the full-on monsoons. They strike when the soil is still dry and especially susceptible to mudslides. The only warning of their approach is usually hot winds that send the dry earth of summer swirling through the air.\n\n\u201cYou have whirlwinds of dust,\u201d said Iffat Nawaz, a spokeswoman for BRAC, an international relief agency that is based in Bangladesh. \u201cSuddenly it gets dark in middle of the day and it pours. We usually welcome that. It\u2019s cooling. This year in the middle of the refugee crisis, it\u2019s not something to look forward to.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSoutheastern Bangladesh is already one of the wettest parts of a wet country, with 12 feet of rain on average every year. A warming atmosphere can hold more moisture and unleash more intense downpours, and make wet places even wetter. That may already be happening in and around Cox\u2019s Bazar. Total pre-monsoon rainfall in the region has increased by about one inch every five years over the past five decades, a 2014 study by researchers from Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology found.\n\nWhen the rains come, latrines are likely to overflow, bringing the risk of cholera and other waterborne diseases.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn February, United Nations agencies began dispatching engineering crews to clear blocked sewage canals at risk of overflowing in the rainy season. They distributed compressed rice husk, an alternative to firewood, but that met only a small fraction of the refugees\u2019 needs. The government has yet to allow the United Nations refugee agency to distribute gas stoves that would decrease the demand for firewood.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBangladesh, one of the poorest, most densely populated countries in the world, opened its borders to the Rohingya in August, when they began arriving with tales of massacres by the Myanmar military. They crossed a swollen river to get to safety, walking through muddy fields and sleeping under the open sky with their children. The Bangladeshi government let them settle around an area where there was already a relatively small Rohingya refugee camp.\n\nA spokeswoman for the International Organization for Migration, which manages the camp, said aid agencies were well aware of the natural disaster risks, but that they struggled in the early months to provide basic services and focused on immediate needs: water, food and shelter.\n\nPhoto\n\nBangladeshi and United Nations officials say they are preparing land elsewhere to relocate roughly 100,000 refugees from the megacamp. In one instance, the United Nations is leveling a hilly area allocated by the government to relocate refugees. And officials are distributing more tarp, bamboo and sandbags to refugees to shore up their tents before the rains begin.\n\nCould any of this have been prevented? Mr. Thompson said it would have helped to set up a camp on flatter land and to prevent the clear-cutting of the forest.\n\n\u201cWe will be looking at decisions that were taken in the first six months of this operation,\u201d he said by phone from Cox\u2019s Bazar. \u201cWe always learn from our previous experiences and get better. Having said that, we find ourselves in circumstances we couldn\u2019t have imagined.\u201d", "title": "The Biggest Refugee Camp Braces for Rain: \u2018This Is Going to Be a Catastrophe\u2019", "authors": ["Somini Sengupta", "Henry Fountain"]} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "The star players Patrick Kane and Jonathan Toews have been left to ponder what went wrong and to answer questions about the team\u2019s focus now that there is no postseason to look forward to.\n\nQuenneville has done his best to remain positive.\n\n\u201cI would say we\u2019re not in a bad spot,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s definitely not easy, but I think guys are still playing with purpose.\u201d\n\nToews told reporters recently: \u201cYou have pride as a team. You know what you\u2019re capable of as a team, even if you\u2019ve underachieved or you haven\u2019t had the success you\u2019ve been looking for in the last couple of months.\u201d\n\nAfter a 5-1 loss to Colorado on Tuesday that eliminated the Blackhawks from playoff contention, Kane said that he and his teammates were trying to remain in the moment rather than consider what may be coming.\n\n\u201cWho knows what\u2019s going to happen,\u201d Kane said. \u201cI\u2019m sure that will kind of be left up to management and coaches and us as players obviously throughout the off-season to rectify what went wrong this season and make sure it doesn\u2019t happen again.\u201d\n\nBowman insisted the Blackhawks were not \u201clight-years away from where we want to be.\u201d\n\nBowman pointed to the way the Tampa Bay Lightning and the Colorado Avalanche rebounded this season after tough times a season ago. Although the realities of the N.H.L.\u2019s hard salary-cap system will force him and the rest of Chicago\u2019s front office to face difficult decisions heading into next year, Bowman said he did not anticipate a need to make sweeping changes.\n\nFor the time being, the Blackhawks will spend the remainder of the season evaluating young talent to determine which players could be moved into the kind of difference-making roles Kane and Toews have maintained during Chicago\u2019s decade-long run of success.", "title": "The Blackhawks Adjust to the View From the Bottom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Kennedy also campaigned on the dignity of work over welfare. In a TV commercial, he declared, \u201cI think welfare is demeaning and destructive of the human being and of his family.\u201d He didn\u2019t blame \u201cwelfare queens\u201d for cheating the system, as Ronald Reagan later would, but said he envisioned a policy of full employment in which a person could say to himself: \u201cI helped build this country. I am a participant in its greatest public venture.\u201d\n\nOn issues of national security, Kennedy took a principled position in opposition to the Vietnam War \u2014 whose very morality he questioned \u2014 but threaded the needle in a way that also made clear to working-class voters that he differed sharply from upper-middle-class white college students who avoided service or even sympathized with the North Vietnamese Communists. At Notre Dame, Kennedy was booed for saying college draft deferments should be abolished. \u201cYou\u2019re getting the unfair advantage while poor people are being drafted,\u201d he said. Remarkably, in Indiana he polled as well among those who favored Johnson\u2019s conduct of the Vietnam War as he did among those who opposed it.\n\nKennedy\u2019s campaign to woo working-class voters across racial lines worked. The candidate most identified with advancing civil rights did well not only with black and Hispanic voters but also among working-class whites, some of whom had supported Wallace\u2019s segregationist candidacy in 1964.\n\nA half-century later, how could progressives try to rebuild the Bobby Kennedy coalition? Kennedy\u2019s appeal was based in part on being the brother of a revered and martyred president, of course, and the most salient issues were different in 1968 than they are today. But Kennedy stressed fundamental themes that travel across time and transcend specific policy issues.\n\nFirst, to appeal to a sizable number of white working-class voters in 1968, Kennedy did not forfeit his basic principles or change his positions on civil rights, or war and peace \u2014 and neither should progressives today. Ignoring the rights of women, gay people and people of color is both morally wrong and politically stupid if your aspiration is an inclusive populism.\n\nSecond, progressives should fight for economic justice in a manner that is relentless rather than episodic. On the campaign trail, Kennedy consistently hit themes of economic inequality and named the names of wealthy individuals, like the oil tycoon H. L. Hunt, who paid little in taxes. By contrast, in the final weeks leading up to the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton de-emphasized economic issues in favor of attacks on Mr. Trump\u2019s qualifications, according to research by Democracy Corps and the Roosevelt Institute, and his support among white non-college voters rose considerably. Progressives also need to vigorously punish Wall Street malfeasance. It is difficult to imagine that Kennedy, a tough prosecutor, would have argued, as some members of the Obama administration did, that some companies are \u201ctoo big to jail.\u201d\n\nThird, progressives should explicitly signal the inclusion of working-class whites in their vision for change by applying civil rights laws to issues of class inequality, consistent with Kennedy\u2019s view that \u201cpoverty is closer to the root of the problem than color.\u201d I have long argued that we should extend the Civil Rights Act to prohibit discrimination against workers of all races engaged in labor organizing; integrate elementary and secondary schools not only by race but also by socioeconomic status; combat discrimination in housing by economic status as well as race; and adopt affirmative action programs in higher education for economically disadvantaged students of every color.", "title": "Opinion | The Bobby Kennedy Pathway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "On March 18, a fourth bomb exploded on a street in a predominantly white residential area southwest of the city, seriously injuring two unidentified white men in their 20s. Two days later, two more bombs, one of which detonated, were found at FedEx facilities. Those last three bombs (if these are indeed the last ones) changed everything. The authorities stopped invoking possible hate crimes and seemed to drop racial motivation from their statements altogether.\n\nBut that has done nothing to alleviate the fear among residents of East Austin that they were being targeted. The House and Mason families are stalwarts of the African-American community with deep ties to the city\u2019s civil rights movement. Families like theirs are becoming a rarity in this rapidly gentrifying part of the city. Over the past four years, I have been studying black displacement from Austin, trying to understand why it was the only major growing city in America to see an absolute numerical decline in the African-American population during the first decade of the 21st century.\n\nWe recently completed a survey in the Masons\u2019 neighborhood, asking longstanding residents what they thought of the changes taking place around them. Respondents described a neighborhood that had lost its children. For them, this was distinguishing feature of gentrification: the families with children moved out and were being replaced by newcomers without children. Draylen and his family were the exception to this rule.\n\nFor Draylen\u2019s neighbors and others in the area, there was nothing coincidental about three bombs being planted and detonated on that side of the interstate. The people I spoke with were dismayed at how hesitant city leaders were to recognize the terror that gripped their community. Gilbert Rivera, a lifelong East Austin resident, told me he was hurt that elected officials \u201cdidn\u2019t acknowledge that black and brown people were under attack after the first three.\u201d\n\nThis subtle erasure of their sense of safety recalls a much earlier wave of crimes that gripped Austin near the end of the 19th century, in 1884 and 1885. They were known as the \u201cservant girl killings,\u201d in which a serial killer murdered eight people, six of them black. At the time, the authorities insisted that these crimes could not have been racially motivated, and they refused to consider the possibility that a white man could have been responsible. Their investigation centered on black male suspects, but the crime was never solved. And Austin maintained its reputation as a city that was, compared to others in the south, racially tolerant.", "title": "Opinion | The Bomber Is Dead, but Fear of Racist Attacks Lives On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere was once a chain of New York restaurants called Brass Rail. But at several new restaurants, the richly glowing golden metal is on the surface of the bar, not just the foot rail. Brass is nudging aside zinc, the traditional metal for bar tops. At Legacy Records near Hudson Yards, the main curved bar and a utility bar are both covered in burnished brass. Robert Bohr, an owner, said he wanted it for warmth and for how well it complemented the midcentury style of the restaurant, designed by Ken Fulk. At Harry\u2019s, a venerable steakhouse on Hanover Square that was recently redecorated for about $1 million by Antonio Tadrissi of PDLab in Toronto, the 36-foot bar is covered in brass. \u201cBrass ages beautifully and gracefully, just like Harry,\u201d Mr. Tadrissi said, referring to Harry Poulakakos, the founder of the 46-year-old restaurant, which is now owned by his son, Peter Poulakakos. At Brasserie Seoul in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, brass is the focus on a bar in the center of the room. You\u2019ll also see brass in accents, like the trim throughout the new Simon & the Whale in Gramercy. And it\u2019s not just a New York trend. Henrietta\u2019s at the Dewberry in Charleston, S.C., is another room with brass on the bar.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "The Brass Section Is at the Bar", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Used as a selling point by real estate agents everywhere, an exposed brick wall \u2014 the more aged and weathered, the better \u2014 can add texture, character and a sense of history to a home.\n\nBut the kind of brick that came with my house in upstate New York was more akin to what you might see in a 1980s pizza chain than the coveted exposed brick found in so many prewar buildings in the city. Years of unattended leaks had left water stains across the top half of my brick fireplace, and below the mantel, it was a garish fire-engine red.\n\nSo when it was time to repaint the living room, I decided to give the fireplace a makeover, too. At about $55 for a gallon of Benjamin Moore\u2019s Stonington Gray, the transformation was cheap, instant and effective. A $5 can of high-heat Rust-oleum in matte black applied to the brass fireplace screen finished off the new look.\n\nBut there are any number of ways to deal with an ugly brick wall. Contractors and interior designers shared some of their favorite fixes.", "title": "The Brick Wall Dilemma", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sullenberger is hardly a technophobe. He has flown passenger jets crammed with advanced electronics and software and has a keen professional interest in technology. What concerns him and other safety experts is that industry executives and government officials are rushing headlong to put self-driving cars on the road without appropriate safeguards and under the unproven hypothesis that the technology will reduce crashes and fatalities. The Senate, for instance, is considering a bill that would exempt self-driving cars from existing federal regulations and pre-empt state and local governments from regulating them. And Arizona became a hotbed of self-driving testing by telling auto and technology companies \u2014 like Uber \u2014 that it will not ask too many questions or institute a lot of new rules.\n\nEven as officials place a big bet that autonomous cars will solve many of our safety problems, American roads are becoming less safe. More than 37,000 people were killed on American roads in 2016, up 5.6 percent from 2015, according to government data. The National Safety Council, a research and advocacy organization, estimates that the death toll was more than 40,000 in 2017.\n\nExperts who are skeptical about the unceasing forward march of technology say fatalities are rising because public officials have become so enamored with the shiny new thing, self-driving cars, that they have taken their eyes off problems they could be solving today. In the federal government and most states, there appears to be little interest in or patience for doing the tedious work of identifying and implementing policies and technologies with proven track records of saving lives now, as opposed to some time in the distant future.\n\nConsider automatic braking systems. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety estimates that there is a 42 percent reduction in rear-end crashes that cause injuries when this technology is installed on cars. Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety and other public interest groups asked the Transportation Department in 2015 to require that all new trucks, buses and other commercial vehicles have such systems, which have been around for years. The department accepted that petition but has yet to propose a rule. The government did reach a voluntary agreement with 20 automakers to make automatic braking a standard feature on cars and light trucks by September 2022.\n\nEven as American regulators have dragged their feet, other industrialized countries have made great strides in reducing traffic crashes over the last two decades. Road fatality rates in Canada, France, Germany and Sweden, for example, are now less than half the rate in the United States. And no, these countries don\u2019t have fleets of self-driving cars. They have reduced accidents the old-fashioned way. Some of them have worked to slow down traffic \u2014 speed is a leading killer. They have added medians and made other changes to roads to better protect pedestrians. And European regulators have encouraged the use of seatbelts by putting visual reminders even in the back seat. Germany, which has the high-speed autobahn, also requires much more rigorous driver education and testing than most American states do.\n\n\u201cThe things that have been killing us for decades are still killing us: speed, impaired driving, not using seatbelts,\u201d said Deborah Hersman, the former chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board who now heads the National Safety Council. \u201cThe things that we know can save lives, some of them don\u2019t cost any money, like seatbelts.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Bright, Shiny Distraction of Self-Driving Cars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile he stays mum about a porn star who is peddling steamy secrets about him \u2014 and who is doing what he hates most, which is using him as a stepping stone to saturation fame. The interview that she gave to \u201c60 Minutes\u201d is scheduled to be broadcast this coming weekend without a peep from the president (though with frantic efforts by his lawyers to quash it). His silence speaks volumes.\n\nIt could say that he has more discipline than he gets credit for, and that instead of a mad, lonely king ranting in his castle, he is actually a profoundly flawed tactician playing his own pale version of chess. The salvos against Mueller last weekend absolutely had a logic: They were shirt-tailed to the firing of the deputy F.B.I. director Andrew McCabe in the service of a corruption narrative, and they were trial balloons to see how negatively Republican leaders in Congress responded. (The unsurprising answer: not negatively enough.)\n\nTrump\u2019s silence could also say that he isn\u2019t actually bothered by Daniels\u2019s account of an affair with him. This is a man whose appearances on Howard Stern\u2019s radio show over the years were all about erotic peacocking; who bragged to Billy Bush about groping women and paid no discernible price for it; and who can apparently do anything shy of converting to Islam and not fret about his evangelical base. Where the rest of us see reckless infidelity, he sees a buxom conquest that lesser Lotharios can only dream about.\n\nBut I wonder more about the opposite. What if the enigma of what Daniels is about to say really rattles him, and his turning away from it is the telltale sign of that? The assumption has long been that his Twitter account gives us his psychic vital signs and that we can chart his distress by his diatribes. But diatribes are his norm. Deviations from them may hold more meaning.\n\nAnd there are reasons that he\u2019d be rattled. His selling of himself as a super-potent stud (\u201cBest Sex I\u2019ve Ever Had\u201d) is one of the pillars of his vanity, and Daniels could smash it to the ground. She didn\u2019t quite do that in a 2011 interview with In Touch magazine, but neither did she sound remotely wowed.", "title": "Opinion | The Calm Before the Stormy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nDispatch from David: Whither stevia? After we published our guide to eating less sugar, several readers wrote to us to ask about stevia: Why was it included on the list of sweeteners people should minimize? Isn\u2019t it natural?\n\nHere are some answers:\n\n\u2022 There is no perfect definition of \u201cnatural,\u201d but, under most reasonable definitions, many versions of stevia fail to qualify. \u201cI know the stevia producers say it\u2019s not artificial because it\u2019s extracted from plants, but really it\u2019s not,\u201d as Marion Nestle, an N.Y.U. food researcher, says. \u201cIt\u2019s mostly synthesized.\u201d\n\n\u2022 There is little reliable information about the health effects of stevia. Makers of the product have financed several studies that found \u2014 get ready to be shocked \u2014 no harmful effects of eating it. But you shouldn\u2019t trust industry-financed research. It has a long history of bias. \u201cUnfortunately, we don\u2019t have reliable evidence on stevia,\u201d says Laura Schmidt of the University of California, San Francisco, School of Medicine.", "title": "Opinion | The Case Against Stevia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Free-traders are not indifferent to national security nor blind to the benefits a nation derives from having a middle class. But the priority of goods is different: Free-traders tend to believe that only by making economic efficiency the supreme goal of public policy can those other ends be achieved. Division of labor produces greater wealth, and so free trade makes everyone better off, with the harm to those whose manufacturing jobs are lost outweighed by the good that comes from, say, cheaper flat-screen televisions. Dollars decide. The figures are the outward and visible signs of the fundamental economic truth.\n\nThe middle class, by this reckoning, must take care of itself, finding new ways to make a living if the factories close. With more wealth available in the aggregate, thanks to the efficiencies of trade and specialization, some happy outcome is sure to materialize. If we cannot say what it is, that only means that spontaneous order has a pleasant surprise in store for us.\n\nAs for national security, exceptions might have to be made; even The Wall Street Journal has recently editorialized against the takeover of the United States communications chip manufacturer Qualcomm by the Singapore-based Broadcom on national-security grounds. But free-trade ideologues say exceptions should be made only case by case, with the benefit of the doubt falling on the side of trade and foreign deals.\n\nTo free-traders, economic nationalism is simply unnatural, an effort to artificially prolong the lives of aged industries. And since technology eliminates more jobs than trade does, the free traders ask, is the economic nationalist\u2019s next step Luddism?\n\nThe fact that technology reduces well-paid industrial employment is no reason to reduce it further through open trade policies. And the example of China today, as well as that of the United States in the 19th century, shows that preference for domestic producers does not have to mean fossilization. Nationalist economies have some of the world\u2019s most impressive records of growth and technical advancement.\n\nTariffs are not magic. Sometimes the unintended consequences at home and retaliation from overseas can be devastating. But trade wars, like shooting wars, shouldn\u2019t be avoided with pre-emptive surrender, which is what the free-trade regime amounts to for America\u2019s long-term security and middle-class prosperity. Steel towns throughout the Northeast and Midwest have been losing a trade war for decades because they cannot count on their leaders in Washington to fight for them.\n\nFree trade is a clear and simple rule, and the economic theory of which it is a part is elegant and logical. But it is only a partial truth. The value of the middle class has to be weighed in political terms, not merely economic ones, and national security has a strategic logic all its own that springs from different and darker assumptions about human nature than the hopeful logic of economic efficiency.", "title": "Opinion | The Case for Trump\u2019s Tariffs and \u2018America First\u2019 Economics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "Beef and dairy cattle together account for an outsize share of agriculture and its attendant problems, including almost two-thirds of all livestock emissions, according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. That\u2019s partly because there are so many of them \u2014 1 billion to 1.4 billion head of cattle worldwide. They don\u2019t outnumber humanity, but with cattle in this country topping out at about 1,300 pounds apiece, their footprint on the planet easily outweighs ours.\n\nThe emissions come partly from the fossil fuels used to plant, fertilize and harvest the feed to fatten them up for market. In addition, ruminant digestion causes cattle to belch and otherwise emit huge quantities of methane. A new study in the journal Carbon Balance and Management puts the global gas output of cattle at 120 million tons per year. Methane doesn\u2019t hang around in the atmosphere as long as carbon dioxide. But in the first 20 years after its release, it\u2019s 80 to 100 times more potent at trapping the heat of the sun and warming the planet. The way feedlots and other producers manage manure also ensures that cattle continue to produce methane long after they have gone to the great steakhouse in the sky.\n\nThe French researchers, from the Toulouse School of Economics, decided to take a look at a carbon tax on beef because the European Union has committed to cut its greenhouse gas emissions more than half by midcentury \u2014 and that includes agricultural emissions. The ambition is to keep global warming under 2 degrees Celsius, widely regarded as a tipping point at which cascading and potentially catastrophic effects of climate change could sweep across the planet. Their study found that a relatively steep tax, based on greenhouse gas emissions, would raise the retail price of beef by about 40 percent and cause a corresponding drop in consumption, much like the sugar tax on sodas and the tax on tobacco products.\n\nWouldn\u2019t it make more sense to put a carbon tax on fossil fuel, a larger source of greenhouse gas emissions? You bet. But many people who now commute in conventional gas-fueled automobiles have no better way to get home \u2014 or to heat their homes when they get there. That broader carbon tax will require dramatically restructuring our lives. A carbon tax on beef, on the other hand, would be a relatively simple test case for such taxes and, according to the French study, only a little painful, at least at the household level: While people would tend to skip the beef bourguignon, they could substitute other meats, like pork and chicken, that have a much smaller climate change footprint.\n\nThe tax would also reduce the substantial contribution of beef and dairy cattle to water pollution, deforestation, biodiversity loss and human mortality. (A 2012 Harvard School of Public Health study found that adding a single serving of unprocessed red meat per day increases the risk of death by 13 percent.) Those factors have already driven down beef consumption in the United States by 19 percent since 2005.", "title": "Opinion | The Case for a Carbon Tax on Beef", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "But talking about cats made Poole almost as excited as discussing his winning shot on Saturday. When told of Robinson\u2019s description of him, Poole smiled and recounted how he grew up with cats in his house, which his family had deemed the most sensible pet solution given all the time it spent traveling to his out-of-town basketball games while he was growing up.\n\n\u201cMy mom didn\u2019t want to get a dog,\u201d Poole said. \u201cPlus, she had hardwood floors and she didn\u2019t want the dogs on the hardwood floors. So we had cats.\u201d\n\nOne in particular was his favorite: a cat acquired when Poole was a young boy. The cat died during Poole\u2019s senior year in high school, but Poole grew animated on Saturday while discussing their years together.\n\n\u201cHis name was Bling,\u201d Poole said, pointing emphatically to a reporter\u2019s notebook. \u201cPut that in there.\u201d\n\nRecognizable around Ann Arbor for his cat shirts, those short shorts and his surplus of confidence, Poole now is familiar to fans in Michigan and beyond for his 3-point shot against Houston, which gave Michigan a 64-63 win in the round of 32. Among the reasons it might have been overlooked, though, was that it settled into the basket after midnight in the Eastern time zone, after many fans had gone to bed. But that did not stop the extroverted Poole from sharing his joy with anyone who asked him about it.", "title": "The Cat-Loving Michigan Star Who Slipped Through the Cracks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Much as the Spanish government would like to portray the case against Carles Puigdemont, the former leader of Catalonia, as purely a criminal matter, his arrest in Germany on Sunday on a Spanish warrant has pushed the bitter struggle over Catalan independence into a far broader and distinctly political arena.\n\nIn response to questions about the arrest, the Spanish government declared that it does not interfere with judicial decisions, and that the Supreme Court is seeking to put Mr. Puigdemont on trial not for his pro-independence ideas, but for rebellion and misappropriation of public funds (that his Catalan regional government used to organize a referendum on independence last October that Madrid ruled unconstitutional).\n\nThat is not the full story, however, as witnessed by the Catalan crowds that have taken to the streets upon news of Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s arrest. Madrid\u2019s relentless and heavy-handed response to the Catalan independence movement, starting with the riot police deployed to forcefully, and sometimes violently, disrupt the referendum last October and continuing with charges of rebellion (which in Spain means actual use of force and carries a penalty of up to 30 years in prison) against Mr. Puigdemont and 12 other leaders of the independence movement, is hardly the way to win the hearts and minds of the Catalans or the support of other Europeans.\n\nSo long as Mr. Puigdemont stayed in Belgium, where he took refuge after fleeing Spain, Madrid left him alone. But when he went on the road over the weekend, Spain issued an arrest warrant and tipped off German police, who arrested Mr. Puigdemont as he was driving through northern Germany.", "title": "Opinion | The Catalonia Dispute Ensnares Germany", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "With time, these original macrophages die and release their pigments, which get vacuumed up by new macrophages, starting the cycle over, said Sandrine Henri, a researcher at the Immunology Center of Marseille-Luminy who led the study with her colleague Bernard Malissen.\n\nThis research \u201cshows that tattoos are in fact much more dynamic than we previously had believed,\u201d said Johann Gudjonsson, a professor of immunology and dermatology at the University of Michigan who was not involved in the study.\n\nThe science behind your emblazoned anchor, sparrow or world map of places you\u2019ve traveled has never fully been nailed down. For years, researchers suspected that tattoos worked by permanently staining fibroblasts, the cells that synthesize collagen, under the surface of our skin.\n\nThen, looking at tattoo biopsies under the microscope, scientists saw macrophages laden with ink globules, and the story of tattoos became one of the immune system. Still, it was thought that tattoo-bearing macrophages were stable and long-lived, giving tattoos their permanence. What this study suggests is that, at least in mice, these macrophages are constantly being replaced.\n\nNeither Dr. Henri nor Dr. Malissen have tattoos, and the pair didn\u2019t set out to study them. They were examining skin cells in black mice for another project when they noticed macrophages scavenging the melanin released by dying, pigment-making cells. They wondered if the same process occurred in tattoos.", "title": "The Cells That Eat, Regurgitate and Eat Your Tattoos Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cLet me do some research, and I\u2019ll get back to you,\u201d my patient said.\n\nMy patient, a 19-year-old undergraduate, had already taken time off from school because of her anxiety. I was her psychiatrist, with over two decades of experience treating university students, and had just explained my diagnostic impressions based on a lengthy evaluation. I\u2019d recommended that she try a medicine I expected would help. I\u2019d also laid out the risks and benefits of other treatment options.\n\n\u201cDo you have additional questions I can answer?\u201d I asked. I wanted to let her know that\u2019s why I was there, to cull the research, to help make sense of it.\n\n\u201cNo, I like to go online and look for myself,\u201d she said.\n\nMore and more, I see students turning away from the expertise that a live person can offer and instead turning to the vast and somehow more objective-seeming \u201cexpertise\u201d of the digital world.\n\nIn an age when journalism we don\u2019t like can be dismissed as \u201cfake news,\u201d suggesting that the information we do like is most credible, regardless of its source, it\u2019s not hard to understand why young people do this. The medical profession itself, under managed care, has played a role as well, providing less time for doctor-patient interactions and undermining the chances that a personal relationship and trust can develop. Under the guise of efficiency, medical test results are now often released directly to patients, sometimes before or even without the benefit of any interpretation.", "title": "The Challenge of Doctor-Patient Relations in the Internet Age", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "The process she described was similar to what journalists normally do. \u201cIn oral history you never use one source only,\u201d she said. \u201cBecause people remember incorrectly, or don\u2019t want to remember, or they are in denial and they lie. All testimonies lie. So you try to understand why they omitted something, or why they emphasize something else.\u201d\n\nAn assistant district attorney once told me something similar: \u201cEverybody lies.\u201d\n\nCertainly, I thought to myself, it is easier to lie about the distant past, both consciously and unconsciously, because it is less checkable and because it has gone through so many filters in the interim.\n\nWell, not necessarily. Immediately after her death, Plath\u2019s family tried to hide that she had killed herself by turning on a gas oven and putting her head in it. What death notices there were omitted that. Her family put out the word that she had died of viral pneumonia. A blatant lie. Now, omitting her suicide would be impossible; it is public knowledge.\n\nAt the time of Plath\u2019s death, \u201cThe Bell Jar\u201d had not yet become a classic, beloved by every young woman who ever had a fight with her mother or wanted to be great at something or wrestled with losing her virginity. At the time of her death, Betty Friedan was eight days away from publishing \u201cThe Feminine Mystique,\u201d the bible of second-wave feminism, which subsequently made Plath one of its martyrs.\n\nVideo\n\nHer suicide opened her tempestuous marriage to scrutiny and drove some fans to deface her gravestone, erasing the married name she shared with her husband, the poet Ted Hughes. At the time she died, Plath\u2019s son, Nicholas Hughes, was only a year old, and her daughter, Frieda, about 3. No one could have predicted that Nicholas would hang himself at the age of 47. Now it felt right to make it part of her obituary.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fact is, Dr. Di Lellio told me, all this was relevant to the obituary I wrote because \u201cshe\u2019s not dead. Icons don\u2019t die. In 1963, she died. But why would you write an obituary 55 years later if she wasn\u2019t still somewhat relevant?\u201d\n\nDr. Di Lellio was in Kosovo as she spoke to me by phone, and she had just given a talk about a family that had been massacred because it fought back when surrounded by Serbian troops. The leader of the family is always referred to as if he were still alive, she said. Like Plath, he is a legend.\n\nBy becoming a household name even without the benefit of an obituary, Sylvia Plath had proven her worth more than many of the people we wrote obituaries about. Half a century later, how many of them still matter?", "title": "The Challenge of Writing Sylvia Plath\u2019s New York Times Obituary 55 Years After She Died", "authors": ["Anemona Hartocollis"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "What happens to American politics after Donald Trump? Do we snap back to normal or do things spin ever more widely out of control?\n\nThe best indicator we have so far is the example of Italy since the reign of Silvio Berlusconi. And the main lesson there is that once the norms of acceptable behavior are violated and once the institutions of government are weakened, it is very hard to re-establish them. Instead, you get this cycle of ever more extreme behavior, as politicians compete to be the most radical outsider. The political center collapses, the normal left/right political categories cease to apply and you see the rise of strange new political groups that are crazier than anything you could have imagined before.\n\nIf America follows the Italian example, by 2025 we\u2019ll look back at Trump nostalgically as some sort of beacon of relative normalcy. And by the way, if America follows the Italian example, Trump will never go away.\n\nSilvio Berlusconi first came to power for the same reasons Trump and other populists have been coming to power around the world: Voters were disgusted by a governing elite that seemed corrupt and out of touch. They felt swamped by waves of immigrants, frustrated by economic stagnation and disgusted by the cultural values of the cosmopolitan urbanites.", "title": "Opinion | The Chaos After Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "JOSEPH A. HIRSCH, NEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAs a former career civil servant of the federal government and a holder of a \u201ctop secret\u201d security clearance, I find it stomach-churning to read of the machinations of the president\u2019s son-in-law, the president himself and the various members of his administration. They treat their offices and their responsibilities to the voters cavalierly and deserve the scorn of ordinary people, and the hope that they get the comeuppance they deserve.\n\nWorking for the government in the early 1950s, I had to travel by train across the United States because air travel was too costly, and had to subsist on $9 a day for meals and lodging. I was chastised for complaining. Compare this with the indecencies of the cabinet members Scott Pruitt and Ryan Zinke and other members of the administration who don\u2019t hesitate to bilk our government.\n\nIf Robert Mueller would accelerate his investigation of the administration and bring some sense of justice, order and humility to all levels from President Trump on down, the country would cheer and be grateful.\n\nSIDNEY S. JACOBSON, CHESTER, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYou write, \u201cDonald J. Trump has thrived on chaos, using it as an organizing principle and even a management tool.\u201d This implies that Mr. Trump is consciously using this approach and makes him appear to be in control of his thoughts when the opposite is so evident. Mr. Trump thrives on chaos because at the core he is not defined by a set ideology; rather he is a self-serving opportunist who exploits situations.\n\nHe views all his relationships as transactional and temporary till he extracts what he needs and moves on. He is a shallow individual who never bothers to deeply analyze a situation; rather he is impulsive and reactive. He is mentally disorganized, thus the constant flip-flopping and chaotic behavior.", "title": "Opinion | The Chaos in the Trump Administration", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "A helicopter is an awkward contraption. There are huge competing G-forces pulling in different directions, and it seems almost a miracle it can fly. It takes no small amount of skill to fly one even without the overlay of ground fire, steep landing zones and various life-or-death emergencies. And these pilots in Vietnam were never pampered.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe got a horrifying example of that one afternoon as we lined up to board choppers coming in to take us to the next landing zone. We were spread out in what were called pickets of six men each. Five groups were in a line on the left separated by about 25 yards each. Five more were on the right as the choppers descended onto our positions. You could figure out quickly which bird was coming for you and it was easy to follow it right to the ground. In this case as my eyes followed our chopper, I noticed a short length of barbed-wire fence just a couple of feet off the ground.
