It seemed too low to make any difference but the chopper came in a little fast, causing the pilot to lift the nose and drop the tail just enough for the tail rotor to hit that wire. The next events happened so fast it\u2019s hard to imagine even now how we survived.\n\nAt the moment the tail rotor hit the strand of wire, the chopper flipped onto its left side. The main rotor was driven into the ground and splintered into a thousand pieces. It was just our good fortune to have been on the right side of the chopper or we probably would not have survived. We had dived onto the ground but we could still see the right side door gunner and the co-pilot climbing out just as the now crashed chopper burst into flames. The co-pilot must have known that was going to happen because he exited the wreckage with a fire extinguisher. But it wasn\u2019t to put out the fire. The fire was already beyond that. He sprayed it directly on the plexiglass windshield in front of the pilot who was struggling to get out. The cold spray of carbon dioxide shrank the hot plastic and the windshield literally popped out. He pulled the pilot to safety as the fire raged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe left-side door gunner never had a chance. He was pinned under the chopper right next to the fuel tank that was exploding into black smoke. By now we were all up and everyone thought to flip the burning chopper upright, but searing heat prevented us from getting near it. The gunner died very quickly.\n\nThe pilot was distraught beyond all description. Anyone would call this a tragic accident, but in his mind it was pilot error. In his mind his mistake had taken the life of one of his crew. There isn\u2019t much worse for a guy in his position.\n\nIt was a very bad scene. A smoldering chopper. A dead door gunner. Scared soldiers and this inconsolable pilot sitting on the ground wailing.\n\nA few minutes into this drama several new choppers arrived on the scene, one carrying a guy who was clearly the man in charge of this whole chopper squadron. He was all business. He walked straight over to the pilot and told him to get up off the ground. He never asked what happened. No arm around the shoulder. He just walked the crying pilot over to the helicopter he had just arrived in and ordered the pilot to get in and take the stick.\n\nThe scene drove things home to us. This was a war. If you are going to be an effective pilot in the future, there is no time for grieving now. It was the ultimate version of getting back on the bicycle. But that\u2019s how they did things. There was no time for sentiment.\n\nI met up not long ago with a former Vietnam chopper pilot who had been a few years ahead of me in our high school. He said it was the best job he ever had, despite all the dangers. He still missed it. As we talked I could tell that even now, 50 years later, he would happily get back in the cockpit. He still had that gritty commitment that reminded me of all the Vietnam pilots I had known. That\u2019s why we all trusted them with our lives.", "title": "The Chopper Pilots", "authors": ["Bill Lord"]} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAt Least 12 States Ready to Sue U.S. Over the Census\u201d (front page, March 28):\n\nBasic civil disobedience 101: Every resident of the United States \u2014 documented and undocumented alike \u2014 should refuse to answer any citizenship question on the census.\n\nThe addition of this question after decades can be nothing but a blatant effort by an administration hostile to undocumented (read: brown) residents to locate and deport them, and to rig congressional districts in favor of Republicans.\n\nAs with many impulsive and ham-handed decisions by this administration, it is simply a means to an end without consideration of collateral consequences.\n\nHere, populations (who are not going anywhere) will be undercounted and could lose funding for trivial things like education, health care and basic civic services as well as their fair and proportionate political representation.", "title": "Opinion | The Citizenship Question on the Census", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Without asking or telling me, the city planted new trees on my block, including one in front of my three-family house in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. We don\u2019t need or want this albatross \u2014 there are thousands of perfectly good trees right across the street in Prospect Park. I want the tree removed and the sidewalk restored at the city\u2019s expense because I am concerned about cracked concrete, leaves falling in the autumn, rats, and dog and bird droppings. I also do not want to lose our northern light, or any property value because a tree would eventually block our park view. What are my options?\n\nA. The area between the curb and your property line belongs to the city, not you. So, if the city wants to a plant tree there, it may do so.\n\nYou are not going to have much luck persuading the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation to uproot the sapling, since the city has invested heavily in planting trees on the streets to \u201cmake the city more livable, improve the environment, and enhance public health,\u201d Maeri Ferguson, a Parks Department spokeswoman, said in an email.\n\nParks Department arborists survey the city to determine where to place trees, and New Yorkers can also request new plantings. In your case, requests had been made for three of the five trees that were planted, according to Ms. Ferguson. So, although you may see the new trees as a nuisance, some of your neighbors may not.", "title": "The City Plants a Tree, but I Don\u2019t Want It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "As pranks go, the case of the missing sport coat is a doozy.\n\nIt has it all: a crime but no conviction, video evidence but no definitive proof, damage inflicted and reparations paid. Its main characters include a former N.B.A. guard, a Final Four-bound coach and a mysterious accomplice (and perhaps a few more).\n\nAnd 15 years later, Porter Moser still swears he had nothing to do with it.\n\n\u201cThat is amazing,\u201d Moser said playfully when asked about the incident Thursday. \u201cThe higher platform you go, the more your closet of things that happen, they\u2019re going to dig up. Wow. You get the award.\u201d\n\nSo many warm, delightful stories have been told about plucky little Loyola-Chicago and its 98-year-old team chaplain, Sister Jean Dolores Schmidt. But the old yarn about its current coach might make Sister Jean blush.\n\nIt all began in 2002, when Moser was the second-year coach at the University of Arkansas-Little Rock and engaged in an overheated rivalry with Monte Towe, the former N.B.A. guard then coaching the University of New Orleans. During a tight game at New Orleans\u2019s Lakefront Arena, Moser and Towe started jawing at each other and, according to Towe, Moser used profane language.", "title": "The Coach, the Rivalry and the Stolen Blazer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "The Tenderloin was \u201cthe city\u2019s go-zone for crack, meth, prostitution, petty crime and public defecation,\u201d Eggers writes, the \u201cillegal-activity containment zone.\u201d But it was also one of the city\u2019s most affordable neighborhoods, where newly arrived families from Asia and the Middle East settled to start a new life.\n\nIn his youth Mokhtar wandered the streets without clear purpose. He became accustomed to the sight of hustlers and junkies and the stench of human feces, urine and weed. In local playgrounds children as young as 13 smoked pot. Mokhtar found it hard to avoid trouble and became \u201ca fast learner, a fast talker, a corner cutter.\u201d His adventures included trips to the city\u2019s wealthiest neighborhoods, where he and his friends dropped their trousers to moon the residents. Aimless and without ambition, he did not appear destined for much.\n\nBut there was another side to Mokhtar \u2014 the autodidact who loved to read and who crammed all the books he had found or stolen onto a shelf in the kitchen pantry: the Goosebumps novels, \u201cThe Lord of the Rings,\u201d and especially the Harry Potter books. When Mokhtar daydreamed, \u201chis mind drifted and allowed the possibility that maybe he was, like Harry, part of this hardscrabble world for now, but destined for something more.\u201d\n\nBy the time Mokhtar was in eighth grade, his parents worried he was going astray and decided he should spend time with his wealthy grandfather in Yemen. Maybe the change of location and immersion in history would do him good.\n\nPhoto\n\nMokhtar spoke some Arabic, but a street-smart American kid from the Tenderloin was predictably out of place in rural Yemen. Unfamiliar with local customs, he didn\u2019t know how to dress, speak, eat or walk like a proper Yemeni.\n\nThis is where you expect the story to take a familiar turn: A smart Muslim kid from a rough neighborhood in the West, sent back to the motherland in an attempt to strengthen his roots, instead becomes disillusioned and lost between two identities before he finds solace and purpose in religious fundamentalism and jihad. Right?\n\nWell, no.\n\nUnder the tutelage of his businessman grandfather, who brings him to meetings and on work trips, the adolescent Mokhtar is converted instead to the religion of capitalism. Back in America he takes a high school job at Banana Republic and starts dressing in sweater vests. His friends began calling him Rupert after the dapper comic-strip bear.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis book is about Mokhtar\u2019s journey from the Tenderloin to the mountains of Yemen in pursuit of a dream. It is also about his personal journey, as he learns to navigate two identities and begins to find his true self.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike Mokhtar himself, however, the book loses focus for long stretches, following him from job to job in arduous pages that go nowhere until Mokhtar, working as a doorman at a luxury building, sees a 20-foot-tall statue of a Yemeni man drinking from a giant coffee cup. He learns about the beverage\u2019s origins \u2014 \u201cYemenis basically invented coffee. You didn\u2019t know this?\u201d his mother tells him \u2014 and feels at last that he has a mission. Finally we get a jolt of excitement and the book starts to flow.\n\nEggers traces the often contested history of coffee, from the Ethiopian shepherd who noticed that his goats were jumping and prancing after eating the fruit of a nearby tree, to Ali Ibn Omar al-Shadhili, a Sufi man living in Mokha who first brewed the drink we know today. Later Eggers tells us about the rogue adventurers who stole coffee and spread it to the rest of the world: Indonesia, Latin America, Africa.\n\nMokhtar imagines himself one of those adventurers, aiming first to revive Yemen\u2019s 500-year-old coffee culture and then to export its high-quality arabica beans. By persuading distributors to pay a premium, he hopes to convince farmers their future is in coffee rather than khat, a shrub grown for its highly addictive chewable leaves.\n\nSimple, right? Yet there are drawbacks. For one, coffee cultivation has almost disappeared in Yemen. For another, Mokhtar knows practically nothing about coffee. He came to the crop not because he loved it \u2014 he\u2019d drunk only a few dozen cups his entire life \u2014 but because Yemen\u2019s historical role in its cultivation and dissemination appealed to him so much.\n\nLet\u2019s be clear: In Yemen, any project \u2014 even one much smaller than resurrecting an ancient trade \u2014 is a serious challenge at the best of times. Access to international markets is difficult, bank loans are nonexistent, and trips outside Sanaa can require hours of haggling with petty bureaucrats and local tribes. Security risks include bandits, feuding tribesmen and jihadis. Throw in an unfolding political crisis, militias taking over the capital, the collapse of the state and a subsequent civil war, and Mokhtar\u2019s mission seems purely impossible. Still, in Eggers\u2019s telling Mokhtar is no ordinary man, and he has more than ordinary luck. Friends offer emotional and financial support; Yemeni farmers treat him as a guest even if they don\u2019t expect to see him again.\n\nEggers describes Yemen, with some justification, as the world\u2019s most misunderstood country. Yet he seems mostly uninterested in closing that gap, serving up clich\u00e9s that only exacerbate the problem. His portrait of Yemen is a cheap cup of instant coffee. Then again, this is less a book about Yemen than the old-fashioned American dream. As Mokhtar makes his way through mountains and villages collecting samples of coffee beans, he grows more and more capable. No longer an ignorant American who can\u2019t distinguish between an olive tree and a coffee tree, he becomes an enthusiastic expert who can capture the attention of a roomful of skeptical farmers with a passionate speech \u2014 admittedly fueled by khat \u2014 about the glories of Yemeni coffee. No longer a dreamer, he is a visionary businessman and leader.\n\nIn an age marked by entrenched identities, nationalism and ideological purity, Mokhtar emerges as a confident member of two cultures, both Yemeni and American. He is a reminder, as Eggers says, that America is \u201ca blended people united not by stasis and cowardice and fear, but by irrational exuberance and global enterprise on a human scale \u2026 driven by courage unfettered and unyielding.\u201d If he seems more symbolic than complicated or deep, well, isn\u2019t that American too?", "title": "The Coffee-Flavored American Dream", "authors": ["Ghaith Abdul-Ahad", "Dave Eggers"]} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "We ate beans simmered, sprouted and fermented \u2014 fava, mung, black gram, pigeon pea, cannellini \u2014 whatever the variety might call for. My favorite, when I was a kid, was a dish of red beans and rice cooked simply with crushed tomatoes and a mash of ginger, garlic and green chiles, with a glug of cream added somewhere near the far end of cooking and a pile of chopped cilantro on top. I remember being patient, intensely focused in a way that I\u2019m incapable of now, eating the red beans one at a time as if they were individually wrapped candies, not caring how long it took and driving my family mad. When we moved, we took the pantry with us \u2014 dried beans are lightweight, they travel well and they form the ideal starter kit for a home-cooked meal in a new kitchen, in a new town. A few tall plastic containers of colorful beans and lentils were the first things to brighten our empty shelves, place holders until we could get to a supermarket.\n\nLegumes were domesticated some 10,000 years ago, and thousands of varieties of beans and lentils have grown all over the world since. Old recipes, particularly for lentils and fava beans, have been well documented, though when I consulted used-book stores in New York, it seemed as if the golden age for bean-themed cookbooks was the 1990s, which gave us \u201cFabulous Beans,\u201d \u201cFull of Beans\u201d and \u201cRomancing the Bean,\u201d to name just a few. I was 17 the first time I bought dried white beans. I\u2019d left home and was learning to cook for myself, captivated by a description of someone eating creamy beans in hot broth, with a big spoon in one hand and a piece of chewy, buttered bread in the other. Beans are cheap, and it sounded easy enough, but I waited so many hours for those beans to soften that I lost interest. They were old, or they had been stored badly, and some had developed tough skins like tiny raincoats, making them nearly impenetrable. It was bad luck, and in the end I ordered a pizza. It hadn\u2019t occurred to me that stocking your pantry in a new place could be such a crapshoot. That traveling with your own beans wasn\u2019t only a matter of thrift but also one of security.", "title": "The Comfort in Stockpiling Dried Beans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cOn Drug Pricing, States Step In Where Washington Fails\u201d (Opinion, nytimes.com, Feb. 27) praised a handful of recycled state legislative efforts purportedly aimed at reducing prescription drug prices that, while they make good political talking points, fail to address the challenges patients face when they visit their local pharmacies.\n\nRecent data show that medicine costs are growing at the slowest rate in years, yet patients are being forced to pay more and more of their prescription medicine costs out of pocket.\n\nWhile biopharmaceutical manufacturers provide large rebates and discounts to middlemen and insurers, those savings often don\u2019t make it to the patient at the pharmacy counter. Insurers use mechanisms like high deductibles and coinsurance to shift the cost burden onto patients.\n\nAs a result, these little-known middlemen continue to make growing profits at the expense of patients.", "title": "Opinion | The Cost of Drugs to Patients", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "Season 2 had already finished shooting when #MeToo exploded, but these 13 new episodes venture even deeper into that toxic territory. While Jessica tries to tamp down the trauma of her past and get on with her work as a hard-boiled detective, her foster sister, Trish (Rachael Taylor), moves in the opposite direction, confronting an older male producer who exploited her when she was a teenage performer.\n\n\u201cWe were writing the second season during the whole Trump/Hillary election, and I was just so angry,\u201d Ms. Rosenberg said of her team of writers. \u201cWe constantly talked about characters that had been trying to be nice for so long, finally just saying, \u2018Get out of my way!\u2019 Just tapping into the rage Hillary must have felt every day.\u201d\n\nAlthough \u201cJessica Jones\u201d springs from the Marvel comic \u201cAlias,\u201d the TV version of Jessica is more self-destructive and nihilistic. Ms. Rosenberg also tweaked the original story line by adding sexual assault to the litany of horrors committed by Season 1\u2019s villain, Kilgrave, whose specter hangs over the new episodes.\n\nMs. Rosenberg, 55, said the show\u2019s approach was partly inspired by her own troubling encounters with men as a girl growing up in a permissive Marin County household.\n\nThe upside of having hippie parents (her psychologist father Jack Lee Rosenberg wrote the 1973 book \u201cTotal Orgasm\u201d) was the freedom to \u201ccreate your own reality.\u201d This resulted in impromptu dance performances and neighborhood plays; she would go on to major in dance and theater at Bennington.", "title": "The Creator of \u2018Jessica Jones\u2019 Serves Up a Dark Mirror for Our Moment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cCuomo Weighs State of Emergency for New York City Public Housing\u201d (news article, March 13):\n\nCity Hall and Albany are both at fault for the New York City Housing Authority\u2019s decrepit condition. Years of neglect and divestment have New York State on the verge of declaring the agency in a state of emergency. But this is a wrongheaded solution to the problem.\n\nTo stop public housing residents\u2019 suffering, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio must simply invest more money. Independent monitors, blue-ribbon commissions, design-build legislation and emergency declarations will not amount to much if the agency\u2019s budget remains flat.\n\nWhile the governor and the mayor duke it out with competing press statements and over social media, let\u2019s not forget that people\u2019s well-being remains in the balance. Both men need to put their egos aside and prioritize the agency\u2019s improvement with real dollars.\n\nThis is a watershed and transcendent moment that calls into question both governments\u2019 ability to cooperate and to address one of the most pressing local public problems of our time.", "title": "Opinion | The Crisis in New York City Public Housing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt takes determination to leave the comforts of a warm home for a woodland walk on one of spring\u2019s first wet nights. Temperatures hover within a degree or two of freezing, and in the inky blackness, a flashlight illuminates nothing but naked branches and thawing pools of jet black water. But in early March, the first calls of the wood frog are like the creaking sounds of an enormous, primitive machine awakening. These ancient voices make my skin crawl and my heart quicken, but these same sounds may have inspired relief in our ancestors; despite the bleak nights, winter was finally at its end.\n\nWood frogs are hardly songsters. Their nasal croaks are best described as resonant, or memorable. They provide a counterpoint to the bell-like clarity of the chorus of spring peepers, which inevitably accompany them. The soft whinnying of screech owls, even the somber hoots of great horned owls, are often a part of this primitive performance. There are few occasions when the elemental vitality of spring is as nakedly exposed.\n\nMeasuring about 3 inches long, and weighing a quarter of an ounce, wood frogs (Lithobates sylvaticus) are woodland wanderers, often traveling long distances between vernal pools. For frogs, they are surprisingly independent of water most of the year, but they are not at all toad-like. Wood frogs have the smooth, thin skin of true frogs, and possess the same long legs. Later in summer, when these frogs are silent, their long leaps are often the only sign they\u2019re present.\n\nPerhaps the wood frog\u2019s most iconic feature is its dark, raccoon-like mask. It is the only masked frog in the Northeast, and though its cowl is almost a clich\u00e9 for roaming the city\u2019s dark corners, it must be one of the least intimidating creatures in the forest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe wood frog often makes a three- or four-foot leap to escape disturbance. I have often chased these jumpers, only to find they were not where they seemed to land. If you\u2019re fast enough, you\u2019ll observe the trick behind the frog\u2019s hop. Often, just after landing, the animal shuffles under the nearby leaf litter and freezes. If you\u2019re patient, a leaf or two rustles and you find your frog \u2014 but this hide-and-seek technique is about as close to a magician\u2019s trick as you\u2019ll find in our local woods.\n\nDuring the winter, an icy wood frog is no magic act; the wood frog\u2019s ability to survive with up to 65 percent of its body frozen may have very real biological implications for humans. The animal lies dormant under the leaf litter, not breathing and without a pulse, through the coldest months of the winter. The frogs resume their lives as the local pools thaw in March, not just uninjured, but eager to mate.", "title": "The Croaky Sounds of Spring", "authors": ["Dave Taft"]} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 In a windowless room in the Second Arrondissement of Paris, about 40 riders were clipped in and warming up, pedaling round and round, waiting for her to enter. When she did, she was wearing all black so that when she climbed onto her bike and stood tall on the pedals, she looked like a blond panther ready to pounce.\n\nThe class followed suit despite her not uttering a word. That\u2019s because they all know Clotilde Chaumet, the 27-year-old spinning coach whose 45-minute classes book up as soon as they\u2019re made available, a week in advance.\n\nSpinning isn\u2019t totally new to Paris, but it just reached a pivotal moment: One of the city\u2019s first studios, Dynamo, which opened in 2015 and was modeled on SoulCycle, was recently bought by its competitor, Let\u2019s Ride, which opened a year later. Clo, as Ms. Chaumet is known, is one of Dynamo\u2019s original master coaches, with devotees at every class and her own brand of yoga.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s mastered this technique of creating a journey,\u201d said St\u00e9phanie Nieman, one of the three founders of Let\u2019s Ride. \u201cShe takes you in and plunges you into a new universe. Whenever the music changes, she knows where to take you and you don\u2019t even realize it\u2019s happening.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Chaumet, who revises her hip-hop-heavy playlist for each of her 13 weekly spin classes, spends less time on the bike and more time moving around the candlelit room, yelling out cues with the rhythm of a rapper: \u201cGauche, gauche, gauche, gauche. Droite, droite, droite, droite,\u201d she will say, instructing her students to go left or right.", "title": "The Cycling Panther of Paris\u2019s Fitness Studios", "authors": ["Sara Lieberman"]} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "NASHVILLE \u2014 The woods are waking up. The stolid hardwood trees are still mostly bare, but the forest understory is already greening and greening and greening. Dormant ground cover is greening up through moldering leaf litter, and tiny green shoots are opening at the tips of saplings and woody shrubs.\n\nOn Presidents\u2019 Day, the high in Nashville was 76 degrees; the next day it hit 80. This, we all assured one another, was nothing more than our annual false spring, an idyll of sunny skies and temperate breezes that briefly gives us all heart before winter crashes back and turns the saucer magnolia\u2019s pink blossoms into a brown smudge against the cold blue sky.\n\nI woke up early that February day because a cardinal was singing \u201cBirdy-birdy-birdy-birdy\u201d so loudly there was no sleeping in, even on a national holiday. Birds rarely sing in winter. Partly that\u2019s because they don\u2019t need to \u2014 they sing primarily to find a mate and defend nesting territory \u2014 and partly it\u2019s because singing burns precious calories. In winter, food is hard to come by just when it takes enormous energy to keep warm.\n\nBut our resident cardinal didn\u2019t know it was only Feb. 19. He sat outside our bedroom window at dawn, singing his heart out. \u201cBirdy-birdy-birdy-birdy! Birdy-birdy-birdy-birdy!\u201d Thanks to his exuberance, I was up early enough to find a parking place at the edge of a little lake I like to walk around \u2014 a little lake the rest of Nashville likes to walk around in fine weather, too \u2014 and that\u2019s how I noticed the woods were already waking up.", "title": "Opinion | The Dark Warning of an Early Spring", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "This much is certain: On Oct. 14, 1981, a teenager armed with a .22 rifle went to the fifth floor of a building in Dunedin, New Zealand, during a visit by Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip.\n\nWhen the royals stepped out of their Rolls-Royce to greet thousands of well-wishers on the street, the gunman, Christopher John Lewis, 17, a self-described terrorist who was hiding in a deserted toilet cubicle, trained his rifle on the queen and fired.\n\nHe missed.\n\nThe Guardian said \u201cit may be the closest anyone has ever come to assassinating Queen Elizabeth II.\u201d Decades later, questions about whether the New Zealand police and government had covered up the seriousness of the crime still linger.\n\nThe New Zealand police announced this past week that they would re-examine the case because of the public interest. In an email, a police spokesman said that Commissioner Mike Bush had assigned a deputy commissioner, Mike Clement, to oversee the inquiry:\n\n\u201cGiven the passage of time, it is anticipated this examination of the old file and its associated material will take some time. NZ Police will share the outcome of this examination once it has been completed,\u201d the statement said.", "title": "The Day the Queen Was Almost Shot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Our frustration gave way to an idea: If the authorities were going to let criminals walk the streets, we would turn the streets into a prison. In 1995, the children of people disappeared, murdered, exiled and imprisoned for political reasons founded the Sons and Daughters for Identity and Justice, Against Forgetting and Silence, or Hijos. We would find out the home addresses of these mass murderers, photograph them, then walk through their neighborhoods in a peaceful protest. The idea was to alert the neighborhood: \u201cWatch out, there\u2019s a murderer living here.\u201d We called it \u201cescrache,\u201d which means \u201cexposure.\u201d It was our way of fighting impunity.\n\nWe didn\u2019t have to investigate anything about Mr. Men\u00e9ndez, because we all knew where he lived. Calle Ilolay, 3269, in C\u00f3rdoba. A one-story house, with white walls and a tile roof. He entered and exited at his leisure, attended official events and traveled around the city without protection, just as he had that afternoon in front of my friend\u2019s house. None of us, however, the tens of thousands of families whose relatives had been disappeared, chose the path of violence.\n\nIn 2013 I saw Mr. Men\u00e9ndez again: in a courtroom, during a trial \u2014 the La Perla \u201cmega-trial,\u201d with 52 defendants and 716 victims. I was witness No. 167. When the judge called me to the stand, I stood there facing Mr. Men\u00e9ndez. His hair, totally gray, was slick with gel, and his eyebrows were still black. What once had been large under-eye circles were now large bags of hanging skin. His eyes were glassy with an icy, pitiless stare.\n\nI testified on behalf of my family, those who were living and those who had died along the way. We, the survivors of a bloody dictatorship, were the ones who pushed the government to prosecute the murderers with the legal guarantees that they had denied our dead.\n\n\u201cLots of people will be happy if I die,\u201d Mr. Men\u00e9ndez once said in an interview. But he was wrong. We do not forgive him, nor do we cry for him, but we are not happy, either. We don\u2019t celebrate death. When he died he left cloaked in cowardly silence, never revealing where he hid the remains of our loved ones. His family, however, was able to bury him because he died in a very different Argentina from the one he terrorized. He died in a country that was more just, which was what our parents had wanted.\n\nMr. Men\u00e9ndez went to his grave with more life sentences than anyone else in the history of Argentina. And though there are days when I feel that no conviction will ever be enough, the day that he died I felt proud, because I was able to say to my 7-year-old son that his grandparents\u2019 murderer died a convicted man, that the struggle is worth it, that justice is something that can be built.", "title": "Opinion | The Death of a Genocide", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Pentagon officials argued that the Joint Chiefs of Staff regarded the introduction of the Honest John and Davy Crockett systems as \u201cessential from a military viewpoint.\u201d In turn they suggested that the North, by obtaining new artillery weapons and high performance aircraft, had violated the agreement and freed the United States \u201cto disregard its restrictions.\u201d\n\nAccording to notes from a National Security Council meeting on June 13, 1957, Adm. Arthur Radford, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, indicated that military planning for South Korea could not continue \u201cwithout being able to count on the use of nuclear weapons.\u201d Eisenhower agreed that jets capable of carrying nuclear weapons should be introduced into the South. But he also noted that if the United States introduced nuclear-capable Honest John rocket systems and 280-millimeter guns to the South, they would be \u201cso conspicuous that you would have to explain their introduction to the whole world.\u201d\n\nOn June 21, 1957, the senior official on the United Nations Command of the Military Armistice Commission, Maj. Gen. Homer L. Litzenberg, indicated that, given the North Koreans\u2019 alleged violations, the command would no longer consider itself bound by certain limitations in the armistice agreement. The North Korean representative at the commission described General Litzenberg\u2019s statement as an attempt \u201cto wreck the armistice agreement and turn South Korea into an American base of atomic warfare.\u201d\n\nThat day, the abrogation of the weapons prohibition was announced by the United Nations Command. The New York Times reported from Panmunjom, North Korea, that during a United Nations meeting, General Litzenberg had \u201cleft the door open for the introduction in South Korea of weapons capable of firing atomic warheads.\u201d General Litzenberg declined to say what type of weapons the organizations planned to bring in.\n\nHowever, that same day in Washington, the assistant secretary of defense for public affairs, Murray Snyder, told Pentagon reporters that no ground weapons capable of firing atomic warheads would be introduced. That turned out to be untrue.\n\nAt an Aug. 8, 1957, National Security Council meeting, Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said, according to meeting notes, that ending the Korea arms prohibitions \u201chad been pretty well received throughout the Free World.\u201d Secretary of Defense Charles Erwin Wilson said the plan to put nuclear weapons in South Korea, if adopted, \u201cwould be able to bring home approximately 8,000 American military personnel and we could cut out four active South Korean divisions, which would save us approximately $125 million a year.\u201d\n\nIt took months to negotiate reduction of four South Korean divisions with Syngman Rhee, the South Korean president. But on Dec. 24, 1957, Army Secretary Wilber Brucker was authorized to introduce into Korea the Honest John and 280-millimeter gun \u201cas soon as is feasible under Army deployment schedules.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Dirty Secret of American Nuclear Arms in Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cThe Pain of Loving Old Dogs,\u201d by Margaret Renkl (Op-Ed, Feb. 26), was a lovely read that expressed so well the love, joy, chaos and eventually grief that a dog (or a cat) can bring into one\u2019s life.\n\nOver the years I have had many dogs, whose photos (not the grandchildren\u2019s, as my children have pointed out) grace the refrigerator door. I now have a squirrel-chasing beagle-shepherd mix and a young field spaniel, a breed known for sweetness, loyalty and food-thievery, much like Ms. Renkl\u2019s dog Emma.\n\nI am 88 years old and in fairly good health but still worry about who will care for my dogs if they outlive me. My children, all dog owners, have promised that they will be well cared for!\n\nJOAN BERGLUND, ORIENT, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMargaret Renkl\u2019s article really hit home. Our 13-year-old dog, Lucy, recently died. I didn\u2019t fully appreciate that dogs age so rapidly until I watched Lucy\u2019s decline.", "title": "Opinion | The Dog in My Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "If, like me, you find the full-tilt art fairs a little overwhelming, the formally ambitious but modestly scaled Independent is a godsend. With just 54 exhibits, many of them solo presentations, arranged over four spacious floors at Spring Studios in TriBeCa, it\u2019s like a leisurely all-star game: It\u2019s not exactly representative of the year in art, perhaps, but it feels as if it ought to be.\n\nBlack and white is in vogue, from the fair co-founder Elizabeth Dee\u2019s presentation of Carl Ostendarp\u2019s cheerful paintings of the existential void (fifth floor, Booth 22) to Canada gallery\u2019s extraordinary onslaught of inky drawings and ceramics by Elisabeth Kley (sixth floor, 20). A London dealer, The Sunday Painter, is making its fair debut with Cynthia Daignault\u2019s attempt to capture the American century in a series of small, gray-tone oils (first floor, 5).\n\nBut explosive color is in evidence, too, from exuberant drawings and paintings by Derrick Alexis Coard and Gerasimos Floratos at White Columns (seventh floor, 1) to Clearing\u2019s show of vivid abstractions painted on small plywood handball courts by Harold Ancart (sixth floor, 10). And outsider art is well represented, with highlights including Leopold Strobl\u2019s colored-pencil drawings of pretty landscapes interrupted by ominous mountains of shadow, at Ricco/Maresca, and Kerry Schuss\u2019s show of wild sunlit scenes by Aaron Birnbaum (fifth floor, 8).", "title": "The Don\u2019t-Misses at Independent and NADA", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nETERNAL LIFE\n\nBy Dara Horn\n\n233 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $25.95.\n\nClassical mythology brings us the tale of the Sibyl of Cumae, a prophetess who bargains with Apollo for endless life, and centuries later comes to yearn for death. She failed to negotiate for eternal youth, you see, and with the years she grows shrunken and decrepit and miserable. The story echoes a sentiment that endures in contemporary life: However much time kale, yoga, spa weekends and wonder drugs may buy us, we accept that at some point we\u2019ll become so enfeebled that we\u2019ll be ready to pack it in, once and for all.\n\nBut what if rolled into endless life were endless youth, and we kept looking and feeling our best, century after century? Would we still, like the Cumaean Sibyl, wish to die? Yup. This is the answer provided by the hero of Dara Horn\u2019s captivating new novel, \u201cEternal Life.\u201d When we meet Rachel, she\u2019s a suburban great-grandmother, recently widowed, with a ne\u2019er-do-well adult son living in the basement. What her family doesn\u2019t know is that she\u2019s 2,000 some-odd years old. And while she may look like a senior citizen now, anytime Rachel burns to death (happens more than you\u2019d think over the course of millenniums), she wakes up in her 18-year-old body, physically equipped to begin life all over again.\n\nBut every new \u201cversion,\u201d as Rachel calls her countless iterations of work, family and home, brings another cycle of grief and loss. The loved ones who surround her in the 21st century mostly remind her of the scores of loved ones who\u2019ve died. For Rachel, the present is coated in thick layers of the past. And her relationships, particularly with her children, have taken on a numbing predictability. As Horn writes, \u201cAt one point she tried to estimate how many thousands of times she had nursed an infant, how many meals she had cooked for others, how many spoons of medicine she had raised to other people\u2019s lips, how many withered hands she had held at bedsides, how many bodies she had buried in the earth.\u201d Rachel\u2019s perspective as a fixed point among ordinary mortals heading from cradle to grave makes her feel isolated, detached \u2014 not fully alive, despite (or really because of) her immortality.\n\nSo Rachel is eager to die. Her problem is she can\u2019t. And she\u2019s given it her best shot: attempted suicide in numerous forms, sought the counsel over the centuries of everyone from ancient holy men to cognitive behavioral therapists.\n\nThe origins of Rachel\u2019s predicament date back to the days of the Roman occupation of Jerusalem, a world Horn recreates with a deft and convincing touch. As a teenager, Rachel falls in love with Elazar, rakish son of the high priest. As their illicit romance twists and turns, the lovers end up making a vow at the Temple, the consequences of which \u2014 eternal life for both of them \u2014 only become clear decades later. As is often the case in Horn\u2019s fiction, Jewish history and the lives of her fictional characters wrap around one another, as Rachel\u2019s realization of her inescapable immortality coincides with a brilliant and brutal depiction of the destruction of the ancient Temple, one of the novel\u2019s high points.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the centuries roll along, Elazar keeps popping up in Rachel\u2019s life. While she has good reason to hate him for a betrayal that had fatal consequences, she can\u2019t forsake him, either. It\u2019s not just that he\u2019s the only other person on earth who knows what it\u2019s like to live forever. Rachel\u2019s undying love for Elazar helps her at least understand why life is something to which everyone else around her is clinging to so fiercely.\n\n\u201cThe hard part isn\u2019t living forever,\u201d Rachel observes. \u201cIt\u2019s making life worth living.\u201d And the question at the heart of this wise and appealing novel is finally not how Rachel finds meaning in her eternal life. It is how we, despite our portions of sorrow, tedium and disaster, persist in finding meaning in ours.", "title": "The Downside of Immortality", "authors": ["Joshua Max Feldman", "Dara Horn"]} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe knew what the suspect was capable of,\u201d Mr. Filla said.\n\nThe story of how law enforcement agents were finally able to stop the bomber\u2019s deadly attacks emerged Friday, as the police continued to review evidence recovered at the suspect\u2019s home in nearby Pflugerville, Tex., and began to release details of an operation that ended in a fatal confrontation near the hotel in Round Rock. The work of the marshals was but one part of an extraordinary puzzle that made up the last 24 hours of the serial-bomber investigation.\n\nIn the predawn hours of Wednesday, emotions were on edge among the dozens of officers lying in wait. Some had hardly slept in days. Like other residents of this fast-growing city, they had grown apprehensive about going near anything resembling a package. Pressure to catch Mr. Conditt was growing intense.\n\nWas he inside the hotel? Mr. Filla wondered.\n\nAgents checked with the hotel management, who confirmed that Mr. Conditt was not checked in as a guest. They kept their eyes trained on the Nissan in the parking lot. Then an officer peering through binoculars glimpsed exhaust coming out of the tailpipe.\n\nThe headlights were off. But the vehicle started to move out of the lot.\n\nA Slip-Up Accelerates the Case\n\nThe authorities knew Mr. Conditt would send or place another homemade bomb \u2014 the question was when, not if. A series of leads had brought investigators to him, including surveillance footage inside and near a FedEx store where he had shipped two packages loaded with explosives. Starting with the license plate from a different truck he drove, agents were able to track his cellphone number and the construction gloves he had worn while shipping the bombs.\n\nThe clues all came together to where Mr. Conditt was on Wednesday morning, in the darkened parking lot off Interstate 35.\n\nThe showdown started with an apparent mistake.\n\nAt one minute past 4 p.m. on Tuesday, paramedics were notified about an \u201cunknown medical alarm\u201d at Mr. Conditt\u2019s home in Pflugerville. Two paramedics from the Pflugerville Fire Department responded. A person inside the home \u2014 it was unclear whom \u2014 answered the door and told the medics no one there had called 911. The paramedics cleared out at 4:11 p.m.\n\nFrom an incident report released Friday by the Pflugerville Fire Department, it now appears that a request by investigators for paramedics to remain near the house was relayed instead as a call for immediate medical aid to the residence. It is possible that Mr. Conditt himself had come to the door or was home at the time, and began to suspect that the authorities were closing in.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFinding paramedics at his door could have been the reason Mr. Conditt drove to Round Rock and appeared to be taking steps that signaled he knew the police were on his trail. At some point in the hours to come, he left a roughly 25-minute recording on his phone that officials described as a confession. Law enforcement officials said the miscommunication involving the paramedics was under review.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClosing In\n\nOn Tuesday night, investigators were still sorting through a multitude of tips and blind alleys.\n\nThe local, state and federal agents hunting the bomber wondered if he had struck again. About an hour after the paramedics had left Mr. Conditt\u2019s residence in Pflugerville, the team of investigators had converged on a Goodwill store in south Austin shortly after 5 p.m. in response to a report of an explosion. That incident ended up being unrelated: Military-style ordnance that someone had donated had ignited and injured a worker. It took attention away from Mr. Conditt.\n\nBut not for long. Later that evening, the police closed Main Street in Pflugerville.\n\nIt was not until later that they traced his vehicle to the Courtyard by Marriott in nearby Round Rock. When Mr. Conditt pulled his Pathfinder out of the parking lot, a stream of vehicles slowly followed. Mr. Filla, the deputy marshal, described it as the opposite of a high-speed chase. Agents, he said, were hoping to capture Mr. Conditt alive and avoid any harm to themselves.\n\nUsing what he described as a \u201ctactical vehicle maneuver,\u201d the SWAT team managed to cautiously push Mr. Conditt\u2019s vehicle onto the edge of a service road just off Interstate 35. Officers approached the vehicle, but were stunned by an explosion triggered by Mr. Conditt as they moved in.\n\n\u201cBomb, bomb, bomb!\u201d some in the vicinity yelled. At one point, one of the officers fired his weapon; another was thrown back by the blast and injured.\n\nOther officers quickly tried backing up their vehicles but found they couldn\u2019t go very far since so many official cars \u2014 from the marshals to local police departments, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and the F.B.I. \u2014 had arrived at the site.\n\n\u201cIt resembled a law enforcement funeral procession,\u201d Mr. Filla said. \u201cThat\u2019s how many of us were there.\u201d\n\nHours after it was all over on Wednesday, the Austin police chief, Brian Manley, told reporters assembled nearby that the bomber was dead, although he declined to identify Mr. Conditt at the time.\n\n\u201cLate last night and early this morning, we felt very confident that this was the suspect in the bombing incidents that took place in Austin,\u201d Chief Manley said.\n\n\u201cThe suspect,\u201d he said, \u201cis deceased.", "title": "The Dramatic Last Hours as Agents Stalked the Austin Bomber", "authors": ["Simon Romero", "Manny Fernandez"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "I have been alcohol free for six months after years of overuse. I feel great but still struggle. I was never a sloppy drunk and may have been too successful in hiding how much I drank from family and friends. The problem: People keep asking, \u201cWhen are you going to start drinking again?\u201d A co-worker even said, \u201cI miss drinking with you. Won\u2019t you have just one cocktail?\u201d The people in my recovery group tell me I don\u2019t owe anyone answers. But staring back blankly at friends doesn\u2019t seem practical. Any ideas?\n\nTRACIE\n\nOther than wanting to give you a ticker-tape parade? Recognizing our toughest problems and getting them in check is backbreaking work. Well done, Tracie! I get what your support group is saying: You have no duty to explain yourself. Especially at the beginning of a program, better to keep the focus on you and not waste energy fending off pals who may try to convince you that you don\u2019t have a drinking problem.\n\nBut now, with six months of sobriety under your belt, consider the flip side. Confiding my struggles in friends almost always makes me feel better \u2014 with a shared sense of life\u2019s inevitable hardships. So, let\u2019s break down these curious cats into two camps: true friends and former drinking buddies.\n\nTo the barflies, say: \u201cI\u2019m not drinking anymore. It didn\u2019t agree with me.\u201d No need to elaborate. But with friends and family who love you (and who won\u2019t be defensive about drinking problems), share more of your struggle. The emotional payoff could be huge, and you might extend your universe of allies beyond the four walls of your support group.", "title": "The Drink That Stands Between Recovery and Relapse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "A combination of historic amounts of money and high quality horses quickly made the Dubai World Cup a staple on the international horse racing calendar. The world\u2019s richest day of racing will take place Saturday at Meydan Racecourse in the United Arab Emirates, and it has once again attracted some of the most talented runners from around the world.\n\nHumble Beginnings\n\nAlthough the World Cup began in 1996, thoroughbred racing started in Dubai in 1981. The setup, however, was significantly more humble than what Meydan offers today.\n\nSheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, the vice president and prime minister of the U.A.E. and the ruler of Dubai, organized three thoroughbred races that October. A camel track was used for a sprint, a mile contest, and a one-and-a-half mile race.\n\nIt wouldn\u2019t be until 1992 that the Dubai Racing Club was formed, and that March, Nad Al Sheba Racecourse, the first home of the World Cup, opened. The following year, the Dubai International Jockeys\u2019 Challenge was held, with riders representing Australia, Europe, Japan, the U.A.E. and the United States.", "title": "The Dubai World Cup, a Story of Horses and Money", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Asked about the meeting and the administration\u2019s internal deliberations, Raj Shah, the deputy press secretary, said: \u201cThe Trump Administration will ensure that any climate science review will be conducted through a robust, interagency process, consistent with federal law.\u201d\n\nThe E.P.A. did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nThe episode reflects some of the challenges that Mr. Kelly faces in bringing order to a chaotic White House, where policy deliberations are sometimes circumvented when people close to Mr. Trump approach him personally to seek his approval for unorthodox moves.\n\nMr. Kelly is a retired four-star Marine Corps general who is said to share the pragmatic view held by military leaders including Jim Mattis, the secretary of defense, that climate change is happening and poses a serious national security challenge. Since he became chief of staff last July, Mr. Kelly has toiled to control access to Mr. Trump to try to ensure that his actions are informed by an orderly process in the West Wing \u2014 a pursuit that flies in the face of the president\u2019s freewheeling style.\n\nThe tension between the White House and the E.P.A. over the red team, blue team idea reflects a broader rift within the administration over whether and how directly to attack climate change science itself. While the words \u201cclimate change\u201d have been removed from many federal websites, and Mr. Trump has mocked global warming in tweets, the administration has stopped short of using the power of the federal government to attack the science.\n\nPhoto\n\nHolding national debates on climate change could have serious policy implications.\n\nThe fundamental science, that man-made pollution is overwhelmingly responsible for warming temperatures and rising sea levels, is widely accepted among mainstream scientists. That science formed the basis of a key 2009 E.P.A. decision known as the endangerment finding, which declares that climate change is a threat to human health and welfare. That finding is the legal backbone for almost all federal climate policy and requires the government to regulate greenhouse gas emissions in some manner. A government critique of climate science could lay the groundwork for challenging the endangerment finding in court.\n\nClimate denialist groups like the Heartland Institute have urged Mr. Pruitt to challenge the finding, while industry associations have expressed little interest in doing so. Tim Doyle, vice president of policy for the conservative business organization American Council for Capital Formation, said the companies he works with have not expressed any interest in a public forum to challenge climate change science.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe definitely haven\u2019t heard any of our members supporting the red team, blue team concept,\u201d he said. \u201cThere\u2019s been, if anything, radio silence about it.\u201d\n\nThe idea for red team, blue team climate debates originated with Steven Koonin, a physicist at New York University who was an energy undersecretary under Mr. Obama. Mr. Koonin in April wrote an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal calling for using the military-style exercise \u2014 in which one team attacks and another defends \u2014 to test the robustness of climate change science. One week later, he paid a visit to the E.P.A. at Mr. Pruitt\u2019s invitation to discuss the idea further.\n\nMr. Koonin, in an interview, said he has \u201cno dog in this fight\u201d \u2014 meaning that he is willing to be persuaded that climate change is an urgent threat \u2014 but that he believes there are uncertainties in the science that are worth exploring.\n\nIn talking with federal officials, Mr. Koonin said he outlined a vision for a debate including not only the E.P.A. but also the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, both of which collect data and conduct studies on Arctic ice melt, global temperature modeling and other issues. The White House science adviser should coordinate any such exercise, he said, to ensure all relevant government offices participate.\n\n\u201cIt would need to be governmentwide, certainly multiagency, in order for it to be robust and taken seriously as a scientific endeavor,\u201d Mr. Koonin said.\n\nClimate scientists and others who oppose the debate idea note that the studies that make up the body of knowledge on climate change already are subject to rigorous peer review. They contend that the red team, blue team exercise would be a politically motivated way to inject doubt into findings that have already been scientifically established.\n\n\u201cThe idea of a red team approach is used to test how well forces, or strategy, will perform against an adversary. But climate science is not our adversary,\u201d said Sherri Goodman, a former deputy undersecretary of defense under President Bill Clinton and now a senior fellow at the Woodrow Wilson International Center.\n\nMr. Pruitt planned to announce his red team, blue team debate in early November, according to a news release that was written but never issued. According to four people who have read the draft news release, the debates were to be organized by the E.P.A.\u2019s science advisory board and not include other agencies.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe announcement of the debates would have coincided with the release of an exhaustive scientific report from 13 United States government agencies that definitively found human activity to be responsible for almost all of the warming that has occurred in the past half-century. It would have also coincided with the start of a United Nations meeting in Germany to discuss the Paris agreement, the global climate accord from which Mr. Trump intends to withdraw the United States\u2019 participation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Mr. Trump\u2019s chief of staff learned about the news release, he demanded the debates be delayed until cabinet secretaries and top White House officials could discuss it, according to three people familiar with the discussions. That initial meeting never occurred, but on Dec. 13, the White House convened senior officials to discuss the matter.\n\nAccording to two people who attended, the meeting included a presentation of the red team, blue team plan by two E.P.A. officials \u2014 Mr. Pruitt\u2019s chief of staff and the head of the agency\u2019s air office. Other attendees included senior officials from the Department of Energy, the White House Council on Environmental Quality, the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, and the National Economic Council.\n\nThe meeting was run by Mr. Dearborn and Michael Catanzaro, who is a member of the economic council and the president\u2019s domestic energy and environment policy director.\n\nThe takeaway, according to people in the room, was that every office within the White House was opposed to the idea. At one point, Mr. Dearborn said the notion of red team, blue team debates was \u201cdead\u201d and should not be mentioned again. \u201cThe chief doesn\u2019t want it,\u201d Mr. Dearborn said, referring to the White House chief of staff, according to one person who attended.\n\nE.P.A. officials were taken aback, the person said.\n\nIn the weeks since that meeting, however, Mr. Pruitt said the red team, blue team debates were still under consideration. In January, he told Congress that a report in E & E News, a news organization focusing on energy and the environment that first reported that the White House had killed the plan, was false. White House opposition to the debates was \u201cuntrue,\u201d he said under questioning by a senator.\n\nFor the moment, even those who have championed the red team, blue team idea like Mr. Koonin are doubtful the debates will happen. \u201cMy optimism that we can get this done in a quality way is pretty low at this point,\u201d Mr. Koonin said. \u201cIt needs to be a governmentwide exercise and there\u2019s nobody that I know of that has picked up the ball in the White House.\u201d", "title": "The E.P.A. Chief Wanted a Climate Science Debate. Trump\u2019s Chief of Staff Stopped Him.", "authors": ["Lisa Friedman", "Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "In that study, which began in the mid-1970s, scientists signed confidentiality agreements so they could track the private medical and occupational histories of more than 22,000 individuals in six cities around the country. They combined that personal data with home air-quality data in order to study the link between chronic exposure to air pollution and mortality.\n\nAcademics aren\u2019t typically required to turn over such private data when submitting studies for peer review by other specialists in the field, or for review and publication in scientific journals, which is the traditional way that this kind of research is evaluated. If academics were to turn over the raw data to be made available for public review, the agency would have to spend hundreds of millions of dollars, according to a federal estimate , to redact private information.\n\nThe bottom line, critics say, is that if the E.P.A. is limited to considering only studies in which the data is publicly available, the agency will have a narrower and incomplete body of research to draw on when considering regulations. \u201cIt sends a pretty chilling message to scientists that their work can\u2019t be used or won\u2019t be used,\u201d said Sean Gallagher, a government relations officer with the American Association for the Advancement of Science, a nonprofit science advocacy organization .\n\nMr. Pruitt laid out his plans for the new transparency policy in an interview last week with The Daily Caller, a conservative news site. The proposal is based on legislation named the Honest and Open New E.P.A. Science Treatment Act, also known as the Honest Act, a bill sponsored by Representative Lamar Smith, a Texas Republican. The bill has failed to gain support in Congress for years despite having the support of the energy, manufacturing and chemical industries.\n\nThat legislation aimed to preclude the E.P.A. from using any studies that could not be independently reproduced. According to data compiled by the Center for Responsive Politics , a nonpartisan research group that tracks campaign finance data, versions of the bill have received support from Exxon Mobil, Peabody Energy, Koch Industries and the American Chemistry Council, which provides policy and research for major chemical companies including Arkema, DuPont and Monsanto.\n\nMr. Smith, the sponsor of the stalled Congressional legislation, applauded the E.P.A.\u2019s proposed move. \u201cOur citizens have a right to see the data that the E.P.A. says justifies their regulations,\u201d he said in a statement. He has argued that E.P.A. regulations in the past were justified by data that was impossible to verify independently.", "title": "The E.P.A. Says It Wants Research Transparency. Scientists See an Attack on Science.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNarrower Scope for E.P.A. Rules\u201d (front page, March 27):\n\nThe discrediting of science is a shocking new piece of American life. The decision by the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Scott Pruitt, to limit use of scientific research when determining agency regulations, unless the raw data can be made public, is simply wrong.\n\nAmerica has led the way in scientific research, and we have depended on that information for everything from medical breakthroughs to space travel. To put a lid on use of important research and to question its validity is dangerous. Proper scientific research as carried out by well-trained scientists is steeped in validity.\n\nWhile warnings about our changing climate abound and threats to our food safety surface, nonscientists are leading a charge to undermine research, and, in turn, much-needed regulation. The E.P.A. is setting the table for a dangerous new world. We need to say \u201cno\u201d!\n\nSALLY COURTRIGHT, ALBANY\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe rhetoric that Scott Pruitt uses makes it seem as though he is doing the American people a favor by providing them the \u201ctransparency\u201d they deserve. But Mr. Pruitt is the one not providing the American people transparency.", "title": "Opinion | The E.P.A.\u2019s Snub of Scientific Research", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The most forged documents in financial history were the work of ordinary rascals who needed little skill to make money. All they needed was a camera.\n\nNewspaper articles in the late 1850s began warning of the danger of counterfeit bank notes that had been made using photography. Both had appeared in the United States in the 1830s after President Andrew Jackson eliminated the federal banking system, allowing private banks to issue paper currency under guidelines set by each state. At one point, forgeries accounted for 40 percent of the nation\u2019s currency, with photography often to blame.\n\n\u201cFor a time, the ease of modification and duplication enabled by negative-positive photography seemed to be a threat rather than a benefit,\u201d said Mazie Harris, the curator of Paper Promises: Early American Photography, a new exhibition at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles which runs through May 27.", "title": "The Earliest Days of American Photography", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "There are 39 pages in the Labor Department\u2019s February report on the employment situation in the United States, but they can be summed up in four words: The economy is humming.\n\nThe 313,000 jobs that the nation added in February are far more than are needed to keep up with population growth and continue a surprising burst of job creation to start the year. In the first two months of 2018, the economy has added an average of 276,000 jobs a month, a big step up from 182,000 on average in 2017.\n\nThis is not the kind of data you expect in an expansion that is nine years old, or out of a labor market that is already at full employment. It suggests that employers are filling jobs not merely from people they\u2019ve poached from competitors, but also from more people who have entered the work force. And other data in the latest report matches that idea.\n\nThe number of adults not in the labor force fell by a whopping 653,000 people, as the participation rate \u2014 the proportion of adults who either have a job or are looking for one \u2014 rose a healthy 0.3 percent to 63 percent. The proportion of people in their prime working years (25 to 54) who are working is at its highest level since 2008.", "title": "The Economy Is Looking Awfully Strong", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Not the usual gold accents\n\nThe decisive sentiment at the shows seemed to be: Go for the gold, and in perhaps unexpected places. Thom Browne\u2019s models went down the runway with gold-painted cropped haircuts or tightly wrapped updos, appearing as modern-day queens. Keep it low-key.", "title": "The Eight Biggest Beauty Trends from Fashion Month", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s style, and then there\u2019s Style.\n\n\u201cStyle, with a capital S, achieves what a rule book never can: it lights the page, draws readers, earns their delight, makes them gasp or weep and sometimes captures a place in memory,\u201d begins the online foreword to The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage, the paper\u2019s reference guide, established in 1895, which encourages consistent and polished language throughout the news report. \u201cWriterly style (even without the illicit capital S) is a set of tools and tricks, a tone of voice.\u201d\n\nThe Associated Press has long been the gold standard for uniformity among most international news publications. But for over a century, The Times\u2019s stylebook has set a parallel course when it comes to journalistic style. The stylebook largely consists of rules dictating renderings, syntax and abbreviations \u2014 Gov. vs. Governor, capitalization of words for headlines and the devilish Oxford comma, for example. But as a living document that constantly grapples with the ethics of language, it also absorbs the larger cultural lexicon.\n\nThe stylebook codifies a set of practices designed to make the paper easy to read.\n\n\u201cIn a news organization where you have hundreds of writers and editors working very quickly on deadline, you want the reader to get the sense that there\u2019s some consistency,\u201d said Philip B. Corbett, the associate managing editor for standards, who oversees the use of style and editing standards across the newsroom.\n\nDespite what some readers may wish, \u201cWe are definitely not looking to be on the cutting edge \u2014 rather the reverse,\u201d Mr. Corbett said. \u201cIdeally we want to use style that is already settled and accepted and familiar in usage.\u201d", "title": "The Elements of the Stylebook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "It was enough to make you think: Feh with the trendy social media meta-commentary! Bring back the sex problem.\n\nWhich is why, when the Rick Owens show began to a medley of voices singing \u201cBaubles, Bangles and Beads,\u201d a tune from the 1953 musical \u201cKismet\u201d that has been covered by everyone from Peggy Lee to Frank Sinatra and that features a woman musing on whether her sparkly accessories will help her catch a man, it was kind of a relief. Hello there, elephant in the dressing room.\n\nBut then, Mr. Owens often likes to go where many other designers fear to tread: to climate change, the refugee crisis, stuff like that. \u201cListening to the words, which are completely innocent, is chilling at this moment,\u201d he said backstage after the show.", "title": "The Elephant in the Dressing Room", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "A native of Rhode Island, the photographer Michael Bailey-Gates first moved to New York after high school in order to meet and make work with the artists he had become friends with online. \u201cThe internet was my secret passage to photography as a kid,\u201d he says, explaining that he would share his early images of his world through Flickr. \u201cI was always making a big mess at home, taking pictures in private to put online. Photography has always felt forbidden and dangerous to me, but has brought me everything in my life.\u201d\n\nIn New York, Bailey-Gates, 24, has continued to grow his network of collaborators, which now includes the artist, model and actress India Salvor Menuez, the singer Dev Hynes and the designers Mike Eckhaus and Zoe Latta, all of whom have appeared in his provocative portraits. A recipient of the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation Award in 2015, Bailey-Gates describes making pictures as a process that has \u201cformed my identity, my relationships, the way I connect to the world.\u201d\n\nIn this new body of work, \u201cHorse in the Rough,\u201d which debuts exclusively here, Bailey-Gates references early motion-study photographs \u2014 but applies a very current perspective, without the gender norms traditional to classical portraiture. \u201cMy photography is an imprint of my accumulated beliefs,\u201d he explains. \u201cI\u2019m not trying to convince you of something, because to me it\u2019s already true.\u201d\n\nFeaturing both the photographer and his friends in and out of garments, the images depict environments teetering between the mundane and the otherworldly, embodying his wider vision of a fluid reality. \u201cGender isn\u2019t real,\u201d he says. \u201cI want photography to support this fact. I want to challenge binary systems of thinking and overcome them.\u201d", "title": "The Emerging Photographer Inspired by Classical Portraiture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-20 00:00:00", "text": "Facebook did not have a comment for this article and referred to Mr. Stamos\u2019s previous comments and his posts on Twitter. On Tuesday, Mr. Stamos tweeted that Facebook executives, including the chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, and the chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, \u201csupported the investigation and disclosure of our work, and I\u2019m glad we put out what we found.\u201d He did not address the disputes over the reorganization of Facebook\u2019s security team.\n\nMr. Stamos, a California native and a graduate of the University of California, Berkeley, previously worked at start-ups and founded a security consulting firm in San Francisco before joining Yahoo as its chief security officer in mid-2014.\n\nHe became somewhat of a legend in 2015 when he pushed back on government efforts to weaken security. At the time, after surveillance disclosures by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, Silicon Valley companies were adding anti-surveillance protections including encryption to their data centers and messaging tools. Washington accused tech companies of going too far, and the F.B.I. pressed companies like Apple to weaken their encryption or build in a government back door.\n\nIn February 2015, at a cybersecurity conference in Washington, Mr. Stamos stood up to Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the N.S.A. director, by likening the government\u2019s requests to \u201cdrilling a hole in the windshield.\u201d A video of the encounter went viral, making Mr. Stamos a celebrated figure in privacy and security circles.\n\nWithin Yahoo\u2019s security team, known as the \u201cParanoids,\u201d Mr. Stamos was considered an inspiration by many of its young engineers. But his vocal \u2014 at times abrasive \u2014 advocacy for privacy and anti-surveillance measures often put him at odds with Yahoo\u2019s leadership, including the chief executive, Marissa Mayer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Stamos had successfully campaigned for Yahoo to encrypt the data flowing through its data centers. But when he pushed for end-to-end encryption \u2014 which ensures that only the parties in a conversation can see what is being said, leaving even Yahoo unable to read it \u2014 Ms. Mayer and other executives scoffed.\n\nSome of Mr. Stamos\u2019s other security proposals at Yahoo, such as resetting customers\u2019 passwords after a breach, were rejected because the added inconvenience might encourage Yahoo customers to leave.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy then, Mr. Stamos had drawn the notice of Facebook executives. Some at the social network worried aloud whether he was too much of a firebrand to join the social network, according to three current and former Facebook employees who declined to be named because of nondisclosure agreements. But others argued that his activism was a benefit for the company.\n\nMr. Stamos joined Facebook in June 2015. From the start, the current and former employees said, he got off on the wrong foot with some executives, including Ms. Sandberg, over how best to police the platform. Facebook was increasingly grappling with cyberattacks from countries like Iran, whose hackers were caught trying to break into the accounts of State Department employees, and from Russia, the current and former employees said.\n\nIn a statement on Monday, Mr. Stamos said his relationship with Ms. Sandberg was \u201cproductive.\u201d\n\nAfter a breach of the Democratic National Committee in June 2016, Mr. Stamos pulled together a team to investigate Russian interference on Facebook. The findings pit him against executives in the company\u2019s legal and communications groups. While Mr. Stamos argued to disclose more, others said that by proactively disclosing what they had found, Facebook had become a target of further public ire, according to seven current and former Facebook employees.\n\nInternally, Mr. Stamos repeatedly argued that Facebook needed to act more like a defense contractor in dealing with security, given that the social network was becoming a similar target for nation states.\n\nIn audio leaked in October to ZDNet, a tech news site, he told his security team that he explained to management \u201cthat we have the threat profile of a Northrop Grumman or a Raytheon or another defense contractor, but we run our corporate network, for example, like a college campus, almost.\u201d\n\nThe tape infuriated Mr. Stamos\u2019s bosses, according to the current and former employees. A leak investigation is continuing, two of the people said. They said some executives believed Mr. Stamos had leaked the audio himself to get Facebook to take his entreaties more seriously.\n\nMr. Stamos later tweeted that the audio was \u201cnot a criticism of anybody, just a statement of why our team needs to be creative in how we protect our corporate network.\u201d\n\nBy October, the relationship between Mr. Stamos and Ms. Sandberg had deteriorated over how to handle Russian interference on Facebook and how best to reorganize Facebook\u2019s security team before the midterm elections, according to more than half a dozen people who work or formerly worked at the company. Mr. Stamos proposed that instead of reporting to Facebook\u2019s general counsel, Colin Stretch, he report directly to Facebook\u2019s higher-ups.\n\nInstead, executives released Mr. Stamos from much of his day-to-day responsibility, employees said.\n\nMr. Stamos has said his remaining days at Facebook will be spent \u201cexploring emerging risks and working on election security.\u201d", "title": "The End for Facebook\u2019s Security Evangelist", "authors": ["Nicole Perlroth", "Sheera Frenkel"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. L\u00f3pez Obrador has promised \u201ca change of regime.\u201d Mexican voters should carefully consider what he means, given the precedents.\n\nTo begin with, he has said that he does not believe in the existence of Mexican democracy, though it has been in the context of its rules, institutions and freedoms that he has gained the likelihood of power. Nor does he trust in the National Electoral Institute. After losing the 2006 election by a wafer-thin margin (0.58 percent), he declared the election fraudulent and led his followers in occupying the Paseo de la Reforma, the central artery of Mexico City, an action rejected by the public. Defeated by a larger margin (6.63 percent) in 2012, he again claimed fraud. He has continued to show disdain for the institutions of liberal democracy. \u201cTo hell with their institutions,\u201d he famously said in 2006 and has not disavowed his assertion. And he recently accused the Supreme Court of being an instrument of the oligarchy used to dominate the people.\n\nThere is a genuine linkage of religious fervor (which it seems just to call messianic) between Mr. L\u00f3pez Obrador and his followers. Confident in that connection, he has shown an unbending intolerance toward criticism from the media and intellectuals. He has a disqualifying adjective for every group that doubts or opposes him: \u201cfakes,\u201d \u201cconservatives,\u201d \u201csellouts.\u201d He has called the press \u201cfif\u00ed\u201d (bourgeois). He has proved to be incapable of self-criticism and shows a significant tendency to divide the country between \u201cthe people\u201d who support him and all the others, who support \u201cthe mafia in power.\u201d\n\nMr. L\u00f3pez Obrador trusts so much in the sheer force of his charisma that he has promised to \u201cbring Trump to his senses.\u201d He wants to bring peace to Mexico by exploring the possibility of granting amnesty to drug traffickers and producers. \u201cOnly I can fix corruption,\u201d he has stated, and he recently announced that he will call for the drafting of a \u201cmoral Constitution\u201d that can inaugurate a \u201cloving republic.\u201d\n\nMr. L\u00f3pez Obrador has surrounded himself with politicians and union leaders formerly of the P.R.I. who were directly involved in gross acts of corruption. He shows a real concern for alleviating poverty though is as yet insufficiently specific in his proposals. Many liberal Mexicans fear that he will reverse the opening to private and foreign investment in Mexican oil production and will choose to protect the domestic economy from international competition.\n\nMy own major concern, however, is his attitude toward our still fragile democracy. In his defense, his supporters point to his record as mayor of Mexico City (2000-05), but that position did not remotely involve the power that would accrue to him as president.
