View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDr. Pastuszak said he primarily prescribes testosterone to men in the F.D.A.\u2019s low category but will sometimes let other men with symptoms try it. \u201cIf you have these guys in the mid range and you put them on it, the majority will say they want to stay on it,\u201d he said, adding that most men will say it makes them feel better and boosts their sex drive. But is that the power of suggestion or the power of the hormone?\n\n\u201cThe reality is we don\u2019t have the answer,\u201d said Dr. Pastuszak, noting that there\u2019s a big gray area. \u201cI have to take their word that they feel better on it, whether that\u2019s real or whether it\u2019s placebo.\u201d\n\nComplicating matters, testosterone levels fluctuate, peaking around 8 a.m. and diminishing throughout the day. Levels tend to be lowest around 8 in the evening, then climb during the night. The peaks and valleys are larger for men 40 and younger compared to men in their 70s. (For a 40-year-old, a morning testosterone reading may be 200 points higher than in the evening, versus a 50-point difference for a 70-year-old.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd all sorts of things can nudge levels in either direction.\n\nResistance training increases levels, as does a high-intensity workout. Even watching your favorite sports team win can nudge numbers up, as a 1998 study that measured testosterone among basketball fans before and after a game found. (Testosterone levels declined among those rooting for the losers.) Still, any gains from such activities tend to be fleeting; levels generally return to the individual\u2019s normal within a half-hour or so.\n\nAnd just as there are things men can do to boost levels, there are activities that lower testosterone scores. Endurance exercises, such as marathon training or cycling long distances, can lower levels, as can stress. Dr. Bhasin said that the kind of training endured by special armed forces \u2014 tough exercise, lack of sleep and food \u2014 can cause testosterone to drop to the levels of men who have been castrated \u2014 lower than 50.\n\nObesity causes testosterone levels to plummet \u2014 while losing 10 percent of body fat can increase levels by 100 points. Even taking care of the kids for several hours can cause levels to drop, a study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences reported. Flu and other viral illnesses can also cause levels to drop, so you should hold off testing until you\u2019re fully recovered.\n\nAs for alcohol, a few beers won\u2019t make a difference in the short term. But the liver damage by chronic alcohol abuse thwarts the production of testosterone.\n\nFurther complicating matters, every testosterone-making lab has its own methods of calculating testosterone, so a man may register 300 with one company\u2019s machine but 400 with another. To find a reputable lab, patients can refer to a website from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that lists accredited laboratories.\n\nSo what about the man who reaches a top reading of 1,000?\n\nJust learning about the score might make him feel so good it boosts his confidence and libido. But that doesn\u2019t mean the effect is a result of changes in his hormone chemistry.", "title": "The Highs and Lows of Testosterone", "authors": ["Randi Hutter Epstein"]} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nA Feb. 26 Op-Ed article by Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel asked, \u201cAre Hospitals Obsolete?\u201d The answer is unequivocally no.\n\nIn times of disasters, outbreaks and tragedies, communities lean on their hospitals: That fact will never change. Hospitalizations for the flu reached record levels this winter, with people flocking to their local hospitals for care, forcing some hospitals to erect tents to care for all who walked through their doors.\n\nHospitals and health systems also cared for people after too many incidents of violence in our communities. Moreover, they will continue to perform sophisticated surgery, diagnostics and therapeutics at the cutting edge of scientific development. This work will always be there and will only grow.\n\nAt the same time, the real issue is the redefinition of the hospital.\n\nHospitals and health systems are leading the greatest transformation in history. They are working to provide coordinated and convenient care beyond their four walls that is more responsive to patients and communities than ever before, all with a focus on keeping people healthy.", "title": "Opinion | The Hospital\u2019s Place in the New Health Landscape", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "Who knew everybody would wear nude? The level of red carpet commentary before the 90th Academy Awards seemed straight out of the hot tub time machine \u2014 as, increasingly, does the event itself. The Oscars have been caught flat-footed by the persistent demurral of stars unwilling to participate in the once-obligatory step-and-strut, the designer name-checking, the preshow interviews, the scrutiny of the relentless likes of Joan Rivers that left on-air talent floundering.\n\nNude hasn\u2019t signified Caucasian at least since Crayola crayons changed Flesh to Peach in 1962. (Memo to E!\u2019s Brad Goreski.) Particularly in a year when the conversation shifted importantly from what women in entertainment are wearing to what\u2019s on their minds, a year in which diversity, inclusion and pay parity became inevitable conversations in Hollywood, there was something bracing in what appeared to be an unspoken consensus among women in the business to bypass the quid pro quo of fashion in pursuit of other ideals.", "title": "The Invisible Man and the Defiant Woman go to the Oscars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nVIENNA \u2014 The centenary of the Russian Revolution has inspired dozens of exhibitions of the art and history of the abbreviated Soviet century, from \u201cRevolution: Russian Art 1917\u20141932,\u201d at London\u2019s Royal Academy, to the Art Institute of Chicago\u2019s \u201cRevoliutsiia! Demonstratsiia!\u201d, not to mention significant shows in Moscow and St. Petersburg. Curators and historians have been grappling once again with the meaning of the 10 days that shook the world: Was it a brilliant dream? A doomed illusion?\n\nNow comes another question: Was it good for the Jews?\n\nStep into the Jewish Museum Vienna, just off the main shopping drag of this imperial city, and you will be greeted by a bust of Karl Marx, the descendant of rabbis who would call religion the \u201copiate of the masses.\u201d Dour, wild-haired Karl presides over the first gallery of an ambitious, searching show on religion and revolution, uniting paintings, posters, propaganda, film clips, and a fair amount of Soviet kitsch. Its romantic title \u2014 \u201cComrade. Jew. We Only Wanted Paradise on Earth\u201d \u2014 sets the tone for an extensive overview of the dreams and nightmares of communism and international socialism, as seen through the lives and work of Jewish politicians, philosophers and artists: not just Marx, but also Leon Trotsky, Rosa Luxemburg, El Lissitzky, and many others.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe museum has certainly got into the bolshie spirit. A pair of red ensigns with hammer and sickle will hang until May Day from its stately facade, and the galleries of \u201cComrade. Jew\u201d have been refitted with a bold, Constructivist design, featuring cantilevered walls painted white and red. But this is no agitprop showcase; it\u2019s a deeply researched dive into the lives of men and women who believed in something with the force others reserved for religion, and could hardly imagine how badly it would turn.\n\nPhoto\n\nYou don\u2019t need me to tell you that this is still hot stuff, a hundred years on. That many communists were Jews has, with horrible frequency, been twisted to imply that all Jews were communists. The Nazis cast \u201cJewish Bolshevism\u201d as a single scourge, and the return this decade of the far right has also witnessed a hideous return of anti-Semitism, not just in Europe but in the United States as well. (Nowhere is this more urgent than in Poland, where a new \u201cdeath camp\u201d law has been called tantamount to Holocaust denial, and where the populist Law and Justice government combines strident anti-Communist rhetoric with anti-Semitism of greater or lesser overtness.)", "title": "The Jews Who Dreamed of Utopia", "authors": ["Jason Farago"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Hoi Eng Chan does not know how all those unbundled un-broken-down cardboard boxes wound up in front of the house she owns in the Bronx. It is near the subway, so a lot of people throw trash there.\n\nAminur Howlader concedes that the rice in the steam table of the Halal food cart he operates was being held at less than 140 degrees, but he was going to throw it out. He had already made a whole other cooker of rice and was serving from that instead. As for the other summons, Mr. Howlader\u2019s cart was indeed parked less than 20 feet from a door of the Target on Avenue H, but that door is used only by employees when the store is closed, which it wasn\u2019t. He has been parking in that spot for nine years and never got a ticket.\n\nThis is life at OATH, a little-known but ever-expanding branch of the municipal justice system. OATH, the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, now handles violation summonses from 19 city agencies, from the health department to the Fire Department to the Business Integrity Commission. OATH hears about 100 times more cases than all the criminal courts in the city put together.\n\nA day spent in the hearing rooms of an OATH office \u2014 there is one in each borough \u2014 offers both a voyage into the small intestine of bureaucracy and a front-row seat at an endless and sometimes heartbreaking parade of excuses and ostensibly exculpatory explanations.\n\nSometimes injustice is exposed and defeated. Sometimes it is as if a pack of homework-eating dogs is roaming the streets.\n\nThe folding table from which Liudmyla Sviderska was selling pastries without a permit on Brighton Beach Avenue was not a mobile food cart, her representative said. Also, they were just pastries from a nearby bakery that got an A on its health inspection. Also, the pastries were individually wrapped and not potentially hazardous. Everyone else on 23rd Road also lets their tenants park illegally on the side of the house. Hector Sanabria would have pleaded not guilty to the open-container summons but he does not remember what happened that day.\n\nIf courthouses, with their columns and marble and carved mottos, are built to inspire awe at the majesty of the law, the aesthetics of an OATH hearing center, with its box-office windows and crowd-herding cordons, will be immediately familiar to anyone who has done time at the D.M.V.\n\nThe judges do not wear robes or carry gavels. They are per-diem city lawyers in business attire and are known as hearing officers.\n\nDefendants \u2014 they are called respondents \u2014 may bring a lawyer, but most do not. The agency that issued the summons can send a representative, and some routinely do. But the Sanitation Department, which accounts for nearly half of the summonses processed by OATH, nearly never sends anyone. Nor does the Police Department, another leading summons source. So most of the time, it is just the respondent and the hearing officer in the little room.\n\nIt is not Arjan Gjushi\u2019s fault if the subcontractors brought their dumptrucks to the site more than an hour early and blocked Featherbed Lane. It is not Metin Kurtulus\u2019s fault if patrons of the bodega next to his vacant lot throw their empty bottles over his fence, especially after he chained his own trash can to a post for them to use and someone stole it. Strokos Gourmet Deli has fired the exterminator responsible for the 46 live fruit flies a health inspector observed on a recent visit.\n\nOver the course of many hearings, patterns of excuse emerge. Very frequently, they hinge on evasion or transfer of blame. This is a risky legal strategy.", "title": "The Judge Will Hear Your 223,000 Excuses Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "JIDDA, Saudi Arabia \u2014 \u201cO.K. Come drive now,\u201d said the trainer.\n\n\u201cOh my God,\u201d the architecture student replied.\n\nShe climbed into the driver\u2019s seat, put on her seatbelt, found the pedals, released the hand brake and put the car into drive. Then she took a deep breath, eased her foot off the brake and began doing, for the first time, what women will soon be doing all over Saudi Arabia: driving.\n\n\u201cIs this O.K.?\u201d the student, Rahaf Alzahrani, 21, asked nervously as she inched along.\n\n\u201cYes. It\u2019s O.K.,\u201d the instructor said.\n\nThree and a half months remain before the date when the rulers of this ultraconservative kingdom have promised to lift the longstanding ban on women driving, and many here are already planning for what is sure to be a major change in Saudi society.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWomen\u2019s universities have announced that they plan to open driving schools, and car companies have shifted their ads, seeking to profit from the anticipated flood of new drivers \u2014 and car buyers \u2014 in this country of 32 million.", "title": "The Keys to the Kingdom: Saudi Women Learn to Drive", "authors": ["Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-03-29 00:00:00", "text": "PHILADELPHIA \u2014 In the 1950s, \u201960s and \u201970s here, as in many big cities, there were dozens of independent men\u2019s clothing stores selling tailored suits, sport coats, dress shirts and \u201cfurnishings\u201d (socks, ties, pocket squares) to dapper professionals. Among these were the Arrow Store, Morvilles, Diamonds, Irving\u2019s and Jacob Reed\u2019s Sons. Today, professionals no longer need be dapper, and only one store from that period remains in business: Boyds. Like the Liberty Bell and the stone Rocky Steps, Boyds is a local landmark, and one equally impervious to the shifting seasons.\n\nFor 80 years, the family-owned business has outfitted lawyers, bankers, doctors, politicians and famous athletes, with all-American brands like Hickey-Freeman, groovy European labels like Pierre Cardin and Tiger of Sweden and lately high-end Italian suiting and sportswear from Brioni, Isaia and Brunello Cucinelli.\n\nWhen the former basketball star Julius Erving flew into the city for a visit from the Bahamas during the January cold snap and found himself in need of warmer clothes, he called Boyds, as he has since back when he was Dr. J., slamming dunks for the 76ers.\n\n\u201cBoyds was the place to shop,\u201d said Mr. Erving, who all these years later still deals with the same salesman, Bill Bolling. \u201cThey always had somebody who would make sure everything was just so: sleeve length, cuff length. They know what you like.\u201d", "title": "The Last Great Clothing Store", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe mermaid has long swum in the sea of our collective imagination, appearing in stories ranging from fourth-century B.C. Chinese mythology to the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen. Most often she is a princess of the depths, with alabaster skin, a giant fin in place of legs and breasts covered by a mess of long, tangled hair. Her appeal, though, is not merely aesthetic. For centuries, men have braved the open waters, knowing full well they may never make it home, and the mermaid has served as either a kind of ballast in times of trouble, saving sailors from floods and deadly storms, or a figure of seduction, luring them to their deaths at the bottom of the ocean. Her passivity, as well as her beguiling exoticness, is an escape from whatever drudgery awaits these men back on land \u2014 the mermaid is a fantasy, yes, but also a way to explain the unexplainable in nature. The admiral on one of Christopher Columbus\u2019s expeditions once mistook a manatee, its silky gray curves moving gently through the Caribbean waters, for one.\n\nLately, though, it\u2019s the mermaid\u2019s male counterparts who\u2019ve surfaced as objects of desire. In Guillermo del Toro\u2019s \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d Sally Hawkins plays a mute woman named Elisa who works as a cleaning lady at a government laboratory. She falls for a mysterious amphibian captured at sea \u2014 he\u2019s less merman, more creature of the lagoon, complete with webbed fingers and gills, but he enchants her nonetheless, gently swaying in his tank to the jazz music Elisa plays for him. The film echoes Rachel Ingalls\u2019s recently reissued 1982 novel \u201cMrs. Caliban,\u201d in which a lonely California housewife falls for a sexy frog man (\u201c \u2026 as for the rest of the body, he was exactly like a man \u2014 a well-built large man \u2014 except that he was a dark spotted green-brown in color and had no hair\u201d). Finally, Melissa Broder\u2019s racy debut novel, \u201cThe Pisces\u201d (out this May), tells of a young woman who, strolling Venice Beach one night, meets a handsome merman named Theo. \u201cThe tail starts below all that,\u201d he reassures her. Their love, as in all of these stories, is doomed, but it is passionate and refreshingly free of judgment.\n\nAre real men these days so unwanted? In these interspecies romances, women aren\u2019t looking to be saved by convention (these frogs don\u2019t turn into princes when kissed). Their love also demonstrates a kind of compassion that feels profoundly absent right now. In light of #MeToo, such narratives of feminist reclamation force us to ask ourselves: Who is actually dangerous, and what is truly safe? What we fear most may not be these so-called monsters of the sea.", "title": "The Latest Subject of Female Fantasies? Creatures From the Deep", "authors": ["Thessaly La Force", "Notes On The Culture"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "Second, the order leaves the door open to discussions with allies other than Mexico and Canada, which are currently exempt. It says that a country that has a security relationship with the United States is welcome to discuss ways to allay the United States\u2019 national security concerns. If successful, the president might decide to modify or remove the tariffs.\n\nAny country with which we have a security relationship is welcome to discuss with the United States alternative ways to address the threatened impairment of the national security caused by imports from that country. Should the United States and any such country arrive at a satisfactory alternative means to address the threat to the national security such that I determine that imports from that country no longer threaten to impair the national security, I may remove or modify the restriction on steel articles imports from that country and, if necessary, make any corresponding adjustments to the tariff as it applies to other countries as our national security interests require.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPresident Trump authorizes tariffs.\n\nThe president defied allies both in his own party and overseas Thursday and signed an order imposing sweeping new tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, reports the NYT\u2019s Peter Baker and Ana Swanson.\n\nStill, he sought to soften the impact on some of America\u2019s closest allies. For now, Canada and Mexico are exempt and there is the possibility of later excluding allies such as Australia. But the order could hit South Korea, China, Japan, Germany, Turkey and Brazil.\n\nFrom the NYT:\n\n\u201cThe orders represented Mr. Trump\u2019s most expansive use of federal power to rewrite the rules of global trade since he took office and upended the prevailing consensus on free markets that has largely governed Washington under administrations of both parties for decades. A longtime critic of globalization, Mr. Trump argued that the United States has been ravaged by unfair trading partners, particularly in fading sectors like steel and aluminum.\u201d\n\nThe details\n\n\u2022 The orders will raise levies on foreign steel by 25 percent and on imported aluminum by 10 percent.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump said the order would give him the authority to raise or lower levies on a country-by-country basis and add or take countries off the list as he deems fit.\n\n\n\n\u2022 The order goes into effect in 15 days.\n\nTariff flyaround\n\n\u2022 A group of 11 nations \u2014 including major United States allies like Japan, Canada and Australia \u2014 signed a broad trade deal on Thursday that challenges Mr. Trump\u2019s view of trade as a zero-sum game filled with winners and losers. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The chances of a complete breakdown in the global trade system remain remote, if a little less remote than a week ago. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The marriage of establishment and populist economic thinking was always an uneasy one. Now President Trump\u2019s steel and aluminum tariffs are forcing the Republican party to choose between its core business supporters and populist voters. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 The tariffs have caused much concern about President Trump\u2019s trade policy. A probe into Chinese intellectual property policy could prove more devastating. (Breakingviews)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat happens when the bond market and the Fed disagree?\n\nWhen the Federal Reserve and the bond market are at loggerheads, it\u2019s almost as if the economy\u2019s parents are fighting. The kids, stock investors and borrowers in this analogy, just don\u2019t know who to side with.\n\nThis dynamic appears to explain what happened in early February when inflation fears sent bond prices lower and, in turn, set off panicked selling in the stock market.\n\nNow, as the Fed gets ready to raise interest rates several times, differences between the central bank and the bond market could start to matter more.\n\nThere is no conclusive way to measure the degree of disagreement between the Fed and the bond markets. But that didn\u2019t stop us having a go.\n\nOne approach is to compare the yield on the bellwether 10-year Treasury note with Fed policymakers\u2019 forecasts for the central bank\u2019s target rate. Several times a year, the policymakers project where the federal funds target rate will be at different points in the future. In this exercise, we compared the 10-year\u2019s yield with the median forecast made in December for the target rate at the end of the next year.\n\nIn December of 2014, 2015 and 2016, the 10-year\u2019s yield was around 1 percentage point higher than the forecast.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in December last year, the difference between the two numbers had shrunk markedly. The yield was only 0.26 of a percentage point above the forecast.\n\nOne interpretation of this narrowing: The bond market was behind in reacting to economic strength. And when it did snap out of its possibly complacent state, it did so sharply. The 10-year yield is now 2.88 percent, up from 2.39 percent before the meeting in Dec. 2017.\n\nWith that increase, there was a 0.77 percentage point difference between the policymakers forecast and the yield on the 10-year Treasury on Monday.\n\nBut if the 10-year yield moved up to reestablish a 1-percentage point difference, it would sail past the psychologically important 3 percent mark.\n\nThe problem, of course, with using Fed policymakers\u2019 forecasts is that the Fed has made them public only for a few years.\n\nTo get a much longer perspective, we looked back at the actual interest rate that the Fed targets, which is set in the market for the funds that banks must keep on deposit at the Fed. We compared this effective federal funds rate with the 10-year\u2019s yield.\n\nSecond Guessing the Fed The difference between the 10-year Treasury note yield and the effective federal funds rate, compared with the median difference since the early 1960s, in percentage points. pct. pts. 4 3 2 1 0 -1 Median Difference 1990 2000 2010 pct. pts. 4 3 2 1 0 -1 Median Difference 1990 2000 2010\n\nOn Monday, that spread was 1.46 percentage points. How does that compare? It\u2019s tighter than the median for the past eight years, 1.95 percentage points. The 10-year yield would have moved a lot higher to take the spread back there.\n\nBut there is a less alarming viewpoint. The current 1.46 percentage point spread is only slightly higher than the median 1.24 percentage points for the 50-plus years we studied.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd, perhaps most reassuringly, 1.46 percentage points is very close to the 1.67 percentage point median for June 2003 till the end of 2006, a period in which the Fed raised interest rates repeatedly.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nCigna shows that health care deal mania is alive and well\n\nCigna finally got a big deal done by buying Express Scripts, one of the U.S.\u2019s largest drug benefits managers, for $69 billion, including debt.\n\nThe bigger point: as always, health care companies want to get bigger and gain negotiating leverage, while branching out into different businesses.\n\nThe details: The insurer agreed to pay $48.75 a share in cash and 0.2434 of a newly issued share for each Express Scripts share. That\u2019s about $96.03 as of yesterday\u2019s close, a roughly 30 percent premium to Express Scripts\u2019 closing price.\n\nThe context: Cigna\u2019s planned sale to Anthem finally collapsed last year, as did Humana\u2019s sale to Aetna, which was then acquired by CVS.\n\nBy the Numbers: Cigna-Express Scripts and the M&A market\n\nCourtesy of our friends at Thomson Reuters:\n\n\u2022 At $69 billion, Cigna-Express Scripts would be the biggest deal of the year.\n\n\u2022 It is the 33rd deal valued at more than $5 billion announced this year. That is a record number for any year through March 8.\n\n\u2022 The value of those 33 transactions is $419 billion, or 53 percent of all acquisitions announced in 2018.\n\n\u2022 With nearly $800 billion in acquisitions announced globally this year, deal making is off to its best start since 2000.\n\nPhoto\n\nActivists press Visa to stop assault rifle sales\n\nProtesters plan to gather at the payment processor\u2019s headquarters in Foster City, Calif., at 11 a.m. P.T. today to demand that such companies stop doing business with sellers of assault-style rifles. It\u2019s a demonstration that grew out of Andrew\u2019s column last month arguing that the financial industry could help alter gun regulations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Lloyd Blankfein, the firm\u2019s chief executive of Goldman Sachs, had seized on the chance to bring back Ms. Powell, Bloomberg reports, in the hope that her experience in the White House would help the firm navigate the Trump presidency.\n\nBut the move has not sat well with some at the bank. Bloomberg reports:\n\n\u201cThe decision to create a new seat on the committee for an executive whose prior experience at Goldman Sachs centered on philanthropy and related initiatives has become a topic of debate inside its hyper-competitive headquarters in lower Manhattan. Before joining the White House last year, Powell\u2019s projects included helping small businesses and charities. Adding that background to a board stocked mostly with profit producers serving elite global clients is frustrating some top executives, people close to the situation said, asking not to be identified describing private conversations.\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 President Trump went against legal counsel and asked witnesses in Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation what the special counsel had asked. The person said the group vetted allegations before making them public.\n\nCritics, including women who work with agencies, say it\u2019s trial by social media.\n\nElsewhere in misconduct: Two directors at Wynn Resorts said they would step down in the wake of the Steve Wynn scandal. And the head of the U.S. Forest Service resigned amid sexual harassment accusations.\n\nPhoto\n\nRobert Smith speaks about his philanthropy\n\nHis day job is head of Vista Equity Partners, one of the top-performing private equity firms. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "The Leeway in President Trump\u2019s Tariff Order: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Say the word \u201cmeme\u201d and most people think of funny videos that go viral or assaults by internet trolls on platforms like 4chan, a website frequented by alt-right groups. President Trump, who regularly retweets memes, many of them directed at Democrats, is perhaps the most famous devotee of the form.\n\nMemes are powerful tools for communicating ideas, a fact Mr. Trump seems to understand better than many of his critics. One needs only to look at the reach of the Russian government\u2019s memes to understand why it exploited the form in trying to influence the 2016 election.\n\nThe term \u201cmeme\u201d was first coined by the evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins in his book \u201cThe Selfish Gene.\u201d Successful memes, he believed, had common elements: They were long-lived and could be copied easily and disseminated widely. The rate at which memes were created increased exponentially with the advent of the internet and social media.\n\nInternet memes typically combine text with images or video, often humorous in nature. And because video is rich in information, it makes memes particularly effective in conveying snappy ideas, such as political expressions like \u201cfake news\u201d or mocking nicknames like \u201cCrooked Hillary\u201d or \u201cthe Amazon Washington Post\u201d favored by the president.", "title": "Opinion | The Left Shouldn\u2019t Be Too Proud to Meme", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "It allegedly performed tests on non-Theranos equipment without telling representatives of a pharmacy company that was poised to invest money in the company.\n\nBased on Holmes\u2019 presentation, Pharmacy A executives understood that the blood from their demonstration samples would be tested on Theranos\u2019 miniLabs. Holmes never told the executives that Theranos was actually testing some of their blood on modified third party analyzers.\n\nTheranos allegedly distributed fake reports by pharmaceutical companies.\n\nInvestors believed that pharmaceutical companies had written their own endorsements of Theranos\u2019 technology, when the pharmaceutical companies had not.\n\nTheranos allegedly made misleading statements about its work with the United States Department of Defense.\n\nWhile Theranos\u2019 technology was used in a D.O.D. burn study, it was never deployed by the D.O.D. in the battlefield, in Afghanistan, or on medevac helicopters. From 2011 to 2014, Holmes had discussions with multiple divisions of the D.O.D. However, Theranos generated only approximately $300,000 from three D.O.D. contracts.\n\nMs. Holmes allegedly told an investor Theranos expected to expand quickly in the stores of a pharmacy chain, but the likelihood of such an expansion was small.\n\nHolmes was aware that Theranos\u2019 retail roll out with Pharmacy A was stalled due to, among other issues, some concerns Pharmacy A executives had with regard to Theranos\u2019 performance.\n\nThe Food and Drug Administration communicated to Theranos that its approval would be needed, but Ms. Holmes allegedly told investors afterward that F.D.A. approval was merely voluntary.\n\nHolmes\u2019 statements that Theranos did not need F.D.A. approval or clearance were important to investors because approval or clearance would have been an obstacle in the company\u2019s path to realizing full commercialization.\n\nMs. Holmes allegedly gave investors fake financial results.\n\nHolmes also provided historical financial information to one potential investor. In August 2015, Holmes met with a potential investor, during which she provided Theranos\u2019 financial results for fiscal year 2014. These financials showed 2014 net revenues of $108 million, and 2015 and 2016 net revenue projections of $240 million and $750 million, respectively. But Theranos\u2019 actual financial performance bore no resemblance to the financial information Holmes shared with investors. Theranos recorded little more than $100,000 in revenue in 2014 and was nowhere near generating $100 million in revenue by the end of 2014\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nSpotting a fraud\n\nThere is an old adage that if it sounds too good to be true, it isn\u2019t. The case filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Theranos and Elizabeth Holmes describes a litany of falsehoods about a claimed revolutionary method to conduct blood tests that turned out to be pure fiction.\n\nMs. Holmes and the company settled the case, although the former president, Ramesh \u201cSunny\u201d Balwani, is fighting the charges. She will pay a $500,000 penalty, return her shares in Theranos, and agreed to a ban on serving as an officer or director of a public company for 10 years.\n\nWhat makes this case interesting is that Theranos was one of the original unicorns, a private company with a value of more than $1 billion. We usually see the S.E.C. pursue charges against public companies and their executives, while private firms operate largely free from scrutiny \u2013 at least until they prepare for an I.P.O.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe antifraud provisions of the federal securities laws, however, apply to any transaction in a security in which there is a misstatement of material fact. Thus, when Theranos raised millions of dollars by selling shares to hedge funds and venture capitalists, the false claims about the viability of its blood-testing labs ended up being a scheme to defraud.\n\nFor Ms. Holmes, the settlement means that she will be cut off from raising money for any new venture for a long time. The complaint shows a systemic effort to deceive investors over a number of years, no doubt in a desperate hope that somehow the technology could be made to work. It is unlikely anyone in Silicon Valley or on Wall Street will trust her again.\n\n\u2014 Peter J. Henning\n\nPresident Trump plans to tap Larry Kudlow.\n\nMr. Kudlow, in an interview with The Wall Street Journal, said that Mr. Trump offered him the job as director of the National Economic Council and that he immediately accepted. Mr. Kudlow told The Journal that an announcement could come as early as Thursday.\n\n\n\nReaction\n\nMark Hamrick, Bankrate.com\u2019s senior economic analyst:\n\n\u201cIt remains to be seen whether Kudlow can step into the role of a virtual moderating influence in this administration. Unlike others in this White House, he does have experience in government and the private sector. But unlike television where on-air conflict is sometimes mostly for show, the health of the national and global economy is at stake here.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWas Bear a bad deal for JPMorgan?\n\nTen year\u2019s ago almost to the day, JPMorgan Chase acquired Bear Stearns, a troubled investment bank, for what looked like a steal. But Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan\u2019s C.E.O., has since said he wouldn\u2019t do a deal like it again, citing the high legal costs that came later.\n\nBut was buying Bear Stearns as bad a deal as Mr. Dimon suggests?\n\nWhile we don\u2019t have all the numbers necessary for a full accounting, there is much in the public domain that can help answer this question. And this information suggests that, while the Bear Stearns acquisition probably wasn\u2019t as profitable as expected in March 2008, JPMorgan may still have benefited from it \u2014 even after taking into account the legal expenses.\n\nWhat caused the legal costs and how big were they? The payouts were made mostly to settle allegations that Wall Street firms had stuffed loans into mortgage-backed bonds that did not meet agreed upon standards. How big were those costs? In his 2015 letter to shareholders, Mr. Dimon said that some 70 percent of JPMorgan\u2019s nearly $19 billion in mortgage-related legal costs were related to Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual, the thrift JPMorgan also bought during the crisis. For the sake of argument, let\u2019s assume that 35 percent of that $19 billion stemmed from Bear Stearns\u2019 mortgages. The cost to JPMorgan then would be around $6.7 billion.\n\nThat\u2019s a lot, but when JPMorgan did the deal, it agreed to terms that gave it a lot of financial protection against nasty surprises like this.\n\nJPMorgan paid $1.5 billion for Bear Stearns, far below the $11.8 billion of shareholders\u2019 equity that Bear Stearns reported on its balance sheet at the end of 2007. This wide margin for error would have helped the bank absorb the $6 billion of merger-related costs that executives anticipated in March 2008.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrue, JPMorgan almost certainly ended up marking down Bear Stearns\u2019 riskier assets by more than expected in the months after the deal, when market conditions got even worse. But many of these assets could have recovered in the next few years as the financial system stabilized. After 2008, \u201cprincipal transactions\u201d at JPMorgan\u2019s investment bank, the business line that included the performance of many of Bear Stearns\u2019 assets, produced over $8 billion of annual revenue, far more than the $4.4 billion that JPMorgan on its own generated in 2007.\n\nLet\u2019s also not forget that the Federal Reserve took a large slug of the risk in the deal. The Fed made an extraordinary loan to a special entity that bought some $30 billion of Bear Stearns\u2019 assets. According to Kate Kelly\u2019s book on Bear Stearns\u2019 final days, JPMorgan was reluctant to buy Bear Stearns without assistance from the Fed. JPMorgan did provide a $1.2 billion loan to the Fed\u2019s entity, in theory exposing it to some losses on the assets. But in the end, that loan generated a $665 million gain for JPMorgan in 2012.\n\nThe Bear Stearns deal also came with some straightforward positives. JPMorgan, for instance, got Bear Stearns\u2019 leading prime brokerage unit, a business that provided brokerage services to hedge funds. That and other Bear Stearns operations were expected to add at least $1 billion a year to JPMorgan earnings, the bank\u2019s executives said at the time.\n\nAnd, of course, JPMorgan scooped up Bear Stearns\u2019 trophy tower in Midtown Manhattan. At the time of the deal, the building, at 383 Madison Ave., had an estimated value of $1.2 billion. According to the estimates of developers in the New York real estate market, the building is now worth at least $1.8 billion.\n\n-- Peter Eavis with reporting from Charles V. Bagli.\n\nPhoto\n\nA former Equifax executive is charged with insider trading.\n\nJun Ying, the former chief information officer of Equifax\u2019s core United States consumer reporting division, was charged on Wednesday with insider trading for selling nearly $1 million in company stock after he learned about a major data breach in 2017 but before it was publicly announced.\n\nCybertrails\n\nThe commission\u2019s complaint against Mr. Ying describes a step he took to estimate what he might lose on his Equifax stock. He took to the internet to find out what had happened to the shares of Experian, a rival credit bureau, after it revealed that hackers had breached its system.\n\nAt approximately 10:00 a.m. on Monday, August 28, 2017, Ying used a search engine to find information on the internet concerning the September 2015 cybersecurity breach of Experian, another one of the three major credit bureaus, and the impact that breach had on Experian\u2019s stock price. The search terms used by Ying were: (1) \u201cExperian breach\u201d; (2) \u201cExperian stock price 9/15/2015\u201d; and (3) \u201cExperian breach 2015.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nBroadcom highlights a new age of tech protectionism\n\nWhen he killed Broadcom\u2019s pursuit of Qualcomm, President Trump put his administration in uncharted territory. The White House has made no secret of its concerns about Beijing, and seems to have been motivated by the prospect of Qualcomm losing its lead in 5G.\n\nSome now worry that this could be another front in a potential global trade war. Here\u2019s Jason Furman, a senior economic adviser in the Obama White House, talking to the NYT:\n\n\u201cIf every country in the world conducted policy like that, it would make cross-border investment difficult to the detriment of American and foreign companies,\u201d Mr. Furman said. \u201cForeign direct investment is an important part of the strength of the U.S. economy.\u201d\n\nOf note: Qualcomm spent far more than Broadcom on lobbying.\n\nBroadcom officially withdrew its bid this morning.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s next for Qualcomm: The chip maker\u2019s Hail Mary \u2014 petitioning the government for a national-security review of Broadcom\u2019s bid \u2014 paid off handsomely. But now it has to show investors that it can fix its business.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take: National champions have to deliver. Will Qualcomm become less efficient under the government\u2019s protection? If so, U.S. tax payers may feel taken advantage of.\n\nElsewhere in semiconductors: The industry largely ignored a short seller\u2019s report on purported security flaws in AMD chips. (Axios)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Boeing could suffer in a Trump trade war\n\nPresident Trump announced his metals tariffs to protect American makers of aluminum and steel. But that could put Boeing in the firing line \u2014 America\u2019s top exporter, which employs nearly as many people as the U.S. steel and aluminum industries combined.\n\nMore from Natalie Kitroeff of the NYT:\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really worried about what it\u2019s going to do to us,\u201d said James Springer, a mechanic who installs stow bins and class dividers on 787 Dreamliners at Boeing\u2019s plant in North Charleston, S.C. \u201cWhat will the E.U. and China do, especially China? They are one of our biggest customers now.\u201d\n\nAnd Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks on Chinese metal production are in some ways a relic of past trade battles, as Beijing moves away from basic commodities.\n\nElsewhere in trade: Marco Rubio argues in an NYT Op-Ed that the U.S. should take measures more targeted than the tariffs to punish China for unfair trade practices. And our columnist Eduardo Porter explains the ways countries \u2014 and companies like Ford \u2014 have gamed other tariffs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe politics flyaround\n\n\u2022 With Mike Pompeo due to replace Rex Tillerson at the State Department, the future of the Iran nuclear deal is in doubt, and renewed sanctions are more likely. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Democrat Conor Lamb has taken a small lead in the congressional special election in Pennsylvania; here\u2019s the NYT vote tracker.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Elizabeth Warren\u2019s attacks on fellow Democrats who support a loosening of Dodd-Frank regulations are annoying Chuck Schumer and Heidi Heitkamp.\n\n\u2022 The Republican leader of the House Intelligence Committee\u2019s inquiry into Russian electoral meddling softened his committee\u2019s conclusion that Russia did not work to undermine Hillary Clinton. Representative Trey Gowdy said it had.\n\nPhoto\n\nBear Stearns was a decade ago. Could it happen again?\n\nToday is the 10-year anniversary of the investment bank, on the verge of bankruptcy, seeking a lifeline from JPMorgan Chase. These days, however, there\u2019s little appetite for an extraordinary government-assisted of a bailout of a troubled financial firm \u2014 and post-crisis regulations are meant to eliminate the need for one.\n\nHere\u2019s what Rodge Cohen, Wall Street\u2019s longtime favorite consigliere, told Justin Baer and Ryan Tracy of the WSJ:\n\n\u201cNobody will ever again buy a severely troubled institution,\u201d he says. \u201cPeriod.\u201d\n\nThe problem: Wall Street\u2019s new defenses haven\u2019t been tested. And today\u2019s algorithm-dominated markets give embattled firms far less time to work out their problems, as the WSJ points out.\n\nMore trivia: Yesterday was the 10-year anniversary of David Solomon of Goldman Sachs contacting his former firm to offer help. Mr. Solomon is now the heir apparent at Goldman.\n\nHas Trump been bad or good for deals?\n\nThe bad\n\nA deregulation-minded businessman in the White House was supposed to be a huge positive for the M. & A. community. Yet investment banks have already lost out on some big advisory fees. And then consider:\n\n\u2022 The blocking of the Qualcomm bid has raised uncertainty over cross-border acquisitions.\n\n\u2022 The battle between the Justice Department and AT&T over the $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner is heating up, with the first day of the trial set for Monday.\n\nAs Matt Levine writes in Bloomberg View, \u201cOne area where Donald Trump is more economically populist than I had expected is: He really does seem interested in blocking big mergers.\u201d\n\nThe good\n\nAnnounced deals so far this year are up 55 percent from the same time a year ago, according to Thomson Reuters. And the Republican tax overhaul has led other deal makers to feel better about opening their wallets. A survey of 500 U.S. companies by EY found that 42 percent of respondents intended to use their tax savings on M.&A., and 73 percent said that they planned to accelerate their deal strategies this year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, tax is not a driver of M. & A., but it certainly is a key element,\u201d Bill Casey, EY\u2019s Americas vice chair of transaction advisory services, told Michael.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 China\u2019s sovereign wealth fund has sold out of Blackstone, severing a longstanding relationship as tensions rise between the U.S. and China. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Elliott Management will use Prosperity Life, which it bought for just over $500 million, to strike more life insurance deals. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Two months after Jared Kushner joined the White House, Kushner Companies sold a stake in a Brooklyn building to a company controlled by the Japanese government. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Bill Ackman sold about $125 million worth of ADP shares as its stock rose. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 K.K.R. is considering a sale or an I.P.O. for Cognita schools, which could be valued at about $2.8 billion, according to unnamed sources. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nGoogle is banning Bitcoin ads\n\nThe ad giant has joined Facebook in restricting ads for virtual currencies. (Together the two companies account for most internet advertising.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne problem: \u201ccrypto-jacking,\u201d in which scammers steal the computing power of those who view their ads and use it to mine digital money. Google removed 130 million such ads last year.\n\nElsewhere in virtual currencies: Blythe Masters of Digital Asset Holdings is disappointed that gender diversity in the sector is even worse than in banking (she used to be at JPMorgan). And Coinbase has a Barclays bank account, which will simplify things for British customers.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 U.N. human rights experts investigating the possible genocide in Myanmar said that hate speech had spread on Facebook there. The investor Roger McNamee, a Facebook shareholder, accused Mark Zuckerberg of being insincere about fighting misinformation.\n\n\u2022 YouTube is trying to combat misinformation by linking to Wikipedia pages and other \u201cfact-based websites\u201d on videos that promote conspiracy theories. Its announcement drew criticism.\n\n\u2022 Amazon is recalling about 260,000 AmazonBasics battery packs because of potential fire and chemical burn risks. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe workplace issues flyaround\n\n\u2022 The architect Richard Meier has taken a six-month work leave after the NYT contacted him about accusations of sexual misconduct by five women.
