Tell them to sign up here.\n\nYou can find live updates throughout the day at nytimes.com/dealbook.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "The Lengths Theranos Went To: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "The John Grisham-worthy twist comes from the investigation of three rapes 1,300 miles away, in two suburbs and a city outside of Denver. The Police Departments in the three places in Colorado (Aurora, Golden and Westminster) pooled their clues and figured out they were probably looking for the same attacker. They found him \u2014 the break in the case came from a single detail about the spotting of a white truck. On the rapist\u2019s computer, they found the photos he took of Marie. Years later, here was incontrovertible proof that she had told the truth.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe parallel tales allow Miller and Armstrong to juxtapose the damage of a botched rape investigation and the triumph of careful and skilled police work. Though stranger rape isn\u2019t the norm for sexual assault, or the focus of the sexual misconduct fueling the #MeToo moment in which this book appears, it offers broadly relevant lessons. One of the valiant detectives in Colorado (this is a book that turns law enforcement characters into heroes) explains that her rule isn\u2019t simply \u201cbelieve your victim\u201d; it\u2019s \u201clisten and verify,\u201d which gives her space to refute or corroborate the account, depending on where the evidence takes her. Another detective in Aurora explains how he learned that there is no \u201cright way\u201d for a survivor to respond to an assault. The 65-year-old victim he interviewed was matter-of-fact rather than emotional, much like Marie, but he didn\u2019t discount her credibility, and that withholding of judgment helped catch the serial attacker.\n\nMiller and Armstrong point out a pattern in Lynnwood. The police there wrote off as unfounded 21 percent of the rape reports they received during the five years in which the book unfolds. That\u2019s five times the national average. An external reviewer said that if the two police officers who interrogated Marie hadn\u2019t documented their own \u201cbullying and coercive\u201d behavior, he \u201cwould have been skeptical\u201d that such conduct actually happened. Though Miller and Armstrong don\u2019t say so, it\u2019s one more telling illustration of who does or doesn\u2019t get the benefit of the doubt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the two officers who blew Marie\u2019s case comes across as a secondary villain. Jerry Rittgarn, who threatened Marie with jail if she failed a lie-detector test, left Lynnwood to work as a private investigator. He told Miller and Armstrong he would talk to them only if they paid him, while complaining about \u201cvictims who lie\u201d and \u201ca biased story.\u201d The other officer, however, is introspective enough to be the book\u2019s most complex figure. Sgt. Jeffrey Mason questioned whether he was qualified to do his job \u2014 after more than 20 years as a cop \u2014 when he learned he\u2019d helped prosecute a vulnerable rape victim. When Marie asked for an apology, he showed up and said he was sorry; she found him sincere. Peggy disappointed Marie at first with her muted response but then expressed her intense regret and worked to repair their relationship.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Lynnwood, the Police Department didn\u2019t fire or discipline anyone, but it did try to learn from its mistakes, Miller and Armstrong reassuringly report. Lynnwood added training on the effect of trauma, which can cause rape victims\u2019 memories to fragment, and adopted well-respected guidelines, which train police officers not to doubt a victim because he or she doesn\u2019t behave as expected and \u2014 crucially \u2014 not to accuse one of lying without definite proof.\n\nMiller and Armstrong tell their story plainly, expertly and well. It\u2019s gripping and needs no dressing up. More confusing accounts of sexual assault, in which consent is disputed with anguish in a toxic swirl of partying and hook-up culture, have become part of the landscape, especially on college campuses. These contested stories divide our sympathies and spur angry debates. The doubt that Marie confronted, on the other hand, leaves no trail of did he or didn\u2019t he. In its moral clarity, it\u2019s possible to find Miller and Armstrong\u2019s project comforting. There is a bad guy. His name is Marc O\u2019Leary. He\u2019s now in prison for life. (Actually, 327\u00bd years, so several lives.)\n\nMiller and Armstrong interviewed O\u2019Leary in prison but it seems, understandably, as if it was hard for them to get into his head. In recreated flashbacks that rely on phrases like \u201cthe beast wouldn\u2019t rest\u201d and \u201cthe monster would gather strength,\u201d the authors show him stalking women and breaking into their homes by night. All the while, O\u2019Leary was secretly operating a group of specialized porn sites. He was also playing guitar with his friends and planning to have a baby with his wife. \u201cIt sounds clich\u00e9, I guess, but it\u2019s really kind of an actual Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde in real life,\u201d O\u2019Leary said at his own trial. That plus some idea about the duality of man, which he got from reading Carl Jung, are about as deep as it gets.\n\nMiller and Armstrong teamed up for the project that became this book when they discovered they were working on it separately. Miller was reporting on the Colorado angle for ProPublica, an investigative news organization, and Armstrong was chasing Marie\u2019s story for the Marshall Project, a group that focuses on criminal justice journalism. They won a 2016 Pulitzer Prize for an article that led to this book (a Netflix series is also in the works).\n\nTwo years ago, \u201cThis American Life\u201d ran an episode (narrated by Armstrong and the producer Robyn Semien) that can serve as a nice companion to the book by giving us Marie\u2019s voice on tape. At 25, she is raw but also resilient. \u201cIt broke me,\u201d she said of the doubt she was raped and its repercussions. But when the police told her O\u2019Leary had been identified as her assailant, and that her criminal record would be expunged, she got her driver\u2019s license and then a job as a truck driver. She is now married and has two children. Marie is a testament to the harm of poor police work that derails a rape investigation. But she\u2019s also a person living her life. That\u2019s the larger lesson of a nonfiction narrative like this one: It continues, beyond a book\u2019s pages.", "title": "The Lesson Here Is Listen to the Victim", "authors": ["Emily Bazelon", "T. Christian Miller", "Ken Armstrong"]} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "Edward Sorel, a caricaturist and muralist, is the author and illustrator of \u201cMary Astor\u2019s Purple Diary.\u201d\n\nFollow New York Times Books on Facebook and Twitter, sign up for our newsletter or our literary calendar. And listen to us on the Book Review podcast.", "title": "The Literati: Going Wilde in America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "Two decades have passed since Joel and Ethan Coen introduced the world to the White Russian-slugging Jeffrey Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) \u2014 better known as the Dude \u2014 and the hair-trigger Vietnam vet Walter Sobchak (John Goodman). And in that time, \u201cThe Big Lebowski\u201d has become a dorm-room staple, inspired an annual festival and spawned a pseudo-religion called Dudeism. A clever riff on the gumshoe fiction of Raymond Chandler, \u201cLebowski\u201d made its widespread theatrical debut 20 years ago, and although the academy has certainly favored the Coens\u2019 more serious films, nothing has compared in terms of cultural impact.\n\nWhile wandering the offices of the other Jeffrey Lebowski, the Dude notices a plaque dedicated to a children\u2019s charity called the Little Lebowski Urban Achievers; so, too, are the annals of cinema full of Little Lebowskis \u2014 movies that seem to take cues from the philosophy and style of the Coens brothers\u2019 film. Much of \u201cLebowski\u201d concerns the Dude\u2019s reproductive fertility, and true to form, he has cinematic children scattered all over. Below, we\u2019ve identified 10 Little Lebowskis that are available to stream. Watch them all \u2014 \u201cif you\u2019re not into the whole brevity thing.\u201d\n\nIf You Miss the Hippie-Slacker California\n\nJoaquin Phoenix, left, in \u201cInherent Vice.\u201d Wilson Webb/Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018Inherent Vice\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis 2014 SoCal noir from Paul Thomas Anderson, based on the book by Thomas Pynchon, is set in the fictitious shoreside enclave of Gordita Beach in 1970, an exceedingly chilled-out community not too far removed from the oddball Los Angeles fringes later frequented by the Dude. A live-and-let-live hippie spirit links the Coens\u2019 Southern California of the \u201990s with Anderson\u2019s version of the \u201970s: As the spacey investigator Doc Sportello (Joaquin Phoenix) untangles a vast conspiracy, he encounters many like-minded burnouts who want nothing more than to kick back, smoke some dope and wax rhapsodical. One easily imagines a younger Dude wandering through a demonstration staged by the radicalized surf-rock saxophonist in \u201c Vice,\u201d Coy Harlingen (Owen Wilson).\n\nIf You Miss the Seedier California\n\nRyan Gosling, left, and Russell Crowe in \u201cThe Nice Guys.\u201d Daniel McFadden/Warner Bros.\n\n\u2018The Nice Guys\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: YouTube\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nExpand the interlude at the pornographer Jackie Treehorn\u2019s hedonistic beach soiree into a feature length film, and it would be something like this agreeably sleazy neo-noir from Shane Black. Ryan Gosling and Russell Crowe portray two mismatched investigators who clear a brutal swath through the adult film industry of 1970s Los Angeles in pursuit of a missing teenage girl \u2014 a milieu teeming with the type of scheming lowlifes who make patsies out of the Dude and Walter a few decades later. The Dude stumbles into this same surreal Hollywood underbelly and immediately wants to find an A.T.M. Black gleefully embraces it as well, with his aesthetic of pool parties, hillside mansions and chintzy baroque decadence. But he takes it a few shades darker.\n\n0\n\nIf You Like Stoner Humor\n\nSeth Rogen, left, and James Franco in \u201cPineapple Express.\u201d Dale Robinette/Columbia Pictures\n\n\u2018Pineapple Express\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nBoth the Dude and Dale (Seth Rogen), the unmotivated process server stumbling his way through this brilliantly dim-witted farce from David Gordon Green, share a predilection for a certain kind of all-natural relaxation. But cannabis proves a fickle mistress for both men, leaving them slow on the uptake when they\u2019re thrust into high-pressure situations. In Dale\u2019s case, he endures a night-long freakout after getting an eyeful of a Mob murder, sending him and his volatile dealer, Saul (James Franco), on a mad scramble for their lives. Both films are keyed into a haziness of form that reflects its characters\u2019 favorite vice, with one scene melting into the next. Viewers may end up at some new juncture with little understanding of how they arrived \u2014 but happy to be there.\n\nIf You Want Another Coen-Bridges Collaboration\n\nHailee Steinfeld, left, and Jeff Bridges in \u201cTrue Grit.\u201d Lorey Sebastian/Paramount Pictures\n\n\u2018True Grit\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAfter creating the Dude, Jeff Bridges and the Coen brothers went their separate ways until 2010, when they reinterpreted the esteemed cowboy novel from Charles Portis (and not, they\u2019ll have you know, the 1969 film starring John Wayne). There\u2019s a knowing Dude-ness about Bridges\u2019s rendition of the loutish, eyepatch-wearing lawman Rooster Cogburn. He agrees to escort young Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) on her search for her father\u2019s killer, but he\u2019d rather spend his days puffing on his corncob pipe and slugging moonshine \u2014 the Old West version of the layabout individualism in \u201cLebowski.\u201d Ultimately, the Dude and Cogburn share a notion of duty, whether that means bringing a murderer to the gallows or ensuring that two rug-ruining thugs get their just deserts.\n\nIf You Liked the Slant on Film Noir\n\nJoseph Gordon-Levitt in \u201cBrick.\u201d Steve Yedlin/Focus Features\n\n\u2018Brick\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Starz, Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Coen brothers transplanted stock elements of film noir \u2014 the femme fatale, the double-cross, the red herring, the sweeping conspiracy \u2014 from the dank alleyways of the \u201940s to palm trees and strip malls of the \u201990s for \u201cLebowski.\u201d Rian Johnson\u2019s breakout debut, \u201cBrick,\u201d moves the same conventions into high school, where a bookish student named Brendan (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) tries to find his missing ex-girlfriend. Johnson\u2019s script has fun with the tough-guy language of Dashiell Hammett\u2019s private eyes, updating it to resemble more closely teen slang. The actors are young, but the perilous stakes and bruised cynicism are decidedly grown-up; the film chews Brendan up and spits him out, giving a hard-boiled edge to the usual coming-of-age narrative.\n\nIf You Want Another Bumbling Crime Yarn\n\nElijah Wood and Melanie Lynskey in \u201cI Don\u2019t Feel at Home in This World Anymore.\u201d Allyson Riggs/Netflix\n\n\u2018I Don\u2019t Feel at Home in This World Anymore\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Netflix\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIncompetence fuels the comic engine that makes \u2018Lebowski\u2019 so entertaining; it wouldn\u2019t be as fun if the Dude had even the slightest clue how to handle a hostage negotiation. Likewise, the assistant nurse in this film (Melanie Lynskey) doesn\u2019t let her lack of experience stop her from taking the law into her own hands after her apartment gets ransacked. Undaunted, she teams up with her unstable, nunchuck-wielding neighbor (Elijah Wood) and promptly gets in way over her head with a cadre of local criminals who have no intention of taking it easy on her. As in \u201cLebowski,\u201d the collision of poorly considered amateur heroics and the violent realities of criminal life makes for a potent combination of humor and brutality.\n\nIf You\u2019re Searching for the Dude\u2019s Closest Descendant\n\nAdam Driver in \u201cPaterson.\u201d Mary Cybulsky/Amazon Studios \u2014 Bleecker Street\n\n\u2018Paterson\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: iTunes, Vudu\n\n\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Dude is a humble creature of habit \u2014 most days he drinks the same cocktail, goes to the same bowling alley, wears the same sweater-robe. Paterson, the protagonist of Jim Jarmusch\u2019s \u201cPaterson,\u201d adheres to a similarly rigid routine: Each day, he drives his bus route through Paterson, N.J., dotes on his wife (Golshifteh Farahani), feeds their dog and treats himself to a single beer. Adam Driver took more than a few strands of the Dude\u2019s DNA when creating this soulful blue-collar poet, imbuing him with a quiet, Zen-like wisdom and a contentment with his lot in life. Both films test the happy stasis these kindred spirits enjoy, breaking their routines and watching as they adapt to new responsibilities. (Paterson has a slightly easier time; his predicaments don\u2019t involve German nihilists.)\n\nIf You Like the Layered Weirdness\n\nJohn Malkovich and Catherine Keener in \u201cBeing John Malkovich.\u201d Universal Studios\n\n\u2018Being John Malkovich\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nOne reason the \u201cLebowski\u201d fan base is so vast and intense is the Coens\u2019 symbol-laden approach. It\u2019s good sport obsessing over the Dude\u2019s journey as a revision of the Western, or as a thinly veiled commentary on American foreign policy, or as a surrealist parable about masculine anxiety. This feature debut from director Spike Jonze and its ingenious premise \u2014 What if crawling into a mysterious portal put you inside the actor John Malkovich\u2019s head for 15 minutes? \u2014 also provides fertile ground for multiple readings. Equal parts rom-com, corporate thriller and heady psychological experiment, the dense script, written by Charlie Kaufman (\u201cEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind\u201d), draws from Freud and Jung, transgender theory and numerology, arcana and myth.\n\nIf You Loved the Unlikely Criminals\n\nRiley Keough in \u201cLogan Lucky.\u201d Claudette Barius/Fingerprint Releasing\n\n\u2018Logan Lucky\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Amazon Prime, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nWalter has experience in war, but he\u2019s still hilariously ill-equipped for an operation as delicate as a ransom handoff. The characters in this heist film from Steven Soderbergh, set in North Carolina, are the inverse: outwardly unskilled hayseeds who execute a complicated theft with finesse. A motley crew of rural types (a strong ensemble including Channing Tatum, Adam Driver, Riley Keough and Daniel Craig) pool their wits to rip off the Charlotte Motor Speedway during the year\u2019s biggest Nascar race, each character contributing special skills or knowledge. Soderbergh mines no shortage of levity from the Southern eccentricities of the characters \u2014 the feral twins Fish and Sam could have stumbled in from a Coens film \u2014 but their talents always command a measure of respect.\n\nIf You\u2019re Into Dark Humor\n\nColin Farrell, left, and Brendan Gleeson in \u201dIn Bruges.\u201d Jaap Buitendijk/Focus Features\n\n\u2018In Bruges\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Starz, Amazon, iTunes, Vudu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cLebowski\u201d isn\u2019t shy about gallows humor: a gust of wind blows a cremated friend\u2019s remains into the Dude\u2019s face; a severed toe disrupts coffee at a \u201cfamily restaurant.\u201d This rip-roaring crime comedy from Martin McDonagh extends that impulse to the extreme, using gunshots the way other films use jokes. An Irish hit man and his prot\u00e9g\u00e9 (Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell) cool their heels in Belgium after a killing goes slightly awry, although trouble soon finds them, along with a body count of Shakespearean proportions. McDonagh\u2019s dialogue freely commingles wry knucklehead wit with fatalist musings on mortality and the Great Beyond. Not unlike the Dude, this film has a casual profundity, dropping kernels of insight as frequently as F-bombs.", "title": "The Little Lebowskis: 10 Righteous Heirs to a Coen Brothers\u2019 Classic", "authors": ["Charles Bramesco"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "PARK CITY, Utah \u2014 At the Sundance Film Festival here in January, executives at A24, the upstart movie and television studio, stood in the back of a makeshift theater looking as if they were about to be physically ill.\n\nA24\u2019s latest offering, \u201cEighth Grade,\u201d an intimate coming-of-age dramedy set for release in theaters on July 13, was minutes away from its festival premiere. What if the audience hated it? \u201cThis movie is just so personal for me,\u201d Nicolette Aizenberg, an A24 executive, said to someone who had just asked why she was quite literally shaking in her brown snow boots.\n\nThere was zero reason to worry: \u201cEighth Grade,\u201d directed by the 27-year-old comedian Bo Burnham, received sustained hoots of approval from the hipster attendees and universal raves from critics, likely setting up the film as another art house hit for A24, a little New York company that has \u2014 seemingly out of nowhere \u2014 established itself as Hollywood\u2019s leading tastemaker brand: Miramax for a new generation.\n\nSince starting five years ago, A24 has delivered one cultural thunderclap after another, peaking with \u201cMoonlight,\u201d last year\u2019s surprise winner (especially to the folks of \u201cLa La Land\u201d) of the Oscar for best picture. Other A24 hits over the past few years include \u201cSpring Breakers,\u201d about college girls who get mixed up with a messianic drug and arms dealer; the creepy-cool \u201cEx Machina,\u201d which introduced the future Oscar-winner Alicia Vikander to most viewers; \u201cThe Lobster,\u201d a dystopian cult favorite; and the Oscar-winning \u201cRoom\u201d (Brie Larson for best actress). Among the A24 films up for Oscars at this Sunday\u2019s Academy Awards ceremony are \u201cThe Disaster Artist\u201d (adapted screenplay) and \u201cThe Florida Project\u201d (Willem Dafoe, supporting actor).", "title": "The Little Movie Studio That Could", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "To reverse the trend, Mr. Lighthizer is trying to rewrite global trade rules in America\u2019s favor. He has found his trade policy soul mate in Mr. Trump, who has elevated Mr. Lighthizer\u2019s role and given him his blessing to embark on an unapologetic mission to take away advantages from countries and systems that both men believe have cheated the United States.\n\nThat includes preparing a major trade action against China, which Mr. Lighthizer has been working on for months and will be aimed at curbing intellectual property theft. It includes efforts to overhaul the World Trade Organization, which trading partners describe as a plan to strip away that organization\u2019s power and clout. But, mostly, it includes sprawling and contentious negotiations with South Korea over the future of its trade deal with the United States and, especially, with Canada and Mexico over the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nMr. Trump has dangled the potential for the two trading partners to be permanently exempt from the steel and aluminum tariffs, as long as they agree to a Nafta deal that satisfies the United States\u2019 demands. What that means, exactly, remains to be seen. The three countries have already been through seven rounds of negotiations over revising the 1994 pact, with little progress to show for it and fairly intractable views on several major provisions.\n\nMr. Lighthizer had a mixed view of the tariffs, supporting the plan during meetings in the Oval Office, but privately expressing concerns that broad measures could target allies rather than the real culprit, China, according to people familiar with his views who were not authorized to speak publicly.\n\nLike his boss, Mr. Lighthizer views China as the biggest offender in the global trading system, accusing the country of using state subsidies to build more factories than it needs and calling China\u2019s trade practices an \u201cunprecedented\u201d threat to the world trading system. He is spearheading an initiative to combat China\u2019s alleged theft of American trade secrets, an effort that may include tariffs on Chinese products and restrictions on Chinese investment flowing into the United States.\n\nAt times, Mr. Trump seems to have taken his China-bashing language straight from Mr. Lighthizer, including in late February when the president blamed the World Trade Organization for China\u2019s rise.\n\nIt is that combination of nationalist instincts and keen understanding of trade law that has aided Mr. Lighthizer\u2019s rise in the White House. Mr. Trump originally envisioned Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, as his trade czar and the person to coordinate trade policy across the government. But Mr. Ross drew the ire of the president as he failed to negotiate a sufficiently tough deal with the Chinese and faced allegations that he had inflated his wealth.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lighthizer has emerged as the indispensable adviser, espousing the type of get-tough views on China and other countries that were red meat to Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cBy virtue of his abilities, Lighthizer\u2019s profile is rising,\u201d said Gary Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. \u201cHis own description might be that he\u2019s very keen on seeing that the rights of U.S. firms are not trampled on, and that international competition is fair and balanced. To my way of thinking, that adds up to a polite way of saying \u2018protectionist.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was Mr. Lighthizer who was most influential in counseling the president to reject a deal Mr. Ross negotiated with the Chinese in July, according to people familiar with the discussions. Mr. Lighthizer persuaded the president that when the United States had engaged in talks with China in the past, China had failed to keep its end of the bargain.\n\nThat advice also shaped the president\u2019s trip to Asia in November. At a meeting in the Oval Office just before the trip began, Mr. Lighthizer argued against presenting the Chinese with a list of demands for access to the Chinese market, people briefed on the matter said.\n\nHe recited all the market-access negotiations between China and the United States \u2014 going back to China\u2019s entry into the World Trade Organization in 2001 \u2014 to make the point that none of them had prevented the trade deficit between the countries from ballooning.\n\nDuring Mr. Trump\u2019s 11-day trip to Asia, Mr. Lighthizer was never far from his side. With Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Gary D. Cohn, the chief economic adviser who said on Tuesday he would resign over the planned tariffs, both staying back in Washington to lobby Congress for tax cuts, Mr. Lighthizer was the most influential economic official on the trip, and he had extended access to the president.\n\nStill, Mr. Lighthizer has not shied away from using the threat of steel and aluminum tariffs in his Nafta negotiations. Speaking in Mexico City on Monday at the conclusion of the latest round, Mr. Lighthizer described the potential for an exclusion as a carrot, \u201can incentive to get a deal.\u201d To his counterparts, it was just the latest stick the Trump administration has used to bully them into acceding to United States demands.\n\nWith Nafta, Mr. Lighthizer has pursued significant reforms aimed at retracting global supply chains back into the United States, and removing what he describes as incentives for corporations to take their investments abroad. His approach has put him at odds with business groups, Republican lawmakers and foreign ministers. But Mr. Lighthizer seems emboldened, not cowed, by the conflict. He has criticized foreign counterparts and dismissed the requests of Republican lawmakers who want the United States to avoid sinking trade deals that have been good for companies in their states.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRufus Yerxa, the president of the National Foreign Trade Council, which represents major American exporters, said Mr. Lighthizer shared \u201ca certain common theme\u201d with many of the hard-line trade advisers surrounding Mr. Trump: that \u201cthe United States has lost its greatness because it\u2019s lost many of its basic industries.\u201d\n\nMr. Yerxa added that the modern economy contradicted that argument. \u201cLook at the six or seven biggest companies in America: Most of those are bigger than the steel industry,\u201d he said. \u201cThose are the ones that are globally oriented, export-oriented. I don\u2019t think this crowd of people understand these industries.\u201d\n\nMr. Lighthizer set the stage for a tough negotiation in August, when he said his criticisms of Nafta echoed those of the president, who was \u201cnot interested in a mere tweaking\u201d of the agreement. \u201cWe feel that Nafta has fundamentally failed many, many Americans and needs major improvement,\u201d Mr. Lighthizer said.\n\nHe has also been unsparing in his criticism of American companies that benefit from Nafta, likening the pact to \u201csugar\u201d that lures businesses to invest in Canada and Mexico, rather than the United States. He describes his mission as winning broader support from American businesses and workers, rather than the narrow pro-trade lobby that he says currently benefits from the pact.\n\n\u201cIf you can get some labor unions on board, Democrats on board, mainstream Republicans on board, I think you can get big numbers,\u201d Mr. Lighthizer said in Montreal in January. \u201cIf you do, that\u2019s going to change the way all of us look at these kind of deals.\u201d\n\nBut to get there, he has said that the companies that currently benefit from the pact may have to surrender some of their advantages.\n\nThat view has been deeply unpopular with free-trade Republicans in Congress, as well as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. The chamber, which usually operates in lock step with a Republican White House, argues that the drastic changes Mr. Lighthizer has proposed \u2014 like tightening the rules for manufacturing cars in North America, or scrapping a process for settling investment disputes that bypasses American courts \u2014 could destabilize American industry and the economy.\n\nLast year, the chamber began deriding those ideas as \u201cpoison pills\u201d for their potential to kill Nafta. A spokeswoman for Mr. Lighthizer fired back by saying the Trump administration always knew that it would be controversial to drain the swamp.\n\nMr. Lighthizer has taken a similarly tough line with Republican lawmakers. On a visit to Capitol Hill in October to meet with House Republicans about Nafta, lawmakers expressed concerns over controversial provisions like a five-year sunset clause that would cause the deal to automatically expire unless it was renewed, and a requirement that all automobiles sold under Nafta have a certain amount of American-made content.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen lawmakers cautioned Mr. Lighthizer that a Nafta deal with those provisions was unlikely to get enough votes in Congress, he responded that he had an \u201caudience of one\u201d to please, a reference to Mr. Trump.\n\n", "title": "The Little-Known Trade Adviser Who Wields Enormous Power in Washington", "authors": ["Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "PYEONGCHANG, South Korea \u2014 When the Olympics conclude and the assembled news media depart, the venues in the host city are not razed, the volunteers do not scatter and the appetite for more competition does not wane. Another major international sporting event is in the offing.\n\nThat is when I pack my bags and go.\n\nOn the evening of March 4, nearly 23 hours after I left my home, I arrived at my accommodations here, to cover my third consecutive Paralympics, the Olympics for athletes with impairments.\n\nIt is one of my favorite assignments, a refreshing break from covering the N.F.L.\n\nAccess need not be negotiated. The press attach\u00e9s are helpful. One-on-one interviews are plentiful. And the athletes are gracious and obliging, eager to discuss more than just their performance \u2014 which, for my purposes, is critical.\n\nThe directive from my editors is at once specific and nebulous, but it can be distilled into this: Feel free to explore a range of subjects and trends \u2014 \u00e0 la my recent article on how skiers who endured horrific collisions at the Sochi Paralympics in Russia four years ago conquered self-doubt and psychological anguish to compete in these Games \u2014 but don\u2019t write traditional profiles of particular athletes, no matter how compelling their back stories may be.", "title": "The Loneliness of the American Paralympics Reporter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "If the price elasticity of import demand is around 1, which is a typical estimate for the short-to-medium run, a 20 percent across the board tariff might, other things equal, be enough to close the gap. But other things would very much not be equal.\n\nLeave aside the issue of foreign retaliation/emulation, although that would be a very big deal in practice. Assume instead that the U.S. gets away with it, with no foreign response. Even so, this wouldn\u2019t work out the way Trump imagines.\n\nYou see, diverting demand equal to 3 percent of GDP from foreign to domestic products would not increase US output by 3 percent relative to what it would have been otherwise, let alone the 4.5 percent you\u2019d expect if there\u2019s a multiplier effect. Why? Because the US is close to full employment. Maybe \u2013 maybe \u2013 we have another half-point of unemployment to go. But a 3 percent rise in output relative to trend would reduce unemployment about 3 times that much, 1.5 percentage points. And that just isn\u2019t going to happen.", "title": "Opinion | The Macroeconomics of Trade War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor her spring men\u2019s wear collection, Miuccia Prada cinched jumpsuits at the midriff and tucked jackets into high-rise (and twice-belted) waistbands. Rick Owens sliced his pants even higher \u2014 grandpa-high \u2014 so that they pinched right under the ribcage, and Dior Homme showed a jacket that emulated the exaggerated, hip-jutting form of the brand\u2019s famous Bar silhouette for women, which Christian Dior introduced in 1947. Nipped waists have long represented femininity incarnate \u2014 think of Scarlett O\u2019Hara\u2019s famously petite Civil War-era midriff (17 inches), or the elaborate stays and busks worn by Elizabeth I, despite her claim that she had the stomach of a king. What does it say about the contemporary man that variations on the theme are now in for him?\n\nPhoto\n\nAt Dior, the fact that a signature piece can so easily transgress the gender divide speaks to the value of heritage. A lot of things manage to do that nowadays, true, but the male waist trend only seems like another step toward neutered androgyny. This is not a look that erases sex, but rather emphasizes it. A Barbie doll\u2019s waist comes to a near V; so does Action Man\u2019s, an ideal propagated in Ancient Greece and revived in the 19th century (when men wore their own corsets). And so the silhouette hints at a different kind of gender fluidity altogether, one based on the notion that the shapes defining the hyper-masculine and the \u00fcber-feminine are remarkably similar. The British designer Antony Price knew as much when, in the mid-\u201970s, he dressed both Bryan Ferry and his girlfriend Jerry Hall in broad-shouldered and slinky-hipped ensembles that would come to symbolize glam rock itself. Grace Wales Bonner and Sarah Burton of Alexander McQueen understand it now \u2014 both use age-old tailoring techniques to carve out severe, body-centric shapes for men and women alike.\n\nPerhaps the pulled-in midsection is a reflection of international belt-tightening, as more and more nations adopt grim austerity measures. Yet self-restraint can have a sort of allure. Certainly it\u2019s a quality we\u2019re craving from our political leaders, and so maybe the wasp-waisted look is on some level oppositional, a subtle jab at the conservative fat cats.", "title": "The Male Waist Comes Back Into View", "authors": ["Alexander Fury", "Notes On The Culture"]} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "GLOUSTER, Ohio \u2014 At first, the experiment didn\u2019t have a name.\n\nRight after the election, Erik Hagerman decided he\u2019d take a break from reading about the hoopla of politics.\n\nDonald Trump\u2019s victory shook him. Badly. And so Mr. Hagerman developed his own eccentric experiment, one that was part silent protest, part coping mechanism, part extreme self-care plan.\n\nHe swore that he would avoid learning about anything that happened to America after Nov. 8, 2016.\n\n\u201cIt was draconian and complete,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not like I wanted to just steer away from Trump or shift the conversation. It was like I was a vampire and any photon of Trump would turn me to dust.\u201d\n\nIt was just going to be for a few days. But he is now more than a year into knowing almost nothing about American politics. He has managed to become shockingly uninformed during one of the most eventful chapters in modern American history. He is as ignorant as a contemporary citizen could ever hope to be.", "title": "The Man Who Knew Too Little", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-24 00:00:00", "text": "When I stepped into his living room, I didn\u2019t even recognize him. Surrounded by his family, he looked happy and relaxed, so different from when I\u2019d seen him in the clinic. He was wearing a vest to hold his batteries, and I could see part of the device bulging under his white T-shirt, but only if I looked closely.\n\nI settled into the seat he offered me and introduced myself to his sisters while he ducked into the kitchen to pull a steaming plate of baked potatoes, chives and sour cream out of the oven. He had found the recipe on Facebook, he explained. He was eager for us to try it.\n\nAs the plate cooled, he showed me around, down the narrow hallway to the bedroom, where he connected himself to a wall socket each night so his batteries could recharge. Limited to the electric cord\u2019s 20-foot radius, he was \u201clike a dog on a leash,\u201d until the morning. Luckily, his house was small enough that he could make it from the bedroom to the kitchen even when he was plugged in. The bathroom was even closer.\n\nOne time, he woke up at 2 a.m. to a jarring noise. Thinking there might be something wrong with his VAD, he changed his connection from the wall unit to a set of batteries. The sound continued. Frustrated, he fiddled around with the machine, doing things he definitely wasn\u2019t supposed to do, and still it wouldn\u2019t stop. He dragged himself out of bed to call his VAD team.\n\nIt was only when he saw the receiver hanging off the hook that Mr. Chauvin realized the source of the noise \u2014 it had been the phone all along. As he told the story, his assembled family members laughed appreciatively, though they\u2019d heard it before. I found myself laughing too, briefly forgetting that he was talking about life or death, about a sound that could have meant he was moments away from collapse.\n\nThe laughter quieted and there was a break in our conversation. In the moment of stillness, I found that I was curious about Mr. Chauvin\u2019s pulse. I asked him if I could feel for it and, seemingly amused, he offered his hand. I placed my fingers on his wrist, where I am used to feeling the rhythmic pulsations of the radial artery. But because the device moved blood through his vessels at a continuous, stable rate of flow rather than the pumping of a normal heart, melding human and machine, I found that I couldn\u2019t feel a thing.\n\nBy the time we met, it had been more than five years since Mr. Chauvin\u2019s heart had started to fail and over a year since he\u2019d been told he wouldn\u2019t get a transplant. So I asked him what it had been like to learn that he would spend the rest of his life with this machine, that the equipment would be with him until he died. That if he were to follow his doctors\u2019 instructions to the letter, he would never be able to shower the way he liked or take his boat out on the lake. I wondered if he regretted his decision, if he had been angry.\n\nBut Mr. Chauvin surprised me. He had a hole in his stomach and a vest to carry his batteries and a cord that tethered him at night and the ever-present threat of a stroke or a bleed or a problem with the machine. But without the uncertainty of a transplant that might or might not come, he had found that he was now free to focus on enjoying his life for what it was. Sometimes that meant bending the rules.", "title": "Opinion | The Man With the Battery-Powered Heart", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-02 00:00:00", "text": "When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Wednesday night that he had chosen Alberto M. Carvalho, the charismatic superintendent of Miami-Dade County Public Schools, as his new schools chancellor, it seemed like a match made in heaven. Mr. Carvalho had an inspiring life story that mirrored the aspirations of many of New York City\u2019s families. On policy, he and Mr. de Blasio seemed well aligned.\n\nBut there were signs, it emerged on Friday, that the partnership \u2014 on both sides \u2014 might have been far less than perfect. Mr. de Blasio, the more eager suitor, chose to overlook them. Mr. Carvalho, in the end, did not, leading him to reject the mayor\u2019s job offer on Thursday.\n\nFor Mr. Carvalho, the red flags were indications that the mayor would heavily involve himself in the job, as he is known to do in other departments.\n\nFor City Hall, the warning signs were incidents in Mr. Carvalho\u2019s past \u2014 his jilting of another school district in 2008, and a scandal over emails that suggested he had conducted an affair with a Miami Herald education reporter, which he has denied. In fact, those two matters had kept Mr. Carvalho out of the running for another major education job in New York just three years ago.", "title": "The Match Seemed Perfect for New York\u2019s Schools. But There Were Red Flags.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "When I arrive at my daughter and son-in-law\u2019s Brooklyn apartment on Thursdays, my 18-month-old granddaughter hurtles toward me with her still lurch-y gait, happy for our weekly date.\n\nWhile her parents work, we spend the day doing toddler stuff \u2014 reading favorite books six times in a row, singing about spiders and stars, placing objects into containers and dumping them out again, going to the park, napping (baby, not Bubbe, alas). If we\u2019re lucky, I spend half an hour with the whole family, once my daughter gets home, then head back to my place in New Jersey.\n\nThe routine I call \u201cBubbe Day\u201d (for the Yiddish word for grandmother) has come to feel so natural that I never stopped to consider whether it would have unfolded differently if my granddaughter had been a son\u2019s child, not a daughter\u2019s. But it might well have.\n\nYou hear this often: Paternal grandparents tread very carefully, mindful that a daughter-in-law might not appreciate their overtures or their frequent presence, anxious that she could limit access to their grandkids.", "title": "The Maternal Grandparent Advantage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "When I asked the jovial manager, Laurence Desjardins, why the meal was such a marathon of Olympic endurance, she observed that in a French-speaking province surrounded by an English majority, the food reflected a culinary cri de coeur, an affirmation of Quebec identity that was akin to a giant exclamation point.\n\nThe Cabane also reflects another hallmark of Quebec, its spirit of generosity. Ms. Lawrence noted that Mr. Picard believed in \u201cabundance,\u201d and doesn\u2019t want diners to have to reach for anything. There is little chance of that when the entire table is blanketed with food.\n\nThe first warning of bacchanalian excess arrived with the first course, the triple-layer almond cake filled with foie gras, one layer with dates and another with cr\u00e8me de volaille. It took four hours to make the cake, which was followed by an entire pig conjured from foie gras.\n\nMost of the dishes were served, appropriately enough, on a tray made from tree bark. The tableware featured etchings of fornicating pigs. It was a vegetarian\u2019s apocalyptic nightmare. There were pigs everywhere, both on the plate and in the dining room.\n\nAnd just in case my stomach ran out of room, the waitress arrived periodically with a plastic funnel, of the type used to extract sap from a tree, so I could down a shot of cognac laced with maple syrup.\n\nAt the end of that meal, just when it seemed I was about to explode like a fattened goose on Christmas Eve, the desserts arrived, among them a rectangular plant holder containing what appeared to be snow filled with maple syrup and adorned with mint.\n\nEarlier, Mr. Picard had stopped by to warn me with a mischievous smile: \u201cYou won\u2019t be able to sleep tonight.\u201d\n\nIf the Cabane embodies Quebec, it is a Quebec of warmth, artistry, an ample supply of pigs and over-the-top expressionistic joy.", "title": "The Meal Began With a Foie Gras Cake. It Ended With Snow and Maple Syrup.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cParole Must Mean Something\u201d (editorial, March 19), about the New York State Parole Board\u2019s decision to grant parole to Herman Bell, who was convicted in the 1971 killings of two police officers:\n\nSince my retirement as a commissioner on the board, I have been advocating for the release of long-termers who are now aged or addled but transformed by time and maturity, and who pose no risk to the community. I can do this because I\u2019m not concerned about political fallout and my job security.\n\nSo I congratulate the board for its integrity in granting parole to Mr. Bell. The decision shows that the panel members understand their role: to assess the candidate\u2019s risk to the public after the person has served the court-determined sentence and to grant parole, with continued supervision in the community, unless the parole panel can articulate clearly why the person poses a threat.\n\nThis job does not include re-sentencing because of the nature of a crime; your editorial is entirely correct that \u201cvengeance is not supposed to guide a system of justice.\u201d Victims who call for eternal lockup should also know that vengeance doesn\u2019t heal.\n\nBARBARA HANSON TREEN\n\nOGUNQUIT, ME.", "title": "Opinion | The Meaning of Parole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-11 00:00:00", "text": "The president sees the final destination as the \u201cultimate deal,\u201d but many analysts regard it as the ultimate lost cause. The effort comes as Mr. Trump is trying to tackle another intractable problem, North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons program, accepting an invitation last week to meet the North\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, sometime in the next three months for negotiations.\n\nTo lay the groundwork in the Middle East, the White House is convening a conference on Tuesday to discuss ways to ease the humanitarian crisis in Gaza. But the Palestinian Authority said on Saturday that it would boycott the meeting.\n\nWhile officials declined to discuss the plan\u2019s content, in keeping with the veil of secrecy they have kept over it since Mr. Trump took office, they said it would not have a set of guiding principles, like the Arab Peace Initiative, first endorsed by the Arab League in 2002, which sketched out the broad contours of an accord and left the details for the two sides to fill in.\n\nFor example, the plan will not call for a two-state solution as one of its goals, though it will prescribe pathways for the creation of two states. Nor will it call for a \u201cfair and just solution\u201d for Palestinian refugees, though it will offer steps to deal with the issue of refugees.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides described a multipage document, with annexes, that proposes solutions to all the key disputes: borders, security, refugees and the status of Jerusalem. They predicted that the Israelis and the Palestinians would each find things in the plan to embrace and oppose.\n\nIn delving into the fine details, the White House is turning the traditional formula for peacemaking on its head. Previous presidents, from Bill Clinton to George W. Bush, avoided going beyond broad strokes for fear that it would give both sides more to object to. But officials said that was no longer sufficient.\n\nThe aides who wrote the plan \u2014 Jared Kushner, Jason D. Greenblatt and David M. Friedman \u2014 had no experience in diplomacy when they took up their jobs. Mr. Kushner is Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser; Mr. Greenblatt was the chief legal officer of the Trump Organization; and Mr. Friedman is a bankruptcy lawyer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNobody outside the administration has seen the document, officials said, though Mr. Kushner, Mr. Greenblatt and Mr. Friedman met for several hours with Mr. Netanyahu at Blair House, near the White House, last Sunday, the day before he met with Mr. Trump.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Sunday, Mr. Netanyahu told his cabinet that \u201cthere is no concrete U.S. peace plan on the table,\u201d according to an Israeli television station, Channel 10 News. American officials said their planning was not dictated by foreign leaders.\n\nFor his part, Mr. Trump still sounds committed. Welcoming the prime minister to the Oval Office, he insisted that he still had a \u201cvery good chance\u201d to broker an accord. \u201cThe Palestinians, I think, are wanting to come back to the table very badly,\u201d he said.\n\nThere is little evidence to support that. By recognizing Jerusalem, and speeding up plans to move the American Embassy there from Tel Aviv, the United States has forfeited its role as a credible broker, the Palestinians say. They have put their energies into trying to enlist other countries to replace the Americans.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s repeated declarations that he has taken Jerusalem \u201coff the table\u201d further antagonized the Palestinians, seeming to dash their aspirations to make the holy city the capital of a future Palestinian state.\n\nDiplomats from Arab countries said the Jerusalem decision had made it politically untenable for them to press the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, to return to the table because of the outcry it would cause within their own publics.\n\nMr. Trump and Mr. Kushner have invested a lot in developing relationships with Persian Gulf states like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. But officials said the White House was not counting on its Arab friends to promote the president\u2019s peace initiative.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides have faced other setbacks. Mr. Kushner was recently stripped of his top-secret security clearance, raising questions about his status as a top adviser and even his longevity in the White House. Officials said it would not hamper his ability to negotiate but could limit his access to sensitive intelligence.\n\nThe Gaza conference, which will be led by Mr. Kushner and Mr. Greenblatt, is designed to give momentum to efforts to stabilize the Palestinian territory, which has been racked by shortages of medicine and water after years of a blockade by Israel and Egypt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a recent op-ed article in The Washington Post, Mr. Greenblatt blamed Hamas, the militant group that rules Gaza, for the suffering there. But he said that Hamas\u2019s role did not \u201cabsolve us of the responsibility to try to help.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are beholden to find a path to a brighter future for the Palestinians of Gaza,\u201d he wrote.\n\nAlleviating the crisis in Gaza is important to the peace initiative, officials said, because any accord between Israel and the Palestinians that does not account for the territory is incomplete. For the White House, however, the more basic question is whether it can ever reconcile with the Palestinians.\n\nOn Saturday, a senior Palestinian official, Ahmed Majdalani, said the Palestinians had turned down the White House\u2019s invitation to attend the conference because America\u2019s goal was to \u201cliquidate the Palestinian national project.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides said they had not abandoned hope that the Palestinians would come back. But they acknowledged that they might have little choice but to release the plan and hope it is not rejected out of hand.", "title": "The Mideast Peace Plan Is Nearly Finished. Is It Dead on Arrival?", "authors": ["Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-03-01 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Generation Emerging From the Wreckage,\u201d by David Brooks (column, Feb. 27):\n\nAs one of the students who sat down with Mr. Brooks to share my worldview, I want to respond to his fascination with what makes my generation tick.\n\nAs I said during his student session at the University of Chicago, and as I was later quoted (unnamed) in his column, our generation is indeed \u201cundergoing a renegotiation of the terms of who is powerful.\u201d A critical part of this is giving a voice to those who have been disenfranchised in our world.\n\nMr. Brooks and I clearly have different views on American history. The American experience isn\u2019t retrospectively one of \u201cgratitude,\u201d as he posits; instead, many of my peers\u2019 grandparents were held in internment camps, marched for their own civil rights and had to fight the American government\u2019s best effort at erasure.\n\nWhy does he attribute my opinions to a lack of historical knowledge rather than engaging with the intricacies of the American experience? If he wants to understand millennials, he should create a real dialogue rather than dismissing their ideas as generational delusions.", "title": "Opinion | The Millennial Experience", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Second, the preferences of Obama-to-nonvoters are almost always closer to the preferences of Obama-to-Clinton voters than they are to Obama-to-Trump voters. For example, nearly three-quarters of Obama-to-Trump voters supported repeal of the A.C.A., while less than half of Obama-to-nonvoters did. The extremely high degree of support for repeal of the A.C.A. among Obama-to-Trump voters clearly played a role in the 2016 election and in the negative reaction to Mr. Obama among this group of voters more broadly. However, considering how strongly Obama-to-Clinton voters in particular favor the A.C.A., it is hard to imagine how Democrats could incorporate anti-A.C.A. voters into future Democratic coalitions.\n\nObama-to-nonvoters are most similar to Obama-to-Clinton voters on the minimum wage, though the proposal draws strong majority support from Obama-to-Trump voters as well. Obama-to-Trump voters are most out of line with the Democratic coalition on issues relating to race and gender. They are less supportive of a path to citizenship, and a supermajority (64 percent) of Obama-to-Trump voters support deporting undocumented immigrants. At 72 percent, Obama-to-nonvoters are also far more in favor of abortion rights than Obama-to-Trump voters are (55 percent). Over all, Obama-to-nonvoters are quite close to the emerging Democratic consensus on issues of class, race, gender and the environment.\n\nDemocratic strategists should recognize that Obama-to-Trump voters do not represent the future of their party. Obama-to-Trump voters diverge from the Democratic Party on many core issues, and in any case they are not particularly loyal Democrats: Less than one third of Obama-to-Trump voters supported Democrats down-ballot in 2016, and only 37 percent identify as Democrats.\n\nIn stark contrast, Obama-to-nonvoters share the progressive policy priorities of Democrats, and they strongly identify with the Democratic Party. Four out of every five Obama-to-nonvoters identify as Democrats, and 83 percent reported they would have voted for a Democrat down-ballot. A similar share of Obama-to-nonvoters said that they would have voted for Mrs. Clinton had they turned out to vote. In short, while reclaiming some Obama-to-Trump voters would be a big help to Democratic prospects, re-energizing 2012 Obama voters who stayed home is a more plausible path for the party going forward.\n\nWhether Democrats can mobilize these voters is an open question, however. Significantly, only 43 percent of Obama-to-nonvoters reported being contacted by a candidate in 2016, compared with 66 percent of Obama-to-Clinton voters. While analysts have focused on why many conservative voters switched to the Republican Party, a better question might be why a campaign that sought to energize young voters of color failed to do so. That\u2019s the question that will decide the future of American politics.\n\nGetting these voters to the polls on Election Day is the most important task for progressives. And given their outlook on the important issues of the day, Obama-to-nonvoters are also likely to be easier to mobilize after two years of a Trump presidency \u2014 never mind four.", "title": "Opinion | The Missing Obama Millions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "Of all the things that are passed on in New York \u2014 the names of good hairstylists, restaurant recommendations, professional contacts and parking secrets \u2014 perhaps the rarest and most valued is a good apartment. Who, in need of a new home, doesn\u2019t thrill to the news of a vacancy in a friend\u2019s building?\n\nTwo years ago, Nick Moran was on the receiving end of such good fortune. A friend with a two-bedroom in Astoria, Queens, was moving in with his girlfriend on the Upper West Side and asked if Mr. Moran, now 31, would like to take over the lease.\n\nMr. Moran, a musician who leads a nine-piece \u201cfunky blues band,\u201d was delighted. He had been living rent-free as a caretaker at a Harlem property, which enabled him to record his first album, but the situation was coming to an end. And he hadn\u2019t relished the idea of returning to his previous living situation: occupying \u201ca closet\u201d in a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, share that cost so much he had to work nights as a hotel doorman to pay the rent.\n\nThe Astoria apartment, with its two good-sized, windowed bedrooms and large closets (occupied only by possessions, not people), seemed ideal. And the rent was a reasonable $1,800 a month.", "title": "The Most Coveted Hand-Me-Down: An Apartment in the City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-04 00:00:00", "text": "It was raining in Paris on Sunday, just days after Europe had been colder than the North Pole. Extreme weather! We\u2019re living it. At Balenciaga, Demna Gvasalia dove right in.\n\nActually, what he did was build a giant faux mountain, covered with graffiti and spray-painted tags and rising out of a runway of spun-sugar snow. It took four weeks to construct in a large warehouse in St. Denis, on the outskirts of Paris. The show notes called it a \u201csnowboarding paradise.\u201d\n\nThen he built a collection to match, for both men and women.\n\nFrom the base of straight black trousers and a stretch velvet turtleneck, the arms extending into integral gloves, he draped the torso in tiny minidresses, added long jackets and single- or double-breasted coats with three-dimensional sculpted hips that stood out on their own, the effect created via precision molding and digital fitting. Floral pleated skirts were fused to suit jacket tops, quilted coats to mountain man plaid shirts, blanket plaid jackets given a tent-like curve in the back via a pleat at the shoulder blade \u2014 and then all the ideas and fabrics and snowboarding colors layered up, literally, so the neck disappeared like a turtle into a shell. Rarely has the cocoon coat been taken so literally, while maintaining its gracefully ironic profile.\n\nAmid it all were some shirts and fanny packs splashed with the slogan \u201cSaving Lives, Changing Lives,\u201d a reference to a new partnership with the World Food Program. Along with the clothes, it put us squarely back on the issues-as-inspiration space.", "title": "The Mountain and the Mix", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAdult Film Star Feared for Safety of Daughter After Trump Threat\u201d (front page, March 26):\n\nWhat can we say about the state of our country when an adult film star sounds more believable and more intelligent, and is more sympathetic, than the president of the United States?\n\nJUDITH KATZ, NEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI do not subscribe to Donald Trump\u2019s conclusion that anything in the media he does not agree with constitutes \u201cfake news,\u201d but I must acknowledge that the media have gone overboard in reporting the stories of Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal, two of the many women who assert that the president engaged in extramarital affairs with them.\n\nThe much-touted \u201c60 Minutes\u201d interview with Stormy Daniels was believable, captivated the nation and scored spectacular ratings for CBS. But it is no revelation that the thrice-married ladies\u2019 man president who boasted of sexually assaulting women is a person with no moral fiber or character.\n\nHis die-hard supporters, many of whom consider themselves to be people of deep faith, do not care what he has done so long as he maintains his few bedrock \u201cprinciples\u201d: providing tax breaks to the wealthy, appointing conservative Supreme Court justices, and marginalizing racial and sexual minorities and yanking the welcome mat away from immigrants. The non-bombshell \u201c60 Minutes\u201d interview is much ado about very little.", "title": "Opinion | The Much-Awaited Stormy Daniels Interview", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cMueller Demands Trump\u2019s Company Surrender Files\u201d (front page, March 16):\n\nMuch has been written in the past year about the classical Watergate investigation standard \u201cFollow the money.\u201d In 2008 Donald Trump Jr. revealed, \u201cRussians make up a pretty disproportionate cross-section of a lot of our assets.\u201d The critical issue at this juncture is how much Russian money and which Russian oligarchs remain invested in the Trump Organization.\n\nThis is clearly one of the reasons President Trump refuses to release his tax returns, even though his lack of transparency could be turning into a national security issue. Robert Mueller\u2019s subpoena of the Trump Organization for documents related to Russia suggests as much.\n\nIt\u2019s becoming apparent that Congress needs to pass a law, before the next presidential election, that compels presidential candidates to release at least a decade\u2019s worth of their tax returns and also demonstrate an ability to obtain a top-secret security clearance. The most powerful office in the world requires such a law, as a minimum level of scrutiny of those who aspire to hold it and lead our nation.\n\nJACK NARGUNDKAR\n\nGERMANTOWN, MD.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYou write, \u201cThe lawyers have advised Mr. Trump to refuse an interview, but the president has said he wants to do it, as he believes he has done nothing wrong and can easily answer investigators\u2019 questions.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | The Mueller Inquiry: \u2018Follow the Money\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRecently, the Museum of Modern Art\u2019s Design Store collaborated with students in the product-design program at the School of Visual Arts in New York on new items for its shops and catalog. Among them is a clever and generous lab-glass mug printed with the proportions of coffee, milk and water needed to prepare various drinks, like a macchiato, an Americano and a flat white. Irish coffee? You\u2019re on your own: Multi-ccino Mug, $16 ($14.40 for members), MoMA Design Stores, 800-851-4509, store.moma.org.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest.
