Photographer\u2019s assistant: Matt Borkowski. Stylist\u2019s assistants: Jeremy Anderegg and Kelly Harris. Set assistant: Russell Mangicaro", "title": "The New Homespun Feel of Men\u2019s Wear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "The beginning of the self-titled debut album by Superorganism unfolds one psychedelic smear after the next: fuzzy white noise, throbbing boom-bap drums, heavily processed vocals, squelchy synthesizers. When the vocals come in, they start as a confusing swirl before resolving into sweet melody. It\u2019s like coming up for air after drowning, except the drowning was a dream.\n\nThere is warped, whimsical stuff all over \u201cSuperorganism,\u201d but none of it is cheeky. In the three years since its inception, and the year since the release of its debut single, this eight-member group \u2014 based in London and made up of members from all over the world \u2014 has honed a style that\u2019s a rigorous take on D.I.Y., lo-fi indie rock. Its album is a full-spectrum auditory experience, the sound of renegade toys weeping after a bender \u2014 curious, saccharine, unsteady and twee, but not weak.\n\nIt is a wild contrast to the central sound of indie rock from a decade ago \u2014 Arcade Fire, LCD Soundsystem and so on \u2014 which was anthemic and demanding, as swaggering as any doltish arena rock (insomuch as indie rock was, at all, rock, which it sometimes wasn\u2019t). Back then, the music had a chip on its shoulder, but now the calculus has changed. The internet has given voice and lent strength to interiority, and also undermined seriousness. The result is a new sort of indie rock that is chipper, rinky-dink, self-consciously handmade with discount-store melodies and neon attitude. You hear it in Superorganism, as well as in the earnest cabaret soul of Rex Orange County, and also the bedroom confections of Clairo. Each reflects a movement toward pocket-size eccentricity and charm masking high-test pop perfectionism.\n\nOn \u201cSuperorganism,\u201d this sound manifests in a few ways: the slumpy march of \u201cEverybody Wants to Be Famous,\u201d the music-box waltz of \u201cSPRORGNSM,\u201d the oozing thumps of \u201cSomething for Your M.I.N.D.,\u201d which sounds like something from De La Soul\u2019s first album. The arrangements are unclean and confident, though they sometimes slip into messiness (like on \u201cNai\u2019s March\u201d). But more often, they nod to grand-scale pop, like the \u201cGrease\u201d-style interjections on \u201cNight Time.\u201d", "title": "The New Indie Pop: Off-Kilter, Handmade, Whimsical and Emotional", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe came up with the concept of elevator music because we both grew up in the \u201990s,\u201d Mr. Gorham said, speaking by phone while traveling in Dubai. \u201cBackground music had such a negative connotation then, but it was something we could relate to.\u201d Think of the fragrance ($275 for 100 milliliters) as more of a backdrop to your life than as something that stands by itself. It is nondescript on purpose. \u201cThe idea,\u201d Mr. Gorham said, \u201cis that its wearer is noticed, not the perfume.\u201d\n\nGlossier, You\n\nThe Glossier aesthetic is all about a glowing bare face and a youthful nonchalance, so it makes sense that the company\u2019s first fragrance is a transparent mist of girlish iris and a warm aromachemical called Ambrette that makes the skin smell milky. The perfumer Frank Voelkl (the man behind the cult hit scent Santal 33), who created You with Dora Baghriche, said that he engineered the scent ($50 for 50 milliliters) as \u201csimplistic but singular. What we are seeing with millennials is they like scent to be personal, not like the big florals.\u201d\n\nMr. Voelkl said that for young consumers, \u201cperfumey\u201d is a dirty word. They want to smell \u201cless complex, and more relatable.\u201d\n\nProenza Schouler, Arizona\n\nThe first foray into fragrance from the dynamic design duo Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, this brand-new bubble-gum-pink liquid is meant to stir the nomadic soul with a light glaze of cactus flower and a velvety undergirding of white musk. The scent ($100 for 50 milliliters) also relies heavily on cashmeran, a New Softie staple ingredient that smells like a fine pashmina and lands on the skin like goose feathers.\n\nComme des Gar\u00e7ons, Concrete\n\nConcrete, a subdued outing for Comme des Gar\u00e7ons, is meant to evoke a city street after it rains. It does this with just one note: an essence of sandalwood, twisted and kneaded until it smells like Silly Putty. This Softie ($165 for 80 milliliters) is the strangest of the bunch, in that it sits close to the body but also smells eerily alien; a metallic tang keeps it interesting.\n\nNomenclature, Holy_Wood\n\nAnother gossamer creation from Mr. Voelkl, Holy_Wood is a showcase for an aromachemical called Clearwood, which the fragrance lab Firmenich calls \u201cthe 21st century\u2019s answer to patchouli.\u201d What it really smells like is the inside of a day spa sauna: immaculate, meditative, vaporous ($195 for 100 milliliters).\n\nGoest Perfumes, Dauphine\n\nJacqueline Steele, the creator of Goest, based Dauphine, an ethereal perfume that smells like almond macarons, on Marie Antoinette\u2019s quiet moments at the palace between gaudy costume balls. \u201cThe concept is extreme cleanliness when cleanliness was coveted; pastries with white sugar when white sugar was an almost abstract luxury object,\u201d Ms. Steele said. The scent ($140 for 60 milliliters) is knowingly innocuous, she said. \u201cMillennials want to show off a sort of luxuriant, well-considered, \u2018well-cared-for-ness\u2019 that doesn\u2019t traffic much in glamour, but still clearly messages wealth and taste.\u201d", "title": "The New Softies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "China, under President Xi Jinping, has launched an ambitious plan to dominate mobile technology, supercomputers, artificial intelligence and other cutting-edge industries, putting huge resources behind an effort that it considers crucial to the country\u2019s government, military and economy. Beijing wants to build its own technology champions and is encouraging companies to acquire the engineering, expertise and intellectual property from big rivals in the United States and elsewhere.\n\nThe aggressive push has set off alarms in Washington, with policymakers and lawmakers fearful that American giants could lose their edge. President Trump is now building up the country\u2019s defenses, as the government investigates potential violations of American intellectual property rights and intensifies scrutiny of overseas deals.\n\nThe secretive panel that is reviewing the Qualcomm deal, the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius, has taken on a central role in the resistance to Chinese investment. The panel, which is led by the Treasury Department and made up of representatives from multiple agencies, has the authority to block foreign acquisitions of American companies for national security reasons; it has effectively killed several acquisitions linked to Chinese buyers over the past year. Lawmakers are also calling to expand the powers of Cfius to reflect the broader scope of China\u2019s interests.\n\n[ What is Cfius? It is the \u201cultimate regulatory bazooka,\u201d according to an executive who works on mergers and acquisitions. Read more about the panel here \u00bb ]\n\n\u201cThe Trump administration turbocharged it,\u201d Tony Balloon, the head of the corporate China practice at the law firm Alston & Bird, said, referring to Cfius. \u201cThere is now a recognition in government that foreign investors, particularly from China, are getting more and more sophisticated on how they get access to technology in the U.S.\u201d\n\nWith Qualcomm, the government has articulated its evolving vision for global economic leadership.\n\nThe company, which is a major supplier to the United States government, is a leading player in the race to build the next generation wireless technology, known as 5G. These high-speed mobile networks will form the infrastructure backbone that ultimately connects home appliances, streetlights and driverless cars to the internet. And Qualcomm\u2019s chips will be in the multitude of devices and machines that will run on those networks.\n\n\u201cHaving a well-known and trusted company hold the dominant role that Qualcomm does in the telecommunications infrastructure provides significant confidence in the integrity of such infrastructure as it relates to national security,\u201d the Treasury official wrote in the letter.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe government specifically cited Huawei, the Chinese telecom-equipment giant, as a potential competitor that could move into a breach created by a merger. The Chinese company has spent heavily on 5G, and the government said it owns 10 percent of the essential patents.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is the new paradigm,\u201d said Paul Triolo, head of global technology policy at Eurasia Group, a geopolitical risk consulting company. \u201cThat implies technologies with 5G, artificial intelligence, biotech and automation are now considered more sensitive and part of a national innovation base that needs to be protected.\u201d\n\nBroadcom said it was cooperating with Cfius, saying it was \u201cmaking the combined company a global leader in critical 5G and other technologies.\u201d Qualcomm, in an earlier statement, said the review was a \u201cvery serious matter.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe letter and the call for an investigation reflect the newly forceful position of Cfius.\n\nIn most cases, the panel weighs in after a deal is announced. With Qualcomm, Cfius is taking a proactive role and investigating before an acquisition agreement has even been signed.\n\nCfius has stymied several deals in the past year.\n\nMoneyGram, the money transfer company, and Ant Financial, the Chinese electronics payment company, called off their merger in January, citing regulatory concerns of Cfius. If the deal had gone through, Ant Financial would have had access to reams of financial data, which could have created security problems. Ant Financial has said that consumer data would have stayed in the United States.\n\nLast year, the White House blocked a Chinese-backed investor from buying Lattice Semiconductor, which is a supplier to the United States government. China Venture Capital Fund Corporation, which was part of the investment group, is owned by state-backed entities.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very much an expansion of what is considered to be national security,\u201d said Tai Ming Cheung, director of the Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation at the University of California at San Diego. \u201cThis is about China\u2019s efforts to invest and acquire key parts of the U.S. innovation system.\u201d\n\nCfius could soon have even more muscle.\n\nThere is new legislation to broaden the jurisdiction of Cfius; it has bipartisan support in the Senate. The Trump administration has expressed support for rewriting the rules governing Cfius, and Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said last year that the administration was working closely with the House and the Senate.\n\nThe bill, proposed by Senators John Cornyn, a Republican from Texas, and Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat from California, would give Cfius the authority to assess some types of joint ventures, minority investments and real estate transactions near military bases. The legislation would also widen the definition of \u201ccritical technologies\u201d slated for potential review to include \u201cemerging technologies that could be essential for maintaining the U.S. technological advantage over countries that pose threats, such as China,\u201d according to a news release on the bill.\n\nAdding to the scrutiny, the United States Trade Representative has also opened an investigation into whether China is \u201charming American intellectual property rights, innovation or technology development.\u201d One concern is that American companies have been forced to hand over technology, create joint ventures and otherwise help homegrown players, in exchange for access to the Chinese market. Qualcomm, for example, has been working with the Chinese government to develop drones, artificial intelligence and mobile technology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTechnology companies are stuck in the middle of the fight between the United States and China. While there are concerns about Chinese encroachment, the industry also recognizes that such deals are the price for entry to the world\u2019s second-largest economy. Companies have protested the proposed changes to Cfius, saying an expansion of its powers could be misused and that the new definitions of emerging technologies are unclear.\n\nIBM has said the bill would limit the \u201cability of American firms to do business abroad while empowering foreign competitors to capture global markets.\u201d The Information Technology Industry Council, a tech trade group, has lobbied against the changes, saying they add complexity for Silicon Valley companies that often have intricate business ties in China.\n\n\u201cThey are between a rock and a hard place,\u201d said Rob Atkinson, president of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a think tank that is sponsored by technology firms like Microsoft. \u201cThe Chinese government says you have to do this to operate here. The U.S. says, but you can\u2019t do that.\u201d", "title": "The New U.S.-China Rivalry: A Technology Race", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In 2016, the feminist press Emily Books held a panel in Brooklyn titled, a bit cheekily, \u201cWhat Is Women\u2019s Writing?\u201d There was no consensus, much laughter and a warm, rowdy vibe. Eileen Myles read from a memoir in progress and Ariana Reines read a poem, wearing a dress with a pattern of a city on fire. All of this felt exactly right.\n\nBut even if it puts your teeth on edge to see \u201cwomen\u2019s writing\u201d cordoned off in quotes, you can\u2019t deny the particular power of today\u2019s women writers \u2014 their intensity of style and innovation. The books steering literature in new directions \u2014 to new forms, new concerns \u2014 almost invariably have a woman at the helm, an Elena Ferrante, a Rachel Cusk, a Zadie Smith.\n\nFor Women\u2019s History Month, The Times\u2019s staff book critics \u2014 Dwight Garner, Jennifer Szalai and myself, Parul Sehgal \u2014 sat down together to think about these writers who are opening new realms to us, whose books suggest and embody unexplored possibilities in form, feeling and knowledge.\n\nAs we put together a reading list, we introduced a few parameters, for sanity\u2019s sake. We confined ourselves to books written by women and published in the 21st century. And we limited our focus to fiction, but not without some grief. Memoir has emerged as a potent political and literary force in recent years (see the terrain-shifting work of Maggie Nelson, for example). And poets like Claudia Rankine, Solmaz Sharif and Tracy K. Smith are some of the most distinctive voices working today.", "title": "The New Vanguard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s also unclear whether the gains in New York will be durable. Gang-suppression efforts in other parts of the country rarely show long-term success, in part because teenagers in poor, racially segregated communities will continue to face the challenges of insecurity and hopelessness that drive youth violence.\n\nThrough the New York Police Department\u2019s use of conspiracy cases, these raids cover a wide range of behaviors that are not acts of violence, like marijuana possession. This approach misunderstands the nature of gangs and the dense social networks inhabited by these young people targeted for prosecution. Despite overheated rhetoric from the police, politicians and the media, there is often very little evidence in these conspiracy cases of an organized hierarchical structure to these alleged gangs, which instead are often loose affiliations without purpose beyond socializing and seeking mutual safety.\n\nMost of the raids in New York have been concentrated in and around public housing developments, where teenagers have little choice but to develop continuing relationships, even if those acquaintances are involved in violence. The police claim that because these young people spend time together in a park, were previously arrested together and are seen together in Facebook posts, they are in a well-defined gang engaged in ongoing crime and violence. But that is much too simplistic.\n\nProsecutors rely heavily on these conspiracy charges, not because they involve true criminal enterprises but because they can be used as leverage against defendants. State conspiracy and federal RICO anti-racketeering statutes allow prosecutors to threaten decades of prison time based merely on evidence of associations and potentially unrelated low-level criminal charges from the past.\n\nThe gang designation also usually makes defendants ineligible for bail, giving them a stronger incentive to provide evidence against others or take a plea deal. In many cases, the only evidence against a defendant accused of violence is the testimony of someone in jail hoping to avoid prosecution. Many young people have complained to their public defenders that during questioning, the police have pressured them to hand over social media passwords, even when they have not been charged with a crime and in the absence of a parent or legal representative.\n\nMany of the defendants in the New York City cases are jailed before trial for long periods of time and face possibly decades in prison, even though a vast majority of them are not being accused of actual involvement in violence. That leaves their families to choose either getting evicted from public housing or agreeing that their child will be banned from their home forever. Communities are undermined as young people are forced to testify against their neighbors to avoid prosecution.\n\nInstead of doubling down on gang-suppression policing, New York City should invest in better alternatives. The city supports 18 Cure Violence programs to reduce shootings. The program\u2019s sites, often a substantial portion of the area\u2019s police precinct, rely on community-based \u201cviolence interrupters\u201d who work with young people. New York also promulgates anti-violence public health messaging and involves young people in social activities like art programs and service projects.", "title": "Opinion | The New \u2018Superpredator\u2019 Myth", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "Above ground, a 7,855-pipe organ is one of the great splendors of St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral on Fifth Avenue, the luminous church that will be the heart of the action in New York on St. Patrick\u2019s Day. But hidden below the cathedral\u2019s floor, a new system of pipes just as intricate is a source of equal pride.\n\nA year ago, as part of its nearly $200 million renovation, St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral launched a state-of-the-art geothermal heating and cooling system to replace its system of steam radiators and 1960s-era air conditioning. Around the cathedral\u2019s perimeter are now 10 wells as deep as 2,200 feet into the Manhattan bedrock, collecting groundwater that helps the church efficiently heat and cool. The cathedral now reaches six times deeper than its Gothic spires soar high.\n\nThe system\u2019s thousands of feet of pipes and dozens of pumps are invisible to the five million visitors to the cathedral each year, and that was the point. The trustees of the 138-year-old building, the centerpiece of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, wanted the church to appear as it always has, even as it was going green.", "title": "The New, Green Pride of St. Patrick\u2019s Cathedral Is Underground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere are other, larger companies, but Goldman\u2019s an icon,\u201d said Charles Elson, a corporate governance expert at the University of Delaware. \u201cAnd it\u2019s occupied a prominent role in American finance for probably almost 70 or 80 years.\u201d\n\nMr. Blankfein has led the firm for nearly a dozen years since his predecessor, Henry M. Paulson Jr., departed to be the Treasury secretary under President George W. Bush. Mr. Blankfein, 63, has joked that he intends to die at his desk, but he has signaled to people inside Goldman that he may leave as chief executive as early as this year, according to two people familiar with his thinking.\n\nThe possibility that Mr. Blankfein could soon step away intensified the competition between Mr. Solomon and Mr. Schwartz, who twice pressed the board for an answer in recent months.\n\nFor more than a year \u2014 since Mr. Cohn stepped down as the firm\u2019s president to be the director of the National Economic Council \u2014 Mr. Solomon and Mr. Schwartz, 54, have been auditioning to be Mr. Blankfein\u2019s successor. Each man held the title of president.\n\nLast month, Goldman\u2019s board met at its headquarters and evaluated the two candidates. Mr. Blankfein offered his view, and the directors decided that Mr. Solomon was their man, according to a person who was briefed on the meeting.\n\nThe anticipated elevation of Mr. Solomon, a Goldman veteran who moonlights under the name D.J. D-Sol, spinning electronic-dance music, marks a strategic shift for the bank.\n\nMr. Solomon, a native of Westchester County, N.Y., was a rare outsider to join Goldman as a partner when he was hired from Bear Stearns in 1999. He is a schmoozer who recognizes the importance of projecting a positive, inclusive image of the bank to its clients, its employees and the public. Unlike Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Schwartz, Mr. Solomon is not steeped in the firm\u2019s cutthroat trading culture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s client-centric, direct and candid,\u201d Bennett Goodman, a senior managing director of the private-equity firm Blackstone, said in an email. \u201cYou never doubt he\u2019ll tell you what he really believes even when it\u2019s not what you want to hear.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe leadership transition comes at a time when Goldman\u2019s traditional business model is under siege. Its bond-trading business, once a huge component of the firm\u2019s revenue, which hit nearly $1 billion a week in 2009, is now a shadow of its former self. The bank\u2019s limited presence in countries like Saudi Arabia and Mexico has meant Goldman has been left out of some lucrative transactions. And its belated attempts to muscle its way into businesses such as consumer lending have failed to transform the company into a real competitor of commercial banks like JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup.\n\nSince his elevation to president was announced in late 2016, Mr. Solomon has been working to address those shortcomings. Last spring, he and Mr. Schwartz presented directors with a plan to generate $5 billion a year in additional revenue starting in the fall of 2020. It called for expanding Goldman\u2019s investment-banking franchise to midsize cities including Dallas and Seattle.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Solomon strayed beyond the traditional mold of a Wall Street power broker. He demanded, for example, that Goldman\u2019s recruiters increase their hiring of women with the goal of eventually reaching total gender parity.\n\nTo many inside Goldman, Mr. Solomon\u2019s ascension was far from a sure thing. Mr. Solomon himself was among the skeptics; associates said that he had told them that the top job was Mr. Schwartz\u2019s to lose.\n\nMr. Schwartz, who had been Goldman\u2019s chief financial officer, knew the firm\u2019s business model cold and had played a central role in the firm\u2019s trading business during its heyday. Mr. Solomon, on the other hand, had won the respect of the banking division but was less well known in other parts of the bank.\n\nFor the past year, the relationship between Mr. Schwartz and Mr. Solomon has been chilly at times. They had never been close personally and, while striving to work together professionally, subordinates could tell that both men knew they were in the midst of a horse race.\n\nMr. Schwartz recently confided to friends that he was worried about being \u201cGary\u2019ed,\u201d said people familiar with the conversations. It was a reference to what happened to Mr. Cohn, who remained Goldman\u2019s president for more than 10 years in hopes of taking over from Mr. Blankfein, before joining the Trump administration.\n\nLate last year, Mr. Schwartz approached Goldman\u2019s lead director, the private-equity executive Adebayo O. Ogunlesi, with an ultimatum, according to people familiar with the exchange. Mr. Schwartz said that unless he was tapped as chief executive in the coming months, he would resign. Mr. Ogunlesi was noncommittal, these people said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Schwartz reiterated his demand to Mr. Ogunlesi this year, the people said.\n\nThe move didn\u2019t work as intended. On Feb. 21, during a meeting at Goldman\u2019s headquarters, the board took up the succession question in earnest. Mr. Blankfein expressed his preference for Mr. Solomon, said the person who was briefed on the meeting, and the board agreed.\n\nMr. Blankfein then left for a business trip to Asia and didn\u2019t tell Mr. Solomon the news for more than a week. Mr. Schwartz was notified last week. He immediately decided to retire, capping a career that started on Black Monday, the day in October 1987 when the stock market plunged 22 percent.\n\nMr. Blankfein announced Mr. Schwartz\u2019s exit and Mr. Solomon\u2019s promotion to be the firm\u2019s sole president at a weekly management committee early Monday morning, according to people briefed on the discussion.\n\nDuring the gathering, Mr. Blankfein also equivocated on his own time frame for retiring. He said that a Wall Street Journal article last week that said he could leave by the end of this year might be right or might be wrong, the people said.", "title": "The Next Goldman Chief Could Be a Banker Who Moonlights as a D.J.", "authors": ["Kate Kelly"]} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "KLAMATH FALLS, Ore. \u2014 Each spring and fall in the old days, Chinook salmon swam up the Klamath River, crossing the Cascade Mountains, to Upper Klamath Lake, 4,000 feet above sea level. For millenniums, the Klamath, Modoc and Yahooskin Band of Snake Indians fished salmon from the lake and the river. The Klamath had agreements with the downriver tribes \u2014 the Karuk, Hoopa and Yurok among them \u2014 to let fish pass so that some could swim all the way back to their spawning grounds.\n\nAfter dams were built on the river starting in 1912, the salmon were blocked. Today the only \u201cc\u2019iyaals hoches\u201d (salmon runs) are enacted by the Klamath Tribes, whose members carry carved cedar salmon on a 300-mile symbolic journey from the ocean to the traditional spawning grounds to bring home the spirit of the fish.\n\nThe Klamath River\u2019s dams are scheduled to be demolished by 2020, in what will be one of the largest river restorations in American history. But there\u2019s a threat to the dream of a revitalized river \u2014 a project that would put a newly unobstructed Klamath at risk of contamination while simultaneously contributing to climate change, desecrating grave sites and trampling the traditional territory of the Klamath people. If you\u2019ve read anything at all about the protests near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota, you might be able to guess what that threat is.\n\nIt\u2019s a pipeline.\n\nThe Pacific Connector Gas Pipeline would run 229 miles from Malin to Coos Bay, Ore., crossing underneath the Klamath River near the city of Klamath Falls. It would extend, via interconnections, the Ruby Pipeline, carrying natural gas from Wyoming to a huge planned storage and export terminal for sales to countries in the Pacific Rim.", "title": "Opinion | The Next Standing Rock? A Pipeline Battle Looms in Oregon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "We watched as some of them, late one Christmas Day and after their patrol shift had ended, pulled grown men from the water and performed CPR on the beach. We watched as those kids learned that sometimes people can\u2019t be saved.\n\nNow we\u2019re parents of our own Nippers, and my happy place is on the beach every Sunday morning of the season. I \u2018manage\u2019 (to use the term in its broadest sense) a group of boys that includes my son. I count heads a lot \u2014 into the water and out again, at the start and the end of each session, and plenty of times in between. This merry band is chaotic, brave, fun and fit \u2014 and they\u2019re all mates.\n\nNippers gives kids (and their parents) another \u2018tribe\u2019 \u2014 beyond school groups and footy teams \u2014 and importantly, a sense that they are part of something that is respected and valued. It teaches them about the value of community, and the importance of giving back. It creates confident, responsible and resilient young people.\n\nNippers also teaches kids that everyone has a place, regardless of ability. One of my proudest moments each season is when the State competition team assembles to hear from the surf club\u2019s senior ranks. Put 120 wet, sandy kids in a stuffy hall, and you could forgive a bit of restlessness. There\u2019s one club member who speaks each season: he has a physical disability that makes his speech slow, but his words are always heartfelt and inspirational. And that hall is completely silent while Neil speaks.\n\nI love the ethos that pervades this group: everyone has a go, and no one gets left behind.\n\nI\u2019ve watched our fastest sprinters get down in the sand to show another boy how he might improve his start technique.\n\nI\u2019ve watched the strongest swimmers finish their surf swim, and then head back out to coax the last ones around the cans.\n\nTogether, we\u2019ve endured hours of waiting on baking beaches for big races, only to have the result not go our way. And yes, there are tears on those occasions \u2014 but they bounce back fast.\n\nThere\u2019s always another race, another wave, another mate to cheer on. They make me achingly proud.\n\nAre there other Australian experiences we should be asking about for Australia Diary, our collection of reader stories reflecting Australia\u2019s unique character? Send us your story.\n\nFor guidance and inspiration, here are few recent entries: tales of growing up on the creek, generational angst, paying with pineapples, magical mermaid pools, lizard friends, nude beaches, music and road trips, curious lifeguards, death and kindness, plus poetry and #metoo on the work site.", "title": "The Nippers Way of Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-10 00:00:00", "text": "Like the fax machine and computer, Alexander Mackenzie\u2019s Northwest Passage was too forward-looking to be practical or useful. Today the melting Northwest Passage \u2014 along the North Slope of Alaska, through the maze of Canadian Arctic islands, then back down along Greenland\u2019s west coast, to the Atlantic \u2014 is regularly in the news. A holy grail for generations of explorers is now finally open, because of climate change. Giant cargo and oil tankers regularly ply those seas, and even the Crystal Serenity cruise ship, with 1,700 people onboard (many in black tie), has made the journey the past two summers.\n\nBut when Mackenzie led his expedition, this was still unknown. By the mid-1700s, all the various straits north of Hudson\u2019s Bay had been explored, often with disastrous results, and all had been found full of pack ice even in summer. That a Northwest Passage existed at all was considered incontrovertible \u2014 \u201ca moral certainty,\u201d according to a British official of the time \u2014 and so conventional geographic wisdom held that a route must pass through the continent. Starting at the St. Lawrence River, through the Great Lakes, up one of the mighty prairie rivers, and then, well, they weren\u2019t sure. The maps went blank. Speculative geographers predicted a fabled River of the West, to the Pacific.\n\nEconomics had always driven this search. Britain, France and Spain, even as they colonized North America, sought a way around the continent, to reach Chinese tea and spices to supply European markets. Furs, the prime commodity of the time, could take years to procure and ship. A direct passage from North America to China would increase profits significantly.\n\nMackenzie embodied the enterprising spirit of the age. He emigrated to America as a boy, a refugee from Scotland, landing in New York City in 1775 in the midst of the Revolution. After his father died in the war, the teenage Mackenzie apprenticed as a clerk in a fur trading firm, quickly rising through the ranks of the international cartel known as the North West Company.\n\nHe was the youngest partner when chosen to lead the expedition with his Chipewyan partner, Awgeenah, paddling a massive river that led west from the continent\u2019s center. When the river hit the Rocky Mountains it turned north, but Mackenzie was undeterred. Hundreds of miles later, at the shore of the Arctic Ocean, Mackenzie and his crew were stopped by indomitable pack ice in all directions. Even in the heat of summer, there was no way past.", "title": "Opinion | The Northwest Passage That Might Have Been", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-14 00:00:00", "text": "The connection between Sister Jean and Moser, 49, dates to 2011, when Moser, a career assistant, was hired to revitalize Loyola\u2019s program. On his first day, he arrived at his new office and found a manila folder on his desk. Inside it was a scouting report, compiled by Sister Jean, detailing the strengths and weaknesses of each player he had inherited.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe scouting reports haven\u2019t stopped. Day after day, season after season, Sister Jean pores over box scores of Loyola\u2019s upcoming opponents, weighing what she finds against her insider\u2019s knowledge of Loyola\u2019s players. She is careful to note the smallest of details, which she conveys when she stands in a huddle to pray with her arms wrapped around players\u2019 waists. The moments, she said, are not as holy as some might guess: In between invocations, she also warns the players to watch out for the opponent\u2019s top performers.\n\nBut it is there, in the huddle, surrounded by players who tower over her, that Sister Jean says she can feel the goodness of the players enveloping her.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re very special, and they\u2019re very good,\u201d she said. \u201cThese kids play with their hearts and their heads because they love their school and because they love basketball.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter each Loyola game, Sister Jean sends emails to Moser, to his coaching staff and then to each player. She limits her written words to the team to only a few paragraphs, she said, but then always adds a personalized message congratulating a player for his performance or encouraging the downtrodden.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s been days throughout my last four years when I had a bad game, a down game,\u201d the Loyola senior Donte Ingram said. \u201cWe might have won. We might have lost. But at the end of the message, she always found a way to make me feel better.\u201d\n\nBefore she fell and broke her left hip on Nov. 14, Sister Jean had missed only two Loyola home games since 1994. She typically makes her way around campus in a pair of custom maroon basketball sneakers with her name stitched in gold thread on the back. When she was forced to miss eight home games this season after surgery to repair her hip, Sister Jean followed the play-by-play of Ramblers games on her iPad, envisioning each play without the luxury of a video feed.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd despite her absence, the prayers, the emails and the scouting reports never missed a beat.\n\nRestricted to a wheelchair, she even made her way to St. Louis to watch \u2014 and pray \u2014 as Loyola won the Missouri Valley Conference tournament title.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI promised God a lot of stuff,\u201d she said of her nonstop prayers during the final. \u201cSo I had to take care of that before I went to sleep that night.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Sunday evening, she was back with her team at Loyola\u2019s watch party, wearing an oversize Loyola varsity jacket and a maroon and gold scarf. She took copious notes throughout the television broadcast that announced the brackets, and she cried tears of joy when Moser and the Ramblers learned that they would be the 11th seed in the South Region, matched against Miami (Fla.) (22-9) on Thursday in Dallas.\n\nWith one more medical clearance from doctors, Sister Jean plans to head to Texas to cheer on her beloved Ramblers. If her health prevents the trip, she said, she will watch on television. It is the same way she watched Loyola\u2019s greatest basketball moment: a 60-58 victory over two-time defending champion Cincinnati in the 1963 national championship game.\n\n\u201cI know she\u2019s going to be there with us in prayer and cheering us on,\u201d Ingram said. \u201cAnd that means a lot to us.\u201d", "title": "The Nun in Loyola-Chicago\u2019s Huddle Has a Few Things to Say", "authors": ["Jeff Arnold"]} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "Why Is It Airing Now?\n\nAccording to the executive producer, Terry Wrong, Fox dug up this interview to satisfy the huge demand for more O.J.-related television. The former network executive Preston Beckman \u2014 known on Twitter as \u201cthe Masked Scheduler\u201d \u2014 noted in a blog post that Fox probably intentionally showed it on Sunday night to counterprogram ABC\u2019s premiere of the revived \u201cAmerican Idol.\u201d (\u201cThey probably don\u2019t want egg on their face if \u2018AI\u2019 returns with an impressive number,\u201d he said.)\n\nIn interviews leading up to the broadcast, both Ms. O\u2019Brien and Mr. Wrong stressed that Mr. Simpson didn\u2019t get a dime for this special. He was reportedly paid $800,000 for the book \u201cIf I Did It\u201d in 2006, but got no money for the interview then, according to Fox. Fox, on the other hand, definitely stands to benefit \u2014 which was one of the complaints levied before the broadcast was scrapped the first time.\n\nFox, Ms. Regan, Ms. O\u2019Brien and Mr. Darden have all insisted that \u201cThe Lost Confession\u201d is a vital document in the era of #MeToo and #TimesUp. The special was framed as a look inside the mind of a domestic abuser, and perhaps a warning to any woman who might be in a relationship with someone who talks the way Mr. Simpson does in the interview. Mr. Wrong also made sure to point out that unlike in 2006, the Brown and Goldman families gave their blessing to show this footage, ostensibly because they believe it makes Mr. Simpson look guilty.\n\nDoes O.J. Come Clean?\n\nIt certainly seemed that way. Bear in mind that this interview has been edited down from about four hours (according to Ms. Regan, in promos Fox sent to TV critics), and that throughout Mr. Simpson is referring to the \u201chypothetical\u201d confession in the book \u201cIf I Did It.\u201d In the six minutes in which he talks about the murders, he describes being on the scene with a friend named Charlie \u2014 whom the panel believes was just a voice inside his head. It\u2019s all very odd.\n\nThat said, when Mr. Simpson describes grabbing a knife (\u201cI do remember that part,\u201d he says), and recalls seeing copious amounts of blood, it doesn\u2019t sound all that hypothetical. The interview goes on to cover the aftermath of the crime \u2014 including the infamous Bronco chase \u2014 and Ms. Regan\u2019s questioning about what was going through Mr. Simpson\u2019s mind at that time keeps steering him toward explaining his feelings of anger, frustration, depression and yes, guilt.\n\n[ALSO READ: The O.J. Simpson Murder Trial, as Covered by the Times]\n\n\u201cThe Lost Confession\u201d also offers a glimpse into its subject\u2019s character. It\u2019s fascinating to see Mr. Simpson blasting the media, all while frequently reminding Ms. Regan of his past reputation as a successful and popular guy. He seems to cling to every half-truth about his relationship with Ms. Brown that makes him look like he\u2019s the real victim.", "title": "The O.J. Simpson Interview on Fox: Gripping, Gross or Both?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhen your laptop is lost or stolen, you aren\u2019t just out $800 (or more). Your personal information is also accessible to whoever takes it, even if you have a password.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, a typical password-protected user account does nothing to protect your data,\u201d says Dennis Stewart, a security engineer at CipherTechs. \u201cWhile the password will prevent someone else from logging into your computer, an attacker can still use other methods to copy files off.\u201d If thieves remove the hard drive and put it into another computer, they have access to any files you have stored on it. In some cases, they can even reset the password on your PC and gain access to your email, passwords and other personal information.\n\nThankfully, you can protect your data against both of these types of attacks with encryption. \u201cEncryption is a mathematical process used to jumble up data. If important files or whole devices are encrypted, there is no way to make sense of them without the key,\u201d Mr. Stewart said. That means if thieves try to access your information, they\u2019ll find only a jumbled mess unless they have your password, and they won\u2019t be able to simply reset that password if the device is encrypted.\n\nEncrypting your hard drive isn\u2019t some super-technical process that only security experts can perform, either \u2014 anyone can do it on his or her computer at home, and it should take only a few minutes to get up and running.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow to Encrypt Your Hard Drive\n\nIf you have a Windows laptop, you have a few options. Some Windows 10 devices come with encryption turned on by default, and you can check this by going to Settings > System > About and scrolling down to \u201cDevice Encryption.\u201d You\u2019ll need to log into Windows with a Microsoft account in order for this feature to work, but if your laptop offers it, it\u2019s an easy and free way to protect your data.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIf your laptop doesn\u2019t support Device Encryption, you can use Windows\u2019 other built-in encryption tool: BitLocker. BitLocker is available only on Professional versions of Windows and above (a $99 upgrade for Home edition users), but it\u2019s incredibly easy to set up. Just head to Windows\u2019 Control Panel > System and Security > Manage BitLocker. Select your operating system drive and click the \u201cTurn On BitLocker\u201d button, following the prompts to create a password that will function as your encryption key. Be sure to store your BitLocker key in a safe place \u2014 somewhere not on that computer \u2014 in case something goes wrong!", "title": "The One Thing That Protects a Laptop After It\u2019s Been Stolen", "authors": ["Whitson Gordon"]} {"date": "2018-03-27 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 In the spring of 2015, 13-year-old Huang Kailong had just skipped a grade, from fifth to seventh, and her future sparkled with promise. Then she ran away from home. In a letter to her parents, Kailong explained the reason for leaving: She felt unloved.\n\nKailong grew up in Jidao, a picturesque village in Guizhou Province, one of the least developed in China. In her letter, she reminded her parents that they had left her with an aunt when she was just a year old. During the bulk of her childhood, her parents would go away for about four months every year to chop sugar cane in Guangdong Province, and they\u2019d leave her with different relatives, an arrangement she had resented.\n\n\u201cI felt like a stray dog,\u201d she said to me in the coastal city of Wenzhou, where she now lives with her boyfriend and several dogs they took in from the street.\n\nIn January, social media across the world lit up with the wind-burned face of Wang Fuman, an 8-year-old living with his grandparents in a remote village in Yunnan Province who treks almost three miles to school every day. He showed up in his classroom one morning with frost-covered hair, a teacher took his photo, posted it online and it went viral. The picture drew attention to the plight of the many Chinese children who grow up in the countryside without their parents nearby.", "title": "Opinion | The Orphans of China\u2019s Economic Miracle", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-30 00:00:00", "text": "Oh, another thing: As a NeverTrumper, you\u2019re guilty of being insufficiently representative of contemporary conservatism. Had you been a Trumper, doubtless you would have been dismissed as a moron unworthy of the pages of The Atlantic.\n\nWeighed against these charges are hundreds of thousands of words of smart, stylish and often hilarious commentary, criticism and reportage. How many of the people now demanding your firing read your unforgettable description of Steve Mnuchin\u2019s \u201cScrooge McDuck-style sphincter-clenching,\u201d or of Anthony Scaramucci\u2019s \u201cbatty and profane interview in which he reimagined Steve Bannon as a kind of autoerotic yogi\u201d?\n\nShouldn\u2019t great prose and independent judgment count for something? Not according to your critics. We live in the age of guilt by pull-quote, abetted by a combination of lazy journalism, gullible readership, missing context, and technologies that make our every ill-considered utterance instantly accessible and utterly indelible. I jumped at your abortion comment, but for heaven\u2019s sake, it was a tweet. When you write a whole book on the need to execute the tens of millions of American women who\u2019ve had abortions, then I\u2019ll worry.\n\nWe also live in an age \u2014 another one \u2014 of excommunication. This is ugly because its spirit is illiberal, and odd, because its consequences are negligible. Should The Atlantic foolishly succumb to pressure to rescind your job offer, you\u2019ll still be widely read, presumably at National Review. If you\u2019re really the barbarian your critics claim, you\u2019re already through the gates.\n\nThe real question, then, isn\u2019t what kinds of arguments are \u201cacceptable.\u201d It\u2019s what kinds are, or ought to be, acceptable to liberals. In The Huffington Post, one writer proposes that the answer is none. This is the liberalism of the 9- year-old sticking fingers in his ears and saying: nah-nah-nah-nah-nah. Anyone still wondering how Donald Trump became president need look no further.\n\nThe wiser test of acceptability is whether an argument is thoughtful, thought-provoking and offered in good faith. That holds true even if the views aren\u2019t politically representative. Last I checked, you and I were hired as columnists, not party ideologues or demographic segments.\n\nIt also holds true whether or not a given opinion is offensive. Offensive to tens of millions of intelligent and morally sincere Americans is the idea that abortion ought to be legal at all, much less in the second or third trimester. If those Americans can make their peace with pro-choice writers like me, the least liberals can do is not make war on pro-life writers like you.\n\nThat doesn\u2019t mean there ought to be limitless tolerance for every shade of opinion: There are cranks and haters both left and right, and wise editors should not give them a platform. But your critics show bad faith when they treat an angry tweet or a flippant turn of phrase as proof of moral incorrigibility. Let he who is without a bad tweet, a crap sentence or even a deplorable opinion cast the first stone.\n\nWorse, they foreclose the possibility of learning something useful from someone smart. Learning does not require agreement. There\u2019s a reason this section of the newspaper is labeled \u201cOpinion,\u201d not \u201cAffirmation,\u201d \u201cReinforcement,\u201d or \u201cEmotional Crutch.\u201d Liberals used to know that. What happened?\n\nMy guess is that you\u2019ll find working for The Atlantic a discipline and a joy. It\u2019s not always easy to write for an audience whose views you rarely share. It\u2019s not always fun to hear back from them, either. But the result will be sharper writing by you, a broader understanding for them, and more competition for us. Congrats.", "title": "Opinion | The Outrage Over Kevin Williamson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve got 11 families who are victims of terrorism and who have suffered a lot,\u201d Mr. Olson said. \u201cThis is so painful and difficult for them.\u201d\n\nThe families had sued the two Palestinian groups under the Antiterrorism Act of 1992, which was designed to allow such suits by giving federal courts jurisdiction over acts of international terrorism against Americans. After a seven-week jury trial in 2015 in Manhattan, the plaintiffs won $218.5 million, which was automatically tripled under the 1992 law.\n\nThe United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, threw out the award, saying the trial court had lacked jurisdiction over the Palestinian groups because they did not have a substantial presence in the United States and had not set out specifically to kill and injure Americans.\n\n\u201cFederal courts cannot exercise jurisdiction in a civil case beyond the limits prescribed by the due process clause of the Constitution, no matter how horrendous the underlying attacks or morally compelling the plaintiffs\u2019 claims,\u201d Judge John G. Koeltl, who ordinarily sits on the Federal District Court in Manhattan, wrote for the unanimous three-judge panel.\n\nKerri Kupec, a spokeswoman for the solicitor general\u2019s office, said the administration was committed to fighting terrorism.\n\n\u201cThe United States condemns acts of terror in the strongest terms, and the Department of Justice is committed to prosecuting those who commit terrorist attacks against innocent human beings to the fullest extent that the law allows,\u201d she said in a statement. \u201cThe United States sympathizes deeply with the American families who, in 2004, sued the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization for acts of terrorism committed against their loved ones between 2002 and 2004.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe court of appeals decided, however,\u201d she said, \u201cthat the suit was not consistent with due process under the Constitution, and its decision does not meet the usual standards for Supreme Court review. He has deep experience molding the artistic profiles of orchestras, having previously served as the vice president of artistic planning for the New York Philharmonic and the senior director of artistic planning for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. But in Philadelphia he will also be responsible for the orchestra\u2019s financial fortunes, after a tumultuous decade that saw the storied ensemble become the most prominent American orchestra to seek bankruptcy protection.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an organization of great resilience, and I think it\u2019s got a foundation for an even more remarkable future,\u201d Mr. Tarnopolsky said in a telephone interview, explaining that he hoped to build on the strong relationship that Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin had formed with the musicians and audiences.", "title": "The Philadelphia Orchestra Looks West for Its New Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve done fieldwork in Kenya and in the Nevada desert,\u201d she said. \u201cThe good thing about doing fieldwork in New York City is that you can go home and take a shower afterward and go to dinner or a Broadway show.\u201d\n\nShe headed east on Fordham Road, surveying the skies while delayed by heavy traffic.\n\n\u201cAs annoying as it is,\u201d said Ms. Carlen about the congestion, \u201cit allows me to spot pigeons.\u201d Her work involves extracting pigeon blood for DNA testing, a procedure that works for dead birds, too.\n\n\u201cSo I stop for a lot of road kill,\u201d she said, approaching the Kingsbridge Armory where a thick flock of pigeons swooped away from its roof.\n\nMr. Carlen parked and grabbed a bag of cracked corn. But on \u201cVortex,\u201d the group\u2019s fourth full-length, the guitarist David Torn joins as special guest and spirit guide, and he changes things. A frequent composer of film scores, he\u2019s a fan of atmosphere and accrual. The single, sustained note is his friend; so is the loop pedal. At the beginning of \u201cRed Shift,\u201d a stubborn, puddly bass opens up a wide bed, and a throng of guitars begins to bite and snipe over top. But here comes Mr. Torn, crafting a big, luminescent haze above it all. Five and a half minutes in, the track strips down nearly to silence: The troops are in retreat, provisioning for another salvo. Then the build starts again, more urgent than before. By the end we\u2019re beyond gravity.
