G.R.\n\nBen Frost, \u2018Self Portrait in Ultramarine\u2019", "title": "The Playlist: Sade\u2019s Haunting Lullaby, and 11 More New Songs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "From one angle, it\u2019s a shame that this 1960 tour of Europe was the last time Miles Davis and John Coltrane performed together. But it was probably inevitable too. After four years in the Miles Davis Quintet, Mr. Coltrane had broken a hole in the parachute and was hurtling somewhere new at terminal speeds. And he was taking the band\u2019s consensus down with him. The live recordings on \u201cThe Final Tour: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 6\u201d capture the tenor saxophonist just as he is starting to define the eruptive, gut-emptying style that would eventually revolutionize jazz\u2019s avant-garde. This remarkable new box set spans four concerts from the Davis quintet\u2019s fractious tour, which have been passed around for years in semiofficial packages but have never before received the proper Columbia remaster-and-release treatment. Mr. Coltrane bleats and heaves through his solos, spewing out odd clusters of notes, splitting acrid tones and repeating big windmill patterns until they seem to have broken free of their context. At the Paris show in particular, there\u2019s dissension in the crowd: The audience\u2019s squalling cries are often difficult to decipher (grateful catharsis? pique?). And then you hear something else: Did Wynton Kelly, the group\u2019s sturdily swinging pianist, catch some of Mr. Coltrane\u2019s bug? Once in a while, you\u2019ll hear him dropping in a darkened harmony or playing swirling, chaotic arpeggios. GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO", "title": "The Playlist: Shawn Mendes Shows His Scars, and 9 More New Songs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\n\u201cOur New Global Garden\u201d (Food, March 14) covers many facets of the global supply chain of fresh produce but barely touches on the conditions of farmworkers who labor on fruit and vegetable farms in the United States and abroad. In fact, farmworkers\u2019 voices are absent.\n\nConditions for most farmworkers in the United States, Mexico and elsewhere are not what they should be. Wages are low. Fringe benefits are rare. Agriculture ranks very high in job fatalities and injuries. Even large farms are often exempt from labor laws, and enforcement of employment protections that do apply is generally weak.\n\nConsumers are increasingly demanding to know how their food, whether grown here or elsewhere, is produced, including how farmworkers are treated. Companies at every level of the supply chain \u2014 growers, processors, marketers and retailers \u2014 need to commit to improving conditions for the workers.\n\nThere are projects to respond to consumers\u2019 concerns about labor practices. Such efforts will amount to false promises unless they truly involve farmworkers in their creation and development.", "title": "Opinion | The Plight of Farmworkers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-17 00:00:00", "text": "And he is not going away soon. On Sunday, Mr. Putin will be \u201cre-elected\u201d to a fourth term as president after a campaign as choreographed (and as dull) as those before.\n\nThough many have pointed out Russia\u2019s underlying weaknesses \u2014 a state-dominated economy eroded by corruption and mismanagement, along with voter malaise \u2014 the inevitable result will nonetheless underscore the resilience of the model he has created.\n\n\u201cThe fact that he is a colossus on clay legs is irrelevant,\u201d said Nina L. Khrushcheva, a professor of international affairs at the New School in New York and a co-author of the forthcoming book, \u201cIn Putin\u2019s Footsteps.\u201d \u201cPerception is more important than facts.\u201d\n\nMr. Putin, she noted, has mastered the craft of shaping one\u2019s image by imposing state control on the media \u2014 television, above all \u2014 while carefully corralling dissent on the streets and online. No one would have seen it coming in 1999, when Russia\u2019s first president, Boris N. Yeltsin, plucked Mr. Putin, then his unassuming deputy, out of obscurity and made him president. But Mr. Putin has come to embody the post-ideology, post-fact age of reality television and \u201cfake news\u201d that all the world is experiencing.\n\nPhoto\n\nLike Silvio Berlusconi, a former prime minister of Italy and, now, Donald Trump, he has shown an uncanny ability to harness the harsh glare of public attention to build a devoted following \u2014 to be all things to all people or, as Ms. Khrushcheva put it, to be \u201ca collage of all movies, both villain and hero.\u201d\n\nRussia\u2019s Constitution limits him to one more consecutive term, and far from entering it as a lame duck, Mr. Putin does so with his stature seemingly ascendant.\n\nExcept for an interregnum from 2008 to 2012 when he handed the office, but not actual power, to his loyal aide Dmitri S. Medvedev, Mr. Putin has been in charge since New Year\u2019s Day in 2000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe has already led the country longer than Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader best known for the country\u2019s stagnation in the late 1970s and \u201980s. With a new six-year term, he is set to remain in office at least until 2024.\n\nMr. Putin\u2019s autocratic tendencies have become self-serving, reinforcing his control of the political and economic levers of power, but they have also evolved.\n\nWhen he first emerged on Russia\u2019s turbulent political scene, he appeared inclined to continue the embrace of the West that Mr. Yeltsin had pursued, however haphazardly. \u201cBy their mentality and culture, the people of Russia are Europeans,\u201d he said in an interview with The New York Times in which I participated in 2003. He once said, perhaps a bit rashly, that Russia could even join the NATO alliance.\n\nHe soon soured on European institutions, including NATO and the European Union, which he came to see as irreconcilably opposed to Russian interests.\n\nThe West\u2019s leaders, in his view, unfairly denounced Russia\u2019s war against Islamic separatists in Chechnya; his crackdowns on the media and the opposition; Russia\u2019s use of natural gas as political leverage; and the suspicious origins of cash flowing from Russia into Western banks and properties.\n\nUltimately, what Mr. Putin most hated was the post-Cold War dominance of the Soviet Union\u2019s old foe: the United States. It began with President George W. Bush\u2019s decision to withdraw from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and invasion of Iraq. His opposition to Mr. Bush\u2019s decision to overthrow Saddam Hussein was hardly unique; it put him in league with people across the political spectrum who distrusted America\u2019s unbridled use of military power.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Putin\u2019s grievance with the West reached full fury after popular uprisings in former Soviet republics, including Georgia and Ukraine, that he viewed as American-orchestrated affairs intended, as he told NBC News this month, \u201cto halt Russia\u2019s progress.\u201d\n\nThe character of Mr. Putin\u2019s nationalism, however, changed when he returned to the presidency in 2012 after Mr. Medvedev left office, and that is when he increasingly became a darling of the right.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStunned by protests among disenchanted urbanites and the palpable disappointment among European leaders with his return to the presidency, Mr. Putin began to make explicit appeals to Russia\u2019s cultural and religious history. He embraced what in the United States would be the familiar terrain of conservatives: \u201cfamily values.\u201d He crusaded against the moral decline of the West, which he once went so far as to describe as \u201cinfertile and genderless.\u201d\n\nConservatives in the West began to write admiringly of him. In 2013, during rising tensions over the civil war in Syria, Matt Drudge, the conservative blogger, called Mr. Putin \u201cthe leader of the free world,\u201d joining Rush Limbaugh and other right-wing commentators who seemed attracted to Mr. Putin\u2019s willingness to oppose President Barack Obama\u2019s plans to bomb Syria over its use of chemical weapons.\n\nMr. Putin\u2019s strongman style and warnings against Western decadence attracted more and more conservative admirers in the United States and beyond. Foremost among them, of course, was Donald Trump.\n\nAlina Polyakova, an expert on far-right populism in Europe at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that Mr. Putin was offering to protect national identity against what are viewed as the threats of a liberalizing global world. These \u201cthreats\u201d included, among others, same-sex marriage, immigration and the surrender of political agency to distant international institutions.\n\nIt is a romantic idealization, Ms. Polyakova said, since few in Europe actually want to live in the sort of corrupted political and economic system that Russia has become. It is nonetheless a powerful one.\n\n\u201cIt gives people something solid to hold on to in a world that is becoming intangible,\u201d she said. \u201cHe\u2019s tangible. He\u2019s real. He represents a sense of nationhood.\u201d\n\nMr. Kasparov said the West itself shared the blame for Mr. Putin\u2019s enduring appeal as a model of authoritarian leadership. Governments and corporations were too willing to look past his repressive actions against opponents (Mr. Kasparov among them) and the corruption that afflicted the bureaucracy and business. \u201cThe real Putin model of government is nonideological kleptocracy,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWhen the free world decided 25 years ago that it was all right to repress your people at home while still enjoying the markets and acceptance of the free world, it was a deal with the devil,\u201d he said. \u201cInstead of liberalizing the dictatorships, the influence flowed the other way, spreading corruption and disdain for democratic ways.\u201d", "title": "The Poison Putin Spreads", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou may be able to follow the celebrities and get up close with them on Instagram and stuff like that,\u201d said Christine Haughney, the regional head of marketing for Merlin Entertainments, the parent company of Madame Tussauds. \u201cBut here, you can actually get your photo taken with them.\u201d\n\nThere are five floors at the attraction, but the most notable recent addition to the array of more than 150 figures is not the figure of Romeo Santos or the immersive \u201c4D Marvel experience.\u201d\n\nInstead, what was striking were the black-and-white Time\u2019s Up pins fastened to the glittering ball gowns of A-list replicas like Susan Sarandon and Anne Hathaway, and to the more casual attire of \u2014 who knows why \u2014 Justin Timberlake and Ed Sheeran. Representing the recent movement by women in Hollywood to end harassment and inequality in all industries, the Time\u2019s Up pins speak for wax figures who, one hopes, can\u2019t actually speak for themselves.\n\nThis slight costume change is the result of what Ms. Haughney said is the secret sauce fueling Tussauds\u2019 300-year survival. \u201cWe always keep our fingers on the pulse and make sure that we\u2019re staying up-to-date,\u201d she said.\n\nThe Oscars are coming up? Actresses get Time\u2019s Up pins. Donald Trump decides to forgo a visit to the United States embassy in London? His wildly lifelike figure is staged outside of the embassy for him. Pope Francis travels to the United States for the first time? Madame Tussauds parades his waxwork through the streets of New York in a veneer-white, top-down convertible.", "title": "The Politics of Waxing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-26 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 History was not supposed to turn out this way.\n\nIn the aftermath of World War II, the victorious Western countries forged institutions \u2014 NATO, the European Union, and the World Trade Organization \u2014 that aimed to keep the peace through collective military might and shared prosperity. They promoted democratic ideals and international trade while investing in the notion that coalitions were the antidote to destructive nationalism.\n\nBut now the model that has dominated geopolitical affairs for more than 70 years appears increasingly fragile. Its tenets are being challenged by a surge of nationalism and its institutions under assault from some of the very powers that constructed them \u2014 not least, the United States under President Trump.\n\nIn place of shared approaches to societal problems \u2014 from trade disputes, to security, to climate change \u2014 national interests have captured primacy. The language of multilateral cooperation has been drowned out by angry appeals to tribal solidarity, tendencies that are heightened by economic anxieties.\n\n\u201cWhat we\u2019ve seen is a kind of backlash to liberal democracy,\u201d said Amandine Crespy, a political scientist at Free University Brussels (ULB) in Belgium. \u201cMasses of people feel they have not been properly represented in liberal democracy.\u201d", "title": "The Post-World War II Order Is Under Assault From the Powers That Built It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-06 00:00:00", "text": "A Tower store near Lincoln Center in New York in October 2006, as shoppers hunted for a few last bargains\n\nCredit Michael Nagle for The New York Times", "title": "The Power of Tower Records", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Comeuppance is a complicated subject in this presidency. Here is a leader who crowds out scandal with more scandal, who tends to insist that the buck stops elsewhere, who boasted of sexual assault on tape and got to the White House anyway. It is not quite that nothing sticks to Mr. Trump; it is that so much sticks that nothing stays visible for very long.\n\nFor nearly two months, since The Wall Street Journal first revealed an October 2016 payment to Ms. Clifford (known on screen as Stormy Daniels), the story had subsisted on the margins of national consciousness \u2014 a consequence, it seemed, of both the daily Trumpian overload and a wide-scale confusion over what, exactly, the whole affair amounted to. Was it tragedy or farce? Serious or sideshow? Was it all of them, leaving us paralyzed by the choice?\n\n\u201cYou almost could float two irreconcilable theories: It\u2019s either too outrageous to be covered, or there\u2019s just too much else that\u2019s important,\u201d said Nancy Gibbs, the former editor in chief of Time magazine, leaning toward the second option. Either way, she noted, the episode had not blossomed into a mega-scandal.\n\nThe facts are these: Ms. Clifford was paid $130,000 just before the 2016 election in what she calls a \u201chush agreement\u201d to conceal a sexual relationship that began in 2006. The White House has denied the affair. Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer, Michael D. Cohen, has acknowledged making the payment himself. Last week, Mr. Cohen secretly obtained a restraining order to prevent Ms. Clifford, who claimed that the agreement had been breached, from speaking publicly about Mr. Trump.\n\nDespite the unrelated tumult of this week \u2014 tariff policy, staff turnover, nuclear intrigue \u2014 the ordeal has begun showing signs of an elusive longevity, coaxed by a lawsuit filed by her lawyer and an acknowledgment from Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, that Mr. Trump\u2019s side had pursued an arbitration proceeding against Ms. Clifford. The White House briefing room has been consumed by repeated questions about the payment. \u201cLook, the president has addressed these directly,\u201d Ms. Sanders said. (Mr. Trump has not addressed this.)", "title": "The President and the Porn Star: A Story\u2019s Slow Rise Above the Din", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Calm Before the Stormy,\u201d by Frank Bruni (column, March 21): We have a former porn star, a former Playboy model and a former \u201cApprentice\u201d contestant all credibly accusing a president of the United States of sexual predation. President Trump and his lawyers have denied any past improper sexual conduct with these women, who are among at least 19 women who have made accusations.\n\nI know one of these 19 women personally, and she told me years ago of Mr. Trump\u2019s advances, long before he was ever a candidate for the presidency. Mr. Trump has bragged about his exploits with women on many occasions, publicly and privately, and as we have now learned, large sums of money have been paid to keep some of these women from speaking out.\n\nI believe the reason that Mr. Trump has not ranted and raged about Stormy Daniels is that she has the goods on the president, including her 2011 polygraph test results, and possibly photographs and tapes of their encounters, and Mr. Trump is beyond scared of what the reaction will be if these get released.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s payment to Ms. Daniels may have been in violation of campaign finance laws, and were certainly in violation of his marital vows to Melania.", "title": "Opinion | The President\u2019s Accusers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cActress\u2019s Lawsuit Opens Door to Further Trouble for the President\u201d (news article, March 9):\n\nPresident Trump is trying desperately with legal maneuvers to keep Stormy Daniels silent. If nothing happened (he denies an affair), then what does she need to stay silent about? Does Mr. Trump really think we should believe him?\n\nMARLA ALLARD, WASHINGTON\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMust the label \u201cpornographic film actress\u201d or \u201cporn star\u201d accompany Stormy Daniels\u2019s name in every article that mentions her? This is not a particularly relevant or important detail about Stephanie Clifford (Ms. Daniels\u2019s real name) that should be put in the lead of a story. If Ms. Clifford were an accountant, would the lead of your story read \u201cthe legal maneuvers involving an accountant who says she had an affair with President Trump\u201d?\n\nOf course not. The story should be about a president who commits adultery and lies about it. The awkward descriptors are there to sensationalize and cast an implicit judgment about adult film actors. Can you see your way to talking about Ms. Clifford as a person instead of a porn star?\n\nJOSH GREEN, BERKELEY, CALIF.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nHooray for Stormy Daniels. She has more guts than any of the cowards, traitors and fools who are destroying this country.", "title": "Opinion | The Pressure to Silence Stormy Daniels", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "text": "The cranium of a Frenchie, in particular, is so out of proportion to its body that puppies are typically birthed by means of C-section. Health problems plague their lives.\n\nThis doesn\u2019t mean they deserve to die in overhead bins. But it means that French bulldogs are far more fragile than they look \u2014 an unfortunate fate that has been guaranteed to them by the choices humans have made in breeding them.\n\n\u201cPeople buy these animals not realizing that the animal may be sick from the time they take them home, or that they\u2019re going to need lots of surgery as they get older. It\u2019s horrible for the dogs and it\u2019s horrible for the owners,\u201d Ms. Block said.\n\nThe breed standard has been continually refined around physical requirements that make the dogs attractive, but put their health increasingly at risk.\n\n\u201cThe same thing that makes them cute is what makes them sick,\u201d said Philippa Pavia, the medical director at the Blue Pearl Veterinary Partners outpost in Manhattan.", "title": "The Price French Bulldogs Pay for Being So Cute", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-05 00:00:00", "text": "In 2016, Independence Blue Cross, Mr. Yeagley\u2019s insurer at the time, rejected coverage of the drug because Xeljanz is approved to treat rheumatoid arthritis, not alopecia. Mr. Yeagley appealed and lost his case; an outside reviewer wrote that there\u2019s not enough evidence that the drug is effective against alopecia. In 2017, Mr. Yeagley switched to another insurer that does not cover prescription drugs.\n\nThere are no approved drug treatments for the condition, and Mr. Yeagley\u2019s son\u2019s doctor at Yale University, Brett King, has found Xeljanz effective at regrowing hair for some patients. (Dr. King is a consultant for the drug\u2019s maker, Pfizer.) Once a year, Mr. Yeagley uses a coupon from Pfizer that covers about three months of the drug, but for the rest of the year he is on his own.\n\nIn the United States, Xeljanz costs about $50,000 a year (through a drug discount website). That\u2019s after Pfizer raised the price of Xeljanz by nearly 8 percent in January. In Canada, the price tag is $15,000.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t have that kind of money to throw away,\u201d said Mr. Yeagley, who has made five trips so far. Mr. Yeagley\u2019s son spoke on FaceTime with a Canadian doctor who asked for pictures and reviewed laboratory results before writing a prescription so the Yeagleys could legally obtain the drug in Canada.\n\nJonathan, who is 20, worries about shouldering the costs in the future. \u201cI don\u2019t tell him that I think about it a lot but I do think about it a lot,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m so grateful for what he does for me but I don\u2019t know how long it can go on.\u201d\n\nTHE BACKGROUND:\n\nDrug prices are cheaper in Canada, where an independent quasi-judicial body is supposed to ensure that pharmaceutical companies do not charge excessive prices.\n\nIn another twist, the price of Xeljanz has come under scrutiny because it was developed in part based on research by the National Institutes of Health, a federal agency. Some consumer groups and lawmakers have questioned whether drugs developed with taxpayer money should carry lower price tags.\n\nIn a statement, Pfizer said it is studying medications to treat alopecia. It has said it spent more than a $1 billion on \u201cthe discovery, development and commercialization of Xeljanz.\u201d", "title": "The Price They Pay", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "Dateline for an Origin Story\n\nWhat would become the National Football League was founded in 1920, at a Canton car dealership. Jim Thorpe was elected its first president, and the Canton Bulldogs won two early championships. Financial troubles and the city\u2019s small size caused the Bulldogs to fold in 1927, but Canton\u2019s place at the heart of the game was secured in 1963, when the Pro Football Hall of Fame opened in town.\n\nFor the next 50 years, the Hall of Fame existed as a museum next to a small stadium \u2014 owned by the local school district \u2014 that attracted football enthusiasts and the N.F.L. once a year for its induction ceremony and preseason game. Then four years ago, the Hall of Fame announced a plan for a $25 million stadium upgrade, with the possibility of additional development.\n\nIn 2015, the Hall of Fame unveiled an expanded plan for what had become a $476 million Hall of Fame Village. An economic development report commissioned by the Hall projected a completion date of 2019, one million visitors by 2020 and three million by 2025.\n\nMonths later, the complete rebuilding of Tom Benson Stadium began. The old Fawcett Stadium was renamed after the late owner of the New Orleans Saints when he donated $11 million toward construction. Much of that work was completed in time for an unveiling ceremony at the 2017 Hall of Fame game in August, though construction in one end of the stadium remains incomplete. The rebuild has cost at least $150 million so far.\n\nLaborers worked double shifts and on weekends to get the stadium ready for the Hall of Fame game. Then, in September, contractors working on the stadium received only 60 percent of what they were owed, according to John Ross, a lawyer for four of the contractors. In January, the contractors filed liens against the project.", "title": "The Pro Football Hall of Fame Expansion Project Hits the Skids", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "text": "For many students, folkl\u00f3rico is an anchor and a source of resilience. Porterville and environs made international news when its wells went dry during California\u2019s five-year drought. Among the families affected was Ms. Ferrer\u2019s; for nearly a year, they showered at relatives\u2019 houses and Ms. Ferrer sometimes resorted to pouring a jug of bottled water over her head. \u201cIt took a toll on us,\u201d she said. \u201cDance was a relief.\u201d\n\nMany of the parents work several jobs to get by, as Mr. Gonzales\u2019s mother did, and some students miss weekend rehearsals to work in the fields, supplementing family income. The cost of costumes \u2014 which can run up to $300 \u2014 and special shoes can be prohibitive. Fund-raisers have become folkl\u00f3rico fixtures, with troupes performing at church fiestas, weddings and even casinos to raise money for stock costumes, and parents selling tamales and T-shirts outside packed auditoriums.\n\nSometimes teachers pick up the slack. Among them is Gustavo Sandoval, a science teacher in Thermal, Calif., where 90 percent of high school students live in poverty, many in ramshackle mobile home parks. Mr. Sandoval and his wife, Gabriela, who works in a school kitchen, subsidize an after-school folkl\u00f3rico program at Desert Mirage High School out of their own pockets \u2014 about $11,000 a year. \u201cWe want to give our youth something positive to do,\u201d he said.\n\nIn Porterville, Mr. Gonzales \u201cmade a decision to give it my all,\u201d he said, by using his own seed money to jump-start the program 15 years ago. His sister, Irma Rios, continues to sew many of the costumes.\n\nThe principal of Porterville High, Jose Valdez, said that when he\u2019s having a bad day he wanders into Mr. Gonzales\u2019s rehearsals, where the effervescence and joy lifts his spirits. \u201cIt gives the students a reason to come to school,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019re all in. They perfect their dances for him,\u201d he said of Mr. Gonzales, \u201cbecause they see and feel his love for what he does.\u201d\n\nAt the Show Offs, a group of female folkloristas from Porterville performed \u201cLa Bruja\u201d(\u201cThe Witch\u201d), a dance from Veracruz in which women in gossamer white dresses emerge onstage, a glass containing a lit candle balanced atop each of their heads.\n\nThe ethereal glow suggested the transformative power of folkl\u00f3rico. As Mr. Goyal from Central High, put it: \u201cEven though we stomp really hard, we feel light.\u201d", "title": "The Prom-Like Intensity of High School Folkl\u00f3rico", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-23 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSenators Call for Paper Ballots to Combat Russian Election Meddling,\u201d about the Senate Intelligence Committee\u2019s recommendations \u201cfor securing American elections from foreign attacks\u201d (news article, March 21):\n\nYou report that Republican legislative leaders \u201chave shown little interest in advancing\u201d bills to address ballot security flaws threatening coming races.\n\nThough their dearth of zeal might be understandable for partisans who expect hacking to help their side, any failure to institute auditable paper backup records should raise constitutional alarms for the rest of us.\n\nIt\u2019s bad enough that voters of populous states already get a fraction of the say in national elections enjoyed by those in less populous states; it would add insult to injury if Republican leaders from smaller states that commit electors on a winner-take-all basis winked at foreign tampering that put a finger on the electoral scale in their favor.\n\nALAN S. FINTZ, BROOKLYN\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe White House press secretary, Sarah Sanders, has said that it is not America\u2019s place to comment on other countries\u2019 elections (\u201cWhy Is Mr. Trump Afraid of Russia?,\u201d editorial, March 22).", "title": "Opinion | The Quest for Fair Elections", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-28 00:00:00", "text": "One of the first people to whom I reached out was Ashley Yates. I had developed a relationship with her since her days as an activist in Ferguson, Mo., after the police killing of Michael Brown. Ms. Yates didn\u2019t hold back with me: She has already been open on social media about her struggles within the movement and had a very public falling out with its leaders.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Yates had also written about how she was affected by the hospitalization of Erica Garner, the 27-year-old daughter of Eric Garner. Ms. Garner had a heart attack last year and later died; while she was in a coma, Ms. Yates shared an image on Instagram of a text message exchange in which Ms. Yates encouraged Ms. Garner to not be bothered by people talking negatively about her on social media.\n\n\u201cI have to make clear just how invisible some of the most heinous violence we experience is,\u201d Ms. Yates wrote in the Instagram post in December. \u201cHow we are often left alone on the front lines grown cold because media and figureheads move on to the next hot story.\u201d\n\nI asked Ms. Yates, who moved to Oakland a couple of years back to work as an activist full time, if she ever had the urge to just say forget it, and take her college degree and go into a traditional profession. Of course she did, she told me, especially when you see someone dropping dead at 27 of a heart attack.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s absolutely scary,\u201d said Ms. Yates, 32. \u201cIt\u2019s enough to make you want to quit.\u201d\n\nBut more than just reflecting on the difficulties of activism and the trauma that comes with it, Ms. Yates ventured into another area that I had not thought about: self-care.\n\nAs it turns out, taking care of yourself is a big issue in the present movement, unlike in times past. There are trained \u201chealers\u201d in communities who run workshops and do private counseling for activists. Ms. Yates started seeing a therapist about a year ago. She also talked about the things that seem small but can make a big difference for her: going to the ocean, putting her toes in sand, remembering to eat, taking time to talk with her friends about things that have nothing to do with activism. Some of these might seem obvious, but for those immersed in the work, that\u2019s not always the case.\n\nAs one reader commented on the story, young activists should temper their expectations for immediate results \u201cand put their personal health first in order to reduce their toxic levels of stress.\u201d\n\nBecause, he added, \u201cstress can kill; emotionally and spiritually, as well as physically.\u201d", "title": "The Quiet Casualties of the Movement for Black Lives", "authors": ["John Eligon"]} {"date": "2018-03-07 00:00:00", "text": "In Philadelphia, whites received 10 times as many conventional mortgage loans as African-Americans during 2015 and 2016, even though the two groups reside in the city in roughly equal numbers.\n\nBanks have subverted the purpose of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which was supposed to get them to lend and invest more, and open more branches, in low- and moderate-income areas. This was to correct decades of damage the federal government caused by encouraging lenders to ignore black areas until the passage of the federal Fair Housing Act in 1968. The Reveal study found that affordable mortgages issued in historically black neighborhoods to comply with the reinvestment act were going to white newcomers instead of longtime black residents. This has accelerated a pattern of gentrification that forces out black residents.\n\nThese problems are rampant throughout the United States. Three years ago, for example, a striking study commissioned by the city of Richmond, Va., found that black applicants were less likely to receive home purchase loans or refinance loans regardless of their incomes.\n\nUpper-income black people were even more likely to be denied loans, as compared to similarly situated whites, than lower income black people were to their white counterparts. This underscored yet again that African-Americans cannot escape economic discrimination simply by becoming wealthier, especially when financial institutions persist in punishing them for living in majority minority neighborhoods. A destructive bill pending in the Senate would deepen this problem by exempting 85 percent of banks from reporting mortgage data that allows regulators and fair housing groups to ensure that home loans are being issued in a nondiscriminatory way.\n\nBy denying African-American families mortgage credit, the financial industry also denies them the opportunity to accumulate household wealth \u2014 part of the reason that white median family net worth is nearly 10 times that of black families. Beyond that, the decision to withhold credit from minority neighborhoods has turned too many of them into hollowed-out areas with high poverty, failing schools, lower property values and a markedly worse quality of life.\n\nNot long ago, fair housing groups that uncovered particularly egregious lending discrimination by banks and mortgage companies could count on federal regulators to curb, at least, the worst forms of predation. But with the federal government rolling back enforcement, state attorneys general will need to band together the way they did to fight off predatory for-profit schools that saddled students with crushing debt for useless degrees.", "title": "Opinion | The Race-Based Mortgage Penalty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTORONTO \u2014 Kyle Lowry scored 30 points, DeMar DeRozan had 23 and the Toronto Raptors beat Houston, 108-105, on Friday night, snapping the Rockets\u2019 17-game winning streak.\n\nJames Harden scored 40 points, but the Rockets lost for the first time since Jan. 27 at New Orleans.\n\nJonas Valanciunas had 14 points and 10 rebounds as the Raptors won their seventh straight in a matchup between the respective conference leaders.\n\nThe Rockets shot 9 for 27 from 3-point range, matching their fewest made 3-pointers of the season.\n\nClint Capela had 13 points and 13 rebounds for the Rockets. Chris Paul and Eric Gordon each scored 14 points, and Trevor Ariza had 13 as Houston\u2019s road winning streak ended at 10.\n\nHouston tied the score at 102-102 on Harden\u2019s 3-pointer with 2 minutes 10 seconds remaining, but DeRozan restored Toronto\u2019s lead with a jump shot with 1:49 left.", "title": "The Raptors End the Rockets\u2019 Winning Streak at 17", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-03-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe picture, a little dark and not quite in focus, shows a cherubic boy in a pink sweater, perched on the edge of a sofa, reaching toward a bright pink flower. It\u2019s the sort of snapshot that loving parents all over the world take every day.\n\nThey pull out the phone, maybe fumble around with the camera, and add another memento to the family photo album, as a consolation for the slippage of time and a reminder of how precious routine life can be.\n\nThe boy in the pink sweater is Jad Allah Jumaa. He is from eastern Ghouta in Syria.\n\nAre you worried about him yet?\n\nYou won\u2019t be alone if Ghouta doesn\u2019t ring a bell. A besieged rebel stronghold near Damascus, population 400,000, it is where the forces of President Bashar al-Assad, dropped chemical weapons in 2013, crossing President Barack Obama\u2019s notorious \u201cred line\u201d that turned out to be no line at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe shells, missiles and barrel bombs are still falling, exacerbating some of the war\u2019s worst carnage. Cease-fires go unheeded. The White House is distracted.", "title": "The Real Face of War? It May Be This Boy in a Pink Sweater", "authors": ["Michael Kimmelman"]} {"date": "2018-03-13 00:00:00", "text": "If anything, there may be a stronger connection between school violence and the sort of creative writing educators seek to foster. When the United States Secret Service and the Department of Education studied violence in schools, they found that 37 percent of attackers \u201cexhibited an interest in violence in their own writings, such as poems, essays, or journal entries,\u201d while only 12 percent exhibited an interest in violent video games.\n\nVideo games do not create murderers. With his Thursday meeting, the president was merely engaging in political distraction.\n\nAnd yet Mr. Trump was absolutely right when he said that \u201cbad things\u201d are happening on the internet. Video games do have a big problem, but it is not stylized virtual violence. Rather, it is the bigotry, social abuse, sexism and other toxic behavior to which players too often subject one another when gaming together online.\n\nIn other words: It\u2019s not the content; it\u2019s the culture.\n\nListen to the voice communications of almost any popular online first-person shooter game and you will hear players constantly using racial and homophobic slurs. Make a mistake in just about any team-based combat game and it won\u2019t be long before one of your teammates chastises you with some vile epithet. There is more than one game community where \u201cJew\u201d is used as a verb, meaning to make money. In many games, women who speak up on voice communications are routinely mocked and harassed.\n\nWhile researchers have devoted ample time to studying the emotional and psychological effects of virtual video game violence, the actual social behavior of players has largely escaped academic attention. That should change. The racism, homophobia and misogyny prevalent in many online game precincts can amount to emotional abuse. This is a phenomenon that needs to be better understood and more widely known.", "title": "Opinion | The Real Problem With Video Games", "authors": []}
